title: RALSTON PURINA CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including unusual gains of $28 million for the quarter and $112.8 million for the year. c-Including unusual gains of $10.4 million for the quarter and $36.9 million for the year.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about the Xerox Corporation's third-quarter results misstated the stock's closing price the day before. The stock rose $1.625, to $50, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: What's Compassion Got to Do With Welfare?
description: To the Editor:

title: SCREEN: 'OUT OF ORDER,' 4 TRAPPED IN ELEVATOR
description: THE lesson of ''Out of Order'' is plain: If you should find yourself in a nonoperating elevator, don't play the hero; just wait for somebody to come and get you. The West German cautionary tale, which opens today at the Metro Cinema, begins with an elevator-eye's view of a big city and ends with an exciting rescue attempt. The trouble comes in the hour between, during which we are cooped up in that elevator with four unpleasant and stupid people.

title: STALEY CONTINENTAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $10,364,000 for the quarter and $19,054,000 for the year. c-Net income, after a loss from discontinued operations of $2,520,000. d-After a loss from discontinued operations of $12,462,000. Latest year figures include results of CFS Continental from the date of its acquisition in November 1984. The company was created in February 1985 from the reorganization of A.E. Staley Manufacturing.

title: New President At CBS/Fox
description: The CBS/Fox Company, the leading producer and marketer of pre-recorded video cassettes, said yesterday that James G. Fifield, an executive at General Mills Inc., had been named president and chief executive.

title: Union Leaders in Pact With General Dynamics
description: The General Dynamics Corporation and union negotiators reached a tentative agreement today on a three-year contract for 4,500 workers who struck the company seven weeks ago.

title: QUESTAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CREDIT LINE FOR BANK IN CANADA
description: The Continental Bank of Canada today borrowed $1.4 billion (Canadian) from the Bank of Canada, the central bank, and arranged for a $1.5 billion standby credit from the country's six largest banks.

title: A Deeper Division
description: If his past statements and general attitude are a guide, President Reagan probably will side with his Attorney General, Edwin Meese 3d, in a dispute on affirmative action that has split the Cabinet - a split that reflects an even deeper division among Americans.

title: MAFIA MEMBER TESTIFIES ON SICILY 'COMMISSION'
description: A major witness testified yesterday that he played a part in creating a ''commission'' of Mafia leaders in Sicily after learning about a similar ruling group in the United States.

title: Cash Demand Follows Hotel Bomb Discovery
description: The discovery of a bomb in a hotel-casino was followed by a phone call warning that ''the next one is going to be 10 times larger'' unless $200,000 in cash was paid, the authorities say.

title: Reader's Digest Change
description: The latest executive change at the Reader's Digest involves the advertising sales staff. John Donghue, 43-year-old former head of Eastern sales, will go into the new year as advertising sales director. He will be replacing Richard N. Murray, 57, a vice president 30 years with the company, who is availing himself of a special early retirement plan offered to employees.

title: OGILVY GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company paid dividends of 27 cents per share for the latest quarter, 81 per share for the latest nine months, 23 cents per share for the year-ago quarter and 67.5 cents per share for the year-ago nine months.

title: AIR FORCE TO DEBAR ROCKWELL
description: Air Force Secretary Verne Orr today announced plans to bar the Rockwell International Corporation, the nation's second-largest military contractor, from receiving future military contracts because of the company's admission Wednesday that its employees had defrauded the Air Force.

title: REAGAN ORDERS INQUIRY INTO FORCING A SOVIET SEAMAN BACK TO SHIP
description: President Reagan today ordered an investigation into the handling of a Soviet sailor who was forced to return to his ship by Border Patrol agents near New Orleans last week, according to Administration officials.

title: KEMPER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After realized investment gains of $3,880,000 for the quarter and $9,744,000 for the 9 months. c-After realized investment gains of $7,032,000 for the quarter and $16,725,000 for the 9 months.

title: AS THEIR LIVES CHANGE, 2 FAMILIES TRADE HOUSES
description: Word spread pretty fast around town about the next-door neighbors on Short Hills Drive who traded houses one Saturday morning.

title: Purchase Price For Mostek
description: The president of Thomson S.A. said the French electronics concern was proposing to pay less than $88 million for the United Technologies Corporation's ailing Mostek Corporation subsidiary.

title: INJURIES IMPERIL JET SECONDARY
description: When the Jets' second-half collapse came last season, it was spearheaded by the secondary. Like dominoes, one regular after the other fell, sidelined by injuries.

title: 5 DEFECTORS, TURNED AFGHAN, FIGHT 'HOLY WAR'
description: One uses a recoilless rifle to fight the Soviet troops in this country. Another is assigned to an antiaircraft machine gun.

title: HELMS BARS ENVOY, DEMANDING REAGAN HALT ABORTION AID
description: Senator Jesse Helms has threatened to hold up President Reagan's nomination of an Ambassador to China until he receives a letter from the President promising that United States funds will not be granted to nations that coerce abortions and sterilization.

title: GIANTS' GRAY NEAR AGREEMENT
description: Today, for the second straight day, Earnest Gray and his agent met with Harry Hulmes, the Giants' assistant general manager. Though the seventh-year wide receiver was still unsigned, both sides said that the dispute might be resolved in a few days.

title: JOHN HANCOCK INVESTORS TRUST INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The net income figures represent net investment income.

title: SCREEN: FROM FRIEDKIN
description: WILLIAM FRIEDKIN was making sleek, sensational, ice-cold thrillers long before rock videos and ''Miami Vice'' were fashionable. And he couldn't be more in his element now that they are. ''To Live and Die in L.A.'' is Mr. Friedkin at his glossiest, a great-looking, riveting movie without an iota of warmth or soul. On its own terms, it's a considerable success, though it's a film that sacrifices everything in the interests of style. Technically a police drama, ''To Live and Die in L.A.'' is a collection of crisp images, sudden starts and well-timed, periodic kicks designed to keep an audience on its toes. Mr. Friedkin can't give this kind of thing any emotional depth, but he certainly knows how to make it exciting.

title: Yes on Constitutional Amendments;   Courtesy for State Courts
description: Next Tuesday's ballot asks voters to pass on five proposed amendments to the New York Constitution. All five deserve support, and one of the five deserves special attention.

title: International Halloween
description: One of the smaller Halloween parades yesterday was mounted by the Greenwich Village Neighborhood School to raise money for UNICEF.

title: SHARON CHARGES PERES WITH SECRET BID TO HUSSEIN
description: Two right-wing Israeli politicians, Ariel Sharon and Yuval Neeman, accused Prime Minister Shimon Peres today of holding secret negotiations with King Hussein on a plan for joint Jordanian-Israeli rule over the West Bank.

title: STUDY WARNS OF SOVIET MOVES IN PHILIPPINES
description: The Soviet Union has begun positioning itself to offer support to Communist insurgents operating in the Philippines, according to a report prepared for the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence.

title: A Role for Retired Primary-Grades Teachers
description: To the Editor:

title: Sex Education Gains Support
description: Seventy-five percent of the public approve of sex education in public high schools and 52 percent approve of it in in grades 4 through 6, according to the 1985 Gallup/Phi Delta Kappa Survey on Education.

title: WESTERN RIDER TRIUMPHS
description: In a week marked by trophy-giving, Rob Gage will receive the biggest one of all tomorrow night when a Mercedes is driven into the ring at Madison Square Garden during the National Horse Show, and the keys to the automobile are presented to him.

title: Warnaco Gets Bid From Its Officers
description: Warnaco Inc., the Connecticut-based maker of Hathaway shirts, White Stag skiwear and other apparel, said yesterday that it had received a buyout offer of more than $333 million from an investor group headed by its top executives.

title: Ogilvy Income Rises
description: The Ogilvy Group, parent company of Ogilvy & Mather, yesterday released its third quarter financial report. Revenues were up 15.3 percent from the $99.9 million in the period last year, to $115.2 million. Net income was $4.9 million, up 6.5 percent from $4.6 million, and earnings per share were 52 cents compared with 49 cents.

title: ART: SWEDISH EXHIBITION AT SHEPARD GALLERY
description: THE growing interest in 19th-century Scandinavian painting more or less marks the anniversary - as far as the art world is concerned - of that interest's birth in Paris. And though the survey now at the Shepherd Gallery, 21 East 84th Street, is of Swedish art (1885-1920), its appreciation is enhanced by some knowledge of the Scandinavian scene in general. The show's catalogue supplies this, though not as extensively as the essays written by Kirk Varnedoe and Emily Braun for the 1983 traveling museum show ''Northern Light.''

title: AUCTIONS
description: MAJOR post-World War II artworks by Arshile Gorky, Frank Stella, Morris Louis, Barnett Newman, Clyfford Still, Claes Oldenburg and Andy Warhol - several of them are among the largest works by these artists - will be auctioned next week at Sotheby's and Christie's.

title: Children's Expo
description: Youngsters will have the run of the New York Coliseum this weekend with the First Children's Expo International, a three-day exposition of goods and services for those up to 16 years old.

title: LEADING INDICATORS RISE 0.1%
description: The index of leading economic indicators, the Government's main forecasting gauge, rose one-tenth of 1 percent in September, the smallest gain since June.

title: Harvester Financial Moves
description: The International Harvester Company today announced a ''series of financial initiatives'' to cut its unfunded pension liability in half and to reduce bank borrowings. It said the measures would enable the company's finance subsidiary to ''regain access to the commercial paper market.''

title: HOUSING PRESSES ON A COMMERCIAL ZONE
description: Just north of the Queensboro Bridge in Manhattan there is a neighborhood that is not a neighborhood. It consists of some eight square blocks, from 59th Street to the south side of 62d Street, and from York Avenue almost to Second Avenue. And although it contains dozens of residential buildings - mostly five-story brick walk-ups - it is considered by the city to be a commercial rather than residential district.

title: Rose's Reward
description: Pete Rose, the Reds' player-manager, has signed a three-year contract worth $2.5 million, but according to the team owner, Marge Schott, the money is ''not so much as salary, but to reward him for what he has done.'' That includes breaking Ty Cobb's career hit record and rejuvenating the Reds, who finished second in the National League West this past season.

title: KNICKS BEATEN 3D TIME IN ROW
description: The Knicks met their match tonight, a team that is in as much a troubled state as they are. But not even that was enough to change their misfortunes.

title: MIDCON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $85,458,000 related to the withdrawal from the Great Plains Coal Gasification Project for the quarter and year. c-Net income

title: CABOT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $8,003,000 for the quarter and $12,665,000 for the year and a loss of $145 million for the quarter and year on the disposal of discontinued operations. c-Net income including income from discontinued operations of $4,641,000 for the quarter and $6,259,000 for the year.

title: DURR-FILLAUER MEDICAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MARSH SUPERMARKETS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SPLIT OVER KISSING RULE
description: The decision this week by the Screen Actors Guild to identify open-mouth kissing as dangerous work out of fear that it may increase the risk of AIDS infection has set the stage for a confrontation between actors and producers.

title: ANDERSON JACOBSON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: Print Ads Becoming A Book
description: TODAY Doubleday & Company brings out a book called ''How to Use the Power of the Printed Word.'' What sets it apart from most of the publisher's hard-cover output is that this 110-page volume largely consists of an ad campaign. What the public has been free to peruse in pieces since parts began running in 1979 is now selling en masse for $14.95.

title: CENTURY TELEPHONE ENERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
HAMPTON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FACTORY ORDERS DOWN 0.6%
description: Orders to factories for manufactured goods fell six-tenths of 1 percent in September, the Commerce Department said today. The demand for military hardware fell sharply, offsetting gains in other areas.

title: TRACKING THE RUSSIANS AND THE ONE THAT GOT AWAY
description: In this Pakistani city that serves as a listening post for events in Afghanistan, there had been many rumors of Russians who had joined the Afghan rebels.

title: BRIGGS & STRATTON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: Changing the Rule
description: Peter Ueberroth, the commissioner of baseball, said yesterday that he was considering replacing the practice of using designated hitters in alternate World Series with a rule that would allow the use designated hitters in American League stadiums but bar them from National League stadiums beginning with the 1986 Series. Appearing on ''Donahue,'' Ueberroth said, ''It doesn't seem fair that the American League plays all year long with it and then they go into the World Series and put aside the thing forever every other year.''

title: U.S. TRADE DEFICIT WIDENS TO RECORD AS IMPORTS SURGE
description: Reflecting a surge in imports of cars, clothing, steel and other manufactured goods, the United States trade deficit grew to a record $15.5 billion in September, the Commerce Department said today.

title: G.O.P. LEADERS OFFER PLAN TO CUT FARM PRICES
description: Senate Republican leaders unveiled a proposal tonight that would freeze the Government-subsidized prices of farm commodities at current levels next year and then reduce them steadily for the next three years.

title: GRUMMAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a charge of $30 million to cover the estimated cost to fulfill an agreement with the Navy, under which Grumman will strenghen and repair the F-14 main landing gear bulkhead and to provide a redesigned bulkhead for future production units, for the quarter and 9 months.

title: SHULTZ SAYS SAKHAROV'S WIFE WILL BE PERMITTED TO DEPART
description: The Soviet Union has informed the United States that Andrei D. Sakharov's wife ''will be free to leave the Soviet Union,'' Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today.

title: Wheeling Pension Cutoff Is Upheld
description: A Federal District Court judge in Pittsburgh upheld today the Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation's plans to terminate its four pension plans under the bankruptcy laws. On Tuesday, Wheeling-Pittsburgh, which has filed for reorganization under the bankruptcy laws, announced it intended to terminate the plans, which are underfunded by $475 million.

title: Family Circle Bases
description: Family Circle magazine with its Feb. 11 issue will lower its circulation rate bases and increase its rates slightly.

title: DYNASCAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: '. . . and Here We Dined and Slept'
description: Abigail Adams's laundry no longer festoons the elegant East Room of the White House. But another legacy of that long-ago era is carved into the State Dining Room mantel.

title: Judicial Dissent
description: To the Editor:

title: JEWISH PROTESTERS HALT FASSBINDER PLAY'S DEBUT
description: Thirty members of Frankfurt's Jewish community walked onto the stage of the Kammerspiel theater tonight and prevented the premiere of a play by Rainer Werner Fassbinder that they denounced as anti-Semitic.

title: KERR GLASS MANUFACTURING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income for year-earlier quarter and both 9-month periods, therefore no share earnings.

title: ARMS OFFER: GAP NARROWS
description: President Reagan's new arms position narrows the gap with the Soviet Union on limiting offensive nuclear forces. If the two sides follow with concessions on space-based defenses, American officials say, there may be a chance of an agreement on general principles at the Geneva summit meeting.

title: ERRATIC STORM RETURNS TO THE GULF, THEN VEERS INLAND OVER ALABAMA
description: Tropical Storm Juan returned to the Gulf of Mexico and spun briefly back up to near-hurricane strength today, then headed inland over rain-soaked Alabama and Florida.

title: Terrorism Killed a 2d American During the Achille Lauro Affair
description: To the Editor:

title: photo of New York City;   THE HIDDEN NEW YORK: A CITY ALBUM
description: THERE is an almost hidden New York, a New York in images of art and artifact, scattered in countless pieces throughout the city. It is the city preserved at the hands of artists and craftsmen and others who have caught it at a certain mood and moment in time that becomes immortal in their hands. These moments and perspectives are by no means hidden from those who visit the many museums, galleries and other institutions where the bits and pieces of this artistic urban kaleidoscope are on view.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday 'DRACULA' AT TOWN HALL Rolling fog, flaming crosses, and that infamously seductive Transylvanian count will set the proper Halloween weekend mood for a mime performance of ''Dracula'' at Town Hall tonight. With a cast of eight and an original score by Neal Kayan, the Bram Stoker classic is being staged by Morse Mime in a production that marks the company's 10th anniversary. The performance begins at 8 P.M. at 123 West 43d Street. Tickets are $12 to $20. Information: 840-2824.

title: Apple Products
description: Apple Computer Inc., hoping to bolster sales of computers to corporations, plans to introduce products in the next 3 to 18 months to allow its Macintosh computers to tie into networks of computers made by the International Business Machines Corporation and the Digital Equipment Corporation. In a speech in Dallas Wednesday, later released by the company, Apple's president, John Sculley, said that products were being developed to allow data and text from the Macintosh to be sent to I.B.M. mainframes and to communicate with other larger machines through I.B.M.'s System Network Architecture.

title: CITY OPENING 100-BED SHELTER FOR HOMELESS MEN
description: The Koch administration said yesterday that it would open a new, 100-bed shelter, perhaps tonight, for the increasing numbers of homeless men seeking shelter from the chilly weather.

title: OPEC Official Says Pricing to End
description: The oil minister of the United Arab Emirates, Mani Said al-Otaiba, said yesterday that each member of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries is free to sell its oil at any price it chooses, according to a Reuters report from Abu Dhabi.

title: SEIBELS BRUCE GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $44,239,115 for the quarter and $46,024,819 for the nine months and capital gains of $73,178 for the quarter and $149,618 for the nine months. c-Net loss, including income from discontinued operations of $1,967,989 for the quarter and $5,262,839 for the nine months and capital gains of $270,803 for the quarter and $327,745 for the nine months.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: IT was not the week for an intimate soiree. New York partygoers crowded into events that, except for seas of black tie, acres of sequins and reasonably good manners, might have been the subway at rush hour.

title: BOND PRICES STAGE LATE RALLY
description: Bond prices rose sharply late yesterday in response to a news report that a Middle East oil minister had declared that members of OPEC were free to sell their oil at any price.

title: ST PAUL COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including investment gains of $12,187,000. c-Including investment gains of $2,460,000 and after a loss from discontinued operations of $23,564,000. d-Net loss, including investment gains of $14,034,000 and after a loss from discontinued operations of $18,001,000.

title: Pilgrims Visit Jordan River
description: For the first time since the 1967 Middle East war, Catholic pilgrims celebrated mass today at the Jordan River site where tradition says Jesus was baptized.

title: THE SCREEN: 'MACARONI,' STARRING JACK LEMMON
description: ETTORE SCOLA'S ''Macaroni'' is a gummy little comedy about a successful, physically exhausted, pill-popping, possibly alcoholic American businessman, Robert Traven (Jack Lemmon), who learns how to relax and live the good life during a three-day trip to Naples.

title: Remembering Johnson
description: In a preview this week of ''The Great Society Remembered,'' a PBS documentary, the laughter was loudest when Douglass Cater, a former White House aide, described the relationship between President Johnson and the Senate and House.

title: HOUSE SHOWDOWN IS SET ON BUDGET
description: Congressional negotiators broke off efforts to reach a compromise tonight on a bill to balance the budget by 1991 and set the stage for showdown votes in the House of Representatives Friday on two versions of the measure.

title: Fall Harvest
description: Moeller is not the only place, of course, where football dominance is a way of life these days. Take the state of Iowa, for instance.

title: SHUTTLE CREW BEGINS RESEARCH
description: Using themselves as guinea pigs, scientists aboard the space shuttle Challenger today conducted a number of experiments involving the puzzles of weightlessness, but they had trouble with a twin furnace assembly in the Spacelab research module.

title: The Navy Secretary's Upward Loyalty
description: Secretary of the Navy John Lehman says his Pentagon superiors agreed to a bad deal when they let John Walker plead guilty to running a spy ring for the Soviet Union. He says their bargain sends a message to the country and the ships at sea, where naval personnel risk their lives, that ''espionage is just another white-collar crime.''

title: SCREEN: TWOSOME IN 'SOTTO'
description: LINA WERTMULLER'S direction is as sweetly and uncharacteristically demure as the behavior of her heroines in ''Sotto Sotto,'' a film in which two women share the most innocent attraction imaginable. Best friends as the film begins, Ester (Veronica Lario) and Adele (Luisa de Santis) find themselves unexpectedly drawn to one another as they wander, in the company of several other pairs of women, among the extraordinary oversized sculptures in the gardens of Bomarzo.

title: CONSOLIDATED FIBRES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a tax credit of $144,000. c-Net income.

title: Byars Won't Play
description: The tailback Keith Byars has not been able to practice all week because of a sore foot and will not play Saturday when Ohio State plays Iowa, which is No. 1 in both news-agency polls. ''He did not practice; he is not going to play,'' said Earle Bruce, the Ohio State coach.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Allied-Signal Inc., Morris Township, N.J., said it had declared a regular quarterly dividend of 45 cents, its first since it was formed last month in the merger of the Allied Corp. and Signal Cos. * American Express Co. said its subsidiary, the American Express Travel Related Services Co., has completed the previously announced acquisition of First Data Resources Inc. * American Transtech, Jacksonville, Fla., a subsidiary of the American Telephone and Telegraph Co., said it was extending its stock sale program through Nov. 22 for shareowners holding fewer than 100 shares of common stock in Bell Atlantic Corp., Nynex Corp., Pacific Telesis Group and U S West Inc. * Armstrong Rubber Co., New Haven, said it had canceled the planned closing of its Hanford, Calif., tire plant after reaching a settlement with the United Rubber Workers union. * Asarco Inc. told securities analysts it was worried about the possibility of its Peruvian copper unit being nationalized. * Associated Dry Goods Corp. said it had merged its Stewart Dry Goods division in Louisville and Lexington, Ky., and Evansville, Ind., with its L.S. Ayres & Co. division, which is based in Indianapolis. * Jaguar P.L.C., the British car manufacturer, said production of Series III Saloons and XJS sports cars rose by 14 percent in the first nine months of 1985 over the same period last year, while worldwide sales jumped 9 percent over the same period. * Western Union Corp., Upper Saddle River, N.J., said it had agreed with its lenders to extend for 25 days the interim financing agreement it announced in April.

title: HNG/INTERNORTH reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $1,374,000. c-After net from discontinued operations of $147,000 for the quarter and $8,282,000 for the 9 months. d-After net from discontinued operations of $3,362,000. The company said third-quarter earnings improved primarily because the results of the Houston Natural Gas Corp. were included in the latest periods. Internorth Inc. acquired Houston Natural Gas earlier this year. HNG/Internorth said the latest 9 months' net includes a $20 million pre- tax writedown on pipeline assets scheduled for divestiture and a $21 million pre-tax expense for job severance programs in connection with the merger of Internorth and Houston Natural Gas.

title: Northern Pacific Begins Financing
description: The Northern Pacific Corporation is offering $250 million of unrated debt securities at a price of par through Drexel Burnham Lambert as sole underwriter.

title: BANKING'S BIG MERGER SPREE
description: When bankers from across the country gathered at the New Orleans Superdome last month to attend an opening bash for the American Bankers Association convention the hot topic of conversation was not the Latin debt crisis, real estate lending or even the health of the economy. It was interstate banking and the frenzy of bank mergers that was set in motion by a Supreme Court decision last spring.

title: Hungarian Leader in London
description: Janos Kadar, the Hungarian Communist Party leader, arrived here today for a three-day official visit that will include talks with Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher. British officials say the visit is part of Mrs. Thatcher's effort to encourage discussions with the Eastern bloc nations.

title: BEST IN BRAINY COMEDY AND LITERATE CABARET
description: POP standards treated with the seriousness of short stories and comedy with an intellectual edge are just the right kind of entertainment to add an extra zing to the crisp air of early November. Susannah McCorkle, Jonathan Schwartz and Karen Akers, three singers with literary sensibilities that match their highly polished styles, are appearing this weekend, respectively, at Park Ten, Michael's Pub and the Ballroom. Listening to their performances, one might well hear overtones of Joan Didion and J. D. Salinger as well as Billie Holiday, Frank Sinatra and Edith Piaf.

title: Still Winning In Faust's Wake
description: Gerry Faust thought he had found paradise when he arrived at Notre Dame as football coach four beleaguered years ago. In truth, paradise was what he had just lost. While the disappointments have mounted with little abatement in South Bend, the Moeller High School varsity team, which Faust created in 1963, continues to embellish a young tradition.

title: Opposition Leader Plans To Leave Pakistan Soon
description: Benazir Bhutto, a prominent leader of the opposition to President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq, is expected to leave Pakistan soon, Government officials and newspapers reported today. She has spent two months under house arrest.

title: Time For Decision
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz is off to Moscow next week to make final preparations for the Nov. 19-21 Geneva summit. Meanwhile, Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger is damning Soviet bargaining offers and arguing against any American concessions on the arms buildup.

title: ASTROTECH INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss. The company changed from a fiscal year ended Oct. 31 to one ended Sept. 30. Year-ago results are for the 2 months and 11 months ended Sept. 30, 1984.

title: Gordon King, Inventor Of Symbols on Checks
description: Gordon van Beuren King, an engineer and inventor, died Oct. 20 at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles after a long illness. He was 74 years old and lived in Beverly Hills.

title: EAGLE CLOTHES INC reports earnings for Year to July 31
description: b-Including a tax credit of $797,000. c-Including a tax credit of $677,000.

title: Police Murders Dramatized In 'Badge of the Assassin'
description: As it did last month with ''Out of the Darkness,'' based on the police work that led to the arrest of the killer known as Son of Sam, this week's edition of ''The CBS Saturday Night Movies'' assembles a fine cast and adopts a straightforward approach to another case of murder that shocked New York during the 1970's.

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: Reversing a three-week decline, assets of the nation's money market mutual funds rose $888.3 million, to $209.59 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Leading the upward turn, assets of the 73 institutional funds rose $1.47 billion, to $54.30 billion. But assets of the 192 general purpose funds fell $140.2 million, to $61.63 billion, and the 87 broker-dealer funds dropped $443.2 million, to $93.65 billion.

title: SHAPIRO'S LONG-SHOT CAMPAIGN OFFERS 'NEW IDEAS'
description: Twelve years ago Peter Shapiro, a junior at Harvard who was determined to have a career in journalism, went to Washington to work as a reporter for The Wall Street Journal for the summer.

title: Nursery of Nobels
description: To the Editor:

title: 10th Seed Tested In Squash Match
description: Tenth-seeded Clive Caldwell of Toronto narrowly escaped an upset yesterday at the hands of a qualifier, David Boyum of Boston, in the opening round of the Chivas Regal Squash Open at the Hunter College Sportsplex. Caldwell prevailed, 15-12, 8-15, 15-11, 8-15, 15-11.

title: AMCA INTERNATIONAL LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $850,000 for the quarter and $3,843,000 for the 9 months. c-Net losses including tax credits of $3,553,000 for the quarter and $11,567,000 for the 9 months and net losses from discontinued operations of $6,001,000 for the quarter and $5,923,000 for the 9 months.

title: Sports of The Times;   Flower Power at Big A
description: ''Are they real?'' Howie Hoffman was stuffing gorgeous yellow mums in a Styrofoam display rack at the rail yesterday, the finishing touch in an attempt to turn the mobile-home tackiness of Aqueduct into something approximating the Taj Mahal for tomorrow's second edition of the Breeders' Cup.

title: JOSEPH C. GIACALONE
description: Joseph C. Giacalone, former economic development director for Suffolk County, died of a stroke Monday at his home in Head of the Harbor, L.I. He was 58 years old.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Earvin (Magic) Johnson, the Los Angeles Laker guard who missed the first two games of the season with shingles, was given medical clearance to play last night against the Phoenix Suns. . . . Marc Buoniconti, the Citadel linebacker who was paralyzed making a tackle in last Saturday's game against East Tennessee, was honored by his teammates. They voted to wear his number 59 on their helmets for the rest of the season. . . . Three major league baseball players, including Willie Randolph of the Yankees, are being sued in Federal court by a New York bank that claims they defaulted on payments on promissory notes.

title: 10 WRITERS WIN WHITING AWARDS
description: Ten writers, including the novelist Wright Morris and the Pulitzer Prize-winning poet James Schuyler, have been named the first recipients of $25,000 Whiting Writers' Awards from the Whiting Foundation, a private philanthropic organization in New York.

title: U.S. WILL PRESENT NEW ARMS OFFER IN GENEVA TODAY
description: President Reagan said today that the United States would offer a new arms proposal to the Soviet Union on Friday calling for ''very significant, balanced reductions'' of nuclear arsenals.

title: Part of an Education
description: To the Editor:

title: FINANCIAL INSTITUTION SERVCES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $146,701 for the quarter and $268,622 for the 6 months.

title: SHONEY'S SOUTH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 6
STAGE: YIDDISH MUSICAL, 'MATCH MADE IN HEAVEN'
description: THE New York Yiddish season is off and running - for the hundredth, and then some, year - with the opening of the musical ''A Match Made in Heaven'' at Town Hall Wednesday night. The show gets the season out of the starting gate at a surprisingly brisk and most pleasant pace.

title: POPULAR WINES FOUND TO HOLD TOXIC CHEMICAL
description: The Federal Government said today that a toxic chemical had been found in low levels in four kinds of Riunite wines, the largest selling imported label in the United States. It was also found in eight less widely sold Italian wines.

title: 8-Point Period For Sonics
description: The Seattle SuperSonics scored 8 points in the fourth period against the Nuggets tonight, tying the league record for fewest points in the last quarter.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: FROM the dynamic duo who brought you Jams, the sunny and highly successful California grill restaurant on East 79th Street, comes Bud's, subtitled ''An American Bistro.'' Jonathan Waxman, the chef, and Melvyn Masters, the soigne front man, have planted their gastronomic flag on the Upper West Side in hopes that the hungry masses foraging along Columbus Avenue will be disposed to pay $20 for roast chicken - that is, if the free-ranging bird in question has the well-toned body of an aerobics instructor, is grilled to a turn, and arrives with a heavenly batch of golden-fried onion rings.

title: Misguided Whale Heads Back Downriver
description: - A humpback whale that has spent three weeks in inland California waters made a brisk dash downriver toward San Francisco Bay today, officials said.

title: Embassy Row;   A Sign of These Indebted Times: For Sale
description: For more than four decades, Peru's Ambassadors to the United States have occupied a rambling stone mansion in a 26-acre private forest about four blocks from Connecticut Avenue.

title: Preparing the President
description: Before President Reagan was interviewed by Soviet journalists today in the White House, he was given an intensive half-hour of practice questioning by Vice President Bush; his chief of staff, Donald T. Regan; his national security adviser, Robert C. McFarlane; his chief spokesman, Larry Speakes, and the foreign policy press specialist, Edward P. Djerejian. It was said to be Mr. Reagan's most thorough preparatory session since he debated Walter F. Mondale in the 1984 Presidential campaign.

title: Nat Adderley Quintet
description: The cornetist Nat Adderley is leading at quintet tonight through Sunday at Fat Tuesday's, 190 Third Avenue, at 17th Street (533-7902). Sets begin at 8 and 10 P.M. and midnight, with a $10 cover and a $7.50 minimum, tonight and tomorrow. Sunday, the group will play at 1:30 and 3:30 P.M., with a $5 cover and a $7.95 brunch.

title: STAGE: 'SEASCAPE,' AT HUDSON GUILD
description: DON NIGRO'S ''Seascape With Sharks and Dancer'' is one from the pastepot -two cardboard characters held together by contrivance. The play, directed by David Kerry Heefner, opens the season at the Hudson Guild Theater.

title: FLORIDA STEEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The nets include gains from the sale and disposal of certain assets of $284,000 in fiscal 1985 and $2,823,000 a year earlier.

title: Tax Code Changes That Hurt Business
description: The House Ways and Means Committee is now engaged in furious horse trading designed to salvage at least part of President Reagan's sweeping proposal to reform the income tax system. Yet among the provisions that have so far survived are several that will make the United States even less competitive in international markets.

title: Khomeini Meets Cabinet Of New Prime Minister
description: Iran's spiritual leader, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, told the country's new Cabinet today not to ''nationalize everything'' and suggested that its members should minimize their ideological differences.

title: F.C.C. Approves A.T.&T. Services
description: The Federal Communications Commission authorized the American Telephone and Telegraph Company to offer two new long-distance service packages that could reduce costs to big business customers but force local phone service rates higher. Local telephone companies had fought the proposals.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: When the pumpkins are lit and the goblins come out to play, movies always put their best ghoul forward. However, this year's crop of Halloween horror films is different from the slice 'em and dice 'em movies of recent Halloweens past.

title: Coast Transit Bond Yields Set
description: The San Francisco Bay Area Rapid Transit District, known as BART, is offering $145 million of sales tax revenue bonds through underwriters led by Paine Webber Inc.

title: BROADWAY
description: ''WE seek him here, we seek him there, Those Frenchies seek him everywhere. Is he in heaven? - Is he in hell? That demmed, elusive. . . .''

title: STAGE: GROSSMAN SOLO
description: JUST as Billy Crystal achieved fame with the single word ''marvelous,'' so Mechthild Grossmann, albeit within the slightly more refined circle of those who attend the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Next Wave Festivals, established herself with the word ''fantastic,'' which she uttered with every conceivable inflection during last season's Pina Bausch production, ''1980.''

title: HUNGRY TIGER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 30
description: b-Net income.

title: BELL CONFIRMS THAT SALVORS FOUND PIRATE SHIP OF LEGEND
description: Salvagers this morning gingerly chipped a thick coating of corrosion off a bronze bell they hauled out of the sand off Wellfleet last month and exposed the name of a pirate ship whose fate has been the object of debate, search and wonder for 268 years.

title: Group Seeks to House Mentally Ill Homeless
description: Citing a need for services for the homeless who are mentally ill, an advocacy group said yesterday that it would begin looking for ways to open emergency shelters to house them.

title: Piedmont Power Offers $446.2 Million in Bonds
description: The Piedmont Municipal Power Agency yesterday began offering $446.2 million of revenue bonds to refund older debt securities that were sold in 1984 with interest rates as high as 11 percent.

title: Music: Goliard
description: THE Goliard Chamber Orchestra and the Astoria Chorale teamed up for the New York premiere of Vincent Persichetti's ''Pleiades'' at Merkin Concert Hall Wednesday night. ''The Pleiades,'' an ambitious, 30 minute setting of a Walt Whitman poem, is scored for chorus, string orchestra, and solo trumpet, which serves the same gently disruptive purpose it does in Charles Ives's ''Unanswered Question.''

title: U.S. FINDS BREAST CANCER RATE NOT AFFECTED BY TAKING THE PILL
description: Birth control pills have no significant effect on the risk of developing breast cancer before 45 years of age, according to the largest study of the issue yet conducted.

title: NOVO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including extraordinary gains of $377,000 for the quarter and $644,000 for the nine months. c-Including extraordinary gains of $395,000 for the quarter and $723,000 for the nine months.

title: EX-TEAMSTERS CHIEF TESTIFIES ON PAYOFFS FOR HELP
description: Roy Williams, former President of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, testified today that a man named by Federal officials as a leader of organized crime paid him $1,500 a month for seven years in return for his help in obtaining $87.75 million in loans from the union's Central States Pension Fund.

title: BRUSH WELLMAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
INTERMET CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MUSEUM'S HOUSE PARTY FOR BTITONS
description: The National Gallery of Art threw a party tonight, and it was one of those occasions where women in jewels, taffetas, silks and velvets lived up to the spectacular backdrop.

title: EXCERPTS FROM ANSWERS BY PHILIPPINE LEADER IN INTERVIEW
description: Following are excerpts from President Ferdinand E. Marcos's answers to questions in an interview here today, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: FARMERS GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Farewell, Refugee Post
description: President Carter created the position of United States Coordinator for Refugee Affairs with the rank of Ambassador-at-Large in 1979 and filled it with Dick Clark, who had been defeated for re-election as a Democratic Senator from Iowa the year before. The State Department already had a Bureau for Refugee Programs, but the coordinator was supposed to make sure that the Departments of Justice, State, and Health and Human Services were all on the same track.

title: LOGICON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CHESS TITLE GAME ADJOURNED
description: The 21st game of the world championship chess match between the titlist, Anatoly Karpov, and Gary Kasparov was adjourned today after Karpov, playing Black, sealed his 41st move.

title: Ball Denies Hutton Role
description: George L. Ball, former president of E. F. Hutton & Company, denied before a House subcommittee today that he played any role in the massive check overdrafting scheme that led to the company's guilty plea in May to 2,000 counts of mail and wire fraud. ''I did not know the actual mechanics'' of the scheme, he said in testimony before the House Judiciary Committee's Subcommittee on Crime, which has been looking into why no individuals were charged.

title: Genex Layoffs
description: The Genex Corporation, suffering from the loss of a contract to its biggest customer, said it would lay off about 40 percent of the 146 employees at its Rockville, Md., headquarters and that several top executives, including its president and chief operating officer, V. M. Esposito, had resigned. Genex has been reeling from the loss of its contract with G. D. Searle & Company to provide a key ingredient for Searle's artificial sweetener, aspartame. The contract with Searle represented 88 percent of Genex's revenues, and Genex had shut down its Paducah, Ky., plant, laying off the 70 workers there.

title: NEW JERSEY RESOURCES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Wallace Polyp Removed
description: A ''very small polyp'' believed to be benign was surgically removed from Gov. George C. Wallace's colon today. Mr. Wallace, who is 66 years old, entered Jackson Hospital for what a press aide, Billy Joe Camp, called routine tests. Mr. Wallace said he wanted an assessment of his health before deciding whether to seek re-election in 1986.

title: SCREEN: FREDDY RETURNS IN PART 2 OF 'NIGHTMARE'
description: LIKE the geeks and goons and psychopaths that it celebrates, the horror genre seems capable of resuscitating itself over and over. Just when the form seemed exhausted, when it looked as though the last dead camp counselor lay butchered on the cabin floor, along have come a couple of better-than-average bloodbaths: ''Re-Animator,'' a grisly mad-scientist movie with a villain who is quite literally a talking head, and now ''A Nightmare on Elm Street, Part 2: Freddy's Revenge.''

title: 'NORTH AND SOUTH,' A MINI-SERIES
description: COSTING tens of millions of dollars, based on a best-selling novel, and featuring everybody from Elizabeth Taylor to Senator Strom Thurmond's daughters in bit parts, ''North and South'' turns out to be a staggering contraption, as ingenious and silly as any ever devised by Rube Goldberg. The 12-hour mini-series, filled with painstaking attention to presumably authentic historical detail, is a monumental absurdity, the kind of television ''event'' that might get the ratings it so desperately covets but, like that comedian, will get no respect. Parceled out in two-hour segments, ''North and South'' begins on ABC this Sunday at 9 P.M. and, excepting time out for air on Monday and Friday, will continue each night during the rest of the week.

title: Activists Switch S.I. Base Tactics
description: Anti-nuclear activists said yesterday that they had abandoned any further legal appeals to put on the Nov. 5 ballot a referendum seeking to block the use of Staten Island as a base for a Navy task force believed to be armed with nuclear weapons.

title: SPACE WEAPON TEST FAILURE REPORTED
description: Technical failures have beset an important Federal program aimed at developing a space weapon powered by a nuclear bomb, according to a report in the latest issue of Science magazine.

title: A Rare Ravel Work
description: Harold Rosenbaum will conduct the Canticum Novum Singers in the world premiere of Maurice Ravel's early choral work ''Tout est Lumiere'' tonight at 8 o'clock at St. Peter's Lutheran Church.

title: TRANSIT OFFICER IS ARRESTED IN SHOOTING DEATH OF WIFE
description: A New York City transit police officer accused of fatally shooting his estranged wife, a Bronx police officer, was arrested on the Main Street of the town of Sparkill last night after a two-day manhunt in Rockland and Orange Counties.

title: Why Greece Could Not Intervene in Defection
description: To the Editor:

title: SMALL CROWD AT LIBERAL PARTY DINNER
description: The Liberal Party, or at least one faction, held a fund-raising dinner last night at which those in the audience were as important as the dignitaries on the dais.

title: Stocks Mixed; Dow Falls 1.26
description: Stock prices were mixed in heavy trading yesterday as investors took profits in some of the blue chip issues that rose to record levels just one day earlier.

title: ADVEST GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: Boscobel Restoration
description: Winter visiting hours will begin today at the Boscobel Restoration, Garrison-on-Hudson, N.Y. The restoration, which was the early 19th-century home of States Morris Dyckman, will be open daily, except Tuesdays, from 9:30 A.M. to 4 P.M. It will be closed Thanksgiving, Christmas and the months of January and February. Admission is $4 ($2 for those 6 to 14). Information: (914) 265-3638.

title: EXPERT SAYS JET WAS NEARLY SAVED
description: The pilots of Delta Flight 191, which crashed after apparently encountering a severe wind shift, fought to regain control of the jetliner but in the final seconds put the nose down, thereby dooming the flight, a Federal engineer testified today.

title: DUARTE SAYS NICARGUA HELPS TERRORISTS
description: President Jose Napoleon Duarte of El Salvador said today that Nicaragua was serving as a ''sanctuary'' for a new stage of terrorism under way in his country.

title: DELMARVA POWER & LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
GAS PRICES SET FREE BY CANADA
description: Canada today announced the deregulation of the price of both domestic and exported natural gas. The move completes the dismantling of the former Liberal Government's energy policy by the year-old Government of Prime Minister Brian Mulroney, a member of the Progressive Conservative Party.

title: RISE OF 23% NOTED IN REFORM JUDAISM
description: The Reform Jewish movement has experienced a period of sharp growth in the last 10 years, partly because it has actively sought the participation of interfaith couples, its leader reported yesterday.

title: Deficit Magic: Worse Than Nothing
description: The Senate and House are deadlocked over the wrong-headed Gramm-Rudman-Hollings scheme to wipe out the Federal deficit, but approval seems inevitable, maybe today. The Senate has passed it, the President wants it and even members who strongly oppose the Administration's budget priorities support it. Resigned to its overwhelming popularity, they claim it's better than nothing. In fact, it's worse.

title: McCoy Tyner Band
description: The pianist McCoy Tyner is leading a 13-piece big band tonight through Sunday at the Village Vanguard, 87 Seventh Avenue South, at 11th Street (255-4037). Sets begin at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M.; there is a $10 cover and a $5 minimum.

title: CIGNA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including realized investment gains of $19.4 million for the quarter and $51.5 million for the 9 months. c-Including realized investment gains of $1.6 million for the quarter and $45.7 million for the 9 months.

title: Diner's Journal
description: DINING out options for Jewish New Yorkers who follow kosher laws are largely limited to informal and predictable dairy restaurants and delicatessens. In the last year, however, a handful of slightly more ambitious restaurants in engaging settings have opened around town.

title: MUSIC: MANHATTAN TRANSFER
description: A VOCAL quartet that looks backward one moment and forward the next, The Manhattan Transfer combines jazz scholarship and pop showmanship in equal measure. Devoted to preserving the tradition of setting lyrics to jazz instrumental solos - a notion invented by the late Eddie Jefferson and popularized by Lambert, Hendricks and Ross - the group recently put out its most ambitious album, ''Vocalese.''

title: FANSTEEL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results include Custom Technologies Corp., acquired in June.

title: EXCERPTS FROM REAGAN'S NEWS CONFERENCE
description: Following are excerpts from President Reagan's news session in Washington yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Chit-Chat
description: Jon Kramer, a 5-foot-2-inch public relations intern for the New York Rangers, when asked by an onlooker what he had been discussing with 4-foot-9-inch Mary Lou Retton: ''It was just small talk.''

title: BOY SAYS PHILADELPHIA POLICE DROVE RADICALS BACK TO FIRE
description: One of two people known to have survived an inferno that killed 11 people said that police gunfire drove fleeing members of the radical group Move back into their blazing house in the May 13 confrontation with the police, according to videotaped testimony heard today.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: UNCOMMON CLAY: The Life and Work of Augustus Saint Gaudens. By Burke Wilkinson. 428 pages. Photographs by David Finn. A Helen and Kurt Wolff Book/Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $22.95.

title: ORIOLE HOMES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a charge from the settlement of litigation of $682,000.

title: DISPUTE OVER, QUEEN VISITS GRENADA
description: Queen Elizabeth II sailed into the small harbor here this morning in a light rain, symbolically bringing to a close a discordant chapter in the history of this former British colony, the mother country and the United States.

title: DATA GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 28
description: b-Including a gain of $12.6 million for the quarter and year from the reversal of taxes on domestic international sales corporation.

title: DOMTAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including gains of $5.8 million for the quarter and $12.3 million for the 9 months from the sale of land and businesses and tax credits. c-Including gains of $4.2 million for the quarter and $10.7 million for the 9 months from the sale of land and businesses and tax credits. Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in June.

title: QUICK BUT EXPENSIVE TRIP TO LONDON
description: N.B.A. people will be going to London not to see the Queen but to make a choice on a King named Albert.

title: SIFTING NEW YORK'S JUNK FOR ARTIFACTS OF FUTURE
description: For anyone not content just to look at bits of old New York, it is possible to buy them. They can cost little, for ornaments plucked from forgotten city haunts long since dismantled, or a lot, for famous pieces of the past from places known to all.

title: E.P.A. RECOMMENDS RAISING FLUORIDE LIMITS
description: The Environmental Protection Agency today proposed a new standard that would double the maximum permissible level of fluoride in the nation's drinking water supplies.

title: MINSTAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $376,000 and an extraordinary gain of $7,375,000 from termination of a pension plan. c-After income from discontinued operations of $274,000 for the quarter and $127,000 for the 9 months and tax credits of $3,445,000 and $7,391,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. d-After a loss from discontinued operations of $18,000 and an extraordinary gain of $7,375,000. The company said 1985 results reflect 50 percent ownership of AMF Inc. from July 8 and includes the results of Aegis Corp. for the entire latest 9-month period. The 1984 results include Aegis from May 17, 1984.

title: SCREEN: DE LA IGLESIA'S 'EL DIPUTADO'
description: IF you have never heard of Eloy de la Iglesia, that's not his fault. Over the last 20 years, the 40-year-old Spanish director has averaged a movie a year and gained something of a cult reputation for his explicit treatment of homosexuality. Mr. de la Iglesia once belonged to the Spanish Communist Party, and ''El Diputado'' (''The Deputy''), which opens today at the Waverly, brings together his political and sexual predilections in a passionate mix. Despite its excesses, the film, his first to find commercial release in this country, attests to both Mr. de la Iglesia's craft and his spirit.

title: A.S.P.C.A. Delays Dropping Rescues
description: The private group that runs the city's animal rescue program yesterday postponed its threat to shut down the program immediately.

title: Pasta Tariff Up In Retaliation
description: At midnight, the United States is increasing duties on Italian pasta in retaliation against the Common Market's failure to resolve a dispute over citrus trade, the United States trade representative, Clayton K. Yeutter, said today.

title: KEMP, EYEING A PRESIDENTIAL BID, RAISES $1 MILLION AT THE WALDORF
description: Representative Jack F. Kemp came to New York last night to raise more than $1 million and lay the groundwork for a Presidential bid in 1988.

title: Securities Appointment
description: Raymond A. Mason was named to a one-year term yesterday as chairman of the Securities Industry Association, the trade group for the investment banking and brokerage industry. Mr. Mason, 49 years old, is chairman of Legg Mason, a Baltimore-based regional brokerage house. He is a graduate of the College of William and Mary.

title: BROWNS KEEP MUM ON THE QUARTERBACK
description: Starting a rookie quarterback is always risky. Even under the best circumstances, the newcomer finds certain unavoidable trap doors, such as odd-looking defensive alignments, all-out blitzes and unfamiliarity with the offense.

title: Grumman and Fairchild Talks
description: The Grumman Corporation is considering buying or investing in the aerospace division of Fairchild Industries, according to spokesmen for both companies.

title: WHAT'S COMPASSION GOT TO DO WITH WELFARE?
description: To the Editor:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I would characterize our arms control position as deep cuts, no first-strike advantage, defensive research and no cheating.'' - President Reagan. [A1:6.]

title: Guerrillas State Conditions For Peace in Western Sahara
description: Polisario guerrillas fighting Morocco for control of Western Sahara have set new conditions for peace in the desert territory, the official Algerian press agency reported today.

title: BIOCRAFT LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: ,FREED RUSSIANS RESTING IN BEIRUT
description: Three members of the Soviet Embassy who were freed Wednesday after being held for 30 days by Moslem fundamentalists are suffering from exhaustion and are resting, the charge d'affaires, Yuri Suslikov, said today.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Nets vs. Philadelphia 76ers, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena. Darryl Dawkins, who fouled out of 11 of the 39 games he played last season, goes up against Moses Malone, who fouled out of none of the 79 he played. The Sixers won four of the six games between the teams in 1984-85. (Television - SportsChannel, 11:45 P.M., tape. Radio - WNBC, 660; 7:30 P.M.) Boxing Angel (El Bravo) Cruz, champion, vs. Rickey Young, 12 rounds, for the New York State Junior Welterweight title, at Felt Forum. First preliminary, 7:30 P.M. Although Cruz is from Allentown, Pa., he qualifies for the title on the basis of having fought more than half of his fights in New York. Cruz is 18-5-2 with five knockouts. Young, from Harlem, will be trying to avenge his only defeat in 16 pro fights. He has six knockouts. In a 10-rounder, Iran Barkley of the Bronx takes on Wilford Scypion (29-7, 22 knockouts) from Port Arthur, Tex., in a middleweight bout. (Television - MSG, 7:30 P.M.) Cross Country The 47th annual Heptagonal Championships, at Van Cortlandt Park. This is the ninth year for the women's championship 5-kilometer race, which begins at 12:30 P.M. Harvard is the defending champion. The men's 5-mile race, which has been run since 1939 with the exception of one year during World War II, begins at 1 P.M., and Dartmouth is the defender. Equestrian 102d annual National Horse Show, at Madison Square Garden, 1:30 and 7:30 P.M. The Mounted Musical Ride will be performed, and the evening highlights are the Dressage Exhibition and the International and Open Jumping $10,000 Top Score Competition ''Gamblers Choice.''

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Brock Adams Heard From
description: Brock Adams, who became Secretary of Transportation after six terms in the House of Representatives, is planning to run for the Senate next year from his home state of Washington. A Democrat, he intends to challenge the re-election bid of Senator Slade Gorton, a Republican who won 54 percent of the vote in 1980 on a ticket headed by Ronald Reagan, thereby retiring the Democratic veteran Warren G. Magnuson.

title: REGIS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
RELIANCE FINANCIAL SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
A SCULPTURE REVIVAL ALL AROUND TOWN
description: SOMETHING good has been happening in sculpture. Anything is once again possible. Wood, stone, plaster and bronze are no longer intrinsically unacceptable or reactionary - they are no longer intrinsically anything. Neither is subject matter. Minimalist principles are still very much in evidence, but they now exist as possibilities or points of orientation, not laws that have to be confronted or obeyed.

title: NOBLE AFFILIATES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $4,235,000 for the quarter and $12,720,000 for the nine months. c-Net income, after losses from discontinued operations of $4,484,000 for the quarter and $10,890,000 for the nine months.

title: COMMUNICATIONS SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
RUDDICK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Leaning Harder on Pretoria
description: Suppose it is now the autumn of 1983. South Africa is quiet. The Reagan Administration orders limited economic sanctions and calls for the release of Nelson Mandela, the imprisoned leader of the outlawed African National Congress. In South Africa, a Government commission calls for an end to the hated pass laws; business leaders meet with A.N.C. representatives.

title: OFFICER CHARGED WITH BRUTALITY WINS SUPPORT ALONG UPPER WEST SIDE BEAT
description: When the night shift replaces the day shift at the 24th Precinct, and policemen gather in front of the station house on West 100th Street, Officer Leon Flowers is lately the target of good-natured heckling.

title: Dining Out Guide: New Jersey
description: Following is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. THE GRAND CAFE, #42 Washington Street, Morristown (201 540-9444) -

title: BUTLER INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net losses after losses from discontinued operations of $339,000 for the quarter and $1,069,000 for the 9 months and a loss of $5 million for the quarter and 9 months on the disposal of discontinued operations.

title: U.S. FAULTS MANILA IN 15 KILLINGS
description: The United States Ambassador said Thursday that in the last two years 15 Americans in the Philippines had been killed, four of them ''allegedly at the hands of security forces.'' He asserted that punishment for the slayings, which had previously gone unreported in the capital, had been inadequate.

title: Continental Strike Ruling
description: A Federal bankruptcy court judge today ordered union pilots to end their two-year strike against Continental Airlines.

title: Post-Merger D'Arcy Wins Its First Account
description: D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles/ Chicago has won its first account as a newly merged entity: the Wilson Sporting Goods Company, with billings of almost $5 million.

title: Semiconductor Concern Layoffs
description: The National Semiconductor Corporation said it would lay off about 500 employees because of the continuing slump in the semiconductor industry. The layoffs, to be completed within the next few weeks, will affect all levels of employees, both in the United States and Europe, but primarily those at the company's headquarters in Santa Clara, Calif.

title: Farewell, Bachlerhood
description: The ranks of Senate bachelors, unlike many Senate waistlines, are thinning. Today in Wapakoneta, Ohio, Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Nimmons will announce the engagement of their daughter, Eva Jean, to Senator Bob Kasten, Republican of Wisconsin.

title: U.S.F.L. IS SEEKING TO CUT FIVE TEAMS
description: The United States Football League, planning for its next season in the fall of 1986 at its annual meeting that began here today, will attempt to reduce the number of teams from 14 to nine.

title: Chase Names President Of Maryland Operation
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation, hours away from acquiring and opening the 13 offices of three Maryland savings and loans as a full-service commercial bank, said yesterday that Stanley T. Burns had been named president of the new entity, Chase Bank of Maryland.

title: Tribute in India To Indira Gandhi
description: With demonstrations and speeches across the country, India today mourned the death of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi on the first anniversary of her assassination.

title: NEW EVENT PROMOTES CONTEMPORARY U.S. MUSIC
description: AS Americans, we might innocently assume that we would be constantly inundated by American music. Indeed we are, of the commercial variety, and certainly some of that can lay claim to genuinely artistic status. But the bulk of our so-called ''serious'' music still comes from the European past, and there are those who want to help tilt the balance a little more toward the American present.

title: BEATRICE TO OPEN TALKS ON BUYOUT BY KOHLBERG
description: The Beatrice Companies, producer of some of the nation's best-known consumer products, agreed yesterday to open negotiations with Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company about a management buyout - a deal that could involve close to $6 billion.

title: Unionist Is Split From Bribery Trial
description: Federal prosecutors in Manhattan agreed yesterday to sever their case against the president of a hotel and restaurant workers' union from the racketeering trial of 11 other reputed members or associates of the Colombo crime group.

title: Convergent Head, Four Others Resign
description: Allen H. Michels, the founder and chairman of Convergent Technologies, resigned yesterday with four other longtime executives, all of whom plan to start a new company.

title: NAURU CHIEF LOSES LIBEL SUIT AGAINST GUAM PAPER
description: A Federal jury today denied damages claimed by Hammer DeRoburt, the President of the tiny South Pacific island republic of Nauru, in a $40 million libel suit against a Guam newspaper.

title: Yes on Constitutional Amendments;   Help for Jobs, Taxes, Bonds and Schools
description: Four other proposals to amend the New York State Constitution deserve support.

title: Benefactor
description: Eugene Lang, a multimillionaire who has promised to pay the college tuitions of 52 Harlem high school students, got a college named after him Wednesday when the New School for Social Research dedicated the Eugene Lang College.

title: A Salute to Comedians Of the Silent Film Era
description: A salute to some lesser-known comedians of the silent film era begins today at 7:30 P.M. in a program devoted to Charley Chase at the American Museum of the Moving Image, 34-31 35th Street, Astoria, Queens. Four films dating from 1925 will be shown, with piano accompaniment. Mr. Chase was noted for his portrayal of a debonair character who found himself in humorous situations; many of his films were directed by Leo McCarey, who also directed movies starring the Marx Brothers, Mae West and W.C. Fields.

title: A Dwindling Team
description: The news releases of Diane McGrath, the Republican-Conservative candidate for mayor, are headed ''McGrath for Mayor Team.''

title: Economic Scene;   Markets' View Of U.S. Policy
description: DESPITE continued worries about the strength of the United States economy, the low savings rate, the budget deficit, the trade deficit, the shakiness of farm debt, third-world debt and much else, the stock and bond markets have turned bullish.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 1, 1985
description: The Economy

title: STORAGE TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including an extraordinary tax credit of $1,343,000 for the quarter and the nine months.

title: COMPUTER MEMORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including an extraordinary tax credit of $476,000.

title: FIRST VERMONT FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
EXCERPTS FROM SHULTZ NEWS CONFERENCE ON SUMMIT MEETING
description: Following are excerpts from a news conference by Secretary of State George P. Shultz here today:

title: DEVILS' LATE GOAL TIES WINGS
description: The Devils, who have recently been giving away leads, rallied twice tonight and gained a 2-2 tie against the Detroit Red Wings at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: GENERAL RE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including realized investment gains of $1,968,000 for the quarter and $4,114,000 for the 9 months and a loss from discontinued operations of $28,528,000 for the 9 months. c-After realized investment losses of $1,429,000 for the quarter and $658,000 for the 9 months, income from discontinued operations of $1,911,000 for the quarter and $5,884,000 for the 9 months and a gain of $80,460,000 for the 9 months from an accounting change. 1985 results have been restated to account for the efect of discontinued operations. The 1984 results have been restated to reflect an accounting change and the effect of discontinued operations.

title: Lumet Tribute Nov. 11
description: A tribute to the film director Sidney Lumet will be presented by the American Museum of the Moving Image on Nov. 11 at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. Mr. Lumet is noted for filming many of his more than 30 films in New York City.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Nov. 1, 1985 GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: MUSIC: VIOLINIST AND PHILHARMONIC
description: A PROGRAM made up of repertory staples need not be a routine affair, but that is what last night's concert by the New York Philharmonic under Riccardo Chailly's direction added up to. Mr. Chailly, who has conducted a good deal of Italian opera, also has made a name on the orchestral scene. Beginning in 1988 he will be principal conductor of Amsterdam's Concertgebouw Orchestra, a post of major importance. However, as he began his second week as a Philharmonic guest it was difficult to hear anything that might set him apart from dozens of other touring conductors.

title: RAMADA INNS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including extraordinary gains of $3,881,000 for the quarter and $4,804,000 for the nine months. c-Including extraordinary gains of $2,837,000 for the quarter and $$3,217,000 for the nine months. Results for the latest periods include results of Continental Baking, acquired in October 1984.

title: IOWA ELECTRIC LIGHT & POWER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
U.S. Leads, 2-0
description: Chris Evert Lloyd routed Jo Durie, 6-2, 6-3, and Kathy Rinaldi downed Anne Hobbs, 7-5, 7-5, to give the United States a 2-0 lead tonight over Britain in the 57th Wightman Cup. Miss Durie, ranked 29th in the world, was no match for Mrs. Lloyd, the world's top-ranked player and the captain of the five-member American squad. The Americans have won the last six meetings in this annual four-of-seven series, and hold a commanding 46-10 lead.

title: AST RESEARCH reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ODDS FAVOR RAIN FOR RACES
description: Even with seven difficult and competitive Breeders' Cup races set to go off tomorrow, everyone around the track is just talking about the weather. It is more than idle chatter. Forecasters say it is a cinch there will be some rain by post time tomorrow, and the question is how much that will affect the races.

title: REAGAN ADMINISTRATION REJECTS, FOR NOW, FARM CREDIT SYSTEM AID
description: The Reagan Administration has decided, at least for now, not to provide Federal financial assistance to the beleaguered Farm Credit System.

title: 'Living the Dream'
description: ''An event the whole family of New York will be proud of'' was how Governor Cuomo described the state's plans to celebrate the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s birthday.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Beneficial Insurance Group Inc., Peapack, N.J., has named Steven E. Sacks senior vice president, product management. * Cluett, Peabody & Co., the apparel company, has named Harris R. Hester, president of the Arrow Co., to the additional position of group executive in charge of its Shirt Group. He succeeds John Currier, who has retired. * Coastal Bank, Portland, Me., has elected to its board Robert J. Dunfey Jr., president of Portland House Inc. * Columbia Pictures Industries, a subsidiary of the Coca-Cola Co., has named John P. Kelleter executive vice president of marketing and sales at Columbia Pictures Publications, its Miami-based sheet music printing division. * Daltex Medical Sciences Inc., which makes medical devices and pharmaceutical products, said Harvey S. S. Miller has resigned as president and chief executive officer, but has been appointed executive director of the company's Scientific Advisory Board. * Daniel Industries, a Houston-based company that supplies fluid-measurement products and systems, has named Ralph H. Clemons Jr. president and chief operating officer. * Dun & Bradstreet Corp. said Phil Bartos has been named president of Dun's Marketing Services. * Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco has promoted John L. Scadding to senior vice president and director of research. * Hartmarx Corp., the apparel maker based in Chicago, has named John R. Meinert senior vice chairman and chief financial and administrative officer, effective Dec. 1. Also, Elbert O. Hand was appointed president and Harvey Weinberg vice chairman. * Howe, Barnes & Johnson Inc., a Chicago-based investment banking firm, has named George H. Shelton president; John L. Fauls 3d senior vice president, fixed income markets; Theodore M. Perkowski senior vice president, equity markets; Richard D. Stockton senior vice president, investments and research, and Stephen H. Landolt, senior vice president and resident manager of the firm's Oshkosh, Wis., office. * Mitel Corp., Boca Raton, Fla., which makes telecommunications equipment and semiconductor devices, has appointed Anthony F. Griffiths president and chief executive officer, and Terence H. Matthews chairman. * National Commercial Finance Association, a trade group, has elected as chairman Frederick S. Gilbert Jr., executive vice president of Citicorp Industrial Credit Inc., Harrison, N.Y.

title: RANCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a nonrecurring after- tax gain of $350,000.

title: CUOMO SEES NO PROBLEM IN ENFORCING THE NEW STATE RULES TO CURB AIDS
description: Governor Cuomo said yesterday that it was an ''absurdity'' to suggest that there would be difficulty enforcing new state rules that allowed the closing of bathhouses patronized by homosexuals.

title: Mission Insurance
description: The Mission Insurance Company, a commercial property and casualty insurance company that holds 20,000 policies in California and other states, was declared insolvent and placed under the conservatorship of the California Department of Insurance. The company is a unit of Mission Insurance Group Inc., which is controlled by Carl H. Lindner, the Cincinnati financier, through his American Financial Corporation holding company. The Mission Insurance Company, which specializes in worker's compensation insurance, had been in poor financial condition for more than a year.

title: JUDGE CLEARS BOEING IN CRASH THAT KILLED 213
description: A Federal district judge today rejected charges of negligence against the Boeing Company and two other defendants in a suit related to the crash of an Air India Boeing 747 in 1978.

title: SCREEN: 'ELENI,' MEMOIR OF A QUEST FOR JUSTICE
description: IN his 1983 book, ''Eleni,'' a personal memoir of epic proportions, Nicholas Gage, an investigative reporter and the former Athens bureau chief for The New York Times, recalls in meticulous detail his search for the Communist guerrillas responsible for his mother's execution in 1948 during the Greek Civil War.

title: ART: GRAHAM DRAWINGS AT EMMERICH GALLERY
description: THE portrait drawings of John Graham, which are on view at the Andre Emmerich Gallery, 41 East 57th Street, have an autobiographical character that is curiously compelling. It is not simply that some of them are antic self-portraits in which Graham appears in a wide variety of guises (not least, as God the Father on horseback). It is that even in the portraits of other people, the image is worked and reworked until it ends up as, in effect, an auxiliary likeness of John Graham. (One of the people who sat for him said that after the first two or three sessions, Graham would worry the image until finally it became ''another Graham,'' rather than a traditional portrait.) This could be mere egomania, but in point of fact we go along with John Graham and are ever eager to find out what role he will play next. Despite his name, Graham (1887-1961) was Russian by birth, and he had more than his full share of the true Russian's ability to negotiate with the world in terms of fantasy. The face that he presented in his drawings was never the one that he saw in the bathroom mirror. It was, on the contrary, a face in which memory mated with make-believe. In ''The Model of Man,'' for instance, he sports imperial whiskers, a hero's wreath around his head and a huge columnar neck and throat. ''Outdo me, if you dare'' is the message. It is further emphasized by the fact that whereas the left eye has the fixed glare of Benito Mussolini in a temper tantrum, the right eye has the blankness of white marble. Service in the Russian Army during World War I left him with a whole repertory of martial images - the frogged dress uniform, the jaunty cap, the boisterous well-tended mustache. The present show also reveals that he drew himself as a fallen angel, complete with matching horns, and as a demon straight out of pre-Columbian sculpture. John Graham adored women. On the evidence of this show, he preferred them to be ample in form and stately in their bearing, with a touch of fat around the jawbone and a wide, clear, penetrating gaze. Big hats amused him, and he opted instinctively for poses that harked back not only to the turn of our own century but, in at least one case, to the opulent and leisured attitudes in which the great ladies of the Italian Renaissance chose to be portrayed. Yet there, too, he could not resist fantastication. A lion's head, a rather vicious-looking dog and some distinctly peculiar birds (in ''Leda'') -all were brought in to hoist the image clear of the matter-of-fact. Though it comfortably fills the ninth-floor Emmerich Gallery, this is a show that leaves us calling for ''More!'' It can be seen through Nov. 23. Also of interest this week: Goya's ''Allegory of the City of Madrid'' (Spanish Institute, 684 Park Avenue, at 69th Street): It is not every day that a major Goya comes into town. We owe the brief loan of his ''Allegory of the City of Madrid'' to the fact that since 1982 New York and Madrid have been sister cities, with all that that implies in the way of cultural exchange. Accompanied in the present instance by a group of related and elucidatory prints from the Municipal Museum in Madrid, the ''Allegory'' dates from the period during which Madrid was occupied by the French and Napoleon had named his brother Joseph King of Spain. In December 1809 the Madrid city council decided, doubtless for reasons of its own, to commission a portrait of Joseph I, as he was called, and in February 1810 Goya got the commission. Given the hatred of the French intruders that was to characterize his famous painting ''May 2, 1808,'' it cannot be imagined that Goya relished the task. What he produced was not so much a portrait of the temporary King as a personification of the city of Madrid.
