Majestic in scale - 8 feet 8 inches by 6 feet 6 inches - the painting made a great effect in the city hall. It was subject, however, to more than one adjustment. When Joseph I found it convenient to leave town after the French were driven from Madrid, the portrait of Joseph Bonaparte was overpainted with the word ''Constitution.'' When Joseph got to come back again, Goya painted him back in, just the same as before. Joseph then got beaten at the battle of Vitoria, and Goya painted him out again. ''Constitution'' was put in again, only to be painted out when it emerged that the new King of Spain did not care for constitutions and was never going to sign one. Not until 1826, when Goya was living in France, did another painter, Vicente Lopez, make the definitive adjustment by painting in the date of the patriotic uprising that had been suppressed by the French in 1808. These ups and downs notwithstanding, this is a painting that no one who loves Goya will wish to miss. It can be seen Monday through Saturday, from 11 A.M. to 6 P.M., through Nov. 9. Christopher James (Witkin Gallery, 415 West Broadway): Christopher James, painter and photographer, is showing 26 new paintings (one of them a 5-panel picture that measures 60 by 90 inches) on the theme of women in and out of water. As was evident in 1983, when he had a first show on this same subject, the theme is just about inexhaustible. Furthermore, waterborne women are omnipresent - or so it would seem -no matter where Christopher James happens to turn up. France, Mexico, Thailand, India, Hungary and New Hampshire - it's splash, splash, splash, all the way. Working, as he does, primarily with watercolor, James has the advantage of a medium that ebbs and flows like the water that is basic to all his images. It also has the disadvantage that it is very difficult to control when used on the huge scale that is fundamental to James's best paintings. To get the weight, the texture and the fullness of the women's bodies to rhyme with the tumult of the water is a neat trick, and one that he carries off as if it were the most natural thing in the world. Within the general theme of the pool or bath, the range of feeling is unexpectedly large, thanks to James's gift for exact observation. There is, to begin with, the contrast between the swimmers' heads, which are customarily above the water, and their bodies, which thrash around below. From the neck up, they look like Neptune's kid sisters - alert, energized, exhilarated, often superb in their looks. From the neck down, their forms are wildly distorted by the movement of the water and the play of reflection. Distortion in this case is not mockery. The combination of frantic activity with optical commotion is one that gives us a new idea of the expressive potential of the human body. The fact that limb and sinew are pushed every which way does not so much debase them as lend them a heroic strangeness, as if the bodies in question were being remade, over and over and over. Puffing and blowing, shaking and shuddering, these are human beings not diminished but magnified. It also seemed to this visitor that Christopher James has a sharp eye for the extent to which the goings-on in the swimming bath offer material for a modern mythology. There is more to these swimmers than athletics, that is to say. The painting called ''Swimming Lesson, Budapest'' has erotic overtones that suggest that something more than the breast stroke is being taught. And as for the fine-looking women who tote monumental hammers and spanners in the series of paintings that deal with the maintenance and underwater repair of the baths, they are colossal presences, as emblematic as they are redoubtable. (Through Dec. 7.) Daniel Bennett Schwartz (Armstrong Gallery, 50 West 57th Street): Last seen in New York in 1967, Daniel Bennett Schwartz is a figurative painter who works in a peculiarly timeless idiom. He can make a small variant of a painting of bathers by Thomas Eakins and not fall flat on his face, for instance, and he can compose and construct a complicated figure subject in ways that suggest a long familiarity with antique sculpture. At the same time, he can paint a sunny day on the Sheep Meadow in Central Park, with groups of young people exercising, reading or lying around doing nothing much of anything, in a way that documents our own day. When he works from a single figure, fully dressed and in close-up, the result has a look of high-grade illustration. It is the middle distance and the jumble of young people minding their own individual business that seem to suit him best. (Through Dec. 4.) Judy Tomkins (Leo Castelli Gallery, 420 West Broadway): With the exception of a wonderfully evocative image of an old-style pork store and an interior of a table laid for two, Judy Tomkins's new photographs have almost no echo of human presence - unless the picture of two trashbins, one bearing the legend ''Lucky,'' the other the legend ''Unlucky,'' may also be said to have human undertones. The other images have in common that their subject matter is spare and sparse, often seen from an unexpected angle and with discreet but fanatical attention to placing, detail and texture. A sliver of staircase, two or three little flowers, a quick sharp glance at bathroom furniture are all that is needed, when this particular finger is on the button, to bring about a memorable result. (Through Nov. 16.)

title: BRIDGE: U.S. IS AHEAD IN OPEN FINAL BUT AMERICAN WOMEN TRAIL
description: One United States team started very well and the other very poorly in the finals of the world team championships here today.

title: PRICES PAID TO FARMERS INCREASE 1.7%
description: Prices farmers get for raw products rose 1.7 percent in October, the first increase in the monthly index in 15 months, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 1, 1985
description: International

title: SLATTERY GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $249,000 for the quarter and $160,000 for the nine months. c-Including income from discontinued operations of $104,000 for the quarter and $471,000 for the nine months.

title: Gilbert and Sullivan
description: The New York Gilbert and Sullivan Players will begin their second year in residence at the Palace Theater in Stamford, Conn., tomorrow at 8 P.M. with a performance of ''The Yeomen of the Guard.'' The Palace Theater is at 61 Atlantic Street in Stamford. Tickets are $10 to $22; for information, (203) 359-0009.

title: S.E.C. CHARGES FIRST JERSEY
description: Just a year after settling one set of charges of securities law violations, First Jersey Securities Inc. and its chairman and owner, Robert E. Brennan, were charged yesterday by the Securities and Exchange Commission with a new series of violations. First Jersey and Mr. Brennan were accused, in the new suit, of defrauding customers of more than $9.6 million through manipulative stock recommendations that produced huge price markups.

title: PGA Rejects Request
description: Seve Ballesteros, the Spanish golf champion, lost his bid to play on the American tour next year because he failed to compete in the 15 tournaments in which he had said he would play this year. Rejecting Ballestero's request that he be allowed to play in 10 PGA tournaments in 1986 despite his failure to keep his 1985 commitments, the policy board of the PGA Tour voted to suspend him from the Tour next year.

title: MARCOS PREDICTS REBELS' DEFEAT WITHIN A YEAR
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos today predicted victory over the country's Communist insurgency within one year, provided the Philippines receives financial aid from the United States. At the same time, he rejected American warnings of a political and military crisis in the Philippines.

title: Hospital Corp. Divestment Order
description: The Federal Trade Commission ordered the nation's largest for-profit hospital chain to dispose of two hospitals and a hospital management contract in the Chattanooga, Tenn., area.

title: Terrorism Killed a 2d American During the Achille Lauro Affair
description: To the Editor:

title: BALLET: JOFFREY COMPANY
description: IT'S not true that the best ballets always come in small packages, but two of the Joffrey Ballet's brightest novelties this season are brief and pungent little works by Gerald Arpino.

title: Market Place;   Some Caution On Oil Stocks
description: THE brisk rally in oil stocks during the last five weeks has been described by Wall Street professionals as ''the only game in town except for takeovers.'' But energy analysts suggested yesterday that the rebound in oil stock prices has run most of its course.

title: PROVACATIVE IS THE WORD FOR SPRING
description: It's not just that the clothes are tight, which indeed they are, but they are cut so provocatively that they open a new era of sexy dressing. Bob Mackie and Fernando Sanchez were two advocates of this fashion direction as the spring fashion showings began in New York this week.

title: Man Guilty of Keeping Woman in Bondage
description: Cameron Hooker, a former mill worker, was convicted today of abducting a young hitchhiker at knifepoint and holding her in bondage for seven years.

title: Indian Museum Seeks Clarification by Court
description: The trustees of the Museum of the American Indian have asked the New York State Supreme Court to clarify the rights and obligations of the museum regarding the offer by the Texas computer executive H. Ross Perot to invest $70 million in the museum if it moves to Texas.

title: WHITE VOTE, BLACK ANGER
description: The Star, an evening newspaper here, publishes two editions each afternoon, supposed to cater to the differing notions of what is news for blacks and whites.

title: Art in West Nyack
description: An exhibition of 120 prints by 60 artists will open at 1 P.M. on Sunday at the Rockland Center for the Arts in West Nyack and continue through Nov. 23.

title: LINCOLN NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a gain on investments of $23,599,000. c-After income from discontinued operations of $7,219,000 for the quarter and $16,873,000 for the 9 months. d-Includes a gain of $39,593,000 on investments and after net from discontinued operations of $12,136,000.

title: RELIANCE INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company is listed on the Philadelphia Stock Exchange.

title: Ban on Nickel Trading Is Urged in Tin Crisis
description: Inco Ltd., the world's largest producer of nickel, called on the London Metal Exchange today to halt nickel trading until the tin crisis is resolved.

title: GAMBINO JURORS HEAR TESTIMONY ON KILLINGS OF 3
description: Federal jurors sat rapt yesterday as a Government informer vividly recounted three killings that prosecutors say were linked to a car theft ring operated by 10 reputed figures in the Gambino crime organization.

title: CASCADE NATURAL GAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: KNOLL INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
EX-NAVY AIDE INDICTED ON DYNAMICS JOB TRIPS
description: A former assistant Navy secretary was indicted today on charges of concealing the fact that he took job-hunting trips paid for by the General Dynamics Corporation while he was still a Government official.

title: RIGHTS CHIEF ASSAILS HIRING GOALS AS FAILURE
description: Assistant Attorney General William Bradford Reynolds today denounced the Government's affirmative action program for Federal contractors, saying it had kept ''deserving blacks'' and women from being hired.

title: The Griffin Quartet
description: The tenor saxophonist Johnny Griffin and his quartet are appearing tonight through Sunday at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, above Bleecker Street.

title: 150 Guatemalans Seize Cathedral in Protest
description: About 150 relatives of missing people took over the Metropolitan Cathedral here today, locked themselves inside and vowed to stay until the Government accounted for the missing.

title: VERVE ON VIETNAM'S AVENUES, SATIRE ON THE STAGE
description: A resident ambassador calls it Hanoi's ''simply lovely'' season - the weeks between the stifling months of summer and winter's dismal, bitter chill. The sky is blue, the air fresh, and the streets are full of activity.

title: UNITED DOMINION REALTY TRUST INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including gains on the sale of real estate of $163,810 for the quarter and $165,166 for the nine months. c-Including gains on the sale of real estate of $643 for the quarter and $2,040,170 for the nine months.

title: WESTERN CAPITAL INVESTMENT reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
U.S. KEEPS WORK FLEXIBILITY
description: Federal clockwatchers can relax, at least for a while. President Reagan signed into law Thursday a two-month extension of the Government's program allowing full-time Federal workers to adjust their hours to suit their personal needs.

title: Computerland
description: The Computerland Corporation plans to reduce the 8 percent royalty fee charged its franchisees by 1 percent as of Jan. 1, industry sources said.

title: BANKS PRESSED TO AID MANILA
description: Administration officials, for strategic reasons, are urging bankers in this country and abroad to lend money to the Philippines, according to American bankers and a Philippine official. The rationale is that the political situation in the islands cannot be stabilized and American bases preserved if the economy continues to deteriorate.

title: JUDICIAL CHOICES INNEW YORK CITY
description: Once again New Yorkers are asked to participate in the farce of choosing judicial candidates from slates served up by party conventions and primaries. Since most voters have no idea who the judicial candidates are, much less their qualifications, popular choice is a myth.

title: MORTALITY ANDLOVE
description: THE PAST. By Galway Kinnell. 57 pages.

title: FERRARO SAYS SHE WON'T DECIDE ON SENATE RACE FOR 4 WEEKS
description: Geraldine A. Ferraro says that she has not made a decision on whether to run next year for the United States Senate seat held by Alfonse M. D'Amato and that she will not for at least four weeks.

title: IVEY PROPERTIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago share earnings have been restated to reflect a 50 percent stock dividend declared effective April 1, 1985.

title: LYNCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BRIEFS
description: * Adobe Resources Corp., said its board has authorized management to purchase up to one million shares of the corporation's capital stock. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Japan Patent Access
description: The International Business Machines Corporation has become the first foreign company to gain access to about 700 Japanese Government-owned patents related to information processing, the Industrial Science and Technology Agency said today.

title: HAVERTY FURNITURE COS., INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a gain of $3,545,000 from the sale of real estate. c-Including a gain of $195,000 from the sale of real estate.

title: Oil Output Up 10% in China
description: China's production of crude oil reached 650.8 million barrels in the first nine months of 1985, up 10 percent, compared with the same period last year, the New China News Service reported today.

title: CUP COULD BRING SEVERAL UPSETS
description: The seven Breeders' Cup races at Aqueduct today will be the most glittering showcase of race horses ever assembled, but the afternoon may well prove that chance and uncertainty are as important as talent at any level of racing.

title: SALE OF ITT STAKE BY JACOBS REPORTED
description: Irwin L. Jacobs, the Minneapolis investor, has sold his stake in the ITT Corporation, thus removing one of the biggest threats to the telecommunications company's independence, according to Wall Street sources.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report in the Company Briefs column of Business Day on Wednesday misidentified the retail chain that plans to withdraw its Gold Circle merchandising division from Pittsburgh next year. It is Federated Department Stores Inc.

title: BLACK MAYOR FAVORED FOR RE-ELECTION IN CHARLOTTE
description: At rush hour the two narrow lanes of Sharon Road are a tangle of traffic, moving slowly past the thicket of new subdivisions and apartment blocks that sprawl across the city's southern flank and into the suburbs beyond.

title: AFGHANISTAN'S OTHER FRONT: A WORLD OF DRUGS
description: Soviet soldiers in Afghanistan use drugs extensively, and some Russians sell gasoline, ammunition and stolen guns to support their habits, according to several Russian defectors living with Afghan rebels.

title: ARGENTINA NO IMPORTER OF CHINA 'HEAVY WATER'
description: To the Editor:

title: UTAH MAN ARRAIGNED ON A WEAPONS CHARGE
description: A man who is under investigation by the authorities in bombings here that killed two people has been charged with a Federal firearms violation unrelated to the blasts, officials say.

title: OFFICIALS TOUR AN INDIAN MUSEUM SITE
description: Mayor Koch and Attorney General Robert Abrams toured the Bronx storage facilities of the Museum of the American Indian yesterday and said they were strongly committed to keeping the museum in New York.

title: HOUSEHOLD INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ZEHNTEL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income, including a tax credit of $411,000.

Adjustment for the Ballot
description: Evelyn Irizarry Guardarramas, the Republican-Conservative candidate for City Council President, is listed in Board of Elections records by her formal name.

description: b-Including capital gains of $805,000 for the quarter and $1,579,000 for the nine months. c-Including a capital gain of $115,000 for the nine months and after a capital loss of $471,000 for the quarter.

title: IDAHO POWER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TV: 'OWL/TV' ON PBS, CHILDREN'S NATURE SERIES
description: A new science and nature series of half-hour programs for children ages 8 to 14 begins tonight at 7 o'clock on Channel 13. Using trick photography, cartoons and video graphics, along with young performers, adult experts and a talking skeleton, the show, ''Owl/TV,'' is a kind of naturalists' ''Sesame Street,'' delivering information in the guise of entertainment. The series is produced by the National Audubon Society and the Young Naturalist Foundation, which publishes Owl and Chickadee, two Canadian magazines for children. The supervising producer is Paulle Clark.

title: DEAD DINOSAURS, LIVE POLITICS
description: A strange seed has taken root among paleontologists, the scientists who study fossil life forms. Fear is a bizarre phenomenon to find in 20th-century American science, as well as a ridiculous way to resolve scientific controversies. Yet some paleontologists fear their careers may be impeded if they oppose the currently fashionable theory that a meteorite collided with Earth and caused the extinction of the dinosaurs some 65 million years ago.

title: IOWA-ILLINOIS GAS & ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PRIMAGES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Holders Back Fleet Mergers
description: Shareholders approved the Fleet National Bank's plans to buy banks in Maine and Connecticut, moves that would make it New England's third-largest bank.

title: BUDGET BATTLE: DEMOCRATS UNITE BEHIND PARTY PLAN
description: House Democrats pulled off one of the most deft legislative tricks of the year today when all but two party members followed their leadership and supported the Democratic plan for producing a balanced budget by 1991.

title: AMERICAN NUCLEONICS CORP reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
SETON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

description: A gallery in New York that deals in rare books said yesterday that it was in possession of the first item ever printed on a press in America - the one-page ''Oath of a Freeman,'' which is said to have been printed in Cambridge, Mass., in 1638 or 1639.

description: Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, will make an unusual trip to Argentina in a week or so, according to senior officials of the Reagan Administration and international banking organizations.

description: The Personal Health column in The Living Section on Oct. 9 misidentified the developer of a hearing device called Tactaid. It was developed by the Audiological Engineering Corporation of Somerville, Mass.

description: Privately built and operated dams on Federal waterways produce billions of dollars worth of electric power at very low cost. Who should reap the benefits?

title: CITY OPERA: 'CASANOVA'
description: THE memoirs of Casanova, the 18th century's most celebrated libertine, are a gold mine of operatic material, and Dominick Argento, whose ''Casanova'' arrived last night at the New York City Opera, has struck it rich with his inspired account of one of the great lover's autumnal escapades. The three-act work, first performed in Minneapolis earlier this year, proved to be a thoroughgoing delight in its New York premiere, a witty theater piece that should go on charming audiences for many years.

description: Phil Silvers, the comedian who portrayed Master Sgt. Ernie Bilko in the 1950's television series ''The Phil Silvers Show,'' died in his sleep yesterday afternoon at his home in Los Angeles, a CBS spokesman said. He was 73 years old.

description: Laura Dean was possibly the most interesting experimental choreographer to emerge in modern dance in the 1970's. As her spinning dancers stamped and skipped through basic geometric patterns, dance as a hypnotic ritual seemed suddenly to find its place in the theater after all.

title: Generous Offers
description: Two more basketball players now in the pros, the guard Isiah Thomas of the Detroit Pistons and the forward Dominique Wilkins of the Atlanta Hawks, have said they were offered improper inducements to attend college, but both said they spurned the offers. Thomas said that when he was a senior in high school in Illinois, a middle western college that he declined to name offered him $50,000, a car and a home for his mother if he agreed to play for the school.

title: THE RUSSIANS' LOT IN AFGHAN HANDS
description: ''The Holy Koran,'' a rebel commander said, ''says if you capture a prisoner during fighting you should not kill him but you should teach him about Islam. If he becomes a Moslem, you should treat him as a brother.''

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 15. 1. The bell salvaged from a wreck off Wellfleet, Mass., bears the name ''Whydah,'' instead of the misspelling ''Whidah'' of most American accounts. It provides definitive identification of the wreck as a pirate vessel that went down in 1717, the first time in history that a pirate wreck had been identified and salvaged. 2. Blackmailing of insurance companies was dismissed as a motive because the paintings, valued at more than $12.5 million, were not insured. 3. Would. 4. Amtrak halted the train for nearly an hour as daylight time ended and standard time resumed, to make the run consistent with the printed schedule. 5. Isaac Newton. 6. True. 7. The policy of providing financial support to the United Nations Fund for Population Activities, whose aid recipients include nations that reputedly practice coercive abortion and sterilization. 8. The annual savings rate. 9. Thomas Jefferson. 10. False. 11. A new ceiling for the Holland Tunnel. No other motor vehicle tunnel in the world has undergone such a major renovation, according to the Port Authority. 12. For the second year in a row, Grete Waitz and Orlando Pizzolato won the New York City Marathon. 13. The ''Treasure Houses of Britain'' exhibit, with more than 800 works, opens tomorrow. 14. The E. F. Hutton Group. 15. West Germany planned and is directing all the mission's scientific operations from a control center near Munich. The crew consists of five Americans, two West Germans and a Dutchman. 16.

title: COMPTROLLER WARNS BANKS ON DIVIDENDS
description: The Comptroller of the Currency cautioned the nation's banks today that they were paying shareholders' dividends that were too high in light of the increased levels of bad loans throughout the banking system.

title: Leapy Lad Wins In Open Jumping
description: Jay Land, riding Leapy Lad, won the Gambler's Choice International and Open Jumping Competiton last night at the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden.

title: 36 Years on U.S. Bench
description: It was a quiet little celebration in the chambers of Irving R. Kaufman, celebrating his 36th anniversary on the Federal bench.

title: SADOWSKY, IN PARTING SHOT, CALLS COUNCIL A 'DUD'
description: Councilman Edward L. Sadowsky, about to leave public life after 24 years in elective office, sent a message to his colleagues yesterday: The City Council is a ''dud,'' involved in ''trivial pursuits,'' and has only itself to blame.

title: A DOCTOR FOR MARCOS IS STABBED TO DEATH
description: A kidney specialist who had treated President Ferdinand E. Marcos was found stabbed to death today after armed men kidnapped him.

title: SENATE VOTES FUNDS FOR AGENCIES
description: The Senate voted 83 to 10 today to appropriate $11.9 billion for the State, Justice and Commerce Departments and other agencies after rejecting an attempt to delete most money for the Economic Development Agency.

title: MAGNETIC TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Year to July 31
HOUSTON CAMPAIGN GOES PAST IMAGE IN EFFORT TO PROMOTE CITY
description: Rushing to greatness in the frenzied oil boom of the 70's and early 80's, Houston neglected to broaden its economy so that it would be insulated against an eventual downturn in its dominant industry.

title: RUSSIAN SAID TO ENTER U.S. MISSION IN KABUL
description: The State Department said today that a Soviet soldier walked into the United States Embassy in Kabul, Afghanistan, on Thursday and was still there, ''being looked after by our embassy staff.''

title: COAST MAYOR SAYS HE ERRED ON FARRAKHAN SPEECH
description: Mayor Tom Bradley told a convention of Jewish leaders today that he might have made a mistake in not publicly denouncing Louis Farrakhan, the Black Muslim leader, before Mr. Farrakhan gave a major address here Sept. 14.

title: CHECKING YOUR BILLS FOR ERRORS
description: RALPH NADER, the consumer advocate, is eager to receive bills in the mail. He is asking consumers to scrutinize their bills for incorrect charges and needlessly complex language and send him a copy. He hopes to use the bills he collects to convince Congress to pass a bill of another sort - one that would protect consumers against merchants' mistakes and punish merchants for billing fraud.

title: LOST MISSILES FOUND
description: The Air Force says it has recovered five armed missiles found sticking out of the mud on the Yukon River near the site of an F-15A fighter crash in June. Three of the plane's eight missiles are still missing but probably will not explode, officials said.

title: TSO FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
LONG-TERM BOND PRICES RISE
description: Prices in the long-term bond market overcame some carryover selling yesterday, and resumed their advance. Short-term interest rates were basically unchanged.

title: DELTA QUEEN BED
description: The Delta Queen Steamboat Company said today it received a merger proposal froum Equity Holdings, an Illinois general partnership and the largest holder of Delta Queen common stock.

title: TAKEOVER ACCEPTED BY REVLON
description: After fighting for three months to avoid a takeover by Pantry Pride Inc., Revlon Inc. gave in yesterday, saying it would ''do nothing to impede'' the takeover. It added that officers and directors would immediately sell their stock to the Florida supermarket chain.

title: Glider Crash Kills Two
description: An Air Force Academy glider went into a sudden nosedive Thursday just before it crashed in a meadow north of the academy grounds, killing an officer and a cadet, witnesses said. The victims were identified today as Capt. Michael G. McVay, 32 years old, of Colorado Springs, a faculty instructor, and Cadet 3d Class Bradley W. Hushaw, 19, of Salem, Mo.

description: Severiano Ballesteros of Spain, banned from all but four 1986 tournaments in the United States by the PGA Tour on Thursday, yesterday called the move ''a terrible mistake.''

title: THE BIG MAC GOES TO MEXICO
description: The McDonald's Big Mac came to Mexico this week, causing traffic jams as hundreds of Mexicans lined up to buy hamburgers, but with chili sauce instead of ketchup.

title: U.S. AND E.E.C. REACH ACCORD ON STEEL
description: The United States and the European Common Market, easing some of the strains on their economic relations, today agreed on a four-year pact holding shipments of European steel to 5.5 percent of the United States market.

title: BREEDERS' CUP GALA HELD AT MUSEUM
description: There were dinosaurs and elephants, lions and impalas, and even a huge whale, but no horses at the Breeders' Cup Gala last night in the American Museum of Natural History. There was, however, the New York Racing Association's bugler in his pink coat to trumpet the 850 guests into cocktails in the Hall of African Mammals and later into dinner in the Hall of Ocean Life.

Physician Commits Suicide At Office With Patient's Gun
description: A 52-year-old physician killed himself yesterday in his Staten Island office with the gun of a patient who is a state correction officer, the police said.

description: For two hours one day this week, it was like old times for the Jets' Pat Ryan. He was the quarterback running the show.

description: International

title: KLOSS VIDEO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
No Headline
description: Companies Revlon gave up its fight against a takeover by Pantry Pride after failing to get a needed victory in a Delaware court. The cosmetics company said its officers and directors would tender their shares immediately. The capitulation came after three justices of the Delaware Supreme Court upheld an injunction against Revlon. A lower court issued the injunction after finding that Revlon directors had breached their fiduciary duty by giving Forstmann Little, an investment house, a contract to purchase two important operations as part of a deal to buy the entire company. But Forstmann Little could still take the case to trial. [Page 35.] CBS stock rose $5, for a three-day gain of $15.50. One rumor said the Fisher Bros. real estate firm was planning a bid. [39.] Irwin Jacobs has sold his stake in ITT, removing a threat to the company's independence, Wall Street sources said. [36.] International Paul A. Volcker will make an unusual trip to Argentina in a week or so, Washington officials said. Economists said the Fed chief might discuss a less restrictive loan for Argentina. [35.] The Administration is urging banks to lend to Manila, American bankers and a Philippine official said. [38.] European steel shipments will be held to 5.5 percent of the American market for four years under an agreement with the Common Market. But American steelmakers were not satisfied. [36.] Oil markets reacted calmly to statements by an Arab oil minister that OPEC members are free to set prices as they wish.

title: A KEY SENATOR CALLS ON MARCOS TO STEP DOWN
description: The chairman of the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence said today that President Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines was incapable of bringing about reform and should step down.

title: EXPERT ON SPACE SHIELD QUITS
description: Roy D. Woodruff, chief of nuclear X-ray laser research at the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, has resigned, a laboratory spokesman said Thursday.

title: PAR TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Tin Trading Suspension By Exchange Extended
description: The British Government put pressure on the troubled International Tin Council today to end the crisis that has halted trading and threatens to collapse the metal's oversupplied market.

title: THE GENEVA TALKS GET AN EXTENSION
description: American and Soviet negotiators today extended their arms-control talks until next Thursday so that the Soviet Union can study a new American proposal that was formally presented here today.

title: NATURAL, FANCY: FOODLINES BLUR
description: The people who sell so-called gourmet or fancy foods emphasize taste; those who sell natural foods emphasize health. They would seem to have nothing in common. But, in fact, many of the products at the Natural Food Expo '85, which took place in Washington last weekend, would have been right at home at an earlier New York show called Taste, where fancy foods starred.

FORD TO OFFER AIR BAGS AS OPTIONS ON '86 COMPACTS
description: The Ford Motor Company will soon offer air bags as optional equipment on one line of compact cars, sources within the company said today. It will be the first time that air bags have been available to the general public in an American car since the mid-1970's.

title: RECORDING GROUP TELLS OF NEW STEPS ON LYRICS
description: The president of the Recording Industry Association of America announced today that many American record companies would soon begin including warnings on albums containing potentially offensive lyrics. Or, he said, they may decide instead to print the records' lyrics on the back of the jackets.

title: REAGAN THREATENED SOVIET ON SEAMAN, OFFICIAL SAYS
description: Before the Soviet authorities permitted a Soviet sailor to be interviewed by the State Department Monday, President Reagan warned them that the United States was prepared to use force to remove him from a freighter in the Mississippi River, a senior White House official said today.

Coach Hayden Fry said the decals would be worn for the rest of the season, which might end in the Rose Bowl for the unbeaten Hawkeyes.

Mr. Hunt, who now serves as president of the Tribune National Marketing Company, joined The Chicago Tribune as an advertising salesman in 1950.

title: KASPAROV SETTLES FOR A DRAW IN 21ST GAME OF CHESS MATCH
description: Despite holding the advantage at adjournment of the 21st game of the world championship chess match, the 22-year-old challenger, Gary Kasparov, made no serious attempt to win. He allowed the champion, Anatoly Karpov, 34, to pull out with a draw after only four moves when the game was resumed yesterday in Moscow's Tchaikovsky Concert Hall.

Cancer Cell Antibiotic

title: Good News for Hagler
description: Marvelous Marvin Hagler has a strained back - not a ruptured disk, as feared - and can resume training in two to three weeks, his doctor said yesterday after a 90-minute examination of the undisputed middleweight champion. Hagler also has a fractured nose, however, which will bar him from contact for about six weeks.

title: 'Quality Starts' Add a Dimension
description: Before he endures another long wintertime without the solace of his favorite weekend listings of baseball statistics, there is a special kind of category that the true fanatic ought to consider, because he might want to keep track of it next season. It is called the ''quality start,'' and, although it is not an official statistic, there may be no better shorthand way of gauging the effectiveness of a pitcher who takes a regular turn. Frequent viewers of NBC's ''Game of the Week'' have heard Vin Scully talk about it.

title: IN RAIN FOREST AT BRONX ZOO, STUDENTS VIEW JUNGLE RITUALS
description: High atop the Jungleworld exhibit at the Bronx Zoo, a group armed with stopwatches and binoculars studied the behavioral patterns of silvered-leaf monkeys yesterday, carefully recording the monkeys' size, coloring and facial expressions.

title: CBS STOCK UP SHARPLY FOR 3D DAY
description: Capping three days of hectic trading, CBS stock rose $4.75 a share yesterday, to $123.25, in heavy volume. Fueled by a variety of takeover rumors, CBS stock has soared $14.50 a share in the past three days, rising $5 on Thurday and $4.75 the previous day.

title: Turnpike Plazas Being Bypassed
description: Bypass lanes have been completed and opened to traffic around the now-closed Connecticut Turnpike toll plazas in Branford, Madison, Plainfield and West Haven, a state Transportation Department spokesman said today.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week.

title: U.S. POLICY ON ANGOLA MOVES CLOSER TO REBEL AID
description: The Reagan Administration said today, in a policy statement of support for rebels fighting the Soviet-backed Government in Angola, that the United States ''should sympathize with and support such resistence.''

title: WHY EXCLUDE RUMANIA?
description: American concern for human rights should be extended to apply to Rumania. The regime of Nicolae Ceausescu is one of the world's most repressive dictatorships. Yet Rumania continues to be given special and generous treatment by the United States.

title: TO GAIN A MARKET EDGE
description: The renewed clamor for import quotas and other protectionist measures can, at best, provide only a temporary advantage to American industry. The best protection in the race against foreign competitors is to run faster and keep ahead through innovation and productivity - revitalizing older industries and creating new ones. Our universities can play a crucial role in this effort.

title: Injured Rangers Ready to Return
description: Tomas Sandstrom and James Patrick have benefited from the Rangers' idleness since last Sunday.

Voltage Limiters
description: The Electric Power Research Institute Inc. in Palo Alto, Calif., received a patent this week for a method of making voltage limiters, especially for use in gapless lightning arresters. Patent 4,549,981 was granted to Tapan K. Gupta and four other inventors. Zinc oxide is a principal ingredient.

title: REAGAN PROPOSES U.S.-SOVIET ACCORD ON MOBILE MISSILES
description: President Reagan has proposed that the United States and the Soviet Union abandon plans for the deployment of mobile, land-based nuclear missiles under a new arms-control proposal offered in Geneva, Congressional and Administration officials said today.

title: GIANTS SIGN A NEW KICKER
description: Eric Schubert has been spending the fall at his alma mater, Lakeland Regional High School in nearby Wanaque, N.J. He has been earning $1,000 for the season as an assistant football coach and $42 a day as a substitute teacher.

title: LEHMAN REBUKED BY WEINBERGER OVER COMPLAINT ON SPY CASE DEAL
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger today sharply rebuked Navy Secretary John F. Lehman Jr. for his criticism of the Government's plea bargain with John A. Walker Jr. in the espionage case against him.

title: DISPUTED CLAIMS CLOUD TOXIC-WASTE ISSUE IN JERSEY CAMPAIGN
description: A mass of ugly, corroded drums of toxic waste fill the television screen. A few seconds later they vanish, and the viewer sees a pristine grassy field.

title: Dale Electronics By Reuters

The transaction, which was announced Sept. 19, involved the purchase of 82 percent of the Dale stock from the Lionel Corporation and the remaining publicly held shares at the same price.

title: CORRECTION

title: Chase in Maryland
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation opened 13 branches in Maryland today, freeing $500 million in deposits that have been frozen since state-insured thrift institutions collapsed in May. Operating as Chase Bank of Maryland, the New York banking giant acquired three major thrift units - Merritt Commercial of Baltimore, Friendship of Bethesda and Chesapeake of Annapolis - and converted them to commercial banks. The acquisition adds assets of $817 million to Chase Manhattan's $87 billion in assets.

Delaware North is the Buffalo company that owned the Bruins and Boston Garden.

McFarlane joined the White House as national security adviser.

description: The oil markets, enjoying firm prices going into the winter months, yesterday shrugged off statements made late Thursday by the oil minister of the United Arab Emirates that OPEC members are now free to set oil prices as they wish.

title: IOWA RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
HER IS THE PANACEA
description: Slowly but surely, people are relearning the old truth that ice cream is a simple panacea for the woes of life. It's the best tonic available for both mind and body - it is spiritually uplifting, nutritious and wholesome. Many nutritionists say the calcium in ice cream has a calming effect. And some psychiatrists, instead of prescribing tranquilizers, will advise patients to try ice cream or, if the patient is worried about gaining weight, sherbet.

title: PITTWAY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ATLANTIC CITY ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CYPRUS TO HOLD ELECTIONS DEC. 8
description: After six hours of bitter debate over the leadership of President Spyros Kyprianou, Parliament voted unanimously today to dissolve itself and hold elections Dec. 8.

title: GOING OUR GUIDE
description: ERIE CANAL The Erie Canal, which has been back in the news lately as a substitute gateway to the Great Lakes while the St. Lawrence Seaway is temporarily out of action, was one of the keys to the greatness of New York City. The canal provided a route from Lake Erie to New York Harbor, which battened on the cargoes the canal barges brought from the Middle West.

title: U.S.-NICARAGUA TALKS HALTED
description: After two rounds of discussions this week, Nicaragua and the United States have failed to reach agreement on the resumption of talks, and each side blamed the other today.

title: Korean Trade Warning
description: President Chun Doo Hwan today called for measures to cope with growing American pressure for Seoul to open its markets further, officials said.

title: THE FLYOVER PEOPLE
description: Leaving aside the French, is there a group of people on earth as self-absorbed as New Yorkers and southern Californians? From all the whining -you know, it wasn't a ''real'' World Series without one of the Coast teams - one gets the impression that all those other teams are there just to fill out the standings. Pretty soon, one supposes, the Yankees, Mets, Dodgers and Angels won't bother to play road games. Yokels will be brought in from the provinces for the entertainment of the Coastal Overlords.

title: BERGDORF'S OPENS A HOMELIKE HOME DEPARTMENT
description: One day this week, a Bergdorf Goodman customer got off the elevator on the seventh floor by mistake. ''He thought he had wandered into Andrew Goodman's private penthouse,'' said Zimmie Sasson, vice president and divisional merchandise manager for The Home, the store's new home furnishings floor. ''We were delighted - that was just the effect we were trying to convey.''

title: GRUBB & ELLIS REALTY reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
VACU-DRY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 29
description: b-Net income.

title: Unofficial Party In Corlears Hook Park
description: The deserted amphitheater gleamed eerily under a bright moon. In a weed-strewn corner of an unused park, it resembled a remnant of a decaying civilization. Thousands of people converged on the site Halloween night, some arriving in antique cars, some on foot.

title: Japan Brokerage Licenses Granted
description: The Japanese Finance Ministry said today it has granted licenses to the Kleinwort Benson International Corporation and Drexel Burnham Lambert (Asia) Ltd. allowing them to engage in the securities business.

title: LINCOLN BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SFM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income, after a loss of $4,000 for the nine months from discontinued operations.

title: NETS' NEW OFFENSE EXCELS IN VICTORY
description: The Nets' new offense is getting more finely tuned with Coach Dave Wohl's constant preaching on controlled speed. Tonight, in their fifth game and third victory, the Nets' running game was at its best as they defeated the Philadelphia 76ers, 106-102, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: Howard Johnson
description: Imperial Group P.L.C. shareholders appproved the sale of the Howard Johnson Company to the Marriott Corporation for $314 million at a special meeting today. Agreement to sell Howard Johnson, excluding its Ground Round chain of restaurants, was announced in late September after lengthy negotiations with a number of potential buyers. Marriott has entererd into an agreement to sell off a substantial part of Howard Johnson's business to Prime Motors Inns Inc.

title: BABY IS FAMILY PROJECT
description: Nine months ago, Sherry King agreed for the second time to help her sterile sister start a family and was again artificially inseminated with sperm from her brother-in-law. Now as Mrs. King, 35 years old, awaits labor pains, she says she has no mixed feelings about giving up the infant.

title: GENERAL PUBLIC UTILITIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
WESTWORLD COMMUNITY HEALTHCARE reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
UPPER PENINSULA POWER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ANTI-U.S. PROTEST IN CUBA
description: About 20,000 protesters chanted revolutionary slogans and carried banners denouncing the United States outside the United States Mission in Havana today after Cuba protested over what it said were spy flights by an SR-71 Blackbird surveillance plane on Wednesday.

title: TOP RHODE ISLAND JUDGE RETURNS AFTER CENSURE
description: Despite pleas to resign, Chief Justice Joseph A. Bevilacqua of the Rhode Island Supreme Court returned to the bench today after a four-month leave of absence because of his friendships with people linked to organized crime.

title: AMERICAN GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including realized investment gains of $18,002 for the quarter and $39,406 for the 9 months. c-Including realized investment gains of $7,139 for the quarter and $26,817 for the 9 months.

title: HOW THE U.S. CAPITOL CAME TO LOOK THE WAY IT DOES
description: To the Editor:

title: AMERICAN FAMILY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results reflect net realized gains and losses.

title: UNITED COMPANIES FINANCIAL CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings reflect a two-for-one stock split paid April 1.

title: BRENNER COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
RISING ISLANDERS OF BED-STUY
description: TODAY WHEN-ever I visit my old neighborhood of Bedford-Stuyvesant and walk along Fulton Street or Nostrand Avenue, its twin commercial hubs, I have to remind myself that I'm in Brooklyn and not in the middle of a teeming outdoor market in St. George's, Grenada, or Kingston, Jamaica, or on some other West Indian island. Because there, suddenly, are all the sights and sounds, colors, smells and textures of the entire Caribbean archipelago, transplanted intact to the sidewalks of New York.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch from the United Nations Oct. 27 on marijuana fields in Belize gave an incorrect site for the sentencing of Eligio Briceno, a former Belizean Cabinet minister, on charges of conspiring to smuggle drugs into the United States. Mr. Briceno was tried in Wilmington, N.C., and sentenced in Raleigh, N.C.

title: AN OFFER FROM REAGAN RAISES HOPES FOR GENEVA
description: AS the countdown to the superpower summit in Geneva moves into the final 15 days, each side is mastering the art of making proposals that the other side cannot refuse outright but does not like. The upshot has been a growing mood of optimism about prospects for President Reagan's meeting with Mikhail S. Gorbachev on Nov. 19 and 20. Yet, as diplomats and Reagan Administration officials hasten to point out, the optimism applies more to atmospherics than to substance.

title: After the Storm: Homeless Squirrels
description: Hurricane Gloria not only knocked the power out in the homes of most people on Long Island, but it knocked the homes (namely trees) down for a large population of the squirrels in this area.

title: SHAPIRO FINDS A WARM WELCOME ON STROLL THROUGH CENTRAL WARD
description: There were friendly faces wherever Peter Shapiro turned on the streets here this morning.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;

BEAR FACTS
description: Contrary to popular perception, teddy bears have not been around forever. Now, Helen Kay of Thornwood has written a book outlining the origin of this classic toy, describing the cuddly creature's ascent from political cartoon character to national craze.

title: A HOSPITAL TESTS CHOLESTEROL FOR FREE
description: A quick and simple test to measure blood-cholesterol level will be offered free of charge this month at the New Rochelle Hospital and Medical Center.

title: 'MENDICANT PROFESSOR'
description: INSTANT CHRONICLES A Life. By D.J. Enright. 58 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. Paper, $6.96.

title: ST. EMILION
description: JACQUES HEBRARD, WHO runs Chateau Cheval Blanc in St. Emilion, France, once explained the difference between the St. Emilionais and their competitors west of the Gironde river, the winegrowers of the Medoc and the Graves. ''Here, we wear the same casual clothes all the time, whether working in the vineyards or meeting a customer - unlike our dinner-jacketed friends over there,'' he said.

title: PAPANDREOU WARNS CABINET OF THREAT OF 'CHAOS'
description: Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou has warned his Cabinet that the conjunction of labor unrest and a bomb explosion on an Athens bus on Thursday raised the threat of ''insecurity and chaos'' comparable to the situation that led to a coup and military dictatorship in 1967.

title: JOAN GOLDSTEIN AFFIANCED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Martin Goldstein of Westfield, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Joan E. Goldstein, to Robert Fisher 3d, the son of Mrs. Fisher Jr. of Rutherford, N.J., and the late Mr. Fisher.

title: PHILADELPHIA LANDMARK SAFE
description: Mellon Bank officials have signed a long-term agreement to lease office space in the Lit Brothers Building, capping a five-year battle to save the historic structure. The 19th-century complex, actually several buildings in a facade of cast iron and terra cotta, will be renovated by 1987 at a cost of $70 million, bank officials said this week.

title: HAYNES TO SEE LIMITED ACTION
description: Mark Haynes, the Giants' all-pro cornerback, will make his 1985 debut Sunday, half a season late.

title: The New York Times Book Review: Nov. 3, 1985
description: FICTION

title:
DINING OUT;

FROM SEA BRIGHT TO FARMINGDALE
description: PRINTED on the first page of the menu at an Italian restaurant called The Farmingdale House are the words ''Benvenuti alla Villa di Antonia'' (Welcome to Antonia's house). Antonia is the attractive blonde chef/ co-owner who previously cooked at the Mirimar in Sea Bright, also in Monmouth County.

title: J.I. ZIMENT, EXECUTIVE, WEDS DEBORAH BAYES
description: Deborah Bayes and Jeffrey I. Ziment were married last evening in Temple Beth El in Spring Valley, N.Y. Rabbis Yaakov Hilsenrath and Louis Frishnan performed the ceremony.

title: NEW JAZZ CONCERTO TO HAVE ITS PREMIER
description: THE world premiere of Gary M. Schneider's Concerto for Jazz Clarinet and String Orchestra will be presented Thursday at 8 P.M. by the Hoboken Chamber Orchestra and the clarinetist Perry Robinson. Mr. Schneider will conduct. The concert, entitled ''Hoboken Pops,'' is part of the orchestra's 1985-86 series. Scheduled to coincide with American Music Week (tomorrow to next Sunday), the concert - it will take place at Demarest School, Fourth and Bloomfield Streets - will include works by Copland, Gershwin, Joplin, Foster, Kern and Herbert.

title:
DINING OUT;

INDIAN SPOT CELEBRATING 10th YEAR
description: AS testimonial to the popularity of Indian cuisine, this year Bengal Tiger celebrates its 10th anniversary in the county. From one small and narrow tunnel of a dining room, the restaurant has tripled its space during that time, adding another dining area and a bar and lounge. Even so, on weekend evenings the place bulges with diners eager to sample the rich and strange, gustable complexities wafting cardamom, coriander, sesame, cumin, to name a few of many heady aromatics. Most Indian dishes depend upon fragrance, not heat, for impact.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Ponce Lions vs. Mayaguez Indians, at Ponce, P. R. Winter League game of the week. Dickie Thon and Jose Cruz, Houston Astro teammates, are on the Ponce squad. Juan Bonilla, an infielder who belongs to the Yankees, and Jose Guzman of the Texas Rangers play for Mayaguez. Commentary is in Spanish. (Television - Channel 41, noon live). Basketball Knicks vs. Trail Blazers, at Portland, Ore. The Knicks pay their only visit of the season to Portland. (Television -Channel 9, 10 P.M. Radio - WNBC, 660, 10 P.M.) Equestrian National Horse Show, final day, at Madison Square Garden, 5:30 A.M. 1:30 P.M. and 7:30 P.M. The Maclay National Championship Eliminations and the Special Junior Working Hunter are the features at the pre-dawn session. At the 1:30 session, the Pony Club Mounted Games and the A.S.P.C.A. Maclay National Championship finals are the leading events. The evening performance features the Saddlebred Three-Gaited Horse Grand Championship and the Saddlebred Five-Gaited-Horse Grand Championship, both worth $5,000, and the $20,000 World Cup International and Open Jumping. (Television - MSG, 8 P.M.) Football Giants vs. Tampa Bay Bucaneers, at Giants Stadium, 1 P.M. (Television -Channel 2, 1 P.M. Radio - WNEW, 1130; 1 P.M.) Jets vs. Colts, at Indianapolis. (Television - Channel 4, 4 P.M. Radio -WABC, 770; 4 P.M.) Soccer Peru vs. Chile, at Lima. This is the second leg of the two-match series for teams still playing off for the fourth and last remaining World Cup spot from South America.

title: Lehman Wins Upset
description: Lehman, the second-place finisher in the Bronx division of the Public School Athletic League, upset Brooklyn champion Lafayette, 34-14, in yesterday's quarterfinal playoff action.

title: SOUTH AFRICA PUTS WIDE RESTRICTIONS ON ALL REPORTERS
description: The South African Government imposed sweeping restrictions on local and foreign journalists today, including barring television crews, photographers and radio reporters from covering unrest in areas affected by an emergency decree.

title: H.U.D.'S ROLE ON THE ISLAND
description: WE at the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development would like to correct the misimpression left by the article ''U.S. Delays Are Slowing L.I. Projects'' [Sept. 8] that the Department of Housing and Urban Development has caused delays in the processing of community development grants in Suffolk County.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: Meme Santerre: A French Woman of the People. By Serge Grafteaux. Translated by Louise A. Tilly and Kathryn L. Tilly. (Schocken, $15.95.)

title: THE GERM-JAR HEIST
description: FAMILY BUSINESS By Vincent Patrick. 281 pp. New York: Poseidon Press. $16.95.

title: NUE SPELING
description: To the Editor:

title: INFORMATIOPN AGE ENTERSSMITHSONIAN
description: The Smithsonian Institution has announced plans for an exhibition hall that will trace the ''information revolution'' from its beginnings in the 19th century to today's sophisticated computers, and that will track new developments in communication.

title: Q AND A
description: Question:I would appreciate learning the name of a company that has first-class motorcoach tours through Italy, visiting cities off the beaten path, such as Mantua, Parma and Modena? - A. M., Brooklyn Answer:Bus tours in Italy generally concentrate on the major cities, including Rome, Florence and Venice, because, the operators say, these are the places most tourists want to see. However, one operator of Italian tours that specializes in the hill towns, with an emphasis on art and architecture, is Italia Adagio (162T Whaley Street, Freeport, N.Y. 11520; 516-868-7825). Mantua and Parma are among the towns on its itineraries. Its trips are slower, longer - 16 days or 23 days of touring - than those usually offered, and their prices are higher. ''Our tours are done at a leisurely pace, with hotel stays of three or four nights,'' says Mrs. Dorothy Kreppein, manager.

title: TEWSBURY SCHOOLS DISPUTE
description: The state Labor Relations Commission on Friday declared a teachers strike here illegal and ordered the strikers back to work Monday.

title: FUN 15 MONTHS OF THE YEAR
description: WHEN I left Sport magazine to become the editor in chief of Doubleday & Company's Literary Guild in 1960, its membership was at the vanishing point. The first meeting I went to with Doubleday's top brass was called to discuss the wisdom of killing the Guild and folding its membership into another of Doubleday's many clubs, the Dollar Book Club. I protested. ''I don't know anything about it,'' I said. ''Let me have a chance to look at it.'' So they set another meeting for th enext week, and by then I had a plan. It was outrageous, but it was a plan.

title: ETHNIC BOUNTY
description: For the adventurous diner, New York has never offered so many temptations. Where else can you eat Afghan, Czechoslovak, Ukrainian, Brazilian and French food on successive nights? New Yorkers learn at an early age that the staff of life is not necessarily a slice of white bread but also bagels and croissants, pita and poori, tacos and injera. The term ''ethnic food'' is a misnomer of sorts in this town, for our culinary experience has made ethnic eaters of us all.

title: ROBIN EDWARDS IS WED TO DR. GEORGE MARZELLI
description: The wedding of Robin Lillian Edwards, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip E. Edwards of Bryn Mawr, Pa., and Dr. George A. Marzelli, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George Marzelli of Valhalla, N.Y., took place yesterday. The Rev. Wendy Watson performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Redeemer in Bryn Mawr.

title: 1985 SEASON DEMONSTRATES WHICH TRADES WERE WISEST
description: GENERAL managers seemed to spend so much time huddled with one another in lobbies and restaurants in Kansas City and St. Louis that the World Series took on the atmosphere of baseball's annual winter meetings. This week, the general managers will have their annual meetings in Florida. In pursuing possible trades, some general managers will be emboldened by their success in trades last winter; others may proceed cautiously because they were burned.

title: BRONX MAN FLEEING 2 ROBBERS LEAPS TO HIS DEATH
description: A 36-year-old hospital administrator died early yesterday after jumping from his sixth-floor Bronx apartment in a desperate attempt to escape two armed robbers who had bound him and were stabbing him in the chest and neck, the police said.

title: AFGHAN TROOPS RING U.S. EMBASSY IN STANDOFF OVER A SOVIET SOLDIER
description: Afghan troops have ringed the United States Embassy in Kabul, cut off the electricity and doused it with powerful searchlights in an effort to force American diplomats to turn over a Soviet soldier who has been there since Thursday, Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''Even as the boat is leaking water, what makes it to port will be the biggest tax-reform bill in 40 years.''

title: STAGE: MIME 'DRACULA'
description: TRANSYLVANIAN

title: LESLIE A. SAUNDERS TO WED KARL FREDERICK HUEGLIN 3D
description: Mr. and Mrs. John David Saunders of Plandome, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Leslie Anne Saunders, to Karl Frederick Hueglin 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Hueglin, also of Plandome. The wedding is planned for Dec. 28.

title: SECURER PRISONS PROMISED IN ENFIELD
description: IN the wake of concern in Enfield over escapes from the state prison in the town, the State Correction Commissioner, Raymond M. Lopes, said he expected improved security to allay fears.

title: THE BOUNTIFUL BALLOT
description: Only seven times in the past 50 years has Congress passed a controversial question down to the states in the form of a proposed Constitutional amendment, but the states are increasingly passing various questions and propositions down to their voters. On Tuesday, 53 such issues will be on the ballot for resolution in nine states and the District of Columbia; that compares with 50 ballot propositions in 1983 and 48 in 1981, comparable off-year elections.

title: NEWARK: AILING CITY ON THE MEND
description: A NEW state map distributed by the Department of Commerce and Economic Development last month shows a series of concentric circles spreading out from Newark, emphasizing its status as northern New Jersey's transportation hub.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Beautiful Science In ''Sympathetic Vibrations: Reflections on Physics as a Way of Life,'' (Bantam), K. C. Cole describes the esthetic dimension in modern science.

title: OSSING MODULARS
description: Until recently, most of the modular housing built in the metropolitian area has been in subsidized low- and middle-income developments. But now this form of construction is gaining favor with developers of upscale condominium projects as well.

title: Ardsley Rallies
description: The halfback C. J. Russo rolled up 200 yards on the ground to lead Ardsley to a come-from-behind, 29-26 victory over Valhalla yesterday. The rally came after Valhalla jumped out to a commanding 26-7 lead early in the second half.

title: POLICE UNITS AROUND THE STATE INCREASING USE OF VIDEOTAPE
description: A VIDEOTAPE of a drunken-driving suspect that Chief Ralph M. Scott of the New Canaan Police Department especially remembers involved a man who pretended to faint in the booking room. He did not know that a videotape camera was rolling, Chief Scott recalled.

title: SUNSET PARK
description: THE Sunset Park section of Brooklyn is about five years into a revival propelled by the availability of relatively affordable housing. But people who drive quickly through the neighborhood may miss its new vitality.

title: GURGLE, GURGLE
description: President Reagan may have set a record for groaners in a recent speech at Procter & Gamble's Ivorydale Soap plant in St. Bernard, Ohio.

title: FIRST-RATE DEBUT
description: Because he looked like maybe the second-best goalie in the N.C.A.A. tournament last spring, Daren Puppa was not selected by the Buffalo Sabres until the fourth round, the 74th pick, of the N.H.L. draft. But on Friday night, the 20-year-old Puppa made up for the slight with a very auspicious debut.

title:
NUMISMATICS;

A HIGH POWERED AUCTION
description: A rare 1927-D Saint-Gaudens double eagle or $20 gold piece provided a fitting centerpiece at Stack's of New York golden anniversary auction late last month. It was hammered down for $250,000 plus the 10 percent buyer's fee (charged on every item) which made the total $275,000.

title: CHANGE IS AN ISSUE IN VERNON ELECTION
description: URBAN problems and political strife appear remote from this 68-square-mile Sussex County township of lakes, mountains and valleys.

title: CHIMNEY SWEEP DEMAND IS REACHING A PEAK
description: FOR the next several weeks, as falling temperatures and shortening days remind homeowners that winter is fast approaching, New Jersey's 300 or so chimney sweeps will be hard put to keep up with the demand for their services.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM;

AND WHY THE DEFICIT MUST BE SLASHED
description: IT IS by now a familiar refrain that we need to cut the Federal budget deficit drastically. But the familiarity of the plea should not be allowed to diminish its force. It is long past time for President Reagan to lead the country in a rally against deficits.

title: THE FINE ART OF DIRECTING THE MET MUSEUM
description: IN AN IMPECCABLY TAILORED gray plaid business suit, Guy-Philippe Lannes de Montebello, to give his full aristocratic name at the outset, receives a visitor in his sunny, spacious office overlooking Fifth Avenue at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. As director of the Met, he is entitled to one of the roomier offices off a dim tunnel-like corridor on the mezzanine floor -the museum's executive row. The visitor makes the mistake of sitting in a red leather designer's chair in front of the large desk, but with a broad gesture, de Montebello beckons him instead to an elegant English-made armchair in the French style, at the side. ''Come over to my turf,'' he says. The leather chair, he continues, is a ''terrible'' place to sit. ''It looks as if you were applying for a job.''

title: NASSAU RACE: THREE ISSUES DOMINATE
description: TO some voters, the race for Nassau County Executive is more like a referendum on the Long Island Lighting Company, the Shoreham nuclear power plant and the kickback trial involving payments to the Republican Party than a contest among four candidates.

title: MARCOS INSTIST HE AND HIS REGIME ARE STRONG
description: Is the Philippines heading for civil war under an unpopular leader whose health is so bad that he may not live two more years? The United States appears to believe so and is deeply worried about the effects on its strategic interests in the Far East.

title: 5 in Ohio Family Slain; Police Charge Suspect
description: A woman, her daughter and three young grandchildren were beaten and shot to death in a Dayton home Friday, the authorities said, and the police today charged a man who lives at the address with murder.

title: INSIDE THE PHILIPPINE INSURGENCY
description: IT WAS ABOUT 6:30 IN THE MORNING WHEN THE shooting started. On a jungle ridge dotted with coconut palms, more than 50 members of the New People's Army, the Communist rebels in the Philippines, were getting ready for breakfast at a makeshift camp in Sorsogon Province, some 240 miles southeast of Manila (map, page 42). They had finished a half-hour of calisthenics and drills, and the morning meal, wild cabbage stewed in coconut milk, and rice, was cooking. Here and there, the young guerrillas - an army without uniforms, wearing sneakers or barefoot - were attending to chores, cleaning weapons, drying laundry and washing in a nearby stream.

title: 21 MEXICAN POLICE REPORTED SLAIN IN AMBUSH
description: Drug traffickers in remote southern Mexico ambushed and killed 21 policemen who had found a marijuana cache Friday, torturing some of the officers before shooting them dead, Mexican officials said tonight.

title: THE VIBRANCY OF SMITHTOWN
description: In response to ''Smithtown Is Dying'' by Anne Fauvell, I'd say the town is changing, not dying, for better as well as for worse. It is not the ''Small Town, U.S.A.'' of 20 or more years ago, and it never will be again.

title: HERMES SCARFS: JUST COUNT 'EM
description: THE Hermes scarf - bold, colorful, luxurious, ebullient - is something of a fashion banner. And as such it is usually worn rather proudly, right out there where it can't be missed.

title: BETHPAGE TOPPLES GARDEN CITY, GAINS FIRST PLACELONG ISLAND
description: Nassau's Conference II now has just one undefeated team: Bethpage. In the final minutes yesterday, the Golden Eagles completed a pass that broke a scoreless tie, beat Garden City (5-1) and gave them sole possession of first place.

title: SIDEWAYS TO THE SUMMIT
description: What the Reagan Administration describes as its ''new and far-reaching'' arms proposal will strike a neutral observer as neither. It builds on a Soviet proposal for a 50 percent reduction in nuclear arsenals, but mainly by reshuffling previous American offers. On available evidence, it yields not an inch to Soviet objections to ''Star Wars,'' the space-based defensive system President Reagan wants. So with their Geneva meeting less than three weeks away, Ronald Reagan and Mikhail Gorbachev are still heading sideways to the summit.

title: MUSIC CANTICUM NOVUM
description: THE Canticum Novum Singers opened their season Friday night at St. Peter's Church with a well-conceived program of French music. It was, in fact, better conceived than executed, but still made a sensuous, thought-provoking package.

title: WHY ART THIEVES WANT 'UNSELLABLE' MASTERPIECES
description: IF history is any indication, the theft of great art is a crime that sometimes pays.

title: 2 FOUNDATIONS JOIN TO HELP REVITALIZE DENVER
description: The Ford Foundation of New York and the Piton Foundation of Denver have formed a multimillion-dollar collaboration to revitalize deteriorating neighborhoods in Denver.

title: ST. FRANCIS PREP LINBACKER FULFILLS A FAMILY TRADITION
description: IT is a familiar sight: the proud father standing on the sidelines with his camera poised to record his son's athletic exploits. This scene has been repeated every Sunday for 12 years on the St. John's University football field, home of St. Francis Prep, where Bill Pickel Sr. has recorded the success of his four football-playing sons: Bill Jr., George, Jim and Chris, the youngest of the Pickel clan.

title: HAMILTON TOPS ST. LAWRENCE
description: Seamus Crotty ran for 134 yards and two touchdowns today and threw for 108 yards to lead Hamilton to a 24-6 victory over St. Lawrence. Crotty scored on runs of 40 yards and 1 yard to give Hamilton (6-1) a 12-0 lead at halftime. Jim Korfonda, who gained 74 yards on 19 carries, scored in the third quarter on a 2-yard run.

title: JENNIFER A. DUKE BECOMES THE BRIDE OF ALEXANDER W. RUTHERFURD, BROKER
description: At St. Thomas More Roman Catholic Church in New York yesterday Jennifer Anne Duke, a daughter of Richard Otis Duke of Sylvania, Ohio, and the late Pauline Eaton Duke, became the bride of Alexander Whelan Rutherfurd, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Guy Gerard Rutherfurd of New York and Allamuchy, N.J. Msgr. James C. Wilders performed the ceremony.

title: TEXAS OIL ADDS ENERGY TO U.S. STEEL
description: U.S. Steel's plan to buy Texas Oil and Gas in a stock deal worth $3.6 billion will push the huge industrial company further from steel. U.S. Steel, like the other steelmakers, has lost billions on steel operations as the industry has slumped in the face of the high dollar and foreign competition. But while other steelmakers have coped by merging, selling out or selling stakes to the Japanese, U.S. Steel has moved into energy. Texas Oil, while hurt by a falloff in natural gas, is still one of the best performers in energy. In fact, analysts were a bit puzzled at the low price - about $17 a share. Meanwhile, U.S. Steel said its net income dropped to $100 million in the third quarter.

title: KEEP CRIME INSURANCE ALIVE
description: Though its oratory occasionally acknowledges the needs of cities, the Reagan Administration has no urban policy. Now it wants to eliminate Federal crime insurance, which helps stabilize neighborhoods plagued by crime. Only quick Congressional action can save this modest, worthwhile program.

title: CLIPPER COACH STILL DREAMING
description: Don Chaney still daydreams. He can't help it, really, nor should he be blamed.

title: Wallace Polyp Found Benign
description: Gov. George C. Wallace was informed by doctors Friday that a polyp removed from his colon was benign. The polyp was removed Thursday at Jackson Hospital here as part of a colonic examination. Mr. Wallace, who is 66 years old, plans to take further medical tests to ''determine the status of his health prior to making any decision about seeking re-election,'' said Rosemary Junkins, an aide to the Governor.

title:
ANTIQUES;

LATE-BLOOMING FOLK ARTISTS
description: AS SCHOLARLY fields of inquiry have broadened, the concept of what constitutes collectible folk art from our own century also has expanded.

title: MCLAIN CAPTURES JUMP EVENT
description: Over a grueling course that eliminated 28 of 36 starters in the first round, Leslie Burr-Lenehan of Westport, Conn., rode McLain to victory last night in the $35,000 Mercedes Grand Prix of New York, the most prestigious individual event for jumpers at the National Horse Show, before a crowd of 12,130 in Madison Square Garden.

title:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;

IMAGES OF A VIOLENT SPIRIT
description: Yukio Mishima, the celebrated Japanese author, is remembered as much for his dramatic suicide in 1970 at the age of 45 as for his many books. Throughout his life, Mishima made a fetish of swords, blood and death, and ''Narakei: Ordeal by Roses, Photographs of Yukio Mishima'' (Aperture, $35) seems also to anticipate his final act.

title: SPOTLIGHT SHIFTS TO ASSEMBLY IN JERSEY
description: WITH Governor Kean expected to win a lopsided victory in Tuesday's New Jersey gubernatorial election, Republican and Democratic politicians have been shifting their attention to the State Assembly elections, where Republicans are hoping to win a majority for the first time in 12 years.

title: LOIS PRAGEN ENGAGED TO A.E. ROSENZWEIG
description: Arthur Pragen of Miami and Helen Ullman of Massapequa, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lois Pragen, to Andrew Evan Rosenzweig, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Leonard Rosenzweig of Freeport, L.I.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: Milestones 2: The Music and Times of Miles Davis Since 1960. By Jack Chambers. (Beech Tree/Morrow, $17.95.) The second and final volume of Jack Chambers's comprehensive critical bioraphy of the charismatic jazz trumpeter Miles Davis shares all of the virtues and flaws of the first. (Beach Tree/Morrow has just published a new hard-cover edition of ''Milestones 1,'' which appeared in 1983.) ''Milestones 2'' picks up Mr. Davis's career in 1960 and is an indispensable turntable companion. It encompases the breakup of Mr. Davis's paradigmatic quintet with John Coltrane and the formation of an equally influential unit with Wayne Shorter, Herbit Hancock, Ron Carter and Tony Williams; Mr. Davis's uneasy truce with free-form jazz and his flirtation with rock and funk; his temporary retirement in 1975, and his far-from-triumphant comeback in 1981. Mr. Chambers does a commendable job of relating Mr. Davis's music to larger jazz trends. He also succeeds in conveying the forces at work in Mr. Davis's private life - his battle against the debilitating side effects of sickle-cell anemia, his fourth marriage, to the actress Cicely Tyson, and his frequent brushes with the law and with racial prejudice real and imagined. As was true of the earlier volume, there is some vital spark missing from ''Milestones 2.'' Mr. Chamberws keeps his distance from his subject - perhaps the ideal stance for a critic but not for a biographer. Denied access to Mr. Davis, who is notoriosly unfriendly to those who would write about him, and curiorusly disinclined to conduct interviews with the trumpeter's associates, Mr. Chambers has relied too heavily on secondary sources.

title: COMEDY BY HART SPARKLES
description: ON Oct. 25, the New Jersey Shakespeare Festival could not have been more festive - and Shakespeare had nothing to do with it.

title: LAY OF THE LAND
description: To the Editor: I was particularly pleased to learn that I am not the only air traveler who requests a window seat - not over the wing - and takes great pleasure in peering out at the many surprisingly interesting things to be seen below. A little knowledge of history, geography or geology is helpful but not essential to enjoyment of this pursuit.

title: RECORDS SHOW U.S. SUSPECTED RADICAL TIES IN GROUP AIDING ILLEGAL ALIENS
description: The Government has long said that its prosecution of people involved in the movement to help Central Americans enter the United States is nothing more than a simple case of alien smuggling. But court documents indicate that some investigators originally suspected the movement had Marxist leanings and was possibly transporting terrorists.

title: LAY OF THE LAND
description: To the Editor: Walter Sullivan's article ''Getting the Lay of the Land From the Air'' (Travel, Sept. 29) is typical of his superb combination of scientific observation and poetic writing.

title: A FRIEND FROM CHINA FINDS SIMPLE PLEASURE
description: I REMEMBER thinking, as I stood on the platform waiting for my Chinese guest, that there wasn't a single bench to sit on in the whole station, and I was tired. I hadn't stopped rushing for hours, what with dusting my entire collection of Chinese spoons and rice bowls, making up the guest bed, hiding the grandchild's toys and preparing to act nonchalant once Hu Shiguang arrived. I had it all worked out to join our mutual Chinese friends for dinner out in our own special restaurant, so I wouldn't have to spend hours in the kitchen. My aim was to return his hospitality in Beijing, and give him a day in the countryside at peace with the world.

title: The Vibrancy Of Smithtown
description: I normally enjoy your Opinion Page, but I must protest Anne Fauvell's ''Smithtown Is Dying'' [Sept. 29] . It is a totally untrue portrait of a wonderful, vibrant town.

title: ENGLAND'S GLORY: THE COUNTRY HOUSE
description: In the matter of the exhibition called ''The Treasure Houses of Britain,'' which opens to the public today at the National Gallery of Art in Washington, I have a confession to make. I did not believe that it could possibly be as good as it is.

title: IN U.S., ILLEGAL ARREST IS NO BAR TO A CONVICTION
description: To the Editor:

title: KEY POSTS ON THE LINE IN ELECTION
description: VIRTUALLY every elective town and county post in Nassau and Suffolk Counties will be on the line on Tuesday - the most important local elections in years.

title: BELLY DANCING
description: Morocco, Elena, Aziz, Sergio, Thalia, Phaedra, Ameena-Tara and even Ma'rina of Connecticut -belly dancers are no longer confined to Greek and Turkish nightclubs.

title: WHITE MOUNTAINS
description: New Hampshire is very much a state of contrasts. The burgeoning growth in the southern tier evaporates just 90 minutes north of the Massachusetts border. First come the sparkling lakes and then the White Mountains, high, jutting, snow-covered peaks, glistening in solitude and sharp-edged against the sky. Names like Lost River, Kancamagus, the Flume, Pemigewasset and the Old Man of the Mountains describe rock formations, roaring rivers and individual spires. There are also deep, wide, green national forests and state parks covering 12,000 square miles of the state's North Country, providing a view that countless artists have tried to capture.

title: HOPES STILL DIM FOR A CONFERENCE OF NINE SCHOOLSIN THE
description: THE Northeast, where intercollegiate football began and first flourished, remains the only region in the nation without a major football league. Advocates of such a conference, a concept at least three decades old, contend that the pattern of the current season demonstrates the need for a league, but there is no visible movement now in organizing one.

title: RECENT RELEASES
description: Pauline at the Beach Amanda Langlet, Arielle Dombasle, Pascal Gregory, Feodor Atkine; directed by Eric Rohmer, 1983 Media Home Entertainment 94 minutes. $59.95 The next best thing to a day at the seashore is this effervescent, sunlit comedy of romantic manners about several intensely self-absorbed, articulate adults and one pretty, clear-eyed teen-ager during a late-summer holiday on the Normandy coast.

title: TENANTS SEEK MORE HEARINGS ON TRUMP'S EVICTION EFFORTS
description: Tenants Donald Trump is seeking to evict from a building on Central Park South have asked for a resumption of state hearings to resolve the bitter dispute, according to their attorney.

title: UP FROM DISENCHANTMENT
description: HEALING THE WOUNDS: A Physician Looks at His Work. By David Hilfiker. 209pp New York: Pantheon Books, $14.95.

title: WEAK OPENINGS AREN'T ALWAYS CONFUSING
