description: The continuing controversy about weird bidding systems was well to the fore during the past two weeks of world championship play in Sao Paulo. Officials argued about whether such methods should be allowed and players argued about whether they are technically sound.

title: QUICK COUNT
description: Mike Tyson, the 19-year-old heavyweight who has specialized in the quick knockout since he turned professional in March, did it again Friday night in a scheduled 8-rounder in Latham, N. Y. This time Tyson dispatched Sterling Benjamin after only 54 seconds of the first round.

title: INTO THE RIFT VALLEY IN PURSUIT OF THE ORIGINS OF MAN
description: ''At what stage of development did the human mind become human?'' the paleontologist Richard Leakey asked last week, posing just one of the fundamental questions that his lifework is devoted to fathoming. And it is one of the many questions raised and addressed in ''Cradle of Mankind,'' a documentary that will have its American television premiere on Nickelodeon today at 5:15 P.M., an entry in the National Geographic ''Explorer'' series.

title: CONCERT: VIENNA ENSEMBLE
description: THE Vienna Philharmonic is one of the few orchestras in the world that has been conscious of preserving a sound distinct unto itself; it has not jumped into the international melting pot. In particular, a brass and woodwind sound of the mellowest smoothness has been cultivated, in some cases by the retention of instrument makes that have become obsolete elsewhere.

title: BOOKSHELF
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: BURROUGHS DRAFTING CONTINGENCY PLAN TO LEAVE SOUTH AFRICA
description: The Burroughs Corporation, the third largest American computer company, has ordered contigency plans drawn up to pull out of South Africa if the conflict over apartheid worsens, a company spokesman said today.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: A Bloody Scandal. By George Milner. (St. Martin's, $11.95) The scandal of George Milner's novel involves murder and greed, and the author successfully mixes these sinister elements with commensurate portions of whimsy and satire.

title: HARPSICHORD RECITALS AT AN INN IN NORFOLK
description: IT is ''a novel partnership,'' said Henry Tremblay of the Norfolk Early Music Society, which he and his wife, Diane, have formed with their Maple Street neighbors, Carl and Marilee Dudash.

title: RECENT LIST
description: Dumont$145,000 151 Grant Avenue 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 30-year-old split-level; new roof, modern kitchen, 1-car garage; taxes $3,028. Livingston$125,000 17 Filmore Avenue 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 35-year-old split-level; basement rec room with bar, 2-year-old ktichen; taxes $2,171.

title: PENN STATE WINS TO STAY UNBEATEN
description: The tale of two seasons, those of Boston College and Penn State, was summed up in one play today: the game-winning play. The Boston College quarterback Shawn Halloran watched as one of his fourth-quarter passes was tipped into the lap of Mike Russo, a Penn State tackle. Russo then ran 21 yards for the touchdown that lifted the Nittany Lions to a 16-12 victory.

title: Chekhov and Hare On Marriage
description: In his article ''David Hare: Playwright as Provocateur'' (Sept. 29), Mel Gussow credits the playwright, as well he might, with a line from Mr. Hare's screenplay for ''Wetherby'': ''If you fear loneliness, never marry.''

title: CONSUMER PROTECTION FOR UNDERGRADUATES
description: Shortly after becoming Secretary of Education in February, William J. Bennett accused many American colleges of ''ripping off'' their students by maintaining poor academic standards. Last week, he said the Federal Government could help do something about it.

title: BATH
description: To the Editor: Rarely am I moved to write a letter about a difference of opinion about a hotel, but I was flabbergasted at the review of the Royal Crescent Hotel in ''A B C's of Shopping and Staying in Bath.''

title: AT SEA WITH 'THE SILENT SERVICE'
description: AS THE SLEEK, BLACK NUCLEAR-POWERED SUBMA-rine City of Corpus Christi passes the 100-fathom line off Montauk Point, the tiny bridge on the ship's tower is cleared. The officer of the deck, Lieut. Comdr. Joseph A. Walsh, secures the hatch and goes below to make his final checks. Satisfied, he asks Capt. Frank L. (Skip) Bowman for permission to take the ship down, then orders ''dive, dive.'' The klaxon sounds twice and the submarine slips beneath the sea.

title: RUSSIANS IN AFGHANISTAN: CHANGES IN TACTICS
description: The continued, elusive resistance of the rebels in Afghanistan, mounting casualties and poor performance by conscripts are forcing the Soviet Union to review and revise its tactics and command system in Afghanistan, according to United States and British intelligence sources familiar with the war.

title:
GARDENING;

THE AUTUMN APPEAL OF THE PEPPERIDGE
description: WITH the memory of autumn foliage is still fresh in our minds, this is a good time to discuss one of the best trees for color - the Nyssa sylvatica, variously called pepperidge, black gum, sour gum or tupelo.

title: FEE- SIMPLE TOWN HOUSES GAIN IN APPEAL
description: OVER the last decade, condominiums have been recognized by thousands in New Jersey as attractive alternatives to traditional, single-family detached houses. They have also shed their tacky image as cheap alternatives to ranches and colonials - glorified apartments for people who cannot afford a real house.

title:
GARDENING;

THE AUTUMN APPEAL OF THE PEPPERIDGE
description: WITH the memory of autumn foliage is still fresh in our minds, this is a good time to discuss one of the best trees for color - the Nyssa sylvatica, variously called pepperidge, black gum, sour gum or tupelo.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN PARAPSYCHOLOGY
description: WHILE he was researching his soon-to-be-published book, ''The Intuitive Manager: Profiting From the Eureka Factor,'' Roy Rowan says he heard an interesting tale from the late H. L. Hunt's son, Herbert. Herbert Hunt told Mr. Rowan that right before his father started a series of major oil explorations, he consulted psychic Jeane Dixon. ''She warned him off certain spots, particularly the Santa Barbara Channel where subsequently there was a big oil spill,'' Mr. Rowan recalled.

title: ALARM LAW NEAR IN 5 VILLAGES
description: A UNIFORM ordinance on the use of burglar alarms is expected to be adopted by the five villages covered by the Old Brookville Police Department in an effort to ease the problem of false alarms.

title: TOPICS
description: I ADMIT it - I am a compulsively obsessive buyer running amok, and I need an antidote for the poison consuming me and my money. This land of plenty is too much for someone earning a moderate salary. The glut of goods and goodies overwhelms me.

title: VERRAZANO STREET
description: To the Editor:

title: Home Design Preview;   Tableware Props That Set the Stage
description: ARRANG-ing a table imaginatively is akin to creating a miniature stage set - the magic lies in its ephemeral quality, the ability to capture one mood for one occasion. This is not to say that table designs don't endure. Grandmother's lace runners and Chantilly silver are coveted for generations. But as John Loring, senior vice president and design director of Tiffany & Co., points out, ''Tables, like stage sets, need a wardrobe of props from different periods and of different styles.''

title: FLORIDA VICTORIOUS
description: Florida's Kerwin Bell threw his second touchdown pass of the game to Ray McDonald with 7 minutes 18 seconds left in the fourth quarter to give the undefeated Gators a 14-10 victory today over Auburn, which was without Bo Jackson for much of the second half.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: GUATEMALA RULERS RENEW VOW ON TODAY'S VOTING
description: Guatemalan military leaders this week repeated their pledge to allow Guatemala's new civilian government, which is to be elected Sunday, to rule freely.

title: A MEAN SPECIES, EVEN BACK IN THE ICE AGE
description: To the Editor:

title: COLGATE TROUNCES COLUMBIA, 55-11
description: Colgate's Barry Chubb returned the opening kickoff for a school-record 100 yards and a touchdown, and the Red Raiders went on to pound Columbia, 55-11, today.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: The Fraternity of the Stone. By David Morrell. (Marek/St. Martin's, $16.95.)In his early thrillers like the post-Vietnam ''First Blood,'' David Morrell demonstrated a talent for taut, violent narrative.

title: MUSIC: MARTIN BEST, TENOR
description: MARTIN BEST continued the ancient tradition of the troubador Thursday night with a poorly attended but pleasant evening of singing and playing at the Metropolitan Museum.

title: REAGAN'S OFFER ON MOBILE MISSILE BAN IS ASSAILED
description: The Reagan Administration's decision to ask at the Geneva arms talks that a ban on mobile missiles be sought has provoked an outcry from Congressional critics.

title: MONTCLAIR SHUTS OUT PATERSON E.
description: Undefeated Montclair, helped by two turnovers, won its sixth game yesterday, a 20-0 shutout of Paterson Eastside at Foley Field in Bloomfield.

title: Andrea L. Florey Weds Samuel C. Bradford 2d
description: Andrea Louise Florey and Samuel Chandler Bradford 2d were married yesterday at the First Congregational Church in Cheshire, Conn., by the Rev. Scott Sanders.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: Megatraumas: America at the Year 2000. By Richard D. Lamm. (Houghton Mifflin, $16.95.)''The United States is a nation in liquidation,'' writes Richard Lamm, Governor of Colorado, at the outset of this apocalypitc view of the country's future.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, NOVEMBER 3, 1985
description: International

title: APPLYING THE COLOR, AFTER THE FACT
description: COLOR doesn't always have to be in the film. Sometimes, it can be applied after the picture is taken.

title: GREECE'S STUBBORN ISLAND FORTRESS
description: The medieval, stone-built town of Monemvasia, set on a fortified, steep rock, is frequently called the Gibraltar of Greece. Indeed, it bears a striking geographical resemblance to the great fortress that guards the southern tip of the Iberian peninsula. But Monemvasia, unlike Gibraltar, has a rich and significant political and cultural history as a city of merchants, fishermen, wine growers, artists and military architects, soldiers, bickering aristocrats, warlike priests, pirates, shipbuilders and rival dynasties.

title: VIRGINIA AND MARYLAND WINEMAKING COMES OF AGE
description: When Archie M. Smith 3d left Oxford University, where he had taught philosophy for eight years, to become a winemaker in this town about an hour's drive from Washington, he had little experience in viticulture and perhaps less reason to expect success.

title: CABARET: JONATHAN SCHWARTZ
description: JONATHAN SCHWARTZ is one of a handful of cabaret singers who is able to verbalize what is special about a popular song and then put his ideas into musical action. Mr. Schwartz, who is appearing at Michael's Pub (211 East 55th Street) through Nov. 30, is also a superb raconteur whose anecdotes about show-business history have the refinement of carefully polished bons mots. The singer's analytical skills stand him in especially good stead because they help him to channel a passionate enthusiasm for the pre-rock American song tradition that might otherwise go unbridled.

title: No Headline
description: Representatives of a local television station's news operation may stand within 15 feet of polling places to survey people who vote Tuesday, Federal District Judge Alcee L. Hastings ruled Friday.

title: DISPUTE ROILS GEORGICA POND
description: THE rich and famous live around East Hampton's Georgica Pond. Local baymen, however, make a living off it. Almost since the time the two factions first encountered each other at the bucolic pond, they have waged intermittent war over who will control it.

title: POLE SAYS CITIZENS' COMMUNIST UPBRINGING SLOWS CHANGES
description: A Polish Government spokesman says public attitudes resulting from Communist upbringing are thwarting efforts to change the economy.

title: HOPING FOR A WINNER
description: Park Ranger Walter E. McDowney is out in Lake Geneva, Wis., today carrying the colors of Washington's National Aquatic Gardens and the eastern National Capital Parks into the finals of the competition for the Freeman Tilden Award. Named for the writer and naturalist who has been called the father of the national park system, the award goes each year to the employee who has most successfully interpreted the heritage of those parks to the public.

title: 7 BALLOT QUESTIONS FACING THE VOTERS ON ELECTION DAY IN JERSEY
description: A longstanding dispute between the New Jersey Legislature and the Governor's office will finally be decided by the voters.

title: TO THE DEFENSE OF SWANS ON CAPE
description: ROBERT A. Maxim says he disarmed two men he saw shooting swans because ''creatures have as much value and place in this earth as we do.''

title: BROOKLYN'S BORSCHT BELT
description: Clubs along the busy strip of Brighton Beach Avenue, a beacon for newcomers from the Soviet Union, tend to offer horas and ballads and an occasional Top 40 song with lyrics in Russian.

title: WENDY GERBER WEDS JOSEPH FRIEDMAN
description: Wendy Beth Gerber, a daughter of Claire Gerber Gould of Great Neck, L.I., and Harold Gerber of Newport Beach, Calif., was married last night to Joseph Friedman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Friedman of Pearl River, N.Y. Rabbi M. Asher Murciano performed the ceremony at the St. Regis-Sheraton Hotel in New York.

title: SETTING HER SIGHTS ON HERSELF
description: MIRIAM IN HER FORTIES, By Alan Lelchuk. 367pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $17.95.

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: CONNECTICUT JAZZ (SILENT) Four musicians from Boston have developed an unusual specialty. They improvise jazz accompaniments to silent film classics.

title: Postings;   B. & B. IN YORKVILLE
description: For most travelers, the bed-and-breakfast inn brings to mind quaint lodges in the English countryside or along the back roads of New England.

title: SHULTZ LEAVES U.S. FOR SOVIET TALKS
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz left Washington today on the first leg of a mission to Moscow to try to prepare understandings and agreements for announcement when President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev meet this month in Geneva.

title: THE TOLLS HAVE LEFT THE ROAD BUT NOT THE MIND
description: I WAS caught with just nine short of a full roll. Two friends had also just ripped open packs of the Connecticut Turnpike tokens a week before. How many tollbooth tokens do you still have sliding around on the floor under the seat of your car, clunking in the glove compartment at each turn or caroming off the windshield from the dashboard?

title: How to Get the Women's Movement Moving Again
description: THIS IS ADDRESSED TO ANY WOMAN who has ever said ''we'' about the women's movement, including those who say, ''I'm not a feminist, but. . . .'' And it's addressed to quite a few men. It's a personal message, not at all objective, and it's in response to those who think our modern women's movement is over - either because it is defeated and a failure, or because it has triumphed, its work done, its mission accomplished. After all, any daughter can now dream of being an astronaut, after Sally Ride, or running for President, after Geraldine Ferraro.

title: PARMESAN: TAKE CARE IN SELECTING IT AND ENJOY ITS USEFULNESS
description: IF I were allowed only one cheese, it would probably be Parmesan. This would certainly not be the choice of people who know this cheese only in grated form. But genuine aged Parmesan, sold in large wheels with the words ''Parmigiano-Reggiano'' etched on the rind, is one of the world's great cheeses. It is superb eaten on its own, accompanied by a glass of chilled champagne or a good red wine. It is excellent for cooking because it doesn't melt or turn to glue like some cheeses. It is also low in fat and high in protein.

title: VAL GARDENA: A CHALET FOR SIX
description: By noon of our first day cruising the packed powder of the Seceda run above Ortisei in northeastern Italy, we knew that we had made the right choice. And a pasta lunch on the sun-drenched terrace at the top of the mountain, overlooking the vast ski bowl that includes the Sella, Sasso Lungo and Ciampinoi ski areas, was the perfect antidote to ski legs still rubbery from jet lag.

title: SEWAGE ISSUE COULD HAUNT COAST POLITICIANS
description: Thirty years ago Aldous Huxley wrote a celebrated essay, ''Hyperion to a Satyr,'' about the deficiencies in Los Angeles's huge main sewage facility. A generation later the troubles not only persist but have also grown into political issues.

title: MUSEUM HOPES FOR CAROUSEL
description: AFTER 14 years of lying dormant, 51 horses, dogs, cats, goats and other animals are going to be brought back to life again if Nassau County's plans materialize.

title: Who Owns LOR?
description: To the Editor Your article ''Moving in on Money Management'' (Oct. 13) is in error with respect to the transaction between First Interstate Bancorp and Leland O'Brien Rubinstein Associates Inc. (LOR).

title: MAYOR'S RECORD IN DETROIT PIVOTAL IN ELECTION
description: Coleman A. Young has been Mayor of this city for almost 12 years, longer than anyone else to hold the office. And he is strongly favored to win another four-year term in Tuesday's election.

title: ANGRY DEMOCRATS EXAMINE NOMINEE 6 HOURS
description: Strom Thurmond of South Carolina, chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, has denounced a day-long interrogation of a Reagan Administration nominee for a Federal judgeship as a tiresome recital of ''the puniest, most nit-picking charges'' by liberal Democrats he had heard in three decades in Congress.

title: SLAP ON THE WRIST FOR BASEBALL
description: Last Tuesday in Pittsburgh, in sentencing Robert W. McCue to 10 years in prison for selling cocaine to baseball players, United States District Judge Maurice Cohill Jr. sharply criticized management officials of major-league teams, saying their ''blindness'' to the drug problem had done incalculable damage to the game. Following are his remarks to McCue: YOU have violated the law and must be punished, for that is our way of justice. It is never easy for a judge to sentence anyone. We can only hope that the action by this court will impress upon you, and others similarly situated, the seriousness of your law violations. The sale of drugs is an egregious offense against your fellow man and society and merits a sentence commensurate with the crime.

title: BABYLON PROPOSAL ASSAILED
description: A PROPOSAL to build an $82 million plant to burn garbage in the Town of Babylon has stirred concern among many local residents as well as outsiders.

title: PROGRAM IN MADISON ON HOBBY OF DOLLS
description: ANYONE who owned a Barbie doll in 1959 has probably heard the news: Original Barbie's are selling for as much as $1,200 among doll collectors.

title: Topics;   ADVERTISIN ADIVISE
description: Prime-Time Message The television networks recently rejected a public-service spot designed to tell young viewers something about sexual responsibility. The ad, prepared by the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists, shows three young women talking about their plans for the future, and ends with the advice that nothing changes one's prospects faster than unintended pregnancy. Then it gives a number to call for an informational booklet.

title: JESSE HELMS IS A BIT ANNOYED
description: Peking is a bit annoyed with the Reagan Administration lately. The Administration, in turn, is more than a bit annoyed with Senator Jesse Helms, who isn't all that happy about the Administration or, for that matter, about China.

title: ISLANDERS AVENGE LOSS TO CAPITALS, 5-3
description: The formula for this 5-3 Islander victory tonight was simple. All it required of each Islander was a short memory, a mind's eye glimpse of the 5-3 defeat by the Washington Capitals Friday night.

title: BONDS FOR JOBS SUPPORTED ON L.I.
description: SUPPORTERS of a statewide proposition that could have a major impact on Long Island fear that it might be defeated on Tuesday's ballot because the public knows little about it.

title: WHEN SOVIET JOUIRNALISTS APPEAR ON AMERICAN TV
description: What is a Soviet journalist, and is he a journalist at all? It is not an academic question.

title: THE WINNINGEST LITTLE HIGH SCHOOL
description: IF you go into just about any tavern in Dobbs Ferry or Hastings-on-Hudson this week you are likely to hear local history buffs holding forth on a cherished and time-worn topic - the upcoming football game between the towns' high school football teams.

title: THE BRASS FALL TO BICKERING OVER DEALS WITH SPIES
description: Reflecting perhaps his service's frustration and embarrassment -and maybe sensing the political gain to be wrung out of spy bashing -Navy Secretary John F. Lehman Jr. aimed a broadside at the Justice Department last week, complaining that its plea bargain with John A. Walker Jr. had been a bad deal for the Government.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: ALTHOUGH many of the hazardous wastes found in water supplies and abandoned landfills have been shown to pose health and ecological dangers, public reaction to these and lesser threats sometimes is called ''chemophobia'' or ''toxics hysteria.''

title: 11 FOOD OUTLETS CITED BY NEW YORK OFFICIALS
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 11 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: TOP REFORM RABBI LASHES AT CRITICS
description: Rabbi Alexander M. Schindler, leader of the Reform Jewish movement, lashed back yesterday at Orthodox Jewish leaders who have challenged the authenticity of his movement and its religious practices.

title: Rhode Island plan aids state farms
description: Doris Chace unrolled the aerial photographs on the table of the farmhouse kitchen and pointed out the buildings on the low hills as if they were the enemy in a military campaign.

title: PLAYERS' DREAMS ALIVE IN MINOR FOOTALL LEAGUE
description: AT 6 feet, 2 inches and 285 pounds, Sam Saylor of Hartford is certainly big enough to play in the National Football League.

title: NEW SEASON OPENS AT ARTS CENTER
description: ALTHOUGH much of northern Westchester is about two hours from Broadway and its acting studios, dance workshops and music centers, a group of residents has been steadily working to provide a taste of these performing arts upcounty.

title: BREAKUP WEIGHED FOR STATE AGENCY
description: IT was an idea conceived of by two aides looking to put some sparkle in Gov. John N. Dempsey's 1967 inaugural address: Bring together under one umbrella those state agencies dealing with various forms of transportation.

title: NOVEMBER SUNTANS
description: THE seagulls wheeled in apparent amazement over what had displaced them from every nook and cranny of Aqueduct on what should have been a bleak, placid early November day. Underneath were many thousands more humans than might ordinarily be found on the first Saturday in November - a mixture of rich and poor, all trying to keep warm and cash a ticket.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: ANTIQUES AUCTION A cache of antiques collected by Lewis B. (Rocky) Rockwell, of Wilton, Conn., will be sold at auction promptly at 4 P.M. Saturday in the Pleasant Valley Auction Hall in Pleasant Valley, N.Y. Gathered over a 40-year period when Mr. Rockwell was a well-known dealer with the firm of Ginsberg & Levy in Manhattan, the collection specializes in Federal and early Empire furniture and accessories, and some fine 18th-century pieces.

title: ART
description: Visitors to Amsterdam go in the hundreds of thousands to the Rijksmuseum, the Stedelijk Museum and the Vincent van Gogh Museum. But the Amsterdam Historical Museum is by comparison known mainly to the happy few who seek out the Historical Museum in no matter what city they are, in the knowledge that it is likely to be one of the more peaceful places in town - and stuffed, what is more, with curious and rewarding exhibits.

title: SUBWAY TUNNEL REPORT IS SENT BACK
description: Metropolitan Transportation Authority officials, under pressure from Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, said yesterday that a consultant's report that pronounced the 63d Street subway tunnel structurally sound might have been based on inadequate information.

title: SOUNDS OF BRAZIL
description: In a room decorated with quasi-African paintings and hundreds of hanging instruments - gourds, lyres, drums - a predominantly upscale, ethnically mixed crowd samples garlicky Brazilian food and international music.

title: Older Than Springsteen
description: May a female Springsteen fan of a certain age add a few observations to Anthony Giardina's article ''Competing With Bruce'' (About Men, Sept. 29)?

title: One Dead and 5 Injured In Grain Elevator Blast
description: An explosion ripped through a grain elevator here tonight, killing one man, injuring at least five others and leaving two missing, the authorities said.

title: LACK OF DONATIONS FOR AIDS REPORTED
description: Private contributions to help AIDS victims and to support research into the disease have been few and relatively modest, but New York's philanthropic community is edging toward increasing such financing, according to foundation officials and others.

title: INVESTMENT TIPS FROM TAROT CARDS
description: CHRISTIAN DIOR reportedly visited a psychic to determine the best day to show his collection and when to go on vacation. Fellow designer Diane Von Furstenberg takes a more skeptical approach to her psychic, Yolana. She does ask her business-related questions, but says, ''She has as much or as little influence as my lawyer or my mother. I'm not sure I would change my mind in respect to some things she said, but she is a point of reference.''

title: LAURIE E. OOSTING WED TO A BANKER
description: Laurie Ellen Oosting, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John W. Oosting of Alto, Mich., was married yesterday to William Ford Reighley, the son of Mr. and Mrs. H. Ward Reighley of New Canaan, Conn., and Hobe Sound, Fla. The Rev. Dr. Duncan Littlefair, a Unitarian minister, and the Rev. Bill Wittland, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Fountain Street Church in Grand Rapids, Mich.

title: THE STAGE: 'WINTER'S TALE'
description: EVEN with the help of Iago, Othello requires most of three acts to work himself up to the dramatically necessary pitch of jealousy regarding his faithful Desdemona. So pity Leontes, the ruler of Sicilia, who has only two scenes to get himself into a similar state over his faithful Hermione, despite the sensible admonitions of all his counselors. The speed with which the fit comes over him has confounded more seasoned companies than the one now doing ''The Winter's Tale'' at Symphony Space. But led by the performances of David Purdham as Leontes and Ellen Parker as both Hermione and her daughter, 16-year-old Perdita, the play gains strength as it goes.

title: FROM A CRISIS, A CRUSADE IS BORN
description: JUDY SPATZ always had all the answers. When her husband, Dr. Murray Spatz, was seeing patients and couldn't come to the phone, she answered the medical and first-aid questions of friends and relations.

title: LORI LYNN GREENBERG WED TO ROY G. RIFKIN, LAWYER
description: Lori Lynn Greenberg, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Forrest M. Greenberg of Stockton, Calif., was married yesterday to Roy G. Rifkin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene H. Rifkin of Woodmere, L.I. Rabbi David Greenberg, the bride's great-uncle, performed the ceremony at the Stephen S. Wise Temple in Los Angeles.

title: Israeli Democracy
description: To the Editor:

title: Man Carrying Bullets Found Dead of Gunshot in Times Sq.
description: A man carrying a shoulder bag of ammunition was found dead of a gunshot wound to the head in Times Square yesterday morning, the police said.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: THE World War I memorial column in Ridgewood was designed by Henry Bacon, architect of the Lincoln Memorial.

title: DOUBLE IDENTITY
description: IN a city with thousands of lawyers, it is perhaps inevitable that some will have the same name. A few will practice near each other, and maybe commute from the same borough.

title: Student Held in Shooting Of a Maine College Dean
description: A 20-year-old student at Bates College was being held today in the Androscoggin County jail on charges of shooting the college dean on Oct. 21.

title: THE HIGH COST OF FIGHTING OUT 'CONTRAS'
description: To the Editor:

title: EXCERPTS FROM DEBATE IN NASSAU EXECUTIVE RACE
description: Following are excerpts from a debate at The New York Times last week among the candidates for Nassau County Executive: Francis T. Purcell, the incumbent (Republican-Conservative), John W. Matthews (Democrat), Jack Olchin (Liberal) and Dr. Raymond J. Vuolo (Right to Life):

title: QUEBEC: ON SKIS AND ON FOOT
description: My wife, a woman of otherwise admirable accomplishments, does not ski. After we married she tried, of course, shivering inside my spare down parka and agreeing through chattering teeth that, yes, it did seem fun. Jaqueline amassed a breathtaking record as a ski school dropout at the very best resorts in the United States and Europe before abandoning the charade and announcing that she much preferred winter inside with a good book.

title: EASTERN EUROPE HOPES TO BRANCH OUT
description: The economic strains besetting Eastern Europe were evident outside the meeting rooms where Warsaw Pact leaders gathered in Sofia last month to prepare for the Gorbachev-Reagan summit Nov. 19 and 20 in Geneva. Cutbacks in Soviet oil and coal supplies had pulled most private automobiles off Sofia's broad boulevards; streetlights had been dimmed, and central heating had been shut off in homes and public buildings.

title: FILLING IN THE BLANKS
description: THE MURDER OF A SHOPPING BAG LADY, By Brian Kates. 247pp. San Diego: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $15.95.

title: A COLLEGE SPORTS COMMISSIONER: THE TIME IS NOW
description: IN looking for a way out of its present scandals involving improper payments, academic abuses and gambling, the National Collegiate Athletic Association should heed the lesson of a powerful analogy from the sport of baseball. In 1920, professional baseball faced a similar crisis of credibility. Public confidence in the sport was shattered by revelations that several players on Chicago's 1919 World Series team had taken bribes to throw the championship games.

title: REAGAN'S GOOD DEED
description: In a few weeks, the Reagan Administration will propose something good for poor people that will encourage voluntary racial integration in schools - and it will drive the liberal establishment up the wall.

title: NORTHWEST JERSEY TO GET A UHF TV STATION
description: The Federal Communications Commission has decided to permit the establishment of a UHF television station in this small Sussex County town. Thirteen companies have filed applications to be selected as the licensee.

title: Karpov Puts Off 22d Game In World Chess Title Match
description: The world chess champion, Anatoly Karpov, who is trailing his challenger, Gary Kasparov, in their title series, called his final timeout today, the official Soviet news agency Tass reported.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: TREASURES OF BRITAIN Queen Elizabeth I, Queen Victoria, Disraeli and King George VI were among those who slept at Burghley House in Stamford, Lincolnshire, England. Today, it is occupied by Lady Victoria Leatham, daughter of the Sixth Marquis of Exeter, and her family. She will give a lecture about her ancestral home after a luncheon Tuesday at the Greenwich Country Club. The event is the first to be organized by the newly formed Antiques Society of the Bruce Museum, which is open to anyone interested in the study of antiques.

title: NOT QUITE HOME IS THE SAILOR
description: FOREIGN LAND By Jonathan Raban. 352 pp. New York; Elisabeth Sifton Books/Viking. $16.95.

title: AT YALE, A SHOW OF OLD AMERICAN SOUNDS
description: ''THE YANKEE LYRE,'' a special exhibition of 40 antique American musical instruments, opens at 2 P.M. today at the Yale Collection of Musical Instruments, 15 Hillhouse Avenue on the Yale University campus in New Haven.

title: NEW YORK AGENCY URGES A BAN ON 'HAPPY HOURS'
description: New York State's Division of Alcoholism and Alcohol Abuse has recommended that ''happy hours'' be barred, alcoholic beverages be required to carry warning labels and a moratorium be imposed on new liquor licenses.

title: NEW YORKERS, ETC
description: IT'S 5 o'clock, it's raining like crazy and the wind is turning your umbrella inside out. You're willing to splurge on a taxi but, of course, there's not a free one in sight. What is in sight is an elegant private car and driver, ferrying a very dry person. Oh, to be snuggled in that car! Talk about luxury, that's it!

title: WEDDING PLANNED BY DR. ANDERSON
description: Dr. and Mrs. Gerald G. Anderson of Stonington, Conn., and Dhahran, Saudi Arabia, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Gretchen Diane Anderson, to Matthew F. Keefe, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Roger M. Keefe of Norwalk, Conn. The wedding is planned for next month.

title: CONCERTS TO HONOR AMERICAN TRADITION
description: THE national observance of American Music Week begins tomorrow, with concerts that will celebrate, in the words of President Reagan's proclamation, ''America's tradition of musical excellence.'' About 30 concert celebrations have been scheduled in Manhattan. In the county there is one program of American music specifically designed to mark the occasion; beyond that there is only Lionel Semiatin's ''Bicentenniala'' on the New Orchestra of Westchester's program Saturday at the State University of New York at Purchase and works of Leon Kirchner and George Gershwin in separate recitals next Sunday.

title: D. B. STERN WEDS NANCY JOSEPHSON
description: The marriage of Nancy Alexandra Josephson and David Bauer Stern took place last evening at the Park Avenue Synagogue in New York. Rabbi Judah Nadich performed the ceremony.

title: Miss McCance Weds Martin Huguley
description: The marriage of Suzanne Valentine McCance, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas McCance Jr. of New Haven and Fishers Island, N.Y., to Martin Creighton Huguley, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur W. Huguley 3d of Tenafly, N.J., took place yesterday. The Rev. Andrew E. Fidler performed the ceremony at Trinity Episcopal Church on the Green in New Haven.

title: G.O.P. IN WESTCHESTER STRONG DESPITE CHANGES
description: Westchester County's Democratic leaders had something to cheer about earlier this year when voter registration figures showed Democrats outnumbering Republicans, 166,000 to 161,000, for the first time in at least 50 years.

title: THE PAST IS EXPLORED BY COMPUTER
description: IT is a study in contrast - an exercise using modern-day computer science to help historians and scholars better understand the people and society of past centuries, while at the same time introducing social-sciences students to the advanced technology available to them through the use of computers.

title: MISS PILGER'S ENGLISH CLASS
description: THE SUBJECT IS SPINACH PIE.

title: JACK KEMP'S WAR CHEST GROWS
description: In his eight terms as a Congressman from suburban Buffalo, Jack F. Kemp had never held a fund-raising event outside his district. He altered his strategy last week in a big way.

title: TRANSCRIPT OF REAGAN'S RADIO ADDRESS ON ARMS
description: Following is a transcript of the radio address today by President Reagan, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: STUDENT DRUG TESTS TO BEGIN
description: A random, voluntary drug testing program, believed to be the first in the state, is to begin next week for junior and senior high school students in the Phelps-Clifton Springs School District in Ontario County.

title: Transmitters Attached To Wandering Whale
description: Scientists armed with a crossbow today successfully mounted two radio transmitters on the misplaced humpback whale to monitor its movements in the Sacramento River.

title: U.S. Says Two Ships Joined Moscow's Fleet in the Pacific
description: A 28,000-ton Soviet cruiser and a 7,900-ton destroyer are heading into the South China Sea from the Indian Ocean, apparently the first ships of their class to join the Soviet Pacific Fleet, a United States Navy spokesman said today.

title: REPORT CRITICIZES ARMY ON OUTSIDE CONTRACTS
description: There is little evidence that the Army has saved money by following a policy of giving contracts for commercial services to private industry rather than using its own personnel, according to a report by the Army inspector general's office.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;

HOW A STRIKE BY TEACHERS CREATED A CRISIS IN A SMALL DISTRICT
description: The following article was written at the outset of a teachers strike in the Morris County community of Passaic Township. The author is the mother of two schoolchildren and a substitute teacher in Passaic Township. The strike began Oct. 10 and ended Oct. 18. The salary provisions under a new two-year contract will be decided by binding arbitration.

title: MARCIA HENDERSON TO WED STEPHEN J. MURPHY DEC. 27
description: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas S. Henderson of Chatham, N.J., and Amelia Island Plantation, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter Marcia Sue Henderson to Stephen J. Murphy, the son of Mrs. Richard vanTubergen of Lowell, Vt., and Thomas W. Murphy of New York. A Dec. 27 wedding is planned.

title: HOW SOON A BLACK N.F.L. COACH
description: SURROUNDED by hoopla and headlines, Eddie Robinson of Grambling passed Paul (Bear) Bryant recently as the college football coach with the most victories. And yesterday, as Grambling beat Texas Southern, he had 327 victories, pushing him past George Halas, the Papa Bear of the Chicago Bears, who has the most victories, in professional football. But all those triumphs revive a long-simmering question - when will a modern National Football League team hire a black head coach?

title: BABIES ARE TESTED FOR CYSTIC FIBROSIS
description: A RELATIVELY simple blood test performed on newborns is credited by researchers at the St. Francis Hospital and Medical Center in Hartford with helping to improve the quality of life for infants with cystic fibrosis, the most common life-threatening genetic disease.

title: IMPASSE ON REMEDIAL EDUCATION ISSUE
description: RELATIONS between the county's public and parochial school leaders have been severely strained by a recent United States Supreme Court ruling barring public school teachers from giving remedial help in parochial school settings.

title: OHIO STATE UPSETS TOP-RANKED IOWA
description: Without Keith Byars, the tailback and injured leader, the Ohio State Buckeyes called upon two substitutes and an old but successful formula - a nearly mistake-free game and the help of ''the Horseshoe'' - to defeat Iowa, 22-13, today on a dark, wet and wild afternoon.

title: EATING WITH THEIR MOUTHS OPEN
description: WHEN NEW YORKERS of a certain age, no matter what their ethnic origin or their station in life, speak of ''eating Chinese,'' a second-floor restaurant in Chinatown is the sort of place they mean. Here meals can last hours, and between courses unhurried and sometimes weighty talk can ensue. It's not exactly an evening at Virginia Woolf's, but then the food is unquestionably better.

title: About Men;   Keeping Count
description: AT THE START OF OUR FAMILY'S TWO-and-a-half-week vacation last summer, my 8-year-old son and I went to the public library together. He took out seven biographies, including ''What's the Big Idea, Ben Franklin?'', ''Robert Frost: America's Poet'' and ''Kareem Abdul-Jabbar: The Story of Lew Alcindor.'' I took out a two-volume work of social history that had been recommended to me. We both enjoyed our selections. Elihu would read for an hour or so each morning at our rented house, and I avidly worked my way through ''Simple Justice'' at the beach.

title: These Are Not Vital Organs
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: MIGHT-HAVE-BEENS
description: THE UNFINISHED JOURNEY: America Since World War II. by William H. Chafe. Illustrated. 516pp. New York: Oxford University Press. Cloth, $24.95, Paper, $14.95.

title: RANGERS DEFEATED AS DEVILS REOALLY, 6-5
description: The Devils rallied from a four-goal deficit in the last period tonight and gained a 6-5 overtime triumph over the Rangers before a sellout crowd of 19,040 at the Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: CAJUN-HUNGARIAN, BUT IT WORKS
description: MISS ELLIE'S CAFE in Smithtown is the only Cajun-Hungarian restaurant on Long Island. It lists jambalaya and chicken paprikash on the same menu. Until Paul Prudhomme takes his traveling restaurant show to Budapest, it will probably be the only one in the world.

title: CABLE TV
description: Some rather elusive titles mask a cluster of good vintage films of cable thes week. There's ''The Sergeant'' (1968), a lean, observanttale of homosexual yearning in the American Army, with Rod Steiger and John Phillip Law - Sunday at 12:40 A.M. on Cinemax. On Monday at 10:05 A.M., WTBS has ''Autumn Leaves'' (1956), a trim drama with Joan Crawford as a protective wife -one of her most becoming roles in her later career - - and Cliff Robertson as her younger, mentally-troubled spouse. The bristling, blunt ''Border Incident'' (1950) details a crackdown on illegal Mexican immigration, with a fine Ricardo Montalban -Monday at 1:05 P.M. on WTBS.

title: THE STATE, THE IMAGINATION AND THE CENSORED I
description: At the height of events in Poland, just when the trade union Solidarity was being outlawed I received a letter stamped ''Nie Cenzurowano.'' What exactly did these words mean? They were probably supposed to indicate that, in the country from which the letter came, there was no censorship. Buth they could aslo have meant that letters not bearing the stamp were censored, a mark of choosiness in official circles willing to demonstrate a faith in certain citizens they deny to others. It could naturally also have meant that all letters bearing this stamp actually did have to be passed by the censor.

title: STATUE OF LIBERTY'S REPAIR: A MARKETING SAGA
description: The restoration of the Statue of Liberty as it heads toward a 100th birthday extravaganza next year has become a unique and utterly American marketing saga, filled with fanfare, debate, men of large character and some of the biggest consumer-product companies in the land.

title: By AIR FORCE WINS
description: The halfback Kelly Pittman scored on runs of 2 and 3 yards and the cornerback Tom Rotello returned an interception 30 yards for a touchdown as unbeaten Air Force overcame a lackluster performance to down San Diego State, 31-10, in the Western Athletic Conference game today. The Falcons, with their 12th in a row, improved to 9-0 over all and 6-0 in the W.A.C. San Diego State fell to 3-5 and 1-3.

title: MELISSA FELDMAN TO WED
description: The engagement of Melissa Jill Feldman and Marc Karetsky has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Frederick R. Feldman of Harrison, N.Y., parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance's parents are Dr. and Mrs. Alfred J. Karetsky of Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: FILM CAPTURES ARGENTINA'S AGONY
description: In the recent history of Argentina's dictatorship so many people were kidnapped and tortured by right-wing death squads and then vanished without trace that a grisly noun came into common use: ''Los Desaparecidos'' - the disappeared ones. Their children, treated as war booty, were often given to government officials or sympathizers who were childless. ''The Official Story,'' a prize-winning Argentine film that is called ''Los Desaparecidos'' in Spanish, examines the social and psychological trauma that is the legacy of such practices even today, after democracy has come.

title: Changing The Libel Law
description: The underlying cause for the plethora of libel cases is the perceived responsibility - or lack of it - of the press.

title: CANADIAN AIRLINE IS WOOING GAMBLERS
description: ALTHOUGH only six passengers were aboard Air Ontario's inaugural scheduled flight to Atlantic City last Sunday, the carrier is confident that more Canadians will soon be heading for the resort.

title: Smoking Etiquette
description: To the Editor:

title: 'PARIS BOUND' FAILS TO GO ANYWHERE
description: MARRIED people need holidays apart from each other, or so says Mary Hutton in Philip Barry's ''Paris Bound'' at the Long Wharf Theater in New Haven.

title: Playing In Peoria
description: John Ehrlichman may think ''playing in Peoria'' was generated only by onomatopoeia and he may be dutifully corrected by William Safire to ascribe it to alliteration, but from what I am told by my friends in Peoria there is likely another origin that lurked in Mr. Ehrlichman's subconscious.

title: NEW YORK VILLAGE LURES KOSHER MEATPACKER
description: New York State has succeeded in a four-year effort to attract a major new industry, a meatpacking company capable of producing low-cost kosher foods and low-fat beef products, officials said.

title: WHAT TO ASK BEFORE YOU GO ABROAD
description: The most commonplace objects and activities - like telephones, taxicabs, crossing the street - can bring fear to the ranks of American travelers when those telephones, taxicabs or streets are not in the United States. Yet sometime, somewhere, every traveler has to cope with them. Visitors may not think of asking questions about such routine matters, or may find it embarrassing to do so, but the answers can make the difference between minor irritation and a feeling of confidence abroad.

title: IN U.S., ILLEGAL ARREST IS NO BAR TO A CONVICTION
description: To the Editor:

title: SONG AIMS TO LIFT BRIDGEPORT'S SPIRITS
description: NEW YORK CITY has one, and so does Los Angeles. Everyone's familiar with Chicago's, and the one about San Francisco has been around for years. So why shouldn't Bridgeport have one, too? a local businessman asked.

title: COZZENE TRIUMPHS
description: Cozzene, a 5-year-old gray horse who was kept in training this year with the specific goal of winning the Breeders Cup Mile, made that plan look good as he ran down Al Mamoon in the stretch to score a 2 1/4-length victory.

title: MOTHERHOOD, MAGIC AND LAVENDER
description: WYNDMERE By Carol Muske. 59 pp. Pennsylvania: University of Pittsburgh Press. Cloth, $12.95. Paper, $5.95.

title: LOVER AND LONER
description: MY FATHER, HIS DAUGHTER, By Yael Dayan. Illustrated. 289pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $17.95.

title: ELECTIONS TUESDAY FOCUS ON 2 STATES
description: Voters in Virginia and New Jersey will elect Governors Tuesday in contests that are being watched by both Democrats and Republicans eager to glimpse the political future as President Reagan's dominance of American politics begins to wane.

title: SERVICE TO ASSIST HIGH-TECH COMPANIES
description: A CLEARINGHOUSE for advice, information and assistance to fledgling high-technology companies was unveiled last week by the State Department of Economic Development.

title: Post to Halt Purchases Of South Africa Paper
description: The publisher of The New York Post, Rupert Murdoch, has announced that The Post will no longer buy newsprint from South Africa.

title: PENN, DOWN 21-0, TRIUMPHS BY 31-21
description: Princeton was leading by 21-0 late in the first half today and was 30 yards away from scoring a fourth touchdown when a Penn cornerback made an interception and started a remarkable comeback. The rally ended with the Quakers beating the Tigers, 31-21.

title: SHIPS HAVE MDE GOOD TARGETS FOR TERRORISTS
description: To the Editor:

title: THOSE TRIPS TO LUSAKA ARE SENDING SIGNALS TO PRETORIA
description: An Afrikaans-language newspaper printed a cartoon the other day showing a small group of Lilliputian figures about to be crushed by a very large hammer bearing the legend ''State Authority.''

title: ANOTHER ATTEMPT
description: Bud Stallworth is 35 years old and hasn't played in a pro league since 1976, when his career was curtailed after he injured his back in an auto accident while with the New Orleans Jazz of the National Basketball Association. Drafted in the first round from Kansas by Seattle in 1972 after he led the Big Eight in scoring, Stallworth had averaged 7.7 points a game in four N.B.A. seasons with the Sonics and the Jazz.

title: Student Group Integrates
description: The University of Mississippi Black Student Union has added white students to its cabinet in an attempt to improve race relations on the predominantly white campus. The group's president, Greg Sykes, said Friday that he hoped to rename the group the Association for Minority Concerns, a plan prompted by white students. ''They're asking me, 'Why shouldn't there be a White Student Union if there's a Black Student Union?' I've been listening to those concerns,'' Mr. Sykes said.

title: NEW AND NOTEWORTHY
description: THE WEAKER VESSEL, by Antonia Fraser. (Vintage, $9.95.) Englishwomen - wives, warriors, heiresses, mistresses, preachers - from the death in 1603 of Queen Elizabeth I to the crowning of Queen Anne in 1702 are Antonia Fraser's subject. Although Mary Lee Settle observed last year in The Book Review that the compendium gives short shrift to working women, she said that ''the depth and scope of research demanded by this amorphous subject presented a challenge that Miss Fraser has met brilliantly.''

title: INFANT INJURIES
description: SIX cases of infants with spiral leg fractures puzzled the police in Kansas City, Mo. Since such fractures are often caused by a twisting force, suspicion was high that the babies - all from one church-run day-care center - had been abused.

title: A PHARMACIST GRADUATES TO ACADEME
description: LOOKING over her schedule for the first weekend in November, Angele D'Angelo of East Rockaway took note of plans to be at the Summit Hotel in Hartford.

title: BRAZIL'S BURGEONING ARMS INDUSTRY
description: BRAZIL'S new 40-ton battle tank, the Osorio, is being tested in the deserts of Saudi Arabia. Its Tucano trainer aircraft has just been adopted by Britain's Royal Air Force. And the first 10 Brazilian-made Astros II rocket systems are already being used by Iraq in its war against Iran.

title: PROFITING FROM THE POSITIONS OF PLANETS
description: WHILE psychics claim to be practicing an art, astrologers insist their vocation is a science. ''It's very mathematical,'' said Manhattan astrologer Bill Attride, who, with the aid of a computer, charts the positions of the planets six months or, indeed, 5,000 years into the future, and predicts how the juxtaposition of those planets will affect events.

title: MIAMI BEACH SEES SIGNS OF A REVIVAL By JON NORDHEIMER
description: The subtle but telltale signs of revival are here.

title: ENTERTAINING SKIES
description: AFTER mentioning in an interview in New York last December that he would give free trans-Atlantic airline passage to musicians who performed for the passengers, Richard Branson, president of Virgin Atlantic Airways, was besieged by applicants.

title: Changing The Libel Law
description: I write in defense of scientists. In his article on libel law, Floyd Abrams mentions an ''indisputable case of skulduggery in scientific scholarship'' in medical research at Emory University and Harvard University medical schools, and the participation of 47 ''scientists'' in the fraud.

title: TOONE ARRESTED
description: For the second time in less than six months, Bernard Toone, the 6-foot-7-inch forward out of Gorton High School in Yonkers and Marquette University, has been arrested in an incident related to an automobile. Toone, who played one season with the Philadelphia 76ers, was arrested Friday for stealing a radio from a 1985 Saab in a municipal parking lot in White Plains.

title: ON THE CHECKS AND BALANCES WITHIN THE STATE GOVERNMENT
description: THE delicate system of checks and balances that lets different branches of government counter one another's power is essential to American democracy.

title: YOUNG MINDS THAT GO OFF WITH THE TV
description: IN the week following the unwelcome visit of Hurricane Gloria, a reporter asked a young girl, about age 11, what she had done all week, since her school was blacked out. ''Nothing,'' she answered. ''I miss school.'' ''You miss school?'' the reporter said, unbelieving. ''Yeah, there's nothing to do. The TV's not working.'' Nothing to do? Has this young girl never heard of an object constructed of a front and back cover, containing from several dozen to several hundred sheets of paper inscribed with symbols known to impart joy, sadness, laughter and knowledge? It's called a book. B-O-O-K.

title: HEARTY HUNGARIAN WITH ZEST
description: IN spite of a sizable Hungarian population, the number of Hungarian restaurants in Connecticut can be counted on one hand. This is surprising, for Hungarian cuisine is among the world's most intriguing.

title: Jacqueline de La Bruyere Is Engaged
description: Mrs. Frederic P. Herter of New York and Jean de La Bruyere of Los Angeles have announced the engagement of their daughter Jacqueline de La Bruyere to Herve Farman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Marcel Farman of Paris. The wedding is planned for Dec. 7.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: Captured Heritage: The Scramble for Northwest Coast Artifacts. By Douglas Cole. (Univeristy of Washington, $17.50.)The ''scramble'' for Northwest Coast artifiacts refers to roughly a 25-year period beginning just over 100 years ago when nearly every conceivable object made or used by the Indian tribes along the Northwest coast of Canada and Alaska was sought by the world's great natural history museums, then in their formative stages and avidly building up their holdings.

title: Japanese Title to Hanshin
description: Rich Gale, formerly of the Boston Red Sox, pitched a seven-hitter today as the Hanshin Tigers defeated the Seibu Lions, 9-3, to win the Japan Series for the first time. The Osaka-based Tigers, winner of the Central League pennant, took the four-of-seven-game Series, four games to two.

title: ALFONSIN HAS YET TO CONQUER THE MILITARY
description: President Raul Alfonsin broached the delicate issue of relations with the military last week in a speech explaining his decision to impose a state of siege. ''The case of the Armed Forces requires attention and care,'' he said. He avoided blaming the military for 42 recent explosions and more than 1,800 bomb threats, but he acknowledged that all is not well with Argentina's 80,000 troops.

title: ELECTION CAMPAIGNS DRAWING TO A CLOSE
description: A SOBER five-month election campaign for county executive, Westchester's top elected post, will end Tuesday when voters decide between two major candidates, the Republican-Conservative incumbent, Andrew P. O'Rourke, and his Democratic challenger, Arthur H. Goodman. A Right-to-Life Party candidate, Francis J. O'Reilly, also is running.

title: A NUCLEAR TEST BAN?
description: In all the speculation about the Reagan-Gorbachev summit meeting in Geneva on Nov. 19-20, there has been very little public discussion of the possibility of an agreement to stop immediately and ban finally the testing of nuclear weapons.

title: REFUGEES TO U.S. SAID TO HELP ECONOMY
description: It is a myth that the most recent refugees to this country live on welfare and displace Americans from scarce jobs, according to the chairman of the International Rescue Committee.

title: U.S. WINS OPEN BRIDGE TITLE: BRITAIN TAKES WOMEN'S FINAL
description: The world contract bridge team championships ended here this afternoon with the titles going to the United States and Britain.

title: H. DOUGLASS MOULTON WEDS ISOBEL L. BEERS
description: The marriage of Isobel Lee Beers of New York, widow of Henry N. Beers, to H. Douglass Moulton of Pittsburgh, a widower, took place yesterday at All Saints Episcopal Church in New York. The Rev. R. DeWitt Mallary Jr. performed the ceremony.

title: NEW YORK CITY SETS RULES FOR LEGALIZING LOFTS
description: Complying with a court order, the New York City Loft Board has announced long-delayed regulations under which nearly 1,000 buildings with illegal residential lofts must be renovated to meet health, safety, and fire codes.

title: BRITAIN ACCEPTS 'STAR WARS' ROLE
description: The Reagan Administration scored a small but important breakthrough last week in its effort to line up the NATO allies behind its space defense project before the President goes to Geneva to meet Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader.

title: PRESSURE ON PRINTERS TO DISPERSE
description: IT took a year, but Stuart Stettner finally found a new location for his business, Superior Lithographers. Last year he moved from Manhattan to Queens - from 10,000 square feet on two floors and a basement at 228 East 45th Street into 18,000 square feet on a single floor at 38-09 43d Avenue in Long Island City.

title: Behind Opposing The Saw Mill Plan
description: Your article about the State Department of Transportation's plans for major construction on the Saw Mill River Parkway [''State's Plan for Parkway Stirs Opposition in Hastings,'' Sept. 8] quotes Nicholas Pucino, D.O.T.'s parkway coordinator, as saying ''we're running into unbelievable resistance'' from the village of Hastings.

title: TRANSLATION IN COURTS IS CALLED INADEQUATE
description: THOUSANDS of non-English-speaking people in New Jersey are being denied fair legal treatment because of inadequate interpreting and translating services in the state's Superior and Municipal Courts, according to a task force created by the State Supreme Court.

title: MISS DENLINGER AND HARRY LEE ENGAGED TO WED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Sutherland W. G. Denlinger of Newtown, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Carley Elizabeth Denlinger to Harry Lee, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest S. Lee of Bethesda, Md.

title: HOW TO GET THE WOMEN'S MOVEMENT MOVING AGAIN
description: THIS IS ADDRESSED TO ANY WOMAN who has ever said ''we'' about the women's movement, including those who say, ''I'm not a feminist, but. . . .'' And it's addressed to quite a few men.

title: VIETNAM ORDEAL
description: VIETNAM said Willam M. Mathers was spying. Mr. Mathers, who had sold a dock-construction company that he ran in Singapore for 14 years, said he was going to Hong Kong to sell his 88-foot schooner when the Vietnamese seized him 36 miles at sea on July 22, 1984. He was imprisoned.

title: NEWARK SCHOOLS CHIEF GETS $660,000 SETTLEMENT
description: The Board of Education here has approved a $660,000 settlement with its Superintendent of Schools to obtain his resignation and end his lawsuits against the board.

title: KEAN VISITS 2 MALLS IN A SHOPPING TRIP TO BOLSTER TICKET
description: Governor Kean took his campaign for re-election to one of the most crowded venues he could find on this Saturday before the vote - two suburban shopping malls.

title:
GARDENING;

THE AUTUMN APPEAL OF THE PEPPERIDGE
description: WITH the memory of autumn foliage is still fresh in our minds, this is a good time to discuss one of the best trees for color - the Nyssa sylvatica, variously called pepperidge, black gum, sour gum or tupelo.

title: A FEFUGEES MISSION
description: A special State Department panel investigating the refugee problem in Indochina took off this weekend on a two-week tour of Hong Kong, Indonesia, Malaysia, Singapore and Thailand. The group, appointed by Secretary of State George P. Shultz, is headed by an Iowa insurance executive, Robert D. Ray, a former Republican Governor of that state.

title:
GARDENING;

THE AUTUMN APPEAL OF THE PEPPERIDGE
description: WITH the memory of autumn foliage is still fresh in our minds, this is a good time to discuss one of the best trees for color - the Nyssa sylvatica, variously called pepperidge, black gum, sour gum or tupelo.

title: KEAN LEADS BY 3-1 IN POLL
description: Governor Kean continued to hold a strong lead over Peter Shapiro, the Democratic candidate for governor, during the final week of the campaign, according to the latest Star-Ledger/Eagleton Poll.

title: SUSAN JANET BOEHM WEDS MARK PATRICK REYNOLDS
description: Susan Janet Boehm, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. A. Bruce Boehm Jr. of Brussels, was married yesterday to Mark Patrick Reynolds, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald B. Reynolds of Berkeley Heights, N.J. The Rev. Craig D. Townsend performed the ceremony at Grace Episcopal Church in Brooklyn Heights.

title: Adoption Story With a Happy Ending
description: After reading ''Couples Caught in the Adoption Maze'' [Oct. 13] , I have to write in order to present a more positive picture to other readers of that article, many of whom may be hoping to adopt.

title: NEWS REPORTS BRING SOUTH AFRICA'S TURMOIL INTO AMERICA'S LIVING ROOMS
description: In the last nine months South Africa has penetrated the American consciousness with a breadth that it rarely has during a quarter-century of racial strife in that troubled country. Significantly, this turnabout has coincided with sustained and vivid coverage of South Africa by American television.

title: POLITICS STEERS THE TAX AND BUDGET DEBATES
description: AFTER months of debate over the philosophy of revising the Federal tax system and reducing the budget deficit, both issues were subsumed last week by partisan politics.

title: THE VISUALLY IMPAIRED WILL GET MORE TO READ
description: MANY of America's 11 million visually impaired people, who are incapable of reading the print of the typical hardcover or paperback book, have had few alternatives to giving up reading altogether. The growing number of books on tape has helped somewhat, but until recently, few bookstores have carried large-print books; libraries that do carry them usually have a limited selection, and none of the 140 or more adult book clubs, which cater to everyone from nurses to chemical engineers to organic gardeners, have catered to people with poor eyesight.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: Paperback Talk. By Ray Walters. (Academy Chicago, Cloth, $19.95. Paper, $9.95.)

title: Mary Halsey Plans to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Selden Halsey of Richmond and Callao, Va., have announced the engagement of their daughter Mary Shaw Halsey to Robert Evan Marks, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Harold Marks of Washington. The wedding is planned for Dec. 7.

title: MEXICAN SPECTERS
description: QUEER, By William S. Burroughs. 134pp. New York: Viking, $14.95.

title: WHEN 60'S FORMALISM MEETS TODAY'S DRAMATIC INTENT
description: Margaret Jenkins and Carolyn Carlson both studied with choreographers who were pioneering innovators, who broke sharply with the very idea of how dance should be viewed.

title: OFFBEAT HISTORY
description: AS a general rule, law firm histories fall into two categories. Some are heavy, leather-bound tomes recounting long-forgotten litigation, often in stupifying detail.

title:
ABOUT WESTHCESTER;

FOUNTAINS OF OUR YOUTH
description: FRANK McCULLOUGH, 80 years old, still visits the pharmacy that belonged to his father, James. He stops by to chat with the current owner, Sal Caraccio, and to eat ''an occasional dish of ice cream, vanilla only,'' at the soda fountain counter where he worked as a boy. He remembers serving citrate of magnesia and castor oil and sasaparilla to customers, and banana splits for 25 cents and plenty of chocolate ice cream.

title: HAVEING A SECOND THOUGHT
description: It was dark when I left the club just off Fifth Avenue where I had handed over a check, which once was equal to five years' salary, for our daughter's forthcoming wedding.

title: AT HOME WITH MOVIE-HOUSE SOUND
description: More films are seen in the home these days by way of video than in regular movie theaters. But many viewers chafe at the shortcomings of such home presentation. Even ardent video fans feel that the tube hardly compares with the wide theater screen, but as long as present tube configuration (the ratio of width to height) and image line-count are maintained, not much can be done about that. Yet, at least with respect to sound, home video is getting closer to the movie house.

title: The Mind of The President
description: If I had needed further convincing that President Reagan is well-liked, unshakable in his ideological convictions and a master at achieving his political goals, Leslie H. Gelb's article ''The Mind of the President'' (Oct. 6) would have done the job.

title: INTEREST IN PRESERVING OLD CEMETERIES GROWS
description: ONE night two months ago vandals damaged 180 gravestones in an old section of the Amawalk Hills Cemetery in Yorktown. It was the worst case of vandalism to a cemetery in the town in recent memory.

title: Guru Arrested
description: Bhagwan Shree Rajneesh does not enjoy much peace for a man who preaches inner tranquillity. The Indian guru, who claims a half million followers, used to spend his days teaching a blend of Eastern mysticism and Western encounter therapy on his Oregon commune.

title: RANDI ZEMSKIY IS ENGAGED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Sam Zemsky of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Randi Jane Zemsky, to Dr. Curtis Slipman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Max Slipman of Hollis Hills, Queens. Miss Zemsky is director of advertising for MIS Week, a weekly publication for the information management industry published by Fairchild Publications. Dr. Slipman is chief resident of physiatry at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center in New York.

title: CONDOMINIUMS FROM A TO Z
description: For many skiers a modern condominium complete with dishwasher and Jacuzzi bath has replaced the traditional rustic inn as a base for a vacation or weekend in ski country. In recent years, families and groups of friends have discovered the advantages of renting a self-contained unit. One is privacy. Another is that they are not controlled by the set mealtimes of an inn or lodge; they have the facilities to prepare their own meals if and when they want. In some cases, daily maid service is included in the rental; occasionally help can be arranged, and it usually costs about $20 a day. In any event, the owner or manager arranges a thorough cleanup before a new group moves in.

title: THEOLOGY AND THE INTERSTELLAR SUBWAY
description: Contact, By Carl Sagan. 432pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $18.95.

title: JOE FRANKLIN LOSES RULING IN LIBEL CASE
description: UNDER New York State law, a statement is libelous if it exposes someone to ''public hatred, shame, obloquy, contumely, odium, contempt, ridicule, aversion, ostracism, degradation or disgrace.''

title: EXECUTIVE IS WED TOMISS DELAHUNT
description: Catherine Mary Delahunt and William Scott McGraw, account executives for the CBS Television Network, were married yesterday at Our Lady of Peace Roman Catholic Church in New York. The Rev. Joseph Burke performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Kenyon Wildrick, a Congregational minister.

title: Putting the Man Before the Cart
description: Country-fair time is here again, as your photographs showed [''Festivals to Celebrate the Harvest, Sept. 29] . Most farm people,those with a modicum of sense, realized long ago that it was good business to protect, rather than damage, investments in livestock.

title: SYMPHONY SERIES TO OPEN
description: THE pianist John Browning will perform with the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra at Symphony Hall here Saturday night in the opening program of the orchestra's November series.

title: OPERA: NEW PRODUCTION OF ARGENTO'S 'CASANOVA'
description: THE memoirs of Casanova, the 18th century's most celebrated libertine, are a gold mine of operatic material, and Dominick Argento, whose ''Casanova'' arrived last night at the New York City Opera, has struck it rich with his inspired account of one of the great lover's autumnal escapades. The three-act work, first performed in Minneapolis earlier this year, proved to be a thoroughgoing delight in its New York premiere, a witty theater piece that should go on charming audiences for many years.

title: RACE AND BLIND JUSTICE BEHIND MIXUP IN COURT
description: Here in Hall County last June one man was arrested as a thief and another as a murderer. And last week, when the murder defendant was summoned to stand trial, the other man was produced, and nearly convicted.

title: ALL IS FORGIVEN IN ITALY'S COALITION
description: For a change last week, an Italian Government was asked not to resign. The once and future Prime Minister, Bettino Craxi, who had stepped down after the Achille Lauro affair but stayed on while things were sorted out, announced that political leaders had agreed to revive his five-party coalition, and President Francesco Cossiga said he would tear up Mr. Craxi's resignation.

title: BOY TALKS THROUGH COMPUTER AT BAR MITZVAH
description: Specially programmed computers helped Lee Kweller through his bar mitzvah today, enabling him to recite from the Bible in Hebrew and English and giving him a voice despite the cerebral palsy that has crippled him since birth.

title: CONSTRUCTION CURB THREATENS JERSEY PROJECTS
description: A building moratorium ordered for New Jersey communities with inadequate sewage-treatment plants last summer has threatened the development of scores of projects across the state totaling millions of dollars, according to state officials.

title: Thief Incriminates Man For Child Abuse in Texas
description: A 39-year-old man incriminated by photographs that a burglar found after breaking into his home has been sentenced to 60 years for sexually abusing a 5-year-old girl.

title: HOMELESSNESS ISN'T SKIPPING A GENERATION ON CITY STREETS
description: As the nights turned crisp and the first wisp of winter blew into New York City last week, the familiar figure of Robert M. Hayes could be seen returning to his usual haunts, the city shelters where legions of the poor and mentally ill spend their nights.

title: PROSECTUORS PLAY DIFFERENT TUNES IN MOB TRIALS
description: In one Federal District courtroom in Manhattan last week, a witness described the structure of the Mafia in Sicily. In another, a Government informer recalled murdering a colleague in an auto theft ring, then sitting down to eat.

title: Hospitals Fear Burden Of Unpaid AIDS Bills
description: The growing number of AIDS victims unable to pay their hospital bills threatens the financial stability of the nation's health-care system, hospital administrators told a Congressional subcommittee this week.

title: HUSSEIN ASSAILS ARMS DELAY
description: King Hussein, disappointed at delays in a $1.9 million arms deal with the United States, declared today that Jordan would seek weapons from any available source.

title: THE STRUGGLE TO PROVIDE DRINKABLE WATER
description: THE widespread concern that dangerous chemicals have contaminated more and more of the nation's drinking water supply is setting the stage for a period of broad technological change in the drinking-water industry, according to Federal experts, environmentalists and water utility officials.

title: EX-TEAMSTER CHIEF ADMITS LYING IN HIS '82 TRIAL
description: Roy L. Williams, former president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, has admitted in Federal District Court here that he lied in sworn testimony three years ago when he was convicted of conspiring to bribe Senator Howard Cannon of Nevada.

title:
ART;

SCULPTORS EXPLORED IN YONKERS SHOW
description: SCULPTORS in the years immediately after 1945 took a back seat to Abstract Expressionist painters such as Jackson Pollock and Barnett Newman. Yet many of their impulses were similar, such as celebrating the natural elements along with the heroic individual. But if primitivism was an issue with these sculptors, new technology, such as advances in welding techniques developed during World War II, was their means.

title: MELISSA ANN MAREK WED TO PHILIP BABB
description: Melissa Ann Marek, an associate at Merrill Lynch Money Markets in New York, was married yesterday to Philip H. Babb, an architect in New York. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Justin Hennessy at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Vincent Ferrer in New York.

title: WHEN 'L.I.E.' REALLY MEANS 'L.I. EXPORTWAY'
description: WHILE there may be a loss of jobs in some areas of the country because of increased imports and the strength of the dollar overseas, that trend has not affected Long Island. The main reason is that Long Island exports are on the increase.

title: PHILADELPHIA LIMIT FOR STREET VENDORS
description: STREET vendors and city officials have been at odds in Philadelphia for years. When vending regulations were last revised in 1976, ''there was much histrionics,'' according to Don Kligerman, the city's deputy managing director.

title: STATE VOWS TO FIGHT DIVERSION OF WATER
description: STATE officials say they are prepared to oppose a possible attempt by Massachusetts to divert water from the Connecticut River at Northfield, Mass., and channel it to Boston's water supply.

title: ANTIMISSILE PLAN SEEKS THOUSANDS OF SPACE WEAPONS
description: The planners of a defense against nuclear missiles are leaning toward a complex, seven-layer system that would consist of thousands of space satellites with weapons intended to furnish a nearly perfect nationwide shield.

title: IN THE BEGINNING WAS THE LOGO
description: PAUL RAND: A DESIGNER'S ART By Paul Rand. Illustrated. 239 pp. New Haven. Yale University Press. $39.95.

title: 1986 TO BE YEAR TO EXAMINE COUNTY'S ARCHITECTURAL HERITAGE
description: NORMALLY he concentrates on the theater. But during much of next year, Brendan Gill of Bronxville, the drama critic for The New Yorker magazine, will be reviewing 300 years of New York architecture. He will not be alone.

title: COMBATING TERRORISM
description: 'It is only through the firm resolve of all nations to act in concert that it will become impossible for terrorists to find safe haven anywhere in the world. These people must be made to know that once having committed an act of terrorism, there will be no place for them to go, no place to run, no place to hide.' rrMarilyn Klinghoffer whose husband was killed in the hijacking of the Achille Lauro, testifying before a House Foreign Affairs subcommittee

title: SUCCESS FOR LUKAS
description: Twilight Ridge, the least accomplished but clearly the fastest of a heavily favored D. Wayne Lukas-trained entry, turned in a championship performance to beat her stablemate, Family Style, by 1 1/4 lengths. Her winning time of 1:35 4/5 under Jorge Velasquez was faster than Tasso ran in winning the Juvenile for 2-year-old males a race earlier.

title: 1947 IMMIGRANT PAYING A DEBT BY SAVING INDIANS' LANGUAGE
description: An anthropologist who began his career 36 years ago as a poor Czech immigrant questioning Arapaho elders is attempting to repay the Indian tribe by helping keep its language alive.

title: LONDON'S GLOBAL VILLAGE
description: Soho's name comes from a hunting-call: ''So-ho! So-ho!'' When London was the City of London within its wall, the fields above the Strand and the Thames were a coursing-ground for foxes and hares. Warrens of little houses grew up in the 18th century, then pleasant low brick streets set around two squares, Soho and Golden Square. The district became a lozenge of intense life between major thoroughfares in the last two centuries, Regent and Oxford Streets to the northwest with their stores and displays, Charing Cross Road with its bookshops to the east, and Shaftesbury Avenue and Leicester Square to the south, all theaters and cinemas and shows.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;

HOMEWORK HELP
description: EVERY weekday afternoon from 3 to 6 P.M., an average of 10 youngsters find their way into the Homework Help Room at the White Plains Public Library. The room is a joint project of the White Plains Youth Services Bureau and the White Plains Public Library/Young Adult Services.

title: WHEN PROFESSOR LECTURES, 2,000 LISTEN
description: Every fall, one in six undergraduate students at Cornell University takes Psychology 101.

title: LIFE OF ORSON WELLES AND HIS WORK CITED AS 500 MOURN LOSS
description: A crowd of about 500 people gathered at the Directors Guild Theater today and heard Orson Welles hailed as a creative genius who ''mastered the art of his profession but not its games.''

title: SECOND THOUGHTS ON AIDS RULES
description: ''I am concerned that people know exactly what we are doing,'' Mayor Koch said last week of New York City's response to new state rules to combat the spread of AIDS. It was nonetheless hard to know precisely what the city was up to.

title: THE DANCE: ANN ARBOR ENSEMBLE
description: THERE were moments when the evening came alive on Friday as the Ann Arbor Dance Works performed at Marymount Manhattan Theater, 221 East 71st Street. Gay Delanghe's recent ''Dancin' Fats,'' a bright, inventive piece for six dancers and six chairs, captured some of the low-down humor of the three songs by Fat Waller to which the dance was set. Miss Delanghe herself performed with a seasoned authority and wit suggestive of Lotte Lenya that made one long to see her do a solo to the music, though the dance was ably performed by a cast that also included Jessica Fogel, Catherine Lichtman, Marsha Pabalis, Henry Van Kuiken and the feathery-footed Bill De Young.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: AMERICAN MUSIC WEEK It's American Music Week and, along with 200 other orchestras and ensembles from coast to coast, the New York Virtuosi Chamber Symphony is marking the occasion by paying tribute to contemporary composers. And the 32-piece ensemble, under Kenneth Klein's baton, is doing it today with a concert featuring Aaron Copland's ''Suite From Appalachian Spring,'' Michael Colgrass's ''Concertino for Timpani, Brass and Percussion,'' and Saul Goodman's ''Ballade for the Dance.'' Joined by Roland Kohloff, principal timpanist for the New York Philharmonic, the orchestra performs at 3 P.M. at the Wunsch Arts Center, 1 Forest Avenue in Glen Cove. For ticket information call 671-2557.

title: A SURVIVOR REMEMBERS OTHER SURVIVORS OF 'SHOAH'
description: ''Shoah,'' the Hebrew title of Claude Lanzmann's monumental documentary at the Cinema Studio, translates into ''Holocaust'' in English. Both terms seem to me pale and inadequate to describe the systematic and inexorable annihilation of countless Jewish communities during the Nazi era. There are really neither words nor means to capture the totality of the event. Even if one were to add ''Night and Fog,'' ''The 81st Blow,'' ''The Final Solution'' and all the other documentaries to ''Shoah,'' one could not encompass this tragedy comparable to no other. Certainly, in one sense, it is the most documented tragedy in history; but in spite of the testimonies, memoirs and superhuman efforts of survivors, we will never know how Auswitz and Treblinka were possible - for the killers as well as for the victims.

title: Execution Order Stayed
description: The Florida Supreme Court voted 5-to-1 today to grant a stay of execution for Ronnie Lee Jones, convicted of murdering three people, who was scheduled to die Monday in Florida's electric chair. Mr. Jones, 29 years old, was convicted of killing three men in a 1981 break-in. His lawyer, Ted Klein, told the court that Mr. Jones, a former boxer who acted as his own attorney at his original trial, had not been competent to represent himself at that hearing.

title: L.I. Man Dies in Truck Crash
