description: A Long Island man was killed today when he lost control of his dump truck, which plowed through an alley, knocked over a tree and hit a wall of the Roslyn Racquet Club building, the police in Nassau County said. The driver, Timothy Clinton, 26 years old, of Westbury, L.I., apparently jumped from the truck as it went through the alley around 12:10 P.M., said Officer Robert Wheeler, a police spokesman. He was pronounced dead at 1:25 P.M.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It's a very complicated area. Had we done nothing, nothing would have happened.

title: LOS ANGELES EXUBERANT
description: Of the half dozen distinct areas in central Los Angeles, the most historic - and unquestionably the most vibrant - is the old downtown just east of Pershing Square. Spring Street, the former Wall Street of the West, is an open-air museum of early 20th-century commercial architecture. One block west, Broadway is a bustling shopping and theater-going street for the cidy's vast Mexican community, and between Third Street and Olympic Boulevard it offers the largest single concentration of pre-World War II movie palaces in America. Parts of both Spring Street and Broadway are listed as historic districts on the National Register of Historic Places.

title: 20 Horses Die After a Stable In New Orleans Catches Fire
description: Fire raced through a stable early today, killing 19 horses and injuring one that later was put to death, the authorities said.

title: CIBA-GEIGY ARRAIGNMENT SET
description: THE Ciba-Geigy Corporation and four of its managers will be arraigned in Superior Court here Thursday on charges of illegally dumping hazardous wastes and of falsifying disposal records.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Just About Everything In Preholiday Gifts Preholiday shopping opportunities are appearing, away from the routine places, and offering the bonus of enjoying fall colors en route to the search for gifts.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: THE NIGHTINGALE, By Hans Christian Andersen. Adapted by Anna Bier. Illustrated by Demi. 32pp. San Diego: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $13.95. (All ages)

title: A HOTBED OF HIGH TECH RAISES ITS INVESTMENT IN INNOVATION
description: In a parking lot across a driveway from the University of Massachusetts medical school, a bulldozer will soon begin ripping up asphalt, beginning the construction of a 75,000-square-foot office building that will be first structure in a new kind of development, a ''biotechnology park.'' The park, to be built with state aid, is meant to be more than a place where genes are spliced; it is supposed to help incubate a whole industry.

title: JAZZ
description: This week someone is bound to make a case for the California-to-New York connections in 1980's jazz. On Monday, the Fort Worth-born clarinetist John Carter will arrive from California with the world premiere of his 90-minute suite - and a powerful octet to play it - at the Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street.

title: METROLINER NOT YET AS FAST AS A SPEEDING BULLET TRAIN, BUT IT'S GETTING THERE
description: With little notice or fanfare, the Metroliners that run between New York and Washington have finally achieved routine speeds of 120 to 125 miles per hour.

title: MICHIGAN TIED, 3-3, AS ILLINI KICK FAILS
description: Chris White's 37-yard field-goal attempt for Illinois with 4 seconds left was partially blocked and bounced off the crossbar as Michigan and Illinois tied, 3-3, in a Big Ten game. The tie left Michigan at 6-1-1 over all and 3-1-1 in the conference; Illinois is 4-3-1 and 3-1-1.

title: DAREN CASAL AND GARY MARK SPITZ MARRY IN BOSTON
description: Karen Casal, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Casal of East Weymouth and New Seabury, Mass., and Gary Mark Spitz, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter H. Spitz of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Stratton Mountain, Vt., were married yesterday at the Boston Park Plaza Hotel. The Rev. Alice B. Lane, a Unitarian minister, performed the interdenominational ceremony.

title: A CRAFTS CONSULTANT FINDS SPECIAL NICHE
description: WHEN St. Peter's Church, in Manhattan's Citicorp Center, was looking for an unusual lectern Bible befitting the new building, the church's art-selection committee turned to a Westchester consultant, Rosanne Raab, whose specialty is contemporary, museum-quality crafts. Mrs. Raab's involvement with crafts has included five years as associate director of the Craftsman's Gallery in Scarsdale, two years as chairman of the crafts-selection committee for the American Craft Museum's Associate Council in Manhattan and five years as an auctioneer for Channel 13's Art and Antique Collection Auction.

title: On Language;   Forewords March
description: AS A BRIEF PROLE-gomenon to today's discourse, be warned: nobody reads prefaces. An introduction is considered part of a text, and is the piece of front matter closest to the first chapter; it usually gets skimmed, rarely perused. A preface comes before that, and is most often a personal comment by the author apologizing for writing the work, or for being alive; in fact, a couple of centuries ago, the preface was often called the apology. Even before the preface comes the most ignored part of what publishers call the prelims: the selling job on why the reader is obligated to read the rest of the book, usually by a famous name willing to shill for his buddy, the author, and it is called the foreword.

title: TOWN ON CAPE COD IS IN FISCAL PINCH
description: Residents of this small Cape Cod resort town are wondering what life might be like with no street lights, less police protection, less snow removal, fewer teachers and larger school classes.

title: WATER CURBS ARE EASED
description: People were once again free to water lawns and wash cars in parts of New York, New Jersey, Pennsylvania and Delaware last week, after restrictions on water use had been lifted by the Delaware River Basin Commission. Mandatory curbs on nonessential water use remained in effect in New York City, however, because rainfall over most of the city's reservoirs has not been as abundant as it has been recently over the Delaware Basin.

title: 4 JERSEY COMMUNITIES TO GET AID FOR BUSINESS
description: Four communities with economic problems have been added to New Jersey's list of urban enterprise zones.

title: I.R.S. ASKS CO-OPS FOR REPORTS ON INTEREST
description: THE Internal Revenue Service, in a crackdown on taxpayers who overstate their deductions, has published new regulations requiring cooperative buildings to file a new set of tax forms beginning next year. The forms will verify to the I. R. S. the amount of deductible interest payments that the co-op received from each of its shareholders during the year as part of their monthly maintenance payments.

title: Q and A
description: Tax and Residency Question: I would like to buy a home in the Poconos and keep my stabilized apartment for weekdays. Since I own no other property, could I claim tax benefits for this home as a primary residence under President Reagan's tax proposal? . . . K. K., Rego Park, Queens Answer: When a taxpayer lives in two locations, the principal residence is the one in which he spends most of his time. Even if you own no other property, a weekend home would not qualify as a principal residence under either the President's tax proposal or current law, according to representatives of the Internal Revenue Service and the Treasury Department, which wrote the Reagan Administration's tax proposal, and tax experts familiar with both. But they add that, depending on the circumstances, there could be tax benefits to owning a resort property.

title: AND IN THE STANDS: DUKES AND ACTORS, AND REGULARS, TOO
description: On a gray, cloud-heavy day at Aqueduct, a great panoply of bipeds in a wide assortment of millinery and haberdashery, streamed through the turnstiles bright with expectation about their considered opinion of quadrupeds. It was a day like most days for horseplayers, only more so.

title: THE PAN ASIAN REPERTORY
description: Tisa Chang is passionate about her mission: ''to promote a repertory of, by and about Asians and Asian-Americans,'' and to do so with the highest professional standards.

title: PARMESAN: TAKE CARE IN SELECTION AND ENJOY ITS USEFULNESS
description: IF I were allowed only one cheese, it would probably be Parmesan. This would certainly not be the choice of people who know this cheese only in grated form. But genuine aged Parmesan, sold in large wheels with the words ''Parmigiano-Reggiano'' etched on the rind, is one of the world's great cheeses. It is superb eaten on its own, accompanied by a glass of chilled champagne or a good red wine. It is excellent for cooking because it doesn't melt or turn to glue like some cheeses. It is also low in fat and high in protein.

title: Saw Mill Group: What It Is and Why
description: Your reporter inadvertently misrepresented the purpose of our organization, the Saw Mill River Association. The article identified the S.M.R.A. with other local groups put together to oppose the State Department of Transportation's plan to rebuild a number of exits and entrances on the Saw Mill River Parkway in the Dobbs Ferry-Hastings-Yonkers area.

title: CLAMMERS FEARFUL OF SHORE CONSTRUCTION
description: STATE legislators and environmental officials must decide how to respond to the pleas of clammers, who say that shoreline construction threatens the supply of clams, and Federal Food and Drug Administration specialists, who urge the hiring of additional state clamming-enforcement personnel to promote the safety of clams.

title: SIX ARTISTS ARE PRESENTED IN RECITALS
description: Garah Landes The pianist Garah Landes, who made his New York debut on Oct. 26 at Carnegie Recital Hall, studied with David Bradshaw at Molloy College, where he received a Gold Medal in Music upon graduation. He took his Masters degree at the Manhattan School of Music, and studies now with Earl Wild.

title: A 'DREAM HOUSE' VERSUS PARK PLAN
description: A MANHATTAN lawyer who wants to build his ''dream house'' on a spit of land jutting into Little Peconic Bay in the Town of Southampton is now battling the town because the site is slated to be a park.

title: MONTEVERDI'S MUSIC INSPIRES DIFFERING INTERPRETATION
description: Claudio Monteverdi's ''Orfeo'' was first performed in 1607, close enough to the dawn of opera to be considered one the form's earliest milestones. Like its handful of predecessors, ''Orfeo'' is essentially a musical rendering of a myth - an approximation, in early 17th-century Italian terms, of the way the ancient Greeks might have told the tale, based on the belief that Greek poetry was intoned rather than spoken.

title: FLIGHTS CALLED KEY TO RESORT'S FUTURE
description: THIS resort has a start once again on daily commercial airline service, which analysts have called essential for the growth of the casino industry and the city's economy.

title: FROM THE GUTTERS OF ROME
description: A VIOLENT LIFE By Pier Paolo Pasolini. Translated by William Weaver. 320 pp. New York: Carcanet. Cloth, $18.50. Paper, $17.50.

title: MISS BOTHWELL MARRIED TO GREGORY C. FERRERO
description: Leslie Ann Bothwell, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. A. Ernest Bothwell of New Canaan, Conn., was married yesterday to Gregory C. Ferrero, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles J. Ferrero of Mendham, N.J. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Edward Danks at the Darien (Conn.) Presbyterian Church.

title: Iraq Reports Raid On Kharg Terminal
description: Iraq said its warplanes made a ''successful raid'' today on Iran's Kharg Island oil terminal and bombed Iranian positions in the southern part of the 730-mile warfront.

title: IMPROVEMENT SEEN IN U.S.-GREEK TIES
description: Greek and American officials say they believe a gradual improvement in relations between their two countries will gain speed as a result of a visit here this week by Michael H. Armacost, Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs.

title: BUCKS EASY VICTORS OVER NETS, 136-113
description: Sidney Moncrief scored 23 points and Jeff Lamp and Craig Hodges scored 17 each to lead Milwaukee to an easy 136-113 victory over New Jersey tonight. The loss broke a two-game Net winning streak.

title: FIGHTING YOUR LAWYER OR ACCOUNTANT
description: YOU are expecting a big tax refund, but the check has not arrived, your accountant will not return calls - and he has sent an outrageous bill. Or perhaps your lawyer is dragging his feet on your pending suit, and you fear that witnesses are fleeing, destroying evidence as they go.

title: BEAUTY CULTURE
description: To the Editor: Marilyn Bender's article ''Hair-Curling Adventures,'' (Travel, Sept. 15) was interesting from a fashion point of view. However, I have always found that beauty salons reflect the sociological aspects of a country.

title: YALE SEARCH PANEL NARROWING THE FIELD
description: THE process of choosing a new president of Yale University is entering its final stage this weekend, according to the head of the search committee, as the panel seeks to narrow a list of 425 candidates to fewer than 30.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: REDISCOVERING AMERICA: John Muir In His Time and Ours. By Frederick Turner. (Viking, $25.) According to Frederick Turner, when John Muir and Theodore Roosevelt spent three nights camping out in the Yosemite region, ''two major figures in American history enacted in microcosm one of the culture's persistent dreams: creative truancy in the wild heart of the New World.''

title: MIXED SIGNALS ON MOVE SIEGE
description: Who ordered Philadelphia firefighters to allow a blaze in a house under siege to burn out of control for at least 30 minutes on May 13? A mayoral commission investigating the city's confrontation with the radical group Move, which left 11 Move members dead and destroyed 61 homes, has heard a tangle of evidence, and last week the contradictions mounted.

title: VIETNAM IS GIVING AMERICAN TOURISM A TRIAL RUN
description: Vietnam is ready to experiment with American tourism, and it has asked a Long Island tour organizer to collect 10 people for a trial run, before the end of the year if possible.

title: Treasure Hunter Sells Andrea Doria Objects
description: A treasure hunter who salvaged the Italian luxury liner Andrea Doria, which sank in 1956, has begun selling artifacts recovered from the vessel.

title: FRENCH ARTICLE SETS OFF FUROR ON IMMIGRANTS
description: The publication of an article asserting that French identity and culture are threatened by the growing immigrant population has touched off a political furor in France.

title: MARY BARFIELD IS BRIDE OF DR. GORDON S. REISS
description: Mary Ashton Barfield, the financial administrator for the Center for Biomedical Research of the Population Council, an advisory foundation in New York, and Dr. Gordon Sidney Reiss, a dentist, were married yesterday at the bridegroom's home in New York. Rabbi A. Allen Block officiated.

title:
ART;

L.I. AS AN 'AMUSEMENT PARK'
description: FOR over a century and a half, the Long Island landscape has provided painters with a seemingly endless supply of inspirational subject matter.

title: BINGO THAT DOESN'T GET ANY BIGGER
description: A blue and white sign towers above the pinon and juniper scrub along a major highway through here, bearing words that are sure the catch the eyes of tourists heading north from Santa Fe to Taos and the Colorado line.

title: NEW WILD TURKEYS TAKING TO TOWNS
description: The wild turkey, which by the turn of the century had been hunted to near extinction in North America and driven from the woodlands by settlers clearing land, has rebounded to such an extent that scientists now say a new strain of the species has evolved - the urban turkey.

title: CEDARHURST BARS DEVELOPMENT
description: THE Village of Cedarhurst has declared a one-year moratorium on many kinds of commercial development because its sewage plant is overloaded.

title: A SMALL TOWN WITH A FOOTNOTE TO HISTORY
description: I had come in search of the ghosts of the unlikely American soldiers who 40 years ago entered the ancient village of Haigerloch in the Wurttemberg region of what is now West Germany looking for a cave in which the Nazis had sown the seeds of another Holocaust. In a cool, damp-walled cave beside the S-bend in the Eyach River, in the last hours of the war, the Nazis had hidden a crude reactor with which they had sought desperately to unlock the secrets of the uranium atom. Humbug, the code name of the Americans' raid, was meant to learn just how far they had gotten.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: UNFNISHED SYMPHONIES IT WAS an unusual assignment, Dennis Bernstein had to admit. Composing music that stops and starts according to whether there are people nearby, and which is compatible with a 16-foot-high abstract sculpture in the middle of a shopping mall, was not something he had tried before.

title: PENNSYLVANIANS CHALLENGE BISHOP
description: THE BISHOP'S word is no longer law to 90 members of St. Mary Magdalen Catholic Church in Lost Creek, nestled in the coal fields of northern Schuylkill County in Pennsylvania.

title: RIGHTS OF SEAFARERS
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWSMEN WORRIED BY PRETORIA CURBS
description: Representatives of American news organizations expressed deep concern yesterday over South Africa's plan to impose severe restrictions on coverage of the widespread unrest in the country.

title: Changing The Libel Law
description: In his proposals to change the libel law, Floyd Abrams might include the granting of absolute immunity to the press in criticizing public officials (''Why We Should Change the Libel Law,'' Sept. 29). This would be the most effective way to demonstrate what Justice William J. Brennan Jr., writing for the Court in the New York Times v. Sullivan decision, found to be our ''profound national commitment to the principle that debate on public issues should be uninhibited, robust and wide open.''

title: THEY FIND US FORMIDABLE!
description: THE MAJORITY OF New York's newest residents from France are scarcely huddled masses, though they often express a yearning to be free - from Old World deliberativeness, as well as from new Socialist reforms.

title: JACKSON LEADS BRITONS IN DENOUNCING PRETORIA
description: Led by the Rev. Jesse Jackson, tens of thousands of demonstrators gathered in London today to denounce apartheid in South Africa and to call for stiff economic sanctions against the Pretoria Government.

title: JETS USE PRESSURE, NOT SACKS
description: Dan Marino tried it and failed. So did Vince Ferragamo. Steve Grogan couldn't do it, so he ran instead. Lynn Dickey was so distraught after failing that he benched himself the next week.

title: SEASONAL JOBS KEEP AGED BUSY
description: SHORTLY after 7 A.M. five days a week, 67-year-old Joseph Grasso arrives at the Dak food plant here, where he checks the assembly line to make sure that the work will run smoothly when the other employees arrive.

title: DELICATE BATTLES
description: A STAY BY THE RIVER, By Susan Engberg. 247pp. New York: Viking. $15.95.

title: WARMING UP IN SHANGHAI
description: Shanghai's Huangpu Park - which, like parks in other Chinese cities, serves as playground, sylvan refuge, meeting hall, kiosk and agora - cuts a curving green band, about 11 city blocks in area, bounded by inky Suzhou Creek and by the broad, brown Huangpu River. On the land side, the park borders Zhongshan Road, known in Shanghai's colonial days as the Bund, where stand the stately old buildings that had been banks and trading houses and that now serve as offices of the People's Republic.

title: THE HEARTLAND HEROES BRED IN QUEENS
description: THE goalpost was gopin to come down as surely as a football had just passed between its uprights, an official's gun had signaled the end of the game, and the Iowa Hawkeyes had beaten Michigan to preserve the top ranking in the nation. The state of Iowa was shaking with joy. The north end of Kinnick Stadium was an epicenter of gold and black, the core made up of football players and the rest a mass of students and fans. The circle was growing with each second, spreading from sideline to sideline, and very soon, without any doubt, the north goalpost would be swallowed.

title: TEN HOURS FROM ASUNCION
description: In theory, at least, no destination is more sought after by travelers than Off the Beaten Track, that elusive Eden unspoiled by civilization. While the prospects of finding such places on our crowded planet shrink almost daily, some relatively unspoiled places still exist and the name of one of them is Filadelfia.

title: CATHOLICS AND JEWS REACH AN ACCORD
description: Leading Catholics and Jews meeting under Vatican auspices have announced agreement on a joint program ''to overcome the residues of indifference, resistance and suspicion.''

title: LAW ON MALPRACTICE INSURANCE FOR HOSPITAL DOCTORS UPHELD
description: An appeals court has upheld a state law requiring hospitals to give each doctor $1 million in extra malpractice insurance protection and has said the state must make sure hospitals are reimbursed for the coverage.

title: JACQUELINE HALLO TO WED IN JUNE
description: Jacqueline Louise Hallo, a student at the Harvard Graduate School of Education, and David Allen Bunis, a second-year law student at Boston University, plan to be married in June, her parents, Mr. and Mrs. William W. Hallo of New Haven and Hamden, Conn., have announced.

title: 240 Women Settle Lawsuits In Synthetic Estrogen Cases
description: Two hundred forty women who said they suffered because their mothers were prescribed synthetic estrogen in pregnancy have settled their lawsuits out of court for an undisclosed amount of money.

title: COMPETING FOR THE BUSINESS MIND
description: THE first wave of the microcomputer invasion of the nation's offices appears to be over. And although it cannot yet be truthfully said that everyone who could benefit from these machines already has one, the initial euphoria surrounding their introduction has been replaced by a much more practical mindset. Now potential buyers are asking: ''What can a personal computer do for us?''

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: Death Is A Lonely Business. By Ray Bradbury. (Knopf, $15.95) Ray Bradbury's first novel in 23 years can be read as a meditation on his own craft; not only is the anonymous hero a thinly veiled stand-in for the young Bradbury, penniless and love-starved as he writes his early fantasy classics for Dime Detective and Weird Tales, but the plot's tangle of murders and disappearances also turns out to be an oblique projection of the hero's imaginative processes.

title: SANCTUARY FOR TIBETAN ART
description: There may be no more improbable art institution in town than the Jacques Marchais Center for Tibetan Art. On a hill in Staten Island, it can seem as far away as Tibet.

title: DENISE O'DONOGHUE WED
description: Denise Brigid O'Donoghue, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John O'Donoghue of Rutherford, N.J., was married yesterday to Kristinn Johannsson, a son of Johann Magnusson and Halldora Einarsdottir of Reykjavik, Iceland. The Rev. Robert Cormier performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Rutherford, N.J. The bride, who will retain her name, is the associate beauty editor of Bride's magazine in New York. Mr. Johannsson is a cabinetmaker in Larchmont, N.Y.

title: GOLDMAN'S MERGER CHIEF: Geoffrey T. Boisi;   MASTERMINDING THE MEGA-DEALS
description: ROWS of tiny lucite blocks are lined up neatly on the end tables flanking the sofa in Geoffrey Boisi's office at Goldman, Sachs & Company. Encased in the lucite are miniature replicas of newspaper advertisements announcing some of the more breathtaking transactions handled by the mergers and acquisitions department of Goldman, Sachs, where the lanky, dark-haired Mr. Boisi (pronounced BWA-zy) reigns as chief dealmaker.

title: ENDURING STYLE
description: THERE WAS A TIME, A QUARTER-CENTURY AGO, when every fashionable woman worth a photographer's flashbulb had a fling with Kenneth. Then a strange thing happened. The fling turned into a long-standing love affair.

title: RAIL SURVEY
description: To the Editor: One point seems to have been omitted in the useful, informative and enjoyable rail survey (Travel, Aug. 11). If there is no need to make connections in a hurry and one stays for any length of time at a destination, why not register the heavy luggage either from station to station or door to door? Then there is no need to worry about porters - who are practically extinct - and the scarcity of baggage carts.

title: EVENTS SET TO WELCOME HALLEY'S
description: ''I'VE HEARD the same thing from so many people,'' said Frank Biribauer of Chester, president of Amateur Astronomers Inc. ''Why make such a big fuss over the appearance of a comet?' ''

title: SPARKLE OF VENICE GLITTERS IN GLASS
description: Venice is a glass lover's paradise, its wares embracing every taste and budget. Tiny glittering glass menageries vie with richly colored blocks of art glass and delicate reproductions of Renaissance wine and water goblets. Glass is sold by street vendors, by shops and markets on the canals, and in the nearby island town of Murano, the city's glassmaking center since the 13th century.

title: SHUTTLE FLIGHT TERMED A SUCCESS AT HALFWAY POINT
description: The international crew of the space shuttle Challenger, reaching the halfway point of their weeklong mission, today reported encouraging success with nearly all the 76 scientific experiments in metallurgy, crystal growth and biology.

title: ROUND ONE TO THE FRENCH MISSIONARIES
description: THE INVASION WITHIN: The Contest of Cultures in Colonial North America. By James Axtell. Illustrated. 389pp. New York: Oxford Univeristy Press. $29.95.

title: NOW SOME KIND WORDS FORLOTTERY PLAYERS
description: To the Editor:

title: Wooster Trounces South Kent
description: The quarterback Gy Kirk threw for three touchdown passes and the halfback Neil Sainsbury-Carter added two touchdowns on the ground to lead Wooster School to a 42-0 rout over South Kent School. The victory was Wooster's first over South Kent in 11 years.

title: WOMEN OF THE CALABASH
description: Playing gourds and other African, Brazilian, Caribbean and American instruments, this four-woman group offers a mix of percussion, voices and dance characterized by intricate rhythms and the performers' witty gusto. Appearing frequently around town - next at Dance Theater Workshop (924-0077) on November 18 and 19 - they blend the new and the traditional into an absorbing re-examination of our common rituals.

title: SETTLEMENT REACHED IN BLAST AT PHILADELPHIA PEIR IN 1975
description: After nearly 11 years of litigation, the owners of a freighter that collided with a tanker at a Delaware River pier in 1975, killing 26 crew members and injuring numerous others, have agreed to pay $30 million to the pier's owners.

title: SAVINGS TAKE A DRAMATIC SLIDE
description: As folklore has it, Americans are a people in whom thrift elicits feelings of near reverence. Reality has, of course, been something different. But while the national savings rate has traditionally been low, it has at least been fairly constant. Over the last 10 years, for example, savings have fluctuated between 5 and 7 percent of disposable personal income.

title: 'GOLDEN WINDOWS' REVEALS A DREAM WORLD IN MINIATURE
description: ''The Golden Windows'' is an extension of Robert Wilson's visual and sonic explorations of theatrical outer space and also a venture into what is, for him, a less familiar realm of introspection. With its formal structure, the piece is the nearest he has come to creating a play for actors. But before one rushes to an unjustified conclusion, it must be said that the work is definably Wilson. It is a stream of impressions, with no story line, character development or single incontrovertible explication. Present, in cameo form, are the artist's signatures - the stop-time pace, the repetition, the sudden, seemingly contradictory alteration of images.

title: COMINGS AND GOINGS
description: A day after the former Syracuse star Tony (Red) Bruin's arrest for possession and sale of cocaine, the school announced that it would begin mandatory drug testing for all its athletes during the fall semester of 1986. . . . Bernie Kosar will be the starting quarterback for Cleveland today when the Browns play Pittsburgh because the other Cleveland quarterback, Gary Danielson, has a sore shoulder. . . . The Montreal Expos signed their No. 1 draft pick from last June, Pete Incaviglia, then, at his request, traded him to the Texas Rangers for Jim Anderson, an infielder, and Bob Sebra, a pitcher. Incaviglia hit a collegiate record 48 home runs at Oklahoma State last season.

title: LOWER FARES IN THE AIR
description: Hijackings, accidents and even hurricanes have created a downdraft on airline traffic - and, perhaps, on fares, too.

title: LAY OF THE LAND
description: To the Editor: ''Getting the Lay of the Land'' evoked two separate experiences for me.

title: OTHER CANDIDATES IN THE RACE TO BE THE GOVERNOR OF JERSEY
description: Although the campaign for governor in New Jersey has focused on two men, Peter Shapiro, the Democrat, and Thomas H. Kean, the incumbent Republican, five other candidates, four men and a woman, are on the ballot for Tuesday's election.

title: FORDHAM TOPS IONA
description: Scott Atkinson threw a 19-yard touchdown pass to John Mazzella in the second quarter and Paul Genzburg scored from 2 yards out in the same period yesterday to give Fordham its fifth straight victory, 21-6, over Iona in a Liberty Conference game at Jack Coffey Field in the Bronx.

title: THE ASIA SOCIETY
description: Among the institutions that cater to the Orientalist, the largest and most comprehensive is the Asia Society, housed in a building recently designed by Edward Larrabee Barnes at 725 Park Avenue, at 70th Street (288-6400). The society was a particular favorite of the late John D. Rockefeller 3d and Mrs. Rockefeller, and their collection, which was formed during travels in many parts of Asia, is the mainstay of the exhibition galleries.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: The Devil in the Classroom: Hostility in American Education. By James Marshall. (Schocken, $15.95.)The education reform movement that began sweeping the country several years ago has increased resources (like teacher salaries) and defined higher standards (like courses required for a diploma).

title: NUE SPELING
description: To the Editor:

title: KINGIN IN VIENNA, HUNTING IN SPAIN
description: Gala of Stars In Vienna Next year, for the first time, the ''Gala of Stars'' concert on public television is taking wing. It is off to Vienna. There - with James Levine conducting the Vienna Philharmonic and Beverly Sills welcoming the audience -the Vienna State Opera will be the site of a night of song by such artists as Kathleen Battle, Mirella Freni, Alfredo Kraus, Christa Ludwig, Hermann Prey and others.

title: HUSSEIN AND PERES STRUGGLE TO GET THERI ALLIES IN LINE
description: If Prime Minister Shimon Peres of Israel and King Hussein of Jordan are to achieve peace in the Middle East, or even sit down to discuss it, they will first have to bring their political allies into line. Last week, Mr. Peres seemed to be doing better at that than the King, although the coalition over which the Prime Minister presides continued shaky.

title: A STEP CLOSER
description: Last month, President Reagan nominated James L. Buckley, the former Republican-Conservative Senator from New York and the director of Radio Free Europe-Radio Liberty, to become judge on the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia. But several senators said they would vote against his nomination, although the Senate Judiciary Committee approved it last week.

title: ELIZABETH WILSON PLANNING TO WED
description: Elizabeth Larkin Wilson, a manager of corporate development at the Penn Central Corporation in Greenwich, Conn., and George Walton Taliaferro Jr., vice president and general counsel of the TER Industries Corporation, a holding and management company in New York, plan to be married next month.

title: THE MAYOR FOR MAYOR
description: And now for the anticlimax, New York City's general election Tuesday. While minor party candidates litter the ground, Mayor Koch bestrides the city. We endorse him; only the fear that no one will bother to vote casts a shadow of doubt on the outcome. The one issue of note concerns the behavior of the Republicans, making them an even more minor party.

title: PEBBLES IN RALLY
description: Pebbles, the English filly who drinks a pint of stout every morning and went to the post in the company of a British gelding she has a crush on, overcame a poor start and traffic trouble to beat the boys by a neck.

title: ROBERT S. WEST, EXECUTIVE, AND MINDY S. ROSS MARRY
description: Mindy S. Ross, a daughter of Mrs. William Ross of Fort Lee, N.J., and Palm Beach, Fla., and the late Mr. Ross, was married yesterday to Robert S. West, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Morton A. West of New York. Rabbi Arnold S. Turetsky performed the ceremony at the Metropolis Country Club in White Plains.

title: Air Today, Gone Tomorrow
description: TWENTY-SEVEN years ago in Maine I purchased a sealed bottle of the local air and brought it home. There, a close relative took advantage of my absence to break the seal and inhale it.

title: WRONGS ALLEGED IN RIGHTS STUDY
description: The United States Commission on Civil Rights often reaches controversial conclusions, but the panel says it bases them on rigorous and objective research. Last week a University of Chicago professor who helped monitor a Federal study on school desegregation challenged that contention.

title: WENDY FREENCH IS WED TO IAN BULLOCK CARVER
description: Wendy French, a daughter of Mrs. Frank Rhodes of Easton, Md., and Arthur French 2d of Summit, N.J., was married yesterday to Ian Bullock Carver, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard P. Carver of Greenwich, Conn. The Very Rev. Mark Sullivan performed the ceremony at the Trinity Episcopal Cathedral, of which he is the dean, in Easton.

title: IN SOVIET, MAN ON THE STREET IS HOPEFUL ON SUMMIT RESULTS
description: Soviet television took to the streets today to ask people who were described as average men and women what they expect from the Geneva summit meeting and what they think about human rights in their country.

title: CENTER FOR AFRICAN ART
description: The best thing to happen in the field of so-called primitive art is the new Center for African Art (861-1200), which occupies a pair of converted town houses at 54 East 68th Street.

title: LIESEL FRIEDRICH PLANS TO WED JAMES LUCAS
description: Mr. and Mrs. Otto Friedrich of Locust Valley, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Liesel C. Friedrich to James Bruno Lucas, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James Lucas of Houston. The wedding is to be Dec. 21.

title: PEER PEDERSEN JR. WEDS MISS QUICK
description: Mary Elizabeth Quick, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leslie C. Quick Jr. of Palm Beach, Fla., and Laurel Hollow, L.I., was married yesterday to Peer Terrill Pedersen Jr., son of Lucy Schaefer Pedersen and Mr. Pedersen, both of Rye, N.Y. The ceremony was performed by Msgr. James Collins at St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church in Manhattan.

title: THE ROSEMARY
description: Don't expect an art house.

title: FOR POSTAL WORKERS, LESSONS IN SEEING THE CUSTOMER'S SIDE
description: The United States Postal Service is sending postal workers to classes in an effort to eliminate their reputation for sullenness and train them to be courteous even to customers who become surly while waiting in line.

title: TALE OF A FACADE
description: Passers-by have been startled recently to see workmen bricking up windows and removing decorative details from a graceful neo-Georgian building at 823 Madison Avenue between 68th and 69th Streets that is protected by the Upper East Side Historic District.

title: TARA B. FLANNERY TO MARRY A LAW STUDENT
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph J. Flannery of Palm Beach, Fla., have announced that their daughter Tara Bridget Flannery and Francis X. Gallagher Jr., a son of Mrs. Joseph T. Michels of Baltimore and the late Mr. Gallagher, are to be married Nov. 23.

title: BEAUTY CULTURE
description: To the Editor: I have washed, set and dried my own hair in bathrooms from Paris to Katmandu. However, I did make an unforgettable exception one afternoon in China.

title: KATHERINE REYNOLDS MARRIED
description: Katherine Louise Reynolds, a daughter of Sally Owen Reynolds and Richard Samuel Reynolds 3d, both of Richmond, was married there yesterday to George Paul Barsness, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Erling Ormseth Barsness of Ligonier, Pa. The Rev. Benjamin O. Sparks performed the ceremony in the Second Presbyterian Church.

title: Nothing to Fear In Bilingualism
description: Xenophobia means ''fear of strangers.'' Helen Bennett's article, ''Strength Comes From One Language'' [Opinion page, Sept. 22] , condemning the use of Spanish on absentee ballots illustrates this feeling. Her dread of an impending bilingualism borders on xenophobia.

title: Pavin Triumphs to Aid U.S. Lead in Japan Golf
description: Corey Pavin of the United States shot a 5-under-par 67 today for a 54-hole total of 205 and built a three-stroke lead in the $203,330 ABC Cup Japan-United States golf match.

title: Guyana Elections Scheduled for Dec. 9
description: Guyana will conduct general elections Dec. 9, four months ahead of schedule, President Hugh Desmond Hoyte announced.

title:
ART;

PHOTOS THAT SHOW GLAMOUR AND GRIT
description: A PAIR of photography exhibitions that could not be more in contrast are at the University of Bridgeport's Carlson Gallery to Nov. 10. Taken together, the shows reveal both the bright and the dark faces of contemporary American life.

title: TALKS ARE CONCLUDED ON INDIAN CONCERNS IN AMERICAN NATIONS
description: An inter-American governmental convention on Indian issues ended here today after five days of debate over the role of independent groups in framing national policies toward Indians.

title: CHILD SURVIVAL THEME
description: The United Nations Postal Administration will issue a set of six stamps Nov. 22 on the theme of child survival.

title: FOSS AND THE BROOKLYN PHILHARMONIC INNOVATE AND 'HAVE A GRAND TIME'
description: ''THE Brooklyn Philharmonic is an orchestra that could only be possible in New York,'' Lukas Foss said. ''It's a collection of superb soloists and chamber musicians who get together a few times a year and have a grand time.''

title: The Mind of The President
description: Those who question President Reagan's intellectual capacity fail to recognize, as an attribute of intelligence, the ability to judge which matters the President should plumb deeply and which matters he should leave to others.

title: U.S. STUDIES BAN ON FLIGHTS IN GRAND CANYON
description: Voices that once were lowered in the cathedral-like Grand Canyon are now pitched in debate over whether aircraft should be banned below its rim.

title: HOLIDAY TOASTS TO TRADITION
description: IF THERE IS A TIME OF YEAR IN THE CITY when people of all backgrounds return to the folds of their ethnic identity, it is winter, when the spirit of such holidays as Christmas and Hanukkah, Chinese New Year and the Greek Orthodox celebration of St. Basil's Day envelops New Yorkers in a sentimental and religious return to their roots.

title: 4TH-PLACE FINALE FOR CHIEF'S CROWN
description: Chief's Crown, the star of the show, made a puzzling and perhaps costly exit yesterday as he closed his racing career by running fourth in the $3 million Breeders' Cup Classic at Aqueduct.

title: Philippine Fire Destroys Hotel for U.S. Personnel
description: A six-hour fire destroyed a hotel that housed United States Air Force personnel and their families today, but Filipino and American officials said there were no casualties.

title: PRECISIONIST WINS
description: Ross Fenstermaker was as much a star as Precisionist as the 46-year-old trainer brought the 4-year-old colt back from a 19-week layoff to win in the sensational time of 1:08 2/5 for six furlongs. Smile finished a gutsy second and favored Mt. Livermore tired a bit to finish third.

title: THE CONNAUGHT
description: To the Editor: After reading about experiences at Claridge's in the Letters column of Sept. 22, I would like to add an anecdote for those who remember the other, equally well-known British treasure, the Connaught Hotel. Remember, that is, the war years in London.

title: FEMALE KICKER IS CUT
description: Jacqueline Lantz, the Yonkers high school junior who waged a court battle to play on her school's junior varsity football team, has been benched.

title: POLICE AGENCIES SEEK WAYS TO AVOID CITIZENS' LAWSUITS
description: Law-enforcement officials from six Northeastern states gathered at a seminar here last week to discuss ways of keeping their agencies from being sued.

title: POP: RED HOT CHILI PEPPERS
description: IF the Red Hot Chili Peppers had an iota of originality or intelligence, they might make great dance music. The Hollywood-based band, who performed Thursday at the Ritz (119 East 11th Street), command some of the funk basics - a stomping rhythm section, a defiant attitude and a taste for noise.

title: WAYNE SHORTER: JAZZ ARTIST MAKES HIS 'MAN MOVE'
description: ''I'm a later bloomer,'' the influential, elusive and somewhat enigmatic saxophonist and composer Wayne Shorter cheerfully admitted the other day.

title: MARIA CALLAS RECORDINGS INSPIRE A WEST GERMAN DANCE WORK
description: ''Callas'' comes to Lepercq Space of the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Tuesday for an engagement that will run through next Sunday. No, it is not a play about the celebrated soprano, but a full-evening performance work presented by the Dance Theater of Bremen, West Germany. Maria Callas's voice will be heard, however, as the sound track for the choreography of the Bremen director, Reinhild Hoffmann.

title: CONSUMER RATES
OCEAN CITY FACING VOTE ON BLUE LAWS
description: VOTERS here will decide in a referendum Tuesday whether they want a sharply divided municipal administration to try to restore the city's Sunday blue law.

title: 3 DIE IN WEST COAST MUD SLIDE
description: Rescuers dug with their bare hands early today to save a man trapped in the wreckage of a mobile home buried by a mud slide near a Cascade Mountain river. The bodies of two women and a man were later found in the debris.

title: THE HIGH COST OF FIGHTING OUR 'CONTRAS'
description: To the Editor:

title: A NEW ACT TAKES OVER AT POLYGRAM
description: AT Polygram Records Inc., there are 33Y revolutions per minute. At least, that is how it has looked in the last few years. Polygram has redrawn its organization chart countless times. It has been in and out of myriad new ventures. It has tried in vain to merge with other record companies. And in the process, it has marched presidents in and out its doors. ''At Polygram,'' said one former employee, ''by the time you learn to pronounce their names, they're gone.''

title: IS BACH THE CLUE TO ELGAR'S ENIGMA?
description: ''The enigma I will not explain,'' Edward Elgar wrote in the program notes for the first performance of his ''Enigma'' Variations. ''Its 'dark saying' must be left unguessed, and I warn you that the apparent connection between the Variations and the Theme is often of the slightest texture. Further, through and over the whole set another and larger theme 'goes' but is not played.''

title: EX-OFFTRACK BETTING AIDE INDICTED IN BUFFALO
description: An Erie County grand jury has indicted the former manager of the Western Regional Off-track Betting Corporation on charges of stealing $27,500 from the upstate betting agency.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;

AN EVENING'S WORK COUNTED IN BRUISES
description: I LOVE boxing movies as intensely as I abhor boxing as a sport. It wasn't always such. As a typical sports-minded youth, the fictional heroes of films like ''Body and Soul,'' ''The Set Up,'' ''The Champion'' and ''Killer McCoy'' served as visual counterparts to the the real lords of the ring - Joe Louis, Rocky Graziano, Sugar Ray Robinson, Willy Pep - whose exploits were either heard on radio or read about in the newspapers the morning after a big match.

title: NINI CUSHING HAS WEDDING
description: Nini Cochrane Cushing, a daughter of Howard G. Cushing Jr. of Newport, R.I., and New York, and Mrs. John P. Jennings of Mill Neck, L.I., and Hamilton, Mass., was married yesterday to Robert K. Marceca, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Marceca of Chatham, Mass. The Rev. Frederick Baldwin performed the Episcopal ceremony at the chapel of St. George's School in Newport.

title: Miners Strike in Tunisia
description: Striking Tunisian workers today paralyzed a key phosphate mining region for a second day, a union spokesman said. The stoppage on the second and final day of a general strike in the south central Gafsa region was 95 percent successful in the mines, where some 12,000 people work, the spokesman said.

title: NYERERE STEPS DOWN BUT KEEPS HIS HAND IN
description: Everybody seemed to be saying goodbye last week. President Julius K. Nyerere, who is retiring as President Tuesday after 20 years in office, met with judges, was feted by the Chamber of Merchants and given three dairy cows, a lion skin and ''assorted household items'' by various women's organizations. Prime Minister Salim Ahmed Salim, who is also leaving office, received a gold watch from the City Council. Several ministers were seen clearing out their desks while others were said to be lobbying for reappointment.

title: 'City of Glass'
description: In Paul Auster's remarkable ''City of Glass,'' the ostensible mystery drives from the book's odd and often strangely humorous working of the detective novel genre. The real mystery, however, is one of confused character identity, the descent of a writer into a laby-rinth in which fact and fiction become increasingly difficult to separate. The city of the title is New York, the only truly constant character in the book, and it is the fate of this city to be walked through and interpreted by the writer Quinn and the philosopher and former convict Stillman. Quinn has been hired to follow Stillman, to prevent him from murdering his son. In the beginning the city is transparent, a place of light and air in which Quinn can stay outside of his mind's tortured concerns, concentrating on neutral details. Later is is reminiscent of that wasted city in Nathanael West's ''Miss Lonelyhearts,'' a place begging for interpretation and order. Always its reflects Quinn's and Stillman's search for arcane truth or psychological peace.

title: Taiwan Mine Cave-In Kills 2
description: Two miners were killed today and 11 injured in a cave-in at a coal mine about 12 miles north of Taipei, the police said. They said the accident occurred at the Fu Chi coal mine at Chitu when a mine car ran out of control and hit steel arch supports, causing a cave-in and killing a 50-year-old worker. Ong Chang-chun, vice president of Fu Chi, said a second worker died on his way to a hospital.

title: Stamps of Presidents Due
description: A series of miniature sheets of commemorative stamps featuring the White House and the 35 Presidents who have died will be issued by the Postal Service next year.

title: MAYORAL RACES TOP TUESDAY'S BALLOTS
description: MAYORS of Connecticut's major cities will be seeking to keep their jobs Tuesday, as voters in 136 municipalities go to the polls in elections for chief executive.

title: TUNNEL REPORT IS CHALLENGED
description: The ink had barely dried last week on a consultant's report about the new 63d Street subway tunnel before transit officials were forced to concede that it may have been based on inadequate information.

title: Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: Senate

title: Cardinals Show What They Lack
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: CANDIDATES' POLITICAL FUTURES ON LINE
description: VOTERS will decide Tuesday whether they want Governor Kean to remain in office for four more years or turn the reins over to Peter Shapiro, the Essex County Executive, who has been the underdog throughout the campaign.

title: SOUNDS OF EXOTIC CULTURES ENTER THE MUSICAL MAINSTREAM
description: Ever since Western explorers ventured out beyond the known limits of civilization, those back home have been fascinated by exotic cultures. In the late 19th century, at the height of colonialism, this fascination had begun to express itself overtly in Western art, so much so that the Museum of Modern Art could mount a whole show last season documenting the influence of ''primitive'' art on the modernists. This influence has continued unabated (except for the disruptions of war) to the present day, and forms the bedrock for any attempt to explain the recent sharp increase in popularity of non-Western music in New York.

title: NEW CHARGES AT FIRST JERSEY
description: Since settling charges of securities-law violations a year ago, Robert E. Brennan, the chairman and owner of First Jersey Securities Inc., has sought to polish the concern's image with a high-profile advertising campaign.

title: MY SON, BEHIND GLASS: WHERE DID WE GO WRONG?
description: THE first time I saw him, he was behind a big glass window. They were watching him closely. I had given birth to him a few hours earlier, and his weight, nearly 10 pounds, had surprised the doctors, so they were checking him for possible problems.

title: MCENROE AND LENDL IN FINAL
description: John McEnroe defeated Boris Becker, 6-3, 6-4, today to reach the final of the $850,000 European Champions Championship.

title: ACCURATE HISTORIES ARE USEFUL
description: DELVING into the history of an old house to determine its date and original architectural style, and to learn something about the family that built it, is becoming increasingly common among owners for both fun and profit.

title: ART DESIGNED TO BE USED
description: A RENEWED esteem for the role of the craftsman who designs prototypes for industrial production is evident in the format of a coming benefit for the American Craft Museum.

title: MAHWAH OFFICES
description: When the Ford Motor Company closed its big assembly plant in Mahwah, N.J., in 1980, it left a gaping hole in the local economy and many people wondered what kinds of enterprises might fill it. One answer is service-oriented businesses.

title: INVITATION TO ETHNIC DANCE
description: Throughout the year on Friday nights, the Ethnic Folk Arts Center (691-9510) offers traditional music and participatory folk dancing from the Balkans and Greece in a large studio space at 179 Varick Street. You can dance to the raucous, bubbly, jazz-crazy sound of klezmer orchestras, which once flourished among the Jewish communities of Eastern Europe, or try lusty steps to the pulse-quickening rhythms of a circle dance.

title: LIMIT IN SIZE OF MULTIHULL SOUGHT FOR '87
description: It has been a frustrating race across the Atlantic Ocean for the three multihull sailboats leading in the Monaco-New York Race. Light winds, the bane of any competitive sailor, have teased skippers who on better days can make their catamarans and trimarans move at speeds approaching 30 knots.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: SOLOISTS IN WAYNE Two of the world's great solo instrumentalists - Richard Stoltzman, clarinet, and Richard Goode, piano -will appear in concert in Wayne Saturday evening.

title: WHO LIVES WHERE
description: A map of New York's ethnic groups resembles a map of the tangled Balkans; it is impossible to account for everyone. This map is based on the latest United States census, material from the Department of City Planning and other demographic data.

title: VIRGINIA TURNURE BECOMES A BRIDE
description: Virginia Romanee Turnure, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael deBurbure Turnure of Salisbury, Conn., was married there yesterday to Jeffrey Bruce Morgan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Bedford Morgan of Syracuse, N.Y., and Palm Beach, Fla. The Rev. Charles Bevan performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church.

title: NUE SPELING
description: To the Editor:

title: WILLIAM C. KEEFE
description: William C. Keefe, retired chairman of the Panhandle Eastern Corporation, died Friday at Twelve Oaks Hospital in Houston after a short illness. Mr. Keefe, who lived in Houston, resided for many years in Bronxville, N.Y. He was 71 years old.

title: ACQUITTALS DEBATED IN L.I. PROSECTOR'S RACE
description: The race for Suffolk County district attorney has heated up in the final week of the campaign, with the challenger's accusing the incumbent of mishandling two recent murder trials.

title: WHEN WINDOW SHADES MISBEHAVE, HERE'S WHAT TO DO
description: WINDOW shades that stick, unroll by themselves or fly up unexpectedly are a nuisance that no one needs to tolerate. Repairs are almost always simple, involving no special tools or skills.

title: EXPLORING SOHO ON FOOT
description: Soho is an enigmatic place, vital to the rich taste of London but detached from the surrounding metropolis, indeed from surrounding England. Soho is the epicurean's mecca, exuding from her foreign character a certain sensuous nuance. One is drawn in to be sated, to breathe in the dissident scents and rhythms of lasciviousness: of gastronomic pleasures by day, of other pleasures by night.

title: FARM TO CITY: A WAY OF LIFE
description: TED AND SUSAN BLEW MAKE FARMING A FAMILY AFFAIR. With their daughter, Charity, 6 years old, and their son, Eric, 3, they work a 160 acre farm in Pittstown, N.J. raising hogs, produce and grain. they sell their harvest at the greenmarket at Union Square on Wednesdays and Saturdays and at the World Trade Center on Tuesdays and Thursdays.

title: LEGAL CONFERENCE AT HOFSTRA TO EXAMINE BURGER'S COURT
description: Judicial officials and experts from nearly 20 countries will participate in a conference at the Hofstra University School of Law this week that will examine the United States Supreme Court's performance in the 16 years since Warren E. Burger was appointed Chief Justice.

title: HEATED WORDS OVER-ON-AGAIN, OFF-AGAIN SEAMAN
description: United States authorities returned to a Soviet freighter last week for the third time a sailor who seemed confused - and confusing - about an offer to remain in this country.

title: FURTHERING SALMON CONSERVATION
description: IF you would like to rub elbows with some of the world's most dedicated fly fishermen and at the same time aid the ongoing effort to improve the lot of the world's most highly-prized food and game fish, the Atlantic Salmon Federation's third annual fund raising dinner at Manhattan's Plaza Hotel on Nov. 21 offers such an opportunity.

title: ROCK MUSIC MAY BE ANTI-EDUCATIONAL
description: Would you be surprised to be told that a strong connection may be drawn between this generation's embrace of rock music and the revival of interest in fundamental religion? I confess that the possibility of a link did not occur to me until I read a paper in which Dennis O'Brien, the president of the University of Rochester, pointed out striking parallels in the two phenomena. An associate of his at the university, responding to my recent article about this generation's loss of interest in borrowing tunes from the classics, sent along a copy of a speech that Mr. O'Brien gave at Lycoming College in Williamsport, Pa., in 1980. Somehow it escaped my notice at the time, as Lycoming College is not on my regular beat, and perhaps it escaped yours as well. If so, pay attention. The O'Brien theory is a stimulating one that may help illuminate some hitherto dark mysteries.

title: Charles Mundy Edwards, 82; Ex-Dean of N.Y.U. Retailing
description: Charles Mundy Edwards Jr., dean of retailing at New York University for 24 years, died Thursday after a brief illness. He was 82 years old and lived in Summit, N.J.

title: RECRUITS TRAIN FOR TROUBLE
description: FROM riots to rescues, a police officer never knows what he or she may face in a day's work. The key, the new class of recruits at the Nassau County Police Academy is learning, is to be ready for anything.

title: PUZZLING OUT THE IMPACE OF EAST SIDE DOWNZONING
description: IN the last six weeks, Manhattan's Upper East Side has become a jigsaw puzzle as developers, city agencies and institutions pore over plans and proposals to see which pieces may or may not fit into the area's new zoning.

title: ILENE GOLD TO MARRY
description: Mr. and Mrs. Murray Gold of Kings Point, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ilene Joy Gold, to Laurent David Bensoussan, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Simon J. Bensoussan of Paris and Raanana, Israel. A May wedding is planned. The future bride is the president of Atrix International, an advertising concern in New York. Mr. Bensoussan is the manager of market analysis and financial subsystems for Club Med in New York.

title: MIAMI OVERCOMES FLORIDA STATE, 35-27
description: Vinny Testaverde passed for 339 yards and four touchdowns, including fourth-quarter scores to Mike Irvin and Brett Perriman, to rally Miami to a 35-27 victory over Florida State today. The triumph was the seventh straight for Miami (7-1). Florida State fell to 6-2.

title: First 5 Bodies Are Found In Utah Coal Mine
description: The bodies of five of the 27 miners who died in a coal mine fire last year were found by crews who entered the early today, an official said.

title: LORRAINE B. KUHN WEDS STEPHEN Q. BRANSON
description: At St. Catharine's Roman Catholic Church in Blauvelt, N.Y., yesterday Lorraine Bernadette Kuhn, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene P. Kuhn of West Nyack, N.Y., was married to Stephen Quill Branson, a son of James T. Branson Jr., of Chevy Chase, Md., and the late Joan Crowley Branson. The Rev. Dennis S. Fernandes performed the ceremony Ann Kuhn Levitan was her sister's matron of honor.

title: GREEN LIGHT FOR RAIL RUN
description: THE resumption of passenger train service between Philadelphia and Atlantic City, for a time considered all but lost on a bureaucratic siding, is firmly back on track.

title: A NEW YORKER'S NEW TEAM
description: I HAVE come to realize that being a New Yorker is not something one can take for granted. What comes so naturally in New York is suddenly endangered outside the city. I've recently been doing battle for my birthright in Ann Arbor, Mich., where I arrived, after 17 years in New York, to attend the University of Michigan. Mixed with the excitement (and fear, don't let any college brochure tell you differently) of being a freshman was a sense of loss. Yes, being away from family and friends would be hard, but nothing compared with the longing I felt for my teams.

title: DANCE
description: Debuts and returns are coming. Perhaps the most important of the debuts is the first New York visit by Italy's Aterballetto (Brooklyn College, Saturday night and next Sunday afternoon).

title: RAIL SAFETY CAMPAIGN IS NO LONGER SPINNING WHEELS
description: Three years ago this fall, a 101-car freight train laden with poisonous chemicals derailed as it sped through the hamlet of Livingston, La.

title: DOCUMENTARIES: LIMITLESS EYES, RECORDING CIVILIZATION
description: John Grierson, sometimes called ''the father of the English documentary film,'' defined the form as ''the creative treatment of actuality.'' Paul Rotha, longtime friend and associate of Mr. Grierson, insisted it was something more, that is, ''the use of the film medium to interpret creatively and in social terms the life of the people as it exists in reality.''

title: WITCH VERSUS DOCTOR
description: THE ROYAL HUNT, By D. R. Popescu. Translated by J.E. Cottrell and M. Bogdan. 174pp. Columbus: Ohio State Univeristy Press. $14.95.

title: FUND FOR ORGAN PATIENTS' KIN
description: FAMILIES of transplant patients at Hartford Hospital soon will have the costs of baby-sitting, gasoline and even a dinner out paid by concerned hospital employees who want to bolster the family's morale.

title: IS HUMPHREY GIVING WHALES A BAD NAME, OR DOES HE HAVE ONE?
description: It's hard to imagine anything more frustrating to a Californian than a whale reluctant to be saved. But ever since a humpback admirers named Humphrey swam into San Francisco Bay and up the Sacramento River three weeks ago, the efforts of would-be rescuers have been thwarted.

title:
ANTIQUES;

CHAIRS FOR CONNECTICUT'S 'ELITE'
description: AN EXHIBIT of 63 chairs made in Connecticut Queen Anne and Chippendale styles for well-to-do New London County families - the ''provincial elite,'' to give them the name used by the Connecticut Historical Society - is on display at that museum now through Dec. 26.

title: THE GAME POSES A TRICKY QUESTION
description: The Nimzovich Memorial Tournament, held in Naestved, Denmark, to mark the 50th anniversary of the death of Aron Nimzovich, the great Latvian-Danish player, theoretician and teacher, ended in a tie for first place among Walter Browne of Berkeley, Calif., Bent Larsen of Denmark and Rafael Vaganian of the Soviet Union. Each scored 6 1/2-4 1/2 in the all-grandmaster event.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: Second Brother. By David Guy. (NAL, $14.95.)Henry Wilder is running his paper route in Pittsburgh the summer before he goes into the eighth grade.

title: KATHERINE THE GREATEST
description: A REMARKABLE WOMAN: A Biography of Katharine Hepburn. By Anne Edwards. Illustrated. 512pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $18.95.

title: OPERETTA INSPIRES A PRIMA DONNA
description: MENTION the composer Franz Lehar, the conductor Bruno Walter or the pianist Arthur Rubinstein - she knew them all well. Recall the demolition of the Savoy Plaza Hotel in Manhattan, where she once lived, or the Paramount Theater on Broadway, where she performed. All these topics make the soprano Marta Eggerth speak wistfully of days gone by.

title: EXPANSION VICTIMS: 11 BAGS OF DREAMS
description: THERE was no doubt that we were doing the right thing: We both use computers for our livelihoods; we needed space for a computer, and all available space in our apartment was taken. Something had to go.

title: IN SEARCH OF THE ABSOLUTE NOVEL
description: THE SLEEPWALKERS By Hermann Broch. Translated by Willa and Edwin Muir. 648 pp. San Fransisco: North Point Press. Paper, $15.50.

title: FREED RUSSIANS TELL OF BEIRUT CAPTIVITY
description: Three Russian officials released from captivity in Beirut this week were quoted today as saying that they were held blindfolded and incommunicado for an entire month and that they were not aware until their release that a fourth hostage had been killed.

title:
FARE OF THE COUNTRY;

IN KYOTO, GREETINGS FOR EACH SEASON
description: There is probably no other culture in which the changing seasons are so sensitively and fully celebrated, both in life and in art, as in that of Japan. The association of a particular place with the beauties of a certain season is described in Japan's earliest poetry, and the customs that grew out of this sensibility are still very much in evidence.

title: 20 Drunken Driving Arrests
description: Twenty people were charged with drunken driving or driving while ability impaired on the Bronx River Parkway overnight Friday, the Westchester County police said today. About 1,650 cars were stopped at checkpoints half a mile north of the Bronx. Since December 1982, about 1,000 drivers have been arrested in similar sweeps.

title: RECENT RELEASES
description: Black Beauty Starring Mark Lester and Walter Slezak; directed by James Hill, 1971 Paramount Home Video 106 minutes. $29.95 Romantic permutations have made it easy to forget that Anna Sewell's novel ''Black Beauty'' was a fierce Victorian argument for humane treatment of animals that focused on the adventures and mistreatment of a beautiful horse.

title: JERSEY AGENCY EXTENDS 10.7 % MORTGAGE PLAN
description: The New Jersey Housing and Mortgage Finance Agency has extended its low-interest mortgage program for an additional five months.

title: RECENT RELEASES
description: Phil Collins Live at Perkins Palace Thorn/EMI Video 60 minutes. $29.95 The singer-drummer Phil Collins comes from an English art-rock background and writes ballads steeped in romantic agony.

title: RAKING IN BILLIONS FROM THE COMPANY PENSION PLAN
description: DURING the final years of his sojourn as a pilot with United Airlines, B. Kirke Watkins eagerly awaited pension time. When the date finally arrived last year, he pulled up stakes in Seattle and headed for balmy Vero Beach, Fla. Now, only 16 months into retirement, Mr. Watkins is finding that a life of tennis and swimming in the sun on a United Airlines pension is not always carefree.

title: Oral Roberts U. Law School To Be Transferred to Virginia
description: The Rev. Oral Roberts announced Friday that the law school at Oral Roberts University would be transferred to CBN University in Virginia Beach, Va.

title: NEW HAVEN INVESTMENT FOR WOMEN ONLY
description: SINCE Shirlee Schaffer made public her idea of a women's entrepreneurial movement to buy the old Edw. Malley store in downtown New Haven, she has got hundreds of phone calls.

title: Playing In Peoria
description: As I read ''Playing in Pretoria'' (On Language, Sept. 29), it became apparent that John D. Ehrlichman has been up to his old tricks again, and has misled William Safire by taking credit for coining the phrase ''play in Peoria,'' while he was a member of the Nixon inner circle.

title: BARBARA GOLDSMITH WED TO DR. MICHAEL SCHACTER
description: Barbara E. Goldsmith, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Goldsmith of Cedarhurst, L.I., was married yesterday to Dr. Michael A. Schacter, the son of Dr. and Mrs. William Schacter of Peekskill, N.Y., and Lauderhill, Fla.

title: 5 in Iran Killed in Kurdistan
description: The prayer leader of a small town in Iranian Kurdistan and four other people were shot dead while traveling in a car, the official Iranian press agency said today. The agency, monitored in Nicosia, accused ''antirevolutionary'' elements of the shooting. The agency said Hojatolislam Essa Tavasoli, prayer leader of Farokhshah in the Chaharmahal-Bakhtiari area, was on his way to the Iran-Iraq war front Thursday when the shooting occurred.

title: JEWELS THAT SHONE IN THE DARK AGES
description: What the Romans viewed as crude and garish seems robust, exotic and definitely appealing in the late 20th century, as can be appreciated in ''Jewels of the Barbarians: A Dark Ages Treasury,'' an exhibition at the Michael Ward Gallery, 9 East 93d Street, through Dec. 14. Jewelry enthusiasts today, be they collectors or followers of the latest in fashion, admire primitive and highly expressive necklaces and earrings that are far closer in spirit to what was worn by the conquering hordes from the fifth century on than they are to the exquisitely refined classical adornments relished by the vanquished Romans.

title: HUTTON ACCUSED OF OVERCHARGING
description: Since pleading guilty last spring to 2,000 counts of mail and wire fraud, E.F. Hutton, which operates the nation's fifth-largest brokerage house, has come under scrutiny by the New York Stock Exchange, a House judiciary subcommittee, and three Federal as well as numerous state agencies. In a finding last week, the Securities and Exchange Commission said two of E.F. Hutton's mutual funds had overcharged investors and failed to pay all the interest the investors had coming.

title: FOR DROUGHT-STRICKEN NEW YORK, A RAINY NOVEMBER IS CONSIDERED CRUCIAL
description: When it comes to the city's water supply, all eyes these days are on the skies of November.

title: PATRIOTS THRIVING WITH GROGAN BACK
description: In 1982, the season split by the strike, Steve Grogan played well enough to lead the New England Patriots to four victories in their last six games and a berth in the Super Bowl tournament.

title: FIRST THINGS FIRST AT THE SUMMIT
description: As the date of the summit meeting approaches, the world public is being assailed by high-level statements from both great powers designed to set the stage for the event. The statements coming from the Soviet side have generally been greeted in Washington with scorn and disbelief.

title: SCREEN: 'DEATH WISH'
description: Being a close friend or relation of Paul Kersey, the sometime architect and protagonist of the ''Death Wish'' movies, is a no-win proposition. Not only are you bound to get killed, but it is certain to be a very unpleasant death, and it may come very early in the show. At best, like Deborah Raffin in ''Death Wish 3,'' you may just have time to take off your glasses and get in a bit of sex before you go up in flames.

title: BROADWAY'S NEW PRODUCERS TRY TO REWRITE THEIR PARTS
description: Where, Broadway wondered only a season or two ago, were the aspiring young producers, the new blood for what was becoming an older gentleman's enterprise?

title: 1,200 HOUSING UNITS PROPOSED FOR AGED
description: A KENTUCKY company has proposed a $100 million project to build a total of 1,200 units of housing for the elderly in several Connecticut cities, with most of the units aimed for New Haven, Bridgeport, Waterbury and Hartford.

title: CAMPUS IN CONNECTICUT GETS NEW NAME AND NEW VITALITY
description: Atop a rural hill here, the former University of Connecticut branch campus looks much as it did last year. But two things have changed: its name and its future.

title: SUSAN RODRIQUEZ PLANNING TO WED C. F. LOWREY JR.
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. J. Paul Rodriquez of Darien, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter, Susan Therese Rodriquez, to Charles Frederick Lowrey Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Lowrey of San Francisco. A February wedding is planned.

title: Police in Soweto Say Blacks Shot at Them
description: The police reported a rare gunfight with armed blacks in Soweto today, the huge black township near Johannesburg.

title: A Myopic Form Of Patriotism
description: To insist on an English-only policy for the United States, as did Helen Bennett [''Strength Comes From One Language,'' Sept. 22] , is to promote a distinctly myopic form of patriotism. A survey of history would not support her argument.

title: ART IN WESTNYACK
description: An exhibition of 120 prints by 60 artists will open at 1 P.M. today at the Rockland Center for the Arts in West Nyack, N.Y., and will continue through Nov. 23. Admission is free. The number for information is (914) 358-0877. The gallery is open seven days a week from 9 A.M. to 5 P.M.

title: EGGS SARDOU
description: WHEN A DISH IS MENTIONED IN THIS COLUMN, HOWEVER casually, readers almost invariably request precise instructions for its preparation. Not long ago, we noted in passing that a specialty of the restaurants of New Orleans is a poached-egg dish called eggs Sardou. It is named for the French playwright Victorien Sardou (1831-1908), who is best known as the author of ''La Tosca,'' the play on which Puccini's opera was based. It is a lesser-known fact that Sardou traveled in America and wrote a satire on the country entitled ''L'Oncle Sam.'' Presumably, it was during these travels that he visited New Orleans and was entertained at Antoine's Restaurant. The owner, Antoine Alciatore, created the egg dish in his honor.

title: AVAST! IT'S A PIRATE'S BOOTY
description: A thick layer of corrosion was carefully chipped off a bronze ship's bell last week to confirm the identity of a legendary pirate vessel that went to the bottom off Wellfleet, on Cape Cod, in 1717, laden, perhaps, with hundreds of millions of dollars in gold and other booty.

title: A SMITHSONIAN MUSEUM TO GET NEW DIRECTOR
description: Robert S. Hoffmann, an authority on mammals, has been named director of the Smithsonian Institution's National Museum of Natural History.

title: THOUGH EVERY RUSE WAS TRIED, A WOODCHUCK WINS AGAIN
description: My story, like lots of guys' stories, is about getting too involved with a beautiful tomato. I'm not talking about infatuation or lust; I'm telling you I was ready to kill.

title: BEST SELLERS
description: FICTION

title: KHAN-TALBOTT SQUASH FINAL
description: Fifth-seeded Steve Bowditch of West Germany upset third-ranked Mario Sanchez of Mexico City yesterday at the $45,000 Chivas Regal Squash Open at the Hunter College Sportsplex. The scores were 15-12, 8-15, 15-12, 15-12.

title: BINOCULAR OBJECT
description: Sooner than many of us expected, Halley's Comet ''will be in a very favorable position, two degrees south of the star cluster Pleiades, high in the sky where there is not much light pollution,'' according to Rick Dilsizian, assistant professor of mathematics and computer science at Westchester Community College in Valhalla. He is organizing a Comet Skywatch from 10 P.M. to 12:30 A.M. Nov. 16, when the public may look through six or more telescopes ranged around the mall of the college's Technology Building and see ''what will look like a fuzzy little blob,'' Mr. Dilsizian said, ''sufficiently bright to be a binocular object.''

title: Business School
description: To the Editor:

title: BOND ISSUES SOUGHT FOR ENVIRONMENT
description: ALTHOUGH the debate over toxic-waste cleanup may help some voters make up their minds about whom they will support for Governor, other environmental programs will be vying for voter support on Tuesday.

title: WHY REFERENDUMS FIND IT TOUGH IN NEW YORK
description: The posters urging New Yorkers to ''keep our city free of nuclear weapons'' still hung from dozens of lamp posts at the end of the week, but the words ''Democracy denied'' had been pasted across them.

title: Zaslofsky Shot Is Recollected
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: LUCK THAT SEEMS LIKE TORTURE
description: THE CITY OF JOY By Dominique Lapierre Translated by Kathryn Spink. 464 pp. New York: Doubleday & Company. $17.95.

title: HOW ECONOMIC POLICY HAS GONE AWRY...
description: Last month, Franco Modigliani was awarded the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science, an honor that many economists regarded as inevitable. His research in corporate finance, monetary policy and savings cycles has laid the groundwork for much of modern economics. Last week, Kyle Crichton, editor of the Business Forum, talked with the 67-year-old Nobel laureate in his office at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. Q. What was the reaction in your native Italy when you won the Nobel Prize? A. In Italy, they just went wild. I am well known there - I speak out on public issues. I had telegrams from the top echelons of the Government, from the President of the Republic on down. Q. Despite your prominence, you have never held a major Government post. Why not? A. The main reason is that I have been told that if you join the Government, then you cannot criticize the Government - you must support it even when you disagree. I'm not willing to do that. In fact, I resigned as an adviser to the Treasury during the Cambodian invasion, because I didn't want to advise a Government whose policies I disapproved. Q. Looking back on your career, what do you consider your greatest accomplishments? A. I would put at center stage two contributions to macroeconomics. One was the clarification of Keynes's General Theory, in my first major journal article, in 1944. I showed that Keynes's theory of wage rigidity - the notion that wages often fail to rise and fall with economic ups and downs - is what makes Keynesian economics so different from classical economics.

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: PAMELA S. POFF'S creed is to accentuate the positive and, if she can't eliminate the negative, to minimize it.

title: RESEARCH BRINGS FURTHER INPROVEMENT IN TAPES
description: Like the best cooks, they never settle on a recipe.

title: RICHARD SERRA WORKS FIND A WARM WELCOME IN FRANCE
description: This fall in Paris, art has been very much in the public eye. The Picasso Museum triumphantly opened, the public flocked to the flashy and frantic Foire Internationale d'Art Contemporain -the annual art fair better known as F.I.A.C. -and Christo staged his latest spectacle at the Pont Neuf. With less fanfare, but perhaps more significance, on the day Christo began unwrapping the 400-year-old bridge, two large public sculptures by Richard Serra, one vertical and one horizontal, were dedicated by French political and cultural officials.

title: DANCE: JOFFREY BALLET
description: ONE gets into the habit of thinking of the Joffrey Ballet as those kids down the block. The Joffrey dancers' freshness and spirit were evident on Thursday, when the company presented Gerald Arpino's ''Kettentanz,'' a romp through popular dance music by Johann Strauss Sr. and Johann Mayer. But the performance also suggested that there are Joffrey dancers whose presence and technical skills alone are worth a trip to City Center, where the company performs through Nov. 10.

title: HOSPITAL SPONSORS SEAT BELT CAMPAIGN
description: WITH a state law requiring the use of seat belts to go into effect in two months, the New Milford Hospital has started a seat-belt safety campaign that involves posters, radio announcements and postcards being mailed to some 55,000 households in 15 area towns.

title: NUE SPELING
description: To the Editor:

title: JAZZ PIANO: DANNY MIXON
description: DANNY MIXON is a pianist who began making an impression in the late 1960's when he was a teen-ager in Brooklyn, playing jazz in a manner that showed a variety of influences, including a strong feeling for Erroll Garner. In the years since then, he has been a member of Charles Mingus's group, has been Betty Carter's accompanist for four years and has worked his own gigs.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: No Marble Angels. By Joanne Leedom-Ackerman. (Texas Center for Writer's Press, P.O. Box 428, Montrose, Ala. 36559, $13.95)''No Marble Angels'' is a series of nine stories linked by the theme of spearation, spanning such barriers as age, race, sex and class.

title: Walking Bass Calls for Asterisk
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: JOAN ROBIN DUNN BECOMES A BRIDE
description: Joan Robin Dunn, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernerd S. Dunn of Longmeadow, Mass., was married yesterday to Brian Hendrickson of Stamford, Conn., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Roland M. Hendrickson of Darien, Conn. Judge Sidney M. Cooley of the Westfield (Mass.)

title: RAIL MEALS
description: To the Editor: Paul Grimes, in his useful guide to North American rail trips (Practical Traveler, Sept. 1), mentioned that readers should judge for themselves about the quality off Amtrak dining car meals.

title: FAITHFUL, DEVOTED, AND STRONG -- WHAT MORE COULD ONE ASK?
description: I HAVE discovered why men fall in love with their secretaries.

title: TELLING MOMENTS
description: GEOFFREY HOLDER TRINIDAD TAKE ME TO FIFTH AVEnue!'' Geoffrey Holder arrived in New York from Trinidad in 1953, as the choreographer and lead performer of a Caribbean dance troupe that was to audition for Sol Hurok. Just moments after he dropped his bags in the foyer of his Uncle Johnny's apartment on Hancock Street in Brooklyn, he made that first request with such theatrical style it foretold everything that was to come: recognition as a dancer, actor, choreographer, painter, costume and set designer and unabashed romantic.

title: TV SCRIPTWRITER AND NOVELIST
description: David Davidson, a novelist and author of about 100 network television plays, died Friday at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center's Neurological Institute after a stroke. He was 77 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: ERIKA NEWMARK ENGAGED
