description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Stuart Newmark of South Merrick, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter, Erika Newmark, to Scott Gordon, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Gordon of Roslyn, L.I., and Palm Beach, Fla. A June wedding is planned. The bride is an independent fashion consultant and her father is a partner in the New York law firm Taylor, Kimmel, Newmark & Rosenberg. Mr. Gordon is a vice president of Walter Gordon Textiles in New York, which his fatherowns.

title: TASSO POSTS UPSET
description: Tasso, considered only slightly the best of a weak crop of California-based 2-year-olds this year, beat the best talent that New York could muster, edging Storm Cat by a nose.

title: BUDGET-BALANCING PLAN FACES NOV. 15 DEADLINE FOR PASSAGE
description: The House and the Senate, deadlocked over rival proposals for balancing the budget by the end of the decade, face a difficult task when they reconvene Monday to try to reach a compromise before Nov. 15.

title: COMMITTEE VISITS BROWN U. TO WEIGH BLACKS' COMPLAINTS
description: A 16-member committee visited Brown University over the weekend to evaluate the quality of life and education for minority students.

title: MORE THAN JUST A SHRINE
description: I ONCE SAT IN A HOTEL IN Bloomsbury trying to have breakfast alone. A Russian with a habit of compulsively licking his lips asked if he could join me. I was afraid to say no; I thought it might be bad for detente. He explained to me that he was a linguist, and that he always liked to talk to Americans to see if he could make any connection between their speech and their ethnic background. When I told him about my mixed ancestry - my mother is Irish and Italian, my father a Lithuanian Jew - he began jumping up and down in his seat, rubbing his hands together and licking his lips even more frantically.

title: REDISCOVERING HELL'S KITCHEN
description: Browsing the gentrified bones of Hell's Kitchen, a gray-haired man rises up the stairs on West 43d Street, past a glass-walled room full of determined women who huff aerobically in multicolored tights, and finds the comfort of a fern bar and some cold white wine. Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan is back in the old neighborhood, nimble and curious as ever.

title: HOMELESS SIKHS RALLY IN INDIA
description: More than 1,000 impoverished victims of an anti-Sikh riot one year ago by Hindus held a rally today, demanding justice and aid from Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi.

title: AIDE TO ABBAS REPORTED TO HAVE LED ACHILLE LAURO HIJACKING
description: The Italian news agency ANSA said today that Italian investigators believe a senior aide to Mohammed Abbas, the Palestinian official, was aboard the Achille Lauro during the hijacking and directed the seizure of the cruise ship.

title: THE NEW NEW YORKERS
description: THEY BEGIN ARRIVING HOURS EARLY, as they always do, filling the Brooklyn courtroom. A woman in a sari, a man in the black cloak of Hasidism, people in denim and people in silk, faces of every hue from ebony to alabaster - all are assembling to take the oath of citizenship.

title: EQUITY LOANS
description: To the Editor:

title: MISS FOSS PLANS WINTER WEDDING TO BANK OFFICER
description: Mr. and Mrs. Martin Moore Foss Jr. of Darien, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Marna Marlene Foss to George William van der Ploeg, the son of Mr. and Mrs. George William Van der Ploeg of Southington, Conn. A February wedding is planned.

title: U.S. WILLING TO TEST SHOREHAM ACCIDENT PLAN
description: A Federal agency said last week that it was prepared to test a plan to protect Long Island residents in case of an accident at the Shoreham nuclear power plant, even though the agency said such a test would be inconclusive.

title: FAME COMES TO HIM WHO WAITS ON TABLES
description: THE KITCHEN MAN, By Ira Wood. 307pp. Trumansburg, N.Y.: The Crossing Pres. $16.95.

title: MAKING SURE THE SEAMS DON'T SHOW
description: The logistics involved in maintaining a seemingly seamless continuity are complex for any filmed project, but in a massive undertaking such as ''North and South,'' the mini-series that begins this evening at 9 on ABC, the task was particularly daunting. This dramatization of two of John Jakes's novels, ''North and South'' and ''Love and War,'' opens tonight with a two-hour installment, to be followed later this week by an additional 10 hours; a 12-hour sequel, ''North and South, Book II,'' will be presented next spring. In total, the 24-hour mini-series will be the equivalent of a dozen feature films.

title: SCIENTISTS WARN OF EARLIER RISE IN SEA LEVELS
description: Scientists from 29 nations say governments must develop economic and social plans on the assumption that the world's climate will be warmer and its sea levels higher early in the next century.

title: LIFE'S MAGIC SCORES
description: Fillies owned by Eugene V. Klein and trained by D. Wayne Lukas took the top two spots in both the Juvenile Fillies and the Distaff, but in the latter race the intramural finish was not what had been expected. Life's Magic, a 4-year-old who had finished second in last year's Distaff, ran down her more highly regarded 3-year-old stablemate, Lady's Secret, and drew off to romp by 6 1/4 lengths.

title: RENAISSANCE OF A NEGLECTED PLAYWRIGHT
description: One of the most unexpected Broadway hits of the last decade was the 1980 revival of an obscure comedy-drama about the ingrown squabblings of four elderly sisters from a long-lost corner of the American heartland. The play was ''Morning's at Seven,'' written in 1939 by Paul Osborn, whose name hadn't adorned a Broadway marquee for more than 20 years. The rediscovery of that play's distinctive mingling of quirky wit and poignant insight has sparked new curiosity in the rest of Mr. Osborn's long-neglected oeuvre. The result is that he has suddenly, if belatedly, become the most produced playwright of the current theatrical season.

title: 'GRANDMA,' THE WORD UNHEARD
description: I RECEIVED a thank you note today from a friend's daughter for a baby gift. It began, ''Dear Additional Grandma and Grandpa.''

title: PLAN FOR EAST 78TH ST. DRAWS MIXED RESPONSE BY TENANTS
description: Tenants of an Upper East Side block owned by the real-estate developer Peter S. Kalikow expressed skepticism, anger and cautious optimism yesterday over the developer's plan to relocate them in new apartments at the site or to pay them to move.

title: REAGAN RECEPTIVE TO A 50% ARMS CUT
description: President Reagan said today that the United States had accepted a Soviet proposal to cut nuclear arms by 50 percent, but officials made clear that he ''had an entirely different perception'' from the Russians on the nature of such a cut.

title: Soviet Gas
description: To the Editor:

title: HOTEL WAVE IN STAMFORD INSIPIRES TOURISM PUSH
description: FACED with a sudden glut of hotels, business and city leaders here have embarked on a campaign to attract tourists and conventions to fill the empty rooms.

title: LUCIE GUERNSEY, A BANK OFFICER, BECOMES A BRIDE
description: Lucie Love Guernsey, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Taylor Guernsey of Litchfield, Conn., and Edgartown, Mass., was married yesterday to Lewis Charles Kleinhans 3d, the son of Mrs. Melvin B. Twitty of North Palm Beach, Fla., and Rumson, N.J., and the late Mr. Kleinhans. The Rev. Judy Balmer performed the ceremony at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in New York.

title: PANEL ON SIEGE FADES AS ATTRACTION
description: In looking for a place for its hearings on the police confrontation last May with the radical group Move, the investigating commission said it needed a large hall: hundreds of people were expected at each session.

title: VANESSA FUTRELL BECOMES BRIDE OF JOHN M. HARTMAN
description: St. Francis Xavier Roman Catholic Church was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Vanessa A. Futrell, a daughter of Cynthia Futrell of Hollis, Queens, and the late James Futrell, to James M. Hartman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Wayne L. Hartman of Farmingdale, N.J. The Rev. Joseph S. Dirr performed the ceremony.

title: GREENHORN IN SEA GATE
description: I ARRIVED IN NEW YORK IN 1935, IN the time of the Depression. The older people I met in Sea Gate, Brooklyn, where my brother, the writer I. J. Singer, lived during the summer, all spoke about the fortunes they had amassed in the time of the Prosperity and the great losses they had suffered in the Wall Street Crash.

title: CATHY LOUISE GARBER PLANS TO WED CLIFFORD M. SALES
description: Dr. and Mrs. Jerome M. Garber of Old Westbury, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Cathy Louise Garber, to Clifford M. Sales, the son of Beverly Sales of Guttenberg, N.J., and Allan Sales of New York. A June wedding is planned.

title: CORPORATE HEALTH PROGRAMS
description: Wearing a basic blue suit and a million-dollar smile, Tom Cody is a motivated young man in a promising new profession.

title: NUE SPELING
description: To the Editor:

title: PARTIES AROUND TOWN
description: Humanitarian Awards Nov. 5 - United Cerebral Palsy of New York will honor Nancy Reagan and Frank A. Bennack Jr., president of the Hearst Corporation, at its annual humanitarian awards dinner. The dinner is to benefit United Cerebral Palsy, which concentrates on the treatment and other needs of children and adults with cerebral palsy at 21 centers in the city. The black-tie evening starts with cocktails at 6:30 at the Waldorf-Astoria followed by dinner at 8. Tickets, $300 ($350 for preferred seating), from 212-683-6700. Mystery on Fifth Ave. Nov. 5 - Come for lunch in the main reading room of the Public Library on Fifth Avenue at 42d Street and settle in for an afternoon of discussion and readings about mystery and crime, fact and fiction, by some leading practitioners of the genre: Calvin Trillin, Shana Alexander, Mary Higgins Clark, Gregory Mcdonald, Robert B. Parker and Tony Hillerman. Tickets for the library benefit, $75 for members, $110 for others, which includes $35 annual membership fee; from 212-930-0501. Cardinal at B'nai B'rith Nov. 6 - John Cardinal O'Connor will receive the Cardinal Bea Interfaith Award of the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith at a dinner at the Marriott Marquis Hotel starting with cocktails at 6 P.M. The award is named for the late Augustin Cardinal Bea, the Jesuit scholar who was instrumental in framing the ''Nostra Aetate'' declaration of the Second Vatican Council repudiating anti-Semitism. Tickets, $200, from Karen Mann at 212-490-2525, extension 384 or 234.

title: OREGONIANS SEE VINDICATION IN TROUBLES OF GURU
description: As hard times come to Bhagwan Shree Rajneesh and his followers, longtime residents around their commune in eastern Oregon see retribution in the indictments and lawsuits that threaten the commune's foundations.

title: ARMY'S LATE SURGE DOWNS HOLY CROSS
description: Tory Crawford danced and scrambled his way to 134 yards and 2 touchdowns today as Army pulled away from Holy Cross in the fourth quarter to win, 34-12.

title: METAPHYSICAL MYSTERY TOUR
description: CITY OF GLASS The New York Trilogy. Volume One. By paul Auster. 203 pp. Los Angeles: Sun & Moon Press. $13.95.

title: PROUD TRUTH WINS $3 Million Breeders' cup Classic
description: Proud Truth, once the favorite for last spring's Kentucky Derby but fifth in that race and sidelined all summer with an injury, stormed from last place to beat Gate Dancer by a head and win the $3 million Breeders' Cup Classic yesterday in an upset at Aqueduct Race Track.

title: IN PURSUIT OF THE PERFECT INGREDIENT
description: FOR THE COOK WHO loves ethnic food, New York is a vast, rich, fascinating marketplace, where Polish dried mushrooms and Chinese winter melons, Mexican blue cornmeal and Vietnamese nuoc mam (fermented fish sauce) exist side by side in neighborhood markets Successive waves of newcomers have given New York foodways a unique character: Brazilian food may be better in Rio and Chinese food in Hong Kong, but in neither of those cities can you find the tremendous variety, the sheer exuberance, of ethnic food in New York. For a WASP like me, raised on the blandly nutritious food of New England, ethnic food means a chance to taste, explore and, above all, to cook from virtually all the cuisines of the world. With so many important end-of-the-year holiday meals coming up - not just Thanksgiving, Hanukkah and Christmas dinners but also the traditional feasts of Santa Lucia (Scandinavian), St. Basil (Greek) and the Three Kings (Hispanic), the Boar's Head Festival (Old English), the Russian and Chinese New Years - this is the perfect time to go in search of other cuisines. For some cooks, the pursuit of a single necessary ingredient is what the quest is all about, the chance to reward one's friends with an authentic national dish, Brazilian feijoada or a genuine Hungarian Szekely gulas, every element in place, the proportions balanced and the recipe evolved over long discussions with a purveyor of Brazilian or Hungarian food who still remembers what it tasted like in the old country and who has the contents on hand to prepare it that way.

title:
INVESTING;

RISING PESSIMISM OVER JAPANESE STOCKS
description: THE recent moves by Japan's central bank to strengthen the yen are not likely to encourage foreign investment in the Japanese stock market. In fact, analysts say, many Japanese stocks are already grossly overpriced, and due for a fall.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: The Class of '49: A Novel and Two Stories. By Don Carpenter. (North Point, $14.50.) Reading Don Carpenter's new novel is a bit like being guided through a museum of American late adolescence, 1940's division.

title: FAMINE RELIEF SHIFTS TO PERMANENT SOLUTIONS
description: A year after the start of an international relief effort for drought-stricken African nations, organizers are redirecting their efforts to solve problems that they say are at the root of the recent famine.

title: ON OLD CAPE COD MORE NEWCOMERS AND BURDENS
description: Sixteen years ago, when Marilyn Fifield moved here from Pennsylvania, this was a tightly knit little community where almost everyone knew everyone else.

title: CITY STEPS UP INSPECTIONS TO FIND HOUSING VIOLATIONS
description: FRANK G. RENYAK, an inspector for the city's Department of Housing Preservation and Development, sat in a Kentucky Fried Chicken parking lot and patiently went over pages of housing violations that had been issued against the six-story apartment building next door at 35-28 153d Street in Flushing, Queens.

title: CELEBRATING A CONSTITUTION OR VIOLATING ITS SPIRIT?
description: ''We are verging fast to anarchy,'' Gen. Henry Knox wrote to a colleague almost two centuries ago as the American colonies' first government was failing miserably for lack of national authority. ''The present Convention is the only means of avoiding the most flagitious evils that ever inflicted three million people.''

title: THE SUBWAY: 'CLEAN AND ORDERLY'
description: A VISITOR who rode the renovated Newark City Subway last week to test the contention of business leaders and city officials that its 12,500 daily passengers use the system in comfort and safety found it clean and orderly.

title: Man Charged With Shooting Girl in the Eye During Parade
description: A Monticello man was arrested today and charged with shooting a .38-caliber ball bearing that hit a girl in the eye during a Halloween parade Thursday.

title: A DECADE OLD, 'SATURDAY NIGHT LIVE' LOOKS TO FRESH FACES
description: Nothing stopped completely when Bill Murray walked into the offices of ''Saturday Night Live'' last week.

title: Search Begins Off Japan For 747's Tail Section
description: A survey ship began searching waters southwest of Tokyo today for parts of the tail section of a Japan Air Lines jumbo jet that crashed in central Japan in August, killing 520 people.

title: COAST GUARD, FACING BUDGET CUTS, HALTS ITS ROUTINE ATLANTIC PATROLS
description: The Coast Guard commander of the Atlantic Area, from the Gulf of Mexico to Canada, has suspended routine sea and air patrols north of Miami in response to cuts of more than 10 percent in the service's proposed budget by the United States Senate.

title: TAKING THE TOUGHNESS TEST
description: FERRARO My Story. By Geraldine A. Gerraro with Linda Bird Francke. Illustrated. 340 pp. New York:

title: SACRED MUSIC BY TWO GREAT OPERA COMPOSERS
description: ''Dear God . . .Have I truly written Sacred music (musique Sacree) or damnable music (Sacree musique)? I was born for opera buffa, as Thou well knowest. Not much skill, a little heart, and that's about it.'' Thus wrote the enigmatic Gioacchino Rossini upon completion of his most enigmatic work, the Petite Messe Solennelle. Most people tend to think of Rossini the bumptious, witty, proverbially lazy purveyor of operatic laughter at the outset of the 19th century. There is more to his genius, however, than is revealed in the familiar patter arias or the energetic crescendos that are the focal point of his Italian finales and popular overtures. To discover the depth of Rossini's sensitivity and his amazing harmonic foresight, one must examine the later works from ''William Tell'' on.

title: STAGE: 'CRIMES OF THE HEART'
description: BETH HENLEY'S Pulitzer Prize-winning comedy, ''Crimes of the Heart,'' is set ''five years after Hurricane Camille'' in Hazelhurst, Miss. The recent memories of Hurricane Gloria on Long Island add dimension to the mention of Camille in Port Jefferson's Theater Three production of the play.

title: BIOTECHNOLOGY MAY AID FARMING, EXPERT SAYS
description: Advances in agricultural sciences now on the horizon could help the United States regain some of the ground American producers have lost in world trade, a Washington official told a gathering of specialists here last week.

title: Sony Task on Coast
description: The Sony Corporation, with a number of major product assignments at the New York office of Marschalk, one of the Interpublic Group of Companies, has now made an assignment to its San Francisco office for the Component Products division, which includes such items as semiconductors. The assignment, formerly in New York at Ammirati & Puris, should bill more than $1 million.

title: VENTURES PLAN NOW TO OUTLAST COMET
description: When Halley's comet vanishes next spring to begin another 76-year loop around the universe, so will demand for Halley's dolls, Halley's comet pills and Halley's glow-in-the-dark clothing.

title: Dutch Religious Journalist Killed at Dachau Is Beatified
description: Pope John Paul II beatified Titus Brandsma, a Dutch religious journalist and priest who died in a Nazi concentration camp, at a ceremony in St. Peter's Basilica today. Beatification is the last step before sainthood in the Roman Catholic Church.

title: PRETORIA CRACKDOWN
description: A foreign television news team was recently detained by the police in an area where soldiers were firing tear gas at demonstrating students. Although members of the crew were not filming the unrest - they were seated in a parked car - they were taken into custody after policemen and soldiers spotted cameras in the car.

title: A Firm Faith in Lower Rates
description: The Federal Reserve is not expected to change monetary policy at this week's meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee, but many credit market participants remained optimistic last week that interest rates may decline in the near future.

title: Ron Hoff Establishing Business in Chicago
description: Ron Hoff, 44 years old, was long associated with the creative heirarchy of Ogilvy & Mather before he went on to similar triumphs at Foote Cone & Belding in New York and then in Chicago.

title: KHAN TOPS TALBOTT IN SQUASH FINAL
description: Top-seeded Jahangir Khan of Pakistan continued his dominance of North American squash racquets yesterday with a 15-6, 15-13, 12-15, 15-9 victory over Mark Talbott of Marblehead, Mass., in the men's final of the $45,000 Chivas Regal Squash Open at the Hunter College Sportsplex.

title: Alan Howard Mandel Wed to Ellen R. Block
description: Ellen R. Block and Alan Howard Mandel were married yesterday at the de Seversky Conference Center in Old Westbury, L.I., by Rabbi Mordecai Rubin.

title: Supply of Tax-Exempt Issues Soars
description: The supply of new tax-exempt bonds is surging, as local governments strive to sell issues that could be banned after the end of the year by changes in the Federal tax law. The result, according to many analysts, is that yields of tax-exempt bond are unusually attractive compared with bonds, whose interest is taxable.

title: Police and Protesters Clash in Frankfurt
description: Police officers clashed today in central Frankfurt with protesters trying to hold a banned demonstration to mark the fourth anniversary of riots against a new airport runway.

title: BEARS TOP PACKERS TO STAY UNBEATEN
description: Walter Payton rushed for 192 yards, including a key 27-yard, fourth-quarter touchdown today, as the Chicago Bears remained undefeated by beating the Green Bay Packers, 16-10.

title: OUTDOORS: IMPROVEMENTS IN SKI SAFETY
description: SINCE the years of skiing's rapid growth in the 1960's, there has been a dramatic decrease in the number of injuries suffered on the ski slopes. Jasper Shealy, a professor of industrial engineering at the Rochester Institute of Technology in Rochester, N.Y., has done several studies on ski injuries over the years. He estimates that in the 1960's, there were about 7.6 injuries per 1,000 skier days, while in the 1980's, there are about 2.2 injuries per 1,000 skier days.

title: Grey's Profit Falls
description: Grey Advertising released its third-quarter results Friday, showing a rise in revenues but a drop in earnings. Revenues were $53.4 million, up 7.3 percent from $49.8 million a year before. Net income fell 10 percent to $1.8 million, or $2.70 a share, from $2 million, or $3.18 a share.

title: Mr. Meese's Petard
description: Attorney General Meese has aroused much controversy with his ideas on how to read the Constitution, but it is not really one of those grand constitutional debates that periodically mark our history. How do you debate a man who advances a radical theory and then, when challenged, retreats in a fog of obfuscation and ignorance?

title: MEXICO SEEKING KILLERS OF 21 POLICEMEN
description: Mexican policemen and soliders searched a remote region 300 miles southeast of here today seeking a band of drug smugglers who ambushed and killed 21 policemen after the police discovered a large cache of marijuana.

title: FOR SIMON, NOVELS' KEY IS 'PLEASURE'
description: Claude Simon, the 1985 Nobel Prize winner in literature, says he is perplexed by all the reports that his work is difficult to read.

title: MALAYSIAN SECRETS LAW IS USED AS A NEWS CURB
description: Malaysia, citing the Official Secrets Act, has begun to prosecute journalists who gain access to unpublished Government reports.

title: Savings Bond Interest Cut
description: The interest rate for series EE savings bonds was set at 8.36 percent for the six-month period from November through April, the Treasury Department announced Friday.

title: KNICKS WAITING FOR CHANCE TO USE BEST-LAID PLANS
description: Patrick Ewing is doing exactly what he is supposed to do, posting up strongly against the opposition's center and pleading for the basketball. Both feet are planted firmly and his right arm is reaching high into the air, providing an easy and inviting target.

title: Three to Visit Argentina
description: Three leading economists in the United States will make an on-the-spot inspection of Argentina's unique anti-inflation program, a Government official announced today.

title: BANK BOARD'S EMBATTLED CHIEF
description: When Edwin J. Gray, the embattled chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, steps up to the podium of the savings industry's annual convention in Dallas on Tuesday morning he will be talking to friend and foe alike.

title: Briton Wants to Help Japanese Shareholders
description: Terry Ramsden, the 33-year-old chairman of the Glen International Financial Services Company, created quite a stir two weeks ago when he joined with an American financier, Charles W. Knapp, in starting a hostile takeover bid for the Minebea Company, a leading Japanese maker of ball bearings and electronics parts.

title: NEW MEASURE SEEN FOR SOVIET A-TEST
description: Accusations by the Reagan Administration that Soviet underground nuclear tests may have violated treaty limits are based on faulty assumptions, according to a group of scientists.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: REALLY MOVING ART There is a mass of lively movement - from the exhibition to the music - today at the Whitney Museum of American Art's midtown branch in the Philip Morris Building, 120 Park Avenue, at 42d Street (878-2550).

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: Mecca Development Plan
description: Saudi Arabia plans to make improvements at the Moslem holy city of Mecca under a 20-year project, Government officials said today. They said the plan, expected to be approved in January, entails construction of a mile-long pedestrian area around the Grand Mosque and of a central business district in the city. An earlier project to build four ring roads around the city has been incorporated into the master plan, the officials added.

title: SIX-PART SERIES OF 'RIVER JOURNEYS'
description: ''RIVER JOURNEYS'' is in the grand tradition - of travel writing, stiff upper lip and adventure in the heart of darkness. It looks wonderful, too. Judged by its first episode, ''A River Journey by Christina Dodwell,'' the six-part series is the best thing to happen to travel documentaries in years. It begins on Channel 13 at 10 o'clock tonight.

title: STUDY WARNS ON WORK RULES FOR CONVENTIONS
description: A confidential study prepared for board members of New York's convention center warns that if the new exhibition hall adopts the same work rules now in effect at the New York Coliseum, it will lose business.

title: A Tangled Account
description: One of the services provided by the Republican and Democratic cloakrooms just off the Senate floor involves a telephone number that a member can call for a recorded report of what has just happened in the chamber and what is scheduled for the rest of the day.

title: TIN CRISIS HAS RIPPLE EFFECTS
description: The crisis in tin trading that started on Oct. 24 is threatening the future of the 108-year-old London Metal Exchange, the world's premier metals market.

title: California's Top Court Enters Hedgecock Case
description: The California Supreme Court has entered the tangled legal case of Mayor Roger Hedgecock of San Diego, postponing a Monday hearing at which the trial judge was to decide if the Mayor wins a new trial on campaign law violations.

title: FRED A. ENKE
description: Fred A. Enke, the head basketball coach at Arizona University for 31 years before his retirement in 1961, died Saturday at the Desert Valley Care Center.

title: President of Mattel Resigns the Position
description: Mattel Inc., the toy and game company, has announced that Glenn Hastings, its president, has resigned.

title: A New Generation At Public Art Fund
description: ''When people walk by a sculpture and say, 'I don't like it,' they're cultivating an eye,'' said the new president of the Public Art Fund. ''That's important.

title: Iranians Rally At Old U.S. Embassy
description: Thousands of Iranian students held a noisy demonstration in front of the old American Embassy compound today on the eve of the anniversary of the takeover of the embassy in 1979.

title: Flying on Business Is Surely No Pleasure
description: To the Editor:

title: DANCE: JUBILATION! PERFORMS 'ESSENCE,' A PREMIERE
description: THE Jubilation! Dance Company almost raised the roof of the Borough of Manhattan Community College Triplex, at Chambers and West Streets, where the group appeared on Wednesday in an engagement that ended yesterday. How could you fail, with fast dancing, a celebration of black women, and a tender look at the passage of tradition from an African ancestral elder to a child of the New World? But Kevin Jeff, founder and director of Jubilation!, and Martial Roumain, its guest choreographer, made something fresh of the familiar in a stirring evening of theater and dance.

title: A REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: CREDIBILITY IS KEY WORRY AS A.P. EDITORS MEET
description: Though the topics on their agenda ranged from libel to competition, the 450 newspaper editors who gathered here this week kept returning to one problem: credibility, or the lack of it.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: PICKING RACKETEERING TRIAL JURY
description: The woman said she was frightened. She sat last week in a jury box in Federal District Court in Manhattan, kneaded her hands and told Judge John F. Keenan that if she had to hear evidence every day about the Mafia, she would not be able to sleep at night.

title: ACADEMICS PLEDGE TO REJECT FUNDS
description: More than 1,600 scientists and nearly 1,200 graduate students have pledged to reject research funds for work related to the Reagan Administration's plan for a space-based missile defense system, according to organizers of the pledge campaign.

title: School Boards Aren't Above the Law
description: One of every six of New York's community school board members has yet to file the financial disclosure statements that state law requires. That frustrates the central Board of Education, understandably, and it has unanimously agreed to ''take all steps'' to remove the non-filers from office. The toughness is sensible. The spectacle of board members holding themselves above law and accountability undermines trust in the system.

title: Amy Weber Wed to Sheldon Goldfarb
description: At the Jewish Community Center in Paramus, N.J., yesterday Amy Linda Weber, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Weber of Paramus, was married to Sheldon I. Goldfarb, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Alex D. Goldfarb of Kingston, N.Y. Rabbi Aryeh Gotlieb performed the ceremony.

title: HORFORD DISMISSED FROM L.S.U. TEAM
description: Alfredo (Tito) Horford, the highly recruited 7-foot freshman center from the Dominican Republic, has been dismissed from the Louisiana State University basketball team, and tampering by other universities might be involved, Coach Dale Brown said today.

title: WANTED: 2 PRISONS, MOONSHINE
description: Most Missourians can remember when one of the easiest ways to start a citizens revolt in any community was to suggest building a prison there.

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Football Cardinals vs. Dallas Cowboys, at St. Louis. Tony Dorsett recently became the sixth player in N.F.L. history to rush for 10,000 yards.

title: WORLD OF OPERA CELEBRATES MET GUILD'S 50 YEARS
description: The Central Opera Service helped celebrate the 50-year past of the Metropolitan Opera Guild over the weekend by talking about opera's next half-century.

title: CUP COULD AFFECT VOTING
description: Almost all of the seven winners of the seven Breeders' Cup races Saturday will race again next year, but all of them are through for this season, leaving the balloting for year-end championship honors in the most chaotic state since the Eclipse Awards were begun 15 years ago.

title: LENDL TOPS MCENROE
description: Ivan Lendl overcame John McEnroe, 1-6, 7-6, 6-2, 6-2, today to win the $850,000 European Champions' Championship of Tennis Tournament. Lendl earned $200,000 for his victory and took home the trophy, a life-size, 13.2-pound gold racquet studded with 1,420 diamonds valued at $700,000.

title: JACKSON'S HEISMAN CHANCES TAKE A DIP
description: When undefeated and powerful Florida beat Auburn, 14-10, Saturday and virtually ended Auburn's Southeastern Conference title hopes and chances at the Sugar Bowl, Bo Jackson's Heisman Trophy chances also took a slight dip. The Auburn tailback is probably still far ahead of the field for that top individual annual college football prize. But a leg injury kept him sidelined in the second half so he gained only 48 yards.

title: Union Local Goes on Strike At Chrysler Plant in Missouri
description: About 2,800 members of the United Automobile Workers' Local 110 went on strike early today at the Chrysler Corporation's No. 2 plant here after efforts to head off a walkout failed.

title: The Heat's Off
description: He can sit back now, relaxed, watching from a safe distance as somebody else tackles the problems. For Bowie Kuhn, baseball is fun again.

title: Barbara Schachter Weds Robert Wallner, a Lawyer
description: Barbara Claire Schachter, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Schachter of Great Neck, L.I., was married yesterday to Robert Alan Wallner, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Leonard Wallner of Philadelphia.

title: STUDY SAYS ECONOMY HOLDS OWN
description: As it entered the fourth quarter, the economy managed to hold the ground it gained in September, the National Association of Purchasing Management said in a report prepared for release today.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE MYSTERY OF HERMANN GOERING'S SUICIDE. By Ben E. Swearingen. 253 pages. Illustrated. Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $19.95.

title: ASIDE FROM A FUGITIVE INSECT, ALL IS WELL ABOARD THE SHUTTLE
description: A fugitive fruit fly named Willie overshadowed the experiments aboard the space shuttle Challenger today, but West German officials said the research mission had its most successful day yet.

title: 'THIS CHILD IS MINE'
description: TONIGHT'S television-movie problem is a custody battle for an infant waged by the adoptive parents and the birth mother. ''This Child Is Mine,'' on NBC at 9 o'clock, explores the painful situation with an admirable degree of clarity but, especially in the end, can't resist milking television's fat sentimentality cow. Still, a dedicated cast, Charles Rosin's sturdy script and thoroughly professional direction by David Greene (''Rich Man, Poor Man,'' ''Friendly Fire'') make this effort more compelling than most.

title: Marc Mitchell Chapman Wed to Bonnie A. Finkel
description: Bonnie Anne Finkel, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lyman W. Finkel of New Rochelle, N.Y., and Marc Mitchell Chapman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jay Chapman of Brooklyn, were married yesterday. Rabbi Paul Siegel performed the ceremony at Le Chateau in South Salem, N.Y.

title: RISKS PAY OFF IN DOCUMENTARY SERIES
description: FOLK groups in the 20th century have to face a paradox:

title: WISDOM IN JUDGEMENT, 38 YEARS IN THE MAKING
description: When Senator Richard B. Russell died in office on Jan. 21, 1971, he had served in the Senate for 38 years and 9 days. That record placed the Georgia Democrat second on the Senate's seniority list behind Carl Hayden of Arizona, who held office for more than 41 years.

title: Anne Bradford Married
description: Anne L. Bradford, the daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Golden of Bronxville, N.Y., was married yesterday to Richard H. Pontone, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Virgil Pontone of Brooklyn.

title: CANADIAN BREWERS FEAR U.S.
description: Despite brewing a generally stronger, often tastier product than its American competitors, Canada's beer industry seems scared stiff of free trade with the United States.

title: CUMMINGS WANTS REST TO HEAL LEG
description: The losses - of games and players - continue to mount for the Knicks.

title: IN MICRONESIA, A GNAWING DOUBT AMID THE PALMS
description: A few years back the Municipal Assembly banned all alcohol sales on this craggy island in the western Pacific.

title: Loss Reported By MGM/UA
description: The MGM/UA Entertainment Company, which has agreed to be acquired by the Turner Broadcasting System for about $1.5 billion, Friday reported a loss of $49.5 million for its fiscal fourth quarter, ended Aug. 31.

title: SOLDIER IN KABUL SEES SOVIET ENVOY
description: A Soviet soldier who ran into the United States Embassy in Kabul on Thursday met with the Soviet Ambassador to Afghanistan inside the embassy today and will see him again on Monday, United States officials said here tonight.

title: NEW TAKEOVER BILL STIRS LIVELY DEBATE
description: The Cuomo administration's proposed legislation to curb hostile corporate takeovers could have a major chilling effect on takeover activity in New York State, according to lawyers and investment bankers who specialize in mergers and acquisitions.

title: Tax Corporate Income
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, NOVEMBER 4, 1985
description: International

title: FLOTILLA DRIVES ERRANT WHALE INTO SALT WATER
description: Cheered by hundreds of spectators, a flotilla of three dozen boats, including three 20-ton Army landing craft and Navy and Coast Guard vessels, lured a misguided humpback whale from the Sacramento River to the mouth of San Francisco Bay and the safety of salt water today.

title: SOME TIMELY COUNSEL
description: Senator Alan K. Simpson, a Wyoming Republican, says that when he first came to the Senate in 1979, he got some sage advice from Senator John C. Stennis of Mississippi, a Democrat.

title: Washington Watch;   S.E.C. Quorum For a Key Vote
description: EFFORTS by the Securities and Exchange Commission to take timely action in the E. F. Hutton Group's overdrafting scheme prompted intense behind-the-scenes maneuvering and brought to light some little-known commission powers to take emergency action.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Nov. 4, 1985: *2*MONDAY Airborne Freight Lockheed Corp Carpenter Tech Corp Minnesota Mng & Mfg Cincinnati Bell NCH Corp Data-Design Labs Oakite Products General Motors Corp Rexnord Inc Jefferson-Pilot Corp Stone Container Corp *2*TUESDAY Adams-Millis Corp Liberty Corp Emerson Elec MCorp General Housewares Monarch Mach Tool Hershey Foods Corp Pioneer Corp (TX) Kansas City Pwr & Lt Sealed Air Corp Leaseway Transp Timken Co *2*WEDNESDAY Arvin Industries Leggett & Platt Cincinnati Milacron Munford Inc Eagle-Picher Indus Portland Genl Elec General Foods Reichhold Chemicals Goodyear Tire Rockwell Intl Heilig-Meyers Scientific-Atlanta Ingersoll-Rand Thomas & Betts Corp Iowa Elec Lt&Pwr UtiliCorp United Inc Lear-Siegler Wallace Computer Svcs *2*THURSDAY Ahmanson (HF) & Co Dover Corp American Standard El Torito Restaurants Anchor Hocking Corp First Mississippi Ashland Oil Inc GTE Corp Automatic Data Nabisco Brands Inc Avon Products Planning Research Chemed Corp Ranco Inc Coastal Corp Robins (AH) Co Continental Telecom West Company Inc Dart & Kraft *2*FRIDAY ASA Ltd Safeguard Business Sys Fabri-Centers Amer State Mutual Securities Hecla Mining *2*SATURDAY Amer Hospital Supply De Luxe Check Printers

title: Mandela Has Prostate Operation
description: Nelson Mandela, the jailed anti-apartheid leader, had surgery today for the removal of an enlarged prostate and is in stable condition, prison officials said tonight.

title: 5 BODIES RECOVERED IN SMOLDERING MINE
description: A recovery team that included Government investigators this morning brought out the first five bodies to be recovered from the Wilberg coal mine fire, which killed 27 miners last December.

title: Remains in Desert Identified As Two Missing Oklahomans
description: Skeletons found in the Southern California desert have been identified as the remains of an Oklahoma woman and her daughter who had been the objects of a cross-country search, officials said Saturday.

title: QUESTION BOX
description: QUESTION: Derek Schmidt of Florida State recently set a school record by kicking his 55th consecutive extra point. Is he nearing an N.C.A.A mark?

title: EMBASSY IN KABUL: STANDOFF AT U.S. OUTPOST
description: The young Soviet soldier taking refuge in the United States Embassy in Kabul has turned international attention on one of America's most isolated diplomatic outposts.

title: AIDS BENEFIT SHOW AT THE MET OPERA
description: The Metropolitan Opera House was awash with emotion last evening, as more than 25 stars from the four corners of show business donated their talents to ''The Best of the Best: A Show of Concern,'' a three-and-a-half-hour gala to benefit AIDS research and care.

title: The U.N. Today; Nov. 4, 1985
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Books: Ramparts of Art
description: THE REVENGE OF THE PHILISTINES:

title: SOME CUTBACKS IN LOW-COST GAS
description: A ruling by the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission that went into effect on Friday has prompted widespread revolt among pipeline companies.

title: Topics;   Profits of Planning Panda Watch
description: Ling-Ling, the romantic heroine of Washington's National Zoo, has lost her appetite, and her hormone level is rising.

title: Don't Let Them Legislate Away the Jury System
description: To the Editor:

title: SUCCESSES AND STRAINS IN DRIVE TO FIX STATUE OF LIBERTY
description: Months before Lee A. Iacocca became involved in the campaign to restore the Statue of Liberty and Ellis Island, Richard Rovsek, a Connecticut marketing executive, hit upon the idea that there ought to be one.

title: Agencies' View of Economy
description: JUST after Labor Day Robert E. Jacoby, president of Ted Bates Worldwide, stood apart from his peers in the upper reaches of major advertising agencies. He was optimistic about 1985. No more.

title: How Intelsat Blocks the Free Worldwide Flow of Information
description: To the Editor:

title: Jet Dives Suddenly to Avoid Small Aircraft Near Chicago
description: A Delta Air Lines jet, emerging from clouds near Chicago recently, dived and banked to avoid a small plane passing so close the airline pilot said he could read some of its numbers, a tape recording of the incident showed today.

title: Austrian Security Steps
description: The Austrian Interior Minister, Karl Blecha, announced new anti-terrorism measures today that are to be introduced at the country's five international airports. Advanced X-ray machines will be installed to screen luggage for weapons or explosives, and plainclothes guards will assist uniformed officers in patrolling airport lounges, a ministry spokesman said.

title: CANADIAN WINS TRANS-ATLANTIC RACE
description: The Canadian sailboat Formule TAG, skippered by Mike Birch of Vancouver, worked its way up the Hudson River yesterday to cross the finish line first in the Monaco-New York Race.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, NOVEMBER 4, 1985
description: Economy

title: Black Tie and Gold Paint
description: What the organizers of the Bal Masque had in mind was a meeting between young members of ''New York's most prominent social circles'' and ''leading figures of downtown Manhattan's emerging 'Avant Garde' scene.''

title: 4 Executed in Soviet
description: Four gangsters have been executed for a series of murders and robberies over the last year in the Soviet city of Kuibyshev, Izvestia, the Government newspaper, reported today.

title: Happy Together
description: What started as an amusing oddity when Jim Pons signed on as the Jets' film director may be getting out of hand. John Seiter has joined the club's film staff, and if the trend continues with contracts for Howard Kaylan and Mark Volan and a search for Al Nichol, it will not be long before the Jets are overrun by Turtles.

title: Air Jamaica Change
description: Altschiller Reitzfeld Advertising quietly split about a month ago with Air Jamaica, for which it was promoting both passenger and cargo. According to David Altschiller, the agency's chairman, the budget (which had been about $1 million at its high point) had dwindled to next to nothing. Now the word is that the carrier is talking to other agencies.

title: John M. Shaheen, 70; Chief of Oil Company
description: John M. Shaheen, president of the Macmillan Ring-Free Oil Company, died Friday at New York Hospital after a short illness. He was 70 years old and had homes in Manhattan and Southampton, L.I.

title: DECISIONS FOR OWNER OF REVLON
description: Pantry Pride Inc. began consolidating its ownership of Revlon Inc. over the weekend as lawyers for the two companies discussed an ''orderly'' transfer of control following Pantry Pride's victory Friday in the three-month takeover battle.

title: ECONOMIC CALENDAR
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

title: Steelers Beat Browns on Late Kick, 10-9
description: Gary Anderson kicked a 25-yard field goal with 9 seconds to play today as the Pittsburgh Steelers edged Cleveland, 10-9, in a driving rain.

title: Poles Ask Release Of Political Prisoners
description: Lech Walesa, the founder of Solidarity, and 76 leading Polish intellectuals appealed today for the release of political prisoners and sought the support of Pope John Paul II and the United Nations Human Rights Commission.

title: LINDNER CALLED KEY TO MISSION RESCUE
description: California insurance examiners worked over the weekend to determine the financial state of the Mission Insurance Group, a casualty and commercial property insurer whose major shareholder is Carl H. Lindner, the Cincinnati financier.

title: SAVING AN AIR HERITAGE FOR HISTORY
description: In a hangar near here, the smell of solvents and the whine of an electric drill surround the Enola Gay, the airplane that carried the first atomic bomb over Hiroshima 40 years ago, now a metal shell without wings or a tail.

title: IN A HOTEL FOR HOMELESS FAMILIES, CHILDHOOD DIES YOUNG
description: Children hung from fire escapes and shared the narrow, littered hallways with drug dealers at 3 o'clock in the morning. The sound of gunfire carried into the rooms from the street below. Mothers called to their children to keep away from the half-lighted stairwells. And everywhere this weekend there were children, 5, 7, 10 years old, who talked matter-of-factly of drugs, muggings and shootings.

title: Susan Epstein Becomes Bride of William Merritt
description: Susan Ellen Epstein, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Epstein of New York, was married yesterday to William Merritt, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Merritt, also of New York. Rabbi David Posner performed the ceremony at the Harmonie Club in New York.

title: SALVADOR OCTOBER TOLL PUT AT 181
description: A total of 181 people were killed last month in fighting in El Salvador, adding to the approximately 55,000 previously killed in six years of civil war, the armed forces announced today.

title: Warnaco Chief Expects Quick Action on Buyout
description: Robert J. Matura, chairman and chief executive officer of Warnaco Inc., the apparel manufacturer, says he likes the rag trade. But he is not so enthusiastic about running a publicly held company any more.

title: I.R.A. ALLY DERIDES PARLEY ON IRELAND
description: Gerry Adams, the head of Sinn Fein, the political arm of the Irish Republican Army, today characterized the negotiations between the British and Irish Governments on Northern Ireland as an effort ''to put a diplomatic veneer on British rule'' and to make it more stable in the long term.

title: Pay TV Job For Cappadona
description: Cappadona Mosier & Partners has been named advertising agency for Request Television, a pay-per-view cable service that will begin service on Nov. 28.

title: Intent and Meaning
description: The Wall Street Journal, with its editorial tongue presumably in its ideological cheek, has proposed that Supreme Court justices stand for election every six years, since too many of them are ''acting like politicians, setting policy, instead of like honest interpreters of the Constitution.''

title: Emission Tampering Is Cited
description: The emission control systems have been deliberately tampered with in a fifth of the cars and light trucks in the United States made in the last 10 years, a Federal study indicates.

title: Pegi Goodman Weds Gregory Bryan Leeds
description: At the Greenburgh Hebrew Center in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., yesterday Pegi Goodman, a daughter of Belle Goodman and the late Sam Goodman of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married to Gregory Bryan Leeds, a son of Mr. and Mrs. F. William Leeds of Merion, Pa. Rabbi Barry Kentor and Cantor Martin Goldstein officiated.

title: Promotional Materials For Cable TV Industry
description: To fill the self-promotion gap created by the death of the Council for Cable Information and its planned $12 million ad campaign, two other cable industry organizations have joined to get promotional materials into the hands of system operators on a monthly basis.

title: Market Place;   Interco Lure: Brand Names
description: EVERYONE, it seems, likes Interco these days. Consumers each year spend millions of dollars on the company's Florsheim shoes, London Fog overcoats, Schrader Sport dresses, Ethan Allen and Broyhill furniture and its dozens of other famous-name products.

title: Norfolk Southern's Bid
description: Some Norfolk Southern Corporation executives are said to be thinking that the big railroad holding company should take its losses and drop its bid to buy the Government's 85 percent stake in the Consolidated Rail Corporation.

title: CANDIDATES AND PROPOSITIONS IN NEW YORK CITY AND SUBURBS
description: Following is a list of candidates appearing on ballots in the New York metropolitan area in tomorrow's election. Incumbent candidates are marked with an asterisk(*). Unopposed candidates are marked (U). The abbreviations are D - Democrat, R - Republican, C - Conservative, L - Liberal, RTL - Right to Life, CO - Coalition Party, I -Independent,NA - New Alliance, PP - People Before Profits, SP - Sparticist Party, SW - Socialist Workers, SRT - Stop Rising Taxes, COA -Coaltion 85, ITC - Independent Tax Cutters, IV - Independent Voter, FP - Freedom Party, OTP- Our Times Party, NBP - Nyack's Best Party, RAL - Ratepayers Against Lilco, PTF - People for Tax Freedom, CAL - Citizens Against Lilco, INT - Integrity, SP - Southold Preservation, IND - Independence, UNC - United North County, CS - Common Sense, YT - Yonkers Taxpaer, PR - Preserve Rye, PRE - Preservation, TI - Town Independent, HI - Harrison Independent, T - Town Party, IT - Inedpendent Taxpayers, RES - Responsible, US - United Somers, SB - Somers' Best.

title: THE DANCE: 'FALL-OUT' BY RUDY PEREZ ENSEMBLE
description: IT is good to have Rudy Perez back in town. Mr. Perez left New York for Los Angeles in 1978. But the dances presented by the Rudy Perez Performance Ensemble on Saturday at the Bessie Schonberg Theater, 219 West 19th Street, as part of the National Performance Network, suggested that Mr. Perez is still in peak choreographic form, though in a perhaps slightly different form than one remembers from his work in the early 1970's, in the heyday of postmodernist dance in New York.

title: STAGE: 'LOVE AS WE KNOW IT,' BY GIL SCHWARTZ
description: NOW and then in his series of thematically related skits called ''Love as We Know It,'' the playwright Gil Schwartz seems on the verge of making a serious comment on the mating fashions of those New Yorkers in their 30's who have been brought up on television, visit singles bars, wear matching outfits, eat fiber and drink Evian by the liter, get excited about the late Wisconsin neo-Fauvism show at the Whitney and say things like, ''How are you going to move up in the infrastructure if you don't go the extra mile?'' Invariably, however, he retreats either into sentimentality or, more often, into a gag. Some of the gags are funny, but there is not much behind them, and by the end of the evening at the Intar Theater you may feel as though you've drunk too much Evian.

title: KNICKS TROUNCED BY BLAZERS, 100-96
description: So far this season, the Knicks have relied on their vaunted defensive trap to keep them close to opponents. But tonight, against the improved Portland Trail Blazers, they couldn't even do that.

title: HOW U.S. MANIPULATED SOCIAL SECURITY FUNDS
description: Experts on Social Security raised many questions today about the Reagan Administration's manipulation of Social Security trust funds and payroll tax receipts to avoid default on the Government's financial obligations.

title: Three Killed in Blast At Grain Elevator
description: An explosion and fire at a grain elevator blew open a 100-foot concrete silo with a column of flame, fatally injured three people and threatened this community's economic base.

title: Persian Gulf Leaders Hear Appeal on Terror
description: Sultan Qabus bin Said, the leader of Oman, today opened the annual summit meeting of the oil-producing Persian Gulf countries with an appeal for the region to work together to fight terrorism.

title: A ROUNDUP OF QUARTERLY SALES AND PROFITS AT 248 COMPANIES
description: (Loss) * not applicable, loss in 1984 period. (1) Quarter ended in June. (2) Quarter ended in July. (3) Quarter ended in Aug. (4) Quarter ended in Oct.

title: Conversations With Government
description: There are no stop signs for northbound or southbound traffic on Vanderbilt Avenue at 43d Street. Many pedestrians cross that intersection going to and from Grand Central Terminal, and it can be risky.

title: AN EYE CHART THAT TELLS MORE
description: The century-old ''E'' eye chart should be traded in on a new model that not only measures visual ability better but also detects some eye disorders in their early stages, a researcher says.

title: ARGENTINA HOLDS MIDTERM ELECTION
description: For the first time in 20 years and the only time under a state of siege, Argentines voted today in midterm Congressional elections.

title: MADE ADVANCES IN BRAIN SURGERY
description: Dr. Irving S. Cooper, a neurosurgeon who developed successful techniques, including cryogenic surgery, for treating Parkinson's disease and several other crippling neurological disorders, died of cancer Wednesday in Naples, Fla. He was 63 years old and lived in Naples.

title: Farm Subsidies Grow Like Weeds
description: Congress aims to please, and never more so than when it aims money at farmers. Even now, under acute budget pressure, the House passes a farm support bill doubling the cost of the current program.

title: The Radar Message From Moscow
description: At one level, the pre-summit proposals that Moscow and Washington are lobbing back and forth are meant to impress an international audience. But beneath the surface, the proposals may also have substance, like the Russian offer on missile-detecting radars.

title: Against 'Comparable Worth'
description: Both houses of Congress and a number of courts are grappling with the question of whether wages should be fixed on the basis of equal pay for work of comparable value to the employer - a proposed remedy for lower pay received by women. One can already see developing many complications and dangers built into the concept of ''comparable worth.''

title: Reagan's Sound Deterrent Strategy
description: President Reagan's latest proposal to the Soviet Union in advance of the summit meeting with Mikhail S. Gorbachev calls for deep, verifiable cuts in offensive weapons and continued research into strategic defensive systems. The President obviously feels we should not trade strategic defense for cuts in offensive weapons and that the two are in fact compatible. He is right.

title: FOLK: KORNOG AND THE BATTLEFIELD BAND PERFORM
description: FOLK groups in the 20th century have to face a paradox:

title: Three Banks Fail in West
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation announced three bank failures, raising the total this year to 98, compared with 79 for all of last year.

title: NEW YORK AND JERSEY CANDIDATES WINDING UP ELECTION CAMPAIGNS
description: Candidates for offices from mayor of New York to suburban town supervisor spent a blustery Sunday in traditional last-minute campaigning in the New York metropolitan area yesterday.

title: Malcolm Forbes Is Divorced
description: Malcolm Forbes, the publisher of Forbes Magazine, and his wife, Roberta, have divorced after 39 years of marriage. Mrs. Forbes, citing irreconcilable differences, applied for the divorce and it was granted Sept. 19, according to Judge Robert Ranck, who presided.

title: JOE MORRIS, ON THE MIND
description: WHEN the Giants are in the huddle, sometimes little Joe Morris isn't. Just close enough to hear the play, he'll be standing off to the side with what Phil Simms calls ''this distant look on his face, maybe he's just out of breath, but it's like he's got something on his mind.'' More and more, though, little Joe Morris is on the mind of opposing defenses. As the Giants held on yesterday for a 22-20 victory over the Tampa Bay Bucs, he rushed for 132 yards, including a 3-yard touchdown, after having had 104 yards in the previous triumph against the New Orleans Saints.

title: TEEN-AGERS TAKING RISKS: WHEN PREGNANCY IS THE RESULT
description: LaTanya Jones had her first son, Traziel, three years ago and her second, Steve, six months ago.

title: WOMEN DRESSING TO SUCCEED THINK TWICE ABOUT THE SUIT
description: ''The skirted suit should become the uniform for almost all business and political situations.''

title: Arrow Through Window Wounds Tennessean
description: A man was shot with a razor-tipped arrow fired through his window by a teen-ager Friday, the authorities said, and he was reported to be ''progressing well'' in intensive care today.

title: 4 DAYS LATER, RUSSIANS HAVE YET TO REPORT THEIR REAGAN INTERVIEW
description: Four days after the first Soviet interview with an American President since John F. Kennedy granted one in 1961, the official information outlets here were still silent on what President Reagan said to Soviet citizens.

title: Chaconne by Bach Featured by Milstein
description: Nathan Milstein, at the age of 80, has earned the right to be called one of the grand old men of music, but the suppleness and acuity of his best playing Wednesday night at Carnegie Hall had a youthfulness about them that belied the years.

title: Catching Up
description: Jay Berger is the 18-year-old tennis player from Clemson University who caused a buzz at the United States Open two months ago by reaching the round of 16 before losing to no less a star than Yannick Noah.

title: MORE AIR FARES CUT AS RIVALRY GROWS
description: As traffic slows in November and early December, airlines have traditionally cut fares to such vacation markets as Florida. But this year reductions are being offered in fares to many other markets as well because of a growing rivalry between two low-cost carriers: People Express and Continental Airlines.

title: RUNNER, 69, LIVES LIFE IN THE PARK
description: On benches and in bars along Broadway, in the Offtrack Betting parlor near 91st Street and the lobbies of residential hotels, Alberto Arroyo sees men and women broken by old age and poverty, resigned to lonely lives in bleak single rooms.

title: U.S. EXPLORES 4 'NUGGETS' IN SOVIET ARMS PLAN
description: The United States, in its latest proposals on arms control, has responded essentially to four ''nuggets'' from Moscow's arms plan that could possibly provide a basis for eventual progress, a senior American official said today.

title: Riitta Parviainen Wed To Sheldon H. Alster
description: Riitta Anneli Parviainen, the daughter of Mrs. Gerald Parks of West Palm Beach, Fla., and the late Reino Parviainen of Helsinki, Finland, and Sheldon H. Alster, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Alster of Jerusalem, were married yesterday. Rabbi Ira Grussgott performed the ceremony at the Water Club in New York.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''If all these childish claims to popularity on both sides have to be settled, I think we'd better settle it by calling an election right now, or say give everybody 60 days to campaign and to bring the issues to the people.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: W.R. Grace & Co. has appointed Harvey G. Knell chairman and Sean F. Lee president and chief executive officer of Grace Home Centers West. * Herbert Clough Inc., Stamford, Conn., a reinsurance company, has appointed George T. Derfus senior vice president. * Melitta International, Cherry Hill, N.J., which makes coffee-brewing systems, has appointed H. Helmut Radtke president, North America division. * Norton Co., Worcester, Mass., which makes tools and abrasives, has elected Richard J. Flynn vice chairman. * Paychex Inc. of Rochester, which provides payroll services, has named Wesley C. Tallman president and chief operating officer. * Peter Paul Cadbury, a division of Cadbury Schweppes that markets chocolates and other confectionery items, has named H. Alton LeBeau Jr. president. * St. Paul Companies Inc., St. Paul, has named Lloyd O. Shervheim senior vice president, law, and corporate secretary. * Spencer Stuart, an executive search consulting concern, has named Akira Ohtomo managing director in Tokyo for its Japanese operations. * Swett & Crawford Group, Los Angeles, a unit of the St. Paul Companies, has appointed Peter A. Wilkens senior vice president. * Synalloy Corp., Spartanburg, S.C., which makes specialty chemicals and alloy pipe and equipment, said Benjamin M. Smith had resigned as president. * Texas Instruments Inc., Dallas, has elected to its board Bernard M. Fauber, chairman and chief executive officer of the K Mart Corp. * Viacom International Inc., a communications and entertainment company, has appointed Martha Burke-Hennessy managing director of Viacom S.A. and Viacom International Ltd., both subsidiaries.

title: U.S. Study Cites Role Of Alcohol in Crimes
description: More than half of jail inmates convicted of violent crimes were drinking before they committed the offense, the Government said today in a study of alcohol's role in fueling crimes of passion.

title: Bridge: For Drama, Team Semifinals Were Better Than the Finals
description: The world championship team finals here were less exciting than on some previous occasions and failed to match the drama of the qualifying and semifinal stages.

title: Alumni Magazine Ads Planned at Wharton
description: The Wharton Alumni magazine, sent quarterly to 53,000 alumni and 3,300 students, has decided to include paid advertising in the fare. So it has retained Decker Decker & Freas, an ad agency heavy in magazine marketing and promotion experience, to be both its advertising sales representative and its ad agency.

title: Briefcases
description: * The Energy Department has awarded a contract to the BDM Corporation to see whether natural gas production can be increased by drilling wells horizontally.

title: STAYING ON AT HOME OF PARENTS
description: ARE the growing number of young single adults who stay on in their parents' homes in danger of remaining in a state of prolonged adolescence?

title: ARAB OFFICIAL SEEKS OIL OUTPUT RESTRAINT
description: Mana Said al-Otaiba, oil minister of the United Arab Emirates, said in an interview published today by the semi-official newspaper al-Ittihad that world oil producers should limit their output to avert a price war.

title: ISLANDERS GET EVEN WITH A BIG RIVAL
description: The Islanders both saved face and recovered Coach Al Arbour's respect this weekend when they split a home-and-home series with their bitter division rivals, the Washington Capitals. The games were almost mirror images of each other, with the Capitals dominating by 5-3 at home on Friday night and an agitated group of Islanders reciprocating with a 5-3 victory at Nassau Coliseum Saturday night.

title: PATRIOTS ADD LOSS TO DOLPHIN WOES
description: A little imagination, a lot of solid running and exceptional pass defense when it mattered most enabled the New England Patriots to overcome an otherwise sloppy performance today and beat the Miami Dolphins, 17-13.

title: Sheldon S. Levy, 58, Is Dead; State Supreme Court Justice
description: Sheldon S. Levy, an acting justice of the State Supreme Court and a judge of the New York City Civil Court, died, apparently of a heart attack, yesterday at his home in Manhattan, a family spokesman said. He was 58 years old.

title: 200 Teen-Agers Fight Outside Theater on L.I.
description: A youth was thrown through a plate-glass window Saturday night during a fight among more than 200 teen-agers leaving a theater showing a horror movie and the rap film ''Krush Groove,'' the police said.

title: SPACE ARMS SCIENTISTS IN U.S. SELLING RIGHTS TO DISCOVERIES
description: A handful of Federal scientists quietly at work in their laboratories have touched off a heated national debate.

title:
SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS;

Passing Fancy
description: Since 1973, when Coach LaVell Edwards of Brigham Young University decided that the best way for the school to win was with an passing game, the Cougars have passed the legacy from quarterback to quarterback as consistently as they have passed the football. Beginning with Gary Sheide and following, in unbroken order, with Gifford Nielsen, Marc Wilson, Jim McMahon, Steve Young and now Robbie Bosco, B.Y.U. has thrown for averages of 3,200 yards and 28 touchdowns a season.

title: COURT WILL HEAR SOVIET SHIP PLEA
description: A Federal appeals court has scheduled arguments for Monday on whether to prevent a Soviet freighter from leaving the United States until American officials can again interview a sailor who jumped from the ship several days ago and was returned by the Border Patrol.

title: Popular Culture
description: James Smithson died in England in 1829, leaving his considerable property to found in Washington ''an establishment for the increase & diffusion of knowledge among men.'' When President Johnson in 1966 accepted on behalf of the nation the art collection now housed in the Smithsonian's Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden, he called the works ''expressions of man's will to make sense of his experience on earth, to find order and meaning in the physical world about him, to render what is familiar in a new way.''

title: Fassbinder Play's Debut Postponed in Frankfurt
description: The Kammerspiel theater decided today to postpone until the middle of the month a play by the late Rainer Werner Fassbinder that has been branded as anti-Semitic by Jews.

title: SOLOMON G. HEIFERMAN, DEMOLITION EXECUTIVE
description: Solomon G. Heiferman, a wrecker who cleared away large sections of New York City to make way for such projects as the United Nations, the Coliseum, and Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village, died at his office in Queens Thursday after a heart attack. He was 77 years old and lived in Forest Hills.

title: MIAMI MAYORAL RACE HINGING ON ETHNIC DIVISIONS
description: When a fair campaign practices committee was organized last spring in an attempt to curb the ethnic smears of Miami politics, its formation was compared to sending Salvation Army soldiers to keep the peace in Beirut.

title: GUATEMALANS VOTE FOR CIVILIAN CHIEF
description: Guatemalans turned out in large numbers today to cast ballots in an election that many hope will produce a stable civilian Government free of military influence.

title: MARCOS DECLARES HE'LL CALL A VOTE EARLY NEXT YEAR
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos announced today that he intended to call for an early presidential election to settle what he called a ''silly claim'' that his Government is inept.

title: A BOOK ON HASIDIM HELPS AUTHOR RECLAIM ROOTS
description: When Lis Harris decided to write about a Hasidic family, some of her friends tried to shoo her away from the subject. ''I don't like them,'' she recalls more than one friend saying of the Hasidim.

title: Topics;   Profits of Planning Luxury to London
description: Summer is over, the dollar is slipping and the airlines must try harder to woo tourists to Europe. British Airways is offering an irresistible bargain: two tickets for the price of one for first-class travel to London, provided the travelers begin their journey by Dec. 15.

title: REAGAN APPROVAL REPORTED ON PLAN TO WEAKEN LIBYA
description: President Reagan has approved a covert plan aimed at weakening the regime of the Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, according to Congressional sources and Administration officials.

title: U.S. PLANS TO LIFT RULES ON HOSPITAL CARE FOR POOR
description: The Reagan Administration is planning to eliminate rules that require public hospitals built with Federal funds to provide specified minimum amounts of free care to poor people.

title: 'All Holders' Rule Studied
description: Senator Arlen Specter, a Pennsylvania Republican, has decided not to offer an amendment to the S.E.C.'s appropriation bill that would bar the commission from spending money to press its ''all holders'' rule.

title: SCHUBERT'S KICKING LEADS GIANTS
description: Instead of watching the Giants' game on television today, Eric Schubert played in it. It was a good thing for the Giants because the 5-foot-7-inch kicker they signed two days ago made five field goals in leading them to a shaky 22-20 victory over the Tampa Bay Buccaneers.

title: JETS EASY WINNERS AGAINST COLTS, 35-17
description: With a superb first half of error-free football that saw them grab a 35-3 lead over the Colts, the New York Jets began the second half of the season today by producing a 35-17 victory that gave them the finest record in the American Football Conference.

title: CORPORATE EARNINGS UNEVEN
description: Although corporate profits for the third quarter have on the whole been flat to lower, many experts are optimistic about the future outlook.

title: IN EFFORT TO UPGRADE COURTS, KOCH ADVERTISES FOR JUDGES
description: Mayor Koch, confident of re-election, has decided to use the time-honored tool of advertising for an unusual purpose: attracting more qualified applicants for the city's judiciary.

title: PINIELLA ANSWERS THE BOSS'S CALL
description: YES, Lou Piniella had said, ''the owner and I have an interesting relationship.''

title: Supplemental Treasures
description: The ''Treasure Houses of Britain'' exhibition at the National Gallery has not only inspired a glittering round of social events but some complementary shows, long in the planning, at other Washington institutions. The Folger Shakespeare Library is opening today an exhibition called ''The Compleat Gentleman: Books from English Country Homes,'' which includes more than 100 books, manuscripts and engravings from the 15th to the 19th centuries.

title: CHILDREN: TEACHING TOO MUCH, TOO SOON?
description: As the debate over the ''superbaby'' phenomenon intensifies, researchers have coined a verb form to describe it: ''hothousing.'' The word was the focus of a conference here on the trend toward the early educational stimulation of infants and toddlers.

title: Dred Scott Decision Was a Taney Legacy
description: To the Editor:

title: Restore South Africa to General Assembly Now
description: To the Editor:

title: Chipping at Hart's Debt
description: Senator Gary Hart is trying to get the most recent phase of his more-or-less continuous political campaign out of the red before the next phase opens, and he's counting on a little help from his friends. Just now, past contributors to Walter F. Mondale, the 1984 Democratic candidate, and George S. McGovern, the 1972 nominee, are getting letters in which those standard-bearers, seek help for the Coloradan to pay off the debt he ran up last year trying to deprive Mr. Mondale of the nomination.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL TEXAS (AL) - Acquired Pete Incaviglia, outfielder, from Montreal Expos in exchange for Jim Anderson, infielder, and Bob Sebra, pitcher.

title: DISPUTE HAMPERS NICARAGUA REBELS
description: The leaders of the main Nicaraguan anti-Government rebel alliance are divided by politically damaging disagreements over the objectives and tactics of the movement, according to rebel and American officials as well as Congressional sources.

title: U.A.W. Council Rejects General Dynamics Pact
description: The United Automobile Workers said today that its national bargaining council had rejected a tentative settlement of a strike by 5,000 General Dynamics workers who build tanks for the Army.

title: Philharmonia Virtuosi In Town Hall Concert
description: The Philharmonia Virtuosi is a fine small orchestra, directed by Richard Kapp, that has made its home in Town Hall at 123 West 43d Street, a pleasant and historic auditorium that deserves to be restored to mainstream concert use. Mainstream was not the word, however, for the ''Handel and Halloween'' program there Tuesday, a crossover exercise featuring Maureen McGovern. The audience was on hand to be amused, and it was, though it had to hunt at times for causes.

title: THE DANCE: BALLETFORE AT RIVERSIDE
description: FROM the beginning of the performance Wednesday night at the Theater of the Riverside Church, one knew that the members of Balletfore receive meticulous coaching.

title: Devils' Veterans Spark Comeback
description: When a Devils' line produces 10 points in a National Hockey League game it automatically becomes the most prominent line on a team whose stigma has always been a lack of scoring.

title: P.T.A.'S ARE PROTESTING CLOSING OF FLEA MARKETS
description: For the last six years, the Saturday flea market at Public School 183 has been an Upper East Side fixture, a shopper's delight offering everything from used musical instruments and costume jewelry to fresh fruit and vegetables.

title: U.S. ENDS HORSE SHOW AT TOP
description: The United States, which last year lost the international team championship for the first time since 1973, returned to its winning ways yesterday as the National Horse Show closed a six-day run at Madison Square Garden.

title: IN MALAYASIA, THE TIN CAPITAL, CRISIS IS WORRISOME
description: Tin is more than a commodity to this prosperous-looking Southeast Asian city. It is the metal that built Kuala Lumpur.

title: U.S. DEBATING NEW POLICY ON ALIEN MINORS' RIGHTS
description: The Immigration and Naturalization Service, in an effort to reach a new policy for dealing with children in its custody, is negotiating with critics who contend the service has been ignoring the children's rights.

title: REAGAN CAUTIOUS ON JEWS IN SOVIET
description: In an effort to increase the emigration of Jews from the Soviet Union and improve Soviet treatment of dissidents, American officials have formulated a carefully calibrated strategy for President Reagan to use in his Geneva meeting with Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader.

title: Amsted Gets Buyout Offer
description: Amsted Industries said that a senior management group and a recently formed employee stock ownership plan have made a joint offer to acquire the construction and industrial equipment maker in a leveraged buyout.

title: PROSTTUTES' IMPACT ON SPREAD OF AIDS IS DEVELOPED
description: A SCIENTIFIC debate has emerged over whether prostitutes are likely to spread AIDS among heterosexuals, a group that has largely been spared by the nation's AIDS epidemic up to now. Many scientists, including New York City's health authorities, say the fear that prostitutes will be a major conduit of acquired immune deficiency syndrome into the heterosexual community is unjustified. They argue that while many American prostitutes are at risk of developing AIDS themselves, there is no evidence they are transmitting AIDS to their patrons and that, more generally, the spread of the AIDS virus from women to men through sexual contact has rarely been documented.

title: LESSONS EMERGE FROM MEXICAN QUAKE
description: The powerful earthquake that killed at least 7,000 people here in September was, in effect, a deadly test in nature's real and very brutal laboratory. And it has yielded important lessons in building design and city planning.

title: TAMBRANDS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After extraordinary charges of $1,296,000 for the quarter for the company's polyacrylate replacement program and $4,266,000 for the nine months for an increase in the provision for the Tampax Super Plus tampon replacement program.

title: REAGAN FORESEES AN END TO A-ARMS
description: President Reagan has told four Soviet journalists that the United States will not deploy a space defense against enemy missiles until both countries ''do away with our nuclear missiles, our offensive missiles.''

title: PENTAGON AND CRITICS DISPUTE ROLES OF SPACE ARMS DESIGNERS
description: THE Pentagon is facing rising criticism over the fact that key assessments of the Strategic Defense Initiative, or ''Star Wars,'' are being made by the same private contractors that may reap enormous benefits in building the project.

title: What Reagan Means by Judicial Responsibility
description: To the Editor:

title: OZARK HOLDINGS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: Talking Business with Schwitter of Swiss Union Bank;   Dollar Plunge Called Possible
description: The dollar, after retreating since September, when the five major industrial powers decided to force it lower, has more or less leveled off. The calm is not caused by government policy makers, analysts say, but by a combination of market forces.

title: HARVARD INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including an extraordinary net income of $729,000 for the quarter and year from prepayment of a bank fee.

title: FROM BEENE AND BLASS: 2 SPRING SIGNATURES
description: Two world-class designers began the second week of New York spring fashion openings yesterday morning with elegant clothes that have distinction. Nobody is likely to confuse the work of Geoffrey Beene and Bill Blass. Each provides the woman who does not flinch at price tags of $3,000 to $4,000 with evening clothes that can hold their own with those made anywhere in the world.

title: CHARGES DISMISSED IN OHIO EXPLOSION
description: A judge ruled today that there was no evidence that criminal activity led to an explosion that killed three repairmen at Akron's trash-burning steam plant, and dismissed all charges against a New Jersey waste hauling company and five individuals.

title: MAJOR BENEFACTOR OF AMERICAN SCIENCE
description: A dispatch from Ithaca, N.Y., on Nov. 3 about a popular psychology course at Cornell University misidentified the professor who teaches it. He is James B. Maas.

title: The Seat-Belt Law And Cuomo's Daughter
description: When it comes to the New York State seat-belt law, Governor Cuomo has a lot of positive things to say. But yesterday, on his behalf, the Governor's office would only say, ''The law is the law.''

title: ANOTHER SURPRISE BY PERRY
description: And the legend grows. This time, William (The Refrigerator) Perry, the 308-pound defensive tackle for the Chicago Bears who had already run for a touchdown, caught a pass for a touchdown on a play that completely bamboozled the Green Bay Packers.

title: RICHARD OULAHAN
description: Richard Oulahan, a writer and editor for Time Inc. for three decades, died at his home in Manhattan Sunday. He was 67 years old.

title: LADY OF THE FLOWERS
description: THE shop is a clutter of antique cupids, towering bouquets of faded hydrangea, heather and delphinium, fringed lampshades (one studded with pink and red silk roses), needlepoint chairs, white wicker, antique mirrors, lace pillows and fragile orchids. There is Mozart on the radio, green moire with black lace and gold ruffles skirting the sink and a bird in a gilded cage.

title: NAPCO INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: CLUETT AGREES TO SALE TO PEPPERELL
description: Cluett, Peabody & Company, in a move to elude the takeover endeavors of a California investor group, said yesterday that it had agreed to be acquired by West Point-Pepperell Inc., the giant textile and soft goods manufacturer, in a transaction valued at $375 million.

title: NEARLY 1,000 VIOLATIONS CITED AT A HOTEL FOR THE HOMELESS
