description: If the Nets ever learn to play consistently for an entire game, they could become a very good basketball team. But for the time being, they are winning with the help of the home-court advantage and some strong second-half play.

title: MEDICAL CARE INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss of $996,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: In One Way, Alas, It Is Like Bombay
description: To the Editor:

title: Big Brother's New Insurance Policy
description: To the Editor:

title: WHO OWNS NEW YORK?
description: Back home in Surrey, England, they call it a ''sitter'' - the ball just sitting there on the grass, waiting to be flicked into the goal. Some soccer players never see an easier ''sitter'' than the one Paul Richardson of Columbia University kicked off the outside of the goal post in the first half yesterday.

title: COAST THRIFT UNITS PROSPERING
description: In perverse moments, Herbert M. Sandler almost wishes interest rates would rise.

title: Grey Receives Account For Mitsubishi Motor
description: Grey Advertising, a one-time Ford agency that last month lost its Renault account, yesterday was assigned the Mitsubishi Motor Sales of America account, which trade press sources put at around $37 million.

title: President Is Appointed By Encore Computer
description: The Encore Computer Corporation, a start-up company that has faced difficulties in bringing its new superminicomputer to market, yesterday named James R. Pompa, a former executive at Honeywell Inc., to be president and chief operating officer.

title: New Editor Is Named At Times of London
description: Charles Wilson, deputy editor of The Times of London, was appointed editor today, succeeding Charles Douglas-Home, who died of cancer last week.

title: The U.N. Today; Nov. 6, 1985
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: SENATE, ENDING IMPASSE, APPROVES ENVOY TO CHINA
description: The Senate today approved the nomination of Winston Lord as Ambassador to China after President Reagan intervened to end a five-week impasse caused by the opposition of Senator Jesse Helms.

title: A 'Special Briefing'
description: Confidant of President Reagan's attitude but fearful that he might be ill-prepared to take on the Russians at Geneva, the Heritage Foundation is planning a ''Special Briefing on the Reagan-Gorbachev Summit'' this morning. A panel of four authorities, headed by Richard V. Allen, the President's former national security adviser, will make public 60 pages of recommendations described by the foundation as ''the advice the State Department would give President Reagan if the State Department shared the President's world view.'' Mr. Reagan is not expected to attend.

title: PARK-OHIO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Net income, including a tax credit of $786,000 for the quarter and the nine months.

title: TANDEM COMPUTERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a tax credit of $9,700,000 for the quarter and the year.

title: ALASKA MAY FACE A STRONG BATTLE FOR THE POST OF GOVERNOR IN 1986
description: Gov. Bill Sheffield, a Democrat, says he will decide next spring whether to run for a second term. Meanwhile, a big field of strong Republican candidates has lined up to compete for his job in 1986.

title: LIQUID AIR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Rumor Flood And the S.E.C.
description: OCTOBER 1985 will long be remembered on Wall Street as the month when the rumor was king. The stock of dozens of corporations rose and fell in frantic fashion as gossip of supposed merger deals whipped around the trading floors.

title: Arafat Meets Mubarak For Two Hours in Cairo
description: President Hosni Mubarak met for more than two hours today with Yasir Arafat, the leader of the Palestine Liberation Organization, in an effort to ease strains in relations in the aftermath of the hijacking of the Italian cruise ship Achille Lauro.

title: Demand for Democracy
description: One of the most hard-earned votes yesterday was cast for Evan E. Edwards, the Republican candidate for City Council in the Fourth District in Manhattan.

title: A KEY WITNESS SETS OFF UPROAR WITH RESPONSES
description: Jurors and spectators laughed, the judge banged on the bench with his palm and defense attorneys smiled yesterday as a key prosecution witness in the trial of 10 reputed members of the Gambino crime group gave irreverent, sarcastic responses to questions under sharp cross-examination.

title: BILLIE HOLIDAY REISSUES
description: ''BILLIE HOLIDAY ON VERVE 1946-1959,'' a boxed set of 10 LP's that was assembled and manufactured by Japanese Verve and is being imported into the United States by Polygram, poses several questions, some old, some new. The oldest question is whether Miss Holiday's singing during these last 13 years of her life bears comparison with her classic recordings of the 1930's, when she was sympathetically accompanied by brilliant musicians like Lester Young and Teddy Wilson.

title: A LONDON FASHION SHOW FIGHTS FAMINE
description: If rock stars could do it, why not fashion designers? A few months ago, Bob Geldof, the rock musician-turned-fund-raiser for the starving of Africa, presented that idea to Jasper Conran, the young British designer.

title: SUN CHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss of $147,000 for the quarter and $428,000 for the nine months from discontinued operations.

title: BLESSINGS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 5
description: b-Including a gain of $1,245,800, or 76 cents a share, from the sale of discontinued diaper service segment.

title: NERCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company is 90 percent owned by Pacificorp.

title: Maxxam Deal Hits Snag
description: A California judge today temporarily halted the Maxxam Group's acquisition of the Pacific Lumber Company.

title: CAPITAL THEORIES: MASTER SPY OR FATHER'S ANGST?
description: The case of the double defector teased this city today with an array of hypothetical scenarios, most of which portrayed the Soviet intelligence agent as either a master of duplicity or a victim of personal frailty.

title: AUTO SALES DOWN 14.1% IN THE OCT. 21-31 PERIOD
description: Sales of new American-made automobiles continued to slide in late October, with sales down 14.1 percent in the last 10 days of the month from the period a year ago, the manufacturers reported here today.

title: FLORIDA NO. 1 ON COMPUTER
description: Florida, unseated as the top-ranked team last week by Michigan, regained the No. 1 spot in The New York Times's computer ranking after its defeat of Auburn. Ohio State, which upset Iowa, moved from ninth to second and Michigan went from first to seventh after tying Illinois.

title: EX-LEGISLATOR USING OLD SKILLS IN SEAWAY JOB
description: When James L. Emery was picked by President Reagan to run the United States portion of the St. Lawrence Seaway, he was told he would have to do something about the destructive competition among the Great Lakes ports.

title: German Output Down
description: West German industrial production fell two-tenths of 1 percent in September, the Government said today in a preliminary report. This followed a revised August drop of 3.2 percent.

title: A Position of Policy
description: L. Kirk O'Donnell, general counsel to Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. since 1978, is leaving Congress to become president of the Center for National Policy, a Democratic research group. He will succeed Ted Van Dyk, who is resuming practice as a private consultant. Mr. O'Donnell is a 39-year-old lawyer who managed Mayor Kevin H. White's re-election campaign in Boston in 1977 and became his executive assistant. Mr. O'Neill predicted his legal aide would do well financially in the move because he regards the center and similar Washington organizations as ''think banks.''

title: Just Ducky
description: Representative Silvio O. Conte is well-known among his colleagues as a duck hunter, so the thematic invitation to his birthday party is headlined ''The Duck Stops Here,'' and the list of hosts includes Mallard Fillmore, Sir Francis Drake, Mahatma Gander, Goose Gos-sage ''and other assorted quacks.'' The Massachusetts Republican actually turns 64 on Saturday, but this evening at the Botanic Garden at the foot of Capitol Hill, celebrants are invited to appear in ''Attire: Fowl.''

title: BERKLEY, W R CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including realized gains on investments of $428,000 for the quarter and $1,859,000 for the 9 months. c-Including realized gains on investments of $958,000 for the quarter and $1,038,000 for the 9 months. d-Net loss.

title: THE CHURCH IN LATIN AMERICA SEEKS INTERCHANGE WITH JEWS
description: Strongly influenced by the activist bishops of Brazil, Latin America's Roman Catholic Church is for the first time giving priority to establishing a permanent interchange of ideas with the region's Jewish groups.

title: Tough Job
description: Ron Brewer, a seven-year guard who was waived by the Nets last week, has been tapped by the Chicago Bulls to replace the injured Michael Jordan, the club announced. Jordan, who broke his foot last week, will be out six weeks. Brewer, a former Arkansas star, has averaged 12.6 points a game in a career that has included stints with the San Antonio Spurs, the Cleveland Cavaliers and the Golden State Warriors.

title: U.N. Calls on Vietnam To Leave Cambodia
description: The General Assembly called on Vietnam tonight to withdraw its forces from neighboring Cambodia.

title: THE MESSAGE ORTEGA TOOK BACK HOME
description: To the Editor:

title: Move by Armco
description: Armco Inc., a steel company that has been in Middletown, Ohio, for 85 years, said that it planned to move top corporate executives to Morristown, N.J. Dr. Robert E. Boni, president and chief executive, said the move, which involves a 22-member corporate executive group, was part of a decentralization strategy.

title: MARQUEST MEDICAL PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 28
A Loss for Tandon In Mitsubishi Case
description: The Tandon Corporation, a maker of disk drives for personal computers, has lost a crucial decision in its patent-infringement case against the Mitsubishi Electric Corporation of Japan.

title: TISSUE RESEARCH WINS AWARD
description: Dr. Hugh O. McDevitt of Stanford University, an expert in research on the links between human tissue types and susceptibility to disease, was named winner of the $100,000 Lita Annenberg Hazen Award for excellence in clinical research yesterday.

title: MANHATTAN NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
HARLYN PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DEFENSE LAWYERS ARE SPLIT AT COLOMBO RACKETS TRIAL
description: An unusual conflict arose at the Colombo crime ''family'' racketeering trial yesterday when lawyers for 2 of the 11 defendants made what lawyers for three others described as prejudicial statements to the jury.

title: The Rev. Morton Hill; Led Pornography Foes
description: The Rev. Morton A. Hill, founder and president of Morality in Media, a Manhattan-based antipornography group, died Monday at a Jesuit residence at Fordham University in the Bronx. He was 68 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: 900 G.E. Jobs To Be Ended
description: The General Electric Company said today that it would eliminate 900 manufacturing jobs at its Appliance Park complex and buy room air-conditioners from an outside supplier.

title: AIDS HOME PLANNED IN WEST VILLAGE
description: The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York is planning to turn the rectory of a West Village church into a shelter for AIDS patients, a priest at the church said yesterday.

title: Castro Bends a Little
description: Twenty-six years after the Cuban revolution, President Fidel Castro is as firmly entrenched as ever, in undisputed control of his 10 million countrymen.

title: KNICKS SUFFER ANOTHER DEFEAT
description: When Jack Sikma looks around these days, he sees the future.

title: Gray Signs With Giants
description: The Giants today signed their holdout wide receiver Earnest Gray to a contract reportedly worth between $200,000 and $225,000 in each of two years.

title: Bid Rejected By Minebea
description: Trafalgar Holdings Ltd. said today that the the Minebea Company had formally rejected a $1.4 billion offer to acquire the Tokyo-based manufacturer of ball bearings and electronic parts.

title: Allied Stores Said To Seek Mall Sales
description: The Allied Stores Corporation, one of the country's largest retail chains, is offering to sell its five regional shopping centers, retail trade sources said yesterday. The centers include the Bergen Mall in Paramus, N.J.

title: LAMPS TO CAST A COZY GLOW
TERESSA BELLISSIMO, INVENTOR OF SPICY BUFFALO WINGS, DIES
description: Teressa Bellissimo, who invented the Buffalo-style chicken wings that won international culinary respect and fame for her hometown, died Monday. She was 84 years old. Mrs. Bellissimo died in her apartment above Frank and Teressa's Anchor Bar and Restaurant on Main Street, which she and her late husband, Frank, opened in 1940.

title: Price Is the Difference In Generic Drugs
description: To the Editor:

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: Value of Home Life
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: MESA PETROLEUM CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PERSONAL HEALTH
description: DESPITE the widespread concern about drug use and abuse by young Americans, alcohol remains teen-agers' most widely used mind-altering substance and the one that is most likely to get them into trouble. In one national survey, nearly a third of high school students who drank at all were ''alcohol misusers'' or ''problem drinkers'' - that is, they had been drunk at least six times in the previous year or had had serious difficulties two or more times that year as a result of drinking.

title: GREY ADVERTISING INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Revenue figures represent gross billings.

title: Soviet Women Lead In World Gymnastics
description: Olga Mostepanova scored a perfect 10.0 on the balance beam tonight to lead the Soviet Union to the top of the team standing after the women's compulsory exercises at the world gymnastics championships.

title: BASTIAN INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Year to July 31
description: b-Including a net gain of $1,945,000 on the disposal of subsidiaries. c-After a net loss of $189,000 on the disposal of subsidiaries and an extraordinary gain of $606,000.

title: TWO PARTIES SPLIT GOVERNORS' RACES WHILE MANY CITIES CHOOSE MAYORS
description: The nation's major political parties divided the spoils from yesterday's two gubernatorial elections, with Democrats and Republicans each claiming a major victory of national significance.

title: PIONEER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Revenue figures represent revenues from continuing operations.

title: MODERN PAINTINGS SOLD
description: Arshile Gorky's ''From a High Place,'' an untitled Surrealist oil painting on cardboard, sold last night at Sotheby's for the highest price ever paid at auction for a work by the artist.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: I HAVE had a passion for mussels since childhood, when my mother would prepare them in dozens of ways - fried, steamed mariner's style, poulette in a cream and egg sauce and so on. Perhaps my favorite was her mussel soup, or rather soups, since she developed many variations on that theme: mussels in a tomato broth, in cream, mixed with any of a dozen herbs that grew in our garden.

title: ARMSTRONG RUBBER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Net income for the latest fourth quarter was increased by approximately $2.5 million, or 24 cents a share, from a gain related to the purchase of annuity contracts for certain retirees which was partially offset by expenses associated with a special severance plan offered to some salaried employees. Result for the period from Jan. 1, 1985 through Sept. 30, 1985 include operations of Balckstone Corp.

title: A SEMINAR ON WINE TO HELP DEMYSTIFY GERMAN LABELS
description: ONE doesn't have to enroll in the German Wine Academy to learn how to decipher a German wine label. But it helps. After five days of morning-to-night field trips to vineyards, wineries and shippers in 7 of West Germany's 11 wine regions - the Rheingau, Rheinhessen, Rheinpfalz, Mittelrhein, Mosel-Saar-Ruwer, Nahe and Baden - numerous lectures and tastings of some 165 mostly low-alcohol bottles, the Gothic label is demystified: Even novices can conquer the distinctions among kabinett, spatlese, auslese, beerenauslese, eiswein and trockenbeerenauslese, and between ''Q.b.A.'' and ''Q.m.P.''

title: 34 Hurt, 150 Arrested In Mass Protest in Chile
description: At least 34 people were injured and about 150 arrested in clashes with security forces during protests today, the police said. Four of the injured had gunshot wounds.

title: BERGERAC QUITS REVLON POSTS
description: Michel C. Bergerac, who engineered Revlon Inc.'s diversification into health care but lost a three-month battle for control of the company, resigned yesterday as Revlon's chairman and chief executive.

title: LILY-TULIP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a tax loss carryforward of $2,210,000 for the quarter and $5,072,000 for the year-ago.

title: GERMANS CONTROL SPACE TESTS FROM HAMLET
description: For one week this unlikely Bavarian hamlet with a name as long as a countdown has been the control center for scientific experiments aboard the United States space shuttle Challenger.

title: D'AMBOISE RECRUITING IN PEKING
description: It was lunchtime in the dining room of a mansion in central Peking. White-jacketed waiters were ferrying laden platters to and fro. Chiang Kai-shek made his Peking headquarters in the building in the 1930's, and a sense of history weighs on the place like a blanket.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: ALIVE AND WELL Some music never seems to go out of style, and this seems true of the mellifluous, whipped cream melodies that came through Vienna, where operetta was to music what country music is to Nashville. This heritage of the Austro-Hungarian Empire still sings out, locally, on a once-a-month basis in a series at the Austrian Forum, 11 East 52d Street.

title: SOVIET PRESS IS PUBLICIZING DEFECTOR'S RETURN TO FOLD
description: Though Vitaly Yurchenko's reported defection had never been mentioned in the Soviet press, his return to the Soviet fold was a major event on the television news.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, NOVEMBER 6, 1985
description: Companies

title: WASHINGTON REAL ESTATE INVESTMENT TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including an extraordinary credit of $2,332,481 for the quarter and the nine months.

title: Tanzania Swears In Mwinyi as President
description: Julius K. Nyerere, 63 years old, gave up the presidency to his hand-picked successor today in a ceremony in a packed stadium.

title: Ex-Cell-O Plant
description: The Ex-Cell-O Corporation, a large and diversified maker of automotive components and industrial equipment, said it had failed to find a buyer for its London, Ontario, plant and intends to close it on Nov. 29. The move affects nearly 200 people who make milling machines, machining centers and transfer lines. Ex-Cell-O cited a ''severely depressed market'' and Japanese competition for the closing.

title: HELP FROM ENGLAND KEEPS HARTWICK STRONG IN SOCCOR
description: In spite of the arrival of the big schools on the fast-growing college soccer scene, little Hartwick College with its 1,400 students remains a power. Although the Warriors' loss to Long Island University last weekend dropped them to ninth place in the national collegiate rankings, they were ranked second before that defeat, behind the defending national champion, Clemson.

title: PURCELL IS RE-ELECTED COUNTY EXECUTIVE IN NASSAU
description: Francis T. Purcell, the Republican incumbent, won re-election last night to a third term as Nassau County Executive.

title: GENERAL DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Net income for the latest 9 months reflects a nonrecurring charge for loss on disposition of Port St. John utility system.

title: SCIENCE MANAGEMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $95,000 for the quarter and the nine months, a tax credit of $35,000 for the quarter and a net gain of $950,000 for the nine months on the sale of ownership in a computer joint venture. c-Including a tax credit of $1,014,000, a net gain of $607,000 on the restructuring of ownership interest in a computer joint venture and the sale of a wholly-owned computer subsidiary to the computer joint venture, and after a loss of $1,942,000 from equity in the losses of unconsolidated subsidiaries and a net loss of $872,000 from discontinued operations.

title: NEWS SPECIAL ON AIDS TO FOLLOW NBC DRAMA
description: NBC plans to broadcast a special news report and undertake an educational campaign in conjunction with ''An Early Frost,'' a drama about AIDS that is scheduled to be shown Monday evening.

title: Democracy Unfolds in Argentina
description: President Raul Alfonsin fell short of a sweeping vote of confidence in Argentina's midterm elections, but his democratic cause nonetheless gained while the most backward-looking Peronists lost ground. Still, friends of freedom can scarcely afford to relax; the foreign debt problem remains dangerous and Washington's help on this issue remains essential.

title: WEDNESDAY, NOVEMBER 6, 1985
description: International

title: ENERTEC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
GUARANTY NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including capital gains of $64,000 for the quarter and $1,173,000 for the 9 months. c-Net losses including capital gains of $1,066,000 for the quarter and $1,147,000 for the 9 months.

title: Mixed Emotions
description: For Galen Hall, the emotion had to be mixed but gratifying.

title: A Question of Power, A Powerful Questioner
description: Over the years Congress has decreed that more than a dozen agencies it created, beginning in 1890 with the Interstate Commerce Commission and today including the Federal Reserve Board and the Federal Trade Commission, must be independent of Presidential control.

title: ENTERRA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary tax credit of $2.2 million for the quarter and 9 months and a charge of $10.4 million for the quarter and 9 months.

title: College Bans Suspect Water
description: Southeastern Massachusetts University has ordered a ban on drinking the water on campus, suspecting that the water caused students and staff members to become ill, officials said. More than 300 people have suffered stomach cramps and vomiting in the past week. The ban took effect Monday night.

title: GEICO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including realized gains on investments of $22,885,174 for the quarter and $53,998,776 for the 9 months. c-Including realized gains on investments of $5,940,558 for the quarter and $23,103,414 for the 9 months.

title: KEAN URGES A BROADER G.O.P. AND LISTS GOALS FOR 2D TERM
description: With the campaign behind him and an unquestioned mandate in hand, Governor Kean is set to start work on his next political agenda, one he hopes will carry him outside New Jersey as a spokesman for an open and more broadly based Republican Party.

title: XEROX HALTS JAPANESE MARCH
description: Xerox has managed to do what hardly any other American company has done: stop the Japanese advance into its market. And its executives even maintain that in some sectors they are recapturing lost ground.

title: DOW RISES 6.99, TO A RECORD 1,396.67
description: Fueled by strength in blue-chip stocks, the Dow Jones industrial average rose to record levels yesterday as it drew a closer bead on the 1,400 mark.

title: MARCOS'S SURPRISE MOVE
description: With his announcement this week that he intends to call an early presidential election, President Ferdinand E. Marcos has for the moment defused mounting criticism of his Government and has regained the political initiative.

title: Testing for AIDS Offers a Chance to Save Lives
description: To the Editor:

title: PLAN TO SELL F.S.L.I.C.'S BAD ASSETS
description: In a continuing effort to bolster the thrift industry's struggling insurance fund, Edwin J. Gray, chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, announced today that the board had approved the creation of a new semiprivate institution to liquidate the troubled assets held by the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation.

title: 2 VISIT GUATEMALA TO SEEK BROTHER
description: Two brothers of an American journalist who has been missing in Guatemala for seven months asserted this week that neither the Guatemalan Government nor the American Embassy here had done as much as it could to learn the missing man's fate.

title: Restaurant Service
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: PRIMARK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings reflect a two-for-one stock split payable November 15.

title: DAHLBERG INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: CONGRESS IS ASKED FOR $54 MILLION TO AID LATIN ANTITERRORIST EFFORTS
description: The Reagan Administration asked Congress today to authorize $54 million in urgent supplemental assistance to train and equip police and military forces in Central America and Panama to deal more effectively with terrorism.

title: Article 134131 -- No Title
description: An illegal alien from Mexico won $2 million, the top prize in the California Lottery on Monday. He will be able to collect his winnings, but he will have to leave the country or risk deportation, officials said today.

title: POLISH CHIEF TO STEP DOWN AS PRIME MINISTER
description: The Polish leader, Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, is expected to step down as Prime Minister on Wednesday but retain the more important post of First Secretary of the ruling Communist Party, according to diplomats and party sources.

title: Lanier Is Manager of Astros
description: Hal Lanier, a former major league infielder and minor league manager who spent the last five seasons as a coach with the St. Louis Cardinals, was named manager of the Houston Astros yesterday and promptly announced that he would try to hire Yogi Berra as a coach.

title: MORMON PUZZLE: BOMBS AND DOCUMENTS
description: It has been three weeks since package bombs killed a prominent Salt Lake businessman and, in a separate blast that same day on Oct. 15, the wife of a former associate of his.

title: GREENPEACE CASE YIELDS NEW DISPUTE
description: A new diplomatic dispute between France and New Zealand seemed in the making today after the French Foreign Minister asserted that negotiations between the two countries had led to the dropping of murder charges against two French agents in the sinking of a Greenpeace anti-nuclear protest ship in New Zealand.

title: Sony of America Shifts Leadership
description: The Sony Corporation of America, the domestic subsidiary of the Japanese electronics company, announced a restructuring of its organization yesterday, including a series of top-level management changes.

title: Frank Hodsoll Confirmed
description: The Senate has confirmed the appointment of Frank Hodsoll to a second four-year term as chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts. The routine approval came without dissent or debate.

title: ADRIFT IN POLAND: 2 POLICEMEN, SONS OF SOLIDARITY
description: Once a policeman, still a nonbeliever, Zdzislaw Kledzik came by himself to attend a special mass for the police last week. It was held at the Warsaw church where the Rev. Jerzy Popieluszko, a Roman Catholic priest killed by Government security police, once preached pro-Solidarity sermons.

title: S.I. REPUBLICAN LEADING IN RACE FOR COUNCIL SEAT
description: The Republican Party, hoping to win its first seat on the City Council since 1982, led in a Staten Island district by about 200 votes early today, but stopped short of claiming victory.

title: REPUBLICANS IN JERSEY WIN CONTROL OF STATE ASSEMBLY
description: Bolstered by Governor Kean's strong showing, Republicans yesterday won control of the New Jersey Assembly for the first time in 12 years.

title: Not in Washington
description: When Alfredo (Tito) Horford, the 7-foot freshman from the Dominican Republic, was dismissed from the Louisiana State basketball team over the weekend and then disappeared from the L.S.U. campus, there were reports he may have been lured to Washington by an offer to play at American University.

title: Comerica Gives Up
description: Comerica Inc. said that it had withdrawn the application it had filed with the Federal Reserve Board for authorization to acquire the Michigan National Corporation. After Comerica proposed a merger in mid-January, Michigan National's board rejected the offer and on July 10 adopted anti-takeover measures. Faced with the prospect of protracted litigation, Comerica said it had concluded that a merger was not in its best interests, and it also ended agreements to sell several banks in deals that were conditioned upon the merger.

title: Alamito Proposal
description: The Alamito Company, a wholesaler of electric power based in Tucson, Ariz., said that a group of senior managers had offered $251 million, or $110 a share, to take the company private in a leveraged buyout. Alamito's stock rose $11.75 a share, to $105, today on the American Stock Exchange.

title: Alonzo Garcelon, 72, Rifle Association Head
description: Dr. Alonzo H. Garcelon, president of the National Rifle Association, died Monday at the Maine Medical Center here. He was 72 years old.

title: VOTERS BACK DOUBLING JOB AGENCY'S BORROWING
description: A proposed amendment to the State Constitution that doubles, to $600 million, the borrowing limit of the Jobs Development Authority was approved by voters yesterday.

title: COMPLEX PROJECT ENDING AT BANK'S FIFTH AVE. SITE
description: The anticipated completion next month of the Fifth Avenue headquarters of the Republic National Bank of New York will bring to a close one of midtown Manhattan's most complex building projects.

title: June Blossom Is Dead at 74; Arranged Events for Charity
description: June Blossom, a prominent member of New York society, died at Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital Sunday. She was 74 years old and lived on the Upper East Side of Manhattan.

title: 'AFTERSCHOOL SPECIAL' ON CHILD ABUSE
description: CHILD molestation is the probthis afternoon. The subject has already received attention on various prime-time offerings, including episodes of the situation comedies ''Webster'' and ''Diff'rent Strokes.'' But ''Don't Touch,'' the ''Afterschool Special'' on ABC at 4 P.M., is aiming directly for very young audiences, trying to help them and their parents recognize the problem and possible solutions.

title: IC Discussing Rail Line Sale
description: IC Industries said yesterday that it was negotiating the sale of a portion of its Illinois Central Gulf Railroad to a group of investors in a deal that sources said could be worth about $125 million. The portion to be sold runs from Meridian, Miss., to Shreveport, La.

title: ROCHESTER & PITTSBURGH COAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
IIS INTELLIGENT INFORMAION SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
War and Laundry
description: Representative Patricia Schroeder, Democrat of Colorado, had a few words to say about women and combat when the House engaged in debate Monday before adopting a resolution authorizing a memorial to women who have served in the armed forces.

title: Tudor Apologizes
description: As a 21-game winner this season, he could hardly be more eloquent on the mound, but off the field John Tudor, the St. Louis Cardinals' ace, is a reticent sort who likes to keep his views to himself, so much so that he has been known to snap at reporters who try to draw him out. Now after seeing himself portrayed during the World Series as a sullen sourpuss, Tudor has moved to improve his image.

title: EXPERT DISPUTES DECISION ON BOMB
description: Disputing a finding of accidental death by the city's medical examiner, an expert pathologist testified today that the children killed in the confrontation between the radical group Move and the police were homicide victims.

title: CENTEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $1,783,000 for the quarter and $3,780,000 for the 6 months.

title: Jury Awards $2.8 Million In Kentucky Libel Case
description: In one of the nation's largest libel verdicts against a news organization, a jury has decided that the former owner of a Louisville television station should pay a businessman $2.8 million in damages.

title: LIBERTY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including capital gains of $2,830,000 for the quarter and $4,102,000 for the 9 months. c-Including capital gains of $420,000 for the quarter and $903,000 for the 9 months.

title: GURU'S FOLLOWERS IN OREGON VOTE ON RESTORING OLD NAME TO TOWN
description: The disciples of Bhagwan Shree Rajneesh appeared to be following the wishes of their jailed leader today by casting ballots on restoring the name Antelope to this town they took control of three years ago.

title: Sardar H.S. Malik, 90; Former Indian Official
description: Sardar Hardit Singh Malik, a former Indian Trade Commissioner to the United States and Canada, died last week at his home in New Delhi after a long illness. He was 90 years old.

title: GRIFFIN WINS RE-ELECTION AS MAYOR IN BUFFALO, IN REVERSAL OF PRIMARY
description: James D. Griffin, who has spent eight contentious years as Mayor of New York's second biggest city, won re-election tonight.

title: COURT DECISION BACKS TOXIC DUMPS
description: A recent Federal appeals court decision may have far-reaching effects on where toxic waste dumps can be established around the country by making it difficult for communities to reject such sites.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: U.S. PRESS IS WARY ON PRETORIA CURBS
description: American news organizations are unlikely to openly defy South Africa's strict new restrictions on coverage of violent demonstrations, according to officials at the three television networks, wire services, newspapers and news magazines.

title: HORTICULTURAL HOPE: APPLES EVERYWHERE
description: ''RHODE ISLAND GREENING is grown more extensively in New York State than any other apple except the Baldwin,'' said Arthur Ode, standing in the orchard of Washington Irving's Tarrytown cottage, Sunnyside, and addressing a cluster of local apple lovers.

title: PRETORIA BLOCKS ACTIVIT'S VISIT TO U.S.
description: The South African Government overruled a magistrate's court today and withheld the passport of the Rev. Allan Boesak, president of the World Alliance of Reformed Churches and a patron of the multiracial United Democratic Front.

title: Manhattan Executive Guilty in Exports Case
description: A Manhattan business executive has pleaded guilty to illegally exporting electronic equipment with possible military uses to North Korea and the Soviet Union.

title: HALLIBURTON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a net provision of $328,012,000 for South Texas Nuclear Project litigation. c-Net income.

title: HIGH COURT HEARS LEGAL ETHICS CASE
description: The Supreme Court heard arguments today that the rights of a man accused of murder had been violated because his lawyer insisted he tell the truth on the witness stand. Some justices expressed skepticism.

title: Lenin Statue Is Unveiled
description: The Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev today unveiled Moscow's largest statue ever, a 70-foot likeness of Lenin, founder of the Soviet state, the official Soviet press agency Tass reported.

title: WHITMIRE RE-ELECTED IN HOUSTON; DEFEATING FORMER 5-TERM MAYOR
description: Kathy Whitmire won re-election today to a third term as Mayor of Houston, beating back a concerted challenge from a former five-term Mayor, Louie Welch.

title: U.S. JUDGE HEARS PLEA TODAY TO GET SAILOR OFF SOVIET SHIP
description: As a Soviet freighter waited upriver for a load of grain, a Federal district judge today set a hearing for a Ukrainian seaman aboard the ship.

title: COLLEGE TELECASTS SET FOR 2 WEEKS
description: ABC announced yesterday that it would televise either or both of the Notre-Dame-Penn State and Auburn-Georgia football games on Nov. 16, and CBS said it would the Iowa-Purdue and Maryland-Clemson games that day.

title: WINE TALK
description: THIS is turning out to be an excellent vintage year for wine books. Some worthy updating has been done, and some exceptional new books are out as well. Two of the best are Robert M. Parker Jr.'s ''Bordeaux'' and ''Hugh Johnson's How to Enjoy Wine.''

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: Coca-Cola Bottling Co. Consolidated, Charlotte, N.C., said it had agreed to acquire eight soft-drink bottling companies in southwest Georgia and eastern Alabama known as the Haley Group.

title: ENTERTAINMENT PUBLICAIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FRESHMAN GIVES TULANE HOPE
description: Mack Brown, in his first year as the Tulane football coach, compared his team's 58-3 loss at Georgia last Saturday to a collision between a Mack truck and a Volkswagen Beetle.

title: SENATE PRESERVES G.O.P. PLAN TO BALANCE BUDGET
description: The Senate today preserved its Republican leaders' plan to balance the budget by 1991, rejecting a series of Democratic amendments to the bill.

title: HOMEMADE FOODS NOW NEAR AT HAND FOR HOLIDAY GIVING
description: A FEW years ago the only way to buy many homemade foods was to travel to some remote American farmhouse or suburban cottage hundreds of miles away. City dwellers, who can buy almost anything in their shops, could not find these regional favorites. Thanks to an impressive array of delivery systems, however, such high-quality foods are now as near at hand as the telephone or the mailbox.

title: New York City Objects To Drama on Homeless
description: The Koch administration has complained to CBS that a movie on homeless women starring Lucille Ball gives a false impression about New York City's shelters and has asked the network to run a disclaimer, city officials said yesterday. CBS rejected the request.

title: The Message Ortega Took Back Home
description: To the Editor:

title: Caracas Cuts An Oil Price
description: Venezuela, a leading oil supplier to the United States, lowered the price of its heavy crude oil by 40 cents a barrel today, following a similar move by Mexico last week. The move will affect exports of about 538,000 barrels daily.

title: Bailiff in San Diego Case Will Not Be Prosecuted
description: Saying there was no evidence of criminal intent, the California Attorney General's office has declined to press charges against a court bailiff accused of interfering with the jury that convicted Mayor Roger Hedgecock.

title: New Thinking On Poor Lands
description: IN the flush of confidence that swept the economics profession after World War II, there was widespread belief that the greatest mission that lay ahead was the economic development of the poor countries of Africa, Asia and Latin America, and that this could be accomplished through the knowledge and skills of economists.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: The New York State Attorney General's office has joined the Washington-based consumer interest lobby Center for Science in the Public Interest and several other groups in a petition to the United States Department of Agriculture to change the way meats are labeled to indicate that they are lean, extra-lean, light or low fat.

title: Hines Lumber Chief
description: The Edward Hines Lumber Company named its chairman, Howell Howard, to the additional post of chief executive yesterday.

title: SETTLERS IN WEST BANK THREATEN DISOBEDIENCE
description: The leadership of Israel's Jewish settlers threatened today to begin a campaign of civil disobedience in the West Bank if Prime Minister Shimon Peres tries to negotiate any exchange of territory for peace with Jordan.

title: Payment Plan For E.S.M.
description: A court-appointed official overseeing the failed E.S.M. Government Securities Inc. of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., said today that he hoped to recommend first payments to E.S.M. creditors by the end of the year, if the creditors can agree on their shares.

title: TREASURY BOND YIELDS DOWN
description: Treasury bond yields fell to the lowest level of the year yesterday, causing credit market participants to take more seriously the possibility that bellwether 30-year Treasury bond yields might soon fall to 10 percent for the first time since mid-1980.

title: DOYLE DANE BERNBACH GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Rangers Switch Backup Goalies
description: The neatly attired Rangers, with the definite air of professional athletes, filed onto the airplane. And then there was Ron Scott.

title: CORDLESS BEATER
description: THE major drawback of many apartment kitchens is lack of counter space. If the working surface is small, the home chef cannot afford to clutter it with mixers, blenders, toasters, coffee machines and the like. The versatile wall-mounting, multiple-use beater shown here, made by Black & Decker, is well suited to these situations.

title: Daisy K. Shaw, Head Of Guidance in Schools
description: Daisy K. Shaw, a former director of the guidance bureau of the New York City schools, died Saturday at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. She was 72 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: WHAT'S BRED IN THE BONE. By Robertson Davies. 436 pages. Viking. $17.95. THE moderns, says a character in Robertson Davies's new novel, ''are painting the inner vision, and working very hard at it when they are honest, which by no means all of them are. But they depend only on themselves, unaided by religion or myth, and of course what most of them find within themselves is revelation only to themselves.'' Mr. Davies, by contrast, adheres to rather a more old-fashioned approach to art: drawing upon both Jungian myth and religious allegory, he has created a rich oeuvre of densely plotted, highly symbolic novels that not only function as superbly funny entertainments but that also give the reader, in his character's words, a deeper kind of pleasure - delight, awe, religious intimations, ''a fine sense of the past, and of the boundless depth and variety of life.''

title: Civic Duty Done
description: She arrived in a wheelchair to vote, a bent woman in her 60's, wrapped in a cloth coat and a look of determination. Officials at the polling place, Public School 84 at 32 West 92d Street, said she could remain seated, that her companion could flip the ballot levers for her if she wished.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: B.P. Will Enter European Market
description: The British Petroleum Company P.L.C. plans to enter the Euro-commercial paper market for the first time, the company said yesterday in London. B.P. Finance International, the financial arm of the giant energy company, plans to place as much as $500 million of this unsecured short-term commercial paper through its Netherlands subsidiary, B.P. Capital.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Boxing Chris Calvin vs. Greg Haugen, 10 rounds, lightweights, at Showboat Hotel and Casino, Las Vegas, Nev. Calvin, from Nashville, has a 18-3-1 record.

title: U.S. TEST FOR 3 CHEMICALS
description: The Bureau of Tobacco, Alcohol and Firearms said yesterday that it had begun to test Austrian wines for three previously unreported toxic chemicals. Austrian officials say they have found the chemicals in wine but do not think the wine has been exported.

title: Jordan Stumped
description: Michael Jordan, the Chicago Bulls' superstar, reflects on the foot injury that is expected to sideline him for a month and a half: ''Something good has to come out of this. I just can't see what it is right now.''

title: Eyeing the Congressional Past
description: Representative Thomas Claiborne, very much the Virginia gentleman, would have been astounded at the idea that one of his female descendants would one day serve in what in his era was an exclusively male Congress.

title: MODULAR COMPUTER SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

description: Three Democrats, a white man, a black man and a white woman, swept the posts of Governor, Lieutenant Governor and Attorney General here today.

Reform Jews Endorse Sanctuary for Refugees
description: Reform Jews representing 791 synagogues in the United States and Canada ended a five-day convention here today with a denunciation of racism in South Africa and a call to provide sanctuary for Central American refugees.

title: OPERA: 'CAVALLERIA' AND 'PAGLIACCI' AT MET
description: AN opera company that cannot adequately cast ''Cavalleria Rusticana'' and ''Pagliacci'' needs to reassess its recruiting methods. The season's first performance of the Mascagni-Leoncavallo double bill at the Metropolitan Opera Monday night occasionally rose to the level of adequacy in the former work but lost all semblance of quality in the latter.

title: SPINKS SWINGING FOR BIGGER PURSES
description: The sign over the dais at the news conference held by Michael Spinks, the International Boxing Federation heavyweight champion, said, in large red letters: ''RESPECT.''

title: Lakers Toppled By Cavs
description: Edgar Jones, a Cleveland reserve, scored 24 points in leading the Cavaliers to a 129-111 victory over the Los Angeles Lakers tonight.

description: Lowe's Inc., another winner from South Bend, Ind., has been having the advertising for its cat litter products done by J. Walter Thompson's Chicago office since 1981.

title: IN MOSCOW, KEEN INTEREST IN REAGAN ARTICLE
description: President Reagan's interview with Soviet journalists, published in today's issue of the Government newspaper Izvestia, was not exactly the talk of the town, but it did attract considerable attention.

title: FRENCH TOP BRITISH ON U.S. CONTRACT

title: Spike Creates A Controversy
description: Early in the third quarter of the Monday night game at St. Louis, Pat Tilley of the Cardinals caught a deflected pass, outraced the Dallas secondary toward the end zone, gleefully held the ball aloft in his right hand as he sprinted past the 10-yard line and, in a wildly premature burst of celebration, spiked it while he was still a yard or two short of the goal. Or so it seemed on the television replays, and in still photographs shot from the videotape by ABC Sports yesterday.

title: ASTONAUTS PACK UP EXPERIMENTS AS THEY PREPARE TO LAND TODAY
description: The crew of the space shuttle Challenger today put the finishing touches on their many scientific experiments and were set to conclude the weeklong mission with a landing Wednesday at Edwards Air Force Base in California.

title: MUSIC PROGRAM OF WORKS COMPOSED BY WOMEN
description: THERE will always be arguments about the advisability of segregating particular types of specialized music. Does it advance the cause of contemporary music or women's music or black classical music to isolate any of them in concerts devoted solely to those subjects? Or is it healthier to program them in conjunction - direct competition, if you will - with mainstream staples from the past?

title: ELECTRONIC VOTING MACHINES GET TEST
description: While most voters pulled the lever next to the candidates of their choice yesterday, some New Yorkers made their selections amid flashing lights, push buttons and soft electronic tones.

description: Under United States law, aliens who defect are generally free to move about within this country, but the Government may block their departure if it feels the departure would be ''prejudicial to the interests of the United States.''

Lawson, the 48-year-old president, was leaving to join a yet-undisclosed agency, and that the name would be changed to Rosenfeld, Sirowitz & Humphrey to reflect the promotion of Stephen E. Humphrey, 43, former president of the New York operation who has been named president of it all.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Dieter Brock, the Los Angeles Rams' rookie quarterback, underwent surgery to remove a kidney stone and will miss Sunday's game against the Giants at the Meadowlands. He is expected to be replaced by Jeff Kemp, who was the starter until Brock arrived from the Canadian Football League this season. . . . Joe Montana, the San Francisco 49er quarterback, who missed last Sunday's game against the Philadelphia Eagles, is expected to be back in action against the Denver Broncos next Monday night. He had been out after suffering a bruised sternum in the victory over the Rams last week. . . . Eric Laakso, an eight-year veteran offensive tackle, has been released by the Miami Dolphins after not playing since he suffered a severe knee injury in the fourth game last season. . . . Alexis Arguello, the three-time boxing champion who returned to the ring last month after two-year layoff, will meet Billy Costello, the former junior welterweight champion, in a bout Feb. 9. . . . The bout between Thomas Hearns and James Shuler that had been scheduled as a preliminary to next Thursday's postponed bout between Marvelous Marvin Hagler and John Mugabi, has been postponed, too. . . . Danny McManus, the sophomore quarterback at Florida State who suffered head injuries in consecutive games Sept. 7 and Sept. 21, will miss the remainder of the regular season because of an inner-ear problem.

Sales are soaring for takeout salmon mousse and pasta primavera, along with burgers, fried chicken and shrimp with snow peas.

title: THEATER: IBSEN'S 'BRAND'
description: ''BRAND'' is a craggy mountain of a play, lasting six and one half hours in its original version. Published in 1866 when Ibsen was 37 years old, the play was not intended to be staged, but it became the first cornerstone of the playwright's fame. Inspired partly by his own feelings of Scandinavian solidarity, it is a harsh parable about a self-made martyr who forces himself beyond compromise. Brand is godlike in his impulses and he is too large to be accommodated on earth. If Ibsen's other major heroic figure, Peer Gynt, is a picaresque scoundrel, Brand is an idealist who would be savior.

title: O'ROURKE EASILY WINS RE-ELECTION AS WESTCHESTER COUNTY EXECUTIVE
description: Westchester's Republican County Executive, Andrew P. O'Rourke, was an easy winner tonight over Arthur H. Goodman, his Democratic challenger.

description: The informed gossip here is that Secretary of Defense Weinberger will not be at Geneva for the Reagan-Gorbachev talks on the control of nuclear weapons. description: C-SPAN, the cable network that provides documentary coverage of House proceedings, is going international. As a result, Canadian lawmakers will be able to watch in their offices the hearings and call-in shows that C-SPAN covers in Washington, as well as action on the House floor.

description: Members of a House Ways and Means working group today proposed increasing the taxes paid by military and building contractors by eliminating a preferential method of accounting that has allowed them to defer paying taxes on their profits for years.

description: THE first opera Lee Stern ever attended at the Metropolitan was ''Salome'' with Grace Bumbry, about a dozen years ago.

description: An oversized, tricolored banner formed a kind of canopy over the frosty-gray head of Jean-Marie Le Pen, the leader of France's far-right National Front Party, who, interrupted by thunderous applause and rhythmic chanting, delivered a two-hour apologia for his party and its goals last weekend.

title: HOW PLAN AIMS TO BALANCE U.S. BUDGET
description: A bill to require a balanced budget within five years has tied the House and the Senate in knots and provoked widespread debate about how it would work and whether it would eliminate the deficit.

title: STAGE: A BASEBALL MUSICAL, 'BINGO!'
description: THE 1976 movie ''The Bingo Long Traveling All-Stars and Motor Kings,'' based on the novel of the same name by William Brashler, dramatized the exuberance of black baseball teams in the late 1930's without overlooking the despair of marvelous athletes playing our national pastime far from the limelight. ''Bingo!,'' a new musical at the AMAS Repertory Theater, is a bush-league version. On several levels, the show simply fans the breeze.

title: STATEMENT BY GOODE TO BOARD
description: Following are excerpts from the prepared text of a statement by Mayor W. Wilson Goode today to the Philadelphia Special Investigation Commission:

title: HERS
description: I HAD an epiphany at the St. Patrick's Day parade in 1984 - a brisk sparkling Saturday, the sun lavishing gold over all that green. I was on 86th Street with my daughter, who was at the time 4 years old. We were watching the last of the parade. The day and the shot of Jameson's I had just tossed back, back at my friend Eileen's, had raised my dormant Irish Catholic consciousness to a level unmatched since I was 17.

title: CONCERT:P FIVE WORKS BY BLACK COMPOSER
description: THE Brooklyn Philharmonic is an orchestra that takes its community responsibilities seriously. Starting in 1977, the orchestra has played more than 60 works by black, Latin and other ethnic composers, often in those communities and mostly under the direction of Tania Leon. On Sunday in Brooklyn's Prospect Park and again on Tuesday at Manhattan's Cooper Union, 41 Cooper Square, the Philharmonic presented what it called ''a culmination'' of those concerts, a program entitled ''300 Years of Black Classical Music.''

title: NUMBERS AND LETTERS FOR THE HOUSE ADDRESS
description: NUMBERS and letters used to identify a home's address can be found in different materials and a variety of styles. The Williams-Sonoma catalogue carries bold brass numbers in two sizes: four inches high for $4 each and six and three-quarter inches high for $10 each. Varnished to protect them against harsh weather, they screw directly into the side of a home; screws are included. The catalogue can be ordered from P.O. Box 7456, San Francisco, Calif. 94120; 415-652-9007.

title: CRAXI DEFENDS P.L.O.'S RIGHT TO FIGHT
description: Prime Minister Bettino Craxi today defended the right of the Palestine Liberation Organization to ''resort to arms,'' setting off an uproar in Parliament.

title: Cox Voted Best
description: Less than a month after he gave up his job as manager and left the American League, Bobby Cox was named manager of the year in the American League. Cox, who led the Toronto Blue Jays to the American League East championship before leaving to become general manager of the Atlanta Braves, was selected for the honor by a 28-voter panel of the Baseball Writers Association of America, the group that on Monday named Whitey Herzog of the St. Louis Cardinals as the National League's top manager for 1985. Cox received 16 first-place votes and finished ahead of Dick Howser of the Kansas City Royals and Gene Mauch of the California Angels, with Billy Martin, the deposed Yankee manager, finishing a distant fourth.

title: AIDS ISSUE SEEN AS MINOR FACTOR IN HOUSTON VOTE
description: In the end, all the sound and fury over homosexuality and the disease AIDS signified little. Kathy Whitmire easily won re-election as Mayor of Houston Tuesday, political experts said, by convincing Houstonians that she was a good Mayor, better able than her opponent to lead the city out of its economic doldrums.

title: Man Is Fined $1,500 In Niagara Falls Stunt
description: A Canadian mechanic who plunged over Niagara Falls in a barrel was fined the maximum $1,500 today, and the police said he promised not to try the stunt again.

title: CAPITAL HOLDING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including net realized investment gains of $2,049,000 for the quarter and $16,009,000 for the 9 months. c-After net realized investment losses of $1,329,000 for the quarter and $179,000 for the 9 months.

title: Office of Management and Budget;   A Wizardly Act to Follow . . . Now
description: Facing what is, by all accounts, one of the most daunting Governmental tasks in recent years, James C. Miller 3d, the new director of the Office of Management and Budget, is already joking about being willing to sell his memoirs for $1 million.

title: BAN ON HOMOSEXUAL GROUP IN VETERANS PARADE UPHELD
description: Homosexual veterans are not entitled to march under their own banner in the Veterans Day parade next Monday, a Federal trial judge ruled yesterday.

title: PRESIDENT SEES POSSIBLE 'PLOY' IN 3 DEFECTIONS
description: President Reagan said today that the Yurchenko affair, along with two other recent incidents involving Soviet citizens, might constitute a ''deliberate ploy'' to disrupt his coming meeting with Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

title: Compassion on Wall St.
description: Members of the American Stock Exchange are collecting money to help the city's homeless. Since Monday, the group has raised more than $150,000, according to Francis R. Sant'Angelo, a partner in Sant'Angelo & Kory, an exchange member.

title: Translation of a Word Interrupts Crime Trial
description: A dispute over the the translation of an Italian word delayed the testimony yesterday in the ''pizza connection'' trial of 22 defendants on narcotics charges in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

title: CARLOS MOSELEY REFLECTS ON PHILHARMONIC YEARS
description: Today in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, the 35th annual Friends of the Philharmonic Luncheon will honor the man who may have been the New York Philharmonic's greatest friend of all, at least over the last 30 years. That man is Carlos Moseley, who seems finally and forever to have retired - as of Sept. 1, but with Mr. Moseley, you never know if the retirement will stick - as chairman of the orchestra's board.

title: The Uses of Mayor Koch's Total Triumph
description: Racial harmony has not been one of Ed Koch's great successes in two terms as Mayor of New York, but the third-term outlook is promising even on that front. He has, in the last year, worked hard to show sensitivity, and on Tuesday he won by very large percentages even in minority districts. Mr. Koch's victory was not only vast but promising. Note that along with Mr. Koch the voters chose David Dinkins as Manhattan Borough President, the first black elected to the Board of Estimate in 12 years.

title: S.I. COUNCIL RACE LEADS TO 'GUARDED EUPHORIA'
description: Susan Molinari, a Republican City Council candidate from Staten Island, held something of a victory party early yesterday after a night of vote tallying that showed her ahead by 134 votes.

title: U.S. SAYS USE OF COCAINE ROSE SHARPLY IN '84
description: Cocaine use in America rose sharply in 1984 and supplies of the drug were so plentiful in many major cities that the wholesale price for a kilogram dropped, a Government study said today.

title: BOND ISSUES DO WELL IN REFERENDUMS AROUND U.S.
description: Americans who voted on ballot questions Tuesday seemed unusually receptive to bond issues, approving construction of public projects as diverse as a $1.4 billion water reservoir system in Texas and a $5.5 million renovation of the State Capitol in Rhode Island.

title: DANCE: BALLET HISPANICO
description: THERE will be no energy crisis in the dance world as long as Ballet Hispanico keeps moving. That was made clear Tuesday night when the company opened at the Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street, with two premieres and an older work from the repertory. All three were energetic, but when the final curtain fell the company seemed ready to dance everything all over again. Tina Ramirez, the group's artistic director, knows how to make her dancers appear to be having fun even when they're working hard.

title: A WISH LIST FOR MAKING NEW YORK A BETTER CITY
description: ''If you had it within your power, complete power, to change one thing in the city over the next four years, what would you do and how would you do it?''

title: Sacramento Sets Utility Financing
description: The Sacramento Municipal Utility District is offering $491 million of subordinated electric revenue bonds through a Goldman, Sachs group.

title: Sibelius's 'Kullervo'
description: A free performance of ''Kullervo,'' an early work by Jean Sibelius, will be presented by the Columbia University Orchestra and the university's male chorus on Nov. 21 at 8 P.M. at St. Peter's Church, Lexington Avenue and 54th Street. This is believed to be the first presentation of the work in English in the United States; it was performed in Finnish in New York City in 1979 by the Milwaukee Symphony.

title: Learning English Is Goal of Bilingual Programs
description: To the Editor:

title: BIDEN SAYS MEESE IS TRYING TO RESHAPE U.S. CONSTITUTION
description: Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., joining a growing constitutional debate, accused Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d today of advocating ''extreme and unacceptable'' views of the Constitution in an effort ''to rewrite in his own image our most basic law.''

title: A 20-YEAR TERM IS GIVEN IN FIRE THAT KILLED 15
description: An admitted alcoholic who confessed to setting a hotel fire that killed 15 people here 13 months ago was sentenced today to 20 years in prison after a plea-bargaining agreement.

title: JUDGE DECLARES MISTRIAL IN EX-AGENT'S SPY CASE AS JURY DEADLOCKS
description: The espionage trial of Richard W. Miller, a former agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, ended in a mistrial today after the jurors said they were hopelessly deadlocked.

title: EUROPEANS APPROVE HIGH-TECHNOLOGY PLAN
description: Eighteen European governments approved a plan today to increase Europe's technological presence through the development of 10 pilot technology projects.

title: DOLE PLANS SUBPOENA TO BAR SEAMAN'S DEPARTURE
description: Senator Bob Dole, the Majority leader, is considering a plan to have the full Senate subpoena a Soviet sailor in a last-minute effort to delay his departure from the United States, the Senator's chief spokesman said tonight.

title: An Eye-Opener for Reagan
description: One senior Congressional aide thinks the Reagan Administration was caught off guard. ''They were asleep at the switch,'' he says.

title: IRREGULARITIES IN A LARGE CONTRACT LINKED TO SOCIAL SECURITY EX-CHIEF
description: The General Accounting Office charged today that the awarding of Social Security's largest consulting contract was flawed by serious irregularities and potential conflicts of interest on the part of several officials, including John A. Svahn, who was Commissioner of Social Security at the time.

title: MARIAN WILLARD JOHNSON, 81, DEALER IN CONTEMPORARY ART
description: Marian Willard Johnson, a dealer in contemporary art who introduced the work of such artists as David Smith, Lyonel Feininger, Mark Tobey and Morris Graves, died Sunday at her home in Patterson, N.Y. She was 81 years old.

title: MAKING THE MOST OF FALLEN LEAVES
description: LEAVES and trees are on everyone's minds these days. As the leaves trickle down to earth, gardeners know they must remove them. If left on a lawn, leaves will smother the grass. If left on drives and walks, leaves will freeze and make traction difficult.

title: DOUBTS CAST ON OPERATION TO PREVENT STROKES
description: A widely used bypass operation that increases blood supply to the brain to reduce the risk of strokes is ineffective for most patients and may even harm some of them, medical scientists concluded after an eight-year international study.

title: All-Out Team
description: The all-lame, all-halt and all-otherwise-indisposed, taken from a computerized ballot of 96 players listed for the consideration of fans who will elect starting teams to the National Basketball Association's All-Star Game:

title: WIFE OF SOVIET AIDE IS DEAD IN CANADA LINK TO SPY DENIED
description: The wife of a Soviet trade representative stationed in Toronto has died under circumstances that were not immediately disclosed, the External Affairs Ministry reported today.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Knicks vs. Milwaukee Bucks, at Madison Square Garden. The Knicks, who lost their season opener at home, are back after losing all five games on their first road trip of the season.

title: Advertising;   Air Canada Picks Young & Rubicam
description: Young & Rubicam has been appointed the international agency for Air Canada in Britain, Europe, India, the Far East and Australia.

title: Kodak Profits Decline 25.9%; Rockwell Up 0.7%
description: The Eastman Kodak Company, hurt by continuing depressed markets for its products and by the strong dollar, reported yesterday that earnings in its third fiscal quarter of 1985 fell 25.9 percent.

title: 2 CANADIAN PLAN UNITS ATTRACT BID
description: A European investment group has offered $300 million (Canadian) for two aircraft manufacturers owned by the Canadian Government, it said yesterday. Several other offers are expected in the next few days, the Government added, perhaps including one from the Boeing Company. No date for a decision has been set.

title: Teleram Corp. Is Bankrupt
description: The Teleram Communications Corporation, which introduced the first successful portable computer a decade ago, has gone bankrupt.

title: Bad News for a Brown
description: He began the season as the Cleveland Browns' starting quarterback, a 34-year-old veteran playing ahead of the famous rookie, Bernie Kosar.

title: Municipal Bond Officer Leads Goldman to Top
description: When Robert N. Downey came to Goldman, Sachs & Company in 1969, the firm was not much of a force in the municipal bond business.

title: HOW YURCHENKO BADE ADIEU TO C.I.A.
description: Vitaly Yurchenko's dramatic return to Moscow began last Saturday at a fern-decorated restaurant a few blocks from the Soviet Union's embassy compound, according to intelligence sources.

title: College Bans Suspect Water
description: Southeastern Massachusetts University has ordered a ban on drinking the water on campus, suspecting that the water caused students and staff members to become ill, officials said. More than 300 people have suffered stomach cramps and vomiting in the last week. The ban took effect Monday night.

title: Dunes Hotels Unit In Chapter 11
description: The major subsidiary of Dunes Hotels and Casinos of Las Vegas, Nev., filed under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy laws after a bank sought to have a receiver appointed for the resort over its default on a loan.

title: AL LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
JEWISH LEADER ASKS CARDINAL TO SEEK VATICAN-ISRAEL LINKS
description: Edgar M. Bronfman, the president of the World Jewish Congress, made a dramatic public appeal last night to John Cardinal O'Connor of New York, urging him to press the Vatican for diplomatic recognition of Israel.

title: MOSCOW MOVES RAPIDLY IN DEFECTIONS TO THE U.S.
description: When a Soviet agent defects, as Vitaly Yurchenko is said to have done before flying home yesterday, the Soviet Union mounts a standard counteroffensive intended to minimize the security damage and lure the defector back, according to intelligence specialists and former defectors.

title: BOOTHE FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including gains from the sale of securities of $745,000, or 17 cents a share, for the quarter and $1,327,000, or 29 cents a share, for the 9 months and gains from the sale of real estate of $109,000, or 3 cents a share, for the quarter and $3,283,000, or 72 cents a share, for the 9 months. c-Including gains from the sale of securities of $306,000, or 6 cents a share, for the quarter and $1,783,000, or 37 cents a share, for the 9 months and gains from the sale of real estate of $88,000, or 2 cents a share, for the quarter and $4,380,000, or 90 cents a share, for the 9 months. Results have been restated to reflect prior period adjustments for the realization of a portion of the tax credits attributable to IDS Realty Trust at Jan. 31, 1980, when it merged with the company.

title: Players' Names in File
description: The names and telephone numbers of several Boston Celtic players were found in a file seized in a raid on the home of an accused cocaine dealer two weeks ago, according to a report in yesterday's Boston Globe. Although search warrants filed in Brookline (Mass.)

title: HOUSE SIDES WITH SOUTH ON WATER PROJECT COSTS
description: The House of Representatives bowed today to the power of Southern lawmakers by defeating an amendment that would have forced communities of the lower Mississippi to contribute to the cost of new Federal water projects, as others in the nation will have to do.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Nick Vanos, the Phoenix Suns' 7-foot-2-inch rookie center, who has been on the injured list since the beginning of the season, underwent knee surgery and will be on crutches from four to six weeks, the club said. . . . David Braxton of Detroit will defend his North American Boxing Federation superwelterweight title against Mark Medal of Jersey City at Madison Square Garden's Felt Forum Nov. 29.

title: Regency-Wilshire
description: The owners of the Beverly Wilshire Hotel, one of the city's best-known luxury hotels, have agreed to sell the 57-year-old establishment to Regency International Hotels for $125 million, the companies said. The sale is expected to close by Dec. 31. Regency International, based in Hong Kong, owns or manages a dozen resort properties around the world, including the Dorchester Hotel in London, the Regent Hotel in Hong Kong and the Mayfair Regency Hotel in New York.

title: ARMY RECRUITER IS WOUNDED IN AN AMBUSH IN PUERTO RICO
description: Two men on a motorcycle shot and wounded an Army major as he rode his motor scooter to work early today, the police said. An unidentified civilian was also wounded.

title: BENEFICIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss of $5.3 million for the quarter and income of $1.3 million for the 9 months from discontinued operations. c-Including income from discontinued operations of $3.3 million for the quarter and $10.4 million for the 9 months.

title: Too Much Noise
description: The way the Iowa football coach, Hayden Fry, sees it, it was as much Ohio State's fans as the Buckeye football team that dislodged Iowa from its No. 1 ranking last Saturday. The crowd noise at Ohio Stadium was so loud, he said, that his acclaimed quarterback, Chuck Long, became disoriented.

title: SHUTTLE RETURNS AFTER SPACE TESTS
description: With an enthusiastic crowd greeting its return, the space shuttle Challenger landed safely here today after a weeklong scientific mission chartered and controlled by West Germany.

title: Stevens Unit
description: J. P. Stevens & Company, the big textile concern, said it was negotiating to sell its woolen and worsted fabrics division to a management group headed by George C. Langston, the company's vice president for information services. Stevens said the woolen division accounted for annual sales of $175 million out of the company's total annual revenues of $2.14 billion. All apparel fabrics accounted for about 36 percent of J. P. Stevens's sales and about 16 percent of profits.

title: LOW OZONE LEVEL FOUND ABOVE ANTARCTICA
description: Satellite observations have confirmed a progressive deterioration in the earth's protective ozone layer above Antarctica, according to scientists who analyzed data recently sent back from space.

title: SPENCER KIMBALL, MORMON CHIEF, DIES
description: Spencer W. Kimball, paramount leader of the Mormon church since 1973 and an innovator in its policy toward black men, died late Tuesday at his apartment in Salt Lake City. He was 90 years old.

title: Advertising;   Slater Hanft Martin Gets Takara Toys
description: Slater Hanft Martin has picked up the Takara Toys Corporation, which sells those dandy little Japanese-made robot-like watches that can be turned into various other things.

title: Couple Is Found Slain At Ransacked House
description: An 81-year-old man and his 79-year-old wife were found slain yesterday in their ransacked house in St. Albans, Queens.

title: Judge Orders Release Of Funds for Refugees
description: The Reagan Administration must release $11.5 million in refugee assistance to state and county agencies, a Federal district judge has ruled in a dispute between the legislative and executive branches.

title: United Press International And Scripps in Debt Accord
description: United Press International, which filed for protection under bankruptcy laws last April 28, has reached an agreement to satisfy its debts with its former owner, the E. W. Scripps Company.

title: PANEL SHIFTS ON CRASH OF PLANE
description: The National Transportation Safety Board reversed itself today and said the fuel in a plane that crashed last September, killing 16 parachutists and the pilot, was not contaminated with sugar.

title: KASPAROV'S LEAD CUT TO A POINT IN WORLD CHESS
description: Gary Kasparov resigned the 22d game of the world championship chess match in Moscow yesterday and saw his lead in the contest diminish. The 22-year-old challenger is now only one point ahead of the titleholder, 34-year-old Anatoly Karpov, with the score at 11 1/2-10 1/2.

title: Rare Snow Leopard Dies
description: A 2-year-old snow leopard, one of the rarest breeds of cats, died Tuesday at Rochester's Seneca Park Zoo from an infection that set in after her mate bit her, zoo officials said today. The female snow leopard, Tara, was bitten in the right hind leg sometime after Oct. 31, when she was placed in a newly built enclosure with her 2-year-old mate, Janusz, according to the zoo's director, Daniel Michalowski.

title: SYRIA-SPONSORED TALKS ON LEBANON SEEM TO FALTER
description: Syrian-sponsored negotiations between Lebanon's warring factions, an effort to end 10 years of civil strife, appear to have run into serious difficulties that are raising fears of renewed fighting.

title: STAGE: 'LEAVE IT TO JANE,' AT GOODSPEED
description: About five minutes into the second act of the Goodspeed Opera House's production of ''Leave It to Jane,'' the show comes alive. Jerome Kern's music picks up, Walter Painter's dances gain zip, even the comic characters begin to be sort of comical, and we are moving smartly down field to an old-fashioned finale. The obstacle to earlier awakening is the obligation in Act I to lay out the story and the dialogue attached to it.

title: CUS D'AMATO'S GYM
description: Nighttime, and the walk up the poorly lit, steep, narrow wooden staircase to the shadowed area on the third floor seemed long. The street noises grew muffled and the creak of the stairs became louder.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond BuyerSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Summit Talk
description: President Reagan said in an interview last week with the BBC that he had heard that there was no word in Russian for ''freedom.'' He was quickly apprised by his staff that indeed there is such a word, ''svoboda.''

title: CULLUM COMPANIES INC reports earnings for 16 wks to Oct 19
Advertising;   Bates Unit In Atlanta To Close
description: MCDONALD & LITTLE, which was the biggest agency in Atlanta when it was acquired by Ted Bates Worldwide in 1981, is being closed by the parent company because it is losing money, Bates announced yesterday. It has gone from $50 million in annual billings to about $10 million now, according to a Bates spokesman.

title: 17 1/2/ ACCORD PUTS AND END TO THE GREAT TOKEN WAR
description: The Great Token War is over.

title: THE DANCE: BREMEN TROUPE
description: THE dominant experimental current in West German dance has taken the name of ''Dance Theater,'' and one of its leading exponents is Reinhild Hoffmann, who directs the dance troupe within the opera house in Bremen.

title: CITY SEEKS TO CLOSE AIDS-RISK PLACE
description: Mayor Koch announced early yesterday that his administration would go to court later in the day to seek to close an establishment where sexual practices that can transmit AIDS were believed to take place.

title: Judy Collins at Benefit
description: Judy Collins, the singer, will star in a benefit for the Paul Taylor Dance Company Monday at the Rainbow Room at Rockefeller Center. Proceeds from the benefit, which begins at 7 P.M. and includes cocktails, dinner and dancing, will help to underwrite the company's spring season at the City Center, where it will perform April 1 through 27. Tickets are $250 and may be obtained by calling Barbara Grove at 966-6959.

title: THATCHER PROGRAM, OUTLINED BY THE QUEEN, STRESSES ORDER
description: Queen Elizabeth II opened the new session of Parliament today with a speech, prepared by Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, that emphasized the Government's determination to get tough on law and order, encourage private enterprise and overhaul the welfare system.

title: OFFICIALS FAULT WORDING IN BALLOT PROPOSAL'S LOSS
description: The only New York State constitutional amendment to be rejected by voters - out of five that were before them on Tuesday - was a technical change in the tax law intended to save printing costs.

title: Can We Do Something For Legal Aliens, Too?
description: To the Editor:

title: Fidelity Group Sees Profitable Victory
description: Twenty years ago, William G. Simon set up a company, made up of California investors, to challenge RKO General Inc.'s license to operate station KHJ-TV in Los Angeles, on the ground that hometown owners could better manage a broadcast outlet than an absentee corporation.

title: Trial Set in Kennedy Drugs
description: A judge ruled Tuesday that two former bellmen accused of selling cocaine to David A. Kennedy before he died of a drug overdose will stand trial early next year. The judge, John Born of Palm Beach County Circuit, set Jan. 21 as a tentative date for the trial of the men, David Dorr and Peter Marchant, who worked at the Brazilian Court Hotel. Mr. Kennedy, the 28-year-old son of Senator Robert F. Kennedy, was found dead at the hotel April 25, 1984. Mr. Dorr and Mr. Marchant are charged with the sale of cocaine, punishable by up to 15 years in prison.

title: JARUZELSKI STEPS UP, DOWN AND SIDEWAYS
description: Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski stepped down today as head of government, stepped up as head of state and stood where he was as head of the Communist Party.

title: DESPITE HIGH COSTS, KITCHENS ARE FIRST
description: OF all the rooms in the house, the kitchen is perhaps the most expensive to renovate.

title: SAFE HOUSES AND SUCH, IN CAPITAL'S BACKYARD
description: When he announced his decision to return to the Soviet Union on Monday, Vitaly Yurchenko shed some light on the normally secret world of safe houses and intelligence sites.

title: HOLLYWOOD IN CONFLICT OVER AIDS
description: Until the announcement in July that Rock Hudson was suffering from AIDS, the movie industry had been under no special pressure to address the social consequences of the deadly disease.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: EASTMAN KODAK CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 6
Local Landslides, National Lessons;   Governor Kean Shatters an 'Article of Faith'
