description: New Jersey voters did more than re-elect a Governor Tuesday. They transformed Tom Kean from an accidental leader into one with a powerful mandate. In the process, they gave the nation a lesson about new political possibilities.

title: EZRA TAFT BENSON IS IN LINE TO LEAD 5.6 MILLION MORMONS
description: The death of Spencer W. Kimball, president of the Mormon Church, is all but certain to lead to the selection early next week of Ezra Taft Benson, President of the church's Quorum of the Twelve Apostles, as the next head of the 5.6 million-member church.

title: Advertising;   Loss for D.D.B.
description: The Doyle Dane Bernbach Group has released its third-quarter financial statement. And although revenues were up 6.5 percent, to $49.4 million, from $46.4 million in the quarter last year, the agency lost $691,000, compared with a $651,000 loss in the 1984 period.

title: STATE FINED HOSPITAL $40,000 OVER CARE OF TWO WHO DIED
description: Presbyterian Hospital has been fined $40,000 for what it admitted was the ''inappropriate care'' of two children who died after being treated in the pediatric emergency room last year, state officials said yesterday.

title: 2D TENNESSE PLAN ON URGED
description: Gov. Lamar Alexander today urged adoption of his new plan to end crowding in the state's prison system, which a Federal judge has directed may not admit new inmates.

title: AFTER BIG VICTORY, KOCH BACKS BUSINESS TAX CUT
description: Only hours after his election with a record percentage of the vote, Mayor Koch yesterday proposed that the city use at least part of its budget surplus to reduce business taxes if the city's economic recovery continued.

title: Market Place;   A Close Look At the Dow
description: WITH the Dow Jones industrial average closing above the 1,400 mark yesterday for the first time, investors wonder: Is this the start of a big rise for stocks in general?

title: Peru Oil Discovery
description: Petroperu, the Government-owned oil company, has announced the discovery of light, high-grade crude oil in northern Peru. Petroperu's president, Carlos Lizier Gardella, said that the new well was nine miles northwest of Talara, a city 692 miles northwest of Lima and, that it was producing 1,000 barrels of oil daily. There are 42 gallons to a barrel.

title: Peres Vows to Respond If Settlers Stir Unrest
description: Prime Minister Shimon Peres told Parliament in Jerusalem today that the Government would act speedily and unhesitatingly against Jewish settlers in the West Bank who called for civil disobedience to oppose any return of territory to the Arabs for peace.

title: Workers in New York State Foster-Care Agencies Need Support
description: To the Editor:

title: GRAY FACES UNCERTAIN FUTURE
description: Earnest Gray, the seventh-year wide receiver who held out for the first half of the season, joined the Giants today. Whether he will ever play for them again is another question.

title: Soviet Says October Quake Killed 29 People and Hurt 80
description: The newspaper Sotsialisticheskaya Industriya said today that 29 people died in last month's earthquake in the Central Asian republic of Tadzhikistan.

title: Topics;   Time And Money; Pandora Shamed
description: Thirteen hundred years ago in Japan, three slender documents -letters? shopping lists? birth certificates? - were placed in a thin box, which was then wrapped in brocade.

title: CITY'S 38% TURNOUT OF VOTERS CONTINUES A DOWNWARD TREND
description: The unofficial turnout of 1.1 million voters - about 38 percent - in the New York City mayoral election Tuesday was the lowest in many years and continued a downward trend that began in the 1973 mayoral election.

title: DOW TOPS THE 1,400 BARRIER
description: With a concerted push from institutional investors in the waning minutes of trading, the Dow Jones industrial average jumped the historic 1,400 hurdle yesterday with relative ease, ending the day at 1,403.44.

title: A Bronx Man Is Seized In Shooting of Teacher
description: A Bronx man accused of shooting a schoolteacher last August at the direction of her husband was brought to New York City from New Jersey yesterday to face attempted murder charges, the police said.

title: ON THE ROAD TO PEKING: WINSTON LORD'S 'DREAM'
description: Bette Bao Lord cannot look at the photograph without laughing. There, on a wall of her Park Avenue duplex, her husband, Winston, is playing Ping-Pong with Henry A. Kissinger, both of their faces grim with determination.

title: STUDIO GLASS: WORKS BY A MASTER CRAFTSMAN
description: Dale Chihuly has long been in the forefront of studio glass. In his current show at the Charles Cowles Gallery, Mr. Chilhuly has once again demonstrated that he has something new to say about the blown vessel form. The show comprises 15 large single vessels and 4 clusters of smaller vessels cradled in larger ones.

title: TREASURY BOND PRICES DROP A BIT
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds fell slightly yesterday after having risen sharply during the previous six trading sessions.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: POP MUSIC: MORRIS DAY WITH HIS NEW BAND
description: ON records and in the film ''Purple Rain,'' Morris Day came up with one of the funniest personas in pop music - a smirking, preening ladies' man whose first loves are himself and his wardrobe, not necessarily in that order. Mr. Day's group, the Time, broke up after the release of ''Purple Rain,'' and Tuesday he took his new band to the Beacon Theater, Broadway and 74th Street.

title: 52 MODERN ARTWORKS AUCTIONED AT CHRISTIE'S
description: John Graham's untitled 1942 portrait of a woman sold last night at Christie's for the highest price ever paid at auction for a work by the artist - and three times the figure it was auctioned for five years ago.

title: PRESIDENT CRITICIZES TAX PANEL
description: In his first direct criticism of Congressional tax-writers, President Reagan declared today that he was dissatisfied ''with some of the waterings down that are taking place as they discuss it.''

title: Topics;   Time and Money; Cashed Out
description: Earlier this year, a Supreme Court ruling on payment of overtime to municipal workers created a costly problem for local governments. Congress deserves credit for finally acting to correct it.

title: AN ARRAY OF FOLDING CHAIRS
description: THE name of the store Dot Zero, according to its designer and part owner, Harvey Bernstein, ''comes from a map maker's symbol for the starting point in the creation of a map.'' He continued, ''It's the zeroing point, signified by a circle with a dot in the center.''

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Blount Inc., Montgomery, Ala., which provides construction and engineering services, has elected to its board Robert M. Adams, senior vice president of the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Co.

title: In '88, Who'll Win The Baby Boomers?
description: Senator Gary Hart, a likely Democratic Presidential candidate in 1988, has reiterated his opposition to trade protectionism, a stance not calculated to improve his strained relationship with labor leaders. Representative Jack Kemp, a possible Republican candidate, has annoyed his New Right allies by speaking out against the South African Government and keeping quiet about abortion and school prayer.

title: Defense Motions Argued In Alien-Smuggling Trial
description: Attorneys for 11 defendants accused of smuggling refugees from Central America into the United States argued today that charges against their clients should be dismissed because their indictments contained legal flaws.

title: Nike Shutdowns
description: Nike Inc., an athletic shoes and apparel manufacturer based in Beaverton, Ore., said today that it would close two footwear production operations in Saco and Sanford, Me. The company said reasons for the closings include increasing labor and fringe-benefit costs and general economic conditions in Maine. It said the bulk of the operations will move to the Far East, although some of the 650 employees would be transferred to a plant in Beaverton, Me.

title: U.S. AIDES DOUBT SUCCESS AT SUMMIT
description: With less than two weeks remaining before the Geneva meeting between President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev, there is only the slimmest possibility that the talks will produce more than a thorough discussion of each side's views, American officials who just returned from Moscow said today.

title: All Hail Linowitz
description: Sol M. Linowitz, who is now senior counsel at Coudert Brothers law firm, will receive an honorary degree in Washington tonight from Haifa University from its president, Ephraim Evron, the former Israeli Ambassador to the United States. Mr. Linowitz is being honored for his years of diplomatic service, including the negotiations of the Camp David accords.

title: EXCERPTS FROM REAGAN'S INTERVIEW WITH REPORTER'S FROM NEWS AGENCIES
description: Following are excerpts from an interview with President Reagan today by United Press International, The Associated Press, Reuters and Agence France-Presse:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I don't think the negotiation of facts and figures about which weapons and how many and numbers and so forth in weaponry should take place at the summit.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, NOVEMBER 7, 1985
description: Markets

title: TAX AGENT TELLS OF BRIBE FOR A PERSICO VISIT HERE
description: A Federal tax agent who had pretended to be corrupt testified yesterday that he was paid $3,500 in 1977 to arrange for Carmine Persico, the reputed boss of the Colombo crime group, to be transferred briefly from a Federal prison in Atlanta to one in New York.

title: TOP-LEVEL TALKS CALLED FOR ON PLAN TO CUT DEFICIT
description: Senate Republican leaders said today that a compromise in Congress on a bill to balance the budget by 1991 would require negotiations among the Speaker of the House, the Senate majority leader and the White House.

title: NETS MATCH OFFER BY KNICKS FOR KING
description: Yesterday was supposed to be a day off for the troubled Knicks, who returned from their 10-day, zero-victory odyssey early yesterday morning on a red-eye flight from the West Coast. But their calm was spoiled by a distressing series of events.

title: Viacom Seeks Part of MGM/UA From Turner
description: Viacom International yesterday said that it was negotiating with Ted Turner to buy 50 percent of certain assets of the MGM/UA Entertainment Company, including its motion picture production operation.

title: There Is No Housing-Affordability Crisis
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Steel Planning More Price Rises
description: The United States Steel Corporation today expanded its efforts to raise prices on key products, saying it intends to charge $40 a ton more for hot-rolled bar and semifinished steel.

title: Heart Patient's Move Put Off
description: William J. Schroeder, the world's longest-surviving recipient of an artificial heart, will not be moving home to Jasper, Ind., by Thanksgiving as planned because he is too weak, an official at Humana Hospital Audubon said Monday. The official said any trip by Mr. Schroeder to his hometown by Thanksgiving would be a visit. Mr. Schroeder, 53 years old, has visited Jasper once since his heart implant Nov. 25, 1984.

title: CINCINNATI MILACRON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a restructuring charge of $46,250,000 for the quarter and 9 months. c-Net income including a tax credit of $6,047,000 for the quarter and 9 months and a loss of $1,510,000 for the quarter and 9 months from the liquidation of a European unit.

title: COAST RV INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Totem to Buy Lykes Parent
description: The Totem Resources Corporation, a closely held operator of high-speed passenger liners to Alaska, said yesterday that it had agreed in principle to acquire the Interocean Steamship Corporation, parent of the Lykes Brothers Steamship Company. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Lewis Federal Merger
description: The $54 million Lewis Federal Savings and Loan Association of Chehalis, Wash., today acquired the financially troubled Sterling Savings Association of Spokane, Wash. The Federal Home Loan Bank Board assisted the merger with a $1.75 million cash infusion and by agreeing to indemnify Sterling, which had $118 million in assets, against litigation and any undisclosed liabilities.

title: STAGE: 'SLEEPY HOLLOW'
description: IF we allow the Theater of the Open Eye the benefit of a doubt and assume that its production of ''The Legend of Sleepy Hollow'' is meant for children, there is something to be said for it.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: AN economical way to acquire new furniture and get personal satisfaction at the same time is to buy unfinished pieces and finish them yourself. The selection of sizes and designs is wide, and the pieces are sold in many department stores, home centers and hardware stores, as well as in shops specializing in this kind of furniture.

title: FOR BLACK MEN ON THE WAY UP
description: John H. Johnson, the 67-year-old founder and chairman of the Johnson Publishing Company, the nation's largest black-owned company, had long resisted putting out a men's fashion magazine. But he changed his mind last summer, associates say, when he saw the splash made by such publications as Gentlemen's Quarterly and M. This month, Johnson Publishing's Ebony Man, a slick monthly replete with articles on fashion, fitness and personal finance, is making its debut, in hopes of wooing the growing cadre of upwardly mobile black men. Indeed, research indicates that nearly 22 percent of Esquire readers are black. And Gentlemen's Quarterly says 17 percent of its readers are black.

title: MARCOS DISCUSSES PICKING SUCCESSOR
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos opened discussions today on a possible successor, saying the person chosen to be his vice president should have the stature to run the country ''if anything happens to the president.''

title: COMMUNITY JOINS IN AID TO A LANDMARK CHURCH
description: In what preservationists hope will be a model for saving threatened landmarks, the financially troubled Universalist Church on Central Park West has formed an alliance with the surrounding community to raise $400,000 for urgently needed repairs.

title: Wausau Plan
description: The Wausau Insurance Companies said it had signed a plan of affiliation with the Nationwide Insurance Company. Under the plan, Nationwide would buy $250 million of notes issued by Wausau and Wausau would become a part of Nationwide's group of companies and its reinsurance pool, with premiums earned by Wausau after Dec. 31 going into the pool. The agreement has been approved by both companies' boards, but is still subject to approval by the Ohio and Wisconsin insurance departments.

title: Mt. Sinai Hospital
description: A $428.5 million issue of bonds to finance expansion of the Mount Sinai hospital in New York City was tentativley offered yesterday through Goldman, Sachs & Company with a maximum yield of 8.942 percent for 8 7/8 percent bonds due in 2026 at a price of 99 1/4. Also included in the financing are bonds due in 2000 with a yield of 8 3/8 percent and a 2006 maturity with a yield of 8 5/8 percent.

title: Soviet Men Win Gymnastics Title
description: The Soviet Union, led by excellent optional routines from Yuri Korolev and Vladimir Artemov, tonight reclaimed the men's team title at the World Gymnastics Championship. China, the 1983 champion, was second, East Germany was third and Japan fourth.

title: Hartwick Wins
description: Hartwick, ranked ninth in the country among college soccer teams this week, rebounded from a 1-0 loss to Long Island University last Saturday with a 5-0 victory over Adelphi yesterday in Oneonta, N.Y. The triumph raised Hartwick's record to 14-2-1 and dropped Adelphi to 12-5-0.

title: DEMOCRATS CALL VOTE IN VIRGINIA A SWEET VICTORY
description: The Democrats of Virginia today splashed in waters of deep satisfaction, reflecting on their achievements at the polls Tuesday.

title: Advertising;   D.D.B. Loses Sylvania Work
description: After 17 years of creating advertising for Sylvania audio-visual products, Doyle Dane Bernbach has received a letter from the client terminating the relationship.

title: 'EUROPEAN LOOK' IN MAJOR APPLIANCES
description: A VISITOR to a newly renovated urban kitchen is likely to see fewer knobs on the oven with the black-glass door, less chrome on the refrigerator and metal heating disks where the stove's electric coils used to be.

title: FLOOD IN HILLS: THIS YEAR THE TOWN HAD THE DAM
description: Over the last few days this small town, tucked in between sharp, jutting cliffs of the Appalachian Mountains, has sustained tens of millions of dollars in damage in its worst flood in 35 years, But residents had feared an outcome even more devastating.

title: Belzbergs' Stake in Potlatch
description: The Belzberg family of Canada said today that it would seek to increase its stake in the Potlatch Corporation, a forest products producer based here.

title: Limited Partnerships Selling at Record Pace
description: Sales of publicly registered limited partnerships are proceeding at a record pace, according to data compiled by Robert A. Stanger & Company, a Shrewsbury, N.J., firm specializing in analysis of limited partnerships.

title: Gooden Helps
description: When he was a member of the New York City Council, Howard Golden, now the Brooklyn Borough President, found that he was spending a lot of time running around trying to raise money for financially strapped local athletic organizations. ''One time I went down to Wall Street with a little jar to solicit right on the street,'' Golden said yesterday, recalling how he had come to the conclusion that there had to be a better way to support youth athletics than his nickel-and-dime efforts.

title: Tickets to Voznesensky
description: Ford's Theater is making a limited number of tickets available to the public for the recital Monday by Andrei Voznesensky, the popular Soviet poet. Originally the evening was planned with an exclusive audience of Govermnent officials and ranking diplomats.

title: Kendavis Filing
description: Three oil equipment companies owned by the Texas millionaire brothers T. Cullen Davis and Ken Davis filed a plan of reorganization that would repay $915.6 million of debt. The Kendavis Holding Company, Kendavis Industries International Inc. and the Loffland Brothers Company were forced into involuntary bankruptcy in February by eight banks demanding immediate payment of $319 million.

title: The Party of Lincoln
description: One of this country's acute problems, by anyone's reckoning, is the existence of a black underclass: underemployed, locked into deteriorating neighborhoods and bad schools. The whole society's health depends on breaking the cycle of deprivation. It is a matter not only of justice but of the majority's urgent self-interest.

title: A LABOR ACCORD IS REACHED FOR NEW CONVETION CENTER
description: Officials of the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center and several key unions reached an agreement yesterday that includes a no-strike pledge and modification of often-criticized work rules in effect at the New York Coliseum, the center's president said.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: TO most of us, Bill Lear was the developer of the Learjet, which is today, seven years after his death, still the world's best-selling executive airplane. But to the industry that directly benefited from his ceaselessly restless, ceaselessly inventive mind, he was known for having contributed more to the safety of flying than any other man of his era.

title: ROYAL COUPLE ON '20/20'
description: WHAT'S not to like about the Prince and Princess of Wales? It's true she can't keep up with her dance classes, while he shows a mild tendency toward vegetarianism, but the stuff about the Ouija board is bilge; he's never even seen one. We get the Prince and Princess, young William and baby Harry, too, on ABC's ''20/20'' at 8 o'clock tonight. It is a stately piece of work.

title: COLONIAL PENN GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including realized investment gains of $29,000 for the quarter and $13,000 for the 9 months. c-Including a realized investment gain of $7,000 for the quarter and a realized investment loss of $47,000 for the 9 months.

title: G.M. to End Automatic Raises
description: Ending a 37-year tradition, the General Motors Corporation is notifying most of its white-collar work force that beginning Jan. 1 it is eliminating their automatic cost-of-living increases.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Arizona Bancwest Corp., Phoenix, said its shareholders had approved the merger into Security Pacific Corp. for $45 a share, or a total of about $480 million.

title: CUBAN-AMERICANS IN MIAMI MOVE TO THRESHOLD OF POWER
description: Suddenly, after years of seeing their numbers grow and their businesses prosper, Miami's Cuban-Americans have moved to the threshold of political power.

title: Mayor of Suburb of Capital Loses Re-election by 7 Votes
description: The 77-year-old Mayor of Takoma Park, Md., lost his bid for re-election by only seven votes Tuesday.

title: Swiss Inflation Rate Up
description: Switzerland's inflation rate rose two-tenths of 1 percent in October, reflecting higher food prices and transportation costs, the Government said today.

title: Bridge: Crowd Totals Disappointing At Fall Nationals in Canada
description: Attendance at the Fall Nationals of the American Contract Bridge League here has been disappointing. Officials now expect it to be the smallest National Championships in 23 years, and blame the geographical location, which has discouraged many United States players from taking part.

title: AMERICAN FIRST CORP (OKLAHOMA)(O) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CREATING THE PERSONAL KITCHEN: 4 OWNERS AND THEIR RENOVATIONS
description: NEW kitchens today are as varied as the cooking habits of their owners. Designs range from the simple to the complicated, but they have one thing in common, a sophistication tailored to suit personal style.

title: SAN FRANCISCO MOVES TO RAZE UNFINISHED FREEWAY
description: San Franciscans take their scenery seriously, and they proved it again Monday night. After fretting for almost 26 years that an unfinished waterfront freeway was disfiguring the city's shoreline, the San Francisco Board of Supervisors approved a plan to tear it down.

title: NASSAU RESTAURANTS FACING STRICT LIMITS ON DINERS' SMOKING
description: Nassau County today adopted a new public antismoking regulation that would be among the strictest in the country.

title: In Flagrante Defecto
description: Three intelligence stories converge this week to raise fascinating questions. 1. In the case of the Ukrainian seaman trying to defect near New Orleans: Did our National Security Agency inform the State Department in timely fashion of what its ''Big Ear'' had learned about the Soviet Embassy's instructions to drug the returned defector?

title: Motor Pool
description: ''Do Not Dive'' warnings surround the 24-foot-long, 4-foot-deep, oval-shaped portable swimming pool. It has blue wood-grain panels. It is stocked with a small school of goldfish.

title: THE KEAN 'REFERENDUM': A MAN WHOSE POPULARITY CUTS ACROSS ALL LINES
description: The leaders of New Jersey's two major parties looked today at Governor Kean's record re-election victory Tuesday and drew different lessons.

title: CORRECTION
description: A map in some copies yesterday with articles about the K.G.B. officer Vitaly Yurchenko incorrectly located the Soviet Embassy in Rome. It is at 8 Via Aurelia Antica.

title: Topics;   Time and Money; Keep On Trucking
description: Among other of its tax-reform exertions, the House Ways and Means Committee finds that it must revise a reform that's only a year old.

title: 'NORTH AND SOUTH'
description: AS ABC's $25 million, 12-hour production of ''North and South'' continues slogging across the nation's television screens this week, reaching the fourth of six episodes tonight at 9 o'clock, a few moments might be taken to ponder the spectacle of arrogance and waste in today's popular entertainment.

title: A $2 Billion Jersey Turnpike Issue
description: A record $2 billion tax-exempt bond issue will be sold next week to pay for a project to widen the New Jersey Turnpike, officials at the Turnpike Authority and Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company said yesterday.

title: BECK TAKES A STAND FOR HOCKEY PEACE
description: Barry Beck has always been so serious. Night after night, through the year, his seriousness is the most striking element of the Ranger locker room.

title: Horse Talk
description: Reporters covering the tax revision story translate a lot of complicated language into work-a-day English, but some of them were stumped by a recent simile from Dan Rostenkowski, the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee.

title: Private Care for Elderly
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:

title: Ameritrust Deal
description: The Ameritrust Corporation said it had reached a definitive agreement to acquire the First Indiana Bancorp for $85 a share in Ameritrust common stock. The company said the transaction was worth about $90 million and would be accounted for as a pooling of interests. The banking company said the price included three banks with total assets of about $100 million.

title: Asbestos Plan Set By Eagle
description: Eagle-Picher Industries said its directors approved a $400 million plan yesterday to cover the cost of resolving asbestos claims that are pending against the company and future ones that might be filed.

title: GURU'S COMMUNE IN OREGON VOTES TO RESTORE TOWN NAME
description: Disciples of Bhagwan Shree Rajneesh, following the wishes of the jailed guru, have voted to return the original name of Antelope to the community in central Oregon that they took over in 1982.

title: Euroline Files Triton Lawsuit
description: A minority shareholder in the Triton Energy Corporation said it had accused the company of insider trading and other securities law violations and said it might seek control of the Dallas-based energy concern. Triton officials did not immediately return a phone call for comment.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: THE REAL THINGS The documentary film, dedicated to the proposition that truth is more compelling than fiction, is being celebrated for a week, starting today at the Carnegie Hall Cinema, Seventh Avenue at 56th Street (757-2131), where more than 40 of the genre, including premieres and great older films, will be screened through next Wednesday.

title: DANCE: CYDNEY WILKES OFFERS 3 NEW WORKS
description: CYDNEY WILKES has done interesting work, as a choreographer and as a performer with Johanna Boyce and Kei Takei, among others. She received a Bessie Award this year for a recent performance piece. But the program Miss Wilkes presented on Tuesday at Dance Theater Workshop's Bessie Schonberg Theater (219 West 19th Street) was a disappointing puzzle.

title: Military Export Rules
description: The Defense Department must improve its export control system to stop the Soviet Union from acquiring Western military technology, Stephen Bryen, Deputy Under Secretary of Defense, said today. Mr. Bryen told a House panel that the Soviet Union was making a big effort to steal Western technology, and said a recent Defense Department study found more than 5,000 Soviet military research projects have benefited significantly each year since 1980 from the acquisition of Western technology. He suggested that controls on technology include a fully integrated automated data processing system for all agencies involved in export control and compilation of a single list of controlled technology.

title: BLACK VICTOR IN VIRGINIA
description: In 1969, when Lawrence Douglas Wilder became the first black man elected to the Virginia State Senate since Reconstruction, a wealthy Charlottesville man who gave legendary parties for state legislators left him off the guest list.

title: Pepperell Chief Plans Flexibility With Cluett
description: As the fourth generation of his family to head West Point-Pepperell Inc., Joseph L. Lanier Jr. knows a thing or two about the textile business. And one thing he knows all too well is how badly the apparel fabrics segment of that business has been hurt by competition from imports: his company's net income fell 49 percent last year, largely because of soft performance in apparel fabrics.

title: FLATLEY SCORES 4 FOR ISLANDERS
description: Patrick Flatley, who has all the generous attributes of a team player, had to take control of his team's offense tonight. On the strength of his four goals and his assist on the game-winning score, the Islanders won a closely fought 5-4 contest with Toronto, a club desperate for a victory.

title: Japanese Brokers' Bid Fought
description: Reflecting the strong anti-Japanese trade sentiment in Congress, 38 members of the House Banking Committee have urged the Federal Reserve Bank of New York to reject applications by Japan's two largest securities firms for admission to an inner circle of primary distributors of United States Treasury securities.

title: 11 Are Dead, 4 Hurt In 2 Blasts in Sri Lanka
description: Land mines believed planted by Tamil guerrillas killed seven police officers and four soldiers in two explosions today, an army spokesman said.

title: Heinz Set to Buy Fitness Concern
description: The H. J. Heinz Company said it had agreed to acquire the Cardio-Fitness Corporation, a New York-based company that operates fitness centers aimed at corporate executives. Terms of the acquisition were not disclosed, although Alan Greditor, an analyst with Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., estimated the price at about $50 milllion.

title: Technology;   A Bottleneck: Chip's Package
description: IT does little good to build faster and faster automobiles if all they can drive on are dirt roads.

title: Miners' Bodies Recovered
description: Ten more bodies were removed from the Wilberg Mine today and Federal and company officials studied how to retrieve the remaining 12 bodies of coal miners killed in an underground fire last December.

title: Niekro Brothers File as Free Agents
description: The Niekro brothers entered their names on the free-agent list yesterday, but even as they did, their agent said he had spoken with George Steinbrenner about the possibility of their remaining with the Yankees.

title: Jurors Acquit a Blind Couple In Dispute Over Airline Seats
description: A blind couple have been acquitted of misdemeanor charges for refusing to move from airline seats near an emergency exit.

title: FOOT INJURIES CITED AS SEVERE PROBLEM
description: The foot injury has become the newest problem to plague pro basketball players. With the National Basketball Association season less than two weeks old, seven players, including Bill Cartwright, Michael Jordan, Darrell Griffith and Andrew Toney, whose annual salaries this season total more than $4 million, are on the sidelines with broken bones in their feet. In all cases, because of the swelling after the injuries, the complexity of the foot's bone structure and the failure of X-rays and sometimes bone scans to pick up the fractures, it has taken doctors several days or even weeks to confirm the extent of the injuries.

title: COACHES PICK VILLANOVA SIXTH
description: Rollie Massimino insists that he has his Big East competition right where he wants it - in front of him. Massimino led his Villanova Wildcats to the national championship last season, but in a poll of Big East coaches yesterday, the Wildcats were picked to finish sixth in the league.

title: VOLCKER IMPLIES FED FAVORS LOWER RATES
description: In an apparent signal that the Federal Reserve wants interest rates to fall further, its chairman, Paul A. Volcker, told Congress today that the central bank was not cracking down on growth of the money supply even though it has been growing faster than desired.

title: BRIGHT LIGHTS MARK THE '65 BLACKOUT
description: THE 20th anniversary of the blackout that darkened New York City and much of the Northeast on Nov. 9, 1965, is being celebrated in the city this week with a festival called Urban Light.

title: Advertising;   Scali Renames Unit Acquired in Brazil
description: Scali, McCabe, Sloves, a subsidiary of the Ogilvy Group, announced yesterday that a Brazilian ad agency acquired a year ago by the parent company had been transferred from Gang S.A. to the Scali chain, and had been renamed Scali, McCabe, Sloves (Brazil).

title: Drug Testing for Tennis Pros
description: Mandatory, confidential drug testing of male professional tennis players will begin next year under a rule adopted unanimously by the Men's International Professional Tennis Council in London yesterday.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: EARLY BLUES LYRICS WERE OFTEN BLUE
description: NOW that many members of the Recording Industry Association of America have agreed to put warning stickers or lyric sheets on the covers of record albums that include sexually explicit material, perhaps the Parents Music Resource Center and its allies can move on to cleaning up rock's ancestors - blues and country music from the 1920's through the early 1950's. Compared with today's pop and rock, innumerable disks from this earlier period contained some of the most salacious music ever made available to the American record-buying public.

title: Castro's 'Rights' Policy
description: Fidel Castro reputedly has one of the most efficient security-police systems extant. Yet he is said to change his sleeping quarters every night.

title: Pentagon Move On Dynamics
description: The Pentagon, as part of its effort to revoke the top-secret security clearance of a General Dynamics Corporation executive, has accused him of lying about his role in a 13-year-old bribery case, the executive's attorney confirmed today.

title: STICKY ARMS ISSUE
description: Every time the United States and the Soviet Union inch toward each other on limiting offensive nuclear forces, the path seems to get clogged by fundamental differences on space-based defenses.

title: BUSINESS MEN'S ASSURANCE CO OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including investment gains of $5,823,000 for the quarter and $11,198,000 for the 9 months. c-Including investment gains of $468,000 for the quarter and $1,359,000 for the 9 months.

title: CONTRADICTIONS UNRESOLVED AS PHILADELPHIA BOMB INQUIRY ENDS
description: Concluding the hearings on how the city handled its May 13 confrontation with the radical group Move, the four officials who were in charge today stood by their contradictory accounts.

title: REAGAN TO CHOOSE HEALTH SECRETARY
description: President Reagan is preparing to appoint a new Secretary of Health and Human Services, with the leading contender being former Gov. Otis R. Bowen of Indiana, White House officials said tonight.

title: VIRGINIA AND NEW JERSEY VOTES STUDIED FOR LESSONS ON WIDENING COALITIONS
description: Republicans and Democrats yesterday studied Tuesday's sweeping election results in Virginia and New Jersey for lessons that could help them fashion strategies for expanding their voter coalitions in the 1986 elections and beyond.

title: MAJOR INCUMBENTS WIN ON L.I. AND IN ROCKLAND
description: Incumbents did well on Tuesday in major races on Long Island and in Rockland County.

title: MULLIN IS SIGNED, SCORES 15 IN DEBUT
description: Chris Mullin, the ultimate gym rat, finally left the confines of the St. John's University gymnasium and began his pro basketball career.

title: AN EMPKRE THAT JUST KEEPS ON GROWING
description: SIR TERENCE CONRAN has made some recent acquisitions. He has become the major shareholder of the Federation National d'Acheter Cadres, the French operation that owns 18 audio-video shops throughout France. He bought the 1910 Michelin factory building in London that is being transformed into a battery of multiuse spaces. He is also working on the Butler's Wharf project of 50 Thames-side warehouses, which will become apartments, stores and restaurants over the next two years.

title: HOUSE PANEL VOTES FOR NEW U.S. PARK
description: The House Interior Committee voted today to create a 174,000-acre Great Basin National Park in Nevada.

title: The Causes of Britain's Riots Won't Go Away
description: To the Editor:

title: GAMBINO-TRIAL DEFENSE ATTORNEYS ASSAIL CREDIBILITY OF KEY WITNESS
description: Defense attorneys for the 10 reputed Gambino crime figures on trial for car theft and murder sought to discredit the testimony of a key Government witness yesterday.

title: Advertising;   Ash/LeDonne Files For Creditor Protection
description: Ash/LeDonne, a 10-year-old ad agency that has specialized in the financially risky business of promoting Broadway shows, filed in State Supreme Court on Monday for an assignment for the benefit of creditors.

title: Labor Contracts Open in '86 Involve 3.8 Million Workers
description: Contracts covering 3.8 million workers expire or will be re-opened for negotiation next year, with major agreements to be negotiated in the construction, farm machinery and steel industries, the Bureau of Labor Statistics said Tuesday.

title: CRITICAL DISCREPANCIES IN VIOLENT CONFRONTATION
description: Since the commission investigating the May 13 confrontation with the radical group opened its hearings on Oct. 8, the testimony has been marked by contradictions.

title: KOCH'S NO. 1 WISH, AND OTHER PEOPLE'S
description: ''If you had it within your power, complete power, to change one thing in the city over the next four years, what would you do and how would you do it?

title: Working Profile: J. Carter Brown;   Banged-Up Legs, a Bang-Up Show
description: Last summer J. Carter Brown, director of the National Gallery of Art, was traveling in Britain and did what many careless American tourists do. He pulled out of a parking lot and unthinkingly drove on the right side -that is to say, the wrong side - of the road.

title: JUSTICES URGED TO BAR RACIAL PREFERENCE PLAN
description: The Supreme Court heard arguments today on whether a school board violated the constitutional rights of white teachers by laying them off instead of blacks and other members of minority groups with less seniority.

title: Dolphins Face Uphill Battle
description: Let Don Shula start to count the ways his Miami Dolphins are struggling, and he can talk for a long time.

title: Private Care for Elderly
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:

title: C.D. Yields Off; Money Funds Rise
description: Yields on money market mutual funds rose slightly in the week that ended yesterday, while rates fell for bank money market accounts and certificates of deposit.

title: ELECTION RESULTS IN VOTING TUESDAY IN CITY AND ON LONG ISLAND; VOTE TOTALS FOR THE ELECTIONS HELD IN NEW YORK AND NEW JERSEY
description: Abbreviations in the following tables are: D -Democrat, R - Republican, C - Conservative, L - Liberal, RTL - Right to Life. (U) denotes unopposed candidate. An asterisk (*) denotes an incumbent. The votes of minor-party candidates will not be available until official canvasses are completed.

title: EVENTS: ANTIQUES REPAIR AND HEATING SYSTEMS
description: Handle With Care, Cooper-Hewitt Museum, 2 East 91st Street; 212-860-6868.

title: Rep. Addabbo to End Long Hospitalization
description: Representative Joseph P. Addabbo of Queens, who has been hospitalized since Aug. 28 with a kidney ailment, is expected to be discharged this week and to resume his duties soon as chairman of the House Defense Appropriations Subcommittee, his staff said today.

title: Private Care for Elderly
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:

title: THE KEAN 'REFERENDUM': A MAN WHOSE POPULARITY CUTS ACROSS ALL LINES
description: In the aftermath of one of their party's most sweeping losses, Democratic leaders in New Jersey yesterday criticized the style of the campaign run by their gubernatorial standard bearer, Peter Shapiro.

title: 'Progressive P.R.'
description: There is no shortage of public relations concerns in Washington, but only a few of them specialize in leftist causes. Fenton Communications is the largest and most visible of those doing what it calls ''progressive P.R.'' Fenton, a branch of a New York concern, has five employees in the capital and a list of a dozen or so clients who pay retainers of $4,000 to $6,000 a month to get their messages out.

title: COMNET CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net losses. c-Including a tax credit of $154,000. Results from the latest second quarter reflect research and development and other expenses of more than $300,000, a non-operating charge of $75,000 to write down Comnet's investment in Zytrex Corp. and a non-operating charge of $66,000 representing Comnet's 16.5 percent ownership interest in the losses of Rand Information Systems of Alameda, Calif.

title: FROM DE LA RENTA AND ANNE KLEIN, CRISP DESIGNS
description: WITHOUT breaking any new fashion ground, both Oscar de la Renta and Louis Dell'Olio showed extremely satisfactory collections yesterday. They didn't overlap very much, since Mr. de la Renta's specialty is rather formal clothes for day and evening; Mr. Dell'Olio's mood is more casual - he designs sportswear for Anne Klein.

title: CP REHAB CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Advertising;   Avenue Magazine Has New Product for 1986
description: Judy Price, creator of the highly successful 10-year-old Avenue magazine, which is delivered to the Gotham homes of the elite by Rolls-Royce, is coming up with a new product for the new year that she describes colorfully as the ''yellow pages for blue bloods.''

title: Violent Vibrations Force Jet to Return to Detroit
description: A Midway Airlines jetliner returned to the Detroit Metro Airport 12 minutes after takeoff when violent vibrations terrified passengers and prompted a stewardess to make the ''sign of the cross,'' a passenger said today.

title: Learning English Is Goal of Bilingual Programs
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Construction Workers Held In Assault on TV News Crew
description: Two construction workers surrendered to the police yesterday and were charged with attacking three members of a WNBC-TV news crew at the scene of a construction accident in Manhattan last July, the police said.

title: Hot Pursuit
description: There was such a thing as a free lunch for Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward yesterday, but it was fast food.

title: FLYERS ROLL PAST RANGERS
description: The Rangers did a lot of the necessary things last night. They checked heartily. They shot the puck often enough. But if they are ever to beat the Flyers again - if any team is ever to beat the Flyers again - they will need to take control of that special zone in front of the goaltender.

title: I.B.M. Chief Predicts Gains
description: The International Business Machines Corporation should post ''some strong growth'' in earnings in the fourth quarter, John F. Akers, the company's chief executive, said yesterday. Mr. Akers, speaking to British securities analysts at I.B.M.'s plant in Greenock, Scotland, said the computer company had expected ''that with some cooperation from the U.S. economy - particularly in capital investment -we should show some strong growth in the fourth quarter.''

title: Nazi Criminal Says Mixup Aided His Escape
description: The Nazi war criminal Alois Brunner, a top aide to Adolf Eichmann, said in an interview published today that he evaded capture by the Allies because of an identity mixup and that another SS member, Anton Brunner, was hanged for his crimes.

title: GULF RULERS IN WARNING ON IRAN-IRAQ FIGHTING
description: The conservative rulers of the Persian Gulf wound up their annual summit meeting here today with a warning that the ''recent escalation'' of the Iran-Iraq war threatened the stability of the region and freedom of navigation in its waters.

title: CNA INCOME SHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
HOW WOMEN FARE IN NO-FAULT DIVORCE
description: IN the world of divorce research, Lenore J. Weitzman is a name to be reckoned with.

title: COPLEY PROPERTIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results are for the period from Copley Properties' initial public offering on July 29, 1985 through Sept. 30, 1985.

title: 400 Students Arrested In Campus Raid in Chile
description: The riot police stormed a university campus today and arrested more than 400 people in the second day of protests against 12 years of military rule.

title: South Africa Police Kill Two Black Men
description: The police said today that a riot patrol shot and killed two black people in a group that was stoning police vehicles near Cape Town in the first confirmed riot deaths in a week.

title: Advertising;   People
description: * Llewellyn G. Ross has been named president of the Howard/Marlboro Group Inc. and Michael Wahl chairman and chief executive officer.

title: FLAMES BEAT SLUGGISH DEVILS
description: There was no dramatic comeback tonight for the Devils, who were defeated by the Calgary Flames, 5-2, before a crowd of 8,775 at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: REAGAN RULES OUT ANY RUSSIAN VETO OF MISSILE SHIELD
description: President Reagan sought today to describe in greater detail his position on deployment of a missile defense system.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: THURSDAY, NOVEMBER 7, 1985
description: International

title: FINANCING U.S. DEFICIT ABROAD
description: In helping to finance the largest budget deficits in American history, overseas investors have stepped forward with large appetites for United States Government securities. Without them, interest rates undoubtedly would have been higher, and the economic recovery following the 1981-82 recession may well have been less robust.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Nov. 7, 1985 GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: REAGAN NOMINATES HEALTH SECRETARY
description: President Reagan today nominated Dr. Otis R. Bowen, former Governor of Indiana, to be Secretary of Health and Human Services. The President said Dr. Bowen had ''all the qualifications'' to run one the Government's largest civilian department.

title: LITTLE CARNEGIE'S SCREEN IS LIT AGAIN
description: The Little Carnegie Playhouse has returned.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''However, this court is convinced that a conviction which rests upon racial stereotypes, fears and prejudices violates rights too fundamental to permit deference to stand in the way of the relief sought.'' - Judge H. Lee Sarokin of Federal District Court in Newark, in overturning the murder convictions of Rubin (Hurricane) Carter and John Artis. [B4:5.]

title: OMI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including an adjustment of $48,347,000 for the quarter and the nine months for the cumulative effect of an accounting change. c-Net loss.

title: THEATER: A MUSICAL, 'THE NEWS'
description: WHEN the house lights go down at ''The News,'' the new musical at Broadway's Helen Hayes Theater, an announcer informs us that the show will run 99 minutes, with no intermission. As it's impossible to predict the running time of any live performance so precisely - there might be unexpected ovations, after all -we are immediately suspicious. And why are we being told the running time in any case?

title: 'THE GOSPEL AT COLONUS,' ON 'GREAT PERFORMANCES'
description: THE idea of placing Sophocles in the context of a black Pentecostal church service may at first seem daunting, but it turns out to be inspired in ''The Gospel at Colonus.'' Taped in performance in September at Philadelphia's American Music Theater Festival, the production can be seen tonight at 9 o'clock on Channel 13 as part of the ''Great Performances'' series.

title: PRIVATE CONCERN SELECTED TO RUN CONVENTION HALL
description: A private corporation was named yesterday to run the new Jacob K. Javits Convention Center.

title: REAGAN SUGGESTS INDIAN MUSEUM SITE
description: The White House said tonight that President Reagan had instructed his staff to determine whether the United States Customs House in lower Manhattan could be turned over to the Museum of the American Indian.

title: MICHIGAN ENERGY RESOURCES CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Saccharine Held Free of Risk
description: Saccharin, an artificial sweetener the Food and Drug Administration tried to ban because studies linked it to bladder cancer in rats, appears to be safe for use by humans, the American Medical Association said today.

title: Surgery Blamed for High Bills
description: An increasing use of surgery, not laboratory tests or new diagnostic machines, is responsible for a significant share of the rising cost of medical care, a study has concluded.

title: TO RESUME JAN. 16
description: The last session of arms talks before the Soviet-American summit meeting Nov. 19 and 20 ended today with an agreement to resume the talks early next year.

title: TENSION RISING ON BALANCING BUDGET
description: Tension is rising between the White House and Capitol Hill over the potential impact of legislation that would require Congress to balance the budget in five years.

title: U.S. AIDES SPLIT ON YURCHENKO'S AUTHENTICITY
description: Reagan Administration officials said today that the Government was divided over whether Vitaly Yurchenko was a genuine defector or a planted agent.

title: Soviet Women Triumph
description: Oksana Omeliantchik and Elena Shoushounova scored perfect 10's on the floor exercise tonight as the Soviet Union easily won its third straight women's team title in the World Gymnastics Championships.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * American Paper Institute, a trade association, has elected as its chairman Roger W. Stone, chairman and chief executive officer of the Stone Container Corp. of Chicago.

title: Sarne Account Moves To Van Brunt/Growick
description: Van Brunt/Growick, a division of Van Brunt & Company, has a new client in the bag.

title: Incident Called Common
description: Aviation experts in the United States said yesterday that the off-course flight of the Japanese airliner was not unusual, and that there had been scores of similar navigation errors over the years.

title: U.P.I. Nearing Accord On Prospective Buyers
description: In separate announcements yesterday, United Press International's management and the Wire Service Guild indicated that the process of narrowing down the candidates seeking to acquire the financially troubled news agency would soon be completed, perhaps as early as Monday.

title: QMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
AFRICAN MEETING ADDRESSES PROBLEMS OF AIDS
description: In recent days, at a closed meeting on AIDS in central Africa, the World Health Organization began to take steps to ease the serious tensions that have pitted leading medical scientists against top African government officials. The meeting, held in Bangui, Central African Republic, was the first such regional one sponsored by the health organization, and it attracted more than 50 representatives of nine central African countries: Burundi, Cameroon, the Central African Republic, Congo, Gabon, Rwanda, Uganda, the United Republic of Tanzania and Zaire. According to Dr. Fakhri Assaad, an official of the organization, the participants agreed on these points:

title: ART: SCULPTURE, 'FIGURE AS IMAGE OF THE PSYCHE'
description: OF the remarkable number of quality sculpture exhibitions in New York at this moment, none is more concentrated and raw than ''The Figure as an Image of the Psyche,'' at the Sculpture Center, 167 East 69th Street. Its subject is the way the human figure is being used by sculptors to confront and transform difficult and sometimes extreme responses and experiences. The theme inevitably suggests an updated version of the ''New Images of Man'' exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art in 1959, which brought together work by artists like Jean Dubuffet, Alberto Giacometti, Jackson Pollock and Germaine Richier.

title: MOOD IN MOSCOW: LIMITED SUMMIT EXPECTATIONS
description: Flanked by burly marshals, Mikhail S. Gorbachev stood on the Lenin Mausoleum today with a defiant set to his jaw as his Defense Minister issued the traditionally tough military invocations of Revolution Day.

title: Dining Out Guide: Steaks and Chops
description: Following is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. FRANK'S, #431 West 14th Street (243-1349) -

title: 40 Are Hurt in California Fire
description: A fire in a downtown store that spread to a telephone company building next door injured 40 people today and forced hundreds of workers to evacuate, officials said. The fire was sparked by a construction worker's cutting torch about 10 A.M. at the Sharper Image novelty store. It spread to the nine-story Pacific Bell offices and caused a total of about $800,000 damage.

title: A Place in Virginia Called Gum Springs
description: Across the river on George Washington's side of the Potomac, the traffic on old Route 1 rolls blurred and hard past a humble place in Virginia called Gum Springs, where Judith Saunders Burton ponders the slavery that once haunted her family there and, in its way, still does.

title: Apparatus in Motion
description: The nation's foreign policy apparatus is constantly in restless motion. According to authoritative reports from that front, Gaston J. Segur of the National Security Council staff in the White House is moving to Foggy Bottom to become Assistant Secretary of State for East Asian and Pacific Affairs.

title: Big Apple Biathlon
description: Some 200 men and women will be running and biking a 24-mile course through Central Park on Sunday in the Big Apple Biathlon.

title: TOUPE RELIES ON SOAP OPERA ACTORS
description: ''Turkish. My accent, indeed, is Turkish, filtered through a global perspective, honed by travel, polished by life! Ankara is but a memory, ladies, and a fleeting one! And tonight! You get to discover that there's more to us than towels, taffy and tobacco! Tonight, we shall explore the major evil of our time.''

title: KARPOV MUST WIN 24TH
description: The 23d game of the world chess championship was drawn today after the challenger, Gary Kasparov, playing White, made his 41st move.

title: UNITED FIRE & CASUALTY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including realized gains on investments of $255,479 for the quarter and $1,223,417 for the nine months. c-Including realized gains on investments of $569,020. d-Net loss, including realized gains on investments of $1,390,922.

title: OVERSEAS SHIPHOLDING GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a net loss of $2,444,000 related to vessel disposals.

title: How to Deter Future Hinckleys
description: My husband and I met through politics and our lives moved from campaign to campaign until early 1981, when Ronald Reagan asked Jim to be his White House press secretary. The first two months of that year were the most exciting we ever spent. But all that was soon to change.

title: Dow Slips Back Below 1,400
description: The Dow Jones industrial average went through 1,400 the wrong way yesterday as profit taking in blue-chip issues set the widely followed indicator back about 4 points in an otherwise mixed session.

title: PHILADELPHIA SUBURBAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TRANSMATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: Patient With Donated Heart Gets Surgery for an Abscess
description: After four hours of surgery to clean and drain an abscess near his donated human heart, Anthony Mandia, who for a while used an artificial heart, remained in critical and unstable condition today.

title: A TAX BILL BY NOV. 28 IS PLEDGED
description: Representative Dan Rostenkowski, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, pledged today that his panel would finish work on tax-revision legislation ''by Thanksgiving,'' but he said the bill ''may not sit well with the purists.''

title: Jersey Sports Authority Offers Bonds Up to 9 1/4%
description: A two-part bond financing by the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority totaling about $280 million was offered yesterday through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: PROPERTY TRUST OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Pro Tennis Suit
description: The Men's International Professional Tennis Council, the governing body of the men's grand prix tour, yesterday filed a counterclaim in United States District Court for the Southern District of New York against the Volvo North America Corporation, International Management Group and ProServ, charging them with illegal restraint of trade, conspiracy to monopolize, and unfair competition. The council believes that Donald Dell, the founder of ProServ, and Mark McCormack, the founder of I.M.G., are in a conflict of interest because their firms not only represent the best players in the world but also control and have a financial stake in many sanctioned grand prix tournaments.

title: Six Experts on Soviet Give Reagan Briefing
description: As part of his preparation for his meeting with Mikhail S. Gorbachev in Geneva on Nov. 19 and 20, President Reagan had lunch at the White House today with six prominent specialists on the Soviet Union.

title: ART: KENSETT LANDSCAPES
description: THEY are beautiful, these Kensetts hanging in the American Wing of the Metropolitan Museum. Considered agreeable even in their own time, the landscapes were painted by an agreeable, well-adjusted man. John Frederick Kensett (1816-72) was among the founders of the Met and one of its first trustees. He was also one of the three artists appointed to oversee art commissions for the United States Capitol - primarily to make sure no more went to foreigners such as Constantino Brumidi and Horace Vernet.

title: ATWOOD OCEANICS INC reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: FLOODS MAKE CAPITAL SOGGY ON THE EDGES
description: The roiling waters of the rain-swollen Potomac River surged through the capital area today, flooding parts of the Georgetown neighborhood and Alexandria, Va., closing monuments and snarling major thoroughfares.

title: Pacific Lumber Bid Is Studied
description: Three grandchildren of a former chairman of the Pacific Lumber Company said today that they are considering making a competing bid to halt the company's acquisition by Maxxam Group Inc.

title: ARAFAT CONDEMNS RAIDS ON CIVILIANS
description: Yasir Arafat said today that the Palestine Liberation Organization condemned terrorist acts against unarmed civilians anywhere and that violators would be punished for carrying out attacks outside Israeli-held lands.

title: Affirmative Action Happens to Be Working
description: To the Editor:

title: SABINE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PACE MEMBERSHIP WAREOUSE reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a tax credit of $22,000 for the quarter and the nine months. c-Including tax credits of $97,000 for the quarter and $148,000 for the nine months. d-Net income.

title: NUMERICOM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: On January 1, the company changed its fiscal year to a calendar year from one ending on October 31.

title: AMEDCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: AMERICAN LOCKER GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including net income from discontinued operations of $88,100 for the quarter and $34,164 for the 9 months and a net gain of $436,946 for the 9 months on the disposal of discontinued operations. c-Including net income of $32,058 from discontinued operations and a net gain of $59,583 on the disposal of discontinued operations.

title: ANTHONY BUTRICO
description: Anthony Butrico, the host for more than 25 years at the Stork Club in Manhattan, died Oct. 19 at the Veterans Administration Hospital in East Orange, N.J. He was 73 years old and lived in Cream Ridge, N.J.

title: OGLEBAY NORTON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
WARY MADISON AVE. AWAITS THE LIMITED
description: Standing outside Isabel Canovas, a two-month-old couture accessories shop on Madison Avenue, its manager, Bimia Picot, scrunched her nose in discreet distaste when questioned about an even more recent arrival, The Limited.

title: THE SEASON OF THEIR SUMMIT DISCONTENT
description: A key White House official, attending a session the other day on the summit meeting between President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev, scribbled three words on his yellow pad as the session ended: ''Keep expectations down.''

title: EATON FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
GRAFFITI AND VANDALS' ATTACKS RUB GLOSS OFF ATLANTA TRANSIT
description: Ever since it opened six years ago, Atlanta's rapid transit system has been the pride of civic boosters here, who have reveled in its upholstered seats, its sleek, clean cars and its absence of graffiti.

title: FOR BENSON, THE WAIT IS NEARLY OVER
description: In the next few days, Ezra Taft Benson is due to take over as president of the Mormon Church, a position of enormous ecclesiastical authority. Church members believe that the president, or ''living Prophet,'' receives guidance directly from God.

title: IRT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: A 'REFRESHER COURSE' ON THE CITY'S SCHOOLS
description: They were not sure what to expect. But when 11 representatives of some of the largest corporations in New York City toured two public schools in Manhattan yesterday, they encountered one pleasant surprise after another.

title: ALLIED PRODUCTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including extraordinary gains of $389,000 for the quarter and $5,561,000 for the 9 months. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,220,000 for the quarter and $2,838,000 for the 9 months and extraordinary gains of $2,660,000 for the quarter and $4,517,000 for the 9 months.

title: MILGRAY ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
AMERICAN LAND CRUISERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NELSON, L B CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ICEE-USA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
181 Sikorsky Copters Grounded for Repairs
description: More than 180 Sikorsky CH-53 transport helicopters have been grounded by the Navy, Marine Corps and Air Force because of problems with the main rotor, the Pentagon said Wednesday.

title: JENNINGS HAVING LOFTIER TIME AS A JET
description: The punts used to be long, driving kicks that would give Dave Jennings one of the top averages in the National Football League, and often land him in the Pro Bowl.

title: Knicks in Talks on Tyler
description: Steve Kaufman, a Philadelphia attorney who represents the free-agent forward Terry Tyler of the Detroit Pistons, was told yesterday that the Knicks may be interested in Tyler - but not yet. ''We talked briefly,'' Kaufman said after speaking with Eddie Donovan, the Knicks' vice president in charge of player personnel, ''but I'm not sure what they want to do or when they want to do it.''

title: ARDEN GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a nonrecurring gain of $1,689,000 for the quarter from the sale of assets and a gain of $14,000 for the 9 months on the early extinguishment of debt. c-Including a gain of $331,000 from the early extinguishment of debt.

title: Bridge: Winnipeg Player in Running For Blue Ribbon Pairs Title
description: No player from this prairie province has ever won a major North American title, but the possibility loomed large when the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals continued here today.

title: AMERICAN TECHNICAL CERAMCS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
T-BAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income, including extraordinary credits of $136,000 for the quarter and $196,000 for the nine months. c-Including an extraordinary credit of $300,000. Share earnings reflect a five percent stock dividend paid in June 1985.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Hockey Devils vs. Pittsburgh Penguins, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, 7:35 P.M. Mel Bridgman's four goals and seven assists helped the Devils establish dominance over the Penguins last season.

title: OILERS HAVE MUCH AT STAKE
description: Rarely in recent seasons have the Houston Oilers approached what could be considered a crucial game, unless you take into account those games in a long and embarrassing losing streak, such as the one they had last year. It wasn't until they reached 0-10 that they finally broke through for a victory.

title: FROST & SULLIVAN INC reports earnings for Year to July 31
Guru Back in Oregon To Answer U.S. Charges
description: Bhagwan Shree Rajneesh arrived back in Oregon tonight to face Federal charges of covering up sham marriages and lying to immigration officials.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 8, 1985
description: International

title: U.S. AND CANADA DENY SUICIDE IS LINKED TO SPY
description: The suicide of a Soviet woman in Toronto has set off a flurry of speculation here that she might have been the lover of the returning K.G.B. defector Vitaly Yurchenko.

title: PRATT & LAMBERT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company paid dividends of 18 cents per share for the latest quarter, 48.7 cents per share for the latest nine months, 15.3 cents per share for the year-ago quarter and 46 cents per share for the year-ago nine months.

title: SCREEN: HORROR SPOOF, 'TRANSYLVANIA 6-5000'
description: THE actors in ''Transylvania 6-5000,'' which opens today at Loew's State and other theaters, seem to have the impression that they are doing something funny, though where they got that idea is anybody's guess. It cannot have come from the screenplay, which was written by Rudy DeLuca, who also directed the film, as a series of utterly listless comic setups. It's not that Mr. DeLuca has done anything wrong, exactly; it's simply that he never does anything right. There's no reason for this material to be funny, so, not surprisingly, it never is.

title: DUARTE'S DAUGHTER, ON TAPE, PRAISES REBELS
description: Salvadoran guerrillas have made public a tape recording in which the daughter of President Jose Napoleon Duarte, held hostage by the rebels for 44 days, says she came around to a different view of the rebels during her captivity.

title: OSHKOSH B'GOSH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Pan Am Jet Loses Wing Part
description: A Pan Am jumbo jet with 192 people aboard lost a left wing slat on takeoff from San Francisco International Airport today but returned safely. The leading-edge slats help lift the jet on departure but are not needed in flight, said Federal and airline officials. Pan Am said there are 13 such slats on each side of the aircraft, a Boeing 747.

title: STARRETT, L S CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a nonrecurring tax credit of $620,047.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: SUZY, the society scribe, was feted this week by 330 of her nears and dears at a $1,000-a-plate charity ball in the Plaza's Grand Ballroom. Everyone donned designer masks because it was billed as a Bal Masque. Don't you aimez it?

title: SENATE CONFIRMS APPELLATE JUDGE
description: A young conservative whose nomination to be a Federal appeals judge was bitterly opposed by liberals narrowly won Senate confirmation today.

title: CHICAGO PNEUMATIC TOOL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
description: b-Net income. c-After a net loss of $26,000 for the quarter and 9 months from discontinued operations and extraordinary gains of $839,000 for the quarter and $1,017,000 for the 9 months. d-Including net income of $277,000 from discontinued operations.

title: REVERSAL IS WON BY RUBIN CARTER IN MURDER CASE
description: A Federal judge, citing ''grave constitutional violations'' by prosecutors, today overturned the triple-murder convictions of Rubin (Hurricane) Carter and John Artis.

title: HAMBURGER HAMLETS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 29
description: b-Including gains on the disposition of property of $475 for the quarter and $446,885 for the 6 months. c-Including a gain of $83,647 on the disposition of property. Results are for 13 weeks and 26 weeks for the latest periods and 14 weeks and 27 weeks for the year-ago periods.

title: PENSION AGENCY CRISIS GROWS
description: When Congress set up the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation in 1974, the aim was to protect the retirement income of workers at companies in trouble. But recently, after the Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation terminated its pension plan, it seemed to some people that it was the companies that are being protected.

title: OHIO FERRO-ALLOYS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
OPTICAL SPECIALTIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a tax credit of $924,000 for the quarter and the year. c-Net income.

title: Race Issues In Europe
description: Western Europe is coming to face a problem of national identity new to the modern age. It has to do with the arrival of huge numbers of migrant workers in the last quarter-century. By now, some of them have settled down and have no intention of leaving. The rising generation of their children hold citizenship in their new homes by right of birth.

title: Booklet to Decorate Airplane Dinner Trays
description: In other above-ground media, Alexander and Harry (Skip), the Ungar brothers, have sold the family box-manufacturing company, and are investing in What's Up? Identified as ''a unique advertising medium,'' it is a 7-inch-by-4-inch booklet that will be placed on airline food trays by the food service companies that prepare them. It will contain - in addition to advertising, of course - information on the goings-on and facilities at major destination cities as well as snippets on secondary cities.

title: CARE ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CELINA FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After investment losses of $337,676 for the quarter and $361,157 for the 9 months. c-Net losses including an investment gain of $2,667 for the quarter and an investment loss of $39,116 for the 9 months.

title: SHOPSMITH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
J.A.L.'S POST-CRASH TROUBLES
description: Ever since the Aug. 12 crash of one of its planes in the worst single plane disaster in aviation history, Japan Air Lines has followed an elaborate protocol to atone for the 520 people killed, providing everything from personal apologies by the company's president to memorial services for the dead to financial reparations.

title: In Memoriam
description: In a place that honors healing, a memorial will be dedicated tomorrow to the victims of a sickness that cannot yet be healed.

title: Playboy Posts a Loss
description: Playboy Enterprises Inc. said today that it recorded a net loss of $1.95 million, on revenues of $48 million for its first quarter. That compares with a net income of $3.59 million, or 37 cents a share, on revenues of $46.4 million, in the similar period last year.

title: Wesray Views A Bid on Avis
description: The Wesray Capital Corporation said yesterday that it was joining with some Avis Rent-a-Car System Inc. licensees to consider a bid to buy the rental car company from the Beatrice Companies.

title: AMERICAN GUARANTY FINANIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $323,000 for the quarter and $1,891,000 for the 9 months.

title: The U.N. Today; Nov. 8, 1985
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: A NEW SNAG IN ALTMAN-HUTZLER DEAL
description: W. R. Grace & Company has withdrawn from an agreement that would have turned over operation of the B. Altman stores in New York to the Hutzler Brothers Company, a Baltimore-based department store chain, a Grace spokesman said yesterday.

title: TECH-OPS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $3,136,000 for the quarter and $6,285,000 for the year. c-Including income from discontinued operations of $133,000 for the quarter and $3,045,000 for the year and a tax credit of $476,000 for the quarter and the year.

title: Group in Puerto Rico Threatens More Attacks
description: An independence group that has claimed responsibility for shooting an Army recruiting officer threatened today to fill the cemeteries with other military recruiters and anyone who helped them.

title: CORRECTION
description: Daniel Schorr erred, in his Tuesday article, ''Beware 'Summit Syndrome,' '' in writing that Franklin D. Roosevelt attended the Potsdam conference. Harry S. Truman did.

title: CITY SUED ON FOSTER CARE OF CHILDREN OF HOMELESS
description: The Legal Aid Society charged in a suit yesterday that New York City had routinely placed hundreds of children in foster care because their parents were homeless or living in substandard housing.

title: CITY CLOSES BAR FREQUENTED BY HOMOSEXUALS, CITING SEXUAL ACTIVITY LINKED TO AIDS
description: New York City yesterday closed a bar frequented by homosexuals, contending that it permitted ''high-risk sexual activity'' linked to the spread of AIDS.

title: AMERICAN EXPLORATION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: Still Pretending to Balance the Budget
description: President Reagan, who has said yes, he favors the bizarre balanced-budget legislation making its way through Congress, now says yes, but. If it ends up looking too much like the House version, he may have to veto it. Good.

title: Philadelphia Blast Kills Two
description: An explosion and fire in a working-class neighborhood destroyed six row houses tonight, killing two people, leaving one other missing and injuring four more, the authorities said.

title: Chinese Dance Troupe
description: A blend of traditional Chinese folklore and modern American dance techniques will be demonstrated in a performance by the Cloudgate Taipei Contemporary Dance Theater tonight at 8 o'clock at the Lehman Center for the Performing Arts, on Bedford Park Boulevard in the Bronx.

title: LEAR PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After non-cash pre-tax charges of $2 million for the quarter and $12 million for the nine months from the writedown of book value of oil and gas properties and a pre-tax charge of $4 million for the nine months related to the establishment of a reserve fund. c-Net income.

title: More Bank Failures Seen
description: At least 200 banks will fail over the next two years, L. William Seidman said today at his swearing in as chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. Mr. Seidman succeeds William M. Isaac at the Federal agency that insures bank deposits for up to $100,000.

title: WASTE DEADLINE TODAY WILL SHUT MANY DUMPS
description: Federal officials estimated today that one-third of the toxic waste landfills in the nation might have to close after monitoring of underground water and requirements for insurance go into force Friday.

title: BALLET: THE JOFFREY IN 'TAMING OF THE SHREW'
description: JOHN CRANKO'S ''Taming of the Shrew'' is like opera without arias. None of the pas de deux or solos say much about the characters who dance them or the mood they are in. They aren't ballet showpieces either. The ballet frolics by, skimming the surface of the Shakespeare comedy. But it was clear from the audience response to the season's first performance of ''The Taming of the Shrew'' by the Joffrey Ballet, on Wednesday at the City Center, that the company has a crowd pleaser in the work. And there was much to admire in the acting and dancing of the ballet by the Joffrey dancers.

title: 2 COUPLES, 1 CASINO JACKPOT: A BEAUTIFUL FRIENDSHIP ENDS
description: As children, Dale Henhaffer and Karen Quitmeyer lived a few cul-de-sacs from each other in suburban Lindenwold, N.J. They rode the same bus to school. In their teens, Dale introduced Karen to his buddy, Bill Hackett, and Bill and Karen have been going together since.

title: BARBER-GREENE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $732,000. c-Net loss after a loss of $3,176,000 from discontinued operations.

title: WORLD AIRWAYS INC reports earnings for Revenue
description: b-Net loss.

title: Proposed Chief Faces A Challenge at Wausau
description: The Nationwide Insurance Companies, which on Wednesday announced that it had agreed to affiliate itself with the ailing Wausau Insurance Companies, said yesterday that Leon J. Weinberger had been nominated to become president and chief executive of Wausau.

title: Showing the Way
description: In New Jersey, Gov. Thomas Kean, a Republican, was re-elected with a majority of the black vote. In Virginia, Gerald Baliles, a Democrat, was elected Governor with 50 percent of the white vote. His running mate for lieutenant governor, Douglas Wilder, the first black since Reconstruction to win a statewide election, took 46 percent of the white vote.

title: ERB LUMBER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
France's Big Political Story
description: The story out of France that really should interest us - from the standpoint of long-term American interests -is not the sinking of the Rainbow Warrior. Nor is it even the Socialist Party's impending Waterloo in the legislative elections scheduled for March. The story is that socialism - as an idea and a national point of reference - is dead as a doornail.

title: Diner's Journal
description: YOU enter the newly renovated Shun Lee (formerly known as Shun Lee West) and are startled to find yourself in a dark, black-ceilinged hallway where eerie red-eyed monkeys glare menacingly at you as they dangle from the ceiling - sort of a funhouse minus the fun. The corridor leads to a sunken dining area that is no less theatrical - alternately black and white with dramatic lighting that sets off graciously appointed tables and, flying around the perimeter of the den, tongue-thrashing dragons.

title: AMERICAN STANDARD INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including $86,200,000 from continuing operations which was before a loss of $19,900,000 from discontinued operations.

title: On Target
description: In the first game of Rafael Septien's career in the National Football League, in 1977, he missed an extra point and did not get a chance to try a field goal. Since then, though, Septien has played 127 games and has scored at least one point in each of them, a streak that gives him third place in N.F.L. history. Here are the top five such streaks, all belonging, naturally, to place-kickers: Fred Cox, Minnesota151 Garo Yepremian, Miami, N.O.133 Rafael Septien, L.A. Rams, Dallas127 Jim Turner, Jets, Denver118 Sam Baker, Dallas, Philadelphia110

title: 5,000 OFFICERS, AT RALLY, CALL HOLTZMAN 'SOFT ON CRIME'
description: Thousands of police officers demonstrated yesterday outside the offices of District Attorney Elizabeth Holtzman in Brooklyn, calling her ''a persecutor of cops, not a prosecutor of criminals'' and demanding that she resign.

title: DUAL-LITE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a tax credit of $187,000.

title: SCREEN: STING IN 'BRING ON THE NIGHT'
description: IN addition to its considerable merits as a music documentary, Michael Apted's ''Bring On the Night'' is of additional interest as a film that winds up being inadvertently revealing, and that seems to change shape as it goes along.
