Its avowed purpose was to document a few days in the lives of Sting, the lead singer and songwriter of the Police, and the American jazz musicians with whom he was about to begin an international concert tour. What emerges instead is the process by which collaborations, friendships and chains of command are established within this newly formed group, as well as a good illustration of how powerful a role a film crew can play in the very process it is attempting to record.

title: Ice Cream Is Good for What Ails Ivan Too
description: To the Editor:

title: A Royal Send-Off For an Outgrown Yacht
description: ''We had Charlie,'' Malcolm Forbes said, ''and now we've got Charlie's aunt.''

title: Pension Fund Shift Is Planned by FMC
description: The FMC Corporation, in a step that several other companies have taken recently, said today that it plans to restructure its retirement plans for salaried and nonunion workers to recover pension fund assets totaling $250 million to $400 million in pretax proceeds. FMC said that it had not decided on a specific use for the surplus funds, only that they would be used ''for general corporate purposes.''

title: Lawrence J. O'Brien Jr., 38; Lobbyist for City in Mid-70's
description: Lawrence J. O'Brien Jr., New York City's chief legislative lobbyist in Washington during the fiscal crisis in the mid-1970's, died of cancer Sunday at his home in Washington. He was 38 years old.

title: CAM-OR, INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Comings and Goings
description: The middleweight title fight between Marvelous Marvin Hagler, the undisputed champion, and John (The Beast) Mugabi, originally set for next week, has been tentatively rescheduled for March 10, promoters said. The bout was postponed when Hagler suffered a back injury, followed by a cut on his nose. . . . Dan Hampton, the Chicago lineman who was shifted from tackle to end to make room in the Bears' defensive kitchen for William (The Refrigerator) Perry, has been given what amounts to a lucrative transfer fee - a four-year contract worth an estimated $2.7 million, which will make him the highest-paid defensive lineman in professional football. . . . A new format for the Atlantic 10 Conference postseason basketball tournament was unveiled by Commissioner Charley Theokas. The tournament will be staged on various campuses with the semifinals and final being played March 1-3 at the Byrne Meadowlands Arena in East Rutherford, N.J. Last year the tournament was held at Rutgers Athletic Center in Piscataway, N.J.

title: The Big Frisk in New York City's Grace Plaza
description: To the Editor:

title: Philippine Democracy, Manipulated
description: Whatever his physical health, Ferdinand Marcos's political instincts are unimpaired. You can bet he wouldn't have proposed an election for Jan. 17 unless he were sure that he could win it. What he wants is not an expression of democracy but a managed plebiscite to confound his enemies at home and deflect reform pressure from the United States. What he offers is not an election but a snare and a delusion.

title: MOBILE COMMUNICATIONS OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
COASTAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
COMDISCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including an extraordinary net gain of $30,035,000.

title: The Editorial Notebook;   Air Bags Make It to the Showroom
description: Cheers for the Ford Motor Company for making it possible to buy an American car with an air-bag safety restraint. The company will soon offer the devices as options on its 1986 Tempo and Topaz compacts. The decision could mark the beginning of the end of Detroit's long, bitter campaign against this life-saving technology.

title: SPIRE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MUSIC: POLLINI AND THE PHILHARMONIC
description: IF you saw a man walk through a thorn hedge and emerge without a scratch, you would marvel at it. Many pianists must have felt a similar sense of wonder last night while listening to Maurizio Pollini play the Brahms Concerto in B-flat with the New York Philharmonic. The Italian pianist is renowned for his technical wizardry, but so are other virtuosos who take on this concerto and have to fight their way through its thickets and brambles. The sense of a great struggle going on can be exciting, of course, and many a Brahms Second has taken on heroic proportions as a result of just such a perilous contest.

title: RECORD NOW 0-7
description: A major debate concerning the Knicks these days is over what kind of player their debilitated roster needs most - a scoring forward who can also rebound, or a slippery playmaker who can run the fast break and convert the 20-footer.

title: TENNEY ENGINEERING INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a nonrecurring tax credit of $224,800 for the quarter and the nine months.

title: SUN COAST PLASTICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: Sonny Sharrock, Guitar
description: The guitarist Sonny Sharrock will perform tonight at First on First, 13 First Avenue, at First Street (982-9310). Live music begins at about 10 P.M.; there is a $5 cover charge.

title: NETS EXPLOIT BULL'S PROBLEMS AND WIN
description: With eight new players and a new coach, and without Michael Jordan, the Chicago Bulls are struggling.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: THE frost is barely on the pumpkin, and already it's time to start selling the Christmas movies. At most of the major studios, the marketing and merchandising push is about to begin. M-G-M, with ''Rocky IV,'' got the jump on its competition by unleashing trailers for its film late this spring, and will be opening ''Rocky IV'' in a record-breaking 2,000 theaters. And McDonald's and Kodak will be among those helping to spread the word that Tri-Star's ''Santa Claus'' is coming to town.

title: STAGE: EQUITY LIBRARY OFFERS 'SHE LOVES ME'
description: WHILE other musicals fade into the footlights, ''She Loves Me'' remains a delectable musical confection, as generously demonstrated in Robert Bridges's revival at Equity Library Theater. What one tends to forget is that it is a beautifully integrated show. Joe Masteroff's book inspires the music, Sheldon Harnick's lyrics advance the dramatic action and Jerry Bock's score is a cornucopia of in-character tunes.

title: HPSC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 28
ENVIRODYNE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TRW Debentures
description: A $100 million issue of TRW Inc. 11 3/8 percent debentures due in 2015 was offered yesterday at a price of 100, through underwriters led by Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company. The 30-year issue, which is not refundable for 10 years and is subject to a sinking fund beginning in 1996, was offered with a yield that was 98 one-hundredths of a percentage point greater than 10 3/8 percent Treasury bonds due in 2012. Proceeds of the debentures, rated Aa-3 by Moody's and A- by S.&P., will be used to repay part of the debt incurred in TRW's recent purchase of 7.7 million shares of its common stock at a price of $81.875.

title: DANCE: BALLET HISPANICO AT THE JOYCE THEATER
description: TINA RAMIREZ founded Ballet Hispanico in 1970 to further opportunities for aspiring young dancers of Hispanic origin and to reflect their heritage in the company's repertory.

title: BRIEFS
description: Altos Computer Systems, San Jose, Calif., said its board had authorized the repurchase of up to 2 million of the company's 14.6 million common shares outstanding.

title: AMERICAN CITY BUSINESS JOURNALS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago results are pro forma as the company only recently went public.

title: Chile Police and Soldiers On Patrol After Protest
description: Hundreds of soldiers and police officers patrolled the streets today, seeking to prevent a renewal of two days of anti-Government protests in which four people were shot dead and more than 750 arrested.

title: Halliburton Official Joins Texas Eastern
description: The Texas Eastern Corporation, a multibillion-dollar gas and oil pipeline concern, said yesterday that it had selected Dennis R. Hendrix, an executive vice president and director at the Halliburton Company, as president and chief operating officer.

title: American Decides to Resign As Leader of a U.N. Agency
description: Bradford Morse, the highest-ranking American official employed by the United Nations, announced in Copenhagen Wednesday that he would resign as head of the United Nations Development Program next year.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday MUSIC ACROSS THE CHANNEL A program that ranges from 17th-century Scottish harp music to contemporary French folk music is this weekend's offering from the World Music Institute, which is presenting a concert tonight as part of its Music From Britain, Ireland and France series. Martin Carthy, the British folk guitarist and singer, is teamed with John Kirkpatrick on concertinas; the duo have been noted for their work with Steeleye Span, the Albion Country Band and Brass Monkey. Robin Williamson, an Edinburgh-born harpist and founder of the Incredible String Band, will perform the Scottish harp music on this program. Also on the agenda is Gabriel Yacoub, a French guitarist and singer and founder of the group Malicorne. Mr. Yacoub will be performing original and traditional French folk music. The concert begins at 8 P.M. in the Triplex Theater at 199 Chambers Street. Tickets are $10 and $12. Information: 618-1980.

title: Hyatt to Build 40 Smaller Hotels
description: The Hyatt Hotels Corporation said it would build at least 40 smaller hotels, in smaller cities and suburban markets. The hotels, which are expected to cost a total of $750 million, will be ''geared to the business traveler'' and are expected to be completed by the end of 1990, Hyatt said.

title: MARCOM TELECOMMUNICAIONS reports earnings for Yr to July 31
description: b-Net income.

title: SOVIET JETS SCRAMBLE AS JAPANESE AIRLINER STRAYS
description: A Moscow-bound Japan Air Lines jumbo jet strayed off course over the Sea of Japan last week, causing Soviet fighter planes to scramble on nearby Sakhalin Island, Government officials said today.

title: 'PIZZA CASE' FIGURE CALLED OPPONENT OF DRUG DEALING
description: A major Mafia informer, Tommaso Buscetta, testified under cross-examination yesterday that he knew of no drug dealing by the main defendant in the ''pizza connection'' trial.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A chart yesterday listing election results in major mayoral races reversed the party identifications of two Louisville candidates. Jerry Abramson, the winner, is a Democrat; Bob Heleringer is a Republican.

title: G.M. PAYMENT ACCORD ENDS TENNESSEE ANNEXING DISPUTE
description: The General Motors Corporation will pay no property taxes on its $3.5 billion Saturn automobile plant, but it will make payments to the county in which the plant will be built, officials said in announcing the plan today.

title: LANCER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
RADIATION TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ATCOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a gain of $923,000 for the quarter and year from a reversal of deferred taxes.

title: Using Logic
description: Harley Duncan, a Kansas state official, explains why George Brett received a driver's license without being required to take a vision test: ''If he can hit .350, we figured he could see.''

title: SCREEN: ARGENTINE LOVE AND LOSS
description: FROM the legacy of anguish left by Argentina's military juntas, Luis Puenzo has created a glowing film. Cogently written and beautifully acted, ''The Official Story,'' opening today at the Paris theater, takes us to the place where politics meets the human heart.

title: Iraq Steps Up Attacks; Iran Said to Plan Drive
description: Iraq has intensified land and air attacks amid reports today that Iran may mount a major thrust through southern Iraqi marshland.

title: IMASCO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Per share figures reflect a 2-for-1 stock split.

title: General Shale To Study Offers
description: The General Shale Products Corporation, a leading producer of brick for residential and commercial construction, said that it had agreed to evaluate any serious inquiries from parties interested in acquiring the company. George C. Sells, the company's chairman and chief executive, said General Shale had been approached by ''seven or eight interested parties,'' none of whom had made an official offer.

title: HANOVER INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including capital gains of $574,218 for the quarter and $9,876,891 for the 9 months and an extraordinary charge of $512,808 for the quarter. c-Including capital gains of $1,693,518 for the quarter and $2,101,397 for the 9 months and an extraordinary credit of $321,156 for the 9 months.

title: WILLIAM H. CHESTER
description: William H. Chester, a leading San Francisco union official who was one of the first blacks to move to the top ranks of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, died Sunday.

title: JOHNSON CONTROLS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CITY TO SHIFT HOMELESS FAMILIES TO A BROOKLYN
description: A new shelter for homeless families will open soon in Brooklyn, with its first occupants to be families now housed in a month-old shelter at Bellevue Hospital Center, officials said yesterday.

title: NOVEMBER'S HUNTING CHOICES
description: November is to the hunter as June is to the angler. In June, the latter is torn between going after trout and black bass in streams and lakes or striped bass and bluefish in the ocean. In November, the hunter must decide whether to pursue deer, upland birds or waterfowl.

title: Control Data Combines 2 Computer Divisions
description: The Control Data Corporation, the troubled Minneapolis computer maker, yesterday announced the consolidation of two major parts of its computer business and named a longtime company executive to head the combined operations.

title: Slide Hampton Quintet
description: The trombonist Slide Hampton will lead a quintet including James Williams on piano and Kevin Eubanks on guitar tonight through Sunday at the Village Vanguard, 87 Seventh Avenue South, at 11th Street (255-4037). Sets begin at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M.; there is a $10 cover and a one-drink minimum.

title: Qaddafi Wants Reagan Tried for Purported Plot
description: The Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, said today that President Reagan should be put on trial for a purported Central Intelligence Agency plan to undermine him.

title: SYMBOL TECHNOLOGIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Per share figures are fully diluted.

title: CHRYSLER RESHAPED INTO 4 UNITS
description: The Chrysler Corporation announced a major reorganization today. Lee A. Iacocca, the chairman, said it would ''give us the flexibility we need'' to manage the auto maker's diversification.

title: AIDS IN AFRICA: A PATTERN OF MYSTERY
description: AIDS appears to be spreading by conventional sexual intercourse among heterosexuals in Africa and is striking women nearly as often as men, according to researchers here.

title: Business Mood: Hope and Fear
description: A WEIRD paradox haunts the securities markets: As the stock market mounts - and nothing could have been more dramatic than the way the Dow industrials sailed over the 1,400 barrier this week - so do anxieties that its rise is based on false hopes and cannot last. The commonest question one hears, in whispered tones, from a wide variety of business executives and investors, is: ''Is this another 1929?''

title: Melba Liston Septet
description: The composer-arranger Melba Liston will conduct a septet including Benny Powell on trombone, Harold Vick on saxophone and Major Holley on bass tonight at 9:30 at the Jazz Center, 380 Lafayette Street, near East Third Street (505-5660). Tomorrow, the saxophonist Billy Harper will lead his quintet at 9:30 and 11:30 P.M. Admission is $8.

title: BROADWAY
description: IT'S keep-your-fingers-crossed time. Bob Fosse has written the book for ''Big Deal,'' a musical he'll probably direct and choreograph, and which may hit the Shubert Theater late next spring. Based on the 1958 film ''Big Deal on Madonna Street,'' it's about a group of bumbling thieves who try to pull off a big job and get themselves into some hilarious situations.

title: Incentive to Saving
description: To the Editor:

title: GENSTAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
GIANTS HAVE A TOUGH DECISION ON BANKS
description: In past years, when the Giants wanted to activate a player, they seldom had a problem deciding who to remove from the roster to make room. There were always players with injuries or players not contributing enough.

title: JURY IN PERSICO TRIAL HEARS BRIBE TAPES AND TESTIMONY
description: The jury in the Colombo crime-group trial heard yesterday of $25,000 in bribes paid to an undercover Federal agent in 1977 to fix a tax investigation for a businessman and to arrange a Christmas visit to New York by Carmine Persico, the reputed boss of the Colombo organization.

title: Coercion Fears Linked To Mistrial in Spy Case
description: Jury deliberations in the espionage trial of Richard W. Miller, which ended in a mistrial Wednesday, broke down mainly over whether admissions he made in interrogation by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation had been coerced, a juror said today.

title: BURRIS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 2
description: Results are for 53 weeks for the latest fiscal year and 52 weeks for the previous fiscal year.

title: Blaze in a Skyscraper In Midtown Injures Six
description: A fire swept through the 34th floor offices of a 45-floor skyscraper in midtown last night, forcing an evacuation of the building and temporarily disrupting traffic around Times Square.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: PIAF. By Margaret Crosland. 240 pages.

title: 9.73% Japan Notes
description: The Japan Development Bank yesterday offered $200 million of 9.70 percent notes due in 1992 at a price of 99.846 to yield 9.73 percent, through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation. The notes, whose yield is about the same as that of seven-year Treasury notes, are triple-A rated and guaranteed by the Japanese Government.

title: HEIST, C H CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 29
S.I. Navy Port Stalled By Change in Budget
description: Completion of a Navy port on Staten Island for ships capable of carrying nuclear weapons will be delayed one year because of a budget decision in Congress, Representative Guy V. Molinari, Republican of Staten Island, said today.

title: CRAXI'S COMMENTS IMPERIL NEW CABINET
description: A political storm that erupted over a statement on the Middle East by Prime Minister Bettino Craxi intensified today, threatening his revived coalition Government.

title: DNA PLANT TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
STATE ACTS TO BAR CARIBBEAN MEDICAL STUDENTS
description: Regulations that would bar graduates of Caribbean medical schools from physician-training programs in New York State hospitals were approved yesterday by the state.

title: PITTSBURGH & WEST VIRGINIA RAILROAD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: YANKEES AND METS HAVE 5 RATED NO. 1
description: Don Mattingly and Dwight Gooden, who are expected to receive postseason league honors in coming weeks, head a group of five members of the Yankees and the Mets who are rated No. 1 at their positions in baseball's official statistical ranking of players. Joining them are Dave Winfield, Gary Carter and Keith Hernandez.

title: THE SCREEN: 'TARGET,' A SPY THRILLER BY PENN
description: THOUGH the members of the Lloyd family clearly love one another, they get on one another's nerves. They're well-meaning but edgy in everything they do. An expression of affection can suddenly be interpreted as criticism, which prompts immediate apologies. Each is bored by the predictability of the others.

title: STAR WARS' JOB NEAR AT LOCKHEED
description: The Lockheed Corporation has been tentatively chosen to design part of a system that would destroy incoming warheads before they enter the atmosphere.

title: Laundering Ring Charges
description: Government officials were trying to determine the dimensions of what they said was an international money-laundering ring today after the arrest of five men, including one bank executive.

title: THERMO ELECTRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings have been adjusted for a 50 percent stock dividend paid September 16.

title: BRACKEN EXPLORATION CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,572,000 for the quarter and $1,780,000 for the 9 months. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $295,000 for the quarter and $747,000 for the 9 months.

title: PACKAGING SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 10 percent stock dividend in May.

title: KOCH TO PUBLISH A NEW BOOK
description: Mayor Koch, who became a surprise best-selling author in 1984, will soon have another book to his name. Titled ''Politics,'' its nominal publication date is January but it is scheduled to arrive in New York bookstores by mid-December and in bookstores elsewhere a week or two later.

title: MUSIC: AMERICAN CHAMBER PLAYERS
description: A DARK and brooding work of more than ordinary interest, George Rochberg's Quartet for Piano and Strings (1983), was given its first New York performance by the American Chamber Players at Carnegie Recital Hall on Tuesday night. The 15-minute essay is not divided into movements, but it is sectionalized and pursues a fitful course marked by numerous stops and starts.

title: OF CHICAGO BLUES, IMPROVISATION AND HIP-HOP
description: A PIECE of music is more than a collection of sounds and silences, more than the message of a lyric or the memorability of a tune. It is also the sign of a specific community - composers, performers, listeners, dancers - that shares the music and that rallies around it. That community can be as large and ineffable as the fandom for a one-hit pop group, or as dedicated as a society of full-time Wagnerians.

title: Affirmative Action Happens to Be Working
description: To the Editor:

title: RANGERS CONTINUE TO SHIFT PLAYERS
description: It was probably to be expected that in this season of transition, the evaluation and re-evaluation of the Rangers from within would go on for some time. With a new coaching staff in place, that is only natural, and that is precisely what has been happening.

title: NEWMAN COMMUNICATIONS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Drug-Penalty Proposals
description: Penalties for college athletes who test positive for drugs at Division I bowl games and championships will range from a warning to the loss of a year's eligibility under a program expected to gain the approval of the National Collegiate Athletic Association in January, the chairman of a special committee said today. Drug testing is being performed independently at 96 of the N.C.A.A.'s 283 Division I schools and is under consideration at 45 others.

title: STANDARD COMMERCIAL TOACCO CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $151,000 for the quarter and $800,000 for the six months. c-Including tax credits of $341,000 for the quarter and $570,000 for the six months.

title: BURMA'S ARMY CLOSES IN ON LONG-RUNNING REVOLT
description: In the rugged, teak-forested hills of eastern Burma across the river from here, the Burmese Army is closing in on one of the world's longest running and least known separatist struggles - the Karen rebellion.

title: ALCO HEALTH SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CUSTOMS SET TO BLOCK SOVIET SHIP
description: The United States Customs Service announced tonight that it would block the departure of a Soviet freighter from American waters until a seaman aboard was permitted to appear before Congress.

title: EX-YALE TEACHER TRIED AS A NAZI COLLABORATOR
description: A former lecturer at Yale University went on trial today on Federal charges that he willfully concealed his activities as a Nazi collaborator who wrote articles calling for the annihilation of Jews.

title: AMERICAN FRONTIER EXPLORATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
'Winter's Tale'
description: The last three performances of the Lincoln Center Institute's production of Shakespeare's ''Winter's Tale'' will be given this weekend at Symphony Space, Broadway and 95th Street.

title: Washington Water Preferred at 8.80%
description: The Washington Water Power Company is offering 450,000 shares of $100 adjustable-rate preferred stock, with an initial dividend rate of 8.80 percent through underwriters led by Kidder, Peabody & Company.

title: KIEFER AND SERRA RECIPIENTS OF CARNEGIE PRIZE
description: Anselm Kiefer, the German painter, and Richard Serra, the American sculptor, are the dual recipients of the 1985 Carnegie Prize, it was announced today. Each will receive a cash award of $10,000 and a striking of the bronze medal first given in 1896 on the occasion of the inaugural Carnegie International exhibition in Pittsburgh.

title: ARMY-AIR FORCE A MATCH OF GLORY AND WISHBONES
description: Army and Air Force, two service academies that were down in the doldrums for years as bigger and better teams hammered at them, have found success in the finesse of the wishbone and will get to hammer away at each other on equal terms again Saturday at the Air Force Academy's Falcon Stadium.

title: Maryland Thrift Unit
description: The state today asked a judge to place Old Court Savings and Loan in receivership and to halt all interest payments on accounts at the ailing thrift institution, where a May run on deposits touched off a crisis in Maryland's thrift industry. The Baltimore Circuit Judge, Joseph H. H. Kaplan, who has been overseeing state conservatorship of Old Court, is expected to approve the request Friday.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 8, 1985
description: Companies

title: Stan Getz Quartet
description: The saxophonist Stan Getz is leading a quartet tonight through Sunday at Fat Tuesday's, 190 Third Avenue, at 17th Street (533-7902). Sets begin at 8, 10 and midnight tonight and tomorrow. Sunday, the group will play at 9 and 11 P.M. There is a $15 cover and a $7.50 minimum.

title: INTELLIGENT COMMUNICATION NETWORK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
THORN APPLE VALLEY reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 20
RESIDENTS ARE SAID TO FORTIFY CAPITAL SHELTER FOR HOMELESS
description: Residents of a shelter for homeless people here are fortifying the shelter to resist possible eviction by the Federal Government, a local activist said today.

title: NEW HOUSES MEAN A NEW KIND OF MAIL DELIVERY, TOO

description: A car bomb exploded near a crowded Teheran street market today, killing one person and wounding 15 others, the official press agency reported.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: THE long wooden bar displays a stunning array of strange and wonderful foods: baby octopus in a sea of red sauce, giant marinated mushrooms, bulbs of baked fennel, stuffed squid, snails with red beans, roasted eggplant, seafood casserole and more. Dangling overhead like an edible raised curtain are braids of blood-red hot peppers, rosy hams, sheets of powdery dried cod and plump black sausages. ''This is it!'' I said to myself upon entering, awash in nostalgia for my former home in Castile. ''Just like a tapas bar in Madrid.''

description: THE newest new management of the five-year-old Dial magazine thinks it has found the way to go as far as drawing advertisers to the 1.2-million-circulation publication that offers public televison programming. Education. ''It was the one demographic that just jumped off the page,'' explained Jeffrey S. Butler, chairman of the East/West Network, publisher of 10 in-flight magazines for airlines, which has added Dial to its responsibilities.

description: The Pittsburgh Pirates have hired Syd Thrift as their new general manager. The 53-year-old Thrift, a real estate agent in Fairfax, Va., has been out of baseball for nearly a decade, but something about him appealed to Mac Prine, the businessman who heads the new Pirate ownership.

IN NEW YORK, FASHION AID HAS A DOWNTOWN LOOK
description: Decked out in leather, latex, spiky hair, spandex, antique velvets, leopard skin and tulle, New York City's downtown fashion world gathered at the Palladium for the Fashion Aid benefit for African relief. Backstage, about 500 designers, dressers, models, hair stylists, makeup artists, and hangers-on swarmed in a crunch of beautiful and sometimes bizarrely decorated bodies. Despite the crowd - or maybe because of it - the fashion show, which featured 60 barely-known designers, came off without a hitch, delighting an audience of 3,500.

title: BOEING GETS $3.1 BILLION UNITED ORDER
description: United Airlines said today that it had ordered as many as 116 new planes, worth about $3.1 billion, from the Boeing Company. The agreement, involving the nation's largest airline and largest commercial aircraft manufacturer, was said by Boeing to be the largest single order in aviation history.

title: TOULOUSE-LAUTREC AT MODERN: THE ARTIST AS MASTER PRINTMAKER
description: THE ''Henri de Toulouse-Lautrec'' show at the Museum of Modern Art is not, as might be expected, a conventional retrospective. It is primarily a survey of Lautrec's printmaking in the 1890's, with one or two important paintings to serve as waymarks along the road. The big painting, dated 1896, of Marcelle Lender on stage in Herve's operetta ''Chilperic,'' makes a particularly strong impression in this context, as does ''The Englishman at the Moulin Rouge'' of 1892.

title: DECISIVE GAME IS TOMORROW
description: Anatoly Karpov staved off a determined assault by Gary Kasparov today, leaving the outcome of their bitter, 14-month chess feud to one last game on Saturday.

Commuter Air Safety Is Below Big Carriers'
description: Commuter planes are still four times as likely to crash as major carriers' aircraft even though the safety record for the commuter industry has improved, an aviation safety official says.

title: VIOLENCE IN COLOMBIA: A TRAIL OF TURMOIL
description: Feb. 27, 1980 - Fifteen guerrillas from the M-19 Movement seize the American Ambassador, Diego C. Asencio, and 51 other hostages after shooting their way into a reception at the residence of the Dominican Republic's Ambassador. They demand $50 million ransom and the release of 311 leftists but settle for a promise that observers from a rights commission will monitor trials and detentions, and, for themselves, passage to Cuba. Jan. 19, 1981 - M-19 guerrillas abduct Chester A. Bitterman 3d, a 28-year-old American linguist and lay missionary, accusing him of being a spy for the Central Intelligence Agency. He is killed on March 7. July 20, 1981 - Two days before the expiration of a four-month amnesty offer by President Julio Cesar Turbay Ayala, M-19 guerrillas fire three training mortar shells into the grounds of the presidential palace in Bogota. Only 20 rebels respond to the amnesty. Jan. 27, 1982 - M-19 guerrillas hijack a Colombian airliner on a flight from Bogota to Pereira with 128 people aboard, and force it to fly Cali, 200 miles away. May 29, 1982 - M-19 guerrillas, saying they want to disrupt national elections the next day, burn buses and bomb targets, including a church. Aug. 7, 1982 - Belisario Betancur, a 59-year-old lawyer, is inaugurated as President and says he will offer a truce to guerrillas. He proceeds to sign an amnesty law, and by December, 60 guerrillas are freed from prisons, including Carlos Toledo Plata, founder of M-19. Nov. 22, 1983 - National Liberation Army guerrillas seize Jaime Betancur, a 53-year-old law professor and brother of the President.

No Offer From Cards

Porter, who missed much of the first half of the season with a broken toe and a broken thumb and then spent the second half platooning with Tom Nieto, is expected to file for free agency before the Monday midnight deadline.

From the beginning, I wanted to explore unusual repertory, and perform the music of my time.''

title: Byrd's New 'Do'
description: Senator Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia, the minority leader, appeared on the floor this week with a new hair-do. In a move of possible political significance, his part had been shifted from the right to the left, and the swooping pompadour that has been his trademark for some time had been smoothed and flattened into relative obscurity. All of which may or may not be related to recurrent reports that his Democratic colleagues may challenge Mr. Byrd for the leadership in 1987, particularly if their party recaptures a majority next November.

'Hellfire' to Be Shown On Channel 13
description: In ''Hellfire,'' a curious half-hour drama by Jonathan Altman that can be seen tonight at 10:30 on Channel 13, a mod young woman, who may be an angel or God Herself, says things like, ''Give me a break.'' Mostly, though, the woman trades quotes from Scriptures with a television evangelist who is either dreaming her or meeting her in the flesh. ''I am not flesh, but spirit,'' she, or She, says, and the evangelist replies, ''You're flesh all right and very nice flesh, too.''

title: Boston Prizes Set
description: The Boston Marathon, which is offering prize money next year for the first time in its 90-year-history, announced a prize list that provides parity for male and female runners with a $30,000 award to the winners and lesser prizes scaled down to $1,000 for the next 14 finishers in each division. ''That's sort of a precedent,'' said Bill Rodgers, a four-time winner of the event.

title: Royal Goodies
description: Are the Prince and Princess of Wales bringing the entire able-bodied population of the British Isles with them to Washington? In the past 10 days, the two branches of Sutton Place Gourmet, a local grocery, have sold 2,000 boxes of British tea biscuits, 746 cases of Walker's short-bread and 40 cases of Callard & Bowser Butterscotch, cleaning their shelves of these United Kingdom staples. Jeff Cohen, the stores' owner, had planned to send a gift basket of English goodies to Sir Oliver Wright, the British Ambassador, and Lady Wright in honor of the royal visit, which begins tomorrow, but he had to substitute American fare.

The concert is dedicated to the soprano and teacher Judith Raskin, who died last December. Tickets are $6; information: 362-8719.

title: EXCERPTS FROM PSYCHIATRIST'S REPORT
description: Following are excerpts from a report to the State Department Oct. 30 by a psychiatrist who, at the department's request, examined Miroslav Medved, a Ukrainian seaman who jumped from a Soviet freighter near New Orleans. The report was made public today by the State Department, which withheld the pyschiatrist's name. Throughout the report Mr. Medved is referred to as MM. WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 - Following are excerpts from a report to the State Department Oct. 30 by a psychiatrist who, at the department's request, examined Miroslav Medved, a Ukrainian seaman who jumped from a Soviet freighter near New Orleans. The report was made public today by the State Department, which withheld the pyschiatrist's name. Throughout the report Mr. Medved is referred to as MM.

title: REUTER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: ZONDERVAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss. c-Net income.

title: UNIROYAL IS SELLING CHEMICAL DIVISION
description: Uniroyal Inc. said yesterday that it was putting its chemical division up for sale to reduce the nearly $1 billion in debt that piled up when the company recently completed a leveraged buyout.

title: COORS, ADOLPH CO reports earnings for 16 wks to Oct 6
NEW YORK SEEKS TO APPOINT BEST JUDGES TO HIGHER COURT
description: Competent judges will serve longer and others who are considered less capable will be transferred more quickly under new procedures that officials say are intended to improve the quality of temporary appointments to State Supreme Court in New York.

title: WIEBOLDT BUYOUT PLAN IS REVIVED
description: Wieboldt Stores Inc. announced the revival of an investor group's plan to acquire the company in a leveraged buyout for $13.50 a share, or about $37.3 million. Wieboldt, which operates 13 department stores in the Chicago area, said that its new agreement in principle with the WSI Acquisition Corporation was still subject to WSI obtaining adequate financing and the execution of a definitive agreement.

title: STANDARD COMMERCIAL TOACCO CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $151,000 for the quarter and $800,000 for the six months. c-Including tax credits of $341,000 for the quarter and $570,000 for the six months.

title: CMX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 29
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $45,000, of 1 cent a share. c-Including an extraordinary gain of $162,000, or 7 cents a share.

title: OCEANEERING INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income, including a gain of approximatedly $700,000 from the sale of an asset.

title: FIBRONICS INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding have been adjusted to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split on June 12, 1985.

title: MILGRAY ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: Make the Fare Fair
description: To the Editor:

title: Abortion Foes' Target Is Family Planning
description: To the Editor:

title: MONITOR LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: VESTRON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
HELPING UNHAPPY CAR OWNER
description: CONSUMERS were awarded nearly $2 million from January 1984 to February 1985 under a car-repair arbitration program administered by the Better Business Bureau of Metropolitan New York.

title: 2 FIRE FIGHTERS NOT GUILTY OF HOMICIDE IN FATAL QUEENS TRAFFIC CRASH
description: Two New York City firefighters were acquitted yesterday of charges of criminally negligent homicide stemming from the death of a motorist in a collision between their fire truck and his car in Queens last year.

title:
PATENTS;

PUTTING WIDE FILMS ON TV RECEIVERS
description: A system to transmit wide-angle pictures to television receivers was patented this week for RCA.

title: KODAK WORKERS' WAGE DIVIDENDS
description: The Eastman Kodak Company said today that it would be giving a total of about $239 million to 85,000 employees in the United States as part of its 73-year-old wage dividend program. When it is distributed in March, each eligible employee will receive roughly 2 percent of his total wages for the five-year period from 1981 to 1985, a company spokesman said.

title: ARD IS AN EDUCATED BLOCKER
description: In 1981, after four years at Wake Forest, Billy Ard earned a degree in economics. In 1983, he spent four months in classes before earning a stockbroker's license. But the education that best prepared him for his major job came on a December afternoon in 1981 on the artificial turf of Giants Stadium.

title: REAGAN MOVE FOR JOB FUNDS
description: President Reagan has asked Congress to restore $100 million for the Labor Department's job training program, with the money earmarked for workers who lose their jobs because of imports, Administration officials said.

title: TAPE SAYS PERSICO REFUSED TO INFORM
description: A Federal jury yesterday heard a secretly recorded conversation in which a friend of Carmine Persico told an undercover tax agent in 1978 that the reputed boss of the Colombo crime ''family'' would rather stay in prison than be labeled an informer and that Mr. Persico was not involved in narcotics trafficking.

title: Belgian Police Report Uncovering Arms Ring
description: The Belgian police said today that they had uncovered an international arms smuggling ring that reportedly involved 40 people, 20 companies and unidentified embassies that helped deliver arms to terrorist groups, including the Basque movement E.T.A. in Spain.

title: ILLINOIS BELL CUTS
description: Illinois Bell, a unit of Ameritech, one of the telephone operating companies carved out of the former Bell System, said that it was aiming to cut 800 to 900 managers through a ''voluntary separation program.'' The company said that if the plan was not successful, ''an involuntary management separation plan will be instituted.'' The company, which has 23,000 employees, also said that it would freeze its basic management salary structure ''at current levels through 1986.''

title: STAAR SURGICAL CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: RUBIN CARTER WINS RELEASE: PROSECUTORS PLAN AN APPEAL
description: After almost 19 years in prison for a triple-murder conviction, Rubin (Hurricane) Carter walked out of a Federal courtroom today a free man.

title: LOUISIANA GENERAL SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The latest year net includes a gain of $1,145,000 from the sale of securities.

title: U.S. TO SEEK UNITARY TAX BAN
description: President Reagan announced today that he would ask Congress to prohibit states from taxing multinational corporations on profits earned outside the United States.

title: THE SAILOR WHO SAID NO
description: Whatever now happens to poor young Miroslav Medved, reasonable Americans can agree on two points. One is that their Government handled his case disastrously at the outset. The other is that critics of the Administration are handling it so badly now.

title: CITY OPERA: PHILIP GLASS'S 'AKHNATEN'
description: Beverly Sills confided during a seminar not long ago that Philip Glass first brought his opera ''Akhnaten'' to the New York City Opera envisioned as one long and flowing experience - unbroken by intermissions, unpunctuated by traditional operatic formats, indeed, encouraging the audience to come and go much as they did at ''Einstein on the Beach,'' his earlier collaboration with the theater artist Robert Wilson. Miss Sills, who is general director of the company, said it couldn't be done, and rightly so. The seating pattern at the New York State Theater does not invite milling audiences, she said, and union work rules would have rendered such an ''Akhnaten'' prohibitively expensive.

title: MATTEL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $5.6 million for the quarter and $19 million for the 9 months. c-Including tax credits of $14.6 million for the quarter and $18.7 million for the 9 months.

title: GETTING CLOSER
description: Knick fact No. 1: After the loss to Milwaukee on Thursday night, Patrick Ewing has now experienced more defeats with New York (seven) than in his entire last two seasons at Georgetown (six).

title: MICHIGAN STATE SENATOR HELD ON CHARGES OF DRUG DELIVERY
description: State Senator Basil Brown of Michigan was arrested today on charges of cocaine delivery and possession, the authorities said.

title: ITALY PREMIER WINS A VOTE OF CONFIDENCE
description: Prime Minister Bettino Craxi won a decisive vote of confidence in his Government today, ending the latest political crisis growing out of the Achille Lauro hijacking.

title: RED CROSS MAKES AN APPEAL TO FILL EMPTY DISASTER FUND
description: The American Red Cross said Thursday that its disaster fund was depleted, even as its volunteers fanned out over a four-state area devastated by Middle Atlantic flooding.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 9, 1985
description: Markets

title: SUNSHINE-JR. STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
LEAR PETROLEUM PARTNERS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After provisions of $9.9 million for the quarter and $43,560,000 for the 9 months for the writedown of oil and gas properties. c-Year-ago results are not available because the company was spun off from Lear Petroleum Corp. in May.

title: E.P.A. RESTRICTING USE OF WASTE OIL AS FUEL
description: The Environmental Protection Agency announced restrictions today on the selling and burning of used oil containing contaminated waste. It said the use of such oil as fuel could cause cancer and other illnesses.

title: CHEMICAL FOUND IN MORE WINE
description: The Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms announced today that it has uncovered traces of the diethylene glycol, a chemical used in anti-freeze, in several brands of wine imported from Italy, and large amounts in more Austrian wines.

title: SCHERER, R.P. CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
COKE IS IT AT A NEW 'CAFETERIA' OF CLOTHES
description: Take the time-honored concept of the cafeteria, add the latest electronic technology and it equals Fizzazz, a shop at 280 Columbus Avenue that will be selling the new line of Coca-Cola Clothes.

title: VIDEOTAPE CRISIS
description: The elevator of the Upper West Side apartment building was packed with people weary from a long week's work. As the door was about to close, a frantic voice echoed through the lobby.

title: BERCOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
RECIPE FOR A DELUGE: TROPICAL AIR MIXED WITH HURRICANE REMNANT
description: When the rains came to the Middle Atlantic states a week ago yesterday, meteorologists knew that this would be no light drizzle. They could see by their charts and satellite photographs that tropical winds from the southeast were converging with the remnants of Hurricane Juan to generate a downpour.

title: SMALL-TOWN DOCTOR, BIG-TIME CHALLENGE
description: White House officials describe Otis Bowen, M.D., as a ''triple crown'' nominee for Secretary of Health and Human Services. He would be the first practicing physician to head the agency, is a politician of proven ability and is a good administrator. On the first two points, there's plenty of reason for confidence. His success in office, however, will depend on how he handles the administrative challenge.

title: Jail Terms for 65 in Comoros
description: A court has sentenced 18 people to life in prison for their part in an attempt to overthrow the Comoros Government of President Ahmed Abdallah in March.

title: DEVILS TOP PENGUINS ON 3 GOALS IN THIRD
description: The Devils played inspired hockey for only 10 minutes tonight, but it proved to be enough against a Patrick Division rival.

title: PROVIDENCE ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company paid dividends of 41 cents for the latest quarter, $1.43 for the latest nine months, 34 cents for the year-ago quarter and $1.24 for the year-ago nine months.

title: FED PANEL VOTED STEADY POLICY
description: Policy makers at the Federal Reserve decided at their October meeting to make no changes in monetary policy, a Fed report said today.

title: CHEVRON UNITS' SALE SEEN NEAR
description: The Chevron Corporation said yesterday that it was in the ''final negotiations'' of its previously announced plan to sell most of its properties in the Eastern half of the country. The talks are being held with four potential buyers, the company said, adding that it expects the sale prices to total about $500 million.

title: LEVITT CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $63,000 for the quarter and $486,000 for the 9 months.

title: UNC RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $1,014,000 for the quarter and $5,414,000 for the nine months. c-After a loss of $1,311,000 from discontinued operations. d-Including income of $13,724,000 from discontinued operations.

title: 3 JUDGES UPHOLD PARADE EXCLUSION
description: A three-judge panel ruled yesterday that the American Legion could exclude a homosexual veterans group from its Veterans Day parade Monday.

title: F.B.I. SAYS JEWISH DEFENSE LEAGUE MAY HAVE PLANTED FATAL BOMBS
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation said today that it had concluded the Jewish Defense League was ''the possible responsible group'' in recent bomb attacks against an Arab leader in California and two East Coast men with purported Nazi ties. Two of the attacks resulted in deaths. The national leader of the Jewish Defense League, Irv Rubin of Los Angeles, said today that his group had nothing to do with the bombings.

title: DEATH TOLL AT 100 AFTER REBEL SIEGE IN COLOMBIAN CITY
description: The death toll in the guerrilla attack on the Palace of Justice here rose to about 100 today as medical teams searched the charred and bullet-scarred building for bodies.

title: 'LA VIOLENCIA' IN COLUMBIA: SEEDS WERE SOWN LONG AGO
description: ''La Violencia'' is a phrase well known in the history of Colombia, a name given to a specific decade of civil war in which some 280,000 people were killed.

title: GROUPS OPPOSE CABINET CHOICE OVER ABORTIONS
description: Anti-abortion groups and several conservative organizations said today they would oppose the nomination of Dr. Otis R. Bowen to be Secretary of Health and Human Services, asserting he had not been a consistent opponent of abortion.

title: MARCOS SAYS HE WILL RESIGN BUT STAY ON
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos said today that he would submit a letter of resignation Monday to pave the way for elections early next year, but that he would nonetheless remain in office.

title: AMERICAN PIONEER SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $1,087,000 for the quarter and $1,912,000 for the 9 months. c-After an extraordinary charge of $410,000.

title: COLUMBIA GAS SHOCK UP SHARPLY
description: The stock price of Columbia Gas System Inc., the Delaware-based gas pipeline company, surged in heavy trading yesterday. The trading was apparently spurred by rumors that the company would announce on Monday favorable revisions of contracts that had locked it into paying above-market prices for natural gas.

title: C.I.A. GIVES A RARE GLIMPSE OF LIFE OF A TOP SOVIET AGENT
description: The Central Intelligence Agency today issued a biography of Vitaly S. Yurchenko, characterizing him as a senior Soviet spy who rose to the military rank of ''General-designate'' in a 25-year career with the K.G.B.

title: FAILURES OF BANKS REACH 100
description: Federal and state regulators closed two more insolvent banks today, bringing to 100 the number shut this year.

title: PRESIDENT VETOES BILL ON RESEARCH
description: President Reagan today vetoed a bill that would have required the National Institutes of Health to undertake specified research activities.

title: WESTCHESTER FINANCIAL SERVCE reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
AT HOME, THE ROYAL COUPLE PROVOKE AN UNREMITTING DEMAND FOR GOSSIP
description: The three-day visit to Washington by the Prince and Princess of Wales, which begins Saturday, has given that city a quick taste of Britain's insatiable appetite for gossip about the pair.

title: TECHNOLOGY RESEARCH reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 50. 1. This is how fast an American speeding ''bullet'' goes. Explain. 2. ''Hello, I am sending kisses to you all,'' said a voice from the past. Who made the remark and what were the circumstances? 3. Incumbents seeking re-election were successful in most major American cities where mayoral contests were held, but there was one notable and unresolved exception. What city is it and what is happening there? 4. The amount of 17 1/2 cents will end one of the more acerbic border skirmishes of recent times. Explain. 5. Oberpfaffenhofen, a Bavarian hamlet with a name as long as a countdown, was an unlikely center of world attention. What is the reason? 6. Under Federal law, aliens who defect to the United States are immediately entitled to all the rights guaranteed under the Constitution, including the freedom to move within the country at will. True or false? 7. For the second time this year, another round number came around on Wall Street. Explain. 8. The Supreme Court (agreed/ refused) to review whether the Constitution protects adults from prosecution for private homosexual acts. 9. The hero of the Giants' 22-20 victory over the Tampa Bay Buccaneers Sunday did something else for a living until two days before the game. Who is he and what did he do? 10. A head of state announced a measure to put an end to what he called a ''silly claim'' that his Government is inept.

title: PREFERRED HEALTH CARE reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
STUDY SAYS A SMALL MOBILE MISSILE WOULD HELP U.S. DETER SOVIET STRIKE
description: At a time when the Reagan Administration has proposed a ban on intercontinental mobile missiles, an Air Force analysis is circulating showing that the development of an American single-warhead mobile missile could help the United States maintain the survivability of its land-based missile force in a nuclear conflict.

title: HARD TO DESCRIBE
description: Brian Noble, a linebacker for the Green Bay Packers, recounts the now-famed touchdown reception by Chicago's William (The Refrigerator) Perry: ''How he got around the end, I don't know. But he waddled around the end and caught the pass. Waddled, rolled, I don't know what you want to call it.''

title: LONDON EXCHANGE LIFTS BAN ON TRAKING IN TIN
description: The London Metal Exchange announced today that it would resume trading in tin on Nov. 18. Trading was halted on Oct. 24, after an international tin cartel said it no longer had the funds to support tin prices.

title: EMPIRE AIRLINES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: BIRD ISSUES REGRETS
description: It's not easy being Larry Bird, or so, anyway, says Larry Bird, the Celtic star who has reached an out-of-court settlement of a lawsuit stemming from a reported fight with a bartender outside a Boston bar last May. Commenting on the incident for the first time, Bird told The Worcester Telegram that it had been primarily his fault.

title: BAR SHUT DOWN FOR HIGH RISK SEX WAS GIVEN A NOT-FOR-PROFIT STATUS
description: State and city officials began separate investigations yesterday after officials said that the Mine Shaft bar, closed Thursday for permitting ''high-risk sexual activity,'' had won status as a not-for-profit corporation.

title: SCALLION? OH, YOU MEAN GREEN ONION
description: Just before my 10th birthday, my mother took me to a restaurant and bar in the Italian section of Waterbury, Conn., for a treat I had never had before. I remember this so vividly because the next day, my birthday, I came down with chicken pox. But before it was diagnosed, my mother thought perhaps I was allergic to the treat she called - and this is a phonetic stab at spelling it - ''ahbeetz.''

title: SMD INDUSTRIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PIEDMONT MANAGEMENT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including realized gains on investments of $232,814 for the quarter and $724,254 for the nine months. c-Including a realized gain on investments of $21,434. d-After a realized loss on investments of $1,341,822.

title: SOVIET SAID TO SHIFT ON UNESCO
description: A senior Eastern bloc diplomat indicated today that the Soviet Union and its allies would join Western nations in opposing a third term in 1987 for Unesco's Director General, Amadou-Mahtar M'Bow of Senegal.

title: WORLD CHESS CHAMPIONSHIP HINGES ON THE FINAL GAME
description: Gary Kasparov pressed Anatoly Karpov throughout the 23d game of their world championship chess match in Moscow on Thursday, but failed to create a winning advantage and let the encounter slip into a draw.

title: LILCO'SMOVE TO PREVENT ADS DISMISSED BY FEDERAL JUDGE
description: A Federal judge dismissed a suit today in which Long Island Lighting Company sought to prevent a group opposed to its management from publishing advertisements advocating public ownership of the utility.

title: HMO AMERICA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CORRECTION
description: A report in the Evening Hours column of the Style page yesterday about Suzy, the society columnist, omitted the name of her newspaper.

title:
PATENTS;

ENGINE COOLING SYSTEM
description: A cooling system for internal combustion engines that was patented this week is being promoted by National Technologies Inc. of Sharon, Conn., as offering fuel economy and other benefits. Patent 4,550,694 was granted to John W. Evans, also of Sharon.

title: TREASURY ISSUES RISE STRONGLY
description: Prices of Treasury debt issues advanced strongly yesterday in heavy daylong buying that carried across all maturity sectors of the market.

title: IN PALM BEACH, THE SOCIAL EVENT NOW A TEMPEST
description: It was supposed to be the hottest ticket of the year, an evening with Charles and Di.

title: Travels With Bush
description: While Mr. Reagan is in Geneva, Vice President Bush will not spend all his time in the capital keeping track of things.

title: The Birthday Watch
description: The ages of Supreme Court Justices are always watched in the capital, given the possibility of the Reagan Administration's replacing one or more of them.

title: OILERS ERUPT, 13-0
description: Raimo Summanen and Jari Kurri touched off a four-goal first period, and the Edmonton Oilers scored seven times in the third period to complete the most lopsided victory in their history, a 13-0 rout of the Vancouver Canucks tonight.

title: The Meese Watch
description: Reporters covering the Justice Department used to like the fifth-floor press room and public affairs office because, situated just a few doors down the hall, they afforded a view of who was visiting the office of Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d. But the arrangement reportedly did not please Mr. Meese, and the press room was moved to the first floor.

title: Negotiations Recessed In Coast Grocery Strike
description: Negotiators in a food workers' strike against major supermarket chains in southern California recessed talks early today without nearing a settlement, officials said.

title: Guru Is Freed on Bail By U.S. Judge in Oregon
description: Over the strenuous objections of Government attorneys, a Federal judge today ordered the release of Bhagwan Shree Rajneesh on $500,000 bail.

title: COMMERCE BANCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BRIEFS
description: * Amoco Oil Co., Chicago, said it had completed the sale of its interests in an Indian refinery and fertilizer plant to the Indian Government. Terms were not disclosed.

title: AIDS-FREE BLOOD SUBSTITUTE PREPARED FOR EMERGENCY USE
description: An AIDS-free blood substitute originally developed by United States Army researchers for battlefield transfusions may soon be available for hospital and emergency use, according to the company that developed it.

title: BRENTWOOD INSTRUMENTS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
JUSTICE DEPT. BACKS PEOPLE DEAL
description: The Justice Department said today that it has urged the Transportation Department to approve the application of People Express Airlines to acquire Frontier Airlines. In comments filed with the Transportation Department, the Justice Department's antitrust division said the proposed acquisition ''clearly would have no anti-competitive effect and therefore should be exempted'' from further Government review.

title: Americans to Excavate Crash Site in Vietnam
description: The Pentagon announced today that American investigators would excavate a bomber crash site near Hanoi later this month, the first time Vietnam has allowed Americans to participate in the search for remains of missing servicemen since the war ended in 1975.

title: DIGITAL PLANS I.B.M. LINKAGE
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation said yesterday that it plans to introduce an I.B.M.-compatible personal computer, leaving Apple Computer Inc. as the sole American computer maker that has not adopted the I.B.M. architecture.

title: ISS INTERNATIONAL SERVICE SYSTEMS (DANISH, CO) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income including a gain of $91,000 from discontinued operations and a gain of $1,809,000 on the sale of discontinued operations.

title: SIERRA HEALTH SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: CABARET: DUO AT PANACHE
description: John Meyer and Leila Martin end their cabaret performance at Panache, 149 East 57th Street, where they appear on Thursday evenings, in such a glow of entertaining material that one almost forgets its pedestrian beginnings.

title: OUT OF HIS PRIME
description: Steve Richmond, former Ranger and current New Haven Nighthawk, explains why he would prefer to be back in the National Hockey League: ''You're probably just a piece of meat wherever you play, but at least up there you're prime rib.''

title: SUNAIR ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Report of Vitamin Panel Didn't Pass Review
description: To the Editor:

title: CITY FIGHTS BRONX YOUTH HOME SALE
description: A wooded campus in the Bronx where troubled children have been cared for for more than 50 years has become the center of a dispute involving the Koch administration, the Bronx Democratic leader, a developer and a nonprofit social-service agency.

title: HANDYMAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago results include $500,000 from the liquidation of LIFO reserves and a gain of $1.5 million on the sale of Texas and Oklahoma stores.

title: NEWS SUMMARY SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 8, 1985
description: International

title: PARIS AND BONN SET ACCORD ON PROJECTS
description: France and West Germany, at the close of two days of talks here, announced agreement today on a range of joint military, space and transportation undertakings.

title: 4 LEBANON HOSTAGES SAID TO SEND PLEA TO REAGAN
description: A letter of appeal to President Reagan that was apparently signed by four American hostages was delivered today to a Western news agency here.

title:
PATENTS;

A DEVICE TO SCREEN PHONE CALLS
description: WITH new telephone equipment, a caller's identity can be discerned before the receiver is lifted from the hook, thus permitting the screening of calls.

title: MENTAL HEALTH IS NOT NEGLECTED
description: To the Editor:

title: CONFLICTS OF THE HEART
description: COLLECTED STORIES. By Tennessee Williams. 574 pages. New Directions. $19.95. ''For love I make characters in plays,'' wrote Tennessee Williams, in the preface to this volume. ''To the world I give suspicion and resentment, mostly. I am not cold. I am never deliberately cruel. But after my morning's work, I have little to give but indifference to people. I try to excuse myself with the pretense that my work justifies this lack of caring much for almost everything else. Sometimes I crack through the emotional block. I touch, I embrace, I hold tight to a necessary companion. But the breakthrough is not long lasting. Morning returns, and only work matters again.''

title: ALL-AROUND TO RUSSIAN
description: Yuri Korolev powered his way to the men's all-around gold medal tonight, giving the Soviet Union its third of the three titles awarded so far at the World Gymnastics Championships.

title: MONSANTO SETTLES WITH TAX AGENCY
description: The Monsanto Company said that it had reached a settlement with the Internal Revenue Service relating to contested tax liabilities of its recently acquired subsidiary, G. D. Searle & Company, from 1976 to 1982. Monsanto agreed to pay the I.R.S. $160 million stemming from a disagreement over the allocation of income from Searle's subsidiary in Puerto Rico.

title: EDITOR'S NOTE
description: An article on the Washington Talk page on Monday about Senator John C. Stennis's long tenure on Capitol Hill said that the Mississippi Democrat had a ''Southern viewpoint'' on race relations and did not vote in favor of a civil rights bill until 1982.

title: PANEL FINDS ANGER AT CUTS IN U.S. AID
description: City officials, welfare recipients and social-service agencies yesterday denounced Federal cutbacks in food stamps and Government aid and warned that hunger in New York City had reached crisis proportions.

title: DOZENS OF FLOOD VICTIMS STILL MISSING IN 4 STATES
description: Dozens of people were still missing today in four Middle Atlantic states where workers began cleaning up extensive flood damage and searched for bodies in mudbanks and crumpled houses.

title: COMSTOCK GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TELECOMMUNICATION SPEIALISTS reports earnings for Year to June 30
Quotation of the Day
description: ''We are bringing a broad agenda to Geneva focusing on the full spectrum of U.S.-Soviet relations, not just arms control, but regional conflicts, bilateral relations and human rights.

title: BOEING MAKES BID FOR DE HAVILLAND
description: Boeing Company officials have submitted a bid to buy the de Havilland Aircraft Corporation of Canada, which is being sold by a Government-backed holding company. De Havilland reportedly earned $40 million last year on revenues of $204 million after taking a $78 million write-off for developments costs of its latest aircraft.

title: POP: ANNIE GOLDEN, SINGER
description: Annie Golden, a veteran of the New Wave band the Shirts and the current star of ''Little Shop of Horrors,'' brings a considerable dramatic power to the portrayal of a ravaged city waif in her new cabaret act.

title: SAX AND FLUTE DUETS
description: The tenor saxophonist David Murray and the flutist James Newton will play duets tonight at 9 and 10:30 at Greenwich Music House, 27 Barrow Street (431-3009), in a concert presented by Jazztrack. Tickets are $10.

title: LOAN FOR SAKOWITZ
description: Sakowitz Inc. signed an $8 million loan agreement with the Chemical Bank of New York paving the way for vendors to ship goods to the Houston-based retailer in time for the Christmas shopping season.

title: K.G.B. MAN REPORTEDLY MET WITH ENVOY'S WIFE IN CANADA
description: Vitaly S. Yurchenko, a former Soviet defector who returned to Moscow from Washington this week, was driven to Ottawa by American intelligence agents in late September so he could ask the wife of a Soviet diplomat to join him in the United States, according to sources familiar with the case.

title: JAPANESE REACTION
description: Dealers and economists today noted several reasons for the dollar's sharp rebound today against the yen.

title: SHAKLEE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After special charges of $600,000. c-After special charges of about $3.2 million resulting from recording of inventory reserves.

title: ANDRES WINE reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
No Headline
description: Three visions of urban life to music by three composers were offered in Nina Wiener's ''In Closed Time,'' which received its premiere by Nina Wiener and Dancers on Thursday night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. Appropriately enough, she had architects design her choreographic city. The results were worth pondering.

title: SYRACUSE, ON THE RISE, SEEKS BOWL BID
description: The Syracuse team that plays Navy at Annapolis, Md., today has won three of its last four games, the only defeat being by 4 points to undefeated Penn State, which came from behind late in the game.

title: EL PASO ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
COURTS ASSAILED BYU ANTITRUST CHIEF

description: ''Sometimes I feel like a puppet with broken strings,'' Justine Hazel said the other day, sitting in the basement of her neat brownstone on Hamilton Terrace in Harlem. ''You get old and you lose your friends, your health, everything. It's lonely.''

title: GYMNAST INJURES THIGH
description: Doctors who examined the injured gymnast Jennifer Sey discovered that she had a broken thighbone rather than a dislocated knee as first suspected, officials of the United States team said. The 16-year-old Miss Sey, from Haddonfield, N.J., was hurt falling from the uneven parallel bars Thursday night at a women's team competition at the World Gymnastics Championships. Don Peters, the coach of the United States team, called for a change in international rules after Miss Sey was hurt, saying she would have fallen without injury if the International Federation of Gymnastics had allowed him to spot her on the bars.

title: G.E. IS CLEARED
description: Federal authorities say they found no basis for a prosecution of the General Electric Company over allegations that employees at a G.E. plant outside Cincinnati cheated on time cards submitted for work on Government contracts. Ann Marie Tracey, an Assistant United States Attorney, said Thursday that the Government had concluded there was no basis for prosecution after investigating the allegations at G.E.'s jet engine plant in Evendale, a Cincinnati suburb. The plant produces jet engines for military and civilian aircraft.

SUBSIDIZING COMMERCIAL RENTS
description: Leaning against a wall on East 7th Street in Manhattan, a weathered old man can be found on most days staring aimlessly, a pile of clothes beside him. The neighbors say he stands outside of a store that had once been his tailor shop. After being forced out when his rent was quintupled, the man would not leave the place that was his life for many decades. The tailor is another sad victim of New York's prosperity.

title: DOCTOR BELIEVES SEAMAN REACTED TO SOVIET THREATS

title: JAZZ: WAYNE SHORTER QUARTET

He leads a quartet, formed a little over a month ago, that has already developed a confident sense of unity in creating broad, supportive foundations for Mr. Shorter's playing on soprano and tenor saxophones.

title: N.B.A. APPEALS RULING

title: SAMUELSON RECOVERING
description: She has been bothered by bone spurs throughout her running career, but not enough to keep her from winning the Olympic marathon last year or the Chicago marathon last month. Still, even a champion must attend to such medical details from time to time, so, with her Chicago victory behind her, Joan Benoit Samuelson checked into University Hospital in Boston last Tuesday to have the spurs removed. Yesterday she checked out to continue what her surgeon, Robert Leach, predicted would be a quick recovery.

title: SOVIET SEAMAN: HOW THE CASE DEVELOPED
description: Oct. 24 - A young Ukranian seaman, Miroslav Medved, jumps from the freighter Marshal Konev into the Mississippi River at Belle Chase, La. He is taken into custody by immigration officials, who question him through a Justice Department interpreter. Mr. Medved indicates that he is not seeking asylum, according to the officials; the interpreter, Irene Padoch, who spoke with him by telephone, later disputes that assertion. Oct. 25 - Mr. Medved is returned to the Soviet freighter at 2 A.M. As the launch approaches the ship he jumps again into the water and swims ashore. Seven Soviet seaman come from the freighter, pick him up and carry him onto the ship. Some witnesses report that there was a struggle. Oct. 28 - Mr. Medved leaves the freighter and is interviewed aboard a Coast Guard cutter by officials from the State Department, the Immigration and Naturalization Service and a doctor. He is given physical and psychiatric examinations at a nearby Navy facility and spends the night on shore. Oct. 29 - The sailor is given another psychiatric examination early in the morning and the interview resumes. He repeatedly confirms his desire to return to the Soviet Union, and is returned to the ship. Oct. 31 - President Reagan orders an investigation into the situation after hearing the conflicting story of the translator in the first interview, who says Mr. Medved told her that he wanted asylum after he first jumped ship. Nov. 3 - Three Ukrainian-American groups petition the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia to keep the ship from departing until Mr. Medved can again be interviewed by American officials.

Luckily today we are mostly free of such disorderliness. That subversive Spirit of Nature which runs through all things with abandoned zeal is now checked and monitored daily. Never before have we enjoyed such levels of hygiene, comfort and order as now exist in the modern Universe.

title: 'World's Fair'
description: "World's Fair'' by E. L. Doctorow is a peculiar hybrid of novel and memoir. Its hero, like Mr. Doctorow, is named Edgar, and grows up in the Bronx in the 1930's; his parents, like Mr. Doctorow's parents, are named Rose and Dave; his brother, like the author's brother, Donald. The family's last name is Altschuler. One is reminded of Renata Adler's novel ''Pitch Dark,'' in which the heroine, Kate Ennis, must choose a name similar to, yet slightly different from, her own, and decides on Alder; in both these works, the naming strategy seems to be a kind of tipoff, a way of telling the reader that the book at hand will unapologetically combine fiction and memory.

title: ART SONGS STILL REACH OUT TO WEAVE A SPELL
description: Vocal art flourishes in huge arenas these days -Luciano Pavarotti at Madison Square Garden, Bruce Springsteen in Giants Stadium. The art song, by contrast, is relegated to near silence: ours is obviously not an age that values intimate songful communication. Recordings, usually originating in Europe, seem to conceal this fact, suggesting that the art of the recitalist is far from dead, that the successors of Lotte Lehmann, Maggie Teyte and Alexander Kipnis are alive, well and even prosperous. That is most certainly true of the great Dietrich Fischer-Dieskau, who is still amazingly productive at 60. But all that activity notwithstanding, recorded song recitals rarely enjoy long life in the catalogue.

title: U.S. SHOULD HEED THIRD WORLD DEMANDS
description: THE General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade has provided a mechanism that has facilitatedthe phenomenal postwar growth of world commerce. But it oversees only trade in goods.

title: WHY ARE CHILDREN WRITING TO ME INSTEAD OF READING?
description: WHEN I was growing up, I felt that authors should stay out of sight. I decided this because their pictures appeared on cards in that educational game called Authors. Henry Wadsworth Longfellow with his long gray hair did not look like a grown-up Hiawatha. Rudyard Kipling wearing spectacles and a mustache looked very much like my beloved grandfather, who never annoyed children by telling them if they could keep their heads and generally behave themselves, they would ''be a man, my son.'' Robert Louis Stevenson with his wispy hair and trailing mustache at one time probably looked like that sissy boy who talked about his ''nursie'' in ''A Child's Garden of Verses,'' poems chanted in derision but never forgotten by the children in my neighborhood. The biggest disappointment was Louisa May Alcott with her hair in a snood. She should have had short dark curls like Jo in ''Little Women'' after she sold her beautiful long hair.

title: THE DOW PREPARES FOR LIFE AFTER 1,400
description: The 1,400 mark on the Dow seemed unattainable just a few years ago, but on Friday the industrial average closed at 1,404.36, 14.11 points higher for the week. Traders and analysts had mixed feelings about passing the milestone: Some said the rise just reflected short-term factors, such as takeover activity. Others said the increase pointed to strong economic growth; still others saw 1929 in every uptick. But the advance is impressive: It took the market more than 10 years to go from 1,000 to 1,100, but it took less than five months for it to leap from 1,300 to 1,400.

title: STATE SEEKS IDEAS ON PARK SPENDING
description: WITH less money available each year for buying and developing public recreational facilities, the State Department of Environmental Protection is taking steps to make sure it spends its money wisely.

title: STICKING WITH THE STATUS QUO
description: INCUMBENCY proved advantageous to both Democrats and Republicans in New York State last week. As expected, Mayor Koch won a third term overwhelmingly by carrying every Assembly district in New York City.

title: CHILDREN LEARN ABOUT ADOPTION
description: FORMS must be filled out. The prospective parents must be screened. Interviews will be conducted to determine whether they will be suitable.

title: CROSS-COUNTRY TO TOTTENVILLE
description: They traveled nearly the entire length of the city, from the south end of Staten Island to the North Bronx, but for Tottenville High School's cross-country squad, the trip paid off in victory.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: STARGAZING Capitalizing on man's timeless fascination with the sky and the stars is an exhibition organized by the Boston University Art Gallery on loan to the Yale University Art Gallery through Jan. 2.

title: JENNIFER N. RIEGEL ENGAGED TO WED PAUL J. ELMLINGER
description: Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence M. Riegel of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter Jennifer Nelson Riegel to Paul Joseph Elmlinger, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph E. Elmlinger of Greenwich, Conn. A February wedding is planned.

title: PIG TALES
description: MORE TALES OF AMANDA PIG By Jean Van Leeuwen. Illustrated by Ann Schweninger. 56 pp. New York: Dial. $8.95. (Ages 4 to 8) I LIKE Amanda Pig and her big brother Oliver. I like their mother and their father too. In a world - the world, that is, of the Read-It-Yourself books - peopled, or creatured, by rather too many wimps, goody-goods and falsehearted cutie-pies, with cipher parents who exist silently in the background representing order at its most coldblooded, the Pigs are an encouraging bunch. They are pleasingly compact in shape, as low to the ground as Bruegel peasants. They all have extremely cheerful ears which manage to be earthbound yet suggest potential holidayish flight. The younger Pigs are occasionally perfectly dreadful to each other. But remember, they are siblings, and one of the great values of these books is their ability to dramatize the ridiculous and trivial and sickeningly frequent fights that siblings engage in every day of their lives, and yet suggest the siblings' essential fondness for each other, their dependency, their mutual good will.

title: TEMPLE RESTORATION UNCOVERS SURPRISES
description: SERENDIPITY has accompanied the restoration of the Charter Oak Temple in the West End of Hartford.

title: Escape from Obligations Keep the Heat On
description: New York City landlords have a growing incentive not to skimp on heat this winter: the realistic threat of jail.

title: IN LONG BEACH, POLITICS ARE FIERCE AND PERSONAL
description: At Komanoff campaign headquarters the day after the election, the mood was mournful.

title: WORKERS DESERVE AN EARLY WARNING
description: ALL across our nation in the last several years, workers and their communities have been buffeted by recession, increasing numbers of imports, and technological and structural economic change. The pain may be most evident in industries such as autos, steel, shoes and textiles; but it has even hit Silicon Valley as computer chip makers close operations and head for low-wage nations abroad.

title: CHINESE NEWCOMER IN STAMFORD
description: LATEST to join the rush to open a restaurant in the corporate boom town of Stamford is Ching Ching, a Chinese restaurant located downtown in a building with its own underground parking garage. The large dining room, decorated in a beige and brown businesslike motif with well-spaced tables, should handle with ease the lunchtime crowds from nearby office buildings. At dinner, the restaurant seems inexplicably characterless.
