In an attempt, perhaps, to appeal to the corporate diner, the restaurant has minimized its Chineseness without creating a personality to replace it.

title: Celebrating New Jersey
description: Those of us who have lived in New Jersey for years don't need Bruce Springsteen or corporate encroachment to tell us how valuable our state really is.

title: ON THE MENU: CHAMPAGNE, DANCING ANDMANNERS
description: President and Mrs. Reagan invited some of the superstars of film, television, ballet, music, sports, science, the arts and New York society to this evening's White House dinner in honor of the royal superstars, the Prince and Princess of Wales.

title: SOUTH SHORE TOPPLES KENNEDY, 21-20, IN SEMIFINALS
description: Only one Public School Athletic League division champion survived last week's quarterfinal competition. Kennedy, which had allowed just 14 points in its six games, extended its winning streak to 16 games and seemed sure to repeat as city champion.

title: HOPING TO MOVE UP
description: Victor Callejas, the World Boxing Association junior featherweight champion, put a challenger in the hospital with a broken jaw Friday night and said he was ready to do some challenging of his own - by moving up in weight to take on the featherweight champion, Barry McGuigan. ''We want to fight McGuigan and very soon,'' said Callejas's manager, Pepito Cordero, after Callejas knocked out Loris Stecca in the sixth-round of their bout in Stecca's hometown of Rimini, Italy, and raised his record to 21-1-1.

title: MISS PIGGY: QUEEN BY ANY OTHER NAME
description: TUESDAY was Election Day in the Children's Room of the White Plains Library. On that day, the children of White Plains and Westchester selected a name for the successor to Miss Piggy, the lovely auburn and white Grand Dame of the Children's Room, the library guinea pig, who died in the summer.

title: ON THE ART OF TEACHING WRITING
description: ''Teaching the Art of Writing'' highlighted special writing programs in Barrington, Ill. and ended with a kind of lament that similar things are not taking place in New Jersey.

title: THE CONCRETE CANYON RANGERS
description: PARIS, PEE WEE, AND BIG DOG By Rosa Guy. Illustrated by Caroline Binch. 116 pp. New York: Delacorte Press. $13.95. (Ages 8 to 12) STORIES about Kids in the City are often not about kids and the city. In some, the city is only a hard presence implied in the shadows; in others, the children are merely pawns of the nasty, thrilling street-force that becomes the book's best character.

title: THE FUN OF ''IF...THEN'
description: ANNO'S HAT TRICKS By Akihiro Nozaki. Illustrated by Mitsumasa Anno. 44 pp. New York: Philomel Books. $11.95 (Ages 8 and up) IMAGINE that you and a friend named Tom keep your eyes closed while a whimsical hatter puts a red hat on one of you and a white hat on the other. When you open your eyes and see a red hat on Tom, you know that your hat is white.

title: Painting With Camera
description: The National Museum of American Art, one of the lesser-known affiliates of the Smithsonian Institution, often has modest but splendid exhibits.

title: Animation With Stockman
description: Over at the Office of Management and Budget at the White House, the traditional official portrait is being painted, and the subject is David A. Stockman, the former director who resigned to go to Wall Street.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: BORN TOO SOON. By Robert Marion. (Doubleday, $16.95.) This disturbing novel by an M.D. seems more a journalistic expose of the horrors perpetrated in a world-famous neonatal clinic than a work of fiction culled from personal experience.

title: CITY STARTS CROSS-SUBSIDY SALE OF EAST VILLAGE PARCELS
description: DESPITE some fears that redevelopment of city-owned properties in the East Village may force low-income residents out of the reviving neighborhood, the city is moving ahead with its controversial plan to sell off almost 200 vacant parcels to raise money for housing programs there.

title: NOTRE DAME ROUTS MISSISSIPPI BY 37-14
description: Steve Lawrence made an interception to set up one touchdown and returned a popped fumble 79 yards to set up another today as Notre Dame routed Mississippi, 37-14. The victory was the fourth consecutive for the Irish (5-3).

title: NEWEST RESEARCH IDEAS COMING FROM CENTERS
description: AT Johns Hopkins today, and presumably at the nation's other major research universities as well, every interesting idea being advanced cuts across existing disciplines and draws on scholarship from several departments -sometimes, indeed, from several colleges.

title: DEBTORS ANONYMOUS GIVES HOPE TO THOSE WITH 'DISEASE'
description: ''I'M Matt and I'm a compulsive debtor,'' began the speaker, addressing the small group that had gathered to hear him at the United Methodist Church in Armonk recently.

title: NEWS SUMMARY SUNDAY, NOVEMBER 10, 1985
description: International

title:
THE LIVELY ARTS;

AVANT-GARDE AT HOFSTRA
description: HOFSTRA UNIVERSITY has sponsored 36 scholarly conferences since 1976, when it began holding such meetings. But the co-director of the 37th, which will be held this week, thinks this one will be different.

title: ADDABBO EXPECTS TO RETURN TO HOUSE IN JANUARY
description: Representative Joseph P. Addabbo, speaking from his hospital room this week, said he had recovered from a near-fatal illness and would be back at work by January as chairman of the powerful subcommittee on defense appropriations.

title: MARY SUTHERLAND TO MARRY FEB. 1
description: Mary Sutherland and Jeremy H. Silverman plan to be married Feb. 1, her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Charles R. Sutherland of Gates Mills, Ohio, have announced.

title: Embattled Nurse
description: THE headlines called it a mercy killing. According to the police, a nurse at Prince Georges General Hospital in Cheverly, Md., admitted in March that she had given a 70-year-old woman there a lethal dose of potassium to spare the patient ''further pain and suffering.''

title:
FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS;

Space Burials
description: THE first application for a business venture in space won Government approval in February, and the Office of Commercial Space Transportation described it as ''a creative response to the President's initiative to encourage the commercial use of space.'' It called for rocketing cremated human remains into orbit.

title:
MUSIC;

COLLEGE CELEBRATING ITS 20 YEARS OF JAZZ
description: THE 20th anniversary of William Paterson College's jazz program is being celebrated with concerts on and off the campus.

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: BY THE time the Statue of Liberty reaches her 100th birthday next July, an immigrant's unorthodox paintings of The Lady should be ready for the party.

title: Family and Friends
description: ASHARP-WITTED spinster who loves the wrong man and lives on the memory ever after - the predictable Anita Brookner heroine resembles a Victorian maiden who has stepped into the present; she is plucky, but befuddled by the new rules of the sexual game. In four previous novels -notably ''Hotel du Lac,'' winner of last year's Booker Prize, and ''Look at Me,'' a drama of emotional string-pulling - we encounter women whose independence is a mask for stoicism, whose stoicism muffles an impulse to wail ''Poor, lonely me.'' So it is a relief that in ''Family and Friends'' the author has sent her characters back to the past, where most Anita Brookner people might feel more comfortable.

title: LATIN DISKS LOOK BACK AND AHEAD
description: A dozen years ago, Latin N.Y. magazine and Fania Records applied the name ''salsa'' (Spanish for sauce, as in hot sauce) to a sleekly orchestrated, percussive dance music with deep roots in the Afro-Cuban tradition. Although salsa music continues to prosper today in nightclubs and ballrooms throughout the city, there are signs that creative stagnation has set in. Meanwhile, the merengue, long the best-known indigenous rhythm of Hispaniola, has swept to unprecedented popularity in the wake of mass immigration to the United States from the Dominican Republic.

title: YES, VIRGINIA, CD SOUND IS CAPABLE OF IMPROVEMENT
description: Each fortnight or thereabouts we are breathlessly informed of a ''revolutionary'' advance in the science of sound reproduction. My guiding rule for evaluating such developments is simple. If I can't hear the difference, I consider the rumors of revolution as unconfirmed and uncharitably suspect them of having originated with public relations agents rather than engineers. This explains why the current clamor about a ''new generation'' of CD players left me quite calm. But since CD players are at an evolutionary stage where design practice has not yet congealed into predictable routine, I made a point of seeking closer acquaintance with a few members of the new breed - and yes, Virginia, I really could hear a difference.

title: RONALD L. KORN IS WED TO AMY M. CALMENSON
description: At Temple Beth Sholom in Fair Lawn, N.J., last evening Amy Merrill Calmenson, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leo Calmenson of Glen Rock, N.J., and Ronald Lee Korn, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney J. Korn of Denver, were married by Rabbi Ira Rothstein.

title: UNION FINISHES UNBEATEN: FIRST SINCE '49
description: Mike Gargiulo passed for three touchdowns as Union completed its first perfect season since 1949 with a 9-0 record and extended its winning streak at home to 20 by beating Hamilton, 28-7. The halfback Todd Walker scored on a 1-yard plunge at 14 minutes 48 seconds of the first quarter to help provide a 7-0 lead. Gargiulo made it 14-0 on a 49-yard touchdown pass play to Cecil Bright with 3:04 left in the first quarter.

title: A LABOR ACCORD FOR JAVITS CENTER
description: Officials of the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center and representatives of 14 labor unions reached an agreement last week that is likely to make the huge exhibition hall more competitive when it opens next spring. Under the accord, the unions agreed to a no-strike pledge, promised to make more jobs available to women and minorities and modified some often-criticized work rules that have been in effect for years at the New York Coliseum.

title: CONFRONTING THE PAST
description: During the 17 years that he taught Russian at Yale University, Vladimir Sokolov became the school's best language instructor, the department chairman recalls.

title: ALICE DARLINGTON IS ENGAGED
description: The engagement of Alice Bonteccou Darlington to Timothy Griswold Cutler has been announced by Mrs. Fred E. Brown of Harding Township, N.J., and Lake Placid, N.Y., and Peter Darlington of New York and Lake Placid, parents of the future bride. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Hinchman Cutler Jr. of Harding Township.

title: BLUE LAW UP IN AIR
description: THE effort of this Shore community's City Council to enlist, through a nonbinding referendum, citizen approval of a plan to restore modified Sunday blue laws succeeded in last Tuesday's election.

title: SYRACUSE DEFENSE STOPS NAVY, 24-20
description: The defensive back Cooper Gardiner caused the Navy receiver Troy Saunders to fumble and the ball was recovered by David Holmes at the 3-yard line with 2 minutes 18 seconds to play today, allowing Syracuse (5-3) to escape with its third consecutive victory, 24-20.

title: MARCOS TALKS OF AN ELECTION
description: Ferdinand E. Marcos demonstrated last week the kind of political skill that has allowed him to survive as President of the Philippines for 20 years. Under unusually strong United States prodding to face up to the threat of a Communist insurgency by introducing clean, democratic government, Mr. Marcos called for an election Jan. 17 to settle the ''silly'' charge that his Government is inadequate.

title: PATRICIA SETTERBERG MARRIES JOHN BAITY
description: Patricia Bowen Setterberg, a daughter of J. Lynn Bowen of Valley Stream, L.I., and the late Mrs. Bowen, was married yesterday to John Cooley Baity, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. R. Flake Baity of Kenilworth, Ill. The Rev. Don W. Lewis performed the ceremony at St. Edmund's Episcopal Church in San Marino, Calif.

title: NOISE CODE SILENT ON MANY NUISANCES
description: THE first problem in dealing with the noises, smells and other major and minor nuisances of life in New York apartments is determining exactly what a nuisance is. And that is no small task. After all, one man's Mozart might bring on another's migraine, while the sweet scent of sushi might be just the smell of dead fish to those whose noses are not so inclined. And even a common air-conditioner, quiet enough to some ears, can drive other people mad, not with its volume but with its mind-numbing, endless throbbing hum.

title: ECLECTIC 1920's MANSION GOES ON VIEW
description: WHEN Chelsea, a 50-acre estate in Muttontown with a 32-room mansion, was built in 1923-24, it seemed almost a metaphor for the Roaring 20's.

title: THE POLITICS OF BILINGUALISM
description: IT came as a surprise to residents of San Diego when a county grand jury last year recommended that all local school districts eliminate bilingual education, arguing that such programs are ''impractical, expensive and, in a sense, un-American.''

title: C.S.S. ASSESSED
description: TO college students and their parents, the phrase Financial Aid Form conjures up images of hours spent pouring forth their financial souls onto a document nearly legendary for its complexity. That form, called the F.A.F. for short, is the master key that can unlock the doors to many kinds of financial aid, from Federal Pell Grants to private university-aid programs. It is also the source of continuing controversy among parents who not only charge that its formulas are inequitable but also turn to commercial or other advisers in an effort to outwit the formulas and thus get more financial aid.

title: TREATING A DISEASE
description: THE Carlstadt-East Rutherford Regional High School District operates only one rather small institution, the Henry P. Becton Regional High School, which until recently went about its business quietly in suburban Bergen County, N. J., just seven miles west of Manhattan. But in August, members of the board of education, concerned about student alcohol and drug abuse, took an extraordinary step, voting to require all of the school's 500 students to take blood and urine tests, which, among other things, would be used to detect drug use and alcohol abuse. Under the new policy, believed to be the first of its kind in the country, the physical exam would be mandatory, and any student who refused to undergo one would be excluded from school. The results of the tests would be confidential and would not be turned over to the police, school officials said.

title: Making Contact
description: MY WIFE NOTICED it while we were walking in Florence in May. ''You don't see men holding hands in Italy anymore,'' she said.

title: TURNPIKE TOKENS BEING REDEEMED
description: THE cessation of tolls on the Connecticut Turnpike is costing Connecticut millions of dollars in expenses that range from the redemption of an outstanding 10 million tokens to overtime for state police patroling the areas where the tollbooths are coming down.

title:
DINING OUT;

JAPANESE RESTAURANT IS ENLARGED
description: AS winter settles in and diners become reluctant to travel from their immediate neighborhoods to sample the ultimate in any cuisine, those living in the southeast corner of the county and wishing to savor such familiar Japanese dishes as beef teriyaki and negimaki have the newly expanded sushi bar and dining rooms of Marimo nearby. Although the menu offers few surprises and several dishes are perfunctorily made, on the whole the food is acceptable. On one recent chilly evening, however, we found ourselves wishing that there were nabemono (casseroles) more interesting than sukiyaki to choose from.

title: DOBBS FERRY EASY VICTOR
description: Kevin Costello ran for 89 yards and scored four touchdowns in the first half to lead Dobbs Ferry to a 48-0 romp over neighborhood rival Hastings before 4,000 fans yesterday. The victory extended Dobbs Ferry's winning streak to 36 games and set up next week's match against undefeated Bronxville for the league championship.

title: JERSEY TO RAISE TOLLS ON TURNPIKE TO HELP PAY FOR ITS WIDENING
description: Motorists can expect to pay up to 40 percent more to use the New Jersey Turnpike starting next summer as part of a plan to finance a $2 billion widening project, according to the Turnpike Authority.

title: OFFICER IS AWARDED BACK PAY
description: A New York City police officer who was discharged for posing nude for a magazine and was then reinstated by a court has been awarded $80,000 in back pay, interest and medical expenses for the nearly three years she was off the job. The award to the officer, Cibella Borges, was made Friday by Justice George Bundy Smith of State Supreme Court in Manhattan. She was suspended in July 1982, discharged 10 months later and reinstated last April.

title: AN INVASION OF PRIVACY
description: THE Carlstadt-East Rutherford Regional High School District operates only one rather small institution, the Henry P. Becton Regional High School, which until recently went about its business quietly in suburban Bergen County, N. J., just seven miles west of Manhattan. But in August, members of the board of education, concerned about student alcohol and drug abuse, took an extraordinary step, voting to require all of the school's 500 students to take blood and urine tests, which, among other things, would be used to detect drug use and alcohol abuse. Under the new policy, believed to be the first of its kind in the country, the physical exam would be mandatory, and any student who refused to undergo one would be excluded from school. The results of the tests would be confidential and would not be turned over to the police, school officials said.

title: HOW SPIES AVERT WARS
description: A WORLD OF SECRETS The Uses and Limits of Intelligence. By Walter Laqueur. 404 pp. New York: Basic Books. $21.95.

title: WESTERN GEAR SOLD IN A BIG, TEXAN WAY
description: For the greenhorn Eastern tourist searching for a wide selection of the best in Western wear or a uniquely Texan gewgaw to carry home, the D & D Farm and Ranch store outside San Antonio is sort of a Texas version of L. L. Bean. With the considerable pride for which the state is known, the store's owners brag of carrying just about anything Western.

title: EFFORTS TO HONOR VIETNAM VETERANS SPREADING
description: The wall at the Vietnam Veterans Memorial here was washed this morning, in an act of caring and a ritual performed by a dozen volunteers who rose at dawn.

title:
WHAT'S NEW IN EDUCATIONAL TOYS;

MAKING SAFETY A WINNING PROPOSITION
description: ''SAFELY HOME,'' the Pressman Toy Corporation's new game, looks like many other children's games. There is a colorful board that maps a circuitous route from starting point (school) to finish (home). Among the various accessories are small cardboard figures, a spinning arrow on a dial and a stack of 50 question cards.

title: PRETORIA CURBS ITS CRITICS FURTHER
description: South Africa tightened restrictions on its critics last week. It prevented a leading dissident from traveling to the United States, forced a delegation of South African churchmen to cancel a meeting with officials of the outlawed African National Congress, and brought charges against a white newspaper editor for publishing an interview with Oliver Tambo, a leader of the congress.

title: SOVIET PRESS TELLS OF AIDS OVERSEAS
description: After long maintaining silence about AIDS, the Soviet press in recent months has taken to reporting on the disease, though insisting that no cases have occurred in the Soviet Union.

title: CONSERVATIONISTS BUY SCENIC PEAK IN VERMONT
description: The Nature Conservancy has bought the summit of Mount Hunger, the highest point along the undeveloped Worcester Range, and several hundred acres below the peak.

title: SHOULD DOTORS BE GIVEN A MORE THOROUGH EXAMINATION?
description: In Virginia last year, the state medical board forced an obstetrician to give up his license after an investigation found that for two decades he had shown ''gross negligence'' and incompetence in treating numerous patients. In one case, the doctor accidentally blocked a woman's urinary tract during a hysterectomy; five days later, she died because urine had backed up in her body. In another case, according to a malpractice suit, the doctor induced labor two weeks early because he wanted to go on vacation, then tried to pull the baby from the patient's womb with forceps, smashing his head. The child was seriously deformed.

title: LEAHY ON LIE-DETECTOR TESTS
description: Senator Patrick J. Leahy, Democrat of Vermont, says he would have ''no problem'' with putting key senators and aides through lie-detector tests to find out who was disclosing national security information to the public.

title: WOMEN POETS SHARE CHORES AT ALICE JAMES BOOKS
description: They count among themselves Fulbright and Bunting Institute scholars, winners of the Pushcart Prize, the Poetry Society of America Prize, the Discovery Award from the 92d St. Y in New York and prizes from 12 states.

title: Celebrating New Jersey
description: Like Randall Rothenberg, I am proud to be a New Jerseyan (''Here Comes New Jersey!'' Oct. 6).

title: MARION MARKHAM ENGAGED TO LAWYER
description: The engagement of Marion Hiscox Markham to Randolph George Abood has been announced by the future bride's mother, Susan Moore Kirkpatrick of Providence and Watch Hill, R.I.

title: UNUSUAL LEGAL MOVE FREED RUBIN CARTER, LAWYERS SAY
description: Defense lawyers said yesterday that they had gambled on an unorthodox legal strategy to win a reversal in Federal court last week of the triple-murder conviction of Rubin (Hurricane) Carter.

title: WILLIE MAYS SCORES HIT WITH THE YOUNG
description: ABOUT five years ago, when Willie Mays began to represent Bally's Park Place Hotel-Casino here, the establishment got dozens of telephone calls each week from young people asking the former baseball star for help. Many asked for financial aid to pay their college tuition and to buy books and clothes.

title: TAX REVISION'S CHAMPIONS BATTLE OVER COMPROMISE
description: Though the House Ways and Means Committee has not yet decided the tougher political questions involved in tax revision - including the deductibility of state and local taxes and the treatment of fringe benefits - Dan Rostenkowski, the committee chairman, pledged last week that his panel would finish its work by Thanksgiving. He also characterized not only the process but the outcome. ''Compromise is the price of reform,'' he said in a speech delivered on consecutive days in Chicago and Washington. ''Like it or not, tax reform ends up a series of compromises.''

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption with a review of ''Bauhaus Photography'' Sept. 22 was incorrect. The picture, taken in 1930 by Walter Peterhans, was of Andor Weininger.

title: U.S. TO RULE ON KEY SHOREHAM DRILL
description: THE Federal Nuclear Regulatory Commission is expected to decide this week whether to authorize an emergency preparedness drill for the Shoreham nuclear power plant. Such a drill could simulate the participation of state and county officials.

title: When a Switch in Time Saved Nine
description: To the Editor:

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LIVING WITH SNAKES. By Daniel Curley. (University of Georgia, $13.95.) ''That Marriage Bed of Procrustes'' was the title of one of Daniel Curley's earlier books.

title: VALLEY OF ANCIENT GODS
description: When Hernando Cortes, the great conquistador, reached Oaxaca in southern Mexico in 1521, he saw a lush tropical valley, bright with jacarandas and bougainvillea, narrowly enclosed by majestic, ocher-colored mountains; and it all looked so pleasing to him that the Emperor Charles V, who knew how to take a hint, made him Marques del Valle de Oaxaca in 1528.

title: RANGERS DEFEATED BY NORTH STARS, 4-3
description: Scott Bjugstad's first thought was to do what hockey players do when nothing else seems worth doing. That's the boring thing: flicking the puck into the corner.

title: POLICE CHIEF' S RULE ON CHURCH STIRS NEW HAMPSHIRE DISPUTE
description: A police officer whose Chief has barred him from attending church while on lunch break is protesting the decision in a complaint to the state's Public Employee Labor Relations Board.

title: The 'Zionism-Racism' Canard
description: Ten years ago today, the United Nations General Assembly, in one of its mindless flights from rational discourse, adopted the infamous canard that ''Zionism is a form of racism.'' Attacks on Israel and on Zionism have consumed more time and attention of the United Nations and its various bodies than any other subject - more time than the problems of world hunger, poverty, genocide, human rights violations, the threat of nuclear war, terrorism or the fight against disease and social disorder.

title: Pennsylvania to Put Limits On 'Happy Hour' at Taverns
description: Regulations to limit ''happy hour'' promotions have been approved by the Liquor Control Board, a move applauded by both tavern owners and a group fighting drunken driving.

title: JUDGE FRITZ ALEXANDER 2D TO MARRY BEVERLY TELPHY
description: Beverly Jane Telphy, a law enforcement official in the office of the Bronx District Attorney, and Judge Fritz Winfred Alexander 2d of the State Court of Appeals plan to be married in February.

title: ARKANSAS OVERCOMES BAYLOR
description: Greg Thomas's first pass completion of the game went 50 yards for a fourth-quarter touchdown that lifted Arkansas to a 20-14 victory over Baylor today and scrambled the Southwest Conference race.

title: KOCH CALLS FOR TAX INVESTIGATION OF UNDERGROUND ECONOMY
description: Mayor Koch proposed yesterday that state and Federal tax agencies join the city in creating a task force to look into ways of collecting taxes from businesses and individuals that do not report their earnings.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: AMORY ON ANIMAL RIGHTS Cleveland Amory, the writer who is a friend of animals and a foe of hunters, will speak Tuesday at a noon luncheon at the Newark Museum.

title: Celebrating New Jersey
description: New Jersey, once regarded as a ''cultural wasteland,'' now ranks fifth in total spending on cultural activity. Responsible for this is Governor Kean, who regards the arts not as ''frills'' but as essential ingredients for a healthy economy and a high quality of life. Since taking office in 1982, Governor Kean has increased public financing for the arts by 300 percent. ALVIN S. FELZENBERG Assistant Secretary of State Of New Jersey Trenton

title: HIGH-TECHNOLOGY LAYOFFS SPUR FEAR IN CALIFORNIA
description: Something unexpected has happened in the community of high-technology industries known, and envied, the world around as ''Silicon Valley.'' People are starting to ask: Did we stake too much of our future on this?

title: SUFFOLK CHIEF SAYS SHOREHAM PROJECT IS DEAD
description: The Suffolk County Executive says there appears to be no chance that the newly elected County Legislature will approve local participation in an emergency preparedness drill for the Shoreham nuclear power plant. The current legislature has opposed county participation since taking office two years ago.

title: NEWARK MUSEUM: RELEASING THE FORMS IN BEAMS OF OAK
description: ED VISSER works in wood.

title: HALFWAY HOUSE IN STUDENT HIRING
description: LAST YEAR James Barnhart, a senior at Oberlin College in Ohio, decided to take a year off because he was tired of school and wanted to get some work experience that would help him select a career. To sort out whether to enter publishing, college teaching or museum work, he took a temporary job that included elements of all three careers, as a tour guide and editorial assistant at the South Street Seaport Museum in New York City. The job was arranged through Venture, a counseling and job-placement program sponsored by a consortium including Oberlin and nine other colleges and universities in the Middle West and Northeast.

title: A Grain Grows In Philadelphia
description: TWO HUNDRED years ago, when cows grazed in fields now paved over with asphalt and crops flourished where row houses stand today, 23 farmers and merchants formed the Philadelphia Society for Promoting Agriculture. They were indeed promoters: Four signers of the Declaration of Independence were among the founders. George Washington and Benjamin Franklin soon joined. And they set out to spread the news of agricultural advances throughout the United States.

title: U.S. TIGHTENING RULES TO PROTECT SECRET DATA
description: The Reagan Administration has begun putting in place a program intended to thwart Soviet intelligence operations in the United States, senior White House officials said.

title: ELIZABETH D. LANNIK PLANS TO WED HOWARD J. DYMM
description: Dr. and Mrs. Milton M. Gardner of Old Westbury and Water Mill, L.I., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Gardner's daughter Elizabeth Dore Lannik, to Howard J. Dymm, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Mandel Dymm of Westbury, L.I.

title: TOKEN REDEMPTION ADDING TO THE COST OF ENDING TOLLS
description: THE cessation of tolls on the Connecticut Turnpike is costing the state millions of dollars in expenses that range from the redemption of an outstanding 10 million tokens to overtime for state police patrolling the areas where the tollbooths are coming down.

title: Helen Mahoney Engaged to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Daniel J. Mahoney of Palm Beach, Fla., and Stanley, Idaho, have announced the engagement of their daughter Helen Stephenson Mahoney to Edward Devon Pardoe 3d, the son of Mrs. Michael W. Bristol of Carversville, Pa., and Mr. Pardoe Jr. of Fort Washington, Pa., and Bay Head, N.J.

title: UNESCO PARLEY A DISAPPOINTMENT FOR BRITAIN
description: Britain expressed disappointment today with some of the results of Unesco's 23d General Conference as the five-week meeting of the organization's 154 member countries drew to a close.

title: MISS CLEVEL HAS A COLD
description: MADELINE'S CHRISTMAS Written and illustrated by Ludwig Bemelmans. Unpaged. New York: Viking Kestrel. $12.95. (Ages 3 to 8) AH! MADELINE! How is it that the name of such a little girl can conjure up for so many Americans our first sweet memories of Paris.

title: JUTTA PERBIX TO BE BRIDE
description: Announement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Gottfried W. Perbix of Westport, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter Jutta Dorothea Perbix to James Llewellyn Gibbons, a son of Sir David Gibbons, former Premier of Bermuda, and Lady Gibbons of Pembroke, Bermuda. A May wedding is planned.

title: LIEUT. MEAGHEN E. FLANAGAN TO MARRY CAPT.GILBERT LEIDIG JR.,ARMY DOCTOR
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edward L. Farrell of Highland Falls, N.Y., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Farrell's daughter Lieut. Meaghen Elizabeth Flanagan, Army Nurse Corps, to Capt. Gilbert Andrew Leidig Jr., Army Medical Corps.

title: NEW PAPER GEARED TO CASINO WORKER
description: A FLEDGLING monthly newspaper for casino employees that is owned, published and edited by a casino dealer here has linked forces with an organization of casino workers.

title: FESTIVE FARE
description: IN THAT VAST storehouse of recipes that emerge from my typewriter, there are a few - very few -that recur in the memory with special precision and appeal.

title: CORPORCRACY
description: To the Editor:

title: BARBRA STREISAND: 'THIS IS THE MUSIC I LOVE. IT IS MY ROOTS'
description: Barbra Streisand, a singer whose recent attempts to keep up with pop music's changing trends have been artistically shaky, has just released what may be the album of a lifetime. ''Barbra Streisand - The Broadway Album'' contains 15 classic songs spanning more than half a century of musical theater, from ''Showboat'' to ''Sunday in the Park With George.'' Most were recorded with an old-time studio orchestra. ''The Broadway Album'' soars with full-bodied, tender bel canto renditions of ballads by Stephen Sondheim, Rodgers and Hammerstein, Jerome Kern, and a ''Porgy and Bess'' medley that stand among the most thrilling performances of her 23-year recording career.

title: COUNSELING CENTER GUIDES FAMILIES OF THE VERY ILL
description: WHEN the man was diagnosed with acquired immune deficiency syndrome last year, he and his wife sought help from the Center for Illness in Families in New Haven. His physical needs were cared for by his physician, but the couple's emotional needs were basically neglected, and that is where the center stepped in.

title: They Could Even Go Sailing Together in Geneva
description: To the Editor:

title: SHOREHAM PLANT AND STORMM CLEANUP
description: Your article ''Lilco Takes Center Stage in Elections'' [Oct. 27] prompts a question. Does anyone out there want to join me in saying a kind word for the besieged utility?

title: TWO SHOWS ARE MERGED WITH LITTLE IN COMMON
description: ORIGINALLY, there were to be two shows at the Thorpe Intermedia Gallery - one of Neo-Expressionism, the other of its antithesis, Geometric Abstraction. But thanks to an inspiration on the part of Adele Myers, the director of this Sparkill gallery, the guest curators merged their respective efforts, calling the result ''This Way/ This Way'' (through Dec. 8).

title: TOPICS
description: IT'S an ill wind that blows no good. There I was with a letter to write and no paper, thanks to Hurricane Gloria. Some people still write letters by hand, but to me pens were something to sign letters with; the sentences and paragraphs came when I turned on my I.B.M. electric typewriter. Powerless! What an awful feeling! I took pen in hand, wrote the heading and then Dear Sir - in my large, naive-looking script, just right for a letter to Santa Claus. Then I remembered the old Remington typewriter in the attic.

title: PILLASTER TRIUMPHS IN PILGRIM STAKES
description: Pillaster, a 2-year-old whose record and pedigree suggested his future was strictly on the grass, rallied and then drew off to win the $89,550 Pilgrim Stakes for 2-year-olds yesterday at Aqueduct Race Track.

title: ABOUT MEDICAL MALPRACTICE SUITS
description: IN New York City, doctors struck. Elsewhere, they are mounting quieter forms of protest. Across the nation, physicians are fearful of a growing medical malpractice affordability problem.

title: Civil Rights Enforcement With Blunted Bayonets
description: ''My belief has always been . . . that wherever in this land any individual's constitutional rights are being unjustly denied, it is the obligation of the Federal Government - at point of bayonet if necessary - to restore that individual's constitutional rights.'' So said President Reagan in May 1983. For all of that eloquence, the Reagan record on civil rights enforcement is dismal, and nothing so drastic as bayonets is needed to make it better.

title: OREGON TEACHERS TOLD TO SHUN FEDERAL SURVEY
description: An Oregon school administrator has told local teachers not to respond to a federally financed survey that asked whether they prayed and how often they had sexual relations.

title: DOLL MAKER CREATES CAST OF CHARACTERS
description: AS the legend of the black stick sisters goes, one sister, a free spirit, released a molting buffalo from a nature center and took it out West to be free. The other, more conservative sister, motivated by responsibility and family propriety spent her life trying to find her recalcitrant sister.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''People pay attention to the round numbers. It's just a tradition, like New Year's Eve.''

title: SNAPSHOTS OF LOST INNOCENCE
description: FAMILY AND FRIENDS By Anita Brookner. 187 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $13.95.

title: TRUSTING BACKUP COPIES TO TAPE
description: IT was years ago, quite early in my involvement with personal computing, that I first came across the concept of backups, the process of making copies of everything entered into or manipulated on a computer. Since I had only recently acccustomed myself to converting the final drafts of my articles into computerized form, I did not give the concept much thought. With a regular stream of weekly articles to turn out, I simply filed their printouts with the tear sheets from the newspapers and periodicals in which they subsequently appeared and forgot them.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: THE LAKE VANISHES THERE'S only one major attraction at Belmont Lake State Park in West Babylon - the lake itself. But right now the park has no major attraction - because right now there is no Belmont Lake.

title:
WHAT'S NEW IN EDUCATIONAL TOYS;

A POST-SPUTNIK SCIENCE REVIVAL
description: TIME was when children thought that building a radio from a kit or staring at the stars through a telescope was the height of fun. But in the last two decades, interest in science toys waned badly. ''Things like computers and video games pretty much blitzed it,'' said Pete Fox, sales manager at Tedco Inc., a maker of toy gyroscopes and prisms.

title: SOCIETY SALUTES ITS ARCHITECTS
description: THE Hillier Group is waving the house flag these days, and for good reason. Earlier this fall, it won two awards presented by the New Jersey Society of Architects at its annual convention in Atlantic City, and earlier this month Steelcase Inc. of Grand Rapids, Mich., a manufacturer of office furniture, approved a design plan by Hillier for a showroom in the International Design Center in Long Island City, Queens.

title: HOW TO LEARN FROM MISTAKES
description: TO become good at photography, one must sometimes learn by taking bad pictures. By studying and correcting the mistakes made, a photographer teaches himself. Almost every professional knows that trial and error is the best school and the only real teacher in the medium.

title: FUR IS BETTER ON THE REAL OWNER
description: THE season has just about started again, as I can tell by the thickness of the catalogues in my mailbox. The Sunday papers are so heavy now that they could double as barbells.

title: A CASTLE FIT FOR MEDIEVAL QUEENS
description: The most fantastic castle in the world is Neuschwanstein, built by Ludwig II, known as the mad Bavarian king.

title: BANKRUPTCY IS DECLARED IN MINNEWASKA CASE
description: LAKE MINNEWASKA MOUNTAIN HOUSE, which controls a 1,200-acre tract in the Shawangunk Mountains near New Paltz next to a New York State nature preserve over which environmentalists and developers have been at odds for years, has been placed into bankruptcy with a trustee appointed to liquidate its assets and pay off creditors.

title: IT CAN BE FUN TO RAISE BANANAS AT HOME
description: Few house plants are as showy or rewarding as the dwarf banana. Even when young, it has flamboyant, ambitiously large leaves. The indoor gardener need never wonder about the banana's state of health. When quantities of water and fertilizer fail to satisfy the plant's appetite, it abruptly stops unfolding new leaves. Once fed and watered, the banana responds just as dramatically.

title: FRANCE APPROVES AN INCREASE IN MILITARY SPENDING
description: The French Parliament early today adopted a military budget for next year providing for a 5.4 percent rise in spending and a modernization of France's nuclear force.

title: DINNER AT THE WHITE HOUSE: LIST OF GUESTS
description: Following are the guests invited by President Reagan and his wife, Nancy, to the White House dinner Saturday night: The Prince and Princess of Wales. Sir Oliver Wright, British Ambassador to the United States, and Lady Wright. Sir John Riddell, private secretary to the Prince. Michael Shea, press secretary to the Prince. David Roycroft, assistant private secretary to the Prince. Anne Beckwith-Smith, lady in waiting to the Princess. Lieut. Comdr. Peter Eberle, equerry to the Prince.

title: FOR TORAH, COMMUNITY AND REBBE
description: HOLY DAYS The World of a Hasidic Family. By Lis Harris. 266 pp. New York: Summit Books. $16.95.

title: SOLVING THE EZRAGRAMS: POUND AT 100
description: AS we commemorate the 100th anniversary of Ezra Pound's birth (Oct. 30) we think immediately of his ''Cantos,'' written between 1919 and 1961 - 117 of them in nearly 800 pages. Technically they are his most innovative writing and in content they are the most extraordinary. The short poems of Pound's ''Personae'' collection will probably always be his most popular work because they are accessible. His English versions of Chinese, Japanese, Latin and Provencal poetry and plays are among the finest translations made in this century. And his literary essays and such books of criticism as the ''A B C of Reading,''

title: CAN THE ERIE CANAL GENERATE BOTH POWER AND TOURISM?
description: Attired in the tails and bow tie required for important ceremonies 160 years ago, Gov. DeWitt Clinton in 1825 celebrated the opening of his pet project, the Erie Canal, by pouring two barrels of Lake Erie water into New York Harbor. With a little less pomp, officials from Albany's Department of Transportation re-enacted the ''Marriage of the Waters'' last week, not only to mark the anniversary but also to celebrate the future of the waterway once disparaged as ''Clinton's big ditch.''

title: STRUCTURE FISHING AND IT LOSES ITS LURE
description: I loved nothing better in those days than the fierce games of half-court basketball with George, Stanley, Ira, Herb and Natey at Wingate Field in Brooklyn.

title: THE BRITISH HAVE LANDED AND WASHINGTON IS TAKEN
description: The Prince and Princess of Wales arrived here today in a burst of Anglo-American amity and personal celebrity, beaming politely as they began a three-day visit of social, commercial and esthetic tasks.

title: NEW BUREAU CHIEF
description: For the fifth time in 10 years, there has been a change in command at the state office responsible for approving cooperative and condominium plans. The move involved replacing James M. Morrissey, the assistant attorney general in charge of the Real Estate Financing Bureau, with Frederick K. Mehlman.

title: ODD ADMISSIONS QUESTIONS
description: VENTURING into the halls of a freshman dormitory last fall, Jean H. Fetter, the new dean of admissions at Stanford University, began amiably introducing herself to incoming students. At one point, a young man broke through the polite banter and fired a question at her. ''Dean Fetter,'' he said, ''which single adjective do you think would be most frequently used to describe you by those who know you best? Briefly explain.''

title: DOLPHINS ACTIVATE DUPER
description: Mark Duper, whose absence has dramatically altered the Dolphins' offense, was activated today and is expected to rejoin Dan Marino when the Dolphins face the Jets Sunday. Duper had been out since the second game of the regular season with a hairline fracture of the left leg.

title: STEREO SOLD IN CANADA LINKED TO TOKYO AIRPORT BLAST
description: The police said today that the bomb that exploded at Narita International Airport in Tokyo in June was contained inside a stereo component bought at a store in Duncan, a town on Vancouver Island.

title: VARIED PARTIES AND CAUSES
description: Movie and Party Nov. 11 - The 6 P.M. movie premiere at the Waverly Theater, Avenue of the Americas at Third Street, of ''Gringo,'' the story of a Lower East Side drug addict, will benefit Daytop Village, the 22-year-old organization that helps young people break drug habits. Afterward, there will be a party at Area, 157 Hudson Street. Tickets, $100, from 212-354-6000, extension 228. Years in the Cafes Nov. 12 - From Courbet to Picasso, from Realism to Cubism, from Napolean III to the outbreak of World War I (1852-1914), the role of the Parisian cafes in the art of the era will be the theme of a 60-painting exhibit at the Wildenstein & Company gallery, 19 East 64th Street. A black-tie Champagne preview of the exhibition will be held at the gallery from 9 P.M. to midnight to benefit the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. The show runs from Wednesday until Dec. 20, Monday through Friday, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Admission is $2, $1 for students and senior citizens. Preview tickets, $50, from 212-794-7972. Futuristic Evening Nov. 13 - The Museum of Holography, showcase of three-dimensional images, will have a benefit at the Crystal Pavillion, Third Avenue at 50th Street, from 8 P.M. to 1 A.M. featuring a cocktail buffet, dancing, laser theatrics and holographic exhibit. Dress is futuristic costume. Tickets, $40, from 212-925-0577, or $45 at door. Briefly: Nov. 13 - The Eye-Bank for Sight Restoration benefit starts at noon at the Pierre followed by lunch and an award for Paul F. Oreffice, president of the Dow Chemical Company.

title: THE STUMP BELONGS TO ALL
description: ONCE THERE WAS A TREE By Natalia Romanova. Illustrated by Gennady Spirin. Adapted by Anne Schwartz. 24 pp. New York: Dial Books. $10.95. (Ages 5 and up) SOVIET children's book illustration has lately enjoyed a degree of international recognition unsurpassed except during the heady Constructivist 1920's. In recent years Soviet artists have won the two most coveted honors open to illustrators worldwide, the Bratislava Biennale's Grand Prix and the Hans Christian Andersen Medal (sometimes called the ''Little Nobel Prize''). Gennady Spirin, a painter now in his mid-30's, is among the Russians to have brought home a Bratislava ''Golden Apple,'' or second prize. Yet scant news or evidence of his or his colleagues' accomplishments has so far reached the United States. The appearance here of ''Once There Was a Tree'' - first published in Moscow in 1983 and subsequently in West German and Greek editions - is therefore an event of considerable interest.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: FOLLOWING THROUGH. By Herbert Warren Wind. (Ticknor & Fields, $20.) Herbert Warren Wind thinks Bernard Darwin (1876-1961), the grandson of the great evolutionist, was the best golf writer ever. Maybe.

title: Private Investor's Guide to Third-World Loans
description: To the Editor:

title: CAPE TOWN BANS CONFERENCE
description: The Cape Town authorities today forbade the Univerity of Cape Town from holding a conference next week to discuss the United Democratic Front, South Africa's largest anti-apartheid organization.

title: EXPLORING THE OUTER REACHES OF ARTIFICIAL INTELLEGENCE
description: IN 1893, Ambrose Bierce published a story about a mechanical chess-playing machine, ''Moxon's Master,'' which opens with the question, ''Are you serious? Do you really believe a machine thinks?''

title: OPERA
description: While the Metropolitan and New York City Operas go about their daily business, two American operas in more modest productions give this week a special interest. One is ''The Crucible'' by Robert Ward presented by the Opera Ensemble of New York; the other - Aaron Copland's play/ opera ''The Second Hurricane'' in a production by the New Federal Theater.

title: AFTER THE STORM: DOCUMENTING DEDUCTIONS
description: IF you are one of the thousands of people along the Eastern Seaboard who sustained damage from the stormy remnant of Hurricane Juan last week or Hurricane Gloria earlier this fall, you may at least reap a tax benefit from your bad luck. An owner who suffers damage from a sudden catastrophe can claim a casualty loss deduction on Schedule A of his tax return for the decline in the value of his property.

title: CHESAPEAKE FISHERMAN SEE HOPE IN CLEANUP BILL
description: Gale winds whipped the Chesapeake Bay into such a fury this week that several wood sailing ships, called skipjacks, that were harvesting oysters could not make it back to their home port and anchored in a nearby cove for the night.

title: U.S.-SOVIET TALKS DROP COMMUNIQUE
description: A senior White House official said today that a communique would not be issued at the conclusion of the Soviet-American summit meeting in Geneva on Nov. 19 and 20.

title: THE VIEW FROM RUSSIA
description: RUSSIANS OFTEN SEEM TO think of America in terms of opposites. There are greedy millionaires and the penniless homeless. There are the whites who have cars, personal computers and suburban homes, and there are the oppressed blacks. There are the militaristic and callous ruling circles led by President Reagan and ''the monopolies,'' and there are the good, industrious American people. America is a land of plenty and a land of violence, a land of extreme wealth and abject poverty.

title: LONG NAVY BATTLE ENDS WITH A LONGER TITLE
description: The Navy, not satisfied with the venerable rank of ''commodore'' or the imprecise title of ''rear admiral,'' has invented an unlikely sounding new rank with the privileges of both: rear admiral lower half.

title: A New Venture for The Workbench
description: The Workbench, a company based in Manhattan that for 30 years has designed and sold a line of modern furniture that appeals largely to apartment-dwellers and people furnishing second homes, has expanded into home-building. It is developing six houses in Litchfield County, Conn., that are suitable for use as country retreats.

title: POP/IN THE CLUBS
description: Martha Raye, self-advertised as ''Big Mouth,'' may be most widely recognized today for her television commercials for Polident Tooth Paste. But behind that sales pitch lies a long and varied show business career that has recently included touring in ''Four Girls Four'' with Kay Starr, Helen O'Connell and Rosemary Clooney and in the musical ''Annie'' as well as several years in the TV series, ''Alice.'' She has made more than three dozen movies, had her own televison series and appeared on Broadway in ''Hello, Dolly!'' and ''No, No, Nannette.''

title: CORRECTION
description: The Practical Traveler column on Sept. 29 incorrectly described the seat-assignment procedure for flights of British Airways. The airline permits passengers to select seats in all classes of service on all long-haul intercontinental flights as far as a year in advance of departure.

title: NORTHEAST SKIERS
description: An event that aims to tell you everything you want to know about skiing in the Northeast is scheduled Nov. 22 at 7:30 P.M. at the Wayne Manor on Route 23 in Wayne, N.J.

title: FEMINISTS IN SPAIN STAGE ABORTIONS
description: Nearly 3,000 feminists gathered at a national convention in Barcelona last weekend and voted to do something ''decisively courageous'' to protest what they said were inadequacies in Spain's new abortion law.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN EDUCATIONAL TOYS
description: FISHER-PRICE'S Dancing Animals Music Box Mobile features four soft vinyl animals meant to be suspended over a baby's crib. Each animal is tilted in such a way as to give the child a full view of its form and, presumably, greater stimulation. And because of that simple design change, toy stores are billing the Fisher-Price mobile as an educational toy.

title:
GARDENING;

FERNS ADD TOUCH OF GREENERY TO INDOORS
description: THOSE of us who have been around for a half-century or more may remember the bay window where our grandmother or mother kept a giant Boston fern in a wicker plant stand. There was something elegant about this combination. It was several notches above the level of growing a common geranium on the windowsill. And when guests came for Sunday dinner, they would admire this evidence of the hostess's green thumb.

title: NEW CASSETEES: TRUFFAUT, BIZET AND JOHN BLEUSHI
description: Bizet's 'Carmen' Starring Julia Migenes-Johnson, Placido Domingo, Ruggero Raimondi, Faith Esham; Lorin Maazel conducts the Orchestra National de France; directed by Francesco Rosi, 1984 RCA/Columbia Pictures Home Video 151 minutes. $79.95 This is a video version of the popular film shot on Spanish locations that often look more like an overlighted Verona Arena than Seville; there is something inherently disconcerting when the indoor conventions of opera get wrenched into the glaring sun, with pitiless close-ups of the mechanics of singing.

title: ESSEX IS CALLED A 'TEST RUN'
description: THE state's Commissioner of Health, Dr. J. Richard Goldstein, views Essex County as a ''test run'' for state and regional health planning.

title: CONSTRUCTION PERSISTS AS JOBS SLUMP
description: NEW construction of manufacturing space is persisting at a modest rate in the city, despite a long-term decline in manufacturing employment. Most of it is being done with city or state assistance by companies that use the space themselves, but a trickle has begun to appear on a speculative basis.

title:
ART;

THE ORDINARY MADE INTO THE UNUSUAL
description: MANY people consider art a luxury. But to others, it is, along with food, clothing and shelter, one of life's necessities. It should hardly be surprising, then, that many artists find in such fundamental concerns the raw material of their work.

title:
MUSIC;

RUTGERS TO PRESENT 4 OPERAS
description: THE music department of Rutgers University's Mason Gross School of the Arts will present the Rutgers Opera Theater in workshop productions of four short American operas next Sunday.

title:
CHILDREN'S BOOKS;

THE SLEIGH BELL RINGS
description: THE POLAR EXPRESS Written and illustrated by Chris Van Allsburg. Unpaged. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $15.95. (Ages 4 and up) A FEW years ago, the young sculptor Chris Van Allsburg decided to go outside his field and write a book. More accurately, he decided to draw a children's book and write a suitable accompanying text. The result was ''The Garden of Abdul Gasazi,'' quickly hailed as one of the best children's books of 1979. The simple story is nicely told; the illustrations are stunning. The book won two awards and was on three lists of notable books.

title: TRENTON LIKELY TO TRY AGAIN FOR CHANGES IN AUTO INSURANCE
description: GOVERNOR KEAN'S record-setting victory and the capture of the Assembly by Republicans in last Tuesday's election set the stage for a new attempt to lower the state's automobile-insurance rates in the coming two-year legislative session.

title: SUCCESS IN NEW YORK
description: WHEN Rafael Rodriguez entered the third grade after arriving here from Puerto Rico in 1982, he had almost no ability in speaking, reading or writing in English. But in three years, Rafael has made steady progress. Currently in the sixth grade, he is conversationally fluent and reads less than a year below grade level. Although still making ''lots of errors in spelling,'' he says learning English ''has not been so hard.''

title: ANTI-IMMIGRANT GROUP ON THE RISE IN GENEVA
description: The recent electoral success in Geneva of a rightist party that opposes any further entry of refugees has set off a wave of national soul-searching over this country's traditional role as a haven for those seeking asylum.

title: THREE PIANISTS AND TWO VIOLINISTS IN RECITALS
description: Georg Friedrich Schenck The pianist Georg Friedrich Schenck, who made his formal New York City debut at the Metropolitan Museum on Nov. 2, studied with Karl Engel, Claudio Arrau and Andre Watts, among others. In 1980, he was the winner of the German Music Competition in Bonn.

title:
GARDENING;

FERNS ADD TOUCH OF GREENERY TO INDOORS
description: THOSE of us who have been around for a half-century or more may remember the bay window where our grandmother or mother kept a giant Boston fern in a wicker plant stand. There was something elegant about this combination. It was several notches above the level of growing a common geranium on the windowsill. And when guests came for Sunday dinner, they would admire this evidence of the hostess's green thumb.

title: AIRBORNE AID FOR CATTLE
description: National Guard helicopters dropped hay today southwest of New Orleans for starving cattle that were stranded by flood waters from Hurricane Juan. State agriculture officials asked the Guard to mount the two-week rescue operation in Lafourche Parish after estimating that more than 600 animals had drowned and 5,000 were stranded.

title: NEW YORK'S MENTALLY ILL FEAR HOMELESS SHELTERS
description: For years, the streets of New York City have been home to men and women who drag their belongings in garbage bags or shopping carts and sleep in shelters run by the city, or by religious or community groups.

title: WHIMSY IN RYE
description: A clay egg carton in which chickens can be seen in various activities -playing Monopoly, for instance, and chatting on a telephone in a bathtub - is one of the toy-inspired modern works of art to be found in Rye, N.Y., at an exhibition that opens Nov. 19 and runs through Jan. 16.

title: OPERA: 'EUGENE ONEGIN' IN WASHINGTON, DIRECTED BY MENOTTI
description: TCHAIKOVSKY'S ''Eugene Onegin,'' with which the Washington Opera is continuing its fall season, poses an unusually acute test of the sensibilities of an operatic ensemble. It demands singers who can seize a moment or command a great line, who can function vocally on the ''Traviata'' or ''Butterfly'' level. But its wonderfully wrought music is not quite sure-fire; even when the basic elements are present, it can fall short in the theater unless singers, conductor and director have probed the story's interactions and relationships in a subtler way - a more modern way, if you like - than those other operas require.

title: ACTION! CAMERA! IT'S TIME FOR A VIDEO MEETING
description: ON APRIL 1, Karl Bays, chairman of the American Hospital Supply Corporation, stood before a raft of television cameras and answered reporters' questions about his company's proposed merger with the Hospital Corporation of America.

title: Settling With Burger
description: Like many another Federal institution, the Commission on the Bicentennial of the United States Constitution has money problems. Its chairman, Chief Justice Warren E. Burger, said at a reception last week that the commission that prepared for the 200th anniversary of the nation in 1976 received $118 million from Congress and had access to an extra $30 million or $40 million but that his group had so far received only $331,000.

title: MALAYSIA'S INDIANS FACING BITTERSWEET TIMES
description: As Indians around the world prepare for the Nov. 11 celebration of their most joyous festival, Deepavali, the Indians of Malaysia, descendants of indentured laborers brought here by British planters, are facing bittersweet times.

title: FOR PETER STRAUSS, ACTING ON TV IS AN INTENSE AFFAIR
description: ''The television film is always being mocked. The film-making community of the Spielbergs, the Scorseses and the Lucases has everything available to it. In television, we have hardly anything.''

title: Saving a Setting
description: Construction is to start soon on a 69-unit residential community planned for a 35-acre site on Shelter Rock Road in North Hills, L.I., but the builder's bulldozers and earthmovers will spare most of the hundreds of specimen trees planted on the property more than 50 years ago by a former owner.

title: Imposing a Twisted View of Fairness
description: Laxness in general enforcement of civil rights laws is bad enough. In one instance, the Administration is going out of its way to attack equal employment opportunities for minorities and women: on its own projects.

title: SIEGE PANEL BEGINS WEIGHING EVIDENCE
description: Having heard 18 days of testimony in which top city officials repeatedly disputed each other's accounts of the confrontation between the police and the radical group Move in May, an investigating commission must now begin apportioning blame.

title: A FEDERAL BENEFACTOR OF THE ARTS COMES OF AGE
description: It's been assailed by critics, threatened with dismantling by Presidential advisers, and warned by Cassandras that it would never survive. But this year the National Endowment for the Arts - a Federal agency that has achieved a national presence out of all proportion to its size and budget - is celebrating its 20th birthday in fairly robust health.

title: REGISTRY FOR ARTISTS IS A STORE OF TALENT
description: SOME 19,000 works of art -enough original sculptures, paintings, wall hangings, photographs, and other forms to art to cover the walls of hundreds of museums - are tucked away on the shelf of a brownstone building in downtown Hartford.

title: WASHINGTON PONDERS YURCHENKO: A TROUBLED SPY OR AN ACTOR?
description: Vitaly S. Yurchenko's voice was breaking and he appeared to be brushing tears from his eyes this week as he described for reporters what he said were his experiences during three months in the hands of the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: FLOCKING TO PAGEANT'S 'PEARLY GATES'
description: From the back of the church comes the wayward woman in a low-cut green dress, dripping cheap jewelry. A bottle of whisky is in one hand; a cigarette dangles from the other.

title: A.T. & T. Grants Go to 3 Dance Companies
description: The A.T. & T. Foundation has announced 1985-86 touring grants totaling $205,000 to American Ballet Theater, Dance Theater of Harlem and the Paul Taylor Dance Company. The grants are the largest touring grants ever presented by a corporation to these companies.

title: AN OLD FAVORITE IS SEEN AGAIN
description: THE cardigan sweater seems an ideal match with the current vogue for both outsized and classic clothing: Few other garments are at once as comfortable and chic, cosy and sexy. This fall, cardigans range from jersey to cable-knit designs, often appliqued with a jaunty yachting emblem.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: CYRUS VANCE. By David S. McLellan. (Rowman & Allanheld, $22.95.) In the American foreign policy process, David S. McLellan notes, ''large issues such as war and peace are decided within bounds set by the President.''

title: Dr. WHITEHEAD, A VETERINARIAN, WEDS IN JERSEY
description: Dr. Suzanne Calder Whitehead and Dr. Russell Hankins Patterson, graduates of the University of Pennsylvania School of Veterinary Medicine, were married yesterday at St. Peter's Episcopal Church in Essex Fells, N.J. The Rev. Dr. David St. George performed the ceremony.

title: BAN ON USED HEATING OIL
description: In an action that may have considerable effect on New York City, the E.P.A. cracked down last week on another problem in the handling and disposal of toxic wastes. It restricted the sale of and banned the burning of used oil containing more than specified levels of toxic chemicals and metals.

title: VERSAILLES
description: To the Editor: The articles on Versailles (Travel, Sept. 15) were a delightful reminder of past visits. In addition to the article in the main section on the Versailles Colloquium, they presented as complete a view of the palace and its environs as one could get in any guidebook. However, I am a little puzzled: no one ever mentions an event I witnessed there.

title: LANDFILL EXPANSION ATTACKED
description: ISLIP TOWN is facing mounting opposition to its expansion of the Blydenburgh landfill. The town is excavating 12.5 acres to avert what it says will otherwise be a crisis situation in June when the existing landfill is expected to reach capacity.

title:
NUMISMATICS;

CANADA INITIATES ITS OLYMPIC OIN PROGRAM
description: The 1988 Winter Olympic Games in Calgary, Alberta, are more than two years away. But the Royal Canadian Mint has unveiled the designs of all 10 silver coins in the series and has issued the first two. The 11th coin, to be struck in gold, is the only one still under wraps.

title: THE CAS FOR KEEPING WRIGHT'S VISION OF THE GUGGENHEIM
description: The most puzzling thing about the proposal to add to the Guggenheim Museum, which was announced last winter and then revealed in its final form last month, is the relative silence with which it has been received. It has neither been celebrated as an architectural triumph nor reviled as the desecration of a landmark. A few architects have come forward to support the plan, and the Carnegie Hill Neighbors, a community group in the portion of the Upper East Side in which the museum is located, has made known its displeasure. But the response has been nothing compared to the outcry that greeted the announcement by the Whitney Museum, the Guggenheim's neighbor 15 blocks to the southeast, that it wished to make a substantial addition to its building.

title: VLADMIR HOROWITZ: 'BEETHOVEN IS SOMETIMES BORING. I PREFER LEHAR'
description: Aging operatic prima donnas, by a long tradition that seems now to have lapsed, used to make a second career of giving Farewell Performances. There are Final Farewells, Absolutely Last Farewells, Irrevocable Farewells, and even farewells in which the impresario's contract actually binds the diva to silence afterward. Adelina Patti bade farewell for fully two decades.

title: PAST IMPERFECT
description: ONE bullish sector in an otherwise flat academic economy is the business of issuing academic reports. Scarcely a semester has gone by without some university, foundation, government agency or private organization pronouncing on the state of undergraduate education.

title: WINTER WEDDING FOR ROBIN COHEN
description: Announcement has been made by Joan J. Cohen and Jerome M. Cohen, both of New York, of the engagement of their daughter, Robin Rose Cohen, to Alan C. Rothfeld, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Rothfeld of Brooklyn. The wedding is planned for Feb. 9.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE WHISTLE BLOWER. By John Hale. (Atheneum, $12.95.) John Hale's eighth novel begins promisingly. When Frank Jones, a middle-aged, middle-class shopkeeper who once served as an enlisted pilot in the Fleet Air Arm, is told his son has died in an accidental fall from his roof, he refuses to believe it.

title: PROKOFIEV'S 'PETER AND THE WOLF' is 50 YEARS OLD
description: Can it really be? Sergei Prokofiev's ''Peter and the Wolf'' - that beguiling, gently ironic and eternally youthful ''symphonic fairy tale for children'' - has reached middle age. Showing no signs of wear and tear, its remarkable popularity undiminished, still fresh and sassy even after countless performances and recordings, ''Peter'' will be 50 years old in the spring of 1986. To celebrate this bittersweet occasion (admittedly, a few months early), Hospital Audiences Inc. has organized a special benefit performance of the piece tomorrow night in Alice Tully Hall.

title: FRENCH AGENTS IN PLEA BARGAIN
description: A plea bargain that may have owed as much to diplomacy as law brought an end to the Rainbow Warrior trial last week. New Zealand's Solicitor General, Paul Neazor, dropped murder charges against two French agents accused of sinking the Greenpeace flagship before it could lead a flotilla protesting French nuclear testing in the South Pacific.

title: KENYA'S ISLAND OF PEACE
description: Against the wind and against the tide, we tacked on the Indian Ocean. It was slow going, and after a while Hamid, the Swahili mate, asked me to help pass the time by telling him a story. I was touched - a young man asking a man in his middle years to fabricate an entertainment. I asked, ''What kind of story?'' and he said, ''Oh, about kings and kingdoms.'' I said that, coming from America, I had rather gotten beyond royalty. Hamid said, all right, then, he would spin the yarn. The hot breeze had parched us, and we drank deeply from our coconuts before Hamid began to speak dreamily of magic spy glasses, flying carpets, golden apples, a monarch, three sons, love and a beautiful maiden. I closed my eyes and rocked with the dhow to the rhythm of the sea; for the first time in an age, I felt serene.

title: MAN WHO JUMPED FROM SOVIET SHIP IS EN ROUTE HOME
description: A freighter pulled away from the dock here this morning and began her trip back to the Soviet Union carrying a seaman who had twice jumped into the Mississippi River.

title: WHERE THE WILD THINGS CAME FROM
description: IN GRANDPA'S HOUSE By Philip Sendak. Illustrated by Maurice Sendak. Translated and adapted by Seymour Barofsky. 42 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $9.95. (All Ages) THERE is a sweetness of soul that illuminates Maurice Sendak's most frightening works, and that quality permeates his father Philip Sendak's posthumously published ''In Grandpa's House.'' Much of the book is a dreamlike set of legends - located in a Polish-Jewish shtetl - that Philip Sendak told his children when they were young. Then, when Philip was a lonely widower of 75, his son insisted that he commit them to paper. In that respect, the book is an inspiring act of filial love.

title: CLEARING THE AIR IN NASSAU COUNTY
description: For people who are tired of complaining about cigarette smoke in restaurants, stores and at the office, Feb. 1, 1986, will be a day of liberation in Nassau County. Last week the County Board of Health adopted one of the strictest antismoking rules in the country, tougher even than one passed last year by the legislature in Suffolk County.

title: MONTCLAIR ST. TOPS JERSEY CITY, 31-17
description: Leroy Horn ran down the field a few times on the kicking team in the first half today, but spent the rest of the first 30 minutes on the bench, watching Montclair State fall behind Jersey City State.

title:
GARDENING;

FERNS ADD TOUCH OF GREENERY TO INDOORS
description: THOSE of us who have been around for a half-century or more may remember the bay window where our grandmother or mother kept a giant Boston fern in a wicker plant stand. There was something elegant about this combination. It was several notches above the level of growing a common geranium on the windowsill. And when guests came for Sunday dinner, they would admire this evidence of the hostess's green thumb.

title: NEWARK IS TRYING TO REVRESE DECLINE
description: IN A WAY, the Newark Legal and Communications Center, a $50 million building for which ground was broken last month, symbolizes this city's beleaguered past and hopes for the future.

title: BREAK BEFORE GRAD SCHOOL BECOMING STUDENT ROUTINE
description: FROM his perspective as an assistant director of admissions at Georgetown Law School, Andy Cornblatt senses a changing attitude about graduate school among the students he interviews during recruiting trips on college campuses.

title: EVELYN VAN INGEN TO MARRY J. R. FELL 3D
description: Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence B. Van Ingen of Glen Head, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Evelyn McLane Van Ingen to John Ruckman Fell 3d, a son of Mrs. Robert L. Stott Jr. of New York and Mr. Fell Jr. of Locust Valley, L.I.

title: O.M.B. BALKS AT BROWN-LUNG RULE
description: Unions and factory owners often disagree bitterly over work-place health and safety standards. In the case of brown lung disease, however, there has been broad agreement among labor leaders and mill bosses that mandatory medical examinations are essential if the disease is to be caught in its early stages, when it can more easily be treated.

title: THE CALL FOR VALOR
description: Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey, in awarding the Silver Cross for Valor last month to Uli Derickson, the airline purser who was credited with saving lives by dealing firmly with hijackers last June in the Middle East:

title: Portrait Of a French Family
description: Francine du Plessix Gray's summer reunions remind me of the ones my family holds in Yenne, a small village in the French Alps.

title: SETON HALL COACH WINS 200th GAME
description: Coach Tony Verducci of Seton Hall Prep gained his 200th career victory and 99th shutout at the school when his team shut out Columbia, 23-0, in South Orange. Two fumbles by the Columbia punter resulted in touchdowns for Seton Hall (6-0-1).

title: GENISIS MEETS TOBACCO ROAD
description: NOT WANTED ON THE VOYAGE By Timothy Findley. 352 pp. New York: Delacorte Press. $17.95.

title: MARRIED LOVE: A BUMPY ROAD, BUT WITH UNBEATABLE VISTAS
description: HE STANDS in the driveway, wondering how it came to pass that, for a runaway weekend for two, there are three suitcases, one tote bag, two shopping bags and a carryall to wedge into the car's small trunk.

title: A COMMON DESIRE FOR GUNS AND BUTTER
description: As President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, move into final preparations for their meeting in Geneva Nov. 19 and 20, calculations over guns and butter figure importantly in their summit strategy. The connections are sometimes direct, sometimes subtle and ambiguous, but in any case, a major incentive to avoid failure.

title: COUNTIES GAIN POWER AS FEDERAL INFLUENCE WANES
description: Four years after President Reagan began dismantling Federal domestic programs, a new order of local government has begun to emerge as once-dormant counties in many areas challenge cities for pre-eminence.

title: MEDICAL GAINS SEEN IN CARE FOR SMALL INFANTS
description: Medical technology is increasingly saving very small babies without increasing the number of physically or mentally damaged children, according to a nationwide project conducted by the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation.

title: AFRICAN DESERT, BRITISH COUNTRY HOMES
description: A Visit With The Bushmen Of the Kalahari Definitely off the beaten track is a land as large as France and slightly smaller than the state of Texas, where the local constabulary patrols on camelback and one can travel for hours without sign of another human being.

title: LATE HARVARD RALLY BEATS HOLY CROSS
description: Harvard scored 21 points in 41 seconds on touchdown passes by Brian White and Robert Santiago, and an interception return by Lee Oldenburg for a 28-20 comeback victory today over Holy Cross.

title:
WHAT'S NEW IN EDUCATIONAL TOYS;

BRINGING THE SALES PITCH HOME
description: BACK in 1978, when Bernard Tessler first started Enchanted Village, his friends and advisers tried to talk him out of it. ''I was told from day one that education would not sell,'' he said. ''People were turned off, they considered it dull.''

title: JENNIE CORBETT BRIDE OF CARY B. SAMOWITZ
description: Virginia Leslie Corbett, a computer operations and systems manager at the Companion Life Insurance Company in Rye, N.Y., was married last evening to Cary Brian Samowitz, an associate in the New York law firm of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison. Rabbi A. Bruce Goldman performed the ceremony at Windows on the World.

title: RONI TANNENBAUM MARRIES
description: Roni Tannenbaum, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Tannenbaum of East Windsor, N.J., was married yesterday to Kyle Dean Chadwick, a son of Matilda Wuest of Avenel, N.J., and the late Sgt. William Chadwick of the Air Force. Mayor Linda Moore of East Windsor performed the ceremony at the Scanticon Hotel in Princeton, N.J. The bride's father is special features editor editor of the Eastern edition of The Daily Racing Form in Hightstown, N.J.

title: FORMER OHIO GOVERNOR SEEKING FIFTH TERM
description: Former Gov. James A. Rhodes, who has already served as the state's chief executive longer than anyone else, said today that he would seek to oust the incumbent and win a fifth term next year.

title: NEW HEALTH PLANS MOVING ONTO ISLAND
description: HEALTH care on Long Island is about to undergo a radical change, one that experts say may save money for hundreds of thousands of residents.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Metros de San Juan vs. Cangrejeros de Santurce, at San Juan. Puerto Rico Winter League game of the week. (Television - Channel 41, noon, live). Football Giants vs. Los Angeles Rams, at Giants Stadium, 1 P.M. The Rams are second only to the Chicago Bears in taking advantage of turnovers in , with a plus 11 in that category. The Giants have a minus 2. (Television - Channel 2, 1 P.M. Radio - WNEW 1130, 1 P.M.) Jets vs. Dolphins, at Miami. (Television - Channel 4, 4 P.M. Radio - WABC 770, 4 P.M.) College: Mississippi Valley State vs. Alcorn State, at Jackson, Miss. Willie Totten has 204 completions in 356 attempts for 2,729 yards and 30 touchdowns for Mississippi Valley. Running National Road Runners Club 17th annual Age Group Championships, at Van Cortlandt Park, 245th Street and Broadway, the Bronx, 10 A.M. More than 2,500 runners from 2 years old to 70 will compete in races ranging from a quarter-mile to 5,000 meters. Soccer Paraguay vs Chile, at Asuncion, Paraguay. First of two World Cup qualifying matches for the final South American berth in next year's tournament. The other three teams already qualified from South America are Argentina, Brazil and Uruguay. (Television -Channel 41, 4:45 P.M. live). Inter vs. Naples, at Milan, Italian Professional League game of the week (Television - Channel 31, 8:30 A.M. live). Other Events BADMINTON: Eastern States Open Championships, at Greenwich (Conn.) High School, 10 A.M. Admission is free for the final day of competition.

title: WORKMEN'S CIRCLE: 85 YEARS OF AID TO JEWS
description: The Workmen's Circle was established in New York 85 years ago. And to this day, no one has ever been quite able to describe exactly what it is.

title: HOW IT'S DONE ELSEWHERE
description: ALTHOUGH Americans have long thought of the ''melting pot'' as peculiar to this nation of immigrants, the character of the modern world as a global village has made bilingual education an issue for most industrial nations.

title: WHEN BUSINESS MOVES, WORKERS ADJUST
description: HOWARD DRUCKER leaves for work early these days.

title: Of Cancer And the Need to Speak
description: My mother-in-law sent us the article ''Truth and Cancer'' [Opinion Page, Sept. 29] . We were delighted that an honest, feeling attitude still exists in papers.

title: THE 3 TEACHING METHODS IN BILINGUAL CLASSES
description: HOW American schools teach English to students who do not speak it fluently depends on the state, school district, school, instructor and the needs of the students. In most cases, though, schools use variations of three approaches:

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: An Anarchist Santa Claus The indignation of concerned people who write protests to their newspaper is an important index of civilization. Here's a letter to The New York Times written by Stephen T. Byington of Ballard Vale, Mass., in December 1913. It's from ''December 25th: The Joys of Christmas Past'' (Dodd, Mead), by Phillip Snyder.

title: TENLEY CRONIN WEDS JOHN MOESER QUIRK JR.
description: Tenley Lois Cronin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Greene Cronin of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married there yesterday to John Moeser Quirk Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Quirk of Morris Plains, N.J. The Rev. William J. Winterrowd performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of St. James the Less.

title: KEEPING INSIDE IN AND OUTSIDE OUT
description: HOMEOWNERS who want to keep heating bills as low as possible this winter can take a number of steps now to seal up heat leaks, even if the house is already insulated.

title: SCARSDALE EDUCATOR EXAMINES EFFECTS OF DIVORCE IN SCHOOLS
description: THE ideas for the recently published ''Helping Children of Divorce, a Handbook for Parents and Teachers'' by Susan Arnsberg Diamond (Schocken Books, $11.95), began germinating in 1975.

title: HOW L.A. SCHOOL DEALS WITH ETHNIC MELANGE
description: ON the playground at Los Feliz Elementary School, five Hispanic girls played with a Chinese jump rope, counting the hops and turns of the girl in the center. ''Dos, tres, cuatro - you're out!'' they cried as she missed her step. Across the yard, a boy from Colombia wrestled a giggling classmate for possession of a kickball. ''No way!'' he said in perfect English.

title: Escape From Obligations Fight Boredom
description: Modern electronics has decivilized the aural world even if you like heavy metal rock music. Watches now chirp the hour, even in church.

title: R. C. PERRY WED TO LISA NEWMAN
