description: Lisa Rachel Newberger, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Newberger of Riverwoods, Ill., and New York, was married yesterday to Richard Cayne Perry, a son of Merel Cayne of New York and Arnold Perry of Los Angeles. Rabbi Joseph Pitasnik performed the ceremony in the ballroom of the Puck Building in Manhattan.

title: DOVER LABORATORY BUILDING SPACE GUN
description: ALTHOUGH some critics view the Strategic Defense Initiative - Star Wars - as unattainable, a small group of engineers here is building, for that defense plan, an electromagnetic gun to be placed in orbit.

title: ON THE ART OF TEACHING WRITING
description: I agree that every community should be committed to improving writing. Nevertheless, I have some doubts about the effectiveness of the Barrington program.

title: SIX ROTHKO MURALS TO HANG AT THE NATIONAL
description: In the late 1950's, Mark Rothko began work on a series of murals commissioned for the Seagram Building in New York City. But when the artist discovered to his horror that they were to hang in the building's restaurant, he withdrew from the project.

title: A FREEWAY SINKS IN THE WEST
description: San Francisco took drastic steps last week to reclaim its most treasured resource: its scenery. The Board of Supervisors voted to tear down a 26-year-old elevated freeway that curves for one mile around the northeast edge of the city, blocking the view of the bay and the ferry building, a city landmark.

title: JOHN T. BRADY JR., ADVERTISING AIDE, WEDS ELLEN KELLY
description: The marriage of Ellen Grace Kelly, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William E. Kelly of Spring Lake, N.J., to John Thomas Brady Jr., the son of Mr. Brady of New York and Jean Brady of Summit, N.J., took place yesterday. Msgr. John E. Grimes, assisted by the Rev. Francis Hamill, performed the ceremony at St. Catharine's Roman Catholic Church in Spring Lake.

title: WORDS, THE DOLLS OF SOUND
description: THE KING OF TIME Selected Writings of the Russian Futurian. By Velimir Khlebnikov. Edited by Charlotte Douglas. Translated by Paul Schmidt. Illustrated. 255 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $18.50.

title: THE MEXICAN DRUG WAR GETS RED HOT
description: The stakes in the Mexican Government's war against illegal drugs destined for the United States were raised substantially last weekend with the killing of 17 police officers and five other members of an anti-drug group who were on a night mission in a remote region of the Gulf Coast state of Veracruz. They were apparently killed by a large band of drug traffickers armed with high-powered automatic weapons after the police discovered a cache of marijuana.

title: SUSAN HORTON TO WED ERIC RAYMAN ON DEC. 7
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harry Horton of Lido Beach, L.I., and Palm Beach, Fla., have announced that their daughter Susan Emily Horton and Steven Eric Rayman plan to be married Dec. 7. The future bridegroom is a son of Dr. Norman Rayman of Bronxville, N.Y., and the late Norma Rayman.

title: IN THE AFTERMATH OF A HEART ATTACK
description: AND so it was at 43 that I was hooked up to a machine in a coronary-care unit. Lying on my back, I thought about my own mortality.

title: ALICE AND CHARLIE AND VIDA AND SOPHY -- A TERRORIST'S WORK IS NEVER DONE
description: LIKE the detective and gangster of popular fiction, the female terrorist - the latest product in the literary marketplace -triggers our fascination with violence, not to say our prurient anxiety. We wonder what could possibly motivate this amazon of political excess, this Hippolyta who explodes our deeply held notions of female behavior. Compared, however, with the stylish tough guy of the 30's -Sam Spade of the narrow-brimmed hat, side-of-the-mouth cigarette and terse, hard-boiled tongue - the tough girl of the 80's seems downright drab. Edgy and combative, her forehead permanently puckered in postpubescent frown, she slaps T-shirts and jeans over unbound breasts and buttocks with a kind of automatic libidinousness.

title: ALABAMA RALLIES TO TIE L.S.U., 14-14
description: Gene Jelks, a freshman running back who was starting his first collegiate game, ran for one touchdown and threw for another today to help Alabama rally to a 14-14 tie with Louisiana State in a Southeastern Conference game.

title: SHOREHAM PLANT AND STORM CLEANUP
description: A news item on Oct. 20 stated that the Long Island Lighting Company had offered to make reparations to all of its customers for the time they were without service. This same bit of information, reporting Lilco's good will and largesse, was also mentioned over several television stations.

title: THE MAYOR GOES JUDGE HUNTING
description: The day after winning his third term, Mayor Koch opened another campaign last week, but this one he has tried to make nonpolitical. The Mayor is hoping to fill vacancies on the city's Criminal, Civil and Family court benches, and he wants more lawyers to apply so that he can be more selective in appointing judges.

title: KARPOV FAILS AS HE TURNS TO FOE'S STYLE
description: Anatoly Karpov tried to turn his opponent's weapons against him in the final game of the world chess championship match in Moscow yesterday, but Gary Kasparov brilliantly scotched the attempt and won the title with a final score of 13 to 11.

title: 7 ARE KILLED IN BELGIAN TOWN IN ROBBERY AT A SUPERMARKET
description: Seven people were shot to death and 15 people were wounded tonight when three armed robbers attacked a supermarket in Aalst, 15 miles west of Brussels, the police said.

title: WHAT'S ENTERTAINMENT? SINGER ANSWERS AT YALE
description: Dennis Greene, a visiting lecturer at Yale this semester, holds a bachelor of arts degree from Columbia and a master's degree from Harvard. And, next year, he expects to receive a law degree from Yale. But Mr. Greene's most impressive academic credential, his seminar students say, is that he performed at Woodstock.

title: ARE 'NEW' WOMEN'S MOVIES GUILTY OF SEXISM IN REVERSE?
description: We're in the siege of ''new'' women's pictures, for better and worse. It's probably just a coincidence in release schedules, but not in a number of years have there been as many movies as there are at the minute in which women not only are the stars but also play the most important dramatic roles:

title: TRANSCRIPT OF PRESIDENT'S SPEECH, BROADCAST TO SOVIET, ON HOPES FOR PEACE
description: Following is a transcript of the radio address yesterday by President Reagan, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: THE YEAR'S BEST ILLUSTRATED BOOKS
description: THE illustrations on these pages have been taken from The Book Review's choices of the 10 best illustrated children's books of 1985.

title: MY CAR AND MYSELF, VANDALIZED
description: IT WAS late on a moonless night, and the lights were out in the Huntington parking lot. I fumbled the car key in, opened the door and leaned in to put my purse down on the floor.

title: FEELING THE FLEETING JOY OF INDIAN SUMMER
description: AN October Sunday afternoon at the Fire Island National Seashore, where an eight-mile wilderness area abuts Smith Point County Park. If it was still summer, tens of thousands of people would be thronging the park to my east.

title: HILLSIDE CLINIC IS PILOT PROJECT ON PET CONTROL
description: ''PET Overpopulation Is a Mounting Problem'' says a bumper sticker on a small foreign car in the parking lot at the People for Animals Spay/ Neuter Clinic in this Union County community.

title: FOR GREENWICH CLOCKS, TOME IS RUNNING OUT
description: In an era of belt-tightening and advancing technology, Britain has decided that it can no longer afford the upkeep of Greenwich mean time.

title: CATHERINE ANE BORRI AND JOHN LYNESS ARE MARRIED
description: Catherine Ane Borri, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Tullio J. Borri of Metuchen, N.J., was married yesterday to John Frederic Lyness, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James K. Lyness of Point Pleasant, N.J. The Rev. Thomas D. Bowers performed the ceremony at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in New York.

title: CHILD ABUSE: REAL DANGERS AND FALSE ALARMS
description: ALMOST every day the news serves up another story of a child-molesting wolf in sheep's clothing - a priest, a grandmother. The sexual abuse stories mesh with the missing children stories. Milk cartons and bank posters expect me to recognize a child from a photograph taken six years ago. Statistics are thrown around like birdseed. ''Millions'' of children are missing every year, ''thousands'' of children are assaulted or murdered. Reasonable parents are terrified of letting their children out of their sight. Across the nation, children are being fingerprinted. Day care seems a sinister plot by pornographers. And where there is fear, there is always advice. Dozens of books are now available, some for children, some for parents, that promise protection from a world grown more dangerous and mad.

title: HUNTING SCOTERS OFFSHORE
description: TRYING to ambush scoters from a one-man layout boat anchored in choppy seas does not enhance one's wing-shooting reputation.

title: THOUSANDS RALLY IN NEWARK TO PROTEST APARTHEID POLICY
description: Representative Walter Fauntroy asked thousands of people rallying against apartheid here today to urge Congress to vote down any measures that would aid the South African Government.

title: PROMISING FOLK SINGERS LOOK FOR BIG BREAK AT VILLAGE CLUB
description: Every Monday evening, almost without fail, Mark Glasmire and Pat Troiani drive nearly 100 miles to Greenwich Village's Folk City, joining scores of singers and comedians, musicians and mimics seeking the fame and fortune the city promises.

title: TO CONSERVATION OFFICERS, NEW YORK CITY IS A JUNGLE
description: Long before the first glint of dawn creeps over lower Manhattan, when the usually bustling South Street Seaport is still, Rick Malin and Kevin Gilmartin are covered with slime.

title: TWO ORCHESTRAS ACCENT YOUTH
description: FOR six years, Osvaldo Ferrari, a North Massapequa barber, has been chauffeuring his daughter, Christina, around Long Island, first to rehearsals and performances of the Camerata String Orchestra, and now to concerts by the Camerata Chamber Orchestra.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article in the Business section last Sunday on Geoffrey T. Boisi of Goldman, Sachs & Company misstated his title and gave the status of John C. Whitehead incorrectly. Mr. Boisi is co-head of investment banking services. Mr. Whitehead has left the firm to become Deputy Secretary of State. In addition, the co-adviser to General Foods in its merger agreement, along with Goldman, was misidentified. It was Shearson Lehman Brothers.

title: KEEPING INSIDE AND IN AND OUTSIDE OUT
description: HOMEOWNERS who want to keep heating bills as low as possible this winter can take a number of steps now to seal up heat leaks, even if the house is already insulated.

title: DOCTORING THE DEMOCRATS
description: THE REAGAN DETOUR By Richard Reeves. 141 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $14.95. CUTTING EDGES Making Sense of the Eighties. By Charles Krauthammer. 221 pp. New York: Random House. $17.95.

title: FAMILY HEIRLOOMS STIR FOND MEMORIES
description: BEFORE going into the kitchen on a dark winter morning I turn on the old lamp in the living room and watch the polished mahogany of my mother's furniture come to life. The camelback couch reflects in the old mirror. The couch is straight and hard (''Good for your posture,'' my mother used to say). I have a faded picture of my grandmother, Christine Rasmussen, sitting on the couch when she was a young girl, very erect.

title: GRADING (AND FLUNKING) TEACHERS
description: When the New Jersey Department of Education disclosed that 10 percent of the prospective teachers in the state had failed the National Teacher Examinations last spring, there was little comment from the schools of education where the test-takers were trained. But last week, when the department released the results of the standardized tests rearranged to show the failure rate of each school, some education deans were furious.

title: COLOMBIA DEBATES HANKLING OF SIEGE
description: As Colombia began burying those who died in the siege at the Palace of Justice this week, a debate was building today over the Government's response to the crisis.

title: ALFONSIN WINS, BUT IT'S NO SWEEP
description: President Raul Alfonsin passed last week his first electoral test since restoring civilian democracy in Argentina in 1983. Given difficult economic and political times, Mr. Alfonsin had reasons for satisfaction, even though, with about 43 percent of the vote, his Radical Party did less well than two years ago.

title: PURSUIT OF TIGERS' GIBSON IS SLOW
description: CAN anybody here use a 28-year-old, left-handed hitting outfielder, who in the past two seasons has batted .285 and averaged 28 home runs, 94 runs batted in and 29.5 stolen bases? Apparently the Kansas City Royals and the Chicago Cubs, among others, can't. Or so they say. But then, the Yankees say so, too.

title: NEW YORK INSPECTORS CITE 36 FOOD OUTLETS FOR HEALTH OFFENSES
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 36 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: DEVELOPERS REMEDYING SUBURBAN ISOLATION
description: ALONG with cookie-cutter designs and tricycles-in-the-driveway domestication, the aspect of suburban life that is most often complained about is the sense of isolation. In the burbs, it is said, buying the Sunday newspaper requires starting up the family car and driving over to the nearest convenience store - which often is neither near nor convenient.

title: JANE DORIAN, ACTRESS, WED TO DAVID HASPEL
description: Jane Elisabeth Dorian, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Dorian of New York, was married yesterday to David K. Haspel, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Haspel of New Orleans. Rabbi David Posner performed the ceremony at the St. Regis-Sheraton Hotel in New York.

title: 475 MAFIA SUSPECTS ARE INDICTED IN SICILY
description: After three years of investigation, Sicilian magistrates have indicted 475 Mafia suspects in what the police called the largest crackdown on Italy's underworld, the authorities said today.

title: THE IMPORTANCE OF FANCY CANCELLATIONS
description: An important postal history auction that includes 75 Waterbury fancy cancels, will be conducted by Richard C. Frajola, Inc. next Saturday at 1 P.M. at the Danbury Hilton Inn, 18 Old Ridgebury Road, Danbury, Conn. Estimated realizations range from $50 to $10,000.

title: TRENTON FEARS CRISIS
description: CONSOLIDATING the hospital system in Essex County and other parts of New Jersey has taken on a new urgency here, as state officials confront what they fear could be a ''capital crisis'' for hospitals.

title: DINOSAUR TRACKS ATTRACTING CROWDS
description: A LAYER of dark Connecticut Valley sandstone that once composed the ooze at the edge of a primeval lake and has been called the state's ''oldest attraction'' is now on year-round indoor display in Rocky Hill.

title: MAKING THE RIGHT MOVES
description: WHEN the Bristol-Myers Company told Richard Ricci he would be transferred from Syracuse, N.Y., to the company's new Pharmaceutical Research Center in Wallingford, Conn., he and his wife, Connie, were most concerned about what kind of school system their new community would have.

title: Calling Bobby Fischer
description: To the Editor:

title: ABOUT BOOKS
description: TWO years ago, H. Bruce Franklin of Montclair, a professor of English at Rutgers-Newark, found himself, he recalled in a recent interview, ''making my usual complaint about a course on Vietnam that I teach here: that no adequate documentary history of the war that tore this nation apart for over 10 years was readily available in one volume.''

title: MUSIC: JAPANESE PERCUSSION
description: PRACTICING martial arts and playing a percussion instrument are two forms of controlled, choreographed violence; so Soh Daiko's Friday night concert at the Japan Society combined them to create an arresting evening of entertainment.

title: NEW CHIEF OF FIRE PERSONNEL APPOINTED BY COMMISSIONER
description: Fire Commissioner Joseph E. Spinnato said yesterday that he had named Assistant Chief Anthony DiMartino as the department's chief of personnel, replacing a civilian, Jane Miola.

title: A DECEMBER WEDDING FOR DIANE DE CORDOVA
description: Diane de Cordova, an analyst for Morgan Stanley International in London, and Michael Monroe Lewis, an associate at Salomon Brothers in New York, plan to be married Dec. 28.

title: THE PROMISES OF GENE THERAPY
description: A PAINFULLY THIN young man sits in a hospital wheelchair with his legs and torso oddly twisted - as though he has been flung there. Strapped on his arms are heavily padded splints, which are there to protect him against himself. Without them he is likely to bite and horribly injure his fingers because of an uncontrollable urge to mutilate himself.

title: NANCY A. JONES IS BRIDE OF ROBERT GERARD LYONS
description: Nancy Allison Jones, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert T. Jones Jr. of Newark, Del., became the bride there yesterday of Robert Gerard Lyons, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David P. Lyons Jr. of Fairfield, Conn. The Rev. Richard A. Reissmann performed the ceremony at St. John's Roman Catholic Church.

title: PICKLE PASTE AND WINGED ARMCHAIRS
description: WHISKERS & RHYMES Written and illustrated by Arnold Lobel. 48 pp. New York: Greenwillow Books. $13. (Ages 5 to 8) WRITING a book of poems for children is like sending a package to a child at camp: the cookies are fed to the fish, the books are fly swatters and the baseball cards are traded. You never know the use to which your gift - or your poems - will be put. If you're lucky, children a hundred years hence will be skipping rope to them or muttering them over the graves of dead cats. Although he didn't like the taste, George brushed his teeth with pickle paste. Not ever was his mouth so clean, Not ever were his teeth so green.

title: GROUP TRYING TO UNIFY EFFORTS
description: ON May 21, 1984, 40 community, government and business leaders met at the New Jersey Institute of Technology here to form an organization, the Newark Collaboration Group, whose aim was to coordinate the city's many disparate revitalization efforts.

title: A LOOK A LAGGING BROKERAGE STOCKS
description: FEW things are more predictable than the stampede by institutional investors to buy shares in the brokerage companies when the stock market gets hot. But the recent strength of the market - the Dow Jones industrial average last week broke through 1,400 for the first time - has failed to carry the brokerage stocks along. The shares of premier retail firms such as E. F. Hutton, Merrill Lynch and Paine Webber are trading only a few points above their September-October lows.

title: TELKA THE WONDERWORKER
description: THE MIRACLE CHILD A Story From Ethiopia. By Elizabeth Laird with Abba Aregawi Wolde Gabriel. Illustrated with reproductions from an 18th-century Ethiopian manuscript. 32 pp. New York: Holt, Rinehart & Winston. $12.95. (Ages 8 to 12) THERE is something very moving about ''The Miracle Child'' in this year of great hunger in Ethiopia. It is the story of Tekla Haymanot, one of Ethiopia's great saints, who was popularly known as the saint who prayed on one leg, after his other had withered away. In fact he was one of the most able patriarchs of the Ethiopian Church and largely responsible for its 13th-century literary and monastic efflorescence. (Christianity came to Ethiopia in the fourth century, and the church there developed its own rich hagiographic tradition.) After Tekla's death, the monks at Debra Libanos, the monastery he founded, wrote down the stories they heard about him and illustrated them with brightly colored illuminations. His story incorporates themes from the Bible and saints' legends, but has its own distinct flavor.

title: 4 TOP PLAYERS LEAD IN BRIDGE
description: The Fall National Championships of the American Contract Bridge League continued here tonight with four of the world's most famous players bidding for an intercontinental double.

title: NIXON IS HOPING FOR KNICK OFFER
description: Dave DeBusschere said several times last week that Norm Nixon, the veteran playmaker who remains a free agent, was not on his shopping list. But several observers who have watched the Knick guards falter repeatedly during the team's miserable start are hoping that his denials are just a smokescreen.

title: HONDA STEPPING INTO LUXURY
description: IN case you haven't noticed, Honda is now the No. 4 American auto maker, and its products from Ohio and Japan include some of the better cars ever to roll down the pike.

title: A PLEA TO REAGAN FROM 4 AMERICANS HELD IN BEIRUT
description: At least four of the six American hostages in Beirut were reported to be alive, if not safe, last week. Only a day after an anonymous telephone report that all six had been killed, a packet of handwritten letters was delivered to a Western news agency.

title: IDLING THROUGH THE MIDI
description: Let me tell you an idler's dream of heaven.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: INTERNATIONAL DANCE As a stop on the concert circuit, the Island has increasingly attracted performers from all over the world. This week, international dance dominates the local stages. Today, Friends of the Arts opens its ''Dazzling Dance'' series at the C. W. Post Center's Bush-Brown Concert Theater (which is being renamed the Gilbert and Rose Tilles Center for the Performing Arts). Not only will there be Oriental dancers who mix classical ballet with Chinese opera movements and classical court dance of Korea and Japan, but the 35-member troupe, Cloudgate, brings along seven trained peacocks to help make its artistic points. The performance is at 8 P.M. on the Brookville campus. Tickets are $12.50 or $15.

title: BY LOVE DERANGED
description: A CRUEL MADNESS By Colin Thubron. 168 pp. Boston: The Atlantic Monthly Press. $13.95.

title: PROFITING THE NOT-FOR-PROFIT THROUGH INSURANCE
description: FORTY years after the founding of the insurance company now known as Mutual of America, William J. Flynn was doing a little reminiscing.

title: TIES OF BLOOD, RIVERS OF BLOOD
description: ETHNIC GROUPS IN CONFLICT By Donald L. Horowitz. 697 pp. Berkeley: University of California Press. $25.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: For This Week:

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN HASBROUCK HEIGHTS
description: ALTHOUGH Hasbrouck Heights is surrounded by a web of public roads and sturdy brick factories, the tiny borough remains a picturesque oasis in the northern section of New Jersey.

title: TEACHER UNITY
description: IN two decades of teaching high school French, Robert Steindler could never quite shake the sense of isolation he came to consider part of his professional lot. Even after he left his first teaching job in West Virginia in 1965, tired of being ''the only French teacher in town,'' for the language department of Lakeland High School in Shrub Oak, N.Y., he never lost the feeling of being cut off from the wider current of thought in his field and of ''groping'' along alone in the classroom.

title:
VIEWS OF SPORT;

FOR GARY CARTER, '150 PERCENT WORTH IT'
description: YOU never know what to expect when you come to a new ball club, but my first season in New York after 10 in Montreal was more than I could have hoped for.

title: Travels With Shultz
description: The Geneva summit meeting between President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev is still nine days away and the results increasingly uncertain, but Secretary of State George P. Shultz is already planning a follow-up tour of Eastern European capitals that appears to presuppose an easing of tensions between the United States and the Soviet Union.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE UNIVERSAL MACHINE: Confessions of a Technological Optimist. By Pamela McCorduck. (McGraw-Hill, $16.95.) Converts often turn out to be the most fervent believers.

title: VILLANOVA STOPS FORDHAM BY 17-3
description: Pete Lombardi scored second-half touchdowns on runs of 1 and 3 yards as undefeated Villanova ended its season by snapping Fordham's five-game winning streak, 17-3, yesterday at Jack Coffey Field in the Bronx before a crowd of 5,379.

title: SERVICE STATISTICS
description: To the Editor:

title: PLENTY OF ALTERNATIVES
description: ANTOINE GENWRIGHT stood before his seventh-grade classmates and, with a saxophone to his lips, belted out the notes to ''Mary Had a Little Lamb'' as though he had been playing them all his life - all 12 years of it. Following an ovation, the soloist elaborated on the importance of knowing how to play a musical instrument. ''It's everything,'' he said. ''Out in the world, even if you lose your job, you will always have something as long as you can make music.''

title: FAITH, WORKS AND GOOD CLEAN ECCENTRICITY
description: FRANK AND MAISIE A Memoir with Parents. By Wilfrid Sheed. Illustrated. 296 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $17.95.

title: DISPUTING THE PRESIDENT ON PRIVATIZATION
description: Representative Gary L. Ackerman eased himself into the chair in the center of the curved dais in the ornate committee chamber. He was the only member of the committee to attend the hearing. Worse, a key Administration official from the Office of Management and Budget, citing the press of Government business, had spurned an invitation to testify.

title: TOPICS
description: FOR two years I had been watching a spider outside our large picture window. It is doubtful that it was the same spider, but certainly a member of the same family. Being fond of all creatures - insects, animals, birds - I found this spider particularly fascinating and named her Rachel. I have been told that all web-building spiders are female.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''If and when our research proves that a defensive shield against nuclear missiles is practical, I believe our two countries, and those others that have nuclear weapons, should come together and agree on how gradually to eliminate offensive nuclear weapons as we make our defensive system available to all.'' -President Reagan, in a speech broadcast to the Soviet Union. [18:1.]

title: DATA BANK November 10, 1985

ABOUT WESTCHESTER;

SINGLE FATHERS
description: AT first glance, it seems like any boisterous gathering of good buddies. The room is filled with laughter and hearty greetings and the sort of back-slapping camaraderie associated with pubs and all-male parties. The ice clinks in the glasses.

title: QUIET CONFIDENCE GETS JOB DONE
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: A BATTLE WITH NO HOLDS BARRED IN A COLOMBIAN COURT BUILDING
description: Colombia's President, Belisario Betancur, has been trying for three years to make peace with M-19, the urban guerrilla group that has specialized in kidnapping, hostage-taking and attacks on police stations. Last week, Mr. Betancur resorted to overwhelming military force.

title: ESCUDELLA, CATALONIA'S MEAL IN A POT
description: In Barcelona and throughout Spanish Catalonia, from the Pyrenees to the Mediterranean coast, the hearty one-dish, two-course preparation with the wonderfully musical name, escudella i carn d'olla, is regarded by that semiautonomous and staunchly independent region as its national dish. And in a region that prepares and seasons its own traditional foods today precisely as it has for centuries, that celebrates its separate ethnicity with patriotic cakes, and its own religious feasts and saints' days with breads, tarts and brioches, that is an appellation that should not be taken lightly. Talk to Catalonians and they will tell you that an escudella of meats and vegetables simmered in a huge earthenware bowl, or olla, is, as Luis Bettonica, probably the most knowledgeable proponent of Barcelona's Catalan cookery, says, ''perhaps the most representative dish of our cooking.''

title: GEORGIA TOPPLES FLORIDA
description: The Florida Gators' first week ever at the top of a news-agency poll ended here today as three long touchdown runs by Georgia freshmen gave the Bulldogs a 24-3 upset victory before a record crowd of 82,327 in the Gator Bowl.

title: NEW CASSETEES: TRUFFAUT, BIZET AND JOHN BLEUSHI
description: The Ashford & Simpson Video Thorn/EMI 60 minutes.

title: 'REVERSE' BILINGUALISM FOR THE NON-ETHNIC
description: WHEN fourth-graders return from their first-period break at the Spence School on Manhattan's Upper East Side, they come back to a changed classroom. Their desks have been replaced by ''pupitres,'' their books by ''livres'' and their teacher by ''la professeure.''

title: GOETZ'S LAWYERS MAKE NEW EFFORT TO AVOID TRIAL AFTER APPEALS FAIL
description: Lawyers for Bernhard H. Goetz, having exhausted their appeals to higher courts to dismiss charges stemming from his shooting of four men last December, have taken their case back to State Supreme Court trying to avert a trial.

title: U.N. HIGH COMMISSIONER JOB: THE RACE IS ON
description: At the height of the General Assembly, when the flesh-pressing and maneuvering in the corridors was broken only by marathon speeches, the most active diplomats were not lobbying for resolutions on disarmament or apartheid. They were looking for a job. The job being sought is the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, and the campaign to fill that post has brought out a level of politicking not seen at the United Nations since the last time the organization elected a Secretary General.

title: CABLE TV
description: What's in store this cable movie week? Some vintage bargains. There's a glittery fable about Hollywood, a British whodunit involving racial bias, a towering tale of Texas, a top musical, a vivid story of a southern demagogue, two John Ford westerns and a children's classic. All these -plus the mighty ''King Kong'' (the original) and ''Son of Kong,'' who's no slouch, either.

title: NASSAU RENTS
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW THEATER CENTER FOR WESTCHESTER
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Nov. 7 -The snake cages have been turned into dressing rooms for cast members. The yard where sheep and goats used to graze has become a parking lot for theatergoers. The aviary on the roof has been dismantled, and underneath it 101 theater seats have been installed in the former exhibition hall, which used to house rock collections. And tomorrow night, such actors as Lindsay Crouse, Ron Silver and Frances Sternhagen will take to the stage in a fund-raising program for a new arts center dedicated to developing and producing new plays.

title: FLYERS TOP BRUINS
description: Tim Kerr scored three goals tonight and Rich Sutter added two as the Philadelphia Flyers defeated the Boston Bruins, 5-3. It was the Flyers' 10th consecutive victory.

title: MCENROE GAINS FINAL
description: John McEnroe, who enjoys playing in Sweden and beating Swedish tennis stars, will have one more to conquer Sunday.

title: PAKISTAN'S PRESIDENT AGREES TO EASE HIS GRIP
description: Gen. Mohammad Zia ul-Haq has agreed to a modest dilution of his powers as President, striking a compromise with the Parliament that could pave the way for martial law to be lifted by next year.

title: WASTE DISPOSAL
description: To the Editor:

title: ART
description: To show the way we live now may not be the highest of art's ambitions, but it is an ambition to which a great many people respond. They look to painting for an index to themselves - to who they are, to where they live, and to the kind of impression that they are likely to make upon posterity.

title: KNICKS (0-8) LOSE CLOSE ONE
description: Once again, the Knicks had an opportunity to win last night. And once again, they failed.

title: CONCERT: SUISSE ROMANDE ORCHESTRA AT CARNEGIE
description: DESPITE the tenure enjoyed by such men as the late Eugene Ormandy (41 years at the helm of the Philadelphia Orchestra) and Frederick Stock (37 years with the Chicago Symphony), no important conductor has come close to rivaling Ernest Ansermet's half-century with the Orchestre de la Suisse Romande. But Ansermet was much more than just a conductor; he was the Suisse Romande incarnate. He founded the group in 1918, fashioned it to his specific tastes and nurtured it through difficult times, while championing the works of friends and compatriots - Debussy, Ravel, Roussel, Frank Martin, Arthur Honegger and, for a time, Stravinsky. It is difficult to imagine the course of 20th-century French music without him.

title: THE REQUIRED COMPUTER
description: FIVE YEARS ago, Carnegie-Mellon University attracted national attention with its announcement that it would require each student to have a microcomputer. It was the first school to suggest imposing such a rule, and though it has since reconsidered that idea, at least a dozen institutions, including Stevens Institute of Technology and Drew University in New Jersey, and Clarkson University in New York, have adopted the computer-requirement policy. And in spite of the problems inherent in the computer-per-student plan, directors of computing at these institutions remain convinced that it will work.

title: NEW CASSETEES: TRUFFAUT, BIZET AND JOHN BLEUSHI
description: The Adventures of Tom Sawyer Starring Josh Albee, Jeff Tyler, Jane Wyatt, Buddy Ebsen, John McGiver; directed by James Neilson, 1973. MCA Home Video 76 minutes.

title: JEWISH MUSIC FROM THE PAST
description: Considering that comparatively little pre-Baroque music has come down to us in written form and that much of what has survived is connected with Christian worship, it is no surprise that early music by Jewish composers should be scarce. Scholars being what they are, however, a body of knowledge has been accumulated from a wide range of Christian and Jewish sources and a repertory of performable music amassed in both the secular and the sacred spheres.

title: Verity With Congress
description: For years, members of Congress have typically been required by the press of legislative business to spend more time in Washington than in their home states and districts. Most say they are looking forward to returning immediately upon retirement to the state or district they love, but often it doesn't work out that way.

title: AUDIT FINDS UNQUALIFIED STUDENTS AT EVERS GOT AID
description: Students at Medgar Evers College in Brooklyn who failed to meet the college's academic standards were permitted to remain in school and receive Federal financial aid, according to a new Federal audit.

title: CRAXI DEFENDS P.L.O.
description: Prime Minister Bettino Craxi of Italy won parliamentary approval of his reconstituted Government last week despite a political storm that arose when he appeared to justify the use of violence by the Palestine Liberation Organization. He criticized the Palestinians' armed struggle as ineffective and a threat to innocent people but implied that the P.L.O. was ''a movement wanting to liberate its own country from a foreign occupation.''

title: A QUILT'S LESSON ON LIFE'S RISKS AND LOSSES
description: WE received a patchwork quilt 15 years ago, and even then it was pretty old. My husband's aunt found it in the attic of the family homestead. No one knew how long it had been up there, packed away in an ancient cardboard box. No one even knew who had made it. The initials R. F. E. were embroidered into it, but whose name they stood for no one could remember.

title:
ART;

TWO ARTISTS ON THE CUTTING EDGE
description: MOST university galleries place high priority on exposing their audiences to examples of spirited innovation. The C. W. Post Center's Hillwood Art Gallery, directed by Judy Collischan Van Wagner, has been doing this well in the last few years, presenting a number of creative people whose work seems to be at the cutting edge of artistic ideas.

title: 'THE PRICE' IS RIGHT AT THE GEORGE STREET
description: IT IS no secret that the status of a play is affected by changing times and changing critics.

title: The Biggest State
description: To the Editor:

title: DISORDER AT 4 A.M.
description: THE RELATIVES CAME By Cynthia Rylant. Illustrated by Stephen Gammell. Unpaged. New York: Bradbury Press. $12.95. (Ages 3 to 7) IT'S in summer that the relatives come to visit, setting out from Virginia at 4 in the morning, traveling in an old station wagon that smells ''like a real car,'' drinking soda pop and munching bologna sandwiches along the way. And when they arrive, it's hugging time. (''Talk about hugging! Those relatives just passed us all around their car, pulling us against their wrinkled Virginia clothes, crying sometimes.

title: THE CITY SHUTS A BAR UNDER NEW AIDS RULES
description: In their first attempt to invoke new state rules to combat the spread of AIDS, New York City officials closed a Greenwich Village bar last week. City health inspectors said the bar, called the Mine Shaft, was frequented by homosexuals, some of whom engaged in sex openly. The inspectors also said that, in visits to the bar last weekend, they saw men moving from one sexual partner to another. Such ''high risk'' sexual activity, usually involving homosexuals, is believed to provide the potential for transmission of AIDS, which destroys the immune system.

title: U.S. TO PUSH PLAN TO PAY FOR PRIVATE SCHOOLING
description: The Reagan Administration next week will again propose legislation to provide Federal money in the form of vouchers for poor children to attend private school, according to Education Department officials.

title: How America Changes
description: You have to cross this beautiful continental country in the bracing autumn air to realize that it is really a vast empire in constant change. It cuts you down to size and makes you canny about passing judgment on what the American people think and where they're going.

title: BIDDING ON LONG ISLAND
description: Old Westbury Gardens on Long Island is holding a quiet fund-raising event for its esteemed trees, which include three mile-and-a-half avenues of linden and beech.

title: CHOREOGRAPHIC VIOLENCE MAY BE GETTING OUT OF HAND
description: Just as certain people are worried about whether pop music, films and television have grown too violent, so it may not be long before audiences ask, ''Is dance getting too violent?'' In some ways, they have little to fear. Since no choreographer or theatrical designer can equal the gory details that a film studio's special effects department can devise, dance's level of violence is probably rather low. Nevertheless, one can still worry about choreographic violence, especially at this time when a renewed interest in both Expressionism and social-protest art has led dancers to explore states of emotional unrest and to express opinions on issues with unusual vehemence.

title: MUMS IN PROVIDENCE
description: Odd chrysanthemums - some with petals resembling teaspoons, some shaped to look like little trees and others that cascade from ceiling to floor - are among more than 100 varieties to be seen in a chrysanthemum show in the newly renovated greenhouse complex of Roger Williams Park in Providence, R.I.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: NORWOOD, by Charles Portis. (Vintage, $5.95.) Norwood Pratt is a young former marine who works at a gas station in Ralph, Tex., and aspires to fame and fortune as a country-and-western star. A chance encounter with Grady Fring the Kredit King leads him to New York City; he returns on a bus, meeting the former ''world's-smallest-perfect-man,'' among others. The tale's funniness derives, reviewers said in 1966, from the author's perfect ear for dialogue and ''Norwood's unstinting goodwill in a world of junk.'' BROTHERS AND KEEPERS, by John Edgar Wideman. (Penguin, $6.95.) Two brothers grow up in Pitts-burgh. The older, John Edgar Wideman, becomes a Rhodes scholar and a professor. The younger, Robert Wideman, is convicted of murder and sentenced to life. Last year their story, as told by John Edgar Wideman, was hailed in these words by Ishmael Reed in The Book Review: ''By combining his own literary skill with the candor and vitality of his brother's street style, Mr. Wideman gives added power and dimension to this book about the contrary values and goals of two brothers.'' THE INVENTION OF MOREL: And Other Stories (from ''La Trama Celeste''), by Adolfo Bioy Casares. (University of Texas, $9.95.) The novella, ''The Invention of Morel'' won the 1941 Primer Premio Municipal award in Buenos Aires. Of this translation by Ruth L. C. Simms, Haskel Frankel wrote here in 1964: ''Here is an interesting mind at work, a mind involved with science, philosophy and psychology.

title: A PREFACE
description: TWO VERY DIFFERENT MEN FROM VERY DIFFERENT BACKGROUNDS WILL SOON meet in a little chateau called Fleur d'Eau on the shores of Lake Geneva. This encounter, between Ronald Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev, nine days from now, will mark the first time in more than six years that an American President and a Russian leader have taken the measure of each other at the summit.

title: MCENROE VOTED NICE
description: If you think of him as a demanding, hot-tempered scold, you've been talking to too many umpires.

title: GYM GOLD TO SOVIET
description: Oksana Omeliantchik and Elena Shoushounova of the Soviet Union tied tonight for the gold medal in the women's all-around at the World Gymnastics Championships.

title: CORRECTION
description: A listing accompanying an article on Oct. 13 about London concert halls gave an incorrect number for the Barbican Center. The number is 638-8891.

title: FERRYBOATS, FOR LOW-COST CRUISES
description: Your cabin may not be as large as one on, say, the Rotterdam, and there may not be as impressive a selection of bars or dinner entrees, but the scenery and the salt air will be the same and the fare will usually be a lot less. If such considerations are more important to you than a full complement of amenities, consider taking one of the many trips by ferryboat that offer a low-cost alternative to luxury cruising.

title: BLOOD, GUTS AND EDNA MILLAY
description: INTO ETERNITY The Life of James Jones: American Writer. By Frank MacShane. Illustrated. 355 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $18.95.

title: Portrait Of a French Family
description: I am an American, born in France in May 1940, daughter of Camille Chautemps, who served as Prime Minister of France in the 1930's. I love the United States passionately: it gave us refuge when we fled Europe seeking freedom from the Nazi scourge.

title: ANDREA VISICH WEDS
description: Andrea Jean Visich, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward T. Visich of Washington, N.J., was married there yesterday to Timothy Charles Coumbe, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Coumbe of Westfield, N.J. The Rev. Thomas McCarthy performed the ceremony at Our Lady of Good Counsel Roman Catholic Church.

title: PROTECTING THE WETLANDS FROM CARS, PEOPLE AND ECONOMICS
description: Ringed by scarlet-leafed maples, birches adorned with bright yellow and oaks in rich brown, Leonard Pond is an almost postcard-perfect picture of autumnal New England. But like the migrating Canada geese browsing noisily on its algae-flecked waters, Leonard Pond may soon vanish. The Massachusetts Highway Department is planning to widen Route 57, which links Agawam to Springfield, flinging four lanes of pavement through the wetland from which the pond draws its water.

title: Budget Problems On Cape Cod
description: BIG issues are sometimes thrashed out in small places, but that is cause more for pain than pride in Truro, Mass. The town, with an off-season population of 1,486, has become a focal point of the dilemmas imposed by a state law that limits the ability of municipalities to raise taxes.

title: A NEW STAGE BEGINS FOR BOND-INSURANCE COMPANY
description: IN contrast to the recent spate of unfriendly or downright hostile corporate takeovers, the purchase of the Municipal Insurers Service Corporation of White Plains by the Miami-based Ryder System Inc., announced on Oct. 22, has been characterized by an abundance of good feelings.

title: STREET PEDDLERS FROM SENEGAL FLOCK TO NEW YORK
description: One stands in front of the elegant shops on Fifth Avenue between 57th and 58th Streets, a colorful blanket spread before him piled with Gucci-style bags. Another claims a spot 10 yards down the block, hawking wristwatches laid on a foldable stand. Still another can be found one block farther west, selling batteries and wallets out of a nylon duffel bag.

title: ECHOES OF A PIAZZA IN ROME
description: NAVONA, in Great Neck, has been open just a few months but seems to be enormously popular. There is a full house almost every night and up to an hour's wait for tables at peak times.

title: CORNMEAL, DOMINANT IN COLONIAL BAKING, STILL HAS ITS PLACE
description: CORNMEAL is the traditional American grain, providing the basis for hundreds of recipes from johnnycakes to hush puppies to tortillas. Cornmeal is ground from dried corn and because there is no gluten that can be activated in the grain, it cannot be used to make yeast breads unless another grain, preferably wheat, is added to the recipe. Quick breads leavened with baking powder, baking soda or eggs can easily be made with cornmeal.

title: BATH
description: To the Editor: On a recent visit to Bath, my wife and I attempted to make a dinner reservation at The Hole in the Wall restaurant, which was mentioned favorably in ''A B C's of Shopping and Staying in Bath'' (Travel, Aug. 18). The place was fully booked, but we were able to make a reservation at the Clos de Roy, just a few doors away on George Street.

title: A CULTURAL EQUIVALENT OF BITBERG UNSETTLES WEST GERMANY
description: A decade after it was written by Rainer Werner Fassbinder, ''Garbage, the City and Death'' has been staged for the first time. But the audience at the premiere last week consisted only of carefully chosen theater critics and journalists who were asked to judge whether the play was anti-Semitic.

title: ONE LANGUAGE OR TWO?
description: IN Fillmore, Calif., a farming area 60 miles north of Los Angeles, nearly 100 parents of English-speaking children are embroiled in a dispute with the Fillmore Unified School District over what language will be used to teach their children. School officials, who are reluctant to isolate Spanish-speaking children, have assigned most students to bilingual classes. The parents say their children have a right to be taught in English. ''I don't deny my heritage as a Mexican-American, but the reason that we have achieved what we have in this country is that we speak English,'' said Arthur M. Vasquez, a contractor with two daughters in the Fillmore schools.

title: Donne's Audience
description: To the Editor:

title: NETS SET BACK BUCKS, 126-123
description: The Nets almost blew a 23-point lead tonight before beating the Milwaukee Bucks, 126-123, at the Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: GOD SAVE THIS HONORABLE COURT: How the Choice of Supreme Court Justices Shapes Our History. By Laurence H. Tribe. (Random House, $17.95.) Laurence H. Tribe, Harvard Law School's distinguished constitutional scholar, mentions William Howard Taft more than Ronald Reagan in this short study of the United States Supreme Court. Indeed, there are only seven references to President Reagan in the entire text. Even so, ''The Senate Save This Honorable Court From Ronald Reagan'' might have been a more appropriate and more candid title. Today's Supreme Court, Mr. Tribe notes in his prologue, is the first ever to have a majority of members over the age of 76. Mr. Tribe never comes out and says it, but his point is clear: President Reagan may remake the Court. Mr. Tribe does not talk explicitly about the President's judicial philosophy or the shape of a possible Reagan court. Instead, he combs the history of the High Court for a set of interesting but unstartling propositions that seem disconcertingly applicable to the situation at hand. A single Justice, he notes, can affect the Court profoundly. The narrow literal interpretation of the Constitution prized by conservatives is largely a myth. Most Supreme Court Justices, even Earl Warren, turn out to be pretty much what their benefactors wanted. Selecting Justices on the basis of a single issue - say, abortion or school prayer - is unacceptable. And, perhaps most important, the Senate has both a long tradition and constitutionally mandated duty to scrutinize all High Court nominees closely.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;

BOOKS AND BOOKS
description: For the last decade, the Bryn Mawr Book Shop at 170 Grand Street in White Plains has been a haven for those who, to paraphrase Will Rogers, never met a book they didn't like. Although off the normal paths of the city's shoppers, the store, run by the 200-member Bryn Mawr Alumnae Club of Westchester, has developed a following. During its usual six hours of Monday-through-Saturday operations, the small space, with thousands of donated books in every nook and cranny of its 600 square feet, enjoys a continual stream of customers. Some are dealers who peruse the rare volumes that often turn up, but most are just book addicts seeking a respite today's malls and retail centers.

title: TOPICS
description: CHRISTOPHER MORLEY PARK is a beautiful place in Nassau County with facilities for cookouts and many sports, including tennis, golf, swimming and softball. In addition, it has a large, hilly, wooded retreat.

title: AFFECTIONS OF THE GREEKS
description: THE USE OF PLEASURE The History of Sexuality, Volume Two. By Michel Foucault. Translated by Robert Hurley. 293 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $17.95.

title: TV REPORTER DIES OF INJURIES SUFFERED IN AUTOMOBILE CRASH
description: Dennis Kauff, a television reporter, died Friday at Newton-Wellesley Hospital from injuries he suffered Sunday when the car he was driving was in an accident with a car whose driver was later charged with drunken driving.

title: BATH
description: To the Editor: Missing from Benedict Nightingale's excellent account of Bath's literary past (Travel, Aug. 18) is Moll Flanders, Daniel Defoe's adventurous heroine of ''The Fortunes and Misfortunes of Moll Flanders'' (1722); she enters Bath, ''a place of gallantry enough,'' seeking a husband. There she quickly learns ''men find a mistress sometimes, but very rarely look for a wife.'' Husband No. 4 would take a while to materialize -Moll Flanders found him not in Bath but in Lancashire.

title: A BRILLIANT EFFORT
description: The impact of world politics on the international bridge scene has diminished in the past decade but it has by no means disappeared.

title: AMHERST WINS IN 100TH GAME
description: Continuing a low-key football tradition that began in 1884, Williams met Amherst for the 100th time today. Continuing a more recent tradition, Amherst won for the fifth time in five years with a convincing 35-20 triumph that extended its lead in the series.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

THE GHOSTS ON THE WALK TO SCHOOL
description: THE walk from our apartment house to school seemed long in the 1940's when I was in my first decade of life in Virginia. This past summer when I returned to my old neighborhood to find the apartment house and the school, the landmarks of my youth were almost totally obliterated.

title: ILLUSTRATOR'S WORKS IN RETROSPECTIVE OPENING TODAY
description: THE first major retrospective exhibition of Stevan Dohanos, one of the nation's leading illustrator-artists and a member of Westport's art colony since the 1930's, will open today at the New Britain Museum of American Art.

title: COMPANIES ACT TO AID COCAINE ADDICTS
description: THE first signs may be sudden furtiveness or tardiness on the job. Or frequent trips to the bathroom, or denial -denial of the theft of a co-worker's money or of such behavior as outbursts of temper followed by complacency.

title: WHAT THE RESEARCH SHOWS
description: ONE new research report on bilingual education suggests that Hispanic students need ''good, sparkling teachers'' in order to perform well. Another forthcoming study claims that, contrary to popular assumptions today, elementary children in transitional bilingual programs actually do learn to speak and read English within one or two years - at least in Texas. A third, federally funded research effort under way examines the effectiveness of immersion classes in English, though the researchers were hard put to find many such classes in the nation to study in the first place.

title: PENN STATE (9-0) BEATS CINCINNATI
description: Penn State's much-maligned offense had its highest scoring day of the season, thumping Cincinnati, 31-10, before 33,528 in Riverfront Stadium today. Penn State had the Cincinnati offense to thank for it.

title: AMBASSADOR CONFIRMED
description: There never had been any doubt that once the Senate got to vote, Winston Lord, nominated to be Ambassador to China, would be confirmed by a whopping margin. Mr. Lord was finally approved last week, but it took a phone call from Ronald Reagan to get Jesse A. Helms, the North Carolina Republican, to allow the yeas and nays.

title: READY FOR ANOGHER FLING WITH NO. 2; WARREN E. AVIS
description: ''WHAT'S the purpose of getting up in the morning unless there's excitement,'' asks Warren Avis, sipping a soft drink in his luxurious Fifth Avenue apartment overlooking Central Park.

title: WHY EVERYONE IS MAD AT GOLDOME
description: ROSS KENZIE is a big man with big ideas. He is a force in American banking, a 6-foot, 4-inch former Wall Street executive who took over a stodgy upstate savings institution five years ago and transformed it into the nation's largest mutual savings bank in fast, unorthodox fashion.

title: BOSTON
description: In Boston, this fall is museum season, with a lifetime of paintings by Pierre Auguste Renoir on display at the Museum of Fine Arts and the opening of the critically celebrated Sackler Museum at Harvard University in Cambridge.

title: BOTH SIDES ANTICIPATE SOME TOUGH SUMMIT TALK
description: THE week's fast diplomatic pace was set at the very beginning. It was on Monday that Secretary of State George P. Shultz flew into Moscow, that Izvestia published President Reagan's interview with four Soviet journalists, that Andrei D. Sakharov and his wife telephoned their relatives in Boston and that Vitaly S. Yurchenko, the spy who had come in from the cold, decided he was going back out.

title: RESULTS FAVOR INCUMBENTS IN VOTE MARKED BY LOW TURNOUT
description: THE morning after last week's election, Andrew P. O'Rourke, the newly re-elected Republican County Executive, was back at an old campaign stop, the platform of the White Plains train station, shaking hands with commuters - this time as a victor, not as a candidate.

title:
ANTIQUES;

GETTING TO THE ROOT OF CANALS
description: CANALS not only have inspired farming and navigation, but also have been the inspiration for folk songs, folklorists, historians and collectors and have served as gateways to development and foundations for fortunes.

title: HURRICANE AHEAD ON POINTS
description: OUTSIDE, in the dazzle of the sun on this steamy June day in 1974, the temperature sizzled in the 90's. Inside, two visitors were being screened by a correction officer at the Vroom Building, the maximum-security New Jersey state psychiatric prison in Trenton.

title: AN ENCLAVE IN BIG SUR
description: Cut into mountains that dive operatically into the Pacific, California Route 1 presents consistently sweeping vistas of Big Sur, about 150 miles south of San Francisco - down the coast to a succession of spurs, up the sides of the mountains and out to the vast, swelling ocean. Subtle for its shifts in color, especially at sunset, the Big Sur landscape is nonetheless awesome for its scale.

title: Attitudes on U.N. Were a Black Mark
description: To those of us old enough to remember, the opening paragraphs of the article, ''County Celebrates U.N. Anniversary'' [Oct. 20] , is ironic, to say the least.

title: FARMAID DISTRIBUTES $900,000
description: Seven weeks after the FarmAid benefit concert in Champaign, Ill., about $900,000, roughly a tenth of the amount pledged, has been distributed to farm groups in 22 states from Montana to Florida.

title: FOR BOSTONIANS, 'WILD IN THE STREETS' IS JUST ANOTHER DAY BEHIND THE WHEEL
description: Detective Robert E. O'Toole of the Boston Police Department was recently visiting Oakland, Calif., and while watching for signs on the unfamiliar streets, he found his car blocking a crosswalk when the light changed. The driver behind beeped the horn, backed up, and motioned for Detective O'Toole to back up and clear the crosswalk.

title: A 'Village' Mortgage-Burning Party
description: Most cooperatives find it advantageous to carry a mortgage because of the tax benefits it provides for shareholders. But it doesn't always work out best that way.

title: For the Bicycle Messenger, No Roadbed of Roses
description: To the Editor:

title: THE PRICE OF A GENUINE FAKE
description: The Transit Authority settled last week a three-year-old dispute with Connecticut over the value of a token. Until last month, the token in question, a stamped metal coin, could have been bought for as little as 17 1/2 cents.

title: A DEADLINE ON TOXIC WASTES
description: The Government gave the nation's toxic waste landfills four years to put in pollution monitoring equipment and increase their liability insurance. But as of Friday's deadline, 30 to 40 percent of the 1,575 dumps had failed to comply and therefore might have to be closed down, according to the Environmental Protection Agency.

title: The Thirsty Animal
description: As a recovering alcoholic myself, with seven years of sobriety, I identify strongly with Brian Manning (''The Thirsty Animal,'' About Men, Oct. 13).

title: GENERAL DYNAMICS TALKS REACH TENTATIVE ACCORD
description: A tentative agreement was reached Friday night on a contract between the General Dynamics Corporation and 5,000 workers who have been on strike in three states for almost eight weeks, the United Automobile Workers said.

title: RUTGERS PEACE COLLOQUY SET
description: A PUBLIC conference, ''Star Wars: An Exploration,'' will be held at Rutgers University Saturday from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M.

title: PRIVATE SCHOOLS CRITICIZE STATE EDUCATION PLAN
description: Officials of leading private schools are arguing with the State Education Department over the potential impact of a new program intended to improve education.

title: Conservator Selection Rules Are Sent to State High Court
description: Amended rules for the appointment and payment of conservators and guardians in New York State have been approved by the Administrative Board of the Courts and have been sent to the State Court of Appeals for review, officials said.

title: BUSINESS NOTES
description: MORSE-DIESEL Inc., the construction and consulting company that built the Sears Tower in Chicago and the Pan Am Building in Manhattan, will open an office in Edison tomorrow.

title: BILINGUALISM, CON: OUTDATED AND UNREALISTIC
description: HOW shall we teach the dark-eyed child ingles? The debate continues much as it did two decades ago.

title: MAIMI DEFEATS TERPS, 29-22
description: A 74-yard punt return in the third quarter by Brett Perriman straightened out the Miami team today and pointed the Hurricanes toward a 29-22 victory over Maryland at Memorial Stadium.

title: DR. LYNN RUDICH WED IN STAMFORD
description: Dr. Lynn Karen Rudich, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irwin Rudich of Stamford, Conn., and Dr. Ronald Charles Bezahler, the son of Claire G. Bezahler of New Hyde Park, L.I., and the late Dr. Leonard Bezahler, were married last evening. Rabbi Mordecai Waxman performed the ceremony at Temple Agudath Sholom in Stamford.

title: PERUVIAN REBELS ATTACK U.S. EMBASSY IN LIMA
description: Leftist rebels attacked the United States Embassy here today with dynamite and submachine guns but caused no casualties, the police said.

title: CONTEMPORARY PAINTERS DEVISE A CONCERT PROGRAM
description: Music does not exist in an artistic vacuum. Cross-fertilization between composers and poets has produced masterpieces of opera and song; the vast majority of dance events still use musical scores, and there is a distinguished history of incidental music for theatrical and motion picture productions. Now, another artistic crossover will be explored next Sunday at the Guggenheim Museum, when the chamber music ensemble called An die Musik will present a collaborative event called ''The Painter's Music, The Musician's Art.''

title: On Language;   The Self-Clasping Squeeze
description: DAN RATHER NOTICED IT, and scooped the world by instantly reporting the gesture.

title: THE PLEASURES OF GIVING
description: THE HOLIDAY SEASON is a time both for reflection and cheerful celebration of family and friendship. It is a time for gift giving, emotionally and materially.

title: AQUINO'S WIDOW A NEW FOCUS OF OPPOSITION HOPE
description: As the political opposition struggles to unite behind a single candidate to face President Ferdinand E. Marcos in an early election, the widow of the slain opposition leader Benigno S. Aquino Jr. has moved to the forefront of consideration.

title: BOTH SIDES TROUBLED AFTER GLIMPSING RENT-CODE DRAFT
description: WILLIAM B. EIMICKE, the state's Director of Housing, recently took the first steps towards issuing a revised Rent Stabilization Code, a compilation of the hundreds of rules and procedures governing nearly a million apartments.

title: Hussein's Double Cross
description: When asked if preliminary private talks were under way with Israel, Jordan's King Hussein told my colleague Anthony Lewis on ''Meet the Press'' last week: ''There is no truth whatsoever to this allegation.''

title: PUTTING A DOCTOR ON THE FEDERAL CASE
description: The announcement last week that Otis R. Bowen, a former Governor of Indiana, had been selected to be Secretary of Health and Human Services seemed to symbolize as much as anything the emergence of health care as the pre-eminent policy issue for a department in which health, education and welfare once shared equal billing. Dr. Bowen, a physician, displayed a low-key, avuncular style as chairman of a Federal advisory commission that studied Medicare, the health insurance program for the elderly, in 1982 and 1983. In that role, he probably gained a more intimate knowledge of the program than any prior Secretary of Health and Human Services.

title: WITHIN THE TIMELESS GATES
description: SEASONS OF SPLENDOUR Tales, Myths & Legends of India. By Madhur Jaffrey. Illustrated by Michael Foreman. 128 pp. New York: Atheneum. $15.95. (Ages 5 and up) ONCE upon a time, when the world was young, the daily life of ordinary people was infused with spiritual meaning.

title: CUSTOMERS OF JERSEY CENTRAL TO GET REDUCED ELECTRIC BILLS
description: The return to service of the Three Mile Island Unit 1 nuclear reactor in Pennsylvania will mean a savings of 50 cents a month on the electric bill of the average residential customer of the Jersey Central Power and Light Company, according to the State Public Utility Board.

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: The headline provided by the editors for the cover article of The Times Magazine on Oct. 13, ''The French: Portrait of a Country Through a Family,'' failed to reflect the author's emphasis. Although the writer, Francine du Plessix Gray, explored resonances current in French society, she did not intend to depict her family as characteristic of the French people as a whole.

title: BEJART PREMIER AT CITY CENTER
description: The other day Maurice Bejart was explaining how he happened to create ''Le Concours,'' the work that will be given its first American performance on Wednesday night as the opening event of the Ballet of the 20th Century's engagement at City Center. ''Le Concours'' is a murder mystery that takes place during an international ballet competition.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: AN ARTICLE in Oceanus, the journal of the Massachusetts-based Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution, suggests that most of the methods for restoring and protecting New Jersey's 127 miles of Atlantic Coast beaches are huge wastes of public money, requiring new capital each time a storm takes away another bit of shore.

title:
ANTIQUES;

IMPRESSIONISTS' ART TO BE SOLD
description: ALMOST exactly a century ago, a young Connecticut man, recently graduated from Phillips Academy in Andover, sailed to Germany with several classmates and a tutor to continue his studies. During his two years there, on numerous trips to Paris, the young man, Harris Whittemore of Nagatuck, became enamored of the then new school of painting called Impressionism.

title: LISA J. HELLER IS MARRIED TO HARRY MITCHELL ROTH
description: Lisa J. Heller, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry E. Heller of Port Washington, L.I., and East Hampton, L.I., was married last evening to Harry Mitchell Roth, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Roth of Merion Station, Pa. Rabbis Martin S. Rozenberg and Arthur Schnier co-officiated at the Park East Synagogue in New York.

title: KIDNAPPING SHAKES DUARTE'S AUTHORITY WITH FRIENDS AND FOES
description: Last month, a group of angry army officers accused President Jose Napoleon Duarte of endangering the national security and asked the high command to consider replacing him.

title: EXECUTIVE WED TO MISS SCANLON
description: At the Brick Presbyterian Church in Manhattan yesterday Katherine Ellen Scanlon, a daughter of Mrs. James Patrick Scanlon and the late Dr. Scanlon of Chevy Chase, Md., was married to David Michael Adams, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David P. Adams of Essex Fells, N.J., and Keeseville, N.Y. The Rev. Dr. Herbert Anderson performed the ceremony.

title: ELECTION AFTERMATH: G.O.P. KEEPS POWER
description: DESPITE close economic ties and an often similar pattern of voting in statewide elections, there is an enormous political gap between New York City and Long Island that shows up in local elections, politicians assessing last Tuesday's elections agreed.

title: SPENCER KIMBALL IS EULOGIZED AS A FORCEFUL MORMON LEADER
description: The Mormon Church said goodbye today to Spencer W. Kimball, its president, prophet and spiritual leader for 12 years, who died Thursday at the age of 90.

title: VIEWING LONDON FROM THE INSIDE OUT
description: Mention European canals and most people think of Amsterdam or Venice rather than London. But hidden behind some of London's most fashionable areas - and some of its most industrial - is the Regent's Canal, an eight-and-a-half-mile stretch of waterway that cuts through London and gives visitors a chance to see the city from inside out.

title: BANGLADESH MILL STRIKE ENDS
description: Workers at a jute mill near Dhaka called off a weeklong strike today after talks with President H. M. Ershad, the state radio said. Nearly 26,000 workers of the Adamjee jute mill went on strike over the deduction of advance pay given them in August. The police opened fire when several hundred strikers refused to leave the mill, and two workers were killed.

title: ENTERPRISE ZONE ATTRACTING BUSINESSES
description: FOUR members of the Region II office of the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development toured this city's 2,400-acre Urban Enterprise Zone last month, seeking information to promote the concept in New York. (Region II embraces New Jersey, New York, Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands.) The four visited six businesses that either have moved to Newark or expanded here to take advantage of the city's Urban Enterprise Zone designation. All told, 218 businesses have expressed such plans.

title: U.N. REFUGEE AGENCY WARNS OF MONEY CRISIS
description: The office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, citing a severe financial crisis, will appeal for urgent contributions from donor nations at a pledging conference to be held in New York next Friday.

title: JEAN KAREN GLASSNER WED TO STEVEN CHARLES BORTNER
description: Jean Karen Glassner, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. David Glassner of Milwaukee, and Steven Charles Bortner, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Allen Bortner of Albertson, L.I., were married yesterday at Congregation Emanu-El B'ne Jeshurun in Miwaukee.

title: ON THE ART OF TEACHING WRITING
description: Dr. Davidson seems to have written an expressive piece that she has failed to revise and edit. A number of sentences might be considered awkward, and there are two dangling participles (it seems to me that doctorates in writing research from Rutgers University who do not write carefully should avoid publication in The New York Times).

title: CAMPUS CONCERTS IN FULL SWING
description: THE universities and conservatories of Connecticut continue to offer a diverse source of concert activity. There are not only numerous student or faculty recitals - usually free or at nominal cost - but also series that bring first-rate ensembles and soloists to the state.

title: A JAPANESE TRIBUTE TO AN ANDOPTED SON
description: Toward the turn of the century, the expatriate American writer Lafcadio Hearn liked to watch the sun set in Matsue from a noodle shop by the shore of Lake Shinji. At dusk the mountains surrounding the city lose their definition and color. They turn from green to black to a shade that has no color at all. It is an unexceptional sunset; there is no blaze or fireball. Mist settles over the hills. A band of sun cuts across the lake. Then the lake turns gray.

title: CELTICS BEAT PISTONS
description: Larry Bird scored 29 points and Kevin McHale added 28 tonight to lead the Boston Celtics to a 124-105 victory over the Detroit Pistons.

title: REFRIGERATOR TURNS ON HUNGRY PUBLIC
description: AFTER a columnist wrote that William (The Refrigerator) Perry has a gap between his front teeth, three dentists called the Chicago Bears to say they would perform cosmetic dental surgery at no cost.

title: SOLVING NEW YORK CITY'S TRAFFIC RIDDLES: IDEAS FROM EXPERTS
description: Transportation experts and traffic engineers may or may not be good drivers. Their specialty, however, is back-seat driving.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;

EVERY TUESDAY NIGHT, THE GAME OF LIFE
description: ALMOST every Tuesday night from October to May, we get together at the local junior high school to play full-court basketball. Originally, I played to savor the sensation of movement, to get all lathered with sweat, to feel my temples pulse with the rush of fresh blood. I wanted to compete and keep fit.

title: HEMPSTEAD IS TIED BY MASAPEQUA
description: Hempstead was dealt the first blemish to its record when it was tied yesterday by Massapequa, a team seeded ninth in Nassau's Conference I at the beginning of the season.

title: ANDUJAR STAYING PUT
description: Joaquin Andujar may have lost his composure in the seventh game of the World Series, but despite rumors, the pitcher hasn't lost his job with the St. Louis Cardinals. ''Why would we trade him?'' asked General Manager Dal Maxvill. ''He won 21 games for us.''

title: WOMEN IN WAR SEEK STUDY ON AGENT ORANGE
description: Women who served as civilians in the Vietnam War are pressing for Government recognition that they may have developed health problems because of exposure to Agent Orange.

title: ANDREA MARIE HAWKINS PLANS TO WED IN JANUARY
description: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Donald Hawkins of White Plains have announced the engagement of their daughter, Andrea Marie Hawkins, to Steven Bennett Stuart, a son of Frederick Ernest Stuart Jr. of Baltimore and the late Jane Lloyd Stuart. The wedding is planned for Jan. 18.

title: COST TO FIX BUSES ASSESSED
description: BY the end of this month, state transportation officials say they hope to have an estimate of the cost of repairing 97 Grumman Flxible buses that were purchased in 1979 but have remained idle for five years.

title: WHEN TV LOOKS AT SCHOOLS, THE LESSONS CAN BE MURKY
description: Everyone argues about the public schools; during the past 20 years, it has become part of the American tradition. Why can't Johnny read? What about drugs and violence? Busing destroys our neighborhoods; busing brings us together. Some arguments are more rewarding than others, while the argument that is the bitterest, most protracted and noisiest is the one that is least rewarding of all. The paradox is that it may also be the most important. Who's in charge of the moral, political, social and intellectual environment in our schools? In short, who runs things? ''Public Schools in Conflict: A Question of Values,'' an ABC News special at 12:30 this afternoon, never quite puts the argument that way, but it runs like a thread through the program.

title: THE VIEW FROM AMERICA
description: ONE DAY LAST SUMMER, my family and I were wandering through a small museum in Concord, Mass., when we came to a diorama depicting the historic clash between British redcoats and American colonists at North Bridge. There, on a miniature landscape, toy soldiers faced each other across a tiny battlefield at the opening of the American Revolution. My 8-year-old son, Michael, pointed to one of the little redcoats that had been tipped over on its side. ''Look,'' he said, ''a dead Russian.'' Then he caught himself, laughed and shook his head at his slip. ''I mean, British soldier.''

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS
description: Nov. 10, 1985 Fiction

title: BILINGUALISM, PRO: THE KEY TO BASIC SKILLS
description: IF we accept that a child cannot learn unless taught through the language he speaks and understands; that a child who does not speak or understand English must fall behind when English is the dominant medium of instruction; that one needs to learn English so as to be able to participate in an English-speaking society; that self-esteem and motivation are necessary for effective learning; that rejection of a child's native language and culture is detrimental to the learning process: then any necessary effective educational program for limited or no English-speaking ability must incorporate the following:

title: AN ALL-WEATHER IDEA
description: SCIENTIST, INVENTOR, ENTREPREneur, sportsman, family man: Wilbert L. Gore not only fits the descriptions, he has combined the roles in a remarkable business enterprise that epitomizes what, in more innocent times, might have been called the American Dream.

title: FEVER CHARTS OF THE 1960's
description: THE COLLECTED POEMS OF PAUL BLACKBURN Edited and with an introduction by Edith Jarolim. 687 pp. New York: Persea Books. $37.50.

title: GROUND WATER IS FOCUS OF CONCERN
description: ''IT'S out of sight and out of mind, but when you turn on the faucet you take it for granted something will come out,'' Ann McDuffie, a director of the Regional Review League, said last week. She warned, however, that ground water in the area, the main water supply for northern Westchester and Putnam Counties, was threatened.

title: GIANTS, RAMS: MUCH IN COMMON
description: The teams that will meet in Giants Stadium Sunday have sound, stingy defenses that discourage opponents from running. They have solid running games that have allowed them to control the ball. They have good punters. They have punt returners who have set up scoring drives with their returns. And they have winning records.

title: Portrait Of a French Family
description: Francine du Plessix Gray aims to probe the ''national consciousness'' of her native land by immersing herself in a ''quintessentially French family'' (''The French: Portrait of a Country Through a Family,'' Oct. 13). Such an exploration is difficult in any society, but impossible in France, where diversity is the quintessence of national life and where the Monestier family at La Croze represents not ''France,'' but a peculiarly rich and fascinating tradition of the French conservative Right - often heroic and humane, at times xenophobic and intolerant.

title: JEWS URGED TO SUPPORT CONVERTS IN MARRIAGES
description: American Jews should actively encourage spouses in interfaith marriages to convert to Judaism, a New York sociologist told the American Jewish Committee's executive council here Friday.

title: BOY ,7, SHOOTS BROTHER, 4
description: A 4-year-old Brooklyn boy was wounded in the stomach yesterday afternoon by a handgun fired accidentally by his 7-year-old brother, the police said. The boy was stable last night at Wyckoff Hospital. The gun was owned by the boys' father, Zacharias Perez, 30, of 280 Suydam Street in the Bushwick section, who was charged with illegal weapons possession.

title: UNSER EDGES SON FOR TITLE
description: Al Unser pulled up beside his son, Al Jr., at the end of the Beatrice Indy Challenge today and the two drivers looked briefly at each other, waved and moved on.

title: A G.O.P. BONUS IN KEAN'S SWEEP
description: NO Republican Speaker has called the New Jersey Assembly to order since 1973, when Thomas H. Kean, then an Assemblyman from Livingston, held the gavel. Last week Mr. Kean won his second term as Governor in a landslide so powerful that it wiped out the Democratic majority in the lower house, paving the way for another Republican to ascend to the Speaker's podium. Mr. Kean carried every county, with a coattails sufficient to transform the Democrats' 44-to-36 Assembly margin into an overwhelming Republican majority of 50 to 30.

title: LOOKING BACK ON THE WORLD OF TOMORROW
description: WORLD'S FAIR By E. L. Doctorow. 288 pp. New York: Random House. $17.95.

title: THE INS AND OUTS OF COLONIAL FURNITURE
description: The 18th-century American furniture exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art is a mini-feast of masterpieces in the sort of people-oriented presentation that collectors long to see in museums, but rarely do.

title: MUSIC: IRISH CHAMBER GROUP
description: IT was a busy time for musical Ireland in New York last week - an interesting debut by Suzanne Murphy at the New York City Opera on Wednesday and on Friday night an appearance by the New Irish Chamber Orchestra at the Metropolitan Museum.

title: ON THE PARIS STAGE, TWO HITS WITH AMERICAN ACCENTS
description: The Paris season, which promises to be rich and varied, started out with a marked American infiltration of the cultural scene. First came Christo's irreverent and witty wrapping of the ancient Pont-Neuf. Then Parisians celebrated the dedication of two public sculptures by Richard Serra, including his 35-foot-tall, 100-ton assemblage, ''Slat,'' erected at the edge of the high-rise business suburb of La Defense.

title: OUTSIDE NEW YORK CITY, THE DROUGHT IS FADING
description: With at least one big exception, New York City, the great Eastern drought of 1985 appears to have eased significantly in the last seven weeks.

title: VATICAN SEEMS TO EASE STAND ON NUNS ON ABORTION
description: Officials of the Roman Catholic Church have begun accepting private ''clarifications'' from some of the two dozen American nuns who were ordered last year to publicly retract a statement that questioned the church's stand against abortion.

title: GOVERNMENT SET TO ISSUE NEWLY DESIGNED CHECKS
description: Millions of Americans will receive newly designed checks from the Government next month.

title: FIGHTING ARTHRITIS WITH EXERCISE
description: ARTHRITIS is becoming an increasing problem on Long Island as the population gets older, experts say.

title: FRANKLIN WHITEHOUSE, REPORTER FOR THE TIMES
description: Franklin S. Whitehouse Jr., a reporter for The New York Times and a former member of The New York Times Company's corporate relations staff, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home in Bronxville, N.Y. He was 51 years old.

title:
GARDENING;

FERNS ADD TOUCH OF GREENERY TO INDOORS
