description: THOSE of us who have been around for a half-century or more may remember the bay window where our grandmother or mother kept a giant Boston fern in a wicker plant stand. There was something elegant about this combination. It was several notches above the level of growing a common geranium on the windowsill. And when guests came for Sunday dinner, they would admire this evidence of the hostess's green thumb.

title: A Word on the Care At the Osborn Home
description: In the Westchester Journal of Oct. 6 you published a very nice picture of Mrs. Gertrude Lowe with a kitten. This demonstrated Dr. Gary Yarnell's program of Pets Along With Seniors.

title: SHOREHAM PLANT AND STORM CLEANUP
description: It would be quite silly for people who are not nuclear physicists to get into a serious conflict over Shoreham, but as your article [''New Criticism for Lilco in Storm's Wake,'' Oct. 20] points out, the hurricane brought us to this conflict.

title: Q AND A
description: Question:I recently took my first global trip and would like to meet others who have had this experience. Do you know of any group or club exclusively for those who have traveled completely around the world? -B. T. P., New York Answer:The Circumnavigators Club, which was founded by two Americans in 1902, is an international organization devoted to bringing together travelers who have circled the globe. Helen Jost, executive secretary of its international headquarters in New York, says there are 10 chapters in other parts of the United States and 5 overseas. The total of more than 1,000 members includes those who belong to the international headquarters, which holds six to eight luncheon or dinner meetings a year. The guest of honor at the next meeting, a dinner at the Union League Club in New York on Thursday, will be the astronaut Sally Ride. She will be presented with the club's Order of Magellan, which is awarded to global travelers who have made a contribution to international understanding.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: PRESUMMIT DISCUSSION Stanley R. Resor - Under Secretary of the Army from 1965 to 1971, and head of the United States delegation to the negotiations between North Atlantic Treaty Organization and the Warsaw Pact bloc from 1973 to 1978 -and Vladimir Shustov of the Soviet mission to the United Nations, a career diplomat in the field of arms control - will meet at Manhattanville College for a public discussion Wednesday at 8 P.M. in Reid Hall.

title: Boston Ballet Faces Bias Charge
description: A Massachusetts agency is trying to negotiate a settlement in the case of a 16-year-old black dancer who contends that the Boston Ballet discriminated against her by denying her a place in a training program.

title: Q AND A
description: Taxes On A Vacant Lot Question: I made an application last year and this year for a tax reduction of 50 percent on a lot I own in Carmel, N. Y. My income is less than $10,500 and I am 67 years old, yet I have been denied twice. Can you tell me why, and refer me to someone who can help? . . . J. M., Bronxville Answer: In Carmel, a resident aged 65 or over can receive an exemption for 50 percent of his property taxes if his income is $10,500 or less; proportional exemptions can be obtained if the income is up to $13,500. However, the exemption is for a legal residential property occupied by the owner, and a vacant lot does not qualify regardless of your age or income. If you have additional questions, call Anthony Randina, the Carmel assistant tax assessor, at 1 (914) 628-1500. He is available 9 to 5 Monday to Friday or by appointments on weekends. Smoke-Alarm Maintenance Question: My landlord installed two smoke alarms, for which I paid $10 each. When the batteries wear out, do I replace them or does the landlord? . . . B. S., Manhattan Answer: The city's Housing Maintenance Code says that after the first year the tenant must maintain Redinger the smoke alarm, according to Frank Dell'Aria, assistant commissioner in the Department of Housing Preservation and Development. This means the tenant must replace dead batteries at his own expense. Notification of Co-op Sale Question: What government agencies are notified when a co-op apartment is sold in New York? . . . H. C., Manhattan Answer: When a co-op is sold in New York State, a capital-gains transfer-tax affidavit must be filed with the State Department of Taxation and Finance.

title: SHIFTY WAS A RAILBIRD
description: THE HARD KNOCKER'S LUCK By William Murray. 265 pp. New York: Viking. $14.95.

title: U.S. TAKES TEAM-GOLF TITLE
description: Ray Floyd and Calvin Peete helped the American team win five of six matches from the Europeans and restored a measure of lost prestige with a lopsided victory today in the inaugural Nissan Cup World Championship.

title: REAGAN, IN SPEECH TO SOVIET PUBLIC, SAYS AIM IS PEACE
description: President Reagan, in a speech broadcast to the Soviet Union, said today that the United States had no hostile intentions and that the two sides must never engage in a nuclear conflict.

title: A BOLD AND INTRACTABLE BEAST
description: THE STORY OF MRS. LOVEWRIGHT AND PURRLESS HER CAT By Lore Segal. Illustrated by Paul O. Zelinsky. Unpaged. New York: Alfred A Knopf. $12.95. (Ages 5 to 9) MRS. LOVEWRIGHT, in this brief, enchanting, alarming and funny-profound children's book by Lore Segal fails to extract coziness from her cat, hopefully christened Purrly, but presently, more appropriately, renamed Purrless. The story, illustrated by Paul O. Zelinsky, is likely to please both children and adults. Children prefer the vulgarity and energy of reality; the adults (who hand over the money and so usually win) like to have created, on the page, a discreet and beautiful world for the children to inhabit. Mr. Zelinsky manages both, with verve and skill, and I tell you it's delightful - if alarming.

title: GHOST OF 'MR. EDDIE ' BARS INTRUDERS AT POE'S HOUSE
description: The street gangs around the inner city Poe Project here do not consider the old house at 203 North Amity Street part of their territory. It's protected by a lone raven and, they say, the ghost of ''Mr. Eddie.''

title: PHEBE A. LIU WED TO STEPHEN J. GARVIN
description: The marriage of Phebe Allison Liu, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Meung-ta Liu of New York and Hong Kong, to Stephen Joseph Garvin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter F. Garvin Jr. of Dover, Mass., took place yesterday. The Rev. John W. Payne, a Disciples of Christ minister, performed the ceremony at the Park Avenue Christian Church.

title: NEW CASSETEES: TRUFFAUT, BIZET AND JOHN BLEUSHI
description: The Best of John Belushi Starring John Belushi, with the original cast of 'Saturday Night Live'; and Robert Klein, Buck Henry, Elliott Gould and Rob Reiner Warner Home Video 60 minutes. $24.95 The samurai slashes a corned beef, splits opens a loaf of bread by smashing it to his forehead and has to be restrained from committing hara-kiri because he didn't make his corned beef lean.

title: BEST SELLERS
description: Nov. 10, 1985 Fiction

title: DOLL MAKER CREATES CAST OF CHARACTERS
description: AS the legend of the black stick sisters goes, one sister, a free spirit, released a molting buffalo from a nature center and took it out West to be free. The other, more conservative sister, motivated by responsibility and family propriety spent her life trying to find her recalcitrant sister.

title: ''HURRICANE,'' PART II
description: Rubin (Hurricane) Carter is a free man. Again. Twice convicted for the 1966 murder of three people in a Paterson, N.J., bar, Mr. Carter, once a ranking middleweight boxer, is now twice released.

title: SUSANNE LYN DEMING BECOMES A BRIDE
description: Susanne Lyn Deming, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Wilson Deming of Summit, N.J., was married there yesterday to Edward Kent von der Linde, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gert von der Linde of Madison, N.J. The Rev. Dr. William Phillippe performed the ceremony at the Central Presbyterian Church.

title: COPYRIGHT BY MIKHAIL GORBACHEV: HIS WORK IS MAKING AMERICAN DEBUT
description: Only days before the summit meeting with President Reagan, a New York publishing house is bringing out a book that identifies Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, as author.

title: NEW CASSETEES: TRUFFAUT, BIZET AND JOHN BLEUSHI
description: Fahrenheit 451 Starring Julie Christie, Oscar Werner, Cyril Cusack; directed by Francois Truffaut, 1966 MCA Home Video 112 minutes. $59.95 This adaptation of a Ray Bradbury story is one of Francois Truffaut's least characteristic movies, but also one of his most personal.

title: Who Jacked Up the Price?
description: FOR THE past several months I have been trying to buy a new car. I should have got it bought months ago and moved on to the task of buying the new suit that would have been bought three years ago by any man capable of feeling shame for his appearance, but buying a car has presented paralyzing psychological problems.

title: BRYANT PARK GUNMAN IS STILL SOUGHT
description: It started as a confrontation between two men inside Bryant Park at 42d Street and the Avenue of the Americas. It ended in a quick series of shots as one of the men opened fire and the other fled.

title: BUSINESS LOANS
description: To the Editor:

title: COMMUNITY GROUPS GET COMPUTER HELP
description: THE COMMUNITY SOUP KITCHEN in New Haven needed a computer to keep track of donations, mailing lists and hours worked by welfare recipients as part of the state's ''workfare'' program, according to its director.

title: AIR FORCE ROUTS ARMY BY 45-7
description: Bart Weiss threw a 64-yard touchdown pass to Ken Carpenter and ran for two other scores today as undefeated Air Force gained its 13th straight victory and probably improved upon its already high national ranking by trouncing Army, 45-7.

title: MISS MCDONNELL ENGAGED TO WED
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Barrington Boardman of Greenwich, Conn., of the engagement of Mrs. Boardman's daughter Michela McDonnell to Jay Stewart, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James Stewart of Concord, N.H.

title: BUSINESSMEN ACT TO AID NEW YORK
description: When David Rockefeller agreed in 1979 to head the New York City Partnership, he undertook a formidable task.

title: Doctor Delivers Girl, But 'Womb' Is a Can
description: Robyn Daigneault, 2 years old, got stuck inside a 40-quart milk can and was rescued only after a doctor decided to upend the can and deliver her like a baby.

title: U.N. STALWART FOR 40 YEARS PLANS TO RETIRE
description: The books and United Nations memorabilia are being packed, and Under Secretary General Brian E. Urquhart is preparing to retire after 40 years with the world body.

title: The Thirsty Animal
description: As an alcoholic entering his third year of sobriety, I congratulate Brian Manning for quitting drinking two years ago. However, a sober alcoholic need not be a zoo keeper, devoting his life's energies to caging a thirsty animal. He can be a genie, freed from his imprisoning bottle, using his sobriety to create new magic in his life. THEODORE V. KREPS Washington

title: Artists' Housing
description: EXTOLLING artists as ''one of our city's primary social and economic resources,'' Mayor Koch announced a program last December to turn unused city buildings into 180 studios for such artists as sculptors, painters, actors and musicians.

title: YOUTH, 18, HELD IN DEATHS OF PARENTS AND 3 SIBLINGS
description: A teen-ager was charged today with five counts of murder in the deaths of his parents, two brothers and a sister, the police said.

title: TO CUT BILLS FOR COLLEGE: A LITTLE CONDO
description: MOST parents don't make money on their children going to college, but when Catherine L. Miller needed a place to live during her sophomore year at the University of Texas at Austin, her father invested in the local real-estate market. The deal pleased both - she moved into a condominium complete with pool, Jacuzzi and microwave oven, and he, while ''hoping the condo's value would increase,'' earned tax breaks and rentals both from his daughter's roommates and from other renters who used the apartment when school was not in session.

title: THE PARADOXICAL SIR TRAMP
description: CHAPLIN His Life and Art. By David Robinson. Illustrated. 792 pp. New York: McGraw-Hill Book Company. $24.95.

title: REAGAN SPEECH IS HEARD CLEARLY INMOSCOW
description: President Reagan's weekly radio address, aimed particularly to the Soviet Union today, could be heard clearly in Russian and English on short-wave receivers here.

title: SURVIVAL TIPS FOR WOMEN IN LOS ANGELES
description: There are some things the guidebooks do not tell you about Los Angeles.

title: CONSUMER RATES
REFLECTIONS ON FAULTS PAST, PRESENT AND, PROBABLY, FUTURE
description: MAYBE New Yorkers don't lie to the income tax people, or smuggle odds and ends through customs, or write off friends they think they've outgrown, or cancel appointments when something better comes up. Maybe they're not piranhas in business and they never steal other people's friends and spouses. Or maybe they don't consider there's anything particularly wrong with any of the above. Then again, it may be that there are certain things they're never going to admit in public, although the way things are going these days it's almost unfashionable to keep anything private.

title: TWO SLOW STARTERS WHO ENDED IN GLORY
description: Collectors come in all shapes and sizes, as we know. They also develop in different ways and at different speeds. Some of them burn out fast.

title: BURGER COURT IS EXAMINED AT L.I. PARLEY
description: Several hundred lawyers, international jurists, law professors and students from across the country gathered on the Hofstra University campus here to discuss the 16 years of the United States Supreme Court under the leadership of Chief Justice Warren E. Burger.

title: JARUZELSKI TAKES ANOTHER ROLE
description: To the ordinary Pole, last week's changes in the official hierarchy will probably not mean much, but it may make things easier for No. 1. Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, who headed both the Government and the Communist Party, relinquished the former position but held on to the latter, where the basic power lies. He also assumed the presidency, which is likely to become less ceremonial.

title: FOR SOVIET-AMERICAN COUPLE, MEMORIES DIM AFTER 11 YEARS
description: The photographs of each other that Irina and Woodford McClellan keep are faded and outdated, worn mementos of a marriage that was defeated by a government.

title: SUBMARINERS RECALL THE DANGERS
description: WHEN Frank O'Brien recalls the effect of depth charges, he closes his eyes and lets the memories come flooding back.

title: KASPAROV, 22, DEFEATS KARPOV FOR CHESS TITLE
description: Gary Kasparov wrested the world chess crown from Anatoly Karpov today with a stunning victory in the last game of their 14-month struggle, becoming at 22 the youngest champion in the history of the game.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: HOLLARAN'S WORLD WAR. By Tim Mahoney. (Delacorte, $14.95.) A spate of recent Vietnam novels have handled the subject in various ways, but ''Hollaran's World War'' may be the first to approach it with whimsy. Tom Hollaran is a character we've seen a lot of lately, the troubled veteran who can't adjust. Questioned about his war experience, he'll say little more than, ''Absurd. It was just stupid.'' ''Absurd'' is the word that best describes his failures back home - marriage, social life, job. Worst and silliest of all, he can't get well, despite two V.A. psychiatrists. Hollaran is likable, and his helplessness all the more poignant, because he faces his difficulties with more irony than self-pity. Yet though his road to recovery is checkered with pratfalls, the roots of his problems are serious. Like many Vietnam veterans he feels let down by the nation, but the betrayal that matters most to him is personal - his wife's desertion during his tour. That private breach of faith makes Hollaran vengeful; his confrontations with Sandra and her new lover, comical at first, soon get him in trouble with the law. Enactment of hostility is undertaken on a grander scale by Hollaran's only friend, the monosyllabic Eddie Sadowski, who builds a private war machine to wreak vengeance on the ''bozos'' who sent him into battle. Once they are harmlessly channeled, these impulses prove survivable and purgative for both men, and it is in this kind of reliance on psychiatric truism that the book is least interesting.

title: POLICE HELP PARENTS IDENTIFY NARCOTICS
description: THE Easton Police Department has started a program in which parents anonymously submit drugs that they suspect their children are taking for analysis by the police.

title: NEWS AGENCY'S LIKELY BUYERS NARROWED TO 3
description: Intense negotiations have been under way in Washington for a week aimed at finding a new buyer for United Press International, the news agency that has been struggling for six months to escape bankruptcy.

title: ANOTHER CHARGE OF CONFLICT
description: The relations between Government officials and their previous employers and friends have been an intermittent source of embarrassment for almost every Administration. For the Reagan Administration, intermittently, they have been more so than for many.

title: LIONS ROUTED BY 34-3, GO TO 0-8
description: The embarrassing moments were abundant again for Columbia yesterday in the last football game of the season at Baker Field.

title: MARTHA QUAINI GALLI WEDS
description: Martha Beatrice Quaini Galli, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Roger Oscar Quaini of Bay Shore, L.I., and Buenos Aires, was married yesterday to Friedrich Otto Hoffmann, a son of Irma Berta Miehe Hoffmann of Frankfurt and the late Ernst Josef Hoffmann. Msgr. Robert Emmet Fagan performed the ceremony at St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church in Bay Shore. Mrs. Hoffmann is an assistant vice president in the international private banking division of BankAmerica International in New York. Her husband is a vice president of the New York branch of Commerzbank, Aktiengessellschaft.

title: Unfair Taxation
description: To the Editor:

title: WAR FILMS DEPICT JAPAN AS A MISUNDERSTOOD VICTIM
description: The enormous success of ''Rambo: First Blood Part II'' served to prove what Japanese film makers have long known: there's money to be made from returning to the scene of a military defeat.

title: BUSINESS AND SCHOOLS TEAM UP IN STAMFORD
description: Private industry and public schools are teaming up in Stamford to improve the quality of science education in seventh, eighth and ninth grades.

title: NATHANAEL WEST INSPIRED YOU
description: THE COLOR OF THE AIR Scenes From the Life of an American Jew, Volume One. By John Sanford. 301 pp. Santa Barbara, Calif.: Black Sparrow Press. Cloth, $20. Paper, $12.50. TOWARD the end of this packed and vivid memoir of his years from 1904 to 1927 - set forth in 171 numbered, titled and dated scenes - the author quotes a remark that was to transform his life and wake his psyche, like a fairy-tale princess, from a 12-year sleep: ''I'm writing a book, Nat Weinstein had said, and ever since, through the course of more than a year, the words had been in suspension near the surface of your mind.'' The year was 1926, and the mind was that of the 22-year-old John Sanford, who prefers in this narrative, despite a strong ego and distinctive opinions, to call himself ''you.'' The book Weinstein announced was published five years later as ''The Dream Life of Balso Snell.'' By then its author was known as Nathanael West.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE DANCER AND THE DANCE: Merce Cunningham in Conversation With Jacqueline Lesschaeve. (Marion Boyars, $27.50.) At the outset of this collection of lively and readable conversations on dance, Merce Cunningham compares his art form to water.

title: MISTRIAL IN SPY CASE
description: Lawyers for Richard W. Miller had set out to portray him as perhaps the Federal Bureau of Investigation's biggest bumbler but not a man who would betray his country.

title: STATE PARTIES SPLIT ON VOTE INDICATIONS
description: SEVERAL upset victories led both state Republican and Democratic leaders to declare last week that Tuesday's municipal elections have strengthened their positions for 1986 races.

title: EDUCATIONAL 'KID-VID'
description: AT THE FLICK of a switch on a VCR, children at home can now tune into a new kind of learning experience: video cassettes that are designed to offer a pleasant and engaging mixture of video entertainment and traditional education.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE IMPERIAL WAY. By Paul Theroux and Steve McCurry. (Houghton Mifflin, $19.95.) The railways of the British Raj have long served as India's lifeline.

title:
SPORTS OF THE TIMES;

STOP WILLIAM PERRY
description: WHETHER Pete Rozelle knows it or not, the National Football League is facing the most severe crisis in its history. The league has survived rival leagues, franchise shifts, threats of antitrust laws, illegal steroids and other drugs in the medicine cabinet. It has even survived Al Davis as opponent and associate.

title: ALCOHOL CRISIS CENTER IS PLANNED FOR COUNTY
description: THE state's Division of Alcoholism and Alcohol Abuse has committed $400,000 for the establishment of what would be the county's first alcohol crisis center, according to an agency spokesman. An additional $200,000 has been committed to underwrite operating expenses for the center, which the agency said should be operating by the end of next year.

title: TIME TO FORM 'EASTERN SEVEN'
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: TRANSIT GRANT WILL FINANCE STUDIES, 65 BUSES
description: THE county's Transportation Department, recently enriched by $17.4 million, is drawing up specifications for 65 replacement buses that it plans to order for the public transportation system.

title: OVERRULLING THE VOICE FROM HEAVEN
description: A LIVING COVENANT The Innovative Spirit in Traditional Judaism. By David Hartman. 340 pp. New York: The Free Press. $22.50.

title: MEETING ADULT NEEDS
description: OFTEN they wake before dawn to put in a full day's work or manage a household of small children before reporting for college classes. Many return home near midnight, red-eyed and weary, after spending the evening in college libraries.

title: U.C.L.A. BOLSTERS ROSE BOWL HOPES
description: Gaston Green scored three touchdowns, the last on a 1-yard dive late in the third quarter, as U.C.L.A. held on to beat Arizona, 24-19, in a pivotal Pacific-10 Conference game tonight.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: All of It Below Wholesale John Mendez Inc. is an importer and wholesaler of natural fiber British-made clothing and furnishings for men and women, with eight years of experience with Manhattan warehouse sales of samples, end-of-the-line quantities and shipments returned for arriving too late, all of it first quality. This year's sale is at the Mamaroneck warehouse Friday, Saturday and Sunday, from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. - cash only and every transaction is a final sale. The move-it-out prices are $2 to less than $100, decidedly below wholesale.

title: SEA LAMPREY ATTACKING FISH IN LAKE CHAMPLAIN
description: The sea lamprey, an eel-like predator that wounds or kills other fish by sucking their blood, is becoming an increasing menace in Lake Champlain, according to fish experts in New York and Vermont.

title: Staying Warm
description: To the Editor:

title: JETS' GLENN, 5-9, LEAPS TO SUCCESS
description: It is only an illusion. The 5-foot-9-inch Kerry Glenn is not leaping higher than the crossbar on the goalposts to bat away passes, but he is getting close.

title: WHEN FARM INTERESTS CLASH WITH THE BUDGET
description: THERE is nothing indirect about Senator Mark Andrews. The North Dakota Republican has three items at the top of his priority list: farmers, farmers and farmers.

title: LAETITIA STOCK IS WED TO DR. J. D. ABRAMSON
description: Laetitia Ann Stock, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Stock of Detroit, and Dr. Jonathan Daniel Abramson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Abramson of New York, were married last evening. Rabbi David Greenberg officiated at the Brooklyn Club.

title: EXPANDED ART CENTER OPENS
description: AFTER 10 years of growth and development and one year of intense fund raising, the Pelham Art Center on Friday will open the doors of a new $425,000 addition that more than doubles its gallery exhibition area.

title: DID CASANOVA LEND A HELPING HAND?
description: Of all the stories that have attached themselves to Giovanni Giacomo Casanova de Seingalt, some twisted versions of which thicken the plot of ''Casanova,'' Dominick Argento's captivating new opera at the State Theater, none is more fascinating than the possibility that the infamous 18th-century libertine himself may have had a hand in touching up the libretto of ''Don Giovanni.'' There is no mention of that legend in the New York City Opera's production, which is understandable: the action in the work takes place in 1774, or 13 years before Mozart and his librettist, Lorenzo da Ponte, produced their opera in Prague.

title: BIRTHDAY BOY
description: GOOD GRIEF! Charlie Brown, moon-faced nice guy and quintessential fall guy (who, after all, runs at a football he knows is going to pulled away at the last millisecond by the quintessential nemisis Lucy?) is 35 years old.

title: EXTER TRIUMPHS
description: Reginald Sellars rushed 207 yards and scored three touchdowns to lead Exeter to a 21-7 victory over Andover yesterday in the 106th contest in the longest-running high school football rivalry in the country. The game was played at Alonzo Stagg Field in Exeter, N.H., before 6,000 fans.

title: BELYAVSKY TRIUMPHS WITH A DELICATE TOUCH
description: The 31-year-old Russian grandmaster Aleksandar Belyavsky won the Ninth LLoyds Bank Masters Tournament in London with a 7 1/2-1 1/2 score. He topped a Swiss-system field of 159 players from 21 countries to capture the first prize of $1,732.80.

title: A WOULD-BE DEFECTOR SAILS WITH HIS SHIP
description: THE leaders of the world's two most powerful nations, maneuvering cautiously toward the summit, were distracted again last week by the case of a 22-year-old Ukrainian sailor. Miroslav Medved, who jumped off a Soviet freighter in the Mississippi River and was sent back to his ship by United States authorities, had become a major embarrassment. Yesterday, the vessel was allowed to leave - with Mr. Medved - despite attempts by Senator Jesse Helms, the conservative North Carolina Republican, and his Agriculture Committee to require another interrogation of the sailor.

title: TESTS ENTER HOMESTRETCH FOR MILLSTONE 3
description: NUCLEAR engineers are to lower 50,952 rods containing $200 million worth of uranium 235 fuel pellets into the reactor of Millstone 3 in Waterford Friday, as Northeast Utilities prepares to start a final round of tests of the plant.

title: PAMPHLET ISSUED ON CHILD ABDUCTION
description: ALONG-AWAITED pamphlet on how to prevent child abductions is now available free ''and will hopefully put a dent in the future number of children reported missing in the state,'' says Richard T. Ruffino, executive secretary of the state's Commission on Missing Persons.

title: Celebrating New Jersey
description: Randall Rothenberg cited Senator Gary Hart's comment about the ''new reality'' of the state in terms of its high-technology and service industries. However, it should be pointed out that Senator Hart is probably better remembered for another statement that he made about New Jersey.

title: SURGE IN INMATES STRETCHES MASSACHUSETTS' CROWDED PRISONS
description: A recent unexpected surge in the number of criminals sentenced to prisons has exacerbated this state's inmate overcrowding problem, now the second worst in the nation.

title: ONE MAN'S VICTORY AT SEA
description: ON JULY 23 AT 7 A.M., RICH-ard Appaldo, 26 years old, and Cristina Bernard, 29, were asleep in the broad rear berth of their tidy, largely self-made 30-foot sloop, Clodokat. But conditions were not favorable for a drowsy morning on the Great Bahama Bank. The little boat was tossing erratically at anchor. They awakened and hastily climbed the narrow ladder onto the deck, which was awash with waves and cold windy rain. Cristina wore no clothes; she was immediately drenched and shivering.

title: Trinity's Gifts
description: To the Editor:

title: AFRIKANER MINISTER TELLS OF HIS LONG ROAD OF CONVERSION FROM APARTHEID
description: He was 4 years old, the Rev. Nico Smith said, when he learned his first lesson of apartheid: You talk to blacks, his mother told him, only when you have an order to give to them, a command to impart.

title:
ART;

PRINCETON GALLERY: MEIERHANS WORKS
description: JOSEF MEIERHANS (1890-1981) may have been an individualist, but he falls far short of having been eccentric.

title: SWING AND DIXIELAND, PERIOD
description: ALL WHAT JAZZ A Record Diary 1961-1971. By Philip Larkin. 316 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. Cloth, $19.95. Paper, $9.95. PHILIP LARKIN once wrote a poem to Sidney Bechet that perfectly captures the response of a young English provincial to great jazz. Attending a concert, he is overwhelmed by the classic soprano saxophonist; both awestruck and liberated, the poet can only cry, ''An enormous Yes!'' ''All What Jazz'' records his search for the same enormous Yes! in the years since then. The search led to dissatisfaction during the English traditional jazz revival of the 1950's, then to increasing dismay as he heard the main lines of jazz's evolution, bop to hard bop to free jazz. Meanwhile, he became a novelist and poet - in fact, he has been a leading contender for poet laureate - and in 1961 he began hacking out monthly jazz record reviews for London's Daily Telegraph, a gig he held until 1971.

title: WHY THE PLAN WOULD SHACKLE BUSINESS
description: THE plant-closing bill now before the House of Representatives can best be described as a wolf in sheep's clothing.

title:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;

PRESENT ARMS
description: In GUN PEOPLE (Dolphin/Doubleday, Paper, $16.95) George W. Gardner's 64 black-and-white pictures of people with guns are accompanied by Patrick Carr's interviews of gun owners who explain how they feel about their weapons. There are benign weapons owners like the city woman who moved to rural Vermont with her children, bought a few guns in a moment of fear and now has them lying around her house.

title: POLAND ANNOUNCES A LIMITED AMNESTY
description: Poland today announced plans to grant amnesty to some of its 368 political prisoners but indicated there would be none for senior Solidarity activists.

title: VIETNAM, TRYING TO BE NICER, STILL HAS A LONG WAY TO GO
description: Do Hoang Hai says that when he was a South Vietnamese student activist in the 1960's he specialized in leading attacks against the United States Embassy in Saigon. But today, Saigon has become Ho Chi Minh City, and Mr. Hai, the deputy director of its Import-Export Corporation, works to bring American trade and investment back to Vietnam.

title: THE CRUCIAL PROCESS OF SELECTION
description: AT one time or another, virtually every co-op and condominium board will need to select professionals. These will include accountants, lawyers and managing agents who will serve on a regular basis as well as architects, engineers, decorators and others retained for particular projects.

title: ESSEX ART PARK HOPEFUL ON FUTURE
description: THE WAR was over, the Army's regional missile command center had shut down and the 40 acres nestled here in the heart of the Watchung Mountains had become a wilderness, the otherwise desolate landscape disturbed only by the vandals and vagrants who regularly invaded the 11 drab military buildings.

title: YOUNGEST CHESS CHAMPION: GARY KASPAROV
description: Even in chess, a game in which every great player was once a child prodigy, few champions have swept to the top as swiftly or relentlessly as Gary Kasparov.

title: AFTER 30 YEARS, DEMOCRACY GETS A CHANCE IN GUATEMALA
description: Only five years ago, Marco Vinicio Cerezo Arevalo was a virtual prisoner in his home. Death squads believed to be linked with Government security forces had repeatedly tried to assassinate him, and it was widely assumed that he was high on their hit list. They had killed the country's two most promising politicians, Alberto Fuentes Mohr, a former Foreign Minister, and Manuel Colom Argueta, who had been Mayor of Guatemela City. Mr. Cerezo's home was surrounded by armed guards. ''If I step outside my front door,'' he once said, ''I'll be killed before I get to the corner.''

title: PROSPECTS
description: Muni Madness A rush to beat the tax revisions now under Congressional scrutiny has the market for tax-free municipal bonds in a frenzy. ''The prospects for November and December are for volume 20 to 25 percent higher than last year,'' said Robert N. Downey, chief of Goldman, Sachs' municipal department. Last year, muni volume hit a record $101 billion. ''This will definitely be a record year,'' said Mr. Downey.

title: Recent Sales
VOTERS GO FOR CENTRISTS AND INCUMBENTS
description: zNLY two governorships were at stake in last week's off-year elections, but the results in both contests commanded the attention of the two national parties in a dramatic way.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: HERBS AND APPLES. By Helen Hooven Santmyer. (Harper & Row, $16.95.) ''When I was still a child and first read 'Little Women,' '' Helen Hooven Santmyer writes in the introduction to this new edition of her first novel, ''I made up my mind that I, like Louisa May Alcott, would like to write books for children.''

title: CORRECTION
description: Elie Wiesel's article ''A Survivor Remebers Other Survivors of 'Shoah,''' on this page last week, should have credited a translator. Annette Insdorf translated it from the French.

title: CRIME'S INFLUENCE OUTLINED TO JURY
description: The face of the slender witness was devoid of expression, and the words came in a low monotone, but his testimony held the rapt attention of jurors in a Federal courtroom here this week.

title: LISA BIRGE NOLEN, J. S. BIRMINGHAM MARRY IN BEDFORD
description: At St. Matthew's Episcopal Church in Bedford, N.Y., yesterday Lisa Birge Nolen, a daughter of Chapin Nolen of Bedford and Barbara Nolen of Tamworth, N.H., was married to James Strong Birmingham, a son of Matthew T. Birmingham Jr. of Norwalk, Conn., and the late Jane Gaillard Birmingham. The Rev. Dr. William E. Foley performed the ceremony.

title: SOUTHAMPTON URGED TO SET UP POWER SYSTEM
description: Officials in this eastern Long Island town are under pressure from voters to establish a local power company to replace the Long Island Lighting Company in two neighborhoods with 1,300 houses.

title: 'HEALING' IS URGED BY ULSTER PARTY
description: The nationalist party that says it believes the problems of Northern Ireland can be solved by political rather than violent means met here today and agreed that the talks now under way between London and Dublin still represented the best chance for peace north of the border.

title: LOVE, AND LEARN TO BEAR IT
description: THE YEAR IT RAINED By Crescent Dragonwagon. 224 pp. New York: Macmillan Publishing Company. $12.95. (Ages 12 and up) IN a way it's too bad that this particular novel is being reviewed on this particular page where it will go largely unnoticed by the older audience that should know about it. It would be ideal to read at age 17, but also at 30, and again at 45 when one's own children are circling 17 - it faces so unflinchingly the anguished and so often unsuccessful attempts to get past all the precious but heavy baggage of love between mother and child and on into some kind of mutual understanding that can set both free.

title: ON THE ART OF TEACHING WRITING
description: Readers of ''Teaching the Art of Writing'' [Opinion Page, Oct. 20] know that Wilma Davidson taught the Barrington, Ill., school staff and community to foster writing in the lives of children.

title: Disengaging From Marcos
description: When President Ferdinand E. Marcos called last week for early elections at the beginning of next year, he hoped above all to deflect American demands for political, military and economic reforms in the Philippines. In fact, his announcement only highlighted the pressing need for change and for American measures to further it. There is a growing consensus in Washington that the United States must get tough with Mr. Marcos, but there is little idea of what to do.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;

RAMBO AND PEACE
description: According to the Toy Manufacturers of America, based in New York City, $12 billion a year is spent on toys and 60 percent of that money is spent in the last three months of the year.

title: ITALY'S JEWS EXCAVATE THEIR ANCIENT HISTORY
description: THERE are only 35,000 Jews in Italy, but they represent the oldest Jewish community in the Diaspora that can document its existence through more than 2,000 years of history, predating the Christian era. However, much of this rich legacy of artifact and architecture is deteriorating, and only now are strenuous steps being taken to preserve and restore it.

title:
CHILDREN'S BOOKS;

GORILLA MY DREAMS
description: GORILLA Written and illustrated by Anthony Browne. Unpaged. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $7.95. (Ages 4 to 8) GORILLA. The word may conjure images of wildness. Contrary to such preconceptions, Anthony Browne's new book, ''Gorilla,'' is a gentle story. It is about Hannah, who loves gorillas and longs to see a real one at the zoo. But her father is too busy. For her birthday she receives a toy gorilla and dreams that it becomes real and takes her to the zoo, and that they spend a most enjoyable time together. The next morning her dream comes true. Her father finally takes her to the zoo. The words tell a simple story. But as in most picture books, the words tell only part of the story, the pictures do the rest.

title: STAGE: ''RUNNING ON EMPTY''
description: THE temptation to do a new play by a relatively well-known playwright was, understandably, too much for the Studio Theater to resist.

title: CONTROL OF MEN'S TENNIS AT ISSUE IN SUITS
description: It has been the contention of the Volvo North America Corp., International Management Group and ProServ that the Men's International Professional Tennis Council has been trying to become a tennis dictator at their expense. It was at the core of the antitrust suit they filed earlier this year, charging the council with illegal restraint of trade.

title: SPECIAL CREDENTIALS
description: Kingman Brewster, the London-based American lawyer who upheld the propriety of the Knicks' offer to Albert King, said that he had brought special credentials to his role as the court-appointed special master in the case. ''I'm utterly ignorant about basketball,'' he said.

title: 'A SHAYNA MAIDEL' AT HARTFORD
description: What is a shayna maidel?

title: A TUG-OF-WAR OVER FM RADIO STATION
description: THE United States Government says Elton Spitzer can no longer operate WLIR-FM, licensed in Garden City, one of the most influential radio stations in the New York metropolitan area. But Mr. Spitzer refuses to go.

title:
DINING OUT;

A TRANSFORMED LOOK IN MEDFORD
description: HOUSED in a log cabin nestled in the woods in Medford, across the river from Philadelphia, Beau Rivage has been an established and popular restaurant for seven years. This fall, it took on a new look.

title: ALLEGORIES WITH ALLIGATORS
description: THE PEOPLE COULD FLY American Black Folktales. Told by Virginia Hamilton. Illustrated by Leo and Diane Dillon. 178 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $12.95. (Ages 8 to 12) THOUGH best known for his dialect poetry, Paul Laurence Dunbar, who was born in 1872, wrote prose as well. In his novels and short stories he employed such a lofty writing style that one has to read between the lines to discern his harsh social criticism. At the University of Iowa, I once heard a critic translate Dunbar's prose so that his students could follow it. Late 19th-century Jim Crow society, when the cocked pistol and the lynch rope were ever present, was not conducive to the candor that we've come to expect from modern Afro-American writers.

title: A FLOTILLA OF CHOICES FOR THE INLAND SAILOR
description: The season for cruising the inland waterways of Europe is generally from March to October or November. Right now is the time to start planning a voyage, since space and availability are limited.

title: A SLIPPERY ROAD AHEAD FOR SUBARU
description: FOR nearly 20 years, Subaru of America has thrived by doing things its way. First, when Japanese cars were still a novelty in this country, it brought in the Subaru, a car so much like a covered motorcycle in engine size and weight that it was exempted from Federal auto safety and emission standards. Then, when Japanese cars began streaming into the United States, Subaru of America carved out a niche for itself in front-wheel and four-wheel drive, and in rural areas. And Subaru did all this while violating a basic tenet of the Japanese: Unlike every other organization set up here for the sole purpose of importing cars, Subaru is American-owned. It is the sole importer into the United States of cars made by Fuji Heavy Industries.

title: EMBARGO ON NICARAGUA APPEARS A LITTLE EFFECT
description: The embargo on United States trade with Nicaragua, imposed in early May, has yet to result in more than a ripple in Nicaraguan economic activity.

title: ON THE TRAIL OF THE COUNTY'S DEER POACHERS
description: FROM their vantage point overlooking a field, the two men waited and waited for the sound of gunshots. The wind was still, the moon nearly full. But on this night there was only silence.

title: What John Walker Really Bargained For
description: To the Editor:

title: MAKING MERGERS EVEN EASIER
description: No person engaged in commerce or in any activity affecting commerce shall acquire . . . the whole or any part of the assets of another person engaged also in commerce . . . where . . . the effect of such acquisition may be substantially to lessen competition, or to tend to create a monopoly. - Clayton Act, Section 7. PASSED in 1914 and strengthened in 1950, the Clayton Antitrust Act is coming under intense fire. The Reagan Administration, which has already won its share of battles to reduce Government regulation, now wants to rewrite the nation's time-honored laws on antitrust.

title: CRIME
description: Here are two first novels, and let's start with THE COYOTE CRIED TWICE by Austin Bay (Arbor House, $14.95). It is the story of a drifter, a young man who was a helicopter pilot in Vietnam. Thumbing his way through Texas, he takes a ranch job to tide him over. Strange things happen in the desert at night - auto headlights where there should be none, low-flying planes on mysterious missions. Then murder. The man who gave him the job and now is his best friend is bushwhacked and killed. The drifter is promptly fired. But he has to find out what happened and is almost murdered doing so.

title: CHANGES ON THE WAY FOR ESSEX HOSPITALS
description: FACED with the prospect of some 2,000 extra hospital beds in Essex County by 1990, state and local officials are struggling to streamline the health-care system of New Jersey's most populous county.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: HOW I SAVED THE WORLD. By Philip Slater. (Dutton, $16.95.) Nothing less than the fate of the planet is at stake in this whimsical thriller by the author of ''The Pursuit of Loneliness.''

title: 'AUNT DAN AND LEMON' CUTS CLOSE TO THE MARROW
description: In his introduction to the published version of ''My Dinner with Andre,'' that tantalizing tete-a-tete between the playwright Wallace Shawn and the director Andre Gregory, Mr. Shawn briefly describes his life in the theater. He calls his plays ''intense, extreme, even maniacal,'' and suggests, with tongue only partly in cheek, that he has ''generously shown on stage my interior life as a raging beast.'' That raging beast has the oddest effect on audiences, driving them into paroxysms of dismay, anger and, as the author might say, ''even disgust.''

title: POLLING AMERICANS
description: AMERICANS THINK of Russians as being quite different from themselves, much more different than the British, Germans or Japanese. The political differences between the United States and the Soviet Union appear to mean more to Americans than, for example, ethnic or other differences between America and Japan. Fifty-six percent of the 1,277 respondents to a New York Times poll thought Russians were ''quite different'' from Americans; only 38 percent said Japanese were ''quite different.''

title: VATICAN-ISRAEL LINK
description: 'Please convey to Rome the importance to Jews everywhere of normalizing relations between the Vatican and Israel, which is home for so much of Jewish culture and so many of the world's Jews - so that all of us - Jew and Catholic alike - may work together for a better world in which we can all share in the blessings of creation.' rrEdgar M. Bronfman, president of the World Jewish Congress addressing John Cardinal O'Connor of New York.

title: Sociobiology and Its Critics
description: To the Editor:

title: Getting Tougher About AIDS
description: After two years on a calmer course, state health authorities have started to get tough with New York City bathhouses, bars and other commercial establishments that persist in fostering ''high-risk sexual activity'' associated with the spread of the AIDS virus among homosexuals. Joined now by city administrators, they still seek the cooperation of owners, but the request is backed by the power to padlock the premises.

title: TRAVEN'S 'DEATH SHIP' -- AUTHENTIC, HYPNOTIC AND MAYBE ALCHEMICAL
description: FIFTY-ONE years ago, B. Traven's first novel, ''The Death Ship,'' was published in English; it had already appeared in German and in a dozen other translations to enormous acclaim. Its reception in England and the United States was no different.

title: AARON COPLAND: 'HE IS LIKE A SONG-FILLED ROCK OF GIBRALTAR'
description: As a teen-ager at Philadelphia's very proper Curtis Institute in 1943 I would occasionally head for New York to get into mischief. One weekend, before boarding the train (I was off to see Virgil Thomson, whom I'd never met, about becoming his copyist), a schoolmate, Shirley Gabis, said, ''Why not drop in on my old friend Lenny while you're up there.'' I did. Accordingly Bernstein put me onto Copland - ''Aaron likes knowing what young composers are up to'' - and I spent an afternoon bleating my tunes for the famous musician. Well, I took the job with Virgil, became an instant fan of Aaron and Lenny, and for the next 42 years with many an up and a down I've remained staunch friends with all three men. Some weekend!

title: LAW FOUND TO CUT FOSTER CARE NEED
description: There were 19,000 fewer children in foster care in the state last year than in 1979, and a report issued today credits a law that increased state spending on programs to keep families together.

title: THE INFANCY OF THE APOCALYPSE
description: BY THE BOMB'S EARLY LIGHT American Thought and Culture at the Dawn of the Atomic Age. By Paul Boyer. Illustrated. 440 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $22.50.

title: Feminists and Pornography
description: To the Editor:

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: BECK SUFFERS SHOULDER INJURY
description: It was a familiar sight last season: a Ranger player in pain. Then Saturday night, it happened again.

title: Advertising;Grey Closing a Unit As Its Head Departs
description: Grey Advertising has decided to close down Grey, Lyon & King, splitting that operation's $35 million in billings between itself and a newly formed division, Grey Entertainment and Media (GEM to its friends). The decision was made with the departure of Grey, Lyon's president, George McGuire, who joined a client, the Weichert Company, realtors based in Morristown, N.J.

title: Getting Rid of Marcos Is Not America's Business
description: To the Editor:

title: GUNMEN HIJACKS UGANDA PLANE WITH 49 ABOARD TO REBEL REGION
description: A gunman suspected of having ties to an insurgent rebel group hijacked a domestic airliner today and forced it to fly to rebel-controlled territory, officials said.

title: DANCE: AYAKO & COMPANY
description: AYAKO UCHIYAMA and the performers of Ayako & Company seemed to be having a bad day when they presented a program of traditional and contemporary dance on Saturday afternoon at Pace University's Schimmel Center for the Arts. Though an experienced Kabuki dancer, Miss Uchiyama failed to make the characters or movements come alive in leaden performances of two solos in the ''Suodori'' style - ''Urashima,'' a dance-drama based on the folk tale of a Rip Van Winkle-style fisherman, and Fujiko Fujima's ''Yuzuki Sendo,'' in which a boatman enjoys the evening sky and waters.

title: Market Place;Macy's Buyout Still Up in Air
description: THE stock of R. H. Macy & Company is remaining at a high level, despite continuing skepticism that the company's management can carry out its proposed $3.6 billion leveraged buyout.

title: Outdoors: A Vermont Bird Hunt
description: A FULL moon had risen above the valley through which 20 Mile Stream Road wanders. Two wraiths fluttered past my truck's windshield, appearing and disappearing before I had time to slow. They were woodcock moving south ahead of the cold weather, and seeing them seemed to augur well for the two-day grouse and woodock hunt that lay ahead.

title: Heart Study Disputes Notion
description: A study of heart disease in southern Florida counters the long-held notion that sedentary white-collar jobs mean a higher risk of heart attacks, according to a researcher at Harvard University.

title: FIFTH PEN CELEBRATION STARS DIDION AND WOLFE
description: Joan Didion and Tom Wolfe instructed and entertained an appreciative audience at the Royale Theater last night, at the fifth of eight scheduled PEN Celebrations.

title: CONGRESS;HELMS PUTS IN ACTIVE WEEK ON HIS FOREIGN POLICY
description: Jesse Helms might be the only Senator with his own foreign policy.

title: Music: Roloff at St. Peter's
description: Roger Roloff's increasing presence as a Wagnerian baritone should not obscure his abilities as a lieder singer. Early Saturday evening in St. Peter's Church (Lexington Avenue and 54th Street), Mr. Roloff reminded us of these talents, singing songs by four composers, all to German texts. One came away impressed not only by the beauty, evenness and security of this voice through all its registers but by the lovely pronunciation of his words and the ardor he breathed into them.

title: OUT OF GRIEF, A DRIVE TO CUT YOUTH SUICIDE
description: Anne Spoonhour has transformed her grief into a crusade.

title: COLOMBIA SIEGE SURVIVORS ARE BITTER
description: The 12 judges who survived a 28-hour siege at the Palace of Justice here last week boycotted an elaborate memorial service today for the scores of people who died. The judges, who said they stayed away to protest the Government's handling of the crisis, were joined in the boycott by most of the relatives of 11 slain justices.

title: HOMES, TREES, AND TOYS BURIED AMID ASBESTOS
description: Not long ago, the 17-acre site on the eastern outskirts of Globe was the Mountain View Mobile Home Estates, a comfortable, attractive community of some 50 families, many of whom had lived in the park since it opened in 1973. Now it looks like nothing more than a vacant lot, perhaps a construction site turned raw from the tracks and blades of the bulldozers still pawing the earth.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;The Osborne at 100. . .
description: United by pride and fond memories of their lives there, residents and fans of the Osborne, that venerable red stone building at 205 West 67th Street, gathered Friday night to celebrate its 100th birthday.

title: Bruins Top North Stars
description: Bill Derlago scored his first goal in a Boston uniform, and Doug Keans turned aside 19 shots as the Bruins defeated the Minnesota North Stars, 2-1, tonight.

title: Doctors Still Need Training
description: For all its impressive results, the Reagan Administration's effort to hold down medical costs creates casualties: the nation's teaching hospitals. To avert serious damage to medical education, the Administration and Congress need to join in a rescue plan.

title: Prices Increase For Gasoline
description: Gasoline prices increased for the fourth consecutive week because of efforts to reduce lead in gasoline and a strong demand for fuel, Dan Lundberg, an industry analyst, said today.

title: It's Dangerous to Tell the Press Anything
description: To the Editor:

title: First Half Sitting, Then 310 Running
description: It was the kind of game a running back dreams of, where the defense cannot get a grip on him and the public-address announcer keeps calling his name as he racks up yardage.

title: Pillsbury German Snag
description: The Pillsbury Company's proposed acquisition of Sonnen-Bassermann, a West German food concern, has been rejected by an antitrust court in West Berlin. The court on Friday upheld a ruling last March by West Germany's Federal Cartel Office, which rejected the acquisition on the ground that it would give Pillsbury an anti-competitive share - about 35 percent - of the West German packaged-food market.

title: TENTATIVE FINDING IN CHIP CASE
description: The International Trade Commission has made a preliminary finding that the American semiconductor industry is being harmed by Japanese competition.

title: STUDY CALLS ADMISSIONS TO HIGH SCHOOLS FAIR
description: New York City's system of selective public high school admissions places poor and minority students at an unfair disadvantage and ''creates the suspicion of racially discriminatory admissions practices,'' according to a new study by a civic organization.

title: Apartheid Discussion At an All-Male Club
description: To the Editor:

title: CANTON BOOMING ON MARXIST FREE ENTERPRISE
description: A local official who spoke with members of a Soviet parliamentary delegation that visited this city last month reported that the Russians seemed equally impressed and perplexed by the thrusting, anything-goes atmosphere that prevails along the banks of the Pearl River.

title: LACK OF FUNDS HAMPERS EUROPEAN EFFORTS TO HALT SPREAD OF AIDS
description: The authorities in Western Europe could prevent the spread of AIDS, researchers say, but lack of funds may prevent them from doing so.

title: SHULTZ DEMANDS SEAMAN'S RELEASE
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that he believed the Soviet seaman who jumped ship, touching off a debate on whether his ship should have been barred from leaving American waters, had initially ''decided somehow that he wanted to come to the United States.''

title: NBC OFFERS A DRAMA ON AIDS
description: TELEVISION'S belated discovery of acquired immune deficiency syndrome is poised to enter the maximum-saturation stage. AIDS is hot copy, providing news programs with footage of everything from parents picketing schools to bars being shut down by stern-looking authorities. Unfortunately, the coverage has often been less than illuminating and has fostered a startling amount of confusion and panic. Ironically, prime-time entertainment is now providing some antidotes. These are scripts carefully couched in a mixture of factual information and compassion, not least for the victims. An exceptionally fine example can be found in ''An Early Frost,'' the television movie on NBC at 9 o'clock this evening.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: King George III had a bit of a raw deal in history. I think slowly but surely people are realizing he wasn't such an ogre as they made out.'' -Charles, Prince of Wales. [A1:2.]

title: Fire Shuts Alaska Pipeline
description: An explosion and fire ripped through a generator building at a pump station on the trans-Alaska oil pipeline late Saturday, injuring two firefighters and shutting down the pipeline for about 10 hours, officials said. The explosion at Pump Station 1 at Prudhoe Bay did not damage the pipeline but cut off electricity for pumping oil until today. The cause had not been determined.

title: Washington Watch;A Banking Bill And Squabble
description: WASHINGTON

title: MISS GRILLO STAKES TO CADABRA ABRA
description: Cadabra Abra and Roberto's Key, a pair of fillies from The Meadowlands, found Aqueduct's slow and choppy turf course more to their liking than their four rivals did and finished first and second in the $87,750 Miss Grillo Stakes at Aqueduct yesterday.

title: COWBOYS DEFEAT REDSKINS BY 13-7
description: For the past 15 years, the games between the Cowboys and the Redskins have been noted for intensity and anxiety. But today's match had almost no fire as Dallas beat Washington routinely, 13-7, before 55,750, the largest home crowd in the history of Robert F. Kennedy Stadium.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: INTO ETERNITY: The Life of James Jones, American Writer. By Frank MacShane. 355 pages. Illustrated.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: POEMS ABOUT WAR Is is Remembrance Day in Canada today, and in the United States it used to be Armistice Day. In both instances, it is a day to observe the signing of the armistice in 1918 that brought an end to World War I, at the 11th hour, on the 11th day, of the 11th month. In 1954, the day was renamed Veterans' Day in the United States, primarily because World War I, ''the war to end all wars,'' did not.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE;Pacific-Maxxam Link Is Fought by a Family
description: Ever since the Pacific Lumber Company agreed to merge with Maxxam Group Inc. late last month, Stanwood A. Murphy Jr. has been spending time indoors, something he does not like to do.

title: DINNER FOR ROYAL COUPLE: GUEST LIST
description: Following are the guests invited to the dinner given tonight by the British Ambassador, Sir Oliver Wright, and Lady Wright, in honor of the Prince and Princess of Wales: The Prince and Princess of Wales.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;A Kindly Recognition Amid the Anonymity
description: In the big-city pandemonium of the Long Island Rail Road platform at Pennsylvania Station, a small-town courtesy is worth noting.

title: ADMISSIONS OF CHILD ABUSE FOUND TO DROP SHARPLY
description: The number of parents nationwide who admit to severe violence toward their children has declined significantly in the past decade while overall acknowledgment of violence has remained stable, according to a study sponsored by the National Institute of Mental Health.

title: Poland Faces I.M.F. Delays
description: Poland's admission into the International Monetary Fund, considered vital by Warsaw to gain fresh credit, has run into minor delays but is expected to be approved by April, monetary sources said Friday.

title: BRIEFING;Big Chicken Market BRIEFING
description: It may or may not contribute to harmony at the Geneva meeting, but Mayor Andrew Young of Atlanta has a new proposal for helping solve the nation's adverse balance of trade, or at least a local portion of it. The former Congressman and United Nations delegate returned recently from a visit to Soviet Union and called for a campaign to export Georgia chickens to the Soviet Union. A lively market exists, Mr. Young maintained, because Russian birds are ''very expensive'' by Georgia standards.

title: Eta Gershen Wed To Steven Cohen
description: Eta Margolit Gershen and Steven Bruce Cohen were married last evening at the Jewish Center in Princeton, N.J. Rabbi Allan Blaine, uncle of the bride, performed the ceremony, assisted by Rabbi Melvin J. Glasser.

title: QUALITY OF NEW TEACHERS RISING AS PAY IMPROVES
description: The nation is making ''slow but steady progress'' in recruiting more and better teachers as salary increases are outstripping inflation, the Carnegie Foundation reported today.

title: SLIM CHANCE SEEN FOR ARMS AGENDA AT SUMMIT TALKS
description: Reagan Administration officials said today that there was an outside possibility that the meeting between President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev might produce an agreement on guidelines to provide impetus to the arms control negotiations. But they stressed there was only a slim chance of this.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;A Balmy November Day
description: Somehow, the evergreen boughs and reindeer that ornament the main floor of Saks Fifth Avenue looked out of place yesterday afternoon, perhaps because shoppers were in their shirt-sleeves.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in some copies on Wednesday about an auction of contemporary art at Sotheby's misidentified an Arshile Gorky painting that was sold. It was an untitled 1944 Surrealist work.

title: KNICK MATCH HAS NO WINNER
description: Rarely does a game so early in the season create such excitement and intrigue.

title: AROUND THE WORLD;Marcos Foes Rebuffed On Resignation Request
description: A caucus of the political opponents of President Ferdinand E. Marcos asked him today to resign before presidential elections were held, but the group was reportedly told the issue was ''non-negotiable.''

title: EAGLES WIN ON 99-YARD PLAY
description: Ron Jaworski and Mike Quick combined on a 99-yard touchdown 1 minute 49 seconds into overtime today to give the Philadelphia Eagles a 23-17 victory over the Atlanta Faccons.

title: SOUTH AFRICA ACCUSED ON PRESS CURBS
description: A South African newspaper accused the authorities today of using unverified and ''bogus'' evidence of improper behavior by foreign television crews to help justify a major crackdown on reporting of the nation's protracted disturbances.

title: VETERAN RECALLS A 19TH CENTURY WAR
description: It was a lark. It was a walk in the sun. It was society sports eating hardtack and sowbelly, and young volunteers from the streets getting their first taste of battle at a place called San Juan Hill.

title: KIND WORDS FROM THE PRINCE ON MUCH-ALIGNED ANCESTOR
description: The Prince of Wales held a rare news conference today, decreeing that his wife finds John Travolta to be a good dancer and that he finds George III to be a better King than Americans might admit.

title: Guatemala Looks to Civilians
description: Guatemala's much-awaited ''democratic opening'' turns out to be just that. Round One of the presidential election was fairly conducted last week, apparently without the gross abuses that marred most recent contests. A runoff between two civilians will be held Dec. 8. With the army's indulgence, Guatemala's first freely elected president in 15 years will take office in January.

title: GORBACHEV AND GENEVA: THE ROLE OF ILLS AT HOME
description: When President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev meet in Geneva Nov. 19 and 20, each will carry his own domestic political burden into the talks. Each is restricted in his maneuverability by factors inside his own country.

title: AROUND THE WORLD;Rallies in Spain Oppose U.S. Troops and NATO
description: Thousands of demonstrators, many carrying effigies of President Reagan and chanting anti-American slogans, marched in several Spanish cities today to press for withdrawal from NATO and removal of United States military bases.

title: Columbia Gas To Give Details
description: A spokesman for the Columbia Gas System Inc. confirmed yesterday that the company would make an announcement today regarding revisions of its natural gas purchasing contracts. Rumors of a favorable revision of the contracts spurred the company's stock price to rise $3 a share, to $39, in heavy trading Friday on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: AMID PACIFIC CORAL REEFS, ASSASSINATION MYSTERY
description: Shortly after midnight last June 30, President Haruo Remeliik was about to enter his house when someone stepped out of the shadows and killed him with four shots from a .32-caliber pistol.

title: HOLIDAY SALES RISE EXPECTED
description: Despite six fewer shopping days this Christmas season than last, retailers and economists expect the holiday period to produce sales gains of 6 to 10 percent over 1984. They said that pent-up demand for merchandise of many sorts, improved regional economies and better-planned inventories would help to overcome the shortened season.

title: College Acts on South Africa
description: The trustees of Mount Holyoke College voted Saturday to divest the school of its $14 million in stock in companies that do business in South Africa, by ''no later than early 1987,'' said a college spokesman, Lu Stone. The holdings in 26 companies doing business in South Africa amounts to 17.2 percent of the college's $84 million endowment, she said.

title: Edward Villella to Head New Miami City Ballet
description: Edward Villella, a former soloist with the New York City Ballet, has been named artistic director of a newly formed local ballet company, the Miami City Ballet.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: American International Rent a Car, Dallas, has promoted Robert S. Ohanian to president.

title: THE DANCE: TAIWAN'S CLOUD GATE
description: THE LEGACY'' is not quite dance, folk theater, martial arts or public spectacle. The full-evening work - presented on Friday by the Cloud Gate Taipei Contemporary Dance Theater in a preview performance at Lehman College's Center for the Performing Arts in the Bronx - merges the four forms in a work that, by its close, drew cheers from an initially hostile audience. Judging by that response, Cloud Gate may prove to be one of the most unusual cultural events of the season, when it moves to the Triplex Theater, at Manhattan Community College, 199 Chambers Street, tonight for a week's engagement that features ''The Legacy'' and two other programs.

title: Potlatch Reply Likely Today
description: A spokesman for Potlatch Corporation, a forest products company based here, said tonight that the company's board was meeting to consider the $45 a share tender offer, totaling $692.4 million, from the Belzberg family of Vancouver, British Columbia, and would have a response Monday.

title: ABROAD AT HOME;To Suppress Reality
description: The press has been celebrating anniversaries here: 100 years of the Milwaukee Press Club, the oldest in the country, and 75 of Marquette University's College of Journalism. As always on such occasions, we talked about the purpose of the business - at its best, to inform the public even when the state tries to suppress reality.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report on Tuesday in the Briefing column of the Washington Talk page, about litigation involving Ralph Nader and Car and Driver magazine, incorrectly described the resolution of the case. Mr. Nader accepted a settlement of $20,000 from the Ziff-Davis Publishing Company, which owned the magazine at the time of the suit.

title: Advertising;Addenda
description: Newsweek will increase its circulation base 1.67 percent, to 3.05 million, and its ad rates 6.5 percent with its Jan. 6 issue.

title: AT LEAST 5 KILLED AS 2 PLANES COLLIDE OVER JERSEY
description: Two private airplanes collided and fell in flames over two New Jersey communities near the Hudson River shortly after dusk yesterday, killing their occupants and setting off clusters of fires in residential and commercial buildings.

title: Mother of Nobels III
description: To the Editor:

title: FOR DALLAS MUSEUM, ART AND A VILLA
description: When Wendy Reves, the 74-year-old widow of Emery Reves, the Hungarian-born author, publisher and art collector, offered to donate the couple's important collections to the Dallas Museum of Art, she presented the museum with a dilemma: she insisted the art be housed permanently in a special wing exactly replicating six rooms of their villa on the French Riviera or else, well, there were plenty of other museums.

title: STAR EXPLOSION HELPS TO TEST NEW WAY TO GAUGE DISTANCE
description: What appears to be the first measurement of distance between Earth and a faraway galaxy using straightforward trigonometry has been made through an analysis of observations of a star explosion, or supernova.

title: IN SPITE OF TECHNOLOGY, PILOTS MUST STILL RELY ON THEIR EYES
description: Despite the tens of millions of dollars of sophisticated techonology that guide aircraft through the metropolitan area every day, the safety and survival of thousands of airplanes still depend on the keen eyesight of the pilots.

title: GIANTS WIN
description: The Giants' offense staggered and struggled today, and it gave away the ball twice deep in its territory and it had Phil Simms overthrow open receivers. The special teams allowed an 89-yard kickoff return. But the defense played a solid, aggressive game, the offense and defense benefited from disputed fourth-quarter calls by the officials and, with a little luck, the Giants hung on for a 24-19 victory over the Los Angeles Rams.

title: REUNION RECALLS SCHOOL FOR JEWS IN NAZI GERMANY
description: Henry Eisner remembered his crush on Eva Frank and finally revealed it, after 47 years.

title: IN GLOOM OF WELFARE HOTELS, VOICE OF HOPE IS HEARD
description: Donna Moore stepped from the elevator at the Carter, her cheery hello ringing through the fifth-floor corridor, and one after another doors popped open, spilling toddlers who clambered at her knees and sad-eyed women who hung on her every word.

title: BUCS GAIN THEIR FIRST VICTORY
description: Steve DeBerg passed 1 yard for a touchdown to Adger Armstrong, and Donald Igwebuike made three long field goals today to lead the Tampa Bay Buccaneers to their first victory of the season, 16-0 from the St. Louis Cardinals.

title: Letter: On Family Planning;A Move to Undercut Women's Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: Banc One Buys Indiana Bank
description: The Marion Bancorp, a bank-holding company based in Marion, Ind., said yesterday that it had agreed to be acquired by the Banc One Corporation in a stock transaction valued at $10.3 million.

title: DANCE: PEGGY SPINA TROUPE IN 'FASCINATING RHYTHMS'
description: PEGGY SPINA is fascinated by rhythm. That was certainly clear in ''Fascinating Rhythms,'' the tap-dance revue that the Peggy Spina Tap Company presented Saturday night at the Marymount Manhattan Theater, 221 East 71st Street.

title: Explosive in the Sewers
description: Veterans of the Office of Strategic Services will obviously have many yarns to swap when they meet, like the one about the day they almost blew up the White House. It was described by Stanley P. Lovell, in charge of the World War II agency's department of nefarious devices and black magic, in his book, ''Of Spies and Stratagems.''

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS;Chance Meetings
description: William J. Bennett, the Secretary of Education, frankly admits that he is awed by professional athletes. Not long ago he was attending a White House reception and was lucky enough to fall into conversation with Roosevelt Grier, the former defensive lineman for the Giants and the Los Angeles Rams.

title: Nets' Richardson Misses Flight
description: Micheal Ray Richardson, the Nets' playmaker, missed the team flight from Newark International Airport to San Antonio today. Team officials said Richardson will have to pay his airfare here and will also be fined by Coach Dave Wohl.

title: DOCTOROW REVISITS THE 'WORLD'S FAIR' OF HIS NOVEL
description: For E(dgar) L(awrence) Doctorow, fact followed fiction followed fact the other afternoon in Queens. He visited the old World's Fair grounds, just as 9-year-old Edgar Altschuler does in Mr. Doctorow's new novel, ''World's Fair,'' and discovered that fictional and real worlds can sometimes run together.

title: Brooklyn Vandals Hit Stores Owned by Jews
description: The display windows of 13 Jewish-owned stores in a predominantly Hasidic section of Brooklyn were smashed during the weekend, the police said yesterday.

title: HIGH-STAKES DRAMA AT REVLON
description: One of the pivotal corporate battles of modern times opened quietly last March when a little-known businessman riffled through a stack of papers from Wall Street investment bankers looking for ideas about companies to take over.

title: CHANNEL 31 TRYING TO CHANGE IMAGE
description: How does Ben Kingsley, an actor noted for his stage work in the classics as well as such film roles as ''Gandhi,'' go about communicating the ironies in an ambiguous passage of Shakespeare? What tactics does Sinead Cusack, who starred here last year in the Royal Shakespeare Company productions of ''Much Ado About Nothing'' and ''Cyrano de Bergerac,'' use to hold an audience's interest during a Shakespearean soliloquy? How do Peggy Ashcroft and Ian McKellen interpret the hidden poetry in Shakespeare's lines?

title: Amy S. Pater Is Bride Of Robert M. Podhurst
description: Amy Sephora Pater, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hyman Pater of Cedarhurst, L.I., was married yesterday to Robert Marc Podhurst, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Podhurst of Lido Beach, L.I. Rabbi Joel Zion performed the ceremony at Temple Israel in Lawrence, L.I.

title: WARSAW LIMITING CLEMENCY ACTION
description: The Polish Government has asked prosecutors to make a case-by-case review of the 368 people in jail for their beliefs and political activities. But the move fell far short of a general amnesty for political prisoners, which had long been hinted at by officials.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE;Tighter Rein Promised For Spendthrift Farm
description: The Combs family of Lexington, Ky., knows a bit about bloodstock. And, based on their recent actions, they are betting that Timothy T. Green does also.

title: U.S. HISTORIANS DISAGREE WITH PRINCE
description: King George III, whose reputation was defended yesterday by Prince Charles, has often been held in low regard both in England and the United States, and not all historians agree that the King has had a ''raw deal,'' as the Prince of Wales put it.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS;Catching Up
description: The Portland Breakers do not figure in the United States Football League's plans for 1986, and besides, they're still being sued by the U.S.F.L. Players Association for salaries due members of last season's team. At the bottom line is this: All of the franchise's players are now free agents, and that includes Marcus Dupree, who bolted the University of Oklahoma as a sensational sophomore running back and later signed a five-year, $6 million contract with the Breakers in 1984, when they were based in New Orleans. Dupree's contractual freedom may be moot, though, because, back home in Philadelphia, Miss., he is still slowly rehabilitating a knee that was severely damaged in the opening game of 1985. ''If it is a career-ending injury,'' says Jack Galmiche, the Breakers' president, ''Marcus will collect the remainder of his contract from Lloyd's of London.'' And if it is not, then Dupree has his sights set on the National Football League. Though not eligible for the N.F.L. draft until 1987, he would likely petition the league to accept him next year.

title: MONDAY, NOVEMBER 11, 1985
description: International Israel and Jordan held talks that could lead to an international conference to which Jordan would bring only Palestinians acceptable to Israel, Israeli Government sources said. [Page A1, Column 6.] The Geneva meeting might produce an agreed-upon statement of ''guidelines'' providing impetus to the arms control negotiations between the United States and the Soviet Union, Reagan Administration officials said. But they stressed that there was only a slim chance of this. [A1:4.] Moscow condemned a radio speech addressed Saturday to Russians by President Reagan, charging the broadcast showed Washington was not interested in peace. [A1:5.] President Reagan gave his support to any move to repeal a resolution adopted 10 years ago by the General Assembly of the United Nations equating Zionism with racism in a message to the Conference on Israel, Zionism and the United Nations in New York. [A1:6.] Thriving free enterprise in Canton impressed and perplexed a Soviet parliamentary delegation that visited the city. ''If this is Marxism, I must re-read Marx,'' one of the Russians is said to have remarked after seeing Western-style hotels and many other signs that Canton is pursuing an ''open door'' policy. [A1:3.] 12 judges shunned memorial rites in Bogota, Colombia, for the scores of people who died in a siege at the Palace of Justice last week. The judges, who survived the battle in which 11 justices died, said they stayed away to protest the Government's handling of the crisis. [A3:1.] Poland took a step toward freeing political prisoners that was still far short of a general amnesty, which had long been hinted at officially. The Government asked prosecutors to make a case-by-case review of prisoners who could be released. [A9:1.] National King George III was defended by his descendant, the Prince of Wales, in a news conference in Washington. He also said his wife found John Travolta a good dancer. The Princess and the actor danced at a White House dinner Saturday night. [A1:1.] An Arizona community was erased because it contained an asbestos hazard. The attractive subdivision of Mountain View Mobile Home Estates, housing about 50 families, was built on the site of asbestos factory just outside Globe, Ariz. [A12:2.] The Soviet seaman who jumped ship off New Orleans had initially ''decided somehow that he wanted to come to the United States,'' Secretary of State George P. Shultz concluded. But he defended the Reagan Administration's decision to permit the seaman to depart with his ship despite a subpoena by the Senate Agriculture Committee. [A13:1.] Irv Rubin, the new leader of the Jewish Defense League, said anti-Semitism is on the rise in the United States and that he plans to revitalize the group by training Jews and non-Jews in the use of weapons and other paramilitary activities. [A17:1.] Metropolitan A plane collision over New Jersey killed the occupants in both private planes and started fires as wreckage fell on residential and commercial buildings in Fairview and Cliffside Park, opposite Manhattan's Upper West Side. Broken power lines blacked out more than 1,400 homes in both communities. [A1:2.] The mother of a teen-age suicide has tranformed her grief into a crusade against suicide prevention among children. Anne Spoonhour's 14-year-old son, Justin, hanged himself in February 1984 near his home in Putnam Valley, N.Y. She is among the volunteers and professionals educating the public about depression among adolescents and about early warnings of suicide. [A1:1.] A high-school admissions study said New York City's selective public high school admissions system places poor and minority students at a disadvantage and ''creates the suspicion of racially discriminatory admissions practices.'' [B3:5.] Refurbishing of bridges, tunnels and airports operated by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey would be undertaken over the next five years under a $5 billion plan now being prepared, Stephen Berger, the agency's new director, said. [B8:1.] VETERANS DAY Parade - Begins at 10 A.M., moving down Fifth Avenue from 39th to 24th Street. Parking - Alternate-side rules suspended. Sanitation - No collections; no street cleaning. Federal, state and municipal offices - Closed. Post offices - Closed; special delivery and express-mail delivery only. Banks - Most closed.

title: Deborah Sussmann Is Wed
description: Deborah Susan Sussmann and Jeffrey Robert Edelheit, 1983 graduates of Ithaca College, were married yesterday at the Colonial Manor in Old Tappan, N.J.
