Rabbi Frederic Pomerantz officiated. The couple's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Frederick A. Sussmann of Harrington Park, N.J., and Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Edelheit of Blauvelt, N.Y.

title: POTVIN FITTING IN, STANDING APART
description: THE ego has landed.

title: Washington Watch;Chamber to Meet on Taxes
description: The business community has been divided over a number of major tax policy issues. But Wednesday, the board of the Chamber of Commerce will decide whether a common ground can be found on some of the most controversial issues.

title: AFTER A 100-YEAR HIATUS, BISON-HUNTING SEASON IS SET TO BEGIN
description: For the first time in nearly 100 years, hunters will have an open season to kill wild bison, the shaggy, lumbering animals that roamed the Plains in the millions before they were driven to the brink of extinction in the late 1800's.

title: A PRINCE'S GAME HOPES TO GATHER COMMON AUDIENCE
description: LITTLE by little, the great places to play polo had disappeared. So William T. Ylvisaker, onetime star of the Saturday night matches in the 69th Regiment Armory in New York, decided in 1976 to build the grandest polo place in America, if not the world.

title: Broodmare Brings Record $7 Million
description: The financier Carl C. Icahn paid a record $7 million for a broodmare at the Newstead Farm Trust dispersal sale today. Mr. Icahn, a 49-year-old New Yorker who recently reached an agreement to acquire Trans World Airlines Inc., paid the record price for Miss Oceana. The 4-year-old bay mare is in foal to the highly prized stallion Northern Dancer.

title: THE FAMILY;USING FAMILY LORE IN THERAPY
description: Most families have their legends, their dreams and their illusions. But researchers who have been studying family myths are gaining greater understanding of their power to influence behavior. This knowledge has given therapists new techniques for helping problem families.

title: Mischief' at the Board of Estimate
description: How do you raise money without losing your soul?'' Mario Cuomo wrote in his diary of the 1982 gubernatorial campaign. The recent New York City primary showed that campaign expenditures still exceed reason and decency. The need to raise big bucks seems to make it harder for candidates to worry about losing their soul. A few have private fortunes; others, usually incumbents, rely on funds from people who have benefited from the officials' public positions.

title: BRIEFING;Modest Proposal
description: Every day the House Ways and Means Committee is in session on tax legislation, dozens of lobbyists hover outside waiting for word about the particular tax preference they are seeking or protecting. Most of them would be delighted if the whole idea of tax revision were scuttled, and recently they have begun to spend the long hours of corridor waiting by plotting schemes to do just that.

title: ARGENTINA IN RUNNING TO GET LOAN
description: The United States is hoping to make Argentina, once Latin America's most incorrigible debtor, one of the first nations - if not the ''test case'' - to receive a new, less-restrictive loan proposed by United States Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d, according to bankers and Government officials here.

title: AROUND THE WORLD;Bus Bombing Kills 6 In Sri Lanka
description: A land mine laid by Tamil separatists blew up a bus today, killing six passengers, the authorities said. The attack was apparently in retaliation for the killing of 33 guerrillas by Sri Lankan troops.

title: U.S. INDIANS ENLIST IN THE MISKITO CAUSE
description: Three American Indian activists have announced in Costa Rica that they are joining the cause of rebel Miskito Indians in Nicaragua.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Nov. 11, 1985 GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: AIR FORCE SEEKING PENN STATE FOR FIESTA
description: If Penn State and Air Force continue undefeated and untied through their two remaining games, Air Force would like to play Penn State in the Fiesta Bowl on New Year's Day for the season's final No. 1 ranking, even though this would cost the academy about $1 million, according to its athletic director.

title: Simms Makes The Big Plays
description: ONLY two teams in the National Football League own a better record than the Giants, who are off and running (and passing and tackling) with a 7-3 start. After a 24-19 victory over the Los Angeles Rams yesterday, the Giants have toppled one of those teams. The other, of course, is the Chicago Bears, undefeated, untied and uncompromising. But in the reality of their four-game winning streak, the Giants deserve to be considered among the Super Bowl XX contenders and their quarterback, Phil Simms, deserves to be considered among the N.F.L.'s most valuable players.

title: PERES AND HUSSEIN ARE SAID TO REACH ACCORD ON TALKS
description: Prime Minister Shimon Peres of Israel and King Hussein of Jordan have an informal agreement to work toward negotiations in which Israel will agree to attend an international conference in return for Jordan's agreeing to bring to the conference only Palestinians acceptable to Israel, Israeli Government sources said today.

title: BRIEFING;DEMOCRATIC FEEL FOR PULSE
description: The Democratic Party, groping for a sense of identity after two thrashings by Ronald Reagan, has commissioned a national study of voter attitudes to help its candidates place themselves favorably in the 1986 and 1988 elections. The first survey research program the party has conducted since 1981, it is designed to discover how Americans feel about the roles of Government and political parties, rather than merely gauge their views on issues.

title: JEWISH DEFENSE LEAGUE'S NEW LEADER TO PRESS WEAPONS TRAINING
description: The new leader of the militant Jewish Defense League, maintaining that anti-Semitism is on the rise around the country, says he plans to revitalize the league by training Jews and non-Jews in the use of weapons and other paramilitary activities.

title: SUBURBAN MALLS THE STAGES FOR PANTOMIME MUSIC
description: Now listen,'' said Diane Schoenbaum, taking the microphone and addressing the audience in Sunrise Mall near the Plaza Dental Group, the Candy Castle and Buster Brown Shoes.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS;Profitable Loser
description: Leonard Postero looks enough like a bulldog to impersonate the University of Georgia's mascot without a costume. He's got the paunch, the jowls, the bald head and, Lord, is he country.

title: Patients Who Can't Turn a Profit Must Go
description: To the Editor:

title: Dinkins Says He Will Replace Board of Education Member
description: David N. Dinkins, the Manhattan Borough President-elect, said yesterday that he would replace the current Manhattan representative to the Board of Education, Marjorie A. Lewis.

title: A TOWN HAILS ITS VIETNAM VETERANS
description: A decade after the end of the Vietnam War, this town welcomed home its Vietnam veterans with a parade down Center Street today.

title: THEATER: 'HAMELIN,' A MUSICAL
description: WITH ''Hamelin,'' a rock musical version of ''The Pied Piper of Hamelin,'' there is no denying the long arm - or tail - of coincidence. It is impossible to watch the new show at Circle in the Square, Downtown, without recalling an uptown feline relative. One can credit the musical's creators only with restraint. They have refrained from calling their collaboration ''Rats,'' although they have slipped in a subtitle, ''A Musical Tale from Rats to Riches.''

title: WORLD WAR II SPIES PLAN SYMPOSIUM ON O.S.S.
description: After 40 years, some of America's grand old spies are preparing to come in from the cold. They want to tell their story before it is too late.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of mechanical failure, a board diagram depicting a key point in the final game of the world championship chess match was illegible in some copies yesterday. An article and corrected diagram appear on page A6.

title: MIDWEST JOURNAL;CONTESTING ATHLETE'S BIG MOVE
description: Marcel Driver is a high school basketball player who wants to live in a suburb of Youngstown, Ohio. But an Ohio judge says he must return to his home here.

title: Advertising;HCM to Be Agency For New Zealand Lamb
description: HCM, the French-American joint-venture ad agency, has been named to handle the New Zealand Lamb Company account, which has a budget in the $4 million area.

title: CRASH SITE: NEIGHBORHOOD AFLAME
description: Oscar and Gloria Velandia huddled on the porch of their house on Cliff Street here, tissues pressed to their noses, and watched firefighters struggle to contain a blaze in a block of buildings just a few doors away.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE;President Named In Sysco Changes
description: The Sysco Corporation, the nation's leading food service marketing and distribution company, has announced a realignment of its top officers.

title: Futures/Options;  A Plethora of New Products
description: FOR a long time, the real battling in the commodities world was between the array of traders and investors who vied for profits in the ''pits'' on the exchange floors. Today, some of the hottest competition is taking place between the exchanges themselves.

title: Advertising;Agencies Rake In Awards
description: AFTER 27 years as a little-known part of the advertising scene, the International Film and TV Festival of New York, held Friday night at the Sheraton Centre, appears to have arrived.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS;Sticky Holdout
description: Topps may be tops when it comes to baseball cards. But if the Major League Baseball Players Association prevails, the Brooklyn chewing-gum company will lose the sway it has long held over a key sector of the market: distribution of the cards as premiums in bubble-gum packages.

title: Recital: Cellist and Pianist
description: Robert Sylvester, who together with Robert Spillman played music for cello and piano at Alice Tully Hall on Saturday night, seems most comfortable in the Romantic world of resonant sound and big gestures. A Telemann Sonata in D, for example, evoked a musical and technical unease from Mr. Sylvester's cello; this awkwardness happily dissolved in the three ''Fantasiestucke'' (Op. 73) by Schumann that came a little later in the evening and were very nicely played.

title: Ester Kurz Becomes Bride Of John Scheibel, Lawyer
description: At the Park East Synagogue in New York yesterday Ester Kurz, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Max Kurz of New York, was married to John Scheibel, the son of Lillian Scheibel of Great Neck, L.I., and the late Herbert L. Scheibel. Rabbi Israel Miller officiated.

title: Peminger Weds Ira Artman
description: The marriage of Amy Lynn Preminger, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Preminger of Englewood, N.J., to Ira Benjamin Artman, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph O. Artman of Pittsburgh, took place yesterday. Rabbi Arthur Hertzberg officiated at the Tamcrest Country Club in Alpine, N.J.

title: AROUND THE NATION;Mayor of San Francisco Plans to Shut Bathhouses
description: Mayor Dianne Feinstein plans to act this week to shut down bathhouses frequented by homosexuals because she believes they encourage sexual activity that helps to spread AIDS.

title: MEXICO CITY AFTER QUAKES: THE HURT RUNS DEEP
description: In most visible respects, life in Mexico City has returned to normal after the September earthquakes that killed at least 7,000 people and left more than 50,000 homeless.

title: A SLOW WEEK FOR TREASURIES SEEN
description: The regular weekly auction of Treasury bills will be delayed until tomorrow, because the Government securities market is closed today for Veterans Day. No auctions of Treasury notes and bonds are scheduled this week, though securities dealers expect the Treasury to quickly announce auctions of new issues due in 3 years, 10 years and 30 years, totaling more than $22 billion, as soon as Congress approves legislation to increase the Federal debt ceiling.

title: UNKNOWN SOLDIER,' ON CHANNEL 13
description: THE inscription on the Tomb of the Unknowns in Arlington National Cemetery reads:

title: Senators Need a Prod On Immunization Plan
description: To the Editor:

title: Holes in the Anti-Apartheid Embargo
description: President Reagan took the wind out of the sails of the bipartisan anti-apartheid movement in September when he buckled to pressure and signed an executive order outlining sanctions against South Africa. But now that the outline is taking shape in the form of diluted regulations, it is clear the Administration's commitment to end apartheid was only half-hearted.

title: One Vote for Explicit Sex Over Original Sin on the Airwaves
description: To the Editor:

title: BRITAIN FINDS SIGNS OF HOPE
description: Polls show Britons losing patience with Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's economic policies, and there is a widespread belief that the prospects are bleak. Britain's industrial imports exceeded exports last year for the first time since the nation gave birth to the Industrial Revolution. Unemployment is at record levels and rising. Manufacturing costs are increasing faster than in other major industrial countries. North Sea oil output is peaking. Amid all this, however, there have been some less noted developments that could lead to a brighter future. Most important, perhaps, has been a revival of interest in economic self-help, reflected in a booming venture capital market and the creation of new businesses at a record rate.

title: AROUND THE WORLD;Pope Condemns Policies That Stop Famine Relief
description: Pope John Paul II today condemned political disputes that prevent food from reaching the world's hungry.

title: Talk to the Opposition
description: To the Editor:

title: KREMLIN ASSAILS REAGAN SPEECH AS EMPTY TALK
description: The Soviet Union today condemned President Reagan's radio address to the Russian people on Saturday, charging the broadcast showed Washington was not interested in peace.

title: MCENROE ROUTS JARRYD
description: John McEnroe, improving with each match of the tournament, routed Anders Jarryd, 6-1, 6-2, today to win a record fourth singles title in the $375,000 Stockholm Open-Scandinavian Tennis Championships. It was the most one-sided championship match ever in this tournament, the world's oldest Grand Prix indoor event.

title: Man, 25, Found Slain In Home on Fire Island
description: A Manhattan man was found shot to death Saturday in the village of Saltaire on Fire Island, where he was a summer resident, the Suffolk County police said yesterday.

title: PORT AUTHORITY CHIEF SEEKING NEW FUNDS FOR BASIC SERVICES
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey is moving away from an era of surpluses and must spend more of its resources to provide basic services to the region, the authority's new executive director, Stephen Berger, said yesterday.

title: Hostages to U.S. Abortion Politics
description: Senator Jesse Helms, who had opposed the nomination of Winston Lord as ambassador to China because he felt that Mr. Lord had not taken a sufficiently vigorous stand against China's birth control policies, finally agreed to let the nomination go through. Even so, United States assistance to third world countries that desperately need help in controlling their birth rates remains hostage to people like Mr. Helms who insist on playing abortion politics here at home.

title: BLALOCK RALLIES TO WIN
description: Jane Blalock of the United States came from behind with an eight-under-par 64 today and won the $300,000 Mazda Japan Golf Classic, the final event of the women's tour, two strokes ahead of Taiwan's Tu Ai-yu.

title: Advertising;Health Account Goes To Saatchi & Saatchi
description: Saatchi & Saatchi Compton has picked up the United States Health Care Systems account that was formerly served by Silberman Whitebrow Dolan in Phildelphia.

title: RELATIONSHIPS;PROTECTING THE RIGHTS OF PATIENTS
description: THEY get things done. They cut through hospital red tape and get an air-conditioner fixed quickly. Or they improve communication between a patient and a doctor. They are also good at sitting down and listening to anxiety-ridden sick people.

title: SERVICE STOCKS STAR IN 6-WEEK ADVANCE
description: When the Dow Jones industrial average moved above 1,400 last week and held its ground, the new high dramatized a broad rally that began in late September to give the bull market new life. Among the 30 Dow stocks, the star performers included Exxon, American Can, Du Pont and Woolworth, along with McDonald's, a newcomer.

title: Advertising;Lawson Joins Laurence Shop
description: Thomas F. Lawson, who left Rosenfeld, Sirowitz & Lawson early last week, is joining Laurence, Charles & Free as president and is bringing $35 million in McDonald's billings and 50 R.S.&L. employees with him, according to an agency source who requested anonymity.

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Football Broncos vs. San Franciso 49ers, at Denver. The defending Super Bowl champion 49ers have won two consecutive games and are trying to climb out of the hole they dug for themselves. Neither team has a winning record Monday nights (6-7 for the 49ers and 5-8-1 for the Broncs). San Francisco beat Philadelphia last week, 24-13, as Matt Cavanaugh had a 20-for-35, 255-yard, one-touchdown passing game. The Broncs lost, 30-10, to San Diego with John Elway having a 20-for-35, 222-yard passing performance. San Diego sacked Elway four times and held the Broncos' rushers to 64 yards. (Television - Channel 7, 9 P.M. Radio - WNBC, 660; 9 P.M.) Hockey Rangers vs. Chicago Black Hawks, at Madison Square Garden, 7:35 P.M. First meeting this season. The Black Hawks swept all three games from the Rangers last season, winning the only one of the games played at the Garden, 4-3, in overtime. (Television - MSG, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WPAT, 930; 7:20 P.M.) Other Events BASKETBALL: Hofstra vs. National Team of Finland, exhibition, at the Hofstra Physical Fitness Center, Hempstead, L.I., 7:30 P.M. Gerald King, the youngest of the King brothers, is a 6-foot-5-inch freshman forward with Hofstra. His brother Bernard is out of the Knick lineup with knee problems. His brother Albert plays for the Nets. HARNESS RACING: Roosevelt, 8 P.M. RUNNING: Veterans Day Run, at Clove Lake Park, Staten Island, 3.5 miles, at 11 A.M. THOROUGHBRED RACING: Aqueduct, 12:30 P.M. The $75,000 added General Douglas MacArthur Handicap for New York bred 3-year-olds and up at a mile and an eighth is the Veterans Day feature. (Television -SportsChannel, 6:30 and 11 P.M.) The Meadowlands, 1:30 P.M. The $50,000 added Jersey Blues is the feature at this special matinee. Reliable Jeff is the highweight at 123 pounds and Bill Wheeler the second highweight at 120. (Television - MSG, midnight.)

title: REAGAN BACKS EFFORT TO REPEAL U.N. VOTE ATTACKING ZIONISM
description: On the tenth anniversary of the passage of a General Assembly resolution equating Zionism with racism, President Reagan sent a message to a conference here today saying he would support any move to repeal it.

title: CITY'S CRYSTAL BALL: CLOUDY OR BRIGHT?
description: Ten years after New York City skirted bankruptcy, nearly 150 urban experts and those interested in what they had to say met here at a palatial mansion to spend the weekend pondering the city's future.

title: WHY JUSTICE DEPARTMENT OPPOSES RAILROAD MERGER IN WEST
description: Since 1970, rail merger after rail merger has passed the Justice Department's antitrust scrutiny. But a proposal to unite two parallel railroad systems in the West has stirred the department to protest, illustrating the competitive overlap necessary to arouse antitrust opposition.

title: Bridge: 2 California Teams Leading In Reisinger Championships
description: Two quartets from California were in the lead going into the final two sessions of the Reisinger Board-a-Match team championship this afternoon.

title: LINDBERGH IS CRITICALLY INJURED
description: Pelle Lindbergh, the National Hockey League's top goaltender last season with the Philadelphia Flyers, was gravely injured in an automobile accident early yesterday. Doctors said he was brain dead and had no hope for recovery.

title: DUPER'S RETURN SPARKS MIAMI
description: Pandemonium, the 46th member of the Miami Dolphins, returned to the Orange Bowl today after a long absence.

title: KASPAROV TRIUMPHANT: LAURELS AND A NEW MIEN
description: Gary Kasparov formally donned the laurel garland of the new champion of the game of chess today and with it a more diplomatic manner, announcing that there was a ''big difference between Kasparov the contender and Kasparov the world champion.''

title: TONG, SILIVAS WIN TITLE
description: Tong Fei of China and Daniela Silivas of Rumania each won a world gymnastics title today on the closing day of competition in the World Gymnastics Championships.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SMONDAY, NOVEMBER 11, 1985
description: The Economy

title: Washington Watch;Curbing the F.C.C. on Murdoch
description: Representative John W. Bryant, Democrat of Texas, is proposing legislation that would require public hearings by the Federal Communications Commission before it waives any rule that restricts media ownership.

title: IF PARENTS PART: YOUNG ADULTS DESCRIBE THEIR OWN ANGUISH
description: Michael Ostrow, who has seen the film ''Twice in a Lifetime'' twice, says it revived memories of his parents' seperation two years ago while he was away at college. ''The Gene Hackman character reminded me of my father,'' he says ''and Ann-Margaret, with dark hair, could be my father's girlfriend. Maybe I'm beginning to understand this better now, although when my father left it was very traumatic.''

title: AROUND THE NATION;3 States Seek Prisoners Who Escaped in South
description: Two escaped prisoners eluded a three-state search today while questions were raised about why they had been placed in an unguarded work crew.

title: A Better Deal for Dogs and Cats
description: What sparked the recent outburst of name calling between New York City's humane society and the Mayor's office? The immediate quarrel was over demands of borough presidents for more animal shelters. But it reflected a deeper need, to reorganize and to expand animal control. That's desirable, but not possible without state action.

title: CREDIT MARKETS;Optimism on Paring Deficits
description: Dismay over the size of the Federal budget deficit is far from gone in the credit markets, but there is increasing optimism that Congressional proposals to alter the budget making process will help shrink the deficit in future years.

title: BRIEFING;Window of No Opportunity
description: When still and television photographers who cover the White House are summoned by public address system from the press room to the Rose Garden for an event, they are usually escorted to a holding area just outside the Cabinet Room and the President's Oval Office. Being photographers, they often look into the windows of these rooms. Being news people, they sometimes take pictures through the windows.

title: Dr. Judith E. Levy Married To Dr. Mitchell A. Maiman
description: Dr. Judith E. Levy, an attending physician in obstetrics and gynecology at the Albert Einstein Medical Center, and Dr. Mitchell A. Maiman, a fellow in gynecological oncology at the State University of New York Downstate Medical Center, were married yesterday. Rabbi Bruce Goldwasser officiated at Esterwood in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y.

title: PRINCE AND PRINCESS ENCOUNTER ELITE IN DINNER WITH 'OFFICIAL'WASHINGTON
description: Official Washington made its way along tree-lined Massachusetts Avenue this evening to the imposing British Embassy residence for a black-tie dinner given in honor of the Prince and Princess of Wales by the British Ambassador, Sir Oliver Wright, and Lady Wright.

title: TAX BILL'S DATES SPUR WARINESS
description: With work on tax-overhaul legislation far behind schedule, it appears that businesses and individuals will be forced to manage their financial affairs under a cloud of uncertainty after Jan. 1.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;And Roundabout at 20
description: They wanted to start a theater company in the neighborhood church. But the pastor did not care to have them under his roof. So they used an empty basement storeroom in the local supermarket.

title: Holiday Schedule
description: Most banks are closed today in observance of Veterans Day. The government securities market is also closed. Stock and commodities markets are open as usual.

title: IMPACT OF MEXICAN CURBS ON FOREIGN BANKS CALLED UNCLEAR
description: It is still too early to measure the actual impact of new curbs on foreign banks in Mexico, according to experts here.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Nov. 11, 1985.

title: MALONE LEADS 76ERS
description: Moses Malone tossed in 35 points and the rookie Terry Catledge sparked a fourth-quarter surge tonight that led the Philadelphia 76ers to a 105-97 victory over the Milwaukee Bucks.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Has any pitcher managed more victories in his first two years as a major leaguer than the 41 Dwight Gooden has achieved in that time with the Mets?

title: BEARS RUSH PAST LIONS, 24-3
description: On a rainy, dreary, cold, gray day, not even William Perry could brighten up the Chicago Bears' latest victory.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

title: IN THE NATION;The Great Turnabout
description: The Reagan Administration's curious decision to keep Caspar Weinberger out of the summit conference in Geneva provides a backhanded reminder of a different Defense Secretary, a different summit and a remarkable turnabout.

title: JEWISH MERCHANTS SEEK REASONS FOR VANDALISM
description: The police said yesterday that they still had no clues to the identity or motivations of the vandals who broke the display windows of 13 shops in a predominantly Hasidic section of Brooklyn last weekend.

title: Pakistan Aide, in U.N., Is Firm on Afghanistan
description: The Foreign Minister of Pakistan called today for the immediate and total withdrawal of foreign troops from Afghanistan.

title: 96 More Names to Go On Vietnam Memorial
description: The Pentagon will add 96 names to the 58,022 on the Vietnam Veterans Memorial here after deciding to engrave combat-related deaths on the black stone.

title: The Editorial Notebook;   The Sparrow and My Stetson
description: Some years ago I bought a Stetson Stockman, a large Western hat, in Butte, Mont. I found it useless in an automobile, but good for the bus. In Manhattan, my hometown, it discourages out-of-town visitors from asking me how to find their way by public transportation.

title: JAIL IS ASKED FOR ARGENTINA'S EX-LEADERS
description: The prosecution asked a military court today to strip three former Argentine rulers of their rank and to sentence them to 12 to 8 years in prison for ''negligence'' in conducting the country's 1982 war with Britain, according to the Defense Ministry.

title: Roaming Representative Of the Finest
description: If the name of Police Officer Janet Greco is not a familiar one in your household, that is because your household is not in the small West German town of Husum.

title: Changes Again In the C.B.A.
description: Since basketball was first played in 1891, any number of administrators have imposed all manner of changes in the rules, both experimental and permanent. But it's a safe bet that nobody has done more rule-changing than Jim Drucker.

title: Uganda Rebels to Free 39 on Plane in 2 Days
description: Ugandan rebels said today that they had custody of the 49 passengers and crew members aboard a hijacked Ugandan Airlines plane and that within two days would free all except 10 military personnel held as ''prisoners of war.''

title: ATLAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DONOVAN COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
COLOMBIAN REBEL, A LAWYER, WENT INTO COURT BUILDING BEFORE IT WAS SEIZED
description: A short while before rebels seized the Palace of Justice here last week, the rebels' commander, a lawyer, showed a guard his credentials, entered the building and had a look around, a senior Government official said.

title: Anti-Pornography Law Defeated in Cambridge
description: A proposed ordinance that would have made it a civil rights violation to ''traffic'' in pornography and would have permitted civil lawsuits against ''traffickers'' was rejected in a referendum last Tuesday, election officials announced today.

title: THOMOPOULOS RESIGNS AS ABC NETWORK CHIEF
description: Anthony D. Thomopoulos, president of the ABC Broadcast Group, resigned yesterday, effective immediately, from his position in charge of the television and radio networks' programming, sales, news, sports and entertainment.

title: Eureka! Lean Prose!
description: It is easy to catch the Federal bureaucracy when it issues poorly written reports, analyses and news releases suffering anything from anacoluthon to zeugma. It is refreshing, then, to happen upon a lean, straight-forward paragraph that clearly summarizes a complex situation.

title: Union to Vote Today on Pact In Strike at General Dynamics
description: The bargaining council of the United Automobile Workers today approved a contract with the General Dynamics Corporation that could end a two-month-old strike against the nation's leading defense contractor.

title: MISTAKE DISCOUNTED
description: It was brave, foolhardy, daring. And it had helped bring the Jets at that point to the best record in the American Football Conference.

title: 2 BORDER AGENTS FACE PUNISHMENT IN SAILOR EPISODE
description: The Commissioner of the Immigration and Naturalization Service said today that he expected disciplinary action to be taken against two Border Patrol agents who forcibly returned a Soviet seaman to his ship last month.

title: Dollar Coin on Subway
description: To the Editor:

title: JUPITER'S BAFFLING RED SPOT LOSES SOME OF ITS MYSTERY
description: THE Great Red Spot of Jupiter is yielding its mystery to a new approach by physicists and meteorologists.

title: PRESIDENT STRESSES STRENGTH IN RITES FOR VETERANS
description: President Reagan marked Veterans Day today by paying emotional homage to the nation's war dead and declaring that the ''surest way to keep a peace going is to stay strong.''

title: The Marcos Connections in the Capital
description: As debate over United States policy toward the Philippines has moved into the forefront in Washington in recent months, so has the discussion over President Ferdinand E. Marcos and his wife, Imelda, in the use of United States aid to their country.

title: Alcohol Level Cited In Lindbergh Crash
description: The blood alcohol content of Pelle Lindbergh, the Philadelphia Flyers' all-star goalie who was critically injured Sunday morning in an automobile accident, was measured at .24 percent, the team's physician said today. A motorist with a level of .10 is considered legally drunk.

title: BULOVA WATCH CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary tax charge of $564,000. c-Including extraordinary tax credits of $836,000 for the quarter and $2,106,000 for the 9 months.

title: 'The News' Closes
description: ''The News,'' a rock musical by Paul Schierhorn about the problems confronting the editor of a big-city tabloid, closed Saturday night at the Helen Hayes Theater. The play, directed by David Rotenberg, ran for four performances and 22 previews.

title: Student Killed, 17 Hurt In St. Louis Bus Crash
description: A school bus carrying 30 students spun out of control on a busy highway today and slammed into a concrete pillar, killing an 18-year-old girl and injuring 17 other people, the police said.

title: High Court and the Fourth Amendment
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 12, 1985
description: International

title: COMPUTERIZED HUMAN BODY ADVANCE ECOLOGY RESEARCH
description: Scientists at the Los Alamos National Laboratory here believe they have created the ''research rat of the future,'' a computer program that duplicates the complex systems of the human body.

title: SIDNEY LUMET HONORED
description: ''It never was a battle between me and the Coast,'' said Sidney Lumet, the New York-based director. ''In the beginning, it just happened that the studio system existed and it seemed to me a dumb way to work. I remember going out there once for a production meeting in the 60's and having 32 department heads there, people who had nothing to do with my movie, people I never saw again. And they wonder where all the money's going to.'' So Mr. Lumet, for these and other reasons, has been making his films in New York ever since.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A report in the Art People column in Weekend on Friday about a suit involving a 1981 auction of Impressionist paintings at Christie's misidentified a lawyer, Robert Weiner. He represents Cristallina S.A., the company that consigned the paintings to Christie's.

title: STOCK AVERAGE SOARS BY 27.52 TO RECORD CLOSE
description: The stock market yesterday recorded its best one-day gain in 10 months as investors bought up shares, drawing confidence from lower interest rates. Most major indicators advanced sharply into record territory.

title: COEUR D'ALENE MINES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: Why Fuel Prices Rise When It Gets Cold
description: To the Editor:

title: SABERHAGEN WINS CY YOUNG AWARD
description: In one of the most unusual outcomes in the annual voting, Bret Saberhagen of Kansas City won the American League's Cy Young award yesterday with a onesided victory over Ron Guidry of the Yankees.

title: SCHOLAR TURNS UP A HAYMARKET BOMBING SUSPECT
description: Ninety-nine years ago this week, four anarchists were hanged in Chicago after having been convicted of killing a policeman by tossing a bomb when the police came to break up a protest meeting of workers near Haymarket Square. The sensational ''Haymarket riot'' case, as it came to be known, forged the reputation that persists to this day of anarchists as violence-prone fanatics.

title: The Leak in the Pork Barrel
description: Nowhere has Congress indulged its taste for political pork more than in the billions lavished on water projects that return little to the general public. That's why the reforms in the big water resource bill now before the House are so heartening - and why it is so important to resist the last-minute demands for continued special treatment of the lower Mississippi Valley.

title: 25,000 ON STRIKE IN EL SALVADOR
description: About 15,000 workers went on strike today, joining 10,000 other workers who previously walked off their jobs to demand higher wages and to protest arrests of union leaders on subversion charges.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: IT was a season for superlatives on Seventh Avenue and beyond. Some lines, such as Oscar de la Renta's, seemed pale with pastels and eye-insulting prints. But even the most sedate and grown-up spring collections - Bill Blass and Geoffrey Beene were the best examples - had something chic to say to customers of any age. And Seventh Avenue's new body-consciousness threw enough curves to startle the most jaded fashion eyes.

title: INDIA'S OLD SCHOOL TIE: HARROW BY THE HIMALAYAS
description: The ''old boys'' will probably talk about it for years.

title: CANADIAN PACIFIC LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Why He Didn't See the Wall
description: He was the best in the National Hockey League at what he did.

title: Monet's Vision
description: The lack of detail and color subtlety in the later works of the Impressionist painter Claude Monet can be attributed to postoperative cataract problems, according to letters the artist wrote to his ophthalmologist.

title: ROUTE OF JET IN CRASH OVER JERSEY THAT KILLED 6 IS CALLED 'UNUSUAL'
description: The corporate jet that collided with a small plane over New Jersey Sunday was on an ''unusual, nonstandard'' course for its intended landing at Teterboro Airport, an official close to an investigation of the crash said yesterday.

title: SUIT TO LINK SMOKING AND DEATH OPENS THIS WEEK
description: John M. Galbraith, an insurance executive, started smoking in 1930, when he was 18 years old. From then on, he smoked two to three packs of cigarettes a day. On July 23, 1982, Mr. Galbraith died at the age of 69.

title: JORDANIAN PRIME MINISTER TO VISIT SYRIA
description: The Prime Minister of Jordan is due to travel to Damascus Tuesday as part of the reconciliation effort by Jordan and Syria, the Amman radio announced today. It will be the first visit of its kind in six years.

title: CORNERSTONE FINANCIAL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Revenue figures represent net interest income.

title: Mullin Makes a Swift Impact
description: Since his belated signing last week with the Golden State Warriors, Chris Mullin has more than lived up to his considerable advance billing and his new $500,000-a-year contract.

title: Getting It Right
description: Charles G. Driesell, esteemed basketball coach at the University of Maryland, has decided it is time for a change. At the age of 53, and after 505 coaching victories in nine years at Davidson and 16 at Maryland, he has let it be known that he no longer wants to be known as Lefty, an appellation that he says was pinned on him in grade school in Norfolk, Va.

title: Live Aid, Live Spend
description: A unit of Georgetown University, the Center for Immigration Policy and Refugee Assistance, has been chosen to screen all proposals for spending about $70 million raised in this country from the Live Aid rock concert last summer in Philadelphia.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: DEFENSE PRAISED
description: The time has arrived to take the Giants seriously.

title: Falwell Praises Marcos In Visit to Philippines
description: The Rev. Jerry Falwell arrived here today for a two-day visit that supporters said would be similar to his recent journey of support for South Africa.

title: Reagan and Freud
description: President Reagan is not known for a psychoanalytic approach to things.

title: DAWSON GEOPHYSICAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: FREUD'S MIND: NEW DETAILS REVEALED IN DOCUMENTS
description: NEWLY revealed documents provide richer detail than has been known before about Sigmund Freud's own thinking and activities as a therapist. Such documents are considered crucial to a better understanding of how psychoanalysis evolved.

title: BENEQUITY HOLDINGS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Year-ago results are not available because the company commenced operations on May 16, 1985. Results for the latest 9 months are for the period from May 16, 1985 through Sept. 30, 1985.

title: No Headline
description: West Bank Palestinian Is Killed by Own Bomb

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: CUTTING EDGES. Making Sense of the Eighties. By Charles Krauthammer. 221 pages. Random House. $17.95. IT is sad to live in present-day America, now that harvests have declined so precipitously, food rationing has been introduced and ''steak has become a memory.'' It must be even sadder to live in ''starvation-wracked Japan.'' Or rather it would be sad, if these particular prophecies of doom had been fulfilled. They were made by Paul Ehrlich in his 1968 book ''The Population Bomb''; they are cited by Charles Krauthammer in ''Cutting Edges'' in a passage that exemplifies one of Mr. Krauthammer's great strengths as a controversialist, his ability to seize on the giveaway quotation or the exquisitely revealing chink in his opponent's armor.

title: OUSTED REACTOR AIDE NOW TRAINING OTHERS
description: A reactor operator who was dismissed from the Three Mile Island nuclear facility after the Nuclear Regulatory Commission found he had cheated on three licensing examinations is now in charge of a training program for operators, a House subcommittee disclosed.

title: FRENCH AIDS PATIENT, TREATED WITH CYCLOSPORINE, IS DEAD
description: A French doctor who helped develop a controversial treatment for AIDS said today that one of his patients had died, but he said the experimental program has shown great promise and is being expanded.

title: Man Shot to Death Fleeing 3 Robbers
description: A 22-year-man was shot to death yesterday when he tried to escape from three robbers who had held him and a friend captive overnight in an apartment in the Co-op City section of the northeast Bronx, the police said.

title: NEW STUDY TIES COFFEE DRINKING OF 5 CUPS DAILY TO HEART DISEASE
description: Scientists from the Johns Hopkins Medical School reported today that a person who drinks five or more cups of coffee a day is almost three times as likely to develop heart problems as a person who drinks no coffee at all.

title: NICARAGUA TIES PEACE ACCORD TO AN END TO U.S. INVOLVEMENT
description: Nicaragua said today that it would not sign any Central American peace agreement until the United States stopped supporting anti-Government rebels.

title: QUESTIONS ON BAR DISCIPLINE IN COHN CASE
description: A disciplinary committee's recommendation that Roy M. Cohn be disbarred has raised a delicate but fundamental question for the five judges who are considering his professional fate:

title: Geneva Rightist Party Gains No Council Seat
description: An attempt by the rightist political party Vigilance to gain a seat in the Geneva cantonal government has failed in an election marked by a higher-than-usual turnout.

title: MIDTOWN DRUG SWEEP CRITICIZED AS VIOLATION OF CIVIL RIGHTS
description: During a noontime narcotics sweep at the W. R. Grace & Company Plaza in midtown last month, dozens of people were singled out from the outdoor lunch crowd, surrounded, spread-eagled and searched by police officers.

title: CUOMO BACKS TAX BILL WITH LOCAL DEDUCTION
description: Governor Cuomo has told Democratic tax writers in the House that he is prepared to give his ''enthusiastic support'' to their overhaul of the Federal tax code, as long as they preserve the right of taxpayers to deduct state and local taxes from Federal returns.

title: LEHRMAN SAYS HE WON'T RUN IN RACE FOR GOVERNOR IN 1986
description: Lewis E. Lehrman, who was defeated in the 1982 race for governor, said yesterday that he would not seek the Republican gubernatorial nomination next year.

title: Broncos Win, 17-16
description: John Elway fired a pair of first-half touchdown passes, and Rich Karlis drilled a 24-yard field goal with 1 minute 27 seconds remaining, lifting the Denver Broncos into sole possession of first place in the American Football Conference West with a 17-16 victory over the San Francisco 49ers tonight.

title: ENERGAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
WHEN THE ROYAL PAIR TALK, YOU CAN HEAR A TIARA DROP
description: Once upon a time, beautiful young princesses wore golden crowns and talked of such things as lumpy mattresses, evil magicians and impudent swineherds wanting to steal kisses.

title: South Koreans Protest Over Purported Torture
description: About 120 leading dissidents held a rally today and began a three-day protest of purported torture of political prisoners by the police.

title: SOVIET REFORMS HAVE FAMILIAR RING
description: THE key word in the current drive for school reforms in the Soviet Union is productivity.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A caption in Metropolitan Report on Friday with a drawing depicting the ''pizza connection'' trial misidentified the judge. He is Pierre N. Leval.

title: Baby Moons and Eggs: Early Theories on Spot
description: THE Great Red Spot has been a 300-year case of ''the more you know, the less you know.''

title: FLYING NEAR NEW YORK IS A CHALLENGE
description: The safe movement of air traffic to and from New York City's smaller, peripheral airports is a tough challenge for both pilots and Government traffic controllers.

title: WEST SIDERS FIGHT SCHOOL ON PLAN TO BUILD TOWER
description: The 70-year-old Walden School, which says its existence depends on building condominiums above its building on Central Park West, is embroiled in a bitter dispute with neighbors who oppose the development plans.

title: Joy From Jersey
description: That smell of excitement in the New York air is wafting in from the direction of the Meadowlands, where the Jets and the Giants, both at 7-3, have now equaled their best collective start since the Jets were founded in 1960 as the Titans.

title: SOVIET COVERAGE OF AFGHAN WAR: HEROIC YOUTH AND TALES OF DANGER
description: The Soviet force in Afghanistan may still be a ''limited contingent'' doing its ''internationalist duty,'' but almost six years after it began, the Afghan war has begun spawning stories about heroes and military feats in the official press -and even some questioning by the public.

title: Stay Out of Angola's War
description: Should the United States come to the aid of anti-Communist rebels in Angola? Doing so would be legal now that Congress has repealed the Clark Amendment, which barred such aid since 1976. Many Americans are pressing the Reagan Administration to side openly with Jonas Savimbi, commander of the Unita insurgents. In their eyes it is a simple choice, no different from helping the guerrillas who resist Soviet invaders in Afghanistan. Angola's Marxist Government gets copious aid from the Soviet bloc. Why not balance the scales?

title: ROYAL TOUR: PENNEY'S TO STATE PAPERS
description: The man who would be king played amiable merchandiser today, inquiring about the quilt presented to him at a J. C. Penney's department store.

title: ATLANTA'S ZOO ADDS A CLINIC TO IMPROVE CARE OF ANIMALS
description: The Atlanta Zoo has cemented the first major step in its effort to shore up its credibility by dedicating a clinic for its animals.

title: COLUMBIA GAS SYSTEM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income after losses from discontinued operations of $300,000 for the quarter and $1 million for the 9 months and a charge for the 9 months of $30 million related to synthetic gas operations. c-After a charge of $207 million to establish a reserve for unrecovered gas costs.

title: Texas Board Reverses Stand on Schoolbooks
description: The State Board of Education has reversed itself and decided that people quoted in history textbooks do not have to be identified by their political affiliations.

title: CONCORD FABRICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 1
description: b-Including tax credits of $309,000 for the quarter and $14,000 for the year. c-Net income. Results are for 13 weeks and 52 weeks for the latest periods and 14 weeks and 53 weeks for the year-ago periods.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The Islanders sent the left wings, Dale Henry and Glenn Johannesen, to the Springfield Indians of the American Hockey League. Greg Gilbert, another left wing, who is recoving from reconstructive surgery on his left knee, was sent to the Indians for conditioning. . . . Angel Cruz will defend his New York State junior-welterweight title against James (Buddy) McGirt in a scheduled 12-round bout at Madison Square Garden's Felt Forum Nov. 29. . . . The forward Buck Williams of the Nets beat out the Houston Rockets' center, Akeem Olajuwon, as the National Basketball Association's player of the week. . . . The Cincinnati Reds and the San Francisco Giants completed a trade involving two 24-year-old left-handed pitchers. The Reds obtained Colin Ward for Bob Buchanan, who was placed on the Giants' 40-man winter roster.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report in the Company Briefs column of Business Day last Tuesday gave a price mistakenly for the Geo International Corporation's sale of its Magnaflux unit.

title: DAMON CREATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results for the latest quarter and 9 months include royalty income from the Francesca licensee.

title: Illinois Democrats Set Ticket
description: Attorney General Neil Hartigan dropped out of the Democratic race for Governor today, saying he would back former United States Senator Adlai Stevenson 3d against Gov. James R. Thompson, who is seeking a fourth term. Mr. Hartigan said he would seek re-election as State Attorney General. In the 1982 election Mr. Thompson beat Mr. Stevenson by 5,074 votes of more than 3.6 million cast.

title: RISING DISCORD ON SKI RESORTS SPILLING INTO VERMONT POLITICS
description: High on the slopes of the sprawling Killington ski complex here, a cluster of handsome new white clapboard town houses is under construction. A ski trail wanders through the development, Sunrise Mountain Village, and each dwelling commands an idyllic view of the valley below.

title: HINTS OF SOVIET SHIFT ON ISRAEL DOUBTED
description: Despite a flurry of contacts and promising rumors, Israeli officials said today that they still saw no sign that the Soviet Union was preparing to restore diplomatic relations with Israel.

title: Richardson Arrives Late
description: Micheal Ray Richardson said tonight that heavy traffic had caused him to miss the Nets' flight Sunday from Newark.

title: Move Against Drugs Begins
description: Several Latin American governments have joined with the United States military and a host of Federal agencies this month in a crackdown on drug smugglers, Vice President Bush said today. About 250,000 pounds of narcotics were seized in the operation's first 10 days, he said.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of a distributor's change of plans, a film listing for ''Sugarbaby'' on Sunday in The Guide was outdated. The film opens Friday at the Lincoln Plaza 2, Broadway at 63d Street.

title: ATLANTIC FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a net gain of $683,000, or 23 cents a share, from a Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. preferred stock dividend received in the first quarter. c-Net income.

title: A TOUCH OF NOEL COWARD
description: At the dinner for the Prince and Princess of Wales at the British Embassy Sunday night, a singing group of four members of the embassy staff and two Americans entertained with five songs, including a modernized version of ''The Stately Homes of England,'' a satirical song by Noel Coward from the 1930's.

title: BIO-RESPONSE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Municipalities' Liability
description: To the Editor:

title: Policeman Slain in Punjab
description: Three Sikh extremists drove off 28 police officers sent to arrest them today, killing one officer in the second slaying of a policeman in Punjab state in less than a week, the authorities said.

title: The Cost of Psychiatric Hospital Care Is Up
description: To the Editor:

title: Q&A: Senator William Proxmire;   On the Occasion of a 70th Birthday
description: One of the Senate's best known mavericks, Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, turned 70 today.

title: Chess: Better to Attack or Defend? Result Provides the Answer
description: It's difference of opinion that is said to account for horse races, but it also explains why one grandmaster will revel in the chance to steal material and show off his uncanny defensive play, while his opponent will lick his chops at the prospect of taking the other side of the position with its exciting opportunities for a crushing attack.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A caption on some copies of the Style page yesterday, with an article about the effect of divorce on adult children, misidentified the student shown at the bottom of the picture grouping.

title: BUFFETS INC reports earnings for 12 wks to Oct 9
ESSEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: PRODUCING FOREIGN CHARACTERS
description: CHI-CHEN WANG, emeritus professor of Chinese at Columbia University, is an aspiring writer who, in his 87th year, has grown disenchanted with the Underwood No. 5 typewriter he has used for four decades. The Underwood was a faithful servant as Professor Wang translated half a dozen volumes of Chinese fiction, but earlier this year he went shopping for a computer word processing system. He chose the I.B.M. PCjr, but ''I soon discovered its limitations and finally got rid of it last week,'' he said. Still, ''even the little experience I have had with my PCjr word processor has convinced me that it is a better tool than the typewriter,'' he added.

title: Fire Warning Forces Landing
description: An American Airlines jet returned to Metropolitan Nashville Airport Sunday and 142 people on board were evacuated by emergency chutes and hatches when a fire warning light went on shortly after takeoff, the authorities said. There were no serious injuries and no smoke or flames, a spokesman for the airline said. The flight had been scheduled to land at Dallas-Fort Worth.

title: GROWTH IS ISSUE IN ALBUQUERQUE RACE
description: No one quite agrees on where this city in the Rio Grande Valley fits in with the rest of the West.

title: CLARK EQUIPMENT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a special charge of $73.1 million for the quarter and 9 months. c-Net income.

title: DISNEY, WALT PRODUCTIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss after a pretax charge of $165,960,000. c-After a pretax charge of $165,960,000 and a gain of $76,111,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: The U.N. Today; Nov. 12, 1985
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: WILLIAMS SEEKING NEW TRIAL OVER ATLANTA CHILD MURDERS
description: Asserting that prosecutors withheld critical evidence, a group of lawyers asked for a new trial today for Wayne B. Williams, whose two murder convictions in 1982 led the police to close 23 other cases involving the deaths of young blacks here.

title: The Bayou Blues
description: Frustrations are producing embarrassment for the New Orleans Saints, who were totally outplayed in the fourth quarter against the Seattle Seahawks Sunday during their fifth consecutive loss. ''The harder we play, the behinder we get,'' said Coach Bum Phillips.

title: SMALLEST PLAYER AIMS FOR BIGGEST GAIN
description: With all the hoopla over one of the largest players in the National Football League, William (The Refrigerator) Perry, it might be easy to overlook the smallest player in the league, Lionel (Little Train) James. He is a 5-foot-6-inch, 172-pound running back for the San Diego Chargers who is bearing down on a 10-year-old league record.

title: Pact Eludes India and China
description: India and China failed today to settle a 23-year-old dispute over their Himalayan border, the Press Trust of India said. Senior officials ended a week of talks here without agreement on rival claims to thousands of square miles of mountain terrain, the news agency said. The two sides agreed to meet again in Peking to discuss the dispute that led to war in 1962 and a 14-year break in diplomatic relations.

title: A Reason to Smile
description: Despite the risk of losing their eligibility, half of the nation's top collegiate athletes ''are being taken care of'' by agents while still playing, said Tony Degrate, a defensive lineman with the University of Texas.

title: Private Plane Crash Kills 5 in Pennsylvania
description: A twin-engine private plane crashed in a dense fog this evening in a woods north of here, killing five people, officials said.

title: PHILIPPINE AIDE SAYS DEFEAT OF REBELS MAY TAKE A DECADE
description: The Philippine Defense Minister said today that it would take at least a decade before the anti-Government insurgency could be contained, an estimate sharply different from one made last week by President Ferdinand E. Marcos.

title: Bridge: Rosenkranz's Team Wins 12-Deal Reisinger Playoff
description: A dramatic 12-deal playoff to resolve a tie concluded the Reisinger Board-a-Match team championship here early today.

title: Lean Language, Not Cuisine
description: Eat less fat to ward off heart disease and cancer. That's the advice of health and nutrition experts, including the National Cancer Institute and the Department of Agriculture. But the department's fat-labeling policy discourages healthier eating habits.

title: PRODUCTION OF A PLAY BY FASSBINDER DROPPED
description: The manager of the Kammerspiel theater in Frankfurt announced tonight that he had abandoned plans to stage the premiere of a play by Rainer Werner Fassbinder that has been denounced as anti-Semitic.

title: Nobel Doctors in Town
description: The Physicians for Social Responsibility is the American affiliate of the International Physicians for the Prevention of Nuclear War, which was awarded the 1985 Nobel Peace Prize.

title: The Value of Workfare
description: The movement, spreading across the country, to require welfare recipients to work for the support they get is a promising trend indeed. Workfare may initially cost the nation more than traditional welfare programs did, but in the long run it will surely be worth the money.

title: JERSEY AIRPORT AMONG BUSIEST IN THE COUNTRY
description: Teterboro Airport, the destination of the corporate jet that collided with a single-engine plane and crashed in flames Sunday, is one of the busiest airports for private craft in the country.

title: RESEARCHERS CHART STRUCTURES DEEP IN EARTH
description: BRITISH researchers have charted features of the earth's interior to a depth of almost 70 miles beneath the sea north of Scotland. Using shock waves generated by multiple air guns and a two-mile array of receivers towed underwater behind a research vessel, they believe they have traced ''the deepest and most continuous structures imaged in the upper mantle.''

title: THE DANCE: ATERBALLETO, A NEW TROUPE FROM ITALY
description: ATERBALLETO is the name of a young ballet company in Italy whose organizers are attempting something new. Since the troupe's appearance over the weekend at Brooklyn College was its New York debut and since it has received considerable attention in the European dance press, this first glimpse drew a good number of viewers from the American dance world.

title: 2 ANTI-SANDINISTA LEADERS WORK ON AN ACCORD LISTING THEIR GOALS
description: Two Nicaraguan rebel leaders, trying to overcome their differences, said today that they were working on a new agreement setting forth the political goals of their United States-backed movement, which is dedicated to the overthrow of the Sandinista Government.

title: HOLDING ON IN A RUNWAY
description: It is an axiom among sports broadcasters that a cheeseburger behind the microphone could hold an audience in a close game, while the test of skill comes during a blowout. That was proven again Saturday night on ESPN, when Jim Simpson and Paul Maguire used all the honest tricks of their trade during Florida State's 56-14 rout of South Carolina.

title: Unesco Head Refuses To Decide on New Term
description: As a Unesco meeting ended here, the organization's Director General, who has been criticized by Western countries for his handling of the agency, refused today to say whether he would seek re-election.

title: DANCE: TAIPEI'S CLOUD GATE TROUPE
description: LIN HWAI-MIN, the artistic director and choreographer of Cloud Gate Taipei Contemporary Dance Theater, is very much an idea man. His version of Stravinsky's ''Rite of Spring'' suggests a contemporary urban population dancing itself collectively to death. In ''Nirvana,'' his vision of enlightenment, all swirl and color, might have been the brainchild of a Scriabin turned Buddhist.

title: PRETORIA PREPARES PLANS TO EXPEL FOREIGN WORKERS
description: South Africa's Minister of Manpower said today that the Government was preparing ''contingency plans'' to send foreign black workers home in light of punitive international economic measures against this embattled nation.

title: RANGERS FALL IN OVERTIME
description: The Rangers, who already had fallen prey to opponents' killer instincts in their three previous overtime losses this season, did not intend to fail again last night. But fail they did, for their fourth overtime loss in four attempts, as the Chicago Black Hawks muscled their way to a 5-4 victory.

title: No Drake Football in '86
description: Drake University is dropping intercollegiate football for one season and will reinstate the sport in 1987 on a scaled-down level, the university president, Michael Ferrari, announced today.

title: 'Organizational Schizophrenia in the I.N.S.'
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW CHIEF OF MORMONS
description: The Banyan of 1927, the yearbook at Brigham Young University, named Ezra Taft Benson ''Most Likely to Succeed,'' and even at that moment in his life, few doubted it was a sound prediction.

title: No Sanction for Games
description: The United States Olympic Committee will not endorse or sanction participation by United States athletes in the 1986 Goodwill Games scheduled for next July in Moscow, said George D. Miller, the secretary general of the U.S.O.C. The Goodwill Games is an event initiated by Ted Turner, owner of a cable broadcasting system in Atlanta. ''The United States Olympic Committee is obviously in favor of international competitions among all nations,'' Miller said.

title: Growing Commodities
description: Three commodities exchanges, now housed on various floors of 4 World Trade Center, have a proposal for new headquarters.

title: DATA DIMENSIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
AMERICAN HEALTHCARE MANAGEMENT reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
AMERICAN PHYSICIANS SERVICE GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income including extraordinary credits of $144,919 for the quarter and $199,164 for the 9 months.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: AN AGNELLI LECTURE Susanna Agnelli is Italy's Under Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, a Senator in Italy's Parliament and a member of the family that owns the Fiat automobile company. She has also been Mayor of Monte Argentario, a town of 10,000 in Tuscany. And this week she can add to her list of accomplishments her visit to Barnard College as Gildersleeve Lecturer in Residence.

title: THE 'STAR WARS' ISSUE EXPLORED ON CHANNEL 13
description: ''STAR WARS,'' or, if you will, the Strategic Defense Initiative, is surely the most controversial and probably the least-understood defense issue of our time. ''Shielding America: Can 'Stars Wars' Make Us Safe?'' goes a long way toward explaining ''Star Wars,'' without deciding whether it is a good idea or not. Wisely, it leaves that to us. The intelligent program can be seen on Channel 13 at 11 o'clock tonight.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Is it king size or queen size?'' -The Prince of Wales, upon being given a bed quilt. [A26:4.]

title: 'WILD HORSES' ON CBS, STARRING KENNY ROGERS
description: FIGURING he knows what his audience wants, the singer Kenny Rogers is back in another TV western. This one, on CBS at 9 this evening, is called ''Wild Horses'' and, like ''The Gambler'' and ''Coward of the County,'' it comes out of the same formula country once roamed by Gene Autry, Roy Rogers and Hopalong Cassidy. Kenny Rogers, his hair whiter and his gut heavier, simply gives the tradition his own low-key, laid-back spin in a contemporary setting. Imagine, if you will, Perry Como riding tall in the saddle.

title: THEATER: RIDICULOUS'S 'SALAMMBO'
description: HAVING created what may be the crowd-pleaser of his career with last season's ''Mystery of Irma Vep,'' Charles Ludlam has reverted to parochial ridiculousness with his new Ridiculous Theatrical Company production, ''Salammbo.'' An ''erotic tragedy'' inspired by Flaubert's historical novel about Carthage in 300 B.C., this extravaganza gets under way when a general orders some surly barbarians to ''go camp outside the city gates.'' The barbarians continue to camp on stage. ''Wine, meat, women!,'' they chant incessantly -until, that is, one of them politely amends the request to ''just wine and meat.''

title: COLONIAL COMMERCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $138,112 for the quarter and $466,804 for the 9 months. c-Net losses after losses from discontinued operations of $433,210 for the quarter and $1,281,384 for the 9 months.

title: DIAGNOSTIC-RETRIEVAL SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: BANK OF MISSISSIPPI reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CARNEGIE HALL AUCTION GALA
description: ''I'll probably bid on Salzburg,'' said James Wolfensohn just before last evening's Carnegie Hall benefit auction at Christie's. And the chairman of the board of Carnegie Hall and co-chairman of the recital hall's $50 million fund-raising effort did just that. He outbid a host of others raising their paddles and bought a four-day trip to the Herbert von Karajan Easter Festival in Salzburg next March for $12,000.

title: Honor for a CUNY Leader
description: The library that serves the Graduate School and University Center of the City University is known simply as ''the library.'' But today it will be dedicated to Dr. Mina Rees, a prominent mathematician and educator who is the graduate school's founding president.

title: 100 CHILDREN IN LINCOLN CENTER PROGRAM
description: Lincoln Center will play host to more than 2,000 children - 100 on stage and the rest in the audience -today at 11 A.M. and 1 P.M. when the Meet the Artists Program presents the first of its Celebration Series, featuring members of Jacques d'Amboise's National Dance Institute.

title: Whale's Odyssey Benefits Scientists
description: A humpbacked whale's 25-day odyssey along the Sacramento River gave scientists a chance to study its elusive species at close range and provided new knowledge into the habits of whales.

title: A SUN FAR FROM HOME COURT
description: Adjusting to a new life in pro basketball is something that about 50 rookies have had to do in these past few weeks. As a rule, the pro game is more physical than college basketball. And the average player is more talented. Those factors, combined with a long and tiring schedule, mean that the rookies' skills and stamina are almost always being tested.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Knicks vs. Phoenix Suns, at Madison Square Garden, 7:35 P.M. Ed Pinckney from Villanova, who starred at Adlai Stevenson High School in the Bronx, makes his only Madison Square Garden appearance this season. The 6-9 forward was the Suns No. 1 pick, the 10th player chosen in the draft. This is his first meeting with Patrick Ewing since Villanova upset Georgetown in the N.C.A.A. final last spring. (Television - MSG Network 7:30 P.M. Radio - WPAT, 7:30 P.M.). Nets vs. Spurs, at San Antonio, 8:30 P.M. First stop on the Nets' seven-game road swing. The Nets are 0-3 on the road so far. Last season the Spurs won both games played between the teams. (Television - SportsChannel II, 8:30 P.M., live. SportsChannel 10:45 P.M., tape. Radio - WNBC, 660; 8:30 P.M.). Boxing Dwight (Tiger) Walker vs. Kevin Watts, at Atlantic City, Tropicana Hotel and Casino, middleweights, 10 rounds. First preliminary, 7:30 P.M. Walker, from Newark, N.J., is 22-5-1, with 9 knockouts, and has won a 10-round decision from Wilford Scypion, a former top contender, on Sept. 17. Watts, from Pleasantville, N.J., is 12-1, with 8 knockouts. Hockey Islanders vs. Montreal Canadiens, at Uniondale, L.I., Nassau Coliseum, 8:05 P.M. The Islanders won the only game played on home ice against Montreal last season and lost both games in Montreal. This is the first of two games at the Nassau Coliseum this season. The next meeting is in Montreal on Jan. 18 and then at the Coliseum on March 4.

title: Kissinger Meets With Deng
description: Former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger met today with Deng Xiaoping, the Chinese leader, to review international issues. Mr. Kissinger is in China as a guest of the Government.

title: LEADER OF BISHOPS' CONFERENCE DEFENDS ACTIVISM
description: The leader of America's Roman Catholic bishops today defended the bishops' activism and called on the coming world synod of bishops to strengthen the role of national bodies like his.

title: Shadows in Chest X-rays
description: Apical densities are shadows the doctor does not like to see in a chest X-ray. They often reveal tuberculosis. But doctors at the County Health Department in Palm Beach, Fla., have discovered another possible cause of these ominous shadows -hair.

title: TWO ROADS TO DODGE CITY
description: THE news is that the peripatetic Nigel Nicolson - Virginia Woolf scholar, lecturer, former Member of Parliament, one-time publisher, historian, master of Sissinghurst Castle and that most English of British intellectual writers - is about to drive himself 3,000 miles into America. The instinct is to laugh. Mr. Nicolson smiles politely. ''Does it sound so odd?'' he asks. He is seated in the Barbizon-Plaza Hotel's coffee shop, sipping coffee and smoking Players cigarettes. He is serious. There is no way to explain that his venture sounds like a banana peel awaiting its victim. His question must be answered.

title: Casino Owner Testifies About Threats to Sons
description: The owner of four Las Vegas gambling casinos says criminals trying to seize control of the casinos threatened to kill his sons if he did not sell out.

title: COMPUTER-AIDED DESIGN DOOMS LESSER TOOLS
description: THE technological scrap pile grows ever larger. In less than a decade, the slide rule has vanished almost completely, replaced first by the calculator, then by the personal computer. Now, it appears, the parallel bar, the compass, the divider, the French curve and other mechanical drawing tools are destined to be relegated to the Smithsonian as well, cast off as the result of the introduction of low-cost - well, relatively low cost -computer-aided design, or CAD, programs.

title: NETS DEFEATED AGAIN ON ROAD
description: The late-game heroics that have kept the Nets unbeaten in six games at home are missing on the road where they are still looking for their first victory in four games after losing tonight to the San Antonio Spurs, 111-104, at the HemisFair Arena.

title: A Wee Hope for Ulster
description: Britain and Ireland are on the verge of an unprecedented agreement about Northern Ireland, which will give the Republic a consultative responsibility in the region.

title: 'Organizational Schizophrenia in the I.N.S.'
description: To the Editor:

title: A Lesson of the Yurchenko Affair
description: I myself have experienced the ordeal of former Soviet citizens known in the West as ''defectors.'' Their behavior can be bizarre and often unpredictable, particularly in the early days of the defection. This simple explanation may be valid in the case of the K.G.B. defector Vitaly Yurchenko, who last week decided to return to the Soviet Union after claiming that he was kidnapped, beaten and drugged by the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: Tiffany and the Prisoner
description: Three years ago, Leonard Bermudez, a prisoner in the Metropolitan Correctional Center in lower Manhattan, sought a ''quality'' ring for his fiancee, Awilda de la Cruz.

title: CANDIDATES WOO BLACKS IN MIAMI RUNOFF TODAY
description: On the north side of Miami, 62d Street cuts across a black neighborhood that whites have tended to avoid since the 1980 riot in Liberty City.

title: Imlach Hospitalized
description: George (Punch) Imlach, the former general manager and coach of the Toronto Maple Leafs and former general manager of the Buffalo Sabres, was listed in stable condition and resting comfortably in the intensive care unit of a Las Vegas, Nev., hospital after collapsing in a casino. The 67-year-old Imlach has a history of heart problems, but a spokesman at Desert Springs Hospital said Imlach apparently had not suffered a heart attack, as first suspected.

title: KARAN, KLEIN: FIRST IN SPORTSWEAR
description: Donna Karan's clothes are sexy and draped to the body; Calvin Klein's are cool and spare. Representing the best of American fashion, they brought the spring fashion openings to an end. What remains is for buyers to pick the clothes that will be in the stores in a few months when consumers will give the ultimate verdict. They will choose from clothes that are singularly lacking in frills and folderol.

title: RANKING UPSETS L.I.U.
description: When the 23 bids for the Division I soccer tournament of the National Collegiate Athletic Association went out yesterday, three New York teams got them, but not in the order expected.

title: COMPANIES AID LABS ON CAMPUS
description: WITH a helpful push from the tax laws, corporations have stepped up their support for basic scientific research at university laboratories, moving into an area that has traditionally been underwritten by the university or the Government.

title: ESQUIRE RADIO & ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: U.S. SEEMS PUZZLED BY SOVIET STANCE ON SPACE WEAPONS
description: A high-ranking Reagan Administration official said today that Soviet negotiators continued to insist on barring research into space-based defense systems although Mikhail S. Gorbachev has hinted that such research might be allowed.

title: ARREST OF 16 SUSPECTS AUTHORIZED
description: Prosecutors investigating the Achille Lauro hijacking announced today that they had issued 16 arrest warrants in the case.

title: A KEY SOVIET ALLY IN POLISH PARTY IS RELIEVED OF HIS POLITBURO SEAT
description: Poland's Foreign Minister, a senior politician long regarded as a key Soviet favorite within the Polish party hierarchy, was relieved of his Politburo seat today.

title: EGYPT REPORTS FOILING A LIBYAN 'HIT SQUAD'
description: Egyptian authorities announced today that four Libyans were arrested here last week on charges of trying to assassinate a group of Libyan exiles, including a former Libyan Prime Minister who was the intended target of a foiled Libyan plot in Egypt a year ago.

title: ARTIFICIAL HEART PATIENT SUFFERS ANOTHER STROKE
description: William J. Schroeder, the world's longest-living recipient of a permanent artificial heart, has suffered a third stroke and was readmitted to the hospital today, a spokesman said.

title: CASTLE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
HECK'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: CURTIS D. MACDOUGALL
description: Curtis D. MacDougall, a journalist, teacher and author, died Sunday. He was 82 years old.

title: City Introduces Water Bonds
description: The New York City Municipal Water Finance Authority made its bond market debut yesterday with a $165 million issue offered through underwriters led by Paine Webber.

title: WURLITZER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including gains of $5,000 for the quarter and $41,000 for the 6 months from discontinued operations and after losses of $840,000 for the 6 months from foreign currency translation and $64,000 for the 6 months from the sale of a vending products subsidiary. c-Including a gain of $31,000 from discontinued operations.

title: CORPORATE PLANE TRAFFIC NEARING 'SATURATION'
description: The air collision over New Jersey Sunday night came after 10 years of increasing traffic by corporate aircraft that has come close to saturating the airspace over New York and its suburbs.

title: SUN SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: WHEREHOUSE ENTERTAINMENT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
THE QUESTION IS 'HOW?'
description: Hondurans are preparing to choose a new President, but with elections only two weeks away a debate over exactly what voting method to use has thrown the process in doubt.

title: ADAMS RESOURCES & ENERGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $219,000 for the quarter and $1,007,000 for the 9 months. c-Including tax credits of $120,000 for the quarter and $1,271,000 for the 9 months.

title: TIC INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $3,000 and settlement and litigation- related costs of $574,000. c-Net income, including extraordinary gains of $30,000 for the quarter and $47,000 for the 6 months.

title: SCIENTIFIC SOFTWARE-INTEROMP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $25,000 for the quarter and $875,000 for the 9 months. c-Including a tax credit of $181,000.

title: STORER COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a $4,723,000 gain for the quarter from the exchange of the company's systems in Phoenix, Mesa and Paradise Valley, Ariz., and Southern Orange County Calif., for the Times Mirror company's systems in North Little Rock and Jacksonville, Ark., Point Pleasant Beach, N.J. and Louisville, Ky., and after merger, proxy and recapitalization expenses of $4,079,000. c-Net loss, including a gain of $3,753,000 from the sale of systems. d-After a loss of $9,410,000 from the sale of systems and merger, proxy and recapitalization expenses of $18,257,000. e-Including a gain of $6,416,000 on the sale of systems.

title: Airlines Urged to Change Engine Part on Jetliners
description: Federal investigators, acting on evidence gathered in the crash of a Midwest Express DC-9 in Milwaukee, urged airlines today to replace an engine part on hundreds of jetliners with a newer, stronger part that has been available since the the late 1970's.

title: UNILEVER N V reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Unilever N.V. c-Unilever PLC. d-Including an extraordinary gain of $70 million for the quarter and the 9 months.

title: Hearing-Impaired Help
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: KIRBY EXPLORATION CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $1,653,779 for the quarter and 9 months. c-Net loss and after a loss from an accounting change of $29,146,609 for the 9 months.

title: A LAGGING MA BELL OFFSPRING
description: For the first year and a half after the breakup of the Bell System on Jan. 1, 1984, the seven new regional phone companies seemed more alike than different. Now, one of the seven, the Southwestern Bell Corporation, has distinguished itself - and not for flattering reasons.

title: MORGAN PRODUCTS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 28
Union Ratifies Contract At General Dynamics
description: The United Automobile Workers today ratified a contract with the General Dynamics Corporation, ending a three-state, seven-week strike.

title: Franklin Whitehouse Service
description: A memorial service for Franklin S. Whitehouse Jr., a reporter for The New York Times and a former member of The New York Times Company's corporate-relations staff, will be held Friday at 4 P.M. at the Reformed Church of Bronxville, N.Y., at Pondfield Road and Midland Avenue. Mr. Whitehouse died Nov. 9. He was 51 years old.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: DEAR SIR OR MADAM In 16th-century England, after Thomas Seymour, Lord Admiral, forced his attentions on 15-year-old Elizabeth Tudor, later Queen Elizabeth I, she wrote him a letter reassuring him of her continued friendship. Mozart wrote what is believed to be his earliest letter, to his mother, when he was 5. Cassandra Austen described in a letter the death of her sister Jane in 1817. Brillat-Savarin, the 18th- and 19th-century gastronome, wrote graphically of his dalliances with a maiden. Sarah Bernhardt begged a lover's pardon in a letter apologizing for her ''spoiled'' behavior. And Lord Cornwallis wrote George Washington to propose an end to the Battle of Yorktown in 1781.
