title: Group Reports Torture On Rise in Zimbabwe
description: Amnesty International, the human rights organization, asserted today that there had been a sharp rise in Zimbabwe of incidents of arbitrary arrest and torture of opponents of Prime Minister Robert Mugabe.

title: TACO VILLA INC reports earnings for 13 wks to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: TREASURY YIELDS FALL SOME MORE
description: Interest rates on Treasury securities continued their descent yesterday, with long-term bond yields moving close to 10 percent, a level not seen since mid-1980.

title: BECTON DICKINSON & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
RECORD FINE BY LLOYD'S IN FINAL SCANDAL INQUIRY
description: Lloyd's of London, in concluding its investigation into a series of scandals that came to light in 1982, today imposed a record $1.4 million fine and expelled from its membership the former head of an insurance syndicate who diverted $60 million in insurance funds to himself and a small group of associates.

title: Hyundai Chips
description: The Hyundai Electronics Industries subsidiary of the Hyundai Corporation has closed its semiconductor factory in the United States because of heavy losses, company officials said. They said that Hyundai Electronics America of Santa Clara, Calif., would continue research, development and marketing work, but would cease production of silicon chips. Hyundai Electronics invested $40 million in the subsidiary in October 1984, but industry sources said that it has since lost more than $200 million.

title: CANADIENS SET BACK ISLANDERS
description: The way Billy Smith perceived it, the goalie who was more distracted was the goalie who lost the game. The Islanders were beaten by the Montreal Canadiens, 3-2, tonight at Nassau Coliseum, and Smith was the goalie most plagued by distractions.

title: Royal Price
description: Princess Rooney, a 5-year-old stakes-winning broodmare in foal to Danzig, brought $5.5 million yesterday in Keeneland's November Breeding Stock Sale.

title: No Headline
description: TWENTY years in the writing, ''The Bone People'' was turned down by virtually every major New Zealand publisher before it was brought out last year by Spiral, a local feminist collective. The book, which has just been published in this country by the Louisiana State University Press, would subsequently win the New Zealand Book Award for Fiction, the Mobil Pegasus Prize for Maori Literature and Britain's prestigious Booker Prize.

title: SONESTA INTERNATIONAL HOTELS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: JAPAN'S MAVERICKS SHUN LADDER FOR PEACE CORPS
description: The last thing Toshio Ogawa wanted out of life was the great Japanese dream.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: NEW YORK is a city of small towns and tiny neighborhoods. Sometimes these little communities are mobile: the bus and subway commuters, the taxi pools, for instance. The mobile community to which Catherine Stern belongs is small but stalwart. Every morning this hardy band walks across the 59th Street Bridge, heading toward Queens.

title: Now Hear This
description: Someone may have discovered a way to stop the Senate from talking: turn off the system that pipes a recording of floor action into all Senate offices. Last week, after he was apparently alerted by an aide, Senator Carl Levin, Democrat of Michigan, suddenly interrupted himself in a floor speech and declared, ''Mr. President, I understand that the squawkboxes are not working and that they are playing music instead of my melodious voice.

title: Chance for Ex-Giant
description: With all except one of their defensive backs injured to some degree, the Jets today will probably look at Larry Flowers, a safety and special teams player cut by the Giants last week. The Jets had intended to give Flowers a tryout yesterday but didn't because of poor weather conditions. Flowers played only on special teams for the Giants this season, his fifth in the National Football League.

title: WESTERN WASTE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Market Place;   Small Investor: A New Mood?
description: DESPITE the dazzling rally in the equity market, retail customers of major brokerage houses continue to sell more shares of stock than they are buying. But there are signs that many individuals - pictured yesterday by their brokers as still somewhat cautious and extremely conscious of yield - are taking a more positive view of equities.

title: POLAND'S NEW CIVILIAN PREMIER OUTLINES ECONOMIC PROGRAM
description: Poland's new Prime Minister presented a 26-member Cabinet today that included more than two economists for each of the four generals still holding key jobs.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, NOVEMBER 13, 1985
description: Markets

title: HIJACK DRAMA'S ENDING IS DISPUTED
description: ''Hostage Flight,'' an NBC drama about the hijacking of an airplane and a group of passengers who decide to fight back, has prompted a dispute between the network and the producers of the film about how far the passengers should go in exacting revenge.

title: Bending Time, Saving Millions
description: With little fanfare, Congress has taken a big step toward sensible national labor policy. Buried in the huge defense authorization bill signed by President Reagan last week is a small provision to let Federal contractors use ''flextime'' work schedules.

title: Real, Not Serious
description: Jim Devellano, general manager of the Detroit Red Wings, describes the perenially weak Norris Division: ''It's like puppy love. No one takes it seriously, but it's real for the puppies.''

description: b-Including tax credits of $556,000 for the quarter and $3,235,000 for the 9 months.

description: b-Net loss

description: b-Including income from discontinued consolidated operations of $142,000 for the quarter and $543,000 for the 9 months, losses from a discontinued unconsolidated affiliate of $3,854,000 for the quarter and $4,424,000 for the 9 months and an extraordinary gain of $470,000 for the quarter and 9 months from the termination of defined benefit pension plans. c-Including income from discontinued consolidated operation of $433,000, a gain of $4,404,000 on the sale of discontinued consolidated operation and an extraordinary gain of $948,000 from the termination of defined benefit pension plans. d-Net loss. Year-ago results have been restated for discontinued operations.

title: An Artisan's Plea
description: After years of watching beautiful old buildings fall to the wrecker's ball, Rene Lavaggi felt he had to speak out. So yesterday, a bit nervous, the 70-year-old stone carver got up before the Landmarks Preservation Commission.

title: U.S. SAYS MANAGUA HARASSES EMBASSY'S NICARAGUAN STAFF
description: The State Department accused the Nicaraguan Government today of harassing Nicaraguan employees of the United States Embassy in Managua by subjecting them to hours of interrogation by state security agents.

title: PACIFICORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Advertising;   Savvy Magazine Plans Trade Advertising
description: Savvy, subtitled The Magazine For Executive Women, starts its first trade advertising campaign on Nov. 18 in Adweek.

title: BRITON TO SEEK HOSTAGES' RELEASE
description: A British church official who helped win the release of four Britons from Libya earlier this year will fly to Beirut on Wednesday to seek freedom for four American hostages, his office said today.

title: Snowballs a Cause of Friction
description: A 24-yard field goal by the barefoot Rich Karlis with 1 minute 27 seconds left was the difference in a 17-16 Denver Bronco victory over the San Francisco 49ers Monday night. But the game will probably be better remembered for a kick that never got off the ground.

title: Oldest Rivalry Is Renewed
description: The football team at New London (Conn.) High School is only 4-4 this season, and its counterpart at Norwich Free Academy only 2-6, and so the two squads will have no big championship at stake when they meet Saturday in New London. What they will have, though - in abundance - is an acute sense of history, because the game will mark the continuation of a series that began in 1875.

title: EMIL N. BAAR, 94, JUSTICE AND LEADER OF REFORM JUDAISM
description: Emil N. Baar, a former justice of State Supreme Court and a leader of Reform Judaism, died Monday at New York Hospital. He was 94 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: HADRON INCORPORATED reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $119,200 for the quarter and $198,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss, after a loss of $136,341 for the 6 months from discontinued operations.

title: Details Expected On G.M.-Hughes
description: The General Motors Corporation will release details of its proposed acquisition of Hughes Aircraft Company on Wednesday, according to sources on Wall Street. G.M. has scheduled a news conference in New York to be conducted by Donald J. Atwood, an executive vice president of G.M. and the president-designate of G.M.-Hughes Electronics Corporation.

title: DECORATOR INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: CITY SAYS TAX INVESTIGATION OF CLUBS WAS HALTED IN '82
description: The City Finance Commissioner said yesterday that in 1981 and 1982 the city investigated several after-hours clubs, social clubs and discotheques for possible tax delinquency but stopped because it was not producing a large enough financial return.

title: ELBIT COMPUTERS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ABC NAMES STODDARD AS ENTERTAINMENT CHIEF
description: Brandon Stoddard, who formerly ran ABC's motion-picture division, was named yesterday to be head of the entertainment division, including all the network's programming.

title: MUSEUM PROMOTES THE ART OF PEACE
description: Some visitors call them keepers of the flame. Durango Mendoza calls them ''Rambos for peace'' - the tiny paid staff and pool of 150 volunteers and 1,500 donors who lovingly built and now sustain the four-year-old Peace Museum here.

title: SOLZHENITSYN AND ANTI-SEMITISM: A NEW DEBATE
description: The expanded version of Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn's ''August 1914'' -containing a new section on the assassination of a Russian prime minister by an anarchist Jew - has touched off a controversy as to whether the Nobel Prize winner and author of the ''Gulag Archipelago'' is anti-Semitic. The new book is already available in French and Russian and is to be published in English next year.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, NOVEMBER 13, 1985
description: International

title: Many Years Off
description: Hopes for Middle East peace are rising again, and they have as usual fastened on the prospect of solving the ''Palestinian problem.'' Before we get carried away, however, we ought to look more closely at some of the proposed ''solutions.''

title: LUSKIN'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 28
LINCOLN INCOME LIFE INSURNCE reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After capital gains of $10,003 for the quarter and $4,530 for the 9 months. c-After capital gains of $24,402 for the quarter and $108,067 for the 9 months.

title: Topics;   New Balance, Old Slang; Bum Rap
description: Nothing evolves faster than slang, and if there's one thing worse than being caught using yesterday's hip expression, it is using yesteryear's. Consider the plan announced by White House publicists for Nancy Reagan and Princess Diana to visit a drug rehabilitation center Monday for a ''rap session'' with the clients.

title: PENTRON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: Ziff Said to Seek Sale of Division
description: The Ziff Corporation is putting its Financial Information Services Group up for sale, a source close to the negotiations said yesterday. The sale, which would be handled by Kidder, Peabody & Company, the investment house, could bring as much as $50 million, according to a source close to the company.

title: TOM BROWN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss of $336,000 for the quarter and the 6 months from discontinued operations.

title: IS HALF A BOTTLE OF WINE BETTER THAN ONE?
description: AT home or in a restaurant, if two wine enthusiasts cannot compromise on a bottle for dinner, the best solution may be a split decision. Interviews with customers and New Yorkers in the wine trade - educators, restaurateurs, retailers - yielded a consensus that the benefits of a half bottle, popularly called a ''split,'' outnumber the liabilities. The exceptions were Champagne and other sparkling wines, because they tend to go flat.

title: '86 Marathon on Nov. 2
description: To avoid conflict with several Jewish holidays, the World Series and the celebration of the Statue of Liberty's centennial, next year's New York City Marathon will take place on Nov. 2.

title: MOVIELAB INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 28
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $573,576 for the quarter and $814,189 for the 9 months and a loss of $2,901,648 on disposal of film processing operations for the quarter and 9 months.

title: DANCE: FENLEY DANCERS AT THE JOYCE
description: TOO much of a good thing -that was the impression one carried away from the opening of Molissa Fenley and Dancers last night at the Joyce Theater.

title: Brain Injury Cited In Player's Death
description: David Cichoke, a Santa Clara linebacker who was found dead Monday in his room, suffered a brain hemorrhage that may have started long after he was injured while making a game-saving tackle, a coroner said today.

title: Chile Truck Owners Say 40,000 Joined in Protest
description: Chile's truck owners, who helped bring down the Government of Salvador Allende Gossens in 1973, said today that a 48-hour protest over gasoline prices had turned into a virtual strike.

title: SCREEN: TWO DOCUMENTARIES, 'CHILDREN' AND 'SILENCE'
description: ''CHOOSING CHILDREN,'' a 45-minute documentary about lesbian mothers, and ''Breaking Silence,'' a 59-minute documentary about incest and child abuse, make up the program opening today at Film Forum. Both are essentially educational films.

title: INDUSTRIAL COOPERATIVES: THE BENEFITS AND PITFALLS
description: While condominiums and co-ops have become the norm in New York's residential market, and office condominiums have started to catch on in recent years, the joint ownership of industrial buildings by small businesses throughout the city is rare.

title: NICARAGUA SAYS IT MAY SEEK JETS TO OFFSET A U.S.-HINDURAN PACT
description: Nicaragua's Defense Minister suggested today that Nicaragua might soon acquire new military aircraft to counter what he said was a United States decision to send F-5 jet fighter planes to neighboring Honduras.

title: Summit Aftereffects
description: Based on the experience of six Presidents over 30 years, the Geneva summit meeting with Mikhail S. Gorbachev is unlikely to strengthen or weaken the political position of President Reagan at home. This conclusion comes from a Washington polling concern, William R. Hamilton & Staff, which analyzed Gallup Poll records of Presidential approval ratings before and after nine summit meetings since 1955.

title: New Deep-Sea Project
description: To the Editor:

title: FALWELL, ON VISIT, ACCLAIMS MARCOS
description: The Rev. Jerry Falwell chided American policy makers today for ''bellyaching'' about the Philippines and said Filipinos enjoy freedom thanks to the family of President Ferdinand E. Marcos.

title: Key Rates
description: n.a.-Unavailable due to observance of Veterans Day * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: HNG/INTERNORTH LOSES TOP OFFICIAL
description: Sam F. Segnar has resigned unexpectedly as chairman, chief executive officer and a director of HNG/Internorth Inc., the big gas pipeline company created last summer through Internorth's acquisition of Houston Natural Gas. Before the merger Mr. Segnar had headed Internorth.

title: HATE THAT TELLTALE GRAY? WELL, NO, BUT PLEASE DON'T ASK
description: I HAVE gray hair and am what the French, with their sometime delicacy, call a woman of a certain age. I'm sort of fond of my gray hair, and I don't mind being of a certain age at all. But what I do mind is when the hair seems to be rushing me from that pleasantly ambiguous category to another, less ambiguous, one.

title: Advertising;   Global Marketing Debated
description: When the topic of global marketing comes up, many people immediately begin to talk about global advertising and its multitude of communications problems. This, said Allen G. Rosenshine, president of BBDO International, is a ''red herring.''

title: Transactions
description: Monday BASEBALL CHICAGO (AL) - Acquired Russ Morman and Dave Cochrane, infielders, and Joel McKeon, pitcher, from Buffalo of the American Association. Purchased the contract of Mike Soper, infielder, from Glens Falls of the Eastern League.

title: SUMMIT PARLEY OVERSHADOWED BY RIGHTS ISSUE
description: Hovering over preparations for the Soviet-American summit meeting, as over any high-level East-West contact these days, is the plight of thousands of people who have clashed with the Government or simply want to leave the Soviet Union.

title: YANKS SET TO HIRE ALTOBELLI AS COACH
description: Joe Altobelli, who occasionally stayed at Yogi Berra's house when both were Yankee coaches, will be given the coaching job Berra rejected, a Yankee source said yesterday.

title: OCCUPIED APARTMENTS WITH INSIDER PRICES ATTRACT A NEW KIND OF LANDLORD
description: Frank Alfredo never dreamed he would become a landlord. But then Mr. Alfredo, a landscape architect from Westchester County, was offered what seemed like an unbeatable deal on two cooperative apartments in Manhattan. There was one catch: The apartments were not vacant. They came with tenants. He bought them anyway, and became a player in one of the city's latest high-stakes, high-risk, real-estate poker games - the purchase of occupied cooperatives or condominiums made available by the conversion of apartment buildings under noneviction plans.

title: DOW RISES 1.782 POINTS, TO 1,433.60
description: Stock prices, after dashing upward on Monday, moved further into record territory yesterday, and the rally showed signs of spreading to more secondary issues.

description: b-Including realized gains from investments of $526,000, or 19 cents a share, for the quarter and $541,000, or 20 cents a share, for the 9 months and a tax credit of $532,000, or 20 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months. c-Including a realized investment gain of $8,000 for the quarter and 9 months.

title: AGENCY CITES STATISTICAL EVIDENCE IN LAWSUITS ON JOB DISCRIMINATION
description: The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission today filed lawsuits charging three employers with illegal job discrimination, and the chairman of the agency said that statistical evidence was an essential part of all three cases.

description: b-Including a gain of $69,002,000 on the sale of subsidiaries and after a loss on investments of $1,445,000. c-Including investment income of $425,000. On Feb. 1, 1985, the company underwent a leveraged buyout, and became privately-held. In connection with the leveraged buyout, the company changed its fiscal year. The current fiscal year began Feb. 1, 1985, and will end Dec. 31, 1985. The prior fiscal year had begun on May 1, 1984.

title: U.S. Official Criticizes Soviet on Africa Famine
description: The United States Secretary of Agriculture John R. Block indirectly criticized the Soviet Union today for not doing enough to assist the victims of famine.

title: Officer Is Guilty of Assaulting Women at an Abortion Clinic
description: A New York City police officer was found guilty last night of assaulting two women outside a Brooklyn abortion clinic last March, according to Brooklyn District Attorney Elizabeth Holtzman.

title: HAROLD KOVNER
description: Harold Kovner, former owner of Park East and Park West Hospitals in Manhattan, died Sunday at the DeWitt Nursing Home in Manhattan.

description: Xavier Suarez, a Harvard-educated lawyer, tonight became the first Cuban-American to be elected Mayor of Miami.

description: A glittering ball inside a fantasy hotel placed by the side of a silvery sea was the setting tonight for the last appearance of the Prince and Princess of Wales on their American visit.

description: In a room crowned by cupids coddled in gold leaf and chandeliers with thousands of shimmering facets, the Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra conducts a classical version of a swinging singles bar.

description: Foote, Cone & Belding/New York has named Ted Littleford executive vice president, executive creative director.

title: Officer to Quit At Allegheny
description: Clayton A. Sweeney, widely regarded as the successor to Robert J. Buckley as chairman and chief executive of Allegheny International Inc., intends to resign as vice chairman and chief administrative officer, the consumer products company said yesterday.

title: Help for AIDS Victims
description: ''An Early Frost,'' an NBC-TV drama about AIDS, dealt with painful issues. But there was cheering among nearly 50 men and women who gathered in an Upper West Side apartment to watch the broadcast.

title: Ship Carrying Drugs Is Sunk
description: A Coast Guard cutter fired warning shots at a Colombian ship loaded with 28 tons of marijuana, boarded her and arrested the crew, then sank the vessel in international waters, officials said today. The cutter, the Gallatin, intercepted the 60-foot vessel Sunday 150 miles northwest of Colombia, Coast Guard officials said. They said the Coast Guard had approval to board the vessel from the Colombian Government.

title: It's Up To Peres, Hussein
description: The prospect for serious negotiations between Israel and Jordan over the so-called Palestinian issue is brighter today than it has been at any time during the three decades of Israel's existence. Preparations for such talks may indeed be taking place now, privately. The next few weeks will be a critical time.

title: TOOLMAKER PLANS CUT IN OUTPUT
description: The Black & Decker Corporation announced plans yesterday to cut manufacturing capacity and take a loss for its fiscal year as a result.

title: CITIBANK ALTERS TERMS ON INDIVIDUAL ACCOUNTS
description: Citibank, the nation's largest bank, said yesterday that it would change the account terms for many of its individual customers in the New York City area, effective Jan. 1.

title: CHALLENGES TO QADDAFI DISCOUNTED
description: The relative weakness of Libyan opposition groups and the rising anti-Americanism among several of Libya's neighbors are likely to complicate any effort to undermine the Government of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, according to Western and Middle Eastern diplomats and specialists here.

title: Bridge: Top Players Can See Danger In Time to Sidestep It Neatly
description: One of the marks of a great player is that he can sense danger threatening a long way down the road. And he can sometimes find a tricky sidestep that will throw a little dust in the eyes of an opponent.

description: ''There is a crying need for babies,'' Sabena Basch said yesterday with no trace of a smile.

description: To the Editor:

title: MUSEUM PIECE ON WAX: ROLLIN'S SOLO CONCERT
description: THE curious and the dedicated, the musicians, the jazz historians and the die-hard fans jammed the sculpture garden at the Museum of Modern Art for a one-time-only event - Sonny Rollins, master modern saxophonist, giving a solo concert. After years of playing easy-rolling music with nondescript bands, Mr. Rollins would perform a full-length concert alone. There was a microphone in the bell of his tenor saxophone that night - last July 19 - and now 56 minutes of music from the concert have been released as ''The Solo Album'' on Milestone Records.

title: ALBERT E. HART Jr.
description: Albert E. Hart Jr., a longtime equestrian official who served as chairman of the American Horse Shows Association, died of a heart attack Sunday at his home in Aiken, S.C. He was 67 years old.

title: 2 Officials in Pope Plot Trial In Turkey to See 2 Witnesses
description: The judge and a prosecutor of the trial in the papal shooting plot arrived in Turkey today to question two key witnesses.

title: 5 DIE IN LEBANON SUICIDE BOMB ATTACK
description: Five Christian political leaders escaped an assassination attempt today when a suicide bomber crashed an explosives-laden truck into a monastery where they were meeting north of here.

title: AGREEMENT REACHED ON SALE OF U.P.I. TO 2 BUYERS
description: The managers, workers and creditors of United Press International agreed late today to sell the financially troubled news agency to a Mexican newspaper magnate and a real estate developer based in Houston.

Another Opinion
description: Marty Schottenheimer responds to the criticism he has received as coach of the Cleveland Browns, who have lost four straight games: ''Some people say I'm dogmatic, bull-headed and maybe lack intelligence, but I don't look at it that way.''

description: When San Francisco lost Monday night to the Denver Broncos, Ray Wersching got some small consolation. title: MAYOR VISITS WITH HOMELESS
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that he spent two hours last Thursday night helping coax homeless people to go to city shelters. And, as a result of his experience, the Mayor said, he will increase pressure on his aides to find ways to compel some of the homeless to go to shelters, even if against their will.

description: Roll over, Ted Stepien, and tell Gulf and Western the news. The record that Stepien, in his own way, helped create in Cleveland will stand for a while longer.

description: A young man was charged yesterday with murdering an elderly couple who lived two blocks from him in St. Albans, Queens.

title: TAKING A LOOK BACK AT DRAKE
description: Drake University's decision to suspend football in 1986 and then reinstate the sport on a scaled-down level in 1987 probably drew ho-hum reactions from most college football watchers across the nation. There was no memorable winning football tradition at the Des Moines institution, which is going to move from its current Division I-AA status in football to the less costly, nonscholarship Division III in 1987.

description: Attorneys for a state judge in Queens charged with taking bribes to fix criminal cases failed yesterday in an attempt to suppress evidence that Federal prosecutors say links the judge to a key witness.

title: Psychiatrist Testifies In Trial of Neo-Nazi
description: A reputed neo-Nazi shot and killed a Missouri state trooper and wounded a second trooper because his religious beliefs taught him that law-enforcement officers wanted to kill him, a psychiatrist testified today.

title: PAISLEY FASHION STATEMENT
Bethlehem Prices
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation said it would raise the price of steel bar $40 to $50 a ton, effectively matching an increase announced last week by the United States Steel Corporation.

title: Several Agencies Offer New Housing Bonds
description: Several large new issues of housing revenue bonds were at the forefront of the tax-exempt market yesterday. The ability of state and local governments to finance housing with tax-exempt bonds would be severely restricted under proposed changes in the Federal tax law, so local governments are trying to sell as many bonds this year as the law now allows.

title: When a President Flouts the Law
description: Down through history, Presidents have occasionally flouted laws passed by Congress or decrees issued by courts. They have tended to be highly selective on such matters, however, usually reserving head-on action for issues of great moment, typically those involving national security.

title: POTLATCH BUYS OUT BELZBERGS
description: The Potlatch Corporation said today that it had bought back a chunk of shares owned by the First City Financial Corporation, led by the Belzberg family of Canada, effectively ending the Belzbergs' takeover bid for the forest products company.

title: Ranger Recall
description: The Rangers recalled Mike Rogers and Steve Richmond yesterday from New Haven of the American Hockey League, just a month after they had been sent to the minors. The two will play tonight against the Canadiens at Madison Square Garden.

title: Another Year
description: Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, the N.B.A.'s leading career scorer, has signed a one-year contract extension to play an 18th season, the Los Angeles Lakers announced yesterday. Terms of the contract were not disclosed.

title: 13 Police Officers Hurt At a Navy Yard Protest
description: Thirteen police officers were injured yesterday when demonstrators seeking more construction jobs for minority workers clashed with the police during a protest outside the Brooklyn Navy Yard, the authorities said.

title: IMPACT OF YOUTH JOB PROJECTS IS DECLARED LIMITED BY PANEL
description: Large-scale Government job training programs for poor youths have had only limited success in increasing employability and preventing socially destructive behavior, a panel formed by the National Academy of Sciences has concluded.

title: NEW WORLD PICTURES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: AIR CARGO EQUIPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a tax credit of 12 cents a share for the quarter and the 9 months.

title: THERMAL PROFILES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
REAGAN EXPECTING FOLLOW-UP TALKS
description: President Reagan said today that he saw no need for a communique after the meeting with Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

title: Ski Film Premiere
description: Four well-known skiers - Jean-Claude Killy, Billy Kidd, and Phil and Steve Mahre - will be among those attending the premiere of the skiing film ''Steep and Deep,'' tonight at 7:30 at Avery Fisher Hall, Broadway and 65th Street.

title: VISTA RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss of $856,156 from discontinued operations.

title: Get It Right, You Guys
description: My admiration for England was born many years ago in darkened movie houses where, as a Jujube-chewing lad in corduroy knickers, I first saw C. Aubrey Smith order the thin red line to hold fast until Ronald Colman and three supporting actors named Reginald could complete the conquest of India and ride to the rescue of the regiment which, unless memory fails, was surrounded somewhere in Africa by a mob of bloodthirsty extras.

title: LIBERIA SAYS IT FOILED COUP ATTEMPT
description: A former military commander tried to topple President Samuel K. Doe in a coup Tuesday, but Mr. Doe said he crushed the revolt 13 hours after it began in this West African nation.

title: HCC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss. c-After an extraordinary loss of $326,000 resulting from the company's repurchase of some of its subordinated debentures.

title: South Dakotans Reject Nuclear Waste Plan
description: South Dakotans voted overwhelmingly today to reject a tangled nuclear waste proposal that had many voters confused and others fearful that it would create a national radioactive dump.

title: Life and Art
description: On the main floor of the State Supreme Court building in lower Manhattan yesterday, reporters were questioning Doron Gopstein, the city's chief assistant corporation counsel, about the Mine Shaft, the bar that was closed last week because, the city charged, it permitted ''high risk sex.''

title: TRILOGY LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a $4 million charge to reserves for the quarter and the 9 months for discontinued development activities. c-After a $43 million charge for initial reserve for discontinued development activities. In October the company completed its merger with Elxsi.

title: TRANSITRON ELECTRONIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 28
description: b-After a provision of $14 million for the shutown of the company's industrial cable and telecommunications divisions and its printed circuit board factory.

title: MONETARY SYSTEM SHIFT IS URGED AT CONFERENCE
description: The volatility of currency exchange rates, especially for the dollar, is causing chaos in the global economy, scores of leading international economists and senior economic officials said today. They argued that a new way to manage currencies was needed, Among those who addressed a conference on overhauling the monetary system was a top official of a Government that until a few months ago disparaged the need for such a change.

title: Provincetown Air Seeks to Cut Fleet
description: Facing stiff competition from a new entrant in the Florida commuter airline market, Provincetown-Boston Airline has worked out a deal with lenders allowing it to continue flying with a reduced fleet. Under the agreement presented to Federal Bankruptcy Judge Alexander Paskay on Monday, the airline would eliminate some flights, end service to three cities, lay off employees and alter routes to steer clear of rival Piedmont Airlines.

title: U.S. FIGHTS FRANCE ON EXPORT CREDIT
description: The Export-Import Bank, officially citing France as the principal cause of export credit wars, today announced a campaign to displace French suppliers with American companies in five export markets, including Algeria, where a French company was hoping to win a $145 million subway car contract.

title: GALOOB, LEWIS TOYS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DEFENSE BEGINS ITS SUMMATIONS IN STEWART TRIAL
description: Defense attorneys, terming the prosecution's case ''baseless,'' began closing arguments yesterday in the trial of six transit police officers charged in the death of Michael Stewart.

title: L E MYERS CO GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NATIONAL HEALTH CORP reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Including a nonrecurring gain of $1,200,000 related to a merger.

title: MICRO D INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: ZENITH NATIONAL INSURANCE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings are fully diluted.

title: KIMMELMAN DECIDES TO QUIT AS JERSEY'S ATTORNEY GENERAL
description: New Jersey's top law-enforcement officer, Attorney General Irwin I. Kimmelman, said yesterday that he would leave his position in January to return to private law practice.

title: LIMITED INC reports earnings for 13 wks to Nov 2
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding have been adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split in June 1985.

title: EAGLE COMPUTER reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 28
THESE VEGETABLES MERIT MORE PRAISE AND LESS BOILING
description: THE autumn produce markets are overflowing with an abundance of cruciferous vegetables: Crisp, shiny green and red cabbages; creamy heads of cauliflower; dark purplish-green clusters of broccoli; brussels sprouts, their tall stalks tightly ringed with miniature cabbages; fringed bundles of pink and dark green kale, and pale globes of kohlrabi, looking like objects about to take off into interplanetary flight.

title: WAL-MART STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings have been adjusted to reflect the 100 percent stock dividend paid Oct. 4, 1985.

title: Unilever Net Rises 15.1%
description: Unilever N.V. said today that its third-quarter earnings rose 15.1 percent, to $183 million, or $3.27 a share, compared with $159 million, or about $2.83 a share, a year ago.

title: BOOTH INC reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
INTERNATIONAL POWER MACHINES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption on Monday with a front-page article about the collision of two planes over New Jersey misidentified the town where an apartment building was on fire. It was Cliffside Park.

title: O'NEILL REPORTED TO BE OPTIMISTIC ON SUMMIT SUCCESS
description: Democratic officials in the House of Representatives said today that as part of a Democratic political strategy for the Geneva summit meeting, Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. planned to say Wednesday that he has high hopes for the talks.

title: 'HAYSTACK' BY MONET IS AUCTIONED
description: Claude Monet's ''Haystack in the Fog,'' sold in an auction at Christie's last night for more than twice the price expected, a price that was about 1,600 times its original purchase price in 1891 by Harris Whittemore. It was the high point of the sale.

title: FRIEDMAN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
A Third AIDS Patient Dies in Test Program
description: A third AIDS patient undergoing experimental treatment in France with the drug cyclosporine has died, the patient's doctor announced today.

title: PERSICO, ON TAPE, DISCUSSES $250,000 PAYOFF TO I.R.S. AGENT
description: Carmine Persico, the reputed head of the Colombo crime group, discussed in 1978 the payment of $250,000 to a supposedly corrupt Federal tax agent if the agent could help him win an early release from a prison term for hijacking.

title: KNICKS WIN BATTLE OF BEATENS, TOPPING SUNS, 103-93
description: Nearly eight months had passed since the Knicks last won a basketball game. In that time, they lost their captain, Bernard King, to a serious knee injury. They lost Bill Cartwright for a third time with a broken foot. And they lost 20 straight games. Last night 12,220 joyous fans at Madison Square Garden stood and cheered as the beleaguered Knicks snapped a club-record losing streak by defeating the Phoenix Suns, 103-93, for their first victory this season after eight defeats.

title: Record Yields in Corn
description: Farmers are getting record yields from this fall's corn harvest despite weather problems that have slowed field work, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: IN most American homes, lamb is considered to be an expensive meat. Yet, ground up, lamb can be a bargain at the butcher, a flavorful bargain at that. I use ground lamb often and in many ways: shaped into patties and grilled, cooked in a skillet, as a basis for stuffed vegetables (it is particularly appealing as a basic filling for eggplant) and so on.

title: PHILIP CROSBY ASSOCIATES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ZAYRE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 26
REAGAN ADAMANT ON MILITARY RISE WITH DEFICIT PLAN
description: In a sharp exchange with President Reagan today, House Democrats said he had to choose between building military strength and eliminating the Federal deficit.

title: IN CALVADOS, THE APPLE'S FINEST HOUR
description: FOR more than 400 years in Normandy, one of only three provinces in France where wine is not produced, the Normans have made their own beloved brandy from apples: Calvados.

title: PROSECUTION COMPLETES RACKETEERING CASE AGAINST GOVERNOR OF LOUISIANA
description: Two contradictory statements by Gov. Edwin W. Edwards in television interviews last year provided the final dramatic moment today in 24 days of testimony in his Federal trial for racketeering and wire and mail fraud. Shortly afterward, the prosecutors rested their case.

title: Machine for Gnocchi
description: WHEN the pasta craze swirled across America several years ago, home cooks ran out and bought pasta-making machines of every type, from simple cranking versions to large electric models. Now from Italy comes the homemade gnocchi machine.

title: SCREEN: 'LOUIE BLUIE,' ABOUT A STRING BAND
description: EVEN if ''Louie Bluie'' were not of musicological interest as a glimpse of the last known black string band in America, it would be winning on the strength of its homespun charm. Howard Armstrong, the fiddler-mandolinist of the title (who got his nickname from a woman who teasingly pretended to confuse him with Louis Armstrong), is mostly seen in an apartment, playing songs and trading wisecracks with a couple of his longtime cronies.

title: General Mills Changes Fills Post of President
description: General Mills Inc., the huge grocery and consumer products company, yesterday announced a sweeping set of executive changes aimed at giving expanded responsibilities to a number of senior officers.

title: SUPERIOR CARE INC reports earnings for 13 wks to Sept 27
description: b-Net loss, after losses from discontinued operations of $670,339 for the 13 weeks and $1,619,587 for the 26 weeks. c-Including a tax credit of $154,000.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Vino Novello Is Here Vino novello, Italy's answer to beaujoulais nouveau, has arrived and is available at a number of New York restaurants and wine dealers, especially those who concentrate on Italian food and wine.

title: Sailor Sentenced to 20 Years For Trying to Sell Navy Codes
description: A 22-year-old American sailor convicted of trying to sell stolen secret Navy code cards was sentenced today to 20 years in prison.

title: At U.N., Soviet and U.S. Clash Over Afghan War
description: The chief delegates from the United States and the Soviet Union clashed here today in a debate over the six-year war Moscow is fighting in Afghanistan.

title: Paris to Try to Counter A Russian Space Shield
description: France will mount a major effort to develop nuclear tipped missiles able to penetrate possible future Soviet space-based missile defense systems, the French Defense Minister said today.

title: BUCKNELL INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Year to July 31
ORGANS DONATED
description: Pelle Lindbergh, the Philadelphia Flyer goaltender whom doctors declared brain dead shortly after his car crashed in Somerdale, N.J., early Sunday morning, died yesterday afternoon at the conclusion of a five-hour operation to remove his organs for transplant.

title: S.E.C. CHARGES SAVIN IN ACCOUNTING VIOLATION
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today charged the Savin Corporation with violating generally accepted principles in its accounting of research and development spending. The S.E.C. said the violations let the company understate its losses by $49 million between 1981 and 1984.

title: ZITEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses of $2,264,000 for the quarter and $3,435,000 for the year from discontinued operations of the company's Gifford Computer Systems subsidiary. c-Net income, after losses of $68,000 for the quarter and $247,000 for the year from discontinued operations.

title: SAVIN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a tax credit of $2,131,000.

title: LIE DETECTORS: SOVIET SPY CASE REVIVES DEBATE
description: The case of Vitaly S. Yurchenko, the purported Soviet defector who returned to his homeland last week in a blaze of publicity, has again raised the question of whether ''lie detectors'' can verify the truthfulness of a trained intelligence agent.

title: SIGMA-ALDRICH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DEFENSE GRILLS INFORMER ABOUT MAFIA TESTIMONY
description: Defense lawyers cross-examined a key Mafia informer yesterday, attacking his testimony in a major narcotics trial in Manhattan.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Nov. 13, 1985 GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: COMPTROLLER NOMINEE GIVES VIEWS AT HEARING
description: The Reagan Administration's nominee for Comptroller of the Currency said today that he did not favor requiring banks to maintain higher levels of capital if that would reduce the overall profitability of the banking industry.

title: PATRICK INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: BISHOPS URGE REVIEW OF NUCLEAR DETERRENCE STAND
description: A group of liberal Roman Catholic bishops has urged a re-examination of a key passage of a 1983 pastoral letter on war and peace that provisionally accepted the idea of deterring war through a balance of nuclear might.

title: COLONIAL GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MONEY TO RUN OUT FRIDAY, FEDERAL AIDES SAY
description: The Federal Government, which has never failed to pay its debts on time, warned today that no further financial maneuvers could be used to avert default if Congress did not break its impasse over the debt ceiling in the next two days.

title: BIG B INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CORRECTION
description: An article on the Style page Oct. 27 about books to ease children's fears reported the availability of ''Alone After School'' incompletely. It is available not only from large book chains but also from local stores.

title: 2 Journalists Cited for Works On 'Subversion of the Media'
description: Paul Anastasiades, a Cypriot journalist, and John Barron, senior editor of The Reader's Digest in Washington, have been given a joint award of $70,000 for ''the best investigative journalism into subversion of the media.''

title: Grand Ol' Backfire
description: Every time President Reagan's campaign to convert Democrats to the Republican Party backfires, the Democrats enjoy a spasm of glee. The latest involves last week's election in Charlotte, N.C., in which Harvey Gantt, the Democratic Mayor, was re-elected, defeating Dave Berryhill, a former Democratic Councilman who became a Republican a year ago. At the same time, Herb Spaugh, another Councilman and Democrat-turned-Republican, was denied re-election when he ran sixth out of eight candidates seeking four open Council seats.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption in Science Times on Nov. 5 with an article about Arnold O. Beckman misidentified the company he founded. It was Beckman Instruments Inc. of Fullerton, Calif.

title: STAGE: 'GOLDEN LAND,' ENGLISH-YIDDISH REVUE
description: ''THE GOLDEN LAND'' is a leisurely journey through the Jewish immigration experience. This potpourri of more than 50 songs in English, Yiddish and a hybrid of both languages traces a patriotic path from the arrival of Eastern European immigrants on Ellis Island through survival in World War II.

title: Shortsighted Surgery
description: A new drug must be proved safe and effective before it can be sold. So must a new medical device. But there is no Government agency that regulates new surgical procedures, just an ad hoc assessment system. Sometimes the system works well; sometimes it runs into quagmires, as with the operation known as radial keratotomy.

title: STOPGAP BILL ON DEBT LIMIT IS APPROVED BY HOUSE PANEL
description: A House committee moved tonight to head off an impending financial crisis that threatened to leave the Government without money by Friday and to cast a shadow over President Reagan's summit meeting in Geneva next week.

title: JUSTICES HEAR BERKELEY AND TV ANTITRUST CASES
description: The Supreme Court heard arguments today on whether a Berkeley, Calif., rent control law violated the antitrust laws and whether Japanese makers of television sets must go to trial on civil charges of antitrust conspiracy and illegal dumping.

title: To Indoctrinate Students With a Fear of All Things Nuclear
description: To the Editor:

title: Topics;   New Balance, Old Slang; Michigan's Magic
description: The misguided notion of a balanced-budget amendment to the Constitution has lost another round. The Michigan House has rejected a resolution calling for a national convention to adopt the amendment.

title: CHICAGO PACIFIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $1,433,000 for the quarter and $15.4 million for the 9 months. c-Including tax credits of $2,776,000 for the quarter and $10,676,000 for the 9 months.

title: LTV Agrees To Sell Mill
description: The LTV Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to sell a steel mill in Alabama formerly owned by the Republic Steel Corporation to the mill's employees.

title: Shuttle Readied for Mission
description: The space shuttle Atlantis was moved to the launching pad today in preparation for its takeoff Nov. 26, two days before Thanksgiving, for a weeklong mission. The seven-man Atlantis crew is to test techniques for space station construction and launch three communications satellites, one of them for the Mexican Government.

title: U.S. STRESSES MANILA DEMOCRACY
description: A senior Reagan Administration official asserted today that while American military interests in the Philippines were of great importance, United States policy toward the Marcos Government was not hostage to the military bases there.

title: COMCAST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a charge of $5 million for the quarter and 9 months from expenses incurred in an unsuccessful bid to acquire Storer Communications Inc.

title: HINDERLITER INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: Gooden Expected to Win
description: Dwight Gooden flew to New York from his home in Florida yesterday at the request of the Mets, who expect the 20-year-old strikeout star to be named the winner of the Cy Young Award tonight as the best pitcher in the National League.

title: BOWMAR INSTRUMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CORRECTION
description: A Company News report in Business Day on Thursday about the forthcoming sale of the Beverly Wilshire Hotel misidentified the purchasing company and one of its other hotels. The buyer is Regent International Hotels, which owns the Mayfair Regent Hotel in New York.

title: WAINOCO OIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income, including extraordinary gains of $622,000 for the quarter and $1,069,000 for the 9 months.

title: American Express
description: American Express opened an office in Peking today to promote its credit card, traveler's checks and tourism operation in China. The company expects that eventually Chinese people will carry credit cards, although there have been no discussions with Peking, the company's president, Louis Gerstner, said. The office will initially help card holders to cash checks rapidly at the Bank of China, replace lost or stolen cards, and advise travelers, he said.

title: OFFICIAL SAYS JET TOOK EVASIVE ACTION
description: The pilot of a corporate jet took evasive action to avoid a single-engine plane shortly before the two craft collided Sunday night east of Teterboro Airport, Federal investigators said tonight.

title: PIPER JAFFRAY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
description: b-Includes a charge of $3.6 million related to the sale of single premium deferred annuities of life insurance subsidiaries of the Baldwin-United Corp.

title: CABLE TV LICENSES WILL GET HEARING
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether the First Amendment bars a local government from allowing only a single cable television operator to run wires through its streets. The case could affect all regulation of cable television.

title: Of Royal Arts and Crafts
description: The Prince and Princess of Wales left town today with their 7,000 pounds of luggage after three fun-filled days, but their legacy to ''art'' remained: a jellybean portrait of the Princess.

title: Restrict RICO to Cases Of Real Racketeers
description: To the Editor:

title: Judges Reach Verdict In Aquino Murder Case
description: A verdict has been reached and will be announced in eight days in the trial of Gen. Fabian C. Ver and 24 other men charged in connection with the assassination two years ago of the opposition leader Benigno S. Aquino Jr., one of the judges said today.

title: FASHION EXPERTS RATE PRINCESS'S STYLE
description: FROM the moment Princess Diana landed on American soil, the big names of America's fashion world were watching. As usual, they found little to agree on but this: ''She is,'' said Lynn Manulis, president of Martha, ''the most charismatic fashion figure that's come down the pike since Jackie O.''

title: KENWIN SHOPS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 29
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $149,000, or 35 cents a share, on the termination of a pension plan.

title: JERSEY JUDGE WEIGHS MANDATORY SCHOOL DRUG TESTS
description: A Superior Court judge heard arguments today on attempts by officials of a regional high school to impose a mandatory drug and alcohol screening test on students.

title: Overweight Children
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: Advertising;   Wilkinson Tries Insert That Turns Into a Box
description: A rather unusual sampling program using a specially designed newspaper insert is apparently having phenomenal results for Wilkinson Sword, U.S.A., the razor marketers in Atlanta.

title: NAVY SECRETARY VISITS SHIPS TO DESCRIBE CUTBACKS
description: Navy Secretary John F. Lehman Jr. said today that the Navy had ordered sharp cutbacks in the time sailors and aviators spend away from home ports in order to save money and reduce morale-damaging family separations.

title: 6 Auditors and 2 Others Indicted in Philadelphia
description: Six present and former municipal tax auditors were charged in Federal District Court today with taking bribes to ignore or reduce tax bills.

title: South Korean Sit-In
description: More than 100 dissidents staged a sit-in for a second day today to protest what they said was the torture of political prisoners held by the Government. A spokesman for the protesters said the sit-in, which will last until Wednesday, was part of a campaign to promote human rights in South Korea.

title: 'LIFE ON EARTH,' ON HBO, NATURE FILM FROM BBC
description: ''LIFE ON EARTH: Themes and Variations,'' at 3:30 P.M., is a curiosity on the Home Box Office schedule. The 50-minute documentary, originally a BBC production, gives us the naturalist David Attenborough and a short lesson in how mammals evolved. Actually, Mr. Attenborough, who wanders in and out, is peripheral. The nature photography, however, is unusual.

title: REAGAN WILL GET PENTAGON REPORT ON ARMS NEEDS
description: The Pentagon said today that before President Reagan goes to the summit meeting next week, Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger plans to submit a report on purported Soviet violations of arms accords and on proposed American responses.

title: Kentucky Crackdown
description: Stung by reports that some former Wildcat basketball players had received improper payments from school boosters, the University of Kentucky's athletic director, Cliff Hagan, has moved to curb boosters' contacts with players and imposed strict new rules on athletes. Hagan ordered all athletes to register their cars with school officials, make written reports on their speaking engagements, provide detailed information on their summer jobs and limit the distribution of their free tickets to Wildcat games.

title: JAMES HANLEY, 84, A NOVELIST AND A PLAYWRIGHT, IS DEAD
description: James Hanley, a prolific novelist and writer of short stories and plays, died Monday in London. He was 84 years old.

title: THE SPORT OF DIVING FOR LOBSTERS IN THE WATERS OFF NEW YORK
description: The Ferris wheel at Coney Island is barely visible in the distant fog as the Scuba Sue, a 36-foot sport-fishing boat, heads away from Brooklyn's Barren Island Marina.

title: SHOULD BASEBALL HAVE MANDATORY DRUG TESTING?
description: Despite gains by other sports, and some problems of its own, major league baseball retains its status as America's pastime. Attendance passed 46.8 million last season and there is talk of expanding beyond the current 26 teams.

title: SUNGROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a nonrecurring gain of $1,611,000 on the sale of three radio stations. c-Net loss. The latest quarter loss reflects a settlement of $225,000 incurred to end an employment contract.

title: Economic Scene;   Kemp, Bradley Monetary Aims
description: THE close bipartisan team of Representative Jack Kemp, the upstate New York Republican, and Senator Bill Bradley, the New Jersey Democrat, summoned the two-day conference on exchange rates and the dollar that got under way here yesterday.

title: PRETORIA RELEASES 5 FROM DETENTION
description: South African authorities have freed from detention the only four whites held under the state of emergency that was declared almost four months ago, the parents of one of those released said tonight.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Boxing Sammy Fuentes vs. Roberto Juarez, 10 rounds, lightweights, at the Showboat Hotel and Casino, Las Vegas, Nev. Fuentes, from Puerto Rico, is 9-1 with six knockouts and is coming off an Oct. 10 seventh-round knockout of Harry Arroyo, former International Boxing Federation lightweight champion.

title: CONTROL RESOURCES INDUSRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
THORN APPLE VALLEY reports earnings for 16 wks to Sept 20
description: The company has changed its name from Frederick & Herrud.

title: Raiders and Romance
description: Last summer, lobbyists for CBS tiptoed through the New York Legislature with a bill that had wide national implications, considering how many corporations are headquartered in the state. It passed, quickly and quietly, making hostile takeovers of corporations (including CBS) almost impossible. Governor Cuomo vetoed the bill, sensibly arguing that no anti-takeover legislation should become law without extensive public discussion.

title: LIGHTER INDONESIAN FARE FOR WESTERNERS
description: SAMPLING Indonesian cuisine is much like reading the vast archipelago's motley history. There are curries; Indian merchants wandered these islands as early as 600 B.C. By the fifth century A.D., the Chinese traded with Sumatra, leaving behind their soybeans along with a treasure trove of Ming porcelain. Others followed, looking for spices: Arabs, Portuguese and, in the 17th century, the Dutch, who established the Dutch East India Company. Each group left its mark.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I have dishonored myself, disgraced my family. Nobody could be any sorrier.''

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: TRAVEL has a way of putting a crimp in the best-laid plans to stay fit. Uncertainty about exercise facilities in hotels and motels, uneasiness about jogging in strange places - especially before dawn or after dark - and lack of control over food choices and preparation lead many people to abandon their at-home program of physical and nutritional fitness temporarily.

title: The Clumsy Giants
description: President Reagan and General Secretary Gorbachev have at least one thing in common on their way to Geneva: together they have demonstrated to the world how not to settle differences between sovereign nations.

title: Comings and Goings
description: John Jefferson, the four-time All-Pro wide receiver who caught only three passes for 30 yards since joining the Cleveland Browns in September, was released yesterday by the club. . . . Willie Horton, who was a batting and first-base coach for the Yankees under Billy Martin this season, has been hired as a batting instructor by the Chicago White Sox. . . . Tom Bensen, the owner of the lagging New Orleans Saints, has been told that if the Saints do not win at least five of their last six games, he should get rid of Coach Bum Phillips. Bensen may not take the advice, but it comes from an expert - Phillips himself. Asked if he was serious about stepping down if the Saints lose as many as two more games, Phillips replied, ''Yep, I think you'd have to.''

title: INTERNATIONAL ALUMINUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a charge of $421,000 from discontinued operations.

title: HANDY & HARMAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a nonrecurring gain of $700,000 for the quarter and 9 months from the forgiveness of prior years' deferred income taxes on the undistributed earnings of the company's Domestic International Sales Corp. under the Tax Reform Act of 1984.

title: BOWL AMERICA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 29
NOW SHOWING ON NATION'S VCR'S: ADVENTURES IN VIDEOTAPE COOKING
description: Take one attractive kitchen and $25,000 to $100,000. Add video cameras, hot studio lighting, sound equipment and a production crew. Mix with miles of videotape. Meanwhile, have a well-known cooking teacher or chef prepare dozens of different recipes. If necessary, settle for unknown actor with a good voice and another with photogenic hands. Stir together all the ingredients and bake for at least 10 hours.

title: TII INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss of $612,000 from equity in the net loss of the company's affiliate, TII Computer Systems. c-After a loss of $66,000 from equity in the loss of the affiliate and including a tax credit of $19,000.

title: Whither Dingell?
description: Representative John D. Dingell of Michigan, who is rounding out 30 years of service in the House, is contemplating running for Speaker next year, associates say. The incumbent, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. of Massachusetts, has announced he will retire at the end of the current Congress.

title: H & H OIL TOOL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income. The company changed from a fiscal year ended Feb. 28 to a calendar year, effective Dec. 31, 1984.

title: SAVOY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: PUBLICITY SAID TO HAVE UPSET DEFECTOR
description: Vitaly S. Yurchenko, once portrayed by the United States as a valuable Soviet defector, had hoped to live anonymously with a woman on the West Coast after he had been thoroughly questioned by the Central Intelligence Agency, a senior intelligence official said today.

title: CONCERT: ROBERT WHITE HOMAGE TO MCCORMACK
description: THE sound of John McCormack's sweet and delicately inflected tenor, once heard, never leaves the ear. Those of us who never experienced a McCormack recital in person must rely on the hundreds of recordings he left to give some idea of the appeal that the Irish artist exerted over his audiences, but those records are enough to persuade us that we are listening to one of the greatest singers in musical history. In a way we are lucky: Making a virtue out of a misfortune, we can say we experience McCormack's artistry in its full purity, without the possibility of being seduced by mere platform charm.

title: STARRETT HOUSING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $717,000 for the quarter and $1,831,000 for the 9 months.

title: U.S. OFFERS SOVIET INCREASED TRADE IF EMIGRATION LIMITS ARE EASED

description: The House of Representatives voted overwhelmingly today to override President Reagan's veto of a bill setting guidelines for biomedical research at the National Institutes of Health.

title: 3 EXCHANGES PLAN MOVE TO BATTERY
description: The three largest commodities exchanges in New York City signed an agreement yesterday to move to a $300 million office tower to be built over the Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel ramp in lower Manhattan.

description: A $235 million bond issue of the Western Minnesota Municipal Power Agency was tentatively offered yesterday through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman Brothers with a maximum yield of 9.55 percent for bonds due in 2013.

title: Dr. James C. Bonbright, 93, Ex-Head of Power Authority
description: Dr. James C. Bonbright, a professor emeritus of finance at Columbia University and a former trustee and chairman of the New York State Power Authority, died Sunday at his home in Athens, Ga. He was 93 years old.

title: Backing Bum
description: Earlier this week, Coach Bum Phillips said that if his New Orleans Saints did not finish at .500 by winning five of their six remaining games, he would recommend that the front office find a replacement for him. Already, without waiting, someone has seconded Phillips's recommendation.

title: HISPANIC NETWORK UNDER FIRE
description: More than two decades ago, the Azcarragas, one of Mexico's wealthiest families, and Televisa, the giant Mexican broadcasting company that the family controls, started an American television network aimed at Hispanic viewers.

title: Suns (0-9) Beaten Again
description: Cliff Levingston of Atlanta scored 23 points, many in key situations, as the Hawks defeated the Phoenix Suns tonight, 108-101.

Results have been adjusted to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split effected on Jan. 14, 1985.

title: SCOPE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: ALTHOUGH unfinished furniture is sanded by the manufacturer, additional sanding is almost always needed if you want a really smooth finish. This is especially true of outside corner joints and edges, and places where the end grain of the wood is exposed. Sand first with No. 150, then with No. 220, then dust thoroughly.

title: The U.N. Today; Nov. 14, 1985
description: SECURITY COUNCIL Meets on Namibia at 10:30 A.M.

title: Soviet Jews' Rights
description: When Mikhail S. Gorbachev speaks about Soviet Jews' rights in 1985, he re-enacts the duplicity practiced in 1787 by Prince Potemkin, Catherine the Great's principal adviser. The only difference is that Mr. Gorbachev is doing orally what the Prince did physically in the Crimea - build villages of only one street, filled with tumultuously cheering crowds, so that the touring Hapsburg Emperor, Joseph II, might be sufficiently impressed to succumb to Catherine's diplomatic importunings.

title: HOMELESS IN CITY FACING KOCH EDICT
description: Mayor Koch yesterday ordered a new campaign to remove homeless people from the streets on freezing nights this winter and take them to shelters or hospitals, whether or not they are willing to go.

title: G.M. GIVES DETAILS ON HUGHES
description: The General Motors Corporation said yesterday that it expected to complete the acquisition of the Hughes Aircraft Company before the end of the year. G.M. also said it would alter the way it reports the earnings of subsidiaries with their own class of stock.

title: BRAND INSULATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

description: A South African business group responsible for marketing Krugerrands said tonight that it had temporarily suspended production of the one-ounce gold coins.

description: City and state officials acknowledge the grave and growing problem of the homeless, but they are still debating how many there are and why these sad, confused and sometimes frightening people continue to wander the streets.

ART OBJECTS: A FELINE SLANT
description: NOT only will cat lovers be able to view the prize felines at the Empire Cat Club's 69th annual show, but they will also be able to browse among cat memorabilia and artifacts on sale at ''The Art of the Cat,'' an exhibition organized by Jeffrey Blumberg. The cat show is scheduled for Saturday and Sunday at the Passenger Ship Terminal, Pier 90, at 12th Avenue and 50th Street.

title: CASE STUDIES OF 4 SUCCESSFUL U.S. PRODUCTS
description: SOME common household objects seem so ordinary, so ubiquitous, that most of us never notice the fine points of their design. But whether it is something as humble as a paper cup dispenser, as functional as an electric blanket control, as satisfying as old-fashioned kitchen china, or as sophisticated as a modern stacking chair, the care and attention that industrial designers have put into the development of the product are part of its success in the marketplace.

title: CHARTER MEDICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Jet Collision Yields 'Good' Recording
description: Federal investigators have a ''good'' recording of the cockpit conversation between the pilot and co-pilot of the business jet that collided with a single-engine private plane Sunday evening east of Teterboro Airport, authorities said tonight.

title: STUDY FINDS VASECTOMY PROBLEMS
description: Even though they can often be reversed, vasectomies may result in permanent changes in the testes that leave men unable to father children, a study suggests.

title: Bear, Stearns Sets Chairman
description: Bear, Stearns & Company, which went public Oct. 29, said yesterday that it had named Alan Greenberg chairman and chief executive.

Unique Office, Retail and Restaurant Space.'' The former Haaren High School in the former neighborhood of Hell's Kitchen is coming to us next spring as - ladies and gentlemen - the all-new media facility, Metropolis!

description: The American Federation of Teachers announced today that Anthony J. Alvarado, who resigned as New York City Schools Chancellor in an inquiry over his personal finances, had been hired as an assistant to Albert Shanker, the federation's president.

description: b-Including a tax credit of $387,000. c-Net income. Share earnings reflect a 10 percent stock dividend paid in October.

title: 'GREAT CAMP' IN ADIRONDACKS IS PASSING INTO PRIVATE HANDS
description: CAMP TOPRIDGE, one of the last remaining ''great camps'' built as a summer wilderness retreat in the Adirondack Mountains, will pass into the hands of Roger Jakubowski, a businessman from New Jersey, next Thursday.

title: MIAMI'S FIRST CUBAN-BORN MAYOR
description: A decade ago, when some senior members of his Miami law firm dropped in on Xavier Suarez, they found themselves stepping over five filing boxes on the carpeted floor of the office of the young Harvard Law graduate.

Latest quarter results include results of Transworld Systems, which the company acquired in July 1985.

title: Neo-Nazi Is Convicted Of Killing State Trooper
description: David C. Tate, alleged to be a member of the Order, a neo-Nazi group advocating white supremacy, was convicted today of first-degree murder in the slaying of a state trooper last April 15.

title: EXPERTS ON CHILDREN SEEK TO CUT ABUSE CASES 20%
description: Through education, research and the establishment of state trust funds, teachers, health professionals and volunteers say they hope to reduce child abuse and neglect dramatically in the next five years.

title: Phoenix Offering
description: Phoenix is offering $79.3 million of airport revenue bonds, rated A by Moody's, through underwriters led by Bear, Stearns & Company, with yields ranging from 7 1/2 percent for bonds due in 1993 to 7.85 percent in 1995, 8.60 percent in 2000 and 8.80 percent in 2002. In addition, the city is offering $57.5 million of general obligation bonds through the Continental Illinois National Bank, with yields ranging from 5 1/2 percent for bonds due in 1987 to 6 1/2 percent in 1990, 7 1/2 percent in 1995, 8.10 percent in 2000, 8.35 percent in 2005 and 8.40 percent in 2009. The bonds are rated Aa-1 by Moody's and AA+ by S.& P.

description: When you're a referee, it always helps if you're the kind of guy the typical player can look up to. Steve Welmer has no problem, because he's 6 feet 10 inches tall.

description: Asserting that the payments on Mexico's $96 billion foreign debt are more than twice as burdensome as Germany's World War I reparations, Governor Bruce Babbitt of Arizona called today for drastic measures to prevent a collapse of the Mexican economy.

description: A teen-age suspect in the death of a police officer and the critical wounding of another killed himself today as the police moved in on his hiding place, officials said.

Terms were not disclosed, but a source close to Ziff-Davis said the price was probably less than $25 million.

description: INVESTORS who missed the sizzling stock market rally of the last seven weeks can take comfort in the fact that many technical analysts who study the internal mechanics of the market also failed to see it coming.

description: A background report on Friday headed ''Mormons at a Glance'' misstated the formal name of the Mormon Church. It is the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints.

title: Illinois Central Pares Further
description: The Illinois Central Gulf Railroad, continuing its efforts to pare its operations, said today that it had signed a contract to sell 418 miles of its lines in Mississippi and Louisiana to the Midsouth Rail Corporation for $123.5 million.

description: Dr. John B. Nelson, associate professor emeritus of animal pathology at the Rockefeller University, died Saturday at his retirement home in Doylestown, Pa. He was 90 years old and a former resident of Princeton, N.J.

title: FOES OF MARCOS DEBATE WHO'LL RUN AGAINST HIM
description: The two leading figures in the Philippines moderate opposition kissed in public today, then sat down in private to begin what promises to be hard bargaining over which one of them will lead an election battle against President Ferdinand E. Marcos.

title: OPERA: 'DON GIOVANNI' AND 'BELLO' IN WASHINGTON
description: The Washington Opera's first and third productions of the season confirmed every impression of the company that this observer has formed in scattered visits over recent seasons. This is a troupe in which everyone pulls together toward a show, in which singers starry and otherwise perform with energy and commitment and traditional staging values are championed with fresh vitality.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: THE WRITER READS Success came quickly for Mary Gordon. In 1978, her first novel, ''Final Payments,'' sold a million copies and critics acclaimed it. She has also written two more best sellers, ''The Company of Women'' and ''Men and Angels.''

description: Officials of ESM Government Securities Inc. began conspiring to defraud investors in 1976 and bankrupted the investment firm by 1980, but financial institutions kept the company alive until this year, a report released today said.

Horowitz, who is under consideration for a White House appointment to the Circuit Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia, is expected to resign next week as counsel to the director of the Office of Management and Budget.
