title: PERES THREATENS TO OUST SHARON FROM COALITION
description: Israel's 14-month-old national unity Government tottered on the brink of collapse tonight after Prime Minister Shimon Peres threatened to dismiss Ariel Sharon, the Minister of Industry and Commerce.

title: Citibank Nevada Deal
description: Citibank Nevada received a state judge's approval today to take over a troubled Las Vegas thrift, paving the way for Citibank to begin full banking operations in Nevada. A new state law enables Citibank to begin full-scale banking operations in Nevada in return for bailing out All-State Thrift. The same law required Nevada thrifts for the first time to carry deposit insurance.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: Green Point Savings Bank has promoted Martin S. Dash to executive vice president and Craig M. Hubmeier to senior vice president and mortgage loan officer.

title: SKYWATCHERS POISED AS HALLEY'S COMET BEGINS APPEARANCE
description: Halley's comet has arrived.

title: PRETORIA LIMITS FREED PRISONERS
description: The authorities said today that stringent restrictions had been placed on the activities of five men released from detention under the state of emergency.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Nets vs. Rockets, at Houston, 8:30 P.M. The Rockets, with Akeem Olajuwon and Ralph Sampson, beat the Nets in the teams' only game in Houston last season.

title: AUTHORS AS ACTORS: THE PLAY'S NOT THE ONLY THING
description: QUESTION: What do Athol Fugard, Harold Pinter, Sam Shepard, John Osborne, Wallace Shawn, Harvey Fierstein, Christopher Durang, David Mamet, John Pielmeier, Michael Cristofer, Samm-Art Williams and Miguel Pinero have in common? Answer: They are all actors. Of course they are also playwrights, but each of them has earned some if not most of his income by acting on the professional stage or in films, often in his own works. Some, such as Mr. Pinter and Mr. Osborne, were actors before they were playwrights. Others have taken up acting later in their careers, as a matter of economy or opportunity.

title: COMEDY: FRED BARTON'S 'MISS GULCH'
description: ''MONOGAMY is like good crystal - beautiful -but once you get it, all it takes is one chip and it's never the same again.'' Offered in a spirit of gleeful malice, this observation is typical of the wit and wisdom of Alvira Gulch as interpreted by Fred Barton.

title: BRIEFS
description: Charter Co., Jacksonville, Fla., said it had reached an agreement in principle to sell its Houston refinery to Channel Refinery Inc. and its Northeast Petroleum Industries Inc. unit to Cargill Inc. of Minneapolis. Total value of the deals is more than $36 million.

title: SMITH SOARS WITH ASSIST FROM CLIPPERS
description: Derek Smith grew up in Hoganville, Ga., where he was one of only 3,000 residents. Two years ago, he became one of more than 2,500 Smiths in the Los Angeles telephone directory. Today, the 6-foot-7-inch guard is one of the four members of the Los Angeles Clippers listed on the National Basketball Association All-Star Game ballot and the league's fourth-leading scorer, averaging 27 points a game.

title: NUCLEAR METALS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
GIANTS ARE WARY OF REDSKINS
description: Since the Giants are tied for their division lead with a 7-3 record and have won their last four games, and since the Redskins are 5-5 and struggling with injuries and age, the Giants obviously should be favored in their Monday night game in Washington.

title: NAUGLES INC reports earnings for 16 wks to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Coach's Question
description: Coach Dick Motta expresses outrage with the play of his Dallas Mavericks, who entered last night's game against Utah having lost four straight: ''Somebody said it can't get any worse. I asked, 'Why?' ''

title: LAWYER GIVES $1 MILLION TO JUILLIARD
description: The Juilliard School has been given $1 million to be used for a scholarship fund by Jerome L. Greene, a New York lawyer and philanthropist. Mr. Greene is to make a formal presentation today at a luncheon at the school attended by faculty members and officials of Lincoln Center.

title: PRINCETON PASSER ZEROES IN ON YALE
description: Since 1967 a long line of Princeton quarterbacks has tried to beat Yale, but only one succeeded, Bob Holly in 1981, and he had to pass for 501 yards to do it. Doug Butler's turn, his third and last, will come at Palmer Stadium Saturday in the 108th game between the teams.

title: PROGROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 28
Daily for Sale In Los Angeles
description: The owners of The San Francisco Chronicle are among those trying to buy The Daily News of Los Angeles, the newspaper reported today.

title: INFORMER IS QUESTIONED ON KEY 'PIZZA' DEFENDANT
description: Tommaso Buscetta, a Mafia informer, testified in the ''pizza connection'' trial yesterday that he had never heard a key defendant express opposition to narcotics trafficking.

title: Reagan Son to Cover Geneva for Playboy
description: Ronald P. Reagan, son of President Reagan, plans to cover next week's American-Soviet summit meeting for Playboy magazine.

title: MUSIC: PIANO-CELLO DUO, FIRKUSNY AND HARRELL
description: PUTTING two important musicians together on the same stage does not automatically insure that a musical duo will be the result, even if both are tested and highly accomplished ensemble performers. Too many variables enter into the equation. Techniques and temperaments must match, or if they do not they must clash in interesting ways. Otherwise what we have is a joint recital, which can be diverting but falls short of being true chamber music.

title: Repairs on the BMT To Start Next Spring
description: The reconstruction of the BMT tracks between the 36th Street station and Stillwell Avenue-Coney Island terminal on the West End line in Brooklyn is expected to start next spring and continue for almost four years, the Transit Authority announced yesterday.

title: U.S. TO ADVISE AGAINST SCREENING FOR AIDS VIRUS
description: New guidelines on AIDS in the workplace, to be announced by the Department of Health and Human Services Thursday, recommend against screening workers for exposure to the virus that can cause the deadly illness even when their jobs bring them close to the public.

title: IMPORTS ALLURING TO THE CONSUMER
description: WHEN Sheila H. Forman thinks of cars and television sets, she thinks of Japan. She associates coffee makers with Germany, leather goods with Italy, rugs with India and linens with Ireland. The best pottery, she says, comes from Mexico. Watches and chocolates come from Switzerland. Perfume comes from France, sweaters from Britain.

title: Gallup Finds a Decline In Financial Optimism
description: Financial optimism among Americans, widely linked to the economic recovery of the last three years, is waning, according to the latest Gallup Poll.

title: Ask the Wife
description: Sondra Gotlieb, the wife of the Canadian Ambassador to Washington, Allan Gotlieb, has been traveling around the United States promoting her book, ''Wife Of . . .'' Mrs. Gotlieb related at a lunch yesterday that the three things she is asked most often by Americans are: ''Whatever happened to Margaret?'' (a reference to the former wife of the former Prime Minister, Pierre Elliott Trudeau), ''Are you separating from Quebec or Nova Scotia?'' and ''Too bad about the Blue Jays.''

title: Funds From Westway Trade-In In Federal Transportation Bill
description: Congressional negotiators cleared the way today for New York to begin receiving funds from the Westway trade-in ahead of schedule.

title: WHEN LIFE IS TOO BUSY TO BE IMPROMPTU
description: SUZANA MONACELLA is an overbooked New Yorker. ''I start my week thinking, 'This week I can do it,' '' said the fashion designer. ''A friend will call to ask if we can have tea, and I say, 'Not this Thursday. Maybe next Thursday.' Now I have my mother staying with us. Where do I have the time to see my own mother? The answer is, I don't.''

title: ON WEST SIDE, A NEW BATTLE OF NORMANDY
description: It is not a matter that suggests complexity: the windows leak. So, comes the thought, replace them.

title: FRENCH SEIZE DOZENS IN VAST HEROIN CRACKDOWN
description: The French police arrested several dozen people suspected of being international drug traffickers in a predawn raid today that officials said promised to break apart a major international ring supplying heroin to the United States.

title: NEW TV MOVIES FROM OLD SERIES
description: A few weeks ago, scheduled opposite the second game of the World Series, ''I Dream of Jeannie: 15 Years Later'' whisked away a third of the television audience. The 11th-highest program in the week's ratings (the World Series game was No. 6), ''I Dream of Jeannie: 15 Years Later'' is the most dramatic example of the success of a new trend - recycling old television series into two-hour movies.

title: City Water Authority Increases Its Financing
description: Strong investor demand, featuring many institutional buyers who are not normally buyers of New York City general obligation bonds, enabled the New York City Municipal Water Finance Authority to increase the size of its first bond issue to $200 million from $165 million, and reduce the yield on the bonds by as much as a tenth of a percentage point.

title: Expensive Move
description: Hugh Green, the linebacker who was traded at his request from the Tampa Bay Buccaneers to the Miami Dolphins last month, had to pay dearly for the trade. According to The Tampa Tribune, Hugh Culverhouse, the owner of the Bucs, would not go through with the trade until Green agreed to repay $335,000 of a $665,000 bonus he was given for signing a two-year contract last year. . . . Jess Atkinson, the place-kicker who was waived by the Giants and then signed by the St. Louis Cardinals after the team's original kicker, Neil O'Donoghue was cut, has been waived by the Cardinals after missing three field goals, his only attempts in two games with the club. Novo Bojovic, a Yugoslavia-born kicker who played most recently with the Oakland Invaders of the United States Football League, has been signed to take Atkinson's place.

description: Over breakfast this morning, Mario Vazquez Rana, the Mexican newspaper magnate who has apparently won the bidding for United Press International, said he hoped to lead a new, revitalized and much richer news service.

title: A WOODWORKER'S SHOW OF CLOCKS
description: ALONG the walls of a SoHo space stand 12 extraordinary long-case clocks and one ghost clock. Now on view at the Alexander Milliken gallery, these are the most recent works by the eminent woodworker Wendell Castle.

title: QUAREX INDUSTRIES reports earnings for 13 wks to Sept 27
TEXAS INTERNATIONAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MEDICINE SHOPPE INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PACO PHARMACEUTICAL SERVCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about a conference on the world monetary system incorrectly characterized remarks by Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d. Nothing he said there departed significantly from his recent pronouncements on the dollar.

title: LASER INDUSTRIES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss c-After losses of $489,000 for the quarter and $589,000 for the 6 months from a former subsidiary, Metalworking Lasers International. d-After a loss of $62,000 from the former unit. The latest quarter's sales includes $56,000 relating to the company's former subsidiary, which was sold in September 1985 and the latest 6 months' sales include $500,000 from the unit. The year-ago 6 months' net also includes a tax credit of $39,000.

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: A front-page article yesterday described the heavy increase in corporate air traffic in the New York area over the last decade.

title: NEW MUSEUM OFFICIALS AT THE MET AND MODERN
description: The boards of trustees of the Museum of Modern Art and the Metropolitan Museum of Art elected new presidents yesterday, at meetings held coincidentally on the same day.

title: NEIGHBORS CRITICIZE PLAN TO EXPAND WHITNEY
description: At a crowded meeting last night, officials of the Whitney Museum of American Art heard new complaints and statements of opposition - and a few new statements of support - to its proposed plan to expand their headquarters at Madison Avenue and 75th Street with a new building designed by the architect Michael Graves.

title: House Passes Water Projects
description: The House today overwhelmingly approved a $20 billion program for dams, harbors and a number of other water projects over the next decade.

title: REPORTED ROBBERIES ARE UP 10% AS FELONIES RISE 4% IN SUBWAYS
description: Reports of robberies in subway trains and on platforms increased by 10 percent in September from the levels a year ago, transit officials said yesterday. The increase came in the first month this year in which the number of reported subway felonies was up.

title: ORION CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including realized investment gains of $5,469,000 for the quarter and $11,115,000 for the 9 months. c-Net income, including realized investment gains of $4,034,000 for the quarter and $4,150,000 for the 9 months.

title: WHERE BOTH DESERT AND OLD WAYS RETREAT BEFORE GROWTH
description: There is about six and a half feet between the brim of husky Steve Culp's 10-gallon hat and the soles of his cowboy boots, and he fills up all of it, mostly with moustache and tattoos, both of which he has in abundance.

title: Illness Interrupts Racketeering Trial
description: The racketeering trial of 11 reputed members and associates of the Colombo crime organization was interrupted yesterday when Ralph Scopo, a defendant, complained of chest pains and nearly collapsed.

title: Negotiate Only With West Bank Palestinians
description: To the Editor:

title: GOODEN IS WINNER UNANIMOUSLY
description: After only two seasons in the big leagues, and three days short of his 21st birthday, Dwight Gooden made more baseball history yesterday when he became the youngest pitcher ever to win the Cy Young Award. And he did it in his dominating, dazzling style by sweeping all 24 votes cast for first place.

title: Negotiate Only With West Bank Palestinians
description: To the Editor:

title: 10-Day Auto Sales Off 12.4%
description: Automobile sales by the nation's major manufacturers fell 12.4 percent, on a daily selling rate basis, in the first 10 days of November from the period a year ago, the companies reported here today. Industry analysts said the manufacturers were still in a ''payback period'' from the popular incentive programs of late August and early September.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We are going to Geneva completely aware of the responsibilty resting on the shoulders of all countries but primarily those of the U.S.S.R. and the United States.

title: INQUIRY WEIGHS HALTING PATIENTS TUBE-FEEDING
description: A New Jersey official said today that he would conduct an immediate investigation to determine whether a feeding tube keeping a comatose, brain-damaged woman alive should be removed, thus allowing her to ''die with dignity.''

title: Consumer Debt Rises By Record $10.6 Billion
description: Americans took on a record $10.6 billion more in consumer debt than they paid off in September, as borrowing for auto purchases hit a record high, the Federal Reserve reported today.

title: Firmer Political Relations
description: The approaching summit meeting between Ronald Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev provides an opportunity for both superpowers to begin to put their relations on a firmer footing. If they are to do this, however, they must digest the lessons of the past decade.

title: HEAD OF PHILADELPHIA POLICE QUITS IN WAKE OF FUROR OVER BOMBING
description: Police Commissioner Gregore J. Sambor, who directed the aerial bombing last May that led to 11 deaths and the destruction of 61 homes by fire, resigned today.

title: DRIED FLORAL WREATHS, BY MAIL ORDER
description: BOTH gardeners and nongardeners will be tempted by an abundance of unusual holiday wreaths, many available by mail. Artful arrangements come in fresh or dried plant materials, and combinations of both. Long a symbol of the cycle of the seasons, wreaths can sometimes grace walls year round.

title: Virginia Housing
description: An $85 million issue of single-family mortgage revenues bonds for the Virginia Housing Finance Authority was tentatively priced yesterday to yield a maximum 9.20 percent for bonds due in 2009.

title: INSPIRATION RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Dawdling Justice for Hurricane Carter
description: New Jersey has had nearly 20 years to validly convict Rubin (Hurricane) Carter, a former middleweight boxer, and his already-paroled friend John Artis of a triple murder in a Paterson bar. According to United States District Judge Lee Sarokin, the state has failed, though it has imprisoned Mr. Carter for most of that time. The judge has set aside the convictions of both men, finding that they were obtained with an unsupported charge of racial vengeance and compromised by the withholding of evidence favorable to the accused.

title: Letter: On Transportation;   Amtrak's Gift to Deficit Reduction
description: To the Editor:

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: Medical Antiques
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:

title: NORTHWESTERN STEEL & WIRE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Including a tax credit of $603,000. c-Net loss.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL ATLANTA (NL) - Added to the roster Marty Clary, Charlie Puleo and Paul Assenmacher, pitchers. Asked waivers on Randy Johnson, outfielder.

title: TIDEWATER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including an extraordinary net gain of $8,077,000 for the quarter and the 6 months. c-Net loss.

title: CODFISH SLOW TO ARRIVE FOR TOURNAMENT
description: This weekend's annual invitation codfish tournament out of Freeport, L.I., reminds one that some hardy saltwater anglers in the Northeast are fishing even as snow falls in the mountains.

title: MONARCH CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After capital gains of $2,678,000 for the quarter and $12,318,000 for the 9 months. c-After capital gains of $2,357,000 for the quarter and $1,431,000 for the 9 months.

title: Big Chance For Media Promoters
description: What would heaven on earth be for a peddler from the media?

title: THE CARTER HAWLEY HALE SOLUTION
description: Philip M. Hawley loves Sherlock Holmes detective stories, and occasionally he tries to solve mysteries on his own. His latest puzzler: how to improve margins, and thereby profits, at the company he heads, Carter Hawley Hale Stores.

title: SOVIET PAPER SAYS SAILOR FELL OFF SHIP INTO THE MISSISSIPPE
description: A Soviet newspaper offered its own version today of the episode of a Soviet seaman who was forcibly returned to his ship near New Orleans, asserting that he fell off his freighter and became ''disoriented.''

title: DURHAM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including capital gains of $71,000 for the quarter and $6,029,000 for the 9 months. c-Including capital gains of $439,000 for the quarter and $1,317,000 for the 9 months.

title: A SENIOR CITY POLICE OFFICER PURSUES HIS ROOTS IN CHINA
description: It was a hero's homecoming in the finest Chinese tradition - on the mainland and on Taiwan. There were motorcades, eulogies, parades, sumptuous feasts, retinues to satisfy every request or whim.

title: Exporting Our Environmental Problems
description: To the Editor:

title: MARGAUX CONTROLS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 29
description: b-After a charge of $28,000 from the reversal of tax credits. c-Net income after tax credits of $212,000 for the quarter and $337,000 for the 6 months.

title: CABARET: MARTHA RAYE AT BALLROOM
description: MARTHA RAYE describes herself as ''a clown at heart'' and ''a barrelhouse character'' during her performance at the Ballroom, 253 West 28th Street, where she is making a monthlong appearance, through Dec. 7. This self-characterization will not come as news to anyone who has seen Miss Raye in films or on television.

title: 2 Stay in Hospital
description: The two passengers who were seriously hurt in the automobile accident early Sunday that fatally injured the Philadelphia Flyer goaltender, Pelle Lindbergh, remained hospitalized yesterday. Edward T. Parvin remained in critical condition, and Kathyleen McNeal's condition was upgraded to guarded. Meanwhile, the Township Committee in Voorhees, N.J., where Lindbergh and his teammates had been drinking at a bar until 5 A.M., said it would consider moving the bar's closing time back to an earlier hour.

title: PERKIN-ELMER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a gain of $18 million from a patent infringement settlement and after a provision for restructuring of $10 million.

title: TII COMPUTER SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
American Hospital Sells McGaw Unit
description: The American Hospital Supply Corporation said today that it has signed a definitive agreement to sell its American McGaw division to the Kendall Company, a subsidiary of the Colgate-Palmolive Company.

title: FITCHBURG GAS & ELECTRIC LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income. c-After a nonrecurring charge of $4,720,000 from the writeoff of the company's investment in Seabrook units 1 and 2 which was determined to be nonrecoverable by the Massachusetts Department of Public Utilities.

title: Intel Manager Becomes President of Valid Logic
description: Valid Logic Systems Inc., a fast-growing manufacturer of computer-aided engineering work stations, said yesterday that Kenneth B. Fine, an executive at the Intel Corporation, had been named president.

title: NAMIBIAN INSURGENTS RAID TOWN
description: Insurgents in the north of South-West Africa attacked a border town with mortars, rockets and small arms fire early today and six of them were killed by Government forces pursuing them into Angola, the South African military said.

title: U.S. TESTS LASER COMMUNICATOR
description: The Pentagon has successfully transmitted messages by laser light from a high-flying airplane to a submarine cruising below the ocean surface.

title: GROUNDING OF COPTERS DELAYS SEARCH FOR STRANDED HUNTERS
description: The state grounded its helicopters today, hampering a search team's efforts to find 100 elk hunters believed stranded by snow in the bitterly cold Cascade Mountains, where two hunters have already died.

title: C.D. Rates Fall Slightly
description: Rates paid on certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds showed slight declines for the week ended yesterday.

title: On the First Lady's Staff
description: Nancy Reagan is getting a new chief of staff. He is Lee L. Verstandig, who has had several posts in the Reagan Administrations.

title: DEREGULATION CHALLENGES ATLANTA AIRLINE HUB
description: For years it has been a favorite joke among weary air travelers in the Southeast: When you die, they say, you do not go directly to heaven or hell. First, you stop at Atlanta to change planes.

title: SERVOTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $113,000 for the quarter and $404,000 for the 9 months. c-Including tax credits of $124,000 for the quarter and $390,000 for the 9 months.

title: SYSTEM INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 27
description: b-Including an extraordinary tax credit of $347,000. c-Net loss.

title: SYMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Tyco-Grinnell Pact
description: Tyco Labs Inc. said it had reached an agreement to acquire the United States and Canadian distribution operations and certain manufacturing facilities of the ITT Corporation's Grinnell Corporation for $195 million. Grinnell had sales of about $460 million last year and makes a range of valves and related products for commericial and industrial applications.

title: OPTROTECH LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TEXTILE CURBS WIN IN SENATE
description: The Senate tonight defied threats of a Presidential veto and approved legislation that would place stringent quotas on textile imports from 12 countries, most of them in Asia.

title: DOUGHTIE'S FOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
REAGAN-CONGRESS CLASH
description: The heated argument between President Reagan and Democratic leaders Tuesday highlighted an increasingly irate confrontation over pending legislation that would require Congress to balance the Federal budget within five years.

title: JOB-LINKED INJURIES AND ILLNESSES ROSE IN 1984
description: Work-related injuries and illnesses increased in 1984 for the first time in four years. The increase was 11.7 percent, the largest since the Government began collecting such data, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

title: THE STAGE: A MORALITY PLAY ON RACIAL MIX-UP OF BABIES
description: THERE'S a morality play in two acts at the Billie Holiday Theater in Brooklyn.

title: SCHWERMAN TRUCKING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $1,630,000.

title: STRONG DOLLAR AND IMPORTS
description: OVER the last two years, a robust dollar has helped broaden the selection of foreign-made furniture, appliances and home accessories for American consumers and made the imports more affordable, dealers and industry analysts say. More quality imports at reasonable prices explain part of the current appeal of foreign-designed products.

title: CARRIERS TO HAUL LOGS
description: CARTING wood from the woodpile to the fireplace is easier with log carriers. L. L. Bean sells a log carrier of heavy, off-white duck with leather handles. It weighs 22 ounces, is 42 by 20 inches and costs $11.

title: MADISON GAS & ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Britain and Ireland Agree On Ulster, Paper Says
description: Britain and Ireland were reported today to have concluded an agreement on Northern Ireland.

title: FPA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Explosive Found; Students Removed
description: More than 4,000 students and teachers at Brooklyn Technical High School and nearby residents were removed yesterday after an explosive chemical was found in the school, authorities said.

title: Dicky Wells, 78, Dies; Trombonist With Basie
description: Dicky Wells, a trombonist who starred with Count Basie's orchestra from 1938 to 1950, died of cancer Tuesday at Harlem Hospital. He was 78 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: What's a Parent to Do?
description: To the Editor:

title: ITEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $700,000 for the quarter and $1.7 million for the 9 months and a gain of $4.3 million for the 9 months from the recovery of certain pension fund assets. c-Net losses. Preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income and therefore there were no share earnings reported.

title: FORMER CHIEF, BACK IN RACE, ROILING BRAZIL
description: His opponents variously portray him as unbalanced, alcoholic, senile and demagogic, and they blame him for the three years of instability and 21 years of military rule that followed his abrupt resignation as President of Brazil in 1961.

title: Prince and Princess Bid America Adieu
description: The Prince and Princess of Wales waved farewell to America today and flew home to England to end a four-day visit that bedazzled the nation's stars and star-gazers.

title: Life Term Given In Racist Slaying
description: A Bronx man was sentenced to life in prison yesterday for shooting and killing a black man who had kissed a white woman outside a Fordham University chapel in 1977.

title: BUCKNELL INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Year to July 31
description: Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: OFFICIALS OF COUNTIES DEBATE PRIVATE JAIL OPERATION
description: Under court pressure to improve jail conditions and worried by the prospect of personal liability for injuries suffered in substandard conditions, county and state officials around the nation are considering giving private companies contracts to manage their jails.

title: PRESIDENT'S FORCES IN CONTROL IN LIBERIA
description: President Samuel K. Doe appeared to be back in control of Liberia today, but rebels who tried to stage a coup Tuesday were still putting up a stubborn resistance to loyalist troops.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization:

title: Ranger Surprise Rogers With Recall
description: He had gone down with no illusions, with no voice inside telling him it was just a matter of time before the Rangers recognized their folly. So when Mike Rogers was recalled Tuesday, along with Steve Richmond, from a month in exile in the minor leagues, it came as a genuine surprise.

title: Coastal Stake In Sonat Is 6%
description: The Coastal Corporation, which earlier this year acquired the American Natural Resources Corporation for $2.5 billion, disclosed yesterday that it held 6 percent of Sonat Inc., a natural gas pipeline concern.

title: VIEWERS MUST FIRST FIND THE PLEIADES
description: For the best chance to see the approaching Halley's comet, which is growing brighter but is still quite dim and diffuse, observers must have a clear, dark night and a pair of binoculars. With the Moon new and thus not bright, conditions over the next four nights, beginning tonight, should be favorable.

title: HOUSE AND SENATE APPROVE INCREASE IN CEILING ON DEBT
description: In an effort to avoid a financial crisis for the Government just before President Reagan's summit meeting in Geneva next week, the House of Representatives and the Senate today approved a one-month extension of the Government's ability to borrow money.

title: MUSIC: 'PETER AND THE WOLF'
description: PROKOFIEV'S ''Peter and the Wolf'' seems both older and younger than its 50 years: a bona-fide classic by now, it yet maintains a fresh appeal to the proverbial ''children of all ages.'' On Monday night at Alice Tully Hall, Lukas Foss conducted the Brooklyn Philharmonic in a special 50th-anniversary benefit performance of ''Peter and the Wolf'' for Hospital Audiences Inc.

title: Jet Parts Believed Located
description: Investigators said today that they had found on the seabed what might be fragments of the tail of the Japan Air Lines Boeing 747 that crashed in August, killing 520 people. A coast guard patrol boat using a supersonic wave device located 10 places where ''unnatural objects'' were lying off the east coast of the Izu Peninsula in Sagami Bay, a spokesman for the investigators said.

title: Technology;   Talking With A Computer
description: COMPUTERS are very good at processing information once it has been entered into their memories. The problem is getting it there. This is a particular problem in industrial applications, where timely reporting on inventory levels and quality control is often slowed by delays in data entry.

title: Destination: Finland
description: Our new man in Helsinki is expected to be Rockwell Anthony Schnabel, who since 1983 has been deputy chairman of the California investment banking firm of Morgan, Olmstead, Kennedy & Gardner. Mr. Schnabel has already held one more or less diplomatic post: In 1983-84 he was the representative of the Los Angeles Olympic Committee to the Netherlands, where he was born in 1936. For that the Netherlands gave him its Olympic Medal of Honor. President Reagan is expected to send his nomination as Ambassador to Finland to the Senate for approval.

title: Plainfield Schools Continue Ban on 5-Year-Old With AIDS
description: The Plainfield Board of Education voted today to continue to bar a 5-year-old girl with AIDS from kindergarten despite orders by the state and a judge that she be admitted.

title: COMPUTER CONCERN HAS DEFICIT
description: Commodore International said yesterday that it lost $39.2 million in its first fiscal quarter. It attributed the deficit to costs associated with the introduction of two new computer models.

title: MATISSE ARTWORKS SOLD IN AUCTION AT SOTHEBY'S
description: Matisse's ''Decorative Figure,'' a 1908 bronze sculpture of a woman reclining, soared to almost twice its sale expectations last night at Sotheby's, establishing an auction record for the artist's sculpture.

title: 20TH CENTURY INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Anti-Semitism, Anti-Murder
description: In the same week that Leon Klinghoffer was murdered in the Mediterranean for the crime of being Jewish, Alex Odeh was murdered in California for the crime of being an Arab. Mr. Odeh, a Palestinian by birth, was killed by a bomb on Oct. 11 when he opened his office door in Santa Ana, where he was West Coast director of the American Arab Anti-Discrimination Committee. On television the day before, while condemning the Achille Lauro hijacking, he had defended the P.L.O. leader, Yasir Arafat.

title: Shield-Sharing
description: When the President gets an idea in his head that he believes to be fundamental to his purposes, he clings to it.

title: GENESCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes a charge of $9.8 million to cover costs of a restructuring plan for U.S. footwear operations. c-Net income d-After a tax credit of $1,468,000. e-After a gain of $4,306,000 from an excess provision for future losses of discontinued operations and a tax credit of $3,176,000.

title: U.S. Officials in Hanoi Seeking Missing Soldiers
description: American military officials arrived in Hanoi today to discuss the fate of American servicemen listed as missing in action in Vietnam and to excavate the crash site of a B-52 bomber in the first such joint effort of the United States and Vietnam.

title: BLACK & DECKER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 29
description: b-Including tax credits of $13.6 million for the quarter and $1.4 million for the year. c-Net income.

title: MACGREGOR SPORTING GOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes a charge of 27 cents a share related to the reversal of a tax credit. c-Net income and includes tax credits equal to 5 cents a share for the quarter and 21 cents a share for the year.

title: ACCELERATION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including capital gains of $170,000 for the quarter and $202,000 for the 9 months, an extraordinary charge of $21,000 for the quarter and a capital gain of $12,000 for the 9 months. c-Including capital gains of $3,000 for the quarter and $14,000 for the 9 months and an extraordinary credit of $4,000 for the quarter and 9 months.

title: RUSS BERRIE & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DANCE: ATERBALLETTO PRESENTS DANISH-STYLE 'BOURNONVILLE'
description: ATERBALLETTO offered a new program Sunday afternoon at Brooklyn College that showed off its dancers unusually well.

title: Chairman Is Named At Gerber Products
description: The Gerber Products Company, the world's largest producer of baby foods, yesterday named William L. McKinley, its vice chairman and chief administrative officer, to be chairman and chief executive officer, effective immediately.

title: U.N., 122-19, ASKS TROOP PULLOUT IN AFGHANISTAN
description: The General Assembly overwhelmingly approved a resolution today calling for the immediate withdrawal of foreign troops from Afghanistan. The Soviet Union was not mentioned by name.

title: Trans-Atlantic Charity
description: For charity's sake, let the record show that the official travel time from the Mayor's Parlour in the Council House of North Warwickshire to the Blue Room of City Hall is 6 hours 40 minutes 30 seconds.

title: New Wisconsin Law Targets Teen-Age Sex
description: As one way of combating unwanted teen-age pregnancies, Wisconsin has adopted a law that holds parents financially responsible if their children under the age of 18 have babies.

title: Women in the Military
description: The movement to create a national women's military monument in the Washington area seems to be accelerating. The House has approved a bill sponsored by Representative Mary Rose Oakar, Democrat of Ohio, to create a ''women under fire'' memorial.

title: JP INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
U.S. AND ITALY PLANNING EFFORT ON PROBLEMS OF EXTRADTION
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d and the Italian Interior Minister announced today that the United States and Italy would try to resolve ''extradition problems'' that have strained relations between the two nations.

title: MACY, R H & CO INC reports earnings for 13 wks to Nov 2
Comings and Goings
description: Marvelous Marvin Hagler, the middleweight boxing champion who suffered a broken nose and had to postpone his Nov. 14 bout with John Mugabi, will meet Mugabi in Las Vegas, Nev., March 10 as part of a rescheduled doubleheader that will also include the postponed bout between Thomas Hearns and James Shuler. . . . Andrew Toney, the Philadelphia 76er guard, underwent successful surgery to remove bone spurs from his left ankle and will be sidelined six to eight weeks. The surgery left Toney with casts on both of his legs.

title: Fiat and Allis End Joint Venture
description: Fiat S.p.A. of Italy and the Allis-Chalmers Corporation said Fiat had acquired Allis-Chalmers's remaining stake in their joint venture, Fiatallis, a maker of construction equipment.

title: HUNT AND POGSON ON DAN AND LEMON
description: One night a score of people stalked out of the theater to protest Kathryn Pogson's final monologue. On other nights people just sit in stunned silence, so still that ''you don't know if they've died,'' Miss Pogson said. At least such reactions were not unexpected. ''In London, sometimes we'd have people cheering sitting next to people booing,'' the actress recalled.

title: ROGERS GETS WINNING GOAL IN RETURN
description: Mike Rogers, who was demoted to the minor leagues before the season, made a triumphant return to the Rangers last night and may have begun to reestablish himself in a new position.

title: Summit Wordsmithery
description: President Reagan has decided to take three of his skilled wordsmiths with him next week for his meeting with Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Never before has Mr. Reagan taken so many speechwriters with him anywhere.

title: PIZZA INN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $360,000 for the quarter and $370,000 for the 9 months.

title: AIR MIDWEST INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: REAGAN PROPOSES VOUCHERS TO GIVE POOR A CHOICE OF SCHOOLS
description: Education Secretary William J. Bennett today urged Congress to give low-income families vouchers worth an average of $600 a child a year so they could choose from a variety of private and public schools for their children.

title: U.S. JUDGE BARS 'STAR WARS' SUIT
description: A Federal district judge today rejected an attempt by George Lucas, the film director, to stop the use of the words ''Star Wars'' in a commercial praising President Reagan's plan for an antimissile shield.

title: IN THIS TALE OF TOW CITY, A HAPPY END
description: This is what happened in New York City yesterday to an itinerant family of holistic healers and musicians from Roswell, N.M.

title: STANDING WATCH OVER U.S. MISSILES
description: If nuclear war comes, the front line of the United States will run through a room-size concrete capsule buried 65 feet beneath the flat farmlands of North Dakota.

title: LONG SOVIET FINANCE MINISTER
description: Vasily F. Garbuzov, the Soviet Finance Minister for the last 25 years, died Tuesday after a long illness, according to Tass, the Soviet press agency. He was 74 years old.

title: U.S.-SOVIET PACT ON CHEMICAL ARMS IS SAID TO BE NEAR
description: The United States and the Soviet Union are poised to announce at the Geneva summit meeting that they have agreed to combine efforts to halt the spread of chemical weapons, Reagan Administration officials said today.

title: SIM-KAR LIGHTING FIXTURE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from a strike by the company's bargaining group employees that lasted more than nine weeks, during which sales were limited to shipments made from remote warehouses, and contract-signing bonus payments of approximately $200,000. c-Net income.

title: FOR GORBACHEV, 'STAR WARS' IS TO BE SUMMIT FOCUS
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev affirmed today that the United States space-based missile defense program will be his main concern at the meeting with President Reagan.

title: Witness Says He Paid Man Who Shot the Pope
description: A Turkish crime figure, Abuzer Ugurlu, said today that he authorized the payment of money in 1980 to a man he found out later was Mehmet Ali Agca, the gunman convicted in the 1981 shooting of Pope John Paul II in Rome.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in SportsMonday this week about the Chicago Bears' victory over the Detroit Lions incorrectly described the best starts in recent National Football League history. The Bears - who have won their first 10 games this season - equaled a performance by the Minnesota Vikings in 1975. In 1984 the Miami Dolphins won their first 11 games.

title: Bridge: Rosenkranz and Wold Gain Grand Slam With Reisinger
description: Victory in absentia is rare but can be very sweet.

title: KIDNAPPER OF GIRL WAS IN PRISON PLAN
description: People around Puget Sound have been mystified over the last few weeks after learning that a convicted murderer, improperly admitted to a program releasing him from prison to work, had used his daytime hours to plan and carry out the kidnapping of a 10-year-old girl.

title: Mullen Advertising To Handle Maserati
description: Mullen Advertising and Public Relations, Beverly Farms, Mass., has been appointed to handle United States advertising for Maserati Automobiles Inc., the Italian car maker. The account, which is expected to bill in excess of $2.5 million, was previously assigned to Govatos/Dunn of Alexandria, Va..

title: CUSTOM ENERGY SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
L.I.U. CHIEF IS INSTALLED AND FETED
description: Long Island University inaugurated its ninth president, Dr. David J. Steinberg, yesterday and then celebrated with a spirited parade down Flatbush Avenue in Brooklyn.

title: MAYOR MEETS CHELSEA AND SPARKS FLY
description: Aaron Solomon complained that ''there is hardly a new building going up in Chelsea that is low-income or moderate-income.''

title: CENTRAL JERSEY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Share earnings for the latest periods reflect a deduction from earnings of $750,000 associated with preferred dividends. c-Including a non-taxable gain of $3,186,000, or $2.03 a share, associated with the settlement of the Lehigh & New England valuation case. Results for the latest periods include operations of Rowe International Inc., effective June 1, 1985. The company is listed on the Philadelphia Stock Exchange.

title: MOTT'S SUPER MARKETS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: HARPER GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $846,000 for the quarter and $1,360,000 for the 9 months. c-Including income from discontinued operations of $179,000 for the quarter and $62,000 for the 9 months.

title: CBS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $143.2 million for the quarter and $175.3 million for the 9 months. c-Net income and after losses from discontinued operations of $7.2 million for the quarter and $28.2 million for the 9 months.

title: METS OBTAIN OJEDA IN AN 8-PLAYER TRADE
description: The Mets made a sweeping series of roster moves yesterday that included an eight-player trade with the Boston Red Sox. The deal brought Bob Ojeda and three lesser pitchers to the Mets in exchange for Calvin Schiraldi, Wes Gardner, John Christensen and LaSchelle Tarver.

title: Surgery for Mattingly
description: Don Mattingly, the Yankee slugger, underwent minor surgery to correct a tendon problem in the little finger of his right hand. The finger had bothered Mattingly during the season, but not enough to keep him from hitting .324, belting 35 home runs and leading the major leagues with 145 runs batted in. . . . Marty Bystrom, the Yankee right-hander who saw limited action this season because of a shoulder iujury, signed a one-year contract that will bring him $125,000 plus a series of incentives.

title: U.S. TO HOLD SHOREHAM DRILL EARLY NEXT YEAR
description: Federal safety officials said today that they would conduct a test early next year of a Long Island Lighting Company plan to protect Long Island residents in the event of an accident at the Shoreham nuclear power plant.

title: IVERSON TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ANDERSON CLAYTON & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DART-HUTTON BID FOR BEATRICE SEEN
description: A surprise new bidder has emerged for the Beatrice Companies, Wall Street sources said yesterday, forecasting that a deal may be near to sell the big consumer products company for about $6 billion.

title: Caterpillar, Soviet
description: The Caterpillar Tractor Company said that it had a contract to sell 200 tractors and 39 pipelayers to the Soviet Union for about $80 million. Caterpillar said it was its largest sale to the Soviet Union since restrictions imposed by the Reagan Administration in December 1981 on export of goods for building the European-Siberian gas pipeline were lifted. The sanctions were a reaction to the Soviet Union's intervention in Afghanistan.

title: STOCKS COOL OFF ON PROFIT TAKING
description: The stock market retreated in orderly fashion yesterday as investors, laden with gains from the two previous sessions, took profits.

title: PETROLEUM EQUIPMENT TOOLS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CHANGING PATTERNS OF FAMILY VIOLENCE
description: Reports of severe wife beating declined 21 percent in the last decade because of changing attitudes and tougher treatment of men who assault their spouses, researchers said today.

title: MANGOOD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss c-Net income

title: PALESTINIANS GO ON TRIAL MONDAY IN GENOA ON CHARGES IN HIJACKING
description: Five Palestinians will go on trial here Monday in connection with the hijacking last month of the cruise ship Achille Lauro, magistrates announced today.

title: Rubin Carter Is Barred From Visiting Canada
description: A Federal judge barred Rubin (Hurricane) Carter today from traveling to Canada for medical treatment during appeals of a decision releasing the former middleweight boxer from prison.

title: Playboy Petitions Over Casino's Debt
description: Playboy Enterprises Inc., said today that it had filed an involuntary bankruptcy petition in Federal court in New Jersey against the Elsub Corporation, the majority owner of the Atlantis Hotel and Casino in Atlantic City.

title: CUTCO INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Edwards Seeks Removal Of Motion for Acquittal
description: Gov. Edwin W. Edwards of Louisiana today asked the judge presiding at his trial on charges of racketeering, wire and mail fraud to withdraw an acquittal motion filed by his attorneys.

title: REAGAN EXPECTS TO ALTER GORBACHEV'S NEGATIVE VIEWS OF U.S.
description: President Reagan believes he will have a significant effect on Mikhail S. Gorbachev's views of the United States through his ''personal dialogue'' with the Soviet leader at the Geneva summit meeting next week, a ranking Administration official said today.

title: Bell & Howell Agreements
description: The Bell & Howell Company said today it had agreed in principle to acquire University Microfilms International, a unit of the Xerox Corporation, for $100 million in cash.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: THURSDAY, NOVEMBER 14, 1985
description: International

title: Chemical Leak in W. Virginia
description: A foul-smelling corrosive chemical began leaking at a chemical plant in the Kanawha Valley, injuring one person and forcing some people from their homes, the authorities said tonight.

title: COHERENT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 28
description: b-Including nonrecurring gains of $2,485,000 for the quarter and $6,728,000 for the year. c-Including a nonrecurring gain of $897,000.

title: BERKSHIRE HATHAWAY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After realized investment gains of $37.2 million for the quarter and $107,554,000 for the 9 months. c-After realized investment gains of $17,654,000 for the quarter and $60,770,000 for the 9 months.

title: HOLIDAY HOUSE TOURS
description: Chelsea Mansion, Mutton Lane, Muttontown, L.I. 516-922-2888.

title: CHANCE FOR COFIELD, VICTORY FOR KNICKS
description: When Hubie Brown arrived this morning for practice, there were two unexpected presents waiting for him. One was a bottle of champagne. The other was a greeting card.

title: Bribe Charges Reinstated
description: Sports bribery charges were reinstated today against the former Tulane University basketball star John (Hot Rod) Williams, clearing the way for another trial in United States District Court.

title: POLICE IN JERSEY FIND BODY OF SLAIN GIRL IN A WOODED REGION
description: A 13-year-old Toms River girl, reported missing Tuesday by her mother, has been found slain in woods 200 yards from her home, the police said today.

title: 'SHADOW CHASERS' ON ABC
description: SAY this much for ''Shadow Chasers'': It tries desperately to be different and, thanks to a giddy sense of humor, it succeeds to an extent that is at least promising. The new series is being given a special two-hour premiere on ABC tonight after President Reagan's speech - at about 8:20 -and will have the unenviable task of trying to survive in weekly competition with NBC's ''Cosby Show'' and CBS's ''Magnum, P.I.''

title: ORBIT INSTRUMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including investment income of $307,100. c-Including investment income of $423,600.

title: NEWPORT ELECTRIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Pitney Bowes Switch
description: Pitney Bowes, which makes metered mail systems and equipment, has moved its U.S. Business Systems division Yellow Pages account to Wahlstrom & Company, the Stamford, Conn., subsidiary of Foote, Cone & Belding Communications. Billings are estimated in excess of $1 million. The account was handled previously by D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles.

title: Amerada to Buy Monsanto Unit
description: The Amerada Hess Corporation has agreed to buy Monsanto Oil Company of the U.K. Inc., a subsidiary of the Monsanto Company, for an undisclosed price, the companies said.

title: CENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MAN WHO RECEIVED 2 HEARTS IMPROVED
description: Michael Drummond, who was kept alive by an artificial heart until he could be given a human heart transplant, is to be released Thursday from the University of Arizona Medical Center, 11 weeks after he made medical history.

title: ALEXANDER & ALEXANDER SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $1.6 million from the early extinsuishment of debt. Year-ago results have been restated to include operations of Reed Stanhouse Cos. Ltd., accounted for a a pooling of interests, as if it had operation as part of the consolidated group and also to include the effect of the discontinuance of the company's insurance underwriting operations.

title: THEATER: AT THE BECKETT, OSCAR WILDE'S 'EARNEST'
description: ''IN matters of grave importance, style, not sincerity, is the vital thing.'' The comment may be taken as a sly aside about the play in which the line is spoken, for ''The Importance of Being Earnest'' is a matter of absolutely no importance, and style is therefore vital in its presentation. In the critic Louis Kronenberger's description, ''It is all surface, even in its satire; all prankishness, even in its fantasy.'' Out of nonsense about a misplaced child who is found, an invented brother who becomes real, two young women who sigh over the name ''Ernest'' and confrontations involving muffins and cucumber sandwiches, Oscar Wilde created his masterpiece.

title: WOOLWORTH, F W CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
CATHOLIC BISHOPS EMBRACE LETTER ON THE ECONOMY
description: The nation's Roman Catholic bishops today warmly embraced a pastoral letter that calls for a major reshaping of the economy to help the poor, but offered some important refinements about the role of parochial schools.

title: DEFENSE LAWYERS IN STEWART TRIAL SEEK TO REFUTE CHARGES OF PERJURY
description: Defense attorneys, focusing on the perjury counts against their clients, concluded their summations yesterday in the trial of six transit police officers charged in the death of Michael Stewart.

title: FOR OFFICIAL, A LEGACY OF POETRY
description: For years Gregory Millard had stolen time from his busy schedule as New York's assistant commissioner of cultural affairs to write poetry. As a black city official with a strong commitment to the minority community, he played an important role in establishing arts programs in the schools and helping minority artists - but his heart was with his poetry, some of which he transformed into works for the stage. Finally, last year, he decided to quit his job to write full time - but before he could do so, he died at the age of 37.

title: Graham in Hospital for Test
description: The evangelist Billy Graham said today that he was admitted to a hospital for cardiac tests after Mayo Clinic doctors gave him a stress test. Mr. Graham, 66 years old, said in a telephone interview from St. Marys Hospital that he had no cardiac symptoms, but doctors wanted to perform an angiogram after he underwent a routine treadmill stress test on Tuesday.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, NOVEMBER 14, 1985
description: International

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond BuyerSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Interfirst Plans To Reduce Staff
description: The Interfirst Corporation, parent of the second-largest bank holding company in Texas, said that it would trim some of its work force of 10,200 employees in an effort to reduce costs. A bank spokesman declined to say how many jobs would be cut, but one analyst, who asked not to be named, estimated that it would be close to 1,000.

title: Article 153714 -- No Title
description: CBS Inc. announced yesterday that it would write down $143.2 million against its third-quarter results to reflect the restructuring of the company. The write-down, coupled with poor results from continuing operations, produced CBS's first loss since the early days of the company.

title: Refco Ruling Is Overturned
description: A Federal appeals court has overturned a $211,073 jury award for commodities law violations against Refco Inc., the nation's largest commodities broker, and against its chairman, Thomas H. Dittmer. Refco, in disclosing the decision today, said it had been handed down last Thursday.

title: Fat Is Now Out
description: Terry Forster is half a foot shorter than Steve Welmer, but he's 20 pounds heavier. And, though becoming a basketball referee is not his idea of a solution, he's determined to trim some of the 270 pounds that he lumbers around with these days. The joke just isn't funny anymore.

title: Denials on Montana
description: It's not that it's been such a dull season in the National Football League. It's just that the Super Bowl champion San Francisco 49ers lost two of their first five games, and, what the heck, maybe the quarterback is on drugs, huh? On such slender speculation are rumors sometimes born, and on such do they spread, acquiring elaborate detail as they multiply until finally somebody gets hurt - in this case Joe Montana and the 49ers, who have now taken pains to expose the rumors and lay them to rest.

title: ICH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After realized investment gains of $7,603,000 for the quarter and $17,234,000 for the 9 months. c-After realized investment gains of $216,000 for the quarter and $1,449,000 for the 9 months. The per share figures for both year- ago periods were restated for a 2-for-1 stock split paid in July. I.C.H. said its earnings from operations in the year-ago third quarter and 9 months include a non-recurring income tax benefit of $11,453,000, or 74 cents per share.

title: 25 WRONGFULLY EXECUTED IN U.S., STUDY FINDS
description: A new study on capital punishment in the United States asserts that in this century 343 people were wrongly convicted of offenses punishable by death and that 25 were actually executed.

title: HEAD OF MANHATTAN SCHOOL OF MUSIC RESIGNS
description: John O. Crosby resigned yesterday as president of the Manhattan School of Music, effective next July 1. He will be replaced by Gideon W. Waldrop, the dean of the Juilliard School of Music since 1961.

title: Birds and Bees and Lean Marines
description: A few days ago, Peter A. A. Berle, president of the 500,000-member National Audubon Society, came across an article in a California paper about boot training for women in the Marine Corps. The article, in The Orange County Register, mentioned the words of a marching song sung by the trainees:

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: Pretending to Educate Poor Children
description: How can poor parents improve their children's schooling? The Reagan Administration has a dazzling answer: Let them buy it. Let Government create a market system for schools. Let each family, using Federal education vouchers, shop for and purchase educational services from any approved vendor, including private schools.

title: ECONOTHERM ENERGY SYSEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MARATHON OFFICE SUPPLY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes tax credits equal to 3 cents a share. The year-ago quarter results include the sales of the Utah branch which was sold in May.

title: SAFEGUARD HEALTH ENTERRISES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Macy and Woolworth Profits Rise
description: Two of the nation's leading retailers yesterday reported sharply higher earnings for their most recent quarters. R.H. Macy & Company showed a 36 percent rise, while F. W. Woolworth & Company gained 46.2 percent.

title: PAR PHARMACEUTICALS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After charges of $151,000 for the quarter and $314,000 for the year related to start-up costs of a newly acquired subsidiary.

title: TOON PICKED TO START FOR JETS
description: As diplomatically as possible, Al Toon officially became the Jets' ''X'' receiver today for Sunday's game against the Tampa Bay Buccaneers. He may be the missing X factor - the big-play receiver - the Jets wanted this year.

title: Westchester Issue
description: Westchester County is offering $83.1 million of general obligation bonds with yields ranging from 4 1/2 percent for bonds due in 1986 to 6 percent in 1990, 7 percent in 1995, 7.70 percent in 2000 and 8 percent in 2005, through underwriters led by the Chase Manhattan Bank. Backed by the county's unlimited taxing power, the high grade bonds are rated Aaa by Moody's and AA+ by S. & P.

title: New Lineup For Coca-Cola
description: The Coca-Cola Company has announced a realignment in its North American advertising agencies. Most of the realignment is under the Interpublic umbrella.

title: Treasury Rates Climb a Bit
description: Interest rates were mixed yesterday, with rates rising modestly for Treasury issues, but declining for tax-exempt securities.

title: DATARAM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Including gains of $102,000 for the quarter and $451,000 for the 6 months from the sale of securities. c-Net loss ater a net loss of $2,009,000 from discontinued products.

title: K N ENERGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss after an extraordinary charge of $19,822,000 from the writeoff of a pipeline venture. The year-ago results were restated to reflect the spinoff of Plains Petroleum Co. in September.

title: EVEN BEFORE A DELUGE, SANG-FROID IN GENEVA
description: When the Swiss Army announced that anyone trying to breach security at the summit conference next week would be shot, it raised few eyebrows.

title: Negotiate Only With West Bank Palestinians
description: To the Editor:

title: TRANS-LUX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings have been restated to reflect the 2 percent stock dividend declared in 1985.

title: New Caledonia Amnesty Is Announced By France
description: France announced a partial amnesty today in its Pacific territory of New Caledonia and a package of steps aimed at helping the economy and resolving rival land claims by European settlers and Melanesians.

title: DESIGNER'S ROLE HERE VS. ABROAD
description: MANUFACTURERS in different countries design and make industrial products in characteristic ways, and a comparison of their production processes reveals strengths and weaknesses in each system. Some Italian manufacturers, for example, with their high regard for the individuality of designers, make products for a consumer elite that regularly star in the marketplace. American companies tend to produce goods with a corporate rather than a designer identity and excel in responding to consumer trends. The Japanese, with long craft traditions that translate into a sensitivity to detail and material in manufacturing, refine more than innovate, making anonymously designed products of high quality.

title: BRADY, W H CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
MCO HOLDINGS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After equity in earnings of unconsolidated subsidiaries of $410,000 for the quarter but losses for the same explanation of $117,000 for the 9 months. c-After equity in earnings of unconsolidated subsidiaries of $4,146,000 for the quarter and $5,823,000 for the 9 months.

title: FORD WILL REPURCHASE 20 MILLION MORE SHARES
description: The Ford Motor Company said today that it would buy 20 million of its common shares, continuing a stock repurchase program. It also said it was exploring ways to take more advantage of the value of its credit and aerospace subsidiaries, perhaps by spinning off and selling shares in the units.

title: HARRY STEINBREDER
description: Harry (Sandy) Steinbreder, director of Time magazine's special advertising projects and former publisher of Money magazine, died Tuesday at Good Samaritan Hospital in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 55 years old and lived in Fairfield, Conn.

title: RITZKY'S, G D INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss reserve of $2,750,000 for the quarter and the 9 months relating to the closing of nine restaurants.

title: AMERICAN SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN (MIAMI, FLA) (N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including equity in net earnings of General Homes Management Corp. & subsidiaries of $2,678,000 for the quarter and $5,185,000 for the year. c-Including equity in net earnings of General Homes Management Corp. & subsidiaries of $5,395,000 for the quarter and $10,321,000 for the year and an extraordinary gain of $1,586,000 from a Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. stock dividend. d-Net income.

title: 2 Backed for Consumer Unit
description: The Senate Committee on Commerce, Science and Transportation today approved and sent to the full Senate the nominations of two members to the Consumer Products Safety Commission, Carol Dawson, who is already a commission member and was renominated, and Anne Graham. Both are Republicans.

title: FOR KELLY, VICTORY IS SWEET
description: For almost two years, Donald P. Kelly has wanted to lead a big, privately held food and consumer goods company. Today, he apparently got his chance. And with it, analysts say, comes the opportunity for Mr. Kelly to use his talent at buying and selling companies. While at the helm of Esmark Inc., Mr. Kelly bought 50 companies - and sold off 22 of them - in a five-year period. Now, some analysts are predicting that he will sell billions of dollars of Beatrice operations.

title: BISHOPS LINK ABORTION FIGHT TO EFFORTS OVER OTHER ISSUES
description: The nation's Roman Catholic bishops today approved a plan to battle legalized abortion that links that fight to other human rights issues in ''a consistent ethic of life.'' Among the issues are nuclear disarmament, capital punishment, poverty, euthanasia, equal rights and racism.

title: Snowball Story
description: Who threw the snowball that interfered with a 49er field goal attempt by Ray Wersching and may have cost San Francisco a victory over the Broncos in Denver Monday night? That's what The San Francisco Examiner wanted to find out, and to induce the person to come forward, the newspaper offered $500 for his story. Yesterday the paper said it had found its man but agreed to keep his name secret because he fears retaliation or the loss of his parents' season tickets to Bronco games. ''It just happened on the spur of the moment,'' he told the paper, noting that while dozens of fans were being ejected from Mile High Stadium for throwing snowballs onto the field, he and a companion escaped official notice.

title: SEAWAY FOOD TOWN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
AFTER THE ASHES FELL, WORLD BEGAN TO SCREAM
description: Survivors of a volcanic eruption that sent an avalanche of mud crashing through their homes early today said the sky lit up with fireballs spewing from the snowcapped mountain.

title: BROADWAY
description: LAST spring it was one of those hoped-for things - now it's definite, or as definite as something can be before the actual opening, which is scheduled for Jan. 5. What opening? ''Corpse,'' of course, Gerald Moon's comedy-thriller in which the star plays twins, one of whom hires a killer to rub out the other. Keith Baxter played the role in London and will do so here, and Milo O'Shea is again slated to play the killer. Performances at the Helen Hayes Theater begin Dec. 12 with John Tillinger directing and Martin Markinson, Gary Leaverton and Robert Fox producing.

title: AMERICARE HEALTH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Candelaria's Son Dies After Coma
description: The son of John Candelaria, the California Angel pitcher, has died after being in a coma since last Christmas Day, the team said today.

title: CONTINUUM CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings have been adjusted to reflect a 100 percent stock dividend, effective Sept. 21, 1984 and a 50 percent stock dividend, effective March 29, 1985.

title: Iroquois Meets On Chairman
description: The board of Iroquois Brands Ltd. met yesterday to discuss charges of cocaine possession pending against its chairman and chief executive, Terence J. Fox.

title: VISUAL GRAPHICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago share earnings have been restated to reflect a 5 percent stock dividend paid in October 1985.

title: Economic Scene;   Stabilizing Currencies
description: THE biggest economic threat to the Republicans in the 1986 Congressional elections is likely to come from the huge United States trade deficit and the damage it is doing to many farms, factories and mines.

title: Summit Debate? No
description: House Republican leaders have rejected a Democratic invitation to respond jointly to President Reagan next week with a one-hour debate on the floor after he gives Congress his live report on the Geneva summit meeting.

title: TECH-SYM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including income of $63,000 for the quarter and after a loss of $689,000 for the 9 months from discontinued operations. c-Including income of $288,000 from discontinued operations.

title: In Defense of the Too-Easily Maligned Secretary
description: To the Editor:

title: BRIEFS
description: * Bank of Boston Corp., Boston, said it had completed the acquisition of RIHT Financial Corp. of Providence, R.I., for about $150 million.

title: Marcos and Opposition Agree to Delay Election
description: Members of President Ferdinand E. Marcos's governing party and opposition groups said today that they had agreed to delay a special presidential election that Mr. Marcos had proposed for Jan. 17.

title: Village Church Concert
description: The St. Luke's Chamber Ensemble will participate in a reconsecration of Greenwich Village's historic St. Luke's-in-the-Fields Church tomorrow at 2 P.M. The church, which was gutted by a fire in 1981, has been rebuilt.

title: G.M. Price Rises
description: The General Motors Corporation said that some models in its newest line of 1986 cars would cost nearly $4,000 more than the 1985 versions. The sports-luxury cars, sharing the same basic body and platforms, are the Cadillac Seville, with a suggested retail price of $26,756, 15 percent over the 1985 price; the Cadillac Eldorado, $24,251, up nearly 16 percent; the Oldsmobile Toronado, $19,418, up 15.6 percent, and the Buick Riviera, $19,831, up 18.7 percent. Clifford Merriott, a GM spokesman, said the increases were justified because the company redesigned the cars ''from roof to road and from front to back.''

title: In Defense of the Too-Easily Maligned Secretary
description: To the Editor:

title: CONGRESS URGED TO PRESS STATES TO GUARD PURITY OF WATER IN GROUND
description: Adding to the pressure for Federal legislation to protect the nation's underground water supply, a public-private coalition today gave Congress a comprehensive plan.

title: Southland Royalty Stake for Boesky
description: The New York investor Ivan F. Boesky said he holds the equivalent of a 6.2 percent stake in the Southland Royalty Company. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Boesky said he had bought the shares ''in connection with merger arbitrage and other investment activities.''

title: WESCO FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a gain of $7,239,000. c-Including a gain of $12,790,000.

title: DOW RISES 11.47 TO NEW PEAK
description: What had been a session of dull trading and only moderately higher prices gave way to another of Wall Street's final-hour rallies that put the Dow Jones industrial average ahead nearly a dozen points to another record closing level.

title: QUANTECH ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $355,876 for the quarter and $154,744 for the 6 months. c-Including a tax credit of $16,069.

title: Rumanian Defector Granted Asylum in U.S.
description: A Rumanian seaman who fled a freighter loading cargo in the Port of Houston was granted asylum in the United States today, the Immigration and Naturalization Service announced.

title: CASTLE & COOKE INC reports earnings for 16 wks to Oct 5
UNIFIRST CORP reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
description: b-After a net loss of $478,000 from discontinued operations. c-After a net loss of $72,000 from discontinued operations. Latest year results are for the 53 weeks ended Aug. 31, 1985; prior year results are for the 52 weeks ended Aug. 25, 1984.

title: ELK HUNTERS SPURN HELP AS NEW SNOW IS PREDICTED
description: More than 50 elk hunters trapped by an early snowfall have been rescued by helicopters from the mountains of Washington's Cascade Range.

title: Reward for Misbehavior
description: For those whose windshields have been covered with tickets, there comes a chance to be covered with glory.

title: Iraq Says Its Jets Attacked Iranian Targets
description: Iraq reported a string of attacks on targets in Iran and the Persian Gulf today.

title: Schiele Work Sold
description: Egon Schiele's ''Portrait of Johann Harms,'' a 1916 watercolor drawing, was sold yesterday at Sotheby's to Serge Sabarsky, a Madison Avenue dealer, for $693,000, the highest price ever paid at auction for an Expressionist drawing. The work, which had been estimated to sell for as much as $200,000, was owned by George Moore, a 31-year-old American artist who lives in Managua, Nicaragua. Mr. Moore, reached after the sale, said he had sold the drawing to start a foundation to help the poor of Central America and that all the proceeds from the sale would be used for this purpose.

title: New Leftist Party in Turkey Is Founded by Ecevit Backers
description: Supporters of former Prime Minister Bulent Ecevit founded a new party today aimed at attracting left-of-center voters.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 15, 1985
description: Companies

title: SYNTECH INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses of $3,972,000 for the quarter and $5,278,000 for the 9 months from discontinued operations. c-Including income of $428,000 from discontinued operations. d-After a loss of $1,108,000 from discontinued operations.

title: No State of Siege Is a Good State of Siege
description: To the Editor:

title: MR GASKET CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Ah, the Auto
description: The 1918 Oldsmobile touring car that goes on display today at the National Museum of American History has tiny plastic bugs on its windshield and a film of dust all over the chassis, as though it had just rolled off an American highway of the 1920's. It is part of an exhibition celebrating the nation's unquenchable love affair with the automobile and the recreational touring it created. On display are 140 vehicles, pieces of touring and camping equipment, documents, photographs, souvenirs and examples of travelers' accommodations, from the tourist home through the roadside cabin colony and campground to today's motel.

title: MOFFETT ENTERS THE RACE AGAINST O'NEILL IN 1986
description: Former United States Representative Toby Moffett, calling Connecticut ''an extraordinary state with an ordinary state government,'' today announced his challenge to Gov. William A. O'Neill for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination in 1986.

title: MUSIC: CHORALES JOIN TRIBUTE
description: THE National Chorale and the National Chorale Soloists, under the direction of Martin Josman, presented a commemorative program of Aaron Copland's choral music at Merkin Concert Hall (129 West 67th Street) on Wednesday, the day before Mr. Copland's 85th birthday.

title: GENERAL INSTRUMENT TO TAKE WRITE-OFF
description: The General Instrument Corporation said yesterday that it would take a pretax charge of about $80 million in its third quarter as part of a major company restructuring.

title: NORDSTROM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
INMED CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 28
description: b-Net income. c-Including a net gain of $586,557 from the sale of land.

title: ADAC LABORATORIES reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-After a charge of approximately $20 million reflecting management's assessment of inventory valuation relative to expected market trends, reduction of carrying value of certain fixed assets and the writedown of other assets to estimated market value. c-Including a tax credit of $3,618,000.

title: A FORMER CURATOR
description: Robert Beverly Hale, former curator of American painting and sculpture at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, died yesterday at his home in Newburyport, Mass. He was 84 years old and also lived in Hydra, Greece.

title: CUSHMAN ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $102,000 for the quarter and $675,000 for the year. c-Including a tax credit of $236,000. d-Net income.

description: b-Including extraordinary credits of $735,000 for the quarter and $2,680,000 for the 9 months. c-Including extraordinary credits of $1,465,000 for the quarter and $2,000,000 for the 9 months.

title: Advertising;   Seagram Forms Unit For Buying
description: SEAGRAM, which last month consolidated its advertising agency roster from seven to three, has now established House of Seagram Media, an in-house media buying operation for magazines, newspapers and outdoor.

title: OPERA: COPLAND'S 'SECONG HURRICANE'
description: OF all the celebrations of Aaron Copland's 85th birthday, none is likely to be more charming and historically piquant than the revival of his children's opera, ''The Second Hurricane.'' The revival opened Wednesday night in the same theater in which it received its world premiere in 1937 - the Henry Street Settlement on Grand Street on the lower East Side - and will run through Dec. 1.

description: Former Senator Harrison Williams, Democrat of New Jersey, has been transferred to a halfway house as he nears the end of his prison term for an Abscam bribery conviction, officials said today.

title: BOY, 15, IS HELD IN GIRL'S SLAYING IN JERSEY WOODS
description: A 15-year-old neighborhood boy was charged today with sexually assaulting and killing a 13-year-old Toms River girl whose body was found late Tuesday in a stream near her home here, authorities said.

description: The city and state governments have allowed public fear of AIDS to stimulate criticism of the homosexual community, City Councilwoman Ruth W. Messinger charged last night.

Tests Find Air Normal At a School in Queens
description: The City Department of Environmental Protection has found ''normal'' levels of carbon monoxide in the air in a Queens elementary school where several teachers and students said they became ill from breathing noxious fumes.

description: SINCE the start of this year security analysts have slashed their 1985 earnings estimates for companies. But lately the preponderance of reduced estimates has slowed markedly.

title: A.S.P.C.A. and City in Accord On Building 3 Animal Shelters
description: City officials and the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals reached agreement yesterday on increased aid to the society and on a plan to open three new animal shelters.

title: Diner's Journal
description: BEER, unlike fine red wine, does not improve with age. The fresher it is, the better the flavor. The only way to find fresher beer than that served in the new Tap Room at the New Amsterdam Amber brewery would be to put your mouth over a barrel spigot. In this cavernous industrial setting on 26th Street and 11th Avenue, you can have drinks and a light meal while watching beer being made in huge copper brew-kettles.

title: Why the Fare Is Fair
description: To the Editor:

title: Elsinore Plans Playboy Fight
description: The Elsinore Corporation said yesterday that it would seek the dismissal of an involuntary bankruptcy petition filed against it by Playboy Enterprises Inc., and that it would ask for unspecified punitive damages from Playboy for a bad-faith filing.

title: AMPAL-AMERICAN ISRAEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including extraordinary income of $704,000, or 3 cents a share, for the latest 9 months and $947,000, or 4 cents a share, for the year-ago period.
