title: Primark-Aviation
description: The Primark Corporation and Aviation Group Inc. said they had agreed to a deal in which Primark would buy all of Aviation Group's common stock for $23 a share, or a total of about $129 million.

title: 'Oldsmobile,' a Drama from Sweden on WNYC
description: Your reaction to ''Oldsmobile,'' the misleadingly titled drama from Sweden on WNYC-TV/Channel 31 at 10 P.M. Sunday, may depend on how much you like the face of Siv Ruud. It is a very expressive, grandmotherly face, rather doll-like, with large eyes that can be loving or tearful, a chin that can tremble or show spunk and a generally sweet look to it. It is no criticism of the face to observe that 80 minutes of watching it may be a strain, considering what is going on around it.

title: In Defense of the Too-Easily Maligned Secretary
description: To the Editor:

title: THE LONG SHIPYARD SLUMP
description: When South Korea's major shipbuilders announced layoffs of thousands of workers last week, they sent an alarming message to the other players in this industry: Even the world's most efficient shipyards are struggling.

title: Advertising;   TBWA Adds G.Q.
description: Conde Nast Publications, which a year ago retained TBWA Advertising to promote its recently acquired Gourmet magazine, must have liked the job it did because it has just moved in a second assignment. It is for both trade and consumer promotion for Gentlemen's Quarterly magazine, which had been assigned to Chalk, Nissan, Hanft.

title: INDEPENDENT INSURANCE GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including capital gains of $1,578,000 for the quarter and $2,270,000 for the 9 months. c-Including capital gains of $1,216,000 for the quarter and $5,336,000 for the 9 months and nonrecurring income of $18,660,000 for the quarter and 9 months from a fresh- start adjustment.

title: Champions of a Cause: Containment
description: It was a gathering of cold warriors, assembled to reminisce about the origins of containment, the post-World War II policy of building political and military bulwarks to hold back Soviet power.

title: SAVANNAH FOODS & INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid on Oct. 15, 1985.

title: Lincoln Center Sonatas
description: Pinchas Zukerman and Mark Neikrug will play violin and piano sonatas by Bach, Brahms and Strauss tonight at 8 at Avery Fisher Hall in Lincoln Center. Tickets are $9 to $17.50. Information: 874-2424.

title: BRITISH AND IRISH APPROVE ACCORD ON ULSTER RULE
description: The British and Irish Cabinets approved today a long-awaited agreement that is expected to give the Dublin Government a powerless but symbolically important advisory role in the affairs of Northern Ireland.

title: THE MAYHEM MOUNTS: EH BIEN, THIS IS MARSEILLES
description: The two main newspapers of this bruised old port city reported with a certain amusement the other day on a gang that tried to commit what might have been one of the robberies of the century, except they mistakenly stopped the wrong train as it crossed a railroad trestle, and while their getaway trucks waited below, they searched in vain for the supposed cargo of goods.

title: BEATRICE ACCEPTS KRAVIS BID
description: The Beatrice Companies, owners of an array of brand-name products, including Samsonite luggage, Hunt's ketchup and Tropicana orange juice, yesterday accepted a $6.2 billion takeover bid from Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, the nation's No. 1 organizer of management buyouts.

title: Winging It With Wright #1
description: This afternoon 200 supporters of Representative Jim Wright, the House majority leader, will board a chartered Boeing 707, temporarily named the Cowtown Clipper, at Dulles International Airport and take off for Fort Worth for a gargantuan political fund-raising event.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday 'CRUCIBLE,' THE OPERA This weekend and next, the Opera Ensemble of New York is performing a new production of ''The Crucible,'' Robert Ward's operatic version of the drama by Arthur Miller, which was based on the Salem witch trials. The cast is headed by Michael Willson, Adelle Nicholson, Deborah Lazenby and John Myers. The libretto is by Bernard Stambler, the production is staged by John J. D. Sheehan, and Michael Recchiuti will conduct. Performances will be given tonight at 8 and Sunday at 3 P.M. at the Lillie Blake School Theater, 45 East 81st Street. Tickets are $15. Information: 288-1485.

title: Backlog of Ships Cleared In St. Lawrence Seaway
description: A backlog of ships created by a collapsed lock at the Welland Canal has been cleared, and an official said today that traffic was back to normal on the 27-mile waterway between Lake Erie and Lake Ontario.

title: VOLCANOES: THE 10 WORST
description: Krakatoa, Indonesia. Aug. 26-27, 1883.

description: Whether professional attitudes carry over to the bridge table is an interesting subject for speculation. Do psychologists try to judge what an opponent is thinking? Do advertising executives demonstrate optimism in their bidding?

title: SPARROW THINKS HE WILL CHANGE
description: Rory Sparrow has a degree from Villanova University - in engineering, no less - and he has given thought to attending law school when his basketball career is over. He tends to be precise, rational and orderly.

description: The catastrophic mud slides off a volcano in northern Colombia appear to be a classic example of what geologists call a lahar, a devastatingly fast and huge avalanche of mud.

description: Two star horses who skipped the Breeders' Cup Nov. 2 are the featured attractions at Laurel Race Course tomorow: The geldings Win and Creme Fraiche are the favorites for the $400,000 Washington D.C. International at a mile and a half on the grass.

description: Echoes of the Democratic primary:

title: CORRECTION
description: A chart in Business Day yesterday with an article about the SIN Television Network incorrectly labeled figures representing the network's advertising revenues. They were in millions, not billions.

description: Wings flapping and beaks snapping, the five Bronx Zoo pelicans resisted capture for an hour yesterday as they were being rounded up for their winter vacations.

description: JAZZ fans know that the best way to hear jazz is to see it.

title: COUPLE WIN FIGHT FOR GIRL THEY ADOPTED
description: Culminating an emotion-charged test of the state's adoption law, New York's highest court ruled yesterday that the adoptive parents of a baby girl with Down's syndrome may keep the child, even though her biological parents now want her back.

title: 15,000 FEARED DEAD IN COLOMBIA AS ERUPTION OF VOLCANO SENDS TORRENT OF MUD OVER 2 TOWNS
description: A snow-capped volcano in northern Colombia that had not erupted in nearly 400 years came to life overnight in a brilliant, explosive burst, touching off floods of raging water and mud that officials feared had swept at least 15,000 people to their deaths. Thousands more were believed injured.

title: ON ROAD TO THE SUMMIT: A PARALLEL TO '55
description: Throughout this week, as the Administration prepared for the Reagan-Gorbachev summit meeting next week, several officials said they saw a parallel to the 1955 conference in Geneva when the Soviet Union and the United States and its allies experienced the first thaw in cold war relations.

title: FREEZE ON TIN TRADING IS EXTENDED IN LONDON
description: With the three-week-old tin crisis still unresolved, the London Metal Exchange decided today to continue its suspension of tin trading indefinitely, reversing an earlier promise to reopen the market next Monday.

description: b-After a provision of $1,975,000 for doubtful long-term notes receivable. c-Net income.

title: The Buck (Pound, Franc) Stops Here
description: There's little dispute that the dollar is too high and other currencies are too low, and it's common to blame the current system of free-floating exchange rates for allowing that. But nobody agrees on what, if anything, might work better. A conference in Washington this week has helped put things into focus. Perfection may be out of reach but there are ways to improve the system.

title: North Korea Ignores I.O.C.
description: Officials in the International Olympic Committee said today that North Korea has failed to reply to an invitation to a meeting scheduled for I.O.C. headquarters early next year to discuss the country's demand to act as a co-host of the 1988 Summer Games in Seoul, the South Korean capital.

title: ITT Trimming Staff by 350
description: The ITT Corporation said yesterday that it planned to reduce its headquarters staff worldwide by 350 people, or 23 percent, as part of the company's drive to restructure.

description: An envoy sent by the Archbishop of Canterbury to seek the release of American hostages said today that he had made contact with the kidnappers and that his next step would be to meet with them.

REGENTS TO LET GIRLS COMPETE WITH BOYS IN THE CONTACT SPORTS
description: Girls in high schools throughout New York State will be allowed to play on teams with boys in contact sports, the State Board of Regents voted yesterday. Before they can play, however, their fitness must be evaluated by a special panel.

title: Topics;   Times Change; Reoriented Morality
description: What a richly eloquent spokesman for international morality the Rev. Jerry Falwell has turned out to be! A few weeks ago he was waxing enthusiastic about the P.W. Botha regime in South Africa. Not for him any qualms about the injustice of apartheid.

title: SANDERS ASSOCIATES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 25
Fast Worker
description: Jimmy Jacobs and Bill Cayton, co-managers of Mike Tyson, have yet to come up with a nickname for their 19-year-old, Brooklyn-born heavyweight. How about Monotonous?

title: Bishops Deny Relief Agency Misused Money in Ethiopia
description: A special committee of Roman Catholic bishops, headed by John Cardinal Krol of Philadelphia, died today that the church's overseas relief agency had misused funds in its Ethiopian famine relief efforts.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Columbia Wins Ivy Soccer Title
description: Columbia won its eighth consecutive Ivy League soccer championship tonight when it defeated Cornell, 2-1, in a rainstorm.

title: 'ENOUGH IS ENOUGH' FOR EX-SUPERWOMAN
description: A self-help group for women troubled by Superwoman Syndrome has been formed in San Francisco. The group, said to be the first of its kind in the country, will hold no meetings, elect no officers and raise no funds. ''It's the perfect organization for women who are already doing too much,'' said Carol Orsborn, founder of the 200-member group known as Superwomen Anonymous.

title: UNIVERSAL MEDICAL BUILDNGS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-No results are available because the company began operations in the summer of 1984.

title: L.I.U., NO. 3, AIMS TO PROVE IT'S NO. 1
description: Although the Long Island University soccer team had the best record in New York State with 16 victories 1 loss and 1 tie when the end-of-season ranking came out, the Blackbirds were ranked third in the region. Hartwick (15-2-1) was ranked first and Columbia (9-2-0) second for the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament.

title: Tandy Computer
description: The Tandy Corporation will introduce a new personal computer this month to compete with the International Business Machines Corporation's high-performance PC AT, John V. Roach, Tandy's chairman, told a shareholders meeting. Called the model 3000, the computer would cost less than the PC AT, but Tandy said it would not disclose the price until the product was introduced next week. Mr. Roach also said it was possible Tandy would post earnings gains of about 30 percent in this fiscal year, after posting a 33 percent drop in profits for the year ended last June 30.

title: In Defense of the Too-Easily Maligned Secretary
description: To the Editor:

title: Apollo Head Quits To Start Venture
description: Apollo Computer Inc., a maker of desktop work stations that has been troubled in the current industry slump, said yesterday that its chairman and founder, John W. Poduska, had resigned to start a new company to build more sophisticated work stations for engineering use.

title: ABC AND CBS GIVE UP ON THE MOVIE BUSINESS
description: Within a few weeks of each other, ABC and CBS have washed their hands of the movie business. CBS Theaterical Films and ABC Motion Pictures, founded with high hopes in 1979, have been closed and padlocked, and Hollywood is neither surprised nor particularly disturbed.

title: ART: DUTCH PAINTINGS COLLECTED BY BREDIUS
description: IN the not too distant past, an art collection acted primarily as the concrete symbol of its owner's wealth and power. It still does, of course, but modernism and psychiatry have so changed the cultural climate that the acquiring of art is now treated as an art form, subject to the same - if sometimes gentler -kind of investigation as all the others. Quite often, it seems that collectors crave applause as much for their creativity, however dependent it may be on outside guidance, as for their ability to buy.

title: Mary K. Rosenwald, Violinist Active in Philanthropic Work
description: Mary Kurtz Rosenwald, a philanthropist whose husband, William J. Rosenwald, was one of the founders of the United Jewish Appeal, died Wednesday at her home in Manhattan. She was 79 years old. Mrs. Rosenwald, who was born in Latvia, moved with her family to Berlin after the Russian Revolution and learned to play classical violin there at the Hochschule fur Musik.

title: HEAD OF CITY U. ASSAILS NEW GROUP, ACCURACY IN ACADEMIA
description: The chancellor of the City University of New York, Dr. Joseph S. Murphy, yesterday cited a new conservative group as a potential threat to academic freedom.

title: EVANS PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Dining Out Guide: Bistros
description: Following is a summary of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. CAFE DU PARC, #106 East 19th Street (777-7840) -

title: FILM: 'ONCE BITTEN,' VAMPIRE HUMOR
description: What do vampires and teen-agers have in common? That all depends on the vampire, of course, but ''Once Bitten'' attempts to bring together a several-hundred-year-old femme fatale and a nice, clean-cut high school boy, all in the name of virginity. Around the time of ''Porky's,'' teen-age virgins were Hollywood's third-class citizens, but times appear to be changing. ''Once Bitten'' is about the efforts of the aforementioned gorgeous Countess (Lauren Hutton) to find herself an innocent young blood supply. If the film is to be believed, chaste 18-year-old boys are no longer in short supply.

title: TOP BRASS ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: FIELD TEST OF GENE-ALTERED BACTERIA IS APPROVED
description: The Environmental Protection Agency today approved the first deliberate release of genetically engineered organisms into the environment, a step that could inaugurate a revolution in using genetic technology for agricultural and environmental purposes.

title: Narragansett Capital Appeal
description: The Narragansett Capital Corporation said there was a ''substantial likelihood'' that a proposed $120 million management buyout of the investment concern would have to be ended if the company could not maintain confidentiality of certain financial statements.

title: ART: NEW SCULPTURES BY WILLIAM TUCKER
description: WILLIAM TUCKER, now 50 years old and long a resident of the United Stares, comes from a generation of British sculptors who are thoughtful, articulate and aware - in an orderly, well-founded way -of the entire history of modern sculpture. (That awareness was less common even 20 years ago when, to name one instance, Picasso's achievement in sculpture was still largely unknown.) In 1974, Tucker published a book called ''The Language of Sculpture,'' reissued last month by Thames & Hudson at $10.95 in paperback, in which he studied the achievements of Rodin, Degas, Brancusi, Matisse, Picasso, Julio Gonzalez and others in a concise, workmanlike way that makes for very good reading. His was a firsthand view - he had been to Rumania, for instance, to see Brancusi's monumental sculptures at Tirgu Jiu long before it was customary to do so - and his book is still a valuable contribution to the subject.

title: TOFU WARS: BATTLING FOR THE SUBURBAN PALATE
description: When the president of the Soyfoods Association, Gary Barat, talks of prime suburban real estate, he is not talking Fairfield County, Conn., or Saddle River, N.J. ''I'm talking the supermarket dairy case,'' he said. ''That's our Fifth Avenue.''

title: TELECOM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses of $39,000 for the quarter and $102,000 for the 9 months from discontinued operations, and including tax credits of $260,000 for the quarter and $836,000 for the 9 months and extraordinary gains of $126,000 for the quarter and $363,000 for the 9 months from the early extinguishment of debt. c-After a loss of $155,000 from discontinued operations and a gain of $2,451,000 from the early extinguishment of debt.

title: SOVIET AIDE SEES CHANCE OF GAINS
description: A Soviet expert on the United States, in a two-hour meeting with reporters, asserted today that the summit conference beginning here Tuesday could provide a turning point in Soviet-American relations, but only if the United States altered its position on a space-based missile defense system.

title: YURCHENKO, IN MOSCOW, OFFERS MORE DETAILS
description: Vitaly S. Yurchenko, considered by the United States a valued defector until his recent return to the Soviet Union, appeared at a news conference here today to offer new details about his experiences.

title: S.E.C. RULING ALTERS MONEY MANAGER FEES
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission unanimously adopted a rule today allowing investment advisers to collect fees based on their investment performance, rather than on the amount of client funds they are investing. The decision should mean considerably higher fee income for successful money managers, and by the same token, lower fees for those less successful.

title: 'PIZZA CASE' DEFENDANT REBUFFED ON CAUSE OF HIS OUTSER BY MAFIA
description: An informer disputed a key defense position by testifying yesterday that a defendant's expulsion from the Sicilian Mafia had not involved his opposition to drugs.

title: DANCE: 'LE CONCOURS,' COMIC BALLET BY BEJART
description: COMIC ballets are in the rara avis category. One that got away is ''Le Concours,'' which the French choreographer Maurice Bejart chose for the opening of his Ballet of the 20th Century on Wednesday night at the City Center, 131 West 55th Street.

title: SCITEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Charles R. Stahl Dead at 65; Edited Commodities Journal
description: Charles R. Stahl, editor of Green's Commodity Market Comments and an authority on precious metals, died Sunday, of complications following coronary bypass surgery, at Presbyterian Hospital in Philadelphia. He was 65 years old and lived in Princeton, N.J.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Nov. 15, 1985 GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. General Committee - 9.30 A.M. Political and Security Committee - 10.30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: CAMPBELL COUP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 27
CORRECTION
description: An article on the Washington Talk page on Tuesday about Senator William Proxmire misstated his tenure. He has served for 28 years.

title: TV Will Be Allowed At Party for Cronkite
description: The journalistic society Sigma Delta Chi today reversed itself and agreed to allow the C-SPAN cable network to videotape its playful criticism of the former CBS news anchor Walter Cronkite at a roast.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: WHITE RUNS HARD TO A GOAL
description: In the Big Ten, 1985 has been a season of football renaissance for a conference recently thought to be in decline.

title: CABINET IN ISRAEL AVERTS COLLAPSE
description: The collapse of Israel's national unity Cabinet was averted late tonight when Prime Minister Shimon Peres and Ariel Sharon, the Minister of Industry and Commerce, hammered out a compromise settlement in their private war.

title: Advertising;   Forbes Will Rerun Ad Twitting Competitors
description: Forbes ran a five-column ad on the back page of the Oct. 30 issue of The New York Times that tweaked its competitors, Business Week and Fortune, for rewarding subscribers with expensive premiums. The ad, prepared by Doremus & Company, had an illustration of a grand Rolls-Royce under the headline ''What premiums will Fortune and Business Week resort to next?''

title: VOLCANO EXPERT SAYS COLOMBIANS TRIED TO PREPARE
description: A leading American vulcanologist said today that emergency plans to cope with an eruption of the Nevada del Ruiz volcano were still being formulated when the disaster occurred today.

title: OLSON INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,760,000 for the quarter and $2,463,000 for the 9 months. c-After a loss of $42,000 from discontinued operations. d-Net income, after a loss of $87,000 from discontinued operations.

title: BRITISH LAND OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Wall Street Forecaster Has Winning Formula
description: Unlike many of his colleagues, Timothy J. Sullivan is one economist who does not not put much faith in econometric models as the best way of projecting the future course of economic growth.

title: Jersey Turnpike Bonds To Yield 4.875% to 7.2%
description: Interest rates were announced yesterday for the New Jersey Turnpike Authority's record $2 billion financing to pay for widening sections of the turnpike.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: Do things go better with Coke?

title: FLYERS REMEMBER LINDBERGH
description: In a memorial that celebrated his life as much as it mourned his death, they said goodbye to Pelle Lindbergh tonight.

title: MURDOCH, ABC DEALS APPROVED
description: The Federal Communications Commission today approved the proposed $3.5 billion takeover of the American Broadcasting Companies by Capital Cities Communications Inc. and the $1.4 billion purchase of seven Metromedia Inc. television stations by Rupert Murdoch, the publisher.

title: CHIEF OF C.I.A. ASSAILS CONGRESS OVER SECURITY
description: William J. Casey, the Director of Central Intelligence, asserted tonight that comments by members of Congress had caused ''the repeated compromise of sensitive intelligence sources and methods.''

title: THE FORCES REVIVING GRAND CONCOURSE
description: New York City housing policy can often seem like some monolithic machine, rolling on at its own majestically slow speed toward goals that may or may not be obvious to the people affected. Rarely, it seems, does the public get a glimpse of the gears.

title: Family Percentage Of Potlatch Stock
description: The Potlatch Corporation said that as a result of the company's repurchase of 2.4 million of its shares, members of the founding Weyerhaeuser family now own 47.2 percent of the shares outstanding, up from just over 40 percent.

title: GIANTS' HAYNES WAITS FOR CALLS
description: Bill Parcells, the Giants' coach, said today that the cornerback Mark Haynes, who rejoined the team Oct. 17 after a long holdout, is ready to play in the secondary again. But whether he will Monday night, when the Giants engage the Redskins in Washington, is another matter.

title: Fed Warns Banks on Payouts
description: The Federal Reserve Board issued a policy statement today warning banks and bank holding companies that are experiencing financial trouble that they should reduce their dividends or not pay them at all.

title: K-TRON INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 28
description: b-Net income.

title: 373 Sentenced in Turkey
description: A martial law court today sentenced 11 people to die and jailed 362 others in a mass trial of members of the revolutionary organization Dev Yol, the semiofficial Anatolian News Agency said. The defendants were found guilty in the eastern town of Erzurum of killing 25 people, wounding 20 and carrying out other guerrilla attacks in northeast Turkey before the military takeover in 1980. Some 25 other mass trials of 5,000 purported members of Dev Yol are going on, stemming from the violence.

title: WEINBERGER DEFENDS JOINT CHIEFS
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger said today that sweeping changes were not needed at the Pentagon and urged Congress to ignore proposals to change or abolish the Joint Chiefs of Staff.

title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT ANSWERS
description: Often an event captures headlines, then fades from view with important questions unanswered - questions that defy news reporting, at least for a while. This column periodically offers a selection of such questions, with today's group concentrating on people - and things - that are missing.

title: Janecyk Suspended
description: The goaltender Bob Janecyk of the Los Angeles Kings, who swung his stick at Peter Zezel of the Philadelphia Flyers after a collision during a game Nov. 3, has received a five-game suspension. . . . Nick Fotiu, the 33-year-old former Ranger who has been playing with New Haven this season, had exploratory surgery on his left knee yesterday, and afterward doctors said he had torn ligaments and would have to stay off his leg for four weeks and then undergo two months of therapy. He hurt the knee in a game last week. . . . Ari Haanpaa, the Islander wing who has been out since hurting his left shoulder against the Calgary Flames Nov. 5 underwent arthroscopic surgery Wednesday and is expected to be out two more weeks.

title: Summit Logistics: Who Sits and Sleeps Where
description: At mid-afternoon Sunday President Reagan plans to slip out of the 18th-century gray stone chateau where he will be staying in Geneva, climb into his limousine and travel two and a half miles for an unofficial visit to the lakeside mansion that will be the site of his first meeting with Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

title: TEXAS AMERICAN ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Come In From the Cold
description: Four years ago a woman named Rebecca Smith rejected the pleas of police, social workers and a psychiatrist to leave her ''home'' - a cardboard carton on a street in Manhattan's Chelsea district -and come in from the cold. As city officials sought a court order allowing them to take her forcibly to a hospital or shelter, she froze to death.

title: Colombia's Calamity
description: Weep for Colombia. A country still grieving over the dozens who died in last week's siege at the Palace of Justice in Bogota must now dig for thousands of bodies buried in mud. For months there have been warning puffs from Nevado del Ruiz, the northernmost Andean volcano. But life continued as before in Armero, which has a population of 25,000, and in nearby Chinchina, with 70,000. That was surely understandable; it last erupted in 1595, and its periodic huffing over the years provoked not terror but shrugs.

title: Bruins Trade Peeters
description: The Boston Bruins traded Pete Peeters, winner of the 1983 Vezina Trophy as the National Hockey League's top goalie, to the Washington Capitals for the goaltender Pat Riggin, the Bruins announced tonight.

title: PUBLIC HAS LOW EXPECTATIONS FOR GENEVA, POLL SHOWS
description: Only half the American public expects the summit meeting next week between President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev to improve Soviet-American relations, and just a third thinks it will lead to an arms-control agreement, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.

title: TOSCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a gain of $3 million from a LIFO inventory adjustment. c-Net loss, including a gain of $8 million from the sale of Angel Fire, a New Mexico land development, offset by a charge of $8 million related to revaluation of other assets and termination costs. d-Including a state tax credit of $1 million. e-Including a state tax credit of $2 million. Results for the latest quarter do not include results for the El Dorado, Ark., refinery, sold on May 1, 1985.

title: POPE, EVANS & ROBBINS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TALK BY K.G.B. MAN SEEN AS POLITICAL
description: Reagan Administration officials asserted today that Vitaly S. Yurchenko's Moscow news conference was aimed primarily at domestic audiences and was not an effort to disrupt the coming summit meeting.

title: On the Table at Geneva
description: If President Reagan puts his Strategic Defense Initiative ''on the table'' at his summit meeting with Mikhail Gorbachev and in later arms control talks, would that mean he had traded it away or promised to abandon it?

title: NETS LOSE AGAIN ON ROAD
description: For three periods tonight, Mike Gminski and Darryl Dawkins, the Nets' centers, combined to harass Akeem Olajuwon. But in the final quarter when they tired, the 7-foot center became rejuvenated, pulled out of a 4-for-14 shooting spell and paved the way for Houston to defeat the Nets, 112-107, at The Summit. Olajuwon scored 11 points and had 3 rebounds in the final quarter.

title: SCREEN: 'LES PLOUFFE,' SAGA OF FRENCH CANADIAN FAMILY
description: ''LES PLOUFFE,'' by Gilles Carle, which opens today at the Public Theater, is a long, plodding domestic saga about a family of working-class French Canadians in Quebec City from 1938 through 1945. The Plouffes - Josephine, the mother; Theophile, the father, and their three grown sons - are each commonplace in an idealized way.

title: Insider Reports
description: The New York Stock Exchange issued this week its latest report of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchange. The report of changes follows: NEW YORK EXCHANGE ALLEGHENY INTERNATIONAL INC.

title: FOLKS RESTAURANTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: THEATER: 'GHASHIRAM,' FOLK TALE FROM INDIA
description: IN several respects, ''Ghashiram Kotwal'' is a departure for the Pan Asian Repertory Theater.

title: FINGERS RELEASED BY BREWERS
description: The Milwaukee Brewers, who finished next to last in the American League East, began an expected house-cleaning yesterday by releasing several players, including Rollie Fingers, the major league career leader in saves with 341.

title: A SPECIALIST IN PLANNED CITIES
description: William L. Pereira, an architect and urban planner who designed the Transamerica building in San Francisco and the master-planned community of Irvine, Calif., died Wednesday at the Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles. He was 76 years old, and lived in Beverly Hills.

title: Mulroney to Visit U.S. in '86
description: The White House announced today that Prime Minister Brian Mulroney of Canada would make an official visit to the United States early next year. Mr. Mulroney will meet with President Reagan on March 18, a year and a day after the two met in Ottawa. Mr. Reagan and Mr. Mulroney also met at the economic summit in Bonn last May and at the United Nations last month.

title: CHRISTMAS COMES EARLY TO FESTIVE RADIO CITY
description: Long box-office lines and milling crowds in the lobby are nothing new at Radio City Music Hall. But the scene is just as frenetic backstage at this time of year as the Music Hall prepares for its annual holiday show, the ''Magnificent Christmas Spectacular,'' which opens today and runs through Jan. 9.

title: Transactions
description: BOSTON (AL) -Released Jim Dorsey, pitcher. Assigned Dave Sax, catcher, and LaSchelle Tarver and Gus Burgess, outfielders, to Pawtucket of the International League.

title: U.S. Steel Pricing
description: The United States Steel Corporation said it was lowering list prices and at the same time eliminating discounts on two categories of pipe, so that the ultimate effect of the changes would be a moderate price rise. The nation's largest steel producer did not give specific figures on the net changes. The changes, the latest in a series of similar moves by major steel producers, bring list prices closer to actual prices being negotiated in an intensely competitive market.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Nets vs. Mavericks, at Dallas, 8:30 P.M. The Nets were 2-10 against the Midwest Division last year, but they split two games with Dallas, each team winning on its home court.

title: RETAIL SALES SHOW STEEP 3.3% DECLINE
description: Retail sales plummeted a record 3.3 percent in October as a big drop in auto purchases offset modest gains elsewhere, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: The Music of Bloch
description: Martin Bookspan will moderate a panel discussion titled ''How Jewish is Ernest Bloch's Music?'' on Sunday afternoon at 3 at the 92d Street Y. He will be joined by the cellist Yosif Feigelson and the pianist Mark Pakman, who will perform portions of ''Schelomo'' and other works.

title: Film and TV Seminar
description: A seminar for those interested in careers in film and television production will be held tomorrow at the Y.W.C.A., 610 Lexington Avenue, at 53d Street.

title: RISK SEEN IN SATURATED FATS USED IN FAST FOODS
description: A consumer organization said today that eight of the country's largest chains of fast-food and family restaurants cooked their french fries and other foods in beef fat, which is high in the saturated fats that researchers say can contribute to heart disease.

title: ON THE STREETS, TOUGH TEST FOR NEW HOMELESS POLICY
description: Vito sat on a bench in Battery Park yesterday and talked about his freedom and how the Mafia controlled the shelters for the homeless in New York.

title: Super-8 Film Festival
description: Super-8 film, which was created by Kodak in the mid-1960's as a low-cost medium for home movies, has often been effectively used by independent film makers.

title: GURU TO LEAVE U.S. IN IMMIGRATION PLEA BARGAIN
description: Bhagwan Shree Rajneesh, leader of a commune established in eastern Oregon four years ago, agreed to leave the country after pleading guilty in Federal District Court here today to arranging sham marriages to allow his foreign-born followers live in the United States.

title: PETROMINERALS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
New Theater Opening
description: An Orson Welles double-bill, featuring ''The Third Man'' and ''Mr. Arkadin,'' will open today at a new movie theater, the Thalia SoHo, at 15 Vandam Street.

title: CENTURY BUSINESS CREDIT reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: ''IT certainly is celebrity-ridden, isn't it?'' Robert Nikirk exclaimed as Jacqueline Onassis' red and black Valentino brushed past him in the candle-lighted New York Public Library rotunda on Monday evening. Mr. Nikirk, librarian at the Grolier Club, was among 200 guests who got into their black-tie best for the library's annual Literary Lions dinner. Russell Baker, Joan Didion, John Gregory Dunne, Amos Elon, Mary Gordon and George F. Kennan were among the 21 writers honored this time around with a golden lion's-head medallion and volumes of congratulations from the likes of Katharine Graham, William F. Buckley Jr., Gloria Steinem, Brooke Astor, Benjamin C. Bradlee, Sally Quinn and Zoe Caldwell, who gave an after-dinner reading of Lillian Hellman.

title: FILM: 'BUDDIES,' TALE OF AN AIDS PATIENT
description: To his credit, Arthur J. Bressan Jr.'s ''Buddies'' is heartfelt and serious, although it's also talky enough to dispel many of the emotions it means to arouse. ''Buddies'' is a two-character drama about an AIDS patient named Robert Willow (Geoff Edholm) and a volunteer worker named David Bennett (David Schachter), who pays Robert frequent visits and becomes more and more deeply involved with his charge.

title: ANDREW CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
OGDEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses of $5,837,000 for the quarter and $8,734,000 for the 9 months from discontinued operations. c-After a loss of $1,015,000 from discontinued operations. d-Including income of $3,994,000 from discontinued operations.

title: CHANNEL 13 OFFERS 'MASTER HAROLD'
description: EVEN in its acclaimed stage version, Athol Fugard's '' 'Master Harold' . . . and the Boys'' seemed perfectly designed for television. The play is short, running under 90 minutes without an intermission, and searingly intimate, almost demanding close-up shots. In an unusual financing arrangement, involving television's Lorimar, the Broadway producer Emanuel Azenberg and WNET/ Channel 13, the television version was made last year and has already been presented on pay cable's Showtime. Tonight at 9 o'clock on Channel 13, it can be seen as part of public television's ''Great Performances'' series.

title: THE BOOM IN STRETCH LIMOUSINES
description: Several times a day, Earle Moloney's staff removes all the wiring and plush upholstery from a top-of-the-line Cadillac Fleetwood Brougham or Lincoln Town Car, cuts the steel frame in half with a huge hacksaw and then welds on some longer body parts.

title: EXPAND MIDEAST TALKS
description: The peace proposals made at the United Nations last month by King Hussein and Prime Minister Shimon Peres injected some life into the Middle East ''peace process,'' moribund since the triumph of Camp David. In an important breakthrough, the two leaders accepted the principle of international participation, and they have apparently been working since toward a more detailed arrangement.

title: PHILHARMONIC: ALL-COPLAND PROGRAM
description: IT was a thoroughly pleasant event, a birthday party disguised as a concert, and in every way as amiable as the famous guest himself. There stood Aaron Copland last night in a box at one side of the stage, smiling his familiar toothy smile and acknowledging the affectionate applause of an Avery Fisher Hall audience that had gathered to help the New York Philharmonic celebrate the composer's 85th birthday. For the occasion, the orchestra had cooked up a seven-layer program consisting mostly of unfamiliar but easily digested Copland pieces, probably with a large television audience in mind (the concert was a Live from Lincoln Center telecast).

title: Keep 'em Packed
description: Glen Sonmor, director of player development for the Minnesota North Stars, discloses what it takes for the risky job of being a coach in the National Hockey League: ''Good luggage.''

title: HOME FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN OF THE ROCKES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: PETRO-LEWIS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a tax credit of $4,221,000. c-Including a tax credit of $2,324,000 and after a loss of $2,492,000 on lease commitments.

title: HOUSE UNIT REJECTS TAX ON POLICY CASH VALUES
description: A working group of House Ways and Means Committee members today rejected President Reagan's proposal to tax life insurance policyholders on the annual increase in the cash value of their policies.

title: STEWART TRIAL PROSECUTOR, IN SUMMATION, URGES JURY TO FOCUS ON TESTIMONY
description: The prosecutor in the trial of six transit police officers charged in the death of Michael Stewart made a seven-hour summation yesterday, arguing that the officers had failed in their duty to protect a defenseless prisoner.

title: MICRO MASK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: Money Fund Assets Off
description: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds fell $971 million, to $207.38 billion, in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. It said institutional investors shifted dollars to short-term securities. Assets of the 192 general purpose money funds were down $505.1 million, to $60.67 billion, while the 73 institutional funds fell $471.1 million, to $52.86 billion, and the 87 broker-dealer funds rose $5.5 million, to $93.85 billion.

title: TERRAMAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TELECOM PLUS INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including gains of $14,722,000 for the quarter and $18,520,000 for the 9 months from the recognition of a gain of issuance of common stock by subsidiaries. c-Including a gain of $17,231,000 from recognition of a gain of issuance of common stock by subsidiaries.

title: VOIT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 29
description: Latest quarter results are for the 13 weeks ended Sept. 29, 1985; year-ago results are for the 14 weeks ended Sept. 30, 1984.

title: Joan Mintz, Jersey Aide, Wed to Robinson Markel
description: Joan E. Mintz, deputy director of the New Jersey State Division on Aging in Trenton, was married in New York yesterday to Robinson Markel, a member of the New York law firm of Milgrim Thomajan Jacobs & Lee. Judge Robert W. Sweet of the Federal District Court performed the ceremony in his chambers.

title: AUCTIONS
description: EMPRESS JOSEPHINE'S copy of Pierre-Joseph Redoute's botanical watercolors for ''Les Liliacees'' (''The Lilies'') will be auctioned next Wednesday at Sotheby's, and the bidding may last five minutes or five hours. The 468 drawings on vellum of the flowers in the gardens of Malmaison, St.-Cloud, Versailles and Sevres, made between 1802 and 1816, fill 16 volumes, weigh a total of 320 pounds and may sell, the auction house says, for $5 million to $7 million.

title: Jackson to Travel to Geneva To Deliver Appeal for Peace
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson says he plans to take a message of peace to the summit meeting next week between President Reagan and the Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

title: SANMARK-STARDUST (INC) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
20 in Chicago Settle Police Spying Case
description: A judge today approved a $306,250 settlement for 20 plaintiffs in a police surveillance case and cleared the way for five others to test the constitutionality of such surveillance.

title: Nixon Seattle Bound?
description: Norm Nixon, who has been unable to reach a contract agreement with the Los Angeles Clippers, has signed an offer sheet with the Seattle SuperSonics that would pay the free agent guard $2.7 million over four years. Lenny Wilkens, the Seattle general manager, also signed the agreement, which includes an option year.

title: INTEGRATED RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ART: THE WILD KINGDOM SHOWN BY MELISSA MILLER
description: WHEN Melissa Miller's paintings of animals have been shown in New York, the response has been generally enthusiastic. The works seemed immediate, imaginative and seamless. The feelings and struggles of her tigers, polar bears and monkeys seemed very much our own. But there were still doubts. Were the paintings too simple? Was the goodness they radiated - no matter how it reflected a widespread utopian impulse in contemporary art - a sign of sentimentality? How far could affectionate paintings of animals go?

title: AMERICAN BUSINESSPHONES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
JOY MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
description: b-After a net charge of $13.7 million for the quarter and year for divestiture, consolidation and writeoff of excess inventories. c-Net income.

title: Bush and the Farmers
description: Vice President Bush will venture into a potential lion's den tomorrow when he sits down with a group of farm leaders at the Marriott Hotel in Des Moines. He is going to Iowa for a Republican fund-raiser in observance of the birthday of Gov. Terry E. Branstad. But party leaders reportedly advised the Governor that if Mr. Bush made a political appearance in the state, he would have to schedule a session with farmers and hear their protests against policies of the Administration and the Department of Agriculture.

title: Which Terrorists to Punish?
description: For a country that takes a lead in declaring ''war on terrorism,'' the U.S. is being inconsistently reticent on extradition of Irish terrorists.

title: The High Cost of Not Institutionalizing Psychiatric Patients
description: To the Editor:

title: U.P.I. BUYER AND THE CALL OF THE NEWS
description: The man who bid successfully for United Press International is an intensely ambitious Mexican who started working at 10 years of age, still works 14-hour days and sometimes oversees the front pages of his newspapers.

title: MISCHER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: US SHELTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: Will an Accord Follow The Tough Act?
description: To the Editor:

title: REAGAN SIGNS STOPGAP BILLS FOR FINANCING GOVERNMENT
description: President Reagan tonight signed two stopgap bills that will enable the Government to get enough money to keep running while the President goes to Geneva for the summit meeting next week.

title: BEDFORD COMPUTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income including extraordinary tax credits of $18,000 for the quarter and $134,000 for the 9 months.

title: INVACARE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: Woodard in Debut
description: The rookie missed a couple of layups, had the ball stolen at one point and bobbled it a bit during the famous ''weave,'' but after scoring 7 points and joining in the fun for a quarter and a half, Lynette Woodard was anything but disconsolate Wednesday night. After all, she was making her American debut in Spokane, Wash., as the first woman to play with the Harlem Globetrotters.

title: 50-Year Trip Coming to an End
description: In the last half-century, ever since Yeshiva University put a basketball program together, the team has played 932 games. But none of them was ever played on the home court, because the school didn't have one. So far as the N.C.A.A. can determine, this gives Yeshiva a singular distinction: at 50 years, the longest road trip in the history of college hoops.

title: Record to Stand
description: Leroy Horn, the reserve Montclair State running back who gained 310 yards in the second half of a Division III game against Jersey City State last Saturday, did not break a record - but he has one now, according to Steve Boda, an N.C.A.A. statistician. Boda noted that the N.C.A.A. did not keep records by halves for Division II and III schools, ''but when there is a performance that is likely to be a record,'' he said, ''I'll put it in the book. I'm putting this one in the book.''

title: Refunding Issue For Intermountain
description: The Intermountain Power Agency, based in Utah, is offering $507 million of electric revenue bonds to refund existing debt through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Advertising;   Ogilvy, T.W.A. Reconciliation
description: William E. Phillips, chairman of the Ogilvy Group, parent of Ogilvy & Mather, did not take being dismissed by the new management of Trans Worlds Airlines lying down. As a result, the agency has been reappointed.

title: WEDTECH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $112,000 for the quarter and $239,000 for the 9 months.

title: FOUR STAR INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 28
ALPINE INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TRIANGLE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $109,000 for the quarter and $535,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss. d-Including a tax credit of $4,000.

title: REAGAN FAVORING U.S.-SOVIET FLOW OF YOUNG PEOPLE
description: President Reagan today proposed ''the broadest people-to-people exchanges in the history of American-Soviet relations.''

title: U.S. GIVES GUIDELINES TO WORKERS ON PREVENTING AIDS TRANSMISSION
description: Nhe United States Public Health Service said today that there was generally no need to place special restrictions on food handlers and health-care workers infected with AIDS because there was no evidence the virus has spread through casual contact.

title: PLESSEY CO PLC reports earnings for 13 wks to Sept 27
description: Share earnings are per American Depository Receipt, which is equal to 10 shares.

title: VAN SCHAAK & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: FILM: PERCY ADLON'S 'SUGARBABY'
description: The following are excerpts from Janet Maslin's review of ''Sugarbaby,'' which appeared in The New York Times on Oct. 1. The film opens today at the Lincoln Plaza 2, Broadway at 63d Street.

title: PAST SUMMIT MEETINGS, UNLIKE REAGAN'S, WERE FOR SIGNING OF KEY ACCORDS
description: By and large, most of the past summit meetings involving the Soviet Union and the United States stand in a different category from the one between President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev in Geneva next week.

title: DOC OPTICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
JUST A LITTLE BITY OFF BROADWAY, YOU CAN CATCH THE RISING STARS
description: FRESH off the bus, the young actress puts down her cardboard suitcase, slips on her tap shoes and auditions her way into a role in the chorus. In a flash, the star of the show breaks a leg - and the new chorus girl, who knows everyone's part by heart and can also play Eliza Doolittle, Tracy Lord and Medea, is rushed into the lead. As memorialized in ''42d Street,'' and countless imitations, the ''youngster'' is instantly transformed into a ''star.''

title: TRANSCRIPT OF PRESIDENT'S SPEECH ON SUMMIT TALKS NEXT WEEK
description: Following is a transcript of President Reagan's speech from the White House last night on the summit meeting in Geneva next week, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: A BIBLIOPHILIC JAUNT THROUGH A CITY OF LIBRARIES
description: Subjects from mime to mountaineering to books about books can be found in the nearly 1,000 specialized libraries in the New York City area. For a city that boasts a public library system of some 205 libraries, 157 museums, 43 universities and countless clubs and associations, it is probably not an exaggeration to say that for every specialized interest in New York City, there is a library.

title: INTERNATIONAL INCOME PROPERTY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a gain of $1,506,000.

title: BRIBE PAYMENT TO STATE JUDGE WAS ADMITTED
description: A convicted gambler has admitted paying a state judge in Queens $30,000 to fix three criminal cases, according to court papers unsealed yesterday.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: IN the summer of 1920, shortly after they were married, James and Alix Strachey left England for Vienna. James had arranged to undergo analysis with Sigmund Freud, with a view to becoming an analyst himself; at first, there was no thought of Alix being analyzed as well, but after an anxiety attack during a visit to the opera (the work being performed was ''Gotterdammerung'') she got James to arrange for Freud to take her on as a patient.

title: A Real-Estate Broker Agrees To $350,000 Bias Settlement
description: The largest real-estate rental agent in the metropolitan area agreed yesterday to a $350,000 settlement in a case in which he and his company had been accused of discriminating against blacks in renting, sales and hiring.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: THE name Arizona 206 sounds more like a highway than a restaurant. In a way, though, it is aptly named, because this exuberant new spot offers a direct route to some of the best California- and Southwestern-style food around. At a time when voguish grill restaurants are turning up like Christmas lights in December, Arizona 206 stands out above the crowded display with a sparkling array of dishes.

title: 20 EMERGE AS CONTENDERS TO BE NEXT YALE PRESIDENT
description: Out of a field of 430, 20 people have emerged as the leading candidates to be the next president of Yale University. The Yale Corporation, the university's trustees, expects to make its selection next month.

title: Keeping It Quiet
description: The muting of a protest at New York University has touched off a not-so-muted exchange.

title: Gorbachev's Book
description: The Soviet Embassy held a news conference yesterday to announce the publication of ''A Time for Peace'' by Mikhail S. Gorbachev, a collection of his statements since last March.

title: HEMOTEC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MCO RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: Deal Is Seen On Tri-Star
description: Home Box Office, the largest pay-television service, is expected to sell a significant portion of its interest in Tri-Star Pictures to Columbia Pictures Industries, sources familiar with the transaction said yesterday.

title: Extras Needed
description: Cedric Maxwell, who has been joined by Marques Johnson, Jamaal Wilkes and now Derek Smith on the list of the Los Angeles Clippers' wounded: ''I once saw this many guys go down, but it was in a war movie.''

title: SCREEN: DOCUMENTARY ON VLADMIR HOROWITZ
description: YOU are not likely to get closer to Vladimir Horowitz's fingers, or for that matter his nose, than in ''Vladimir Horowitz, the Last Romantic,'' the documentary that will be shown, most appropriately, at Carnegie Hall tonight.

title: CORRECTION
description: A front-page picture caption on Oct. 25 about the Children's Parade for Peace near the United Nations incorrectly located the school attended by some participants. It was P.S. 15 in Brooklyn.

title: Liberia Makes Arrests After a Coup Attempt
description: Leaders of Liberian opposition parties were rounded up today as soldiers went on a rampage of looting in revenge for a failed coup two days ago, according to reports reaching here.

title: TENNESSEE AND U.S. COURT IN A DISPUTE OVER CROWDED PRISONS
description: Like an old maze of pipes blocked at either end, the overburdened Tennessee prison and local jail system is backing up and spilling over.

title: KEY PHARMACEUTICALS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
COPLAND AT 85: FANFARE FOR AN UNCOMMON MAN
description: Aaron Copland stepped hesitantly from a limousine onto the wet sidewalk yesterday and paused to embrace his memories.

title: HOBOKEN, A 10-MINUTE RIDE TO FAR AWAY
description: HOBOKEN, the author Christopher Morley once proclaimed, is ''the last seacoast of bohemia.'' As New Yorkers hopped on the ferries to what they called a ''Greenwich Village West'' in the late 1920's, it was not the first time and certainly not the last that the mile-square city across the Hudson was to be ''discovered.'' The cabarets are gone, as are the speak-easies, but yet another renaissance has brought new restaurants, nightclubs and feverish development to this once-industrial waterfront city.

title: FINE ART ACQUISITIONS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $21,000 for the quarter and $58,000 for the 9 months.

title: Barge Explosion Kills Man
description: A petroleum barge exploded in a ball of flame and sank Wednesday, killing a man and blocking the Harvey Canal, the authorities said. Five other people were injured in the explosion at the Gretna Machine and Iron Works at the intersection of the canal and the Intracoastal Waterway. The identity of the dead man, who was on the barge, was not immediately known.

title: HARVARD FIELD A TEST FOR PENN
description: The Penn team that has brushed aside every Ivy League challenger this season faces one more tomorrow at Cambridge, Mass. Harvard, with an upset victory, could tie the Quakers at 5-1 and continue the championship race into the final week of the season.

title: HOUSE INVESTIGATORS CRITICIZE JUSTICE DEPT. IN E.P.A. CASE
description: A draft report prepared for the House Judiciary Committee is critical of the Justice Department's role in urging President Reagan in 1982 to block the release of Environmental Protection Agency files on toxic waste cases.

title: WESPERCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income, including a gain of $822,000 on the sale of leasehold improvements.

title: Shady Corporate Practices
description: Do recent reports of check-kiting (E.F. Hutton), overcharging on defense contracts (General Dynamics), failing to inform authorities of deaths to patients who took Oraflex (Eli Lilly) and employee deaths from cyanide poisoning (Film Recovery Systems) involve only a few rotten apples, or is the corporate core corrupt?

title: MEDEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 15, 1985
description: International

title: PENNSYLVANIA HEART PATIENT DIES
description: Anthony Mandia, who was kept alive by a new type of artificial heart for 11 days before he received a transplanted human heart last month, died today, officials at the Milton S. Hershey Medical Center here said.

title: GORBACHEV'S GLOOMY AMERICA
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev's America is a land controlled by wealthy capitalists and conservative business interests.

title: INVESTMENT ADVISER DISSENTS FROM BACKING OF BID FOR U.P.I.
description: A crack has appeared in what had seemed to be solid backing for a wealthy Mexican newspaper publisher's bid to buy United Press International.

title: Lendl and Becker Gain at Wembley
description: Ivan Lendl, the defending champion, powered his way into the quarterfinals of the $375,000 Benson and Hedges Tennis Championships today, crushing fellow Czechoslovak, Tomas Smid, 6-2, 6-0, in just 44 minutes at the Wembley Arena.

title: TREASURY NOTES, BONDS FALL SHARPLY
description: The bubble burst in the Treasury market yesterday as prices of notes and bonds fell sharply after a late afternoon announcement of $61 billion of new Treasury securities to be sold in the next nine business days.

title: 3D-WORLD GROUP SAID TO IMPEDE TRADE ROUND
description: The United States trade representative, Clayton K. Yeutter, said today that a small group of developing countries was objecting to a new round of trade liberalization talks, thus ''blocking the will'' of most of the global trading community.

title: JETS SIGN EX-GIANT FLOWERS
description: The Jets today took decisive action to fill a sudden need when they acquired the former Giant Larry Flowers, one of the most acclaimed special-team players in the National Football League.

title: FIRST AMERICAN FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Topics;   Times Change; Untimely Demise
description: Give the British credit. They have kept up appearances long after a relentlessly practical lot like us in America. But finally, another symbol of their imperial past, Greenwich mean time, has become an unaffordable luxury.

title: WILLIAM B. SHEALY
description: William B. Shealy, a lawyer specializing in tax law, died last Sunday at Waterbury (Conn.) Hospital.

title: WILSON BROTHERS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BACHE TO GET CAPITAL INFUSION
description: The Prudential Insurance Company of America said yesterday that it would increase the reported capital of Prudential-Bache Securities, its brokerage subsidiary, by $600 million. The action, to be accomplished through an accounting switch, will more than double the firm's capital.

title: TV: SPECIAL ON NEWARK ORCHESTRA
description: ''The Cathedral Symphony of Newark Special,'' which airs tomorrow on Channel 9 at 8 P.M., is as much a promotional effort as a concert. The city's image has not been a very lustrous one in recent years and this two-hour program - which interweaves a concert by the Cathedral Symphony Orchestra with various interviews, rehearsal scenes and views of the Cathedral of the Sacred Heart's French neo-Gothic architecture -tells us about a Newark cultural renaissance accompanying the more publicized economic one.

title: ATLANTIS CASINO SEEKS BANKRUPTCY PROTECTION
description: The Atlantis Casino Hotel in Atlantic City, mired in debt, has been forced to seek protection from its creditors in Federal bankruptcy court.

title: HOW CAN REAGAN FACE THE INDOCHINA P.O.W.'S
description: Ten years ago, Representative G.V. (Sonny) Montgomery headed a Congressional commission charged with determining whether American prisoners of war were being held captive in Indochina. The verdict: No P.O.W.'s were alive there. The other day, Mr. Montgomery admitted that, amid new reports of sightings of Americans imprisoned in Vietnam and Laos, doubt has crept into his mind. ''This is the issue that won't go away,'' he said.

title: CONGRESS PLEA FOR CONTROLLERS
description: Seventy-eight members of the House of Representatives have urged President Reagan to rehire some of the air traffic controllers who were dismissed four years ago, saying the current controller work force ''is stretched beyond its human capacity.''

title: Compounds to Treat Intestinal Diseases
description: Compounds called coherin were isolated from the pituitary glands of cows by Irving Goodman and Robert B. Hiatt while they were faculty members at Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons in New York. They were granted patent 4,552,764 this week for the compounds, which have been used on about 300 patients in the treatment of intestinal diseases.

title: FEDERAL REALTY INVESTMENT TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
2 CHILDREN FOUND BRUTALLY SLAIN IN A ROOMING HOUSE IN PLAINFIELD
description: An 8-year-old boy and his 7-year-old sister were found slain this morning in a rooming house here where they lived with their mother.

title: ENTERPRISE ZONES FOR NEW YORK STATE
description: Putting new economic life into New York State's chronically depressed areas is one of the greatest challenges facing us. One method of meeting that challenge is through creation of enterprise zones - a method that has proved extremely effective in reviving numerous deaying areas in 25 other states.

title: APPEAL MADE ON INFANT DEATHS
description: Medical researchers complained to a House panel Thursday that Federal money for research on sudden infant death syndrome had been cut severely, despite the 7,000 apparently healthy babies who die from it each year.

description: A former Gestapo leader high on the list of wanted Nazi war criminals has been arrested in Argentina on a special extradition warrant from West Germany, Argentine officials reported yesterday.

title: No Coffee Halt Seen
description: Coffee supplies from Colombia, the world's second-largest producer, will not be affected by Wednesday's deadly volcano eruption, coffee industry officials and growers said today. Nestor Osorio, Colombia's delegate to the International Coffee Organization in London, said the area affected by the eruption was on the other side of the mountain from the region where coffee is grown. Plantations suffered no damage and the main roads linking the coffee-producing areas to the ports were open, he said.

title: Riggs Stephenson, 87, Dies; A Leading Hitter in Baseball
description: Riggs Stephenson, who compiled a .336 batting average in 14 years in the major leagues but was never elected to the Hall of Fame, died at his home today after a long illness. He was 87 years old.

title: Smith Out 4 Weeks

description: AThe Government today detailed its evidence against 11 people, including two Roman Catholic priests, a nun and a Protestant minister, who are on trial in connection with providing sanctuary to Central Americans in this country.

description: Glenn A. Hastings, vice chairman of the board of Mattel Inc., the toy manufacturer, died of cancer yesterday in Torrance, Calif. He was 58 years old.

title: TURNER PRIZE IN ART TO HOWARD HODGKIN
description: The 1985 Turner Prize, which is awarded annually for an outstanding contribution to British art, has been awarded to Howard Hodgkin, the 53-year-old painter whose retrospective exhibition was recently seen at the Phillips Gallery in Washington, the Yale Center for British Art in New Haven and the Venice Biennale. A voluptuous colorist who is also, in his paintings, an oblique commentator on human entanglements, Hodgkin is well known in New York for his successive exhibitions at Knoedler & Company.

title: ENGINEERS ARE HELD AT FAULT IN '81 HOTEL DISASTER
description: A state judge today found the structural engineers for the Hyatt Regency Hotel guilty of ''gross negligence'' in the 1981 collapse of two suspended walkways in the hotel lobby that killed 114 people.

title: MEESE SAYTS SOME JUDGES PRACTICE 'CHAMELEON JURISPRUDENCE'
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d renewed his constitutional debate with the Supreme Court today, arguing that many judges have read the Constitution too broadly and are engaged in a form of ''chameleon jurisprudence, changing color and form in each era.''

description: H. Earl Hoover, the former chairman of the Hoover Company, the vacuum cleaner manufacturer, died Wednesday in Highland Park Hospital.Mr. Hoover, a resident of Glencoe, was 94 years old.

title: IN MIAMI, MANY WORRY FOR COLOMBIA
description: Colombian expatriates, unable to contact family and friends near the Nevada del Ruiz volcano, crowded flights to Bogota today, and others organized a collection of goods and money to help victims of the eruption on Wednesday.

description: President Reagan intends to nominate Lois Burke Shepard to be the director of the Institute of Museum Services, the White House announced Tuesday.

description: In the first elections since civilian government returned here last March, about 18 million Brazilians voted today in elections to pick the mayors of 201 cities, including all state capitals and urban centers.

description: By all accounts, the top executives at Esmark Inc. before it was bought by Beatrice last year formed a formidable management corps, remarkable both for their business success and their operating style.

A FORMER PREMIER OF CHINE
description: Dr. V. K. Wellington Koo, a Nationalist Chinese diplomat, a former Prime Minister and a signer of the United Nations Charter, died Thursday night at his home in Manhattan. Dr. Koo, whose ties to the United States date from his student days at Columbia University, was 97 years old.

title: THE JUDGES' PROTECTIVE ASSOCIATION
description: In most respects, New York's judges are working sensibly to reform the state's disgraceful conservatorship system for managing the estates of children and incompetent adults. The judges have agreed to prohibitions against nepotism. They'll accept more public accountability. They'll even agree to explain some appointments that might look funny to outsiders. But on one reform, they won't give a inch: that judges who leave the bench should wait a few years before accepting cases from their former colleagues.

St. Luke's had been there for 160 years, a solid piece of history in a city whose past is mostly a matter of old prints and photographs.

title: NIXON TRADE SOUGHT
description: Dave DeBusschere, the Knicks' director of basketball operations, has maintained for several days that the team has not ''pursued'' the free-agent guard Norm Nixon. Yet, he and other team executives have made inquiries around the league about Nixon, including calls to Jerry West, the Laker general manager, for whom Nixon once played.

title: TEXAS RANCHERS 'SHEAR' GOLD FROM ANGORA GOAT
description: With a wad of chewing tobacco in his cheek, scuffed cowboy boots and dusty pickup truck, 69-year-old James Wittenburg doesn't look much like a part of the glittery fashion world of Milan, Paris and New York. Mr. Wittenburg raises Angora goats, those shaggy animals that are veritable mohair factories.

title: MEXICANS SEEK TO SAVE MURALS IN QUAKE RUINS
description: Deep inside a hospital so seriously damaged by the September earthquakes that the building is in danger of collapse, a team of four men, experts in the restoration of art works, is working against time to remove a mural by the Mexican artist Luis Nishisawa from the walls of a stairway.

title: AMERICAN EDUCATIONAL COMUTER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a tax credit of $73,000.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 16, 1985
description: International

title: DIAGNOSTIC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: SALES OFF BY 0.5% IN SEPTEMBER
description: Business sales fell by five-tenths of 1 percent in September, while inventories climbed by two-tenths of 1 percent, the Commerce Department said today.

title: SMOKERS GET A DAY TO ABSTAIN
description: ALTOGETHER, 33 million Americans have quit smoking. If the American Cancer Society has its way, the 54 million who still smoke will join them Thursday during the ninth annual Great American Smokeout.

title: THREE NAVY FLIERS KILLED IN ALABAMA PLANE CRASH
description: Three Navy fliers were killed today when their recently overhauled twin-engine transport plane crashed shortly after takeoff on a routine test flight.

title: MUSIC: COPLAND CELEBRATION
description: Madison Square Garden, with the financial support of a local bank, is making a heartfelt effort to reconcile its own sports-and-spectacle world to the music that usually draws listeners a little farther uptown, to Carnegie Hall or Lincoln Center. The latest Arts in the Garden effort on Wednesday night seemed a happy bridge to cultural crossover, a concert of music by Aaron Copland at the Felt Forum in celebration of his 85th birthday.

title: IN THE LOST CITY OF ARMERO: THE MAIN STREET IS 'ALL GONE'
description: Benjamin Rojas stood on the roof of San Lorenzo Hospital and stared out over a vast expanse of gray mud.

title: Goalies Switch Teams
description: What was the point of the Thursday-night trade that sent the goaltender Pete Peeters from the Boston Bruins to the Washington Capitals in exchange for Pat Riggin, another goaltender? On the surface, there does not seem to be much difference between the two. Peeters, a seven-year veteran who began his career with the Philadelphia Flyers and came to Boston in June 1982, was named the league's top goalie in 1983 after compiling a 40-11-9 record with a 2.36 goals-against average.

title: ARMED MEN DELAY EVICTION OF A GEORGIA FARMER
description: Armed men vowing to block the eviction of a debt-ridden farmer ended their daylong standoff tonight when the local sheriff agreed to postpone the eviction pending a new challenge to foreclosure proceedings against the farmer.

title: MICROFRAME INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Coast Guard Searches Sound For 5 Who Left Sinking Boat
description: The Coast Guard searched the waters of Long Island Sound tonight for five people who radioed that they were abandoning their boat after it started taking on water, authorities said.

title: FLARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago results have been restated to reflect equity investment in a joint venture.

title: COMPUTERIZED BUYING NETORK reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CABARET: BOB NELOMS, PIANIST
description: Bob Neloms, who will solo on a baby grand piano through Monday at Burgundy, 467 Amsterdam Avenue, is a thoroughly up-to-date player whose strong sense of history is underlined by a solid left hand.

title: COLUMBUS NEWSPAPER SOLD
description: The Columbus Citizen-Journal, which was facing extinction Dec. 31 with the expiration of a joint operating agreement with The Columbus Dispatch, is being sold to a management consultant, the Scripps-Howard chain announced today. Lawrence Leser, president and chief executive officer of Scripps-Howard, owner of The Citizen-Journal, said the paper was being purchased by a suburban Cleveland concern that had pledged to continue publishing as a morning newspaper. Nyles Reinfeld heads the concern that is buying the paper.

title: HEADED TAX PANEL IN THE LINDSAY ERA
description: Michael Freyberg, a president of the City Tax Commission in the first administration of Mayor John V. Lindsay, died Wednesday at his home in Manhattan after recent heart surgery. He was 55 years old. Mr. Freyberg, who worked for Mr. Lindsay during his 1965 mayoral campaign, was named a member of the seven-member Tax Commission in January 1966 and sworn in as its president six months later, at the age of 35.

title: Liberals' 'Break-In' Dropped by Prosecutor
description: The case of the Liberal Party headquarters ''break-in'' ended yesterday when Mary DeBourbon, a spokesman for the Manhattan District Attorney, said there was ''no evidence to warrant any further action.''

title: Hyundai Picks Site in Quebec
description: Hyundai, the South Korean car maker, said yesterday that it had selected a site in Quebec, about 55 miles east of Montreal, for a new car assembly plant.

title: MORTGAGE BANKER SHUTS
description: A big mortgage banker with offices nationwide suddenly shut down its operations yesterday, apparently after running into serious financial problems. Shortly after, E.F. Hutton & Company, which said it had bought millions of dollars of mortgages from the mortgage banker, filed a lawsuit against it charging failure to make payments and fraud.

title: HAROLD H. PLOUGH
description: Harold H. Plough, professor emeritus of biology at Amherst College, died Tuesday at his home here.

title: REAGAN NOW OPEN TO FINAL CEREMONY
description: President Reagan is prepared to make a joint appearance with Mikhail S. Gorbachev and issue a separate statement at the conclusion of the Geneva summit conference next week if the two-day meeting yields positive results, a White House official said today.

title: CONCERT: NEW RILEY WORKS
description: The composer Terry Riley's latest efforts to bridge the music of East and West involve improvisation, a piano tuned in just intonation (using exact proportions rather than the usual well-tempered system), and collaborations with the sitar player Khrishna Bhatt. On Wednesday at Carnegie Recital Hall, they played two new duets, ''Salome Dances for Peace'' and ''Variations on Shri Camel,'' and Mr. Riley performed the hour-long piano solo ''The Harp of New Albion,'' in a radically different version than the one he played here in March.

title: BANKNORTH GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Comings and Goings
description: For the second straight game, Steve Fuller will start at quarterback for the Chicago Bears instead of Jim McMahon, who has a bruised right shoulder. The Bears said that McMahon will not play at all tomorrow against the Dallas Cowboys.

title: NEWPORT ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $75,000 for the quarter and $145,000 for the nine months.

title: Computer Tool
description: The Mylex Corporation, a Miami-based manufacturer of equipment for personal computers, received a patent this week that it regards as essential to the Text Wand it intends to manufacture. This is described as a high-resolution hand-held optical scanner that would put numerals and text directly into a microcomputer's data base without the usual keyboard. Patent 4,553,035, granted to Igor Malinsky, vice president for engineering, and two co-inventors, covers apparatus for controlling the acquisition of data with hand-held readers.

title: UNITE ARAB EMIRATES ESTABLISHING SOVIET TIES
description: The United Arab Emirates announced today that it was establishing diplomatic relations with the Soviet Union.

title: COLLEGE GAMES AT A GLANCE
description: Home teams are listed first. Season records are in parentheses.

title: LIBERIAN PRESIDENT SAYS COUP LEADER IS DEAD
description: President Samuel K. Doe of Liberia said today that one of his bodyguards had shot and killed the man who led a coup attempt this week.

title: WRENCHING WEEK FOR BACKUP GOALIE
description: Last Sunday night, the Philadelphia Flyers, bereaved and shocked, were like children lost in a deep forest. So they clustered in the home of their captain, Dave Poulin. They said hardly anything, but they were together, having recognized immediately the strength to be found in one another.

title: ARISTOTLE, DENG AND CHINA'S PEASANTS
description: Aristotle got it right.

title: SUNSHINE MINING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NORTH KOREA SUPPORTED
description: Sports ministers from 13 Soviet-bloc countries, including the Soviet Union, issued a communique in Hanoi today supporting North Korea's demand to be co-host of the 1988 Seoul Olympics and establish a joint North-South team for that event, the Kyodo News Service of Japan reported. It was the first time the Soviet-bloc countries issued a unified statement on the Seoul Olympics.

title: MISSILE COMPLEX DEDICATED
description: The Navy today dedicated a $30 million missile launching complex for the Trident 2, a powerful new submarine-launched nuclear missile. An officer here said 20 unarmed Trident 2 missiles would be fired at about 40-day intervals in tests starting in January 1987.

title: FLOCK INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $245 for the quarter and $4,097 for the 9 months. c-Net income including tax credits of $194,238 for the quarter and $1,069,842 for the 9 months.

title: CALLING ALL WOMEN
description: A major effort to help women win elective office is to be sponsored by 14 women's organizations, including the Y.W.C.A., the National Women's Education Fund, the League of Women Voters and the National Organization for Women.

title: NORRIS OIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
HAZLETON LABORATORIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $786,000. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $36,000. Year-ago results have been restated to reflect discontinued operations.

title: WEINBERGER MAINTAINS HE IS NOT UNDERCUTTING PRESIDENT ON BUDGET
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger assured top White House officials today that he was not seeking to undercut President Reagan on legislation to balance the Federal budget.

title: HOMELESS IN CAPITAL RESISTING MOVE
description: Homeless men, led by a local activist, are resisting efforts by the Reagan Administration to move them to a temporary new shelter, and today an official said the Government might respond by shutting off the old shelter's utilities.

title: UNDEFEATED PAIR FACE STERN TESTS
description: Penn State and Air Force, two of the three Division 1-A teams still undefeated and untied, face what appear to be their strongest opposition of the regular season today. The Nittany Lions will be hosts to a revived Notre Dame squad and the Falcons will visit last year's No. 1-ranked team, Brigham Young, in a game for the Western Athletic Conference championship.

title: 2 CONCORDES EVACUATED IN 2 DAYS
description: Passengers aboard two British Airways Concorde flights were evacuated down inflated chutes at Heathrow Airport near London on Thursday night and last night because of emergencies involving the landing gear, passengers and the airline reported.

title: JOSEPHSON INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a tax credit of $4,546,000 and a pretax profit of $14,325,000 from the previously announced sale of radio stations WNIC AM and FM in Dearborn-Detroit. c-After a loss of $473,000 from discontinued operations.
