BIOTECHNOLOGY DEVELOPENT reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
COMPANY BRIEFS
description: Black & Decker Corp., Towson, Md., said it plans to cease operations at its Brockport, N.Y., manufacturing facility by the end of September 1986. Officers of the corporation are negotiating the possible sale of the facility to its local management.

title: CURTAINS FOR THE EMPIRE
description: Crossing Fifth Avenue at 42d Street the other day, I ws saddened to discover that the Empire State Building was gone.

title: Marshal Pokryshkin; Soviet Air Ace in War
description: Marshal Aleksandr I. Pokryshkin, a Soviet flying ace who is credited with having shot down 59 German planes in World War II, has died at the age of 72, it was announced in Moscow.

title: ANGELES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including an extraordinary tax credit of $321,000. c-Net loss.

title: WALKER TELECOMMUNICAIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MAHRES SAY SKIING PAID THEM WELL
description: The perception persists that ski racers don't make much money -that they are poor relatives in the world of athletes. Phil and Steve Mahre, the twins who captured a mound of trophies before retiring at the end of last season, are now talking about the mounds of dollars they took home for their victories on skis.

title: AMBULATORY MEDICAL CARE reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PANEL APPROVES NOMINATION OF BUCKLEY TO APPEALS COURT
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee has unanimously approved the nomination of James L. Buckley, a former Republican Senator from New York, as a judge on the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia.

description: IJust before the Geneva summit meeting, Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger has sent President Reagan a letter urging him not to make any agreements involving two key aspects of arms control.

description: The Economy

title: DEALS IN EDWARDS TRIAL TERMED PURE BUSINESS
description: A business arrangement that Federal prosecutors call an illegal conspiracy was portrayed today as business as usual by defense attorneys as they began presenting their case in the fraud trial of Gov. Edwin Edwards.

title: Mets Fill Farm Posts
description: The Mets filled the managerial slots of their top two farm clubs yesterday, naming Sam Perlozzo manager at Tidewater of the Class AAA International League and the former major league infielder Mike Cubbage manager at Jackson of the Class AA Texas League. The Mets also announced that the former major league pitcher Glenn Abbott had been named pitching coach at Jackson.

title: INVESTMENT TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company was in a development stage and had no significant income in the year-ago thirs quarter.

title: 11.1% PROPERTY-TAX RISE IS URGED IN WESTCHESTER
description: County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke submitted a proposed 1986 budget of $721.2 million today, carrying an increase of 11.1 percent in the Westchester County property-tax rate.

title: NOBEL ALUMNI
description: To the Editor:

title: MOSCOW TELLS U.S. IT WILL ALLOW SPOUSES OF AMERICANS TO LEAVE
description: The Soviet Union, apparently in a gesture in advance of the summit meeting next week, today told the United States that it would give exit visas to some American citizens' spouses who for years have been denied permission to leave, State Department officials said today.

title: GIANT GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net losses.

title: EAST VILLAGE FOOD: TRADITION AND CHANGE
description: Across the street from the schmaltz herring store, they sell raspberry apple cider. Next door to the herb teas and unsulfured dried fruits, sfoglietelle and cannoli are dispensed just as they have been since 1904.

title: FINAL ARGUMENTS HEARD IN WEYERHAEUSER TRIAL
description: The eruption of Mount St. Helens on May 18, 1980, may have been an ''act of God,'' but the negligence of the Weyerhaeuser Company toward its workers made their deaths in the volcano ''an act of man,'' a lawyer said Thursday in closing trial arguments.

title: LONDON HOUSE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Adviser on Esthetics
description: State Senator Roy M. Goodman, Republican of Manhattan, who has been eager to be offered a Reagan Administration post at the Cabinet level, has settled for a lesser White House appointment - membership on the National Commission of Fine Arts.

title: CITING A LACK OF FUNDS, HOLTZMAN SAYS SHE WON't RUN FOR SENATE IN 1986
description: District Attorney Elizabeth Holtzman of Brooklyn announced yesterday that she would not seek the Democratic nomination for the United States Senate next year, saying it would be difficult to raise enough money to challenge Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about the Control Data Corporation's planned sale of a part of its business to the Xidex Corporation incorrectly described the operation being sold. The sale involves only the business products group of the company's Peripheral Products subsidiary.

description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $400,000.

title: U.S. SECURITIES UP MODESTLY
description: Despite a severe credit tightening caused by heavy Government borrowings yesterday, prices of Treasury securities rebounded in late trading to close moderately higher. The best gains were in the intermediate maturities.

title: GENETIC DIAGNOSTICS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Philolexian Revival
description: After 23 years, the Philolexian Society of Columbia University is making a comeback. The mission of Philolexian - from the Latin for ''lover of words'' - according to its recently unearthed 1899 constitution, is ''to improve its members in oratory, composition and forensic discussion.''

title: HOW EUROPEAN ALLIES VIEW THE SUMMIT: THE HOPE IS FOR REGULAR MEETINGS
description: After intensive consultations with the Reagan Administration, the Western European allies are awaiting the summit meeting here with only modest expectations for concrete results but with hopes for an atmospheric improvement in East-West relations.

title: CAREFUL LISTENING IS HELPFUL WHEN A DUCK IS AT THE TABLE
description: Whether they are lurking in a lake or in a deck of cards, ducks can be difficult to spot. Others, however, betray their presence by loud quacking, and an example occurred in the diagramed deal. It was played in the 1985 Epson Inter-City tournament in Tokyo in a match between one of the Tokyo teams and a Taipei team.

title: CARVER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
A TRUE CONFESSION: HOW I BECAME UNBUTTONED
description: When I was 10 years old and for some reason in need of my first suit, my father took me to Brooks Brothers. We selected a three-piece gray flannel. In the next 23 years, virtually everything I wore, from shoes to sunglasses, came from Brooks Brothers. I am perhaps the only American who in the last 20 years never considered wearing blue jeans. Brooks doesn't sell them.

title: DAWKINS EJECTED IN 110-98 LOSS
description: With 7 minutes 27 seconds to play, the Nets were making a comeback against the Mavericks. Then a fight broke out between Darryl Dawkins, the 6-foot-11-inch New Jersey center, and Wallace Bryant, the Mavericks' 7-foot center. When the fight ended, the Nets lost Dawkins - and their momentum. Ultimately, they lost the game, 110-98.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 17. 1. The portrait of the Princess was created with 10,000 jellybeans. 2. The collapse of Israel's national unity Cabinet was averted when Prime Minister Shimon Peres withdrew his threat to dismiss Ariel Sharon, the Minister of Industry and Commerce, after Mr. Sharon added ''clarifications'' to an apology for accusatiions he had made against Mr. Peres. 3. Homeless people will be removed from the streets on freezing nights this winter and taken to shelters or hospitals, whether or not they are willing to go. 4. Observers can find Halley's comet on clear, dark nights about 9 P.M. by aiming their binoculars at the Pleiades, a prominent cluster of stars high above the eastern horizon. 5. Police Commissioner Gregore J. Sambore, who directed the bombing from a helicopter of the group's headquarters, resigned. 6. Employing his brash strategy, Gary Kasparov succeeded in wresting the world chess championship from Anatoly Karpov. 7. Many airlines are offering steep discount fares to encourage travel on Thanksgiving weekend. 8. Bret Saberhagen of the Kansas City Royals, 21 years old, won the Cy Young Award as best pitcher in the American League, and Dwight Gooden of the Mets, three days short of his 21st birthday, became the youngest pitcher to win the Cy Young Award. 9. The eruption of the Nevada del Ruiz volcano in northern Colombia caused a devastatingly fast and huge avalanche of mud, known by the geological term lahar. 10.

title: DOW DROPS BY 4.13 IN HEAVY TRADING
description: Profit taking set the stock market back moderately yesterday, but trading remained heavy as the Dow Jones industrial average finished the week with its second 30-point gain of the month.

title: SCIENTIFIC SYSTEMS SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: SHCUMAN AWARD GOET TO DAVID DIAMOND
description: David Diamond, the 70-year-old American composer, has been named winner of Columbia University's William Schuman Award.

title: MOTHER'S LETTER GETS HIGH-LEVEL RESPONSE
description: Amy Stevenson missed President Reagan's address to the nation Thursday night because she was bathing her three children - until her brother called to say the President was talking about her.

title: ASHOULD FARMERS BEAR SHARE OF BUDGET CUTS?
description: Of all the legislation facing Congress this year, none better captures the conflict between fiscal and social pressures than the new farm law that Congress hopes to pass by Christmas.

title: WEINBERGER LETTER TO REAGAN ON ARMS CONTROL
description: Following is the text of a letter from Secretary of Defense Caspar W. title: AMERICAN MIDLAND CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $41,000 for the quarter and $353,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss.

title: RENOVATION TAX AID FACES CUT
description: The House Ways and Means Committee voted today to limit the tax credits that can be claimed by investors in projects to rehabilitate old buildings, but the panel rejected President Reagan's proposal to disallow the credits altogether.

title: SHOPS FIND MORE ABUSE OF RENTED VIEOTAPES
description: The reasons differ, but the result is the same. A video cassette recorder is sent off to the repair shop with a rented tape inside. A customer, on his way to the airport for a three-week vacation, intends to stop at the video rental store to return the tape, but forgets. A VCR, not properly cleaned by its owner, scratches and ruins a rented tape. A movie buff, wanting a high-quality tape for his collection, duplicates a rented movie and returns the copy to the store.

title: Journalism Society Names 3 To Receive Its Highest Honor
description: Three American journalists were named today as Fellows of the Society, the highest honor given by the Society of Professional Journalists, Sigma Delta Chi.

title: A CREATIV BID FOR ULSTER PEACE
description: At first reading, the agreement by Britain and Ireland to share responsibilities in Northern Ireland was worth the long wait. It seems to offer an ingenious way around the obstacle of sovereignty in Ulster - b passing around it. The deal offers a chance at peace if the exhausted antagonists can finally rise to self-interest.

title: AIDS Evidence Found In Former Sperm Donor
description: A man who donated sperm used to inseminate 19 women was later found to have antibodies associated with the incurable disease AIDS in his blood, according to Pennsylvania Hospital.

title: BALLY OFFER FOR MGM HOTELS SEEN
description: The Bally Manufacturing Corporation is in talks to acquire MGM Grand Hotels Inc., sources familiar with the negotiations said yesterday.

title: THE SCREEN: 'RAINBOW BRITE'
description: ''Rainbow Brite and the Star Stealer'' isn't a movie; it's a marketing tool. Presented by Hallmark Properties to sell a line of Hallmark products, it tells of a snub-nosed, big-eyed girl named Rainbow Brite and her efforts to bring joy and color to the universe.

title: DAXOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a net realized gain of $681,328 for the quarter and a net realized loss of $667,848 for the 9 months on marketable securities. c-Including a net realized gain of $563,739 on marketable securities.

title: BIRDSBORO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including equity in loss from discontinued operations of an affiliate of $132,000 for the quarter and 9 months.

title: Beecham May Seek Norcliff Thayer
description: The Beecham Group P.L.C., the British household-products and health-care concern, said today that it was discussing the possible acquisition of Norcliff Thayer from Pantry Pride Inc. Norcliff Thayer makes health aids and over-the-counter medications and is a unit of Revlon Inc., which Pantry Pride acquired earlier this month for $1.83 billion.

title: New Rights Panel Chief Due
description: The White House has announced that President Reagan was planning to appoint Joseph Al Latham Jr., chief counsel of the National Labor Relations Board, as staff director of the Civil Rights Commission, succeeding Linda Chavez. Miss Chavez was appointed in April as director of the White House office of public liaison.

title: PICKING BEST HORSE A PUZZLE
description: What a pity that old John Henry is sauntering around a retirement paddock at the Kentucky Horse Park these days. If the 10-year-old gelding could have just made it to the gate for a couple of grass races again this year, he probably could have been voted the horse-of-the-year title one more time. He didn't deserve it last year, when he nosed out Slew o' Gold for the honor, but this year he would have had to accomplish even less. In a year of outstanding horse racing, there was no bona fide horse of the year.

title: BARRIER SCIENCE & TECH reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
WHERE CHEESE STEAKS ARE KING, ONE FAMILY HAS ASSUMED THE CROWN
description: On a little triangle of concrete at Ninth and Passyunk in South Philadelphia -''Rocky'' country - is a sidewalk eatery called Pat's King of Steaks.

title: ARISTEK COMMUNITIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Cosmos Alumni
description: In the halcyon days, the Cosmos' roster was a Who's Who of world-class soccer. Then came Cabanas and Romero. Who? And who?

title: Control Data Omitting Dividend
description: The Control Data Corporation, which said recently that it was losing ''woeful amounts of money'' on some business, said today that it was omitting a fourth-quarter dividend to stockholders.

title: WHO WANTS THIS KING OF TAX REFORM?
description: To the Editor:

title: O.E.C.D. TAX CUT BID
description: Warning that the world could return to economic ''stagnation'' next year, senior Western economic policy officials appealed today to a number of major countries to reduce taxes in an effort to strengthen investment and increase growth.

title: JETS DEFEAT DEVILS, HALT 4-GAME SLIDE
description: Laurie Boschman scored one goal and assisted on another, and Robert Picard scored early in the third period tonight to help the Jets to a 5-3 victory over the Devils. It was Winnipeg's first victory in five games.

title: Deere Plans Cuts
description: Deere & Company said it will lay off about 350 employees and shut down its combine factory in East Moline, Ill., for 42 production days in January and February. Deere said in a statement that it was lowering production schedules for tractors and combines because sales of farm equipment during the fall selling season have been disappointing and were significantly lower than last year.

title: Board Says Molinari Is Victor in S.I. Race
description: Susan Molinari, a Republican City Council candidate on Staten Island, won a final ballot count and defeated her Democratic opponent, a spokesman for the City Board of Elections said yesterday.

title: AQUANAUTICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $46,229.

title: SATIRIC TOUCH
description: FOXYBABY. By Elizabeth Jolley. 261 pages. Viking. $14.95. How, wonders the heroine of ''Foxybaby,'' has she got herself in such a ridiculous predicament? Here she is, Miss Alma Porch, novelist and lecturer, stuck in some Godforsaken little town in the middle of nowhere in Australia, trying to teach drama to a bunch of unhappy women, who are more intent on shedding a couple of pounds than thinking about art. Can she really use them as a sounding board for her latest work of fiction? Can she inspire them to create something vaguely artistic themselves? Can she find, here, a respite from her own boring life at home? Or failing all that, can she simply get through the semester without going mad?

title: A PROTEST ERUPTS OUTSIDE HEARING ON AN AIDS BILL
description: The frustration of many homosexuals over what they say is growing discrimination and hysteria generated by the fear of AIDS erupted at City Hall yesterday - at a demonstration outside and a hearing inside.

title: Buttes Chapter 11
description: The Buttes Gas and Oil Company said that it had filed for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code.

title: 'WE NEED PEOPLE'
description: Rescue workers struggled today with the immense task of saving survivors and recovering thousands of bodies from the sea of mud that destroyed this town and severely damaged 13 communities after the eruption Wednesday of a long-dormant volcano.

title: NBC PLANS A MOVE FROM RCA BUILDING
description: The National Broadcasting Company is planning to move its headquarters from the RCA Building, which it has occupied for more than a half century, company and city officials said yesterday.

title: HUMAN RIGHTS COURT RULES AGAINST COSTA RICA
description: The seven-member Inter-American Human Rights Court has ruled that laws requiring the obligatory licensing of journalists violate a fundamental right to free expression.

title: BOMB IN COLOMBIA DAMAGES OFFICES OF COMMUNIST PARTY
description: A bomb seriously damaged the national headquarters of the Colombian Communist Party today, but no one was wounded, the police said.

title: SUSPECT HELD IN ILLINOIS IN RAIL AMBUSH INCIDENT
description: Railroad track supervisors checking an apparent attempted train derailment were ambushed by an unidentified man who shot arrows at them, officials said today. No injuries were reported.

title: DEWEY ELECYRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: A SOVIET PUBLICITY DRIVE IN GENEVA
description: At the Inter-Continental Hotel, where the American briefings will be held, workers were busy today laying cable for the press briefing room. At the International Conference Center, the Russians were busy making news.

title: TONY LAMA CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: TH ULSTER PACT: BIG HOPES, BIG RISKS
description: The agreement between the British and Irish Governments to give Dublin a voice in the affairs of Northern Ireland is both risky and fragile.

title: EX-F.B.I. AGENT SENTENCED
description: Dan Mitrione Jr., a former agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation who called himself a ''double agent'' in the war on drugs, was sentenced Thursday to 10 years in prison for taking $850,000 in bribes and stealing about 85 pound of cocaine from a drug shipment. Mr. Mitrione, 38 years old, had been an agent for 11 years when he resigned in 1983.

title: MCM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including net realized investment gains of $81,000 for the quarter and $1,114,000 for the 9 months. c-After a net realized investment loss of $68,000. d-Net income including a net realized investment gain of $209,000.

title: KOSS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: JACKSON WARNS TEEN-AGERS TO AVOID DRUGS
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson yesterday took his revivalist anti-drug presentation to Martin Luther King Jr. High School, where a predominantly black student body and a determined new principal seemed bouyed by the message of pride and discipline.

title: FOSTER CARE IS A SERVICE OF CRUCIAL IMPORTANCE
description: To the Editor:

title: Article 163284 -- No Title
description: Stephen A. Wynn, chairman and president of Golden Nugget Inc., said he had offered to buy the Dunes Hotel and Country Club in Las Vegas, Nev., for $115 million. The Dunes resort, whose managing company filed for protection under Chapter 11 of Federal bankruptcy laws last week, covers 116 acres on the so-called Strip in Las Vegas and includes a 1,200-room hotel, a casino, golf course, tennis courts and recreation facilities.

title: NOBEL ALUMNI
description: To the Editor:

title: SMALL BUSINESS FINDS A FRIEND ON TAX PANEL
description: Time and again over the last month, members of the House Ways and Means Committee have demonstrated a soft spot for small business.

title: Ivy Streaks
description: Columbia's victory over Cornell on Thursday gave the Lions their eighth straight Ivy League soccer championship. Here are the longest streaks of outright or shared sports titles, with the seasons they began, since the league was formally established 30 years ago: Cornell, gymnastics10 (1967-68) Cornell, lacrosse10 (1974) Columbia, fencing9 (1959-60) Columbia, soccer8 (1978) Penn, fencing8 (1975-76) Cornell, hockey7 (1966-67) Harvard, crew7 (1964) Harvard, squash racquets7 (1961-62) Harvard, swimming7 (1977-78) Penn, outdoor track7 (1971) Princeton, lacrosse7 (1957)

title: Armistead I. Selden Jr. Dies Ex-Congressman of Alabama
description: Armistead I. Selden Jr., a former Congressman, Defense Department official and Ambassador, died of cancer Thursday at the Veterans Administration Hospital here. He was 64 years old.

title: SCHOOLS STUDYING AIDS RULES
description: IN THE wake of the death of a Long Island schoolteacher with AIDS, local school districts are trying to come up with procedures for handling teachers or students who might be diagnosed as having the illness.

title: ROMANTICS WHO LURK IN THE SHADOWS OF OBSCURITY
description: The dimmer lights of 19th-century music have always had a certain attraction.

title: FILM SERIES/JAZZ
description: An exhibition made up of screenings of 20 two-hour programs culled from more than three decades of jazz on television has just started at the Museum of Broadcasting, 1 East 53 Street, and will continue there every week, Tuesday through Saturday, to the end of January. It includes programs devoted to Duke Ellington, Benny Goodman and Louis Armstrong, selections from such TV series as the Timex Jazz Shows, Ralph Gleason's ''Jazz Casual,'' ''Camera Three,'' ''Dial M for Music,'' foreign television featuring John Coltrane and Charles Mingus, and the most widely praised jazz program producer on television, ''The Sound of Jazz.''

title: TopicsA WOMAN'S PLACE;   THE STEPFORD WOMEN
description: Commuters in Westport, Conn., were greeted at the station the other morning by two impeccably coiffed women promoting a new service. They will shop and run errands on weekdays for harried working couples who are willing to pay an additional 15 percent to avoid having to do the shopping themselves come Saturday.

title: THE KEY TO TEACHING IS CREATIVITY
description: HAVING taught for 15 years, I have seen many changes in our schools. Although techniques, methods and even curriculums have changed, throughout it all one constant has remained: the children.

title: HOUSE UNIT NEARS FINISH ON TAX BILL
description: The House Ways and Means Committee, approaching the final stage of its six-month struggle to write tax-revision legislation, took steps today to limit the ability of American companies to shelter their overseas profits from United States taxes.

title: Olympic Chief Optimistic
description: After attending a meeting of sports ministers from 13 Soviet-bloc nations, Juan Samaranch, the president of the International Olympic Committee, described today the Olympic movement as ''very united'' and predicted ''some very successful'' Summer Games in Seoul in 1988.

title: NEW ISRAELI COINS
description: Israel has issued two new silver coins that continue one coinage series and end another. The coins commemorate Hanukkah continuing a series that dates back more than two decades. They also are the last two coins to bear sheqel denominations. Henceforth, all Israeli coins will be valued in accordance with the recently adopted new sheqel system.

title: INTERNATIONAL WON BY VANLANDINGHAM
description: Vanlandingham, making his grass debut in what could have been the last start of his career, led every step of the way to score a one-length victory today in the $400,000 Washington D.C. International at Laurel Race Course.

title: SKATING RINK OPENS
description: The Lasker Memorial Rink in Central Park, near 110th Street and Lenox Avenue, is now open for ice skating. The rink will open at 11 A.M. each day and will close at 10 P.M. on Fridays and at 9 P.M. on other nights. Information: 397-3142.

title: WHY NOT COMPUTERIZE VOTING?
description: IT'S A logical progression. We can register to vote by mail and we can obtain and submit absentee ballots by mail. The next step to accommodate the electorate and insure maximum participation should be casting the ballot by mail.

title: CHILD-ABUSE REPORTING REQUIRED UNDER LAW
description: In an Oct. 13 article on child abuse, Dr. Seymour Kuvin, a psychiatrist, was reported as saying that ''a person who suspected that abuse was occurring should not necessarily first talk to the state authorities.''

title: IOWA WINS, 27-24 ON LATE FIELD GOAL
description: Rob Houghtlin made a 25-yard field goal with 68 seconds to play today to give Iowa a 27-24 victory over Purdue in a Big Ten Conferencegame. Iowa, 9-1 over all and 6-1 in the Big Ten, moved into first place because of Wisconsin's 12-7 upset over Ohio State. Purdue fell to 4-6 and 2-5.

title: RECENT RELEASES
description: Strindberg's 'Miss Julie' Starring Helen Mirren and Donal McCann; directed by Robin Phillips and John Gleniston, 1971 MasterVision 105 minutes. $74.95 The turbulent currents of Strindberg's ''Miss Julie'' are amply conveyed in this 1971 Royal Shakespeare Company production, directed on stage by Robin Phillips.

title: Developing An 'Ethical' Portfolio
description: THREE years ago, Howard and Manya Shapiro decided they wanted to put their money where their ethics were. But they had trouble finding professional advice.

title: FLAMES TRIUMPH OVER DEVILS BY 7-2
description: The rookie center Joel Otto assisted on three goals in the second period tonight to tie a tem record and help the Calgary Flames defett the Devils, 7-2.

title: HOW TO STOP SMOKING AND NOT LOSE YOUR SANITY OR FRIENDS
description: WE DID IT! After 22-plus years, my husband and I finally gave up cigarette smoking. Not just like that, of course. We spent many months talking about it, agonizing over it and planning it.

title: Cincinnati Center Is Named For Polio Vaccine Developer
description: This city now has an Albert B. Sabin Convention and Exposition Center as well as a downtown street named Pete Rose Way.

title: HOBOKEN GETS A NEW THEATER
description: STARTING a theater is a risky business, but there's no stopping the stagestruck.

title: DENVERITES ASKED TO DRIVE LESS IN CAMPAIGN FOR CLEANER AIR
description: The city is moving into the second year of a campaign to reduce driving in an effort to cut air pollution and perhaps avert the loss of millions of dollars in Federal funds.

title: IN GREENHOUSES, THE MOOD IS SPRING
description: SPRING can seem to be just around the bend to a visitor to one of the state's greenhouses. From Greenwich to Hartford, they abound - glass cages warmed with humid air and bright with tropical foliage. And each has a personality of its own.

title: DEBRA SUE WASSER ENGAGED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Bernard D. Wasser of Rockaway, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Debra Sue Wasser, to Henry Morris Rosen, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Leon Rosen of Livingston, N.J. Miss Wasser is a merchandise statistics analyst at Gimbels East in New York.

title: WELCH, GIANTS' LAST PICK, IS PERSISTENT
description: When the Giants chose Herb Welch last April in the 12th and final round of the National Football League draft, the U.C.L.A. cornerback had no illusions.

title: DEPARTURE OF STARS DIMS R.P.I.'S CHANCES
description: Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, the defending National Collegiate Athletic Association hockey champion, has an unbeaten streak that reached 37 games after it beat St. Lawrence Friday night. Still, Coach Mike Addesa says, ''We're a shadow of our former selves.''

title: NEWFOUNDLANDERS INSIST CANADA OWES THEM MORE
description: When it comes to setting records, the province of Newfoundland and Labrador can claim some that it would rather do without. Newfoundland has the highest unemployment rate in Canada, the highest income and sales taxes, and one of the lowest per capita incomes.

title: Classes for Gifted: Another Response
description: Since Patricia Corley has chosen to single out my letter regarding separate classes for gifted chidren [Letters to the Long Island Editor, Oct. 20] , I would like the opportunity to refute her statements.

title: POLICE CENTENNIAL
description: When the New Rochelle Police Department was founded 100 years ago, the officers' principal duties were to prevent hogs and cattle from running wild in the streets. Today, the 180-man force is considerably more sophisticated, but the past has not been forgotten: Two days of festivities are planned for next weekend to celebrate the police department's centennial birthday.

title: RECITAL: PINCHAS ZUKERMAN
description: A FAIRLY large audience gathered in Avery Fisher Hall Friday to hear Pinchas Zukerman play sonatas by Bach, Brahms and Strauss. If at this point in his stellar career there is no need to describe Mr. Zukerman's technical mastery, that is in part a comment on the superlative standard it sets - but also in part a reflection of the violinist's failure, at times, to excite one anew over the command he has achieved.

title: Insurance Packaged For Investors
description: MARRYING such traditional benefits of an insurance policy as low-interest loans and tax-deferred income with the possibility of a high return from investments can create an enticing package, and the more creative arrangements now being marketed demonstrate how much insurance has changed.

title: HOW TO PHOTOGRAPH SPORTS ACTION
description: ALTHOUGH they fall short of physical contact, sports photographers are as competitive on the sidelines as the uniformed players on the field, the ice and the court.

title: High-Risk 'Pennies' For the Bold
description: AFICIONADOS compare the ''penny stock market'' with playing a slot machine: Your quarters may get eaten up one after another, but if you hit the jackpot, the rewards are sweet. Whether you come out ahead reflects both your luck and your discipline in knowing when to stop.

title: Oakland Loses Appeal For Return of Raiders
description: A state appeals court has rejected the City of Oakland's attempt to move the Raiders back from Los Angeles, saying it would place an unconstitutional burden on interstate commerce.

title: Space Defense
description: To the Editor:

title: NANCY BROADBENT ENGAGED TO WED D. J. A. CASSERLEY
description: Peter Edwin Broadbent of Richmond has announced the engagement of his daughter, Nancy Talbot Broadbent, to Dominic James Andrew Casserley, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Christopher Casserley of London. The wedding is planned for April 5.

title: BULLET PRIVACY
description: PROSECUTORS in Richmond wanted to force a suspect in an armed-robbery case to undergo surgery so they could remove a bullet lodged under a collarbone and use the slug as evidence against him. The United States Supreme Court said no.

title: A STARK THRILLER FROM STRINDBERG
description: AUGUST Strindberg, one of Sweden's greatest authors, was also one of the world's most famous misogynists. His earlier plays - compared with his later, more symbolic writing -were bitter, realistic dramas that analyzed the basic corruption of human nature, especially that of women.

title: HANDS-ON EXPERIENCE IN HANDLING OF CHILDREN
description: EVER since Herricks Senior High School opened for the fall term, Margaret Considine, like a dedicated drill sergeant, had been putting the young women of her Child Study Lab through very specialized basic training.

title: ANOTHER REEF WINS VOSBURGH
description: Thomas K. Leachman's Another Reef tore through Aqueduct's gloom and sloppy going yesterday and posted an upset victory in the $170,700 Vosburgh Stakes for 3-year-olds and up.

title: RADON MAY ENDANGER 8 MILLION HOMES
description: A construction worker knelt in front of a flower bed at the home of Linda Rogers in Glen Ridge, N.J., earlier this fall, carefully replanting a row of tulips, first red, then yellow, another red, another yellow. He was finishing restoration work on a project begun last summer, when a crew dug up and hauled away Mrs. Rogers's driveway, front yard, garage and even the foundation of her house. The soil they removed packed enough drums to fill three 35-car freight trains.

title: Left Stranded By the L.I.R.R.
description: This time it wasn't Hurricane Gloria that stranded the Hampton passengers on the Long Island Rail Road trip to Montauk, on the 12:32 P.M. train on Oct. 25. This train was halted in Speonk, a ghost-town station, about 50 miles from its ultimate destination, and the passengers were invited to leave and wait for buses to continue their trip.

title: A PHILADELPHIA FORUM FOR CAUSES ASKS AID
description: The Church of the Advocate, a meeting place for hundreds of social activists since the 1950's, has been designated by the city's chapter of the American Institute of Architects as one of the most significant pieces of architecture in the city.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: DANCE AND POETRY

title: ELLINGTON: UNFAILINGLY MODERN
description: When a broad sampling of the nation's jazz critics was asked in a recent poll to name the most important jazz albums made since the beginning of the 1960's, almost all the lists included key works by Sonny Rollins, Miles Davis, John Coltrane, Ornette Coleman and other musicians widely recognized as the period's innovators. But one critic, Stanley Dance, who spent a substantial portion of his career chronicling the activities of Duke Ellington and his orchestra, practically on a day-by-day basis, submitted a list consisting entirely of Ellington albums, all made since the beginning of the 60's and each, in one way or another, a classic.

title: MUSIC: BROOKLYN GROUP
description: THE pieces at each end of the Brooklyn Philharmonic's program Friday night emanated each from its very different place. Hindemith's ''Philharmonisches Konzert'' from 1932 - which we are told had its New York premiere at this Brooklyn Academey of Music event - began with the listener in mind.

title: BIG NEWS IN SOVIET: 5-YEAR PLAN, NOT THE SUMMMIT
description: In the final days before Mikhail S. Gorbachev and President Reagan meet, the prospects for growth in the Soviet economy have received more attention here than the outlook for the summit meeting.

title: HE RESISTED EVERYTHING EXCEPT TEMPTATION
description: MORE LETTERS OF OSCAR WILDE Edited by Rupert Hart-Davis. 215 pp. New York: The Vanguard Press. $14.95. LORD ALFRED DOUGLAS By H. Montgomery Hyde. Illustrated. 366 pp. New York: Dodd, Mead & Company. $19.95.

title: SAVINGS RATE
description: To the Editor:

title: Plotting Year-End Tax Moves
description: BRUCE SCHARF, a New York lawyer, will be spending some time between now and the end of the year planning ways to save on taxes. He is thinking about switching from a taxable money market fund to one that invests in tax-free municipal bonds, establishing a Clifford Trust in which the earned income will be taxed at his children's lower rate and deferring his bonus until next year, when rates may be lower if the tax laws are changed.

title: SHOREHAM AND RATES: WHAT IS THE TRUE COST?
description: THE Long Island Lighting Company and the State Consumer Protection Board have come up with totally different estimates of what the Shoreham nuclear plant would cost consumers.

title: ARMY MOVES TO TOUGHEN ITS STANDARDS FOR PHYSICAL FITNESS
description: The Army, convinced that too many of its soldiers are passing physical fitness tests without regularly exercising, has decided to toughen the tests.

title: COLONIAL TOMBSTONES, AFTER WEATHERING THE CENTURIES, SUCCUMB TO THIEVES
description: A cold wind blew through the stands of pines enclosing Palmertown Cemetery. From a distant field, the lowing of a cow could be heard.

title: COLLEGES USING MORE ADJUNCTS
description: FIVE days a week he is an accountant, a journalist, perhaps an advertising copy writer. But for a few hours a week he changes hats and becomes a college instructor, teaching others what he has learned in his profession.

title: LOOKING AHEAD TO A MOMENTOUS ENCOUNTER
description: PRESIDENT Reagan flew to Geneva yesterday for what he called ''a mission of peace,'' his first meeting with Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader. As the first Soviet-American summit meeting in more than six years approached, each side sought to position itself in the most favorable light.

title: CHINESE HIBISCUS IS EASY TO GROW - JUST FOLLOW THE RULES
description: Once my plants are indoors for the winter and settled in their appropriate locations, my thoughts usually turn to acquiring new ones. Like most indoor gardeners, I search for plants that satisfy three criteria: easy to grow, but worth the effort; months of bloom, and long life. To me nothing is more challenging than mastering the secrets of cultivating a special species followed by the thrill of success. And all of this must be done without the benefit of a greenhouse.

title: Flooding Threat Seen
description: High water levels in the upper Great Lakes region may lead to severe flood and erosion damage this winter, according to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration.

title: WATCHING LUDLAM STUMBLE AND OSBORN FALL FLAT
description: One would have thought that Charles Ludlam could be counted on to brighten a doleful week of theater. Such, unfortunately, is not the case. In his newest creation for the Ridiculous Theatrical Company, he has flummoxed Flaubert and outwitted himself with his send-up of the novel, ''Salammbo.'' Having demonstrated in dozens of Ludlamized spoofs from ''Bluebeard'' to last season's ''Mystery of Irma Vep'' that he can carry ridicule to heights of hilarity, he now reminds us of what seemed to be a dormant streak of self-indulgence. Mr. Ludlam's ''Salammbo,'' which rhymes with ''Rambo,'' is as muscle-bound as its cast of characters. The show's single - and not saving - grace is the star's own performance in the title role.

title: AIR CONTROL STRIKE IN SPAIN
description: Spanish air-traffic controllers voted today to stage a 48-hour strike starting Monday after talks with the Government failed to produce an agreement on their wage demands, union officials said.

title: SIDNEY ANDERSON, GEOFFREY KENYON, TOMARRY JAN. 11
description: Sidney Walt Anderson, a research account executive for Young & Rubicam in New York, and Geoffrey Robert Thornton Kenyon, an associate in the Boston law firm of Goodwin, Procter & Hoar, plan to be married Jan. 11.

title: HEALY LEADS ARMY TO A 49-7 TRIUMPH
description: For the second straight week, it almost snowed on Army's parade toward a second straight bowl bid today. But a timely suggestion by a reserve tight end, Charlie Moses, helped the Cadets adjust to the weather and go on to a 49-7 victory over Memphis State. The victory had to impress the crowd of 10,158 in Michie Stadium as well as the representative from the Peach Bowl who was on hand.

title: SUSAN HEILBORN TO WED A. A. GOLDMAN
description: Announcement has been made by Fritzie Heilbron of New York of the engagement of her daughter Susan M. Heilbron to Andrew A. Goldman, the son of Jane Adler Goldman of Rochester, Sun City, Ariz., and Menemsha, Mass., and the late Manuel D. Goldman.

title: A LITTLE EFFORT FOR WINTER PROTECTION
description: IT will soon be time to wind up the outdoor gardening season, but there are still a number of important last-minute tasks that may need to be done.

title: MODERNISM: SMOTHERED BY ITS FRIENDS
description: THE REVENGE OF THE PHILISTINES Art and Culture, 1972-1984. By Hilton Kramer. 445 pp. New York: The Free Press. $25.

title: JORDAN SETS OFF DIPLOMATIC MOVES
description: A swift and somewhat bewildering set of Arab diplomatic moves has been under way in the last few days, apparently in efforts to further King Hussein's goal of an international conference on Middle East peace.

title: DATA BANK November 17, 1985

title: A New Attack On Alcoholism
description: It was encouraging to read that more and more people are regarding alcoholism as a disease whose behavioral aspects are often the result of biochemical complications rather than weak wills or deep-seated psychoses (''A New Attack on Alcoholism,'' by Lucinda Franks, Oct. 20). However, two things must be pointed out about alcoholism.

title: BEAUTY AWARDS
description: IF a thing of beauty is a joy forever, what are 10 things of beauty? Winners of the county's first Beautification Committee awards, selected from more than 50 projects submitted by various community organizations, municipal agencies and commercial businesses. The awards program was sponsored by a 13-member Beautification Committee named last year by County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke.

title: MARCOS MOVES TOWARD A VOTE
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos and those eager to unseat him after 20 years of nearly absolute power over the Philippines edged toward agreement last week on an election early next year, though not quite so early as Mr. Marcos had sought.

title: How to Judge Summit XIV
description: How do you judge a summit?

title: BAR GROUP REFECTS PLEA FROM ANTIOCH LAW SCHOOL
description: The American Bar Association's legal education committee has recommended withdrawing the association's accreditation from the Antioch Law School, which it said had not increased faculty salaries or improved library and classroom facilities. The move adds new uncertainty to last-ditch efforts to rescue the school from bankruptcy.

title: The Uninvited Guests
description: Willy Brandt, the former Chancellor of West Germany, was in Washington the other day and made a speech that President Reagan and Mr. Gorbachev might find useful reading before they meet in Geneva. It would take only five minutes.

title: Funeral Held for 2 Girls Killed in Radical House
description: The family of two teen-agers believed to have died in the May 13 confrontation between the police and the radical group Move held a funeral even though the city has not released their bodies.

title: 'APOLLO' - A BALLET OF ETERNAL YOUTH
description: The title role of ''Apollo'' comes with heavy baggage: first, the ballet's immense historic prestige, and, then, the fame of the handful of dancers who, in their different ways and at different times, earned the right to call it theirs. Created for Diaghilev's Ballets Russes in Paris in 1928, and the oldest of George Balanchine's pieces to survive, it sets as sure a caesura in the history of classical ballet as Stravinsky's ''Sacre du Printemps'' does in music.

title: FIVE PIANISTS TO PRACTICE TWO-HANDED DIPLOMACY
description: FIVE new United States ambassadors will be named this week. But they are not typical State Department diplomats or Reagan appointees. Rather, they are pianists chosen as representatives in an innovative cultural program.

title: HOLIDAAY ENTERTAINING: HELP IS AT HAND
description: WITH every year, the holiday season appears to arrive earlier and to linger beyond decency. Busy schedules and careers limit our time for an elaborate holiday scenario; yet, as though to compensate for the rest of the year, we plan holiday visits and parties with a passion. Just when there isn't enough time for heavy kitchen action, well-stocked county food shops come to the rescue and give the home cook a break.

title: ANOTHER CHAPTER IN U.P.I. STORY
description: A Mexican newspaper publisher last week won the bidding for United Press International, the struggling news service that has been operating for the last seven months under the protection of a Federal bankruptcy court.

title: COLUMBIA: 0-9 AND 0-20 AFTERLOSS
description: All season long, Jim Garrett has said he has lofty goals for Columbia. But each week, the Lions' first-year coach has seen his hopes dashed and his aspirations diminished. And now, his dreams have dwindled to just one -preventing Columbia's second straight season without a victory.

title: ELIZABETH MULLER TO MARRY IN MAY
description: Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Steven Muller of Baltimore of the engagement of their daughter Elizabeth Muller to Theodore Lenert Casparian, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Haig M. Casparian of Pelham, N.Y., and Nantucket, Mass. The wedding is planned for May 18.

title: DIGGING A SHELTER AND A GRAVE
description: THE NUCLEAR AGE By Tim O'Brien. 312 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $16.95.

title: FARMINGDALE STARS IN A PLAY
description: WHERE is Walden Court?

title: MORE ERUPTIONS REPORTED
description: Thousands of people, fearing another volcanic eruption, today fled several towns in the area where an avalanche of mud earlier this week buried an entire town.

title: FOR JOE PATERNO, TOUGH CLIMB BACK
description: FOR the first time in 14 years, the exodus from central Pennsylvania last December consisted of nothing more than trips home for the holidays. There was no excuse for people dressed in blue and white to parade in and out of the establishments in the French Quarter of New Orleans. There was no reason to hope for warm weather in Miami or Tempe, Ariz., or shiver in Dallas; not even a return to Honolulu or Jacksonville or Memphis. ''Fortunately,'' Joe Paterno said, ''we didn't have a bowl game to go to. Which was good.''

title: ACID RAIN CAMPAIGN STARTED IN STATE
description: WEARYING of this country's failure to deal with what many believe to be the most dangerous threat to North America's environment, the Atlantic Chapter of the Sierra Club has started an Americans Against Acid Rain campaign in New York State.

title: MAN WAS MEANT TO FLY, BUT NOT AT FIRST
description: In these days of the Concorde and the space shuttle, it is astonishing to realize that, as Clive Hart's PREHISTORY OF FLIGHT (University of California, $35) reminds us, until a century ago ''by far the most voluminous notes on the theory of bird flight were made by Leonardo da Vinci.'' Mr. Hart, who teaches literature at the University of Essex in England, elegantly and lucidly explores thinking about flight and flying machines from preclassical times to the 18th century. ''The Prehistory of Flight'' is not, he tells us, a general survey of aviation - his ''Dream of Flight'' (1972) was about practical attempts at flying, and he promises a later book about the iconography of flight. Instead, this beautifully illustrated volume explores what sages through the centuries have thought about flying and how they have applied scientific principles to the problem of human flight. He tells us, for example, that some commentators, believing human flight to be inevitable, urged that all flying machines be owned or regulated by the state. Others predicted disaster and felt that if people could fly, no one would be safe from marauding aeronauts. Mr. Hart also examines several heavier-than-air inventions, including Burattini's flying dragon (whose landings, the 17th-century Italian engineer promised, would cause ''only the most minor injuries''), Swedenborg's flying saucer and Pierre Desforges's airborne gondola (which, unlike many others discussed here, was actually tested, in 1772; the pilot, the Abbe Desforges himself, escaped with only a bruised elbow).

title: BOOKS FROM THE TIMES
description: THE NEW YORK TIMES GUIDE TO WHERE TO LIVE IN AND AROUND NEW YORK.

title: OUTLOOK BRIGHT FOR WASHINGTON
description: While New Dorp and South Shore played for the city championship yesterday, the players from George Washington High School were idle for the fifth consecutive Saturday. The Trojans played a four-game, nonleague schedule, which ended Oct. 12 with a 27-12 loss to Stevenson.

title: JAPAN'S TRADERS TRY HARDER IN U.S.
description: IT used to be relatively easy to describe a Japanese trading company. It was a mammoth concern that did not make anything itself, but served as the middleman between Japan's huge industrial cartels and the rest of the world. Its branches and subsidiaries bought raw materials to fuel Japanese industry, and marketed Japanese products abroad to help pay for those materials.

title: FRIENDS HAIL MARION TANNER AS A LOVING 'AUNTIE MAME'
description: It was just the sort of miserable day that Marion Tanner, with her indomitable exuberance, could have been counted on to turn into a party.

title: Arsonist Is Appointed To a Fire Department
description: A man convicted of arson eight years ago has been appointed to the town's fire department.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in this section on Oct. 27 about the Northport High School girls soccer team on Long Island misidentified the team that last defeated Northport. It was Berner High School, in 1983.

title: SYRACUSE WINS 4TH STRAIGHT
description: The wide receiver Scott Schwedes caught eight passes for a school-record 249 yards today, and Don McPherson threw for three touchdowns and ran for another as Syracuse routed Boston College, 41-21. Syracuse (6-3) extended two streaks, claiming its fourth straight victory and dealing Boston College (3-8) its fifth consecutive loss.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE GREAT THIRST. By William Duggan. (Delacorte, $16.95.) The story of modern Africa is of two struggles - to survive and to absorb the invasion of European civilization without sacrificing the ancient tribal roots of the continent's people.

title: JERSEY COLLEGES CRITICIZE STUDY ON TEACHER TESTING
description: A recent New Jersey Department of Education study used results from a test of prospective teachers to assail teacher-training programs in the state.

title: CONSUMER RATES
SODLIER, SCHOLAR, STATESMAN, TRICKSTER
description: GEORGE WASHINGTON WILLIAMS A Biography. By John Hope Franklin. Illustrated. 348 pp. Illinois: The University of Chicago Press. $24.95.

title: RATE DECLINE AIDS AFFORDABILITY
description: THE decline in mortgage interest rates in the last year, and particularly in the last six months, has significantly increased the number of American families that can afford an existing median-priced single-family house, according to a recently released study by the National Association of Realtors.

title: AN AGREEMENT FOR ULSTER
description: Seeking an end to the age-old problem of Northern Ireland, the British Government agreed last week to give the Republic of Ireland a formal advisory role in setting policy for the province. Britain, as it has since the division of Ireland 65 years ago, would exercise direct control over the affairs of the six counties that make up Northern Ireland.

title: Pilot Killed as 2 Jets Collide
description: Two Air Force jet fighters collided over the desert in a training mission Friday, killing one pilot while two others parachuted to safety. The dead pilot was identified as Capt. Jerry N. Allison, 31 years old, of Corpus Christi, Tex.

title: ART
description: The most striking aspect of this new art season has been the amount of serious sculpture. There does not yet appear to be any primary development, or any single body of work that could raise sculpture to the kind of prominence it had during the late 60's and early 70's, when the most ambitious sculpture was inspired by a Minimalist esthetic.

title: FROM 10 A.M. TILL DAWN
description: Ensemble Studio Party Nov. 18 - Last year, the Ensemble Studio Theater produced 237 projects, from readings to full dramatic works by new writers, making it one of the nation's most active developmental theaters. To celebrate and help raise $225,000 for a matching National Endowment for the Arts grant, there will be a party at the Palladium, with Robert Duvall as host, starting with cocktails at 6:30 P.M., dinner at 8, a cabaret show at 9:30 and dancing till dawn. Tickets, $200, from 212-957-7920. Friars Award Nov. 18 - The Friars Foundation, the charitable arm of the New York Friars Club, the show-business fraternal order, will hold its annual black-tie award dinner at the Plaza, starting with cocktails at 7 P.M., followed by dinner and dancing. This year the group's annual award will go to the radio announcer William B. Williams for his service to the foundation, which provides grants to college art and drama departments. Tickets, $250, from 212-751-7272. Aid for the Blind Nov. 18 - A benefit evening for the Manhattan League of the Helen Keller Services for the Blind will begin at the 8 P.M. performance of the Broadway show ''Song and Dance'' and will continue with an after-theater party at Regine's. Tickets, $80, $100 or $125 for the performance and $90 additional for the party, from 718-522-2122. British Fair Nov. 18 - The 65th annual British Fair will be held at the Women's Republican Club, 3 West 51st Street, from 10 A.M. to 8 P.M. Cornish pasties, antiques and British woolens are among items to be sold for the benefit of the Victoria Home for Retired Men and Women in Ossining, N.Y. There is no admission charge.

title: ...OR RUMMAGING THE CLOSETS AT MOM'S?
description: SHOPPING at Mom's is one of our daughter's favorite pastimes. It's convenient; there are no parking problems. No worry about remembering which space the car occupied, no anxiety about a deflated tire, a dead battery, a stolen stereo or the appropriation of the car itself.

title: THE SUGAR INDSUTRY TURNS UP ITS SALES PITCH
description: In the midst of an embarrassing flip-flop on its ''new'' and ''Classic'' formulas last summer, the Coca-Cola Company was attacked on another public relations front.

title: UNCONVENTIONAL IS THE WORD FOR THIS QUARTET
description: There are concerts most every night in Carnegie Recital Hall, but Friday's is unusual in more ways than one. It marks the first of 17 concerts the Composers' Forum is presenting here this year in celebration of its 50th anniversary. The program consists of three world premieres and one New York premiere of music for string quartet by black composers associated with the jazz tradition - Leo Smith, Leroy Jenkins, Anthony Braxton and Muhal Richard Abrams. And the performers are four string players who have made a quite remarkable success by ignoring nearly every bit of convetional wisdom there is about how to build a career in classical music.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE MAKING OF A PUBLIC MAN: A Memoir. By Sol M. Linowitz. (Little, Brown, $19.95.) Sol Linowitz begins ''The Making of a Public Man'' with a chapter on his term as ambassador to the Organization of American States under President Johnson - a tantalizing introduction both to the book and to Mr. Linowitz, who left a rewarding job as chairman of the board of Xerox to fulfill what he considered ''an obligation of the successful professional or businessman: to devote a period of his life to the service of his country.''

title: Tax Plans Weighing On Investors
description: WITH uncertainty on the tax front unlikely to be resolved for some time, investors are left with two possible courses: Do nothing or press ahead with investment activities regardless of what might happen on Capitol Hill. There are drawbacks and advantages to both.

title: Democrats Advocate High-Level Meetings
description: Democrats in Congress said today that the Geneva summit meeting would be a success even if it only laid the groundwork for future high-level meetings between the United States and the Soviet Union.

title: CITY OPERA'S ASTONISHING GOOD HEALTH
description: The New York City Opera's 1985 season ends tonight with, as fate will have it, a performance of ''Kismet,'' a feeble new production that did nothing to advance the proposition that American musicals belong on the opera stage. Ideally and more symbolically, the company would be bringing down the curtain with one of its unquestioned successes, of which there were enough to reinforce the impression that the City Opera is enjoying astonishingly good health. To predict that the company is entering into a golden period in its history may be foolhardy, but if that proves to be too sanguine an outlook at least it must be conceded that the financial and/or artistic disaster that many skeptics were predicting when Beverly Sills took charge of the company six years ago has not come to pass. Far from it. The attendance figures for the 19-week season that began on July 5 will not be official for a while, but company officials estimate that box office held at or about 80 percent of capacity, off 3 or 4 percent from last year. The loss is attributed chiefly to a slippage on summer weekends, when many people tend to leave town or stay home next to the air-conditioner. How the figures will break down in terms of individual performances is unknown at this writing. Who knows, perhaps ''Kismet'' will lead all the rest. If so, it would not shake my faith in the taste of the City Opera audience, merely in my ability to fathom it.

title: SEAFOOD IN A CONVIVIAL SETTING
description: EVERY town should have a Georgetown Chowder House. This tiny, convivial, minimally decorated one-room eatery fairly rocks with good spirits, especially on weekend evenings. All this in spite of - or maybe because of - crowded tables and access to the dining area via a long, narrow, scruffy bar.

title: GROUPS TAKING AID DONATIONS
description: American Jewish World Service, Suite 101, 29 Commonwealth Avenue, Boston, Mass. 02116. Mark checks ''Colombian Recovery Fund.''

title: TENNESSEE TRIUMPHS BY 34-14
description: Sam Henderson ran for two touchdowns as Tennessee kept alive its Sugar Bowl hopes with a 34-14 victory over Mississippi today in the Southeastern Conference game. Henderson, a 250-pound fullback moved to tailback in Tennessee's injury-depleted backfield, ran for 1- and 2-yard touchdowns, his first since a 1983 knee injury.

title: MULLIN IS SUED
description: Chris Mullin, the former St. John's basketball star, has been sued by a bicyclist who contends that Mullin was driving an automobile unsafely when he struck the bicycle rider at a Queens construction site last June. The action, which seeks $20 million in damages, was filed in Brooklyn Supreme Court on Friday by Fulgencio Tirado, a 33-year-old man who said he lost a toe and spent seven weeks in the hospital as a result of the incident. In addition to Mullin, the suit also names his mother, who owned the car he was driving, and the company that was resurfacing the roadway at the scene of the accident.

title: THE CARIBBEAN: IN SHAPE FOR THE SEASON
description: It is a recurring fantasy triggered by the bone-chilling days of winter. First there are the palm trees, always the palm trees; then the wide, tawny beach leading down to a gentle emerald sea, a clear robin's-egg sky stretching out forever and the embrace of a soothingly warm breeze, heavy with the aroma of the sea.

title: Press in Southeast Asia Faces New Restrictions
description: In the wake of Malaysia's recent arrests of journalists under its Secrets Act, two other Southeast Asian nations have also taken action against reporters.

title: TEACHER OF YEAR FOR '86
description: Donna Viveiros, an elementary school teacher who created a program in which second graders and residents of nursing homes become foster grandchildren and grandparents, learning from each other, has been picked from among 13 semifinalists as Massachusetts' 1986 Teacher of the Year. Mrs. Viveiros, who is 37 years old, will represent the state in a national teachers' competition, education officials said this week.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, NOVEMBER 17, 1985
description: International

title: RYE WEIGHS FILMING RULES
description: LIKE many of his fellow merchants in Rye, Joseph Cox watched the CBS television series ''Hometown,'' filmed on location in the city last summer.

title: WHO SHOULD HAVE KNOWN YURCHENKO WAS A PROBLEM?
description: There was an extraordinary round of fingerpointing last week over the case of Vitaly S. Yurchenko, the erstwhile Soviet defector. As American intelligence analysts attempted to determine whether Mr. Yurchenko's return to the Soviet Union signified a change in heart or the success of a complex Russian plot, various Government agencies were blaming one another, the Congress and the press for mishandling his case.

title: Keep Umpires Consistent
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: BRITISH PLUCK, GALLIC DUCK
description: There is a vast difference between going on holiday and traveling. Go on holiday, and all that results is a few postcards, a suntan, ruptured credit cards and massive relief at getting home. That seems a bit of an anticlimax. But if you travel - ah! Who knows? A best-selling book? A feature-length film for television? Death by man-eating crabs? Conversion to an exotic faith? None of which can be regarded as anticlimactic.

title: EAST MEETS EAST IN CEDARHURST
description: WITH the opening of Homer's Oriental in Cedarhurst, Homer Lee's restaurant empire now extends from the eastern edge of Nassau County to the Five Towns. It includes not only Chinese but Japanese restaurants and, with this latest addition, a Chinese-Japanese combination plate.

title: PLEASURES AND PALACES IN DUCAL MANTUA
description: Built around three squares, on three islands, Mantua is suspended like a mirage on three lakes formed by an elbow of the River Mincio. A tributary of the Po, the Mincio was an avenue of transportation for people and goods in Mantua's golden years. When Isabella d'Este came to the city as a bride in 1490, she arrived by barge from her native Ferrara. Seen from the east bank of Lago Inferiore, the city looks like an undiscovered side of Venice.

title: Guru, Ousted From the U.S., Gets Hero's Welcome in India
description: Bhagwan Shree Rajneesh, the guru ousted from the United States on immigration charges, returned early today to India and a hero's welcome by red-robed followers who scattered rose petals and chanted, ''Bhagwan, we love you.''

title: CITY'S SPY IN SKY
description: NEW YORK CITY'S Environmental Protection Department, anxious to account for all use of water in a drought emergency, analyzed aerial photographs of the city and concluded early this year that the owners of 18,000 swimming pools had failed to report the installations. The department billed the owners a total of $3 million for extra water use.

title: FIDELITY SWITCHES MANAGERS, QUIETLY
description: The Fidelity Freedom Fund has been one of the most visible stock funds offered by Boston's Fidelity Investments. Heavily promoted as a fund for the huge market for Individual Retirement Accounts and Keogh plans, the $500 million growth stock fund is managed without regard for tax consequences.

title: HOW 'LIVE AND DIE' HOOKS ITS VIEWERS
description: William Friedkin's ''To Live and Die in L.A.'' is not a very satisfying melodrama, but, even when it turns wildly, improbably stupid, it's never boring as it could be. With a series of bizarre images and a hypnotic score on the soundtrack, it hooks you at the start and, long after you've told yourself that what you're watching is utter nonsense, it holds the attention up to -and through - its anticlimactic, nihilist ending.

title: KEAN CABINET GETTING A NEW LOOk
description: WHEN the voters re-elected Governor Kean for four more years, they were opting for the status quo, but the Governor's second administration is going to have a different look from his first. So many cabinet members and top aides are leaving or changing jobs that it resembles the transition that takes place when a new Governor takes office.

title: E.P.A. AIDES FAULT AGENCY'S SCHOOL ASBESTOS PLAN
description: Internal reports by three officials of the Environmental Protection Agency have faulted the agency's program to remove asbestos from schools in the Middle Atlantic States, New England and the Middle West.

title: MEETINGS IN ELEGANT SETTINGS
description: Much of the business and pleasure of the Geneva summit talks will take place in these meetingplaces, diplomatic missions and sumptuous chateaus: 1 rrMaison de Saussure. This two-story 18th-century gray stone chateau is currently being rented by the Aga Khan, who will vacate it for President and Mrs. Reagan. Situated in Creux-de-Genthod, about three miles outside the city of Geneva and a few yards from the lake, the house is owned by a Swiss businessman and named for Horace-Benedict de Saussure (1740-1799). The Swiss physicist and geologist is credited with being the first man atop Mont Blanc, but was actually head of the second expedition and financed the first one. The Reagans are to be hosts at a dinner for Mr. and Mrs. Gorbachev there on Wednesday, and Mr. Reagan's key aides are to stay in a couple of adjacent buildings, where they will brief the President before his meetings with the Soviet leader. The house was built between 1727 and 1735, and sits on its own 20-acre park. 2 Fleur d'Eau. This 19th-century chateau, which will be the site of the round of talks for which the Americans will be hosts on Tuesday, has a spectacular view of the Alps, including Mont Blanc on a good day. The chateau, about five miles outside Geneva in the outskirts of a lakeside town called Versoix, sits in a seven-acre park that gives the site a sense of intimacy and charm. The chateau, now unoccupied, also belongs to a Swiss businessman, who lent it to the Government so it could be offered as a neutral site. 3 The Soviet Mission.

title: JAMES FRIEDLICH PLANS TO WED MELISSA STERN
description: Dr. and Mrs. Bernard S. Stern of Philadelphia have announced the engagement of their daughter Melissa Ann Stern to James Leo Friedlich, a son of Bruce Friedlich of New York and the late Katherine Langsdorf Friedlich. A spring wedding is planned Miss Stern, a ceramics sculptor, graduated cum laude from Wesleyan University and received a Master of Fine Arts degree from the State University of New York at New Paltz.

title: JEWISH ARTISTS WRESTLE WITH TRADITION
description: Is there such a thing as Jewish art? In his pioneering study, ''Jewish Experience in the Art of the 20th Century,'' Avram Kampf indicates that this charged question has been around since the end of the 19th century. ''In the West the notion of Jewish art arose largely from the need of the Jewish minority to affirm a distinct cultural identity.'' In Russia, Mr. Kampf writes, the ''quest for a Jewish secular art was inseparable from the quest for political emancipation and cultural autonomy.''

title: JACKSON'S RUNNING HELPS AUBURN WIN
description: The only tangible souvenir Auburn's Bo Jackson took home today from the Tigers' 24-10 victory over Georgia was a twig from the famous hedges that surround the Bulldogs' football stadium.

title: WAITING FOR BECKETT
description: A PRODUCER UNKNOWN TO ME, Michael Myerberg, phoned me in the fall of 1955 asking if I might be interested in doing a Broadway-bound production of a play called ''Waiting for Godot,'' with - long pause for emphasis - Bert Lahr and Tom Ewell. A year or so before, Robert Whitehead, the Broadway producer, had asked me what I thought of the play's New York chances, and I had responded only halfheartedly.

title: CHILD-ABUSE LINE
description: THE medical director of the New York Foundling Hospital said abusive parents in the city killed more than 100 children a year.

title: THE BEST AND BIGGEST IN PITTSBURGH
description: The 49th Carnegie International Exhibition opened in Pittsburgh just 10 days ago in an atmosphere of good will that verged on euphoria and has not been rivaled at any international exhibition of its kind in this visitor's experience. Remembering the student demonstrations, the unauthorized re-hanging in the middle of the night, the open hostility between one country and another and the bitterly disputed prize givings that have been the mark of this or that opening since the end of World War II, we could hardly credit what was going on in Pittsburgh. In a troubled world the Carnegie International of 1985 seemed to have been launched in an atmosphere of multinational harmony. For this, credit is due to John R. Lane, director of the Carnegie Institute Museum of Art, to his curator for contemporary art, John Caldwell, and to the international committee which they have invoked.

title: DECLINE AND FALL OF TEACHING HISTORY
description: FUTURISTIC NOVELS WITH A BLEAK vision of the prospects for the free individual characteristically portray a society in which history - knowledge of the past - has been systematically eliminated. In Aldous Huxley's ''Brave New World,'' the regime successfully waged a ''campaign against the Past'' by banning the teaching of history, closing museums and destroying historical monuments.

title: CUOMO FAVORS COLLEGE TRACT FOR AIRONDACK PARK CENTER
description: Governor Cuomo has recommended that a 2,885-acre Franklin County site owned by Paul Smith's College be used for a proposed Adirondack Park Visitor Interpretive Center.

title: CRIME
description: How nice. A first novel that is original; that moves alertly along; that has considerable charm as well as action; that has believable characters and elegant writing; that has moments of high humor and some black humor; that has a plot well conversant with the amenities of the mystery story (private-eye subdivision). All this is contained in SLEEPING DOG by Dick Lochte (Arbor House, $15.95). It should be in strong contention for an Edgar award next year.

title: BEATRICE DEAL IS BIGGEST BUYOUT YET
description: The buyout of Beatrice for $6.2 billion will be the largest instance of a company being taken private, if Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company completes the deal it has organized. Its $50-a-share offer for the maker of Samsonite luggage, Tropicana juices and other consumer products beat out a bid led by E.F. Hutton. The deal was seen as an especially sweet victory for one member of the purchasing group, Donald P. Kelly. When he was chairman of Esmark Inc. he tried to take that company private, only to have Beatrice intervene and buy out Esmark. Now, Mr. Kelly is expected to be the next chief executive of Beatrice.

title: A New Attack On Alcoholism
description: Having grown up with alcoholism in my immediate and extended families, I was encouraged to read Lucinda Franks's article on this disease.

title: O'MEARA IS WINNER IN PLAYOFF
description: Mark O'Meara rolled in a 15-foot birdie putt on the third extra hole today to defeat Corey Pavin for the $125,000 first prize in the Isuzu Kapalua International golf tournament. For O'Meara, it completed a Hawaiian sweep; he won the Hawaiian Open last February.

title: PENN STATE TROUNCES NOTRE DAME TO STAY UNBEATEN
description: Undefeated and underappreciated Penn State did not seem offended by the criticism that it had no business sitting on top of the college football rankings.

title: YES, IT'S BACK, AND BRIGHTLY
description: Halley's comet staged a revival last week for those with good binoculars. After 76 years on the road around the solar system, the comet re-appeared, so far without its tail, in a moonless sky near the cluster of stars known as the Pleiades in the constellation Taurus.

title: BALLOT QUESTIONS CALLED CONFUSING
description: The ballot for the general election on Nov. 5 created confusion and concern among Morris County voters. The problem stemmed from the ambiguous and complex wording of the seven public questions, the accompanying interpretive statements and the unusual length of the voting machine ballot.

title: BRAZIL RIGHTIST WINS SAO PAULO MAYORAL VOTE
description: Just eight months after Brazil returned to civilian rule, a former President has won election as Mayor of Sao Paulo, the country's largest city, with the support of rightist forces long identified with the former military Government.

title: SUMMIT ADVICE
description: With only two days to go before the start of the Geneva summit conference, the press release explosion continues. Every group and lobby around the capital seems to have advice for President Reagan, the Soviet Union and anyone who might pay attention.

title: PRISONERS PRESS FOR PROGRAM TO CURB AIDS SPREAD
description: IN THE law library at Rahway State Prison here is a three-inch-thick collection of brochures and newspaper and magazine articles about AIDS (acquired immune deficiency syndrome) published since last January.

title: ASSESSING BLAME IN A CO-OP
description: FEW situations generate more anger and confusion among residents of co-ops and condominiums than damage caused by the negligent acts of a neighbor.

title: WHEN PHOTOGRAPHERS AIM THEIR CAMERAS AT THEMSELVES
description: A corollary of Newton's law of motion prevails in the art world: For every observer eager to herald the arrival of something truly new, there is someone else equally eager to prove it's all old hat. Case in point: ''Self-Portrait: The Photographer's Persona, 1840-1985,'' a survey exhibition of some 45 photographs organized by Susan Kismaric, now on view at the Museum of Modern Art (11 West 53d Street, through Jan. 7).

title: IT'S GERMANY'S TURN TO TAKE THE LEAD
description: WEST GERMANY must take a more active role in expanding the global economy. Confronted with slower growth in the United States, and continued unwillingness on the part of Japan and other European nations to take up the slack, the world is waiting for Bonn to adopt more stimulative economic policies.

title: REAGAN AIDES UPSET BY DISCLOSURE OF WEINBERGER'S LETTER ON ARMS
description: President Reagan arrived here today for the Soviet-American summit meeting amid a dispute over the disclosure of a letter written by Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger urging that no accords be made on two key arms issues.

title: CABLE TV
description: Several good Swiss versions of ''Heidi,'' the children's classic, pop up occasionally, and the worthy Shirley Temple vehicle reappeared only last week. But there's room for more - a perfectly beautiful television version (1968) will be shown Tuesday at 4 P.M. on Showtime, with Jennifer Edwards (director Blake Edwards' daughter), Maximilian Schell and Jean Simmons. Later that evening, strictly for adults, there's Luis Bunuel's ugly but fascinating drama ''Diary of a Chambermaid'' (1964), with Jeanne Moreau, Michel Piccoli and Francoise Lugagne - at 8 P.M. and 1 A.M. on Bravo.

title: WOMEN ALONE: LUNCH IS FINE, BUT DINNER IS VERY DIFFERENT
description: LUCI DIAMOND loves her microwave oven. The reason she loves her microwave oven is that, if she doesn't have a date, male or female, she can heat some Lean Cuisine in it in a flash. The reason she is heating Lean Cuisine in a flash is that she does not like to have dinner alone in a restaurant.

title: REGIONAL TROUBLE SPOTS
description: The summit participants are expected to discuss several regional conflicts, particularly in light of President Reagan's United Nations speech calling on the Russians to help resolve such wars. Many strains in American-Soviet relations have arisen over the years because of problems in other parts of the world, and regional crises have not infrequently set back progress in other areas, such as arms control. Afghanistan rrIn December 1979, more than 100,000 Soviet troops entered Afghanistan, which shares borders with the Soviet Union and Pakistan. The cause, the United States says, was Soviet dissatisfaction with the Afghan leadership and the need to prop up a leader who was closer to Moscow. The Soviet Union says its soldiers were invited to help Afghanistan fight rebels supported by Pakistan and the United States. After the Soviet troops arrived, the civil war continued, pitting the Kabul Government's forces and their Soviet allies against thousands of Islamic rebels. Efforts to find a political settlement, including the withdrawal of Soviet troops, have been conducted under United Nations auspices, but have produced no agreement. Cambodia In December 1978, Vietnamese troops invaded Cambodia and toppled the Khmer Rouge Government, which had taken over in 1975 and slaughtered, it is estimated, millions of its own people. The Soviet Union supports the Vietnamese-backed Government of Heng Samrin, which has been battling guerrillas from a Western-backed coalition that includes forces loyal to Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the former head of state; the Khmer Rouge, which is led by Pol Pot; and the non-Communist Khmer People's National Liberation Front.

title: IN SEARCH OF HOSTAGES
description: Hopes rose a bit last week for the release of at least four of the six Americans taken hostage in Lebanon by the shadowy group known as Islamic Holy War.

title: DOROTHY MILNER WEDS WALTER PEASE JR.
description: Dorothy Soule Milner and Walter Franklin Pease Jr. were married yesterday at the home of her mother, Mrs. Benjamin Charles Milner 3d, in Upper Brookville, L.I. The Rev. Thomas Lamont, a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony.

title: ROBERT GEORGE SOMMER WEDS MARJORIE A. GLASER
description: Marjorie Ann Glaser, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Glaser of Old Tappan, N.J., was married last Sunday to Robert George Sommer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Sommer of Hillsdale, N.J. Rabbi Andre Ungar performed the ceremony at Temple Emanuel in Woodcliff Lake, N.J.

title: PRINCETON DOWNS YALE, 21-12
description: Princeton scored two touchdowns in a four-minute span at the start of the second half and then staved off a determined fourth-quarter charge to defeat Yale today, 21-12, in the 108th meeting in this rivalry.

title: THE DRIP-DRIP-DRIP OF MIRTH
description: NOT EXACTLY WHAT I HAD IN MIND By Roy Blount Jr. 175 pp. Boston: The Atlantic Monthly Press. $14.95.

title: BELLE FRANCE
description: To the Editor: When my mother had her wallet lifted in Nice in June, my family experienced ''la civilisation francaise'' in action. In the few seconds she looked up to pay for some sandwiches at a counter, a pickpocket made off with her wallet containing three $100 bills, 3,000 French francs, two passports and $2,000 in traveler's checks.

title: SHALL IT BE SHOPPING IN PARIS...
description: THE flutter of gold and yellow catches the eye from every window as the leaves drop from the trees in the yard.

title: BUSINESS NOTES
description: TOTAL-TEL USA, a long-distance telephone company with headquarters in Belleville, will convert its entire operation from an analog to a digital system by the end of March.

title: DON'T WORRY, WRESTLING WILL SOON VANISH BACK INTO OBSCURITY
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW ST. LUKE'S DEDICATED IN VILLAGE
