description: Through a chill afternoon drizzle, Bishop Paul Moore Jr. of the Episcopal Diocese of New York led the clergy of St. Luke in the Fields yesterday from the school gymnasium where they have held services for the last four years to the threshold of their newly rebuilt church.

title: REAGAN URGES RED CROSS AID
description: President Reagan, noting that the American Red Cross was ''running out of money,'' today appealed to the public for help.

title: A DOLLAR HERE, A DOLLAR THERE
description: We were not surprised when a recent month in Italy cost us about $2,500 for rooms and meals. That was roughly what my wife and I had expected, based on what we had learned from guidebooks and our travel agent. We were amazed, however, to find that we spent $167.60 simply for admissions to museums, galleries, other sightseeing attractions and local transportation.

title: COMPARABLE WORTH IS THE AMERICAN WAY
description: To the Editor:

title: A CIDER MAKER'S TRADITION
description: ''YOU need to press slowly and evenly,'' Jack Bucklyn, owner of B. F. Clyde' s cider mill in Old Mystic, said as he carefully switched to a lower gear on a steam-powered 1898 cider press. ''You want all the little cells to wake up and release the juice.''

title: LET'S GIVE EVEN YUPPIE PARENTS A BREAK
description: To the Editor:

title: EXPLORING 3 MEDIUMS
description: THE current exhibition at the Primavera Gallery in Huntington features three young artists using very different means to achieve personal modes of expression, yet the show is surprisingly harmonious.

title: BLACK-HISPANIC SPLIT HINDERS POLITICAL HOPES, STUDY FINDS
description: Divisions between black and Hispanic New Yorkers threaten to diminish their political power at a time when the two groups combined are close to a majority in New York City, according to a study by a Puerto Rican group.

title: EWING OVERPOWERS HAWKS
description: When the Knicks and the Atlanta Hawks play each other, the result is usually not an esthetic masterpiece. Because they run essentially the same plays and the same disruptive trapping defense - primarily because Mike Fratello, the Atlanta coach, is a former assistant to Hubie Brown, the Knick coach - they usually bog each other down.

title: New Hurricane Poses Danger in Caribbean
description: Warnings of coastal flooding and beach erosion were issued today for the northern shores of Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands as Hurricane Kate showed signs of picking up strength, the National Hurricane Center said.

title: INCORPORATING ANTIQUES INTO ART
description: IN AN old stone house beside a narrow road near the Delaware River - in the part of Warren County settled in the 1700's and early 1800's by hardworking farmers and mill workers - Dan and Pauline Eble Campanelli have created a rare communion between their life and their work.

title: NURSING HOMES APPLY TO ADD 4,646 BEDS
description: WITH data showing the state's population growing older, applications to build, expand or renovate nursing homes have inundated the Commission on Hospitals and Health Care.

title: COMINGS AND GOINGS
description: Gayle Sayers, the former Chicago Bear running back, and Dan Devine, a former head coach at Notre Dame and Green Bay, head a list of candidate for the job of athletic director at San Diego State. . . . Michael Spinks, who has been told that he will lose his International Boxing Federation heavyweight boxing title if he fights an unranked opponent, may be preparing to do just that. The Associated Press said it had learned that Spinks had agreed to fight Gerry Cooney in March but that no contracts have been signed. . . . Barry McGuigan, the World Boxing Association featherweight champion, will fight Fernando Sosa, the South American champion, early next year, according to Sosa's manager, Juan Carlos Lectoure. . . . Richard Sevigny, the Quebec Nordique goaltender who broke his left hand in a game Thursday night, will be out six weeks, the team announced.

title: BOSTON ARCHIVE TO HOUSE 350 YEARS OF HISTORY
description: The records of 350 years of state and local history, including court papers of the Sacco-Vanzetti case and the Salem witchcraft trials, will now be stored in Massachusetts's new Archives, Museum and State Records Center.

title: A MOUTHFUL
description: ONE OF OUR favorite foods is the avocado. Its name stems from the Spanish and means advocate or lawyer. The etymology is said to relate to an Aztec name for the fruit, ahuacatl, a confusion on the part of the European who first named it. However, a friend of ours, Sylvia Rosenthal, has a more interesting explanation of the word's origin. In her book ''Fresh Food'' (Tree Communications, 1978), she says that one of the first Spaniards to taste the avocado on a conquistadorial mission to Mexico some 400 years ago exclaimed in ecstasy, ''bocados,'' which the author translates as ''a mouthful.''

title: PACIFIC ISLANDS TAKE MICRO-STEPS TOWARD HOME RULE
description: President Tosiwo Nakayama considers himself a patient man, but once in a while pent-up irritation punctures his calm, as it did on a recent morning here in the capital of the Federated States of Micronesia. ''I've got my own government - I've got my own people,'' he said. ''When are you Americans going to stop dictating to us what to do?

title: RACQUETBALL PLAYER FINDS NEW LIFE AT 50
description: AT the age of 50, things were not exactly looking up for Janet Kettman of Fairfield.

title: DREW UNIVERSITY: THE PHOTOGRAPHIC ART OF PHILLIPE HALSMAN
description: THE photographic art of Phillipe Halsman, who died in 1979, does not raise many problems or issues.

title: Getting Hooke On Distant Team
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: WHERE TO INVEST TO MEET YOUR GOALS: WALL STREET CAUTIOUS ON STOCKS
description: SELDOM do the highly paid professionals who make a living on Wall Street by predicting the twists and turns of the stock market admit to being stumped.

title: LENDL AND BECKER IN WEMBLEY FINAL
description: Ivan Lendl and Boris Becker, seeded first and second, won their semifinal matches today in the $375,000 Benson and Hedges tennis championships but were stretched to the limit.

title: MEDICAL EXPERTISE IS ON TRIAL, TOO
description: After two years of heated public debate and a five-month trial, a jury will now attempt to decide how and why Michael Stewart died. The 25-year-old Brooklyn resident fell into a coma on Sept. 15, 1983, less than 30 minutes after transit police officers arrested him for scrawling graffiti on a subway station wall. He died 13 days later.

title: TRIPLE-FORGED TRINITY
description: THE BONE PEOPLE By Keri Hulme. 450 pp. Baton Rouge: Louisiana State University Press. $17.95.

title: HOLOCAUST: CONFERENCE SCHEDULED
description: THE first regional conference of New Jersey residents who are children of Holocaust survivors will be held here Saturday and next Sunday.

title: A New Attack On Alcoholism
description: I know that Lucinda Franks's honest and factual expose of the ''myths'' and the truth about alcoholism will help many people deal with their disease or seek professional intervention for a friend.

title: IN MORRISTOWN, A SPURT IN HOUSING
description: THE road builders severed Morristown when they put through Interstate 287 in the early 1970's. Most of the community prospered from the increased accessibility brought by the new highway, but parts were cut off and isolated from the rest of the town and its growing success.

title: ARTIST AT WORK: A DIALOGUE SHARED
description: SOME of my sculptor friends work in studios with other artists. Occasionally I have been asked to join one of those groups. They tell me that the give and take helps the artistic process and that the critiques are extremely beneficial. I always refuse, telling them that I am uncomfortable when people watch me work. I have this terrible feeling that I will make a mistake while someone watches, possibly because someone watches.

title: MAJORITY IN POLL LOOK TO CONGRESS TO CUT SPENDING
description: Even though President Reagan's popularity remains very high, Americans think Congress should have the most say in deciding how to cut Federal spending, the latest New York Times/ CBS News Poll has found.

title: A PIANIST, FLUTIST AND MEZZO-SOPRANO IN RECITALS
description: Erik Berchot All the artists who give debut recitals during Young Concert Artists' 25th anniversary season will be accompanied for at least one number by an alumnus of the organization. On Tuesday night at the 92d Street Y came the first of the debutants, the French pianist Erik Berchot, who was joined for a performance of Ravel's ''Tzigane'' by the violinist Ida Kavafian.

title: PENSION PLANS
description: To the Editor:

title: R. D. Laing's Ideas
description: To the Editor:

title: ARIZONA CHEERS AS CANAL CARRIES COLORADO RIVER WATER TO PHOENIX
description: Water from the Colorado River began to spill into Phoenix's waterworks Friday, coursing 200 miles through the Central Arizona Project's big concrete canal.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: FIGHTING FOR SCHOOLS ''Good enough for the best and cheap enough for the poorest'' was the public school policy that Henry Barnard, a state legislator from 1837 to 1840, spent several decades trying to establish, despite statewide indifference and hostility. As a prelude to the Connecticut Historical Society's fall exhibition on common school reform in the 1800's, Christopher Bickford, the director, will give a free lecture on the findings of his research vis-a-vis Henry Barnard at noon Monday.

title: CRUSADING EDITOR DIES RICH
description: RALPH INGERSOLL A Biography. By Roy Hoopes. Illustrated. 441 pp. New York: Atheneum. $19.95.

title: CARSON'S AGRESSIVE STYLE HAS JETS' DEFENSE THRIVING
description: Bud Carson is on the move. He grabs a defensive back by the arm and positions him on another part of the field.

title: RUSH-HOUR BLUES: SHOULD NEW YORK RESTRICT CARS WITH ONLY DRIVERS?
description: IN the continuing effort to regain control over rush-hour traffic, the possibility of banning autos with only drivers inside from toll-free East River crossings during rush hour is back under discussion.

title: FOR THE FLIP CITY TEAM, IT'S UP, UP AND AWAY
description: TODAY, $4 a year, a C average and a passion for flipping 15 feet or more in the air can earn someone a spot on the Flip City team.

title: HIS WIFE'S MUSTACHE
description: MR. WAKEFIELD'S CRUSADE By Bernice Rubens. 190 pp. New York: Delacorte Press. $15.95.

title: TRYING TO OUTFOX THE FAKERS
description: WHEN Pat Benatar broke onto the rock 'n' roll scene seven years ago with her passionate, hard-driving music, it quickly became clear that Chrysalis Records, the small Los Angeles recording company that signed her, had tapped a gold mine. It was also immediately apparent that counterfeiters, who for years have generously helped themselves to a slice of the recording industry's business, had a new and wealthy pocket to pick.

title: FUND FEES: A BAFFLING ARRAY
description: Commissions charged by mutual funds used to be much simpler. For years there were only two choises: the funds charged a onetime, upfront commission, known as a load, or the investor paid no commission at all.

title: Homage to Newton
description: Salvador Dali, the 81-year-old surrealist painter, has not appeared in public for 13 months, since he left a Barcelona hospital following treatment for burns suffered in a fire.

title: 2 Flee Oklahoma Prison And Are Recaptured
description: Two convicted murderers who escaped from a maximum-security prison by cutting through the bars of a visiting room and scaling a wall were recaptured today 300 yards from the prison.

title: COHN, ILL AND WEAK, REFLECTS ON HIS LATEST BATTLES
description: Both in law and life, Roy M. Cohn has usually got his way. But now Mr. Cohn is fighting battles on two fronts, and his lawyers and friends say it is not clear whether he will win on either one.

title: MR. CLEAN
description: The feminization of housework has a long and unglamorous history. Now there's a turnabout, not only masculine but glamorous.

title: PET EDUCATION
description: THE children were excited, but Chessie was cool as a cucumber. The big golden retriever thumped its tail lazily against the floor, cast a brown eye over the crowd and stretched out as if about to sleep.

title: Article 160976 -- No Title
description: The New York City subway and bus fare would rise to $1 next year and commuter rail fares would rise an average 11 percent under a plan that has been submitted to Governor Cuomo by his staff.

title: A Cautionary Trend in Real Estate
description: FALLING interest rates, flattened inflation and uncertainty over the future of the Federal tax code have changed the premises of real-estate investment in the last year.

title: BOSTON POST OFFICE SEEKING FRIENDS
description: CAN charm be taught? How about patience, grace and consideration for others? Thinking about such questions may help pass the time in line at the post office, but usually the answers remain elusive.

title: HOW THE BIG SIX STEER THE ECONOMY
description: AROUND 10 A.M. on Tuesday, Sept. 24, the currency markets were acting up, and Richard G. Darman, Deputy Secretary of the Treasury, was shown a snippet from the Treasury's news ticker. The item quoted the Secretary of Commerce, Malcolm Baldrige, doubting that the United States and other countries would intervene strongly in the currency markets to reduce the exchange rate of the dollar.

title: EXPLORING SCENT THERAPY
description: CAN SCENTS BE USED TO get you going in the morning? To ease the hassles of modern life? To lower blood pressure, curb cravings, alleviate pain, counter allergies, relieve headaches, help you fall asleep at night?

title: U.C.L.A. CLOSES IN ON THE ROSE BOWL
description: David Norrie passed for 236 yards and one touchdown in less than three quarters as U.C.L.A. routed Oregon State, 41-0, today to move one victory from a berth in the Rose Bowl game. If the Bruins defeat Southern Cal in their regular-season finale Saturday, they will represent the Pacific-10 Conference for the third time in four years. U.C.L.A. leads the Pac-10 with a 6-1 record and is 8-1-1 over all.

title: DANCE
description: All ballet training emphasizes the same five basic positions. Yet ballet styles seldom look alike. Just consider two companies performing this week.

title: DIVER AT WORK IN YONKERS DIES AS ACCIDENT CUTS AIR SUPPLY
description: A diver working 20 feet underwater to remove silt from murky dockside water died today when his air supply was accidentally cut off, authorities said.

title: JULL M. ABRAMS MARRIES STEWART ALLAN SCHNECK
description: Jill Marla Abrams, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sol Abrams of New Milford, N.J., and Stewart Allan Schneck, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Burton Schneck of Livingston, N.J., and Hallandale, Fla., were married last evening. Rabbi Samuel Cohen, assisted by Cantor Henry Butensky, performed the ceremony at the Short Hills in Short Hills, N.J.

title: Another New Wolverine
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: JETS' CARTER OUTR FOR SEASON
description: Russell Carter, the Jets' top defensive back in their aggressive man-to-man coverage, will be out for the remainder of the regular season with a pinched back nerve. The condition arose from an accidental kick by a teammate, Bobby Humphery, in practice several weeks ago.

title: RULES ON ACCESS FOR DISABLED CLASH
description: WHERE the handicapped are concerned, Connecticut law and Connecticut code are two different things.

title: SACHEM ADVANCES
description: It has taken the Sachem a year, but the Arrows did it. On a rainy day and a muddy field, the Arrows beat Walt Whitman 21-0 in the opening round of Suffolk's Conference I playoffs. Last year Whitman (4-4) beat Sachem -with a last-minute touchdown pass -in the final.

title: REVIEWING THE REGENTS' DECISION
description: THIS was in the coal fields of southwest Virginia more than a decade ago. My hosts had just finished serving a sumptuous Sunday dinner, and some of us were quite content to flop on the porch swing and enjoy the fall colors on the opposite ridge.

title: PLAN FOR STUDENT DRUG TESTS IN HANDS OF COURT
description: CONSTITUTIONAL questions were the focus last week as lawyers for the American Civil Liberties Union and Becton Regional High School in East Rutherford clashed in Superior Court here over the school's proposal to require student drug-screening tests.

title: FOR GOOD BEHAVIOR
description: Former Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. is home again in New Jersey. Federal prison officials said last week that Mr. Williams, a Democrat who was once chairman of the Labor and Human Resources Committee, had been transferred two weeks ago to a halfway house in Newark, where he will complete a prison term for an Abscam bribery conviction. Mr. Williams, who is 65 years old, was found guilty of attempting to use his influence to aid undercover Federal agents posing as representatives of a wealthy Arab sheik. He began serving a three-year prison term in January 1984, and a Federal parole board decided early this year that he qualified for an early-release program for well-behaved inmates. Mr. Williams was moved on Nov. 4 from the Federal prison in Allenwood, Pa., to Pyramid House in Newark, which he is allowed to leave during the day, but to which he must return at night.

title: BLK WOMEN'S GROUP URGED TO ACT FOR POOR
description: They came from Co-Op City in the Bronx and from Gulfport, Miss., and from points between and beyond. At the convention of the National Council of Negro Women, which ended here today, more than a thousand women looked back at battles waged and won, and forward to problems that remain.

title: A GORWING TASTE FOR ORNAMENTAL DRAWINGS
description: Drawings of furniture, silverware, porcelains, glass and objets d'art, collected by connoisseurs since the Renaissance are now being acquired by a larger following. The growing interest in such drawings is reflected in ''The Art of Design, 1575-1875,'' at the gallery of Armin B. Allen, 33 East 68th Street, on view through Dec. 7. The show is described by the dealer as the first exhibition of such ornamental drawings organized by a New York gallery.

title: BATTLE FIELD CALM IN RHODE ISLAND
description: PEACE prevailed last week at the Oakland Beach Elementary School in Warwick, R.I., where pupils had been waging a battle of the sexes with literal-minded determination and the boys had been getting the worst of it.

title: DANCE: TWO NEW WORKS BY EIKO AND KOMA
description: HOW terrifying silence can be.

title: BEETHOVEN'S SONATAS REMAIN A PIANISTIC EVEREST
description: Speak to a keyboard player of ''the 48'' and it will immediately be understood that you refer to the 48 preludes and fugues that make up Bach's ''Well Tempered Clavier.'' Only one other body of work in the piano repertory commands a similar distinction - ''the 32'' - Beethoven's canon of piano sonatas.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LIFE IN THE BALANCE: Exploring the Abortion Controversy. By Robert N. Wennberg. (Eerdmans, Paper, $7.95.) In recent years the abortion battle seems to have come to a painful impasse, with good people on both sides feeling passionately and unwilling to yield an inch of ground.

title: RIO DE JANEIRO
description: On a first visit to Rio de Janeiro, you wonder how you could have missed out on it until then. The next time, you immediately remember why you swore to return. It has ease and style and grandeur.

title: MISS HAMILTON TO WED IN MAY
description: Prof. and Mrs. John Ross Hamilton of Darien, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Heather Crawford Hamilton to Mark John McFaul, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James A. McFaul of Franklin Lakes, N.J. The wedding is planned for May.

title: 11 FOOD OUTLETS CITED BY NEW YORK OFFICIALS
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 11 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: Interest Rate Outlook, Key To Investing
description: SUPPOSE an investor found a modern-day Aladdin's Lamp that would provide a before-the-fact look at any single 1986 economic statistic he desired.

title: THREE-STAR CHINESE CUISINE
description: RARE are the Chinese restaurants in the county that will go to the trouble to lavish on their simple dishes the flair, sophistication and elegance other places -if they have the talent to begin with - seem to reserve for their special, and more expensive, items. What lifts The Pagoda out of the ordinary is an accomplished and disciplined kitchen, one that sees to it that every dish, from the most modest to the most elaborate, retains its particular characteristics and receives appropriate presentation. Having overcome the culinary inconsistencies that marked its early days, The Pagoda has evolved into its present pre-eminence. Its menu offers a rich selection augmented by a dozen or so seasonal specialties that add further interest and deserve serious consideration.

title: MEESE PRESSES HIS VIEWS ON THE CONSTITUTION
description: In a strongly worded speech before the Federalist Society Lawyers Division in Washington last week, Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d pressed his case for the ''jurisprudence of original intention.'' Picking up the extraordinary debate he opened in July with members of the Supreme Court over the Constitution and how it should be interpreted, Mr. Meese said that many judges are engaging in a form of ''chameleon jurisprudence, changing color and form in each era,'' usurping legislative powers rather than obeying the language of the Constitution and following the principles its framers and ratifiers agreed upon.

title: YOUTH - ART - HYPE: A DIFFERENT BOHEMIA
description: ANN MAGNUSON SITS ON a worn couch in her East Village apartment, rummaging in the junkyard of American culture. She talks, with affectionate mockery, about icons and totems and slogans, past and present. Her allusions spill out like the contents of some crazed time capsule - Steve and Eydie, ''The Beverly Hillbillies,'' Patty Hearst, Gidget, Wonder bread, Amway, TV evangelists, Lawrence Welk, Jim Morrison and the Doors, Chicken McNuggets, high-fiber diets, midstate pork princesses, Mantovani, Mr. Spock and ''Beyond the Valley of the Dolls.''

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: ART OUT EAST For their mid-winter shows, the two East End museums - Guild Hall in East Hampton and the Parrish Art Museum in Southampton - today open exhibits so diverse that they promise to provide something for most museumgoers. At the Parrish, the emphasis is on the unusual with ''Flower Show: Photographs rom the J. Paul Getty Museum, Selected by Sam Wagstaff Jr.'' Spanning the years 1843 to 1983, the more than 200 photographs by such well-known photographers as Henri Cartier-Bresson, Robert Frank and Robert Mapplethorpe explore the role of flowers in life's major events. Created for the Parrish and the Detroit Institute of Arts by Mr. Wagstaff, a noted collector, the show runs through Jan. 26 and can be seen from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Mondays and Thursdays through Saturdays, and from 1 to 5 P.M. Sundays at the museum on Job's Lane.

title: WEIRD STUFF IN THE CIRCUMAMBIENT NUMEROSITY
description: THE progress of irony in recent literature is like the escalation of the arms race in politics. While classic irony was elegant, almost dandified, modern irony is domestic and dangerous, a literary ultimatum. In two of this year's most interesting novels - ''White Noise,'' by Don DeLillo and ''The Death of My Brother Abel,'' by Gregor von Rezzori -irony approaches holocaust proportions. If the idea of nuclear warfare is to think the unthinkable, the irony of these two authors speaks the unspeakable.

title: Possible Pledge Seen On Chemical Arms
description: Administration officials said today that the United States and the Soviet Union were still in a position to issue a joint pledge at the summit meeting next week to work against the spread of chemical weapons.

title: UPDATING THE GRIDIRON RULES
description: The playing fields of New York may never be the same again because of a change in rules approved last week by the State Board of Regents. The board, which oversees the Education Department, voted to allow girls to participate with boys on high school teams that play contact sports.

title: WALL STREET'S BULLS TAKE COMMAND
description: FROM the tumultuous trading floor at Broad and Wall, where records are shattering with numbing regularity, to the staid brokerage offices on America's Main Streets, where gleeful crowds peer fixedly at the electronic tickertapes, investors are catching bull market fever once again.

title: THE MAYOR SHOWS HE CAN ALSO LISTEN
description: Something has happened to Mayor Koch since he began his re-election campaign. He has changed his rhetoric. He always calls the old poverty programs and New Deal-type social programs failures. But after he won the Democratic primary in September, he put the amelioration of urban poverty right at the head of his list of concerns.

title: CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Holiday Seasonals At Masters School The 19th-century neo-Renaissance mansion on the grounds of The Masters School is called Estherwood -and Estherwood's Elegant Boutiques describes the holiday shopping atmosphere Tuesday through Friday at the Dobbs Ferry school. The architectural bonus is the opportunity to view the interior of the mansion recognized by the National Register of Historic Places. This is the sixth year the Alumnae Association and the Parents Association have jointly sponsored the event.

title: Recent Sales
description: Hackensack $88,000 277 Prospect Avenue *2* 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 9-year-old high-rise condominium; *2* balcony, health club, $249 monthly charges; taxes $1,400. Park Ridge $143,500 12 Mountain Avenue *2* 2-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 30-year-old ranch; *2* pool, patio, basement with bar; taxes $2,464. Rumson $132,500 84 Avenue of Two Rivers *2* 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 6-year-old colonial; *2* central air-conditioning, cathedral ceiling, fireplace; taxes $2,719. South Orange $98,000 435 Meeker Street *2* 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 60-year-old colonial; *2* living room with fireplace, basement rec room, *2* enclosed porch; taxes $2,831. Wayne $315,000 77 Urban Club Road *2* 5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 12-year-old ranch; *2* greenhouse, wine cellar, sauna; taxes $4,956. Westfield $192,500 6 Thomas Court *2* 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 27-year-old split-level; *2* screened porch, fireplace in family room; taxes $3,439. OTHER AREAS New Rochelle, N.Y. $140,000 111 Mount Joy Place *2* 4-bedroon, 1-bath, 77-year old frame colonial frame; *2* dining room, pantry, front porch; taxes $1,707. Rowayton, Conn. $235,000 11 Sheffield Road *2* 2-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 1850 colonial; *2* beach privileges, barn, antique interior; taxes $2,245. Mastic, L.I. $69,990 180 Meadowmere Avenue *2* 4-bedroom, 1-bath, 11-year-old ranch; *2* eat-in kitchen, 0.5 acre; taxes $1,560.

title: Banker Fills Fordham Post
description: Fordham University yesterday named Arthur R. Taylor, an investment banker and former president of CBS Inc., as dean of its Graduate School of Business Administration. Mr. Taylor, a Phi Beta Kappa graduate of Brown University, began his corporate career with the First Boston Corporation. He was president of CBS Inc. from 1972 until 1976. The 50-year-old Mr. Taylor will remain chairman of Arthur Taylor & Company, a private investment concern.

title: VOLUNTEER COUCNIL PLANS FOOD DRIVE
description: A CONCERTED effort by corporations, schools, service groups and individual volunteers is expected to brighten the holidays for many of the poor in the county. On Nov. 25 the second yearly countywide food drive sponsored by the Corporate Volunteer Council will begin. It is scheduled to continue through Dec. 6.

title: CAROLINA WIDOW GETS $351,500 IN KLAN KILLINGS
description: The City of Greensboro has turned over a check for $351,500 to Marty Nathan, whose husband, Michael, was one of five anti-Ku Klux Klan demonstrators killed here by Klansmen and American Nazi Party members on Nov. 3, 1979.

title: ARMS ACCORD: ELUSIVE GOAL
description: With new proposals advanced on both sides, the United States and the Soviet Union are now in a position for some form of general accord on limiting offensive and defensive nuclear arms.

title: A New Attack On Alcoholism
description: I wonder why the disease model for alcohol addiction has become so popular lately.

title: FIRST SNOW OF SEASON IN NEW YORK BRIEFLY GIVES AREA A WINTRY LOOK
description: The first snowfall of the season swirled over the New York metropolitan area yesterday, slowing traffic and briefly giving the city and most suburban landscapes a wintry contour before turning to bleak November rain.

title: GROWING SEAWEED FOR FOOD
description: NORI, the paper-thin seaweed wrapped around the rice and fish in sushi, may soon turn into big business. The United States already imports about $10 million worth of nori a year from Japan. Now, with America's appetite for the Japanese delicacy growing, the drive is on to set up a domestic nori industry.

title: HOSPKTALS' MERGER STUDIED BY OTHERS
description: THE merger of a Catholic and non-Catholic hospital in Morris County this month got more than passing notice at East Orange General Hospital and the Hospital Center at Orange, whose officials are exploring the state's recommendation that they consolidate with St. Mary's Hospital in Orange.

title: LIBRARIES RUN OUT OF SPACE FOR BOOKS
description: LIBRARIES around the state are finding they have too many books.

title: Caveat Investor
description: IT was not an investment for the squeamish. But then the road to riches is not usually the common path trodden by the masses, its promoters insisted.

title: CONSOLIDATING HOSPITALS IS A COMPLEX AFFAIR
description: DAY and night, the kidney dialysis stations at East Orange General Hospital are filled with patients whose lives depend on the blood-cleansing treatment.

title: OAKLAND'S 'RENAISSANCE' IS ONE OF MANY IN THE WEST
description: Enduring inevitable comparisons with San Francisco, its more glamorous neighbor, this city has long suffered a kind of inferiority complex. Lately, however, Oaklanders have had something to crow about. New office buildings, a 21-story hotel and a forest of other glass-sheathed structures are changing the city's skyline and prompting local optimists to mention an ''urban renaissance.''

title: FAILED COUP IN LIBERIA
description: There was dancing in the streets of Monrovia, Liberia, last week when Samuel K. Doe, who won power in a 1980 military coup, seemed to have lost it the same way. But a few hours later, the streets quickly emptied after General Doe, who was declared the winner in a presidential election in October, put down a revolt led by a former military associate who is believed to have tried the same thing in 1983 and fled to the United States when he failed.

title: SAVINGS RATE
description: To the Editor:

title: RECENT RELEASES
description: Ricochet With David Bowie; directed by Gerry Troyna Passport 59 minutes. $29.95 David Bowie's 1983-84 ''Serious Moonlight'' tour itinerary led him through Hong Kong, Singapore and Bangkok.

title: LAST WEEK'S TALLY OF KEY EASTERN STATES
description: Senate

title: KEEPING AN EYE ON COSTS
description: FRANKLIN E. WHITE, the newly appointed State Transportation Commissioner, is known as a budget man. Members of the General Contractors Association got the point quickly when Mr. White addressed their recent annual meeting.

title: CONVERSION OF A SUBURBAN PIONEER
description: Conde Nast, whose publications include Vogue, House and Garden and Glamour magazines, was among the first companies to establish headquarters in the suburbs when it opened its 23-acre office and production facility in Greenwich, Conn., in 1918.

title: THE PRIDE OF A FAMILY
description: ''YOU don't plant trees for yourself, you plant them for you children and grandchildren,'' my grandfather always said.

title: NEW DORP EDGES SOUTH SHORE, 7-6, TO WIN CITY TITLE
description: New Dorp claimed its first city championship in 26 years yesterday, blocking an extra-point attempt late in the game to edge South Shore, 7-6, in the Public School Athletic League final at rain-soaked Midwood Field.

title: TESTING OUT THE FINE POINTS? REACH FOR RACHMANINOFF
description: People asking what records I play to test a sound system are nonplused by my answer: none.

title: BRITISH AIDE RESIGNS OVER ULSTEUR PACT
description: An official in Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's Government has resigned in protest over an agreement between Britain and Ireland granting Dublin a consultative role in how Northern Ireland is governed.

title: Q AND A
description: Question:We are a group of friends who will be in Zurich next March 14 from noon until the following morning, when we go to Lech in Austria to ski. In this brief time what would be the most interesting, or ''don't miss'' things to see? - P. R., Cranbury, N.J. Answer:Among several sightseeing options within a relatively small area is the Bahnhofstrasse, one of Europe's major shopping streets. Luxury stores and banks line this busy avenue of lime trees, which leads from the central railroad station to Lake Zurich, about two-thirds of a mile away. Many strollers stop for coffee and shop for chocolates in one of the street's confiseries.

title: AN OBSERVER'S UNUSUAL ROLE IN STEWART TRIAL
description: Each day during the trial of six transit officers charged in the death of Michael Stewart, Louis Clayton Jones has sat in the second row, far right, taking notes and dispensing briefs, a fixture at a criminal trial he says he doubted would ever occur.

title: 4,000 Syracuse Phones Out
description: Four thousand downtown customers were without telephone service today after employees of the Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation accidentally cut through five phone cables Friday afternoon as they repaired a gas main. Service was expected to be restored late today, according to Howard Williams, a spokesman for the New York Telephone Company.

title: SUZANNE MARIE DAVIS, BANKING AIDE, PLANS TO MARRY JAMES JOSEPH PHELAN
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Blake Davis of Purchase, N.Y., and Quoque, L.I., have announced that their daughter Suzanne Marie Davis plans to marry James Joseph Phelan in the spring. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Thomas Phelan of Rockville Centre, L.I., East Quogue, L.I., and Deerefield Beach, Fla.

title: French Top Yugoslavs To Reach Cup Finals
description: Michel Platini ended months of anxiety for French soccer fans yesterday by scoring both goals in his country's 2-0 victory over Yugoslavia.

title: SCHOOLS NEAR AIRPORTS GETTING NOISE RELIEF
description: Florence Feuer sat in a circle surrounded by 15 kindergarteners. They listened silently as she read one of their favorite fairy tales, ''The Three Bears.'' But every few minutes the teacher stopped. She waited until the roar of an airplane flying overhead grew faint.

title: IN CHICAGO, STILL MONSTERS OF MEMORY
description: IT now has reached the point where a Chicago radio station is running a contest to change the Bears' nickname from ''Monsters of the Midway.'' What the station doesn't realize is that you can work up all kinds of names, but never really change what the Bears are all about.

title: BBC DAYS
description: ORWELL The Lost Writings. By George Orwell. Edited and with an introduction by W. J. West. Illustrated. 304 pp. New York: Arbor House. $20.

title: A YOUNG RABBI
description: Rabbi Hammerman's article reminds me of the yarn about the young minister who applied for a job but was told by the church elders, ''You're somewhat young.''

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on page 22 of the Arts and Leisure section today incorrectly describes the death of the artist Franz Kline. He died in 1962 as a result of heart disease.

title: IN PORTUGEUESE RUGS, A STITCH OUT OF TIME
description: On sunny afternoons the women of Arraiolos sit in companionable clusters in the cobblestoned streets, their needles flashing as they fashion the needlepoint carpets that have made this little Portuguese town synonymous with both a craft and a stitch.

title: MOST IRISH OF ALL?
description: PUCK OF THE DROMS The Lives & Literature of the Irish Tinkers. By Artelia Court. Illustrated. 297 pp. Berkeley: University of California Press. $24.95. IRISH FOLKTALES Edited by Henry Glassie. Illustrated. 353 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $19.95.

title: TRADE CENTER SITE FOR COMPUTER DATA
description: Beneath the World Trade Center, in a space that extends down 100 feet and spans two city blocks, workers are installing bulletproof glass, motion detectors and giant vaults. They are transforming the cavernous, gritty ''basement'' of the twin towers into a high-security storage center for computer data.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Nets vs. Los Angeles Lakers, at Inglewood, Calif. It is a homecoming of sorts for Coach Dave Wohl, who was the Lakers' assistant coach when they beat the Nets in both meetings last season on their way to winning the league title. (Television - SportsChannel, 10:30 P.M. live. Radio - WNBC 660, 10:30 P.M. live.) Football Jets vs. Tampa Bay Buccaneers, at Giants Stadium. (Television - Channel 2, 1 P.M. Radio - WABC 770, 1 P.M.) Seahawks vs. New England Patriots, at Seattle. The Patriots have won six straight games, are tied for the American Conference East lead with the Jets and have a 4-1 edge in the series against Seattle, including last year's victory when they spotted the Seahawks a 23-0 lead and then scored 38 points for a 38-23 victory. (Television - Channel 4, 4 P.M.) Hockey Rangers vs. Edmonton Oilers, at Madison Square Garden, 7:35 P.M. The Rangers did fairly well against the two-time Stanley Cup champions last season, losing one game and tying one in Edmonton and winning an 8-7 shootout at the Garden. (Television - MSG, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WNBC 660, 7:30 P.M.) Islanders vs. Flyers, at Philadelphia, 7:05 P.M. The Islanders and the Flyers split the season series, 3-3-1, last season. (Television - SportsChannel, 7 P.M. Radio - WOR 710, 7 P.M.) Soccer Chile vs. Paraguay, at Santiago, Chile, second leg of the two-game match to determine the final qualifier for the World Cup from South America.

title: TECHNOLOGY STOCKS MISS THE RALLY
description: DESPITE the stock market rally, technology stocks have not yet shown signs of recovery from their two-year-long thrashing by investors. Even last week, when the Dow Jones industrial average spurted sharply, many technology issues nudged up only slightly. ''Talk about a bombed-out area,'' said Frank J. Husic, president of the Alliance Technology Fund.

title: CHAIR HEIRS
description: One of the lesser-known Senate perquisites involves allowing a member who has retired or been defeated to keep the chair that he or she used in the chamber, shipping it home or downtown to a Washington law office as circumstances dictate.

title: IN ST. THOMAS, CHALLENGE IS PAR FOR THE COURSE
description: The 14th hole of Mahogany Run is perched on a cliff 200 feet above a rocky inlet of the Atlantic Ocean, commanding an unlimited view of the sea and of neighboring Virgin Islands. It may well be the most photographed par-3 hole in the world of golf. At last count four couples, on separate occasions, esteemed the 14th so highly that they married there, on the green.

title: MANN, KAFKA AND THE KATZENJAMMER KIDS
description: A ROARING cavalcade of tanks, trucks, jeeps and bulldozers appeared on the green hill beyond the old brickyard. It was a splendid April day. The streets of the village were deserted. From the top of the steeple an enormous white flag made of two bed sheets flutered in the breeze. Not a shot was fired.

title: TRAPPED GIRL, 13, DIES
description: Omayra Sanchez, a 13-year-old girl whom rescue workers had been trying for 60 hours to dislodge from a neck-deep pool of cold, muddy water, died of exposure this morning.

title: SCOTT SCHOEN TO WED MISS GACHELIN IN MAY
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jean-Pierre Gachelin of Geneva have announced the engagement of their daughter, Laurence Maria Madeleine Gachelin, to Scott Alan Schoen, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Sheldon S. Schoen of Short Hills, N.J. The wedding is planned for May.

title: DOBBS FERRY WINNER, 8-0
description: In a battle of unbeaten teams, Dobbs Ferry defeated Bronxville, 8-0, to win the division championship yesterday. The victory extended Dobbs Ferry's winning streak to 37 games and qualifies it for a bowl bid.

title: HITACHI SETTING UP U.S. PHILANTHROPY
description: With a $20 million endowment and prominent Americans as trustees, Hitachi Ltd. of Tokyo is establishing a foundation in the United States to promote amicable United States-Japanese relations and cultural understanding.

title: POWER FROM THE BARREL OF A GUN
description: POLITICAL MURDER From Tyrannicide to Terrorism. By Franklin L. Ford. Illustrated. 440 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $29.50.

title: SELLING CAPITALISM WITH A VENGEANCE
description: Like most American mini-series, ''Kane and Abel,'' the seven-hour production getting under way on CBS tonight at 9, is based on a best-selling novel. But in this case, the name of the author elicits an added measure of interest. Jeffrey Archer is an Englishman who recently was picked by Margaret Thatcher to be deputy chairman of the Conservative Party. He will apply his own peculiar brand of positive thinking to drumming up support for the Tories in the next general election. Mr. Archer is a great believer in the theory that life's unsuccessful unfortunates deserve what they get. Thumping for the Tories on a radio show, he observed that much of Britain's current unemployment crisis could be traced to laziness. The solution was ''getting off your backside and finding a job.'' Predictably, the 3.3 million jobless were among those listeners not amused.

title: AN UPDATE ON ISLAND AMENITIES
description: Escaping to the Caribbean and the Bahamas, for many winter vacationers, is a journey to a gentler world, where changes come slowly, if at all. But changes do come, as the islands and their businesses try to attract visitors. In the island-by-island survey in the following pages, based on information gathered in the last few weeks, the first section of each island highlights new places to stay, expansions at familiar resorts, new attractions and shops, and improvements to airports, harbors and roads.

title: LAWYER MARRIES NANCY R. NORTON
description: The marriage of Nancy Ruth Norton, a doctoral candidate in Chinese literature at Princeton University, to Mark Daniel Tomasko, group counsel for the consumer products group of the Singer Company in Stamford, Conn., took place yesterday at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church in New York. The Rev. Kenneth O. Jones performed the ceremony.

title: ENERGY-AID GRANTS INCREASE IN FAIRFIELD
description: AS it begins its eighth year of raising money to help heat the homes of the poor, leaders of Operation Fuel are trying to counteract the impression that the program operates only in the Hartford area.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: SEASONAL PARADE Neither rain nor snow will prevent the county's only Thanksgiving Parade from stepping off at 10 A.M. Saturday for the 24th year. Sponsored by the City of New Rochelle and the New Rochelle Chamber of Commerce, the parade will assemble at Maple Avenue, then move east on Main Street to North Avenue, past the reviewing stand at City Hall to the dispersal point at New Rochelle High School.

title: MASSACHUSETTS PRESSING AID FOR FAMILY HOUSING
description: Massachusetts communities that have long been suspicious of subsidized housing for low-income families are now beginning to seek out such developments, state officials say.

title: A CHAMPION MOVES TO TEACHING
description: THE instructor turned and smiled slightly at his class. ''We have a problem here. What can we do about it?'' Hands shot up instantly around the room. Every child was involved.

title: Burglary Suspect in Bad Fall
description: A suspected burglar fell through the false ceiling of a liquor store early today and was found there, his posterior hanging between two beams, by sheriff's deputies who had been summoned by a silent burglar alarm. The deputies said John Mayfield, 20 years old, broke into the store through a skylight and appeared to have sampled some of the merchandise before trying to leave.

title: IN ANGOLA, REBELS LOOK TO WASHINGTON
description: Angola's 10-year-old civil war is becoming more costly as it edges closer to a proxy confrontation between the United States and the Soviet Union.

title: HEIDI R. KREUTER TO WED STEPHEN M. BROWN DEC. 8
description: Heidi Ruth Kreuter and Stephen Mark Brown plan to be married Dec. 8, her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Henry W. Kreuter of Tewksbury, N.J., and Harwichport, Mass., have announced. Mr. Brown's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Milton L. Brown Jr. of Lowell, Mass.

title: THE SURPRISING AFFLUENCE OF THOSE OVER 50 LURES BUSINESSMEN
description: AFTER decades of being ignored, the 50-plus generation has finally come under the scrutiny of marketers who are realizing that there is gold to be made in selling to the silver-haired.

title: SEQUEL TO A RAID
description: VERMONT'S raid on a church commune in Island Pond in June 1984 did not lead to any court finding of child abuse - the announced goal of the raid. But the 90 state troopers who took part in the raid manhandled the church's property, the church group told the State Claims Commission in applying for reimbursement.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We just had a bed, a gas stove and plastic plates - now we have nothing.

title: Sovietology
description: To the Editor:

title: MANCHESTER UNITED HELD TO 0-0 TIE AT HOME
description: Manchester United, the First Division English League soccer leader, failed to score at home for the first time this season and was held to a scoreless draw today by Tottenham Hotspur.

title: YOUTH DEW DID IT
description: ESTEE A Success Story. By Estee Lauder. Illustrated. 223 pp. New York: Random House. $19.95. ESTEE LAUDER Beyond the Magic. By Lee Israel. Illustrated. 186 pp. New York: Macmillan Publishing Company. $15.95.

title: On Language;   Summitspeak
description: DEFINITIONS ARE critical,'' an unidentified spokesman told a diplomatic reporter last week. ''If we can come to some broad agreement on terms and if the Soviets are convinced that Reagan is both serious and flexible, then it might be possible for the negotiators at Geneva to work out a specific agreement after the summit.'' ''That,'' concluded this skilled practitioner of summitspeak, ''would be a real breakthrough.''

title: No Headline
description: The Reagan Administration has decided to propose to the Soviet Union at the summit meeting next week that the two nations use their influence to try to bring an end to the Iran-Iraq war, Administration officials said today.

title: POLES, SHORT OF SASUSAGE, MAY TURN TO GOULASH COMMUNISM
description: The Polish Government last week announced changes that contained the promise of a new beginning, but Poles have heard that before.

title: LOCAL MONOPOLIES SERVE THE PUBLIC BEST
description: WHEN a once-flourishing manufacturing company in Ellenville, N.Y., closed its doors last fall because of dwindling sales, the event was not considered particularly noteworthy. The concern was the Channel Master Company; its product was the rooftop television antenna. Today, with more than 40 percent of American families receiving television signals by cable, we are well into the era of ''single-wire dependence.''

title: MYRON GOLDSTEIN, LESLIE NICHOLSON EXCHANGE VOWS
description: Leslie Nicholson, the daughter of Susan Zeckendorf Nicholson of New York and Roland Allen Nicholson of New York and Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Myron Goldstein, the son of Eleanor Goldstein of Sunrise, Fla., and the late George A. Goldstein. Rabbi Hillel Friedman performed the ceremony at the St. Regis-Sheraton Roof in New York.

title: ON THE LOTS: a bumper crop of used cars
description: LAST month, Ray and Judy Broudeaux bought a 1981 silver blue Buick Park Avenue. The two-door sedan is the first used car the couple ever purchased. They needed a larger car because their son is growing up, and ''the price was right,'' said Mr. Broudeaux.

title: 3 Experts Look Ahead On Investing
description: Three leading Wall Street professionals discuss their outlook for alternative investment opportunities over the next six months to a year. The professionals are: Robert Farrell, vice president and chief market analyst at Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith; Robert Heisterberg, senior vice president and director of research for the Alliance Capital Management Corporation, and Susan Byrne, president of the Westwood Management Corporation. They were questioned by Fred R. Bleakley and Jan M. Rosen, editors in the financial news department of The Times. QUESTION: Stocks have gone up more than 60 percent since August 1982. Has the bull market now run out of steam?

title: ANTIFROST BACTERIA WIN A TRYOUT
description: The cause of genetic technology took a leap forward last week when the Environmental Protection Agency approved experiments to protect strawberry plants from frost. But some opponents of the idea, which calls for the first deliberate release of genetically altered organisms outdoors, say it is a step that might eventually have disastrous results.

title: POLITICAL PARABLES FOR TODAY
description: THE 1986 CAMPAIGN SEASON IS ALMOST upon us, a prelude to the 1988 Presidential race. In short order, we will be treated to a new round of speeches, debates and interviews concerning America's most pressing problems. Some of the proposals will be original, a few of the perspectives novel.

title: JERSEY PET CEMETERY OWNER UNDER-FIRE FOR MASS BURIALS
description: The owner of a pet cemetery here and the state are involved in a dispute over the cemetery's disposal of pets.

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: POPCORN SOUP ON L.I.

title: BARNEGAT HOMES
description: The emergence of Atlantic City as a major resort town has accelerated the demand for both year-round and summer homes in communities along the New Jersey Shore, particularly in Ocean and Atlantic Counties.

title: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest: ARE WE ALMOST THERE? Written and illustrated by James Stevenson. Greenwillow. $11.75. (Ages 5 to 9) The title is the joke - the plaint from the back seat of every family car on the way to every family holiday, vacation, party, or, in this case, day at the beach.

title: STAR BUFFS ON L.I. GET AN EARLY PEEK AT HALLEY'S COMET
description: Stargazers intent on catching an early glimpse of Halley's comet on Jones Beach tonight fell into two categories. Those who kept saying, ''There, there!'' and those who kept responding, ''Where, where?''

title: STATE IS PUTTING HIGH-TECH EGGS IN MANY BASKETS
description: REPORTS of an unexpected business slump in California's ''Silicon Valley'' -the area around Palo Alto where high-technology industries are concentrated - do not alarm the panel formed to bring a similar concentration to New Jersey.

title: CONFERENCE IS SET ON ART IN CITIES
description: BECAUSE Mayor William A. Collins of Norwalk believes that art projects have played a vital role in the revitalization of his city, he will go to a statewide conference later this month and encourage other municipal officials to support the arts, too.

title: FORTRESS SUBURBIA, OR WHY THE WISTERIA HAD TO GO
description: BURGLAR alarms are all right as far as they go, the police officer said, and what probably scared the guys off after they cut the screens was seeing the wiring on the windows. But why ask for trouble?

title: ETHNIC NO MORE
description: THE AMERICAN CATHOLIC EXPERIENCE A History from Colonial Times to the Present. By Jay P. Dolan. 504 pp. New York: Doubleday & Company. $19.95.

title: PHOOEY TO YOUNG AND OLD
description: THE ELDER By Cris Freddi. 323 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $16.95.

title: Tackling the Implausible
description: ONE MONDAY NIGHT while flicking a dial I paused for the Green Bay Packers. Maybe at last somebody would say what it is they pack in Green Bay.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: SECRETS. By Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $17.95.) The model for ''Manhattan,'' the fictitious television soap opera dramatized in Danielle Steel's new romance, appears to be ''Dynasty.''

title: PERSISTENT WAGE GAP
description: To the Editor:

title: COLOMBIA AND ITS VOLCANO
description: Earthquake, mud slide, volcano - nature itself seems in insurrection in Latin America. Again there are casualty numbers beyond comprehension. Again we read of communities instantly entombed. Again on television we hear the cries of the trapped, the sobs of the bereaved. At least for a few days, a remote land becomes close, its population resolves into real people and their suffering is entered in the common account of humanity.

title: 11 Killed in Sri Lanka In Explosion and Battle
description: A land mine attack by Tamil separatists and a battle with security forces killed 11 people, including 4 policemen, in eastern Sri Lanka today, Government officials said.

title: ONE MOTHER'S ANGUISH: 'NOW WE HAVE NOTHING'
description: Volcanic sand still lodged in her hair, Blanca Olivia Ochoa lay on a hospital bed today, worrying about the future of her family without her husband's salary of $20 a week.

title: A CLOSER LOOK AT TWO TAPE BACKUPS
description: BACKUPS are to personal computers what spare tires are to cars. There is one major difference, however. A flat without a spare may take longer to fix than a flat with the remedy right in the trunk, but chances are, even without a spare, there is a way to get the vehicle back on the road again. In computing, where there is no backup, all is lost.

title: NEW THIRD PARTIES AROUND STATE GAIN WINLESS VICTORIES
description: FOR a party that had captured only 10 percent of the vote, the Greens in New Haven seemed to have a lot to celebrate election night. Party workers cheered as the results came into election headquarters. Politicians from other parties dropped by to congratulate them. Even though the Democrats came in first, the way Democrats usually do in New Haven, the Greens chanted ''We won!''

title: BONDS HOLD APPEAL WITH RATES HIGH
description: DRAWN by prevailing high interest rates and a deluge of new, innovative issues, more and more individuals are placing their investment dollars in the bond market.

title: HOW INNER TORMENT FEEDS THE CREATIVE SPIRIT
description: During Diane Arbus's funeral, the photographer Richard Avedon turned to a friend and whispered, ''Oh, I wish I could be an artist like Diane.'' The friend, Frederick Eberstadt, answered, ''Oh, no, you don't.'' Their brief exchange - as recounted in Patricia Bosworth's biography of Arbus - raises the charged questions surrounding the tormented, even self-destructive, creative artist. Chief among them is where reality ends and mythology begins.

title: MONEY, MONEK EVERYWHERE
description: THE Transit Authority will be able to spend only 80 percent of its 1985 capital budget allotment by the end of the year, transit officials said last week at a hearing by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority Capital Program Review Board.

title: MAJOR GOAL IS STILL ELUSIVE FOR A PERENNIAL CANDIDATE
description: LOU PINIELLA didn't have to interview for the job, even though he had no previous managerial experience. Billy Martin used to get another job almost as soon as he was dismissed. Earl Weaver, in retirement, was besieged with offers. Ralph Houk was lured out of retirement twice and, if he were willing, some team would probably end his retirement a third time.

title: OILERS TIE ISLANDERS ON TWO LATE GOALS
description: The Edmonton Oilers exploded for two goals 21 seconds apart late in the third period and gained a 4-4 tie against the Islanders tonight before a Nassau Coliseum crowd of 16,236, the first sellout since the season opener.

title: THE ISSUE WE ALL MUST FACE
description: A CHILD of the 50's, I used to believe that the ''grown-ups'' were in possession of a truth I was yet to know. They were older, they had experienced life, they knew.

title: BAGPIPE BAND NAMED A CHAMPION
description: ON a clear day, the sound of a bagpipe can carry nearly two miles. That ability, coupled with its exotic drone, at one time made the instrument a formidable psychological weapon. Marching to battle, Scottish soldiers used it to frighten opposing forces.

title: MANY PATIENTS DUE FOR SURGERY STORING OWN BLOOD IN FEAR OF AIDS
description: In the past two months, Rosella Arnold has made five trips to the blood bank at the Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles. Each time she rolled up a sleeve and watched as a nurse inserted a needle into her arm and withdrew blood.

title: ELLEN B. RESNICK TO MARRY BANKER
description: The engagement of Ellen Barbara Resnick and Paul Daniel Lewis has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Stanly I. Resnick of Roslyn, L.I. Mr. Lewis is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter A. Lewis of New York, East Quoque, L.I., and Bakersfield, Calif. The wedding is planned for May.

title: HERE LIE THE HIGH KINGS OF IRELAND
description: The best route to take to Clonmacnoise is probably the one preferred by its destroyers: the Shannon River. You can sail it to the ruined monastery - which was the largest in Celtic Ireland - and dock at a nearby jetty. Or, if you approach by car, coming through County Offaly from the west, you can drive through the ancient town of Shannonbridge and gaze left at the river, which twists with such frequency and definiteness that you feel as if you're above it, or looking at an aerial photograph. The monastery lies just east of a 13th-century castle whose ruins are so tilted and craggy that they resemble a geologic formation more than medieval architecture.

title: RECITAL: RICHARD GOODE
description: THE pianist Richard Goode is a musician's musician, and a substantial number of colleagues came to applaud his Friday night recital at the Metropolitan Museum.

title: DANCE: RACHEL LAMPERT
description: ''LOVE IT, LEAVE IT, LET IT BE LONELY'' was the title of a new dance by Rachel Lampert, which her company performed on Friday at the Nikolais-Louis Studio, 33 East 18th Street. It was hard to guess what the ''it'' referred to.

title: Goal Setting Pays Off
description: EDWARD FOX says his biggest investment to date has been his education. ''That was my first real investment,'' the 25-year-old said. ''And it has paid off pretty well.''

title: DUBLIN OPPOSITION CHIEF ATTACKS ACCORD
description: Ireland's opposition leader, Charles J. Haughey, today attacked the agreement between Britain and the Irish Republic to give Dublin a limited voice in the affairs of Northern Ireland, and he vowed to fight its ratification in Parliament.

title: SYMPHONY MARKS ITS 30TH YEAR
description: THE Garden State Philharmonic Symphony Orchestra, conducted by Robert Hall, will begin its 30th anniversary season with a concert next Sunday at 8 P.M. at Toms River High School North.

title: Reviving History
description: To the Editor:

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: SAINT. By Christine Bell. (Pineapple Press, $14.95.) Meet Rubia, which means ''Blondie'' in Spanish, although Susan didn't know that when her husband, Frederico, gave her the nickname.

title: VOLCANO WARNING TERMED DIFFICULT
description: Volcano specialists said yesterday that without the aid of extensive monitoring devices, such as those emplaced around Mount St. Helens in Washington, it is difficult to assess the likelihood of further major eruptions from the volcano Nevado del Ruiz. They added, however, that such volcanoes typically produce eruptions of lesser and lesser magnitude at intervals of days, weeks or months over periods that may run to several years.

title: FIGHTING NATURAL AND MAN-MADE LAWS
description: NOT every fish is easily cultivated. Cod and haddock are too big and voracious to be reared economically. Sturgeon require fresh water at some parts of their life, salt water at others. Immature lobsters have the inconvenient habit of eating each other. And surf clams are highly vulnerable to predators on the bay bottom.

title: PACIFIC ISLANDERS OCCUPY 'STAR WARS' TEST SITE
description: Militant landowners of Kwajalein atoll in the central Pacific have occupied an island in the atoll that has played a central role in the Reagan Administration's space-defense program. They are protesting the terms offered by the United States for the continued use of their property as a billon-dollar missile testing range.

title: VISITS AT HOME AND AWAY
description: THE UNLOVELY CHILD By Norman Williams. 52 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. Cloth, $13.95. Paper, $6.95. THE UNBORN By Rodney Jones. 79 pp. Boston: The Atlantic Monthly Press. Cloth, $13.95. Paper, $8.95. NEW WORLD ARCHITECTURE By Matthew Graham. 51 pp. Baltimore: Galileo Press. Cloth, $6.50. Paper, $4.50.

title: ROBERT B. FAIBROTHER WEDS BONNIE MEHLIN
description: Bonnie Allen Mehlin, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert C. Mehlin of Chatham, N.J., was married yesterday to Robert Bailey Fairbrother, a son of Mr. and Mrs. LeRoy D. Fairbrother of Egg Harbor, N.J. The Rev. David E. Mulford performed the ceremony at the Presbyterian Church of Chatham Township.

title: MCCLURE HAS BIG NUMBERS BUT FAME REMAINS ELUSIVE
description: BRIAN McCLURE, the quarterback for Bowling Green State University, is neither rich nor famous, although both are possibilities soon. He is not Bernie Kosar.

title: STATE DEPT. IDENTIFIES THOSE EXPECTED TO LEAVE SOVIET
description: The State Department today made public the names of separated spouses of Americans and others in the Soviet Union who, the United States was told, would be given permission to emigrate.

title: Currency Options Offer A Dollar Play
description: FOR the investor who is interested in the foreign-exchange market, currency options afford a convenient way to take a position on whether the dollar will rise or fall within a certain period of time. Given the uncertainty of the dollar's future course, an investor who guesses correctly can reap huge profits. Those who are wrong can lose their entire investment, but unlike the futures market they will never be at risk for more than they have put up originally, and that can be as little as $1,000 or $2,000.

title: JUDGE IN SCHOOL CASE IN BOSTON STEPS ASIDE
description: Federal District Judge W. Arthur Garrity Jr., who spent most of his 19 years on the Federal bench watching over the desegregation of Boston's schools, has decided to limit his work.

title: ANTI-LILCO PARTY AN ELECTION FORCE
description: THE Ratepayers Against Lilco party proved to be a formidable force in the elections in Suffolk County.

title: AFTER SCHOOL BUS DEATH, NEW CALL FOR SEAT BELTS
description: The death of a Mahopac boy in an unusual school-bus accident last month has given new impetus to efforts to obtain a state law requiring seat belts in school buses.

title: MUSIC: 'THE CURCIBLE,' BY OPERA ENSEMBLE
description: ARTHUR MILLER'S play, ''The Crucible,'' makes for stirring drama, its vision of hysteria and cruel injustice during the Salem witch trials ominously set against another real-life contemporary drama: The play was first produced in 1953, at the height of the McCarthy hearings. And Robert Ward's opera of the same name counts as one of the most powerfully affecting of all American operas, capitalizing on the play's strengths and adding a striking musical subtext.

title: CALIFORNIA'S OTHER WINE COUNTRY
description: A hundred years ago there were dozens of wineries in the Santa Cruz Mountain region of central California. After the ax of Prohibition fell in 1919, nearly all of them shut, and stayed shut while vineyards were neglected or torn out.

title: CARE FOR THE POOR
description: To the Editor:

title: Reviving History
description: To the Editor:

title: O'ROURKE BLAMES AID CUTS FOR NEED TO RAISE TAXES
description: COUNTY EXECUTIVE Andrew P. O'Rourke, despite an overwhelming re-election victory, was in a sober mood last week. ''Things look bleak for 1986,'' he said, referring to a proposed county budget carrying an 11 percent tax increase.

title: PANCAKES WITH A FLOURISH
description: The French have crepes, Russians blini, Belgians waffles, and Americans flapjacks, griddle cakes or pancakes.

title: A Supporter Of Latin Study
description: I was delighted to read the article that mentioned the workshop that was jointly sponsored by the State University at Stony Brook and the Suffolk County Latin Teachers Association [''Rise in Latin Study Outpaces Teachers,'' Oct 27] .

title: ABOVE ALL, AT THE SUMMIT
description: A Soviet-American summit is not a duel. If Ronald Reagan and Mikhail Gorbachev expect to wound each other in Geneva this week by force of argument or personality, they are wasting their time. Both are riding high politically and can easily survive a propaganda battle about human rights or third-world revolutions. And both are shielded by bureaucracies that will protect them against making any damaging concessions.

title: Medical Panel Finds A Doubling of Cases Of Whooping Cough
description: Cases of whooping cough among American children, some of them fatal, have nearly doubled in three years as parents, wary of possible side effects of the vaccine against the disease, have apparently chosen not to immunize their children, medical experts say.

title: L.I.'S PLACE IN JAPAN'S PAST
description: A HISTORIC link between Japan and Long Island -one most remembered, perhaps, by the Japanese -was reinforced last month when Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone visited Sagamore Hill, the Oyster Bay Victorian mansion that Theodore Roosevelt built a century ago.

title: FRED SLATER, ACCOUNTANT, MARRIED TO CAROL LAZARE
description: Carol Lazare, the daughter of Ray Lazare of New York and the late Paul Lazare, was married yesterday to Fred Slater, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bert Slater of Southampton, L.I. Family Court Judge Michael Ambrosio officiated at the Terrace Restaurant.

title: TRAUTMAN IS WINNER
description: John Trautman of Monroe-Woodbury High School won the New York State Federation Cross-Country Championship in 15 minutes 44.2 seconds, and led his team to second place in the meet yesterday at Sunken Meadow Park in Kings Park, L.I.

title: A JOURNEY BACK TO WHERE IT ALL BEGAN
description: Like William Blake, who saw the world in a grain of sand, scientists today discern the story of the universe in the infinitesimal particles inside every atom known as quarks, leptons and gluons. In a union as startling as it is sublime, cosmologists studying the heavens and physicists studying the smallest units of matter and energy are trading discoveries. The fruits of this collaboration are explored in ''The Creation of the Universe,'' a 90-minute special to be shown Wednesday evening at 9 on Channel 13.

title: THE INDUSTRY IS SHAKING OUT BAD MANAGERS, NOT BAD BANKS
description: JUST as Texas has not been exempt from the difficulties facing bankers all over the country, nither has its banking commissioner, James L. Sexton. Known throughout the industry as a highly effective regulator, Mr. Sexton closed the Northshore Bank of Houston earlier this month, making it the 100th American bank to suffer that fate this year. Almost all of them had become insolvent as a result of heavy losses from real estate, energy and agricultural lending. And the failures continue. On Thursday, the 101st insolvent bank of the year - the First National Bank of Teague, Tex. - was shut down by the Comptroller of the Currency, the regulator of nationally chartered banks. In an interview last week with Nathaniel C. Nash, a reporter for The New York Times, Mr. Sexton discussed banking regulation, Texas style.

title: Headliners;   SUCCESSION
description: The Brigham Young University yearbook of 1927 named Ezra Taft Benson ''most likely to succeed.'' Any lingering doubts about the prediction were surely eliminated last week when Mr. Benson was named the temporal and spiritual leader of the Mormon Church.

title: WHY CABLE TV NEEDS A FREE MARKET
description: THIS week the Supreme Court decided to hear a landmark First Amendment suit that has thrown the cable television industry into a legal quandary. If the Court upholds the decision of the Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit in Preferred Communications v. City of Los Angeles, municipalities will lose the power to issue monopoly franchises to cable operators, and existing franchisees will face open competition for cable viewers.

title: COLLABORATION
description: SINCE HE WAS 16, SAM WATTERS HAS HAD A PENCHANT for Biedermeier furniture - those solid, forthright objects that German and Austrian artisans crafted in the first half of the 19th century with blond fruitwoods and decorated with ebony details.

title: BIG ORDERS CHALLENGE BRIDGEPORT BAKER
description: WHEN John DiMarco of Luigi's Bakery in Bridgeport received an order recently for a wedding cake to serve 425 people, he began designing the elaborately decorated Italian rum cake. It did not matter that the wedding was in Wisconsin.

title: CLEARING THE AIR: A FIRST FOR MOSCOW SINCE '80
description: The cessation of Soviet jamming on three radio frequencies during President Reagan's speech to the Soviet Union marked the first time since 1980 that there had been no interference with a broadcast of the Voice of America, Administration officials say.

title: BELLE FRANCE
description: To the Editor: For years we have heard from both travelers and nontravelers how cold, anti-American and rude the French are, with regard to American tourists. We've been to France now four times and have found the French to be pretty much like everyone else - some rude, some nice, some indifferent, But I feel impelled to write about two extraordinary experiences we have had on two widely separate occasions in France.

title: FRIENDS OF ARTHUR ROTHSTEIN RECALL THE CRAFTSMAN AND THE MENTOR
description: ARTHUR ROTHSTEIN took his most famous photograph when he was 21 years old, yet he devoted the rest of his life to the profession, mastering virtually all the styles and techniques of photography. But the photojournalist, who died last Monday at his home in New Rochelle, at the age of 70, is most remembered and appreciated by his colleagues for his willingness to share his knowledge with others in a profession in which strong egos constantly compete with each other.

title: MISS GILBANE HAS WEDDING
description: Helen A. Gilbane, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William James Gilbane of Providence, R.I., was married there yesterday to Angus Lett Macdonald, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James E. Macdonald Jr. of Bristol, R.I. Bishop Louis E. Gelineau of Providence performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Cathedral of SS. Peter and Paul.

title: IRREVERENCE REVERED
description: Eddie Murphy's comic personality is brashly irreverent, and sometimes iconoclastic and subversive even when his characters seem to succumb to authority. The star of movies like ''Beverly Hills Cop'' thus becomes the envy of every timidly rebellious high-school kid and their No. 1 hero, according to a national survey of 4,000 teen-agers.

title: PAPLUM JACKETS' FLAIR
description: ITS distinctive tucked waist gives the peplum jacket a most satisfying flair. The dramatic silhouette of a chic, slim woman in a peplum - a frequent sight in the 1940's -was a proven head-turner.

title: HELP FOR A TROUBLED NEIGHBORHOOD
description: THERE was no light switch to flick on and no banister to hold as Glenda Lowe walked down the rickety stairs of her rooming house in Hempstead Heights three months ago. Halfway down, she said, she slipped and cracked a rib.

title: CHAMBER: WAVERLY CONSORT PERFORMS
description: IN its own temperate, understated manner, the music of the Elizabethan composer William Byrd can have a profound effect on a listener. Thursday night at Alice Tully Hall, the Waverly Consort, under the artistic direction of Michael Jaffee, presented an engaging sampler of Byrd's sacred and secular works for voices and instruments.

title: 101 DAYS IN SOUTH AFRICAN JAIL LEAVE ACTIVIST STILL RESOLUTE
description: It was winter when she was taken and summer when she returned, and not only the seasons had changed.

title: CHALLENGE TO O'NEILL
description: In Connecticut, Gov. William A. O'Neill was challenged last week by a member of his own party. Toby Moffett, a former Representative, said he would seek the Democratic gubernatorial nomination next year. Mr. Moffett, who is 41 years old, called Connecticut ''an extraordinary state with an ordinary state government,'' and said that he could provide ''fresh and dynamic leadership.''

title: BEST SELLERS
description: Nov. 17, 1985 Fiction

title: FROM BLUE NOTE, JAZZ BY BECHET
description: Although Blue Note Records, one of the earliest and most influential record labels devoted to jazz, is now thought of primarily as a seedbed for such stars of the bop and post-bop periods as Thelonious Monk, Bud Powell, Horace Silver, Sonny Rollins, Jimmy Smith, Clifford Brown, Miles Davis and John Coltrane, the label began its life in 1939 with a series of boogie-woogie records by the pianists Albert Ammons and Pete Johnson. Until the mid-40's, when its emphasis shifted to the jazz musicians and styles that were emerging at the end of World War II, it continued to concentrate on older jazz styles - blues and small-group swing.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: WITNESSES AT THE CREATION: Hamilton, Madison, Jay, and the Constitution. By Richard B. Morris. (Holt, $16.95.) The bicentennial of the Constitution is approaching, and the celebration promises to be more scholarly than festive.

title: OSSINING
description: IN the 1930's and 40's, Jimmy Cagney and other movie gangsters immortalized being ''sent up the river'' to Sing Sing Prison in Ossining as the fate of the worst criminals. But the quiet, attractive and moderately wealthy Hudson Valley village of 21,000 residents belies this nefarious reputation.

title: SOMETHING OLD, SOMETHING NEW
description: HAVING decided that it was time to replace 18 subway-tunnel fans installed in 1912, the Transit Authority soon discovered that new was not necessarily better than old.

title: THE DEADLY TORRENTS OF MUD IN COLOMBIA
description: AFTER smoldering for months, the Nevada del Ruiz volcano in northern Colombia erupted last week in a roar of dark smoke, steam and ash. More than 21,000 people were killed or missing, officials said, after walls of gray mud 15 feet high crashed down valleys lush with rice and coffee, burying thousands of buildings in more than a dozen communities.

title: MUTUAL FUNDS -- OFFERINGS FOR ALL: SALES BOOM AS VARIETIES PROLIFERATE
description: BY almost any measure, the mutual fund industry is experiencing an unprecedented boom. The public has discovered mutual funds and mutual funds have discovered the public.

title: GRESCHNER GOAL TIES MONTREAL
description: For long stretches tonight, the Rangers became all the things that their new coach, Ted Sator, does not want them to be. They were undisciplined, lacking in cohesiveness and - of all things - not smart with the puck. But they can still play a workingman's game, and that kept them above water.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: FATHER AND SON. By F. Forrester Church. (Harper & Row, $15.95.) Offspring often are savage or saccharine, whining or windy in memoirs about their parents.

title: FESTIVE VESPERS MUSIC BY MONTEVERDI
description: Among all the clear advantages of digital compact disks over conventional LP records, which is the most striking? The convenience of the format cannot be gainsaid: A small disk that need not be turned over is ideal for an age marked by shrinking storage space and growing slothfulness. On the other hand, manufacturers as a group have not yet fulfilled the promise of CD's packed solid with over 70 minutes of music, and many listeners do not consider the improvement in musical reproduction to be earth-shaking -given always that the LP version is in good condition.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: MRS. DEMMING AND THE MYTHICAL BEAST. By Faith Sullivan. (Macmillan, $16.95.) Lately Larissa Demming, a housewife, mother and sometime painter, has been ''awash in unsettlement.''

title: RHODE ISLAND WINS, 56-42
description: Tom Ehrhardt threw for 566 yards and eight touchdowns as Rhode Island outlasted Connecticut, 56-42, today. Ehrhardt, the 6-foot-3-inch, 210-pound senior, broke the single-game New England college passing yardage record set by Doug Flutie at Boston College when he had 520 yards against Penn State in 1982.

title: U.N.'S CHIEF URGES JOB EQUITY FOR ITS WOMEN
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 15 -Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar has announced that he is committed to correct what he called ''severe disparities in women's representation'' on the professional level at the United Nations.

title: FROM SPAIN, 10 CENTURIES OF BOOKS
description: A MILLENNIUM of Spanish civilization is proclaimed, soundlessly, in the thousands of pages of 200 unusual books now on display at the New York Public Library, at Fifth Avenue and 42d Street. It is an awesome display of knowledge and fancy that fills the cases and walls of the Gottesman Exhibition Hall, an effusion of culture that includes ancient Korans and Hebrew Bibles, letters by Christopher Columbus, literature by Cervantes and Lorca and art by Miro and Dali.

title: Soviet Team Beats U.S. in Volleyball
description: The Soviet Union put up a strong defense to beat the United States, 15-6, 13-15, 15-12, 15-6, today in a 10-nation men's volleyball tournament and advanced to the final with France.

title: CABARET: BARRETT, AT JAKE'S
description: THE singer and pianist Chris Barrett is one of the more engaging young performers to carry on an elegant piano-bar tradition typified by entertainers like Bobby Short, Steve Ross and Ronny Whyte. Mr. Barrett, who is appearing in an extended engagement at Jake's (801 Second Avenue, at 43d Street), possesses a polished lyric baritone with an interestingly rapid vibrato.

title: 'HOW DO YOU FEEL ABOUT OUR CAREER?' GO AWAY,' HE SAID
description: Durang: Tell me, why are you interviewing yourself instead of having someone else do it?

title: HARVARD'S DEFENSE UPSETS PENN, 17-6
description: Penn's march through the Ivy League that began wo years ago came to an abrupt halt in Harvard Stadium today. Harvard shut down the defending league champions for 59 minutes as the Crimson pulled off the Ivy upset of the year with a 17-6 victory.

title: ALL-STAR CABARET TO BENEFIT YIVO INSTITUTE
description: JOSEPH PAPP will sing Irving Berlin's ''Russian Lullaby,'' and Joseph Wiseman and his wife, Pearl Lang, will read excerpts from Isaac Bashevis Singer's Nobel Prize acceptance speech, along with the poems of Kadia Molodowsky. The saxophonist Stan Getz will head a ''Jewish all-star'' jazz ensemble that includes Mel Lewis (drums), Harvie Swartz (bass) and Phil Markowitz (piano), and Elizabeth Swados will lead two dozen performers in an excerpt from her multilingual oratorio ''Jerusalem.''

title: NANCY'S DARK AND VIOLENT LOVE
description: A GLIMPSE OF SION'S GLORY By Isabel Colegate. 153 pp. New York: Elisabeth Sifton Books/ Viking. $14.95.

title: A HARVEST OF DIALECTS IN THE SOUTH
