description: It was somewhere along Thomas Creek, not far from Bristol, Tenn., that Lee Pederson first learned about tommytoes. ''You don't really call them tommytoes, do you?'' Mr. Pederson asked an old farmer.

title: J.B. HUTTLINGER JR. WEDS KAREN COLE
description: At St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church in New York yesterday Karen Louise Cole, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James S. Cole of Fairfield, Conn., was married to John B. Huttlinger Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Huttlinger of Lake Placid, N.Y. The Rev. Edward Hogan performed the ceremony.

title: COLLECTORS OF HANDEL HAVE REASON TO REJOICE
description: This has been a banner year for Handel, as the music world has marked the 300th anniversary of his birth.

title: A FIELD NATURALIST IN A STARCHED COLLAR
description: FOR 60 years, William T. Davis wandered the fields and beaches of Staten Island, a quaint little man as conspicuous for his crinkly smile and bristly mustache as for his ever-present butterfly net and specimen bag.

title: DR. MACHLOWITZ PLANS TO MARRY
description: Dr. Marilyn M. Machlowitz and Edward C. Katz plan to be married in January, the parents of the bride-to-be, Mr. and Mrs. Roy A. Machlowitz of Glenside, Pa., have announced. Mr. Katz is the son of Mrs. Nathan R. Katz of Oceanside, L.I., and the late Mr. Katz.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: SPACE TIME INFINITY: The Smithsonian Views the Universe. By James S. Trefil. (Pantheon/Smithsonian Books, $29.95.) ''Space Time Infinity'' is a richly illustrated tour of the night sky and its secrets.

title: LEFT TO OUR OWN DEVICES, WE CREATE A NOISY WORLD
description: ''I'M going out to rake the leaves so I can mow the lawn,'' my husband announced.

title: JOBLESSNESS IN MASSACHUSETTS DROPS AND, WITH HELP, SO DO WELFARE ROLLS
description: Declining unemployment does not necessarily mean declining welfare rolls, according to officials in Massachusetts, who proudly assert that they have both.

title: ELIZABETH EVANS TO WED LAWYER
description: Mr. and Mrs. Donald J. Evans of Cohasset, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Hendrik Evans, to Randall Wayne Bodner, a son of Elsie M. Bodner of Danville, Ky., and Jack K. Bodner of Corning, N.Y. The wedding is planned May 31. The future bride is an alumna of Milton Academy.

title: JENNIFER GORDON BECOMES A BRIDE
description: The Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More was the setting in New York yesterday for the marriage of Jennifer Anne Gordon, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin F. Gordon of Newport Beach, Calif., to Stephen Lucian Schweich, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Schweich of New York. The Rev. Stanley Moseley performed the ceremony.

title: Youth Dew Did It
description: THE beauty industry, a ferociously competitive enterprise masquerading as comic opera, has been staging this year's fall tournament on the battlefields of publishing. And why not? The book business, of late, has borrowed strategies from the marketers of packaged goods such as cosmetics and fragrances - pre-selling products with brand-name identification. Preferably celebrity names.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS
description: Nov. 17, 1985 Fiction

title: SHIPPING QUARANTINE EASED FOR MOST FLORIDA NURSERIES
description: A quarantine on sales and shipments from most of Florida's 900 citrus nurseries has been eased, but new measures have been announced in the state's 14-month battle against citrus canker.

title: USING VOUCHERS TO OFFER THE POOR A CHOICE OF SCHOOLS
description: EDUCATION Secretary William J. Bennett is urging Congress to give poor families Federal aid in the form of vouchers that could be used by their children at private or public schools. He sent a draft bill to Congress last week, predicting that it would fare better than a similar proposal offered by the Reagan Administration in 1983. Here are some questions and answers about the voucher plan.

title: TEACH OR TREAT
description: WHEN CHILDREN DON'T LEARN Understanding the Biology and Psychology of Learning Disabilities. By Diane McGuinness. Illustrated. 310 pp. New York: Basic Books. $19.95.

title: DVORAK'S MELODIC GIFTS ENLIVEN THE QUARTETS
description: Antonin Dvorak was a relatively prolific composer in almost all areas, including chamber music. Part of the latter output included 14 string quartets, which cover practically the full span of his creative life. What is astonishing is the average high quality of these works. Although the earliest ones are flawed, all the quartets show the same qualities that set Dvorak off as a major composer - his natural talent as a melodist, as a reflector of his Czechoslovak heritage, as a builder on his great predecessors and as a knowledgeable writer for strings (he played both the violin and viola). These qualities have made his music both popular and critically satisfying.

title: NOW, THE LOWER EAST SIDE'S TURN
description: WITH the Board of Estimate's approval last month of the sale of two vacant buildings on the Lower East Side to a development company, the Koch administration has launched its ambitious Cross-Subsidy Program in Manhattan.

title: STATE IS CHALLENGING NEW MORTGAGES
description: SINCE mortgages with biweekly payments were introduced in this country last year by a Connecticut bank, four other banks in the state have begun offering similar loan plans and hundreds of residents have signed up because of the interest savings.

title: 25 YEARS OF MAKING MUSIC SOUND BETTER
description: CHRISTOPHER JAFFE does his job too well for some musicians. ''It's too good, you can hear all my mistakes,'' they say.

title: FINDING A FOREST
description: In the years since it was founded, St. Paul's Church has been the setting of historic events, including those that helped to establish the First Amendment rights of religion, speech, press and assembly. It has been used as a courthouse and as a hospital for Hessian soldiers; President John Adams worshipped there in 1797 when the First Family moved to Westchester during a yellow fever epidemic in Philadelphia.

title: PUPPETS TELL YOUNG ABOUT HANDICAPS
description: MARK RILEY, an 11-year-old with cerebral palsy, pops ''wheelies'' in his wheelchair as he talks to other children about what it is like to be handicapped. Renaldo Rodriquez, a blind 9-year-old, describes the special baseball with a built-in buzzer he uses.

title: CHURCHES ARE HOST TO CONCERTS GALORE
description: SOME of the most interesting music-making in Connecticut takes place in churches.

title: The Permissive Dutch
description: Richard Reeves's account of left-wing politics and liberal policies toward ''fringe groups'' in the Netherlands was informative and consistent with our recollections of a year's residence there a decade ago (''The Permissive Dutch,'' Oct. 20).

title: ALISON SPEAR PLANS TO WED
description: Dr. and Mrs. Harold Charles Spear of Miami Shores, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter Alison Leelyn Spear to Campion Acheson Platt, the son of Dennis Covel Platt Dickson and the late Jeremy Acheson Platt of Washington. A March wedding is planned.

title: MUSEUM THEFTS IN DELAWARE
description: IN the rolling countryside outside Wilmington, Del., the renowned Winterthur Museum has a mystery on its hands: How much of its 71,000-piece collection of early Americana is missing and who took it?

title: MEDICAL STUDENTS HELP PHILADELPHIA HOMELESS
description: A Peace Corps stint in Tonga taught Amy Sisley something about human need, but she was not prepared to find so much of it at her doorstep when she enrolled in the University of Pennsylvania School of Medicine.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: MOON TIGER By Phyllis Root. Illustrated by Ed Young. Unpaged. New York: Holt, Rinehart & Winston. $12.95. (Ages 4 to 8) THE NIGHT FLIGHT By Joanne Ryder. Illustrated by Amy Schwartz. Unpaged. New York: Four Winds Press/ Macmillan Publishing Company. $11.95. (Ages 4 to 8) A WINTER JOURNEY By David Updike. Illustrated by Robert Andrew Parker. Unpaged. Englewood Cliffs, N.J.: Prentice-Hall. $12.95. (Ages 7 and up) WINTER MAGIC By Eveline Hasler. Illustrated by Michele Lemieux. Unpaged. New York: William Morrow & Company. $11.75. (Ages 4 to 8) ANY parent who's discovered a groggy 2-year-old, the same child who might quite casually have witnessed the preparation of a lobster dinner, now screaming and literally climbing the walls to get away from a cribful of giant, writhing arthropods, knows that you don't read just any old book to your children before they go to sleep. What to read, when and what for, has been a bone of contention for decades, ever since psychologists began to suspect that books like the 19th-century ''Struwwelpeter'' (''Slovenly Peter''), in which children are graphically punished in both words and picture for various misdemeanors (such as sucking a thumb or refusing to eat supper) by having their thumbs cut off or eyes pecked out, are a form of child abuse. So what's a parent to do when we read to our children or tell them bedtime stories? Are we supposed to soothe, educate, moralize, or stupefy?

title: New & Noteworthy
description: THE STRUCTURES OF EVERYDAY LIFE: The Limits of the Possible, by Fernand Braudel. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $16.95.) ''The Structures of Everyday Life'' is Volume One of an economic history of Europe titled ''Civilization and Capitalism: 15th-18th Century.'' Fernand Braudel writes about people's food, buildings, furniture, clothes, roads and energy sources. In 1982 our reviewer, Paul Robinson, speculated that Mr. Braudel's fellow professionals would consider him the greatest living historian and said reading him on material life ''is to experience the past anew.'' FOREIGN AFFAIRS, by Alison Lurie. (Avon, $3.95.) A 54-year-old professor of English, a Southern businessman she meets on a trans-Atlantic flight, a young American faculty member at a London university and an aristocratic English television actress constitute the cast of ''Foreign Affairs,'' for which Alison Lurie won this year's Pulitzer Prize for fiction. In her review here Anne Bernays noted the intelligence evident in the novel while disapproving of the author's omniscience. A DEATH OF ONE'S OWN, by Gerda Lerner. (University of Wisconsin, $7.95.) Gerda Lerner, a historian and feminist, describes the death of her husband, Carl Lerner, a film editor who died in 1973, 18 months after the discovery of a brain tumor. Our reviewer, Helen Yglesias, wrote in 1978 that this was ''a beautifully controlled account'' of an attempt to enact, in Rilke's words, ''a well-crafted death.'' MISS PEABODY'S INHERITANCE, by Elizabeth Jolley. (Penguin, $5.95.) In ''Miss Peabody's Inheritance,'' an Australian who wrote a lesbian romance corresponds with one of her readers, Dorothy Peabody, an unmarried fiftyish typist who lives in England with her bedridden mother.

title: SPAIN'S TAPAS BECOMING INTERNATIONAL
description: SEVERAL years ago, when on tour in Spain with a ballet company, I learned to appreciate the Spanish tradition of tapas. Our schedule was arduous: we traveled by bus to a different town each day, often arriving late in the afternoon and always confronted with performances that did not begin until 11 o'clock at night. Because pirouettes and grand jetes don't work particularly well on a full stomach, we never saw dinner before 2 A.M. So we survived on tapas.

title: HEWLETT BETS THE STORE ON SPECTRUM
description: LIKE most of its Silicon Valley neighbors, the Hewlett-Packard Company is in the grip of an austerity program. Since July, its factories have been shut down two days a month, paychecks of most of the company's 85,000 employees have been reduced and hiring any new employee requires highest-level approval.

title: MISUNDERSTOOD CHINESE SILVER ON VIEW
description: IT is only within the last 15 or 20 years that collectors have rediscovered Chinese Export silver, says Robert Egleston, curator of the New Haven Historical Society Museum, adding, ''It's important to understanding our own late 18th- and 19th-century society.''

title: LANDLORDS MOVE TOHALT ILLEGAL SUBLETS
description: THE Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, which built an entire neighborhood of moderately priced rental apartments on the East Side just above 14th Street 38 years ago, is now renting apartments to people who have been on the waiting list since 1971.

title: WHY THE U.N. ANNIVERSARY DECLARATION FAILED
description: To the Editor:

title: LET'S GIVE EVEN YUPPIE PARENTS A BREAK
description: To the Editor:

title: PLANTS THAT URN SEWAGE TO ENERGY
description: TUCKED in a corner of the 27,000-acre Walt Disney World complex near Orlando, Fla., is a pond with large green leaves resembling water lilies floating on top. The leaves, which belong to the water hyacinth, are not only there to spruce up the Magic Kingdom; they are also part of a two-pronged experimental program to dispose of waste and produce methane gas.

title: KATHERINE FORD OF MODELING AGENCY IS THE BRIDE OF ANDRE TOMES BALAZS
description: St. Thomas Episcopal Church was the setting in New York yesterday for the marriage of Mary Katherine Ford, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gerard William Ford of New York and Greenfield Hill, Conn., to Andre Tomes Balazs, the son of Dr. Endre A. Balazs of New York and St. Tropez, France, and Dr. Eva K. Balazs of Cambridge, Mass. The Rev. Gary P. Fertig performed the ceremony.

title: BRITON TO MEET WITH BEIRUT CAPTORS OF AMERICANS
description: Terry Waite, a special representative of the Archbishop of Canterbury, said today that he had made arrangements to talk directly with the captors of four Americans held in Lebanon.

title: FIRST LADIES: TEATIME DIPLOMACY?
description: It is a personal meeting, said a friend of Nancy Reagan, a chance for two women to get together, talk and get to know each other.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: BY THE OPEN SEA. By August Strindberg. Translated by Mary Sandbach. (University of Georgia, $15.95.) This odd novel, written in 1889 and 1890, when Strindberg had already produced some of his best-known plays, veers erratically from wooden, pedagogical prose to luminous descriptions of nature.

title: OCEAN CITY STARTS BUILDING A PROMENADE
description: CONSTRUCTION has begun on a $2 million promenade here, thus marking the most extensive renovation of the Ocean City Boardwalk in more than 20 years.

title: ON STAGE IN JAPAN, TRUTH IS OFTEN SOUGHT IN FANTASY
description: Beyond Kabuki and Noh, beyond Japanese adaptations of Western classics and Broadway musicals, there is the country's nontraditional theater. It is a young person's theater, in its themes, actors, writers, directors and audience and in what it says about Japan.

title: LEGISLATURE LOSING ENVIRONMENTAL CADRE
description: ENVIRONMENTALISTS lost key backers in the Assembly in the Nov. 5 election, and the consequences, environmental leaders say, could prove troublesome for some pending and future legislation while having little effect on other important measures.

title: DIRTY VERY OLD MAN
description: ILLYWHACKER By Peter Carey. 600 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $18.95.

title: SEARCH FOR FIVE IN L.I. SOUND IS SUSPENDED BY COAST GUARD
description: The Coast Guard yesterday suspended a 20-hour search of Long Island Sound for five people on a pleasure boat that was reported sinking Friday night. Officials, still uncertain whether the incident had been genuine, said late last night that they planned to resume searching today.

title: U.S. Island Territories Grow At Faster Rate Than Mainland
description: The populations of most of the nation's island territories have increased considerably faster than the nation as a whole, the Census Bureau has reported.

title: IN GRENADA, LIFE IS QUIET, HOPE IS HIGH
description: A little more than two years after American troops landed on Grenada, this little Caribbean island is trying to revitalize an economy that had shriveled under the leftist regime. Many Americans and other foreigners who frequent Grenada say they consider it ideal for lazing in the sun. Its admirers love it for its simplicity and informality. Grenada's natural beauty and quiet atmosphere recall what much of the Caribbean may have been like before tourism started to become a big business here 20 to 30 years ago.

title: MIDAIR COLLISIONS OVER NEW JERSEY
description: The central question after last Sunday's collision of two private planes over New Jersey was how two pilots, each of whom had been warned about the other's presence, could knock each othe out of the sky.

title: NANCY ABENDSHOEN TO WED B. R., DUKE
description: The engagement of Nancy Ann Abendshoen to Barclay Robertson Duke has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Edgar J. Abendshoen of Point Pleasant Beach, L.I., parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is a son of Anthony D. Duke of Glen Head, L.I., and Mrs. Hunter Goodrich Jr. of New York.

title: TROUBLED CASINO POSES NEW REGULATORY ISSUE
description: When the Atlantis Casino Hotel petitioned for protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy code last week, it posed a new regulatory problem for the New Jersey Casino Control Commission.

title: INDUSTRIAL OUTPUT STATIC IN OCTOBER
description: Martin J. Mauro, senior economist for Merrill Lynch Economics, gave the consensus view of the week's principal economic statistic, a disappointing flatness in the Federal Reserve's index of industrial production for October. ''Some people,'' Mr. Mauro said, ''overestimated the effect of the employment figures'' that had showed exceptionally strong growth in nonfarm jobs last month.

title: LYNDHURST TRIUMPHS
description: Undefeated Lyndhurst, headed for the North Jersey, Section 1, Group 2 playoffs, won its eighth game yesterday with a 13-0 shutout of Becton in Lyndhurst.

title: A HOMETOWN TEAM
description: Fourteen countries competed in last month's World Championships in Sao Paulo, Brazil, and as many more were represented in other capacities: officials, journalists and spectators.

title: FITNESS ON THE ROAD, CALIFORNIA RESORT
description: Guide to Health Clubs Not all motion burns calories. Many an individual who is on the move, on the run or on the road is chalking up high mileage without achieving any of the benefits of exercise.

title: OHIO STATE STUNNED
description: Air Force's 13-game winning streak and any hopes it had for a final top-ranking this season were ended today by the arm of Robbie Bosco.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: As Stupid as Tom Eliot For something like 50 years, Janet Flanner was a legend, the Paris correspondent of The New Yorker. In ''Darlinghissima: Letters to a Friend'' (Random House), edited by Natalia Danesi Murray, Miss Flanner describes her meeting with Djuna Barnes, ''the most important woman writer we had in Paris.''

title: OUTLOOK FOR SCALLOPS AND BAYMEN IS GLOOMY
description: IN most Long Island waters, the scallop-harvesting season is only a month old, yet for baymen on the East End it is virtually over. They have discovered that approximately 90 percent of the scallop crop was destroyed by last summer's mysterious algae bloom.

title: BLEND ON EAST 74th
description: A 25-story cooperative apartment building, one of the last to be built the old Upper East Side zoning rules, is rising on a midblock site on East 74th Street between First and Second Avenues next door to the Hellenic Eastern Orthodox Church.

title: JOHN SPARKMAN, 85, EX-SENATOR, DIES
description: Former Senator John J. Sparkman, the Democratic Vice-Presidential nominee in 1952, died of a heart attack early yesterday at Big Springs Manor Nursing Home in Huntsville, Ala. He was 85 years old.

title: MANAGING YOUR INVESTMENTS: FINDING THE RIGHT BANK OR BROKER
description: CAROLINE D., a musician who lives on Manhattan's Upper West Side, is in love with her Shearson Lehman Brothes financial management account. ''They just do so much for you!'' she exclaimed. Caroline preferred that her last name not be used, because she thinks she is taking advantage of Shearson Lehman and fears her account might be canceled if she is found out.

title: WEDDING PLANNED BY JENNIFER LUCE
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Dudley Gordon Luce Jr. of Rye, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter Jennifer Susan Luce to William Wilson Taylor, a son of the Rev. and Mrs. Walter Hamilton Taylor of Darien, Conn. A May wedding is planned.

title: COMING OF AGE, GOING TO PIECES
description: LONG WITH YOUTH Hemingway, the Early Years. By Peter Griffin. Illustrated. 258 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $17.95. HEMINGWAY A Biography. By Jeffrey Meyers. Illustrated. 644 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $27.50.

title: CANDIDATES BEGIN THEIR MANEUVERS FOR BATTLES OF '86
description: WITH the dust barely settled from the municipal elections across Connecticut on Nov. 5, the campaigning began in earnest last week for statewide offices in 1986.

title: Stop Knocking Students
description: It's high time someone spoke up for today's college students. They're probably the most industrious, ambitious people in America and their problems are not being properly appreciated.

title: RESIGNATION IN PHILADELPHIA
description: Eighteen days of public hearings on Philadelphia's attempt last May to evict armed members of the radical group Move from a fortified house in a middle-class neighborhood ended in a tangle two weeks ago. Last week, the ramifications grew, as the man who directed the aerial bombing, Police Commissioner Gregore J. Sambor, resigned.

title: WHEN WINDS HOWL: TIPS FOR KEEPING OUT DRAFTS
description: THERE are many steps the wise homeowner can take to plug heat leaks that contribute greatly to the amount of fuel wasted in winter. In addition to adding insulation to attics, basement walls, heating ducts and hot water pipes, as discussed last week, most are simple do-it-yourself projects.

title: GUARDING COUNTY'S ARCHEOLOGICAL PAST
description: ''WE'RE trying to educate people about archeology - the need to preserve what little is left of Westchester,'' said Dr. Allen Vegotsky, president of Material Archives and Laboratory for Archeology, an organization involved in the archeological investigation of the county's past.

title: Newsletters For Investors Abound
description: SOME 1,000 market letters roam the investment universe - and the gulf that separates the best of Wall Street's advice from the worst is wide enough to swallow many an unwary investor.

title: THE DANCE: CLASSICAL INDIAN FARE
description: INDRANI and Sukanya are persuasive advocates of Indian classical dancing. On Thursday, at the Theater of the Riverside Church, the mother-and-daughter team of dancers presented a program in the Kuchipudi, Bharata Natyam and Orissi styles that was informative and charming.

title: ALICE L. MARSHALL PLANS TO MARRY MARK R. ELLIS
description: Alice Lee Marshall, director of public relations for the Cunard Line in New York, and Mark Richard Ellis, president of CBS Toys International in Secaucus, N.J., plan to be married in February.

title: ACTIVITIES PLANNED FOR SMOKEOUT DAY
description: IN the effort to get people to stop smoking, National Smokeout Day Thursday will be a ''fun day'' around the state, say officials of the American Cancer Society.

title: ILLUSTRATORS DRAW ON THE INNER CHILD
description: THE work of Jane Breskin Zalben and Petra Mathers, two of the three artists featured in ''A Sense of Wonderment: Children's Book Illustration,'' which opens today at Huntington's Heckscher Museum, differs substantially in style and content. But they do agree on some fundamentals about their art.

title: TAX REFORMERS OFFER NO HELP FOR SAVERS
description: To the Editor:

title: Eglevsky School Lives On
description: Andre Eglevsky may have been ''out of the picture'' [''Role Reversal in New Ballet Poses Challenge to Dancers,'' Oct. 20] when Frank Ohman started his dancing school, but the Eglevsky School of Ballet lives on, directed by his wife, Leda Eglevsky.

title: MIRIAM WESTHEIMER TO MARRY IN JUNE
description: Mr. and Mrs. Manfred Westheimer of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miriam Yael Westheimer, to Joel Henry Einleger, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Hyman Einleger of New York. A June wedding is planned.

title: NACAR TITLE ON LINE TODAY
description: The National Association for Stock Car Auto Racing wraps up its season today at Riverside, Calif., with the running of the Western 500. For the seventh consecutive year, the championship will be decided by the final event in an arduous, 10-month season.

title: CHILD OF THE '80'S PRESSES A FATHER TO PLAY HIS ROLE
description: THE liberal posture I acquired in the battles of the 1960's keeps me from wearing my fatherhood as neatly and as conveniently as other fellows. My sons, who are all but full grown, suffered under a parent with an urge to free them rather than to hold them.

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: MIXING magic with a dash of chemistry has spelled success in the world of entertainment for ''The Amazing Ronzo.''

title: CORRECTION
description: A caption with an article Oct. 20 about Tuscany incorrectly described a church in Spoleto as the church of San Eufemia. It is the Duomo (cathedral).

title: A New Attack On Alcoholism
description: Researchers and therapists are finding that flotation helps alcoholics to stop drinking and remain sober. The flotation tank is an enclosed chamber about the size of a single bed.

title: JOBS FOR YOUNG PEOPLE ON ISLAND GO BEGGING
description: LONG Island employers say there is a growing shortage of young people to fill entry-level jobs in fast-food restaurants and other types of businesses.

title: MAKING HER MARK AT 'MA-PA' HOSPITAL
description: ''IF A hospital can have a mother,'' said Cynthia Zirinsky of Lawrence, ''then that's what I am.''

title: INFANT DEATH DATA INDICATE HIGH RISK GROUPS
description: Researchers have identified groups of infants who run a higher-than-average risk of dying from sudden infant death syndrome, according to the initial results of a study by the National Institutes of Health.

title: COINED PHRASE 'A NEW DEA:'
description: Stuart Chase, an economist and member of President Franklin D. Roosevelt's ''brain trust'' who coined the phrase ''a New Deal,'' died yesterday at his home in Redding, Conn. He was 97 years old.

title: EFFECTS ON THE HEART
description: There was more evidence last week that smokers are not the only ones to suffer from cigarettes. At the annual meeting of the American Heart Association in Washington, scientists reported the latest results from the Multiple Risk Factor Intervention Trial, a large study that is exploring ways to prevent heart disease.

title: STATE JUDGE FAULTS MEESE'S EFFORTS TO CURB HEROIN
description: A state judge has criticized Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d for not advocating immediate economic penalties against countries that export heroin to the United States.

title: Developing Strategies
description: WHEN Ann and Andrew Hawryluk were married in 1977, they were both still graduate students - she at Harvard Medical School and he in a doctoral program in electrical engineering at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. They lived in a small apartment in a rundown part of Somerville, Mass., they recalled recently, ''because it was all we could afford.''

title: CONGRESS MOVES TO RESTORE SOCIAL SECURITY FUNDS
description: Congress is moving to reimburse the Social Security trust funds for interest income lost as a result of their recent manipulation by the Treasury Department.

title: COLLEGE SPORTS AND GAMBLING: UNION BORN OF APATHY
description: GAMBLING and point-shaving are as much a part of college basketball as the zone defense and 20-minute halves. It has been that way almost from the start, but few paid much notice until 1951, when the cork popped for the first time. That was the year when the first big point-shaving scandal was uncovered. It involved seven schools in all, including championship teams from City College and Kentucky. An investigation that spanned the better part of a year implicated 32 players in the fixing of 86 games in 17 states. The reaction was as strident as it was unavailing. Committees were appointed, reports were made, laws were changed, new ones were passed. Back then, in the 50's, a breath of scandal in the world of sports was like the touch of ice on an open nerve.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''Unlike a number of economists, particularly the monetarists, I am not worried about inflation next year.''

title: PROGRAM FOR COCAINE-ABUSE UNDER WAY
description: THREE years ago the director of research and treatment at Regent Hospital in Manhattan, Dr. Arnold M. Washton, developed a curative program for cocaine abusers that he described as the first such specialized private drug-treatment program in New York City. Now he is duplicating that model here in Westchester, where, he says, there is considerable need for it.

title: WAVE OF DEVELOPMENT CHANGING THE FAR WEST
description: THE Wild West, 65 square blocks of Greenwich Village so-called because of its considerable collection of waterfront saloons and seedy hotels, is undergoing a boom in development fueled by relatively cheap land, the Manhattan housing shortage and the prospect that Westway's replacement - whatever it is - may transform the area into a veritable Rive Gauche.

title: OPPORTUNITIES FOR THE PATIENT INVESTOR: HOLDING ON IN UNNERVING TIMES
description: AS any seasoned investor knows, it pays to be skeptical when everyone else is rushing to embrace a new investment idea. Time and again the sure thing turns out to be fool's gold. Nowadays, however, there is no clear signal of how to make a bundle in stocks or bonds, or even if it is wise to keep plowing cash into money market funds.

title: ROAD TO BALANCED BUDGET PAVED WITH CONFLICT
description: Just before midnight Thursday, President Reagan reluctantly signed a bill that allowed the Government to borrow for another month and allowed him to go to Geneva without a fiscal cloud hanging over the summit meeting. But the action only postponed the resolution of a question that has been preoccupying Capitol Hill for weeks: Will the lawmakers be able to fashion a consensus plan that requires them to produce a balanced budget within the next five years?

title: STATE MUSEUM AIDE TO BE HONORED
description: THE end products of other people's artistry are the starting point of creativity for Jean West, assistant curator of contemporary New Jersey art at the State Museum in Trenton.

title: THELMA WHITE MARRIES PHILADELPHIA PHYSICIAN
description: Thelma Bradburd White, a nursing administrator with the Philadelphia School District, and Dr. Edward Gosfield Jr., clinical associate professor of medicine at the University of Pennsylvania Medical School and associate chairman of the department of medicine at the Graduate Hospital in Philadelphia, were married yesterday. Judge Marvin Halbert of the Court of Common Pleas, First Judicial District of Pennsylvania, performed the ceremony at the Bellevue Stratford Hotel in Philadelphia.

title: MUSIC OF THE HEMISPHERE
description: THE SOCIAL BRAIN Discovering the Networks of the Mind. By Michael S. Gazzaniga. Illustrated. 219 pp. New York: Basic Books. $17.95.

title: YALE GIVEN TROVE OF AUDUBON PAPERS
description: A DRAFT of a note sent by the naturalist John James Audubon to Queen Victoria and a long letter written by President John Quincy Adams to assist Mr. Audubon's research on dogs are among the documents on display in the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library at Yale University.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: 4 LEGS AND ALL EARS At first glance, Sunny appears to be just a typical beloved family pet. Rescued from a dog pound three years ago, the friendly German shepherd-mix loves to have her stomach scratched, and she rushes to bring her rubber bone to one of her masters.

title: BRIDGEPORT MUSICAL IS BETTER AS A BOOK
description: BETTER forget the Downtown Cabaret Theater's production of ''The Best Little Whorehouse in Texas,'' and read instead ''The Whorehouse Papers,'' Larry L. King's 1982 account of how the musical was made.

title: 'BLUE YONDER' ON DISNEY TELLS OF A BOY'S TRIP THROUGH TIME
description: If Mark Rosman is undergoing an identity crisis, it is probably understandable. His first film as a director was ''House on Sorority Row,'' a grimly gruesome horror movie of the slice-and-dice variety that had respectable play at the box office in 1983. But heart-pounding has given way to heart-warming in Mr. Rosman's second effort, an original film for the Disney channel called ''The Blue Yonder'' that will have its premiere this evening at 8.

title: ART IN THE DARK
description: DOUBLE EXPOSURE Fiction Into Film. By Joy Gould Boyum. 287 pp. New York: A Plume Book/ New American Library. Paper, $10.95. MOVIES have long had a voracious appetite for narrative, stocking up on plays, novels, short stories, newspaper stories, biographies, fairy tales, poems, paintings, operas, popular songs, sex manuals. Film's free and easy interaction with other art forms is the subject of much theoretical writing, because theorists feel they can readily identify film's distinctive qualities by specifying how it differs from the other arts.

title: NICARAGUA PLANS TIES WITH PEKING
description: Nicaragua will soon break relations with Taiwan and allow the Peking Government to open an embassy here, senior foreign diplomats said this week.

title: Panda Keeper Confident Ling-Ling Is Pregnant
description: The nation's chief panda keeper says she is confident that Ling-Ling, the female giant panda at the National Zoo here, will give birth next month.

title: 'THINGS WORK OUT FOR THE BEST'
description: DURING his first season in 1981 as the Notre Dame football coach, Gerry Faust was at practice one day when a ''For Sale'' sign suddenly appeared on the lawn of his home in South Bend, Ind.

title: Buying Funds For Yields
description: AS interest rates have fallen in the past few years, liquid assets have flowed - some would say flooded - into a variety of mutual funds that invest in Government securities, Government-backed mortgages and other nonequity instruments.

title: ELLEN GREIPER ENGEGED TO LOUIS H. WEINBERG
description: Announcement has been made by Beverly Greiper of Brooklyn of the engagement of her daughter Ellen H. Greiper to Louis H. Weinberg, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Weinberg of Great Neck, L.I.

title: IMPRESARIOS IN U.S. AWAITING RUSSIANS
description: Leading American impresarios and museum directors are guardedly looking forward to the anticipated signing of a new cultural exchange agreement between the United States and the Soviet Union in Geneva next week. But they say there will be no immediate, dramatic influx of Russian performers and exhibitions to this country.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN AQUACULTURE
description: FARMING is a hot field today - not on land, but under water. Small companies, Government agencies and university researchers are setting up shop in countless bays, estuaries, ponds and rivers. They are replenishing depleted stocks of clams and oysters, raising endangered fish species, growing ''perfect'' vegetables all year round through so-called hydroponic technology, and growing seaweed and algae for conversion into fuels and chemicals.

title: TODAY'S WOMAN: RUNNING IN PLACE
description: DO women have to be better in order to be equal? The world says yes, but I say no! For the young woman who wants to play football on her high school team, the barriers are not subtle. There were no welcoming voices for that New Jersey youngster who fought and won that right. Listen to the comments of her teammates: ''It's no place for a lady'' ''We're concerned for her safety'' And from her coach:

title: IS THERE SOMETHING IN THE AIR?
description: Some players repeatedly play well in some places and worse in others. For want of any better explanation, we might as well say it is the air.

title: FIRST ROWING TRIP TO ANTARCTICA SET
description: The offshore waters between Cape Cod and Long Island are anything but hospitable at this time of year. But last weekend they offered just the kind of rough conditions needed for a New England team that wants to become the first to row a boat from Cape Horn to Antarctica.

title: LEHRMAN DECLINES TO RUN IN 1986 AGAINST CUOMO
description: After narrowly losing the 1982 New York gubernatorial race to Mario M. Cuomo, Lewis E. Lehrman vowed ta he would stay in public life. Last week, the former president of the Rite-Aid drugstore chain announced that he would not challenge Governor Cuomo again next year; according to his friends, the decision was based in part on Mr. Lehrman's desire to fulfill the earlier pledge.

title: OUTMANEUVERED
description: It was getting to be late in the season and the New Orleans Saints were down to the last of their five free activations from the injured reserve list, so Bum Phillips, with several injured players yet to be reactivated, decided to try a little head coach linebacker sneak. Rather than using the last of his free transfers to reactivate Jim Kovach, the linebacker who has been out with a knee injury, Phillips put Kovach on 24-hour procedural waivers, confident that no other team would claim a player who had recently undergone major knee surgery.

title: Wolff's Characters
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch from Ithaca, N.Y., on Nov. 3 about a popular psychology course at Cornell University misidentified the professor who teaches it. He is James B. Maas.

title: THEATER: AN ADAPTATION, 'CRIME AND PUNISHMENT'
description: TO the extent that Dostoyevsky's ''Crime and Punishment'' is melodrama, the adaptation now at the Harold Clurman Theater is faithful to the major events in this novel of murder, guilt, penance, salvation and other matters. In a little more than two hours and on a tiny stage, there pass before us the book's main characters: the drunken Marmeladov, the sinister Svidrigaylov, the hypocritical Luzhin, the shrewd examining magistrate, the saintly Sonia and of course the neurasthenic Raskolnikov. And there, owing to the ingeniously versatile set, lighting and sound of John Sowle, are the big scenes: the ax murder of the nasty old pawnbroker and the luckless Lisavetta; Marmeladov's death and the disrupted wake; Svidrigaylov's worshipful assault on Raskolnikov's high-minded sister; Luzhin's infamous accusation of theft against Sonia; the climactic moment when Raskolnikov falls to the ground before her, ''before all suffering humanity.''

title: PREISIDENT ARRIVES FOR GENEVA CONFERENCE
description: President Reagan arrived in Geneva tonight for his meeting with Mikhail S. Gorbachev -the first encounter between the leaders of the world's two dominant powers in more than six years.

title: Peking Warships Go Abroad
description: China sent two warships today on a three-nation Indian Ocean tour, the first visit by Chinese Navy vessels to foreign ports since 1949, the official New China News Agency reported. The East China Sea Fleet warships - a guided missile destroyer and an accompanying supply ship - embarked on the ''good-will voyage'' to Pakistan, Sri Lanka and Bangladesh, the agency said.

title: A New Attack On Alcoholism
description: We are concerned that the intervention described in ''The Story of James B'' may be misleading: 14-hour family-run confrontations are not the norm. As an agency specializing in this technique, we have found that intervention is most effective when it is well planned over a period of time, rehearsed, conducted most often away from the drinker's home ground and facilitated by a counselor who keeps the focus in place. This meeting usually lasts one or two hours. MONA MANSELL President Freedom Institute New York City

title: PUNCH LINES FROM THE RUBBLE
description: THE THERAPY OF AVRAM BLOK By Simon Louvish. Illustrated. 328 pp. New York: Stein & Day. $16.95.

title: KATHERINT WITKOWSKI AND ROBERT J. JACOBS WED
description: Katherine Mary Witkowski, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Vernon J. Witkowski of Detroit, was married there yesterday to Robert J. Jacobs, the son of Mr. and Mrs. S. Robert Jacobs of Maspeth, Queens. The Rev. Arthur McGovern performed the Roman Catholic ceremony in the Sacred Heart Chapel at Marygrove College.

title: Taiwan's Ruling Party Wins Local Elections
description: Taiwan's ruling Nationalist Party swept to victory today in elections for local representatives.

title: Jones Beach Requires A Stargazer's Permit
description: Park officials say those wishing to observe Halley's comet from Jones Beach, the only state park open at night for viewing, should write for a ''stargazer's permit,'' which is available free of charge.

title: MIAMI ELECTS A CUBAN MAYOR
description: Xavier Suarez is a native of Cuba who came to this country as a refugee 25 years ago. He eventually made his way through Harvard Law School and, after running unsuccessfully for elective office four times, last week became Miami's first Cuban-American Mayor.

title: HIDING BEHIND GOALS
description: ''There are real practices out there that discriminate. There are people who don't like women in certain jobs, who don't like blacks in certain jobs, and they act on that.

title: Sector Funds Break Into The Spotlight
description: THE hottest performers among mutual funds in the past year have been sector funds - funds that are limited to equities of specific market groups, such as utilities, health care or overseas companies. In the first nine months of 1985, as the Dow Jones Industrial Average climbed 13.49 percent, the Fidelity Overseas Fund, the best performer, grew 45.87 percent.

title: THE ENVIRONMEN
description: ALTHOUGH gains continue to be made in New Jersey's protection of the environment, there have been setbacks for the environmental movement, which, since the 1970's, has led the fight for protective statutes.

title: Texas Flora
description: To the Editor:

title: SWISS OFFICIALS HOPE TO SWAY PUBLIC ON U.N.
description: Swiss Government officials have started a campaign of public appearances, meetings and speeches designed to persuade voters to approve Swiss membership in the United Nations in a national referendum scheduled for March 16.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: ALTHOUGH some 500 people will wander through Hahne's Department Store in Eatontown next Sunday, not a cent will be rung up in sales. The profits will enrich the coffers of the Central New Jersey chapter of the March of Dimes.

title: THE IMAGE GETS SHARPENED
description: The perennial battle between VHS and Beta has entered a new phase. No longer will they contest the same ground. The two chief rivals among video formats have reached a standoff, and Beta, while yielding the mass market, is gaining higher ground.

title: LUCIENNE PATTISON TO WED IN MARCH
description: Mr. and Mrs. Michael Geber of London and Los Angeles have announced the engagement of their daughter Lucienne Felice Geber Pattison to Charles Dewess Dilworth, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Richardson Dilworth of Princeton, N.J. A March wedding is planned.

title: IT'S MOVEMENT QUALITY THAT COUNTS
description: Exploring movement, finding new ways of moving, and hammering out a signature style that is identified with movement quality - these are resolutely the concerns of American modern-dance choreographers. By contrast, European choreographers in the experimental corner do not appear primarily interested in movement, regarding it essentially as a tool for expression of dramatic and philosophical ideas. Even when American choreographers no longer focus exclusively on pure-movement works - when anecdotal images surface through the movement - it is nonetheless the movement (the kind of movement employed by the choreographer) that we notice first.

title: A Young Rabbi
description: As a 25-year-old social worker who counsels families and children, I appreciate Joshua J. Hammerman's concerns in ''A Young Rabbi'' (About Men, Oct. 20).

title: JUST ASK
description: Fund-raising specialists discovered years ago that direct-mail solicitations attracted more response if the recipient was asked to answer a short questionnaire and send it back with his or her contribution. People apparently like to be asked their opinions and are more inclined toward generosity if they have some sense of participation.

title: NATIONAL STAMP SHOW OPENS IN NEW YORK
description: The 1985 National Postage Stamp Show will be held Thursday through Sunday at Madison Square Garden, 33d Street and Eighth Avenue in New York City. Show hours Thursday are from noon to 7 P.M.; Friday from 11 A.M. to 7 P.M.; Saturday from 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. and Sunday from 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. Admission is $3 for adults. Youngsters under 14 accompanied by an adult are admitted free.

title: HILL CHASING COWBOY RECORDS
description: Nine years ago, when he was a rookie wide receiver for the Dallas Cowboys, Tony Hill thought enough of his abilities that he told Drew Pearson, ''I should be starting in front of you.'' Pearson was in his fifth season at the time and had played in two Pro Bowls.

title: FORMER HOSPITAL SOUGHT FOR SHELTER
description: IN his proposed $721 million budget for 1986 that was unveiled on Friday, County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke has sent the County Board of Legislators a request for authorization to purchase and renovate the former Yonkers Professional Hospital on Ludlow Avenue to temporarily house ''displaced families.'' Mr. O'Rourke expressed hope that the establishment of a shelter at the ex-medical facility, which closed April 29, 1980, could ''wipe out the problem we have dealing with the homeless family,'' a problem he called ''the single biggest in Westchester.''

title: BRIDGE, AT 101, FOCUS OF DISPUTE
description: A NEARLY two-year battle to save one of Westport's historic landmarks - a century-old swing bridge crossing the Saugatuck River - will likely reach a key stage Thursday at a hearing in Town Hall.

title: Off-Duty Officer Shot 5 Times at Social Club
description: An off-duty police officer was shot five times early yesterday when he interrupted a robbery at a social club in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn, the police said. A suspected robber and a patron of the club were also seriously wounded.

title: TRIBUTE TO A BLACK WRITER
description: ''I AM a writer. I am going to write.'' The words are touching and revelatory when uttered by the young Lorraine Hansberry who broke through racial and theatrical barriers in 1959 when her historic play, ''A Raisin in the Sun,'' emblazoned Broadway with what now reads like an awesome cast: Ruby Dee, Sidney Portier, Diana Sands, Claudia McNeil, Louis Gossett, Lonne Elder 3d and Douglas Turner. The director was Lloyd Richards.

title: HERITAGE FOUNDATION: SUCCESS IN OBSCURITY
description: James Gattuso is an obscure 27-year-old lawyer who dropped out of a law firm here to get more actively engaged in politics. Unable to find a job in Congress, his first choice, he became an analyst of regulatory issues at the Heritage Foundation.

title: A TRIAL OPENS IN A NEW WAVE OF CIGARETTE SUITS
description: After the Surgeon General first warned of smoking's dangers two decades ago, a flurry of liability cases were filed against cigarette makers. None of them succeeded.

title: HONORS FOR 300-YEAR-OLD HOME
description: WHEN Albert Waring's ancestors came to Long Island, Peter Stuyvesant ruled the New Netherlands. And from that time, nine generations of Warings have lived in the original family house in North Bellmore.

title: 'RIVER' SHOW EXULTS IN STATE'S CREATIVE HISTORY
description: THE Wadsworth Atheneum's ''Great River'' exhibition numbers 375 objects. This means 1.07 paintings, silver tankards, articles of clothing, grandfather clocks, chests, chairs or bear traps (to suggest a few of the categories) for each of the 350 years it covers. And, as everyone must know by now, the show marks the anniversary of the state's first permanent European settlement, in 1635, along the Connecticut River.

title: SLAYING SETS OFF MOVE TO BRIDGE 2 BLACK CULTURES
description: The other girls mocked Roslyn Hawkins for her old-fashioned clothes and her accent. Sometimes they shouted, ''Go back to Jamaica.'' And sometimes the insults were worse.

title: OFFICER WHO BROKE JAPANESE WAR CODES GETS BELATED HONOR
description: Forty-three years after Joseph J. Rochefort broke the Japanese code that helped the United States win the Battle of Midway, the former naval officer is to be awarded the Distinguished Service Medal.

title: About Men;   Simple Answers
description: BY THE FOURTH summer of her life, my daughter, Katharine, a healthy and happy 3 1/2-year-old, had reached an initial understanding about death:

title: TUNISIA'S NEW WAVE IS FUNDAMENTALIST
description: Anti-American anger in recent weeks has spurred a growing Islamic fundamentalist movement, which is challenging nearly 30 years of Westernization under President Habib Bourguiba. The fundamentalists have exploited Israel's bombing of the Palestine Liberation Organization headquarters here last month, and the American interception of an Egyptian plane carrying the Achille Lauro hijackers, telling Tunisians that the Western way is not theirs.

title: Scoring the Summit Won't be Easy
description: If past summit meetings are any guide, judging what constitutes success may not be so easy this week. It is notoriously difficult to score a summit. The same two questions always arise: Did the leaders get along? Who won the propaganda battle? But the answers don't necessarily tell us much about the substance of the meeting or its lasting effects on relations between the superpowers.

title: A VERY SPECIAL SOPRANO
description: THE OPERA WORLD KNOWS TWO kinds of power. The first wins by assault, battering the senses into love and submission, exhilarating by sheer breadth and surge. The other is rarer, less often at center stage. It stands a little to one side, drawing the ear to it rather than reaching out for attention.

title: 4 Managers In the Thick Of Things
description: ''I'm a Cubs fan,'' said Ralph Wanger, ''and therefore I've learned to have patience and root for losers.'' But the manager of the Acorn Fund, a no-load growth fund that specializes in emerging companies, is not sentimental when it comes to investing. He shuns the stocks of the American automobile companies, for instance, and has invested in Fuji Heavy Industries, which makes Subaru cars and trucks.

title: MARTHA SHIRO IS MARRIED
description: Martha Elizabeth Shiro, a daughter of Elizabeth Shiro of Chevy Chase, Md., and Eugene Shiro of Arlington, Va., was married yesterday to Bruce Alan Rosen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Mitchell Rosen of New York. Judge Shirley Wohl Kram of the United States District Court performed the ceremony at the Women's National Democratic Club in Washington.

title: Hanoi Calls for Meeting On Missing Americans
description: Vietnam asked the United States today to send a high-level delegation to Hanoi to finish details of the two-year Vietnamese plan to account for missing Americans. It also announced that it would soon return the remains of seven Americans.

title: A NEW HOME FOR 3 EXCHANGES
description: The three largest commodity exchanges in New York had been seeking a new home for 18 months. Last week, they found one.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in this section last Sunday on the 100th football game between Amherst and Williams Colleges misstated the record in their series. Williams leads, 52-44-4.

title: IN 'SUGARBABY,' STYLE ENHANCES CONTENT
description: ''A woman can never be too rich or too thin,'' the Duchess of Windsor once said.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: GARDENS. By Holly Prado. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $14.95.) Mother Kate is in the attic, painting. Daughter Sheila is in her bedroom, writing.

title: ITHACA SETS BACK MERCHANT MARINE
description: Ithaca rallied for a 20-15 victory over the Merchant Marine Academy yesterday in heavy rain at Tomb Memorial Field, Kings Point, L.I., to improve its record to 8-1 and stake a claim for one of the four regional spots in the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division III playoffs.

title: THE BEAT OF BROADWAY CRACKLES IN A REBIRTH OF 'FOLLIES'
description: In ''The Book of Laughter and Forgetting,'' the Czechoslovak emigre author Milan Kundera wrote, ''The past is full of life, eager to irritate us, provoke or insult us, tempt us to destroy or repaint it.'' And in Stephen Sondheim's ''Follies,'' whose story depicts the corrosive effect of nostalgia on personal relationships while its score surveys the history of the Broadway musical, the past does all these things and more.

title: GENEVA: A TEST OF TWO WILLS
description: FROM THE VERY START OF HIS PRESIDENCY, Ronald Reagan has accused Soviet leaders of being willing to ''commit any crime, to lie, to cheat'' to achieve their goals, and denounced their system as an ''evil empire,'' destined for ''the ash heap of history.'' In urging an embargo against a Soviet gas pipeline, he once told other Western leaders: ''If we push the Soviets, they will collapse.''

title: Q AND A
description: Question: I signed a contract to buy a garden-apartment condominium for which the sponsor is providing a mortgage. I assume that my contract is the same as it is for everybody else and that others will have a lawyer. Do I have to undertake the expense of hiring a lawyer for the closing? . . . L. W., Astoria, Queens Answer: It is possible to buy a condominium without a lawyer, but there are some things to consider in deciding whether to hire one. While it is true that, in a first offering of a condominium, everyone will be signing the contract that appears in the prospectus, there is no guarantee that it is the contract you should sign. After the condominium is sold out, the sponsor or other owners may resell units under a different contract and terms.

title: Pitt Sells Out Arena For Basketball Games
description: The University of Pittsburgh, which sold fewer than 600 season-tickets only four years ago, has sold out 6,798-seat Fitzgerald Fieldhouse for its 13 home basketball games this season.

title: RECENT RELEASES
description: That's Dancing! Written and directed by Jack Haley Jr., 1985 MGM/UA Home Video 104 minutes. $79.95 ''That's Dancing!'' purports to offer an overview of film dance, starting with early archival moving pictures and continuing on through a Michael Jackson music video.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: For This Week:

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: DOING BUSINESS: The Anthropology of Striving, Thriving, and Beating Out the Competition. By Olivia Vlahos. (Franklin Watts, $18.95.) Pop history and a gung-ho appraisal of business today are sloppily thrown together in this book, which sets out to demonstrate how unfairly businessmen have been treated throughout the ages.

title: Bly's Poetics
description: To the Editor:

title: Getting More As I.R.A.'s Grow Larger
description: INDIVIDUAL Retirement Accounts, which Congress made available to all income earners through the 1981 Tax Act, are becoming more than just an agreeable tax break for many people. Those who faithfully made annual contributions have seen the size of their accounts reach, bit by bit, a level that has to be viewed as serious money. After three years of investing the full $2,000 amount, some investors may now have accounts approaching the $10,000 mark, a size that is forcing them to view their I.R.A.'s more as accounts that should be managed than as savings accounts requiring little attention.

title: A YOUNG RABBI
description: As the 29-year-old, newly ordained, female rabbi of a home for the aged, whose congregants range in age from 80 to 101, not just youth stands between me and the traditional image of a rabbi.

title: SECOND TIME AROUND IN ESSEX
description: JUST over two years ago, Il Tulipano, the stylish and popular Italian restaurant in Cedar Grove, Essex County, was given one star by this reviewer. Since that time, the menu has remained essentially the same, apart from the prices, which have risen gently.

title: NEW UNCERTAINTY -- AND HOPE-- IN THE MIDEAST
description: King Hussein of Jordan moved closer to an erstwhile enemy last week, adding a new note of unpredictability to the always-cloudy prospects for Middle Eastern peace. The King apologized to President Hafez al-Assad of Syria for Jordan's behavior six years ago when it was a base for Moslem Brotherhood terrorist attacks in Syria.

title: NEW FRONTIERS
description: Rising office rents, traffic congestion and the shortage of affordable housing in such suburban office strongholds as Westchester County, N.Y., and Fairfield County, Conn., have prompted some space users to venture into such areas as Orange County, N.Y., and New Haven County, Conn.

title: ARRAY OF CONCERTS IS OFFERED TODAY
description: TODAY offers a bountiful pre-Thanksgiving feast of solo, chamber and choral music, beginning with the Pleasantville Chamber Music Society, which is embarking upon its ninth season of presenting concerts by superb artists at no charge to the community.

title: Behind-the-Scenes Strategists
description: Fred C. Ikle Under Secretary of Defense. Longtime conservative arms strategist and director of Arms Control and Disarmament Agency under President Ford. Robie M. Palmer Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for European and Canadian Affairs. State Department's senior Soviet specialist and the State Department summit coordinator. An idea man, known for being daring by diplomatic standards. Accomplished speechwriter. Richard N. Perle Assistant Secretary of Defense. Regarded as perhaps the most formidable opponent of arms control in the Administration. Kenneth L. Adelman Director of Arms Control and Disarmament Agency. Youngest of senior members of the arms control team. His appointment to the arms control agency met opposition in Congress because of his lack of experience in the field. Rozanne L. Ridgway Assistant Secretary of State for European and Canadian Affairs. Career Foreign Service woman; former Ambassador to Finland and East Germany.

title: Aide Who Sent Letter On Religion Loses Job
description: A Treasury Department official who sent what Representative Patricia Schroeder, Democrat of Colorado, called an ''insulting and derogatory letter'' to a California man has been dismissed, but ''it was due entirely to staff cutbacks,'' according to a Treasury spokesman.

title: The Summit: What It's All About
description: Charts and thumbnail outlines of the issues, the background, the key figures: a primer on the gathering at Geneva. Pages A6 and A7.

title: PENN STATE FAVORS ORANGE BOWL BID
description: Penn State was the last team to gain the final No. 1 ranking by winning a bowl game between the first-and second-ranked squads. That happened in the Sugar Bowl on Jan. 1, 1983, when the Nittany Lions, No. 2 going into the bowl, beat No. 1-ranked Georgia, 27-23, to gain the top spot for the 1982 season.

title: Dart Group's Quest For a Big Company
description: Herbert H. Haft, chairman and chief executive officer of the Dart Group Corporation, likes to buy things and then break them up. But recently the 65-year-old executive has had more success demolishing houses than companies.

title: MCFARLANE IS DOUBTFUL ON EXTENDING '79 PACT
description: The White House national security adviser, Robert C. McFarlane, said today that it was unlikely that President Reagan would agree this week to a joint affirmation with Mikhail S. Gorbachev to extend compliance with the 1979 strategic arms treaty.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, NOVEMBER 18, 1985
description: International

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We get bogged down in technicalities. The big decisions we can make rather quickly.''

title: YUGOSLAVS ARE ABASHED: MONEY FROM A 'MIRACLE'
description: About three million pilgrims have come to this village in the last four years, in what has been a mixed blessing for both the Communist Government and the Roman Catholic Church.

title: Coastal's Sonat Stake
description: The Coastal Corporation may buy up to 10 percent of the outstanding common stock of Sonat Inc., it disclosed in a filing Friday with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: A REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: 14 WORDS FROM REAGAN
description: The earth still has to rotate on its axis about one and a half times more before its two most powerful inhabitants finally come eye to eye here in an encounter that already seems to have exhausted the global stockpile of metaphors for single combat.

title: PARTNERS AND ALSO FRIENDS
description: FOR 15 years, Jerry and Susan Lieberman of Los Angeles have been best friends as well as husband and wife. They help each other solve problems at work, share the same hobbies and sports and even do together such things - shopping for clothes, for example - that others do alone or with friends of the same sex.

title: School Chiefs of States Oppose Voucher Plan
description: The nation's chief state school officials took a united stand Saturday against the Reagan Administration's tuition voucher plan.

title: The Summit Record
description: July 1955.President Eisenhower meets in Geneva with Nikolai A. Bulganin, British and French leaders. Results: The ''Spirit of Geneva'' began to thaw the cold war. General discussion; no agreements. September 1959. Mr. Eisenhower and Nikita S. Khrushchev meet at Camp David, Md. Results: ''The Spirit of Camp David'' - a general feeling that scientific and cultural exchanges would be good, and that disarmament is the world's main problem - but no concrete results. May 1960. Mr. Eisenhower and Mr. Khrushchev go to Paris, but the Russian uses the shooting down of the American U-2 spy plane over the Soviet Union to torpedo the meeting. Results: Increased tensions. June 1961. Mr. Khrushchev and President Kennedy, in Vienna, have heated exchanges. Results: No formal agreements. A year later, the Soviet Union tries to put missiles in Cuba; U.S. forces their removal. June 1967.President Johnson meets in Glassboro, N.J., with Aleksei N. Kosygin to discuss Middle East, the Vietnam War and nuclear arms. Results: No results on Vietnam; seeds sown for later arms talks. May 1972. President Nixon and Leonid I. Brezhnev, in Moscow, sign first treaties setting ceilings on strategic nuclear arms and limiting antiballistic missile systems. Results: They agree to keep negotiating on arms; regional issues still divide them. June 1973. Mr. Nixon and Mr. Brezhnev meet in Washington. Results: Agreement to try to complete a new arms treaty by 1974; agreements on practical issues. June-July 1974. Mr. Nixon and Mr. Brezhnev meet in Moscow and Yalta.

title: M.T.A. CHIEF SAYS INCREASE IN FARES IS LIKELY BY JAN. 1
description: Robert R. Kiley, the chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, said yesterday that the fare on the city's subways and buses would probably rise at least a dime, to $1, by New Year's Day.

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Football Giants vs. Redskins, at Washington, 9 P.M. The Giants defeated the high-flying Rams, 24-19, last week and go after their fifth straight victory.

title: GREENMARKET SEES THREAT IN FACELIFT OF UNION SQ.
description: On a typical market day at Union Square Park, the Greenmarket does a brisk business, serving tides of people who come to pinch, poke and buy an array of produce picked from fields and orchards only a few hours before.

title: Where 'Star Wars' Fits In
description: Space-based weapons, and the issue of defensive arms in general, have become a central issue in Soviet-American arms talks.

title: PREMIERE OF ORIGINAL 'EARNEST'
description: After the immensely successful opening-night performance of Oscar Wilde's ''Importance of Being Earnest'' in 1895, the playwright stalked backstage. ''It was charming, quite charming,'' he acidly told the producer. ''And do you know, from time to time I was reminded of a play I once wrote myself, called 'The Importance of Being Earnest.' ''

title: OUTDOORS: DEER MOST AFFORDABLE OF BIG GAME
description: RANGING throughout the continental United States, the white-tailed deer is this country's one big game animal that is widely sought by rich and poor alike.

title: CITY TO USE RACIAL QUOTA TO PICK AT LEAST 1,000 POLICE SERGEANTS
description: The Koch administration has decided to breach its own hiring policy and fill all immediate vacancies for police sergeant on the basis of a racial quota, First Deputy Mayor Stanley Brezenoff said yesterday.

title: STADIUM PROGRESS TOO SLOW FOR HESS
description: At a time when the Jets appear on the verge of sustained success, they will not be returning to New York, their owner, Leon Hess, indicated today.

title: YALE CO-OP SELLS MORE THAN THE OLD SCHOOL TIE
description: Jimmy Dixon, a stalwart of the men's wear department of the Yale Cooperative Store, has schooled generations of Yalies in the fundamentals of the classic Ivy look - soft-shouldered suits, button-down shirts and regimental ties.

title: On the Record
description: President Reagan Mikhail S. Gorbachev On the Summit Meeting xhrr''We are bringing a broad agenda to Geneva focusing on the full spectrum of U.S.- Soviet relations, not just arms control, but regional conflicts, bilateral relations and human rights. Genuine improvement in the relationship can only result when there is progress in all four areas.'' - Nov. 8, 1985 ''We believe that to travel all the way to Geneva just to get acquainted, just to look at the beauties of Lake Geneva, the beauty of Swiss mountains - that is not adequate to the leaders of two such great nations. It is an expensive luxury.'' -Sept. 1, 1985 On International Relations xhrr''In your discussion of the nuclear freeze proposals, I urge you to beware the temptation of pride - the temptation of blithely declaring yourselves above it all and label both sides equally at fault, to ignore the facts of history and the aggressive impulses of an evil empire.'' - March 8, 1983 ''As for relations with capitalist states, I would like to say the following: We will firmly follow the Leninist course of peace and peaceful coexistence. To good will the Soviet Union will always respond with good will, as it will respond with trust to trust. But everyone should know that we shall never waive the interests of the motherland and those of its allies.'' -March 11, 1985 On Each Other xhrr''It isn't true that I don't trust anyone under 70.'' - March 14, 1985 ''I think what is most evident, and I believe that this will be reflected in him, is that the Soviet Union is in a different frame of mind than they've been in the past.''

title: Threatened Farmer Gets Many 'Bitty' Cash Gifts
description: A farmer who said he would fight rather than lose the land his family has owned since the Civil War has received hundreds of letters with donations to help with a debt estimated at $112,000.

title: HARD TIMES DON'T FAZE MANY FUTURE FARMERS
description: Hard times appear to have taken a toll on the number of young people who plan to make their livelihood in agriculture, but not, it seems, on their enthusiasm as they thronged downtown for this year's national convention of Future Farmers of America.

title: Waltrip Wins Nascar Title From Elliott
description: With Bill Elliott suffering a transmission breakdown less than 10 minutes into the race, Darrell Waltrip coasted to his third Winston Cup championship today with a seventh-place finish in the Western 500.

title: The Numbers Game
description: While a good deal of the rest of Congress is painfully searching for enough self-discipline to reduce the yawning Federal deficit, Representative Mario Biaggi thinks he has as much as half the solution already on hand. A national lottery, the Bronx Democrat says, could raise $12 billion to $18 billion a year, a third to a half of the budgetary saving that Congress is now trying to achieve. Eighteen states already have lotteries, which earned a collective $5.2 billion in 1983, so national morality does not seem to be seriously at issue.

title: Hurricane Warnings Are Posted in Bahamas
description: Hurricane Kate, with sustained winds of 92 miles an hour, continued its westward drift today, and hurricane warnings were issued for the southeast Bahamas and the north coast of the Dominican Republic.

title: Bridge: Despite Flawed Moysian Winnipeg Declarer Survives
description: The name of the late Alphonse Moyse Jr. will always be associated with contracts played with four trumps opposite three: the Moysian fit. Such contracts are desirable if no-trump is unattractive, if the partnership owns nearly all the honor strength in the suit and if an early ruff will come in the short hand.

title: CONCERT: BERNSTEIN LEADS DEBUT OF DIAMOND'S NINTH
description: LISTENING to David Diamond's new symphony at Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon reminded us how often musical politics confuses style with quality. New ideas carry us into the future, the general wisdom goes. And, as a result, innovation is assigned an esthetic, even an ethical, worth all its own.

title: Marine Fossils Support Catastrophe Theory
description: To the Editor:

title: 44% in Survey Want U.S. to Press Pretoria
description: Close to half the American people want the Government to take stronger action to press South Africa to abandon apartheid and want major corporations to stop doing business in that country, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll shows.

title: BUSINESSES CHANGE WAYS IN FEAR OF LAWSUITS
description: Charles Shultz, creator of the comic strip ''Peanuts,'' closed a public ice-skating rink he owns in nearby Santa Rosa recently, saying he could no longer obtain liability insurance to protect himself against possible lawsuits in case of accidents.

title: ROSTENKOWSKI SAYS TOP TAX RATE WILL BE ABOVE 35% REAGAN GOAL
description: The chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee acknowledged today that his committee would fall short of President Reagan's goal of lowering the top tax rate for individuals to 35 percent.

title: American Airlines Hub
description: American Airlines said Friday that it planned to open a small hub in San Juan, P.R., beginning in November 1986, to expand its flights in the Caribbean, where it competes with Eastern Air Lines. The airline, a unit of the AMR Corporation, said it planned to spend $30 million to expand the Luis Munoz International Airport. It plans to increase the number of flights from the airport from eight a day to five cities, to 26 a day to 17 cities.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: American Express Bank Ltd., the international banking arm of the American Express Co., has elected Francois Giscard d'Estaing chairman of the Trade Development Bank (France) S.A., a Paris-based subsidiary.

title: Prospecting In the Low List
description: THE equity market's recent march to new records has seen hundreds of issues on the New York Stock Exchange trade at 52-week highs. Lagging far behind is a much smaller list of stocks registering new lows.

title: Bramble Fights the Good Fight, In and Out of Ring
description: THE woman in pink leotards looks across the prize ring at the man in sweat clothes.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

title: Ad Council Chairman Talks of the Future
description: In an interview Friday, James H. Rosenfield, retiring senior executive vice president of the CBS Broadcast Group, said that he would now be able to give more attention to his other (but nonpaying) job as chairman of the Advertising Council. One of his first official acts will be to preside at the annual dinner on Wednesday.

title: Norway Bans Arctic Plans
description: Norwegian authorities have effectively banned further oil and gas drilling operations this winter in its northern waters, calling exploration rigs off northern Norway unfit for harsh Arctic conditions.

title: LED CAMBODIA IN EARLY 1970'S
description: Lon Nol, the Cambodian general whose pro-American military Government ruled his country for five years until it was overwhelmed by Khmer Rouge forces in 1975, died yesterday at St. Jude's Hospital in Fullerton, Calif. He was 72 years old and lived in Fullerton.

title: Banished Guru, Back in India, Calls Americans 'Subhuman'
description: Bhagwan Shree Rajneesh, banished from the United States for breaking immigration laws, returned to India today and described his four years in America as ''hell'' and Americans as ''subhuman.''

title: Force and Fraud in Liberia
description: Gen. Samuel Doe has now imposed himself upon Liberia three times in this decade, twice by force and once by fraud. General Doe is neither Liberia's first autocrat, nor Africa's worst. But he holds one distinction that is becoming a distinct embarrassment to the United States.

title: Space, Part 1
description: To say that the musicians earn standing ovations or that they attract standing-room-only crowds is accurate enough. But it misses the point slightly.

title: POWER PACT GALLING TO NEWFOUNDLAND
description: The adage ''Marry in haste, repent at leisure'' can apply not just to couples but sometimes to provinces in Canada too.

title: Canadian Inflation Rate
description: Canada's annual rate of inflation edged up a notch in October to 4.2 percent, from 4.1 percent in September, the Government's Statistics Canada said.

title: THEATER: 'MR. STONE,' SERIAL ADVENTURE BY FOSTER
description: AGNEW STONE is found dead, face down in the hollyhocks.

title: THE CHILDREN OF CALAMITY: FOR SOME, A JOYFUL ENDING
description: Armando Molana Salinas, 10 years old, clutched his purple Big Bird doll and described how he saw his mother for the last time.

title: U.S. NAMES 403 TOXIC CHEMICALS THAT POSE RISK IN PLANT ACCIDENTS
description: The Environmental Protection Agency has concluded that 403 highly toxic chemicals produced, sold and used throughout the United States would pose potentially serious health dangers to the public in a chemical plant accident.

title: FEDERAL AUDITS OF LEGAL AIDE AT ISSUE
description: Groups providing legal services to the poor have asserted that their work is being disrupted by auditing teams dispatched by the Legal Services Corporation, the Federal agency that oversees much of their financing.

title: Barbara Kaplan Marries
description: The marriage of Barbara Louise Kaplan, a psychiatric nurse at the Payne Whitney Clinic of New York Hospital, and Dr. Lawrence Bruce Jacobsberg, a psychiatrist at the New York State Psychiatric Institute at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, took place yesterday. Rabbi Bernhard Cohn performed the ceremony at Congregation Habonim in New York. The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Kaplan of Tampa, Fla. Dr. Jacobsberg is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Jacobsberg of New York.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: ILLUSTRATORS The Society of Illustrators occupies a comfortable town house at 128 East 63d Street (838-2560), and two floors, understandably, are given over to exhibition - a section called the Museum of American Illustration.

title: AMID JUICY ANTICIPATION, SIGNS OF DANGER ABOUND
description: WITHOUT trying to put words into Charles Dickens's pen, it is a good guess he would have known exactly what to write about the coming college basketball season. ''It was the best of times,'' we can picture the old chronicler noting, ''it was the worst of times.''

title: >Lendl Tops Becker in Final
description: Ivan Lendl needed nearly four hours today to defeat Boris Becker, 6-7, 6-3, 4-6, 6-4, 6-4, and retain the title in the $375,000 Benson and Hedges tennis championships.

title: AWAITING THE VISTA OF A CALDER
description: Alexander Calder, American patriot and sculptor, never asked for the impossible, merely for an end to hypocrisy, self-righteousness, self-interest, distortion and fear wherever they exist. And also, on the day he suddenly died, for just the right balance and delicate turning in his last and most elaborate public work, ''Mountains and Clouds.''

title: CAROLINA ISLAND ACTS TO FEND OFF DEVELOPERS
description: Residents of South Carolina's oldest coastal resort are trying to fend off the tide of condominium development sweeping the state's coast.

title: Time
description: ''Under Old Management.''

title: REDSKIN AIR ATTACK IS STALLED
description: THEIR best receiver was open for a touchdown, and the quarterback overthrew him by a yard. Their second-best receiver was about to catch a touchdown pass when a defender got one finger on the ball and deflected it. Their defensive backs dropped two interceptions. The other team saved a fumble when it rolled into the hands of a player already on the ground.

title: Mixed Defense-Offense Deterrent Is Perilous
description: To the Editor:

title: DIVIDED FAMILIES DRINK THE SWEETEST WINE OF ALL
description: After years of forced separation, of marriage by correspondence and forgotten pleas and dashed hopes, a group of Americans reveled with joy over the weekend at word that their relatives would soon be permitted to leave the Soviet Union.

title: CABARET: HELEN MERRILL SINGS
description: HELEN MERRILL has had an off-and-on singing career since she came to the attention of jazz followers in the 1950's working with the Earl Hines sextet, and through a series of well-received albums of her own. For the last 25 years, however, she has spent much of her time in Europe or Japan and, while she has built faithful followings there, her sporadic returns to the United States have never rekindled the audience she once had here.

title: Shell-Exxon-China Pact
description: Royal Dutch/Shell said it and the Exxon Corporation of the United States signed a contract with the state-owned China National Offshore Oil Corporation to explore for oil in the Pearl River in south China.

title: TRUCKS CAPTIVATING AMERICAN MARKET
description: When the domestic car makers closed the books on the 1985 model year recently and tallied their sales, they found that the best-selling car in the United States was a truck - Ford's F-Series full-size pickup. The second best seller was also a pickup - Chevrolet's C-Series.

title: Protectionism That Protects Nothing
description: Let's pay billions more for clothing and shoes! Let's go out of our way to infuriate China! And let's organize a cartel while we're at it, just like the OPEC oil cartel, for copper-mine owners!

title: A Nicaraguan Crisis?
description: While the world's attention has been focused on the summit, storm clouds have darkened over Nicaragua. And though ''regional disputes'' are on the agenda at Geneva, it's unlikely that anything done or said there will much affect what may be the coming crisis in Central America.

title: Merrill Ad Review
description: Merrill Lynch confirmed Friday that it planned to review its advertising situation in keeping with a year-old corporate policy of periodic review of all vendors. Young & Rubicam has been the agency since 1979. The current budget is $40 million. According to the brokerage, the country's largest, it has not yet contacted any other agencies and is getting complete cooperation from Y.&R. What's its alternative?

title: Maple Leafs 5, Sabres 3
description: Peter Ihnacak's two third-period goals helped Toronto erase a two-goal deficit tonight.

title: The Diabolical Russians
description: ''After all these years, almost 40 years, of being deeply con-cerned about arms and arms control, I've come to realize we took the wrong road. We could not make a rational policy on nuclear weapons because we were obsessed with Russia.

title: Uneasy Rests the Head
