description: IF it's Sunday, it must be New York. The towns change and the colors of the uniforms change and sometimes even the languages change, but the murderous zeal in the opponents' eyes? Never.

title: On the Table: 2 Arms Plans
description: These are the latest arms reduction proposals the Americans and the Russians have been discussing in Geneva talks on strategic and intermediate-range weapons and space arms, before the summit. The Soviet proposal seems tied to a ban on ''Star Wars.'' U.S. PROPOSAL SOVIET PROPOSAL

title: British Inflation Down
description: Britain's annual inflation rate fell to 5.4 percent, from 5.9 percent, in October, its fourth consecutive monthly fall and its lowest level since February, the Government said. The Department of Employment said Friday that its retail price index rose two-tenths of 1 percent in October. The department said rises in the cost of beer and women's clothes were mostly offset by a cut in the price of gasoline and some foods.

title: MATURING PHASE SEEN FOR CASINOS
description: The recent flurry of financial activity in the casino industry, including at least two major sales, two bankruptcy filings and the prospect of still more sales, reflects a period of consolidation and reorganization in a maturing business, analysts and casino representatives said yesterday.

title: Pride's Flights Are Suspended
description: Pride Air has suspended its flights for at least five days because of a cash problem, according to company officials.

title: STATE LEGISLATURE: CENTER STAGE FOR WOMEN
description: At a time when women feel disheartened about their failure to gain more seats in the Congress, more governorships, more Cabinet appointments and when affirmative action has lost ground, there appear to be solid gains in state legislatures. The number of women serving in those bodies is growing and so, too, is the influence they wield, as they ascend to the chairmanships of committees and leadership roles in party structures.

title: Videogenic Wins Handicap
description: With a patient ride by Robbie Davis, Videogenic took the $113,300 Ladies Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday by 5 1/2 lengths.

title: SOUTH AFRICA'S GOLD COLOSSUS
description: Shortly before he assumed the chairmanship of the Anglo American Corporation of South Africa, this country's biggest mining and industrial conglomerate, Gavin Relly was asked about his relationship with his predecessor, Harry Oppenheimer.

title: Defining the Jargon
description: The language of nuclear arms talks includes many specialized terms. These are a few of those words. Ballistic missile. This missile, powered by a rocket engine, travels outside of the atmosphere for part of its flight.

title: COURT MOVE STIRS HOPE ON REFUGEES
description: Programs for refugees in California and in some other states will be able to continue operations now that the Reagan Administration has been ordered to release additional funds for the programs to local officials, the officials say.

title: INTRUSIONS ABOUND IN HALLWAY CLASSES FOR EARLY GRADES
description: It was time for reading class, and the teacher, Eileen Blumenfeld, sitting on a toddler's chair in the hallway of Public School 128, was guiding her first graders through the uses of the letter T. Fifteen children eagerly sounded out such words as cat and table as they sprawled and squirmed at her feet on a tile floor.

title: Wertheim Hires RCA Executive
description: Herbert S. Schlosser, an executive vice president at the RCA Corporation and a former president and chief executive of the National Broadcasting Company, will become a senior adviser at Wertheim & Company, the Wall Street investment banking firm, at the start of next year, according to an announcement by James A. Harmon, vice chairman of Wertheim.

title: REPORTERS CURBED IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: South Africa's leading information official said in an article published today that despite a ban on television reporting of disturbances in black townships, ''accredited print journalists will still be able to report on any unrest incidents.''

title: Mixed Defense-Offense Deterrent Is Perilous
description: To the Editor:

title: Getting Smarter About Teen-Age Sex
description: ''A family is formed when a child is born,'' Senator Moynihan of New York said in a lecture last spring. ''When an unwed teen-ager gives birth, a broken family is formed.''

title: Hospital Corporation
description: The Hospital Corporation of America, the world's largest operator of for-profit hospitals, said Friday that its board had authorized the repurchase of up to $350 million of its common stock. The company, which has 89.8 million common shares outstanding, said that the purchases would be made from time to time on the open market and in private transactions.

title: FLYERS, DOWN 4-1, BEAT ISLANDERS, 5-4
description: It was a week in which the Philadelphia Flyers felt strangely vulnerable - an uncomfortable feeling in a sport that demands a certain degree of bravado and fearlessness. It was a week in which the Flyers talked about fate and how little control people - even hockey players - appear to have over events. It has helped them keep the game they play for a living in perspective and enabled them to treat a winning streak with the carefree attitude of someone enjoying a favorite amusement park ride.

title: WOMEN ATTRACT MORE SPECTATORS
description: For women's college basketball, the 1984-85 season was an auspicious one. National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament revenues reached an all-time high, as did spectator interest, due in no small part to the United States team's gold-medal performance in the 1984 Olympics. Georgeanne Wells of West Virginia even executed a dunk, the first successful one in women's organized competition.

title: Asleep at the Wheel, a National Nightmare
description: To the Editor:

title: ROCKEFELLER TREADS WARILY AROUND EXPECTATIONS
description: The name has talismanic power, even in a city crowded with famous men. The expectations are higher, the curiosity more intense. John D. Rockefeller 4th could not slip quietly into the apprenticeship of a freshman senator.

title: BEARS TROUNCE COWBOYS, 440
description: Walter Payton ran for 132 yards. The Refrigerator played fullback and ran for a yard. The Chicago Bears won again. Routine stuff? Forget it. The Bears' remarkable season rolled on today with their most emphatic victory of the year, 44-0 over the Dallas Cowboys. The triumph gave them an 11-0 record and a host of other residuals:

title: Advertising Executive Weds Patti Levenson
description: Patti Jo Levenson, a daughter of Malcolm N. Levenson of Florham Park, N.J., and Delray Beach, Fla., and Mrs. Alvin J. Simon of Livingston, N.J., was married at the Pierre Hotel in New York yesterday to William Lawrence Katz, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley H. Katz of West Orange, N.J. Rabbi Samuel Cohen performed the ceremony.

title: SEEKING MORE BERTHS FOR BOATS, JERSEY PLANS TO BAN FLOATING HOMES
description: Houseboats that are more house than boat will soon be banned in New Jersey, according to the State Department of Environmental Protection.

title: COLUMBIA WINS IN SOCCER PLAYOFF
description: By defeating the Long Island University Blackbirds yesterday for the second time in 13 days, the Columbia Lions proved they are indisputably the superior collegiate soccer team in New York City.

title: Lobbyists Turn to Ads to Shape Tax Bill
description: Between strains of classical music on a local radio station, listeners were lectured recently on the history and merits of the ''completed-contract'' method of tax accounting.

title: HOLLYWOOD WORRIED BY GROWING CASSETTE RENTALS
description: Patronage at the nation's movie theaters so far this year is down almost 15 percent from a year ago, causing growing concern in Hollywood that video-cassette rentals are cutting deeper and deeper into box-office receipts for new movies.

title: Victoria Louise Schwartz Married to Alan Rudolph
description: Victoria Louise Schwartz, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ruben Schwartz of New York, was married at the Pierre Hotel yesterday to Alan David Rudolph, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Wallace Rudolph of Reading, Pa.

title: Bette Miller Married To Dr. Robert Gromis
description: The marriage of Bette Miller, a daughter of Samuel Miller of Ridgefield, N.J., and Elaine Miller of Baltimore, to Dr. Robert Marvin Gromis, a son of Irving Gromis of Rego Park, Queens, and the late Anna Gromis, took place yesterday at the Park Avenue Synagogue in New York. Rabbi Harlan Wexler, assisted by Rabbi Harold Hirshman, performed the ceremony.

title: The City Gets Ready
description: No reservation? Too bad. xhrrAlmost all of the city's 12,000 or so hotel rooms and 200-some private limousine drivers are fully booked, and have been for months. The 500-plus rooms at the Intercontinental Hotel, the city's top private conference center, were reserved long ago by the White House, which is using it as a center for Reagan aides and White House press. The givers. xhrrGeneva officials say the summit meeting, which has required hundreds of hours of work by thousands of people, will ultimately cost the city some 2.5 million Swiss francs (about $1.15 million). The receivers. xhrrThe hotels and summit sites have been strung together by about 1,300 miles of telephone cable serving about 3,000 special direct lines. The Swiss Post, Telephone and Telegraph estimates the job has taken 3,700 working hours. Staying up late. xhrrGeneva's landmark, the Jet d'Eau, which spouts a geyser of water weighing seven tons more than 450 feet into the air - that's higher than the Statue of Liberty - will be turned on until 2 A.M. Normally in the autumn it is shut off at night and turned on only on windless, warm days to keep the Geneva harbor from being coated by ice from its mist. The Cordon Lumineux de la Rade, a string of lights illuminating Geneva's lakeshore harbor and roads, will also be left on until 2 A.M., as will the lights at such monuments as the Cathedral Saint-Pierre, the 12-foot floral clock in the Jardin Anglais, and other Geneva sites.

title: Mixed Defense-Offense Deterrent Is Perilous
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Toy' Blowguns Seized At Coast Sales Offices
description: More than 300 illegal blowguns advertised as ''toys'' were seized here, the police said Saturday.

title: Baby Sitter Held In Slaying of 2
description: A man who was caring for two small children when they were slain was arrested today and charged with their murder.

title: Election Policy Is a Legislative Job
description: New York's Court of Appeals recently approved Governor Cuomo's plan to distribute mail voter registration forms at state welfare, motor vehicle and other offices. But citing a ''potential for mischief,'' it struck down the part of the plan that would let state employees collect the completed forms.

title: SALVADORAN REBELS AGAIN CALL FOR SHARE OF POWER
description: The top military leaders of the leftist guerrilla movement made public a proposal here today that repeats past calls for a direct share of power in a transition government while promising a prolonged war if the Salvadoran Government refuses to negotiate.

title: Letter Bomb Injures Aide
description: A bomb in a package mailed to a University of Michigan professor exploded when the instructor's research assistant opened the parcel, causing minor injuries, the authorities said today. Nicklaus Suino suffered arm and stomach injuries when he opened the package Friday at the home of the psychology professor, James McConnell, according to the authorities, who said they had not determined a motive.

title: 'THE BRIEFINGS WAR': Q. AND A. IN ENGLISH AND RUSSIAN
description: The Soviet briefing followed the established pattern: a recitation of Soviet positions, a fiery exchange with a dissident, attacks on American policies and some snipes at the Reagan Administration.

title: After Marcos, More of the Same?
description: The Administration's pressure on President Ferdinand E. Marcos may well spell his downfall. Given the regime's grievous faults, this would seem to be an improvement over the current situation in the Philippines. But the key question is whether a future government will be competent to cope with the enormous economic and social problems that were becoming increasingly critical even before Mr. Marcos seized absolute authority in 1972.

title: LAKERS DEFEAT NETS
description: Dave Wohl spent most of the morning watching game tapes and planning strategy, but he had still allowed himself time to consider his homecoming. In the afternoon, he would visit the executive offices at the Forum and pick up his championship ring, a reward for his contribution, as assistant coach, to the Los Angeles Lakers' league title last season. In the evening, he would sit on the bench -but this time as the Nets' head coach.

title: 6TH-CENTURY MANUSCRIPT ADDS TO MYSTERY OF STAR
description: The long-standing mysteries surrounding Sirius, the brightest star seen from Earth, have been deepened by the discovery in a sixth-century manuscript of a description of the star as red.

title: S.E.C. Widens Insider Net
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission, whose insider trading charges against W. Paul Thayer have led to a four-year prison sentence and the relinquishment of more than $1 million in stock market profits, is pressing hard to extend the boundaries of improper behavior by insiders.

title: Ban on Libyan Oil
description: President Reagan on Friday banned the importation of refined petroleum products from Libya, saying the Middle Eastern country is circumventing a previous ban, issued in 1982, on crude oil imports while continuing terrorist activities. The order provides that no petroleum product refined in Libya may be imported into the United States, its territories or possessions, except for those loaded onto maritime vessels at any time earlier than two days after the order, which is effective immediately.

title: Joint Arco Venture
description: Another hot story from the far country involves Kresser, Craig/ D.I.K., a three-way joint venture of the Kresser, Craig agency, Doyle Dane Bernbach and Dai-Ichi-Kikaku of Japan, which beat out four other shops for the $15 million Atlantic Richfield account. The agency will be promoting the company, its petroleum products, and its gas station/ convenience store combinations in 13 states. The other shops in the competition were Foote, Cone & Belding, the incumbent; Backer & Spielvogel; Keye-Donna-Pearlstein, and Scali, McCabe, Sloves.

title: OPTIMISM ON HEAVY U.S. SALES
description: Although securities dealers do not expect to sell this week's heavy supply of new Treasury issues at the low yields that prevailed early last week, there is widespread optimism among investors, economists and traders that the new issues can be absorbed without any sizable rise in interest rates.

title: Filipino Opposition Disrupted by Infighting
description: The head of a coalition of opposition parties resigned today in a dispute with a possible challenger to President Ferdinand E. Marcos in elections next year.

title: Montclair State Gets Playoff Berth
description: Montclair State, winner of the New Jersey Conference championship for the third straight year and for the seventh time in the last eight seasons, will be host to Western Connecticut (10-1) in the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division III Eastern Regional playoffs Saturday afternoon at Sprague Field, Upper Montclair, N.J.

title: OLD CONFEDERATE CAPITAL BUILDS RACIAL HARMONY
description: For a long time, ''forever and ever,'' says M. Philmore Howlette, a black optometrist here, this graceful city on the James lived a separated life, the blacks mostly north of Broad Street, the whites south of it. The two camps came together mainly in the struggle over political access and power.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, NOVEMBER 18, 1985
description: The Economy

title: WEINBERGER NOTE SEEN AS OPPOSING SOFTNESS AT TALKS
description: Senior Administration officials said today that Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger did not disagree with White House positions on arms control but was concerned that those positions might not be maintained with sufficient firmness at the summit conference here.

title: Don Tennant Gets Lotte U.S.A. Account
description: Lotte U.S.A., the United States subsidiary of the Japanese chewing gum giant, has just retained the services of the Don Tennant Company, a Chicago ad agency, to help it outmarket the Yankee confectioners who have long dominated the domestic market.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: A TALL FOREIGNER KNOWN AS 'KOCHI' GIVES TOKYO A TASTE OF 'NYU YOKU'
description: A faraway place called Nyu Yoku burst onto this city's consciousness today in exhibitions of art, photography and film and a brief parade led by a man known here as Edowado Kochi.

title: ITALIAN LEADER SETS A RECORD FOR LONGEVITY
description: Prime Minister Bettino Craxi broke an Italian political record Friday that nearly eluded him: His became the longest-serving administration in Italian postwar history.

title: Poetry Grant to Kumin
description: Maxine Kumin has been named the 49th recipient of the $10,000 Fellowship for ''distinguished poetic achievement'' of the Academy of American Poets. Mrs. Kumin, who is also a novelist and essayist, received the Pulitzer Prize in 1974 for her collection of poetry, ''Up Country.'' Her latest collection, ''The Long Approach'' (Viking Press), was published in October.

title: Jane MacCallum Becomes a Bride
description: Jane Elizabeth MacCallum, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Douglas Clark MacCallum Jr. of Wyckoff, N.J., was married there yesterday to Benard Vincent Preziosi Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Preziosi of Brooklyn. The Rev. George J. Ruane performed the ceremony at St. Elizabeth's Roman Catholic Church.

title: Students in California Open A 'Safe House' for Refugees
description: Students from nine Southern California campuses have opened a ''safe house'' for Salvadoran and Guatemalan refugees who are in the United States illegally.

title: CHAMBER: ENSEMBLE FROM YALE
description: THE Yale Chamber Music concert at Merkin Hall on Saturday night was a strong advertisement for music at the school. Pieces from its teachers -played by other teachers and by students - were on display, first the ''Variations of Greek Themes'' by Frank Lewin, a faculty member for 15 years, and at the end Paul Hindemith's Concert Music for Piano, Ten Brass and Two Harps. Hindemith taught at Yale for 12 years.

title: BILL WOULD EASE STRINGS ON U.S. AID
description: The Reagan Administration has drafted a proposal calling on Congress to exempt state and local governments from many of the laws and rules that are a condition of receiving money from Washington.

title: I.C.C.'s Next Chairman
description: Heather Gradison, one of Washington's most aggressive deregulators, seems likely to be the next chairman of the faction-ridden Interstate Commerce Commission.

title: Fairchild Loses $77.6 Million
description: Fairchild Industries announced Friday that it had a loss of $77.6 million in the third quarter, compared with a profit of $7.5 million, or 32 cents a share, a year earlier.

title: Change of Pace
description: The emergence of Ron Brown as a kick-returner and receiver for the Los Angeles Rams has caused the Olympic flame to burn brighter still in the National Football League, which, except for the United States-boycotted Games of 1980, has enrolled at least one gold medalist from each Olympics since 1956.

title: RESERVOIRS HIT 56% LEVEL
description: The nearly 16 hours of rain, snow and sleet Saturday increased New York City's water supplies to 56 percent of capacity from 54 percent, environmental officials said yesterday.

title: DANCE: 2 NEW WORKS FROM COHEN
description: ZE'EVA COHEN'S presence and way of moving is so resonant that a decently danced program of her pieces, presented on Wednesday night at the Theater of the Riverside Church, seemed insubstantial without her on the stage. But she is also an appealingly literate choreographer, and the evening had its interest.

title: Back to Bipartisanship
description: The conventional wisdom is that a bipartisan foreign policy is dead, the victim of Vietnam, Iran, Afghanistan and an all-guns, no-butter President. Don't be too sure: There may be life in the old bipartisanship yet, and President Reagan has a rare historic opportunity - starting at the summit meeting - to restore it to robust health.

title: U.S. Financings to Dominate Week
description: A heavy slate of Treasury financings this week may deter many corporate borrowers, but state and local governments are expected to continue selling bonds at a record-breaking pace.

title: Statehouse Oddsmaking
description: This month's elections of governors in Virginia (a Democrat) and New Jersey (a Republican) did not change the political balance of power in the nation's statehouses, with 34 of the 50 remaining in Democratic hands. But political authorities believe this standoff is not likely to be repeated in November 1986, when the law of probability alone persuades the experts that some Republican gains are going to be made in the 36 contests for governor.

title: Ganges Pact to Be Signed
description: Irrigation Minister Anisul Islam Mahmud of Bangladesh left today for New Delhi to sign a three-year agreement on sharing waters of the Ganges River, starting next January. He told reporters before leaving that in three days of talks with Irrigation Minister B. Shankaranand of India, starting Monday, he would also discuss a possible joint study of the river.

title: Pacific Southwest Move
description: The news from the Coast was that Della Femina, Travisano Partners of California has once again become the agency for San Diego-based Pacific Southwest Airlines, which it had served in 1979 and 1980. The account, billing some $12 million, was formerly with the DYR agency, which resigned it. The airline operates in California and Arizona and is extending itself northward.

title: L.I.R.R. Suspends 8 Off-Peak Trains
description: Eight off-peak trains between Hicksville and Republic on the Ronkonkoma branch of the Long Island Rail Road will not run today through Friday because of electrification work on the main line.

title: Briefcases
description: Senator Lloyd Bentsen of Texas, ranking Democratic member of a Senate trade subcommittee, is pleading with President Reagan to reject a proposal to create a Cabinet-level committee to assess the strategic implications of international trade. He and others fear that trade would be subordinated to national security and foreign policy considerations.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: A SPATE (or, rather, glut) of books has come out about management and corporate life whose common message seems to be: How to overpower your rivals by guile. Reading as if they were stamped out by the same M.B.A. cookie-cutter, they offer advice about everything from dressing for success to applying military tactics in the company board room and marketplace. Their canny, commercial authors suggest that the product is less important than the hustle or hustler behind it, that the customer no longer comes first. On the highest levels, the new version of old-fashioned free competition now goes: Arbitrage thy neighbor.

title: Quaker State Purchase
description: The Quaker State Oil Refining Corporation, seeking to become the national leader in the fast-lubrication business, has acquired 90 fast-lubrication centers from Arctic Circle Inc. of Salt Lake City. Arctic Circle also operated more than 100 fast-food restaurants, primarily in the West.

title: CUOMO'S NEW COUNSEL IS GETTING HIS BEARINGS
description: The papers heaped on Evan A. Davis's desk as he prepares for the proposed autumn session of the Legislature remind him of his role in the impeachment proceedings against President Richard M. Nixon. He headed the Congressional legal team looking into the Watergate break-in.

title: Space, Part 2
description: A million pinpoints of light shone beneath them, but the most eagerly sought pinpoint - that new arrival in the night sky known as Halley's comet - eluded the Scouts' search.

title: Bush Hears Pleas Of Farmers in Iowa
description: Vice President Bush, after hearing an appeal for Federal help to ease farmers' credit problems, toured an Iowa farm and met with three families today.

title: New Challenge
description: When you're born poor, you're not supposed to run the road of life with as much speed and control as Nate (Tiny) Archibald continues to display at age 37. But after retiring as a player two years ago, the little kid from the South Bronx who grew up to be a five-time all-star in the National Basketball Association is proud, wealthy and, having been recently appointed an assistant coach at the University of Georgia, newly inspired.

title: THE DANCE: 'ULTRACITY,' BY ROBERT DESROSIERS
description: ROBERT DESROSIERS, a young Canadian choreographer who belongs in a happily zany class by himself, showed off his free-spirited imagination locally for the first time Saturday night with the New York premiere of a full-evening work, ''Ultracity.''

title: HUTTON CITES DELINQUENT MORTGAGES
description: A significant portion of the more than 6,000 residential mortgages issued by the failed First American Mortgage Company are in delinquency, according to papers filed in a lawsuit against the company by E. F. Hutton & Company. Such a large-scale delinquency raises the possibility of a new upheaval in the secondary market for home mortgages.

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: An article on the opinion page of the Sports section yesterday discussed the recurrent problem of college sports and gambling. The article was illustrated with photographs made in 1951 of some of the college students who were involved in basketball scandals then. These students do not figure in the current situation, and in fairness the photographs should not have been republished at this time, 34 years after the event.

title: Ulster Protestants Vow To Undermine Accord
description: Protestants vowed today to protest a new British-Irish accord by paralyzing Northern Ireland's Government.

title: FOR CARTWRIGHT, WAIT, WATCH
description: Bill!

title: STAGE: 'CHRISTMAS SPECTACULAR' AT RADIO CITY
description: CHRISTMAS in America encompasses so many different images, myths and traditions that any attempt to sum up all of them in a single stage show requires finding a coherent tone and style of presentation.

title: The U.N. Today: Nov. 18, 1985
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: OF LAKES, AIRPORT JAMS AND A GIFT OF DONKEYS
description: Environmental issues tend to be local concerns in many parts of the West, confined to a fight over a dam on some river, a road through a trackless forest.

title: AXELROD SAYS HOTELS ARE SUBJECT TO CURBS ON SEX LINKED TO AIDS
description: The New York State Health Commis sioner said yesterday that the state's drive to curb unsafe sexual activity linked to the spread of AIDS will be extended to any hotel in which such activity is found to be taking place.

title: BRITON SAYS HE MET HOSTAGES' CAPTORS
description: A special envoy of the Archbishop of Canterbury who has spent five days in Lebanon trying to obtain the release of four American hostages returned to London today after saying he had met with their captors.

title: MAILER AND VIDAL AT PEN CELEBRATION
description: Writers are like boxers, Norman Mailer likes to argue - they are not so much literary gentlemen as ambitious prize-fighters, slugging it out for the crown of ''presumptive literary champ.'' Unlike most contenders for that title, however, he and Gore Vidal have not been content to compete for popular and critical acclaim with their work. Instead, they have held a series of nasty verbal sparring matches, spanning more than a decade - and even resorted to punching and shoving. Back in 1971, Mr. Mailer butted Mr. Vidal in the head before going on ''The Dick Cavett Show,'' and six years later, the two authors again came to physical blows at a New York party.

title: Missing the Prince
description: In politics, priorities can be controlling. Last month Chief Justice Warren E. Burger, who is chairman of the Commission on the Bicentennial of the Constitution, asked Griffin B. Bell, the former Attorney General, if he would be free to come to Washington Nov. 11 and brief the Prince of Wales on the Constitution during the Prince's scheduled visit to the Library of Congress. Mr. Bell checked his engagement book and said he couldn't make it; he had agreed to introduce former President Jimmy Carter to the Downtown Rotary Club of Atlanta that day.

title: O'BRIEN LEADS 62-28 ROUT
description: Once the Jets finally got started today, after being delayed by a brief power failure in Giants Stadium and a surprising 14-0 deficit, they produced their most high-powered victory ever, 62-28 over the Tampa Bay Buccaneers.

title: QUESTION BOX
description: QUESTION: Have there been any 0-0 games in the National Hockey League since the five-minute overtime was instituted?

title: COLOMBIA REPORTS A SUSPENSION OF RESCUE EFFORTS
description: The search for survivors in the mud-covered town of Armero was reported to have been suspended today despite reports that many people were still trapped alive there. Government officials issued conflicting statements on whether the search would be resumed.

title: Bus Crashes in England
description: A bus filled with elderly people smashed into a tanker truck and several cars in a chain-reaction accident today on a fog-shrouded highway, killing 2 people and injuring 51. The police said the crash occurred near Birmingham, about 100 miles northwest of London. The bus was carrying World War II veterans from Liverpool to a memorial service in London.

title: SOVIET REACTOR BID DIVIDES U.S. AIDES
description: Only two days before the start of the summit meeting in Geneva, the Reagan Administration was reported today to be sharply divided on whether to accept a Soviet proposal for beginning construction of a huge test reactor for development of controlled thermonuclear fusion energy.

title: 'RIVER JOURNEYS' LOOKS AT THE CONGO
description: THE fine ''River Journeys'' series on public television proves that eloquent words can help a thousand pictures. So many documentaries use only a form of simple caption writing, the words coming across almost as an afterthought to the scenes. In this series, writers are placed at the center of the narrative, on camera, and carry the story along with unusual eloquence. The viewer can hear real sentences spoken with the pictures.

title: Allis Appoints New Chairman
description: The Allis-Chalmers Corporation said Friday that Wendell F. Bueche, its president and chief executive, had been named chairman, effective Jan. 1.

title: OIL GROUP EXPECTED TO ASSAIL TAX PLAN
description: A change in tax policies, oil exploration in the Great Lakes and offshore California and the poor prognosis for oil prices next spring, as well as the short-term natural gas outlook, are expected to be discussed widely at the annual meeting of the American Petroluem Institute that begins Monday in San Francisco.

title: Paula S. Reichler Wed To K. R. Parker in Rye
description: Paula S. Reichler, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Reichler of New Rochelle, N.Y., and Kevin R. Parker, the son of Mrs. John Dolan of New Milford, N.J., and the late Charles M. Parker, were married yesterday. Rabbi Robert Rothman performed the ceremony at the Rye (N.Y.) Community Synagogue.

title: Ambassador to Somewhere
description: How fleeting is fame, or, how remote Ithaca. Cornell University's most recent alumni magazine listed among ''lost'' Class of 1969 members ''Richard Burt (in Washington, D.C., somewhere).'' Mr. Burt, former Assistant Secretary of State for European and Canadian Affairs, is now United States Ambassador to West Germany.

title: TV APPEALS TO SEEK FUNDS TO COMBAT AIDS
description: Television stations in New York and at least two other major cities plan to begin airing public service announcements urging Americans to contribute to the fight against AIDS.

title: RANGERS OVERTIME LOSERS
description: With the Garden crowd pumped up last night as it has not been this season, in came the Rangers from every angle. Jan Erixon shot from the left. Ron Greschner sidestepped a defenseman directly in front of the goalie and shot. Mike Ridley tried to force the puck in with a desperate jam. But each time, there was the goalkeeper Andy Moog warding them off.

title: Explaining Revamped Newsweek
description: NEWSWEEK magazine, totally overhauled from back to front in a $1 million reformatting, will be introduced to its reading public today in a nationwide mass newsstand and home-delivered effort. At the same time, the new look will be explained to agency executives in nine important advertising cities by the magazine's top editorial and business executives.

title: How to Make a Successful Convention Center
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Opportunistic Acquirer' Will Operate a Railroad
description: W. Wallace McDowell has never run a railroad, but that did not stop the Prospect Group, the closely held New York venture capital company he heads, from agreeing last week to invest in one.

title: BALLY-MGM GRAND DEAL ANNOUNCED
description: The Bally Manufacturing Corporation, expanding its interests in the hotel and casino business, agreed this weekend to buy MGM Grand Hotels Inc. for about $440 million. The purchase, if completed, would give Bally ownership of the two MGM Grand casino-hotels in Reno and Las Vegas, Nev.

title: EAGLES TOPPLE CARDS
description: Earnest Jackson ran for 162 yards and a touchdown and Mike Quick caught two touchdown passes today to lead the Philadelphia Eagles to a 24-14 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals.

title: Catching Up
description: Just how nasty can people get? Ask Don Denkinger, the American League umpire who called Jorge Orta safe at first in the ninth inning of Game 6 and - if you believe his most heated critics - thereby handed the World Series to the Kansas City Royals. Denkinger, back home in Waterloo, Iowa, says he is still receiving mail about the call from baseball fans, some 75 percent of it sympathetic.

title: Halley's Comet
description: Halley's Comet will rise over the New York City area at 4:14 P.M. today and set at 6:59 A.M. tomorrow.

title: ABC SERIES 'LADY BLUE' SWITCHES TO SATURDAYS
description: KATY MAHONEY'S most distinguishing characteristics are her screaming red hair and a .357 Magnum that appears to be a grotesque extension of her right arm. Clearly a fan of Clint Eastwood movies, Katy won't flinch if called Dirty Harriet. Played by Jamie Rose, she is shooting her way through the streets of Chicago in ''Lady Blue,'' an ABC series that has the distinction of topping several watchdog lists as television's most violent entertainment program. It has just been shifted to a new time period, Saturdays at 9 P.M.

title: Athens Police Kill Boy After a Protest March
description: The police shot into a crowd of protesters today and killed a 15-year-old boy when a march on the United States Embassy by 100,000 people seeking Greek withdrawal from NATO turned violent.

title: SYRACUSE BOWL BID SEEMS LONG SHOT
description: Syracuse's impressive 41-21 victory over Boston College, the team's fourth straight triumph, improved the Orangemen's record to 6-3 but it apparently brought them no closer to a bowl bid. No representatives from any of the 18 bowl games showed up at the Carrier Dome, although Syracuse had expected the All-American, Cherry and Liberty bowls to send people.

title: Perry's Small Favor
description: Among those who have followed the backfield exploits of William Perry with special interest is Larry Kinnebrew of the Cincinnati Bengals. He has a personal steak - er, stake - in mind. ''Everybody was saying that I was too big,'' declares Kinnebrew, who, if you ignore Perry (that's no small undertaking, granted), is the largest fullback in the National Football League. ''But they can't talk about my size now.''

title: Why Geneva?
description: Geneva's role as a gathering point is rooted in the days of John Calvin in the 16th century, when the Reformation attracted Europe's refugees from religious persecution.

title: On the Agenda
description: Arms Control: Talking Tough rrxhThe focal point of Soviet-American dialogue has been the arms talks on strategic arms, medium-range weapons and space-based defenses. Both sides have offered cuts in offensive missiles, but there are differences on the cuts. The Russians have seemed to rule out progress on arms cuts until Washington ends work on President Reagan's plan to develop a space-based missile defense.

title: GRAIN FUTURES ARE DETHRONED
description: A decade ago, the go-go pulse of Wall Street had nothing on the commodity pits in Chicago, where mobs of shouting traders wheeled and dealed in wheat, corn, soybean and other agricultural futures.

title: PARITY REPLACES EWING
description: FOR all of its final drama in Lexington last April 1, the 1984-85 college basketball season was dominated by super players on super teams in super conferences.

title: Most Pipelines Shun Rule 436
description: A KEY element in the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission's sweeping new regulations for the natural gas industry is proving far less successful than had been hoped. So far, only four of 28 major pipeline companies have signed up for the voluntary program under which they may choose to become ''open access'' carriers, transporting gas on a nondiscriminatory basis for all.

title: Space for Arts Groups Is Topic of Conference
description: Volunteer Lawyers for the Arts will present ''The Space Chase: A Conference for Nonprofit Arts Organizations on How to Find and Finance Administrative, Rehearsal, Exhibition, and Performance Space'' on Dec. 12 and 13 at New York Telephone's midtown headquarters, 1095 Avenue of the Americas, at 42d Street.

title: Wheeling Has 3d-Period Loss
description: The Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation, still reeling from the aftershocks of a recently settled 98-day strike, reported a third-quarter loss Friday of $133.1 million, compared with a loss of $9.9 million a year earlier. Wheeling said its results were ''severely affected'' by the strike, which began July 31.

title: U.S. Joins Companies In Program
description: In a joint approach to providing technical assistance to developing countries, the Government and more than a dozen American corporations have been training hundreds of telecommunications managers and engineers from abroad.

title: GIANTS RECEIVE ADDED INCENTIVE
description: The last time the Giants won five consecutive games was in 1977. The last time they had a record as good as 8-3 was in 1963, when their big guns included Y. A. Tittle, Frank Gifford, Alex Webster, Del Shofner, Rosey Brown and Don Chandler.

title: What Kind of School Costs $630 a Year?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Smart Man, Indeed
description: In World War II, Albert Einstein took on some research assigments for the Navy while he was attachedto the Institute for Advanced Study at Princeton, N.J. Some of his 1943-1944 correspondence with the Bureau of Ordnance, including a handwritten letter with torpedo diagrams,recently came to light in the Pentagon and has been transferred to the National Archives.

title: CROWDED CITY SCHOOL USING HALLS FOR CLASSROOMS
description: Public School 128 in upper Manhattan has so many pupils and so little space for them that some have to attend reading and English classes in hallways and consult with the school psychologist in a small storage room.

title: LATE PATRIOT SCORE DEFEATS SEAHAWKS
description: Steve Grogan's 13-yard touchdown pass to Irving Fryar with 2 minutes 39 seconds left today gave the New England Patriots a comeback 20-13 victory over the Seattle Seahawks.

Academy, which is based in Valley Forge, Pa., also said that its chairman and chief executive, Elvin H. Clemens, had resigned.

title: Vatican Recognition of Israel Has Been Discussed for Years
description: To the Editor:

title: PENTAGON INVESTIGATORS LOOKING INTO DISCLOSURE
description: Secretary of Defense Casper W. Weinberger has ordered the Pentagon's own investigative arm to determine how a letter he wrote to President Reagan urging a firm stand in arms negotiations at Geneva found its way into the press.

Donald Droll, 58, Dies; Art Dealer and Patron
description: Donald Droll, a curator, art patron and former dealer in New York City, died Sunday, apparently of a heart attack, at his home in Greensboro, N.C. He was 58 years old. For the last three years Mr. Droll had served as assistant director of the Wetherspoon Art Gallery of the University of North Carolina.

title: ITALY CONVICTS PALESTINIANS IN ARMS CASE
description: Five Palestinians accused in the hijacking of the cruise ship Achille Lauro were convicted today of gun and explosives possession and sentenced to jail terms ranging from four to nine years.

title: 2D-HOME DEDUCTION IS BACKED
description: A working group of members of the House Ways and Means Committee, rejecting President Reagan's proposal, voted today to permit taxpayers to deduct all their interest payments on mortgages on second homes.

title: COUSINS HOME FURNISHINGS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
GORBACHEV, IN GENEVA, ASKS FOR END TO THE ARMS RACE
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev arrived here today and said that the ''first and foremost'' issue facing his meetings with President Reagan starting Tuesday was how to halt the arms race ''and its extension to new spheres.''

title: Tesoro Sells Stake In Trinidad Unit
description: The Tesoro Petroleum Corporation said that it had sold its 49.9 percent stake in the Trinidad-Tesoro Petroleum Company Ltd. to the Government of Trinidad and Tobago, which owns the other 50.1 percent of the company. Tesoro, which is based in San Antonio, will receive as payment 3.23 million barrels of fuel oil from Trinidad over 18 months starting next May.

title: NOSE IS BATTLEGROUND FOR FIGHT AGAINST WINTER'S ILLS
description: EVERY winter the human nose is besieged by germs. This year, through new medical research, the nose is being encouraged to fight back.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: CHAD THERAPEUTICS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
U.S. IS FACED BY THREE LAWSUITS TO RESTORE TIGHT AUTO FUEL RULES
description: The Reagan Administration's decision to roll back Federal fuel efficiency standards for new cars is being challenged in court even as the two largest car companies prepare strategies so they can comply with the relaxed requirements.

title: Advertising;   Arnold & Co. Stake Sold to Employee Trust
description: At a meeting in a Boston hotel the work force of the 39-year-old Arnold & Company heard confirmation yesterday from its founder, Arnold Z. Rosoff, who had been the sole stockholder, that he had indeed sold a majority of his stock in the agency to its Employees' Profit Sharing Retirement Trust. And he got less money than he would have if he had sold to some of the agencies that were looking to acquire the agency.

title: BERRA TO BE COACH IN HOUSTON
description: Yogi Berra, who in 39 major-league years as a player, manager and coach worked only for the Yankees and the Mets, will leave home next season to serve as a coach with the Houston Astros.

title: K MART CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
ROSE M. TRAPANI
description: Rose M. Trapani, a partner in the Brooklyn law firm of Carroll & Trapani, died of cancer yesterday at New York Hospital. She was 73 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: Colombia's Insurgents Capture a Cattle Town
description: A band of 150 leftist guerrillas traveling in milk trucks today seized the cattle town of Urrao, west of Medellin, and took about 100 people hostage, according to reports on Colombian radio stations.

title: DANCE: BEBE MILLER WORKS PERFORMED AT P.S. 122
description: BEBE MILLER and her four dancers rarely stopped moving Saturday night in a performance of Miss Miller's dances at P.S. 122, First Avenue and Ninth Street. There were sleek lunges, a few freezes and brief moments of stillness as bodies touched the floor in falls. The overall impression, however, was of nonstop dancing by five exceptional performers. Yet by the end of the program, one had the sense of witnessing quite complex emotions and relationships, as well as being invited to share in the delight of purely physical wit. It was an evening that promises to be one of the season's highlights.

title: GRESCHNER FEELS REJUVENATED
description: There was old Ron Greschner of the Rangers, the man who had seen it all, sitting back, watching over the locker room, wondering where the time had gone. That's the way he saw himself, and it seemed he relished the role. ''I've been at this a long time,'' he said. ''I'm the old guy on this team and I've lived to tell about it.''

title: FARM BILL FACING VETO, HELMS SAYS
description: As the Senate resumed work today on a comprehensive four-year farm bill, Senator Jesse Helms warned lawmakers that President Reagan would veto the legislation if its cost to the Federal Treasury was not significantly reduced.

title: McGee Named Most Valuable
description: Willie McGee, whose 1981 trade to St. Louis has turned out to be one of the most one-sided in baseball, was named the National League's most valuable player yesterday in balloting that was dominated by Cardinals and Mets.

title: O Little Town . . .
description: There is still some doubt whether there will be a Christian nativity scene this year next to the National Christmas Tree behind the White House. Technically, the decision is to be made by the National Park Service on the recommendation of the Pageant for Peace Committee. But considering how Washington works, it is unlikely that a decision would be made that did not have at least the tacit approval of President Reagan, who is to light the tree in mid-December.

description: Government, they say, is all about dividing up the pie. So when Governor Cuomo was in Washington yesterday, he stopped on Capitol Hill to pick up his slice - of pizza.

U.S. PRICES CLIMB DESPITE SALES DUE
description: On the eve of four consecutive days of Treasury note and bond auctions, the credit markets brushed aside worries about the heavy supply of new issues, and prices rose sharply to send interest rates down for short- and long-term securities.

title: Loeb's Long Arm
description: William Loeb, the outspoken conservative publisher of The Manchester Union Leader in New Hampshire, seems to have lost little influence since his death in 1981. A political group is holding a black-tie dinner in New Hampshire in his honor on Dec. 11, and the four most active Republican Presidential candidates for 1988 are all planning to attend, mindful of course that New Hampshire holds the first Presidential primary.

title: Holy Cross Star Hurt
description: The Holy Cross star running back, Gill Fenerty, was hospitalized with a head injury after leaving Saturday's football game against Boston University at halftime because of headaches and vomiting. The 22-year-old senior from New Orleans was listed in fair condition yesterday at St. Vincent Hospital in Worcester, Mass., and his headaches had eased. Dr. James Walsh, the team physician, said Fenerty was expected to be hospitalized for the rest of the week so his condition could be monitored. Fenerty set a Holy Cross record for touchdowns in a career with 27 when he scored two in the first half Saturday.

title: E.P.A. ISSUES ADVICE ON AVOIDING TOXIC ACCIDENTS
description: The Environmental Protection Agency began an effort today to help states, municipalities, chemical companies and unions avoid a major chemical accident like the one in Bhopal, India, last December.

title: NATIONAL FUEL GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BEARS, AT 11-0, FACE NEW CHALLENGES
description: With five more victories, the Chicago Bears can become the first team since 1972 to finish a National Football League regular season undefeated and the first to do so under the 16-game format, which has been in effect since 1978.

title: CELIA CRUZ: AT THE TOP OF SALSA
description: ''When people hear me sing,'' said Celia Cruz, the widely acknowledged queen of Latin music, ''I want them to be happy, happy, happy. I don't want them thinking about when there's not any money, or when there's fighting at home. My message is always felicidad - happiness.''

title: Advertising;   Henderson Friedlich Given Name Change
description: Last week's Henderson Friedlich Graf & Doyle is this week's Doyle Graf Mabley, reflecting the arrival last August of Thomas Mabley, 52, to be executive vice president and domestic creative director.

title: Maxxam Files Suit
description: Maxxam Group Inc., led by the Houston investor Charles E. Hurwitz, said it had filed suit in Federal court here to block a temporary restraining order issued in California Superior Court in Humboldt County that prevents Maxxam from accepting and buying shares in the Pacific Lumber Company. There will be a hearing Nov. 25 on the injunction sought by two Pacific shareholders. As of the expiration of Maxxam's $40-a-share tender offer on Nov. 8, about 13.1 million, or 60 percent, of Pacific's shares outstanding had been tendered.

description: BIG advertising agencies apparently are quite content with giving less than the best service to their clients in the area of print media planning. They seem willing to allow planners to totally base their judgments on audience and cost efficiency data generated by a computer and not factor in judgments that come from firsthand familiarization with the magazines themselves. That seems to shortchange the advertisers.

title: 5 MORE ARE FOUND ALIVE IN MUD AS COLOMBIAN SEARCH CONTINUES
description: Rescue workers found at least five more people alive in the sea of mud in this ruined town today, including an 18-month-old boy.

title: TRIAL OF DISSIDENTS IN YUGOSLAVIA SEEMS TO HAVE SPLIT COMMUNISTS
description: More than nine months after a trial in which three dissidents were sentenced to jail terms, a belief is growing here that the Serbian authorities would prefer to end the case, which has embarrassed Yugoslavia abroad, by not carrying out the sentences.

title: JACOB JOHN GORDON
description: Jacob John Gordon, a perennial political candidate who once forced television networks to cancel coverage of one of President Ford's news conferences, died Friday after an illness. He was 65 years old. Mr. Gordon, a mortgage broker, came to national attention in 1975 when the CBS and NBC broadcasting networks canceled coverage of a Ford news conference because Federal law required them to give equal time to Mr. Gordon, who was running for the 1976 Republican Presidential nomination.

title: SUMMING UP SPRING: 7TH AVENUE TRENDS
description: Within the framework of neat, slender shapes, New York designers have developed spring fashions that look fresh without assaulting the eye. Clothes are in an evolutionary cycle, and there are no drastic revisionist theories, which means there is no need to toss out last year's wardrobe, or even to contemplate doing so.

title: Toxic Chemical Leaks; Hundreds Are Routed
description: One of the chemicals on the Environmental Protection Agency's list of highly toxic substances leaked yesterday at an Olin Corporation plant in Wilmington, Mass., last night, forcing the evacuation of hundreds of people.

title: VERDIX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-The company said it had no meaningful revenue in the year-ago quarter.

title: PHYSICIANS PANEL SAYS PUPIL HAS THE VIRUS BUT NOT AIDS
description: A child whose attendance in a New York City public school has been the subject of a bitter court fight does not technically suffer from AIDS, a panel of seven doctors has determined.

title: TMBR DRILLING reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * All Seasons Resorts Inc., Redmond, Wash., said James J. Flood had resigned as chairman and chief executive officer.

title: Arts Club Award
description: Joseph Kesselring must have felt right at home in the sumptuous Victorian mansion of the National Arts Club at 15 Gramercy Park South. Mr. Kesselring, author of ''Arsenic and Old Lace,'' liked the place so much that he bequeathed a substantial endowment to the club for an annual young playwright's award in his name.

title: SOUTH FLORIDA PREPARES FOR A HURRICANE
description: South Florida was placed on alert today for a freak late-season hurricane that blew out of the Caribbean and sent boats and people heading for shelter.

title: DATRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PLAN WOULD PROMOTE 200 WHO FAILED EXAM
description: The city's Corporation Counsel said yesterday that 200 black and Hispanic police officers who had failed a sergeant examination would be promoted under a racial quota the city has proposed to settle a lawsuit.

title: For a Young Family, a Home Is Mostly a Dream
description: To the Editor:

title: LASER PRECISION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
JACQUES HNIZDOVSKY
description: Jacques Hnizdovsky, an artist whose woodcut prints were shown in galleries and museums around the world, died Nov. 8 at Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville, N.Y., after suffering a stroke. He was 70 years old, and lived in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.

title: E. RODRIGUEZ MONEGAL
description: Emir Rodriguez Monegal, director of graduate studies in Spanish and Portuguese at Yale University, died Thursday at the university's Health Services infirmary in New Haven. He was 64 years old and lived in New Haven.

title: MUSIC: NEW YORK SYMPHONIC ENSEMBLE
description: THE New York Symphonic Ensemble's concert at Alice Tully Hall Sunday night was most interesting for its two pieces from Japan. Toshio Hosokawa's ''Hajah,'' written for two small orchestras and accordian, featured delicately colored, high-pitched sheets of sound, scattered with the small ornamental details that ultimately created the character and the content of the music.

title: SHARON STEEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MARGARET AKAGI
description: Margaret Akagi, an advertising account executive, was struck and killed by a truck last Wednesday near her office on the West Side of Manhattan. She was 67 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: 'PEOPLE TRAUMA' IN MERGERS
description: After Gulf Oil was acquired by Chevron in March 1984, John H. Pronsky, a Gulf general manager of marketing, felt betrayed by his company's leaders. ''How could my management let this happen to me?'' he recalled feeling. ''It was like a death in the family,'' said Mr. Pronsky, who, after working at Gulf for eight and a half years, quit last January and went to work for Schlumberger.

description: The Deputy Commissioner of the Immigration and Naturalization Service today recommended the demotion and temporary suspension without pay of two border agents who forcibly returned a Ukrainian seaman to his ship last month.

title: APPRAISING ARTIFICIAL HEART: DAYS OF DOUBT
description: William J. Schroeder, the longest-living survivor of an artificial heart implant, is approaching an important anniversary. Next Monday he will have lived for a full year after his diseased natural heart was replaced with a permanent plastic-and-metal pump that draws its power from a large, external machine.

title: Philippines' Loan Backed
description: The International Monetary Fund said today that a special lending team had recommended release of a $110 million loan to the Philippines that the fund had held up since September.

title: CHESS: THREE SOVIET PLAYERS IN A TIE AT MONTPELLIER TOURNAMENT
description: Artur Yusupov, Rafael Vaganian and Andrei Sokolov, all of the Soviet Union, tied for first place in the World Championship Candidates Tournament in Montpellier, France. They each scored 9-6.

title: REDSKINS RALLY PAST GIANTS AFTER LOSING THEISMANN
description: The Redskins could have folded when Joe Theismann, their 36-year-old quarterback, suffered a compound fracture of the lower right leg tonight. Instead, behind Jay Schroeder, a rarely used backup, they struck back and beat the high-flying Giants, 23-21.

title: O'NEILL SUGGESTS SUMMIT GOAL
description: The Speaker of the House, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., said today that reversing the nuclear arms race and ''reducing the danger of nuclear war'' should be the most important goal of President Reagan at the Geneva summit meeting with Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader.

We're Growing Up as a Nation of Loners
description: To the Editor:

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: JAZZ The Art Ensemble of Chicago is in its 20th year of togetherness, and the good news is that it is observing its milestone this week in New York, at Sweet Basil, the Greenwich Village restaurant at 88 Seventh Avenue South, at Bleecker Street (242-1785).

title: Maryland Transit Unit Offers Bonds

description: Ameritech, one of the regional telephone companies created out of the breakup of the Bell System, said today that it would acquire Applied Data Research Inc. for $32 a share, or a total of about $215 million.

description: THE proposed addition of three new psychiatric disorders - for those with a masochistic personality, for men who rape and for women with premenstrual syndrome - to the official diagnostic manual aroused vigorous opposition at a meeting of psychiatrists today.

title: PROTESTERS DEFY DARTMOUTH ORDER
description: Students demanding immediate divestment of Dartmouth College's holdings in South Africa today defied an order by the school administration to dismantle a small shantytown on the college green. Instead, they built a third shack.

title: Business and Health;   The Magnetic Body Scanner
description: HUGE magnets that produce internal pictures of a patient by computer are a leading glamour item in health technology. The new machines, known as magnetic resonance imagers, are already credited with important advances in medical knowledge. They are also generating opportunities for investment, stirring ethical controversy among physician-entrepreneurs and challenging the national effort to control health costs.

title: Tyler Signs Offer

The offer sheet with the seven-year forward was signed following discussions between the Kings' president and general manager, Joe Axelson, and the Pistons' general manager, Jack McCloskey, Axelson said.

title: Ex-Lecturer Tells Of Work for Nazis
description: A former Yale University lecturer testified today that he collaborated with Nazi propagandists during World War II because he needed the money to survive in his native Russia.

title: Passive Smoking Risk
description: Parents who smoke can expose their children to enough nicotine to equal the effects of smoking about 80 cigarettes a year, a British study has found. The research team said this much ''passive smoking'' in children aged 11 to 16 may be enough to have ''deleterious effects on health,'' including chronic coughs and related respiratory problems.

title: Credit Card Rate List Released
description: Representative Charles E. Schumer and two consumer groups released a list of the 30 banks today that they said issue credit cards at the lowest interest rates.

title: Silent Summit Vigil
description: While President Reagan is in Geneva talking to Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, today and tomorrow, the National Council of Jewish Women plans to have 700 people standing in a silent vigil near the Soviet Embassy on 16th Street in downtown Washington. The council will demonstrate because it feels that since Mr. Gorbachev came to power eight months ago, ''life for Jews trapped within the Soviet Union has worsened.''

title: CONTINENTAL HEALTH AFFILIATED reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
WEST SIDERS VOICE CONCERN ON PLAN
description: An overflow crowd of West Siders listened attentively last night as Donald J. Trump, surrounded by drawings, photographs and a scale model, presented his 13-block Television City project to its neighbors. The initial reactions ranged from skepticism to outright opposition.

title: Books: A Jazz Genius
description: A recent guest appearance by Miles Davis on ''Miami Vice,'' the television series, offered a humorous reminder that the 59-year-old trumpet player, who first moved to New York in 1945, continues to search for varied, if not higher, ground. Jack Chambers, in this impressive, almost note-for-note, two-volume musical biography, traces the roots of that search.

title: Carroll Listed as Stable
description: The former major-league pitcher, Clay Carroll, was listed in stable condition yesterday with gunshot wounds suffered in a domestic dispute that left his wife dead and his son critically injured. ''Mr. Carroll's condition was upgraded from serious to stable on Sunday,'' said Margie Cannon, the nursing supervisor at Blake Memorial Hospital in Bradenton, Fla. Hospital officials have refused to say what injuries the 44-year-old Carroll had suffered.

description: A picture caption with the television listings yesterday misidentified an actor in the film ''Contract on Cherry Street.'' The actor, shown with Frank Sinatra and Martin Balsam, was Harry Guardino, not Ron Polito.

description: Anyone who thought that America's Cup politics would subside once the New York Yacht Club was no longer the host has been proved wrong. Indeed, Alan Bond's Australian defense team is loudly crying foul.

title: U.S. AND MOSCOW ARE SAID TO AGREE ON FUTURE TALKS
description: High-ranking American and Soviet officials were reported tonight to have agreed in principle that President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev should hold a second summit meeting after their two days of talks that start Tuesday.

title: PROSECUTORS CHARGE JUDGE TOOK 7 BRIBES
description: Federal prosecutors yesterday charged in opening arguments that a state judge in Queens had engaged in a ''pattern of racketeering'' since the early 1970's by taking bribes to fix seven criminal cases, even promising to return the bribes if the results were unsatisfactory.

title: THE SUMMIT: A PROLOGUE?
description: Soviet officials here, apparently in a policy shift, are now talking about the summit meeting more as an occasion to begin a dialogue with the United States than as an event to score a breakthrough in arms control.

title: AMERICAN FAMILY PIZZA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 29
VOYAGER 2 SPOTS RINGS OF URANUS
description: THE spacecraft Voyager 2, approaching the outer planet Uranus for a close approach in January, has been able to detect the outermost and largest of that planet's nine known rings, according to the Jet Propulsion Laboratory of the California Institute of Technology, which is conducting the mission for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.

title: Possible Appointee
description: Mayor Koch is entertaining the idea of appointing Robert F. Wagner Jr., one of his former deputy mayors, to a vacancy on the Board of Education. The idea would be for him to become president of a revamped board in the future.

title: IF WE ENDED THE ARMS RACE
description: A 60-year-old friend told us that he was beaten up in his own home in Washington, D.C., not long ago when he surprised a large man who was ransacking the apartment. The man was looking for television equipment he could sell to buy drugs. He was also one of more than 10,000 people on parole in that city, most of whom are drug offenders. Many of these men have been let out of prison because there are not enough jail cells to hold them. At the same time, parole officers carry heavy caseloads, and funds for rehabilitation and treatment are drying up.

title: SULFUR CLOUD FROM ERUPTION TRACKED WITH SATELLITE'S AID
description: Satellite measurements of the gas cloud ejected rom the Nevado del Ruiz volcano last week indicate that the eruption released twice as much sulfurous gas into the sky as the 1980 eruption of Mount St. Helens and five times as much as the 1982 eruption of Galunggung in Indonesia.

title: Company Charged In Guard's Death
description: A metal-recovery company here was charged today with criminally negligent homicide in the death of a security guard who was overcome by carbon monoxide.

title: A Familiar Voice Expounds
description: The telephone is ringing. ''Hello.'' ''Hello, this is Howard Cosell.''

Iroquois Head Enters Plea
description: Terence J. Fox, chairman of Iroquois Brands Ltd., pleaded not guilty today in Hartford Superior Court to a charge of cocaine possession stemming from his Nov. 6 arrest at a Hartford hotel.

title: Bonds Are Priced For Austin Schools
description: A $185 million issue of Austin, Tex., Independent School District bonds was tentatively priced yesterday through underwriters led by Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company. Yields ranged from 5 percent for bonds due in 1986 to 6.90 percent in 1990, 7.70 percent in 1995 and 8 1/4 percent in 2000.

title: GEMCO NATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

description: Liberia recalled its Ambassador to Sierra Leone yesterday because of what it said was that country's complicity in an unsuccessful coup attempt last week, a Liberian Embassy spokesman in Washington said.

title: Educating Minorities About Health Care
description: The departing Secretary of Health and Human Services, Margaret M. Heckler, said recently that the one fact from the agency's recent report on minority members' health that disturbed her most was the enormous number of premature deaths caused by bad habits: cigarette smoking, alcohol and drug abuse and overindulgence in fatty and sugary foods. Those deaths could have been avoided by helping the victims break their bad habits and addictions.

title: MAINE PUBLIC SERVICE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a charge of $806,586 related to the Seabrook Unit 2 nuclear project.

title: Bail of $1.5 Million Is Set in Slayings

description: There are no share earnings for the latest 9 months and the year-ago quarter and 9 months because net income was exceeded by preferred dividend requirements.

title: CHANGES EXPECTED AT ALLIED
description: Allied-Signal Inc. is expected to announce a major restructuring plan in the next few days that could include the divestiture, or perhaps a spinoff, of a number of operations in its health care and industrial groups, industry sources and analysts said yesterday.

title: Robbery Hostage Killed After Offering Himself
description: A fast-food restaurant manager was killed Sunday after he talked two intruders into taking him as a hostage in place of one of his colleagues.

title: Coupons in Laker Case
description: British Airways, Pan American World Airways and Trans World Airlines have agreed to set up a fund of coupons worth $30 million that could be used for air travel from the United States to the United Kingdom as part of the settlement of a class action suit brought against the three airlines after the collapse of Laker Airways. Under the settlement, announced by British Airways yesterday, passengers who bought tickets from the three airlines after Feb. 26, 1982, and used them for travel between the United States and Britain between March 1, 1982, and March 31, 1984, will be entitled to claim benefits.

title: A PLAT SURVIVES AGAINST THE ODDS
description: When ''The Foreigner'' opened last November, several critics complained that its plot, featuring a shotgun marriage, a disputed inheritance, Ku Klux Klansmen and an Englishman babbling an invented language, was preposterous even for a farce. But the onstage story, convoluted as it may be, seems to pale next to the real saga surrounding ''The Foreigner.''

description: b-Figures are not available because the company did not have a separated business identity or take ownership of its properties before Oct. 1, 1984, when the transfer from K N Energy took effect.

title: CRITICAL THINKING
description: CRITICAL thinking has become the latest addition to the curriculum of many schools. Few observers question the importance of learning to think critically, logically and independently; the question is how to accomplish it.

description: The K Mart Corporation, the country's second-largest general-merchandise retailer after Sears, Roebuck & Company, said third-quarter net income dropped 16.2 percent, to $77.4 million, or 60 cents a share, from $92.4 million, or 71 cents a share, a year earlier.

title: Greenland Under Thin Ice
description: It has long been assumed that the ice sheets of Greenland and Antarctica were thicker in the ice ages than today, but an analysis of ice obtained by drilling to bedrock through the crown of the Greenland ice sheet and through the ice cap on Canada's Devon Island suggests that the ice may actually have been thinner.

O'Brien vs. Marino (Cont.)
description: For richer or poorer, Ken O'Brien and Dan Marino are handcuffed in history. For two years nobody judged the Jets' quarterback without comparing his performance to what Dan Marino of the Miami Dolphins had accomplished. But as the Jets await a summit meeting with the New England Patriots on Sunday at Giants Stadium, their 24-year-old quarterback is suddenly the National Football League's top-rated passer.

description: When John Concheri was in nursery school, a policeman brought him home after he assaulted the teacher. He smashed panes of glass with his hands and threw as many as 70 violent tantrums a day, sometimes hitting his sister and mother. A doctor called him ''a wild animal.''

But for scientists at Haifa University's Center for Maritime Studies, who discoverd the pits in a survey of Israel's Mediterranean coastline last December, they were nothing less than a sunken treasure.

title: PRISON DRAMA SHOWN LIVE ON ABC
description: One odd but understandable fact of television life is the direct ratio between being at the bottom of the ratings and being a bit more adventurous and creative. When there is nothing much to lose, it seems, broadcasters are willing to take chances. Over the past decade, for instance, NBC, lagging far behind CBS and ABC in the ratings race, would occasionally surprise viewers with such quality offerings as a Vladimir Horowitz concert or a serious stage production, carried live no less. Now, apparently, NBC's fortunes having improved, it is the turn of the struggling ABC to try being different, at least once in a while.

description: Present and former heads of the three major networks will be among the speakers at a three-day conference beginning today at the Hofstra Television Institute at Hofstra University, on Hempstead Turnpike in Hempstead, L.I. The conference, ''Television 1985-86: Issues for the Industry and the Audience,'' is open to the public and features panel discussions, readings of scholarly works, screenings of vintage films and a video-art installation. It marks the opening of Hofstra's Television Institute, a multimillion-dollar facility housing the university's communications department, which opened for classes this fall.

description: H. Everett Olson, the chairman and former chief executive officer of the Carnation Company, died Sunday at his home here after a long illness. He was 79 years old.

These plays, now at the New Federal Theater, have nothing to do with seances, and although they share a theme of loss, it is by no means mainly through death.

Middle Managers After 50
description: IS there corporate life for anyone dismissed after age 50? James Challenger thinks there is. In fact, he has found an increase in the hiring of older middle- and lower-level managers. Mr. Challenger heads a Chicago outplacement concern called Challenger, Gray & Christmas Inc.

description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev made his entrance this morning, landing in a cold wind at the Geneva airport 37 hours after President Reagan.

title: DOME MINES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss. Revenue figures represent bullion revenues.

title: Topics;   Restorations: Park and Party; Green vs. Greenmarket
description: New York, rich in great pleasures, is less so in small amenities. That's why the city's 18 greenmarkets are cherished - and why the sprucing up of Union Square Park engenders a little fear among those who sell and buy at the 40 or so farmstands that appear there three days a week.

title: PLEXUS RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DONALDSON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
