title: Village Seeks Aid For Manhunt Bills
description: The Mayor of this Rockland County village today asked for help from the state or the county in paying the costs of a three-day manhunt last month for a transit police officer charged with killing his wife.

title: BARRICK RESOURCES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a tax credit of $700,000 for the quarter and 9 months. c-Net losses.

title: Britain and France Plan Pact on Channel Tunnel
description: Britain and France announced today that they would sign a treaty next February committing both countries to build a tunnel under the English Channel.

title: Guilty Plea on Drugs
description: E. J. (Doc) Kreis, the former Vanderbilt University strength coach, pleaded guilty yesterday to illegally distributing steroids to a Clemson coach in a case that focused national attention on the use of chemical bodybuilders by athletes.

title: TREATMENT FOR BALDNESS STIRS INTEREST
description: A BLOOD pressure pill turned to liquid is being tested in treatments of a rare but perplexing form of baldness, alopecia areata.

title: Groups Accepting Donations
description: American Jewish World Service, Suite 101 29 Commonwealth Avenue, Boston, Mass. 02116. Mark checks ''Colombian Recovery Fund.''

title: A 'REMBRANDT' ISN'T, EXPERTS SAY
description: One of the world's most celebrated paintings, ''The Man With the Golden Helmet,'' is not a Rembrandt, art experts announced today.

title: Trading in Liberty
description: For Irina McClellan, who has not seen her American husband in 11 years, and Abe Stolar, who has not seen the Chicago Cubs play for 54 years, the Reagan-Gorbachev summit conference is already a success. In a gesture on the way to Geneva, Mr. Gorbachev has agreed to let 10 individuals out of the Soviet Union to rejoin - indeed, in most cases to begin - their families in the United States.

title: A TELEPHONE CALL DOES NOT REACH SAKHAROVS
description: An effort today by the stepchildren of Andrei D. Sakharov to learn when their mother, Yelena G. Bonner, will leave the Soviet Union for medical treatment was frustrated when a Soviet telephone operator said Miss Bonner was not available.

title: HADSON PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a tax credit of $1.4 million for the quarter and 9 months and a pretax gain of $30,991,000 for the 9 months from the sale of properties.

title: COMMONWEALTH SAVINGS ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Q&A
description: Q. How are geodes formed? A.

title: MALAYSIA LEADER IS GOING TO CHINA
description: Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad will leave Wednesday on a visit to China. The trip is seen as an indication of Southeast Asia's interest in improving relations with China.

title: Halley's Comet
description: Halley's Comet will rise over the New York City area at 4:01 P.M. today and set at 6:43 A.M. tomorrow.

title: Show Jaruzelski A Carrot and Stick
description: Preoccupied as they are with the summit meeting, few Western governments seem to know what to make of the top-level changes in Warsaw this month - changes very much aimed at the West and timed to coincide with preparations for the Geneva meeting. The blunt truth is that for all its good will and sympathy for the Poles, the West has no coherent policy toward Poland - and the Communist leadership has brilliantly exploited its confusion.

title: President Is Chosen For Mobil's Oil Unit
description: The Mobil Corporation said yesterday that Richard F. Tucker, president of Mobil Diversified Businesses since 1983, had been elected president and chief operating officer of its Mobil Oil subsidiary and a vice chairman of the parent company.

title: ALCO STANDARD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $19,453,000 for the quarter and $23,418,000 for the year. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,029,000 for the quarter and $545,000 for the year.

title: DEL-VAL FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
OVEX FERTILITY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ENTREPRENEUR WITH OLD-WORLD CHARM
description: Nicholas L. Deak, the chairman of Deak & Company and a canny entrepreneur known for his Old World charm, created the country's largest retail business for dealing in foreign currencies, with about 35 offices in 15 American cities and numerous offices abroad.

title: South Korean Students Seize Ruling Party Office
description: Students protesting against the South Korean and United States Governments seized offices of the ruling party for six hours today, setting the building on fire before they were expelled by the police.

title: MAYNARD OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: Advertising;   HCM/New York
description: Patrick Hillman, 37, has been promoted to managing director of HCM/New York, from senior vice president and director of overall planning for the entire company. The agency is a joint venture of Young & Rubicam and Havas Conseil of France. Mr. Hillman was formerly with Scali, McCabe, Sloves and Levine, Huntley, Schmidt & Beaver.

title: Market Place;   Semiconductor Rise Expected
description: THE semiconductor industry has suffered heavy losses, intense Japanese competition, severe price cutting and depleted revenues -enough to make any stockholder consider throwing in the towel. But shares of the five biggest chip producers - Advanced Micro Devices, Intel, Motorola, National Semiconductor and Texas Instruments - have outperformed the overall stock market in recent weeks.

title: Minebea Opposes Foreign Takeover
description: The Minebea Company Ltd. will withstand a foreign takeover because under Japanese law its weapons contracts will prevent non-Japanese from increasing their stake in the concern, Takami Takahashi, the company president, said.

title: CIRO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DATAPOWER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income including tax credits of $75,000 for the quarter and $116,000 for the 6 months and a gain of $258,000 for the 6 months from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: CHARGIT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: CLAIRE'S STORES reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 2
description: Share earnings have been adjusted to reflect stock splits in fiscal 1985 and fiscal 1986.

title: AMERICAN ISRAELI PAPER MILLS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
U.S. APPELLATE JUDGE CRITICIZES JUDICIAL ACTIVISM
description: Judge Robert H. Bork of the Federal appeals court here added his long-held views to a growing public debate over constitutional law today, arguing that judges have no authority to add new rights to those specified by the framers of the Constitution.

title: Top-Level Changeover Arranged at Ciba-Geigy
description: The Ciba-Geigy Corporation, the American argicultural chemicals and pharmaceuticals concern owned by Ciba-Geigy Ltd. of Switzerland, announced yesterday that its chief executive and its president would step down from those positions on April 1.

title: Bankers Trust Uses Libor Tie
description: The Bankers Trust New York Company is offering a $100 million issue of seven-year 10 5/8 percent debentures at a price of 100 through Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. An unusual feature of the financing calls for the interest rate on the notes to be reduced by whatever amount the London interbank offered rate for six-month deposits, or Libor, rises above 10 1/2 percent.

title: CLASSIFIED FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CUTLER-FEDERAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net losses.

BELDEN & BLAKE ENERGY reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago 9 months results do not include administrative and interest expenses for the first quarter of 1984 and are therefore not directly comparable to the latest 9 months results.

title: UNIVERSITIES LOBBY IN WASHINGTON FOR RESEARCH FUNDS
description: QUIETLY but effectively, a controversial new pattern of Federal aid is emerging in higher education. It is happening as some universities lobby Congress on their own to obtain funds that other universities say ought to be awarded through competition based on merit.

title: SOME IN CONGRESS SAY MONEY TALKS TOO MUCH
description: Money talks on Capitol Hill, and many lawmakers do not like what they are hearing.

title: PETROL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FIRST FEDERAL BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

title: BEEBA'S CREATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: Beatrice Is Sued By 2 Shareholders
description: Two shareholders of the Beatrice Companies filed suit in state court today seeking an injunction to block the agreed upon sale of Beatrice to Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company for $50 a share or a total of $6.2 billion.

title: COURT REJECTS BID TO END LAW CURBING MALPRACTICE SUIT FEE
description: The Supreme Court today rejected a challenge to a law that limits fees paid to lawyers by people who win medical malpractice suits.

title: CALUMET INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $415,000 for the quarter and year. c-Net income.

title: COACH ASSAILS LAW ON FAILING PLAYER
description: A law that bars students who fail one course from extracurricular activities harms those prevented from participation and results in the student's being ''labeled a dummy,'' a football coach testified today.

title: A Debt Insurer Nears Closing of First Deals
description: Financial Security Assurance, an insurance company created earlier this year to insure various kinds of debt securities, is nearing completion of its first transactions and expects to have insured almost $500 million of securities by the end of the year, an official said yesterday.

title: BROWN, ROBERT C & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
A.T.&T. Asks Increase
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said today that it had filed for a $123.6 million rate increase with the California Public Utilities Commission. The company said the filing, which calls for higher charges for directory assistance and off-hours long-distance calls, was the result of high-access costs and state regulation. The filing includes a decrease in the night and weekend discount rate; a decrease in the evening discount rate, and increases in the rates for WATS, 800 and private-line services.

title: FAY'S DRUG CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, a dispatch from Richmond yesterday on construction there misstated the status of the Richmond Braves ballpark. It was completed in time for the 1985 season.

title: ALLIED RESEARCH ASSOC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Little Known, But Nearing No.1
description: Little more than three years from now, Eddie Robinson of Grambling will reach Louisiana's mandatory retirement age of 70, and then college football will have a new No. 1 man on its list of active coaches with most career victories. Odds are you've never heard of him.

title: JETS HAVE RIGHT MAN AT NOSE TACKLE
description: Bud Carson, the new defensive coordinator of the Jets, and Ray Callahan, the defensive line coach, were in the office one day last spring when the idea was hatched. The decision had already been made to switch to a three-man defensive line, which meant there had to be a nose tackle. But who?

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: ALTHOUGH the ringmasters of Seventh Avenue have finished conducting their shows, the circus of style never stops. Last week, downtown's fashion aerialists cavorted, the lions of society roared around town and three department stores dueled in the city's center ring.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: CHASING TORNADOES ON 'NOVA'
description: WATCHING the winds roar across the darkening skies and flattening a small American town in ''Tornado!'' (the hourlong ''Nova'' documentary, produced by WGBH in Boston, is on Channel 13 tonight at 9 o'clock), a viewer can envision the reality of atomic war on home grounds. The destruction in Barneveld, Wis., looks just like the pictures of Hiroshima after the big manmade wind, as some people later called it, pulverized the city.

title: George Weltner Dead; Ex-Paramount Official
description: George Weltner, a former president of the Paramount Pictures Corporation, died last Friday at the Convalescent Center of the Palm Beaches in West Palm Beach, Fla. He was 84 years old.

title: Coach Suspects Spying
description: An angry Don James, the University of Washington football coach, said yesterday that two local high school football coaches spied on the Huskies last week and supplied the University of Southern California with information before Saturday's Washington-U.S.C. game, which the Huskies won, 20-17. ''We had the feeling that they'd seen our offense,'' James said.

title: TESORO PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes an $8.6 million writedown in the company's investment in Trinidad-Tesoro Petroleum Co. Ltd. for the quarter and year. c-Includes writeoffs of $54.6 million from the parent company's exploration production and other writeoffs. d-Net income e-The net income did not cover preferred dividend requirements, therefore no share earnings.

description: A Federal judge in Fort Worth yesterday denied a request by the Southland Royalty Company for a temporary restraining order against Burlington Northern Inc.'s $695 million tender offer.

description: To the Winner . . .

MISSING LINK OF WORD PROCESSING
description: THE thought of having to give up the familiar and comfortable electric typewriter for a computer word processor has caused many a typist to reach for the smelling salts. Computers can be terrifying to those who have never used one; the one on this desk has 48 extra buttons and 8 little red lights that are not on the standard Selectric typewriter keyboard.

title: PHYSIO TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CRESTEK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings adjusted to reflect a 1-for-5 combination of shares approved Dec. 21, 1984.

title: Like the Kangaroos
description: A baby girl who weighed less than 2 pounds when she was born 12 weeks prematurely was carried around in a kangaroo-like pouch for 10 days at the Albion (Mich.) Community Hospital, and gained enough weight to go home last week.

title: DAVID JAMISON CARLYLE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 29
TURNER BROADCASTING SYSEM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $627,000 relating to Turner Broadcasting's withdrawn exchange offer for CBS Inc. c-Includes gains of $2,632,000 for the quarter and $4,203,000 for the 9 months. d-Includes a charge of $13,101,000 related to Turner's withdrawn offer for CBS. e-Net income

title: ACCORD PROPOSED IN ALABAMA IN U.S. SUIT OVER COLLEGE BIAS
description: The United States Justice Department has proposed that the State of Alabama pay a sum reported to be $100 million to two primarily black colleges in the state university system, in settlement of a Federal desegregation suit.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: DEBORAH E. LIPSTADT'S ''Beyond Belief'' is a valuable addition to recent studies of the Western response to the Holocaust. Inevitably it overlaps to some extent with a book like David S. Wyman's comprehensive account of American reactions during World War II, ''The Abandonment of the Jews''; inevitably, limiting itself as it does to the way Nazi enormities were covered by the press, it is more narrowly based. But that doesn't diminish its importance. It deals at one remove with deeds as well as words - the press may not make policy, but in a free society it certainly makes things easier or harder for those who do.

title: JACK DONAHUE
description: Jack Donahue, founder of New England's first halfway house for recovering alcoholics and a longtime proponent of alcohol treatment programs, died of injuries suffered in an automobile accident Saturday.

title: DECA ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
When Hospitals Shun the Poor
description: Ann Murphy struggled to support a household of four on a housekeeper's $8,000 salary, yet earned enough to lose her Medicaid coverage, the Federal health insurance for the poor. She therefore got no medical care before her baby's birth and had to pay a hospital deposit before delivery. She couldn't afford a needed Caesarian section. The hospital pursued her with a collection agency, then sued. And it refused her baby the necessary special monitoring unless she paid in advance.

title: TRUMP ANNOUNCES PLAN TO CONSTRUCT WORLD'S TALLEST BUILDING
description: There are six 76-story apartment towers in Television City, the new proposal by Donald J. Trump for the old Penn Central rail yards on the Upper West Side. And the most important thing to know about them is that when you look at the model for the entire complex, they seem relatively small.

title: HERITAGE ENTERTAINMENT YEAR reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $36,000 for the quarter and $300,000 for the 6 months.

title: 'STAR WARS' INDUSTRY RISES
description: Inside a dozen low, nondescript buildings just south of the Los Angeles airport, ''Star Wars'' is slowly beginning to take shape.

title: FAFCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: Penn Agrees to a Fine To Settle Animal Case
description: The University of Pennsylvania has agreed to pay a $4,000 fine and take other steps to settle charges that it violated the Animal Welfare Act in its treatment of primates used in studies of head injuries, the United States Agriculture Department said today.

title: PERINI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $12,568,000 in the quarter and a loss from discontinued operations of $20,673,000 in the 9 months. c-Net income, including losses from discontinued operations of $1,131,000 for quarter and $1,769,000 for the 9 months.

title: Lurching To the Summit
description: There is widespread confusion as the first Soviet-American summit conference in six years opens here. And no wonder. There have been volleys of proposals and counterproposals, all apparently brushed aside.

title: U.N. Expresses Hope On the Summit Parley
description: The General Assembly today called on American and Soviet leaders to conduct negotiations that will ''produce early and effective agreements on the halting of the nuclear arms race.''

title: NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 19, 1985
description: International

title: SOUTH SEEKS TO REDUCE INFANT DEATHS
description: A public awareness campaign and increased government spending on health and nutrition programs are needed to reduce the South's infant mortality rate, Gov. Richard W. Riley of South Carolina said today.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Knicks vs. Washington Bullets, at Madison Square Garden, 7:30 P.M. Manute Bol, the 7-foot-6-inch Sudanese makes his first visit of the season to Madison Square Garden.

title: CHAPMAN ENERGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: Anti-U.S. Protests Jar Greek Socialists
description: Two Cabinet officials submitted their resignations tonight, and the country's three top police chiefs were suspended over clashes after an anti-American rally.

title: COMPUTER MICROFILM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 5 percent stock dividend paid in July 1985.

title: Cleaning Up the Sergeant Test Mess
description: Having gone to expensive lengths to avoid promoting sergeants according to racial quotas, New York City's Police Department now must do so anyway. It's the least bad way to clean up a bureaucratic mess.

title: OMAN GIVES SUPER PARTY: IT'S COME A LONG WAY
description: The Bedouins are in from the desert for the celebration, camped at the far edge of the city: dark, whippet-lean men with hawklike faces, few teeth and daggers in their belts, hobbling their camels out by the silvery disk antennas of the television satellite station.

title: MCNEIL'S INJURY MIGHT HURT JETS
description: Freeman McNeil, who glides through holes to be met by much bigger people, was hardly recognizable today. He was walking with a cane. ''Hey, you limping?'' shouted Bobby Jackson across a crowded locker room.

title: WOMEN WHO WORK INCREASING
description: The number of women in the work force has increased dramatically over the last decade, but women largely remain concentrated in traditional and low-paying occupations, according to a recent report from the Census Bureau.

title: A ZINFANDEL COMPLEMENTS THE FARE
description: WHAT can be more fitting than an all-American wine to drink with an all-American dinner? The wine known as zinfandel -''zin'' by nickname - is produced in nine varieties, more than enough to enhance holiday fare prepared in traditional or innovative forms.

title: Little Woman, Little Man
description: Remember the little woman? The one poor men kept barefoot and pregnant, rich men put on a pedestal and all men told not to bother her pretty little head? Bet you thought she'd disappeared from the national psyche. Well, not from Donald Regan's.

title: SHORT KICKS ARE DOUBLY EFFECTIVE
description: The onside kickoff has a well-defined role in football. If a team is trailing and time is running out, an onside kickoff is expected, because the kicking team is desperate to get the ball back. Otherwise, an onside kickoff is too dangerous, because it usually fails and the receiving team gets the ball in excellent field position.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Knicks vs. Pistons, at Detroit, 7:30 P.M. The Knicks, who lost eight straight games before finally winning, face the Pistons for the first time this season.

title: 2 WINERIES VS. NAPA WOODLAND
description: A Seventh-day Adventist college nestled among the evergreens on Howell Mountain is trying to adjust to new neighbors: two wineries that have cleared trees to plant grapes.

title: TRUMP'S PLAN FOR 150-STORY TOWER ON WEST SIDE FACES A STRENUOUS REVIEW
description: Before Donald J. Trump gets the opportunity to build either the world's tallest building or the rest of the sprawling complex he envisions for the Upper West Side waterfront, he will have to work his way through a sometimes humbling city approval process that has led to the overhaul of many a sweeping development plan.

title: REAGAN CONFERS WITH GORBACHEV IN GENEVA PARLEY
description: President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, met today for more than four hours in what the two sides described as a ''good atmosphere.''

title: Let American Indians Decide Fate of Museum
description: To the Editor:

title: Gracious Guests
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: Newspaper's Claim Rejected
description: A judge today dismissed a $6 million counterclaim that McClatchy Newspapers had filed in response to a $250 million libel suit by Senator Paul Laxalt of Nevada. The counterclaim, dismissed by Federal District Judge Edward Reed, was based on arguments that the Republican Senator had sought to suppress the newspaper group's First Amendment rights when he filed his lawsuit in September 1984.

title: FLYERS' STREAK IS ENDED AT 13
description: On a rough, tough night at the Coliseum, the Philadelphia Flyers' winning streak came to an end. They staged another remarkable comeback, but this time it wasn't enough.

title: THE TURKEY STILL PLAYS A LEAD ROLE
description: THOSE who dote on turkey at Thanksgiving are loath to admit that serving the bird on this holiday table is not easy to justify historically. It is not a clear-cut issue from a culinary point of view either, given the tough, dry bird many people must face on this festive occasion. It need not be so, however. Turkey, properly prepared and served with a suitable stuffing redolent of fresh sage or other herbs can be a fitting centerpiece to the Thanksgiving meal.

title: Charitable Hunger
description: This is Lunchless Lunch Day, according to a proclamation signed last week by Governor Cuomo.

title: State Taxes Shouldn't Span the Globe
description: Should California tax Shell Oil on the profits of the company's refineries in West Germany and chemical plants in Britain? California and five smaller states claim the right to do just that. They argue that local subsidiaries of multinational corporations would otherwise fudge their accounts to deny them their fair share of taxes on business inside the state.

title: LATIN ANTI-TERROR AID RESISTED IN CONGRESS
description: The Administration's request for $54 million in supplemental aid to create anti-terrorism programs for police and military forces in Central America ran into strong resistance in Congress today.

title: What Chance for Humphrey the Whale?
description: To the Editor:

title: PROXMIRE CALLS CITY'S RECOVERY A FISCAL MODEL
description: Senator William Proxmire, New York City's chief nemesis on Capitol Hill during the fiscal crisis of the 70's, said today that the city's recovery from its budget troubles should be a model for the Federal Government.

title: FETE FOR CUOMO SETS FUND MARK OF $3.4 MILLION
description: Governor Cuomo broke the New York record for political fund-raising parties last night, collecting more than $3.4 million at a dinner at the Sheraton Centre.

title: A Reason for Testing U.S. Resolve in Angola
description: To the Editor:

title: DEVILS END A SLUMP
description: Kirk Muller scored a short-handed goal in the second period tonight after assisting on Doug Sulliman's go-ahead goal, helping the Devils to a 6-3 victory over the Los Angeles Kings.

title: HOUSE TAX PANEL VOTES TO TIGHTEN INVESTMENT RULES
description: The House Ways and Means Committee voted today to abolish the investment tax credit and to lengthen the time over which companies can write off their investments in plants and machinery.

title: WHERE IS THE WEALTH? U.S. HOLDINGS ARE CITED
description: Soon after the death of Fan Fox Samuels, a New York philanthropist, in 1981, her husband put up for sale her large collection of furnishings and English antiques. The sale was to be handled by an auction house, but before any auction could be held a buyer with wide knowledge of English antiques bought the entire collection for more than $4.5 million.

title: Faith and Work
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: Waiting for Rumsfeld
description: Ever since Donald H. Rumsfeld resigned as Secretary of Defense in 1977 to become chief of the G. D. Searle Corporation, Washington has periodically vibrated to rumors that the former Congressman and White House official was interested in re-entering national politics.

title: November Hurricane Unusual but Not Rare
description: While Caribbean hurricanes this late in the year are less common than in August and September, they are by no means rare, according to a spokesman of the National Hurricane Center in Miami.

title: Zimbabwe Rejects Charges That Detainees Are Tortured
description: Zimbabwe has rejected charges by Amnesty International that it has increased the detention and torture of suspected Government opponents, the country's embassy in Britain said today.

title: ONE-PERSON HOMES SHOW BIG U.S. RISE
description: Almost half the households added in the United States since 1980 consist of people living alone or with nonrelatives, the Census Bureau reported today.

title: 2 Troopers Are Killed In Crash During Chase
description: Two troopers of the New York State police were killed last night when their patrol car crashed into a parked tractor-trailer on the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway during a pursuit, the Yonkers police reported.

title: English Hits For 54 Points
description: Alex English scored a career-high 54 points, the highest individual total in the National Basketball Association this season, as Denver defeated Houston, 127-113, tonight.

title: 2 Hyatt Hotel Engineers Offer Their Resignations
description: Two St. Louis engineers found negligent in the 1981 collapse of the Hyatt Regency Hotel sky walks, which killed 114 people, have offered their new employer their resignations.

title: JACKSON, IN IMPROMPTU SESSION, PRESSES GORBACHEV ON SOVIET JEWS
description: Between sessions with President Reagan today, Mikhail S. Gorbachev spent 45 minutes in a stand-up, impromptu discussion with the Rev. Jesse Jackson, who twice pressed him on the predicament of Soviet Jews.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Peter Sundstrom, the Ranger right wing who has appeared in only eight of the team's first 17 games, was sent to New Haven of the American Hockey League along with the rookie defenseman Kjell Samuelson. . . . Michael Graham, the former Georgetown star, said he had not signed a contract with the Albany Patroons, the Continental Basketball Association club that announced last week that it had signed him to a $6,000 contract. There was no immediate explanation for the discrepancy from the Patroons, but a team spokesman conceded that Graham would not be joining the team. . . . Quintin Dailey has rejoined the Chicago Bulls after spending a month in a California hospital for treatment of drug dependency. . . Clyde Drexler, the Portland Trail Blazers' high-jumping, high-scoring guard, has been sidelined with a stress fracture of his left leg.

title: Judge in Rhode Island Lifts Crime Data Curb
description: A Federal district judge today lifted an order prohibiting a newspaper and a television station here from reporting on illegally recorded taped conversations between a reputed leader of organized crime and his father.

title: Alcohol Abuse
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: Same Family, Different Sizes
description: The large of it is this: Darin Lintner is an all-conference college football player, is 6 feet 2 inches tall and weighs 230 pounds.

title: OLD GRADS SUPPORTING IVY FOOTBALL
description: Booster clubs in the Ivy League?

title: ITALIANS IDENTIFY 16 IN HIJACKING OF SHIP
description: Italian magistrates identified 16 Palestinians today who they said were wanted for the hijacking of the cruise ship Achille Lauro.

title: Deposed Coach 'Hurt'
description: Texas Tech's football coach, Jerry Moore, said yesterday that he had been dismissed, effective after next Saturday's Southwest Conference game against the University of Houston. ''I'm confused and hurt, but I am not bitter, because I am not that way,'' Moore said.

title: THEIR CUP OF TEA: FIRST LADIES CHAT
description: Over almond herbal tea and freshly baked cookies, Nancy Reagan and Raisa M. Gorbachev today discussed their husbands, their countries and the prospects for ''better understanding.''

title: Balanced-Budget Bill Is Wrong Way to Fiscal Sanity
description: To the Editor:

title: By Golly or by Cap?
description: Here is a shadowy tale, by golly.

title: PHILADELPHIAN OUTLINES FIGHT ON GRAFT
description: Mayor W. Wilson Goode today disclosed detailed plans for eliminating the widespread corruption that he said had ''overwhelmed'' the Philadelphia police department's credibility and shamed the entire city.

title: KOCH FINDS SUBWAYS CLEAN, SAFE, PROMPT (IN TOKYO)
description: Midway through his eight-day journey to Japan, Mayor Koch saw Tokyo from above and below today - in a helicopter and then in the subways. To the surprise of no one, including himself, he pronounced Toyko's trains clean, safe, prompt and all in all somewhat different from New York's.

title: BIRTH OF BUTOH RECALLED BY FOUNDER
description: Kazuo Ohno totters, flounces and slashes through stage space, a primeval specter that is half death, half lingering sweet perfume. Offstage, however, the 79-year-old ''father of Butoh'' - who opens tonight at the Joyce Theater in a week of alternating performances with Kuniko Kisanuki - is a remarkably cheerful and practical man, given the dark quality of that Japanese experimentalist theater-dance form.

title: Senator East Hospitalized
description: Senator John P. East, Republican of North Carolina, was hospitalized Monday for tests and observation after the discovery of a low white blood cell count, his office said today. A short statement said the low count was found in a routine examination and the 54-year-old Senator was admitted to Georgetown University Hospital.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Better Salmon Roe Around 1959, red salmon roe had a brief fling of popularity when countless hosts and hostesses served it up as a fancy hors d'oeuvre to top sour cream dip. The plump and sticky globules, which were highly salted, had a distressing way of sticking to the back molars, thus inhibiting cocktail party conversation, and the roe's popularity went into decline. Today it suffers from an unhappy reputation as poor man's caviar.

title: ZESTY NEW VARIATIONS ON TRADITIONAL FAVORITES
description: ''NO more turkey,'' said Dennis the Menace, and perhaps countless other small children at Thanksgiving. ''But I'd like some more of the bread it ate.'' Apparently, children already understand what many adults are coming to recognize about the Thanksgiving meal - that the trimmings are the main attraction. By comparison, the turkey, though an admirable centerpiece for the table, is a bit player, an excellent excuse for indulging in all the accompaniments appropriate to the occasion.

title: 2 More Bodies Identified In Mass Slaying on Coast
description: Officials investigating the discovery of 11 bodies at a survivalist's cabin in a remote part of Calaveras County say two women who appeared in video tapes found at the cabin have been identified as among the victims.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in the New Jersey Weekly on Sunday about the opening concert of the Garden State Philharmonic Symphony Orchestra misstated the performance date. It is Saturday at 8 P.M., at Toms River High School North.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: RICHARD LLOYD, who is opening for Adrian Belew and the Bears at the Ritz (119 East 11th Street) on Friday, projects a quiet strength and determination these days, and a sense of rising energy. Back in the late 1970's, when Mr. Lloyd played alongside ambitious new bands like Talking Heads and Blondie as one of the two exceptional guitarists in Television, his energy was restless, sometimes manic. Television balanced the poetic, visionary style of Tom Verlaine against Mr. Lloyd's rawer but equally lyrical intensity. Although the group never achieved a spectacular commercial breakthrough, Television set the pattern for the next generation of guitar bands, from Georgia's R.E.M. to Ireland's U2 and a virtual cavalcade of British bands.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report in the Food Notes column last Wednesday on the Little Pie Shop in the Big Apple omitted its address and telephone number. The shop is at 410 West 43d Street, in the Manhattan Plaza complex. The telephone number is 212-736-4780.

title: MARCOS FORTUNE: QUESTIONS ARISE ABOUT GRAFT
description: As has often happened in the history of the Philippines, official corruption is emerging as a central issue within the nation. Now, according to Congressional sources and Administration officials, it is becoming an increasingly important factor in relations between the United States and the Philippines.

title: NEW HEAD FOR UNITED ARTISTS
description: Anthony T. Thomopoulos, who resigned as president of the ABC Broadcast Group last week, has been named president of the motion picture and television groups of the reorganized United Artists studio, it was announced today by Jerry Weintraub, chairman and chief executive officer of the United Artists Corporation.

title: CASINOS' PROFITS DECLINE 27% IN ATLANTIC CITY
description: Third-quarter profits for 10 Atlantic City casinos skidded to $55.1 million, down 27.4 percent from a year earlier, the New Jersey Casino Control Commission reported yesterday.

title: SUSPECT IN DEAK-PERERA KILLINGS HAD BEEN IN MENTAL HOSPITAL, OFFICIALS SAY
description: The woman charged with murdering the head of the Deak-Perera foreign-exchange company and a receptionist in Manhattan was released from a mental hospital last August in Washington State, law-enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: Politics-Free Political Asylum
description: It is rare that I find myself supporting Jesse Helms. It happened this month when Senator Helms valiantly tried to prevent a young Soviet seaman, Miroslav Medved, from being returned to his country. Though the Senator did not prevail, his defense of the 22-year-old sailor was entirely justified - and his humanitarian approach to political asylum ought to be pursued in all such cases, whether those seeking refuge come from the East or the West.

title: EWING IS HURT AS KNICKS WIN 3D STRAIGHT
description: For more than two hours last night at Madison Square Garden, the Knicks and the Washington Bullets engaged in a contest that would prove to be close and entertaining. But what most of the audience was concerned about was not the outcome - the Knicks won - but the condition of Patrick Ewing.

title: Roasting Helms
description: Sponsors of the $125-a-ticket roast of Senator Jesse Helms planned for tomorrow night had been promising for weeks to feature a ''mystery liberal'' among the speakers who are scheduled to demonstrate their affection and respect for the North Carolina Republican by insulting him. But efforts to fill that spot have proved fruitless, even after C-SPAN, the cable network, decided to cover the affair.

title: Successful Grad
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: SOVIET REAFFRIMS ITS LINKS TO ARABS
description: The Soviet Union has begun a campaign to reassure the Arabs that Mikhail S. Gorbachev will not conclude a deal with President Reagan at Arab expense.

title: CITY ENVIRONMENT CHIEF QUITS IN KOCH SHAKE-UP
description: The city's Environmental Commissioner, Joseph T. McGough Jr., submitted his resignation yesterday - the third mayoral appointee to do so this week in a continuing shake-up of the Koch administration.

title: HURRICANE UPSTAGES FORECASTER
description: Forecasters from Hawaii to Puerto Rico thought they were in for a relaxed review of the past hurricane season when they arrived this week for their annual meeting. Then came Hurricane Kate.

title: Queens Court Clerk Testifies Judge Was Known as Honest
description: A key clerk of State Supreme Court in Queens testified yesterday that a judge charged with taking bribes had a good reputation in legal circles for his honesty and integrity in handling cases.

title: COLONEL INDICTED FOR MISUSE OF TRAVEL MONEY
description: An Army colonel was indicted today on charges of defrauding the Government, and Federal investigators continued a broader inquiry into purported financial wrongdoing in an Army intelligence unit.

title: SPAIN INSISTS U.S. CUT TROOPS THERE
description: Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez affirmed today that Spain would continue to press for a reduction in the number of American troops stationed here.

title: ELVES SUPPLANT BYTES
description: THE computer, commonly re garded as a soulless bundle of electronic parts, is really a Christmas decoration in disguise, according to a software manufacturer who plans to put elves into the microchips of 600,000 computers by Christmas.

title: Iraq Raids Kharg Island; Pipeline and Tanker Hit
description: Iraqi warplanes raided Iran's main oil terminal at Kharg Island on Monday, damaging a pipeline serving a main loading jetty and hitting a tanker, shipping sources said today.

title: Let American Indians Decide Fate of Museum
description: To the Editor:

title: Nancy Lopez Honored
description: It was a day for celebrating the accomplishments of Nancy Lopez at yesterday's annual awards luncheon of the Ladies Professional Golf Association, but Miss Lopez said that awaiting her second child is more meaningful than being named the woman golfer of the year. Miss Lopez got so emotional when she spoke about her relationship with her husband, Ray Knight, and his contribution to her career, that she cried openly as she stood to accept all the honors bestowed upon her.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: IRON TEETH, PRESIDENTIAL UNDERWEAR
description: With American and Soviet officials withholding substantive information on the summit conference, there was time today to clarify some other points.

title: DISCOVERIES
NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, NOVEMBER 20, 1985
description: International

title: NETS BEAT BLAZERS, NOW 1-7 ON ROAD
description: The losing seemed to go on forever, but Dave Wohl remained steady. Even as his team moved from one city to the next and lost with frustrating regularity, the Nets' rookie coach found silver linings.

title: Blueprint for a New York City Housing Program
description: To the Editor:

title: WINE TALK
description: BOTH the 1974 and 1976 cabernets of Mount Eden Vineyards are listed. So are the Grgich Hills chardonnay and Sanford & Benedict pinot noir, both from 1977; Heitz Cellar's Martha's Vineyard cabernet 1974, in magnum, and the 1979 and 1980 Opus Ones from Robert Mondavi and Philippe de Rothschild.

title: AUGUSTANA STILL GRINDING OUT VICTORIES
description: The longest winning streak in college football is the 33-game string held by Augustana College of Rock Island, Ill., which has not been defeated since a 14-0 loss to West Georgia in the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division III championship game in 1982. Since then the Vikings have won two straight N.C.A.A. III titles.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: ONE of the most basic rules about the marriage of wine and food is that white wines are to be served with fish and red wines with meats. It is a dictum that I find to be quite sound and serviceable, but, like most rules, one that can easily be broken.

title: STATE SAYS TWO-THIRDS OF SCHOOLS WITH POOREST RECORDS ARE IN CITY
description: A state-sponsored evaluation of all elementary and secondary schools in New York State has found that two-thirds of the 600 schools with the lowest academic performance are New York City public schools, officials said yesterday.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report in the Briefing column of the Washington Talk page yesterday misstated the location of a dinner to be held Dec. 11 as a tribute to William Loeb, late publisher of The Manchester Union Leader in New Hampshire. It will be held at the Sheraton Washington Hotel in Washington.

title: HURRAHS (AND DOUBTS) FOR JAPAN'S POLITICAL LORDS
description: The governing Liberal Democratic Party is celebrating one of the great constants in modern Japanese life - itself.

title: STATEN ISLAND RANGERS WAGE NASAL WARFARE
description: Only recently did Esther Aponte realize that the fragrance she had been smelling was New Jersey. For the longest time she had been punishing the dog.

title: BRAMBLE FIGHT CANCELED
description: An injury to the right hand of Tyrone Crawley has caused the cancellation of the World Boxing association lightweight championship bout scheduled for Saturday in Reno between challenger Crawley and the champion, Livingstone Bramble.

title: Can We Talk?
description: George Steinbrenner, the New York Yankees' owner, says he will meet this weekend with Billy Martin and Martin's agent, Eddie Sapir, to discuss a new role he has in mind for his four-time former manager.

title: Postal Politics
description: Geraldine A. Ferraro has mailed 200,000 letters nationwide seeking funds and ''advice'' for her exploration of a candidacy for the United States Senate next year.

title: MUSIC: SHURA CHERKASSKY IN RECITAL
description: A RECITAL by Shura Cherkassky is a time-warping experience, a trek back to a time when the stars of the piano world played each piece in a totally individual, often eccentric, manner that placed far more weight on the pianist's personal vision of the score than on the score itself. There are few pianists still active for whom that style would not be a pose, but the 74-year-old Mr. Cherkassky, who performed at Carnegie Hall last night, is one of the few.

title: Lindbergh Remembered
description: Former teammates and friends paid their respects to Pelle Lindbergh in a ceremony Monday night in the arena where the late Philadelphia Flyer goalie started his hockey career.

title: CHURCH WORKERS AT TRIAL DEFEND AID TO ALIENS
description: Lawyers for 11 church workers on trial here on Federal charges involving aid to illegal aliens offered opening arguments today, stressing that their clients had been motivated by religious and humanitarian concerns.

title: Uganda Troops Fight Rebels
description: Guerrillas of the National Resistance Army clashed with Government troops Monday, leaving at least 25 people dead and a dozen others wounded, the newspaper Munno said today. The death toll in the clash near the rebel-controlled town of Masaka included 8 civilians and 17 rebels, the newspaper said. There was no report of Government casualties.

title: Books: Darkest Sicily
description: THE WINE-DARK SEA. By Leonardo Sciascia. Translated from the Italian by Avril Bardoni. 142 pages. New York: Carcanet. $14.95. AS novelist and essayist, Leonardo Sciascia is the most authentic voice writing in Sicily today. He remains in Palermo, avoiding the literary mainstream in Milan and Rome, spinning stories that unfold so naturally they seem derived from folk tales. Some are; they can begin with a great-grandfather who ran through the streets of Palermo with Garibaldi's Thousand, and suddenly turn into a story on Mafia vengeance. The better-known Italo Calvino, who died two months ago at the height of his powers, also drew strength from old tales for his fabulist novels.

title: DANCE: KUNIKO KISANUKI IN BUTOH
description: JAPANESE modern dancers have often performed in New York - and some are leading members of American troupes, such as the Martha Graham Dance Company. Yet it is only with the recent performances here of Japan's innovative Butoh dance theater that light has been shed on a current of experimental dance that seems specifically Japanese.

title: TOP RANKING TO PENN STATE
description: The New York Times's computer made Penn State a consensus choice as the top college football team in the nation.

title: CONGRESS DELAYS NAVY FLEET PLAN
description: The Navy's plan for dispersing its growing fleet of warships to 15 new home ports in New York and on the West and Gulf Coasts hit an obstacle today when Congress ordered the plan delayed for further study.

title: Meese Ignores History In Debate With Court
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d ignores history in his debate with the Supreme Court, and particularly with Justices William J. Brennan and John Paul Stevens, over the Constitution and how it should be interpreted.

title: GIANTS OF THE TOY INDUSTRY RELOCATING IN MANHATTAN
description: For decades two connecting structures at 200 Fifth Avenue and 1107 Broadway have been a mecca for the toy industry's manufacturers and buyers. The buildings, which together are known as the Toy Center, hold the showrooms of a vast majority of the country's toy manufacturers.

title: Radical Chic
description: To the Editor:

title: Stewart Jurors Rehear Witnesses' Testimony
description: The jury in the State Supreme Court trial of six transit police officers charged in the death of Michael Stewart reheard testimony yesterday describing officers' kicking Mr. Stewart at Union Square West.

title: IMAGES SERVED AT HOLLYWOOD PARTIES
description: Whether the free food is a vegetable cart and melted Brie or caviar and champagne, whether the actors invited to dress up the room are A-list or B-list, cocktail parties in Hollywood have their own inexorable rhythms.

title: 20TH ANNIVERSARY TOAST
description: In 1965, when Jack L. Davies took over the hundred-year-old relic of a winery near Calistoga, Calif., in the Napa Valley, his goal was to produce premium sparkling wine in the authentic Champagne method. His friends and colleagues were skeptical at best.

title: Another Summit
description: The Poor Clares may have the best of this city, ignoring it serenely inside their cloister, walled off from such transient phenomena as death, taxes and the careerist cravings and fears of all the politicians.

title: CONCERT: JOSEF SUK
description: Two elements made the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center's Sunday-afternoon concert at Alice Tully Hall a memorable one: the sweet, immaculate violin playing of the guest artist, Josef Suk, and the revival of a macabre little masterwork by Frank Martin.

title: MARTIN SHORT DISPLAYS MULTIPLE COMIC GUISES
description: TAKING a cue from Home Box Office, which has had some of its more notable successes with comedy specials, pay cable's Showtime service is pushing ahead with its ''Comedy Spotlight'' series. The latest effort, recorded before an audience in Toronto, is ''Martin Short: Concert for the North Americas''; the hourlong special is on tonight at 8 o'clock.

title: Music for Minors
description: They giggled at ''Pop Goes the Weasel.'' They wiggled during a passage of Haydn's Symphony No. 94. And they warbled ''We Are the World.''

title: USEFUL ROASTER-STEAMER
description: KITCHENWARE designers are constantly trying to create the better mousetrap. This is no easy task when the mousetrap is a simple utensil, such as a pot or a pan. After all, how many variations can there be?

title: HOUSE WILL NOT TRY TO OVERRIDE REAGAN VETO OF A SPENDING BILL
description: The House of Representatives today sent back to committee a bill appropriating $13.2 billion for the Treasury Department and the Postal Service, avoiding a confrontation with President Reagan.

title: A B-52 Crash Site Yields Human Bones
description: The first joint United States-Vietnamese search for Americans missing in the Vietnam War found human remains today at a rural commune where a B-52 bomber crashed 13 years ago, an American spokesman said.

title: WINDS WHIP FLORIDA KEYS AS HURRICANE HITS CUBA
description: Hurricane Kate battered the Florida Keys and the northern coast of Cuba today before moving into the Gulf of Mexico and turning slowly northward.

title: LIBERIA COUP CHARGE DENIED
description: Sierra Leone's Ambassador to the United States yesterday denied charges that his Government had helped conspirators in an unsuccessful coup in Liberia last week.

title: Setback for Nixon
description: Norm Nixon may have signed a multimillion-dollar offer sheet with the Seattle SuperSonics last week, but it could be some time before he sees the money. The National Basketball Association said it had told the SuperSonics that the offer sheet was technically defective and that the SuperSonics are now reworking it with Nixon's agent to satisfy the N.B.A. objections.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''If New York City, with its long tradition of permissive, easygoing government and its notorious lack of discipline, can embrace austerity and succeed, why can't this Congress?'' - Senator William Proxmire, citing the city as an example for Federal budget cutting.

title: TO OFFSET INFLUENZA MISERIES, TIME HAS COME TO GET A SHOT
description: WINTER'S least welcome visitors, the viruses that produce the misery and malaise of influenza, will soon arrive. And medical experts are warning, as they do each fall, that thousands of Americans may die unnecessarily because they failed to protect themselves against the flu.

title: Letter: On Indian-Run Gambling;   Few Tribes Profit From Bingo
description: To the Editor:

title: Taco Strikes Out
description: Terry Forster, the rotund Atlanta reliever who is trying to melt away some of his 270 pounds at a West Coast spa, talks about his biggest enemy, the chicken taco: ''I'd like to have one more before the day I die.

title: GIANTS RELEASE GRAY
description: The Giants waived Earnest Gray today, two weeks after the wide receiver ended a long contract dispute.

title: Reorganized Court Needs a New Name
description: To the Editor:

title: AGENTS DESCRIBE CAR-THEFT RING AT GAMBINO TRIAL
description: F.B.I. agents testified yesterday that a stolen-car ring reputedly run by the Gambino crime group operated for a time in 1980 out of a warehouse and garage next door to the 71st Precinct station house in Brooklyn.

title: More on 'Date Rape'
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: Free Ride Denied
description: Imagine the bus driver's nerve!

title: ABRAMS PLEASED AS COURT LIMITS STATE'S LIABILITY
description: A decision today by the State Court of Appeals, coupled with two other recent decisions, should be read as a signal to lower courts that laws governing physician and governmental liability should be applied strictly, State Attorney General Robert Abrams said.

title: Asian Wall Street Journal Apologizes to Singapore
description: The Asian Wall Street Journal and its editor apologized to Singapore's High Court today for committing contempt of court in an editorial published in The Journal last month.

title: ABRACADABRA! MAGICIANS MULTIPLYING
description: THERE is a lot of hocus-pocus going on in offices and living rooms these days. Between appointments and after hours, lawyers, doctors, priests and Wall Street wizards use their pens as magic wands, turning dimes into pennies and making playing cards change suit before the very eyes of clients, friends and relatives.

title: PANEL IN SENATE REJECTS NOMINEE
description: President Reagan's nomination of Edward A. Curran to be chairman of the National Endowment for the Humanities was rejected today by a Senate committee that questioned his qualifications and credibility.

title: VARIATIONS NOTED IN COMET'S LIGHT
description: Astronomers scrutinizing the approaching Halley's comet through the 158-inch telescope here in the last few nights were surprised by rapid variations in its brightness. The comet was trying to tell them something, perhaps of its shape, its rotation or it reactions to increasingly strong solar forces.

title: Martial Law Is Lifted In Istanbul After 7 Years
description: Martial law was ended today in Istanbul, the country's largest city, almost seven years after it was declared, the authorities announced.

title: Drug Clause Protested
description: The baseball players' union threatened to take action over a mandatory drug-testing clause included in at least one new contract and reportedly intended for up to 200 more players. Because such a clause appears in Steve Yeager's new contract, a grievance, or an unfair labor practice, is being considered against the Los Angeles Dodgers, the union chief, Don Fehr, said.

title: Ex-Falcon Guilty On 4 Drug Counts
description: Harmon Wages, a former Atlanta Falcon running back, was found guilty today of cocaine possession, but was acquitted of the more serious charges of possessing the drug with intent to distribute and lying to a grand jury.

title: Politics;   Operation Patch and Mend 695.2, 0,413.6,4.5,1434.4,0,695.2,4.5>
description: After more than a year of self-scrutiny and regeneration, the Democratic Party has patched itself up and is hoping for a political turnaround in the 1986 Senate elections.

title: The Black Bag
description: Wherever President Reagan travels, an accompanying security agent carries ''the black bag,'' which contains secret codes and equipment that keep the President in constant touch with the Pentagon and would enable him, in an emergency, to order military action.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: SOUTH AFRICAN POLICE SHOOT AND KILL 3 PROTESTERS
description: The police said today that they had shot and killed three black protesters in a segregated township east of here.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: SOME AMERICAN MEN. By Gloria Emerson. 315 pages. Simon & Schuster. $17.95.

title: RULES TO HANDLE ASBESTOS VOTED BY CITY COUNCIL
description: The City Council yesterday voted broad new restrictions on the handling of asbestos in an effort to reduce dangers to construction workers and to the public.

title: U.S. NOT DOUBTING TALKS ON CAPTIVES
description: Senior Reagan Administration officials said today that they were confident the United States was now in contact through an intermediary with the captors of at least four Americans in Lebanon. They said the fate of the hostages might be decided in the next few days.

title: The U.N. Today: Nov. 20, 1985
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Two Ghanaians Plead Guilty To Passing Secrets to U.S.
description: Two former Government security officers pleaded guilty today to charges of passing secrets to the United States Central Intelligence Agency.

title: COACH SAYS GIANTS WERE 'OUTPLAYED'
description: Make no mistake about it. The Giants were beaten not by themselves on Monday night, but by the Redskins.

title: Gifts Are Exchanged By 2 Summit Couples
description: President and Mrs. Reagan today presented gifts to Mikhail S. Gorbachev and his wife, Raisa, including two ballpoint pen desk sets inscribed with the words, ''Peace through communications.''

title: Eritrea Rebels Report Halting Offensive by Ethiopia Troops
description: A rebel group, the Eritrean People's Liberation Front, said today that it had killed or wounded nearly 5,000 Ethiopian troops in halting a Government offensive against strongholds in the Eritrean heartland in northern Ethiopia.

title: Doctor Is Convicted Of Murdering His Son
description: A jury today convicted a debt-ridden doctor of killing his son with two shots to the head to collect more than $140,000 in insurance benefits.

title: Still Going Strong
description: This season marks a decade since the merger agreement between the National Basketball Association and the American Basketball Association, and there are enough holdovers from the A.B.A. who are still on N.B.A. rosters that you could field an entire squad of 10 players with them. Here they are, ranked by average minutes on the court for each game their teams have played this season, before last night: Moses Malone, Philadelphia35.7 Artis Gilmore, San Antonio33.8 Julius Erving, Philadelphia32.6 Dan Roundfield, Washington32.4 George Gervin, Chicago25.4 Maurice Lucas, L.A. Lakers21.9 Mark Olberding, Sacramento21.4 Caldwell Jones, Portland11.8 Bobby Jones, Philadelphia11.5 Marvin Webster, Knicks0.0

title: THE SECRET OF REACHING 100? DON'T ASK
description: WHEN you have lived for 100 years, you are used to birthday telegrams from President Reagan, televised greetings from Willard Scott of the ''Today'' show and reporters who shout predictable questions into your bad ear. When you reach 105, however, you may be as bored as Alma Palmer is with the business of being so old.

title: POISON THREAT IN CALIFORNIA STRIKE PROMPTS GROCERS TO REMOVE ITEMS
description: A letter warning that meat and produce had been injected with insecticide at several supermarkets where workers have been on strike caused removal of some items from shelves.

title: More Sick Workers, Less OSHA
description: What accounts for the big increase in job-related injuries and illnesses recently reported by the Labor Department? The Reagan Administration's hostility to health and safety regulation, says the A.F.L.-C.I.O. Increased business activity and employment, says an analyst for the Congressional Office of Technology Assessment. The answer almost surely is both, but while the latter is inescapable, the former is inexcusable.

title: ISRAELIS SAY THEY SHOT DOWN 2 MIG-23'S IN SYRIAN AIRSPACE
description: Israeli fighter jets shot down two Syrian MIG-23's over Syria today as the Syrian planes tried to approach the Israeli aircraft, the commander of the Israeli Air Force said.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: HER name is Rita, his name is Frank. She is in her early 80's, he's in his 20's. Rita has emphysema, and once a week Frank, who works for a medical supply company, arrives at her apartment in Manhattan to replenish her supply of oxygen. Rita also has a handsome baby grand piano on which, in days past, her children took lessons and that now serves mainly as a space on which to display framed photographs of her family.

title: TAKEOUT TRIMMINGS WITH NEW TWISTS
description: CATERING shops throughout the city are offering a wealth of alternatives to the typical trimmings for the holiday bird.

title: Reagan and Sleep
description: The Reagan-Gorbachev summit meeting had barely started when the White House began expressing concern about the President's report to Congress afterward. The problem, aside from anxiety about the sensitive negotiations, involves Mr. Reagan's inability to sleep on airplanes and an overly ambitious schedule on his return to the capital.

title: The Campaign Is Over, But Trappings Live On
description: Patrons of a lower Manhattan liquor store have more to show from Kenneth Lipper's campaign for City Council president than the unusuccessful candidate does.

title: A Reason for Testing U.S. Resolve in Angola
description: To the Editor:

title: Orchestra of Toulouse In All-French Program
description: The Orchestre du Capitole de Toulouse, under the direction of Michel Plasson, will play an all-French program at Carnegie Hall on Sunday as the finale of its United States tour.

title: JAY SCHROEDER WAS READY
description: There were only two ways Jay Schroeder was going to see any significant action at quarterback this season: one, if the Redskins were eliminated from the race, or, two, if Joe Theismann were seriously injured.

title: Stop That Leak!
description: Nothing intrigues the performers in this political circus more than a purloined letter from a Cabinet officer to the President, especially if there's a whiff of treachery in the wind.

title: A SON'S PLEA IN COLOMBIA: 'MORE TIME'
description: Early this morning, rescue workers searching for people still alive in the mud that inundated this town six days ago heard the voices of two women.

title: GROUPS IN U.S. ACCEPTING DONATIONS FOR COLOMBIA
description: Adventist Development and Relief Agency International, 6840 Eastern Avenue N.W., Washington, D.C. 20012. American Jewish World Service, Suite 101, 29 Commonwealth Avenue, Boston, Mass. 02116. Mark checks ''Colombian Recovery Fund.''

title: Families in Glomar Case Settle for $51 Million
description: Families of crew members killed or missing in the sinking of the Glomar Java Sea off the coast of Vietnam in 1983 have agreed to a $51 million settlement.

title: THEISMANN FACING SECOND OPERATION
description: Joe Theismann, the Washington Redskin quarterback, was scheduled today for additional surgery to repair a compound fracture of his right leg that threatens to end his football career.

title: CALENDAR: FOR THANKSGIVING
description: Thanksgiving Workshops, City of New York Parks and Recreation Department.

title: Subpoena Fails In Maryland
description: For the third consecutive day, Maryland officials failed again yesterday to gain control of the books of the First American Mortgage Company, the failed Baltimore-based mortgage banker accused of fraud by E.F. Hutton & Company. Although the officials were able to serve a subpoena on First American's lawyer, the subpoena was declared invalid because of technical reasons.

title: RESIDENTS OF GULF COAST BRACE FOR HURRICANE KATE
description: Hurricane Kate turned its 115-mile-an-hour winds northward tonight on a collision course with a 300-mile stretch of the central Gulf Coast that has suffered more than $3 billion in hurricane damage since August.

title: SEACO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
AT HOLIDAY FAIRS, CRAFTS AND ANTIQUES
description: BEGINNING today, handmade craft items, antiques and collectibles, ceramics and Hanukkah gifts are among the offerings of holiday fairs and festivals taking place in Manhattan, Long Island and Westchester.

title: PARADE IN DETROIT BARS HANDICAPPED
description: A group of 200 people with disabilities has not been invited to march in the Thanksgiving Day parade here because sponsors want to make sure the procession moved along fast enough to keep its spot on national television.

title: GRAB BARS FOR THE BATH
description: A BATHTUB grab bar or safety rail can help prevent slips and falls while showering or bathing. The Comfortably Yours catalogue carries a grab bar made of white nylon-coated steel, with a clamp at its base that holds it tightly to tub rims from three to seven inches wide. The bar is 15 inches high and has a middle rail for additional support. It is $71 from Comfortably Yours, 52 West Hunter Avenue, Maywood, N.J., 07607; 201-368-0400.

title: Federal Court Halts Eviction Of 600 in Washington Shelter
description: The Federal Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia today blocked the eviction of nearly 600 people from a shelter for the homeless.

title: Dawkins Fined $500
description: Scotty Stirling, the National Basketball Association's vice president of operations, has fined Darryl Dawkins of the Nets $500 and Wallace Bryant of the Mavericks $250 for their fight in the fourth quarter of last Friday night's game in Dallas. The fines are in addition to the automatic $250 in penalties each center will have to pay for their ejections from the game. ''Dawkins's fine was higher because he instigated the incident with a push in the back,'' Stirling said.

title: NAVY PROCEEDS WITH PROJECT TO BASE SHIPS IN NEW PORTS
description: The Navy will proceed with its plans to base battleships, aircraft carriers and other warships in 15 new or expanded port facilities, including Staten Island, unless Congress kills the concept by Feb. 9, a Navy spokesman said today.

title: Bill on Boxing Gains in House
description: A bill to establish a United States boxing commission today received the tentative support of the House subcommittee on transportation and tourism of the Energy and Commerce Committee Although the subcommittee agreed to forward the bill to the full committee, several members expressed reservations about the proposal, and the bill's authors promised to consider amendments before presenting it to the full committee.

title: ANOTHER DAY IN THE LIFE OF THE MONTANA LOGGER
description: The lights in Orval Bothman's house flick on shortly after 5 A.M. these dark, early winter days in the mountains. He dons several layers of flannel, downs a hearty breakfast, grabs a silver thermos of coffee and starts the 45-mile trip to work.

title: Slow Buick Sales Lead to Layoffs
description: The General Motors Corporation will lay off 1,723 workers in Michigan because of falling demand for the Buick Regal midsized car, the nation's largest car maker said.

title: ROYALTIES ON RECORDERS AND BLANK AUDIO TAPES
description: What does copyright mean in the electronic age? That question is at the heart of bills currently before Congress that would impose a royalty on blank audio tape and tape recorders. By making electronic copying more expensive, the legislation would reimburse those who believe they lose sales when music is taped at home.

title: LINKING AIDS TO AFRICA PROVOKES BITTER DEBATE
description: Tantalizing but sketchy clues pointing to Africa as the origin of AIDS have unleashed one of the bitterest disputes in the recent annals of medicine.

title: RANGERS THUMP LEAFS BY 7-3
description: His face to the glass, Don Edwards screamed. He pointed his finger. For a moment, it looked as if he might climb the glass to get to the goal judge. And that was one of the calmer scenes in a wild night at the Garden.

title: THEATER'RUSSIA,' FROM SAUSALITO TO BROOKLYN
description: ''RUSSIA,'' the new theater piece at the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Next Wave Festival, comes equipped with all the latest technology known to man or performance art: elaborate masks (variously reminiscent of Duchamp, Tanguy, Oriental puppets and Mr. Potato Head), kaleidoscopic slide projections, electronic music, deafening sound effects and a multilayered audio collage of garbled human voices. And to what purpose is this machinery put? Well, let me give you one example: In the opening minutes of ''Russia,'' theatergoers are treated to the most lavish audio-visual demonstration imaginable of the often neglected fact that the initials ''U.S.A.'' can actually be found among the letters in the word ''Russia.''

title: DIRECTOR OF 'STAR WARS' PREDICTING A SPEED-UP WHEN MEETING ENDS
description: The director of the Strategic Defense Initiative program said today that he expected to receive instructions after the Geneva summit to move ahead ''much more quickly and effectively'' with the design of a space-based defense against nuclear missiles.

title: CORRECTION

He said the price equaled about one and a half times Applied Data's annual revenues, not its earnings.

MUSIC: SONGS FROM BRITAIN
description: VICTORIA VILLAMIL'S programs usually take on the form of musical excavations, and Sunday night's celebration of 20th-century British art song at Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street, was no exception. Accompanied by the pianist Joel Sachs and the violist Marilyn Dubow, Miss Villamil sang works by Gustav Holst, Elisabeth Lutyens, Benjamin Britten, Judith Weir, Frank Bridge and Peter Warlock, proving, once again, that the British repertory remains a rich, diverse and largely untapped source of musical gratification.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: TO call Neil Postman a critic of television would be as inadequate as calling Bishop Tutu a critic of apartheid or Jerry Falwell a critic of abortion. In Mr. Postman's view, the much-criticized medium is a peril to our society, our culture, our civilization. The theme of his 16th book, ''Amusing Ourselves to Death,'' is that television is bringing us speedily to the condition of the residents of Aldous Huxley's ''Brave New World,'' who were seduced into happy mindlessness. He writes: ''When a population becomes distracted by trivia, when cultural life is redefined as a perpetual round of entertainments, when serious public conversation becomes a form of baby-talk, when, in short, a people become an audience and their public business a vaudeville act, then a nation finds itself at risk; culture-death is a clear possibility.''

title: Israeli Paper Aids Etan Patz Search
description: At the request of Federal and New York City investigators, an Israeli newspaper this week printed a photograph of Etan Patz and asked for information about his disappearance six years ago, law-enforcement officials said here yesterday.

The utility had requested annual increases of $444 million for the Waterford Three unit, which began commercial operation in September, and $113.9 million for Grand Gulf One, which went into service in July.

Streaking through scales, making notes moan or sting and cutting across funk and jazz rhythms with be-bop figurations, the violinists played rounds of solos on one another's tunes.

title: DANCE: THE CITY BALLET BEGINS ITS 83D SEASON
description: THE New York City Ballet opened its 83d season on Tuesday at the New York State Theater with a performance that was City Ballet at its familiar, exalted self. The company ought always to open with George Balanchine's signature ''Apollo,'' as it did here, in a performance conducted by Robert Irving. The stringent purity and look of inevitability of ''Apollo,'' Balanchine's first collaboration with Stravinsky and the oldest ballet in the repertory, are hallmarks of Balanchine's classical ballet style. But ''Apollo'' also offers a view of Balanchine at his most paradoxically unassuming.

title: CONCERT: MUSICAL ELEMENTS PLAYS AT COOPER UNION
description: IT could be argued that music's biggest - and still unsolved -problem in the 20th century has had to do with trying to put new compositions into circulation. The approach taken by Musical Elements at Cooper Union on Tuesday night was simply to throw a big batch of relatively recent products at a few listeners and hope that some of the pieces ''took,'' as it were. The results were no more heartening than such ventures usually are.

title: Music/Noted in Brief;   For Margaret Whiting, A 40-Year Look Back
description: There are several personal facets to Margaret Whiting's life that provide handy hooks on which she can build her performances: Her father, Richard Whiting, wrote some of the great pop songs of the 1920's and 30's; she grew up on intimate terms with the songwriters who were her father's friends, and her own singing career has covered more than four decades and has brought her in touch with a variety of performers. One of Miss Whiting's special talents is her ability to use these resources in ways that, rather than seeming to be name-dropping, add warmly revealing color to her programs. She has never done this more effectively than in her current show, written and produced for her by Jack Wrangler, at Freddy's Supper Club, 308 East 49th Street. The fact that her father wrote the songs for the only Ethel Merman show that ever flopped out of town leads her to sing a song from a revised version that finally reached New York - ''You're an Old Smoothie,'' a love song built on collegiate hip talk of the Depression years. This recalls a conversation with Miss Merman in which they find that each made her stage debut playing the same role in ''Girl Crazy,'' which leads to a song by George and Ira Gershwin that they both sang in the show: ''Boy! What Love Has Done to Me,'' a torch song that is both funny and touching in Miss Whiting's treatment.
