Indeed, an article in the opera program about Mr. Rizzo and his working conditions used the name to describe him.

title: Mike Bell of Chiefs Is Arrested
description: Mike Bell, a 28-year-old defensive end for the Kansas City Chiefs, and two former players, one of them Bell's twin brother, Mark, were arrested yesterday on Federal narcotics charges.

title: Sugar Producers Meet
description: The world's four major sugar exporters met here today at the headquarters of the International Sugar Organization to explore possibilities for lifting the world's depressed sugar market, delegates said. It was the first time the four - Australia, Brazil, Cuba and the European Economic Community - had met since negotiations over a new International Sugar Agreement collapsed in July 1984. One delegate said most sugar exporters now favor a fresh try at reaching agreement, but that they differ on when to make such an attempt.

title: BANGOR HYDRO-ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results for the latest quarter and 9 months include a net provision of $3,179,000 for loss on Seabrook Unit 2 investment.

title: THE DANCE: KAZUO OHNO'S 'DEAD SEA'
description: THE uncanny exercises in both impersonation and personification carried off last night by Kazuo Ohno, the grand old man of Japanese Butoh dance theater, are not necessarily for everyone.

title: More Wreckage Found At Vietnam Crash Site
description: United States and Vietnamese workers found more pieces of metal and fabric-like material today from an American airplane that the Vietnamese Government says is a B-52 that crashed in a rural garden 13 years ago. Human bone fragments were found earlier, but it was not yet determined whether they were the remains of American airmen.

title: SEAPORT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: Bank Board Names Enforcement Chief
description: Rosemary Stewart, an attorney at the Federal Home Loan Bank Board since 1974, has learned how to live with red tape. But from now on, Mrs. Stewart intends to be dealing with less of it.

title: ARGO PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After net losses from discontinued operations of $2,087,000 for the quarter and $2,300,000 for the 9 months, which include a writedown of $1,450,000 of a building to its estimated fair market value and a provision of $249,00 for the estimated loss to be incurred during the period of disposition, before income tax credit. c-Net income. d-Including a net gain from discontinued operations of $17,000 for the quarter and a net loss from discontinued operations of $339,000 for the 9 months. Year-ago results have been restated.

title: Advice on Using Steel Shells
description: The areas in which waterfowlers must use shells loaded with nontoxic steel shot have been slowly increasing the last several years, and there are many hunters who are unfamiliar with the ballistics of such ammunition.

title: ALLIANCE WELL SERVICE reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $6,000. c-After net from discontinued operations of $1,004,000.

title: TELECONCEPTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Advertising;   Grey Wins John Henry Shirtmakers Account
description: Manhattan Industries has assigned its John Henry Shirtmakers division to Grey Advertising.

title: LAW REPEAL URGED FOR SOUTH AFRICA
description: A South African Government committee today recommended the abolition of laws that bar blacks from competing on an equal basis in business.

title: HELIONETICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss. c-Net income.

title: To Be Young, Southern and Liberal
description: Virginia Foster Durr of Montgomery, Ala., was holding court in the capacious living room of an Arlington, Va., condominium. She was wearing a black velvet suit, a white ruffled blouse and a radiant smile as she lifted her face for the busses of old friends.

title: WEST GERMAN DANCE: FADDISM AND HIPPOS
description: REINHILD HOFFMANN'S ''Callas,'' which Tanztheater Bremen brought to the Brooklyn Academy of Music this fall, abounded with surprising images showing how fame can fade and glamour tarnish and how an affluent but Philistine public can treat artists like grotesques. There were also images of erotic warfare. These came as no surprise, for such choreographers as Miss Hoffmann and Pina Bausch have helped make erotic warfare the rage in West Germany.

title: Advertising;   People
description: * Albert C.M. Winninghoff has been named regional managing director of the European/Middle East division of Leo Burnett, effective Jan. 1.

title: Failed Banks In Brazil
description: The collapse of three banks with about $750 million in international loans could hurt negotiations to reschedule Brazil's $103 billion debt unless the Government agrees to honor all their foreign commitments, banking sources said today.

title: Memories of Haaren
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:

title: INTERNATIONAL THOMSON ORANISATION LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $26.8 million.

title: GOLDEN NUGGET INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After extraordinary losses of $268,000 for the quarter and $1,398,000 for the 9 months. c-After an extraordinary loss of $2,788,000.

title: Farm Credit Bill in House
description: Leaders of the House Agriculture Committee introduced a bill today authorizing Federal financial assistance to the ailing Farm Credit System without specifying how much aid would be provided.

title: GULFSTREAM LAND & DEVELOPENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $226,000 for the quarter and $1,705,000 for the year. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $849,000 for the quarter and $942,000 for the year.

title: INSTRUMENT SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After tax credits of $200,000 for the latest quarter and $600,000 for the earlier period. c-After extraordinary gains of $4.5 million for the latest year and $2.8 million for 1984.

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: An article on Tuesday about the slaying of Nicholas L. Deak, the founder of Deak & Company, the foreign-exchange concern, discussed allegations made in October 1984 by a Federal commission on organized crime that the company had been used to launder drug money.

title: Experience Recycled
description: To the Editor:

title: WITNESS SAYS HE COLLECTED BRIBES FROM MOBSTERS FOR QUEENS JUDGE
description: In emotional testimony, a Florida restaurant owner said yesterday that he had collected bribes for 15 years from organized-crime figures on behalf of a state judge in Queens, and that he had lied about it to protect his ''good friend'' the judge.

title: HERS
description: I GOT an invitation to Playboy's new Empire Club, where they've introduced The Rabbit, ''for female members who believe that turnabout is hare play.'' This, in the same month that Virginia Slims gave us longer cigarettes. Things were looking up. Christie Hefner's in charge now, and what with the Rabbits and all, I had to see for myself what a long way we've come.

title: SHOULD PARENTS ASSUME A CHILD'S DUTY?
description: WHAT do parents do when their children let responsibilities slide and the consequences are sure to cause problems? By many accounts it is a dilemma: to jump to the rescue or not.

title: Market Place;   Picking Stocks At Templeton
description: JOHN M. TEMPLETON, founder and president of a mutual fund group managing $4 billion that bears his name, often does not follow the pack when it comes to making investment decisions.

title: Californians for Cuomo
description: Governor Cuomo's status as a national figure was reinforced by some non-New Yorkers among the more than 2,000 who attended his record-breaking fund-raising dinner Tuesday night.

title: OPTICAL RADIATION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MATTINGLY WINS MOST VALUABLE AWARD IN LANDSLIDE
description: Don Mattingly, who did just about everything this year except put the Yankees into the playoffs, achieved a runaway victory yesterday in the voting for the American League's most valuable player award. In so doing, Mattingly became the first person to stop the Kansas City Royals in a postseason contest.

title: First Maryland Gets Conservator
description: First Maryland Savings and Loan, told it had ''no hope'' of gaining Federal deposit insurance before a Dec. 31 deadline, became the fourth thrift unit to be placed into conservatorship since the state's financial crisis began in May. Baltimore Circuit Judge Joseph H. H. Kaplan turned operations of the Silver Spring-based thrift unit, the state's eighth largest, with assets of $393 million, over to the Maryland Deposit Insurance Fund.

title: DE ROSE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-New income

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: Using U.S. Muscle in World Markets
description: A few years ago, the president of one of the leading semiconductor companies in the United States complained to me about the unwillingness of the Japanese to open their markets to his company's products. When the then Prime Minister, Takeo Fukuda, visited California a few months later, I asked the business executive to join me in greeting him and to make his point directly. This he did, and with such force and bluntness that the rest of us in the room became uncomfortable at his frankness. Mr. Fukuda listened politely, and then replied that Japan had opened its markets, and very much welcomed his company's competition.

title: Nixon Offer Matched
description: The Los Angeles Clippers have matched an offer sheet that Norm Nixon, the free-agent guard, signed with the Seattle SuperSonics. On Tuesday, Nixon signed a second, revised offer sheet with the Sonics, who changed their offer after the original one was contested by the Clippers and the league over incentive clauses that were judged to put Seattle over the salary cap.

title: Tin Talks to Continue
description: The International Tin Council met today and agreed to meet in December in a marathon session to work out a plan for reopening tin trading. The council said in a statement that it would reconvene Dec. 2 and would ''remain in session until it reaches a definitive decision'' to resolve the crisis.

title: Open File Ordered In BMT Shoving
description: An appellate court yesterday ordered the city to make public the transcript of a hearing that led to the release of a 19-year-old mental patient charged with shoving a woman in front of a subway train.

title: UNREST IN GREECE: A CONFRONTATION ON THE LEFT
description: Three days of strikes and violent street disturbances this week have aggravated a growing confrontation between the governing Socialists and the Communists.

title: JEFFERSON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a gain of $1,060,000 for the quarter and 6 months from the sale of assets.

title: The Busy Life
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:

title: 41 Rebels Reported Dead After Battle in Nicaragua
description: The Government reported today that its soldiers had killed 41 rebels in a clash in the central province of Chontales.

title: Bridge: Odd Contract for L.I. Pair Ends Up as Winning One
description: It is sometimes obvious, from inspection of a hand diagram and the accompanying bidding, that something has gone wrong. Exactly what has gone wrong is usually less obvious.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Beirut dispatch on Monday about efforts to free the American hostages in Lebanon misidentified Terry Waite, special envoy of the Archbishop of Canterbury. Mr. Waite is a lay official, not a clergyman, of the Anglican Church.

title: Tandy Introduces Computer at Show
description: The Tandy Corporation, joining a growing list of companies, introduced a computer compatible with the International Business Machine Corporation's most powerful personal computer, the PC-AT. Tandy said its Tandy 3000 would sell at $2,600 for a model with floppy disks and $3,600 for a model with a hard disk drive capable of storing 20 million characters of information.

title: CRIMINAL LAWYERS IN STUDY SAY NEW LAWS INHIBIT CASE CHOICES
description: Many defense lawyers across the country have drastically revamped the way they handle white-collar, racketeering and drug cases as a result of recent Federal laws, a new study shows.

title: Up to 100,000 Said to Die In Ethiopia Resettlement
description: Up to 100,000 refugees have died in Ethiopian resettlement programs after having been forced to move at gunpoint, the chairman of a leading French medical aid agency said today.

title: Founder of Pride Air In Search for Investors
description: When Paul R. Eckel, a former chief pilot for Continental Airlines, founded Pride Air Inc. last year, he had a dream that an employee-owned airline could find success by becoming the first carrier to offer low-fare, coast-to-coast service from a base in New Orleans.

title: STANDARD HAVENS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
AMERFORD INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes extraordinary charges of $397,000. c-Net income

title: NEW METHOD IS PRODUCING FETUS FOR A WOMAN WITHOUT A UTERUS
description: Doctors say they are helping a woman without a uterus to have a child by implanting her fertilized egg into the body of a surrogate mother.

title: 'CURRENTS' OFFERS 'DIAGNOSING THE DOCTORS'
description: TONIGHT'S subject on ''Currents,'' Channel 13's public affairs program airing at 8:30 o'clock, is a perennial -why doctors are not as compassionate as they once were. Viewers who have missed a couple of decades' worth of newspaper and magazine articles on the subject may find something new in ''Diagnosing the Doctors.''

title: The Next Trump Tower and Its Shadow
description: Time alone can distinguish between great dreams and vain illusions. It's too early to know which describes Donald Trump's desire to loom over New York and all other cityscapes with a 150-story tower flanked by six huge apartment houses and a vast Television City. But it's possible to frame a first list of questions.

title: Some Differences Between Ortega and Lincoln
description: To the Editor:

title: HOWELL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
The Fireside Summit
description: ''A stroll in the park, a fireside chat, and thou beside me'' is the Rubaiyat of Ronald Reagan.

title: FRANCO MATTEI
description: Franco Mattei, president of an Italian holding company, died today in Milan, the employers' federation Confindustria said. He was 66 years old. Mr. Mattei, an economist, headed the Gemina company, which has holdings in Montedison, the chemical concern, and Rizzoli, the publishing empire. He was also vice president of Confindustria, the management association.

title: Smokeout Drive Spreads To Tobacco Country
description: The American Cancer Society's annual ''Great American Smokeout,'' beginning at midnight today and continuing until midnight Thursday, is spreading its antismoking message into the heart of tobacco country.

title: HAIG WEIGHING MOVE TO SEEK NOMINATION OF G.O.P. IN 1988
description: Former Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. indicated today that he would consider seeking the Republican Presidential nomination in 1988, but he added, ''I don't want to be pushed prematurely into a lame-duck status.''

title: VIPONT LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss after a one-time charge of $2,768,356 related to the purchase of technology from Periodontal Associates Partnership. c-After a $65,000 charge from the settlement of litigation.

title: CONCERT: FOR MAYER' 60TH BIRTHDAY
description: ''HAVING gotten used to being out of step with fashion for so many years,'' remarks the composer William Mayer, ''writing romantic and relatively unconvoluted music long before the arrival of the 'New Romanticism' and the current accessibility of so many new works, I feel a bit bewildered that my music is rather suddenly mainstream.''

title: Scotland Wins
description: Scotland defeated Australia, 2-0, tonight in the first game of a two-game playoff to decide a berth in next summer's World Cup in Mexico.

title: NOW JACKSON IS EMBRACING THE NUANCES
description: ''I simply assumed the responsibility,'' the Rev. Jesse Jackson said today in reply to a question from the floor after a speech at a church center here.

title: The Return On C.D.'s Is Stable
description: Rates paid on certificates of deposit and bank money market accounts showed little or no change for the week ended yesterday, while money market mutual funds moved higher.

title: UNITED EDUCATION & SOFTARE reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $248,000 for the quarter and $360,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss.

title: LEISURE DYNAMICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income including an extraordinary tax credit of $672,000.

title: CENVILL INVESTORS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including income of $64,000 for the quarter and $296,000 for the 9 months from the amortization of deferred gains. c-Including income of $189,000 for the quarter and $789,000 for the 9 months from the amortization of deferred gains.

title: JUDGE FINDS YONKERS HAS SEGREGATION POLICY
description: A Federal judge ruled yesterday that city and school officials in Yonkers had ''illegally and intentionally'' segregated the city's public schools and public housing along racial lines.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Texas A&M (19-11 last season) vs. Alabama-Birmingham (25-9) and Duke (23-8) vs. Lamar (20-12), at the Houston Summit. Opening-round doubleheader in the first Big Apple National Invitation Tournament.

title: LOMAK PETROLEUM reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
GIANT FOOD INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 2
SHIP HIJACKER TO BE TRIED AS MINOR
description: One of four Palestinians accused of hijacking the Italian cruise ship Achille Lauro will have to be tried separately by a juvenile court because it has been learned he is 17 years old, legal officials said today.

title: MODERN CONTROLS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
'I Feel Good for the City'
description: He grew up in Evansville, Ind., and lives there in the offseason. But when Don Mattingly was asked last night about his reaction to having been voted the American League's most valuable player award in a landslide, the Yankees' first baseman sounded as if he were a New Yorker instead of a Hoosier.

title: KETCHUM & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After tax credits of $128,000 for the quarter and $230,000 for the 6 months. c-After tax credits of $112,000 for the quarter and $179,000 for the 6 months.

title: A SECRET EFFORT IS REPORTED FOR A PACT ON AIRLINE FLIGHTS
description: In a last-minute effort to provide more agreements to announce at the Geneva summit meeting, American negotiators flew secretly to Moscow on Sunday to reopen talks on restoring direct air service between the United States and the Soviet Union, Reagan Administration officials said today.

title: 77 degrees Establishes a Record
description: Four days after the first snow of the season, New York City's temperature climbed yesterday to the highest mark ever recorded so late in the year.

title: Advertising;   Magazine Publisher's Acquisition
description: HAVING tired of being ''a single-title publisher in a multi-title world,'' Owen J. Lipstein, 34-year-old founder and publisher of the highly successful American Health magazine, has now acquired Mother Earth News.

title: REDOUTE WATERCOLORS AUCTIONED TO SYNDICATE
description: The Empress Josephine's copy of Pierre-Joseph Redoute's botanical watercolors for his book ''Les Liliacees,'' (''The Lilies'') was auctioned yesterday at Sotheby's for $5.5 million to W. Graham Arader, a rare-book and print dealer, who organized a syndicate to make the purchase.

title: 26 SENATORS BACK BIPARTISAN TRADE LEGISLATION
description: A group of 26 Senators, setting aside 12 months of partisan squabbling, introduced legislation today to spur the Reagan Administration to step up action against unfair trade practices abroad.

title: REAGAN CONTINUES PRIVATE MEETINFS WITH GORBACHEV
description: President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev held three more private meetings today and agreed to conclude their conference here with a joint appearance on Thursday morning, Larry Speakes, the White House spokesman, announced tonight.

title: Newspaper's Claim Rejected
description: A judge on Tuesday dismissed a $6 million counterclaim that McClatchy Newspapers had filed in response to a $250 million libel suit by Senator Paul Laxalt of Nevada. The counterclaim, dismissed by Federal District Judge Edward Reed, was based on arguments that the Republican Senator had sought to suppress the newspaper group's First Amendment rights when he filed his lawsuit in September 1984.

title: Mentor Role for Retired Teachers Is Expanding
description: To the Editor:

title: JB'S RESTAURANTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a pretax loss of $84,000 for the quarter and year on the disposal of assets and a tax credit of $626,000 for the quarter. c-Including a pretax gain of $10,000 on the disposal of assets. Results are for 13 and 53 weeks for the latest periods and 12 and 52 weeks for the year-ago periods.

title: GERBER SYSTEMS TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net losses. The company is 80 percent-owned by Gerber Scientific Inc.

title: EX-CHOATE STUDENT RECEIVES PROBATION ON COCAINE CHARGE
description: A former Choate Rosemary Hall student who admitted smuggling cocaine from South America for his prep school classmates was sentenced today in Federal District Court to five years of probation and 5,000 hours of community service.

title: CONCEFT: A PROGRAM OF 'PAINTER'S MUSIC'
description: AN DIE MUSIK'S Sunday afternoon concert at the Guggenheim Museum, entitled ''The Painter's Music, the Musician's Art,'' raised more questions than it answered. Four painters - Helen Frankenthaler, David Hockney, Robert Motherwell and Kenneth Noland - were asked to choose particular works that appealed to them from An die Musik's repertory, to discuss the significance of music in their lives and to design posters commemorating the chamber group's 10th anniversary.

title: Advertising;   John Blair to Sell Off Units in Restructuring
description: John Blair & Company, a multifaceted company in broadcasting and marketing, has announced plans to drop a facet or two.

title: GERBER SCIENTIFIC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
HOME REPAIR
description: UNCLOGGING a toilet usually requires different techniques than unclogging a sink drain. This is because sinks have an accessible U-shaped trap underneath that can be taken apart, but toilet traps are part of the porcelain bowl.

title: Pentagon;   The Steady Rise of the Submariners
description: Quietly, the way they drive their ships under the seven seas, the Navy's submariners have broken the hold of naval aviators on the top rungs of their service.

title: WHITE HOUSE CHIEF'S VIEW ON WOMEN APPEARS SINGULAR
description: A comment by the White House chief of staff, Donald T. Regan, that women lacked interest in the issues in the summit meeting found little support among the principals today.

title: $50,000 Fine Given In Toxic Dumping
description: The former owner of an printed-circuit electronics factory in Farmingdale was fined $50,000 today for dumping millions of gallons of toxic wastes into a pool hidden under the factory floor.

title: Polish Debt Accord Seen
description: Poland has reached agreement with Western creditor governments to reschedule about $1.3 billion of official debt falling due this year, diplomats here said today.

title: A BLUNT KOCH WOOS JAPANESE TRADE
description: Mayor Koch, praising Asian immigrants for having ''revitalized '' New York, ended a five-day stay in Tokyo today with an appeal to Japanese businesses to move to his city.

title: IMMUNOGENETICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $52,000 for the quarter and $187,000 for the 9 months and a gain of $569,000 for the 9 months on the extinguishment of debt. c-Including a tax credit of $225,000.

title: U.S. ISSUES A WARNING ON SUDAN
description: The United States urged Americans today not to travel to Khartoum, charging that the Sudanese capital had become a base for Libyan and other terrorists.

title: Senate Overrides Veto of Medical Research
description: The Senate voted overwhelmingly tonight to override President Reagan's veto of a $2.3 billion bill reauthorizing biomedical research at the National Institutes of Health through 1988.

title: What Smokers Have in Common
description: John Galbraith started smoking when he was 18 years old. For him it was surely a rite of passage, as it still is for millions of teen-agers. Fifty-one years later, still a smoker, he died of the habit - but not before he hired a lawyer to sue the R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company. Cigarette manufacturers, his suit claims, knew years ago that their product could be addictive, but failed to warn the consumer.

title: The Big Iranian 'Lottery'
description: The news out of Iran has been sparse ever since most Western journalists were expelled when Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini took power in 1979. Nonetheless, I occasionally hear from a close friend who lives in Teheran and whose letters provide a glimpse of life under the Ayatollah and the effects of the Iran-Iraq war.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: FUNNY MAN In the eight years since Charlie Chaplin died, interest in him and his work - including the more than 80 movies he made in a 53-year film career - hasn't waned in the least. Retrospectives and television specials abound. Most advertise rare or recently discovered footage, outtakes and otherwise unused Chaplin matter, all of it providing new glimpses of the Little Tramp.

title: Graham Passes On Patroons
description: No, Michael Graham does not want to play in Albany, certainly not for $6,000 a year. So yesterday, while the training camps of the Continental Basketball Association were getting cranked up, he was reported to be still in class at the University of the District of Columbia, unable to come to the phone. At the same time, the C.B.A.'s Albany Patroons were trying to get over a case of severe embarrassment, which stemmed from their announcement last week that Graham would play for them this season.

title: Role Reversal
description: Victor Gotbaum, the labor leader, crossed a picket line when he went to work yesterday. Office workers for District Council 37 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, A.F.L.-C.I.O., are on strike.

title: KALEIDOSCOPES TURN MODERN
description: THE kaleidoscope, once a dime-store children's toy, is now the stuff of museum shops and boutiques. In the hands of modern craftsmen, it has been elevated to something of an object d'art.

title: Staying Home
description: When Larry Flowers joined the Jets last week, he became the 20th man to suit up for both them and the Giants. The roll call, in alphabetical order: John Bookman, defensive back Jim Carroll, linebacker Mike Dennis, defensive back Larry Flowers, defensive back Chris Godfrey, guard Lee Grosscup, quarterback Proverb Jacobs, offensive tackle Charlie Janarette, defensive tackle Dave Jennings, punter Curley Johnson, punter Ed Marshall, wide receiver Don Maynard, wide receiver Ed McGlasson, center Chuck Mercein, running back Bob Mischak, guard Mark Reed, quarterback Lee Riley, defensive back Billy Taylor, running back Mo Tyler, defensive back Roscoe Word, defensive back

title: VARO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income, including a nonrecurring tax credit of $1,379,000 for the 6 months.

title: FIRST CITY INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income including a tax credit of $1,179,000, or 14 cents a share.

title: Bush Details Obstacles To Caribbean Initiative
description: Vice President Bush said today that Caribbean governments had not been doing enough to make a success out of the Caribbean Basin Initiative, the Reagan Administration's economic development plan for the region.

title: A First-Class Joke
description: Senator David Pryor, the Arkansas Democrat, was headed home recently, sitting in the tourist section of the plane. Just before the doors closed, Senator David L. Boren, Democrat of Oklahoma, rushed aboard and was seated up front in first class.

title: JAZZ QUINTET FEATURING 2 HOLLYDAYS
description: TWO young brothers from Boston - Richard Hollyday, a 20-year-old trumpeter, and his 15-year-old saxophonist brother, Christopher - brought a quintet to the Blue Note (131 West Third Street) on Monday evening that showed a personal absorption of be-bop as a performance foundation and a knowledge of rarely heard jazz compositions of the 1950's and 60's.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, NOVEMBER 21, 1985
description: The Economy

title: FOX PHOTO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 26
description: Fox Photo Inc. was formerly Fox- Stanley Photo Products Inc.

title: NEWPARK RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After charges of $18.6 million for the quarter and $24.6 million for the 9 months to provide for losses from certain assets and losses of $66,000 for the quarter and $1,510,000 for the 9 months from discontinued operations. c-Including income of $176,000 from discontinued operations. d-After a loss of $2,553,000 from discontinued operations and charges of $6 million from the sale and writedowns of inventory property, plants, equipment and other assets.

title: 7 HELD IN CORRUPTION LINKED TO FEDERAL CONTRACTS
description: Seven people, including the Republican chairman of Niagara County and a former official of Buffalo's new subway project, were arrested today on corruption charges stemming from a 15-month investigation of Federal contracts in Erie and Niagara Counties.

title: YALE DECIDES AGAINST TV FOR THE GAME
description: Although the annual Harvard-Yale contest is in some quarters grandly called The Game, another reference might be The Crowd. The numbers who show up for this social and sporting event, regardless of the teams' circumstances, are a phenomenon considering the decline of Ivy League football attendance in the last two decades.

title: ECONOMY SEEN SETTLING INTO A 'SOFT LANDING'
description: The American economy has been listless for more than a year, and some of the experts have been warning that it would list right into another grueling recession, this year or next.

title: VOLCANO RESCUE APPEARS TO END
description: Officially, the search for survivors of the eruption of the Nevado del Ruiz volcano here is still under way. But except for intensified efforts by two small teams of French and British rescue workers, the operation, which from the beginning had been fragmented, small and poorly equipped, had all the signs of being over.

title: ARTRA GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,678,000 for the quarter and $397,000 for the 9 months, a net gain of $175,000 for the 9 months on the sale of securities and debt conversion costs of $304,000 for the 9 months. c-Including income from discontinued operations of $418,000 for the quarter and $1,974,000 for the 9 months and an extraordinary credit of $230,000 for the 9 months. Results for the latest periods include Artra's interest in R. N. Kock Inc. since Feb. 8, 1985. Year-ago results have been restated to reflect discontinued operations and a 1984 fourth quarter reversal of a portion of an extraordinary tax credit.

title: Memories of Haaren
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:

title: THE STAGE: 'HARM'S WAY,' BY MAX WELLMAN
description: THE killer named Santouche will stop at nothing, gunning down a mother, several children and a man who insists he is President McKinley. Even a sweet lady named Isle of Mercy gets no mercy. When his actions are questioned, Santouche resorts to a favorite excuse: ''I ain't got no respect.''

title: WSI Purchases Wieboldt Stores
description: Wieboldt Stores Inc. and the WSI Acquisition Corporation said they had signed a definitive agreement for the acquisition of Wieboldt by WSI for $13.50 a share, or about $37.3 million.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: THURSDAY, NOVEMBER 21, 1985
description: International

title: Jury Requests Death Penalty For Man Who Killed His Son
description: Jurors recommended today that Dr. John Dale Cavaness, a general practitioner from southern Illinois, die in the gas chamber for murdering his son.

title: JAMESWAY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 2
ERNST, E C INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Revenue figures represent contract income.

title: THE TETE-A-TETES AT THE SUMMIT: A DRAWN CURTAIN OF UNCERTAINTY
description: Tete-a-tetes have been a feature of all of the United States-Soviet summit conferences since World War II.

title: A SERENE COURTYARD REOPENS AT THE MET
description: CONNOISSEURS of indoor green spaces are again able to enjoy a favorite garden inside the Metropolitan Museum of Art. On Tuesday, the American Wing's Charles W. Engelhard Courtyard, which had been closed since Aug. 1 for renovation, reopened to the public. The rejuvenated garden forms the setting for the museum's current exhibition of sculpture by the 19th-century American sculptor Augustus Saint-Gaudens.

title: Stocks Mixed Again; Dow Up 0.23
description: Stock prices were narrowly mixed again yesterday, continuing the week's indecisive activity.

title: THE OSBOURNE: NOW 100 YEARS OLD AND STILL A NICE PLACE TO LIVE
description: DAVIDA DEUTSCH sometimes sits on the steps in the stairwell outside her apartment in the Osborne at 57th Street and Seventh Avenue, diagonally across from Carnegie Hall, to hear the concert pianist Gary Graffman practicing on another floor. Mrs. Deutsch, the unofficial historian of the 1885 Renaissance-style building, can also occasionally hear the practicing of Bobby Short, the entertainer, through the fireplace flues.

title: LOBBYIST ON A NATIONAL SCALE
description: Her name is on a foundation that has changed the course of medical research in this country, on a skating rink, on 10 honorary degrees and a new pink tulip. As one of her fans, Dr. Michael E. DeBakey, said yesterday: ''Mary Lasker is an institution unto herself.

title: MANY OIL INCENTIVES RETAINED
description: Facing heavy lobbying from the oil industry and pressure from the Administration, the House Ways and Means Committee voted tonight to retain a majority of the special tax incentives that now exist for oil and gas drilling.

title: DE TOMASO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: Of Arms and Legs
description: Many Washingtonians seem to be paying about as much attention to the Geneva summit meeting as they are to Joe Theismann, which is a lot. Mr. Theismann, the Washington Redskins quarterback, broke a leg Monday night as the Redskins defeated the New York Giants, and his playing days may well be over. Washington, a town that abhors losers, was down on Mr. Theismann earlier in the season because of his relatively poor play.

title: MICROBIOLOGICAL SCIENCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
2 STATE TROOPERS DIE AS PATROL CAR SWERVES TO AVOID A TRACTOR-TRAILER
description: Two state troopers were killed late Tuesday night when their patrol car swerved to avoid a tractor-trailer crossing their path at a toll plaza and crashed into a parked tractor-trailer.

title: MPSI SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
The Military-Industrial Complex
description: Mikhail Gorbachev provoked American officials, on the eve of the summit, by telling them that the ''military-industrial complex'' had great influence in the United States. Military contractors, he said, were pushing President Reagan's Strategic Defense Initiative in order to increase their profits.

title: INTEGRITY FINANCIAL GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a net realized investment loss of $581,000 for the quarter and 9 months. c-Including net realized investment gains of $46,000 for the quarter and $31,000 for the 9 months and net losses from discontinued operations of $389,000 for the quarter and $361,000 for the 9 months.

title: Technology;   Human Tasks For Computers
description: NEARLY two years ago, Apple Computer introduced its Macintosh and began to revolutionize the way people look at computer screens. It banished the cryptic ''A'' symbol that prompts users of most personal computers to enter their first instruction, replacing it with a visual ''tool kit.'' Now, sitting in front of the Macintosh and other computers that have mimicked its easy-to-use approach, users are accustomed to picking up a fat or thin pencil, a paintbrush or an elastic rectangle to draw images on the screen and to dispose of old files by simply dumping them into an electronic trash pail.

title: Israel Not Discussing Return Of Captured Land, Peres Says
description: Prime Minister Shimon Peres told the Parliament in Jerusalem today that his Government was not discussing the return of territory captured from Israel's Arab neighbors in 1967.

title: HARRY M. JACOBSON
description: Harry M. Jacobson, senior partner in the securities concern of Adler, Coleman & Company, died of cancer Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 59 years old.

title: VICTORIAN TOUCH: CHEVAL GLASS
description: THE cheval glass - a full-length mirror that swings or slides between columns on arched feet - was in use in the 18th century, but it wasn't until the next century, when it became possible to make larger plates of glass at a reasonable cost, that such mirrors became popular.

title: UNIROYAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After costs of $12 million for the quarter and $22 million for the 9 months incurred in connection with defending an unsolicited tender offer and its leveraged buyout in September and including income of $5 million for the quarter and $6 million for the 9 months from discontinued operations. c-Net income, after a $2 million loss from discontinued operations. d-After a $11 million loss from discontinued operations and a $57 million charge for the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: SEIS PROS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: Special-Interest Snipers
description: Don't fret about the explosive growth of PAC's, says Senator Jake Garn. Sure, there are now 4,000 of these political action committees raising campaign contributions in the name of some special interest -up from 600 in 1974. But never mind, says Mr. Garn, the Utah Republican. PAC's represent all sides of a given issue and so they check and balance each other's influence.

title: Music/Noted in Brief;   'Beehive,' Satirizing Pop Music of the 60's
description: ''Beehive,'' a revue that weaves three dozen 60's pop songs into a tongue-in-cheek history of the decade, bursts with so much vocal talent and zany humor that one can forgive the show for seeming to have only half a brain in its head. Like its prototype, ''Leader of the Pack,'' ''Beehive'' (the title refers to the hair style) strings together songs that are funny in hindsight for their attentiveness to the fashions of the day. The show, which began an open-ended run at Sweetwater's (170 Amsterdam Avenue, at 68th Street) on Tuesday, is performed by a cast of six young women costumed in parodies of period fashions. The material has been grouped into four blocks, covering teen-age girl talk, the women of the British Invasion, soul music and Janis Joplin (skillfully impersonated by Laura Theodore). Where ''Beehive'' succeeds best is in re-creating the silly, party-loving spirit of the early and mid-60's. In the show's wittiest sequence, singers doing cartoon impersonations of Connie Francis, Annette Funicello, Brenda Lee and Leslie Gore have a singing bee, sharing their old hits. The conference climaxes with Pattie Darcy's rip-roaring recreations of two musical melodramas by the Shangri-Las. The formidable task of impersonating both Tina Turner and Aretha Franklin falls to the young pop-soul singer Peggi Blu, and she meets it more than halfway, delivering ''Proud Mary'' and ''Respect'' with power and zeal to spare. The show's musical high point is a medley of ''A Natural Woman'' and ''Do Right Woman,'' sung by Miss Blu with Miss Darcy.

title: OAKWOOD HOMES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a nonrecurring charge of about $785,000 due to transactions related to a gift of 50,000 shares of the company's common stock from its chairman to its president. Share earnings have been adjusted for a 5-for-4 stock split declared Oct. 15.

title: RIZZO, EX-MAYOR OF PHILADELPHIA, IS SAID TO CONSIDER RUNNING IN '87
description: Frank L. Rizzo, the former Police Chief who provoked controversy when he was Mayor from 1972 to 1980, is back in the public eye here as a possible candidate to challenge Mayor W. Wilson Goode for his old job.

title: MSA REALTY reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income Results for the 9 months periods are not comparable because the company began operations in April 1984.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Ivan Lendl, who has been having his differences with the Czechoslovak Tennis Association, may not play on his country's Davis Cup team next year. According to his Davis Cup teammate, Tomas Smid, Lendl has told the team captain, Jan Kodes, that he will not be on the 1986 team. According to Lendl's American manager, Jerry Solomon, however, no final decision has been made.

title: THE LAWYER WHO BEAT TEXACO
description: Kirk Douglas sent a note. Willie Nelson called. So did such high-powered personal injury lawyers as Philip Corboy from Chicago, Bruce Walkup from San Francisco and Richard Haynes, from just down the street.

title: MARCOS'S PLANS: PUZZLING QUESTIONS
description: After more than two weeks of debate and political maneuvering, the nature and even the likelihood of early elections called for by President Ferdinand E. Marcos have become fragmented into an array of political and procedural questions.

title: QUINONES CRITICIZES SCHOOL STUDY, BUT VOWS TO CORRECT DEFICIENCIES
description: The New York City Schools Chancellor, Nathan Quinones, yesterday criticized as ''foolish'' a state evaluation ranking 417 public schools here as among the 600 worst in the state, but said he would order a sweeping program to relieve the academic failings noted in the study.

title: Music/Noted in Brief;   Howard Jones, Singer Of Technological Rock
description: The English singer, songwriter and keyboardist Howard Jones is a skillful electronic pop technician with a pronounced streak of old-fashioned showmanship. Mr. Jones, who appeared at a sold-out concert at Radio City Music Hall on Tuesday, writes moderately catchy tunes whose largely electronic textures evoke the sunny side of technology. His upbeat lyrics reduce the idea of collective experience into cheerfully romantic psychobabble that turns ''I'' into ''we.''

title: A REDESIGNED OPERA SHOP
description: IT's not exactly the kind of project for which Dorothy Draper, the interior decorating company, is known.

title: DANCE: BEJART'S 'DIONYSOS' HAS DEBUT
description: Since Maurice Bejart can be choreographically wayward, it was no surprise that the program his Ballet of the 20th Century presented Tuesday night at the City Center, 131 West 55th Street, included a silly ballet, an exciting one and a historically important work that has lost some of its impact.

title: PROFESSIONAL INVESTORS INURANCE GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SMITHFIELD FOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 27
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $4,533,000 for the quarter and the 6 months related to the repurchase and retirement of notes. c-Net income.

title: A Few Good Timpani
description: The United States Marine Band departs for the Netherlands tomorrow on what it says is its first overseas trip in its 187 years. The band played at the Canadian National Exposition in Ottawa in 1932, and string ensembles of band members accompanied President Nixon to Yugoslavia, in 1970, and to the Soviet Union, in 1974.

title: Runaway Automobile Kills 6
description: A car skidded out of control on a bridge and plowed into a catwalk, throwing six people on the span, including a pregnant woman, into the bay to their death Monday night, police officials said. The premature baby also died after delivery. The police identified the driver of the car as Richard T. Hayes, 37 years old, of St. Petersburg.

title: Consumers Power
description: The Consumers Power Company said it could refund $46.4 million to its 1.1 million gas customers on their December bills.

title: JAMES A. FOWLER Jr.
description: James A. Fowler Jr., a retired senior partner of the law firm of Cahill Gordon & Reindel of New York, died Tuesday at the St. Johnland Nursing Home in Kings Park, L.I. He was 88 years old and lived in Setauket, L.I.

title: LIBERIANS PLANNING TO START TRIALS TODAY FOR COUP PLOT
description: Liberia will hold trials starting today for 11 civilians and an undisclosed number of military personnel who were implicated in an unsuccessful coup last week, a spokesman for the Liberian Embassy in Washington said yesterday.

title: EWING IS MISSED
description: They coped with serious injuries last season to the starters Bernard King and Bill Cartwright, and survived additional minor ones this season to such players as Pat Cummings and James Bailey. But tonight, in the cold and cavernous Silverdome, the Knicks discovered that the loss of Patrick Ewing will be decidely more difficult to overcome.

title: NATIONAL STANDARD CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Right States
description: Which states turn out the most high school players for big-time college football? According to The Florida Times-Union and Journal, which surveyed the current rosters of 105 Division I-A colleges, the leaders are California (1,740 players produced), Texas (1,125), Ohio (815) and Florida (604). At the bottom of the list are Maine, North Dakota, Rhode Island and Vermont, with only one player each. In between are New Jersey (ranked 10th, with 299 players), New York (14th, with 209) and Connecticut (37th, with 48).

title: The U.N. Today; Nov. 21, 1985
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Laufenberg Returns
description: With an acclaimed starter and a strong backup man on the staff, the Washington Redskins decided before the season to limit their roster to two quarterbacks. Accordingly, Babe Laufenberg, a former Indiana star who sat out the 1984 season because of a sore shoulder, was cut. Now, two days after Joe Theismann suffered a broken leg in the Giants game, the Redskins have re-signed Laufenberg to serve as a backup to the new starter, Jay Schroeder. . . . Jeff Christensen, a quarterback who was cut by the Eagles just before the season, has been re-signed by Philadelphia after Ron Jaworksi hurt his right shoulder in Sunday's victory over the St. Louis Cardinals.

title: Top 8.88% Yield For School Bonds
description: The Chicago School Finance Authority is selling $194.2 million of general obligation school assistance refunding bonds, through underwriters led by First National Bank of Chicago.

title: YELENA BONNER OFF DEC. 2, PLEDGED TO AVOID PRESS
description: Yelena G. Bonner, the wife of Andrei D. Sakharov, told her children here by telephone today that she had won permission to leave the Soviet Union for medical treatment only after signing a pledge not to talk with reporters abroad.

title: CONCERT: A PROGRAM OF SCARLETTI'S 'OTHER' WORKS
description: DOMENICO SCARLATTI, born three centuries ago this year, is best remembered for his brilliant, technically challenging keyboard sonatas. We owe an automatic debt of gratitude, therefore, to the Pleasant Moments Ensemble, which presented a program of Scarlatti's ''other'' music at Symphony Space, Broadway at 95th Street, Tuesday evening, under the direction of Kenneth Cooper.

title: A REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: FUR SCARF, BLACK BOOTS
description: The veil of secrecy that shrouded the meetings of their husbands has not affected Raisa M. Gorbachev or Nancy Reagan. On the contrary, it seemed only to increase the First Ladies' share of the Geneva limelight.

description: A fire destroyed the local headquarters of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People on Tuesday, hours before a hearing on a voting rights suit. The organization's national director called the blaze ''a tragic throwback to overt acts of racism.''

title: PHOENIX AMERICAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
LAWMAKERS MAY NOT LIKE IDEA BUT SAY A DEFICIT CURB WILL PASS
description: Legislators trying to reach a compromise on a budget-balancing bill agree on one point: The legislation may be a horrendous way to run the Federal Government but it is going to pass Congress.

Forgotten Refugees
description: Refugees are still fleeing Indochina, but concern for them and the rate of their resettlement has fallen sharply. Governments respond best when a calamity makes headlines, as when 500,000 boat people fled Vietnam in 1979.

description: b-Including a $37 million tax credit. c-Including a $16 million tax credit.

title: STUDENTS IN PEKING RENEW PROTESTS AGAINST JAPAN
description: Several hundred students in Peking staged their second protest against Japan in as many months today, raising new concerns that Deng Xiaoping and fellow Communist Party leaders may be facing a broader groundswell against their ''open door'' policies.

title: Books: Dance Masters
description: THERE is history, and there are anecdotes. ''But First a School,'' an account of the School of American Ballet since its founding in 1933 by George Balanchine and Lincoln Kirstein, takes the anecdotal route. In many ways this approach befits the subject splendidly. One would be hard put to find under any other roof the galaxy of colorful characters who work at the school. The book is replete with quotes from Russian emigre teachers who never had to learn good English; shrewdly, Jennifer Dunning, a dance critic and reporter for The New York Times, doesn't clean it up. She also has good informers. The dancer Jacques d'Amboise gets at the heart of the pre-Revolutionary style that students absorbed, and still do, from their teachers. Reminiscing about Pierre Vladimiroff, he says: ''He epitomized the Petipa school, the pre-Soviet manners, that are gone now. With the Soviets, everything is big. Up. For Vladimiroff, princes didn't look up.''

title: BREZENOFF PINCH-HITS FOR MAYOR
description: First Deputy Mayor Stanley Brezenoff was trying to explain what he has been doing as Acting Mayor of New York in the absence of the real thing.

title: U.N. Appoints Ghanaian
description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar appointed Kenneth K. S. Dadzie today to be Secretary General of the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development for a three-year term, beginning Jan. 1. Mr. Dadzie is Ghana's High Commissioner in London. In 1982, he was appointed a personal representative of the Secretary General for Special Missions.

description: The police found two runaway children yesterday and charged a man and a woman with attempting to force the youngsters into prostitution in Times Square.

description: Texaco Inc. said yesterday that it had strong grounds for overturning a Texas jury's decision that the concern had to pay a record $10.53 billion to the Pennzoil Company.

description: A Pentagon commission studying ways to deter espionage has recommended a broad array of security measures, a member of the commission said today. It includes a significantly expanded program of random polygraph, or lie-detector, tests for military personnel and civilian contractors, he said.

title: EIP MICROWAVE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
A Freddie Mac Offering Is Divided Into 8 Parts
description: The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, which introduced the collateralized mortgage obligation to Wall Street in mid-1983, refined its concept yesterday with a $1.04 billion financing divided into six domestic issues plus two issues offered only to foreign investors.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Big Apple N.I.T. opening-round doubleheader, at Hartford: St. John's vs. Navy, 7 P.M.; Auburn vs. West Virginia, 9 P.M. Walter Berry and the Redmen open their season, as Lou Carnesecca says, ''in Macy's window'' in the first N.I.T. preseason tournament. The regional final will be held Sunday, with the four regional champions advancing to games in Madison Square Garden next weekend. (Radio - WCBS 880, 7 P.M., St. John's game only.) Other Big Apple Games: Tulsa (23-8) vs. Dayton (19-9) and Louisville (19-16) vs. Miami (Ohio) 20-11, opening-round doubleheader, at Cincinnati. Washington (22-10) vs. Texas-El Paso (22-10) and Kansas (26-8) vs. Pepperdine (23-9), opening-round doubleheader, at Denver. Figures in parentheses are last season's records. Knicks vs. Washington Bullets, at Landover, Md., 8 P.M. When these teams met at the Garden Tuesday night, Patrick Ewing left after injuring his ankle in the first quarter, but the Knicks won, 98-94. Ewing, the Knicks' rookie center, missed Wednesday night's game against the Detroit Pistons and is not scheduled to play tonight. (Television - Channel 9 and WTBS, 8 P.M.) Nets vs. Suns, at Phoenix. The next-to-last stop on the Nets' seven-game trip through the Western Conference. Last season, the Nets split the two games played against the Suns in Phoenix. (Television - SportsChannel, 9:30 P.M. Radio - WNBC 660, 9:30 P.M.) Boxing Marlon Starling, champion, vs. Simon Brown, 12 rounds, United States Boxing Association welterweight title bout, at the Sands Hotel and Casino, Atlantic City.

description: Executives and other workers told a City Hall hearing yesterday of a corporate world that had become such a province of the young that someone 45 years old was often considered over the hill.

title: MASKED REVELS RETURN TO TOWN
description: Several elaborate costume balls this year have put another item on the high-fashion checklist: the designer mask. Oscar de la Renta has designed a mask. So have Carolina Herrera, Pauline Trigere and Jeremy Wren, the Texas designer. (But the 50-cent variety is equally popular.) Two November parties gave masks a new emphasis: a benefit for Memorial Sloan-Kettering at the Plaza in honor of Aileen Mehle, who is Suzy, The New York Post columnist, and the Venetian Carnival at the Guggenheim, both in early November. On Dec. 14, a group of artists is giving a Beaux-Arts Ball in SoHo.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: American Motors Corp., Southfield, Mich., said it would make cash rebates of up to $700 to customers buying Renault Alliance and Encore models from yesterday through Jan. 10.

title: 2 CITIES CONSIDER A BATHHOUSE BAN
description: As New York seeks to slow the spread of AIDS, elected officials here and in Los Angeles are considering actions to close or strictly regulate bathhouses and other facilities catering to homosexuals that permit sexual activities linked to the disease.

title: Spuds for Berra
description: The way some North Dakota boosters are telling it, when Yogi Berra was playing in a golf tournament in Fargo last June he questioned claims that the area was one of the largest potato-growing regions in the country, asserting at one point, ''You don't have enough potatoes to fill my front yard.''

title: Bridge: Techniques of Relay Bidding Have Steadily Been Refined
description: The most original and fertile concept in modern bidding theory is the ''relay,'' a minimum artificial bid that asks for a description of partner's hand.

description: The Soviet-American-Japanese civil aviation pact announced in Geneva sets up the first procedures for foreign airliners or other civil planes to make emergency landings in the Soviet Union, the chief American negotiator said yesterday.

title: FREQUENT FLIER PROGRAM FACING HOSTILE SCRUTINY
description: Kenneth S. Kramer had no sooner checked in for a new airline's inaugural flight from Washington to Hartford last month than a ticket clerk handed him a blue booklet and pressed two fresh ink stamps onto the first page.

description: A $71.6 million bond issue for the Texas State University System was offered yesterday with yields ranging from 4 3/4 percent in 1986 to 6 1/4 percent in 1990 and 7.20 percent in 1994 through underwriters led by Prudential-Bache Securities The bonds, rated triple-A, are backed by half of an annual pledge from the state to the university system. The pledge expires Aug. 31, 1990.

title: CLOSE-UP ON THE CRAFTSMEN OF INDIA
description: ''THE GOLDEN EYE: An International Tribute to the Artisans of India'' at the Cooper-Hewitt Museum is consistently arresting to look at. But it is not, in any traditional sense, an ''art exhibition,'' for it treads that ambiguous terrain somewhere between art and craft. It also treads the terrain - no less ambiguous in India - between craft and industry, craft and starvation, and craft and kitsch.

Michael Spinks, the International Boxing Federation heavyweight champion, said he expected to defend his title by the end of February, in a rematch with Larry Holmes or against Gerry Cooney.

title: FILM: 'BEACH BOYS,' A DOCUMENTARY
description: NO American rock group has matched the Beach Boys for ingenuousness, and no other has endured so much prolonged suffering in public. That would make any documentary about the group revealing, even one as stilted and sanitized as the Malcolm Leo film ''The Beach Boys: An American Band.'' Like Mr. Leo's ''This Is Elvis,'' another authorized biography, this film says the least when it attempts to be straightforward, and the most when it lets the material speak for itself.

title: FOR SOME OF INDIA'S POOREST, THE GIFT OF SELF-HELP
description: In front of a mud hut, a dozen small children sat on the dusty ground and sang songs. From such innocent beginnings comes hope for progress for some of the poorest families in India.

Gun-Law Murder, Again
description: John Hinckley, who shot and wounded President Reagan and his press secretary, James Brady, bought handguns at a Texas pawnshop with barely a question asked. Any half-serious inquiry would have shown that he had recently been arrested for trying to carry guns aboard a plane.

title: SHELLER-GLOBE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
AT THE MOVIES
description: SANTA fanciers will have a choice this Christmas. Maybe they'll want to see the traditionally jolly hero of ''Santa Claus - The Movie''; maybe they'll opt for the more unusual Santa of ''One Magic Christmas.'' Maybe they'll want to see both. In any case, it's definitely a buyer's market this year, and potential Santa-watchers will want to take into account such details as reindeer realism, North Pole architecture, toy preferences and work habits of elves.

title: Middle South Utilities To Get New Chairman
description: Middle South Utilities, the nation's fifth-largest electric utility holding company, announced late yesterday that Floyd W. Lewis, its 60-year-old chairman, chief executive and president, will retire Dec. 1.

title: 2 OFFICERS HURT
description: Two police officers were wounded yesterday when another officer's gun accidentally discharged in the basement of their Manhattan precinct station house, authorities said.

Detroit Parade, in Shift, To Allow Handicapped
description: Besieged by a flood of complaints, the head of the Thanksgiving Day parade today reversed an earlier decision and said a contingent of people with disabilities would be allowed to march.

title: Advertising;   People
description: * Michael Johnson and Frederick D. (Sandy) Sulcer named to board of D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles.

title: Steven Crist on Horse Racing;   PILLASTER GETS FIRST RACE ON DIRT, BUT TRADITION IS ON HIS SIDE
description: The question in the Remsen Stakes at Aqueduct tomorrow will be whether Pillaster, a 2-year-old son of Riverman and Flying Buttress, can run on the dirt. The colt has won two of his three career starts, all on the grass, has won at the mile-and-an-eighth Remsen distance, and will probably be favored. If history repeats itself, he will come home a winner.

title: 2 AGENTS ARE JAILED IN GREENPEACE BLAST
description: Two French secret agents were sentenced today to 10 years in jail for manslaughter in the death of a crewmen killed in the bombing of the Greenpeace flagship, Rainbow Warrior. They were given seven years each for willful damage to the ship.

title: STORM CARRIES HEAVY RAIN
description: Forecasters said yesterday that there was a possibility that Hurricane Kate would cause as much rain and severe flooding along the middle-Atlantic coast as did Hurricane Agnes in 1972.

title: TIME PICKS 4 TO RUN MAGAZINE
description: Time Inc., in a major restructuring aimed at tightening control over its fast-growing magazine business, yesterday announced the formation of a four-man executive team to run the publications.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 22, 1985
description: International

title: NEBRASKA'S FULLBACK MAKES SURPRISE GAINS
description: Nebraska's offense has been eye-catching year after year, thanks to the running of the I-backs Mike Rozier, Roger Craig, I. M. Hipp, Jarvis Redwine and now Doug DuBose.

title: GREAT WESTERN SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SECRET SERVICE STOPS SCHEME OF ILLEGAL CALLS
description: The Secret Service said yesterday that it had disrupted a scheme to defraud telephone companies of more than $1 million in revenue from long-distance phone calls. The arrests were the first since the Secret Service was empowered a year ago to pursue those who make such illegal calls.

title: HOW FIRST AMERICAN MADE LOANS IS TOLD
description: Before its collapse last Friday, the First American Mortgage Company made loans at triple-digit interest rates, according to court records obtained here today. And lawyers familiar with First American's practices said it lent money to borrowers whose credit rating was so poor that they were cut off from normal banking sources.

title: DOW SOARS BY 23.05, TO 1,462.27
description: Inspired by signs that the Government may curb its voracious appetite for funds, the stock market soared yesterday, with all major indexes going deeply into record territory.

title: ALPINE GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Including a tax credit of $121,000 for the quarter and the 6 months. c-Including tax credits of $99,000 for the quarter and $200,000 for the 6 months.

title: LTV'S STEEL-INDUSTRY GAMBLE
description: Already under pressure from cheap steel imports, the LTV Corporation chose to double its bet on steel: In 1983, it agreed to acquire the Republic Steel Corporation, reasoning that by using the best operations from Republic and its own Jones & Laughlin steel unit, it could fashion a more efficient operation to compete with foreign rivals.

title: Baldrige Rides Again
description: Let the Internal Revenue Service take note: Secretary of Commerce Malcolm Baldrige received a check this week for $241.81 for winning second prize in a calf-roping event at a rodeo in Harrisburg, Pa., Nov. 9-10. Mr. Baldrige, who is 63 years old, is the ''heeler'' on a two-man team, roping the back feet of the calf while his partner takes care of the front end. Although he rides less frequently than he used to, the Secretary is a longtime member of the Professional Rodeo Cowboys Association, which sanctioned the Harrisburg contest.

title: NEVADA RESOURCES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ELLERY KURTZ PAINTINGS WILL ORBIT EARTH
description: IMAGINE an artist at his easel, sinking in a foot of dust, painting a picture of the earth from the moon. Or on a tether attached to the space shuttle, sketching the sunrise from his floating vantage point. Or drawing a nude, perhaps, in the warmth of a spaceship hurtling toward a galaxy far, far away.

title: POPE EMPHASIZES ROLE OF VATICAN
description: Pope John Paul II opened a special meeting of the College of Cardinals today with a strong assertion of papal authority and a defense of the Roman Curia.

title: TIERCO GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Congress Approves Bill For Programs in Space
description: Congress gave final approval today to a bill continuing programs of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, including its space shuttle and work on a planned space station.

title: FUGITIVE EX-JERSEY SENATOR TELLS ATTORNEY HE IS AFRAID
description: A former New Jersey State Senator who vanished shortly before his indictment on fraud charges in September telephoned his Washington lawyer late Wednesday and said he was alive and feared for his life, the F.B.I. said yesterday.

title: BELLWETHER EXPLORATION COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CENTENNIAL GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Blaze Victim Identity at Issue
description: A medical examiner said today that he would consider new contentions that the body of a victim in the fiery battle with the radical black group Move was misidentified, raising the possibility that a third person may have escaped the blaze.

title: SUNLITE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $61,025. c-Including tax credits of $32,000.

title: The Spirit of Geneva
description: Not a bad two days' work in Geneva. After years of bitter name-calling and sterile combat, the leaders of the Soviet Union and the United States decided that they really needed a more respectful relationship. After hours of spirited debate, Mr. Reagan and Mr. Gorbachev attest that, much as they deplore each other's military buildups, they share an interest in controlling the arms race and restraining their other rivalries. Nothing startling there; these conclusions merely ratify the attitudes of their predecessors. Yet both men judged this to be progress, which makes it so.

title: BGS SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
ENERGY ASSETS INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
WEDCO TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

title: CHIEF U.S. WOTNESS TESTIFIES AGAINST 11 WHO AKDED ALIENS
description: The Government's key witness opened his testimony in Federal District Court here today by describing how he infiltrated a group of church workers who are charged with conspiring to smuggle Salvadorans and Guatemalans into the United States.

title: NAVY EMPLOYEE ARRESTED AS SPY
description: A counterintelligence analyst for the Navy was arrested today on espionage charges, accused of selling classified code information to the Israeli Government, Federal officials said.

title: 23 DIE IN WEEK
description: The police shot dead at least six people in this black township today, including several elderly women, according to witnesses. The deaths brought the number killed by the authorities so far this week to at least 23.

description: b-Net income.

HOPE IS EXPRESSED ABOUT SOVIET JEWS
description: Although the Geneva summit meeting did not produce an agreement providing for the increased emigration of Soviet Jews, the director of the National Conference on Soviet Jewry said today that he was optimistic that discussions of human rights would continue.

title: STAGE: 'ALCHEMEDIANS' IN BROOKLYN
description: A METAL mixing bowl rolls on stage, followed by another bowl of equal size, then by one as tiny as a teacup and another as big as a basin. Soon, the stage is bouncing with matching bowls of all sizes, scurrying in circles like planets spinning out of orbit. The bowls are followed by the offstage bowlers, Bob Berky and Michael Moschen.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Abitibi-Price Inc., Toronto, a forest products company, has elected Robert L. Johnson senior vice president, marketing of the Abitibi-Price Sales Corp., New York.

title: EPIC Accord By Insurers
description: The three largest insurers of mortgages issued by EPIC real estate partnerships said yesterday that they would advance $43 million to make up for overdue interest payments on the mortgages.

title: 2 Policemen Killed in Peru
description: Two policemen were killed in a hail of bullets today near a crowded food market in a Lima shantytown, the police said. No one claimed responsibility for the killing.

CORPORATION FOR ENTERTAINMENT & LEARNING reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

title: Will Yolen, Former Executive And Kite Enthusiast, Is Dead
description: Will H. Yolen, a former publishing executive and self-proclaimed ''world's champion kite flier,'' died Tuesday at a nursing home in Holyoke, Mass. He was 77 years old and lived in Hatfield, Mass.

title: RENT-A-CENTER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Year-ago figures have been restated to include the acquisition of Rent-a-Center of Indianapolis L.P. on July 31, 1985.

title: IN WASHINGTON, SOME ARMS CONTROL EXPERTS LAMENT ABSENCE OF PROGRESS
description: Some arms control experts criticized President Reagan today for failing to reach any concrete agreements or to affirm existing arms accords with Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, during their two-day meeting.

BARNES ENGINEERING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 29

title: GEORGE C. SCOTT AS MUSSOLINI ON NBC
description: FOR the second time this season, Benito Mussolini is being put through the grinder of a television biography, and for the second time, the result resembles Italian sausage - of the spicy variety. Home Box Office gave us Il Duce as seen through the curiously reluctant performance of Britain's Bob Hoskins. Beginning this Sunday, from 8 to 11 P.M. on Channel 4, NBC is offering an aggressive George C. Scott in the title role of ''Mussolini: The Untold Story,'' a seven-hour exercise over three consecutive nights.

title: TRIPLE BILL
description: Rock and funk will be heard tonight at Irving Plaza, 17 Irving Place at 15th Street (212-477-3728), with a triple bill of Liquid Liquid, They Might Be Giants and Joshua, beginning at about 11:30 P.M. Tickets are $10.

title: COMMENTS BY 2 LEADERS: 'COOPERATION' FOR 'HARD WORK AHEAD'
description: Following are transcripts of remarks today by Mikhail S. Gorbachev and President Reagan at a ceremony marking the end of the summit conference here, as recorded by the White House, which also translated Mr. Gorbachev's remarks:

title: BUNDY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $231,000.

title: Texas Officials Attack Suit on School Sports
description: A suit challenging a new Texas law that bars students from sports and other extracurricular activities if they fail one course hit a snag Wednesday. Lawyers for the state attacked the credibility of a survey purporting to show the law discriminated against minority group students and the handicapped.

title: Wilson Foods Plans Cutbacks
description: The Wilson Foods Corporation, reacting to excess slaughtering capacity in the meat industry, said today that it intends to sell its pork slaughtering and processing plant in Monmouth, Ill., and halt slaughtering at its plant in Cherokee, Iowa.

title: TACOMA BOATBUILDING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a reserve established for the company's investment in At-Sea Incineration Inc., its 70 percent- owned ocean incineration subsidiary, of $35,984,000, for the quarter and 9 months. c-Reflects a $16,065,000 adjustment for the cumulative effects of a change in accounting method. The company filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act in September.

title: Happier Story
description: When it comes to records, Rutgers-Newark's opposite number is the girls' volleyball team at Sweet Home High School in Amherst, N.Y. By defeating West Seneca West High on Wednesday night, 15-1, 15-5, the Panthers ran their winning streak to 219 matches. That is a national high school record for any sport by any team, male or female, eclipsing by one a string of victories that the girls' basketball squad in Baskin, La., put together from 1947 to 1953.

title: REAGAN SELECTS HIS BIOGRAPHER
description: President Reagan has selected Edmund Morris, the Pulitzer Prize-winning author of a biography of Theodore Roosevelt, to chronicle his life and presidency, a White House spokesman said.

title: APPLIED COMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Occidental Stock
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation paid $86.1 million to redeem preferred stock it had issued to the financier, David H. Murdock, as part of Occidental's purchase of Iowa Beef Processors Inc. four years ago.

title: GRAND UNION CO reports earnings for 12 wks to Oct 12
Ewing Will Miss 2d Game Tonight
description: The prognosis was good. Yet for the Knicks, it wasn't good enough.

title: A 48-STORY RENTAL TOWER FOR THE UPPER WEST SIDE
description: In 1980 New York City's division of real estate auctioned a parcel of land on Amsterdam Avenue at 67th Street that had once been condemned to make way for a public garage. The land had been partly cleared by the time the city dropped the garage plan, but there were 20 residential tenants in buildings that remained. The buyer would have to relocate them.

title: Halliburton Plan
description: The Halliburton Company said it had authorized the repurchase of up to 10 million shares of common stock.

title: Burlington Bid Accepted By Southland Royalty
description: After a month of jockeying, the Southland Royalty Company, the Texas oil and gas concern, yesterday agreed to be acquired by Burlington Northern Inc., the giant railroad company, for $17 a share, or a total of about $695 million.

description: Per share figures reflect the 100 percent stock dividend paid in March.

title: LEIF STENBERG, SWEDISH HEART RECIPIENT, DIES
description: Leif Stenberg, the first person outside the United States to receive a permanent artificial heart, died of respiratory and vascular failure today, his doctor said.

title: FINANCIAL INDUSTRIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including an extraordinary credit of $464,628 from the sale of the company's Knickerbocker Life Insurance Co. unit.

title: GENEVA SUMMIT COVERAGE, A MEDIA 'HAPPENING'
description: HOW did it play? What did it mean, or, as Ted Koppel asked on ABC, ''Did anyone get the story straight?'' On television, the summit conference between Ronald Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev was made up of smiles, handshakes, shouted questions and discussions about the answers. It may not have been television's finest hour, but it was a long way from its worst.

description: The agency that oversees New York City's waterfront yesterday made public its first comprehensive plan to regulate the construction and operation of recreational and commercial marinas and boatyards.

description: The Chrysler Corporation said that bonuses promised by its chairman, Lee A. Iacocca, to employees for helping the auto maker avert bankruptcy would total more than $230 million.

title: Prayer Vigil in Geneva
description: A group of American and Soviet Christians held a prayer vigil throughout the two-day summit meeting here and said today that they planned to hold a similar vigil in the United States next year. The group of 13 Americans and 12 Soviet citizens met at St. Pierre Cathedral here Tuesday and Wednesday to pray for the success of the meeting between President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader.

Farm Credit Bill Discussed
description: The Reagan Administration renewed its opposition today to an immediate Federal bailout of the Farm Credit System, but welcomed parts of a House bill to reorganize the nation's largest farm lender.

title: 20 ARE INJURED IN MIDTOWN BLAZE
description: At least 20 people were injured last night when a three-alarm fire broke out on a lower floor of a 45-story office building in midtown Manhattan, according to fire authorities. Several hundred people were removed from the building.

title: VICOM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

Diner's Journal
description: TODAY is a sort of St. Patrick's Day for enthusiasts of French wine. As posters and hotel marquees attest, ''Le 1985 Beaujolais nouveau est arrive!'' The annual landing in New York of this fruit-drenched quaffing wine has turned into a media carnival in recent years, surrounded by more hype than a sideshow fire-eater. This week, there are the usual Concorde flights and screeching limousines racing the wine to midtown as if a heart transplant depended on it, and bibulous parties are planned all weekend. If you would like to toast the new crop with the tip of your beret and a glass of Beaujolais, here are several spots to consider:

description: Following is a transcript of President Reagan's remarks to Congress in Washington last night about the Geneva summit meeting, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Disaster Relief
description: Many New Yorkers feel a distant kinship with the victims and survivors of the volcanic eruption in Colombia. For a 36-year-old painter in Sunnyside, Queens, the sense of kinship - and of loss - is firsthand.

title: Armory Antiques Sale
description: An array of antiques and collectibles will be on sale this weekend at the New York State Armory, 125 West 14th Street.

title: Son of Crime Leader Guilty in Theft Scheme
description: Salvatore Bonanno, son of Joseph Bonanno Sr., a reputed leader in organized crime, has been found guilty of nine counts in a home-improvement scheme that bilked elderly people.

title: 500,000 SAID TO RALLY IN CHILE FOR EN END TO MILITARY RULE
description: Hundreds of thousands of Chileans chanting ''freedom!'' and ''democracy now!'' held a rally today to demand the end of the 12-year-old military Government of President Augusto Pinochet.

description: While inspecting the Tokyo subway, Mayor Koch called on Deputy Mayor Stanley Brezenoff to deal two heavy blows to the New York City Housing Authority. The Deputy Mayor requested the resignations of Joseph Christian, chairman of the authority, and John Simon, its general manager.
