title: VOLKER SEES PERIL IN GROWTH OF DEBT
description: The chairman of the Federal Reserve, Paul A. Volcker, warned today that the rapid growth of debt in the United States threatened widespread economic disruption.

title: CENTENNIAL SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
Alzado Out for Season
description: Lyle Alzado, the defensive end who has been a mainstay of the Raiders since 1982, was lost for the season yesterday after doctors discovered that he had suffered a tear of his left Achilles' tendon against the Bengals last Sunday. . . . Joe Theismann, the Redskins' quarterback, who suffered a compound fracture of his right leg in Monday's game against the Giants, underwent surgery for a second time at Arlington Hospital, and the club said yesterday's operation had been a success.

title: A Spinoff Challenge At Allied-Signal
description: To some analysts, it looked as if Michael D. Dingman, the 54-year-old president of Allied-Signal Inc., was taking a fall when Edward L. Hennessy Jr., Allied's chairman and chief executive, announced on Wednesday that the company was spinning off 30 subsidiary operations into a separate company that Mr. Dingman would run.

title: Contact Regained
description: Just once. For a few seconds.

title: MITCHELL IS FIRST STRING IN GIANTS' EYES
description: Most teams would be in deep trouble if they lost a running back as good as O. J. Anderson. The St. Louis Cardinals, who are in last place and in deep trouble as it is, may hardly feel the loss of Anderson when they play the Giants Sunday in St. Louis because they have Stump Mitchell to replace him.

title: Advertising;   McCann Promotions
description: Michael A. Sennott, 44-year-old joint managing director of McCann-Erickson New York, has been promoted to executive vice president of the worldwide company, and will be responsible for half of its 52 global accounts. He will also part of the Worldwide Operations Group of McCann, which is the largest component of the Interpublic Group of Companies. At the same time, the other joint managing director in New York, John J. Dooner Jr., 37, has been raised to general manager of the New York office.

title: INTERLOGIC TRACE reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 26
description: Year-ago results are pro forma.

title: BEN LIPSHY
description: Ben Lipshy, a businessman who built the Zale Corporation into the world's biggest retail jewelry company, died today hours after being hospitalized for a heart attack.

title: Emhart Goes Outside for Chairman
description: The Emhart Corporation, reaching unexpectedly outside its own management ranks, yesterday named Peter L. Scott, a former top official of the United Technologies Corporation, to be chairman and chief executive officer, effective next month.

title: BROADWAY
description: THERE'S no saying whether it's the old or the new formula, but ''El Grande de Coca-Cola'' is returning to New York with Ron House, Diz White and Alan Shearman, who were not only its creators but also its original cast. And while we may not know which formula, we do know that the entertainment, which began in London and was presented here in 1973, will open at the Village Gate, 160 Bleecker Street, on Jan. 10.

title: Taxed on Taxonomy
description: To the Editor:

title: 57 Artists in Show
description: At the time of his death 50 years ago, Childe Hassam bequeathed more than 400 works to the American Academy and the Institute of Arts and Letters. The idea was for the academy to sell them, use the money to buy works by living American artists, and then donate those pieces to museums with small acquisition budgets.

title: A U.S.-Vietnam Team Confirms It Found Jet
description: An American-Vietnamese team searching for the remains of four American airmen near Hanoi has confirmed that it found a United States Air Force B-52 bomber that went down in the Vietnam War, a spokesman said today.

title: Shipyard Protest in Spain
description: Hundreds of shipyard workers blocked roads and railways today with blazing barricades during protest marches that marked the first anniversary of violent clashes with the police in this Basque port city over an overhaul program that had cut jobs and was designed to prepare Spain's aging shipyards for entry next year into the European Economic Community. The police said no arrests were made today.

title: Latin American Music
description: The North/South Consonance will present new works by six emerging Latin American composers and one old master at the Center for Inter-American Relations tonight at 8.

title: STANDARD-BRED PACERS & TROTTERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a $14,500 extraordinary tax credit. c-Net loss.

title: Thousands in Colombia Panic in Volcano Drill
description: Thousands of people living near the Nevado del Ruiz volcano northwest of here, which erupted eight days ago, panicked late Wednesday night when the Government, for the second time in five days, ordered a sudden evacuation of the area.

title: CORRECTION
description: A review of the New York City Ballet yesterday misidentified a company member who died in September. He was John Bass.

title: POLICE IN NASSAU TEACH FOREIGNERS
description: For the past two weeks, a dozen high-ranking Ecuadorian police officials and several members of the Costa Rican Police Department have been undergoing anti-terrorist training given by the Nassau County Police Department.

title: Duke Defeats Lamar; Ala.-Birmingham Wins
description: David Henderson scored 18 points and Johnny Dawkins added 14 as Duke defeated Lamar, 66-62, tonight in a first-round game of the Big Apple National Invitation Tournament.

title: INTERMARK GAMING INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
United Head Warns Of Fare War Effect
description: Richard J. Ferris, the chairman of United Airlines, said yesterday that the airline industry was in the midst of a fare war that showed no signs of abating soon and that the industry could suffer a sharp decline in earnings in the first quarter.

title: Treatment for Maris
description: Roger Maris, the former Yankee slugger, has agreed to try experimental treatment for cancer, according to a cancer researcher, Dr. Robert Oldham of Franklin, Tenn.

title: Philippine Opposition Groups Are Backing Aquino Window
description: Seven political groups backing the presidential candidacy of the widow of the opposition leader Benigno S. Aquino Jr. formed a coalition today, raising the possibility of a three-way race.

title: WATSCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including gains of $2,553,000 for the quarter and $2,776,000 for the 9 months from the sale of the company's investment in Florida Commercial Banks.

THE LAW FIRM THAT TOXIC WASTE BUILT
description: The tip-off that something big was going on at the law firm came when the bagel situation got out of control. Until a few years ago, a lawyer stopped on the way to work and picked up a bag of bagels to brighten up Friday morning coffee breaks.

title: FILM: 'GRINGO' OBSERVES LIFE OF AN ADDICT
description: LECH KOWALSKI'S ''Gringo,'' which opens today at the Waverly Theater, is a harrowing, nonjudgmental neo-documentary about a real-life New York junkie named John Spacely, and about how he gets from fix to fix, from one day to the next. ''Gringo'' is not an easy movie to watch, though it's of some importance as a report from the Lower East Side's drug underground and as a picture of a society that most of us prefer to ignore.

The 1984 Democratic Vice-Presidential nominee is said to be ready to enter the race despite polls that show her trailing Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, the Republican incumbent seeking re-election next year.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: DMITRI KAPUSTIN, whom we meet at the outset of ''Lion's Run,'' is a senior officer and full deputy chairman of the K.G.B. He is also a would-be defector, in contact with the head of British Intelligence, Sir Kenneth Aubrey. The two men meet surreptitiously whenever Kapustin is on one of his visits of inspection to a Soviet embassy in Western Europe; the Russian doles out scraps of high-level Kremlin gossip, and talks about coming over for good when conditions are ripe. Then, deep in their negotiations, he suddenly changes his mind. Poor Sir Kenneth has been led skillfully, K.G.B.-ishly, up the garden path.

New York's highest court, the Court of Appeals, ruled unanimously yesterday that a lower court had acted properly in dismissing the suit.

title: CONSUMER SPENDING DROPS 0.9%

title: STEELER DEFENSE STIFF TEST FOR SCHROEDER

title: Hoping to Stay Tied for Record
description: What did John Adams do to prepare for Rutgers-Newark when he was the basketball coach at William Paterson College, a New Jersey Athletic Conference rival? ''Nothing,'' he says. ''We never scouted them. They were so bad, we could have a bad night and still not worry about it.''

title: Meredith to Buy Health, Ladies' Home Journal

description: The longest unbroken debate ever conducted in the Senate, according to its historian, ran 82 hours and 2 minutes March 2-5, 1960, and was devoted to the pending Civil Rights Act. There are no official records of the shortest debate, but the Congressional Record reports that on Friday, Nov. 8, the Senate was called to order at 10 A.M. and adjourned at ''10 o'clock and 20 seconds A.M.''

title: THEATER: 'ANTEROOMS,' A MADCAP COMEDY
description: THE people who inhabit ''Anteroom,'' the new Harry Kondoleon comedy at Playwrights Horizons, have all the advantages that money and class can confer, and yet they still make messes of their gilded Southampton lives. Although Mr. Kondoleon doesn't identify with these characters - they're referred to as ''pigs'' at one point - he isn't quite so far removed from their wasteful behavior as he may think. ''Anteroom'' is the fifth (and perhaps best) major production that this young writer has received Off Broadway in the past three years, but, like the others, it leaves us wondering when he is going to write a play as robust as his mordant comic voice.

title: NEW EFFORT ON ARMS PLANNED; PRESIDENT SEES A FRESH START
description: President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, ended their summit conference here today without achieving breakthroughs on key issues. But they expressed hope that they had opened a new, more promising chapter in United States-Soviet relations.

The film, which has nothing to do with Fyodor Dostoyevsky's ''White Nights,'' moves, but it isn't going anywhere, and although it's newly manufactured, it's simply a modification of the basic design created for the Cold War movies of the 1950's.

There was nothing odd about his circumstance, except that Fitch suddenly decided to do something about the unfortunate spell that had fallen over his team, the expansion Cleveland Cavaliers.

title: RESTAURANTS

Such longevity alone in this volatile business merits at least a silver spoon award; even more impressive, though, is how this grand vessel of luxury has managed to stay right on course during its long voyage, maintaining standards of food quality and service that are paragons of the industry.

title: A Summary of the Geneva Talks
description: AGREEMENTS xhrrGeneral Exchanges Agreement. Renews academic, cultural, and performing arts exchanges. New Consulates in Kiev and New York. Linked by Soviet Union to conclusion of a civil aviation agreement. North Pacific Air Safety Agreement. Signed Nov. 19 by U.S., Soviet Union and Japan to improve communications and cooperation to avoid accidents and deal with other problems. Process of Dialogue. Intended to hold regular high-level meetings to resolve political issues, including humanitarian cases. RESTATEMENTS xhrrPrevention of Nuclear Spread. To strengthen means to prevent spread of nuclear weapons capabilities. Chemical Weapons Ban. To continue talks on banning new weapons and destroying stockpiles. Mutual Balanced Force Reductions in Europe. To continue the talks in Vienna on reducing conventional forces in central Europe. Conference on Disarmament in Europe. To continue the talks in Stockholm on developing confidence-building measures. Civil Aviation Agreement. To continue work on resuming U.S.-Soviet air services. Environmental Protection. To promote joint research and practical measures in accord with existing agreement. NEW INITIATIVES Risk Reduction Center.

title: GREAT START FOR A DANCE SEASON

The company has now returned to the New York State Theater, and if this weekend is any guide, the season is likely to be a busy, varied and provocative one. There is dancing throughout the city, and it is dancing that touches nearly every base, from the exotic foreign avant-garde to age-old ethnic ritual, and from familiar ballet to intriguing new talents.

The bank, which owns the LaSalle National Bank of Chicago, said Homer J. Livingston Jr., LaSalle's chief executive officer, would head the new Chicago-based operation.

title: ART: 'DRAWN' PAINTINGS IN SUTART DAVIS SHOW
description: FOR the next month or so, Stuart Davis has the Salander O'Reilly Galleries to himself, and with one exception it is Davis in black and white. Were it confined to the 56 works in pencil, ink and ballpoint on paper, this would be a show of drawings. But it includes 10 large compositions done in a water-based medium on canvas that are closely related to paintings of the 1950's and 60's. They were never exposed in the artist's lifetime, and so far, no allusion to them has been found in his copious writings.

title: Federal Financing of Senate Campaigns
description: A year from now, Americans will elect the 100th Congress. While no one can know the identity of the victors, we can be sure they all will take office under a shadow - the long shadow cast on the political process by the powerful, growing influence of private campaign contributions. And in every subsequent decision they make, they will be affected by the size and the sources of the bankroll that helped bring them to office, and by the need to plan for an even larger purse to keep them there.

title: THE FEEL OF A ONE-RING CIRCUS
description: THE lights dim and the drums begin to pound in a steady beat, like the thudding hoofs of a distant horse. Suddenly, a charcoal-colored Percheron bursts from behind the red velvet curtains and into the ring, pulling a curlicued green-and-gold gypsy wagon. When the horse slows to a halt, a slight figure in clown face, curled on the back of the wagon, stretches and wakes. Jumping down into the ring, he pulls an ocarina from his pocket and sounds an inquiring note, delicate as bird-song. From somewhere in the dark, the song is answered with a flutelike trill. The clown beams, and as he begins to play a lilting duet with his invisible paramour, a troupe of gypsies tumbles out of the wagon. The circus is about to begin.

title: A FRESHMAN POWERS OKLAHOMA'S OFFENSE

description: To the Editor:

title: Review at Clemson
description: Robert James, the commissioner of the Atlantic Coast Conference, said he had asked an expert to review the officiating at two recent Clemson games, including last Saturday's 34-31 loss to Maryland, which led to a protest by Coach Danny Ford. James, who would not identify the expert, said that in commissioning the review he had acted on his own and not at the request of Clemson officials.

title: 30 Years of Futility
description: Perhaps the first significant nuclear arms control achievement was the Limited Test Ban Treaty, negotiated in July 1963, ratified by the Senate in September and taking effect on Oct. 10 of that year.

title: BASIC EARTH SCIENCE SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a tax credit of $902,000 for the quarter and 6 months. c-Net losses. Revenues for the latest 6 months include a gain of $2,483,000 on the sale of marketable securities.

title: Probation in 2 Drownings
description: A Japanese immigrant was put on five years' probation today for drowning her two children in a suicide attempt. Fumiko Kimura, 33 years old, was ordered to undergo psychiatric treatment and was sentenced to one year in the county jail, but the jail sentence was reduced to time already served.

title: Polaroid's Holograms
description: The Polaroid Corporation has announced a new service to help customers create and mass-produce holograms, two-dimensional images that appear three-dimensional by the use of light.

title: GENEVA CEREMONY LIVE ON SOVIET TV
description: Soviet television broke into normal programming at noon today for a live broadcast from Geneva of the joint appearance of President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

title: SCREEN: 'STARCHASER,' AN ANIMATED SPACE TALE
description: ''STARCHASER: THE LEGEND OF ORIN,'' the animated 3-D feature that opens today at the Criterion and other theaters, is such a brazen rip-off of George Lucas's ''Star Wars'' that you might think lawyers would have been called in.

title: Milestone Near
description: Heading into Sunday's game at Pittsburgh, John Riggins of the Washington Redskins is three rushing touchdowns short of the National Football League's career record. These are the players who have scored most often in N.F.L. history via the ground: Jim Brown106 John Riggins103 Walter Payton96 Franco Harris91 Jim Taylor83 Pete Johnson76 Leroy Kelly74 Earl Campbell73 Chuck Muncie71 Steve Van Buren69

title: TBC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Key Rates
description: N.A. - Not available due to Thanksgiving Day holiday * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond BuyerSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Dvorak's 'Stabat Mater'
description: The Collegiate Chorale will present Dvorak's rarely heard ''Stabat Mater'' at Carnegie Hall tomorrow night at 8.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday SALUTE TO SCHUMAN A salute to William Schuman in honor of the composer's 75th birthday provides the occasion for ''An Opera Gala'' by the Juilliard American Opera Center this weekend. The program features a cantata by Mr. Schuman called ''Casey at the Bat,'' a concert version of his opera, ''The Mighty Casey.'' There will also be a serenade to Mr. Schuman - who was long the president of Juilliard -called ''Ensembles From Grand Opera'' that includes music by Rossini, Beethoven, Donizetti and Offenbach. The concert, a benefit for the Juilliard Student Aid and Scholarship Fund, will be given in the Juilliard Theater at Lincoln Center tonight at 8 and again on Sunday at 3. Tickets are $7 and $10. The information number is 874-7515.

title: Advertising;   Book Campaign
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev's book ''A Time For Peace,'' published by Richarson & Steirman of New York, is going to get a direct marketing push through IGC/Direct Response Group of Union, N.J. Henry C. Kavett, president of the Independent Group of Companies, the parent, is confident of selling 250,000 copies of the Soviet leader's book through broadcast advertising using ''800'' phone numbers.

title: OLLA INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ALLIED NURSING CARE reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Summitry Without Tears
description: There were no evident hitches at the Reagan-Gorbachev summit conference, and nobody gave away anything. Both men went home sticking on the same conflicting positions they brought to start, as far as could be told.

title: Peale portrait of his brother.
description: REMBRANDT PEALE'S sensitive 1801 portrait ''Rubens Peale With a Geranium,'' in which the potted plant is as important as the artist's bespectacled younger brother, will be auctioned Dec. 5. Sotheby's expects it to bring $3 million to $4 million - the highest price ever paid at auction for an American painting -but some dealers said this week that the estimate seemed excessive.

title: Marty Lyons Can Adjust
description: Marty Lyons is a bachelor for most of this football season while his wife, Kelley, works on her career back home in Alabama. He is also a part-time player these days, since the Jet coaching staff restructured its defensive line.

title: MASTERS ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income including gains from the settlement of litigation of $1,362,335 for the quarter and $1,996,912 for the 9 months.

title: ISLANDERS TIED AS BRUINS RALLY
description: The Islanders experienced another collapse in the third period tonight, squandering a two-goal lead and settling for a 4-4 tie with the Bruins.

title: WESTERN COMMERCIAL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: FILM: HARRY MILLER'S 'BAD MEDICINE'
description: ''BAD MEDICINE,'' which opens today at the Gotham and the RKO Warner Twin, is so good-humored that you find yourself rooting for it at every spurt of irreverence even as it moves in a rather disorderly way to a gushy conclusion that undermines what has gone before.

title: USR INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Brazil Bank In U.S. Move
description: The New York office of the Government-owned Banco do Brazil S.A. said yesterday that it had taken over the New York operations of two failed Brazilian banks.

title: CENTRAL RESERVE LIFE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Per share figures reflect a 3-for-2 stock split effective June 1985.

title: CBS Offers 'Doubletake,' A Police Procedural
description: For most of its four hours, ''Doubletake'' is a trim police procedural, blessedly without car chases, rock music or mayhem. As the police remark of the murders of two young women with which the story starts, there is surprisingly little blood.

title: Don't Forget the Afghans
description: A popular analogy applied to the Soviet war against the Afghan people is that Afghanistan is Moscow's ''Vietnam.'' That's superficially true. According to recent reports, the war has not won the wholehearted support of the Soviet people or even - as the high desertion rate suggests - the Soviet soldiers sent to Afghanistan. Thus, in the sense that it is an unpopular war, Afghanistan can indeed be said to be ''Moscow's Vietnam.'' But there the analogy ends.

title: Advertising;   New Magazine Focuses On America's Cup Race
description: In 1983, J. Patrick Moran Jr., an alumnus of NBC, The Wall Street Journal, U.S. News & World Report and Discover magazine, became a publisher himself, with a one-shot called Here's Newport - The America's Cup Summer, which was sponsored by the New York Yacht Club. It carried 63 pages of advertising, and emboldened Mr. Moran, 42, to give it another try.

title: Topics;   Postcards From Ed Koch; Thanksgiving, Live
description: It's almost a principle of modern life: Even sober adults can be induced to behave like fools when a television camera is pointed at them. Consider the organizers of Detroit's Thanksgiving Day parade.

title: ROCKWOOD NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $318,000 for the quarter and $334,000 for the six months. c-Including tax credits of $587,000 for the quarter and $888,000 for the six months. The company is listed on the Pacific and Philadelphia stock exchanges.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: IT was a night for designer dresses and jewels the size of Ping-Pong balls, for black ties and stretch limousines. It was a night for not one but two fancy parties that each raised over $300,000.

title: YONKERS OFFICIALS LOOK TO SETTLE SEGREGATION CASE
description: A day after a Federal judge ruled that city and school officials had illegally and intentionally segregated public schools and public housing along racial lines, Yonkers officials indicated today that they would prefer to settle, rather than continue to fight.

title: Advertising;   Herman Changes Name And Doubles Billings
description: Herman & Rosner of Astoria, Queens, will be changing its name on Monday to Harvey Herman Associates, which is quite fitting, since Charles Rosner returned to Lord, Geller, Federico, Einstein a year ago.

title: PAGE AMERICA GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ORS AUTOMATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses of $262,215 for the quarter and $725,526 for the nine months from discontinued operations of Vulcan Software.

title: SIGMA RESEARCH reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago results have been restated to reflect the fiscal 1985 acquisition of Optical Instruments Corp.

title: INFORMATION INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $15,674 for the quarter and $31,672 for the 6 months and tax credits of $577,500 for the quarter and $215,300 for the 6 months. c-Net income including income from discontinued operations of $17,296 for the quarter and $35,425 for the 6 months and $471,000 for the quarter and 6 months from the elimination of deferred DISC taxes.

title: REDKEN LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
REAGAN REPORT PLEASES NATO LEADERS
description: The leaders of several Western European nations expressed strong support today for the outcome of the Geneva summit meeting between President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

title: IDENTIX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
IMREG INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Revenue figures represent interest income.

title: EMONS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $250,000 for the latest first quarter and $37,500 for the year-ago first quarter. There are no share earnings for the year-ago first quarter because preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income.

title: OFFICIAL IN INDIA CONCLUDES A BLAST FELLED JET
description: An Indian investigator has concluded that an explosion apparently occurred on the Air-India jumbo jet that crashed into the Atlantic in June, killing all 329 people aboard.

title: SUTTON PL. BUYS A BETTER VIEW OF ROOSEVELT I.
description: Some of the most expensive town houses and cooperative apartments in the city are on Sutton Place. In the opinion of more than a few of the neighborhood's residents, so are some of the worst views.

title: CHIEF OF PANEL ON ESPIONAGE SAYS HE MET DEFECTOR
description: The chairman of a Pentagon commission on security said today that he had discussed Soviet espionage techniques with a Soviet intelligence officer who said he was defecting but later returned to Moscow.

title: Market Place;   Award's Effect On Pennzoil
description: IN the wake of the Pennzoil Company's record damages award, Wall Street analysts are trying to handicap the value of Pennzoil's shares.

title: OPERA: 'PORGY' CAST CHANGES
description: ONE of the frustrations of last year's ''Porgy and Bess'' performances at the Metropolitan Opera was the casting of Michael Smartt in the lesser role of Jim. Mr. Smartt is, vocally at least, the handsomest Porgy before the public - an impression which he reinforced at the Met on Wednesday night.

title: VECTOR GRAPHIC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
May Petroleum Merger Canceled
description: May Petroleum Inc. said its previously announced agreement to be acquired by the Hall Financial Group had been terminated, mostly because of a downward revision in reserves for May's oil and natural gas properties as of Sept. 30 and May's previously announced $13.5 million third-quarter loss. The company said that, under a new agreement, Hall, which is controlled by the Dallas investor Craig Hall, on Friday would purchase from May a total of 1,052,630 common shares at $4.75 each, and that May would use the proceeds to meet a new demand for accelerated payment of bank debt.

title: Frontier-People Merger Approved
description: Frontier Airlines' shareholders approved the airline's merger with People Express, ending Frontier's 39-year era as one of the West's original airlines.

title: MORGAN KEEGEN & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Dining Out Guide:;   Thanksgiving Day
description: Following is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given.

title: Investor Raises Sea-Land Stake
description: Harold C. Simmons, the Dallas investor who has offered to acquire the Sea-Land Corporation for $25 a share, said yesterday that he had increased his stake in the shipping company to 22.1 percent. He had owned about 10 percent on Tuesday and had increased his holdings to 18 percent by Wednesday, according to filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Lendl Dispute
description: Ivan Lendl, the world's top-ranked tennis player, will probably withdraw from Czechoslovakia's Davis Cup team, the West German sports-news agency S.I.D. quoted his manager, Jerry Solomon, as saying yesterday.

title: African Practices May Offer Insights on AIDS
description: To the Editor:

title: 143 Renegade Kickapoos Accept U.S. Citizenship
description: Immigration officials today distributed citizenship cards to a renegade band of Kickapoo Indians who have resisted the ways of the white man for nearly two centuries.

title: FREY ASSOCIATES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a tax charge of $1,882.

title: SUMMIT FINALE: RUSSIAN IS OPTIMISTIC
description: Following are excerpts from Mikhail S. Gorbachev's news conference in Geneva today, as translated by the Swiss organizers of the summit meeting.

title: RICHTON INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $2,693,000.

title: AIR FORCE PUTS HIGH PRIORITY ON 'AEROSPACE PLANE'
description: A senior Air Force official said today that the military had decided to go ahead with a $500 million program to design a hypersonic plane capable of flying around the globe in less than two hours.

title: FILM: 'MAGIC CHRISTMAS,' WITH SANTA AND ANGEL
description: ONLY at Christmastime can the cautionary tale take on the kind of inspirational quality it has in Frank Capra's ''It's a Wonderful Life,'' in which a good man sees what the world would have been like without him. Phillip Borsos' ''One Magic Christmas'' doesn't have the same multi-hanky impact, but it's an affecting, well-played film in a similar vein. Mr. Borsos, the director of ''The Grey Fox'' and ''The Mean Season,'' has a gravity here that at first seems decidedly un-Christmasy. But his solemnity is credible and appealing, and it ripens, slowly but surely, into a charmingly seasonal brand of childlike wonder.

title: In Chile, a Show of Hands
description: ''Tenemos las manos limpias!'' ''Our hands are clean!'' These words have become the rallying cry for thousands of Chileans in recent months as they attempt to rid themselves of the dictatorship with which Gen. Augusto Pinochet has been oppressing them for 12 years.

title: DEPORTED AFGHAN REFUGEE IS SAID TO RISK PRISON TERM
description: An Afghan refugee was deported this week to Pakistan, where he risks imprisonment or being shuttled from country to country in search of asylum, immigration lawyers said.

title: AIDE SAYS U.S. GAVE PRE-GENEVA VOW ON '79 ARMS PACT
description: A senior State Department official said today that the United States told the Soviet Union before the Geneva summit meeting that it would indefinitely continue its policy of not undermining the 1979 arms treaty, but only under certain conditions.

title: New Mode On Fashion Ave.
description: A block north of the Dubrow's Cafeteria, which closed Aug. 2, what was billed as the first art gallery in the garment district opened Thursday evening.

title: XCOR INTL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MAKING A 'LIVING WILL'
description: A GROWING number of people are executing living wills, documents that state that they do not want medical intervention if the technology or treatment that keeps them alive cannot offer a reasonable quality of life or hope for recovery.

title: YOUR MONEY
description: CONTRARY to what many individuals thought, the Internal Revenue Service still requires extensive record-keeping to support tax deductions for the business use of a car.

title: THE REV. ROY McCLAIN
description: The Rev. Roy McClain, the pastor of the First Baptist Church here who preached on the radio program ''Baptist Hour,'' died of a heart attack Thursday.

title: Books of The Times;   Times Are A-Changin'
description: LYRICS. 1962-1985. By Bob Dylan. 524 pages. Illustrated by the author. Alfred A. Knopf. $21.95. ''You don't necessarily have to write to be a poet,'' Bob Dylan declared once. ''Some people work in gas stations and they're poets. I don't call myself a poet because I don't like the word. I'm a trapeze artist.'' Like so many of the gnomic, contradictory pronouncements he would make over the years, that statement attests to a decidedly equivocal attitude on Mr. Dylan's part - in this case, toward literature and the whole literary establishment.

title: Dancers and Writers Will Pair for Talk Series
description: A four-part discussion series with dancers and those who have written on the subject will begin on Nov. 25 at the New York Public Library at Lincoln Center, 111 Amsterdam Avenue, at 65th Street. Appearing at the first event will be Robert Joffrey, founder of the Joffrey Ballet, and Clive Barnes, critic for The New York Post.

title: Chicago Jazz
description: The Art Ensemble of Chicago is presenting its open-ended jazz at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South (242-1785), tonight and tomorrow. Sets begin at 10 and 11:45 P.M. and 1:30 A.M. tonight, 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M. tomorrow; there is a $10 cover and a $6 minumum.

title: DREW INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued and split-off operations of $387,000 for the quarter and $731,000 for the year and extraordinary credits of $243,000 and $785,000 for the quarter and year, respectivley. c-After a loss of $133,000 from discontinued and split-off operations.

title: McEnroe Will Play
description: John McEnroe has committed himself to play in the Australian Open next week despite a sore shoulder, according to tournament officials. They said he was scheduled to fly to Melbourne Monday or Tuesday to prepare for his first-round match on Wednesday.

title: WITNESS SAYS JUDGE FEARED TRAP BEFORE AGREEING TO ACCEPT BRIBE
description: A Queens judge accused of accepting bribes tried to withdraw from a deal to fix the case of a convicted drug dealer but agreed to proceed after becoming convinced that the dealer was not a Government informer, the chief prosecution witness said yesterday.

title: What Evacuation Day Meant to New York
description: It used to be that Nov. 25 was a big day around here. Evacuation Day, as they called it, marked the date in 1783 when George Washington's victorious colonials marched into town from the north, while George III's troops left at the south, ending a seven-year military occupation.

title: ROHATYN PROPOSES SPENDING PART OF M.A.C. SURPLUS ON CITY'S TRANSIT NEEDS
description: The chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation recommended yesterday that city and state officials consider spending part of the second wave of the corporation's surplus - what he called M.A.C. II - on capital needs of the Transit Authority.

title: Sea-Land Stake
description: The Dallas investor Harold C. Simmons said today that he had raised his stake in the Sea-Land Corporation to 24.9 percent of the shares outstanding. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Simmons said he expected to file today for permission under Federal antitrust laws to clear the 25 percent level. On Thursday, Mr. Simmons purchased 639,000 common shares of the container company on the open market for prices ranging from $24.37 to $24.87 a share.

title: FOR JAPANESE VISITORS, TEA AND HOSPITALITY
description: Chizuko Boone's job has gone far beyond selling her hotel as a destination to Japanese businessmen.

title: Army to Move a Madonna
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger has authorized the use of a giant Army helicopter to airlift an 80-ton statue of a Madonna to a mountain site 3,500 feet above Butte, Mont. The nonprofit Lady of the Rockies Foundation, sponsor of the project, will reimburse the Army for all costs of moving the giant figure, said Senator John Melcher, Democrat of Montana.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''This is not a subject that should be brought out publicly and some kind of an agreement signed, because in a world of politics, to try to push someone in a corner in which he must then publicly try to get out of that corner, and in doing that appears to take orders from a figure in another government, that becomes an impossibility.'' - President Reagan, discussing human rights in the Soviet Union. [6:1.]

title: U.S. RESUMES PLAN FOR SPACE REACTOR
description: The Federal Government today picked the Hanford National Laboratory in Richland, Wash., to develop a compact, space-based nuclear reactor to power the weapons and radar in President Reagan's planned missile defense system.

title: Up in the Rarefied Air
description: Following is an excerpt from the best-selling memoir ''First, but Never a Gentleman,'' to be published in the spring of 1998. I had dreaded the summit conference ever since Jill Glossy, the White House photo-opportunity director, made the President order me to attend. The press ran vicious stories about my reluctance to go, but the worst came from Sam Donaldson, the grand old man of TV journalism.

title: Extradition Requests Would Aid Nazi Hunt
description: To the Editor:

title: Sculpture of the 40's
description: More than 100 pieces of sculpture dating from the 1940's are on exhibit in ''Transformations in Sculpture: Four Decades of American and European Art,'' at the Guggenhem Museum, 1071 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street.

title: Kazuo Tashima, 85, Is Dead; Founder of Minolta Company
description: Kazuo Tashima, founder and chairman of the Minolta Camera Company, died of kidney failure Tuesday night at a hospital in Kobe, his family said today. He would have been 86 years old last Wednesday.

title: Q&A: Ralph Nader;   Whither Consumerism?
description: It has been 20 years this month since Ralph Nader published ''Unsafe at Any Speed,'' a book that started a revolution in automobile safety and catapulted its author to the forefront of the American consumer movement.

title: GENERAL METAL & ABRASIVES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: CALSTAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $163,000 for the quarter and $314,000 for the 6 months. c-Including tax credits of $239,000 for the quarter and $522,000 for the 6 months. Share earnings figures are pro- forma, reflecting share earnings as if 1,050,050 shares had been outstandinging since the earliest period presented.

title: Truck Wreck in Java Kills 45
description: A truck carrying workers from a construction site in eastern Java went off a bridge and into a river Thursday, killing 45 people and injuring 13 others, the police said today. Witnesses were quoted as saying the driver of the truck swerved to avoid a motorcyclist. The police said the incident occurred in Kepanjeng district, 419 miles southeast of Jakarta.

title: U.S. AND SOVIET AGREE TO RESUME AIRLINE SERVICE
description: The United States and the Soviet Union agreed today to resume direct commercial airline service between the two countries, the Department of Transportation announced.

title: SOVIET OVERHAULS FARM BUREAUCRACY
description: In the first major Government reorganization since Mikhail S. Gorbachev took power in March, five ministries and a committee dealing with agriculture were abolished today and their responsibilities combined in a new super agency.

title: Death Penalty Is Too Final for Our Justice System
description: To the Editor:

title: McNeil Uncertain For Patriots Game
description: Forty-eight hours before game time for first place, Freeman McNeil was alternately soaking his sprained right ankle in hot and cold water today.

title: CONTEXT INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
30-YEAR U.S. BONDS AT 9.93%
description: Interest rates plunged to a six-year low on the new bellwether 30-year Treasury bond, which was auctioned yesterday. However, in the secondary market, prices dropped and interest rates rose.

title: EPIC Portfolio Liquidation Step
description: The TMIC Insurance Company Inc., formerly the Ticor Mortgage Insurance Company, announced that it had entered into an escrow agreement with a group of Equity Programs Investment Corporation investors led by the Federal National Mortgage Association. TMIC will deposit $24 million into the escrow fund, which will be used according to a final plan for the orderly liquidation of the EPIC portfolio, William J. Fitzpatrick, TMIC's chairman and chief executive, said.

title: Harassment Missile
description: The Boeing Company of Seattle received a patent this week for a naval harassment missile to be launched by a ship. The missile searches for a target such as a warship and then guides other missiles to the target. The inventor named in patent 4,553,718 is George T. Pinson, manager of the Boeing research center in Huntsville, Ala.

title: FILM: IN UPDATED FORM, 'KING SOLOMON'S MINES'
description: The story of ''King Solomon's Mines,'' the perennially popular adventure novel that H. Rider Haggard wrote a century ago, may be discerned in the new movie of that name that opened yesterday at the RKO National and Manhattan Twin theaters, among others. Like the 1950 version starring Deborah Kerr and Stewart Granger, and the 1937 version with Cedric Hardwicke, Anna Lee and Paul Robeson as the chief of the Kukuanas, the latest effort begins with the white hunter Alan Quatermaine setting forth to find a legendary African treasure.

title: Gray Fit to Play
description: Earnest Gray, the wide receiver the St. Louis Cardinals claimed Wednesday from the Giants, passed his physical examination.

title: WILLIAM P. SIRIGNANO, OFFICIAL OF HARBOR WATERFRONT PANEL
description: William P. Sirignano, a senior official of the Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor for more than 20 years, died Thursday in the Northern Westchester Medical Center in Mount Kisco, N.Y., after a brief illness. He was 71 years old and lived in Mount Vernon, N.Y.

title: Chevron Sale Of Gulf Canada
description: The Chevron Corporation said yesterday that Olympia & York, the giant Canadian development company, had exercised its option to gain control of Gulf Canada Ltd. by purchasing the remaining 23.5 million common shares of Gulf Canada that Chevron held for $340 million.

title: Protesters Battle Police In South Korean Capital
description: Hundreds of anti-Government protesters clashed with riot policemen at a university and in the streets of Seoul today, and about 20 people were arrested, witnesses said.

title: WINSTON MILLS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses of $1,025,000 for the quarter and $1,563,000 for the 9 months from discontinued operations and $883,000 for the quarter and the 9 months on disposal of discontinued operations. c-Net income after losses of $245,000 for the quarter and income of $201,000 for the 9 months and a gain on the sale of a license of $1,016,000 for the quarter and the 9 months and including tax credits of $1,215,000 for the quarter and $1,907,000 for the 9 months.

title: GREAT SOUTHERN FEDERAL SAVNGS BANK reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: SAXON OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss. On Aug. 29, the company formed Saxon Oil Development Partners L.P., which assumed the company's remaining bank debt in exchange for oil and gas properties. The company owned 1,280,414 units in the partnership as of Sept. 30, 1985.

title: ADVISORY PANEL ASKED TO HELP SETTLE ELLIS I. PLANS
description: Interior Secretary Donald P. Hodel reactivated a long-dormant Federal advisory commission on the Statue of Liberty and Ellis Island yesterday and called on it to help decide how more than 20 acres of Ellis Island should be restored.

title: Meanwhile, Back in 1986
description: While Congress flaps about, trying to balance the budget in fiscal 1991, how goes the budget for this year? Not well, thank you. Indeed, the fact that Congress has done so little about deficit reduction now is another good argument for scrapping the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings bill and its hallucinatory promise to make the deficit vanish.

title: TULSA, LOUISVILLE CAPTURE OPENERS
description: Tracy Moore and Byron Boudreaux scored 14 points each tonight to lead Tulsa to a 63-60 overtime victory against Dayton in a first-round game of the Big Apple National Invitation Tournament at Riverfront Coliseum.

title: GENEVA REVIEWS ARE IN: PLAUDITS, IF NOT RAVES
description: With near unanimity rare on a global scale, political leaders of the East and the West, the press and ordinary people around the world voiced hope and optimism yesterday over the Geneva summit conference, calling it a first step in easing international tensions.

title: SOUTHWESTERN PUBLIC SERVCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
BEIRUT BATTLES MARK INDEPENDENCE DAY
description: Many residents of Beirut huddled in basement shelters on Lebanon's independence day today as Druse and Shiite Moslem militiamen battled in the streets for a second consecutive day.

title: Static in the Senate
description: The Rules Committee has put on hold a plan to install a new telephone system in the Senate.

title: MEDICARE BACKS NEW DIAGNOSTIC TECHNIQUE
description: Medicare, the Federal health insurance program for the elderly, today began paying for a new diagnostic procedure that helps identify abnormalities in the brain, the central nervous system and certain organs and glands.

title: Kenya Seizes Papers With Article on AIDS
description: The International Herald Tribune reported yesterday that the Government of Kenya had confiscated the Nov. 9 issue of the Paris-based newspaper, apparently because of displeasure with an article on AIDS in Africa. The article, by Lawrence K. Altman, originally appeared in The New York Times on Nov. 8.

title: SAGE-ALLEN & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: The Need to Ban Armor-Piercing Bullets
description: To the Editor:

title: A NEW WAY TO PRINT NEWS
description: Jerry DeHimer had a problem. He needed to replace the worn-out presses at The Providence Journal and Evening Bulletin, the daily morning and afternoon newspapers here. And he wanted presses that could print a paper faster and cheaper - and maybe even end the problem of ink rubbing off on readers' hands.

title: John F. Mee Is Dead at 77; Management Field Pioneer
description: John F. Mee, former chairman of the department of management at the Indiana University School of Business, died Sunday at Bloomington Hospital in Indiana. He was 77 years old and lived in Bloomington.

title: Intelsat, a Cost-Sharing Cooperative, Has No 'Monopoly Profits'
description: To the Editor:

title: Iran Says Its Planes Attacked Troop Concentration in Iraq
description: Iran said today that its warplanes hit an industrial plant and a troop concentration in northern Iraq, causing ''high casualties and losses,'' and Iraq reported that it had repelled an Iranian ground attack and raided the Kharg Island oil terminal again.

title: First Mezuza in Space?
description: As the next member of Congress scheduled to travel in space, Representative Bill Nelson has been getting requests that he take along as souvenirs such things as a deck of trick playing cards, baseball caps, postage stamps and, from one widow, her husband's ashes. The ashes and the cards will not go, the Congressman's office says.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 23, 1985
description: International

title: ARMEL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Hospital Supply Link Advances
description: The Justice Department today proposed a consent decree that it said should resolve competition questions about the proposed acquisition of the American Hospital Supply Corporation by Baxter Travenol Laboratories Inc.

title: BERGER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for 14 wks to Sept 30
description: Results for the quarterly periods are for 14 weeks for the latest third quarter and 13 weeks for the year-ago third quarter.

title: Tough Talk About New York's Schools
description: It comes as no surprise that an evaluation by the State Education Department lists 417 of New York City's schools as among the worst in the state. The question continues to be what can be done to improve them.

title: LAW ON HONEY: KEEPERS PROFIT
description: Established in 1949, the honey support program was designed to assure a sufficient supply of honeybees for pollinating the nation's fields and orchards.

title: LEWIS, PALMER G. CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding have been adjusted to reflect 4 percent stock dividends distributed in September 1984 and October 1985.

title: Give 'em 22 Minutes
description: There are two ''all-news'' stations in New York City, and I like to switch back and forth between them so that I can be a truly well-informed listener. Democracy, as we all know, rests on a citizen's being knowledgeable.

title: THE DANCE: CITY BALLET IN BALANCHINE'S 'REGINA'
description: At its best, the New York City Ballet's performance Wednesday night at the New York State Theater conveyed the delight that trained bodies must know as they move confidently through space.

title: CORRECTION
description: An art review in Weekend yesterday, on an exhibition of sculptures by Jacques Lipchitz at the Marlborough Gallery, incorrectly dated their casting. They were cast during the artist's lifetime and under his supervision.

title: Appeals Court Backs Maxxam
description: The Maxxam Group Inc.'s takeover of the Pacific Lumber Company moved nearer to completion today as the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, upheld Federal Judge William Schwarzer's denial of a California State Superior Court ruling that blocked the merger of the two companies.

title: TUNA: A MULTIPLICITY OF CHOICES
description: The makers of the first no-salt-added canned tuna previewed their product at a lunch several years ago. Most of the guests were certain afterward that someone had sabatoged their efforts. The tuna that was prepared and presented was fishy, dry and singularly unappealing.

title: SATURDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Knicks vs. Boston Celtics, at Madison Square Garden, 7:35 P.M. This is the Knicks' first meeting of the season with the defending Eastern Conference champions. The Celtics swept all six games last season. (Television - MSG, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WNBC 660, 7:20 P.M.) College: Syracuse vs. Utica, at the Carrier Dome, followed by Dowling at St. Francis of Brooklyn. (Radio - WNYE-FM 91.5, 7:35 P.M. live for the Syracuse game, tape delay for the St. Francis game.) Football College: L.S.U. at Notre Dame (Television - Channel 11, and USA network, noon); Duke at North Carolina (Television - MSG, noon); Tennessee at Kentucky (Television - WTBS, noon); Fordham at Pace (Radio - WFUV-FM 90.7, 1 P.M.); Columbia at Brown, 1 P.M. (Radio - WKCR-FM 89.9 1 P.M.); Dartmouth at Penn, 1 P.M.; Cornell at Princeton, 1 P.M. (Television - Channel 13, 1 P.M.); C. W. Post at Iona, 1 P.M.; Syracuse at Rutgers, 1 P.M. (Radio - WCTC 1450, WRSU-FM 88.7 WNYE-FM 91.5, 12:35 P.M.); Harvard at Yale, 1 P.M.; Ohio State at Michigan (Television - Channel 2, 1:30 P.M.); Holy Cross at Boston College, 2 P.M.; Southern U. vs. Grambling at the Superdome, 2 P.M.; Oklahoma at Nebraska (Television - Channel 7, 3:30 P.M.); Penn State at Pittsburgh (Television -ESPN, 7:30 P.M.); Colorado State at Miami (Fla.). (Television - WTBS, 8 P.M.) High School: Sheepshead Bay of Brooklyn vs. Nazareth of Brookyln, B Division, 10 A.M., and New Dorp of Staten Island vs. St. Francis Prep of Queens, A Division, 1 P.M., Metro Bowl championships, at Midwood Field, Brooklyn.

title: Farmer in Georgia Is Spared From Eviction
description: A farmer who faced eviction from the land his family had owned since the Civil War has been spared from eviction because he was remembered as a man ''who never turned anyone down.''

title: PROFITS OF WELFARE HOTEL ARE PLACED AT $3 MILLION
description: The Holland Hotel, one of 55 New York City welfare hotels, has made large profits housing homeless families, taking in $6 million a year and netting between $3 million and $4 million, according to documents released in an unusual court proceeding.

title: DUARTE RIGHTS UNIT REPLACED, BUT INVESTIGATIONS STILL LAG
description: To many of his followers, an order by President Jose Napoleon Duarte for an investigation of a series of political killings seemed a daring move, a signal that the military and well-to-do would become accountable before the law.

title: HEALTH INFORMATION SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: REAGAN PICKS A PULITZER-WINNING BIOGRAPHER
description: President Reagan has selected Edmund Morris, the Pulitzer Prize-winning author of a biography of Theodore Roosevelt, to chronicle his own life and Presidency, a White House spokesman said Thursday.

title: ANNE SEDDON BROWN
description: Anne Seddon Brown, an authority on military history who assembled a rare collection of books and military prints, died of cancer Thursday at her summer home in Newport, R.I. She was 79 years old.

title: Summit Interpreters
description: The American team of interpreters at Geneva was the largest the United States had ever used for a meeting between a President and a Soviet leader. And, as it turns out, for a special reason.

title: DEBATE ON AIR SAFETY
description: The recent in-flight collision of a corporate jet and a small plane southeast of the Teterboro, N.J., airport that killed six people has intensified debates on several issues concerning the safety of air-traffic operations.

title: WHY RATES FELL AT GIANT U.S. SALES
description: When the Treasury announced on Nov. 14 its plans to sell a record $32 billion of notes and bonds this week, interest rates rose immediately as traders assumed that more generous returns would be needed for investors and speculators to absorb the immense new supply.

title: Malaria Treatment
description: The Army received a patent this week for a treatment of malaria. Twenty-eight compounds are listed in patent 4,554,279 granted to Andrew J. Saggiomo and Edward A. Nodiff of the Franklin Research Center in Philadelphia. Test results suggest that the compounds will undergo further screening and development before being used to treat malaria.

title: SPRING FASHION WITH NO FRILLS
description: Even designers who are fond of elaborate clothes with plenty of exterior decoration are cleaning up their act for spring. Basic shapes are lean and uncluttered. A kind of austerity prevails.

title: CUMMINGS GETS 34 AS KNICKS LOSE
description: The Knicks returned tonight to the building that for years Patrick Ewing made his domain. But they came without the former Georgetown center, much to the chagrin of the Capital Centre crowd of 13,439, who wanted to see Ewing play against the Washington Bullets.

title: ADVERTISING UNLIMITED INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
SENATE VOTES TO CUT HONEY FROM FARM SUBSIDIES
description: For the first time in more than three decades, the Senate today voted to remove a crop, honey, from the Government's price subsidy program.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on Nov. 15 about a New York State Regents decision, letting girls play in contact sports on teams with boys, incompletely described the procedure to determine a student's fitness. Under the new rules, when a girl seeks to try out for a team, a review panel will be set up to evaluate both boys and girls.

title: PRESIDENT TELLS THE CABINET HIS TALKS 'CLEARED THE AIR'
description: President Reagan told the Cabinet today that his talks with Mikhail S. Gorbachev had ''cleared the air'' and that the two leaders had agreed to ''keep in touch, keep in contact'' even before they meet again next year.

title: METEOROLOGIST PREDICTED PATTERN OF HURRICANES
description: Last June a meteorologist at Colorado State University, using statistical analyses of several global weather patterns, made a relatively accurate prediction of hurricanes and tropical storms that originated over the Atlantic Ocean this year.

title: REAGAN SAYS U.S. FAVORS COVERT AID TO ANGOLA REBELS
description: President Reagan said today that his Administration favored covert aid to insurgents seeking the overthrow of the leftist Government of Angola.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * BankAmerica Corp., San Francisco, said it had closed the previously announced sale of its FinanceAmerica unit to Chrysler Financial Corp. for $405 million.

title: CONFIDENCE POWERS SHEEPSHEAD BAY
description: First, the nicknames. The Icebox is Sheepshead Bay High School's 310-pound nose tackle, who was known as Darrell Washington before it became chic to be an appliance.

title: BUYOUTS ALTERING FACE OF CORPORATE AMERICA
description: In the business world's latest craze, Wall Street financiers and small groups of executives are borrowing billions of dollars to put some of America's best-known corporations into private hands.

title: LA-Z-BOY CHAIR CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 26
MUSIC: WORKS OF MORAN AT ALTERNATIVE MUSEUM
description: Robert Moran is now 48 years old, but although he has been composing steadily, he remains less well-known than some of his contemporaries. That may be changing, however, since he's been based on the East Coast recently and has been giving frequent concerts here, and since the opera he and Philip Glass have co-composed, ''The Juniper Tree,'' will be presented next month by the American Repertory Theater in Cambridge, Mass., directed by Andrei Serban.

title: PHH GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Indictments Disclosed In T.W.A. Hijacking
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d said Thursday that a Federal grand jury in Washington had indicted the three men believed to have been responsible for the hijacking of a Trans World Airlines jetliner on an Athens-to-Rome flight last summer.

title: Newark to Check Officers for AIDS
description: The city has agreed to examine all police officers who came in contact with a detective who died this week after suffering from AIDS for the last year.

title: TORK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $204,506 for the quarter and the year. c-Net loss.

title: Toxic Fumes at a Fuse Plant Hospitalize 3 in Connecticut
description: Three employees at an electrical-fuse plant were hospitalized and 144 others were treated for chemical exposure today after a worker mixed chemicals that gave off toxic fumes, officials said.

title: SENATE APPROVES $8.5 BILLION BILL ON MILITARY CONSTRUCTION PROJECTS
description: The Senate today approved and sent to President Reagan a bill appropriating $8.5 billion for military construction projects this year, including the first major expenditures for the Navy's plan to move some of its ships to new ports around the country.

title: U.S. AND NICARAGUA CLASH AS U.N. OPENS DISCUSSION OF REGION
description: The General Assembly heard two sharply divergent voices today as it opened a debate on the situation in Central America.

title: Theismann Optimistic
description: Joe Theismann, the Washington Redskin quarterback who suffered a season-ending injury last Monday, vowed yesterday that he would return for the 1986 season. ''There has never been a question in my mind I would play again,'' said Theismann during a news conference at Arlington (Va.)

title: Harris Laureates
description: To the Editor:

title: CELEBRITY WIOTH A POOL CUE
description: For the pool player Steve Mizerak, recognition comes in the form of a beer bottle. It is a lesser-known fact that the cue wizard of low-calorie-suds notoriety is one of the dominating pocket billiards champions of the last 20 years. During the past week, Mizerak has been in Niagara Falls, N.Y., competing in the World 14.1 Pocket Billiard Championship. Unless he loses unexpectedly in this afternoon's semifinals, he will defend his title tonight.

title: Saving the Day For the Defense
description: You'd think that Indianapolis, the beneficiary of the midnight Mayflower, would have had its fill of football-related take-aways. But no. For instance, there is the case of Tom Collins, who delighted Indiana Central's followers again this season with grand aerial theft so prolific that he became the Willie Sutton of the N.C.A.A. record books.

title: Greek Prime Minister Curtails Press Access
description: Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou announced today that he was eliminating the post of government spokesman and the practice of daily government news briefings and that he was preparing legislation to regulate the press.

title: Bridge;   Certain Suit Combinations Raise Surprising Problems
description: Most players think about suit combinations as kindergarten stuff, an area they have completely mastered. But some of them are quite tricky and deceptive.

title: ILC TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Corrected from Thursday's editions.

title: GORBACHEV, BACK HOME, IS GREETED BY OPTIMISM
description: As Mikhail S. Gorbachev returned to Moscow today, there was a palpable sense of optimism among many Russians over his meetings with President Reagan.

title: Device Helps to Carry And Turn a Mattress
description: Donald C. Strachan of Yucalpa, Calif., received a patent this week for a device designed to help carry bed mattresses or turn them over. Patent 4,553,780 says the turning of a mattress is necessary - some manufacturers say every two weeks for the first three months and every month thereafter - to avoid body impressions.

title: HENDERSON PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DEMOCRATS TOLD TO SHUN DEBATE ON REAGAN IN '86
description: Democrats have little to gain, and possibly something to lose, if they turn the 1986 elections into a political debate on President Reagan's policies, party officials were told here today.

title: BURGER KINGS ON WHEELS
description: Beginning next month in Miami, the fast-food chain will roll out the first of 20 mobile restaurants. The daily goal of the gastronomic experiment will be to reach large pockets of take-out customers on college campuses, construction sites, industrial parks and military bases before they decide to eat elsewhere.

title: BIG FLORIDA BANKS IN MERGER TALKS
description: The Barnett Banks of Florida Inc. and the Southeast Banking Corporation said yesterday that they might merge. Although a combination of the two big Florida banking companies was far from certain because important details remained unresolved, Wall Street analysts said they were pleased that the companies were talking, and Southeast's stock surged by $3.125, closing at $38. Barnett Banks' stock was unchanged at $39.375.

title: PHOTON SOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Cuban Sugar-Cane Fields Hurt by Hurricane
description: Nearly 2.5 million acres of sugar cane were damaged by Hurricane Kate, which whipped across Cuba on Tuesday and Wednesday with winds of more than 100 miles per hour, the official Communist Party newspaper Granma reported today.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 23, 1985
description: The Economy

title: VARLEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including income of $61,000 from discontinued operations. c-After a loss of $3,436,000 from discontinued operations, and including a tax credit of $3,061,000. d-Net income including income of $172,000 from discontinued operations. Year-ago results have been restated to reflect discontinued operations.

title: Gas-Cooled Nuclear Reactor
description: A PLAN for a gas-cooled nuclear reactor was patented this week for the Department of Energy. It includes a system that continues the cooling process even if an emergency stops normal circulation of the gas.

title: Local Stirrings in Brazil
description: Eight months after Brazil's generals yielded power to a civilian regime, Latin America's largest nation has conducted the first elections of the democratic era. The voting for 200 mayors last week was mostly reassuring, but in the two major cities it furthered the fortunes of mavericks who once fostered instability.

title: CONSOLIDATED PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 25
description: b-After a charge of $50,000 from the reversal of a tax credit. c-Net income. d-Including tax credits of $142,500 for the quarter and $480,000 for the year.

title: Celebrity Reading Of 'A Christmas Carol'
description: A cast of noted actors, including Len Cariou, Helen Hayes, Celeste Holm, Raul Julia, Mary Elizabeth Mastrantonio and Carole Shelley, will take part in a staged reading of Dickens's ''Christmas Carol'' on Dec. 2 at 7 P.M. at Symphony Space, Broadway and 95th Street. The reading is adapted by Bille Brown, who will also appear, and is a benefit for the Riverside Shakespeare Company, 165 West 86th Street.

title: Suspension Upheld
description: Kenny Danforth, one of four Clemson players suspended for the season-ending game against South Carolina today, failed yesterday to win a court order overturning the suspension. Danforth, a senior safety, and three other players were suspended by Clemson's athletic director, Bobby Robinson, for pummeling a rival player on the sideline after the last play of the Maryland game last Saturday.

title: MHP MACHINES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a foreign currency exchange loss of $32,000. c-Net loss. d-Including a foreign currency exchange gain of $40,000.

title: EMOTIONS RUNNING HOT IN U.S. TIMBER DISPUTE
description: Above the narrow roads that wind through the Nantahala National Forest here, the areas totally cleared of trees stand out distinctly, bald patches of up to 40 acres hewn out of the densely wooded mountainsides.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Britt Burns, the top pitcher for the Chicago White Sox last season, has asked to be traded to the Atlanta Braves, and Bobby Cox, the Braves' general manager, has opened talks with the White Sox in an effort to give him his wish. . . . Doug Rader, the former manager of the Texas Rangers, said he had been contacted by the Chicago White Sox about replacing the third-base coach, Jim Leyland, who was hired as the Pittsburgh Pirates' manager earlier this week. . . . Malcolm Barnwell, the wide receiver who was placed on waivers by the Washington Redskins, has been claimed by the New Orleans Saints. . . . Rick Parros, the fullback who was waived by the Denver Broncos, has been claimed by the Seattle Seahawks.

title: FRENCH AT ODDS ON COMMERCIAL TV
description: A Government plan to allow France's first private commercial television station to transmit from the Eiffel Tower has generated a storm of protest.

title: ROSE'S STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Big Cocaine Cache Seized in Jersey
description: The police have confiscated more than 200 pounds of cocaine and arrested five people in what the authorities called the largest cocaine seizure in the state.

title: RESIDENTS OF FLORIDA'S PANHANDLE RETURN TO ASSESS STORM DAMAGE
description: Residents returned to this old Gulf town today to survey the damage caused by Hurricane Kate. Like thousands of others along the coast of the Florida panhandle, they found it was neither as bad as they feared nor as good as they hoped.

title: MAJOR LABOR BILL REJECTED IN HOUSE
description: The House of Representatives has rejected a bill sought by organized labor that would have required employers with more than 50 workers to give at least 90 days' notice of plant closings.

title: Bank Clearing Is Resumed
description: Conditions in the government securities markets returned to normal yesterday after computer problems at the Bank of New York prevented it from making billions of dollars worth of wire transfers of Federal funds and securities on Thursday.

title: CITY SHUTS HETEROSEXUAL CLUB FOR PROSTITUTION
description: New York City obtained a court order yesterday to shut down a Manhattan club, Plato's Retreat, where it said acts of prostitution had taken place.

title: Liberia Leader Promises Fair Trials in Coup Plot
description: Liberia's leader, Gen. Samuel K. Doe, promised today that speedy and fair trials would be granted to those arrested after abortive coup against him last week.

title: PHILADELPHIA CURBS GATHERINGS AFTER RACE PROTESTS
description: Mayor W. Wilson Goode declared a state of emergency today in a predominantly white neighborhood where residents have demonstrated for two nights outside houses bought recently by a black family and an interracial couple.

title: NEW INQUIRY REJECTED IN MARILYN MONROE'S DEATH
description: Charles Richardson, foreman of the Los Angeles County grand jury, announced Thursday that the jury had turned down a request from the county's Board of Supervisors to reopen the investigation into the death of Marilyn Monroe 23 years ago.

title: ST. JOHN'S RALLIES TO DEFEAT NAVY
description: For the first 20 minutes of tonight's game with Navy, St. John's lived out Lou Carnesecca's worst nightmare of how his team might begin the season.

title: Bogged Down
description: It would have been the perfect welcome. A readied police escort, a light flurry of snow and rain, a pair of anxious spectators.

title: TELERATE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Senator Byrd, Mr. Byrd, Honorable Byrd?
description: Senator Robert C. Byrd thinks it is time that Americans learned the proper use of titles, not least those directed toward elected officials.

title: MCDERMOTT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CIRCLE K CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Harmonica Star
description: The harmonica player Toots Thielemans is appearing through tomorrow at at Fat Tuesday's, 190 Third Avenue at 17th Street (533-7902). Sets begin at 8 and 10 P.M. and midnight tonight, 9 and 11 P.M. tomorrow; there is a $12.50 cover and a $7.50 minimum.

title: ADMAC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-The company said that comparable figures for the year-ago net income and share earnings were not available.

title: PUNTA GORDA ISLES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
WHITING PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PRIMATE OF 80,000-MEMBER RUSSIAN CHURCH DIES
description: Metropolitan Philaret, Archbishop of New York and Eastern America and Primate of the Russian Orthodox Church Outside of Russia, died Thursday at his home in Manhattan after a long illness. He was 82 years old.

title: 16th-Century Music
description: The early-music groups Pomerium Musices and the New York Consort of Viols will collaborate in a program of unusual music from 16th-century Naples at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church tomorrow afternoon at 2. The church is at Fifth Avenue and 55th Street; there is a suggested contribution of $4. For information - 580-9787.

title: Rescue the Mitchell-Lama Housing Program
description: New York State's Mitchell-Lama program of housing for low- and middle-income families has provided decent homes for tens of thousands of people who could not otherwise afford them. It has rescued dying neighborhoods from terminal plight and created healthy, lively communities, integrated by race, income, ethnicity, age and life style. It has been a success story almost without parallel in the state. It is threatened with extinction.

title: Eye on Safety
description: Did you know that the National Basketball Association is using a different backboard this season?

title: HARPER & ROW PUBLISHERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $366,000. c-After income from discontinued operations of $1,137,000.

title: Car Registrations Extended
description: All state motor-vehicle registrations due to expire Nov. 30 have been extended until Dec. 6, the State Department of Motor Vehicles has announced. The extension is designed to reduce congestion at motor-vehicle offices after Thanksgiving caused by motorists who wait until the last days of the month to renew their registrations.

title: Death Penalty Is Too Final for Our Justice System;   Flip Side of Coin
description: To the Editor:

title: LOS ANGELES YOUTH GANGS TRAVELING HUNDREDS OF MILES TO PLUNDER THE WEST
description: A police detective was surprised last week when he found himself in the middle of an armed robbery as he dropped off his wife's watch at a swank jewelry store in the Phoenix suburb of Scottsdale. He was surprised again after the six young men who were arrested turned out to be suspected of being members of a Los Angeles street gang.

title: IN BORNEO, IT'S EASIER TO WIN OFFICE THAN KEEP IT
description: Joseph Pairin Kitingan is a man under siege.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: STOMPIN' AT THE SAVOY There was a time when ballroom dancers held onto each other - sometimes for dear life. The man swung the woman vigorously; pulled her, twirled her and threw her. He, dressed in a wide-shouldered, full-cut, double-breasted suit, did jumps, splits and other strenuous gyrations. They were jitterbugging. The basic dance on which jitterbugs added their variations was the lindy hop, or, the lindy. It was the dance of the 1930's and the 1940's. And some of its most imaginative and innovative performers seemed to be among the patrons of Harlem's Savoy Ballroom.

title: Extend Time Period for New York Toxic Suits
description: To the Editor:

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 50.

title: MISSISSIPPI HONORS A 'NATIVE SON' WHO FLED
description: When he was 19, Richard Wright, the impoverished son of Mississippi sharecroppers, left his native soil forever, fleeing what he would later describe as ''that most racist of all the American states.''

title: WESTERN ENERGY DEVELOPENT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company has signed a letter of intent to merge with Worldwide Energy Corp.

title: SOUTH AFRICA SAYS 13 DIED IN CLASHES
description: The authorities said today that 13 people were killed Thursday in clashes with the police in the black township of Mamelodi. Until today, only two deaths had been confirmed by the police, although witnesses had reported at least six dead.

title: Times Receives Award On First Amendment
description: The New York Times today received the First Amendment Defender Award, given by the Columbus School of Law of the Catholic University of America, in recognition of a generation of journalistic and legal contributions to strengthening the First Amendment.

title: Jazz Quartet
description: The vibraphonist Bobby Hutcherson is leading a quartet - with John Hicks on piano, Cecil McBee on bass and Al Foster on drums - through tomorrow at the Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South (255-4037). Sets begin at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M.; there is a $10 cover and a $5 minimum.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 16. 1. Experts said that ''The Man With the Golden Helmet,'' long considered to have been painted by Rembrandt, was not by the Dutch master but that it was ''an independent original in its own right.'' 2. The President wanted to emphasize process and play down substance, and Mr. Gorbachev had hoped to achieve an arms control breakthrough. 3. Households that consist of people living alone or with nonrelatives. 4. 40. 5. A study of the blood samples that had been frozen and stored since 1963 has led American and European researchers to conclude that the children were infected with the AIDS virus or with one similar to it, and that the disease originated in Africa, a theory that the Africans bitterly dispute. 6. As the special envoy of the Archbishop of Canterbury, he met in Beirut with the captors of four American hostages. 7. The Ohio production is the first of Wilde's original script, which was discovered in 1977 in the New York Public Library. 8. House and Senate conferees voted to hold up the plan for 90 days, until Feb. 9, saying the Navy must justify the cost. 9. Seventeenth- and eighteenth-century gravestones, stolen from New England cemeteries. 10. He will become a coach with the Houston Astros. 11. The Washington Monument. 12. Congress. 13. The party honored the 100th birthdays of eight residents of the Isabella Geriatric Center. 14. Yonkers. 15. A jury ordered Texaco Inc. to pay Mr. Jamail's client, the Pennzoil Company, after it found that Texaco had improperly enticed the Getty Oil Company to back out of a merger agreement with Pennzoil in January 1984. 16.

title: The Editorial Notebook;   The Ticking Time Bomb of the Aging
description: Who is responsible for the care of aging Americans? Right now the answer is no one in particular, and that portends social disaster. Consider some typical cases:

title: HONDURAS BARRING U.S. AID FOR REBELS
description: The Honduran Government has not allowed any supplies from the United States to be shipped to Nicaraguan rebels since it confiscated an air shipment on Oct. 10, a Reagan Administration official said today.

title: GENESEE BREWING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
FRANCE WANTS 2 AGENTS BACK
description: Defense Minister Paul Quiles said today that he hoped to arrange the quick return to France of two covert agents who were sentenced to 10-year prison sentences for their role in the sinking of the flagship of the antinuclear, environmentalist organization Greenpeace.

title: ONE FOR ELI YALE
description: For the 102d annual Harvard-Yale game at the Yale Bowl in New Haven this afternoon, the weatherman said there was a chance of rain, but not necessarily a torrent. It seems unlikely that it would be anything like the 1932 Harvard-Yale game, which was played in one of the worst rainstorms in New Haven history. It rained so hard for so long that even Babe Ruth left the game early.

title: Manville Pact With Insurers
description: The Manville Corporation said yesterday that two insurers had agreed to pay $28.5 million to help it settle personal-injury claims filed by asbestos victims. The pacts will end a court battle between Manville and the two companies.

title: U.S. DEDUCTION FOR LOCAL TAXES VOTED BY PANEL
description: The House Ways and Means Committee early today voted to continue to allow taxpayers to deduct from their Federal tax returns all state and local income, property and sales tax payments.

title: ISLANDERS, RANGERS SQUARE OFF
description: As champions and contenders for the last several years, the Islanders have also been relentless finishers. When they took a lead into the third period, they were rarely taken by surprise or overtaken by the opposition.

title: Many Searchers
description: In an era of government by committee, David N. Dinkins, the Manhattan Borough President-elect, is outdoing some of his fellow politicians.

title: A FACTORY TOWWN, WORRIED ABOUT JOBS, SUPPORTS COMPANIES IN E.P.A. DISPUTE
description: For the past five years, the water supply in this economically battered factory town has been dangerously polluted.

title: Indian Rights Leader Paroled in South Dakota
description: A leader of the American Indian Movement who was a fugitive for nine years after being convicted of riot and assault was granted parole today from the South Dakota Penitentiary.

title: Odd Advice?
