description: Coach Pat Quinn of the Los Angeles Kings, upon reading his players' recommendations as to how the team could play better: ''I think some of our guys got into the wrong profession.''

title: PACER TECHNOLOGY & RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: PVC CONTAINER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
U.S., CANADA AND JAPAN IN COMPUTER PARTS PACT
description: The United States, Canada and Japan today signed an agreement to eliminate duties on parts of computers - from terminals and printers to basic brains or logic units - in a pact expected to increase sales and cut costs for the international industry.

title: Airliner Slides Off Runway
description: A Boeing 727 preparing to take off from Hobby Airport today slid off a runway into the mud when the pilot made a sharp turn. Officials said the 90 passengers on the American Airlines flight bound for Dallas-Fort Worth were unharmed.

title: THE DANCE: 'SHADOWS' PREMIERE
description: Thirty years ago, ''Shadows,'' a ballet by Jean-Pierre Bonnefoux, would have looked old hat. Today it looks new. This paradox was only one of several unusual things about the work, which had its world premiere with the New York City Ballet Thursday night at the State Theater.

title: Streak Snapped
description: Something unusual happened in the Seattle Seahawks' loss to New England last Sunday: Dave Krieg didn't throw for a touchdown, having passed for at least one in each of the last 28 games.

title: NEUROLOGIST AND PSYCHIATRIST
description: Dr. Saul Isaac Heller, who practiced neurology and psychiatry in New York for more than 50 years, died of cancer Monday at the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center. He was 80 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: OPERA: MOZART'S 'FIGARO' IN NEW MET PRODUCTION
description: Nine seasons is an inexcusably long time for any opera company to go without a performance of ''Le Nozze di Figaro,'' but the Metropolitan made amends last evening with a new production of the Mozart masterpiece. Partial amends, at any rate. Jean-Pierre Ponnelle's clever but enormous sets worked only sometimes, often succeeding in dwarfing one of opera's most intimate works and diminishing the effect of several highly respectable individual performances.

title: LOCAL ROSE 0.2% LAST MONTH
description: The Consumer Price Index for the New York-northeastern New Jersey region rose two-tenths of 1 percent last month, the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday. The price of liquor, fuel oil, shoes and furniture increased, while food, electricity and gas prices dropped, The bureau's regional commissioner, Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, noted that the index has been relatively steady all year. He said the October rise was equivalent to an annual rate of 3.5 percent, while October 1984's rise was at an annual rate of 4.7 percent. Both were much lower than the 10 percent inflation rates of the early 1980's.

title: BALLET: BEJART'S 'SALOME' IN ITS WORLD PREMIERE
description: A remark by George Balanchine helped inspire Maurice Bejart's ''Salome,'' which received its world premiere at Thursday night's performance by the Ballet of the Twentieth Century at the City Center Theater, 131 West 55th Street. According to the program note, Balanchine once declared that he suspected Salome was a boy.

title: Volcker In Argentina
description: The Federal Reserve chairman, Paul A. Volcker, arrived today to review Argentina's much-heralded economic program and to discuss a United States proposal to lend about $30 billion to debtor countries, officials said.

title: PATENT SUIT IS WON BY FONAR
description: A Federal District Court jury has ruled that a subsidiary of Johnson & Johnson infringed upon a valid patent held by the Fonar Corporation. The patent is for the magnetic resonance imaging system, a medical device that produces detailed pictures of the human body without using X-rays or injecting contrasting dyes.

title: DAUGHTER OF PIONEER IS DEAD
description: Laura Blache Clark Cook Silver Cook, whose father was one of the original Mormon pioneers in Utah, died here Monday at the age of 105. Mrs. Cook's father was an associate of Joseph Smith, founder of the Mormon Church, and crossed the plains with Brigham Young to help settle Utah. She outlived three husbands and is survived by five children, 11 grandchildren, 29 great-grandchildren and six great-great-grandchildren.

title: Computer Controls Speed of a Motor
description: A motor patented this week for Genentech Inc. of South San Francisco, Calif., has its speed controlled by a computer.

title: Cyanide Blast Injures 46 At Factory in Florida
description: A 55-gallon drum of toxic silver cyanide exploded at a military contractor's plant today, injuring at least 46 people and forcing the partial evacuation of the plant, the authorities said.

title: CONSUMER PRICE INDEX UP BY 0.3%
description: The Consumer Price Index climbed three-tenths of 1 percent in October, slightly more than the string of two-tenths of 1 percent increases that prevailed from May through September, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Notre Dame Search
description: Officially, Notre Dame won't make a decision on Gerry Faust's future as coach until after the season.

title: City Groups to Get Housing Grants
description: Governor Cuomo announced yesterday that 45 nonprofit groups, including 20 in New York City, would share $17.5 million in state grants to shelter homeless people.

title: HUSBAND CHARGED AS A SPY
description: The wife of a Navy counterintelligence analyst was arrested tonight and charged with unauthorized possession of classified documents, the day after her husband was arrested and accused of spying for Israel.

title: STOCKS GAIN A BIT TO RECORD LEVELS
description: Stock prices closed slightly higher yesterday, but the gains were enough to nudge major market indicators to new highs and to give the Dow Jones industrial average its second consecutive weekly gain of about 30 points.

title: Article 176603 -- No Title
description: The state government sued the EPIC real estate operations and its owners today, seeking at least $50 million from company officials for reportedly reaping profits by endangering the funds of the depositors of the Community Savings and Loan Association.

title: DIMIS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $240,000 on the sale of a software license and equipment.

title: SPYING ON ALLIES COMMON
description: The arrest of an American Navy analyst suspected of spying for Israel highlights a longstanding practice among allied intelligence services of spying on each other.

title: EDITOR'S NOTE
description: The Sports of The Times column last Saturday speculated on divisional winners in Horse of the Year voting. It suggested that Mom's Command, a 3-year-old filly who was retired last month, now had a chance at the title.

title: Newsprint Pact
description: Donohue Inc. said it and The New York Times Company will build a $170 million newsprint machine to increase annual capacity at Donohue's Clermont, Quebec, plant to 550,000 metric tons from 410,000 tons by early 1988. The Times Company will contribute 49 percent of the equity financing for the project and will increase its interest in Donohue's Donohue Malbaie Inc. subsidiary to 49 percent from a current 35 percent.

title: DESIGNATRONICS INC reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding give retroactive effect to 5 percent stock dividends declared in October 1984 and September 1985 and a 10 percent stock dividend declared in September 1983.

title: Devils Win, 6-5, On Sulliman's Goal
description: Doug Sulliman scored with 7 minutes 19 seconds left in the third period tonight to lift the Devils to a 6-5 victory over the Vancouver Canucks.

title: Kenyan AIDS Death Toll Is 8
description: At least eight people in Kenya have died of acquired immune deficiency syndrome, and 13 people suspected of having the disease are being treated, Health Minister Peter Nyakiamo was quoted as saying today.

title: On the Early Wine Watch
description: Isabelle Richard got up at 5 A.M. on Thursday.

title: NETS SAVED BY THEIR DEFENSE
description: He is still not pleased with the development of the offense, which is understandable because it can be good, bad and mediocre in the same night. But Dave Wohl, the Nets' rookie coach, is not quite so concerned as he once was. On a road trip that began poorly, the Nets have found some salvation in their defense.

title: MACROCHEM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company did not report revenue figures because it is still in the development stage.

title: IN SPORTS, RICH GET RICHER
description: IN the World Series and the Super Bowl, the race goes now to the solvent, not the swift.

title: COMPANY CAFETERIAS AS CORPORATE TOOL
description: AS anyone wrestling a Thanksgiving turkey knows, preparing a meal for 20 is a formidable job. Yet feeding hundreds of employees daily is a chore faced by Westchester companies that open plants and offices off the beaten tracks. When downtown restaurants are 20 minutes away, corporations feel obliged to provide on-site dining facilities.

title: Photography
description: ''25 Years of Space Photography,'' an exhibition of more than 100 images at the I.B.M. Gallery (Madison Avenue at 56th Street) through Jan. 4, contains pictures of considerable scientific interest. This is to be expected, since they were produced by the Jet Propulsion Laboratory on behalf of NASA.

title: TOPICS
description: A PROFILE of two Americas emerged in the wake of Hurricane Gloria. One: a nation grossly dependent on electrical gadgets and helpless in the face of their loss. The other: a reassuring picture of Yankee ingenuity and perseverance in the face of difficulty.

title: NOW DEAL
description: ''I gained a better perspective; I feel he did, too. . . . We cannot assume that their ideology or purpose will change. This implies enduring competition. Our task is to assure that this competition remains peaceful. - RONALD REAGAN The talks proceeded in political language, in a very open way, in a very straightforward manner. And I think that was not only of great significance, I'd say it was decisive. - MIKHAIL GORBACHEV There, unanswered, lie the great questions about last week's encounter between America's charming tough guy and the Kremlin's bright new strongman. How, precisely, did Geneva improve President Reagan's perspective on the Soviet Union? What bursts of candor did Secretary Gorbachev find so pivotal?

title: BLOOD TRANSFUSION PREACTICES CITES IN AFRICAN AIDS
description: As scientists intensify their search for the reasons so many African men and women are suffering from AIDS, new studies reported here point the finger of culpability, at least in part, at risky blood transfusion practices throughout that continent.

title: ONE'S DISCOUNT IS ANOTHER'S DISMAY
description: In late July, when S. Sue Aramian paid $2,045 for a week's cruise on the Rotterdam to Alaska departing Aug. 8, she assumed the price was appropriate.

title: IS THAT MISS MARPLE AT THE NEXT TABLE
description: The spirit of Schrafft's lives on - in Paris. For a sentimental New Yorker of pre-McDonald's vintage, finding the staples of that prim, paper doily-dotted hostelry - sundaes, sodas, apple and chicken pies, club sandwiches, tea and buttered spinach - is almost like finding the fountain of one's American youth just footsteps from the Place de la Concorde. Upstairs at W. H. Smith's English-language bookstore, at 248 Rue de Rivoli, to be precise.

title: Depiction of Somers Called Into Question
description: When I read the feature article on Somers in The Westchester Weekly section Sunday [Oct. 27] , I was appalled. My husband and I found no place for ourselves or our friends in this polemic description of our town. The article, ''A Town Prepares for Change,'' suggests that I.B.M. and Pepsico will initiate a flow of corporate-types into a splintered community of small hamlets and wipe the smiles off the faces of the lifelong residents pictured on page one. Where do we fit in? My husband and I, residents of Somers for 11 years, are not old-timers nor are we part of the ''sweeping change'' to come. We have both commuted to out-of-town jobs. But we, too, have good reason to call Somers our home. We love the open spaces it provides us and our two sons, and we have both spent many hours on various committees and other community efforts, attempting to deal with the town's inevitable growth.

title: COLUMBIA'S TENANTS
description: WE ARE TALKING ABOUT HOMES A Great University Against Its Neighbors. By Lynne Sharon Schwartz. 175 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $15.95.

title: RUBEN RIERA
description: A genial guitar recital was given at the same hall by Ruben Riera the next evening. Mr. Riera has an unhurried delicacy of style and a secure technique that only occasionally falters under the pressure of high speed. A group of ''Cuban Pieces'' by Leo Brouwer, a Bach transcription and works by Moreno Torroba and Ginastera exemplified those skills (there was an especially nice series of carefully placed, consistently resonant harmonics in Brouwer's ''Lullaby'').

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: VETERANS DAY is behind us, but for Michael ''Hal'' Kowal of the Morris County community of Kinnelon (and other veterans of the 94th Bomb Group based in England during World War II), every day is a day to remember those with whom they served and those who were lost in the flak-filled European skies.

title: Outmoded Factories Are Rejuvenated as 'Incubator Parks'
description: CONNECTICUT'S outmoded factory buildings are getting a new lease on life as developers turn them into multitenant industrial complexes and so-called ''incubator parks.''

title: BACKPACKING
description: To the Editor: In the article ''The Long Way: Land's End to John o'Groats (Travel, May 26) John Hillaby, the president of the Backpackers Club in Britain, reprised his end-to-end United Kingdom hike.

title: Video Conferences
description: To the Editor:

title: EXPERTS LIST POTENTIAL TARGETS FOR BOMBING IN NUCLEAR WAR
description: EXCEPT for a primary target in Cape May County, 12 facilities linked to nuclear weapons in New Jersey would be secondary military targets in a Soviet attack.

title: UNRUFFLED LITTLE MUSTIQUE
description: Friends of ours who own a villa on Mustique, an island in the Grenadines off the Venezuelan coast, invited us to spend a week with them during the second week of January. I had never been to the Caribbean, but the name of the island rang a bell. ''Why have I heard of Mustique?'' I asked.

title: ADVICE TO LOVELORN (WRITERS)
description: WRITERS whose works have been rejected gather themselves in groups, as do writers who specialize in everything from history to mystery.

title: MICHIGAN SHATTERS OHIO ST. HOPES
description: With 106,102 fans in Michigan Stadium cheering as if a bid to the Rose Bowl were at stake, Michigan defeated Ohio State today, 27-17, to win a berth instead in the Fiesta Bowl to play Nebraska. The winner of this game was denied a trip to the Rose Bowl earlier when Iowa defeated Minnesota, 31-9, to win the conference championship.

title: ONE MAN'S CONTRIBUTION TO THE HISTORY OF MODERN DANCE
description: Modern dance is still so young an art form that a comprehensive history of its development has yet to be written. If the pioneers in the field are familiar, there are many dancers of lesser importance who stand to be lost to that history even if they were known in their own time.

title: SYRACUSE ROUTS RUTGERS AND GOES TO CHERRY BOWL
description: For many schools, it is like having a regularly scheduled 12th game, and the revenue is so much holiday cheer. But at Syracuse University, ''goin' bowlin,' '' as the players called it today, was a part of the past, a page from days when bruising running backs like Jim Brown, Ernie Davis, Jim Nance, Larry Csonka and Floyd Little placed the Orangemen among the elite in college football. They went bowlin' and no one ever confused it with spending a night at the lanes.

title: SCIENCE FICTION
description: I have to apologize for failing to review William Gibson's NEUROMANCER (Ace, Paper, $2.95) when it appeared last year. What put me off, I think, was the title, which struck me as an ungainly play on words, hinting at some trendy hybrid of sword-and-sorcery fantasy and high-tech adventure, with perhaps a bit of heavy-breathing sex thrown in. I was led to believe I had done Mr. Gibson an injustice when this novel (the author's first) won both of the important 1984 best-of-the-year awards in science fiction: the Nebula (voted by members of the Science Fiction Writers of America) and the Hugo (voted by the fans). Now that I have read the book, I would like to cast a belated ballot for Mr. Gibson.

title: PALESTINIANS CONVICTED
description: After a trial of nearly eight hours in a heavily guarded basement courtroom in Genoa last week, five Palestinians were convicted of possessing guns and explosives in connection with the hijacking of the Achille Lauro cruise ship last month.

title: SEASON'S FRESH APPLE CIDER FNDS MANY USES IN THE KITCHEN
description: Among the many seasonal delights lining the displays of farmstands, produce markets and groceries at this time of year is fresh apple cider. Not long ago finding the rich, tart-sweet freshly pressed juice of the fall apple crop required a trip to an orchard or a farm stand. The only ''cider'' then sold in groceries was a clear, sweetened, pastuerized apple juice, called cider because it came in demijohns.

title: Black March Called Off In Philadelphia District
description: A civil rights group today canceled a march through a racially tense neighborhood here at the request of Mayor W. Wilson Goode.

title: MONTCLAIR STAT IN EASTERN FINAL
description: Walter Briggs threw three touchdown passes, two of them to Tony Sweet, as Montclair State routed Western Connecticut, 28-0, today in an opening-round game of the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division III Eastern playoffs at Sprague Field.

title: PETS FOR ELDERLY
description: TO help elderly people in New York City ''combat loneliness,'' the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals offered a year ago in August to give them pets.

title: ARCHITECTS FIND LIABILITY PREMIUMS AT 'DISASTER' LEVEL
description: IN the 13 years that the firm of R. M. Kliment and Frances Halsband Architects has been in business, handling commissions that range from the Parrish Art Museum in Southampton, L. I., to Columbia University's Computer Science Building, it has never been the object of a lawsuit. Nonetheless, the firm's liability-insurance premium was raised almost threefold this year.

title: HAWKEYES IN ROSE BOWL
description: New Year's Eve began at Kinnick Stadium when the clock ticked under one minute. When the clock reached zero, and the Hawkeyes were alone atop the Big Ten for the first time in 27 years, the band played - what else? - ''California, Here We Come.'' The plans for the Harmon family reunion, however, had already been made.

title: F.D.A. Approves a New Drug For Treatment of Gallstones
description: The Food and Drug Administration has approved a new drug to dissolve or soften gallstones and says it may help 14,000 to 42,000 patients each year for whom surgery was not completely successful.

title: A SHRINE TO JAPAN'S CRAFTS
description: Tokyo certainly is an interesting city, but the most infatuated Japanophile would be hard pressed to call it beautiful. Even its museums are plain, set in functional, stubbornly styleless structures. There are exceptions, of course, and the cheeriest of these is also one of Tokyo's best-kept secrets.

title: MODERNISM ON THE MISSISSIPPI: THE SOUTHERN REVIEW 1935-85
description: IT is fashionable today first to describe, then to decry, the homogenization of culture in the United States. If one no longer hears about the ''Americanization of Dixie'' - by whose mysterious agency the family farms and churches have been boarded up while the populations and apartment houses of Houston, Atlanta and even Charlotte, N.C., bulge at the seams - it is only because now the tables have been turned. America, we are told with egregious diction, is being ''Dixiefied.''

title: OLD IDEA, NEW TWIST
description: MANUFACTURERS of recycled paper have come up with a new twist to the old shopping-spree promotion.

title: SUPERSONIC FLIGHT, BRITISH GUIDEBOOKS
description: The Concorde To Fly Around World in 1987 For travelers who like to plan really far ahead, now is the time to circle March 1987 -yes, 1987. That is when what is called the first commercial round-the-world flight by Concorde will lift off from Heathrow Airport in London.

title: U.N. REPORT ON RIGHTS AND IRAN IS CRITICIZED
description: A United Nations report on human rights in Iran has come under fire from Western diplomats, Iranian exiles and other groups who say it does not adequately document the widespread torture and summary executions carried out by the regime of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini.

title: Talking: TV Dishes;   Wider Use Is Raising Questions
description: SPROUTING like high-tech mushrooms on the lawns and roofs of suburban homes, satellite-dish television antennas are beginning to raise some serious issues for homeowners, their neighbors and those who regulate the environment.

title: 'Still Life'
description: Anyone who has read Antonia Byatt's three previous novels or her critical study of Iris Murdoch knows that this English writer has an acute, supple mind not always primarily interested in the narrative mode as such. She excels at finely attuned brooding and an emphatic introspection, which reveal so much of how it feels to be a certain character that we don't always care what the character does next. A psychological novelist, enthralled by the sensation of being alive, she is best when she works the vagaries of self-communing against the obstinacies of the appended body. She does what Dreiser called ''chemisms'' with the rippling, elated touch of a Virginia Woolf.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: IN SUMMER LIGHT By Zibby Oneal. 149 pages. New York: Viking Kestrel. $11.95. (Ages 12 and up) ZIBBY ONEAL'S heroines are cool, leggy and intelligent adolescent girls who struggle to unlock the repressed rage that blocks their growth to womanhood. Though the preoccupation seems narrow, the literary resolution grows more polished and mature with each novel. Miss Oneal's new book, ''In Summer Light,'' is also her most ambitious and coherent work to date.

title: SEASON'S FRESH APPLE CIDER FINDS MANY USES IN THE KITCHEN
description: AMONG the many seasonal delights lining the displays of farmstands, produce markets and groceries at this time of year is fresh apple cider. Not long ago finding the rich, tart-sweet freshly pressed juice of the fall apple crop required a trip to an orchard or a farm stand. The only ''cider'' then sold in groceries was a clear, sweetened, pastuerized apple juice, called cider because it came in demijohns.

title: A BIT OF SOHO COMES TO THE ISLAND
description: MANHATTAN'S SoHo district has long since made the transition from artists' habitat to tourist mecca, an evolution not unlike that of Montmartre in Paris. In the early years of this century, before its cafes became crowded with curiosity-seekers hoping to observe the antics of art-world luminaries, Montmartre's main attraction was its cheap, roomy studios - analogous to SoHo's lofts before gentrification set in.

title: COMING TO TERMS WITH ONE'S CLOSET
description: IT iS autumn and for me that usually means closet-cleaning time. Most years, when I go to my closets, I begin with a sense of mission, only to retreat 20 minutes later, overwhelmed. I always vow to attack the task again - next year. You see, I come from three generations of what some people call ''squirrels''; some others, ''pack rats.'' I prefer to call myself an archivist. My closets have become the archives of my life and times.

title: SUSAN KORB IS BRIDE OF KURT CLARKE JOMO
description: Susan Merrie Korb, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald C. Korb of Pittsburgh, was married there yesterday to Kurt Clarke Jomo, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald R. Jomo of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Bruce W. Thielmann performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church.

title: HISTORIC BUILDINGS VS. MALL IN SMITHTOWN
description: A PLAN by a developer to remove three historic structures in Smithtown to make way for a shopping plaza is raising concern among local residents, businesspeople and historians.

title: CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: A Gourmet Cornucopia At Wholesale Prices Fancifood opened early in October both on Central Park Avenue south of Ardsley Road in the Scarsdale postal area and in Rockland Plaza of Nanuet in Rockland County. Both outlets offer sampling portions of imported and domestic gourmet foods sold at 25 to 70 percent discounts off retail prices elsewhere. Frequent travelers may recognize treats enjoyed elsewhere and nontravelers can finally have a taste at home of wares from 40 countries.

title: SOUP KITCHENS SEEKING AID FOR THANKSGIVING PROGRAMS
description: FOR most people, Thanksgiving means a warm get-together and turkey, stuffing, cranberry sauce and apple pie. To provide the same kind of Thanksgiving for the less fortunate in the state, soup kitchens and food pantries are seeking donations of food and money.

title: HEMPSTEAD TRIUMPHS
description: The Hempstead Tigers, champions of Nassau's Conference I, came from behind to beat Massapequa, 21-14, a team which dealt the Tigers the only blemish on their record - a tie two weeks ago.

title: HOUSE COMMITTEE COMPLETES DRAFT FOR TAX REVISION
description: The House Ways and Means Committee early today finished drafting the most sweeping changes in the Federal income tax system approved by a Congressional committee since World War II.

title: NEW GRANDMASTER
description: When Maxim Dlugy tied for second place in the Manhattan Chess Club International Tournament with a 6-3 score, he added himself to the increasing horde of grandmasters in the United States.

title: ARMS VERIFICATION ISSUE AT HEART OF U.S. DEBATE
description: The summit meeting between the United States and the Soviet Union has not dispelled the controvery over one feature of the Administration's arms-control proposal: its decision to seek a ban on mobile intercontinental ballistic missiles.

title: TYSON BY KNOCKOUT
description: A pounding to the ribs followed by a solid left to the chin of Conroy Nelson, the No. 2-ranked Canadian heavyweight, gave Mike Tyson of Catskill, N.Y., his 13th knockout in 13 professional fights Friday night in Latham, N.Y. Nelson, 27, a 6-foot-5-inch boxer who had won 19 fights against five defeats and two draws, was counted out after 30 seconds of the second round. He was only the fourth fighter to last more than one round against the 19-year-old slugger.

title: Drinking Water
description: To the Editor:

title: E.P.A. CRITICIZED ON LANDFILL
description: THE Federal Environmental Protection Agency has not chosen the best method for cleaning up the Lipari Landfill in Gloucester County, the nation's worst toxic-waste site, according to a report by Congress's Office of Technology Assessment.

title: Envoy Named by Foundation
description: The United States Ambassador to Brazil, Diego C. Asencio, has been appointed executive director of the Una Chapman Cox Foundation, a nonprofit organization dedicated to supporting the effectiveness of the Foreign Service, it was announced Friday. Mr. Asencio, who is 54 years old, is assume his new duties March 1. A replacement for him in Brazil has not been announced.

title: CONSUMER RATES
CANADIAN PRO FOOTBALL FINDS ITSELF THROWN FOR A LOSS
description: Canadian football has long carried a peculiar fascination for a people seemingly groping for an identity that allows them to be pretty much like Americans but ever so slightly different.

title: A MASTERPIECE NOT BY REMBRANT
description: Some art experts have long had doubts about ''The Man With the Golden Helmet,'' one of Rembrandt's - and the world's - most celebrated paintings.

title: SPARE THE ROD AND SPOIL THE SCHOOL?
description: This fall, for the first time, no child attending public school in New York State has to worry about being spanked for misbehavior. The Board of Regents outlawed corporal punishment earlier this year, making New York the eighth state to take such an action. Except for Hawaii, the other states that do not allow it are all in the Northeast: New Jersey, Massachusetts, Maine, Rhode Island, Vermont and New Hampshire.

title: BELGIUM IS SHAKEN BY BOMBS AND 'CRAZY KILLERS'
description: A spate of banditry and terrorism has shaken this normally tranquil, relatively prosperous country of 10 million to its core.

title: PAPER GOALIE
description: OPEN NET By George Plimpton. Illustrated. 288 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $16.95. FOR his books to succeed, George Plimpton must fail. It would not do for him to actually triumph at what he calls participatory journalism. Everyman cannot become Superman.

title: MARLA ROTH IS WED
description: Marla M. Roth and William Smith were married yesterday at the Cold Spring Country Club in Huntington, L.I., by Arthur Dobrin, a leader of the Ethical Humanistic Society of Long Island. The bride is the daughter of Mrs. Herbert Sugarman of Great Neck, L.I. Her husband is a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Smith of Woodmere, L.I. Mrs. Smith is a manager at A.T.&T. Communications in White Plains and her husband is a manager at A.T.&T. Communicatons in Manhattan.

title: A STRAY FRUSTRATES VILLAGE
description: A FUGITIVE hound roaming the streets of Larchmont has eluded capture for the last 18 months, confounding local police and Humane Society officials by using a blend of both street smarts and charm.

title: CORRECTION
description: A caption Nov, 17 that accompanied a listing of Caribean islands and their offerings misidentifies a harbor in Autigua as St. John's harbor. The harbor was English Harbor.

title: L.I. READY FOR POWER LOSS
description: IT'S been almost two months since Hurricane Gloria left 750,000 Long Island customers without electricity, but the memory is still vivid.

title: THE PARIAH OF FIRST AVENUE
description: South Africa's flag still flies in front of the United Nations headquarters but its delegates have not spoken or voted in the General Assembly since 1974, when their country was suspended. Last week, representatives of nearly 100 countries stepped to the podium to condemn South Africa's occupation of Namibia. South Africa is the United Nations pariah, the only country whose policies are universally condemned.

title: Sri Lanka Land Mine Kills 6
description: A land mine killed six soldiers and wounded seven in Sri Lanka's Northern Province today. Security officials said the wounded were taken to hospital after the attack at Mullaitivu.

title: A PLACE WHERE SEEDSMEN JUDGE THEIR WARES
description: Rows upon rows of marigolds, petunias, geraniums, impatiens and zinnias in full bloom is a sight for anyone to see. But seven acres of them?

title: U.S. STUDIES SAY MILITARY ISN'T READY FOR CASUALTIES
description: The United States military commands in Europe and the Pacific region are beset by a range of problems that would prevent them from providing adequate medical care to casualties in wartime, according to two long-classified Pentagon reports that were made available today.

title: CLIPPERS SIGN NIXON
description: After a bitter and complex holdout, the veteran guard Norm Nixon signed a contract yesterday with the Los Angeles Clippers, the team he has played for the last two seasons.

title: WEEHAWKEN
description: FOUR years ago, Weehawken seemed headed for catastrophe. The township faced virtual bankruptcy: It did not have enough money to maintain its police or fire department, or clean the streets or repair the sidewalks, or even pay overdue bills.

title: IS NEW ROAD TEMPTING FATE?
description: THE completion of a four-mile section of four-lane highway in this Gloucester County township has brought a warning from an Indian chieftain that building the highway - work is continuing on other sections - or using it is fraught with danger because it runs through an Indian burial ground.

title: HAYNES STILL AWAITS KEY ROLE
description: Chris Mullin signs with the Golden State Warriors on a Wednesday morning and scores 15 points that night in his professional basketball debut. Eric Schubert signs with the Giants on a Friday and kicks five field goals that Sunday in his first regular-season pro football game.

title: AMY B. LEVINSON WED TO HARRIS LEE SCHWALB
description: Amy Beth Levinson, the daughter of Linda Smith Levinson and Fred Levinson of New York, and Harris Lee Schwalb, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jacob Schwalb of Rockville, Md., were married last evening. Rabbi Ronald Sobel performed the ceremony at the Helmsley Palace Hotel in New York.

title: SUPPORT BUILDS FOR BAN ON USING POLYGRAPH TESTING IN WORKPLACE
description: Polygraph, or lie-detector, tests are administered to two million American workers every year, but bipartisan support is building in Congress for legislation that would end their use in the workplace.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: INSIDE WARNER BROS. (1935-1951). Edited by Rudy Behlmer. (Viking, $19.95.) Rudy Behlmer, the author of the fascinating 1972 ''Memo From David O. Selznick,'' has compiled a second look at Hollywood through memos, letters and telegrams. This time it doesn't work. ''Inside Warner Bros. 1935-1951'' is a jumble of memos by actors, writers, directors, producers and Harry and Jack Warner, the heads of the studio. ''Memo From David O. Selznick'' was shaped by that great producer's obsessions and spent, for example, more than 100 pages on ''Gone With the Wind.'' ''Inside Warner Bros.'' dips in and out of more than 100 movies, often in only one or two memos. The result is a hodgepodge that contains some nuggets but only rarely any depth. Most interesting are the sections on ''Casablanca,'' John Huston and the war between art and commerce in the making of Tennessee Williams's ''Glass Menagerie'' and ''Streetcar Named Desire.'' An exchange of letters between B. Traven, the reclusive author of ''The Treasure of the Sierra Madre,'' and Mr. Huston, who was to win Academy Awards for writing and directing a movie version of the novel, is compelling. One is struck also by numerous angry letters from Bette Davis, one of the few actors who expressed her dudgeon on paper, and such oddities as William Faulkner trying to get out of his screenwriting contract. One of the problems with ''Inside Warner Bros.'' is inherent in the material. Casting decisions on bad or forgotten movies seem trivial decades later.

title: LURING SLAMON TO THE ISLAND'S WATERS
description: WITHIN three or four years, Long Islanders for the first time may be able to see migrating Atlantic salmon leave the sea and ascend a local stream.

title: WHERE THE BOOM BEGAN
description: ''BUT FIRST A SCHOOL'' The First Fifty Years of the School of American Ballet. By Jennifer Dunning. Illustrated. 242 pp. New York: Elisabeth Sifton Books/Viking. $20. BALANCHINE Photo Album and Memoir. Photographs by Steven Caras. A Memoir by Peter Martins. 64 pp. New York: Rizzoli. Paper, $14.95.

title: CLETICS BEAT KNICKS AS EWING RETURNS
description: Kevin McHale says the Boston Celtics have been together so long that they take their skills for granted. It took Bill Walton, one of the newest members of the team, to make him understand just how difficult it was to play against the towering Celtic front line.

title: A PERSONAL TRIBUTE TO THE LORE OF SUBMARINES
description: THE Navy's new museum in Groton honoring the submarine Nautilus will not open until spring, but anyone who wants to begin boning up on submarines would do well to drop by Bernard Bastura's house in Middletown.

title: WE NEED NO MYTHS TO TELL OUR STORY
description: MISTAKING hoopla for history can be the sorry outcome of any well-meaning festival of heritage. Yet, Connecticut's ongoing 350th anniversary progresses without any undue gilding of the mountain laurel, our ubiquitous state blossom. Restraint is not really surprising on ground hallowed by generations of ''steady habits.''

title: FIGHTING AMONG MOSLEMS RAGES IN BEIRUT STREETS
description: Druse and Moslem Shiite militiamen battled with tanks and mortars in West Beirut today, defying a cease-fire on the fourth day of street battles that have killed 52 people and wounded 225.

title: NEW INQUIRY ON ATHENS AIRPORT IS SET
description: The Athens airport, the security of which was strongly criticized by Washington after hijackers boarded a T.W.A. airliner there earlier this year, is to come under renewed investigation as the starting point of another hijacking.

title: THE MYTH MAKER
description: I felt a wave of nostalgia, reading the excerpt from E. L. Doctorow's ''World's Fair.''

title: FATE OF RARE OPEN SPACE DEBATED IN ESSEX
description: IN Essex County, which contains the state's largest city as well as several of the country's most densely populated urban areas, open space commands respect. Parkland is comparatively rare and jealously guarded, and encroachments are fiercely resisted.

title: A NAVAJO WEAVER IN NEW JERSEY
description: THE serious production today of traditional native American artifacts is a phenomenon that is not usually viewed within the mainstream of contemporary crafts.

title: CABARET: FRANKIE MANN
description: IN overflow crowd filled Roulette (228 West Broadway) Friday night for a concert of music by Frankie Mann. Roulette, a loft space owned and operated by two composers, has become one of New York's premiere venues for new and unusual music, and Miss Mann's concert, while lightweight, made for an amusing evening.

title: ON THE ROAD TO MEXICO CITY
description: If you decide it would be fun to see Mexico close up and make plans to tour the country by car, be prepared to have friends, family and casual acquaintances react to the idea with alarm. Most people carry on in a jocular way about bandits and potholes and cows and goats, and other hazards of the Mexican roads. Others will more earnestly warn of the dangers, retelling a vaguely remembered story about a tourist who encountered troubles in a sojourn on Mexico's highways.

title: WRITING LESSONS IN BALTIMORE
description: DO the people who run Baltimore's public schools ever have a nice day? Several weeks ago, it was disclosed that the system had hired teachers with literacy problems because of a shortage. Now the schools are struggling to overcome students' writing deficiencies.

title: ITHACA TOPS UNION
description: A reserve quarterback, Mike Middaugh, passed for two fourth-quarter touchdowns to Pete Minturn to give Ithaca a 13-12 victory over Union in a Division III playoff game. The second touchdown came with 35 seconds remaining and capped a 12-play, 68-yard drive to send Ithaca (9-1) to the East Regional final Saturday against Montclair State.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE MAMMOTH HUNTERS. By Jean M. Auel. (Crown, $19.95.) This is the third in the ''Earth's Children'' series about Ayla - the brilliant, beautiful, blond cavewoman.

title: SCHOOL LIBRARIES TERMED IN TROUBLE
description: Gerald Ford is President of the United States, and the space shuttle is still on the drawing boards. With hardly a new book purchased since 1975, such is the state of knowledge available in the libraries of many New York public elementary schools.

title: SARAH MCC. REX TO WED IN APRIL
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Rex of Darien, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sarah McCune Rex, to John Norton Geary, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John C. Geary of Suffield, Conn. An April wedding is planned.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: COLD DOG SOUP. By Stephen Dobyns. (Viking, $15.95.) ''Cold Dog Soup,'' while often a clever, intriguing and verbally playful novel (its author is also a poet and mystery writer), seems to have been constructed to put off its readers.

title: AROUND THE WORLD IN TWO HOURS?
description: Federal officials involved in defense and aerospace research dreamed aloud last week about a plane that would fly at the edge of space 10 or 20 times faster than the speed of sound.

title: MONTREAL
description: A waggish Montrealer once described his hometown as having nine months of winter and three months of poor skating. It is true that winter in Montreal is more severe than in almost any other major North American city, but Montrealers compensate by finding lots to do indoors and out; wintertime activities can range from fine dining and cultural displays and performances to skating.

title: CONNECTICUT
description: To the Editor: Nancy Jenkins's article ''Along the Connecticut Shore'' (Travel, Sept. 29) although short, was an informative survey of some of the history and attractions of this part of our state, especially the Mystic area. Visitors might also want to know of another place of interest, a church called St. Mary, Top of Fort Hill.

title: TWO U.S. EXPERTS EXCITED BY FIND
description: The discovery of 90 lines of verse attributed to William Shakespeare was greeted by excitement yesterday by two Shakespearean scholars in the United States.

title: Man in the News;   IN PURSUIT OF THE BARD: GARY LYNN TAYLOR
description: ''I didn't actually plan to discover this poem when I started looking for work,'' said Gary Taylor. But only days after making his discovery - a nine-stanza love lyric that appears to be the first addition to Shakespeare's canon since the 17th century -he already knows he will always be identified with it, and it with him.

title: BOOK HUNT
description: Farbrengen. The word means get-together in Yiddish, and it is what the Y.M.-Y.W.H.A. of Southern Westchester is holding Sunday afternoon, from 1 to 4 o'clock.

title: GRAND VEFOUR
description: To the Editor: Susan Heller Anderson's lovely profile of Grand Vefour (Travel, Aug. 11) stirs in me memories similar to those recounted by numerous correspondents who find nostalgia in the Travel section.

title: 'PARADISE LOST' AT HUDSON RIVER MUSEUM
description: ONE of the Hudson River Museum's most significant holdings is a full-length white marble sculpture by Hiram Powers called ''Eve Disconsolate.'' For more than 15 years this blinding white work has stood in one of the period rooms of the museum's Trevor Mansion, one of the wings. But through Jan. 26, the sculpture is the centerpiece of a small but engaging exhibition on the theme of ''Paradise Lost'' in the 19th century as expressed through Powers's work. More mundane facts about the regimen of a successful artist in those days are also brought to light.

title: MARKETING THE PROFESSIONS
description: ''WE had perfected one art for the first 65 years of our existence - the art of anonymity.''

title: DANCE: KAZUO OHNO
description: KAZUO OHNO summoned up ghosts on Friday night at the Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Avenue. The spirit he tried hardest to reach was that of La Argentina, who at her death in 1936 was considered the leading Spanish dancer of her day.

title: DR. JAMES J. NICKSON
description: Dr. James Joseph Nickson, a former chairman of the department of radiation therapy at the Sloan-Kettering Institute for Cancer Research in New York City, died Friday at his home in Walpole, N.H. He was 69 years old.

title: Q AND A
description: Question:We plan to fly to Zurich in May and from there travel by train to Vienna and again from Vienna to Venice. Where on the way should we stop? - R. M. F., Jackson, Wyo. Answer:Many Austrians would agree that Innsbruck and Salzburg make the best stops on the 535-mile run from Zurich to Vienna. (If no break is taken, the journey takes close to 10 hours.) The ride to Innsbruck, Austria, with the Alps rising on both sides of the valley, is one of the most scenic routes in Europe. Innsbruck itself offers a legendary setting: the street called the Maria-Theresienstrasse seems to run into the steep slopes of the Nordkette mountain, which rises to 7,657 feet. The city is the cultural and tourist capital of the Tyrol. Salzburg, too, is much admired for its attractive setting and historic sites. Its stands at the foot of the Hohensalzburg, the medieval stronghold of the prince-archbishops who ruled the region. Guided tours of the castle are available. Other attractions include the house where Mozart was born. Another old city on the route is Linz, built on both sides of the Danube, but since it is only 100 miles from Vienna, it may not make such a convenient break in the journey.

title: THE AWARDS AND REWARDS OF BEING A SCIENTIST
description: IF all goes according to schedule, Betsy M. Sutherland of Wading River will find herself in Washington tomorrow making history.

title: SAVING 'THE LAST SUPPER'
description: In Curtis Bill Pepper's article ''Saving 'The Last Supper' '' (Oct. 13), Father Angelo Caccin is quoted as calling any eucharistic interpretation of Leonardo's ''Last Supper'' ''ridiculous.'' His insistence on an exclusively dramatic reading of the event - 12 men in reaction to Christ's announcement of the betrayal - has a long tradition behind it, a tradition that includes even Rembrandt, whose several variations on Leonardo's picture further dramatize the event. But there is a countertradition: In Rubens's close rendering of Leonardo's mural, preserved in a large etching bearing Rubens's name and copyright, the table is cleared so as to leave only a loaf and chalice in front of the Christ; below is the legend, ''Take, eat, this is my body. . . .'' In other words, Rubens found that the entire presentation, including all the gestures of the Apostles, might be interpreted as reactions to the institution of the eucharist. LEO STEINBERG New York City

title: WOMAN IN KIWANIS TOUCHES OFF SUIT
description: Kiwanis International, with 8,200 clubs and 300,000 members worldwide, could be destroyed by the decision of its Ridgewood affiliate to admit a 45-year-old woman as a member, lawyers for the organization argued in Federal court this week.

title: FORMER C.I.A. AIDE IS HELD ON CHARGES OF SPYING FOR CHINA
description: A retired analyst for the Central Intelligence Agency was charged today with selling American secrets to China for more than 30 years.

title: GOING DOWN THE TUBE
description: AMUSING OURSELVES TO DEATH Public Discourse in the Age of Show Business. By Neil Postman. 184 pp. New York: Elisabeth Sifton Books/Viking. $15.95.

title: MARK TWAIN AND HALLEY'S COMET
description: Mark Twain and Halley's Comet will share honors on a 36-cent aerogramme to be issued Dec. 4 by the United States Postal Service. The aerogramme commemorates the 150th anniversary of the birth of Samuel Langhorne Clemens, who adopted the pseudonym Mark Twain. It will have its first day of issue in his hometown, Hannibal, Mo.

title: PRIVATE INSURANCE IN MEDICARE PROPOSAL
description: The Reagan Administration will soon propose changes in the Medicare program to encourage beneficiaries to use Federal funds to sign up for private insurance offered by Blue Cross and Blue Shield or by commercial insurance companies.

title: FROM THE BIBLE, A WEALTH OF WORDS
description: THIS week has been designated the 45th annual National Bible Week, and anyone who is not a doubting Thomas can read the handwriting on the wall and conclude that the Bible is inescapably a part of our everyday language.

title: DIARY OF A CANCER PATIENT
description: Last June, Nathan Perlmutter, national director of the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith, was told by his family physician, Dr. Elias R. Stoller, that he had lung cancer, a disease that is almost always fatal. For nearly two months he kept a diary, but stopped after X-rays showed the cancer's growth had been arrested. ''Maybe the upbeat news relaxed the drama in my head and eased my need for an attentive, unquestioning confidant - my diary,'' Mr. Perlmutter says. ''Maybe though, it was something else. Maybe stunned by the positive biopsy, the sheer act of talking with myself assisted my self-control. And now, 'accustomed' to my cancer, like people who adapt to living by live volcanoes, the drama has ebbed and my fascination with my stranger self too.'' In his entries, Mr. Perlmutter, author of three books and many articles on social issues, reflects on his medical experiences, his friendships, and his relationship with his wife of 42 years, Ruth, and their children, Nina and Dean.

title: PROMOTING THE PRACTICE WITH BYLINES
description: ONCE a month, Dr. David K. Emerson, a physician in Omaha, sends out letters containing health tips or the schedules for immunization shots. He hopes his patients will clip tidbits from the letters and paste them on their refrigerators or in some other highly visible spot, where they could serve as a ''reminder'' to call him for regular checkups as well as just when they are ill.

title: SNOW HONDERS DEER HUNT IN NEW HAMPSHIRE
description: THE four inches of wet snow that fell the night before we reached our log cabin hideout in the valley of the Dead Diamond River augured well for the success of our annual deer hunting trip to this remote area of northeastern New Hampshire.

title: COURT RULES ON MALPRACTICE FEES
description: Sometimes, what the Supreme Court does not say is as important as what it does say. That may be the case with its decision last week to uphold a California law limiting the fees paid to lawyers who win medical malpractice suits.

title: THE WORLD AHEAD
description: In dwelling on the potential problems of raising black children colorblind in predominantly white neighborhoods, Mr. Morgan overlooked the value of having an entire generation of white children growing up experiencing the black culture firsthand. Surely, such experience will go a long way toward eliminating the elusive and subtle racism of the present generation. LAURA A. CECERE Abingdon, Va.

title: TASTING TURKEY AND FREEDON
description: THANKSGIVING 1940 was celebrated long ago, but of all the Thanksgivings that have come and gone, it will always remain my very favorite, and for a very good reason - it was my first.

title: THE QUALITY OF MERCY
description: To the Editor:

title: AT YALE, ALL THE WORLD'S A STAGE
description: YALE UNIVERSITY is bursting at its seams with theater. On almost any weekend during the school year, a potential theatergoer can see a play not only on the university's two main stages, but also in such untraditional spaces as dining halls, art galleries, libraries and even squash courts.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: NATA By Helen V. Griffith. Illustrated by Nancy Tafuri. 23 pp. New York: Greenwillow Books. $11.75. (Ages 2 to 5) WHATEVER adult fears that exist about a child's introduction to fairy tales - whether it is the goriness of some stories or the sexual stereotyping of passive princesses who must wait while heroic males do battle - at varying points in a child's development there is an appetite, perhaps even a need, for fairy tales. No other literature is as fierce or as eloquent in capturing our most primal fears and desires.

title: NEWS CASSETTES: FROM LATE CHAPLIN TO ANNA RUSSELL
description: White City: Pete Townshend Vestron MusicVideo 60 minutes. $29.95. ''White City: Pete Townshend'' is a brave attempt, but only partly by the former leader of the Who, to fuse video and rock music into a semi-autobiographical memory play.

title: An Oil Barge off L.I. Sinks, Causing Slick
description: A 240-foot barge sank Friday in Long Island Sound with 840,000 gallons of oil on board, forming a two-mile slick between Fishers Island and the eastern tip of Long Island, Coast Guard officials said today.

title: Penelope Fitzgerald's Works
description: To the Editor:

title: MARY SUSCA, A LAWYER, PLANS TOMARRY IN MAY
description: Dr. and Mrs. Louis A. Susca of Jamaica Estates, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter Mary Jane Susca to Anthony Michael Sabino, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Vito Sabino of Brooklyn. The wedding is planned for May.

title: PRIVATE SECTOR TAKES A LARGER ROLE IN HELPING HANDICAPPED
description: Steven Camhi dived into the shallow end of a swimming pool on Long Island five years ago and broke his neck. He was rushed to the hospital, but the damage was done - he was paralyzed from the neck down.

title: PENN STATE ROUTS PITT TO STAY UNBEATEN
description: Penn State, Orange Bowl-bound and determined to remove the tarnish of a humbling loss to Pitt last season, advanced one step closer to a national championship tonight by routing the Panthers, 31-0.

title: STUDENTS PLAYING A ROLE IN HIGH-TECH EFFORT
description: THE mission of the New Jersey Commission on Science and Technology to transform the state's economy by encouraging high-technology businesses is based on the premise that the brain power will be available when needed.

title: REAGAN STRESSES 'STAR WARS' PLAN
description: President Reagan said today that Mikhail S. Gorbachev had not achieved his ''main aim'' in Geneva, to force an end to the space-based missile defense program.

title: Barbara J. Willmarth Becomes a Bride
description: Barbara Jane Willmarth, a vice president of the Citicorp Investment Bank in New York, and Edward William Callahan, the vice president of health, safety and environmental sciences for Allied-Signal Inc. in Morristown, N.J., were married yesterday. The Rev. Thomas D. Bowers performed the ceremony at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in New York.

title: IT'S TOUGH TO GET AN OUT IN, AND VICE VERSA
description: ALTHOUGH the New Year is still six weeks away, the 1986 political year has already begun to take shape in the region. The combination of large campaign war chests, thriving local economies and aggressive television image-building by public officials is likely to make it the year of the incumbent.

title: THE SUMMIT -- SOMETHING OF A SUCCESS
description: Neither Ronald Reagan nor Mikhail S. Gorbachev left Geneva disappointed. Still, nothing of real substance was accomplished at the meeting. The agreements signed there are of marginal significance. So why do both governments claim success? Because superpower relations are different from ordinary diplomacy. Meetings between rivals, unlike those between friends, do not always aim above all to reach agreements.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: SHOWING THE FLAG ''IT'S a matter of recognition,'' said Anne Fegley of Yaphank. ''It's time we senior citizens have our own symbol.''

title: Balanchine's Legacy And Eglevsky's
description: In an otherwise very interesting article [''Role Reversal in New Ballet Poses Challenge to Dancers,'' Oct. 20] , I was dismayed by the comment by my old friend Frank Ohman suggesting that George Balanchine felt that with ''Andre Eglevsky out of the picture,'' no professional dance school existed on Long Island.

title: FEIFFER RESHAPES HIS 'GROWN UPS' FOR THE SMALL SCREEN
description: What is the interpretive power of television?

title: SENSATIONS OF BEING ALIVE
description: STILL LIFE By Antonia Byatt. 384 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons. $16.95.

title: 'WAR' GAME DRAWS PROTEST FROM TOWN
description: ''TROOPS'' garbed in camouflage regalia who have been stalking each other in the woods of Ellington for the past month have raised protests from some local officials and residents upset by these weekend warriors.

title: NEWS CASSETTES: FROM LATE CHAPLIN TO ANNA RUSSELL
description: A King in New York Starring Charles Chaplin, Dawn Addams, Oliver Johnson and Michael Chaplin; written, produced, directed and scored by Charles Chaplin, 1957 Playhouse Video 104 minutes, $29.98 Though released in Europe in 1957, ''A King in New York'' - Charles Chaplin's bitter effort to satirize the McCarthyist spirit that had tarred him in 1952 - did not open in the United States until 1973.

title: TARA B. FLANNERY BECOMES A BRIDE
description: At St. Vincent Ferrer Roman Catholic Church in New York yesterday Tara Bridget Flannery, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph J. Flannery of Palm Beach, Fla., was married to Francis Xavier Gallagher Jr., a son of Mrs. Joseph T. Michels of Baltimore and the late Mr. Gallagher. The Rev. J. Joseph Gallagher, uncle of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony.

title: TRYING TO SURMOUNT A MOVIE
description: MOVIE memories can be as intimidating as they are irreplacable. For example, no one can forget the triumphant Katharine Hepburn-Cary Grant-James Stewart triumvirate in ''The Philadelphia Story'' of 1940.

title: FOR SUSHI LOVERS, GOOD VARIETY
description: PROOF of Stamford's increasingly diverse restaurant scene is the latest arrival: a Japanese sushi bar called Kotobuki.

title: TOXINS A CONCERN IN NORTH TARRYTOWN
description: TOXIC wastes generated at Duracell's former battery-manufacturing plant in North Tarrytown have become a concern among residents living in the tree-lined neighborhood around the factory.

title: SELLING THEMSELVES
description: A SPIFFY LITtle storefront wine shop opened recently on Third Avenue and 67th Street in Manhattan. That in itself is not news. What is, however, is who opened it - Wagner Vineyards, a highly regarded winery in the Finger Lakes region of upstate New York - and what transpires there. In this store, for the first time since Prohibition was enacted in 1919, customers can taste some of the wines for sale before deciding which to buy. What's more, the two-month-old store cum tasting bar is open on Sundays, and purchases can be made with credit cards.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: FAMOUS PEOPLE I HAVE KNOWN. Ed McClanahan. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $13.95.) Before Vietnam, Woodstock, Watergate or Charles Manson, ''we had the swellest parties'' writes Ed McClanahan.

title: 17,000 PLAINTIFFS
description: OUTRAGEOUS MISCONDUCT The Asbestos Industry on Trial. By Paul Brodeur. 374 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $19.95.

title: PROJECT RAISING SCHOOL ATTENDANCE
description: A NEW state program designed to reverse severe attendance problems in a number of state school districts, including 30 on Long Island, is showing promising results, officials say.

title: HIGH-TECH FORESTS AND TREES
description: OUR company was formed, and eventually acquired by the Lockheed Corporation, long before anyone was talking about high technology. You might say that we reached the point we're at today the old-fashioned way: We worked for it.

title: POLITICAL REVERSALSHUMANISM, HUMANITIES
description: It's hardly surprising that a Senate committee voted 8 to 7 to reject the appointment of Edward Curran as chairman of the National Endowment for the Humanities. The surprise is that he was even nominated.

title: A COLLOQUY TO CALM A NUCLEAR AGE
description: FEW have accused Mikhail S. Gorbachev of being sentimental or prey to what Leninists call ''subjectivism.'' But for a moment last week one of the world's two most powerful citizens sounded like any ordinary mortal who feels comforted when the Soviet Union and the United States are talking to each other instead of shouting at each other.

title: RACIAL VIOLENCE FLARES AGAIN IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: Racial anger again reached the flashpoint in South Africa last week. At least 36 people were killed in some of the worst violence since the Government imposed emergency restrictions in July.

title: CHANGE OF PACE
description: FOR THE LAST 15 YEARS, GWATH-mey Siegel & Associates Architects has been the Pied Piper of an architectural style known for its dramatic sculptural forms and sleek open spaces articulated by white walls, glass brick and classic modern furniture.

title: Navy Tests Cruise Missile
description: An unarmed Tomahawk cruise missile was launched Friday from a Navy ship in the Pacific Ocean to a Mojave Desert military base in a test of the weapon, a spokesman said. The Navy withheld most details of the test, including the length of its flight and whether it hit a target or was allowed to parachute to the ground.

title: OILERS' NAPIER HELPS DEFEAT DEVILS, 3-2
description: Mark Napier scored the game-winning goal at 7 minutes 17 seconds of the second period tonight as the Edmonton Oilers defeated the Devils, 3-2.

title: CATHERINE CHEUNG WEDS A. P. MOON
description: St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Catherine M. K. Cheung, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Yu-Keun Chang of Hong Kong, to Alexander P. Moon, a son of Bernadette Moon of Los Angeles and the late Ignatius B. Moon. The Rev. Paul E. Dinter performed the Roman Catholic ceremony.

title: Preferred Treatment Of Foreign Guests
description: I must say that Penny Stamm's way of treating her Chinese friend from Beijing was inconsiderate, to say the least [''A Friend From China Finds Simple Pleasure,'' Opinion Page, Nov. 3] . Who wants to be invited as a guest, ending up pulling weeds in his ''pin-striped pants and shiny black shoes,'' running errands and digging up 36 holes in the backyard for planting? As a member of the United States-China People's Friendship Association, Mrs. Stamm must be quite knowledgeable about Chinese culture. Mr. Hu might be too gracious to refuse or say anything, as Chinese are taught; I bet he felt insulted and being taken advantage of.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: CLASSICAL ILLUSIONS. By Jascha Kessler. (McPherson, $14.95.) This volume of short fiction is a collective odyssey of the contemporary ruling class, with places as varied as Los Angeles, southern France and Central America the equivalents of classical settings.

title: TRUE VIRTUE
description: THE LANGUAGE, IF MY RECENT EX-perience be any guide, badly needs a new word. The word needed is one to describe those people who are extremely confident about their own virtue and whose spectacular confidence nicely feeds their general feeling of superiority. They are superior to me, or so they have made plain, and they are probably superior to you, if only you will give them the opportunity to demonstrate it. The people I have in mind have a superiority complex; they are completely convinced of their own moral superiority. I think of them as ''virtucrats,'' for they are empowered by the unfaltering sense of their own virtue.

title: 'Politics of Race' At Stony Brook
description: An article in the Long Island Weekly section on Oct. 13 [''Protests Grow on Tenure Denial at Stony Brook''] dealt with the controversy regarding Dr. Ernest Dube, a South African black who conducts a course called ''The Politics of Race'' at the State University of New York at Stony Brook.

title: TWISTS AT THE SUMMIT: INSIDE THE GENEVA TALKS
description: In the predawn hours before President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev left Geneva on Thursday, American officials grew concerned about the outcome of the summit meeting and devised a ''blow-up scenario'' to limit political damage in case the meeting collapsed at the final ceremony.

title: ALAYNE LANDERS WEDS JOHN ANTHONY MURPHY
description: At St. Catherine of Siena Roman Catholic Church in Riverside, Conn., yesterday Alayne Catherine Landers, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Leo A. Landers of Stamford, Conn., was married to John Anthony Murphy, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Kevin L. Murphy of Rocky Hill, N.J. The Rev. Robert J. Starrett performed the ceremony Dr. Doreen Landers Weller was matron of honor for her sister. Jeffrey Dorsk was best man.

title: SKYWARD
description: SOMEWHERE, out in space, is Halley's Comet. Somewhere, 58 million miles away, it begins to glow silver as it nears the sun and our planet. Somewhere, sometimes, people here can see it.

title: SELECTIONS FOR THE GIFT-LIST
description: THIS year, as an alternative to selecting between bottles of red and white for oenophiles on your holiday gift list, consider one of the many wine accessory items available at area shops.

title: ISRAELIS DOWN TWO SYRIAN MIG'S
description: Several times a week, Israeli fighters take off on reconnaissance missions over Lebanon. And whenever that happens, the Syrians scramble several MIG's to watch them.

title: DEATH OF A SPORTS DEITY
description: YOU already knew this, but the ancient Greeks were smart. Their gods had human qualities, human foibles, so that ordinary mortals could feel a kinship with - take their lessons from - deities capable of jealousy, anger and fear, as well as more noble qualities.

title: ADVICE TO GIANTS: USE IMAGINATION
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: G.O.P. CHIEF FACING INQUIRY
description: THE Senate Judiciary Committee plans to invite Frank B. Holman, the Republican state chairman, to its Dec. 5 meeting to answer charges that he tried to force a Republican Assembly candidate to drop out of the recent election by threatening to block her appointment to the State Board of Education.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: THE Year of the Environment is not over yet, and the lame-duck Legislature has until noon on Jan. 14 to act on several important bills. If the measures are not approved, their sponsors will have to start fresh in the next two-year term, when Republicans control the Assembly. (Democrats will still control the Senate.) Following are some of the most significant measures and where they stand:

title: WHY THE PHILIPPINES IS MAKING ITS NEIGHBORS NERVOUS
description: For the noncommunist nations of Southeast Asia, trouble in the Philippines is trouble in the family. No ally of President Ferdinand Marcos within the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, to which the Philippines belongs along with Indonesia, Singapore, Malaysia, Brunei and Thailand, will publicly criticize a fellow member of Asean. That is not their style.

title: LINE BY LINE, THROUGH SHAKESPEAREAN RICHES
description: ''Playing Shakespeare,'' the nine-part series seen in New York on WNYC-TV, Channel 31, is eloquent in at least three areas - as a close-line examination of the art of Shakespeare, as a masterful use of television in understanding live performance and dramatic poetry and as a workshop in actor appreciation. Created by the director, John Barton, in collaboration with an ensemble of actors from the Royal Shakespeare Company, the series is designed to remove the mystique and awe that can surround Shakespeare and isolate him from a contemporary audience. The program, continuing on Monday nights at 9, through Dec. 16, could be subtitled, ''Shakespeare Without Fears.'' In New York, Monday is traditionally an off night for theater. This season, that is no longer true.

title: ARTIST-HOUSING TENANTS ARE PLIT ON CO-OP PLAN
description: A proposal to convert a housing complex for artists to cooperative ownership as the only means of meeting almost $3 million in delinquent mortgage payments and avoiding possible foreclosure has sharply divided tenants in the center in Greenwich Village.

title: PISTONS TRIUMPH OVER 76ERS
description: The guard Vinnie Johnson came off the bench to score 25 points and Kelly Tripucka collected 17 of his 19 points in the second half as the Detroit Pistons beat the Philadelphia 76ers tonight, 119-114.

title: AN EYE ON '88
description: Alexander M. Haig Jr., who served 18 months as Secretary of State for President Reagan and as White House Chief of Staff for former President Nixon, indicated last week that he may consider making a run in 1988 to become President Haig. After his booking agent said he expected Mr. Haig to seek the Republican Presidential nomination, the former Secretary of State indicated that he expects to be ''increasingly active politically,'' but he added that ''it is too early to talk about '88.'' Mr. Haig said through an aide that he would not announce his intentions until after next year's Congressional elections. A career military officer, Mr. Haig now serves as a consultant to corporations and is a senior fellow at the Hudson Institute in Washington, a policy research organization.

title: How the Senators Voted on Farm Bill
description: Following is the roll-call vote by which the Senate passed its version of the 1985 farm bill today:

title: YALE'S DEFENSE STYMIES HARVARE, 17-6
description: The Yale team that was supposed to be such a a decisive winning one this season emerged in its final game today and upset Harvard, 17-6, before a crowd of 57,647 at the Yale Bowl.

title: A STRONGER CHAIRMAN
description: Brushing aside Administration objections, the House voted overwhelmingly last week to strengthen the hand of the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff by making him the principal purveyor of military advice to the President and other top Government leaders.

title: HEIDI BRINE WED TO PAUL E. STEIGER
description: Heidi Schwarzbauer Brine, a senior vice president of Herzfeld & Stern, a securities firm in New York, was married yesterday to Paul Ernest Steiger, a deputy managing editor of The Wall Street Journal. The Rev. Susan Harriss performed the ceremony at St. James' Episcopal Church in New York.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: PEOPLE WHO KNOCK ON THE DOOR. By Patricia Highsmith. (Penzler Books, $15.95.) The gods seem to be napping in this master storyteller's new suspense novel.

title: LEADING LINEMEN
description: The field for the Lombardi Award, honoring the best college lineman of the year, has been reduced to four finalists. The selection committee for the Rotary Club of Houston announced that the quartet consisted of Tony Casillas, a nose guard from Oklahoma; Mike Hammerstein, a defensive tackle from Michigan; Leslie O'Neal, a defensive tackle from Oklahoma State; and Mike Ruth, a nose guard from Boston College. The winner will be receive a trophy, a 40-pound block of granite, on Dec. 4 at a dinner in Houston that will benefit the American Cancer Society.

title: CORRECTION
description: A caption Nov. 10 accompanying an article about Boston incorrectly described the skyline pictured. The skyline was that of Cambridge, Mass., viewed from across the Charles River in Boston.

title: Cable TV
description: ''These Three'' (1936), a Showtime film presentation this week on Friday at 10 A.M., is a durable Hollywood beauty that must be seen, at least once. This is Lillian Hellman's own adaptation of her somber Broadway hit, ''The Children's Hour,'' about an evil child's accusation of Lesbianism against two teachers and its destruction of their school and lives. With the calumny theme triangularized (for screen censorship), the story lost none of its power. ''These Three'' proved to be rounded, skillful, sensitive and superb, with an exceptional cast headed by Miriam Hopkins, Merle Oberon, Joel McCrea and the young Bonita Granville. It was wondrously directed by William Wyler. The best performance of all? Little Marcia Mae Jones, as a frail, terrified student.

title: WARD WALLAU WED TO MISS WAYMAN
description: Elizabeth Wayman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Bentley Wayman of Wayland, Mass., and Charles Ward Wallau, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Lee Wallau 2d of Riverside, Conn., were married yesterday. The Rev. Joseph Amato performed the ceremony at Our Lady of the Isle Roman Catholic Church in Nantucket, Mass.

title: UP IN MICHIGAN
description: A neighbor was driving the newlyweds through northern Michigan to the train station. The car crested a hill, and suddenly Little Traverse Bay spread out below them, wide and blue and shining. ''See all that,'' Ernest Hemingway told his bride. ''Talk about the beauty of the Bay of Naples! I've seen them both, and no place is more beautiful than Little Traverse in its autumn colors.''

title: REMEMBER MISS LIBERTY'S FRENCH COUSINS
description: To the Editor:

title: BOUNDARY QUARREL
description: CALIFORNIA said that surveyors had made a mistake in 1868-69, and that as a result its border with Oregon should be a quarter of a mile north of where it is now drawn.

title: WOLDENBERG TO MARRY IN JUNE
description: Dr. and Mrs. David H. Woldenberg of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter Rona Fern Woldenberg to Dr. Burt Greenberg, a son of Joyce Winson of Woodbury, L.I., and the late Dr. Gerald Greenberg. The wedding is planned for June.

title: MUSIC: FINNISH TRIBUTE
description: THE Columbia University Orchestra's ''Concert for Finland'' Thursday night was an elegantly conceived American tribute to that country. At its root was the ''Kalevala,'' a collection of poems published 150 years ago that has come to represent Finland's mythic past and its sense of self today. The Kalevala was served by two composers in this concert at St. Peter's Church (at Lexington Ave. and 54th St.): by Jean Sibelius, Finland's resident creative hero during his long life, and by one of the country's musical wanderers, Charles Wuorinen, the American composer of Finnish descent.

title: HISTORIC QUARTER OF AUGSBURG
description: Augsburg, in Bavaria, abounds with tourist attractions that are legacies and reminiscences of its two most famous families, the Fuggers and the Welsers. Visitors can see their palaces and mansions, their churches and private chapels as well as seemingly omnipresent monuments during a walking tour of the 2,000-year-old Swabian town, 42 miles north of Munich.

title: PUBLISHER IS WED TO AMY S. DAVIES
description: At Union Presbyterian Church in Newburgh, N.Y., yesterday Amy Sarah Davies, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John D. Davies of Newburgh, was married to William M. Doolittle Jr., a son of Mr. Doolittle of Lakeville, Conn., and the late Mary Hill Ingersoll of Charlottesville, Va. The Rev. Robert Martin performed the ceremony.

title: COLUMBIA COLLEGE HONORS ITS FORMER DEANS
description: All of Columbia College's living deans, past and present, gathered last week in the Low Library rotunda, where the five former deans were honored for ''a life given to caring for others,'' in the words of Robert E. Pollack, the current dean.

title: Paper Goalie
description: FOR his books to succeed, George Plimpton must fail. It would not do for him to actually triumph at what he calls participatory journalism. Everyman cannot become Superman.

title: NEW SAAB: STYLE AND SPEED
description: IF you remember those funny little Saabs from the 60's, aberrant cars with asthmatic V-4's and burbling two-cycle powerplants that had to have oil added to the gas, the company's newest offering serves to show just how far automotive technology has come.

title: THE KOCH RESHUFFLE
description: Mayor Koch was touring in Japan last week, but that didn't prevent him from doing a little housecleaning at City Hall.

title: FIGURING THE TAXES ON FRINGE BENEFITS
description: IF the recent stock market rally has helped you reap handsome capital gains on some well-chosen securities, or if your company has provided you with a Mercedes that you also use for weekend jaunts, or if substantial outside income means that part of your Social Security retirement benefits are now taxable, you may be among the thousands of people who need to review their estimated tax status promptly.

title: MODERNISM REAFFIRMS ITS POWER
description: ''The fact that many so-called modern architects still go around practicing a trade as if it were alive can be taken as one of the great curiosities of our age,'' the critic Charles Jencks wrote in 1977, for modern architecture, in his view, had already ''expired finally and completely.'' Mr. Jencks was not alone: numerous critics have spoken over the last decade of modernism's end, its collapse, its upheaval, its death. Whatever the favored metaphor, the message was the same - modern architecture's time is over.

title: LAND WHERE FOOTBALL BLOSSOMS IN THE SUN
description: MIAMI

title: LIVING HIGH IN WASHINGTON
description: THAT man hard at work on the scaffolding 165 feet above the rotunda floor of the Capitol in Washington is 69 years old and lives - would you believe it? - in a retirement community in Middlesex County.

title: SCHOOL SALES DISPUTED
description: TWO Huntington Town civic groups that have lost court efforts to force local school boards to retain closed school buildings plan to continue their battles.

title: A 'SOFT LANDING' FOR THE ECONOMY
description: On last week's report of a 4.3 percent increase in the gross national product from July through September, Administration economists were generally more optimistic than private analysts about the outlook for a faster growth ahead.

title: MEETING EXPLORES CREATIVE PROBLEM-SOLVING
description: THEIR backgrounds could not have been more diverse, but the 15 people who gathered at the New Rochelle home of Eleanor Wakin last weekend shared a common interest: creativity and creative problem-solving.

title: A PARKING BREAK AT HUNTINGTON STATION
description: LONG Island Rail Road commuters using the Huntington Village station this week will again be able to park within easy walking distance of the station, buy a newspaper and even have time to gulp down a cup of coffee before boarding trains. This is because the town plans to reopen the three nearby parking lots that have been closed since early summer.

title: HUGE RALLY IN BELFAST PROTESTS BRITISH-IRISH ACCORD
description: Tens of thousands of unionists who want Northern Ireland to stay British turned out for a huge rally in Belfast today to show their opposition to giving Dublin any say in their affairs.

title: STATE IMPOSES MORATORIUM ON HOSPITAL CONSTRUCTION
description: STATE regulators have imposed a nine-month freeze on hospital building and renovations so the state's Department of Health can revise the way it decides which projects are needed. Health Department officials say the changes are needed because of a steady decline in hospital use and a proposed Medicare cutback that will make it harder for hospitals to repay construction loans.

title: THE MAP OF LOVE
description: Years and years ago when Dylan Thomas was a child in Wales, few American tourists with wind-bussed cheeks and cherried noses came to visit at Christmas, certainly not tourists on a trip arranged by the Smithsonian Institution.

title: WILD OR TAME, NO SHORTAGE OF TURKEYS
description: BACK before Thanksgiving was a legal holiday (it was in 1863 that Lincoln set aside the last Thursday in November as ''a day for national thanksgiving, praise and prayer''), wild turkeys abounded in New Jersey's woodlands.

title: A JILTED PENNZOIL GETS ITS REVENGE
description: Texaco was told to pay $10.5 billion to Pennzoil for enticing Getty Oil to jilt Pennzoil in favor of a $10.1 billion bid from Texaco. The Houston jury's award, which is subject to revision by a judge, would be a record in a corporate court fight. Pennzoil claimed a victory for ''integrity'' in business; Texaco said it was confident it would win on appeal. Wall Street, which had not been taking the suit seriously, pushed Texaco's stock down while sending Pennzoil's shares soaring. The betting was that Texaco would eventually be writing a check to Pennzoil, but almost no one believed the ultimate settlement would be as high as $10.5 billion. Texaco's net worth is about $13.5 billion.

title: AESTHETICS AND COMPROMISES
description: THIS is the month my love-hate relationship with a coal-burning stove begins again.

title: MEMORIES WANTED FOR HISTORY OF ELLIS ISLAND
description: Along corridors that once echoed with the clamor of foreign tongues, only the purr of fans drying damp plaster breaks the silence now. A tangle of aluminum scaffolding hides the cavernous hall where millions of immigrants first encountered America.

title: ST. JOHN'S RECEIVES LIFT IN CONFIDENCE
