description: Moments after St. John's had rallied to defeat Navy, 66-58, Friday night, Coach Lou Carnesecca, Walter Berry, Ron Rowan and Mark Jackson appeared at a postgame news conference, looking drained, as if they'd just played for the Big East basketball championship.

title: MUSIC: LATIN AMERICAN
description: IT was an evening for Latin American composers at the Center for Inter-American Relations (Park Avenue and 68th Street) on Friday. And as usual with these kinds of new-music surveys, surprise and pleasure were interwoven with disappointment.

title: FIXING WOOD VENEER: BEAUTY IS ONLY SKIN DEEP
description: MANY older pieces of furniture were built with a thin veneer of hardwood laminated on the outside, usually to make it appear as though the entire piece was constructed of the same hardwood. This furniture is just as durable as pieces of solid wood and often closely rivals it in appearance.

title: THE 'GENTLE GIANT' TRIES AGAIN
description: To his colleagues, Terry Waite is known as ''the gentle giant.'' Given the towering, bearded Anglican lay worker's avocation - negotiating the release of hostages held by various Moslem factions - his imposing presence is no doubt an asset.

title: JUDGE BORK OFFERS ANOTHER VOTE FOR ORIGINAL INTENT
description: Robert H. Bork, a Federal appeals court judge often mentioned as a possible nominee for the Supreme Court, reiterated last week his longstanding criticism of judicial activists who drift from the ''original intent'' of those who wrote the Constitution and its amendments.

title: U.C.L.A. TO ROSE BOWL
description: Rodney Peete divied 1 yard with 73 seconds to play to give Southern Cal a 17-13 upset victory over U.C.L.A. (8-2-1 over all and 6-2 in the Pacific-10 Conference) that briefly jarred the Bruins' Rose Bowl chances. But Arizona State, which could have gained the berth with a tie or a victory tonight, was upset by Arizona after having led 13-3 in the third quarter.

title: PARIS HAS PLENTY TO READ (IN ENGLISH
description: There are surely as many good English-language bookstores in Paris as in all but a handful of cities in the United States. Whatever that may tell us about relative cultural priorities, it's also an indication of the American (and British) presence in Paris, the importance of American literature to literate Parisians and the large number of Americans visiting and living there.

title: BROTHERHOOD OF THE INEPT
description: PROBABLY IT RUNS IN THE family, this clumsiness, not as a river but at least as a stream enveloping one of us each generation. My father held on to a garage door handle after he had pulled it down. It slammed on his thumb. He fell off a bicycle and broke his arm. Once, when my mother threw a dress-up luncheon party in our backyard for his business colleagues, a tablecloth concealed a large irregularity on the edge of our rustic table. It was at this spot that my father, wearing a white suit, placed his plate of spaghetti with tomato sauce. It toppled into his lap. He changed into another white suit, sat down at the same place and spilled a second plate. Changing again upstairs, he dropped his pocket watch on the tile floor of the bathroom. It stopped.

title: THE ESSENCE OF THE MASTER
description: HENRY JAMES A Life. By Leon Edel. Illustrated. 740 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $24.95.

title: NEWS CASSETTES: FROM LATE CHAPLIN TO ANNA RUSSELL
description: Handel's 'Messiah' Starring Judith Nelson, Emma Kirkby, Carolyn Watkinson, Paul Elliott and David Thomas. The Academy of Ancient Music and Choir of Westminster Abbey conducted by Christopher Hogwood.

title: SHOWDOWN IN CANADA
description: A great East-West rivalry, unmatched in the history of the game, has developed during the past two years.

title: MARY FITZGERALD IS MARRIED TOHOWARD BELGER 3d
description: At St. Theresa's Roman Catholic Church in Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., yesterday Mary Elizabeth Fitzgerald, an associate decorating editor of Family Circle magazine, was married to Howard Joseph Belger 3d, a national account representative for MCI Telecommunications in New York. The Rev. Bernard Ahern performed the ceremony.

title: PROSPECTS
description: The Flip Side of Flops More than 58,000 businesses will shut down this year, a rise of 6 percent over 1984's failures. But Joseph W. Duncan, an economist at the Dun & Bradstreet Corporation, says the increase - the first since 1983 - is not necessarily bad news.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: WHERE SHE WAS. By Anderson Ferrell. (Knopf, $13.95.) Farm life has become fashionable again, to judge by movies such as ''Country'' and ''Places in the Heart,'' and by this precisely wrought first novel, ''Where She Was.''

title: HEALTH BEHAVIOR OF THE YOUNG IS STUDIED
description: RESEARCHERS at Rutgers University have been closely following the life patterns of 1,000 adolescents in five New Jersey school systems to determine how schools can encourage better health and safety habits that the children would carry with them through adulthood.

title: FOR SALVADOR REBELS, A WORLD APART
description: The four top commanders of the most powerful Salvadoran guerrilla faction sat for an evening recently in this small mountain village and talked of their war against the Salvadoran Government and the United States.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: NOTHING, it seems, is going to deter Myron Engelman from the completion of his appointed task.

title: A HARSH VIEW OF CITY SCHOOLS
description: More than 40 percent of New York City's 968 public schools are in the bottom 10 percent in the state on the basis of academic performance, according to the preliminary results of a State Department of Education evaluation. Of about 600 schools in the lowest category statewide, the study showed, more than two-thirds - 417 of them - are in the city.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Wrought-Iron Words As an Italian journalist, Luigi Barzini's father not only had to find a story - he had to invent a language to write it in. Mr. Barzini describes this predicament in ''O America: When You and I Were Young'' (Penguin).

title: WILL THE TANK SURVIVE?
description: FROM THE TEXAS HILLTOP, YOU could see the M-1 Abrams tanks moving to attack their targets under the harsh summer sun. Their pace was far faster than that of the tanks of a generation or even a decade ago. As they moved, the guns spoke. The barrels were steady as the vehicles moved at 40 miles an hour over broken ground. ''There she is,'' said Col. Benjamin W. Covington 3d, ''the best damn tank in the world.''

title: AN INSIDER'S VIEW OF MAFIA SECRETS
description: An important Mafia informer has completed his first public testimony, providing a colorful saga that seems more like a gangster movie than a court case.

title: VERMONT STRIVES TO KEEP UP A WINTER SAFETY NET FOR POOR
description: When the winds were up last winter Teja Leonard would wake in the morning to find drifts of snow in the hallway leading to her bathroom: The back door of the mobile home she rents was two inches too short.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: A. A. E. DISDERI AND THE CARTE DE VISITE PORTRAIT PHOTOGRAPH. By Elizabeth Anne McCauley. (Yale University, $30.) When Andre Adolphe Eugene Disderi patented the carte de visite - a small photograph about the size of a calling card - in 1854, he was thinking arithmetically rather than esthetically.

title: SONORITIES ALONE DO NOT SUFFICE
description: What is the connection, if any, between music and spoken or written language? That looks like a simple enough question, but theoreticians have been wrestling with it for centuries without pinning it to the mat. The late Deryck Cooke made a valiant start in ''The Language of Music,'' but his theories, tentative and arguable to begin with, did not pretend to extend beyond Western music of a traditional, tonal sort. Leonard Bernstein, who always can be depended upon to ride off on some quixotic quest, also tried to confront the issue in a series of talks at Harvard in 1976 but only managed to stir up resentment in both musical and linguistic circles with his attempt to apply Noam Chomsky's theories of transformational-generative grammar to music. The heat that his arguments generated on all sides suggested that Mr. Bernstein had taken up a larger subject than he could swallow, but he was chewing at a problem that, as a composer and practical musician, he knew to be a real one.

title: TRENTON SOUP KITCHEN IS A FOCUS OF CONTROVERSY
description: AS SOME 450 to 500 hungry and homeless people look forward to a pre-Thanksgiving Day feast of ham, turkey, sweet potatoes, green beans and cranberry sauce at the Trenton Area Soup Kitchen on Wednesday, a controversy is swirling around relocating the kitchen.

title: HEAD OF DARTMOUTH SAYS THAT SHANTIES ARE A PROPER PROTEST
description: A shantytown built on the Dartmouth College green by students and faculty members may stay there as a protest against the college's investments in companies that do business with South Africa, its president says.

title: DAWKINS THRIVING IN ROLE AS RESERVE
description: He is not exactly a new Darryl Dawkins, but he is different. The smile has returned, and so has the special enthusiasm he brings to the game. When someone asks why, Dawkins invariably offers a wide grin.

title: U.S. SAYS SOVIET COMPLIES ON SOME ARMS ISSUES
description: The Soviet Union has quietly taken steps to reduce some American concerns over purported arms-control violations, according to Administration officials.

title: Specter Delays Early Bid For State G.O.P. Backing
description: Senator Arlen Specter, faced with the possibility of a political embarrassment, today backed away from plans to force the Pennsylvania Republican Party to endorse him for re-election next year.

title: CRIME
description: The world of big-time gambling occupies the major part of THE WINNING STREAK by Arnold Grisman (St. Martin's, $15.95). Goldberg is the central character; no first name is ever given. Now nearly 60 years old, he was a football hero at Yale University before an injury ended his career. He is now tired and disillusioned - and a professional gambler who consistently wins. When he is ready to go on a winning streak, he knows he can't lose. A female friend suggests he must work through extrasensory perception.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: RAY-GUN SHOW About five years ago Tim Cunard, an art instructor at Williams College in Williamstown, Mass., bought a toy ray gun at a garage sale. ''It reminded me of my childhood in the 1950's,'' he said. Since then, he has accumulated a few more. ''I have more than 200,'' he said. At least half of them will be on display in his one-man Ray-Gun Show at the University of Connecticut at Storrs Monday through Dec. 6 in the Atrium Gallery of the art department.

title: ELIS DOMINATE IN LESSER GAMES
description: Even before the kickoff in the 102d Yale-Harvard varsity meeting today, Yale had come out ahead, 15 to 2, in the games they play as an overture to The Game.

title: GOVERNMENT'S ROLE
description: TWO of President Reagan's longstanding goals, reducing the regulatory burden and giving more responsibility to state and local officials, have come together in a new Administration proposal to exempt recipients of Federal grants and contracts from many of the laws and rules they must now obey as a condition of receiving money from Washington. Requirements that would be lifted range from the Clean Water Act to the Rehabilitation Act, which orders that public buildings and transportation be accessible to the handicapped.

title: STATE FIGHTING AIDS WITH INFORMATION
description: WITH neither a vaccine nor a cure in sight, public and private health care and social service agencies in Connecticut are fighting the spread of AIDS ''with the only tool we have available - education,'' said Dr. James L. Hadler, chief of the State Department of Health Services' epidemiology section.

title: NEW SHOWS FOR CHILDREN: SHOULD WE EXPECT MORE
description: You might just as well watch ''Ewoks: The Battle for Endor,'' the ABC movie at 8 o'clock tonight, and, judging from past experience, it is possible, even likely, that you will. ''The Ewok Adventure'' was ABC's highest rated film last year. The new television movie is not a sequel to the first, but its executive producer is also George Lucas and it also has Ewoks in abundance. Ewoks, of course, are the large Teddy bears in monk's cowls first seen in Lucasfilm's ''Return of the Jedi,'' and the nice thing about them is that they are almost totally benign. Nonetheless, there's no denying that benignity has its limits, especially on prime-time television, and tonight's appearance by the Ewoks is different than the one they made last year. This time, the Ewoks are ''action oriented.''

title: PILLASTER WINS REMSEN BY FIVE LENGTHS
description: Pillaster, making his first career start on the dirt, ran right into the Triple Crown picture for next spring with an easy five-length victory in the $248,000 Remsen Stakes for 2-year-olds at Aqueduct yesterday.

title: For Home Buyers: One-Stop Shopping
description: For those in the market for existing residential properties, the search is a fairly straightforward process. But where do home buyers who want to start from scratch begin?

title: LJILANA CUKOVIC MARRIES
description: Ljiljana Cukovic, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Radivoj Cukovic of Dubrovnik, Yugoslavia, was married yesterday to David Worcester Sinclair, the son of Cynthia Smith-Hutton Bowers of New York and Hugh Joseph Pinkney Sinclair Jr. of Baltimore.

title: AN APPRECIATION OF INDIAN FOODS
description: FOOD enthusiasts say that long-overdue credit is being given to American Indian food, the country's original ''ethnic'' food. These dishes are so esoteric that one has to forage for the ingredients of cattail pollen cake, yet are so mainstream that we consume clam and corn chowders, baked beans, steamed lobsters and barbecues without considering their Indian origins.

title: Rental Gloom
description: To the Editor:

title: A BAD YEAR FOR JERSEY OYSTERS
description: New Jersey's small but historic oyster industry on Delaware Bay has been struck this year by the highest mortality rate recorded among the shellfish in 24 years, according to an expert who monitors the oyster beds.

title: SUZAN DISTENFELD TO WED
description: M. Suzan Distenfeld and Ian Donald Crabb, members of the class of '86 at the New York University School of Medicine, plan to be married in April. Dr. Ariel Distenfeld of Scarsdale, N.Y., has announced his daughter's engagement to a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Crabb of Manhattan.

title: MINI-OPERA: ROREM-STEIN COLLABORATION
description: OF the two compact works the American Chamber Opera Company presented at P.S. 9 (100 West 84th Street) Thursday night, Ned Rorem's ''Three Sisters Who Are Not Sisters'' came off most successfully.

title: LAWMAKERS MULL SHIFTING STATE AGENCY TO CONTRACTOR
description: COULD the State Department of Motor Vehicles, frequently criticized for long waiting lines and inefficiency, be better run by a private company?

title: FEARS OF BEING SENT BACK
description: No matter how risky the trip over, many immigrants landed on Ellis Island convinced that the worst dangers still awaited them. Aaron Cheifetz, a 93-year-old musician and former shopkeeper in New York City, recounted to oral historians his arrival in America and his fears of being turned away by immigration officials. Mr. Cheifetz, who came in the fall of 1913 from what is now the Soviet Union, paid $50 for the passage from his native town of Mogilev. The trip required slipping across the Polish-Austrian border. Here is some of what Mr. Cheifetz said:

title: SICILIAN TALES
description: THE WINE-DARK SEA By Leonardo Sciascia. Translated by Avril Bardoni. 142 pp. New York: Carcanet. $14.95.

title: READING, THE MOST DANGEROUS GAME
description: READING is an intimate act, perhaps more intimate than any other human act. I say that because of the prolonged (or intense) exposure of one mind to another that is involved in it, and because it is the level of mind at which feelings and hopes are dealt in by consciousness and words.

title: THE MYTH MAKER
description: E. L. Doctorow states that his new novel, ''World's Fair,'' is based on the presumption that a child is a ''perception machine'' (''The Myth Maker: The Creative Mind of Novelist E. L. Doctorow,'' by Bruce Weber, Oct. 20). In fact, this presumption has helped to shape many of Mr. Doctorow's earlier works.

title: RANGERS ROUT ISLANDERS, 5-0
description: The New York Rangers scored by the fistful, the New York Islanders scored not at all, and the visitors gained a shocking 5-0 victory at Nassau Coliseum tonight. ''They outplayed us and deserved to win,'' said Pat LaFontaine. ''In a sense, we didn't even play.''

title: President's Proclamation
description: Following is the text of President Reagan's Thanksgiving Day proclamation: The White House By the President of the United States of America A PROCLAMATION Although the time and date of the first American thanksgiving observance may be uncertain, there is no question but that this treasured custom drives from our Judeo-Christian heritage. ''Unto thee, O God, do we give thanks,'' the Psalmist sang, praising God not only for the ''wondrous works'' of His creation, but for loving guidance and deliverance from danger.

title: THE PRIVATE PALACES OF BRITAIN
description: It's nice that there's an exhibition of some of the contents of English country houses, but it's too bad someone isn't pointing out that these houses are living examples of the British class system (''The Private Palaces of Britain,'' by John Russell, Oct. 27). Mr. Russell writes that the English country house ''marries to perfection not only with the climate and the countryside, but with the unchanging leisure habits of the English.''

title: Pension Plans
description: To the Editor:

title: THE SKY IS NO LIMIT FOR NEW YORK'S MASTER BUILDERS
description: In good economic times in other cities, a local developer may think of putting up an office tower or apartment building.

title: IN POINT PLEASANT BEACH, UNITY ELUDES BUSINESS COMMUNITY
description: THIS borough by the sea in Ocean County maintains an old-fashioned air. Downtown, there is a Woolworth's with creaky wooden floors and nostalgic smells reminiscent of the ''five and dimes'' that all but disappeared 30 years ago. There are still some barber poles and, at the Good and Plenty, a lumberjack-size breakfast costs just $2.97 - coffee, tax and a smile included.

title: BEST SELLERS
description: Nov. 24, 1985 Fiction

title: CORRECTION
description: An incorrect photograph and caption accompanied a review Nov. 3 of ''The City of Joy,'' Dominique Lapierre's book about an area of Calcutta. The picture was taken elsewhere in Calcutta.

title: OUR PLURALISTIC WORLD
description: SUPERPOWER RELA-tions are like octopi making love,'' I wrote in a summitary thumbsucker about the need to link issues and interests, ''and all the tentacles must intertwine.''

title: A JUNE WEDDING FOR DR. GINSBURG
description: Dr. Elizabeth Sarah Ginsburg, a resident in obstetrics and gynecology at the Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston, and Dr. Robert S. Weinstein, a resident in internal medicine at Beth Israel Hospital in New York, plan to be married in June.

title: Miss Tegarden Plans to Marry
description: The Rev. and Mrs. William Hollis Tegarden of Princeton, N.J., and Jamestown, R.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Deborah Armington Tegarden to Roderick Winthrop Bass, the son of Mrs. Philip Hammer Bass of Princeton and Amagansett, L.I., and the late Mr. Bass.

title: GUESS WHO'SNOT COMING TO DINNER
description: It won't rival the Geneva summit conference, but photographers will be jostling for position Tuesday to record the meeting between President Reagan and a Minnesotan named Wilfred.

title: ANGLO-IRISH AGREEMENT PITS BOTH ENDS AGAINST THE MIDDLE
description: The agreement Britain signed with the Irish Republic Nov. 15 is supposed to bring peace and stability to Northern Ireland, but last week it drew determined opposition from the leaders of the strongest political parties on both sides of the border.

title: SARAH ROBERTS TO WED L.I. KOPLIK IN JANUARY
description: Sarah Longden Roberts, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Warren E. Roberts of Bloomington, Ind., and Lawrence Irwin Koplik, a son of Myron J. Koplik of Jamestown, N.Y., and the late Shirley W. Koplik, plan to be married Jan. 5.

title: PULLING THE PLUG ON ELECTRIFICATION
description: FOR almost 20 years, Long Island Rail Road commuters living in Northport and Greenlawn have been promised electrification of their line, a move that might cut 10 to 20 minutes off their hour-and-10-minute ride to New York City.

title: CRAGGY LANDMARKS GETTING A FACELIFT
description: ON opposite sides of New Haven stand West Rock and its granite mate, East Rock - towering crags comprising hundreds of acres of parkland, hiking trails, picnicking and recreational areas. Residents have long looked upon these landmarks as giving the city character and beauty, especially with the splendid foliage of autumn.

title: ROBERT WILLIAM SCHRIJVER IS MARRIED TO WENDY WALWORTH, PROTRAIT ARTIST
description: Wendy Walworth, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore H. Walworth Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., and Robert William Schrijver, the son of Karen J. Schrijver of New York and Bethel, Conn., and the late Adolf L. Schrijver, were married in New York yesterday. The Rev. Thomas F. Pike performed the ceremony at St. George's Episcopal Chapel.

title: DANCE: SOLO WORK BY BEVERLY BLOSSOM
description: ON Thursday evening at 8:05, a woman in black with a reddish fuzz of hair burst from the wings of the Nikolais/Louis DanceSpace at 33 East 18th Street and dived into the stage space. Time seemed to stop, in the proverbial theater sense. On a rare visit from Champaign-Urbana, where she is on the dance staff of the University of Illinois, Beverly Blossom proved once more what a rare performer she is.

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: NATIONAL Adoption Week starts today, and the New Jersey Committee for Adoption is holding a fair to provide information and help for potential adoptive parents. It will take place from 2 to 4:30 P.M. in the Student Center at St. Joseph's College in Philadelphia. (A similar fair was held in North Jersey last Sunday).

title: BUS-SERVICE EFFORTS DRAW CRITICISM
description: EFFORTS by county transportation officials to establish bus services in northern Westchester were sharply criticized last week by two key members of the Board of Legislators.

title: A REVIVAL OF MANNERS
description: Maybe the main news out of the Geneva summit is not what happened but what didn't happen. There was plenty of hot air but no explosion. Nobody walked out, nobody pretended everything was dandy, and President Reagan and General Secretary Gorbachev agreed to meet again in Washington next year and in Moscow in 1987.

title: MORE AMERICANS GOING IT ALONE
description: The number of Americans who live alone or with unrelated people is growing faster than any other household group, the Census Bureau reported last week. Since 1970, the number of people living alone has almost doubled, the bureau said, with the largest increase among widows, in many cases mothers whose children have grown and moved away.

title: AS THE SENATE TURNS
description: The moment that students of television drama have been awaiting - live broadcasting of the United States Senate in action -appears to be just over the horizon. More than six years after the House opened its proceedings to continuous camera surveillance, a solid majority of the 100 senators are now said to favor televising their sessions, at least in principle, and a proposal for experimentation has been approved in committee.

title: Old Houses
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW ECHOES OF DURAN DURAN
description: Andy Warhol was wrong, when he predicted that in the future, people would become famous for 15 minutes. This is the future. Now people become famous in 15 minutes.

title: FREE SAMPLES TO WOO PAYING CLIENTS
description: FREE legal advice? Gratis tax hints or medical tips?

title: NAZARETH WINS, 31-12
description: John Walsh, Nazareth's quarterback, said he could see confusion in the eyes of Sheepshead Bay's defensive players as he gazed across the line of scrimmage yesterday in the Metro Bowl B Division game.

title: ADVICE ON WATERING: FEED THE SOIL
description: HORTICULTURISTS are frequently asked how often one should water a certain plant. Since watering involves so many variables, it is almost impossible to give an exact answer to the question.

title: HELPING THOSE HOW HELP
description: Red Cross Tasks Nov. 25 - A cataclysm such as the volcano eruption in Colombia gives dramatic evidence of the monumental tasks that often face the Red Cross and its need for support. The American Red Cross in Greater New York is holding its second annual humanitarian award dinner-dance at the Rainbow Room in Rockefeller Center. Tickets for the black-tie benefit, which starts with cocktails at 7 P.M., are $300, from a Red Cross representative at 212-355-1055. Fortune Society Benefit Nov. 25 - Since 1967, the Fortune Society has helped thousands of former convicts on the road to rehabilitation while seeking greater public understanding of them. Margaret Whiting and Borough Predident-elect David N. Dinkins of Manhattan will be on hand at a benefit celebration, with cash bar, for the society at the club Waverly & Waverly, 157 Waverly Place in Greenwich Village. Tickets are $30 from 212-206-7070. Diamond Jubilee Dec. 2 - The New York League for the Hard of Hearing is a comprehensive rehabilitative private agency serving 16,000 infants, children and adults a year. To celebrate 75 years of service, a buffet with drinks and entertainment will be held at the Ballroom, 253 West 28th Street, from 7 P.M. to 11 P.M. Tickets are $75 from 212-741-3143 or special hookup for hearing-impaired (TTY), 212-255-1932. Scrooge's Return Dec. 2 - Helen Hayes, Raul Julia, Fritz Weaver and Celeste Holm will be among the readers of ''A Christmas Carol'' at Symphony Space, Broadway at 95th Street. The evening, starting with the reading at 7 P.M., will benefit the Riverside Shakespeare Company, now heading into its 10th season.

title: 27 ARE ARRESTED IN COCAINE RAIDS
description: Federal agents and local police officers in New Jersey, New York, Florida and Puerto Rico arrested 27 people and seized 1,474 pounds of cocaine in coordinated raids Friday night and early yesterday.

title: A PLAYWRIGHT'S OPERATIC LOVE AFFAIR
description: By the time I was 16, I had written my third opera. It was my own adaptation of ''Anna Karenina.'' I still remember the long scene where Anna, having been hit by a train but still able to sing, is discovered by Vronsky, and dying, confides in his arms that she is carrying his child. My composition class received this with undisguised hilarity and contempt. I was very upset, since I was proud of my ability to generate long, sweetly nostalgic themes in B flat from Anna's fragmented groanings in G minor.

title: PAROLES ARE NOT LIKELY IN THE WALKER SPY CASE
description: To the Editor:

title: WILD TURKEYS AT HOME IN COUNTY BUT NOT ON PLATTERS
description: AS the Thanksgiving holiday approaches, Barry Samuel says area residents have still one more thing to be especially thankful for: Westchester's turkeys have come home to roost.

title: GRAVES BLOCK A DEVELOPMENT
description: A DEVELOPER will not be permitted to begin building homes on land he bought last summer in Smithtown unless he excavates the bodies of the original property owners and proves there are no other bodies on the site, officials say.

title: IN WEST TEXAS, SMALL TOWNS GET SMALLER, OLDER AND POORER
description: The ranchers, farmers and merchants gather daily at the Hard Times Restaurant to sip coffee and wonder if the fall rains will hold. ''We named the restaurant after our town,'' says Mayor Jim Schumann. And these are hard times indeed in West Texas. Small cities and towns like Eden are slowly turning into 20th century ghost towns, with abandoned filling stations at the crossroads and tumbleweed in the parking lots of shuttered banks.

title: NEWS CASSETTES: FROM LATE CHAPLIN TO ANNA RUSSELL
description: The Children of Theater Street An Earle Mack Film. Narration by Princess Grace of Monaco Kultur 92 minutes. $59.95 Filmed in 1977, this documentary about the famous ballet school in Leningrad that produced Rudolf Nureyev and Mikhail Baryshnikov, not to mention Anna Pavlova, Vaslav Nijinsky and George Balanchine, is still the best of its genre.

title: TEXAS ELIMINATES BAYLOR'S BID, 17-0
description: Texas eliminated Baylor from Cotton Bowl contention today with a 17-10 Southwest Conference victory behind a fierce James McKinney-led defense and Edwin Simmons's tough running. Keeping alive a Memorial Stadium jinx over Baylor that goes back to 1951, Texas moved one victory from earning the host spot in the 50th Cotton Bowl on New Year's Day.

title: LIVELY LONDON
description: To the Editor: My husband and I have just returned from an exciting nine-day visit to London. Primarily we went to luxuriate in attending the easily accessible and (by New York standards) reasonably priced theater.

title: REMEMBERING CREATORS OF THE FRENCH TRADITION
description: When the Metropolitan Opera brings us a conductor who has inherited French style intact, we are grateful. If it can offer one who helped create that style, our gratitude is doubled.

title: AN EGYPTIAN TERROR GROUP
description: The Egypt Revolutionaries organization, which is taking responsibility for the hijacking in Malta Saturday, first surfaced here in August with the slaying of an Israeli diplomat.

title: IMAGES THAT TESTIFY
description: W. Eugene Smith's images have changed the way we see history. LET TRUTH BE THE PREJUDICE (Aperture, $50) is a tribute to this master of photojournalism who, in a 40-year career, sacrificed health and personal life in the struggle to document human lives.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, NOVEMBER 24, 1985
description: International A ''blow-up scenario'' for Geneva was quickly devised by American officials who feared early Thursday morning that the summit meeting might collapse at the final ceremony. ''We had a nightmare vision with world headlines saying, 'Summit Breaks Up Over Star Wars,' '' one official said. [Page 1, Column 1.] Terrorists seized an Egyptair jetliner carrying more than 100 people and forced it to land in Malta, where the Government radio station reported that five people had been killed. One American was reported injured. In Washington, a State Department spokesman said officials had received reports that the body of one person from the plane was at a Malta hospital. [1:3.] Many people trapped by mud in Armero, Colombia, last weekend died because of bungled rescue operations, according to frustrated volunteers. They said the rescue efforts were hampered by shortages of manpower, helicopters, expertise, medicine and such basics as shovels. [1:4.] A nine-stanza love lyric attributed in the manuscript copy to Shakespeare has been discovered in Oxford University's Bodleian Library by an American scholar. It appears to be the first addition to the canon of Shakespeare's works since the 17th century. It is untitled. [1:1.] Nelson Mandela was transferred from the South African hospital, where he was recovering from surgery, back to prison. The black nationalist leader is serving a life sentence for sabotage. [15:1.] Remarkably candid comments about priestly celibacy were made by Bishop James W. Malone, the head of the American Roman Catholic delegation to an extraordinary synod that starts today in Rome.

title: VICTOR BERNSTEIN
description: Victor Bernstein, chairman of the New York Land Company, which converted the Korvettes store at Herald Square into the new Herald Center, died Thursday at Presbyterian Hospital in Pittsburgh after a long illness. He was 68 years old and lived in Great Neck, L.I.

title: WHY ITALIANS THINK THEY HATE ROMANS
description: If you rent a car in Italy that happens to have ROMA license plates and you encounter some unfriendly stares in, say, Florence or Naples, it's nothing against you personally. An innkeeper near Pavia who had gruffly helped me unload my suitcases turned genial when he saw my American passport later: ''Ah, I thought you were a Romanaccio.''

title: NEWSPAPERS ARE EXPANDING COVERAGE IN WESTERN SUFFOLK
description: AS competition for advertising increases, the daily and weekly newspapers that serve western Suffolk County are expanding into new communities, strengthening news coverage and changing their appearance.

title: BIOGRAPHY AND THE SEXUAL REVOLUTION -- WHY CURIOSITY IS NO LONGER VULGAR
description: OUR sexual revolution - a loose phrase for the unbuttoning of America - has many different meanings to different layers of our population. The literary folk think promptly of ''Lady Chatterley's Lover'' and ''Ulysses'' and the freedom to print four-letter words. The antipornography crusaders think of magazine centerfolds where the camera lens now has permission to move in on the (usually) female crotch. Others think of bedroom doors formerly tightly closed and now left wide open, so authors of blockbusters can describe minutely what goes on. A great many people think the revolution allowed homosexuals to surface. Some will connect openness about sex with the general freedom to undress the human body publicly - all the way to diagramming the intestines of President Reagan at the time of his recent operation. References to hemorrhoids and menstruation in commercials, allusions to oral sex and masturbation in health and psychology programs are now routine on broadcast and cable television.

title: THE WORLD AHEAD
description: I was struck by the incident reported by Thomas Morgan's mother about how he had resigned his favorite T-shirt, a Bat Masterson T-shirt, because some schoolmate had told him that there was no such thing as a black Bat Masterson.

title: OBSERVATORIES OFFER CHANCES TO SEE COMET
description: No one knows how spectacular Halley's comet will be when it passes Earth this time to round the sun as it does every 76 years or so. But the experts agree that because of the bright lights, residents of the New York metropolitan area will almost certainly miss the comet unless they venture outside the city limits.

title: Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: Senate

title: THE NONPROFITS DROP THE 'NON'
description: BIG BIRD and his furry friends have become big business at the Children's Television Workshop.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: TWO MODEL EXHIBITIONS The Model Railroad Club's annual Christmas show, featuring 3,600 feet of HO-gauge track running through 28 model-size towns and 3 cities, opens Friday at the club's headquarters in Union.

title: LOWERING THE HIGH COST OF SOFTWARE
description: ON MY WAY to Las Vegas for the seventh annual Comdex-Fall, the personal computer industry's giant trade show, I was reflecting on the changes that have swept Silicon Valley this year.

title: AND GLADLY TEACH
description: SOMETIMES A SHINING MOMENT The Foxfire Experience. By Eliot Wigginton. Illustrated. 438 pp. New York: Anchor Press/ Doubleday & Company. $19.95.

title: INGRES'S PORTRAIT OF A LADY IS THE MIRROR OF AN AGE
description: ''Nothing ever changes at the Frick,'' people say, and they mean it as a compliment. Among the huge mutations of the world, the Frick is a constant. It is always there, always the same ideal size, ever to be counted upon. Not only is it counted upon, but it is loved. Who would wish it changed?

title: THE CHOATE DEALER
description: When Derek Oatis entered Federal court in Bridgeport, Conn., last week for sentencing, he was an admitted drug smuggler. When he left, he was a repentant college student, pleading tearfully for other young people to avoid using drugs because ''they've got too much to lose.'' Mr. Oatis and a classmate from Choate Rosemary Hall were arrested last year at Kennedy International Airport when they returned from a drug-buying trip to Venezuela carrying 350 grams of cocaine for themselves and their schoolmates.

title: NANA MUKHADZE
description: A series called ''The Art of Teaching'' at the Metropolitan Museum features debutant pianists chosen by famous artists who have taught or coached them.

title: 'INSTANT SUCCESS,' 10 YEARS LATER
description: THE PUSHCART PRIZE X Best of the Small Presses. Edited by Bill Henderson with the ''Pushcart Prize'' editors. Poetry edited by Stanley Plumly and William Stafford. Introduction by George Plimpton. 499 pp. Wainscott, N.Y.: The Pushcart Press. $25.

title: BRAZIL HITS A FEW BUMPS ON THE PATH TO DEMOCRACY
description: Following a plan worked out by politicians and army officers, Brazil moved smoothly from military to civilian rule eight months ago. There was no general election or dramatic shake-up in the national leadership, but the country was assured that democracy had arrived. Now, however, Brazilians are showing signs of impatience. In municipal voting Nov. 15, they rebuffed the centrist parties that had just led them out of 21 years of authoritarianism. Instead, they responded to the charisma of two opposition politicians, one conservative, the other socialist, who had been powerful before the 1964 coup. Overnight, it seemed, the plans for an uneventful transition toward the first presidential election by direct vote since 1960 were threatened by the wild cards of populism and ideology. In a conciliatory and pragmatic political system, the new fear was polarization.

title: NAVY'S DISPERSAL HITS A SHOAL
description: Congress approved last week down payments for new Navy facilities in New York and Puget Sound, but after adroit maneuvering critics ran plans for spending the money aground, at least temporarily.

title: LOSING STREAK ENDS AT 47
description: The Rutgers-Newark basketball team ended a record-setting losing streak that began two years ago when it beat Bard College, 62-42, tonight.

title: DATA ON WHEELS
description: What has four wheels, window blinds, cafe-style tables and a theater? The answer: ''InfoBus,'' a bus converted to a mobile information center.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: SMILES ON WASHINGTON SQUARE. By Raymond Federman. (Thunder's Mouth, $13.95.) The French expatriate novelist and critic Raymond Federman has for years been teaching at the State University of New York at Buffalo and writing in the avowedly ''experimental'' mode - which meant books that, as a waggish writer once remarked, looked funny on the page.

title: THE POPE'S GUARDIAN OF ORTHODOXY
description: THIS MORNING, SOME 165 BISHOPS and archbishops from around the world are scheduled to gather in St. Peter's Basilica for a papal mass inaugurating a solemn assembly that could alter the course of Roman Catholic history.

title: Classical Music
description: Francophiles are in luck this week. In addition to ''Parade,'' the Metropolitan Opera's triple bill of Satie, Poulenc and Ravel that opens Friday, there will be a symphonic concert of French music - performed by French musicians - at Carnegie Hall on Sunday night.

title: How Solow Won Permits For a 49-Story Tower
description: A FORMER gas station on East 73d Street that stands opposite a Sanitation Department garage on a tired block of tenements and lofts does not sound like a promising location for a grand apartment house. But just beyond the site is the East River, and any apartment building that can be developed beside it will command long views and high rents.

title: WHAT'S WRONG WITH PATRIOTS? NOTHING
description: Like everyone else in pro football, Pat Sullivan used to wonder just what was wrong with the Patriots. The fact that his father, Billy, owned the team made the club's failures harder to swallow.

title: QUESTIONS AHEAD FOR COLUMBIA
description: IN the hallway outside the office of the football coach at Columbia University, the promise of last spring remained hanging on a wall last week. A black and white photograph of the 1961 Ivy League football champions was the inspiration for Jim Garrett's vow:

title: VIRGINIA POLLS AND POLITICIANS INDICATE FALWELL IS SLIPPING IN HIS HOME STATE
description: Here in the Rev. Jerry Falwell's home state of Virginia, the base from which he flies off to try to influence political opinion from forums in Washington, in South Africa or in the Philippines, his ability to sway the electorate appears to be in decline.

title: MELISSA MCGLYNN
description: The engagement of Melissa Ann McGlynn to David Whitman McGraw, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Cushing McGraw Jr. of Gulfstream, Fla., and Osterville, Mass., has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Howard John McGlynn of Pitts=field, Mass. A June wedding is planned.

title: BOB DYLAN SUMS UP A LIFE IN MUSIC
description: Remember Bob Dylan? He was that skinny, hunted-looking folk-rock poet, the one whom some people thought defined the 1960's. With his raspy voice, his fiercely strumming guitar and his wailing harmonica, he sang songs like ''Blowin' in the Wind'' and ''Mr. Tambourine Man'' that shaped a generation's understanding of itself. But in recent years, Mr. Dylan has hardly seemed so central, either to the pop-music business or to the culture at large. And that's what makes his new, five-LP album ''Biograph'' so thought-provoking.

title: SPECIALISTS IN BALLADS OF LOVE LOST AND WON
description: During the film ''In the Company of Wolves,'' the Little Red Riding Hood character is warned to avoid men whose eyebrows meet in the middle. She ignores this only to discover a werewolf in gentleman's clothing.

title: CHESS MATCH AT SEA, 7,000 MILES OF MOVES
description: ON Sept. 28, 15 well-appointed ocean-racing yachts ranging in size from 50 to 82 feet set sail from Portsmouth, England, for the first leg of the Whitbread Round-the-World Race. Cape Town was 7,000 miles away, and in this race, dubbed the ''sailor's Everest,'' it was just the beginning. During the next seven months, through fair weather and foul, this fleet manned by adventurers from 10 nations will call at Auckland, New Zealand, and Punta del Este, Uruguay, before returning to England sometime next May. By then, they will have logged more than 27,000 miles.

title: IN CENTRAL PARK, COMFORT IS KEY
description: ROLLER skating, cycling, jogging, touch football, strolling, people watching, dressing up, showing off: name a sport and it's a good bet that Central Park has got it. What's even better is that anyone, any age, can play. The only requirements are a free spirit and a sense of fun.

title: MAKING WELFARE WORK
description: BEYOND ENTITLEMENT The Social Obligations of Citizenship. By Lawrence M. Mead. 318 pp. New York: The Free Press. $19.95.

title: INNOCENT GOES EAST
description: THE MAKING OF MARK TWAIN A Biography. By John Lauber. Illustrated. 298 pp. Boston: American Heritage/ Houghton Mifflin Company. $17.95.

title: IS THE TRANSIT AUTHORITIY WINNING THE WAR ON GRIME?
description: The sleek, stainless-steel train pulls into the station, the last stop on the subway line. As soon as the passengers disembark, six men and women wearing blue jump suits and armed with buckets and mops attack the cars, wiping the walls and sweeping away empty coffee cups, gum wrappers and scattered newspapers. Within minutes the train, now sparkling, speeds off on another run.

title: TEX-MEX WITH SOME VARIATION
description: BEYOND the large, arched window and massive wood door, Santa Fe, one of the several new Tex-Mex places to open in the county, turns out to be one of the most amiable as well. And by happy coincidence, the food served here is a notch above that in other places offering the same familiar favorites such as nachos, enchiladas, tacos, tamales and burritos -available singly or glopped together incoherently in combination platters that these restaurants seem compelled to offer. Although it produces decent enough examples of the genre, Santa Fe doesn't stop there. Fajitas and Indian blue corn tortillas and young, sweet and mild Monterey Jack cheese drizzled over quite a few dishes and vegetarian variations that are a treat make the menu a little special.

title: BROCHURES THAT DEFINE A SPECIAL NICHE
description: PATIENTS walking into Dr. Kenneth Fox's office in Falls Church, Va., are handed more than just a medical history form to fill out. They are given a brochure that tells them about Dr. Fox, an ophthalmologist, and the other doctors in his group. ''It tells them who we are and what we do,'' said Dr. Fox.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: CANNIBALISM AND THE COMMON LAW: The Story of the Tragic Last Voyage of the Mignonette and the Strange Legal Proceedings to Which It Gave Rise, by A. W. Brian Simpson. (University of Chicago, $12.95.) In 1884 four shipwrecked English sailors bounced about the Atlantic Ocean in a lifeboat for 24 days. When one became ill the captain killed him, and the survivors drank his blood, butchered his body and ate it. A famous trial ensued. At issue: did cannibalistic homicide on which survival depended constitute murder? Last year our reviewer, Sally Falk Moore, called the book ''a happy mixture of adventure story, colorful description, moral parable and legal argument.'' JULIA AND THE BAZOOKA: And Other Stories, by Anna Kavan. (Norton, $5.95.) The French-born, twice-divorced author renovated houses, raised bulldogs and for 30 years used amphetamines and heroin until her death in 1968. But Jill Robinson said in The Book Review in 1975 that Anna Kavan is interesting not for her life, but ''because her work comes through with a powerful androgynous individuality and because the stories are luminous and rich with a fresh kind of peril.'' ''Julia and the Bazooka'' contains 15 stories and an informative introduction by Rhys Davies. Miss Robinson compared Kavan's novel ICE (Norton, $5.95) to Baudelaire. THE COGNITIVE COMPUTER: On Language, Learning, and Artificial Intelligence, by Roger C. Schank with Peter Childers. (Addison-Wesley, $12.95.) The authors provide an inside view of research in artificial intelligence, the scientific discipline that seeks to simulate the human thinking process in a computer.

title: AMONG OTHER TOPICS, THE VATICAN BANK'S DEFICIT
description: On the eve of the Roman Catholic Church's Synod of Bishops, the College of Cardinals heard a report today on the Vatican's growing budget deficit. Meanwhile, a group of Italian Catholics pressed a campaign to ask forgiveness from Jews for centuries of religious persecution.

title: PUTTING EARS TO THE AIRWAVES RATHER THAN THE GROUND
description: Electronic eavesdropping -once the domain of Federal agents, foreign spies and a handful of amateurs with hours to spend tuning their ham radios - has come of age.

title: WILDWOOD WAS PARADISE ENOUGH
description: PRIDE By William Wharton. 288 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $16.95.

title: SHOPS ADVISED ON CARD FRAUD
description: WITH the holiday shopping season approaching, merchants around the state are being warned to take steps to avoid credit-card fraud, a crime that has greatly increased in the past five years.

title: BURMA'S ERODING ISOLATION
description: SHE ARRIVES UNNO-ticed, a young woman selling pineapples at the busy ferry slip in Mandalay. Arranging her wares on a board, she dips into her basket for a handful of white flower buds. With small puffs of breath, she blows each into a blossom to decorate each fruit. The last flower she tucks un-self-consciously into her black hair.

title: Saving the Woods: Mountain Complex
description: When developers approached West Paterson, N.J., officials with plans to build a speculative office complex on a 30-acre site at the crest of Garret Mountain between Garret Mountain Reservation and Rifle Camp nature preserve, a major concern was that the project be compatible with the parks.

title: CARROL HANLEY TO WED MICHAEL HILTON
description: Announcement has been made by Mary S. Hanley and William L. Hanley Jr., both of Greenwich, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter Carroll Stollenwerck Hanley to Michael Otis Hilton, a son of Patricia H. Hilton of Palm Beach, Fla., and the late C. Nicholas Hilton Jr. of Los Angeles.

title: A LIBERAL BY ANY OTHER NAME MAY GET MORE VOTES
description: POLITICIANS dislike labels, at least the ones they don't choose for themselves. When Democratic Party leaders gathered at Disney World this weekend to discuss their problems, the shorthand image of the party as ''liberal'' cannot have been far from their minds.

title: FLIGHT OF THE SPARROW
description: PIAF By Margaret Crosland. Illustrated. 240 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $16.95.

title: THE WORLD AHEAD
description: The major concern of most black parents is not how well their children will be received by white students; it's keeping food on the table and hoping their children will complete high school. The families in the article are primarily blacks who suffer deeper feelings of inferiority concerning their blackness because of their closer-than-average proximity to whites.

title: PROVIDING LONG-TERM FOR OLDER AMERICANS
description: To the Editor:

title: YOUNG ACTORS SEEK THEIR OWN TRUTHS ABOUT VIETNAM
description: When Herbert Ross began to direct ''The Boys of Winter,'' John Pielmeier's new play about the Vietnam War, he realized that part of his task was to educate - not the audience, but the actors.

title: Brooklyn Condos: 42 Affordables
description: The Boerum and Cobble Hill sections of Brooklyn are among the outer-borough neighborhoods that have become magnets for young professionals in search of affordable housing.

title: EMILY DAVIS CROLL IS WED IN CAPITAL TO C. G. WALLACE
description: Emily Davis Croll, the daughter of Mrs. Joseph D. Croll of Washington and the late Mr. Croll, was married yesterday to Christopher Graham Wallace, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Rich Wallace of Bordentown, N.J. The Rev. John C. Harper performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church at Lafayette Square in Washington.

title: WASHINGTON WIVES JUGGLE GLAMOUR AND PROBLEMS
description: FROM the outside, the life looks glamorous. But the day-to-day life of a Long Island Congressional wife is filled with more problems than receptions.

title: WHY KEITH HERNANDEZ WAS CHEERED AT SHEA
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: STATE LEADERS GRAPPLE WITH MALPRACTICE ISSUE
description: The highly emotional issue of medical malpractice insurance, which has turned out to be only one element in a series of complex insurance issues facing the state, has continued to frustrate efforts to schedule a fall legislative session.

title: Our Ghastly Longings
description: To the Editor:

title: PENN HOLDS OFF DARTMOUTH TO TAKE TITLE
description: An aggressive and inspired performance by the Pennsylvania defense sparked the Quakers to a 19-14 victory over Dartmouth today and earned Penn the Ivy League title outright.

title: RENOIR SHOW TICKETS: PANIC, FABLES AND A MYSTERY
description: The call came from a Boston policeman.

title: A CHANGE IN VENUE, NOT THE MENU
description: IT IS always risky and often disappointing when a popular little gem of a restaurant expands into larger quarters. Not only is there a strain on the kitchen and service staff to keep up with the additional numbers, but also when these new quarters are in another town, it can take some doing to persuade regulars to come along, too.

title: PHILADELPHIA IMPOSES A STATE OF EMERGENCY
description: After two nights of demonstrations, Mayor W. Wilson Goode declared a state of emergency last week in the predominantly white Elmwood neighborhood of Philadelphia. Mr. Goode said the demonstrations, outside houses bought recently by a black family and an interracial couple, presented an ''imminent danger of civil disturbance.'' They also presented a reminder that racial polarization has been a constant threat in Phildelphia, which was 38 percent black in 1980, an increase of 4 percentage points since 1970.

title: No Nostalgic Fallacy
description: To the Editor:

title: Never Mind Latin, Study English
description: In the article ''Rise in Latin Studies Outpaces Teachers'' [Oct. 27] it is indicated that pupils taking Latin score higher in English reading skills and other tests, whereas efforts by younger children to learn Latin have not improved their English vocabulary substantially. This contradiction invites comment, since champions of Latin as a subject of instruction have often maintained that its study helps improve one's English vocabulary. Their claim should be nuanced in several ways.

title: SUZANNE F. CLIFTON TO MARRY PETER WALSH IN SPRING
description: Mr. and Mrs. Peter F. Clifton of Water Mill, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Suzanne Frances Clifton, to Peter Mallon Walsh, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James J. Walsh of Manhattan. A spring wedding is planned.

title: WINNER FROM THE BALKANS
description: Emir Kusturica concedes that it is not an altogether bad thing to have won the Golden Palm, the top prize of the Cannes film festival, last May for directing ''When Father Was Away on Business.'' It is making it easier to find backers for future films.

title: CRNABERRIES
description: WHEN THE GROUND RULES FOR THE NEW AMERICAN cuisine were first being codified, back in Plymouth, Mass., in 1621, the cranberry figured large in the repertory of chefs of the day. No one has ever been able to state categorically exactly what our Pilgrim forebears and their native American guests ate at that first Thanksgiving feast, but chances are that the carte du jour included roast game from the surrounding forests and an accompanying sauce made from wild cranberries gathered in low-lying wetlands along the Massachusetts coast.

title: IAN SWENSEN
description: Ian Swensen is a violinist whose secure technique and easy stylistic versatility have brought him success relatively early. Even before he won the Naumburg prize last year at 21, he was touring in recital; by chance, I heard him in Virginia when he must still have been in his teens, playing some of the same sonatas he brought to Tully Hall for his debut concert Wednesday.

title: MASTROSIMONE SCORES AGAIN
description: WILLIAM MASTROSIMONE is sizzling again, and so is the Crossroads Theatre Company. With ''Tamer of Horses,'' the state's most prolific and often-produced playwright has come up with a powerhouse.

title: Greece Reverses a Plan On Restricting the Press
description: The Greek Government, under pressure from opposition parties and journalists, reversed itself today and scuttled plans to impose new, restrictive policies on press briefings.

title: DREAMS OF REASON...AND OF FOXES
description: THE CUNNING LITTLE VIXEN By Rudolf Tesnohlidek. Translated by Tatiana Firkusny, Maritza Morgan and Robert T. Jones. Illustrated by Maurice Sendak. 186 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $19.95.

title: PRETORIA RETURNS MANDELA TO JAIL
description: Nelson Mandela, South Africa's most prominent black nationalist leader, was returned to prison today from a hospital where he had been recovering from surgery.

title: OPERA: RAIMONDI AND BATTLE AS LOVERS IN THE MET'S NEW 'FIGARO' PRODUCTION
description: NINE seasons is an inexcusably long time for any opera company to go without a performance of ''Le Nozze di Figaro,'' but the Metropolitan made amends Friday evening with a new production of the Mozart masterpiece. Partial amends, at any rate; Jean-Pierre Ponnelle's clever but enormous sets worked only sometimes, often succeeding in dwarfing one of opera's most intimate works and diminishing the effect of several highly respectable individual performances.

title: PERIOD FRAMES ARE BACK IN FASHION
description: Antique picture frames are sought these days increasingly by collectors of 19th-and early 20th-century art - paintings, drawings, photographs and architectural images. The development comes after a 30-year period during which the austere look reigned in framing and thin strips of metal or wood, painted black, silver or gold, were all the rage. Now, elaborately carved or molded frames that were banished as too decorative in the 1950's by modernist architects and Abstract-Expressionists are making a comeback.

title: MANCY ALDEN IS MARRIED
description: The marriage of Nancy Caroline Alden, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Ellinwood Alden of Riverside, Conn., to Charles Lyon Olson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jay Raymond Olson of Pleasantville, N.Y., took place yesterday at the First Congregational Church in Old Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Thomas L. Stiers performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Jack S. Miller, a Presbyterian minister.

title: NEWS CASSETTES: FROM LATE CHAPLIN TO ANNA RUSSELL
description: Anna Russell The First Farewell Concert Video Arts International 85 minutes. $59.95 If there is anyone with even a passing interest in classical music who has not yet had the opportunity to learn about the lyric art from Anna Russell, help is at hand.

title: CORPORATE ANGELS SEEK MORE FLIGHTS
description: AS it approaches its fourth anniversary in December, the Corporate Angel Network, an organization that uses corporate planes to fly cancer patients without charge to and from medical treatments nationwide, is serving more people than ever. Still, it is not enough to satisfy the goals of the organization's co-founders, Jay Weinberg and Priscilla Blum.

title: MUSIC GROUP USES SOUNDS OF NATURE IN RECORDS
description: THE cry of wolves and the song of whales are among the sounds of nature recorded by the Paul Winter Consort, which is now making the environment itself an integral part of its compositions.

title: ST. FRANCIS BEATS NEW DORP IN METRO BOWL'S A DIVISION
description: St. Francis Prep defeated New Dorp, 28-6, yesterday to win the Metro Bowl's A Division title, but the game between the Catholic High Schools' Football League and Public Schools Athletic League champions was interrupted early in the fourth quarter as officals threatened to cancel the contest at Midwood Field in Brooklyn.

title: LAMBERTVILLE'S FORTUNES TAKE AN OPTIMISTIC TURN
description: TEN years ago, this pictur-esque city on the banks of the Delaware River seemed to be facing the beginning of the end: Stores were empty and its once-elegant Victorian mansions were decaying.

title: INDUSTRY PAYING FOR COOPERATIVE RESEARCH WITH UNIVERSITIES
description: WHEN the Center for Ceramics Research opens its new fiber-optics component this winter, participating industries will pay $50,000 a year each for research in a field that has become essential to advances in communications.

title: FAMILIES SUE IN '82 JERSEY AIR CRASH FATAL TO 2
description: The families of two pilots who died in a collision over the Essex County Airport in 1982 are seeking damages from the Government and other defendants in a trial under way in Federal District Court here.

title: RETURN OF THE FIRES OF LONDON
description: Peter Maxwell Davies, the solitary music master of Britain's remote Orkney Islands, is bringing his ensemble, the Fires of London, to Alice Tully Hall this week for five performances beginning Friday. It is the group's first visit to New York since 1983.

title: DANCE: SEAN LAVERY AS BALANCHINE'S 'APOLLO'
description: SEAN LAVERY made a superb debut in the title role of George Balanchine's ''Apollo'' with the New York City Ballet Friday night at the New York State Theater.

title: SHOWDOWN IS COMING UP OVER DRUGS
description: THE drug war is heating up. As more and more clubs tell players they have to accept drug testing if they want guaranteed contracts, the Players Association is primed to challenge the unilateral decision by management. The union, in the next couple of days, will decide whether to use the National Labor Relations Board or baseball's grievance procedure as the battleground.

title: MAJOR PARTIES RESIST INQUIRY BY STATE INTO THEIR FINANCES
description: The State Investigation Commission is looking into the finances of state and county organizations of the Democratic and Republican parties, but both parties are resisting the investigation.

title: MARY FRANCES SHEIL GIBBONS MARRIES SPENCER ADRIAN SLOAN, PHOTOGRAPHER
description: The marriage of Mary Frances Sheil Gibbons, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John M. Gibbons Jr. of Hartford, to Spencer Adrian Sloan took place yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Patrick and St. Anthony in Hartford. The bridegroom is a son of Mrs. Charles Walters of West Hartford, Conn., and the late Harry Sloan. Msgr.

title: READING PROGRAM IS PUT TO A NEW USE
description: ON the verge of having to repeat the second grade for the second time, a local 8-year-old boy joined an experiment at Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville last summer. At the end of seven weeks, the child had gained six months in the reading-skills measurements and was ready to enter the third grade.

title: 'YOUR HUSBAND HAS ALZHEIMER'S'
description: IT was February 1975 and my daughter and I had just left the office of the neurologist with his words going round and round in my mind: ''Your husband probably has Alzheimer's disease and in six months he won't recognize you, so be prepared to put him in a nursing home.''

title: INSPECTORS IN NEW YORK CITE 39 FOOD OUTLETS
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 39 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: NEW YORK STUDIES S.I. LANDFILL ODORS
description: In 1982, odors from the Brookfield landfill on Staten Island were so bad that they sickened people living near it, according to a study by the New York City Health Department.

title: HIGHWAY WORK SLOWS TRAFFIC
description: Motorists who have had problems on the Schuylkill Expressway this year may find driving even more vexing in 1986. Seven bottlenecks are expected while reconstruction is going on throughout the Philadelphia area.

title: Pace Quickens in Battery Park City
description: IT is hard to pass Battery Park City these days without feeling a sense of awe. Construction is in progress on 6 million square feet of office space at the World Financial Center and 2,200 apartments in the Rector Place residential area at an estimated cost of $1.9 billion. Site work is proceeding on roads, parks and waterfront improvements in preparation for future residential construction.

title: ARRIVAL OF THE AVANT-GARDE
description: TURNING points in history are almost always fascinating, and this should help attract attention to ''The Avant-Garde Comes to New York,'' a new exhibition at Hofstra University in Hempstead that focuses on the innovative European artists who fled to this country before and during World War II. Their influence altered the course of American art.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Nets vs. Kings, at Sacramento Calif, 9 P.M. The seven-game odyssey of the Nets comes to an end in the league's newest city. (Television - SportsChannel, 9 P.M. Radio - WNBC, 10:15, tape delay.) Big Apple NIT, at Hartford Civic Center, 8 P.M. St. John's vs. West Virginia. The winner goes to the semifinals in Madison Square Garden next Friday. (Television -SportsChannel, midnight tape. Radio - WCBS 880, 8 P.M.) College: U.C.L.A. vs. North Carolina, at Chapel Hill, N.C. (Television - ESPN, 7 P.M.) Football Jets vs New England Patriots, at Giants Stadium. The game for first place in the A.F.C. East. (Television - Channel 4, 1 P.M. Radio -WABC 770, 1 P.M.). Giants vs. Cardinals, at St. Louis. (Television - Channel 2, 4 P.M. Radio - WNEW 1130, 4 P.M.) Hamilton Tiger-Cats vs. British Columbia Lions, at Montreal, Grey Cup Canadian Football League championship game. Hamilton, the Eastern champions overwhelmed the Montreal Concordes, 50-26, last Sunday to reach the C.F.L. equivalent of the Super Bowl against British Columbia, which outscored the Winnipeg Blue Bombers, 42-22, to take the Western title. Hockey Rangers vs. Islanders, at Madison Square Garden, 7:35 P.M. Second game of a home-and-home weekend series. (Television - MSG, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WNBC 660, 7:20 P.M.) Black Hawks vs Los Angeles Kings, at Chicago (Television -ESPN, 9 P.M.) Running Manufacturers Hanover Corporate Challenge National Championships, at 270 Park Avenue, 9 A.M. The 3.5-mile race begins and ends in front of the sponsoring bank's headquarters between 47th and 48th Streets.

title: COLOMBIA'S RESCUE OPERATION DRAWS DIVIDED ASSESSMENTS
description: Thirteen-year-old Omayra Sanchez died last weekend in the mud-covered town of Armero, surrounded by helpless volunteer rescue workers who despite a 60-hour effort were unable to dislodge her from a pool of neck-deep water and slime.

title: OF MOBCAPS AND SPIDERS
description: DOROTHEA CONNOLLY of this Hunterdon County community is New Jersey Public Television's ''Fireside Cook,'' a comfortably matronly figure who appears in a billowing skirt and mobcap and whose approach to the complexities of open-hearth cooking in 18th-century kitchens around the state is disarmingly relaxed and chatty.

title: FARM BILL PASSES SENATE, 61 TO 28
description: After nearly a year of negotiation and a week of often bitter debate, the Senate reached a compromise today and passed a four-year farm bill by a vote of 61 to 28.

title: HIGH DEBT COULD STRANGLE THE ECONOMY
description: BY THE end of 1985, American corporations will achieve the dubious distinction of being in debt $1.56 trillion, the highest level in our entire history. After netting out the impact of inflation, this debt has been growing at a dizzying pace of 8.6 percent a year in 1984 and 1985, compared with 2.7 percent annually from 1975 to 1983. Corporate debt now exceeds the total net worth of corporations by 12 percent.

title: A CONSERVATIVE MADHOUSE
description: TRIUMPHANT CON-servatism is now splitting into so many sects that it's hard to keep track of what they are and where they are going. Here are just a few:

title: TENNESSEE'S PRISONS HARDLY HAVE ANY BREATHING ROOM
description: In the darkness before sunrise a few mornings ago, Sheriff Gene Barksdale loaded up 12 of the most dangerous convicts in his county jail, drove them to the nearest state prison reception center and left them chained to the prison fence. The sheriff said he did it because the Shelby County jail was almost full, and a Federal court order barred him from overfilling it.

title: Walesa Says the Police Tapped His Phone
description: Lech Walesa, founder of the banned trade union Solidarity, said today that a state prosecutor had told him that the police had been taping his telephone conversations since Oct. 1.

title: DECISION IN DALLAS
description: If Danny White plays strongly in the final games of the regular season and leads the Cowboys into the National Football League playoffs, reports from Dallas indicate that Gary Hogeboom, the backup quarterback, will probably be traded. Hogeboom told the Dallas Times Herald that Coach Tom Landry intended to trade one of his quarterbacks after this season and that if White was successful in landing a playoff berth for the Cowboys, Hogeboom would go.

title: Corporate America
description: 'There are more pompous, arrogant, self-centered, mediocre-type people running corporate America who should be sent on some postal route delivering mail. I know - their judgments and misjudgments have made me rich.' Joseph D. Jamail Jr. the lawyer representing Pennzoil Company who won a $10.5 billion judgment against Texaco Inc., which a jury found had improperly persuaded Getty Oil Company to renege on a Pennzoil merger.

title: I.M. PEI'S PYRAMID: A PROVATIVE PLAN FOR THE LOUVRE
description: IT WAS MORE THAN 300 YEARS AGO, IN 1665, that the French Government, then under the firm and royal control of King Louis XIV, invited a foreign architect, the renowned Bernini of Italy, to submit a design for the completion of the Louvre Palace. When Bernini arrived in France, he was received magnificently, but he turned in an ill-fated design, full of Baroque curves, balustrades and loggias. The plan contradicted the more practical tastes of Louis's powerful Finance Minister, Colbert, who became Bernini's adversary.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on March 24, about a Queens couple who filed a malpractice suit because the woman became pregnant after sterilization, carried an incorrect identification, obtained from erroneous court papers, of one of the two doctors being sued. Dr. Benjamin Greenberg did not participate in the procedure. Another Dr. Greenberg, whose full identity cannot now be learned, is listed as a defendant.

title: GAMBINO JURY FOLLOWING PAPER TRAIL
description: Early in the trial of 10 reputed members of the Gambino crime organization, a defense attorney suggested to jurors that the case would turn on the credibility of Government informants who gave dramatic testimony about five murders.

title: CHRISTINE M. ROY WED TO WILLIAM H. BARNETT
description: Christine Mary Roy, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward P. Roy of Greensboro, N.C., was married yesterday to William Hale Barnett, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John C. Barnett of Ridgewood, N.J., and Shelter Island, L.I. The Rev. Edward J. Coyle performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Cathedral of St. Catharine of Siena in Allentown, Pa.

title: BOARD SEEKS TO TRIM RISE IN PROPERTY TAX
description: THE budget review process began in earnest last week, but there seemed to be agreement among county legislators on only one aspect - that the 11.1 percent property-tax increase proposed by County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke for 1986 would have to be reduced, at least to a single-digit figure.

title: DEBRA SLOTT TO MARRY
description: Mr. and Mrs. Elliot R. Slott of Oceanside, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Debra Joan Slott, to Daniel Goldbeck, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Goldbeck of Sunrise, Fla. Miss Slott is an art director at Sussman & Sugar, a New Yok advertising agency. Her fiance is manager of client services for Automatic Data Processing Inc., a financial services concern in Melville, L.I.

title: MEMORY IS CLOUDED ON THE BEARS OF '63
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: PIPELINES DEBATED
description: NASSAU County residents opposed to plans to build two pipelines to carry jet fuel and heating oil from Kennedy International Airport to tank farms in Inwood have petitioned the Army Corps of Engineers for a public hearing on the project.

title: NEW YOPRKERS, ETC.
description: ABE HIRSCHFIELD, the real estate developer, arrived in this country from Israel 35 years ago. He's a man who has been described as ''still speaking like he is arriving next Thursday,'' because, to this day, his English is flavored with a marked accent.

title: LIVELY LONDON
description: To the Editor: Regarding ''Where Music Lives in London'' (Travel, Oct. 13): Travelers who find themselves wondering what to do on a Sunday morning in London should know about the Coffee Concerts at 11:30 A.M. in Wigmore Hall. There they will enjoy a chamber music concert of about an hour, always by excellent artists, and after the concert they may discuss it with others of the audience while sipping a complimentary sherry (three varieties offered) or coffee.

title: ANIMATOR BREAKS NEW GROUND IN FILM
description: WHEN ''The Cosmic Eye,'' a 71-minute feature, was shown at the International Animation Festival in Los Angeles in September, a newspaper reviewer wrote: ''Walt Disney blazed a great popular trail when he first set for his artists the task of imitating reality. But it has fallen to Faith Hubley to lead the way in liberating the medium from the constraints with which Walt inadvertently saddled it.''

title: WAYS AND MEANS HAMMERS OUT AN IMPERFECT TAX BILL
description: ''Perhaps a faculty of scholars could do a better job,'' Representative Dan Rostenkowski declared not long before sunrise yesterday. ''A group of ideologues could have provided greater consistency. But politics is an imperfect process.''

title: MACHINE LOVE
description: DOGWOOD AFTERNOONS By Kim Chapin. 249 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $13.95.

title: CONFESSIONS OF A VCR RECRUIT
description: Not long ago in northern Westchester, a mother and her teen-age son were browsing through a video cassette store. Son: ''Do you want to rent 'Silkwood'?'' Mother: ''Isn't that the one with Jane Fonda?'' Son: ''No, the other woman.'' Mother: ''I hate docudramas . . . You never know what really happened.''

title: PENNY JOHNSON WEDS FREDERIC PUTNAM
description: Penny Crandall Johnson, co-founder and a partner in the New York design firm of Kollberg/Johnson Associates, was married at the Congregational Church in Warren, Conn., yesterday to Frederic Parker Putnam, a project manager for the H. J. Davis Development Corporation in Brookline, Mass., and New York. The Rev. Peter V. Marsden performed the ceremony.

title: FARM TAXES WOULD RISE UNDER ALBANY PROPOSAL
description: New York State has proposed a schedule of increased monetary values for farmland that, if adopted, would mean increased taxes for farms in the state next year.

title: LITTLE REASON TO CHEER LOW WAGES
description: A RECENT front-page news story informed us that ''As wage settlements and salary plans for next year take shape, all signs suggest that 1986 will become the fifth consecutive year that the typical American worker will receive a smaller pay increase than in previous years.'' What I found particularly newsworthy was that some of the economists who are consulted on such occasions allowed themselves to wonder whether this news might not, after all, be bad news.

title: MARIA SALDIVAR WED TO A.C. HOAGLAND JR.
description: Maria Teresa Saldivar y Fernandez del Valle and Alexander C. Hoagland Jr. were married yesterday in Mexico City. The Rev. Octavio Munoz performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Parroquia Francesa.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article about Subaru in this section on Nov. 10 incorrectly stated the history of front-wheel drive cars in the United States. The first front-wheel drive car was introduced here in 1904. In the 1970's, Subaru became the first importer to offer front-wheel drive on all of its models.

title: PROGRAM TO CURB MILITARY SPIES
description: A Pentagon commission created last summer after embarrassing disclosures about spying in the Navy outlined last week a broad program to help the military keep its secrets to itself.

title: AQUINAS AND THE BEATITUDES AT THE HARVARD BUSINESS SCHOOL
description: To the Editor:

title: HONDURANS VOTE FOR A PRESIDENT TODAY
description: Hondurans will vote for a new president on Sunday, but as of this afternoon it continued to appear that they would do so without knowing how their next leader will finally be selected.

title: STUDENT EDITIOR AT PACE RESIGNS AFTER PAPER IS SHUT
description: The editor of the student newspaper at the New York City campus of Pace University resigned last week after a faculty committee decided to shut down the paper and recommend his dismissal as editor for publishing an article that used graphic language in describing ''healthy sex,'' or ways for homosexuals to avoid getting the fatal disease AIDS.

title: SYRACUSE OVERPOWERS UTICA
description: Rafael Addison made 12 of 14 field goal attempts and scored 25 points tonight as Syracuse eased past Utica College, 102-55, in the season opener for both teams.

title: Q & A
description: Consent to a Sublet Question: I specialize in subletting furnished apartments. I have found that the management of rent-stabilized buildings can take 45 to 60 days to grant permission, which creates a hardship for my elderly clients, many of whom want to go south for their health. Is there a time limit in which an answer must be given? . . . T. K., Manhattan Answer: Section 226b of the State Real Property Law says that a landlord has 10 days to request additional information after a tenant asks to sublet, and an additional 30 days to consider after the information is provided. If the owner does not request additional information, he has 30 days to reply.

title: JETS' O'BRIEN IS A MAN IN CONTROL
description: Sometimes, the Jets' trainer, or one of the coaches, wonders about the quarterback: What really is on Ken O'Brien's mind. Is he angry? Is he hurt? Is he happy? What's the difference? For the bottom line is that, three days before his 25th birthday, O'Brien leads the Jets against the Patriots today at Giants Stadium, for sole possession of first place in the American Football Conference's Eastern Division.

title: ARE THEY FOR REAL?
description: My ulterior motive in going to summits is to meet Soviet counterparts where they are free to talk and when they have been told to be communicative.

title: DEMAREST LOSES, 28-14
description: Wayne Valley scored three touchdowns after turnovers to defeat Demarest, 28-14, in the North Jersey Section 1, Group 3 playoffs in Wayne yesterday. An interception by Mark Hill at the Wayne Valley 37-yard line set up an 11-play drive that ended with Bud Zuberer's 1-yard touchdown run to give Wayne Valley a 21-6 lead in the fourth quarter.

title: DREAMS OF ESCAPE, DREAMS OF LOVE
description: FAREWELL TO THE SEA A Novel of Cuba. By Reinaldo Arenas. Translated by Andrew Hurley. 413 pp. New York: Viking. $18.95.

title: LOSING PERSPECTIVE
description: TWO of President Reagan's longstanding goals, reducing the regulatory burden and giving more responsibility to state and local officials, have come together in a new Administration proposal to exempt recipients of Federal grants and contracts from many of the laws and rules they must now obey as a condition of receiving money from Washington. Requirements that would be lifted range from the Clean Water Act to the Rehabilitation Act, which orders that public buildings and transportation be accessible to the handicapped.

title: N.I.T. MIGHT CHANGE
description: Because of poor attendance at opening games for the first Big Apple National Invitation Tournament, the format for regional games will probably be changed next season. Peter Carlesimo, the executive director of the preseason tourament, told The Denver Post that the concept of four permanent regional sites for opening round games would probably be scrapped.

title: Better Than 'Male-Hating'
description: To the Editor:

title: FRENCH AGENTS ARE SENTENCED
description: Two French secret agents who pleaded guilty to bombing the flagship of the environmentalist group Greenpeace got tough prison sentences in a New Zealand court last week, but in Paris, the Government indicated that it was working for their quick return to France.

title: Recent Sales
description: East Brunswick $155,000 6 Griffin Street *2* 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 12-year-old colonial; *2* burglar alarm, underground sprinklers, *2* garage-dooropeners; *2* taxes $3,112. Lake Hopatcong $92,000 *2* 109 Minnisink Road *2* 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 30-year-old ranch; *2* skylights in kitchen, bedroom and living room, *2* wood stove, full attic; *2* taxes $1,438. Madison $131,000 *2* 19 Greenwood Avenue *2* 4-bedroom, 1-bath, 100-year-old colonial; *2* oak floors, new windows and electric, clapboard siding; *2* taxes $1,251. Mendham $467,000 Cedar Lane *2* 5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, new Tudor; *2* central air-conditioning, 3-car garage, 5 acres; *2* taxes to be assessed. Short Hills $580,000 11 Hardwell Road *2* 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 20-year-old colonial; *2* living room with fireplace, breakfast room, *2* 2-car attached garage; *2* taxes $7,337. Springfield $122,000 130 Wentz Avenue *2* 4-bedroom, 1-bath, 40-year-old Cape Cod; *2* rec room and workshop in basement; *2* taxes $1,599.
