OTHER AREAS Farmington, Conn. $220,000 19 White Oak Road *2* 5-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 29-year-oldbrick contemporary; *2* separate studio, 2 acres; *2* taxes $2,063. Kent, Conn. $120,000 Appalachian Trail Road *2* 3-bedroom, 2-bath, new ranch; *2* extra insulation, borders on state park, 1 acre; *2* taxes not yet available. Bay Shore, L.I. $57,000 28 Smith Avenue *2* 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 50-year-old colonial; *2* eat-in kitchen, basement; *2* taxes $1,000.

title: HEROIC, MOCK-HEROIC
description: COLLECTED POEMS #1957-1982. By Wendell Berry. 268 pp. San Francisco: North Point Press. $16.50. CROSS TIES Selected Poems. By X. J. Kennedy. 168 pp. Athens: The University of Georgia Press. Cloth, $16.95. Paper, $9.95. WENDELL BERRY'S poetry is a validation of his decision nearly 20 years ago to give up the literary life in New York and seek a deeper bond with his ancestral home, a hillside farm in Henry County, Kentucky, on the Kentucky River. His straightforward search for a life connected to the soil, for marriage as sacrament and family life, affirms a style that is resonant with the authentic. The lyricism is not forced, but clearly grows out of a deep bond with the earth and its generosity, with all of nature. He mocks little except man's arrogance and destructiveness, and he can be said to have returned American poetry to a Wordsworthian clarity of purpose. Nor is Wordsworth's piety out of place in Mr. Berry's world; the rustic and the rural are honored and celebrated with seldom if ever a touch of doubt for the course undertaken, a deeply committed life.

title: BUDGET PROBLEMS CLOSING SCHOOLS IN OREGON
description: Normally busy classrooms and playgrounds in the Sandy Elementary School District are locked and empty these days, shut since Nov. 7, when the town's middle school and three grade schools were closed for lack of money.

title: HUN SCHOOL, NEAR ITS 75th YEAR, PLANS A MAJOR EXPANSION
description: WITH the announcement of a $10.5 million capital improvement project, The Hun School here is undertaking its most ambitious building program.

title: 'OFF-BROAD STREET' AT SYMPHONY HALL
description: ''OFF Broadway on Broad Street'' is the catch phrase for Newark Symphony Hall's attempt to implant a theatrical identity locally.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: BENEFIT WALK A Walk for Hunger, sponsored by the Yonkers Council of Churches, steps off at 2 P.M. today from the Asbury United Methodist Church at 167 Scarsdale Road in Crestwood. Walkers can set their own pace because they are not competing in a race or a marathon. Contributions from per-mile sponsors will help with the expected $10,000 cost of a year's operation at the Emergency Food Center at 2 Hudson Street in Yonkers. The Rev. Lester McGonagle, pastor of the North Yonkers Community Church, is chairman of the center.

title: THE POLICE EXAM THAT FLUNKED
description: About 200 black and Hispanic police officers who failed the last examination for promotion to sergeant will be promoted anyway, the Koch administration disclosed last week - explaining that the supposedly bias-proof exam had just earned an ''F'' from the city's own lawyers.

title: PHILADELPHIA AREA TAKES ON NEW IDENTITY FOR A ROBUST, POST-INDUSTRIAL ERA
description: In its three centuries of life, Philadelphia has grown into and out of at least two sharply defined personalities. Now a third is rapidly crystallizing, and economists say it illustrates the way the Northeast as a whole has entered a new, more robust economic era.

title: A BRITISH PRODUCER SAVORS 'THE FREEDOM TO GET IT RIGHT'
description: ''British television comes from a theater tradition - it is rooted in literature and drama. American television comes from the cinema tradition - Hollywood film making. That difference in origin tells a great deal about our approach and yours to television dramatization.''

title: PUTTING THE HOMESTEAD DEEPER INTO HOCK
description: TURN on the television. Open the junk mail.

title: DENISE RUEPPEL TO WED CLAY EDWARD STOBAUGH
description: The engagement of Denise Charlotte Rueppel to Clay Edward Stobaugh has been announced by Charlotte Norton Rueppel of Sacramento, Calif., and Bruce Edwin Rueppel of San Francisco, parents of the future bride. Her fiance is a son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Blair Stobaugh of Belmont, Mass.

title: Our Ghastly Longings
description: To the Editor:

title: IRAN NAMES CLERIC KHOMEINI'S EVENTUAL SUCCESSOR
description: The Iranian Government press agency announced today that Ayatollah Hussein Ali Montazeri had been formally designated as the eventual succesor to Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, Iran's religious leader.

title: CRAIG POWELL MARRIED TO LORAINE A. WILDER
description: The Bryn Mawr (Pa.) Presbyterian Church was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Loraine Alexandra Wilder, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert G. Wilder of Penn Valley, Pa., and Montego Bay, Jamaica, to Craig Charles Powell, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Powell of Stroudsburg, Pa.

title: KNICK REUNION
description: The starting team that won the National Basketball Association championship for the Knicks in 1973 will be reunited. The Knicks have announced that the No. 15 worn by Earl (The Pearl) Monroe will be officially lofted to the ceiling of Madison Square Garden, never to be used again by a Knick player, after ceremonies honoring the 6-foot-3 1/2-inch guard at the Garden March 1.

title: LILCO TAKEOVER: DEBATE INTENSIFIES
description: PROPOSALS for a public takeover of the Long Island Lighting Company are gaining ground and appear likely to be debated at length when the State Legislature convenes in January, Long Island officials said last week.

title: BOOKSHELF
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: DRAMA GROUP FOR DISABLED GKVEN $20,000
description: THE $20,000 check that arrived last week was the largest single contribution ever received by the National Theater Workshop of the Handicapped since it was founded in Manhattan in 1977.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: I NEVER PLAYED THE GAME. By Howard Cosell with Peter Bonventre. (Morrow, $18.95.) Over and over, as you read Howard Cosell's ''I Never Played the Game,'' you wish he would stop.

title: ONCE BURNED
description: The first time Edward A. Curran came before the Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee, he promised to promote the work of the research agency he had been nominated to head, the National Institute for Education.

title: A QUIET BOOM IN INITIAL STOCK OFFERINGS
description: THE strong stock market rally of the past two months has encouraged a lot of corporations to go public. On Tuesday, for instance, there were four initial public offerings, and on Wednesday underwriters brought out stock in 12 more companies. Indeed, 1985 is shaping up as the second-most-active year ever for I.P.O.'s.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch on Sunday about the opening of the Colorado River Project in Phoenix described Eldon Rudd incorrectly. He remains a member of the House of Representatives from Arizona.

title: Train Derails in Oregon Spilling Carloads of Grain
description: Fifty-eight grain cars on a Union Pacific Railroad freight train jumped the tracks in a remote canyon in eastern Oregon today, tearing up more than 500 feet of track and disrupting Amtrak traffic.

title: THE THANKSGIVING GUESTS: QUIALITY OF MERCY STRAINED
description: The call came to the church office in Huntington when the ushers were counting the morning offering. A man and his wife were jobless, homeless and hungry on Thanksgiving. Could the church help? The ushers acted with the usual predictability to unexpected events: they told the caller that the pastor would help them out.

title: YONKERS OFFICIALS HELD LIABLE FORE SEGREGATION
description: Judge Leonard B. Sand ruled in Federal District Court last week that public housing and schools in Yonkers had been ''illegally and intentionally'' segregated. There were immediate signs that city and school officials would try to find remedies themselves rather than let the court do it for them.

title: AUTEUR DIRECTORS BRING NEW LIFE TO THEATER
description: When people talk about memorable evenings in the theater, they usually tend to cite indelible plays, performances, scenes and lines. But, with ever increasing frequency in recent seasons, one could just as easily compile a list of highly charged theatrical moments that have little or nothing to do with playwriting or even acting in the conventional sense. They are directors' moments -often visual or gestural rather than verbal - and, at their best, they carry a weight that can rival a dramatist's highest achievements. While such stage pictures may not create characters or tell stories, they invade or provoke an audience's consciousness, producing what Artaud once called ''the truthful precipitates of dreams.''

title: SPRUCING UP PHILADELPHIA
description: SOME Philadelphians call their city Filthydelphia, but PhilaPride is out to change all that.

title: WRECKED BARGES STALL ECONOMY ON MONONGAHELA
description: The floods that overran the Monongahela River earlier this month put a blue-collar river out of work, and workers using cutting torches and explosives are laboring round the clock to clear wrecked barges from the channel.

title: TAX REFORM GETS CLOSER, AND BETTER
description: Against expectation, the House Ways and Means Committee has moved a giant step closer to tax reform. The reality of this labor is that rewriting the tax code is a political act. Reformers seek simplicity, fairness and efficiency but disagree on how to get there. One person's simplicity is another's unfairness, and sweating out compromises causes new complexities.

title: CARRIE THOMAS IS WED TO DAVID D. FARRINGTON
description: Carrie Thomas, a daughter of Judge and Mrs. P. Richard Thomas of Meadville, Pa., was married yesterday to David D. Farrington, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Ralph Farrington of Framingham, Mass. The Rev. Thomas K. Tewell performed the ceremony at the Presbyterian Church at New Providence, N.J.

title: ANNE STRASSNER, A LAWYER, WED TO S. K. FELDMAN
description: Anne Lemoine Strassner, a lawyer with Sann & Howe, and Sandy Kligerman Feldman, a lawyer with Webster & Sheffield, both New York law firms, were married yesterday at the Lotos Club in New York. Civil Court Judge Robert Lippmann performed the ceremony.

title: JANE CLARK IS ENGAGED
description: The Rev. and Mrs. Holland Ball Clark of Hilton Head Island, S.C., have announced that their daughter Jane Edmonds Clark and Robert Lee Banse Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Banse of Lawrenceville, N.J., are to be married Dec. 31.

title: BEDROOM MEETING AN ISSUE IN LOUISIANA TRIAL
description: Testimony in the racketeering trial of Gov. Edwin W. Edwards has turned once again to the Governor's appearance in the back bedroom of a house in north Louisiana, an incident portrayed by prosecutors as significant and by defense lawyers as routine.

title: CENSUS DATA NOTE WIDER INCOME GAP
description: THE gap in average incomes between the state's poorest and richest areas widened from 1979 to 1983, the Connecticut Census Data Center reported last week.

title: U.S. Renews Seychelles Pact For a Satellite Tracking Post
description: The Government has signed a new lease agreement with the United States for the use of a satellite tracking station on the island of Mahe.

title: FARM IS HONORED FOR ITS INNOVATIVE WAYS
description: DRIVING around his farm in a red pickup truck, John Dzen pointed to rows of evergreens, each about a foot high.

title: ETHICS UNIT FIGHTS TO RESTORE POWER
description: Seven years ago the Massachusetts Legislature created the State Ethics Commission to police conflict of interest and financial disclosure laws for public officials. Now the State Senate is working to curb the commission's powers.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE EVIDENCE OF THINGS NOT SEEN. By James Baldwin. (Holt, $11.95.) The worst two years in Atlanta's history were 1980 and 1981, when the bodies of dead black children turned up all over the city. In the atmosphere of panic and paranoia that grew with each horrible discovery, ''Atlanta became, for a season, a kind of grotesque Disneyland.'' So writes James Baldwin of the plague of unsolved murders that ultimately totaled 28, according to a police task force set up to investigate them. The ordeal in Atlanta, whose black leadership was slow to recognize the crisis being visited upon its poorest citizens, would seem an aptly challenging subject for a writer of Mr. Baldwin's gifts. But this slim volume will not satisfy many readers. Nor, one suspects, does it satisfy the author himself. ''I have never, in all my journeys, felt more of an interloper, a stranger, than I felt in Atlanta,'' writes Mr. Baldwin, who was on assignment for Playboy, where much of this book first appeared. There is far too much sermonizing here on the overall state of race relations in America and not enough digging into specific facts of the Atlanta murders. Nonetheless, when Mr. Baldwin steps down from the pulpit he can still bring passionate intensity to reportage, especially in an assessment of Wayne Williams, the failed music promoter whose 1982 conviction for two murders closed the Atlanta case. Mr. Baldwin derides the controversial fiber evidence that allegedly connected two victims with Mr. Williams's home in what the author terms ''an untidy trial,'' and he judges the verdict dubious.

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: TINKERS IN PHILADELPHIA As many adults as children show up at the Franklin Institute in Philadelphia at Thanksgiving time to play with Tinkertoys. Big Tinkertoys, inspiring grandiose concoctions.

title: FATAL FLAWS FOR A SHOREHAM DRILL
description: A VERY attractive argument has emerged in the Shoreham nuclear power plant controversy: Resolve the question of whether evacuation, in the event of a Shoreham mishap, will work by conducting a test of the plan, as has been scheduled by the Federal Emergency Management Agency. If the test fails, so goes the argument, then Shoreham should rightfully be abandoned. Conversely, the plant should be licensed for full-power operation if this test gets a passing grade.

title: Merlo J. Pusey Dies; Justice's Biographer Won a Pulitzer Prize
description: Merlo J. Pusey, a Pulitzer Prize-winning biographer and retired editorial writer, died of cancer Friday at a Washington hospital. He was 83 years old and lived in Dickerson, Md.

title: GURU'S DEPARTURE FORCING COMMUNE TO DISBAND, MAYOR SAYS
description: Members of this religious community in central Oregon will disband their commune now that its leader, Bhagwan Shree Rajneesh, has left the United States, its Mayor says.

title: DOCTOR FIGHTS FOR DYSLEXIA THEORY
description: A GREAT NECK doctor is in conflict with a segment of the national medical and educational community over the best way to treat dyslexia -the reading disorder that turns the letter b into d, the word ''was'' into ''saw,'' and bright children into frustrated students.

title: TENNESSEE ROUTS KENTUCKY BY 42-0
description: Daryl Dickey passed for three touchdowns and ran for one as Tennessee recovered in the second half to rout Kentucky, 42-0, in a Southeastern Conference game. Tennessee is 7-1-2 over all and 4-1 in the conference. The Volunteers need a victory over Vanderbilt next week to win their first conference championship since 1969 and a berth in the Sugar Bowl.

title: DR. J. WARREN TOFF
description: Dr. J. Warren Toff, a public health official in New York City for many years, died of a stroke Wednesday at the Boca Raton Community Hospital in Florida.

title: STATE CUTS SCHOOL AID ON PROJECTS
description: THE State Department of Education has notified at least 12 towns that they will be receiving millions of dollars less than they expected in state reimbursement for school construction projects.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: IN THE CHAMBER If it is also true that good things musical come in small ensemble packages, then today is a day to take advantage of them. Starting real small - with just five musicians -concertgoers have two choices at 3 P.M. The first is the New York Woodwind Quintet, which plays Hindemith, Mozart and Villa-Lobos at the Recital Hall of the Fine Arts Center at the State University of New York at Stony Brook (call 246-5678 for tickets). The second is the Ray Alexander Quintet, which offers the ''Great Sounds of Jazz'' in a free performance at New York Institute of Technology's Salten Hall on its Old Westbury campus. The latter is the first of three concerts in the Town of Oyster Bay's jazz series that will also feature Galt MacDermot in March and Billy Mitchell in April.

title: HUGH TINNEY
description: It took no more than a few bars of Beethoven's Sonata no. 7 (Op. 10, No. 3) for the Irish pianist Hugh Tinney to establish the qualities that made his recital at the 92nd St. Y last Saturday a bracing success. The vitality of accentuation, the clean brightness of the forte playing, the rhythmic urgency and lively independence of contrapuntal voices all made the ears perk up.

title: HARTMAN REVIVES 'PHILADELPHIA STORY'
description: MOVIE memories can be as intimidating as they are irreplaceable. No one can forget the triumphant Katharine Hepburn-Cary Grant-James Stewart triumverate in ''The Philadelphia Story.''

title: FEW GOALS REMAIN FOR BERGEN COACH
description: FOR Elaine Borzotta, being first is habit-forming. She was a co-captain of the boys' junior varsity soccer team at Rutherford High School - the first female to serve in such a capacity -and, as a senior, the first girl to play on the boys' varsity team.

title: J. G. GLICKER ENGAGED TO ROBIN H. HELFAND
description: The engagement of Robin Hope Helfand and James G. Glicker has been announced by her parents, Dr. and Mrs. Eugene Helfand of Berkeley Heights, N.J. A spring wedding is planned.

title: A WARM RECEPTION FOR FREE FIREWOOD
description: THE kitchen is a little warmer these mornings for Joseph Rouillard, a 60-year-old retired mill worker in Plainfield, thanks to a town program that distributes firewood to the disabled, elderly and the needy, free of charge.

title: URBAN CHIC, ECLECTIC TASTES
description: R.S. JENSEN, a new restaurant in Glenwood Landing, takes its kitchen seriously. Its chef, a graduate of the Culinary Institute of America in Hyde Park, N.Y., is a young man of talent. Much of his cooking, a blend of new American and Continental with a liberal dose of spicy Cajun, provides the components for a fine meal.

title: CORRECTION
description: A caption with two photographs accompanying the Oct. 27 article ''The Private Palaces of Britain'' misidentified an interior designed by Robert Adam. The picture at the upper left of page 50 and the full-page close-up of detail of the same room, on page 51, are of the anteroom of Syon House, in Middlesex, designed by Adam in the mid-1760's.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption from the Associated Press in some copies of this section last Sunday, with an article about the Penn State-Nortre Dame football game, misidentifies a player from Notre Dame. He was Hal Von Wyl, not Steve Beuerein.

title: THE ANSWER WOMAN
description: It sometimes seems in Washington that most of the people not in the Government are trying to make a living as consultants to the people who are in the Government.

title: TRAVEL BOOKSHELF
description: Liners to the Sun By John Maxtone-Graham. 495 pages. Macmillan. $29.95.

title: MUSIC: KRONOS QUARTET IN JAZZ WRITERS' WORKS
description: JAZZ composers belong with America's other modern musicians. The Kronos String Quartet made that clear in an intelligent program Friday night at Carnegie Recital Hall that presented four premieres -three world, one New York - by composers who are normally associated with jazz. The concert opened the 50th season of Composers Forum, which presents new music, and it was more than good public relations: It yielded four worthwhile new pieces for string quartet.

title: DENTAL DILEMMA
description: THE 15-year-old boy settled into the orthodontist's chair in a suburb outside of Detroit and demanded that the braces on his teeth be removed. The orthodontist replied that he would first have to get the permission of the youth's parents.

title: CRIME FIGURE AT TRIAL TELLS OF CASINO SCHEME
description: Leaders of organized crime in four Middle Western cities joined to press a pension fund of the teamsters' union to grant loans with which they gained control of four Las Vegas gambling casinos, according to testimony from Angelo Lonardo, who said he participated in the operation.

title: KIM SCHOLES
description: Lively teamwork between the cellist Kim Scholes and the pianist Marc Silverman was the most memorable feature of the former's debut concert at Carnegie Recital Hall Tuesday. Their timing, unity of rhythmic impulse and careful blending of sonorities made rather more of Prokofiev's Op. 119 sonata and Bloch's ''Meditation hebraique'' than one had thought was there.

title: ISTANBUL
description: To the Editor: Your recent article ''What's Doing in Istanbul'' (Travel, Oct. 13) captured many of the wonderful highlights of the city.

title: HEMINGWAY'S SPAIN
description: ''Spain,'' the woman of Pablo said bitterly. Then turned to Robert Jordan.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: A PILGRIM QUEST (FOR PLYMOUTH ROCK)
description: Heather Vincent posed impatiently before the Rock while her father, William, focused the camera, determined to get one of the nation's oldest symbols in the background of the picture.

title: OSSINING GOES TO 9-0
description: The fullback Don Ridenhour rushed for more than 200 yards and scored four touchdowns to lead undefeated Ossining to a 28-27 victory over rival Sleepy Hollow in a hard-fought game at Ossining Field yesterday.

title: WHITE HOUSE POINT MAN: Clayton K. Yeutter;   ENFORCING REAGAN'S NEW TRADE POLICY
description: WITH his beefy six-foot frame and hog-caller's voice, the United States trade representative, Clayton K. Yeutter, of Eustis, Neb., resembles the successful farmer he once wanted to be: He flashes a contagious grin and his strong handshake suggests that he has milked a lot of cows.

title: BETH WESLER IS ENGAGED
description: Norman Wesler and Dorothy Wesler, both of Dix Hills, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Beth J. Wesler to Philip Powell Dunn, the son of Gloria Dunn of Flushing, Queens.

title: BATTLE OVER EAST END MALL
description: THE refurbishment and expansion of a shopping center on the development-conscious East End is causing an outcry from local residents.

title: PLAN TO TAKE STATE MONEY OUT OF PRETORIA
description: THE General Assembly is to consider a proposal in its upcoming session to withdraw all state money invested in American companies doing business in South Africa.

title: SMALL VINEYARDS BY THE BARREL IN AUSTRALIA
description: On the first night my wife and I were in Australia, we had dinner at the San Francisco Grill of the Sydney Hilton, and the wine list was proffered. There were, of course, French wines on it; one expected no less from an elegant, expense-account-oriented restaurant. But the majority of the entries were of Australian provenance.

title: BALANCE SHEETS AREN'T ALL THAT WEAK
description: INCREASINGLY, we hear that United States corporations are sliding down a slippery slope of excessive reliance on shaky debt financing. This trend, it is argued, could lead to strings of bankruptcies in the event of a serious economic contraction.

title: ONE-DAY MARKET OFFERS VARIED ITEMS
description: SMALL furniture, pottery, porcelains, glass and a great variety of other antiques -mostly decorative accessories - will be shown today at the second annual Collector's Eye market in Danbury.

title: CORRECTION
description: A caption Nov, 17 that accompanied a listing of Caribean islands and their offerings misidentifies a harbor in Autigua as St. John's harbor. The harbor was English Harbor.

title: A SCHOLAR'S FIND: SHAKESPEAREAN LYRIC
description: A 32-year-old American from Topeka, Kan., has discovered a previously unknown nine-stanza love lyric that is attributed in the manuscript copy to William Shakespeare. It appears to be the first addition to the Shakespeare canon since the 17th century.

title: Tish Beitzel Weds a Financial Analyst
description: At the First Congregational Church in Chappaqua, N.Y., yesterday Mary Elizabeth Beitzel, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George B. Beitzel of Chappaqua, was married to Robert Vredenburgh, a son of Dr. Donald Vredenburgh, also of Chappaqua, and the late Margaret Vredenburgh. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Richard Ryder, assisted by Msgr.

title: FURNITURE IS STAR OF CRAFTS EXHIBITION
description: THE unfortunate thing about describing items on display at the Annual Celebration of American Crafts at the Creative Arts Workshop in New Haven is that many of them may have disappeared before you get a chance to see them. That is because the exhibition is also a sale that raises money for the workshop.

title: WOOLWORTH'S NEW WAGER
description: THEIR names are hardly household words. Herald Square Stationers. Frame Scene. The Rx Place. Kids Mart. Athletic Shoe Factory. But if the gamble taken by their parent pays off, they may add luster to a name that is, in fact, known in practically every American household: Woolworth.

title: WHEN IS A CRIMINAL CONSPIRACY ALSO AN ACT OF CONSCIENCE?
description: Before their trial opened last week, 11 religious activists accused of smuggling Central American refugees into the United States said their case would be presented ''in silhouette.'' They meant that the jury would have to guess what their defense would be, since a judge had restricted the arguments they could make at the trial. When their lawyers presented their opening statements, the defendants - including two Roman Catholic priests, a nun and a Protestant minister - learned just how vague that silhouette is likely to be.

title: SHOOTING TIPS FOR THE GREAT OUTDOORS
description: THE L. L. Bean Christmas catalogue comes with a surprise this year - a few pages after the snow sneakers, sleeping-bag liners and combination compass-match case-whistle, it offers videotaped lessons in outdoor photography.

title: WHEN THE YUPPIE TIME FRAME REACHES THANKSGIVING
description: WHEN my friend Hilda's daughter called last week and invited her for Thanksgiving, Hilda was, naturally, very thrilled.

title: Unemployment
description: To the Editor:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: Still we passed till at last We sat to repose us for our pleasure.

title: TWISTS AND TURNS
description: TRADITIONALLY, AN INVITATION THAT READS ''BLACK tie'' has meant just that: evening clothes, more popularly known as a tuxedo, set off by a black bow tie on a white pleated dress shirt. These days, however, it is not necessary to take such dressing instructions quite so literally.

title: MANDATORY RECYCLING: WHERE IS IT?
description: LAST January, when Governor Kean called for a program to ''recycle fully 25 percent of this waste stream by the end of next year,'' he drew praise. But when the administration's mandatory recycling bill was introduced in March, praise for the concept gave way to criticism of the legislation.

title: THE PSYCHOLOGICAL ROUTE TO CUTTING COSTS
description: Bill Thompson was in bad shape. He had no appetite, could not sleep, and had lost interest in sex. His lower back pain had gotten so bad that he was missing work frequently. Finally he could not go to work at all.

title: A SKEPTIC REFLECTS ON ENCOUTNER WITH UFO
description: NO one really takes UFO sightings too seriously. After all, have you ever seen an unidentified flying object?

title: BROWN ROUTS COLUMBIA (1-10)
description: When Jim Garrett held his first team meeting as the Columbia football coach last January, one of the first things he told his players was: ''Last year, 0 and 9; next year, 10 and 0.''

title: THE WORLD AHEAD
description: As a white educator interested in issues concerning young children and social policy, and as an urban public-school parent, I would tell Dr. Deborah Prothrow Stith that she is right when she says, ''There is a part of me that says I still can't trust white folks'' (''The World Ahead,'' by Thomas Morgan, Oct. 27). In no way, should black parents assume that racism has been eliminated from the American public school system.

title: AMERICAN DREAMS
description: American Dreams Alexander Haig still has trouble with political parlance. The man once known for nuancing this or caveating that now hints he might run for the Republican nomination for President in 1988.

title: FRESH VITALITY FOR SOME FAMILIAR WARHORSES
description: Of making many books, Ecclesiastes said, there is no end. The same seems true of recordings of staples of the symphonic repertory.

title: NEW YORK LEADERS HAIL VOTE TO RETAIN LOCAL-TAX DEDUCTION
description: Governor Cuomo, Mayor Koch and New York's two United States Senators yesterday hailed the decision of a Congressional tax-writing committee to continue allowing taxpayers to deduct state and local taxes from their Federal income-tax returns.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article about pensions in this section on Nov. 4 incorrectly stated Lockheed's plans for its pension funds. The company says it has no intention of terminating its pension plans or of withdrawing money from them.

title: Sulka Back on Park
description: Park Avenue has never been known as a shopping street. But signs of change have appeared recently along its short, staid retail strip, which runs roughly from 54th to 60th Streets.

title: A SPECIAL GATHERING OF BISHOPS
description: The key figures at the Extraordinary Synod of Bishops being convened today by Pope John Paul II include the group's three co-presidents - from the United States, Zaire and the Netherlands - as well as both national, elected leaders of the church and personal representatives appointed by the Pope himself.

title: KILLINGS PROMPT QUESTIONS ON U.S. GUN LAWS
description: The man in the pawnshop seems to remember Lois Lang very well. A week ago she walked into the shop he was tending for a friend and selected a blue-steel .38-caliber revolver.

title: A National Health
description: To the Editor:

title: Jazz
description: Little Jimmy Scott, one of the most strikingly original singers in jazz, returned to New York clubs this year after nearly three decades of retirement. This week, he will be appearing Wednesday through Saturday at the West End Cafe, 2911 Broadway at 114th Street.

title: PAPER IN A DISPUTE WITH SCHOOL BOARD
description: A LOCAL newspaper and a Five Towns school district are locked in a dispute that the editor of the paper says is an attempt at censorship.

title: Bomb Blast on Train In India Kills 2 Hindus
description: A bomb exploded Friday night on a train packed with Hindu workers entering Punjab state, killing 2 passengers and wounding 18 others, the police said today.

title: BUT ARMS DANGERS LURK
description: On one level, the summit meeting appears to have been a triumph of form over substance.

title: WHY THE TAX PLAN MAY TAKE DOWN COLLEGE SPORTS
description: YOU should have seen the look on Alixandra Hughes's face when she scored the winning goal for Penn State University as the Lady Lions defeated previously unbeaten and No. 1-ranked Connecticut in a women's field hockey match. The upset 3-2 victory at Lady Lion Field earlier this fall shocked the team and crowd into a joyous celebration as Penn State dethroned its archrival.

title: LANDMARK RULING IN YONKERS SUIT CHRONICLES INTENT
description: JUDGE Leonard B. Sand of Federal District Court in White Plains last week found Yonkers government and school officials liable for illegally and intentionally segregating the city's schools and public housing along racial lines. His decision marked the first time a Federal Court has linked housing patterns with racial segregation in schools.

title: CATHOLICS SEE SYNOD AS KEY TO ROLE OF WOMEN
description: When Eileen McMahon was a first grader in a Queens parochial school, she was asked to draw a picture of what she would like to be. She sketched herself as a priest.

title: SCOTTICH KILTS AND TWEEDS
description: The tiny village of Beauly, population 1,500, deep in the Western Highlands, has been snaring discerning shoppers in search of tweeds away from Inverness - its larger neighbor to the east - for as long as anyone can remember. There are those who would willingly travel farther to avail themselves of the merchandise at Campbell & Company, Highland Tweed House, Beauly. A family concern started in 1856, Campbell's has achieved an enviable reputation for its extensive selection of well-priced tweeds and tartans, and the flawless tailoring that is their hallmark.

title: LYNN PALGUTA IS MARRIED TO JOHN WILLIAM HAFFEY
description: Lynn Ann Palguta, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert F. Palguta of Woodridge, N.Y., was married yesterday to John William Haffey, the son of Jane D. Haffey of Norwalk, Conn., and the late William C. Haffey.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LOS ALAMOS EXPERIENCE. By Phyllis Fisher. (Japan Publications/Kodansha, $14.95.) Like millions of other American women during the early 1940's, Phyllis Fisher found one day that her world - a secure nest filled with a brilliant young husband, who was a physicist, a baby and a beloved fox terrier - had been thrown suddenly out of kilter by the war.

title: LOW-COST ADMISSION TO THE PLEASURES OF GOOD STEREO
description: The Puritan virtue of thrift, abandoned during the profligate years of inflation, now seems to be making a modest comeback. Balanced budgets are back in style (or at least talked about), and even being a tightwad is becoming trendy.

title: MARK YOUR CALENDARS
description: Not many people know now what they will do to celebrate the 200th anniversary of the Constitution two years hence, but over at the National Archives, the history-conscious document-collectors have one event all worked out. In 1976 the Archives held a 76-hour vigil in the rotunda where the original copies of the Declaration of Independence and the Constitution are displayed, encouraging the public to come in at any time and view the historic papers.

title: A QUESTION OF PARKING OR PULCHRITUDE
description: One of the most cherished perquisites to workers on Capitol Hill is a free, close-in, guaranteed place to park, of the type found on the East Plaza, directly in front of the Capitol, and on adjacent streets.

title: WICHITA GETS A CITY SONG FROM TWO WHO HADN'T BEEN THERE
description: When Wichita residents were looking to sing the praises of their city, it took a couple of carbetbagging New Yorkers to show them how.

title: MISS NADEAU PLANS TO WED
description: Dr. and Mrs. Robert E. Nadeau of Rochester have announced the engagement of their daughter Elizabeth Nadeau and Alan N. C. McHugh, the son of Dr. and Mrs. William D. McHugh, also of Rochester. A June wedding is planned.

title: 'TALK EXCHANGE': A PARTY LINE FOR 10
description: ''IT'S the best way to meet girls since the malls.'' That is how one teen-ager described a new telephone service offered by New Jersey Bell.

title: CHAIRMAN'S CLUB YIELDS DIVIDENDS FOR SUFFOLK G.O.P.
description: THE chairman's club run by the Suffolk County Republican leader, William M. Blake, proved to be a highly successful fund-raising device this year, according to financial reports filed with the Suffolk County Board of Elections.

title: JUDGES OF THE KEYBOARD
description: THERE THEY WERE, IN Sydney, Australia - 32 highly talented pianists, male and female, from 20 countries; the cream of the international crop; average age about 26 years; every one of them having a dozen or so required pieces at his finger tips, two concertos, a chamber-music piece and two full recital programs; all pinning their hopes on capturing first prize in this piano competition and going on to international celebrity, big fees and the other rewards of stardom.

title: ON EVE OF ROME SYNOD, A TOP U.S. BISHOP SEES POSSIBLE NEED FOR CHANGES
description: Bishop James W. Malone, the head of the American Roman Catholic delgation to an extraordinary Synod of Bishops that opens here Sunday, has raised the possible need for changes in key church policies in remarkably candid comments before a group of Catholic foundation heads.

title: 2 VIE TO LEASE RESORT BOAT BASIN
description: EAGER to rid itself of looming extensive and badly needed capital improvements to a marina here, the state will award a long-term operating lease for the boat basin before the new year.

title: AN ONTOLOGY FOR THE '80's
description: To the Editor:

title: HOLIDAY CONCERTS BEGIN
description: IN the county, the musical celebrations of the coming holidays have already begun. Today at 3 P.M., for example, Westchester's own Philharmonia Virtuosi is presenting a pre-Thanksgiving concert that not only offers a slightly belated 85th anniversary bow to Aaron Copland with a performance of his ''Quiet City,'' but pays fascinating tribute to another dean of American composers, Virgil Thomson, on the eve of his 89th birthday.

title: INTERNATIONAL CONVENTION
description: Coin dealers and collectors from around the world will gather this week for the 14th annual New York International Numismatic Convention. The show opens Saturday at the Sheraton Centre Hotel and continues through Monday.

title: SONIA RUBINSKY
description: The following afternoon in Carnegie Recital Hall, the Brazilian pianist Sonia Rubinsky played a program that began oddly but grew steadily in authority until it eventually became the most exciting debut of the week. The climax came with the visceral impact and virtuoso excitement of Villa-Lobos's ''Rudepoema,'' a long, brawny, unpredictable showpiece.

title: THE PAIN AND SHAME OF COLLEGIATE FOOTBALL
description: COACH kept running the halfback sweep through the projector over and over, clicking the stop, rewind and forward buttons to dwell on each ''individual breakdown'' by our defense. The play had gained 20 yards, and 11 individual breakdowns added up to a ''total team breakdown.''

title: WHO CHURCHILL HAD FOR BREAKFAST
description: THE FRINGES OF POWER #10 Downing Street Diaries 1939-1955. By John Colville. Illustrated. 796 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $25.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS
description: Nov. 24, 1985 Fiction

title: A CLAMDIGGER-BANKER CARRIES ON
description: IT'S not something you hear every day, but every time I do hear ''Old Long Island Clamdigger,'' I think of the men standing in the tough little boats along the route of the Great South Bay ferries, manning their great tongs and keeping their balance perfectly in the ferries' bouncing wake; of how they concentrate so hard on what they're doing, hardly glancing at the pleasure-bound or pleasure-leaving passengers: This is my living.

title: AMERICAN PERFORMERS LEARN CHINA'S STYLIZED AND INTRICATE TECHNIQUES
description: SU ZHI and Qu Yongchun usually spend their days teaching advanced classes at the Academy of Chinese Opera in Peking, the central training school in China for performers of the Peking Opera. But for the last six weeks, their students have been Americans, in classes and lecture demonstrations held at the Eugene O'Neill Theater Center in Waterford, Conn., and throughout the area.

title: GRACE BAKER ENGAGED
description: Mrs. J. C. Barden of Pleasantville, N.Y., has announced the engagement of her daughter Grace Baker to Ross Wade Sanders Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Sanders of Dallas.

title: NEW ERA FOR THE HEBREW ARTS SCHOOL
description: IN 1952, 16 students met once a week in Manhattan for a Sunday morning lesson in music and dance under the tutelage of a determined young woman named Tzipora Jochsberger.

title: SOONERS GAIN ORANGE BOWL
description: A sophomore tight end was Oklahoma's leading ground-gainer and scored the opening touchdown on an 88-yard trick play today as the Sooners earned a spot in the Orange Bowl by crushing Nebraska, 27-7.

title: MODERN-DANCE PIONEER IS PAID TRIBUTE ON COAST
description: It's been 32 years since he died, and the site of his Lester Horton Dance Theater has mutated into a flashy district of pop boutiques, art galleries and punk-rock diversions. But over the last few days, former students and collaborators of Mr. Horton assembled here to pay formal tribute for the first time to the leading West Coast pioneer of modern dance.

title: WARD SAYS POLICE DEPT. SHOULD CONTROL EXAMS
description: Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward called yesterday for major changes in the way police officers are promoted, suggesting as a first step that the Police Department be permitted to draw up its own examinations.

title: RIGHTISTS MARCH IN MADRID TO HONOR FRANCO
description: Tens of thousands of right-wing Spaniards marched through Madrid today singing fascist songs in a celebration marking the death 10 years ago of Francisco Franco.

title: CASE INTENSIFIES QUESTIONS AT C.I.A.
description: The arrest of a former Central Intelligence Agency analyst on charges of spying for the Chinese has raised new questions about security at the C.I.A., whose standing in Congress and within the Reagan Administration has been damaged by security breaches and public reverses.

title: MILITARY'S MESSAGE SYSTEM IS OVERLOADED, OFFICERS SAY
description: The United States military communications system has become so overloaded that it is nearly choking on the volume of messages it must handle, according to senior officers here and operational officers in the field.

title: Children's Peace Concert
description: Filling the air with songs of peace, bearing colorful banners and origami cranes, a procession of children marched through the nave of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine to the crescendoing music of the Independent School Orchestra.

title: Jewish Settlers Reach 51,600 in West Bank
description: The number of Jewish settlers living in the Israeli-occupied West Bank grew in the last year by 21.5 percent, to about 51,600, according to an authoritative Israeli study published today.

title: States Get $15.8 Million For Victims of Crime
description: Twenty states and the Virgin Islands will share $15.8 million to provide compensation and such services as rape counseling to the victims of crime under a grant program announced today by the Federal Government.

title: Advertising;   Brouillard Is Retained By Mead Data Central
description: Mead Data Central, a subsidiary of the Mead Corporation, Dayton, Ohio, has assigned its advertising account to Brouillard Communications, which is part of the J. Walter Thompson Company.

title: U.S. COMMENT ON ASSAULT
description: Following is a statement issued by the State Department after the assault by Egyptian commandos on the hijacked Egyptair jet at the Malta airport:

title: NETS DEFEAT KINGS BY 118-103
description: They were never known as a team of defensive specialists before, but the Nets are slowly building a reputation. They are willing to bump and bruise when it becomes necessary, and the results have been vivid. Tonight, they battered the Sacramento Kings, 118-103, and won their third consecutive road game after losing their first seven of the season.

title: Papua New Guinea Studying Clash on Indonesian Border
description: A reported ambush of an Indonesian border survey team by rebels and a counterattack by Indonesian soldiers are being investigated by Papua New Guinea authorities, officials said today.

title: Advertising;   Times Sq. Presence For Kodak
description: THE Eastman Kodak Company, which for 35 years has presented its own gigantic photo album to the multitudes passing through Grand Central Terminal, will add its own touch of colorful beauty to the Times Square scene starting tomorrow in a 30-foot by 50-foot niche built into the facade of the new Marriott Marquis Hotel.

title: NEW SPYING CASE REPORTED BY U.S.
description: A former communications specialist for the National Security Agency was arrested early this morning and charged with spying for the Soviet Union.

title: Explosion at an Irish Prison
description: An attempt by prisoners to blast their way out of a top security Irish prison failed today when a bomb planted at the front gates did not fully detonate, a Government spokesman said. He said that no one escaped and no one was injured in the attempted breakout at the prison here, about 40 miles from Dublin. The facility houses several members of the outlawed Irish Republican Army, but it was not clear whether any members were involved.

title: A Sticky Launching Pad
description: Many of George Bush's political supporters may not be aware how difficult, historically and statistically, the political goal is that he has apparently set for himself: using the Vice Presidency as a direct launching pad for a successful Presidential campaign.

title: Sheryl R. Miller Wed On L.I. to a Physician
description: Sheryl R. Miller, a fourth-year medical student at the State University of New York Downstate Medical Center, and Dr. Michael Rabinowitz, an intern at the Staten Island Hospital, were married yesterday. Rabbi Sheldon Thall performed the ceremony at the Great Neck (L.I.) Synagogue.

title: COMPANIES GIVING A HAND TO HARTFORD'S POOR
description: Under pressure from several highly organized and sometimes strident neighborhood organizations, some of this city's larger corporations are being asked to play a major and growing role in housing, educating and employing the poor.

title: CONFLICT ALL ABOUT , LEADER WORKS THE HAT TREE
description: Bob Dole of Kansas, the Senate majority leader, was on his feet last week, extolling the virtues of a substitute farm legislation he was about to introduce. For the Reagan Administration, he said, the amendment would cut costs by more than $11 billion. For the Kansas wheat farmers, price supports would stay high.

title: ATTACK 'WAS OUR ONLY HOPE,' PILOT OF FLIGHT 648 DECLARES
description: Capt. Hani Galal, his head bandaged and dried bloodstains on his pilot's uniform, early today staunchly defended Egypt's storming of the Boeing 737 in which at least 50 people died.

title: IMPACT OF TEXAS SCHOOL LAW HITS HOME WITH FOOTBALL SEASON
description: Texans are getting little television lectures from Gov. Mark White these weeks. ''The other day a mother told me that her son couldn't play on the local high school football team because he had failed his English course,'' he intones as a youth in football gear and his parents appear on the screen.

title: Richard Sasanow Marries Terri S. Feinstein, Lawyer
description: Terri Suzanne Feinstein, a senior associate in the law firm of Kleinberg, Kaplan, Wolff & Cohen, and Richard Stuart Sasanow, a senior writer and marketing consultant at Arthur Young & Company, the tax, auditing and management consulting firm, were married in New York yesterday.

title: KINGS ARE WINNERS TO SACRAMENTO FANS
description: The acceptance was immediate and absolute, perhaps because the people who live here have thirsted for an identity apart from state politics. And now they have one: the Sacramento Kings, uprooted from Kansas City by new owners at the end of last season and embraced - for the moment, at least - by a city willing to give pro basketball a chance.

title: SOHN'S RUN TO LEFT A COMMITTEE CALL
description: One of the most difficult feats in the National Football League is to return a punt for good distance. That is the opinion of Larry Pasquale, special teams coach of the Jets, and figures bear him out.

title: Learning There Are Limits
description: When we look back at the Geneva summit a few years from now, will it mean anything? Will it have earned a page of history? Not likely. But it will if time has shown that it did one thing: taught the two principals something about the limits of their power.

title: Treasury Financings Remain Heavy
description: Treasury financings will continue to be heavy this week, with auctions of three- and six-month bills today, 12-month bills tomorrow and notes due in five years and two months on Wednesday.

title: Still Lower Yields Forecast
description: Expectations of a weak economy, a more generous monetary policy and Congressional action to reduce budget deficits were three widely cited explanations for the decline in Treasury bond yields to about 10 percent recently from 10 1/2 percent in late October.

title: 50 ON PLANE DIE AS GUNMEN HURL GRENADES WHEN EGYPT STORMS HIJACKED JET IN MALTA
description: At least 50 passengers aboard a hijacked Egyptair jetliner were killed here Sunday night when Egyptian special forces stormed the plane and the hijackers retaliated by tossing three grenades at the passengers, the authorities here said.

title: Bridge: A Tournament Chairman Has a Number of Worries
description: The hardest worker at a tournament is the director, who is a paid professional. The second-hardest is the tournament chairman, an amateur who is constantly occupied with, and frequently interrupted at the card table by, a variety of topics that may include air-conditioning, appeals and conventions.

title: COWBOYS TOP EAGLES
description: Danny White threw three touchdown passes today to lead the Dallas Cowboys back from the worst defeat in their history to a 34-17 victory over the Philadelphia Eagles.

title: Washington Watch;   Volcker Trip, Martin Denial
description: The Federal Reserve Board's chairman, Paul A. Volcker, left town Thursday for an unusually long overseas trip that will keep him away from his office until next Monday. He flew to debt-strapped Argentina and might stop in Venezuela on the way back, an aide said.

title: HONDURANS VOTE FOR A NEW LEADER
description: Disputes over voting procedures in the presidential contest today delayed balloting in much of Honduras and many voters standing in lines appeared to be unsure what method would be used to determine the victor.

title: I. Magnin Officer Shifts To Allied's Taylor Unit
description: As a student at New York University in the late 1960's, Mark Shulman thought he wanted to be a lawyer. But that changed one day after he invited Lawrence Lachman, then the chairman of Bloomingdale's, to address a group of undergraduates.

title: JURY ACQUITS ALL TRANSIT OFFICERS IN 1983 DEATH OF MICHAEL STEWART
description: The six transit police officers charged in the 1983 death of Michael Stewart, who lapsed into a coma while in police custody and died 13 days later, were acquitted of all charges yesterday before an emotional crowd in State Supreme Court in Manhattan.

title: Dial M For Muddle
description: I want to believe that economic competition is the best way to create quality goods and services at reasonable cost. It seems logical that winners and losers should emerge from the chaos of the free market - and that the winners should be those entrepreneurs best able to meet consumers' needs. Lately, however, my faith in the free market has been shaken. I blame the phone company.

title: VIETNAMESE GANGS ACTIVE IN FLORIDA
description: Law-enforcement officials here have noted an increasing number of robberies of Vietnamese families.

title: JAZZ: CARMEN LUNDY
description: FOR several years Carmen Lundy has been one of the most promising of today's younger jazz singers. But that ''promise'' has been tantalizing, just a step away from fulfillment, although in some of her performances she has been undercut by mechanical problems.

title: SAM WEST
description: Sam West, a former major league baseball player who appeared in the first All-Star Game in 1933, died Saturday at a local hospital.

title: Less Than a Revolution
description: American women, despite sharply heightened political activity and public attention in the last decade, have not made significant gains in their representation in Congress, and 1986 does not appear, at this point, to be the year of their big breakthrough.

title: TO GUNN, CITY'S TRANSIT IS BETTER, BUT NOT BEST
description: ''It's not perfect,'' said David L. Gunn, leaning back in his high-backed black leather chair with his feet on his desk. ''I'm not trying to give the impression that the place is a Swiss watch. But we feel we have established a little bit of credibility that I don't think we had before.''

title: TAPES AT COLOMBO TRIAL OFFER A GLIMPSE INTO THE UNDERCOVER WORLD
description: When testimony resumes today in the Federal racketeering trial of 11 reputed leaders of the Colombo crime organization, the focus will again be on conversations with some of the defendants secretly recorded by an Internal Revenue Service agent who pretended to be corrupt.

title: GREY CUP TO BRITISH COLUMBIA
description: Ned Armour, a former San Diego State track star who never played college football, caught two long touchdown passes today to lead the British Columbia Lions to a 37-24 victory over the Hamilton Tiger-Cats for the Grey Cup, representing the Canadian Football League championship.

title: FEIFFER'S 'GROWN UPS,' ON SHOWTIME
description: THE ''Broadway on Showtime'' series on the pay-cable channel has been compiling an impressive record as it mixes the popular (''Sweeney Todd,'' ''You Can't Take It With You'') with more demanding productions ('' 'Master Harold' . . . and the Boys,'' ''The Biko Inquest''). Tonight at 9 o'clock, it is offering a play that deserves attention even though it fell considerably short of being a Broadway smash hit. Jules Feiffer's ''Grown Ups'' opened in 1981 and, despite some enthusiastic reviews, ran for only a couple of months. Mr. Feiffer's humor is far darker and more unsettling than, say, Neil Simon's.

title: ISLANDERS TOP RANGERS, 4-3, IN OVERTIME
description: He saw a teammate across the ice. He also saw the opponent in the way, but the danger did not register until it was too late. As the Rangers' Steve Richmond let the puck go, he wished to himself, ''Oh, give me that back.''

title: STUDENTS SEEK OUT AIDS ADIVCE
description: For the students of the Birch Wathen School who meet weekly to discuss local and global problems in a community service seminar, volunteering is nothing new. What is new for the group, whose members' average age is 17, is raising money for AIDS research and inviting speakers from the Gay Men's Health Crisis and the National Gay Task Force to speak at their school.

title: EXPANDING MOVEMENT TRIES TO PRESERVE SEEDS, AND CULTURE, OF BYGONE FARMING
description: In what was a kitchen when the Talavaya Center's offices were still a house, the cupboards and counters are crowded with jars full of seeds.

title: Maria A. Danzilo, Lawyer, Marries David Roy Smith
description: Maria Agatha Danzilo and David Roy Smith were married yesterday at Waveny House in New Canaan, Conn., by the Rev. J. Peter Cullen, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Article 180037 -- No Title
description: The Federal Government, which ran up the largest deficit in history in the fiscal year 1985, started the new fiscal year on the same note, recording a $27.09 billion imbalance for October, the Treasury Department reported Friday.

title: Explosion Grounds Jetliner
description: An explosion aboard an Eastern Air Lines jetliner carrying 70 passengers spewed smoke through the cabin tonight, forcing the Miami-bound plane back to the St. Croix, V.I., airport just after if had taken off, officials said. One passenger, Pete Meyer, said from the airport that four passengers on the Boeing 757 jet had been taken to a hospital for X-rays, but an Eastern spokesman, Glenn Parsons, said he could not confirm the report. Mr. Parsons attributed the explosion to an air-conditioning malfunction.

title: Article 181061 -- No Title
description: A fire that police said was set swept through offices at Colonie Central High School late Saturday, causing an estimated $500,000 damage.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Adams Drug Co., Pawtucket, R.I., has named William Sudhaus president and chief executive officer, succeeding James A. Salmanson, who will continue as a consultant.

title: SYRACUSE'S COACH TRIES TO QUIET FANS
description: Most coaches draw technical fouls on themselves by cursing and harassing basketball officials. But Jim Boeheim, the Syracuse coach, deliberately wanted one Saturday night when he asked an official to assess a two-shot technical against his team in an effort to curtail the shouting of obscenities from a student section among the crowd of 24,357 in the Carrier Dome.

title: Sri Lanka Arrests 30 In Crackdown on Rebels
description: More than 30 people have been arrested in a crackdown on a militant Sinhalese group with links to guerrillas fighting to set up a separate Tamil state, security sources said today.

title: HOTEL'S COURTSHIP OF CONVENTIONS
description: WHEN William Greulich was ushered into an unmade hotel room earlier this month, he was suffering one of those indignities that routinely befall business travelers. But Mr. Greulich was not any ordinary traveler; he was a staff member of a group - in this case the Society of Naval Architects and Marine Engineers - that would shortly spend about $500,000 for its annual convention at the New York Hilton. ''We were deeply embarrassed,'' said Gregory Gibadlo, the Hilton's director of marketing. ''We did handstands trying to figure out what happened.''

title: CAIRO PUTS TROOPS IN WEST ON ALERT
description: In the wake of the hijacking of an Egyptian airliner, Egypt declared a state of emergency along the Western border with Libya today and troops there were put on alert and reinforced.

title: MET OPERA: 'PAGLIACCI'
description: THE chief interest of the current ''Pagliacci'' performances at the Metropolitan Opera is the return of Jon Vickers as Canio, the role of his Met debut a quarter-century ago. He came into the cast last Tuesday and performed again Saturday evening, both times magnificently.

title: New Chief at Carrier
description: William A. Wilson, president and chief operating officer of the Carrier Corporation, a subsidiary of United Technologies, has been named to the additional position of chief executive, United Technologies announced.

title: COALITION ACCUSES WELFARE HOTELS OF PLOTTING TO CHARGE HIGH PRICES
description: The Coalition for the Homeless charged yesterday that many welfare hotels in the city had violated antitrust laws by fixing exorbitant prices for rooms and services.

title: Texaco Raises Prices
description: Texaco Inc. of White Plains said Friday that it had increased posted prices for crude oil between 15 and 50 cents a barrel, retroactive to Nov. 1.

title: PLANS FOR HAWAIIAN HIGHWAY HIT SNAG OVER ANCIENT BURIAL GROUND
description: A long-running dispute over a proposal to build a 15-mile freeway through the mountains of Oahu has moved into Congress, which is considering legislation to exempt the highway from Federal environmental laws.

title: Sex Club to Fight Closing by City
description: The owner of Plato's Retreat, a Manhattan sex club shut down on prostitution charges as part of the city's crackdown intended to slow the spread of AIDS, said he would fight the move in court.

title: Sanko Steamship Loans
description: The Daiwa Bank and the Tokai Bank said Friday that they had written off most of their outstanding loans to the Sanko Steamship Company, which is seeking court protection from its creditors. Daiwa, estimated to have the largest exposure to Sanko - about 100 billion yen, or $481.5 million - said it wrote off 62.4 billion yen, or $311.9 million, in the fiscal first half, ended Sept. 30.

title: DANCE: BEJART COMPANY PERFORMS 'BOLERO'
description: MAURICE BEJART'S ''Bolero'' is probably his best known and most popular dance. It certainly is Mr. Bejart's most exciting, going much further than his ''Rite of Spring'' in apportioning the stage in bold, dramatic patterns and building to a frenetic peak. In ''Bolero,'' however, he builds from a start as simple as the repeated tune in the Ravel score of the same name, to which the dance is set.

title: SOME ANALYSTS SAY BID FOR SEA-LAND IS 'FAIR'
description: Harold C. Simmons' unsolicited $25-a-share offer for the Sea-Land Corporation, which goes before the container company's board today, may be too good to turn down, analysts say, even though management has previously indicated that a takeover is undesirable.

title: Political Pitch
description: Two years ago, after winning 314 games and Cy Young awards in both leagues, Gaylord Perry retired from baseball and went home to Williamston, N.C., for a full-time existence as a peanut farmer. Peanuts it was, too, at least as Perry tells it. ''Anybody that's in the farming business,'' he says, ''knows the money's not in farming.''

title: Bar on Document Upheld
description: The Administration won an unheralded but significant victory last week when Federal District Court Judge Thomas F. Flannery ruled that the Environmental Defense Fund was not entitled to certain documents it sought in a suit involving standards for underground waste storage tanks.

title: A TRIP TO TURKEY YIELDS FEW CLUES TO PAPAL PLOT
description: The court investigating a purported conspiracy to kill Pope John Paul II four years ago returned from Turkey this week, but it brought back little evidence to support the prosecution's central contention that Bulgaria was behind such a plot.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, NOVEMBER 25, 1985
description: International

title: What Schizophrenia Means to a Doctor
description: To the Editor:

title: Repurchase Guidelines
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board has approved new guidelines for Government securities repurchase agreements that urge federally insured savings and loan associations to obtain possession or control of securities underlying such agreements.

title: Railway Officials in India Order Convoys in Punjab
description: Railway authorities today ordered trains to travel in protected convoys through Punjab state after a bomb set by Sikh extremists killed two Hindus on a passenger train.

title: Tax Plan Divides Executives
description: As they have throughout the yearlong process of developing a tax-revision package, business executives reached yesterday had varying reactions to the proposals that emerged this weekend from the House Ways and Means Committee.

title: COLUMBIA BLANKED IN REGIONAL FINAL
description: Hartwick never allowed Columbia to get into its rhythm today and defeated the Lions, 2-0, in the New York State Region final of the National Collegiate Athletic Association soccer tournament.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: LIST OF PASSENGERS AND CREW MEMBERS ON EGYPTIAN PLANE
description: Following is a list of those aboard Egyptair Flight 648 when it was hijacked Saturday in Greek airspace and flown to Malta. The list was released by the Greek authorities today before the plane was stormed by Egyptian commandos. Some names and ages differ from those given by other sources.

title: DANCE: 'WIND SHEAR'
description: THE choreographic winds were mild Saturday night when ''Wind Shear'' was presented at Just Above Midtown (503 Broadway, between Spring Street and Broome Street). The work for a cast of four was a collaboration with choreography and costumes by Meg Eginton, sets and lights by Al Taylor and music by Pat Irwin.

title: SCHROEDER LEADS REDSKIN TRIUMPH
description: If the tough get going when the going gets tough, the Washington Redskins are well over the speed limit.

title: PROBLEMS AT CHEMICAL PLANTS RAISE BROAD SAFETY CONCERNS
description: The type of management, training, equipment and response problems that characterized last December's gas leak disaster in Bhopal, India, exist in many American chemical plants, according to recent inspections and studies of the American chemical industry by a variety of experts.

title: SINGLE WOMEN, MARRIED MEN
description: SHE was an editor, he was a writer and they met ''on line'' or by computer. It was strictly business until he began to call her on the ''personal mode.'' ''I was flattered because I had this mental picture of him as someone important,'' she recalled. ''I thought an electronic flirtation would be safe.''

title: The U.N. Today; Nov. 25, 1985
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Iraq Says Iran Plans 'Human Wave' Offensive
description: Iraq's Defense Minister said today that Iran was preparing a ''human wave'' offensive in an attempt to gain ground in the Persian Gulf war.

title: The Editorial Notebook;   The Unsettling Mr. Meese
description: Reveling in his debate with Supreme Court justices, Attorney General Edwin Meese is pleased to demonstrate that his constitutional quarrel is not just with the ''liberals'' of the Earl Warren Court. He deems it necessary to correct even justices who lived much closer to the time of the Founding Fathers. He's a true believer in a Jurisprudence of Original Intention and has a fundamentalist's certainty of what the Constitution means.

title: Beth Stewart Married
description: Beth Stewart, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sy Stewart of Brookville, L.I., and Palm Beach, Fla., was married in New York yesterday to Steven Jay Morris, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Morris of Freeport, L.I. Rabbi Henry Morris, a cousin of the bridegroom, officiated at the Pierre. Mrs. Morris, a graduate of Boston University, is a senior television producer for the J. Walter Thompson Company. Her husband, a Yale graduate, is a producer of television commercials for Moir Productions.

title: Arms Cache Is Found In Brooklyn Basement
description: The police arrested three men in a Brooklyn basement yesterday, confiscating an Uzi submachine gun and other weapons and thousands of dollars in cash, a police spokesman said.

title: ST. JOHN'S SURVIVES LATE RALLY
description: Perhaps motivated by its failure to make any of the major preseason top 20 polls, St. John's has come off the mark strongly.

title: PUSH THE RUSSIANS, INTELLECTUALS SAY
description: The United States could achieve an ''ideological reformation'' of the Soviet system with a series of regional victories, in the view of a group of writers and political thinkers who have come to be characterized as neoconservatives.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE knickknacks and luxuries offered here in this annual gift-book roundup are indeed books, each and every one of them. But some of them are as fun as toys. Others are as useful as tools or instructive as a schoolhouse. As a group they looked so good arranged together on the dining-room table that I wanted to leave them there and admire them for the season. But one must eat as well as read. Alas.

title: PIONEERS: WOMEN WHO LED THE WAY IN AVIATION
description: ''If I can fly and land a plane successfully, weighing as I do but 105 pounds, almost anyone ought to be able to,'' Manila Davis said many times in the 1920's.

title: 170 HOMOSEXUAL OFFICIALS CONFER ON TACTICS AND NATIONAL PLATFORM
description: Homosexual politicians held a national meeting this weekend to discuss establishing their own political platform. Many said that homosexuals could no longer rely solely on liberal political groups to support candidates who acknowledge their homosexuality and to address such issues as AIDS, discrimination and civil rights.

title: BIG JOE TURNER, SINGER, DEAD
description: Big Joe Turner, the Kansas City blues singer, died of kidney failure yesterday at Daniel Freeman Memorial Hospital in Englewood, Calif. He was 74 years old and lived in Los Angeles.

title: Gail S. Schneider Marries Capt. Jonathan P. Kushner
description: The marriage of Gail Stephanie Schneider, a registered nurse at the George Washington University Hospital in Washington, to Capt. Jonathan Paige Kushner, U.S.A., Medical Corps, took place yesterday at the Four Seasons Hotel in Washington.

title: RAIDERS OVERCOME BRONCOS
description: Chris Bahr, getting a second chance, kicked a 32-yard field goal at 2 minutes 42 seconds of overtime today to give the Los Angeles Raiders a 31-28 victory over the Denver Broncos.

title: Market Place;   Hammermill Merger Talk
description: A SWISS investor, a New Jersey construction company and the first British insurance broker ever expelled from Lloyd's of London all have one thing in common. In the last few months, according to Wall Street sources, each has been dabbling in the stock of Hammermill Paper, a company whose profits have been depressed but whose shares have not because of takeover speculation.

title: THEATER: 'PRAIRIE,' BY MUELLER
description: THE travail of pioneer American women is the challenging subject of Lavonne Mueller's ''Breaking the Prairie Wolf Code.'' As in her previous three plays in the American Place Theater's Women's Project, Miss Mueller reveals an empathy for those who are conscripted into embattled legions.

title: BALANCE IN THE BIG EAST GIVES COACHES CAUSE FOR OPTIMISM
description: FOR the first time in four seasons, there is a feeling among most Big East coaches that they have a legitimate chance to win the conference championship.

title: An Eskimo in the Bronx
description: Studying Polar Eskimos, the northernmost people in the world, Dr. Rolf Gilberg scarcely expected that his research would bring him to 175th Street and the Grand Concourse.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''After the third victim was shot, I was prepared to do anything to prevent more killing, especially killings like these, in cold blood.

title: NEW KOCH TEAM WILL LOOK FAMILIAR
description: It is an expectation that has been growing for months - that Mayor Koch's third term would be something new indeed: a shaken up, reconstituted administration, replete with new faces.

title: Advertising;   People
description: * Richard Russo is rejoining John Russo, his brother, at Plapler Russo & Associates as an executive vice president.

title: Joan Feinstein a Bride
description: Joan D. Feinstein, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Clifford Feinstein of New York, and Barry N. Winograd, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Maxwell Winograd of the Bronx, were married yesterday at the Park Avenue Synagogue in New York. Rabbi Judah Nadich performed the ceremony. Mrs. Winograd is a psychiatric social worker at the City Hospital Center in Elmhurst, Queens. Mr. Winograd is a certified public accountant and a partner in the accounting firm of Coopers & Lybrand.

title: Bellamy's Secret Platform
description: Criminal justice kindergarten.

title: HOW TAX PLAN DIFFERS A YEAR LATER
description: The national debate on overhauling the Federal tax system formally began one year ago this week. After three proposals - one by the Treasury Department, one by the President and one by the House Ways and Means committee - the original concepts of fairness and simplicity have become somewhat clouded.

title: Employees Vote to Purchase Ailing Steel Plant in Alabama
description: Workers at the financially ailing Gulf States Steel Corporation approved a tentative employee purchase plan containing major wage and benefit concessions, union officials said Saturday.

title: The New Lawyers
description: What kind of lawyers is the Administration selecting for its top legal positions in Mr. Reagan's second term? Well, a survey of 16 appointments made in the last year indicates the second round of lawyers is a little less experienced than the 39 who joined the Government in major posts in the first term. The 1985 appointees average 12.8 years of bar membership, as against 17.3 for the 1981-1984 group.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day on Saturday about Burger King's mobile restaurants misstated the name of the chairman and chief executive of the Pillsbury Company. His name is John M. Stafford.

title: Question for Jets: How Strong Is Strong?
description: HE has been a Jet longer than any of his teammates, which means he has suffered longer. Pat Leahy is in his 12th season with the Jets and now, after having produced the 32-yard field goal that defeated the New England Patriots, 16-13, in overtime yesterday, the 34-year-old place-kicker was asked to compare this first-place team with the Jet teams of the past.

title: Elizabeth Harpel Becomes a Bride
description: Elizabeth Louise Harpel, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Peter Cahners Harpel of New York, and Dean Casper Kehler, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Kehler of Harrisburg, Pa., were married yesterday. Rabbi Emily Korzenick performed the ceremony at the Beach Point Club in Mamaroneck, N.Y.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: EVOLUTION OF AN ART FORM What is said to be the latest in poster art - three-dimensional posters and posters that change appearance as the viewer changes position - will be part of the exhibition opening today at the New York Public Library at Lincoln Center (870-1670). The exhibition is ''Twenty Years of Graphic Design for the Library and Museum of the Performing Arts.'' It includes work by artists who have revolutionized the craft by making prints that have a basic uniform format - but with an image that is adjusted differently for each copy print.

title: CATHOLIC DISSENT ON CHURCH RULES FOUND
description: Majorities of American Catholics hold views that differ sharply from teachings of their church on such issues as women's ordination, divorce, birth control, and marriage for priests, a New York Times/CBS News Poll has found.

title: GIANTS OUTPLAY CARDINALS BY 34-3
description: In the early going against the Cardinals today, the Giants were not at their best and the weather, with the wind-chill factor at 14 degrees, certainly was not. But the Giants put together big plays on offense and defense and smothered the Cardinals, 34-3.

title: The High Cost of Hostile Corporate Takeovers
description: To the Editor:

title: Advertising;   Iberia Air Lines Gives U.S. Billings to Ayer
description: Iberia Air Lines of Spain has selected N. W. Ayer as its United States agency. Ayer, which had served Pan American worldwide, is anxious to get the same arrangement with the Spaniards.

title: JOB HOPES PICK UP FOR COLLEGE CLASS
description: College graduates next June will have an easier time finding jobs than the previous year's graduates did, for the third consecutive year, according to at least two reports.

title: MEXICO'S '86 BUDGET DISPUTED
description: Mexico's Minister of Budget and Planning, Carlos Salinas de Gortari, will appear Monday before the Chamber of Deputies to explain and defend the Government's austere - and most likely recessionary - budget for next year.

title: JOHN PAUL OPENS SYNOD OF BISHOPS
description: Pope John Paul II opened an extraordinary Synod of Bishops today under the dome of St. Peter's Basilica by exhorting the bishops to remain open to new ''vistas'' for the Roman Catholic Church's mission.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Nov. 25, 1985: *2*MONDAY American Express NWA Inc Connecticut Nat Gas United Illuminating Crane Co United Industrial Corp Detroit Edison Unocal Corp Disney (Walt) Prdtn Watkins-Johnson Excelsior Income Shs Zurn Industries Interlake Inc *2*TUESDAY Angelica Corp Medtronic Inc Becton,Dickinson&Co Merck & Company Brush Wellman New England Elec Sys Cluett Peabody & Co Pacific Tin Consol EDO Corp Penney (JC) Co The Gap Inc Reading & Bates Corp IPALCO Enterprises Revlon Inc Kansas Gas Elec Westvaco Corp Macy (RH) & Co *2*WEDNESDAY Cigna Corp Ocean Drill & Explor Deere & Co Pennsylvania Pwr & Lt KeyCorp Philip Morris New Jersey Resources Tucson Elec Pwr *2*THURSDAY Holiday *2*FRIDAY None Reported

title: THE HIGH COST OF HOSTILE CORPORATE TAKEOVERS
description: To the Editor:

title: AIRPORT SECURITY TIGHT, GREEKS SAY
description: Greek authorities, shocked by the second hijacking of an airliner from Athens in five months despite a security crackdown after the first incident, said yesterday that they did not believe the weapons were smuggled aboard at the Greek airport.

title: I'M SWEET WINS DEMOISELLE
description: I'm Sweets, who looked like she would finish no better than third in deep stretch, rallied back courageously to beat heavily favored Family Style by a neck in the $118,800 Demoiselle Stakes for 2-year-old fillies at Aqueduct yesterday.

title: GEORGE HARDING 3D
description: Dr. George Tyron Harding 3d, who once sued to prevent publication of love letters written by his uncle, President Warren G. Harding, died Friday in Sarasota, Fla. after suffering a heart attack. He was 81 years old.

title: Report on Foreign Exchange
description: An estimated $150 billion a day is traded in foreign exchange markets around the world, twice the amount of five years ago, the Group of 30 said in a report issued yesterday.

title: A Freebie Is a Freebie. Also Income
description: Many readers have written to object to the Government's playing Scrooge with the airlines' ticket giveaways for frequent fliers. Our correspondents are right that the Treasury will survive these untaxed bonuses. But symbols matter, and it's hard to imagine a worse symbol than yet another tax break for affluent Americans.

title: 'SHOCKED' ISRAEL INVESTIGATES CHARGE BY U.S. OF ESPIONAGE
description: Israeli officials said today that the Government was investigating whether its intelligence agents had spied on the United States, but they said the country's top political leaders had no prior knowledge of such operations.

title: Defending 'Star Wars'
description: Undeterred by his failure to stop supporters of President Reagan's Strategic Defense Initiative from calling it ''Star Wars,'' George Lucas, who made the 1977 film of that name, will be in court today trying to keep opponents of the space-based missile defense project from using that language.

title: BEARS REMAIN PERFECT
description: In case there was any doubt at the start of the 12th game of Chicago's perfect season, a propeller plane, one of the many trying to sell something in the air space over Soldier Field, carried a message above the shores of Lake Michigan. The message was intended to promote a postseason vacation with members of the best team in the National Football League.

title: HUNDREDS MOURN RELIGIOUS LEADER
description: More than 700 people from across the nation attended a four-hour funeral service yesterday in Manhattan for Metropolitan Philaret, Archbishop of New York and Eastern America and Primate of the Russian Orthodox Church Outside of Russia.

title: Required Reading;   In Defense of Women
description: Remarks of Representative Thomas J. Downey, Democrat of Suffolk. L.I., inserted in The Congressional Record, Nov. 21:

title: Defense vs. Deep Cuts
description: Of course the summit was worthwhile. It's good that President Reagan and General Secretary Gorbachev got to know each other, and will visit each other's country. New consulates, cultural exchanges, possibly ''risk-reduction centers'' -all are welcome and should be useful. But one fact emerged most clearly from the Geneva meetings:

title: SOUTH AFRICANS REPORT 3 DEATHS, TOTAL IN WEEK OF UNREST HITS 42
description: The authorities reported the deaths of three people today, including a 3-year-old girl, in one of the worst weeks of violence since a state of emergency was declared in several areas on July 21.

title: THIS TIME TO MAKE MONEY
description: By the many thousands they step off the planes from Tokyo, two by two, one of the steadier processions of traveling couples since Noah's Ark.

title: CONCERT: BEHRMAN WORKS
description: ARTIFICIAL intelligence research, music division, could be sampled Saturday night at the Samaya Foundation, 75 Leonard Street in TriBeCa. The composer David Behrman presented two works, ''Circling Six'' and ''Interspecies Smalltalk,'' that centered on computer programs responding to a live soloist.
