title: RETTON COMES TO GRIPS WITH NEW DEMANDS
description: MARY LOU RETTON, her Olympic gold medal in a safe-deposit box and her star-spangled performance leotard in mothballs, has lately concerned herself with staying ''sane.'' Seventeen-year-old girls ought to have less sobering priorities, but ever since Miss Retton captured the 1984 Olympic individual all-around gold medal for gymnastics, her life has not belonged to her. To be a national heroine, she has discovered, is to be both icon and commodity, and there is often little time left to be the person she calls ''just plain Mary Lou.''

title: Bargaining Breaks Off In Coast Grocery Strike
description: Bargaining in a bitter labor dispute at seven southern California supermarket chains has broken off after unsuccessful talks between two unions and the owners.

title: LOWER NET AT AIRLINES IS FORECAST
description: The airline industry is gearing up for heavy traffic during the Thanksgiving and Christmas holidays, but there is great concern that traffic will weaken and fare wars will widen early next year. That is causing some analysts and executives to predict a sharp drop in earnings in the first quarter.

title: Keep Federal Affirmative Action Strong
description: Imagine a Government program that's been supported by five Presidents, Republicans and Democrats in both houses of Congress, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. and the National Association of Manufacturers. Imagine, too, a program credited with increasing the participation of women and minorities in our economy at small cost to taxpayers. Such a program, combining the goals of social justice with economic common sense, might seem an abstract ideal. It already exists. It's called affirmative action. Affirmative action was set in place almost a quarter century ago by President John F. Kennedy and strengthened by the executive order signed into law by President Lyndon B. Johnson in 1965. Since then, affirmative action has proven its worth, using the leverage of Federal contracts and public investment to create equal job opportunities and thus translate the dreams of the civil rights struggle into reality.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

title: EXPLORING 'PERSONALITY OF POWER'
description: Edmund Morris is a writer poised two ways in time.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, NOVEMBER 25, 1985
description: The Economy

title: Jo Meltzer Is Married To Dr. Arthur Brown
description: Jo Frances Meltzer, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin I. Meltzer of Syracuse, was married there yesterday to Dr. Arthur Edward Brown, the son of Jeanne S. Leavitt of Edgewater Park, N.J., and Dr. Milton C. Brown of Trenton. Rabbi Charles S. Sherman performed the ceremony at Temple Adath Yeshurun.

title: MUSIC: LIFE IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: IN a musical concept called ''Cape Town, South Africa,'' the South African pianist and composer Abdullah Ibrahim has attempted to project a mixture of nostalgic memories and bitterness with which he looks back at that city from his current home in New York. Using songs, dance, narration and jazz, he has tried to compress a suggestion of black life there from slavery to apartheid in a very brief space.

title: Jay Nelson Tuck, 69, A Reporter and Editor
description: Jay Nelson Tuck, a journalist and former president of the Newspaper Guild of New York, died of lung cancer Friday at his home in Lafayette, N.J. He was 69 years old. Mr. Tuck, a native of Chapel Hill, N.C., was raised in New York and graduated from Columbia College in 1938. He was a conscientious objector in World War II.

title: Outdoors: Big Apple Bass Fishing
description: BETTER fishing than you'd dream is nearer than you think. Put it this way: We stopped fishing before noon and a half hour later one of us was seeing a patient, another was having lunch with an old friend, and Gary was operating on some fellow's left foot. That's near. And if the fishing was not so rural as that on a mountain creek, it was very good fishing, indeed.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in SportsMonday Nov. 18 on the 1985-86 college basketball season misstated the status of two prosepective Villanova players, Barry Bekkedam and Tommy Greis.

title: 13 at Xerox Dismissed
description: The Xerox Corporation announced Friday that it had dismissed 13 workers at a suburban Rochester plant in connection with financial ''irregularities'' that cost the company hundreds of thousands of dollars over several years. Xerox turned over information to the county district attorney's office, Dan Minchen, a Xerox spokesman, said. The irregularities include ''misappropriation of property, money and services'' and ''appear to involve only white-collar workers,'' Kathleen Majewski, an Assistant District Attorney, said.

title: U.S. AIDES SAY SOVIET MAY BE VERGE OF PLAN FOR AFGHAN PULLOUT
description: Reagan Administration officials said today that they believed the Soviet Union might be on the verge of offering a timetable for a phased withdrawal of its 100,000 troops as part of a political solution in Afghanistan.

title: SNAGS LOOM FOR MASSACHUSETTS ATOM-WASTE SITE
description: Massachusetts, one of the nation's largest producers of low-level radioactive waste, is struggling to select a disposal site within its borders.

title: THRIFT QUANDARY IN MARYLAND
description: About 1,600 Maryland residents recently stood on the steps of the Annapolis Statehouse and chanted, ''We're mad, and we vote.'' They carried signs reading ''We want our money, not just talk,'' and ''Hey, Harry, we pay taxes.''

title: U.S. BACKS RAID, REGRETS DEATHS
description: The United States said today that it was greatly distressed over the loss of innocent lives in the storming of a hijacked jetliner in Malta, but said it nonetheless supported the ''difficult decision'' to take firm action to end the situation.

title: OIL-LADEN BARGE SINKS IN 180 FEET OFF FISHERS I.
description: A disabled oil barge sank yesterday in waters off Fishers Island, but salvage crews decided to leave the vessel there temporarily rather than risk raising her in choppy seas and bad weather.

title: Hostage-Protection Act No Bar to Terrorism
description: To the Editor:

title: A GROWTH OF ISSUES-ORIENTED ADVOCACY PROGRAMS AND COMMERCIALS ON TV
description: Carrying a briefcase stuffed with $5,000, the makers of a 30-minute television program opposing United States policy in Latin America demonstrated in front of a San Francisco television station last week to draw attention to their inability to get the program, ''Faces of War,'' on the air.

title: 'A Fuss Clawss Drapery Business' Is Lost
description: To the Editor:

title: POP: FERRON SINGS
description: FERRON, the Canadian feminist singer and songwriter, is one of a handful of folk artists whose concerts break down the barriers between performer and audience to the extent that the two almost melt into one another.

title: One Lilco Battle Too Many
description: Thanks to lobbying by Senators D'Amato and Moynihan, Congress has offered Long Island residents a multimillion-dollar break on electric rates. But the state agency that must accept the gift is balking, apparently deferring to Governor Cuomo's wish to reject any benefit that would appear to help the Long Island Lighting Company.

title: Tentative Pact Reached at St. Louis Auto Plant
description: The Chrysler Corporation and union officials announced a tentative agreement today that could end a three-week-old walkout by 3,200 auto workers at a plant in the suburb of Fenton.

title: NASA STARTS SHUTTLE COUNTDOWN AFTER A FAULTY VALVE IS REPLACED
description: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration said today that it had begun the countdown for launching the shuttle Atlantis Tuesday night, reversing an earlier announcement of a 24-hour delay because of problems with a hydraulic valve.

title: PURCHASES FOR TOOLS JUMP 33%
description: Machine tool orders jumped 33 percent in October from September, according to a report issued yesterday by the National Machine Tool Builders' Association.

title: Kuwait Plans To Import Gas
description: Kuwait, sitting on enough crude oil reserves to last for 200 years, is running short of gas.

title: In Tune With Hoops
description: Wasn't it Jimi Hendrix who said, '' 'Scuse me, while I kiss the sky''?

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: The text of a poem attributed to William Shakespeare that accompanied an article yesterday on the poem's discovery in the Bodleian Library at Oxford University included five words in brackets.

title: BRAZIL ACTS TO TAME STATE OWNERSHIP
description: Six months into his job of identifying all companies, departments, commissions and other bodies belonging to the Federal Government, a hardy Brazilian official had reached the staggering figure of 20,224 and was still counting. ''This,'' Gileno Fernandes said, ''represents about one-third.''

title: BOMBING AT PX IN FRANKFURT WOUNDS 34
description: At least 34 people were wounded today when a bomb planted in a car was detonated just outside a crowded American military shopping complex in northern Frankfurt, the authorities said.

title: We Can't Deprive People of Food and Shelter for Not Working
description: To the Editor:

title: Advertising;   AC&R Chosen By Korbrand
description: The agency selection procedure started in August by the Kobrand Corporation, importer of alcoholic beverages, ended last week with a victory for AC&R Advertising.

title: Meredith Won't Tinker With Added Magazines
description: Robert A. Burnett, president and chief executive officer of the Meredith Corporation, is one executive who does not believe in tinkering when tinkering is not necessary.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: How successful a punter was Dave Jennings of the Jets in college?

title: Orange Bowl Has No. 1 Game
description: When Penn State and Oklahoma meet in the Orange Bowl, the game will decide the final No. 1 team for this season only if Penn State wins. The Nittany Lions ended the regular season at 11-0 after their 31-0 victory at Pitt Saturday night and would retain their No. 1 ranking by beating Oklahoma.

title: IN WASHINGTON, A JERSEY-BORN FLIGHT
description: There was concern up in Boston that Representative James J. Howard, the New Jersey Democrat who is chairman of the Public Works Committee, was getting ready to retaliate against Massachussetts, which wants to dump Boston's sludge off Jersey.

title: HALLEY'S COMET
description: Halley's Comet will rise over the New York City area at 2:41 P.M. today and set at 5:00 A.M. tomorrow.

title: Train Kills Reclining W9>oman
description: A woman was killed Saturday afternoon by an Amtrak passenger train headed for New York City after she lay down on the tracks in the path of the train and refused to move, Columbia County sheriff's deputies said today. The woman, Rennee Knight, 34 years old of Catskill, N.Y., was killed about 4:20 P.M. a half mile south of the Hudson Amtrak station in the Town of Greenport. The train's engineer and fireman saw the woman step onto the tracks and lay down, but were unable to stop in time to avoid her, according to Sgt. Richard Hofstetter.

title: SCHOLARS RE-EXAMINING REMBRANDT ATTRIBUTIONS
description: The announcements last week that two paintings in European museums thought to be by Rembrandt are in fact not by the 17th-century Dutch master are part of a widespread scholarly re-examination that has radically diminished the number of Rembrandt attributions.

title: The Crimes of Iran
description: Disturbed by charges of Iran's barbarous abuse of its own people, the United Nations last March ordered an inquiry by its Human Rights Commission. Iran has responded predictably. The U.N.'s special representative, Andres Aguilar of Venezuela, was barred from visiting Iran and could not even elicit a reply to detailed accounts of torture and summary executions. Teheran's clerical rulers found time only to send him a boilerplate description of legal procedures.

title: Ann Daniels Weds Jonathan Zingman
description: Ann Grossman Daniels and Jonathan Alan Zingman, a theoretical physicist at the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory in Livermore, Calif., were married yesterday at the National Arts Club in New York. Rabbi Emily F. Korzenik performed the ceremony.

title: Vice Chairman For Champion
description: The Champion International Corporation said Friday that Aubrey L. Cole, a senior vice president, had been elected vice chairman and a board member.

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Football 49ers vs. Seattle Seahawks, at San Francisco. This is the rubber game in the series. San Francisco won, 37-21, in 1976 and Seattle won, 35-24, in 1979.

title: Futures/Options;   Arbitrage-Led Stock Volatility
description: THE fun may be drawing to a close on some of the complex arbitrage plays between stock index options and the stock market as the Securities and Exchange Commission steps up its efforts to find a means of reducing the volatility that the investments can cause in the stock market.

title: 10 MORALS, A MISTAKE, NO LEAKS
description: Up in Hazard, Ky., where life revolves around coal mines and church, the Perry County School Board has taken a stand on the Ten Commandments. Alone among all the 180 school districts in the state, it refuses to remove them from the classroom walls.

title: Euphoria for Elis
description: The realization came slowly to Mike Curtin, the Yale quarterback. Against Harvard on Saturday he had probably played his last game. Now would come life after football.

title: Washington Watch;   Savings and Loan Gap
description: Despite a projected record earnings year for the nation's savings and loan associations, the fortunes of insolvent or nearly insolvent thrift units are continuing to decline, according to a study by economists at the Federal Home Loan Bank Board and George Washington University. This means the gap is increasing between sick and healthy institutions.

title: Anglican Envoy Leaves Beirut for the U.S.
description: Terry Waite, the Archbishop of Canterbury's envoy, arrived here today on his way to New York to meet with United States officials in his efforts to free Americans held hostage in Lebanon.

title: Quakes Continue in Albania
description: Another earthquake struck northern Albania early today, the official Yugoslav press agency, Tanyug, said.

title: Chief Pushed Rates At First American
description: When the Baltimore-based First American Mortgage Company suddenly shut its nationwide mortgage banking operation earlier this month, a number of people were eager to speak with Michael H. Clott.

title: BRITISH HOSTILE BIDS SETTING OWN STYLE
description: In recent weeks British television has been showing a 60-second commercial that tells about Alexander Elder, an Englishman who set sail for Australia in 1839 to seek his fortune. The spot ends with a deep-voiced narrator saying: ''Elders IXL. It's great to be back.''

title: OFFICIAL ASSERTS ARABIC ACCENT POINTS TO HIJACKERS' IDENTITY
description: Egypt's Revolution, the organization that claims to have hijacked the Egyptair Boeing 737, is an obscure terrorist group that claimed responsibility for the killing of an Israeli diplomat in Cairo in August.

title: ALWAYS A CELTIC
description: THE Boston Celtics didn't want Bill Walton to feel they were in any way skeptical about his past quests into the counter-culture, so they went out of their way to extend a gracious welcome when he joined the team this September.

title: OPERA: 'I CAPULETI' IN CHICAGO
description: Cecilia Gasdia's interesting concert appearances in New York last month left a trail behind that last night led to Chicago. Here Miss Gasdia, the young Italian soprano, made her American stage debut at the Lyric Opera singing Giulietta in Bellini's half-forgotten ''I Capuleti e i Montecchi.''

title: Laura Ashley Stock Sale Set
description: The business empire built up by the fashion designer Laura Ashley will be floated on the London stock market next month with a price tag of nearly $378 million, the company announced Friday. Applications for some 46.5 million shares in the furnishings and textiles group will open next Thursday.

title: Catching Up
description: * Is it possible for a player to win the Lombardi Award as the nation's very best college football lineman one year and then fail utterly to be even a backup in the pros the next? Yes, it is. Just ask Tony Degrate, the Texas Longhorn defensive tackle who captured the Lombardi in 1984. Right from the start, there were clues that Degrate would have a tough time cutting it in the National Football League. The word from the scouts was that he lacked sufficient agility and quickness, and he was not drafted last spring until the fifth round. It was Cincinnati that chose him, and it was Cincinnati, after three preseason games, that cut him. He was picked up by Green Bay, where he played just two downs in one game last month before being dropped again. Degrate, now working as a freelance commercial artist in Austin, says that he was hurt by being drafted so low and hurt again by being dumped so quickly, but that he'll try once more next summer. ''Right now,'' he says, ''I'm available for a call-up -like to the National Guard.''

title: STAGE: 'PERSONALS,' MUSICAL COMEDY
description: IT'S not often that a musical announces its central failing before the curtain has even gone up, but such is the case with ''Personals,'' the new show at the Minetta Lane. ''Personals'' is a determinedly perky revue about lonely-hearts advertisements, and its curtain, a blowup of a newspaper's classified columns, is meant to set the comic mood: As the show begins, a spotlight travels about the drop to reveal the supposedly wacky ads (''Single white grandmother seeks Heathcliff'') that will spur the evening's merriment. But the laughter quickly becomes strained. We immediately discover that personal ads just aren't funny enough to sustain an entertainment for two minutes - let alone two hours - especially when their real-life absurdity must be exaggerated even further to vary what is essentially a single, one-note joke.

title: Washington Watch;   Wriston Board May Convene
description: WORD has it that the White House will probably soon call a meeting of the outside economic advisers who make up the President's Economic Policy Advisory Board, possibly for next month. That would be an event of some note because the board, whose head is Walter B. Wriston, the retired chairman of Citicorp, has not been invited to offer its advice since April.

title: Dollar Trades Below 200 Yen
description: The dollar traded below 200 yen in Tokyo for the first time in nearly five years, dealers said this morning. The United States currency traded at 199.90, they said.

title: JETS WIN ON OVERTIME KICK
description: It was a game for first place, and the Jets and Patriots went at it clawing and hitting today as if it also were the only game that mattered this season.

title: FLUOROCARBON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Including income of $286,063 from discontinued operations and a net gain of $635,032 from the sale of discontinued operations. c-Including income of $217,142 for the quarter and $491,249 for the 9 months from discontinued operations and an extraordinary gain of $607,746 for the quarter and the 9 months.

title: GRAPHIC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in August.

title: The Mystery Hijacking
description: It does no good to fault Egypt or Malta or Greece for the death of 60 passengers in the storming of Egyptair Flight 648. The responsibility for the carnage falls squarely on the terrorists. But to recognize that brings the world no closer to understanding the mystery at the heart of this chilling episode: Why did they do it?

title: At Stop & Shop, Wife Is Husband's Successor
description: The Stop & Shop Companies, a multibillion-dollar retailing concern, said yesterday that Carol R. Goldberg had been named president.

title: WILEY, JOHN & SONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After pre-tax writedowns for currency losses of $964,000 for the quarter and $2,006,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss d-After gains of $193,000 for the quarter and $166,000 for the 6 months.

title: $313 Million Ohio Issue For Prison Construction
description: The Ohio Building Authority is offering $313 million of bonds to finance construction of new prisons and to refund previously issued bonds through underwriters led by the Cranston Securities Company.

title: ACCOUNTS IN EGYPT FAIL TO MENTION THE DEATH TOLL
description: Egypt said today that its assault on a hijacked airliner had been carried out successfully and according to plan, but made no mention of the number of casualties.

title: Baker to See Brazil Aide
description: Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d will discuss his plan for easing the global debt crisis with his Brazilian counterpart today and will try to persuade him to enact economic reforms, a senior Treasury official said.

title: Topics;   Discoveries Mall World
description: ''I wanted to wish my friend Kim a happy birthday,'' a Manhattan friend reports, ''and thought to take her shopping in some interesting place. Maybe the Willowbrook or Woodbridge mall in New Jersey, or Green Acres in Nassau County or the Galleria in Westchester. They are all immense shopping malls, on the order of 1.5 million square feet. At least I thought that was immense. Then I heard about the West Edmonton Mall in Alberta, Canada.

title: Justice Issues Stay In Maxxam's Bid
description: Associate Justice William H. Rehnquist of the Supreme Court of the United States called a temporary halt to Maxxam Group Inc.'s acquisition of the Pacific Lumber Company.

title: SUPERMARKETS GENERAL CORP reports earnings for 13 wks to Nov 2
description: On Aug. 8, 1984, the company acquired all of the outstanding stock of Purity Supreme Inc. for a cash payment of $79,250,000. Purity Supreme's results of operations are included in the company's statement of earnings subsequent to the date of acquisition.

title: MANUEL IS SIDELINED WITH INJURED LEG
description: Once the preseason ended, the Giants survived the first 11 weeks of the regular season without a serious injury to an offensive player. Now their winning ways and title hopes are threatened by a hamstring injury to Lionel Manuel, their leading pass receiver.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch and an accompanying table yesterday on a poll surveying the views of Roman Catholics in America misstated one finding. The percentage of all Roman Catholics favoring the current status of legal abortion was 26, not 36.

title: GRAHAM-MCCORMICK OIL & GAS PARTNERSHIP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income. Year-ago results are for the 3 months and 8 months ended Sept. 30, 1984. Effective Jan. 31, 1984, substantially all of the assets and liabilities of McCormick Oil & Gas Co. were transferred to the partnership.

title: Spate of Bombings Hits 2 Cities in Chile
description: Six bombs exploded in the Chilean capital and three in the port city of Valparaiso today, the police said. Bomb disposal experts defused another outside the South African Embassy here.

title: GARRETT RESIGNS POST AT COLUMBIA
description: Columbia's latest and boldest attempt to end the embarrassment of its recent football history ended yesterday afternoon when the university announced the resignation of Jim Garrett at the end of his first season as coach.

title: HYDE ATHLETIC INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NATIONAL GYPSUM GETS BUYOUT OFFER
description: Executives of the National Gypsum Company offered yesterday to buy the big supplier of building products for about $1.1 billion in cash and securities and then make it a private company.

title: Try, Try Again
description: Tim Kides is determined to make editors at the Guinness Book of World Records sit up and take notice. The sophomore physical education major at Glassboro State College in New Jersey has attempted twice in the last year to gain recognition by setting a world record in sit-ups.

title: Lawyers for Goetz Ask for Dismissal
description: Attorneys for Bernhard H. Goetz said in State Supreme Court in Manhattan yesterday that the attempted murder charges against him should be dismissed because prosecutors had withheld evidence from and improperly instructed the grand jury that indicted him.

title: India Agrees to Buy 11 Jets And Missiles Made in Britain
description: India signed an agreement today to buy 11 British Sea Harrier jets as well as Sea Eagle missiles in a major sign of warmer relations between the two countries, authoritative sources said.

title: F.C.C. Allows Sale by Storer
description: The Federal Communications Commission today approved the transfer of seven TV stations owned by Storer Communications Inc. to SCI Holdings Inc. as part of the leveraged buyout led by the New York investment firm Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company.

title: FAZIO IS LET GO BY PITTSBURGH
description: Having failed to achieve a winning season and a bowl invitation, the University of Pittsburgh dismissed its football coach, Foge Fazio, today and began seeking a replacement.

title: U.S. SUSPECT HELD AFTER CONFESSION OF SOVIET SPYING
description: A former communications specialist for the National Security Agency was arrested this morning after admitting that he sold American intelligence secrets to the Soviet Union for more than five years, the authorities said.

title: SPECIAL COMPUTERS AND TELEVISION CAMERAS TAKE A BAT CENSUS IN THE DARK
description: When the sun sinks below the Guadalupe Mountains and the swallows make their last swooping dives of the day, the bats come out of their caves and begin their nightly hunt for food.

title: HASSAN OF MOROCCO WILLING TO HOLD MEETING WITH PERES
description: King Hassan II of Morocco said today that he would be happy to receive Prime Minister Shimon Peres if the Israeli leader had serious proposals for a Middle East peace.

title: MOTHER TESTIFIES SHE HELPED DAUGHTER IN SLAYING
description: In surprise testimony, the mother of a 20-year-old woman charged with manslaughter in the ax slaying of her father testified that she herself had participated in the killing. The daughter has said she was sexually abused by her father.

title: SWIFT INDEPENDENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 26
description: b-Includes pre-tax charges of $2.5 million associated with the pending acquisition of the company, a $1 million adjustment to workers compensation costs for prior years and a $7.9 million pre-tax charge in the third quarter for realignment of operations. c-Net income

title: EMOTIONAL IMPACT OF DISASTER: SENSE OF BENIGN WORLD IS LOST
description: IN a major catastrophe like the Mexican earthquake and the mud slides in Colombia, experts say, the psychological world collapses just as resoundingly as the physical one.

title: Syntex Posts Record Gains
description: The Syntex Corporation, a leading health-care company based in Palo Alto, Calif., today reported record gains in first-quarter earnings and sales.

title: MERGER IS COMPLETED
description: Baxter Travenol Laboratories announced today that it had completed its $3.8 billion merger with the American Hospital Supply Corporation.

title: IN CRUMBLING ZANZIBAR, THE SPICE OF LIFE IS GONE
description: There was a time, Hashim Siddique remembers, when everything seemed possible here. Fortune seekers and Arab traders, fresh from white-hulled steamers and peeling wooden dhows, hurried down deeply shadowed streets to trade in gold and ivory, cloves and cinnamon and nutmeg.

title: TRIANGLE MICROWAVE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
DOW DROPS BY 7.68 AS TRADING FALLS
description: Profit taking pushed stock prices lower yesterday in a relatively dull session that saw trading volume fall below the 100 million mark for the first time in the last 19 sessions.

title: Hopes Rise Willy-Nilly
description: There is no ambiguity in the delighted European reaction to the Geneva summit meeting. Senior officials at NATO headquarters confess it stems in part from relief. They had feared something would go seriously wrong, if only by miscalculation.

title: Martha Schlamme Memorial
description: A memorial for the singer Martha Schlamme will be held today at noon at the Circle in the Square Theater, Broadway and 50th Street.

title: A New Show in Town
description: THE awnings and brick floors are understated beige. The lamps are stained glass. The counters sparkle, their bright contents laid out in meticulously conceived patterns. Fresh fruits and vegetables are there in abundant variety. Grace Balducci's Market Place has finally opened its doors. The Upper East Side is ecstatic.

title: SWAP IN SPY CASES MADE WITH GHANA
description: The United States has agreed to release a man convicted of spying for Ghana, officials said today. In return, they said, Ghana has agreed to release eight Ghanaians accused of spying for the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: Survey Finds Buyer's Market
description: Consumers became less confident in the third quarter, but are willing to buy if the price is right, according to a University of Michigan survey of consumer attitudes released today.

title: Working Hard?
description: There are those who might dispute it, but the Labor Department now says productivity is rising among Federal employees. Not only that, but the rise is said to be sharper than the rate of increased productivity among workers in private concerns.

title: Bananas
description: ''Bananalock.''

title: OPERA: SUTHERLAND IN DONIZETTI'S 'ANNA BOLENA'
description: IT is too bad that the phrase ''a legend in her own time'' has been ground down to banality by being applied to every other soprano capable of walking across a stage without falling down. It certainly could be applied to Joan Sutherland at this point in her career without suspicion of hyperbole. The great Australian singer's performance last night at Avery Fisher Hall in a concert version of Donizetti's ''Anna Bolena'' was astonishing on many counts, but doubly amazing as the work of an artist who will be 60 years old next year. It is hard to think of many sopranos in recent times who have sounded so good so late, though the names of Kirsten Flagstad and Birgit Nilsson do come to mind.

title: ON CHANNEL 5, 'LAST DAYS OF MARILYN MONROE'
description: THE BBC exports more than costume dramas and nature programs to America; there is the occasional investigative piece as well. ''The Last Days of Marilyn Monroe,'' on Channel 5 at 8:30 tonight, ought to be regarded as a classic. Sex, sin, Kennedys and mobsters join, while the background sound is heavy breathing. Somewhere, the Central Intelligence Agency is hanging around, too.

title: GROUP W CABLE BIDS REPORTED
description: Hallmark Cards Inc. and the Bass brothers have joined in a group bidding for Group W Cable, sources familiar with the negotiations said yesterday. Bids for the Westinghouse Corporation property were due last Friday, and a decision is expected soon.

title: SUAVE SHOE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
To Seek Origins of AIDS in Africa Is Not to Cast Blame for It
description: To the Editor:

title: Earning a Lot?
description: If there is one person in a Congressional office who knows more than the elected member, it is usually the administrative assistant, commonly known as the A.A. So there is always considerable interest in the capital in how much these people are paid. A new study by a management concern, the Congressional Management Foundation, discloses some not-quite-predictable trends in A.A. pay scales.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: INSIDE WARNER BROS. (1935-1951). Selected, edited and annotated by Rudy Behlmer. 358 pages. Illustrated. Viking. $19.95.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Atari Corp., the personal computer company based in Sunnyvale, Calif., has named Michael V. Katz executive vice president.

title: JAMES T. LICAVOLI, CRIME LEADER IN CLEVELAND
description: James T. Licavoli, a leader of organized crime in Cleveland, died Saturday after suffering a heart attack. He was 81 years old.

title: I.B.M. Executive To Head Tandon
description: The Tandon Corporation, stepping up its drive to expand its computer-making operations, yesterday named Dan H. Wilkie, the head of the International Business Machines Corporation's main personal computer making complex, to be president and chief operating officer.

title: PIONEER FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN (VA) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
AID TO THE REBELS IN ANGOLA FOUGHT
description: A group of 101 members of Congress urged President Reagan today not to provide covert aid to the rebels fighting against the Marxist Government in Angola.

title: ALBERTSON'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
TUESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yogi Berra, while playing recently at a golf tournament in Fargo, N.D., speculated that there were not enough potatoes in that area to fill his front lawn. Today, Berra will receive delivery from the Red River Valley Potato Growers of North Dakota and Minnesota of 45,000 pounds of potatoes in 900 50-pound boxes that will be deposited in the driveway of his home in Montclair, N.J. 8:30 A.M. Basketball Knicks vs. Hawks, at Atlanta, 7:30 P.M. The Knicks have split their two meetings this season against Atlanta, losing by 102-87 on Oct. 29 in Atlanta under a barrage of 22 points by the Hawks' Dominique Wilkins, who outscored his brother Gerald of the Knicks by 18 points. Patrick Ewing got some revenge in the second meeting with season highs of 28 points and 20 rebounds in a 103-96 Knicks victory. (Television - MSG, 7:30 P.M. Radio -WNBC, 660; 7:20 P.M.). #76ers vs. Boston Celtics, at Philadelphia (Television - WTBS, 8 P.M.). College: John Jay at City College, 8 P.M., Beavers home opener; Fordham at L.I.U., WNYE-TV, Channel 25, tape delay, 9 P.M.; St. Francis (Brooklyn) at Pace; Wagner at Manhattan; Hofstra at Brown; Lehigh at Princeton; Yale at Connecticut; Vermont at Army, and Iona at North Carolina. Boxing Vinny Pazienza vs. Frankie Baltazar, at Atlantic City, Harrah's Marina Hotel and Casino, lightweights, 10 rounds. First preliminary, 8 P.M. The undefeated Pazienza, from Cranston, R.I., (16-0, 13 knockouts), was supposed to fight Melvin Paul.

title: HITACHI, SPERRY IN ACCORDS
description: The Sperry Corporation said yesterday that it had negotiated several agreements with Hitachi Ltd. to evaluate ''technology exchanges'' between the two companies, leading industry experts to speculate that the Japanese electronics giant will soon be manufacturing key components of Sperry's mainframe computer systems.

title: Sea-Land Board Meets on Offer
description: The Sea-Land Corporation's board met yesterday to consider an unsolicited $25 a share buyout offer from Harold C. Simmons, the Dallas investor, but did not immediately make any statement about whether it would accept or reject the offer.

title: DESKTOP PUBLISHING COMES OF AGE
description: THE fall Comdex show is to the personal computer industry what the annual model change used to be to Detroit: a time when what the consumer owns becomes suddenly outdated as next year's version comes on the scene, complete with everything one could ever have dreamed of. But just as the demarcation between past and future in the automotive world is beginning to blur, so any true newness at Comdex is becoming harder to unearth.

title: JUJAMCYN AWARD TO AMERICAN REPERTORY THEATER
description: The American Repertory Theater of Cambridge, Mass., one of the leading resident companies in the country, was given the $50,000 Jujamcyn Theaters Award in a ceremony last night at the St. Regis Hotel.

title: The U.N. Today; Nov. 26, 1985
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Rhone-Poulenc
description: Rhone-Poulenc Inc. said it had signed a 10-year contract with Decker Energy International, which will design, finance, install and operate an energy supply system for a Rhone-Poulenc chemical plant in the Houston area. Rhone-Poulenc said it would purchase steam from Decker at a discount, enabling it to save about $2 million over the 10 years. The plant will be operational in 1986.

title: CITY BALLET: 'CORTEGE'
description: A NEW cast appeared in George Balanchine's ''Cort ege Hongrois'' at the New York City Ballet's performance on Sunday afternoon at the New York State Theater.

title: SCHROEDER ADDS POISE, SPARK
description: Watching Jay Schroeder and the Washington Redskins win for the second straight week without Joe Theismann, one could not help but think of how fortunate Theismann is, despite his broken leg.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: Aetna Life and Casualty Co., Hartford, said it had reached an agreement in principle with Globe Investment Trust P.L.C. to acquire Globe's wholly owned subsidiary Tyndall Group Ltd. for nearly $51 million.

title: On Blessing This Mess
description: The Senate is an incredible place, no more so than when it stays in session until the wee hours.

title: Jersey Bonds' Top Yield 8 7/8%
description: An $88 million financing by the New Jersey Health Care Facilities Finance Authority for West Jersey health systems was tentatively offered yesterday with a maximum yield of 8 7/8 percent for bonds due in 2012, through underwriters led by Bear, Stearns & Company.

title: Release Ordered For Crime Figure
description: A reputed Mafia leader, Philip Rastelli, has won a court ruling to release him from prison because parole officials had ''no rational basis'' for revoking his parole in an extortion case.

title: Harmon Charges Are Dismissed
description: Clarence Harmon, a running back for the Washington Redskins for six years and for the last two seasons with the New Jersey Generals, yesterday won a dismissal of charges involving his arrest for possession of cocaine in March 1983 in Texarkana, Tex.

title: SUSPECT IN TWO CHILD KILLINGS SPENT YOUTH IN FOSTER HOMES
description: The 24-year-old factory worker accused of the brutal murder of his girlfriend's two children 11 days ago spent much of his youth in foster homes and facilities for the mentally impaired, according to officials familiar with his background.

title: A THREAT TO FREE ACADEMIA
description: SOME years ago, when I taught a graduate seminar in editorial writing and freedom of the press at Hunter College, the class radical from the extreme left bade me farewell at the end of the term and said: ''I still disagree with everything you said, but I'm not as sure anymore.'' I thanked him for the compliment; but my real thanks went to a system that allowed a free exchange of conflicting ideas. No need for me to worry about being monitored by ideological watchdogs from the left or the right.

title: The City's Endless, Awful Truth
description: The family, steeped in welfare chaos and bound by a kind of wily matriarchy, lives seven blocks from the Capitol -30 people strong and weak under one roof, according to Police Officer Becky L. Hazlett, who also notes two dogs and a gray jumble of filthy laundry in the backyard.

title: Midmonth Auto Sales Off 27.2%
description: Sales of new American-made automobiles continued to slide in the mid-November period, falling 27.2 percent from the comparable period last year on a daily selling rate basis, the manufacturers reported today.

title: Texas Convict Is Given A Stay of Execution
description: A 23-year-old man was given an indefinite stay of execution by the United States Supreme Court today.

title: Phillips Quits Saints
description: Bum Phillips, the coach of the New Orleans Saints since 1981, abuptly resigned today, foregoing the final three years and $1.3 million of his contract.

title: NEW TECHNIQUE ADVANCES 'TEST TUBE' FERTILIZATION
description: AUSTRALIAN doctors have reported that, for the first time, they have been able to extract sperm from a man's testes, culture them to maturity and use them to impregnate an egg cell from the man's wife. The man had been unable to ejaculate normally because of scar tissue in his penis. The fertilized egg, or embryo, was then inserted into the woman's womb, leading to a normal birth.

title: No American P.O.W.'s in Vietnamese Territory
description: To the Editor:

title: Home Resales Climb by 1.2%
description: Sales of existing homes climbed by 1.2 percent in October to the second-highest level in the last six years, a real estate trade group said today.

title: EXPANSION AT WHITNEY: THE DEBATE BROADENS
description: Since last spring, when the Whitney Museum of American Art announced its intention to raise $37.5 million to expand its building at Madison Avenue at 75th Street, the museum has been the focus of an intense public controversy.

title: INTERIOR DEPT. ACCUSED OF HOLDING ILLEGAL TALKS OVER WATER RIGHTS
description: Senator William Proxmire said today that the Interior Department was negotiating what he said might be an illegal ''secret agreement'' to provide farmers in California's Central Valley with cheap subsidized water.

title: CORRECTION
description: A table in Business Day on Saturday with an article about leveraged buyouts included an erroneous identification supplied by Merrill Lynch Capital Partners for one company. The Union Texas Petroleum Corporation, not the Texas Eastern Corporation, was sold in a leveraged buyout.

title: 2 Holdup Men Kill Sexton of Church
description: The 50-year-old sexton of Brown Memorial Baptist Church in the Fort Greene section of Brooklyn was killed yesterday during an attempted robbery in the church office, according to the police.

title: Giants' Martin Sets Mark
description: Research by the Giants today showed that George Martin, their 32-year-old defensive end, had become the National Football League's career leader in touchdowns by a defensive lineman.

title: Mexico and GATT
description: Mexico has announced that it will negotiate entry into the General Agreement on Trade and Tariffs. The announcement was contained in a letter from Mexico's President, Miguel de la Madrid, that was published in the Government's official gazette and instructed the nation's Finance Secretary, Hector Hernandez, to begin the negotiating process. The Mexican Government made the decision in light of a weakening of its foreign economic relations and a trade deficit that has contributed to the country's indebtedness, the letter said.

title: SWEATER SETS BY GLORIA SACHS
description: Sweaters have become the surprise entry in the spring fashion race. Usually fall is considered the big sweater season. But the popularity of lightweight yarns such as cotton, linen and silk has spurred interest in sweaters appropriate for milder weather.

title: Request for Delay In MGM/UA Deal
description: Turner Broadcasting System Inc. announced that it had asked the Securities and Exchange Commission to delay the processing of the three registration statements that Turner filed in connection with its acquisition of the MGM/UA Entertainment Company. The S.E.C. deferral was requested so that Turner could reflect a transaction with Viacom International Inc. in amended filings.

title: Norelco and Oster Ad Accord Set
description: The manufacturers of Norelco and Oster air cleaners have agreed not to misrepresent the ability of their products to eliminate indoor air pollution, the Federal Trade Commission announced. The commission had contended that Norelco Clean Air Machines, made by the North American Philips Corporation, and Oster brand air cleaners, made by the Sunbeam Corporation, do not effectively eliminate significant amounts of air pollution and that advertising for the products was false and misleading.

title: PEGGY FEURY
description: Peggy Feury, who began her career as a Broadway actress and then taught acting to students who included Lily Tomlin, Sean Penn and Melissa Gilbert, died in an automobile collison in Los Angeles last Wednesday. She was 62 years old and lived in Los Angeles.

title: JACKSON OF JETS IS OUT
description: Faced with the shortest work week of their season - one day of practice at home, one on the road - the Jets also learned today they will have precious little time to replace at least one defensive starter, and possibly two.

title: WEST GERMANY SEEKING 2 ARABS IN CAR BOMBING AT AMERICAN PX
description: The West German federal criminal police announced tonight that they were seeking two men believed to be Arabs in connection with a car bombing Sunday at an American military shopping center in northern Frankfurt. The attack wounded 35 people.

title: ECI TELECOM LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PURSES RELEASED EXCEPT FOR TURF
description: The New York State Racing and Wagering Board has released for distribution all purse money from Breeders' Cup Races run at Aqueduct on Nov. 2 except the $2 million purse for the Breeders' Cup Turf race, the sixth on the program.

title: CITY TO WEIGH NEW ACTION AGAINST STEWART DEFENDANTS
description: Mayor Koch and the Transit Authority president said yesterday that the city and the agency would investigate whether departmental charges should be filed against the six transit police officers acquitted on Sunday in the death of Michael Stewart.

title: WACOAL CORP reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
FINALCO GROUP reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-After a nonrecurring charge of $1,313,000 from settlement of Federal income taxes from 1977 to 1983 and $321,000 in reserves related to certain investments. c-Net income.

title: 'THE HITCHHIKER' SERIES, SUSPENSE TALES ON HBO
description: HOME BOX OFFICE has apparently decided that ''The Hitchhiker,'' a series of half-hour suspense tales, can be something more than a joke. In the beginning, the productions looked like show-and-tell demonstrations of pay cable's ability and eagerness to supply customers with more ''permissive'' fare. Each episode became a game of guessing when an opportunity would be devised for the featured performers to take off all their clothes. More often than not, this happened at least twice in the course of the 30 minutes. Other creative considerations tended to be secondary.

title: RESERVOIR LEVELS INCREASE BUT THE CITY IS STILL WARY
description: The water level in New York City's reservoirs has risen sharply in the last month, city officials said yesterday, but they cautioned against optimism that the water shortage was nearing an end.

title: Woman Found Dead In Danbury Was Slain
description: A woman whose body was found in a wooded area near the Padanaram Reservoir here was strangled, an autopsy showed, officials said today.

title: CHARMING SHOPPES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 2
A Lobbyist Delivers A Message in Song
description: Dressed in a top hat and tails, a messenger arrived yesterday in the Albany office of Warren M. Anderson, the Republican majority leader of the State Senate.

title: TACTICS OF EGYPTIAN TROOPS IN ASSAULT ARE QUESTIONED
description: The death toll in the hijacking of an Egyptian airliner rose to 60 today as passengers and others questioned the way in which Egyptian commandos had carried out an armed rescue attempt.

title: What Business Can Do
description: The Reagan Administration says it wants to improve educational standards by encouraging public and private schools to compete. It says the poor should have the same opportunity as the affluent to ''shop around'' for the best schools. To achieve this goal, Secretary of Education William J. Bennett recently proposed channeling Federal aid directly to low-income families through vouchers that can be presented at any school. Although I'm all in favor of competition, this particular voucher plan is doomed to fail.

title: INTELLIGENCE EXPERTS SEE NO LINK AMONG ARRESTS
description: Administration officials say the spate of espionage arrests - four people in four days - is largely coincidence and reflects increased awareness of security problems, not a sudden decision to round up all Americans known to be spying for foreign powers.

title: CDI CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
BUYING A FUR FOR THE FIRST TIME
description: The showrooms of Maximilian, the furrier, are on the third floor of a building just off Fifth Avenue, marked only by a discreet brass sign. Customers sit in a mirrored salon and coats are brought out one at a time for approval.

title: PANEL ORDERS DATA RELEASED IN COHN CASE
description: A state appeals court panel, in an unusual departure from its own strict secrecy rules, ordered yesterday that details of disciplinary proceedings against Roy M. Cohn be made public.

title: CITY TO EXAMINE ITS HOUSING COST AT THE HOLLAND
description: Mayor Koch yesterday directed his staff to examine whether the city was paying too much to house homeless people at the Holland Hotel on West 42d Street near Times Square.

title: EXPOSAIC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DRUG SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 12
description: b-After pretax non-operating losses and charges totaling $2,636,000 from the sale of White Drug Enterprises. c-Net income.

title: COMPLEX PLANNED FOR OLD MADISON SQ. GARDEN SITE
description: A development team that includes William Zeckendorf Jr. announced plans yesterday for a $500 million office and housing complex on the site of the old Madison Square Garden on the West Side of Manhattan.

title: SUMMIT STATEMENT BRINGS NEW LIFE TO FUSION EFFORT
description: A BRIEF sentence in the joint Soviet-American statement issued after last week's summit meeting could give a new spur toward development of an exotic, potentially inexhaustible energy source that has fallen out of political and budgetary favor in recent years: controlled thermonuclear fusion.

title: FILM: 'THE GIG,' BY FRANK D. GILROY
description: ''THE GIG,'' by Frank D. Gilroy, is a small-scale, big-hearted comedy about a group of middle-aged men who enjoy one last fling with freedom and artistic fulfillment, in the form of a two-week Catskills engagement for their amateur Dixieland band. The situation is loaded with potential for soddenness - indeed, several group members are teary-eyed 10 minutes into the story - but on the whole, the film is a nice surprise.

title: ST. JOHN'S STARTING WELL
description: St. John's has begun its 1985-86 season in a manner that probably has surprised even its most optimistic supporters.

title: Where Can Gorbachev Get Such Ideas of Us?
description: To the Editor:

title: Smoking Much?
description: The next annual anti-smoking report of Surgeon General C. Everett Koop will argue that smoking in the workplace multiplies and aggravates the health hazards of asbestos, cotton dust, coal dust, uranium and the like, according to Federal health officials. The report is to be made public Dec. 18.

title: METHODE ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 26, 1985
description: International

title: Where Arthur Ashe Is Assured a Table
description: ''There are a lot of Frenchmen in New York who want a place to hang out with French expatriates,'' Arthur Ashe observed. As in other metiers, tennis players stick together. Mr. Ashe is a friend of Yannick Noah, an owner of Guignol's, a new restaurant at 54 Varick Street in Manhattan.

title: RESULT IS CLOUDED IN HONDURAN VOTE
description: With about two-thirds of the votes counted, the ruling Liberal Party appeared to retain this country's presidency today, if the rules set by a new election law are observed.

title: SECRET SPY INQUIRY MAY MEAN 'HEADS WILL ROLL,' ISRAELIS HEAR
description: Israeli officials said today that an unidentified ''senior Government figure'' was conducting an intensive secret investigation of charges of an Israeli espionage operation in Washington and that it was likely that some ''heads will roll'' soon.

title: 'NEW' LOESSER MUSICAL ON THE BOARDS
description: An unproduced and largely unknown Frank Loesser musical, which sat in a basement file cabinet for 13 years after the composer's death, is now having its New York premiere. The musical, ''Senor Discretion,'' opened last week at Musical Theater Works, a developmental theater, and runs there through Dec. 5.

title: COMPANIES UPSET BY TAX BILL
description: Some of the best-known names in American industry - from Chrysler to Dow Chemical to A.T.&T. and Kaiser Aluminum - began expressing their opposition to the House Ways and Means Committee's tax bill yesterday.

title: ROGERS CABLESYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
description: b-After a loss of $15,925,000 from discontinued operations and a loss on the sale of the company's Irish operations. Year-ago results have been restated to reflect an accounting change.

title: Iranian Gunboats Seize Kuwaiti Cargo Vessel
description: Iranian gunboats have seized a Kuwait-registered cargo ship with a 43-man crew in the Gulf of Oman, the ship's owners said today.

title: 100 YEARS OF MAXIM'S 'KILLING MACHINE'
description: THE centennial year of a weapon that may have killed more people than any other is passing unobserved.

title: INDUSTRIAL NEW JERSEY GIRDS TO PREVENT TOXIC DISASTERS
description: Here in the heart of this state's chemical belt, the other-worldly landscape of tanks, pipes and fire-belching towers that line the New Jersey Turnpike has long been a cue to roll up the car windows, hold the nose and make sardonic jokes about the ''Garden State.''

title: Winning Isn't All
description: Do winning football and basketball programs influence alumni to open their wallets wider?

title: 'HALLEY' ON CHANNEL 13
description: THE best part of ''Comet Halley'' is a segment, ever so brief, on Edmund Halley, who predicted that the comet would reappear every 76 years. The old Astronomer Royal is considerably more interesting, at least on the television program, than the large object bearing his name. The program can be seen on Channel 13 at 10 tonight.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: Business and the Law;   Pennzoil's Huge Award
description: LAWYERS from coast to coast are wondering whether the record award given the Pennzoil Company in its suit against Texaco Inc. will stand up on appeal.

title: CHESS: ALBURT IS AGAIN THE WINNER OF THE U.S. CHAMPIONSHIP
description: For the second straight year, Lev Alburt has won the United States Championship. Alburt, a 40-year-old former Russian grandmaster who now lives in New York, scored 9 1/2-3 1/2 and was awarded $5,000 in the tournament held at the Stanley Hotel in Estes Park, Colo.

title: SYNTEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $258,000. c-After a loss of $1,116,000 from discontinued operations and a gain of $153,000 on the sale of discontinued operations. The share earnings are on a pre- split basis. The company announced a 2-for-1 stock split in October effective Dec. 16. On a post-split basis the share earnings would be 75 cents for the latest quarter, compared to 53 cents for the year-earlier period.

title: N.B.A. Appeals on King
description: Charging the Knicks have made a ''sham'' of the salary cap with the offer sheet they presented to Albert King, the National Basketball Association yesterday appealed to Federal Judge Robert L. Carter to overturn the decision of the special master, who ruled that the offer sheet was legal.

title: Congress;   Democrats: Judicially Frustrated
description: Before his eight years in Washington are finished, President Reagan could well have nominated more than half of the nation's 741 Federal judges. And with a majority of the Supreme Court now at least 77 years old, he might also have the chance to pick at least one more justice in the next three years.

title: Heart Patient's Anniversary
description: William J. Schroeder showed slight improvement today from his third stroke as he quietly marked his first anniversary with a Jarvik-7 artificial heart, a spokesman said.

title: WOMAN WHO INJECTED BELUSHI WITH HEROIN FACES TRIAL FOR MURDER
description: Rejecting defense assertions that Cathy Evelyn Smith was acting on John Belushi's behalf when she repeatedly injected him with heroin, a Municipal Court judge today ordered Miss Smith to stand trial on charges of murdering the comedian in 1982.

title: Con Edison Rates to Rise
description: The State Public Service Commission has given the Consolidated Edison Company permission to raise natural gas rates by 2 percent for its one million customers in Manhattan, the Bronx and parts of Queens. The increase, which takes effect Thursday, was less than the 7.8 percent requested by the utility.

title: How to Remember Michael Stewart
description: Q. Now that a New York jury has refused to hold any police officers responsible for the death of Michael Stewart, how should the community respond?

title: HORMEL, GEORGE A & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 26
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid Sept. 3.

title: ARCHIVE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
description: b-Including a tax credit of $215,000 and after an extraordinary loss of $193,000. c-Including an extraordinary credit of $236,000.

title: Newly Merged Agency Gets A.&P. Account
description: D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles's red-letter day yesterday - the day the merger papers were finally signed - was redder still since the company could announce the arrival of a big new client, the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: KOLLECK RAISES FUNDS AND GAINS HONORS
description: Mayor Teddy Kollek of Jerusalem closed a weeklong visit to New York City last night with a benefit dinner honoring his 20 years as Mayor of Jerusalem and celebrating his approaching 75th birthday.

title: New Zealand Says U.S. Spurns Meeting
description: Prime Minister David Lange said today that United States officials had refused to meet with an official delegation that was planning to travel to Washington early next month to explain New Zealand's proposed legislative ban on nuclear warships.

title: NEWMARK & LEWIS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
SHUTTLE IS SET FOR NIGHT LAUNCHING
description: Preparations for Tuesday night's launching of the space shuttle Atlantis continued smoothly today, and space agency officials said they expected no difficulty in meeting the unusually stringent time schedule dictated by this mission.

title: TERROR: AMERICANS AS TARGETS
description: Americans have been attacked in 72 countries since 1968, and American citizens and property are now the targets of about 30 to 35 percent of all international terrorist incidents, according to State Department figures. Attacks so far in 1985 have left 17 Americans dead and 154 wounded.

title: BROWN-FORMAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After a nonrecurring charge of $2.7 million mainly attributable to the relocation fo the Lenox Candle production facility. Latest quarter results include the sales of California Cooler, acquired on Sept. 5.

title: AFTER 5-YEAR HALT, BANKS IN U.S. SET SOVIET LOAN
description: For reasons that analysts atttribute partly to the spirit of the Reagan-Gorbachev talks but more to serious new strains on the Soviet economy, American banks have started lending to the Russians again after a five-year hiatus.

title: Donaldson Traded
description: The way has been cleared for Benoit Benjamin, the third player selected in the June draft of the National Basketball Association, to become the starting center for the Los Angeles Clippers. James Donaldson, who started at center in the Clippers' first 14 games of the season, was traded to the Dallas Mavericks in exchange for the center Kurt Nimphius, who will become Benjamin's backup.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: ''EVERYONE has gone out of town, at least until the Met opens India,'' Consuelo Crespi complained as she arranged a charity dinner Sunday. Indeed, India fever is rising, but Mrs. Crespi was exaggerating. The fashionable flew all around town last week.

title: RANGERS TO HEAR REVIEWS
description: Not long after each Ranger game, the door to the coach's office closes and Ted Sator and his assistants begin the evaluations. Usually on the following day, they watch the tape of the game and assign a grade to each player. The scores and the comments are filed into a computer and eventually discussed openly, but not until the 10-game review.

title: Tulane Sentences
description: A former Tulane University basketball player and two students escaped prison terms yesterday when they were sentenced for their part in a point-shaving scheme, but they were ordered to give their gambling proceeds to charity. Bobby Thompson, a senior guard who pleaded guilty to one count of conspiracy to commit sports bribery, was fined $2,000 and given a two-year suspended sentence.

title: STUDY SET ON RENT DISCLOSURE
description: The city's Rent Guidelines Board voted yesterday to study the feasibility of requiring landlords who seek rent increases to open their financial records.

title: Reynolds Closes 2 Arkansas Plants
description: The Reynolds Metals Company said it had permanently closed two of its primary aluminum plants in Arkansas.

title: SOVIET POLITBURO BACKS SUMMIT RESULTS
description: The ruling Politburo today described the Soviet-American summit meeting in Geneva as a ''major political event in international life'' that could improve the ''political and psychological climate.''

title: NEW TORCH SHINES ATOP MISS LIBERTY
description: As brilliant autumn sunlight glinted on its gold-leaf flame, a new torch was raised to the right hand of the Statue of Liberty yesterday and set in place high above the majestic amphitheater of New York Harbor.

title: Minstar Will Sell Three AMF Units
description: Minstar Inc. of Minneapolis, the holding company controlled by Irwin L. Jacobs, said it had signed letters of intent to sell three units of its AMF Inc. subsidiary.

title: Removal of 90 Criminals In Refugee Camp Sought
description: Senator Lawton Chiles today filed suit seeking to force the Reagan Administration to remove Cuban refugees who have been convicted of crimes from a detention camp for illegal aliens near here.

title: PLAN FOR OLD GARDEN SITE: IMPRESSIVE RESTRAINT AND A SENSE OF THE CITY
description: The design just proposed for the complex to fill the former Madison Square Garden site between Eighth and Ninth Avenues and 49th and 50th Streets does not look like an object dropped into Manhattan from some alien planet.

title: Maleeva Gains In Melbourne
description: Seventh-seeded Manuela Maleeva of Bulgaria scored a 6-1, 6-1 first-round victory over Lea Antonoplis of the United States in a first-round match Monday at the Australian Open tennis championships.

title: SHOT IN HEAD OR CAUGHT IN INFERNO, PASSENGERS LIVE TO TELL OF ORDEAL
description: Patrick Scott Baker, 28 years old, of White Salmon, Wash., survived because he played dead after being shot by a hijacker at point-blank range and left for dead.

title: WALTER W. JENKINS, TOP AIDE TO JOHNSON IN THE WHITE HOUSE
description: Walter Wilson Jenkins, a longtime aide and close friend of President Lyndon B. Johnson, died Saturday in St. David's Hospital in Austin, Tex. Mr. Jenkins, who was 67 years old, suffered a stroke June 17.

title: Continental Illinois Declares Preferred Dividends
description: In a move that investment analysts said was encouraging, the directors of the Continental Illinois Corporation today declared current quarterly dividends on two classes of preferred stock, and voted to pay full arrearages on them. The arrearages total $45.8 million and the fourth-quarter dividends total about $9.8 million.

title: 49ers Defeat Seahawks, 19-6
description: Joe Montana led the San Francisco 49ers on a 66-yard drive early in the second period, and they went on to a 19-6 victory tonight over the Seattle Seahawks.

title: CONSTRUCTING BUILDINGS NEAR MASS TRANSIT HUBS
description: For the last 20 years, regional planning groups in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut have been urging that commercial developments be placed in what they call regional subcenters, moderate-size cities and developed towns where they can be served by mass transit instead of endless lines of automobiles.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL CALIFORNIA (AL) - Re-signed Bobby Grich, second baseman, to a one-year contract.

title: Careers;   Engineers Introduced To Poetry
description: POETRY and engineering?

title: JAZZ: DEAN PRATT AND BAND
description: THE 16-piece big band led by the trumpeter Dean Pratt, a veteran of the Woody Herman and Buddy Rich bands, is, in some ways, a throwback to the bands of the big band era. Playing for dancing on Sundays from 6 to 10 P.M. at the Jazz Hall of Fame, 21 Hudson Street, a new, large club with both a stage and a dance floor, Mr. Pratt's band makes its major impression as a polished and colorful ensemble.

title: THOR INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Olympics Sets Sponsor Plan
description: Juan Antonio Samaranch, the president of the International Olympic Committee, yesterday announced a new corporate sponsorship program for the Olympic Games, and at the same time said he expected all 161 I.O.C. member nations to participate in the 1988 Games in Calgary and Seoul.

title: MARCOS FOES ARE HINDERED BY NEW RIFTS
description: A clash of personal rivalries has dimmed hopes for unity within the moderate Philippine opposition, to the evident delight of President Ferdinand E. Marcos.

title: Wieboldt's New Chief Ready for Tough Battle
description: Chicago has long had a reputation as a tough town, and that image seems especially deserved in the city's competitive retailing market, led by such strong stores as Marshall Field & Company and Carson Pirie Scott & Company.

title: What New York Needs
description: For all the recent debate about Federal tuition ''vouchers'' and other alternatives to public education, only 30 percent of New York City's children attend private or parochial schools. For better or worse, our public schools will continue to educate an overwhelming majority of the city's children - 930,000 at the moment. In these adverse national conditions, only a concerted effort by government and the private sector can hope to deal with the crisis in our schools.

title: VIRCO MANUFACTURING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $406,000 for the quarter and $656,000 for the 9 months. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $145,000 and a loss on disposal of discontinued operations of $1,161,000.

title: The World Of Sales Promotion
description: ''THE money spent on consumer promotions is going to climb and climb and climb,'' said Thomas M. Hamilton, clearly delighted with the prospect, adding, ''and we're going to use all the tools increasingly to keep up with the growth in consumer spending.''

title: PRETORIA REHIRES 1,700 AT HOSPITAL
description: The authorities today reinstated more than 1,700 black student nurses and auxiliary workers at Baragwanath Hospital who went on strike earlier this month for improved wages and other benefits.

title: ELECTRO-CATHETER CORP reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
description: b-Net income.

title: ACCORD AT BALLET THEATER
description: The American Ballet Theater, which ended its last fiscal year with a $2.4 million deficit, has reached an agreement with its dancers that includes wage givebacks.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The Detroit Red Wings recalled the right wing Lane Lambert and the center Claude Loiselle from the minor leagues and sent down the rookie center Adam Oates. . . . The Hartford Whalers demoted the defenseman Jack Brownschidle to the team's American Hockey League affiliate in Binghamton. . . . The Texas Rangers traded the infielder Wayne Tolleson and the pitcher Dave Schmidt to the Chicago White Sox for the pitcher Ed Correa, the infielder Scott Fletcher and a player to be named.

title: CROP RESIDUE FED TO ANIMALS
description: USING a weak solution of ordinary hydrogen peroxide, crop scientists have found a way to make more of the food energy in corn stalks, corn cobs and wheat straw available for digestion by cows and sheep. By permitting animals to eat more crop residues and less grain, the technique could increase the supply of food for humans.

title: 3 BLACKS LEAVING THEIR WHITE AREA
description: A black family has turned down the city's offer of protection and has decided to move out of a home that was picketed last week by residents of the predominantly white neighborhood, officials said.

title: Bridge: Laws of the Game Discussed In an Authoritative Booklet
description: The fuzzy claim is a frequent source of dispute at every level of the game. If your opponent claims his contract but fails to indicate that he will draw a missing trump, what should the ruling be?

title: MARS STORES INC reports earnings for 13 wks to Oct 26
description: Year-ago figures have been restated because the company changed its fiscal year from a calendar year to a year ending in January.

title: MAURICE PODOLOFF DEAD AT 95, WAS FIRST N.B.A. PRESIDENT
description: Maurice Podoloff, the first president of the National Basketball Association, died Sunday at Yale-New Haven Hospital. Mr. Podoloff, who had been in a coma for several days, was 95 years old.

title: Heller and Coetzee Get A French Book Award
description: The American novelist Joseph Heller and South Africa's J. M. Coetzee were honored today as the best foreign novelists of the year by France's Inter Allie book awards.

title: ROSS STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 2
Mary Lasker's Laboratory
description: Scientific research is so expensive that it has few private patrons. But medical research has the next best thing in Mary Lasker, the New York philanthropist. The 40th annual Lasker prizes, nearly as coveted as the Nobel Prizes, were presented in New York last week.

title: Eating Mightily?
description: The way the Agriculture Department figures it, Americans are likely to surpass themselves this year in turkey eating. According to a department economist, Allen Baker, the number of turkeys going, or already gone, to market this year is 180,485,000.

title: Guillen Top Rookie
description: Ozzie Guillen, the shortstop who came to the Chicago White Sox in a seven-player trade that sent the Cy Young winner LaMarr Hoyt to San Diego, was named the American League Rookie of the Year yesterday by the Baseball Writers' Association of America.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: SOME TRENDS ARE APPARENT AT COMDEX
description: THE computer industry held its annual crapshoot and beauty pageant in Las Vegas last week, and tens of thousands of conventioneers gathered to make deals and display wares at the giant Comdex show. There were few surprises this year, but some product trends did emerge.

title: Rhode Island Seeks Rule On Tenure of Chief Judge
description: Rhode Island's Chief Justice serves at the whim of the General Assembly and can be ousted by a simple majority vote, an attorney for Gov. Edward D. DiPrete argued before the state's Supreme Court today.

title: MOST WOULD PAY 9% LESS TAX UNDER HOUSE PANEL'S PACKAGE
description: The vast majority of Americans could expect to pay an average of about 9 percent less in taxes under the tax-revision plan completed by the House Ways and Means Committee over the weekend.

title: Airport Financing Set By Charlotte
description: The City of Charlotte, N.C., is offering $110 million of airport revenue bonds through underwriters led by Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company.

title: At Grand Central, Kodak Could Lose Its Beam
description: Love it (as a spectacular display) or spurn it (as an esthetic intrusion), there is one thing you cannot do in the presence of the Kodak Colorama in Grand Central Terminal: miss it.

title: Greyhound Parts
description: The Greyhound Corporation said its Greyhound Lines unit would begin selling rebuilt Greyhound bus engines, transmissions and other components to carriers throughout the United States. The units, which will include diesel engines, alternators and condensors, will be rebuilt by mechanics at Greyhound's Chicago rebuilding facilities.

title: SNAG IN U.S.-CANADA TRADE
description: A dispute over the right of an American company to own a publishing house in Canada has put a chill on talk of a free-trade pact between the two nations, the world's biggest trading partners.

title: When Dying Is More Than a Bad Attitude
description: To the Editor:

title: Milwaukee Road Reorganization
description: The reorganization of the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul & Pacific Railroad was completed after an eight-year effort by the railroad to resolve its financial woes through Federal bankruptcy proceedings. Trustee Richard Ogilvie turned the railroad's remaining assets over to the CMC Real Estate Corporation, the corporation's new name, with cash and property estimated to be worth at least $400 million.

title: HONECKER TRIP TO BONN? ODDS GROW
description: The optimism generated by the Soviet-American summit meeting in Geneva has increased the likelihood that Erich Honecker, the East German leader, will reschedule a visit to Bonn that he abruptly canceled a year ago, West German officials and experts on Eastern Europe say.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Atari Corp., the personal computer company based in Sunnyvale, Calif., has named Michael V. Katz executive vice president.

title: DUNES HOTELS & CASINOS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income c-Including income of $30,000 from discontinued operations. d-After a loss of $711,000 from discontinued operations. e-After a loss of $61,000 from discontinued operations and including an extraordinary gain of $11,489,000 from the exchange of stock for debt.

title: NOVELIST WON ITALIAN PRIZES
description: Elsa Morante, the Italian author whose novels won two of her country's highest awards, the Viareggio and Strega prizes, died of a heart attack yesterday in a clinic in Rome. She was 67 years old.

title: $55 Million Issue In New Hampshire
description: A $55 million financing by the New Hampshire Housing Finance Authority was tentatively priced through underwriters led by Kidder, Peabody & Company with maximum yields of 9 1/8 percent for bonds due in 2011 and 9 percent for bonds due in 2000.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: A GO-GO COMEBACK David Rabe has rewritten his play ''In the Boom Boom Room,'' which was first produced at the Vivian Beaumont Theater in 1973 under the supervision of Joseph Papp. The drama's central figure is a go-go dancer trying to determine her value as a human being. Mr. Rabe also wrote ''The Basic Training of Pavlo Hummell,'' ''Streamers,'' ''Sticks and Bones'' and ''Hurlyburly.'' In 1974 ''In the Boom Boom Room'' was produced at the Public Theater, and in 1983 it was produced by the Orange Theater Company in a stylized version that did away with realistic sets and props. Mr. Rabe liked this concept and decided to rewrite the play, emphasizing its surreal and timeless elements.

title: FARMERS ARE TAKING THE BLOWS WITH SLOWDOWN OF INCREASES IN GROCERY PRICES
description: As an agricultural depression grips the country's principal farming regions, the surpluses that are causing problems for farmers are producing a boon for millions of consumers.

title: Repayment Plan Collapse
description: A plan to repay customers of Volume Investors Corporation, which went into receivership in March, collapsed yesterday when the owners refused to provide $4.1 million because some customers had not signed waivers of their right to sue Volume or its owners, according to John F. X. Peloso, Volume's receiver.

title: BRIDGING THE GAP WITH NICARAGUA
description: On the face of it, the prospect that we will soon see a democratic Nicaragua working in diplomatic harmony with the United States seems remote. On Oct. 15, the Sandinistas announced severe restrictions on civil rights. This action, surely ill-timed and ill-conceived, also underscored the bankruptcy of our own policies in the region. The gap between the two governments could not be wider. It's time we thought of some new ways to bridge it.

title: KEITHLEY INSTRUMENTS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Highlights Aren't Enough
description: Wanted: Two broadcasters who can deliver the sports news quickly. Good teeth and nice hair essential. Perks include high pay and high profile. Must believe in divine right of athletes.

title: OUTSIDE TURKEY PLANT, UNION IS TESTING A BOYCOTT
description: Turkeys for the American holiday table are being killed, cleaned and shipped, at the rate of 50,000 a day, from a poultry plant that has been struck for 18 months.

title: JETS-GIANTS SUPER ODDS: 50-1
description: For all those New York pro football followers who have suffered through so many years of famine, this year of plenty has produced the potential of a double dream come true - the Jets vs. the Giants in Super Bowl XX on Jan. 26 at the Louisiana Superdome. But what are the odds on this possibility turning into a reality? And so that very question was asked of Bob Martin, who is Las Vegas's most respected sports oddsmaker.

title: Topics;   Discoveries Labored Love Found
description: ''A pretty bare, past compare Parts those plots which besots still asunder.'' Are these lines by Shakespeare? Flyspecks or old blots or a blunder? ''It is meet naught but sweet Should come near that so rare 'tis a wonder.''

title: GEO INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $858,000 for the quarter and $6,122,000 for the year.

title: PREVENTING DROPOUTS
description: TRENTON STATE COLLEGE makes freshmen take a one-credit course in ''campus survival'' and guarantees them on-campus housing. American University in Washington assigns faculty members to befriend new undergraduates. Canisius College in Buffalo has a computerized ''student services data base'' that shows counselors which newcomers have not joined a club or signed up for intramural sports.

title: Sweater Campaign Is A Full-Page Warning
description: The Homer & Durham Advertising agency has put its indigenous blue nose to work for its client Cutlass & Moore, the men's sweater maker.

title: THE FOUR SUSPECTS IN THE SPY CASES
description: Over the last five days, the Federal authorities have arrested four people on espionage-related charges. Here is a summary of their cases and their backgrounds: Jonathan Jay Pollard Jonathan Jay Pollard, 31 years old, is suspected of spying for Israel while working as a counterintelligence analyst for the Navy.

title: Sterile Salmon
description: Scientists at Michigan State University are developing a type of salmon that cannot spawn and will therefore live to a ripe - and very large - old age.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''In no way should the impression be given of weakness on our part in the face of the cruelty and inhumanity of the hijackers.

title: 4 IOWA ATHLETES AMONG 7 DEAD IN PLANE CRASH
description: A twin-engine plane carrying members of the Iowa State University women's cross-country team crashed in a freezing drizzle this evening, killing seven people aboard as it burst into flames in a residential neighborhood, the authorities said.

title: GATT Opens Trade Talks
