description: Trade officials opened a top-level meeting today under the sponsorship of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. The session's chairman called for a joint effort by the 90 member nations of GATT to stem what he called serious problems in world trade.

title: Rates on U.S. Issues Stable
description: Interest rates were little changed for short- and long-term Treasury issues yesterday, but slightly higher for tax-exempt and corporate bonds.

title: Suspicious Baggage Traced to Vancouver
description: A man who gave a Sikh name checked baggage onto a Vancouver-to-Toronto flight that connected with the Air-India jet that plunged into the Atlantic last June 23, a Canadian investigator said today.

title: Beirut Hostages Well, Anglican Envoy Says
description: An Anglican envoy who was in Beirut recently trying to gain the release of four American hostages there said yesterday in New York that the four men ''are of good heart and well'' and that he was hopeful that their release could be arranged.

title: Stepped-Up Effort Against Vandals
description: The police said yesterday that they would increase surveillance and assign plainclothes officers in the Borough Park and Flatbush sections of Brooklyn to halt vandalism of Jewish-owned shops.

title: Seattle Bank Fined by U.S.
description: The Treasury Department said today that the Seattle First National Bank had agreed to pay a $697,000 fine to settle charges that it failed to report currency transactions required by bank secrecy laws.

title: 3Com, Convergent to Merge
description: The computer maker Convergent Technologies and the 3Com Corporation, a maker of personal computer networks, said today that they hade agreed in principle to merge.

title: MARTIN MAY JOIN YANKEE BROADCASTERS
description: Billy Martin has served the Yankees as a player, a manager, a scout and an advisor. His next role could be as a broadcaster.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 26, 1985
description: The Economy

title: Winter Storm Kills 14 As It Rakes Midwest
description: A winter storm that contributed to the deaths of at least 14 people and caused hundreds of traffic collisions in two days continued over the Rockies and the Middle West yesterday.

title: AIRLINES DOUBTFUL ON GUARDS
description: The weekend hijacking of an Egyptian airliner has underscored international airline officials' concerns that posting armed guards aboard airliners may be counterproductive.

title: A Floating Exchange Rate Without the Speculators
description: To the Editor:

title: Health of the Homeless
description: To the Editor:

title: Sonat Gets Option On Coastal's Stake
description: Sonat Inc. yesterday removed any threat of a takeover by the Coastal Corporation by agreeing to buy $117.7 million worth of Coastal debentures that can be exchanged for the 6 percent stake of Sonat stock that is held by Coastal.

title: REAGAN AIDES CALL BILL VEHICLE
description: Key White House advisers are close to recommending that President Reagan support the House Democrats' tax bill so that the measure can serve as a vehicle for introducing the issue of tax revision in the Senate.

title: Combustion Engineering
description: Combustion Engineering Inc. has combined two of its business groups into one division that will sell products and services to cities, towns and governmental agencies, the company announced.

title: HIJACKERS LINKED TO PALESTIAN FACTION
description: The gunmen who hijacked an Egyptian airliner to Malta were pro-Libyan followers of Abu Nidal, a Palestinian known for his strong opposition to Yasir Arafat, according to sources close to the Palestinians here.

title: BARTON VALVE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MAIL CALL FOR JETS' HAMILTON
description: The most intriguing questions among the press corps covering the Jets are: Who are these Harry Hamilton letter-writers and what do they want?

title: Market Place;   Nuclear Utility Payout Outlook
description: IN these days of declining interest rates, a dividend yield of about 17 percent, as shown currently in the newspaper stock tables for the common shares of the Northern Indiana Public Service Company, can be quite alluring. The yields in these tables are computed on the basis of the latest dividend payout rates.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Nov. 13 about Lloyd's of London misstated the relationship of Peter Cameron-Webb to the Insurance Exchange of the Americas. Mr. Cameron-Webb represents a company that manages an insurance syndicate there.

title: South Pole Satellite
description: Two Government agencies, two universities and several commercial manufacturers have joined forces to give scientists stationed at the South Pole a reliable satellite link to the outside world.

title: New Data Service Set
description: A new electronic information service drawing largely on the contents of The New York Times, news services and consumer publications will become available to business and residential users in the New York area next spring.

title: REAGAN VACATION BEGINS AT RANCH
description: President Reagan arrived here today for a Thanksgiving visit, putting decisions behind him for a six-day holiday.

title: TOYS 'R' US CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 3
HALLEY'S COMET
description: Nov. 27, 1985 Halley's Comet will rise over the New York City area at 2:16 P.M. today and set at 4:24 A.M. tomorrow.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: FLAUBERT & TURGENEV. A Friendship in Letters: The Complete Correspondence. Edited and translated by Barbara Beaumont. 197 pages. W. W. Norton & Company. $19.95.

title: ROANOKE ELECTRIC STEEL CORPQtr to Oct 31 reports earnings for 1985
WEAPONS CACHE IS FINAL EVIDENCE PRESENTED AGAINST ARYAN GROUP
description: Prosecutors rested their case today in the racketeering trial of 10 members of a neo-Nazi splinter group accused of murders and bank robberies in an alleged plot to overthrow the United States Government.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: U S SHOE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Yugoslav Leaders Warn of Social Unrest
description: The Yugoslav state leadership has warned Prime Minister Milka Planinc's Government that a worsening economic crisis could start social unrest among the country's 22 million people, the Yugoslav press agency said today.

title: Lomas & Nettleton Is Offering Notes
description: The Lomas & Nettleton Financial Corporation, the largest mortgage banking concern in the country, is offering $500 million face amount of liquid yield option notes due in 2001 through Merrill Lynch Capital Markets as sole underwriter.

title: Fund Sales Set Record
description: Sales of mutual funds reached $12.3 billion in October, a monthly record, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Net sales - sales less redemptions - also set a new high last month at $9.6 billion.

title: Health Unit's Variable Bonds
description: A $326.1 million issue of variable-rate bonds due in 2020 for the Health Care Facilities Authority of Sayre, Pa., was tentatively offered yesterday through underwriters led by Kidder, Peabody & Company.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: United-Pan Am
description: President Reagan will not oppose United's acquisition of Pan Am's Pacific air routes, clearing the way for the $750 million deal to be completed. A United statement said that the only remaining obstacle was the transfer of landing rights by Japan, South Korea, China, Taiwan, Hong Kong, the Philippines, Singapore, Thailand, Australia and New Zealand. The Transportation Department gave its approval on Oct. 31, despite objections from Northwest Airlines, which said the sale could force it out of the Pacific market and endanger its financial viability.

title: U.S. SENATORS IN LETTER, URGE MARCOS TO HOLD FREE ELECTION
description: Senator Richard G. Lugar, chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, and three other members of the committee have sent a letter to President Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines saying it is ''essential'' that the coming elections there ''be conducted in a free and fair manner.''

title: New Tremors in Balkan Area
description: Yugoslav seismological stations reported more earth tremors today in Albania and in the neighboring Yugoslav region of Montenegro. Montenegro was hit by strong earthquakes last Sunday, reportedly causing considerable damage but no casualties.

title: RANDOM HOUSE BUYS REAGAN BOOK
description: After a spirited auction involving six other publishers, Random House won the publishing rights to Edmund Morris's biography of Ronald Reagan yesterday. The winning bid, said to have been $3 million, is believed to be the highest advance ever paid for a single book.

title: Doctor Says Baby Improves After Rare Heart Transplant
description: An infant known as Baby Moses, recipient of a rare baby-to-baby heart transplant at the age of 4 days, is progressing well, the Loma Linda Medical Center announced today.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Market Place;   Time's Talks With Gannett
description: IT was a meeting that under other circumstances would not have caused a stir. But when the president of Time Inc., J. Richard Munro, met last week with the Gannett Company's chief executive officer, Allen H. Neuharth, it started imaginations on Wall Street working overtime.

title: Air Force Sees Improvement in Republic Project
description: The Air Force said today that the Republic division of Fairchild Industries was correcting the management problems that had been found in the manufacturing of the T-46A trainer aircraft.

title: STOCK FALLS ON TEXACO STATEMENT
description: The stock of Texaco Inc. fell yesterday in response to published remarks by its president that the company could be forced into bankruptcy proceedings if it were required to post a $12 billion bond to appeal a Texas jury's verdict against it in the Pennzoil case.

title: GENERAL DEFENSE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
ABRAMS INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
IMARK INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 28
Advertising;   Ogilvy & Mather Gets Covidea Account
description: Ogilvy & Mather has been named agency for Covidea, a videotex venture of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, Chemical Bank and Time Inc. Marketplace rumblings estimate that start-up annual billings could be $5 million to $10 million.

title: SHOCK SETS IN AS GURU'S FOLLOWERS IN OREGON LEAVE TO FACE OUTSIDE WORLD
description: What used to be the reception center has become the departure lounge as the population of the Rajneeshee commune here melts away.

title: CBS Held to Libel Company
description: A Federal jury today found that CBS Inc. and a commentator at the network's Chicago television station had libeled a tobacco company by broadcasting an anticigarette commentary.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: MORE and more companies throughout the country are taking an active interest in the physical condition of their most vital resource: their employees. As Denny Haefner, fitness director at Life Investors Inc., put it: ''When you run a company, you're concerned about your people because you are only as strong as your people.''

title: DURABLES ORDERS DOWN 2.1%
description: Factory orders for durable goods tumbled 2.1 percent last month, the biggest decline since July, the Commerce Department said today.

title: TANGLED RULES ON TOXIC HAZARDS HAMPER EFFORTS TO PROTECT PUBLIC
description: Federal efforts to protect the public from dangerous chemicals and other environmental risks are foundering in a confusing, contradictory, haphazardly administered mire of laws, rules and procedures, according to both proponents and opponents of greater regulation.

title: ACCORD REACHED ON LANDFILL CLEANUP
description: A cleanup of the nation's largest chemically contaminated landfill was agreed to here today by the Federal and New York State governments and the Occidental Chemical Corporation.

title: AGENCY RENT-A-CAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Including a nonrecurring gain of about $300,000 related to the sale of the company's Thriftway Motel property. Share earnings have been adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split paid Aug. 14.

title: Carbide Relief Plan Approved
description: An agreement was reached yesterday under which the Union Carbide Corporation would contribute $5 million in relief to victims of its gas leak disaster in Bhopal, India.

title: ALASKA BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BIAS IS CHARGED IN REDISTRICTING OF LOS ANGELES
description: The Justice Department today filed a suit seeking to overturn a 1982 redistricting plan that it says deprived Hispanic residents of adequate political representation on the City Council.

title: Drug Tests Approved For Railroad Workers
description: A Federal judge today approved a mandatory drug testing program for 200,000 railroad workers over union objections that the tests are illegal searches.

title: Of John 3:16
description: Washingtonians who recognize the ''John 3:16'' banner hung over railings at many nationally televised sporting events have not sighted one at Robert F. Kennedy Stadium for the past year. The reason is that stadium managers ordered security guards to remove three such banners on Nov. 4, 1984, just before a Redskin football game, and now the banners are the subject of a lawsuit alleging constitutional infringements.

title: WRAPPING THE BODY IN SCARF AND BELT
Suicide Bomber Strikes Israeli Post in Lebanon
description: A teen-age girl exploded a car bomb at a joint post of Israeli troops and pro-Israeli militiamen in southern Lebanon today, killing herself and causing a number of casualties, Lebanese security sources said.

title: 'Anarchy' in the Senate
description: Senators who plan to continue being Senators for the indefinite future, God and the voters willing, are rarely critical of the institution, its procedures or its members. Senators who are approaching voluntary retirement tend to be more candid.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, NOVEMBER 27, 1985
description: International A hijacking survivor has been called ''the chief of the hijackers'' of an Egyptair jet by several other survivors, according to a Maltese Government spokesman. He said the accused 20-year-old man was in satisfactory condition, had given his name as Omar Marzouki and claimed to be Tunisian. [Page A1, Column 6.]

title: JAZZ: COMPO AND TRIO
description: PETE COMPO, a jazz bassist who began his musical studies on the violin, has recently renewed his interest in that instrument and now plays violin exclusively with a trio he leads on Sundays at the Red Blazer, Second Avenue near 82d Street.

title: JAMES BASIL WAGSTAFF
description: James Basil Wagstaff, a former general manager of De Soto and vice president of the Chrysler Corporation, died of cancer Sunday at his home in Boca Raton, Fla. He was 89 years old.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, NOVEMBER 27, 1985
description: The Economy

title: Comings and Goings
description: Wallace Bryant, a 7-foot center who started the last 35 games of the 1984-85 season for the Dallas Mavericks, was waived, a day after the Mavericks acquired James Donaldson, a 7-2 center, from the Los Angeles Clippers. . . . Hank Peters, the general manager of the Baltimore Orioles, said the club was asking players negotiating new contracts to sign an agreement requiring them to submit to drug tests next season.

title: Economic Scene;   Testing Time For Texans
description: ARE the strains that have been hurting the Texas economy temporary or do they signify lasting troubles for the state? And, if so, what can be done about them?

title: SEA-LAND REJECTS SIMMONS OFFER OF $25 A SHARE
description: The Sea-Land Corporation said yesterday that it had rejected as ''inadequate'' an unsolicited $25-a-share takeover bid by Harold C. Simmons, a Dallas investor.

title: Problem Sharing
description: Amsterdam and New Amsterdam have much in common. And yesterday the Mayor of the former called on the Mayor of the latter to discuss them.

title: 2 PARTIES TO RUN POLITICAL DEBATES
description: The Democratic and Republican national chairmen signed an agreement today to make the two political parties the principal sponsors of Presidential debates in the general election campaign.

title: OUT OF THE PEN AND INTO THE OVEN
description: Will Miloski doesn't believe anyone should feel guilty about having one of his turkeys at Thanksgiving.

title: BRANIFF INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes extraordinary tax credits of $4.1 million, or 33 cents a share, for the quarter and $10.8 million, or 88 cents a share, for the 9 months. c-Net loss The year-earlier 9 months figures reflect only 8 months of operations because Braniff began scheduled service on March 1, 1984.

title: Contract Pentagon Costs
description: To the Editor:

title: BOHEMIA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After an extraordinary tax loss of $94,000. c-Net income d-After income from discontinued operations of $1,563,000, or 36 cents a share, for the quarter and $1,715,000, or 40 cents a share, for the 6 months and income on disposal of marine construction equipment of $3,093,000, or 72 cents a share, for the quarter and 6 months. e-After an extraordinary tax credit of $414,000, or 9 cents a share. The share earnings for the year- earlier periods have been adjusted for a 3 percent stock dividend distributed Jan. 7.

title: EXPERT ON LAW OF COPYWRIGHT
description: Prof. Melville Nimmer, an expert on copyright laws and an advocate of free speech, died of cancer Saturday at Cedar-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles. He was 62 years old and a resident of Los Angeles.

title: WARNER-LAMBERT PLANS WRITE-OFF
description: The Warner-Lambert Company yesterday announced a $550 million charge against fourth-quarter earnings as part of a substantial reorganization that will take the company out of the hospital supply business.

title: Community Boards Shouldn't Rule on Aid to Small Businesses
description: To the Editor:

title: A Holiday Sale
description: Just in time for Christmas baking as well as Christmas gift giving, H. Roth & Son (Lekvar by the Barrel), the food and kitchenware emporium at 1577 First Avenue (82d Street), has marked down everything in the store. Cooking equipment from wooden spoons to heavy-duty copper pans, from wire whisks to ceramic baking dishes, from bottle openers and potato peelers to stockpots, mixing bowls, storage bins and souffle dishes - everything in the shop has been reduced in price by 50 percent or more. Hand-carved wooden boards for stamping springerle biscuits, for instance, are just $3 and $6, depending on the size, and Sabatier knives are offered two for the price of one. Heavy, tin-lined French copper crepe pans are $18 (for the eight-inch size) instead of $35.95.

title: Capital Plan For Mission
description: The Mission Insurance Group Inc. today announced an agreement in principle with the California Insurance Department to allow Carl H. Lindner, Mission's chairman and largest shareholder, to inject an additional $125 million in capital into its Mission American Insurance Company subsidiary.

title: LINCOLN TUNNEL CRASH ADDS TO JAMS
description: There were rain-slicked roads and a preholiday crush of motorists. There was an accident in the Lincoln Tunnel and flooding on the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway. And all over the city yesterday, there were traffic jams.

title: FEMA Playing Wrong Role in Evacuation Plans
description: To the Editor:

title: CHINA FIGHTS STUDENT PROTEST AGAINST 'OPEN DOOR'
description: Chinese leaders have summoned an emergency congress of the Communist Youth League in an attempt to quell mounting student protests against Deng Xiaoping's so-called open door policies.

title: FINALCO GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a nonrecurring charge of $1,313,000 from settlement of Federal income taxes from 1977 to 1983 and $321,000 in reserves related to certain investments. c-Net income

title: YONKERS, IN MIDST OF A DECLINE, STRUGGLES TO RECAPTURE ITS PAST
description: From the east side to the west side of Yonkers, in churches and synagogues, schools and on the streets, residents were talking this week about the landmark housing and school desegregation case that they commonly call ''the suit.''

title: YELENA BONNER IN MOSCOW EN ROUTE TO WEST
description: Yelena G. Bonner, the wife of Andrei D. Sakharov, the physicist and rights advocate, arrived here today, evidently en route to the West for medical treatment.

title: PARTIES FOR TOTS TURN LAVISH
description: WALKER BROCK, a blue-eyed blond with an easy grin, celebrated his fifth birthday the other day by having the former star of ''Godspell'' present a two-hour show for him and 20 of his friends. Jeremy Sage, who portrayed Jesus in the musical's Off Broadway production, captivated the youngsters by directing a band of stuffed animals, chasing Maurice the Robot and darting in and out of the first-floor window of the Manhattan brownstone.

title: High Rollers
description: When multimillion-dollar contracts are bandied about at the drop of a base hit, there's not much inclination to take notice of far more modest milestones. Still, history of a sort is about to be made on the professional bowlers' tour.

title: ASCENDING 2D SUMMIT
description: The general sense among Soviet and American officials is that it was easy for the two leaders to walk away from their first summit meeting with only handshakes and pledges to intensify the diplomatic process. But next time, the officials say, there must be real movement on the arms control front - or failure.

title: TUNNEL SPEEDS I-95 FLOW IN BALTIMORE
description: The opening of the gleaming Fort McHenry Tunnel, which triples the number of Interstate highway lanes through the Baltimore Harbor area, has brought predictions that one of the East Coast's worst highway traffic bottlenecks will finally be unclogged.

title: Temporary Chief
description: Larry Hazzard, a former Golden Gloves boxer who has been serving both as New Jersey's chief boxing referee and principal of a junior high school in Newark, was named acting state athletic commissioner. He will serve until the state's new three-man Athletic Control Board is empaneled and can select a permanent director. Hazzard replaces Bob Lee, a former deputy commissioner, whose nomination to serve as commissioner was withdrawn after a conflict-of-interest investigation earlier this year.

title: HECHINGER CO reports earnings for 13wks to Nov 2
description: Results reflect a 5-for-4 stock split effective June 17.

title: 3 More in Philadelphia Guilty of Taking Payoffs
description: A former police chief inspector and two other former police officers were found guilty today of conspiracy and extortion for taking payoffs to protect gambling and prostitution.

title: TAX FAVORS OF ROSTENKOWSKI: TAX REVISION'S QUID PRO QUO
description: As a rule, the legislation on tax revision that the House Ways and Means Committee finished drafting last weekend would prohibit the use of tax-exempt bonds to finance sports stadiums, convention facilities and parking garages.

title: JURY HEARS ABOUT 'SKIMMING'
description: A jury heard opening statements yesterday in the Manhattan trial of a reputed crime leader and 11 other defendants indicted on racketeering charges involving the operation of several bars and restaurants.

title: State Department;   Governmental Lessons on Surviving Terrorism
description: A sedan driving down an isolated desert highway comes upon a roadblock manned by armed terrorists. The driver stops, quickly analyzes the situation, then steps on the gas, careening through two blocking cars to safety.

title: SAGE DRILLING CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a tax credit of $80,000. c-Net income.

title: ONE-MAN OFFICE PICKS WORLD'S BEST DRESSED
description: ''Yeah,'' said Charles Richman, picking up the phone at the Fashion Foundation of America. ''This is Fashion. Whaddyawant?''

title: SMUCKER, J M CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split to be paid in December.

title: Insulation Contractor Takes On Lilco Leaders
description: John Matthews has run for public office on Long Island four times since 1970 and has been defeated every time. Just this month, he lost his second bid to become Nassau County executive.

title: Guerrillas Kill 4 Tamils Who Opposed Violence
description: Tamil separatist guerrillas killed four people in Sri Lanka during the past 24 hours and tied their bodies to lampposts, the national news agency said today.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Nets vs. Philadelphia 76ers, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, 7:30 P.M. The 76ers won the last season's series, 4-2, but in their only meeting this season Micheal Ray Richardson scored 20 points to lead a 106-102 New Jersey victory.

title: NORTH CAROLINA CRUSHES IONA
description: Brad Daugherty set a conference record for a perfect string of field goals and Steve Hale scored 15 points to lead a balanced attack as North Carolina crushed Iona, 110-67, tonight.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: LEICHTER SAYS BUILDERS GAVE MOST TO MEMBERS OF BOARD OF ESTIMATE
description: Most of the largest campaign contributors to members of the Board of Estimate were major city contractors or developers with projects requiring board approval, according to a survey released yesterday.

title: Transactions
description: BASKETBALL DALLAS (NBA) - Waived Wallace Bryant, center.

title: Truck Driver Is Hurt By Mine in South Africa
description: Two land mine explosions damaged two farm trucks and injured a driver near the Zimbabwe border today in what was thought to be the first mining of roads in South Africa by anti-apartheid guerrillas, the authorities said.

title: Aristotle Was No Supply-Side Advocate
description: To the Editor:

title: CUTBACKS TO ALTER FORM OF ANTIMISSILE PROGRAM
description: Congressional budget cuts have forced researchers in the antimissile program to focus on land-based lasers and killer rockets in the quest for a way to destroy attacking nuclear missiles, the director of the program said today.

title: Eastern Fare Cuts
description: Eastern Airlines said it was reducing some of its regular coach fares by 70 percent for travel from Dec. 26 through Dec. 28 on most of its domestic flights. Earlier this month, Delta Air Lines announced similar discounts. The discount tickets must be bought within seven days of making a reservation, but no later than Dec. 23.

title: MOROCCAN HARDENS POSITION ON TALKS WITH ISRAEL
description: King Hassan II elaborated today on terms for holding peace talks with Prime Minister Shimon Peres of Israel, saying that such negotiations could not take place until Israel made it clear it was willing to discuss giving up occupied territories and granting Palestinians self-determination.

title: ZEUS COMPONENTS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a $48,000 tax credit.

title: Penn State Still No. 1
description: Penn State, with its 11-0 record, remained on top in The New York Times's computer ranking. No. 2 Miami and No. 3 Auburn exchanged last week's rankings; Michigan went from fifth to fourth, and Oklahoma moved up three places, to fifth.

title: SCREEN: 'ROCKY IV,' VS. THE U.S.S.R.
description: THERE are two big boxing matches during ''Rocky IV,'' one set at the MGM Grand Hotel in Las Vegas (this is an MGM/UA movie) and the other in the Soviet Union. The two locales are meant to be very different, what with James Brown singing at the first fight and large red banners in honor of Soviet leadership flying at the other. But the carnival atmosphere surrounding both bouts gives them the sameness that has become the ''Rocky'' series' most debilitating feature.

title: STERLING SOFTWARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Advertising;   Promoting Modern Maturity
description: GENERALLY when advertisers and their agencies think about mass-market products and the media to sell them, they are thinking about reaching the 18-to-49 age group with their growing households. They are not thinking about the older crowd. But they should.

title: 1.9 MILLION TAX RETURNS ARE STILL UNPROCESSED
description: More than seven months after the April 15 Federal income tax filing deadline, the Internal Revenue Service said today that 1.9 million tax returns remain unprocessed because of taxpayer or agency error.

title: Dr. Edward O'Connor, Leader Of Displaced Persons Agency
description: Dr. Edward Mark O'Connor, who served as United States commissioner of displaced persons after World War II, died Sunday at his home in Buffalo. He was 77 years old. Dr. O'Connor headed war relief services for the National Catholic Welfare Council during World War II.

title: New Hybrid Security At Household Finance
description: Shearson Lehman Brothers, which introduced money market preferred stock last year and money market notes this year, has refined those concepts with a new security called exchangeable money market preferred stock.

title: PETRIE STORES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
What To Do And Not To Do
description: In instructing Government personnel on how to cope with terrorism abroad, the State Department offers a number of ''Do's and Don'ts.''

title: ACMAT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
AT FARM TABLES, SIMPLE IS STILL THE BEST
description: FARMERS in New York State are supplying the ingredients that are the cornerstone of the new American cuisine - the free-range chickens, Cortland apples, Anjou pears, handcrafted cheeses, fresh herbs, Swiss chard, arugula and the like with which city dwellers are familiar. But on their own tables these New York State farm women serve dishes that have very little that is ''new'' about them. They are the same old-fashioned recipes for which farm kitchens have always been admired.

title: Philadelphia Concern Recalls 19 Snack Mixes With Sulfite
description: Consumers in five Eastern states, including New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, were warned today by the Food and Drug Administration that dried fruits and snack mixes sold in 320 retail stores might contain sulfite preservatives that could cause a severe allergic reaction in some people.

title: ANGLICAN BRIEFS BUSH ON BEIRUT HOSTAGE TALKS
description: Terry Waite, the Church of England representative seeking the release of American captives in Lebanon, conferred for an hour today with Vice President Bush and other American officials to discuss some ways of winning the hostages' freedom.

title: Policeman Is Killed In Athens Car-Bombing
description: A car bomb exploded tonight as a police bus was passing, killing one of the policemen inside and wounding 14, officials reported.

title: GRAND TOUR FOR RUDBY TEAM
description: The United States is not known as a rugby-playing nation. But during the last week, an American women's team touring Britain has shown that, as far as the women's game is concerned, the American standard will be difficult to match.

title: WEISFIELD'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Perot Termed G.M. Dissenter
description: H.

title: U.S. OFFICIALS FIND IMMENSE DAMAGE IN ESPIONAGE CASES
description: Senior intelligence officials say the United States has been immensely damaged by the series of espionage cases disclosed in the last week.

title: 30 YEARS OF SPYING FOR CHINA IS CHARGED
description: A Federal law-enforcement official said today that a former analyst for the Central Intelligence Agency had admitted that he provided the Chinese Government with extensive intelligence information for 30 years.

title: Honor Bestowed, At Long Last
description: Charles Bornstein will be decorated today with a Purple Heart that he earned 40 years ago.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: A GOLDEN AGE The V. and A., as the Victoria and Albert Museum in London is often called, has, since its opening in 1856, been collecting photographs. This was a crucial and prescient move because photography's best years in Britain came during the Victorian era, following the invention there by William Henry Fox Talbot of the calotype, the first negative-positive process, in 1839. Now more than 200 photographs from the museum's collection have been brought here for an exhibition, ''The Golden Age of British Photography, 1839-1900,'' on view at the Pierpont Morgan Library (685-0008).

title: Georgia Farm Rescuer Is Charged With Theft
description: A man who promised to save a farmer from having his land foreclosed was arrested Monday on theft and forgery charges after a businessman saw him on television and told the authorities the man had failed to return $2,000 in rented party equipment.

title: Bridge: British Parliament Defeats Congress in Annual Match
description: The United States Congress suffered a severe defeat yesterday, at the bridge table. Playing in London against the British Parliament, which fielded a strong team of peers and M.P.'s, the Americans lost by 2,690 points.

title: What the Democrats Should Do Next
description: The Democratic Party should appreciate that public policy is not like Modiglianis or Gregorian chants - artifacts of civilization that survive because of their splendor. Unrevised public policy is likely to grow not only gray but weak with age, unable to attack problems necessarily unforeseen when those policies were new and young.

title: Such Delicate Innards
description: Why is it now stylish to look down the nose at turkey? I believe the rise of this patronizing attitude coincides with the spread of the word ''gourmet.''

title: MONSANTO UNIT SOLD TO BHP PETROLEUM
description: The Monsanto Company and the Broken Hill Proprietary Company of Melbourne, Australia, announced today that they had signed a definitive agreement in which BHP Petroleum (Americas) Inc., a Broken Hill subsidiary, would acquire Monsanto's oil and gas interests for $745 million.

title: Noisy Crowd May Affect Jets
description: The question struck Darryl Rogers, the Detroit Lion coach, as amusing: ''How do you handle the noise problem?''

title: GLOBAL STOCK TRADING NEARER
description: Around-the-clock trading of major American and international stocks moved a step closer to reality this week with the announcement by the London Stock Exchange and the National Association of Securities Dealers of plans to swap price quotes on more than 550 British and American issues.

title: The Rape of the Rain Forests
description: The tropical rain forests that girdle the equator teem with exotic creatures - army ants, giant slugs, electric-blue butterflies, rattans 500 feet long, plants with the botanic alchemy to produce quinine, coffee, curare, vincristine. Yet these forests are being rapidly cleared, and the destruction usually leaves nothing of comparable value, only floods, drought and barren land.

title: 2 SHERIFF'S OFFICERS SHOT, 1 FATALLY
description: An off-duty Essex County Sheriff's officer was fatally shot and another was critically wounded last night during an apparent robbery attempt at a Newark tavern where they were patrons, the Newark police reported.

title: NIGHT LAUNCHING OF SHUTTLE BEGINS AMID SEARING LIGHT
description: Roaring into the night sky on a column of searing white light, the space shuttle Atlantis tonight began a seven-day mission in which astronauts will practice building a large space station.

title: ECLIPSE TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
description: b-After a loss of $1,434,716 from discontinued hard disk manufacturing operations.

title: Soviet Sets Growth Targets
description: Soviet officials today outlined modest economic growth targets for 1986 that they pledged would begin a period of sustained prosperity that would last through the end of the century.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: S & K FAMOUS BRANDS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Eight in Michigan Sect Accused in Boy's Death
description: Eight members of the religious sect, the House of Judah, have been indicted on Federal civil rights charges in the beating death of a 12-year-old boy at the group's camp, a prosecutor said today The eight members of the group, who call themselves ''black Hebrew Israelite Jews,'' were accused of trying to make slaves of children at the western Michigan camp through assaults, beatings and intimidation, resulting in the death in 1983 of John Yarbough, the son of a sect member, according to United States Attorney John Smietanka.

title: 'Star Wars' Usage Is Upheld
description: Although it is a trademark owned by the film maker George Lucas, the term ''Star Wars'' can be used by the public to describe President Reagan's spaced-based missile system, a Federal district judge ruled today.

title: YANKS INTERESTED IN DAWSON
description: The Yankees and the Montreal Expos are seriously discussing a trade that would put Andre Dawson in the Yankees' outfield with Dave Winfield and Rickey Henderson, people familiar with the talks said yesterday.

title: Bell Atlantic
description: The Bell Atlantic Corporation said it planned to spend up to $200 million to buy back stock on the open market between now and Dec. 31, 1986. The company, one of the seven operating companies spun off from the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, said it has 99.9 million shares outstanding. At yesterday's close of $98.875, Bell's buyback would total about 2 million shares.

title: SOME FAR-FLUNG PILGRIMS CELEBRATE THANKSGIVING ABROAD
description: THANKSGIVING may well be the quintessential American holiday - rooted in traditional celebrations of the land and its bounty and in the survival of a band of settlers over the country's hostile environment. Americans generally have a sense of how Thanksgiving should be observed: by family, at home, with certain foods. They also have a sense that Thanksgiving should be observed, regardless of where they are or what they must do to mark the occasion. In a story about an American innocent abroad, one expatriate explains it this way:

title: ARAB APPOINTED MAYOR OF NABLUS
description: A Government spokesman said today that it was appointing a Palestinian described as a moderate without ties to the Palestine Liberation Organization as Mayor of the occupied West Bank city of Nablus.

title: WORKER DRUG TESTS RESISTED
description: Two court cases here involving an employer's right to test workers for alcohol and drug abuse are being closely watched by labor and management officials from around the country. The cases, along with a San Francisco ordinance that awaits action by the mayor, are at the forefront of a growing legal fight that pits an employer's need to ferret out substance abuse against a worker's right to privacy.

title: Summit Excitement
description: They're pretty excited over at the Heritage Foundation about the reported impact of their briefing book on the Geneva summit conference. Richard V. Allen, a former White House national security adviser, is telling friends that in the first 10 minutes of the first United States-Soviet group meeting Nov. 19, Mikhail S. Gorbachev cited the 54-page volume to President Reagan as evidence of ''right-wing pressure'' on their talks.

title: WORLD HUNGER PRIZES GIVEN
description: The fourth annual World Hunger Media Awards were presented tonight to 17 individuals and one group for publicizing the world hunger crisis.

title: The U.N. Today; Nov. 27, 1985
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: PACT ON EXCHANGES: 200-HOUR WRANGLE
description: It looked so simple in Geneva last week. Secretary of State George P. Shultz and Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze picked up pens and signed a new cultural exchange agreement laid out on a desk in front of them by aides.

title: INDIAN ELEGANCE AT A PARTY AT BERGDORF'S
description: FOR the next two weeks, Bergdorf Goodman will be suffused with merchandise from India, from quilts so elegantly made they can double as wall hangings to men's cummerbunds and ties to, of course, saris. The saris are not the kind you drape yourself, a challenge even to Western women who have spent some time in India. Rather, sari fabrics, glimmering with gold threads, have been made into evening dresses by Victor Costa. At least one was worn to the black-tie dinner party Monday night called ''A Celebration of India'' that opened Bergdorf's first storewide promotion and the first devoted to a specific country.

title: TRANSACT INTERNATIONAL, DIVISION OF GRAM INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including an extraordinary tax credit of $90,000. c-Net loss, including gains of $144,477 for the quarter and $235,664 for the 6 months from discontinued operations. d-Including a gain of $160,431 from discontinued operations.

title: Letter: On Flood Control;   Southern States Are Paying Their Share
description: To the Editor:

title: THE OPERA: SUTHERLAND IN 'BOLENA'
description: DONAL HENAHAN

title: FARM HOUSE FOODS CORP reports earnings for 12wks to Oct 12
EASIER COOKIE-MAKING
description: THE baking bug is contagious during the holiday season.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Borg-Warner Corp. reached an agreement with Chilton Corp. under which Chicago-based Borg-Warner will begin a cash tender offer today of $33 a share, or a total of about $244 million, for Chilton, based in Dallas.

title: SPAIN'S POLICE, ONCE DREADED, RALLY TO DEMOCRACY
description: The nearly 40 men and women gathered in a meeting hall here were planning a protest campaign against militarism, the keeping of files on citizens and other vestiges of the dictatorship of Francisco Franco.

title: ISRAELI NEWSPAPERS NAME MAN WHO PURPORTEDLY RECRUITED AMERICAN SPY
description: Two leading Israeli newspapers today named Rafi Eitan, who was an adviser on terrorism to Prime Minister Menachem Begin, as the man who is purported to have recruited an American to spy for Israel.

title: PRESENT CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 2
DR. REUBEN SILVERSTEIN
description: Dr. Reuben B. Silverstein, a general practitioner for 50 years, most of them in South Ozone Park, Queens, died of a heart attack Monday while on a flight home from visiting his daughter in Pennsylvania. He was 80 years old and lived in Beechhurst, Queens.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Dynamics Corp. of America has appointed Neil K. Gerhardt executive vice president and chief operating officer of the Waring Products division, a manufacturer of small kitchen appliances in New Hartford, Conn.

title: CHELSEA INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 28
High-Stakes Game On the Sidelines
description: Once upon a time, sports were fun and games. But any doubt that sports are big business nowadays is being dispelled this week by the seventh annual International Sport Summit Conference.

title: BISHOPS' POWERS ARE TOP ISSUE AT SYNOD
description: As the two-week synod ended its second working day today, the bishops' desire to protect and in some cases expand their local authority had become a central topic of discussion.

title: Grateful and Busy
description: Don King, who was acquitted last week after a trial on Federal tax-evasion charges, celebrated what he called his ''vindication'' yesterday by proclaiming his faith in God, the United States Constitution and his skills as a boxing promoter. King, who announced a series of heavyweight championship matches beginning with a Jan. 17 bout in Atlanta between the World Boxing Association champion, Tony Tubbs, and Tim Witherspoon, repeatedly expressed his gratitude for the American system of justice.

title: Hallmark Will Get 3d Chief in 75 Years
description: Hallmark Cards Inc. said yesterday that Irvine O. Hockaday Jr., who joined the company two years ago from Kansas City Southern Industries as executive vice president, had been named president and chief executive.

title: DETAINEE IN MALTA IS NAMED AS CHIEF OF HIJACKING GANG
description: A Maltese Government spokesman said today that a 20-year-old man hospitalized for wounds after the storming of the Egyptair jet here Sunday night had been identified by several people as ''the chief of the hijackers.''

title: IN FRANCE, THE FEAST COMES EARLY
description: ''I ASSOCIATE Thanksgiving with my mother's country place near New York, with family and close friends, but this is the next best thing,'' Carol Cardon said as she and her husband, Patrick, prepared for their first Thanksgiving dinner abroad.

title: For a National Effort to Develop A Vaccine to Counteract AIDS
description: The time has come for the Government to underwrite a nationwide effort to produce an effective vaccine against HTLV III, the virus that causes AIDS. Though a frightening new disease, AIDS is no longer so novel that such an effort would be premature.

title: LEO L. KAPLAN
description: Leo L. Kaplan, a vice chairman of Lazare Kaplan International Inc., the Manhattan-based diamond cutters, died Sunday after a long illness at his winter home on Longboat Key, Fla. He was 72 years old and a resident of Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: McEnroe Faces Press
description: Heavy rains drenched Melbourne, washing out yesterday's matches in the Australian Open, so the action switched from the Kooyoong grass courts to the lobby of the Regency Hotel. There, John McEnroe salvaged a slow news day by exchanging words and then scuffling with a reporter and getting into a spitting match with a photographer, according to The Sun.

title: WILKINS OF HAWKS DOMINATES KNICKS
description: Dominique Wilkins is known as the Human Highlight Film, a nickname that refers to the sensational way the Atlanta Hawk forward puts on one of his one-man shows of jumping ability, dunking and rebounding.

title: Willets Pt. Protest
description: More than 20 years ago, Mario M. Cuomo, a lawyer, helped owners of junkyards and other businesses in Willets Point, Queens, withstand eviction by Robert Moses.

title: Rates Mixed on U.S. Issues
description: Interest rates on Treasury securities were mixed in quiet trading yesterday, with yields rising slightly for issues due in three years or less and little change for longer-term issues.

title: LOUISIANA GOVERNOR WON AT CRAPS, COURT IS TOLD
description: A gambling casino manager testified today that Gov. Edwin Edwards was a winner at Lake Tahoe, Nev., contradicting earlier testimony in the Governor's racketeering trial.

title: THESPIANS LEARN TO CUT UP, OFFSTAGE
description: ''DEB!'' Don Borsh called to Deborah Stenard. ''You cover the fillet!''

title: EMBATTLED FAUST RESIGNS AS COACH OF NOTRE DAME
description: Gerry Faust, who resigned earlier today after five troubled years, took the blame tonight for Notre Dame's lackluster football performance and said his decision will allow the university to move quickly to find a new coach.

title: COLOMBO WITNESS TELLS OF $3,000 BRIBE
description: An undercover agent for the Internal Revenue Service testified yesterday that he was paid $3,000 in 1978 to thwart a possible perjury indictment of a Nassau County lawyer who represented members of the Colombo crime organization.

title: FILM: 'SANTA CLAUS,' WITH MOORE AND LITHGOW
description: ONCE upon a time, according to the storyteller who opens ''Santa Claus: The Movie,'' there was a kindly woodcutter named Claus, who lived in a northern country with his admiring wife, Anya. They were lonely because they had no offspring. To fill the void, Claus and Anya lavished affection on the children of their village, spending all year making toys that they distributed by sleigh on Christmas Eve.

title: AT 28, A PROLOGUE OF PROMISE, BUT A LIFE IN RAGS
description: For seven months now, Gary Doe, whose life once seemed so filled with promise, has been wandering the city's streets in filthy clothes, foraging for food in garbage cans, sleeping in Central Park.

title: Homes Hit in Bomb Mishap
description: A Spanish Air Force F-4 Phantom fighter accidentally dropped an unarmed bomb on a Madrid suburb today, causing heavy damage to three houses but no injuries, police said.

title: 2 BUSINESS GROUPS SPLIT OVER HOUSE TAX PLAN
description: Two prominent business groups today took opposing sides on the tax revision package produced by the House Ways and Means Committee. Both sides promised a fierce lobbying battle in the next three weeks as the bill moves to a vote on the House floor.

title: THE EMPIRE STRIKES BACK
description: There is good news from the Olympic movement, and just in time for Thanksgiving, too. The hit-or-miss financial structure of the 1984 Summer Games, which allowed the Los Angeles organizers to make a $220 million profit, is being dragged into the real world.

title: SCM AND MERRIL WIN ROUND
description: A Federal judge in Manhattan yesterday refused to prevent Merrill Lynch Capital Markets from exercising an option to buy two key businesses from the SCM Corporation as part of a larger plan to buy the entire company.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We are no warmongers, we are the opposite. If we adopt war it will be for the sake of peace.''

title: HYTEK INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Thanks For What?
description: No thoughtful citizen of the United States can reflect on the sufferings of the world in the year 1985 without counting the blessings of America on Thanksgiving Day.

title: DEVILS WIN ON MACLEAN GOAL
description: The fear of a letdown after a long trip kept the Devils on their skates tonight and they triumphed, 4-3, over the Winnipeg Jets.

title: Travel Plan
description: A bumper sticker spotted after a recent football game at Giants Stadium: ''Go Rangers - and take the Knicks with you.''

title: Questioning Planned For Youth Goetz Shot
description: The Manhattan District Attorney's office will question Darryl Cabey, one of the four youths shot by Bernhard Goetz last Dec. 22 on an IRT subway train, about Mr. Cabey's recent assertion that his three companions had planned to frighten and rob Mr. Goetz.

title: U.S. IS STEPPING UP WATCH ON LIBYANS
description: The United States has increased its aerial and electronic surveillance of Libya in recent days to monitor any military moves in the aftermath of the hijacking ordeal in Malta, Administration officials said today.

title: 2 Sosnoff Stakes
description: Martin T. Sosnoff, a New York investor, said that he had purchased a 5.4 percent stake in the American Can Company, a Greenwich, Conn., container corportion, and a 6.29 percent stake in the First Executive Corporation, a Los Angeles-based life insurance holding company. In two filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the chairman of the New York investment firm Atalanta/ Sosnoff Capital Corporation said he spent approximately $91.7 million to purchase the shares, which he said were bought for investment purposes.

title: MARKET OVERCOMES TEXACO'S DROP
description: The stock market ended narrowly higher yesterday after weathering a continuing storm of bad news concerning Texaco Inc.

title: A. MORGAN MAREE JR.
description: A. Morgan Maree Jr., who handled financial investments for movie figures including Humphrey Bogart, Robert Taylor and David O. Selznick, has died.

title: A NEW BENEFIT IN WORKPLACE IS SPREADING: GOOD NUTRITION
description: Concerned with the health of employees and their own financial welfare, businesses and manufacturers nationwide are advocating good nutrition in the workplace. They include multinational corporations such as the Xerox Corporation and the Ciba-Geigy Corporation and small family-run establishments such as the Scherer Brothers Lumber Company in Minneapolis. The nutrition programs they have instituted cover employees at all levels, from the highest reaches of management to stockroom clerks and blue-collar laborers.

title: BRAZIL TO TRY TO REVAMP DEBT BEFORE I.M.F. PACT
description: Brazil's Finance Minister said Monday night that the country would try to renegotiate some of its foreign bank debt before signing an agreement with the International Monetary Fund.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: ONE of the most admirable things about supermarket shopping is the number of convenience foods that are available. These include fresh turkey breasts - meaty, white and tender and ready for roasting. They are a fine idea for small families who do not wish to contend with the leftovers of a large bird. A turkey breast will easily serve six or more, and whatever is left over will be perfect for cold turkey sandwiches. (The only criticism I can level against this product is that there is no dark meat.) On a recent occasion I roasted a four-pound turkey breast, not according to package directions, which would have required more than 60 minutes, but simply seasoned and cooked in a hot oven. Within 55 minutes, I had a tender, moist main course.

title: Report Was Flawed On Soviet Seaman
description: To the Editor:

title: East-West Conference On Culture Adjourned
description: An international culture meeting closed today without agreement because of East-West differences, but delegates said it was a success.

title: CELLULAR PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BANK OF MONTREAL (CALIFORNIA) reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The bank is listed on the Montreal, Toronto and Vancouver stock exchanges.

title: Holiday Hotel Sale
description: The Holiday Corporation, parent of Holiday Inns Inc., said it has sold 26 hotels to VMS Realty Inc. of Chicago for $390 million. Holiday Inns will have a long-term management contract for all 26 properties, Holiday said in a statement. Holiday will realize after-tax profits of $66 million, the company said. VMS Realty has a real estate portfolio valued at more than $4 billion, with more than $1 billion invested in hotels, Holiday said.

title: STAGE: 'CRUISE CONTROL,' COMEDY BY KEVIN WADE
description: WHILE it remains to be seen whether he can write a wholly satisfying play, Kevin Wade remains one of our more entertaining young playwrights. In ''Cruise Control,'' his new comedy at the WPA Theater's new home in Chelsea, the author of ''Key Exchange'' again demonstrates his gift for creating persuasive, highly sympathetic contemporary characters and casual but stinging comic dialogue. What's paradoxically lacking is an ability to blend the glistening anecdotes into a broader canvas. Let Mr. Wade's people stop chatting spontaneously about their sex lives and start attending to his exposition, plot or themes, and ''Cruise Control'' inevitably runs aground.

title: 'FORTRESS,' FILM ON HBO
description: SEARCHING rather unsuccessfully for properties to flesh out its ''Premiere Film'' roster, Home Box Office has now gone as far as Australia. It shouldn't have bothered. The pay-cable service found a two-hour film entitled ''Fortress,'' adapted by Everett De Roche from a novel by Gabrielle Lord. Its only asset is Rachel Ward, star of such movies as ''Sharkey's Machine,'' ''Dead Men Don't Wear Plaid'' and ''Against All Odds.'' And even Miss Ward, a former model and still beautifully angular, is not terribly convincing as a grade-school teacher clucking over her young wards in the Outback.

title: Grogan Has Surgery
description: Steve Grogan, the New England Patriots' quarterback, underwent surgery yesterday in Boton to repair a fracture in his left leg and will be in a cast for four weeks, the team said. After the cast is removed, a determination will be made as to how long he will be sidelined, said Jim Greenidge, a club spokesman.

title: The U.S. Constitution Was Never Color-Blind
description: To the Editor:

title: On Hitting Children
description: To the National Institute of Mental Health, ''violence against children'' means more than dramatic incidents that make newspaper headlines and television dramas. Its definition means everything from a slap to murder - and the good news is that it's decreasing.

title: U S VACATION RESORTS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Prejudice Triumphs in Philadelphia
description: Charles Williams, his wife, Marietta, and their 7-year-old son have lost their Philadelphia home not because they played the stereo too loud or littered their property or made a nuisance of themselves. They lost it only because they were black in a neighborhood of whites; and in America in 1985, sadly, outrageously, that can still outweigh everything else.

title: COLOMBIAN TOWN NOW NEEDS HOMES
description: Now that rescue operations from Colombia's devastating volcanic eruption and mudslides have ended, the major problem facing the authorities is to find permanent housing for the 8,000 survivors.

title: STUDY LINKS 3 INFANT DEATHS TO CONDITIONS IN CITY'S FACILITIES FOR HOMELESS
description: An advocacy group for the homeless charged in a study yesterday that three infants had died and others had suffered irreversible damage because of ''life threatening'' conditions in city-run facilities for the homeless.

title: 'GREAT' PRESENT FOR AIDS BOY
description: A state hearing officer ruled Monday that a teen-age AIDS victim could go back to the classroom, and the boy today called the decision ''a great birthday present.''

title: CONGRESS VIDEO GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $1,203,000 for the quarter and $1,217,000 for the 6 months. Both year-earlier periods' nets include income from real estate and restructuring transactions.

title: EGYPT SAYS LIBYA WAS BEHIND HIJACKING
description: Egyptian officials accused Libya today of responsibility for the hijacking of an Egyptian airliner on which 59 people were killed.

title: Advertising;   NBC All Booked Up For Super Bowl Spots
description: NBC, which will be telecasting the Super Bowl for the first time in three years, announced yesterday that its commercial time inventory of 25 minutes was already sold out. Robert C. Blakemore, sales head, said that all 50 of the 30-second units had sold for $550,000 each.

title: Hucksters Head For Victory
description: Who's your Hoosier team? Hickory? Hooray!

title: STAGE: 'INSIDE OUT' BY JAMES VAN LARE AT PLAYERS
description: THREE attractive performers make the most of ''Inside Out,'' a romantic comedy by James Van Lare that opened last night at the Players Theater. They compose an up-to-the-minute New York triangle - a wife and a young man fighting over her husband.

title: ANALYST TOLD 10 YEARS AGO OF WORKING FOR ISRAELI INTELLIGENCE, FRIEND SAYS
description: Jonathan Jay Pollard, a civilian counterintelligence analyst for the Navy who was accused last week of spying for the Israeli Government, has boasted for 10 years of colorful international exploits, including service to the Israelis.

title: Gunmen Wound Sikh Priest And Kill Guard at Holy Temple
description: Gunmen today wounded the head priest of the Golden Temple, the most sacred shrine of the Sikh religion, and killed his bodyguard, the police reported.

title: FILM: 'CHRYSANTHEMUMS'
description: THOUGH his films are ranked with those of Kenji Mizoguchi and Yasujiro Ozu in Japan, the Japanese director Mikio Naruse (1905-1969) remains largely unrecognized in this country. His ''Kimiko'' was received with little interest when it was released here in 1937. ''When a Woman Ascends the Stairs'' prompted more enthusiasm from New York critics in 1963, but he's still virtually an unknown quantity to American audiences. That may be about to change.

title: Fleet Bank Inquiry
description: The Fleet National Bank had ''significant institutional failures'' in its relationship with the state housing agency that led to the bank's rubber-stamping of ''irregular'' agency mortgages, a special investigator hired by the bank, Griffin B. Bell, said. Mr. Bell, a former United States Attorney General, also said bank employees had sought preferential loans from the Rhode Island Housing and Mortgage Finance Corporation for themselves and for other bank workers in violation of Fleet's policy against ''self-dealing.''

title: FROM TAKEOFF TO RAID: THE 24 HOURS OF FLIGHT 648
description: The Maltese Government said today that it had tried a variety of stratagems to persuade the hijackers to release the passengers and crew of Egyptair's Flight 648 before it agreed to allow Egyptian commandos to storm the plane.

title: AMERICAN NATIONAL PETROEUM CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Carolingian Manuscript Is Auctioned in London
description: A long-lost illuminated Carolingian manuscript of the ninth century, known as the ''Gospels of St. Hubert,'' sold yesterday at Sotheby's in London for $2,099,240 to an unidentified European buyer. The price paid for the vellum work was more than five times what the auction house had expected it would bring.

title: TRANSIT AGENCIES GET NEW U.S. RULE
description: The Federal Government said today that it would give ''priority consideration'' to applicants for grants for public transit ''who demonstrate their commitment to competitive bidding and private sector involvement.''

title: E.P.A. TO PERMIT TEST OF BURNING OF TOXIC WASTE OFF JERSEY COAST
description: The Environmental Protection Agency today announced a tentative decision to permit the test burning of toxic wastes at a site off the New Jersey coast.

title: SADE'S 2D ALBUM, A REFINED FUSION
description: ''PROMISE'' (Epic/Portrait), the second album by the Nigerian-born British pop star Sade, marks an impressive leap forward for the singer-lyricist whose debut album, ''Diamond Life,'' was a worldwide hit this year. Like its forerunner, ''Promise'' ignores the prevailing pop trend toward bright electronic surfaces in favor of a refined, acoustically based fusion of pop, jazz, funk and Latin influences. The arrangements feature horns, brass, guitar and occasional strings set against rich polyrhythmic underpinnings that suggest a funkified extension of Steely Dan's groundbreaking rock-jazz.

title: CONCERT: ORCHESTRE DU CAPITOLE DE TOULOUSE
description: THE French - with their long history of independent thinking, factionalism and mutual distrust - have rarely blessed us with great orchestras. Ensemble playing at the highest level requires a willing, not a grudging, obedience, and French musicians in the past have always seemed uneasy in the face of mass submission and trust. The Orchestre du Capitole de Toulouse paid a vist to Carnegie Hall on Sunday night and conveyed a rather contradictory report on the progress of orchestras in France today. Some of the playing was stunning. Other moments did not work very well at all.

title: Garrett Incidents Described
description: Two football players from Columbia University have described exchanges during which they were slapped or pushed by Jim Garrett, the head coach, for making a mistake in practice.

title: Kansas Highway Bonds Yield 8.40%
description: The State of Kansas is offering $151.5 million of highway refunding revenue bonds through underwriters led by Dillon, Read & Company.

title: FLEISCHMANN NAMED DIRECTOR OF PARIS OPERA
description: Ernest Fleischmann, since 1969 the executive director of the Los Angeles Philharmonic, has been named general administrator and artistic director of the Paris Opera. He begins his duties in Paris in mid-December, but will continue to oversee the Los Angeles orchestra until September 1986.

title: WINE TALK
description: IN autumn, the slopes rising above Keuka Lake in upstate New York are a medley of golden yellow and dark blue grapes and the red, rust and orange of foliage. It is a scene Willy Frank has observed through 23 vintages at Vinifera Wine Cellars. But this year, it marked the end, and the beginning, of an era.

title: URGING THE RULE OF LAW, NOT GUNS, IN NICARAGUA
description: Since the Sandinistas came to power in Nicaragua in 1979, the Miskito Indians have been fighting for rights they say are being ignored or violated. This month they enlisted the aid of Russell Means and two other American Indian leaders to recruit ''warriors from North America'' to join them.

title: QUIET ACTS, SILENT HALLS, AS A CITY GIVES THANKS
description: Official Washington slips quietly away on Thanksgiving. The powerful retreat, the Government printing presses fall silent, and only a handful of the most driven aides wander the halls of the Capitol.

title: MUSIC AND THE NEW TECHNOLOGY
description: THE phonograph record -basic black with a groove -is losing ground. In the current music market, it is being displaced by prerecorded cassettes, which now account for more than half of music sales; the compact disk is also whittling away at album sales, currently accounting for 7.5 percent of the market.

title: 'BOMBSHELL,' A SPECIAL FOR YOUNG
description: LOVE strikes 14-year-old Harry, sort of, in ''My First Swedish Bombshell,'' a ''Young People's Special'' on Channel 4 at 7:30 tonight. It's pretty slender stuff, but adolescents might find it amusing.

title: ANGLICAN ENVOY LEAVES U.S.
description: Terry Waite, the Church of England envoy, left yesterday for London, stating that his mission to seek the release of four American hostages in Lebanon had moved ''a step forward.''

title: Snag in Buyout Plan for Amsted
description: Amsted Industries, a Chicago-based maker of products for the construction market, said that a management group does not expect to pursue the leveraged buyout proposal it made Nov. 4 but is working on an alternative offer.

title: Towle Chief Resigns; Successor Is Named
description: Leonard Florence has resigned as chairman, president and chief executive of the financially troubled Towle Manufacturing Company, apparently under pressure from the company's outside directors.

title: ISRAEL TO HELP U.S. INVESTIGATE SPY CASE
description: American and Israeli officials said today they had agreed to cooperate on investigating the case of Jonathan Jay Pollard, a civilian Navy employee who was arrested on espionage charges last Thursday outside the Israeli Embassy here.

title: BIRD SCORES 47 AS CELTICS WIN
description: Larry Bird broke out of a shooting slump with a season-high 47 points tonight as the Boston Celtics scored their fifth consecutive victory, a 132-124 decision over the Detroit Pistons.

title: Heart Recipient, 26, Goes Home in Arizona
description: Michael Drummond, who was kept alive with an artificial heart nine days before getting a donor human heart, has been allowed to go home.

title: EXCERPTS FROM SPEECH BY GORBACHEV TO PARLIAMENT
description: Following are excerpts from Mikhail S. Gorbachev's speech today to the Supreme Soviet, as distributed in translation by the Soviet press agency Tass:

title: Army to Pay Olin
description: The Army said it would pay $110.6 million to the Olin Corporation's Winchester Group to operate and maintain the Lake City Army Ammunition plant in Independence, Mo. through October 1986. Also, the Air Force said it had increased by $90 million a contract with the Martin Marietta Corporation for low-altitude navigation and targeting equipment.

title: CALENDAR: CRAFTS AND WOODCARVINGS
description: Thanksgiving Contemporary American Crafts Weekend, American Arts and Crafts Alliance; 212-866-2239.

title: MUSIC: SALERNO-SONNENBERG, VIOLIN
description: TWO elements made the Y Chamber Symphony's Sunday afternoon concert at the 92d Street Y, at Lexington Avenue, one of the most memorable of the season: the haunted music of Dmitri Shostakovich and the equally profound - and perhaps equally haunted - playing of the young violinist Nadja Salerno-Sonnenberg.

title: STRAWBRIDGE & CLOTHIER reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 2
FALCON OIL & GAS CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
U.S. TO OFFER PAIR OF CHOICES FOR NEW FORMALDEHYDE RULE
description: Under orders from a Federal court, the Occupational Safety and Health Administration is expected to propose new rules next week on the use of formaldehyde, agency and industry officials said today. They said that one option being considerd would weaken the existing rules protecting 1.4 million workers now exposed to formaldhyde.

title: BLACK INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
KEEPING TOOLS TIDY
description: STORING tools properly not only makes a garage or tool shed much neater but it also preserves the tools. Green River Tools sells two tool-hanging systems. One is for tools with long, straight handles, such as brooms, axes, rakes and hoes, and consists of a piece of pine 48 inches long and 8 inches high that has five S-shaped hooks. It sells for $18.50. Hooks can be bought separately in sets of three for $5.50. The other system is for shovels and other tools that have what are referred to as D-handle or T-handle tops. This rack has a 28-by-6-inch piece of pine with three hangers; it costs $12.50. These hangers are also sold separately, a set of five for $4.50. Prices do not include shipping and handling. Green River Tools is at 5 Cotton Mill Hill, P.O. Box 1919, Brattleboro, Vt. 05301. 802-254-2388.

title: ANALYSTS DEBATE SPEED OF THE DOLLAR'S DESCENT
description: The dollar's descent, after briefly bringing the currency to five-year lows early this week, has abated, but many analysts say the dollar is set for a steady decline in coming months. The only argument seems to be over how fast it will go.

title: CITY LISTS HIGH SCHOOLS RATED DEFICIENT BY STATE
description: Schools Chancellor Nathan Quinones yesterday made public the names of 72 New York City public high schools whose academic performance was found to be in the bottom 10 percent statewide in a recent state-sponsored survey.

title: SOME SPECIAL REPAIR PROBLEMS
description: PROBABLY no other style of furniture varies so much in design as Biedermeier. Although many delicate pieces were crafted and some small pieces were intended for feminine use, it is the sturdy architectural look that is usually associated with this period.

title: 6-0 STREAK BY NETS AT HOME IS ENDED
description: The season is barely a month old, but there had already been talk that age and injuries had finally taken a toll on the Philadelphia 76ers. Once the dominant team in the National Basketball Association, the Sixers appeared to be fading from glory.

title: FLEETWOOD ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 27
INFANT-CARE LEAVES: PANEL URGES POLICY
description: Mandatory availability of leaves for childbirth and infant care, income replacement for wages that would have been earned, and continuation of employee benefits and job security constitute the cornerstone of a national policy on infant care leaves that was recommended by a blue ribbon panel today at Yale University.

title: LAND MINES WOUND 4, PRETORIA ASSERTS
description: Two land mines exploded today on South Africa's northern border with Zimbabwe, bringing to four the number of such explosions since Tuesday, and Pretoria warned that its security forces would pursue insurgents across the frontier if the attacks continued.

title: 'FORGIVE,' ASKS WOMAN IN RAPE DISAVOWAL
description: Across the continent from her home in Jaffrey, N.H., Cathleen Crowell Webb was here to persuade people that the Illinois man she once accused of raping her is really innocent.

title: China Freeing American Arrested in Fatal Fire
description: China announced today that it would release a United States businessman who had been serving an 18-month prison sentence for accidentally causing a hotel fire earlier this year in which five North Koreans, four Chinese and the businessman's Hong Kong business partner were killed.

title: A CABLE FROM U.S. REPORTEDLY WARNED OF HIJACKING THREAT
description: Several days before the Egyptair hijacking, the Transportation Department warned that terrorists trained in Iran might be planning to seize an airliner, according to a source familiar with a cable sent to United States airlines and international aviation authorities.

title: Those Mysterious Cracks
description: Dr. Edgar O. Seaquist, an investigative engineer, has been seen sleuthing around the black granite walls of the Vietnam Veterans Memorial lately with a magnifying glass, searching for clues about 14 cracks that have mysteriously appeared on the 10-foot panels of the memorial.

title: MANUEL STATUS GIANT PROBLEM
description: When the Giants began practice today for Sunday's game here against the Cleveland Browns, Lionel Manuel was in the trainer's room trying to get his left hamstring mended.

title: GENETIC SIGN FOUND FOR CYSTIC FIBROSIS
description: Scientists have discovered genetic markers that are closely linked to the faulty gene responsible for cystic fibrosis, the most common hereditary disease among Caucasians, and they have narrowed the location of that gene to a single region on one of the 23 pairs of human chromosomes.

title: BEKER INDUSTRIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a provision of $11,229,000 for the estimated loss on the disposition of discontinued operations.

title: CONSOLIDATED STORES reports earnings for 13wks to Nov 2
description: b-Includes gains from discontinued operations of $220,000 for the quarter and $733,000 for the 9 months. The share earnings were adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split paid Nov. 25.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: AS the do-it-yourself industry continues to expand, manufacturers keep introducing new and improved tools and accessories that can make life easier or save time and money. Here are some recent ones.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: THURSDAY, NOVEMBER 28, 1985
description: International

title: Let's Be Plain About Politics and Money
description: There are few matters in which Americans have taken more pride than their commitment to plain speech. All have heard it: We are a down-to-earth, plain-spoken people; we abhor evasion or cant. And with this have gone two other claims: We believe ourselves wisely alert to political motivation, evasion and chicane. And we are also deeply attached to the thought that more income is more enjoyable than less. I would like to urge that our supposedly forthright habits of speech be allowed to express what we all know to be true about politics and money.

title: MARMON GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said it did not report share earnings because its common shares are privately held.

title: Crash Kills Pilot and Co-Pilot Of Jersey Charter Air Service
description: A chartered plane crashed here today, killing the two people aboard, both New Jersey residents.

title: The Brooklyn College Dorm Has an Ancestor
description: To the Editor:

title: Lloyd Advances In Australia Open
description: Chris Evert Lloyd led three other seeded players into the second round of the $1.5 million Australian Open tennis championship at Kooyong today with a 6-1, 6-2 victory over Ros Fairbank of South Africa.

title: Greek Leftists Take Responsibility for Raid
description: The leftist November 17 terrorist group said today that it carried out the bombing Tuesday that wrecked a police van, killing a police officer and wounding 14 others. The group has taken responsibility for several political assassinations over the past decade, including that of the C.I.A. station chief in Athens in 1975.

title: MESTEK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-The company said that due to the significance of the changes resulting from a plan of reorganization implemented in October 1984 results for the year-ago periods are not meaningful and, therefore, not presented.

title: Babies Have Long Been Big Business in America
description: To the Editor:

title: ARGENTINE PACE SAID TO WORRY U.S.
description: Washington officials are concerned that Argentina's economic program could lose momentum, and they are encouraging the Government here to use World Bank loans to move quickly into the program's second stage, according to bankers and diplomats.

title: ENDOTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: MUSIC: MARTINA ARROYO
description: THE chief interest in the National Orchestra of New York's first concert of the season Tuesday night in Carnegie Hall was Martina Arroyo addressing herself to the ''Immolation'' Scene from Wagner's ''Gotterdammerung.''

title: UNIVERSITY GRAPHICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
EX-SECURITY AGENCY WORRKER IS SAID TO ADMIT SPYING ROLE
description: Ronald William Pelton, a former employee of the National Security Agency, admitted spying for the Soviet Union an hour after he was confronted with the case against him, a Federal investigator testified today.

title: ICAHN SAID TO ASK FOR NEW FUNDS
description: Carl C. Icahn, the investor, is seeking a sharp increase in the financing for his takeover of Trans World Airlines, sources close to the financing arrangements said yesterday.

title: THE STAGE: 'DOUBLE BASS'
description: IF you have always wanted to see a man make love to a double bass, you can now satisfy the craving in Brooklyn. The scene is a funny high point of ''Double Bass,'' the German writer Peter Suskind's play for one voice and one instrument, the opening production at the New Theater of Brooklyn's new theater at 465 Dean Street. Since the work, fluidly translated by Eric Overmyer and Harry Newman, proceeds generally along a level line without many highs, much of the credit for an entertaining evening must go to the soloist, Boyd Gaines.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It's often said that the English just can't understand any of the Irish, and I think we just have to accept that that's true.'' - Edward Heath, former Prime Minister of Britain. [A11:4.]

title: DIVERSION OF WATER OVER CONTINENTAL DIVIDE PROMPTING A FIGHT
description: The Continental Divide stands as a barrier to man and weather, yet water, gathered through a maze of pipes west of the divide and channeled into major tunnels, drains easily eastward to serve the thirsty cities of the Front Range.

title: 3 Quakes Hit Guatemala
description: Three moderate earthquakes shook Guatemala today. The authorities said they had no immediate reports of damage or casualties.

title: Steel Imports Decline 49%
description: Steel imports plunged nearly 49 percent in October, to 1.3 million tons, producing a slight decline in 10-month tonnage from the 1984 pace, according to Commerce Department figures issued today by importers and domestic producers.

title: Hospital Profits Climb In New Medicare Plan
description: Hospitals receiving Medicare payments recorded above-average profits in the first year of a new payment strategy that the industry had said might cause substantial losses, says an internal report by the Department of Health and Human Services.

title: KLECKO PLANS TRICKS FOR LIONS
description: Joe Klecko, who is playing so well at nose tackle this season that he could be voted to the Pro Bowl at his third different position, says he expects to be able to pull some surprises against the Detroit Lions on Thursday.

title: Buzzards of the Bar
description: A New York court acted curiously the other day. It made public 2,400 pages of testimony, much taken in witnesses' expectation of confidentiality, in the local bar association's attempt to disbar the attorney Roy Cohn.

title: Pseudo-Democracy in Honduras
description: Jose Azcona Hoyo appears to have been elected the next President of Honduras, polling about 25 percent of the vote in last Sunday's balloting. That doesn't sound so bad considering he had eight opponents. But one of them, Rafael Leonardo Callejas, polled more than 40 percent - and still lost. And that strange circumstance fairly defines the state of democracy in Honduras today.

title: ARMATRON INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.
