title: Bond Prices Resume Advance
description: After four days of flat to slightly lower prices, the rally in the Treasury securities market resumed yesterday, as dealers reported heavy demand at the early afternoon auction of $7.5 billion in new five-year notes.

title: WEBCOR ELECTRONICS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CORRECTION
description: The Discoveries column in The Living Section yesterday misstated the price of the Hanukkah menorahs designed by Robert Lipnick. They are $250 each.

title: TEMPLETON ENERGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
HEAVY PRESSURE PULLED MALTA BOTH WAYS
description: Malta's decision to allow Egyptian troops to storm a hijacked airliner was made under heavy diplomatic and political pressure, some of which militated against the operation, according to Maltese officials, diplomats and others familiar with the episode.

title: HERS
description: WHEN my sister Mary Ann was 19 she changed her name to Ruby. Just Ruby, not Ruby Rockwell, not Ruby anything. While she was Ruby she wore 30's dresses and a lot of makeup and she sang us songs the way Janis sang them. ''Get it while you can,'' she sang to us one summer's end on an old screened porch in the night, in the rain that came through to us a little from the roof we had neglected. We sat quiet, wrapped in blankets drinking beer and listening to Ruby, and in the light from the kerosene lamp, we saw how her pretty young face grew dark in the singing.

title: RECALL REPORTED OF 2 ISRAELI AIDES
description: Two Israeli diplomats involved in the collection of scientific information have been recalled to Israel from the United States because of their connections with an American Navy employee accused of selling secrets to Israel, Government sources said today. One man was based in Israel's Washington embassy, the other in the New York consulate, The two diplomats are already back in Israel, the sources said. One arrived late last night and the other earlier in the week. Both are being kept out of sight, the sources added.

title: Worker Drug Test Law Set
description: Mayor Dianne Feinstein will allow a city ordinance prohibiting random drug testing of workers by employers doing business in San Francisco to become law without her signature.

title: NEEDIEST CASES FUND POISED FOR THE 74TH ANNUAL APPEAL
description: Mrs. V. can still remember the day her oldest daughter died, leaving a 3-month-old baby and a 5-year-old child.

title: MOVE TROY? TO DALMATIA? WHO SAYS? A MEXICAN?
description: None of the evidence is in yet, but the people of this sleepy village about 15 miles inland from the Dalmatian coast have begun to act as though they are sitting on the cradle of Western civilization. A steady flow of tourists from many countries strengthens them in their belief.

title: YOUNG ARCHITECTS CRITIQUE NEW YORK
description: Like other conventioneering tourists, they swarmed through the streets with the frenzied urgency of those determined to cram a thousand experiences into a hundred hours.

title: EMIGRE SUCCESS STORY: 4 RUSSIANS ON BRAODWAY
description: This is about how three guys from Leningrad (and one from Kiev) made it to Broadway. Their story starts in the conservatories and symphony halls of the Soviet Union and ends in the orchestra pit of ''A Match Made in Heaven,'' the Yiddish musical at Town Hall.

title: Herbert Prashker, 63; Practiced Labor Law
description: Herbert Prashker, a lawyer who specialized in labor law, died of cancer yesterday at the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center. He was 63 years old and lived in Manhattan and Alford, Mass.

title: KNICKS BEAT PACERS BY 80-77
description: The Knicks won the battle of the least in the East tonight.

title: William F. Keough Jr. Dies
description: William F. Keough Jr., the former head of the American School in Pakistan who was one of 52 Americans held hostage for 444 days in the United States Embassy in Teheran, died at his home in Washington yesterday. He was 55 years old and suffered from amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, a degenerative disease of the nervous system known as Lou Gehrig's disease.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Belden & Blake Energy Co., North Canton, Ohio, said it had completed the purchase of some oil and gas interests of Willard A. Ryan and others, including seven Mississippi oil wells. Terms were not disclosed.

title: DURO-TEST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Severance Deal At Beatrice
description: The Beatrice Companies said today that it had agreed to severance-benefit packages for 60 key employees that could have an after-tax cost of as much as $75 million.

title: U.S. OPPOSES PLAN TO STORE AGRICULTURE GENES
description: The Administration has thrust itself into an international dispute over the availability of genes essential to the world's supply of food.

title: ASSERTING THE RIGHTS OF THE MALE
description: When Dan Logan was a Washington speechwriter, politicians were only too happy to listen to his suggestions. But now, as executive director of Free Man, a men's issues organization, Mr. Logan feels that his ideas are seldom taken seriously.

title: CIVIL LIBERTIES UNION TELLS COURT CITY LIED IN PLATO'S RETREAT CASE
description: The New York Civil Liberties Union charged yesterday that police officers and city inspectors lied in saying there was prostitution at Plato's Retreat, because city officials were under political pressure to close the Manhattan club.

title: Chart House Chain Sold by Pillsbury
description: The Pillsbury Company has sold The Chart House restaurant chain, which it acquired earlier this year through Pillsbury's purchase of Diversifoods, to Pacific Ocean Enterprises Inc. of Solana Beach, Calif.. Terms were not disclosed. The Chart House, with fiscal year 1984 sales of approximately $87 million, operates 54 restaurants in 16 states, Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands. Pacific Ocean Enterprises Inc. is a new company owned by affiliates of the First Boston Corporation and other investors.

title: Bergesen Trading Halts
description: The Oslo Stock Exchange suspended trading in Bergesen D.Y. today after the shipping group said its six subsidiaries might be merged into one company, whose shares would be listed.

title: BRITISH M.P.'S APPROVE ULSTER ACCORD, 473 TO 47
description: The House of Commons gave its overwhelming approval tonight to Britain's agreement with the Irish Republic that allows Dublin a consultative role and official presence in Northern Ireland.

title: Contract Extended
description: The University of Florida has added two years to the the contract of Coach Galen Hall, who has guided the Gators to a 16-1-1 record since taking over a football program rocked by a recruiting scandal. The extension takes Hall, who had a four-year contract, through the 1990 season. No other details were disclosed. . . . Rick Bay, the athletic director, told The Columbus Dispatch that Earle Bruce would be given a new one-year contract at Ohio State, where he has the best record in the Big 10 over the last seven years.

title: LEXICON CORP reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
description: b-Net income Figures for the latest year include consolidated financial results of Scope Inc., a majority owned subsidiary acquired in July.

title: PRISON PREPARES TOTS' AREA
description: A state women's prison is trying to improve relations between children and their imprisoned mothers with a new visiting area.

title: Drug Detection Voids a Cup Race Purse
description: The State Racing and Wagering Board yesterday disqualified the 4-year-old French colt Lashkari from his fourth-place finish in the Breeders' Cup Turf Nov. 2 at Aqueduct because the stimulant etorphine was detected in his urine after the race.

title: Famine Aid Channeled
description: About $38 million of the more than $80 million raised by Live Aid and the Band Aid song ''Do They Know It's Christmas?'' has been spent on relieving famine in seven African nations - Ethiopia, Mozambique, Chad, Burkina Faso, Niger, Mali and Sudan - organizers said. They said about 70 percent of the Live Aid money will go toward long-term planning, 20 percent for emergency supplies and 10 percent for logistics.

title: Tribute to Boz
description: Incidentally, for Dickens lovers who were waiting, like Mr. Micawber, to see if anything turned up, there is going to be a kind of Dickens festival at the Library of Congress starting next month and running through June.

title: GENOVESE DRUG STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 8
description: b-Including a gain of $2,445,000, or 61 cents a share, on the sale of 9 stores, less the closing of a store.

title: Cemetery Owners in Chicago Lock Union Employees Out
description: Owners of 26 cemeteries locked workers out Tuesday after employees at three other cemeteries struck.

title: REXNORD INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $1,621,000.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Football Jets vs. Detroit Lions, at Pontiac, Mich. Both teams are coming off overtime games on Sunday. The Jets won, 16-13, from New England on Pat Leahy's 32-yard field goal and the Lions lost, 19-16, at Tampa Bay on Donald Igwebuike's 24-yarder. The Lions have lost six straight games on the road but are so far invincible at home in five games. The Lions are the most active Thanksgiving Day team in league history (45 games, with a 22-21-2 mark), including a 37-20 victory over the Jets in 1972. The Jets (9-3) have the best record in the American Football Conference. The Lions (6-6) are six games behind the Bears, who have already clinched the N.F.C. Central Division title. (Television - Channel 4, 12:30 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 12:30 P.M.) Dallas Cowboys vs. St. Louis Cardinals, at Irving, Tex. The Cowboys rebounded from their humiliating 44-0 loss to the Chicago Bears and beat the Philadelphia Eagles last Sunday, keeping even with the Giants at 8-4 atop the N.F.C. East. The Cardinals, 1-5 on the road this season and sinking deeper into last place in the division, were routed, 34-3, at home by the Giants last Sunday. (Television -Channel 2, 4 P.M. Radio - WNBC, 660; 4 P.M.) Texas A&M vs. Texas, at College Station, Tex. The winner goes to Dallas to face Bo Jackson and Auburn in the Cotton Bowl on New Year's Day. (Television - ESPN, 8 P.M., live.) Tennis Australian Open, at Melbourne.

title: The Early Days of Radio Are Alive, Though Barely
description: ''A ll is not well in Radioland this morning.''

title: INERTIA DYNAMICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $430,353 for the quarter and $883,505 for the year. c-Net income. d-After losses from discontinued operations of $120,804 for the quarter and $367,068 for the year.

title: SHAKE DOWN ONE-LINERS
description: Cheer, cheer for old Notre Dame, Wake up the echoes, Holtz is the name. Send a witty gag on high, Shake down one-liners from the sky.

title: GALLUP POLL FINDS SHARP RISE IN SUPPORT FOR DEATH PENALTY
description: American support for the death penalty for a variety of serious crimes has increased sharply over the last seven years, according to the latest Gallup Poll.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: CHELSEA CENTER FOR TEEN-AGERS IS CELEBRATED
description: Kevin Caron remembers when he was a 17-year-old high-school dropout who ''never had any real attention from family or friends.'' For him, life was sleeping on rooftops, occasional street brawls and unending loneliness.

title: GORBACHEV CALLS REAGAN MEETINGS A 'POSITIVE' START
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev said in a speech today that his discussions with President Reagan had been a success and that preparations for the next summit meeting, in 1986, should start now.

title: HOLTZ HIRED AS NOTRE DAME COACH
description: Lou Holtz promised no miracles today as he took over the most pressure-packed job in college football, coach of Notre Dame.

title: KREIS SENTENCED
description: E. J. (Doc) Kreis, the former strength coach at Vanderbilt University, was sentenced today to one year of unsupervised probation for distributing muscle-building steroids to a coach in South Carolina.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, NOVEMBER 28, 1985
description: Markets

title: ISRAELI CHALLENGES SOVIET ON JEWS
description: Benjamin Netanyahu, the Israeli delegate, today disputed Mikhail S. Gorbachev's assertion that Jews in the Soviet Union had more political and cultural freedom than Jews elsewhere.

title: Theater Wins Use of Williams's Name
description: New York's highest court has ruled that a Manhattan theater may be named after the playwright Tennessee Williams, despite objections from the Williams estate.

title: POST OF SEATTLE ARCHBISHOP IS AFFIRMED BY VATICAN AFTER AN INQUIRY
description: The Roman Catholic Archbishop in Seattle has been affirmed in his post by the Vatican after an inquiry into his pastoral performance but has been told to use ''greater vigilance'' in opposing divorce, homosexuality and artificial contraception.

title: Bridge: Pause Before Playing a Card Appealed as Clue to Partner
description: The recent world team championships in Sao Paulo, Brazil, provided very little work for the appeals committee handling objections to rulings by tournament directors.

title: CHINESE NEEDLEWORK FOR U.S. TABLES
description: THEY say it was the women of ancient China who created the anonymous art form of embroidery called paintings in thread. The Chinese still excell at hand embroidery, but as the role of women changes, the art is gradually becoming industrialized.

title: MUSIC: 2 SOLO SAXOPHONE RECITALS
description: LIGHTNING never strikes twice in the same place, but two saxophonists decided to give New York debut recitals Tuesday evening. Joseph Wytko played a program of 20th-century music at Carnegie Recital Hall, and Peter Saiano offered transcriptions of ''standard repertory'' works for other instruments at Merkin Concert Hall. It seemed logical to sample half-a-concert of each.

title: Books: Israel's History
description: ISRAEL: The Partitioned State. By Amos Perlmutter. 398 pages. Illustrated.

title: STUDY WARNS OF INCREASE IN NUCLEAR ARMS SPREAD
description: Despite international efforts to stop the spread of nuclear weapons, the problem is worsening, according to a new report.

title: Supplier Recalls Turkeys Sold By Foodtown Supermarkets
description: A food company today ordered a recall of about 200 fresh turkeys sold by Foodtown supermarkets after receiving consumer complaints of a bad odor from the birds, company officials said.

title: Robot Retrieves Material At 3 Mile Island Unit
description: A robot has obtained the first samples of concrete from the highly contaminated basement of the crippled Unit No. 2 nuclear reactor at Three Mile Island, the operator of the atomic power plant said today.

title: SCURRY-RAINBOW OIL LIMITED reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
THE STORY OF A WOUNDED PASSENGER: 'I FROZE, PRETENDING TO PLAY DEAD'
description: Tamar Artzi, 20 years old, from Kibbutz Revivim in the Negev Desert in Israel, had never been on a plane before when she boarded Egyptair Flight 648 on Saturday night.

title: INNOVEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The share earnings reflect 2-for-1 stock split paid in August.

title: MID-STATE FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN (OCALA, FLA) (O) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
F.B.I. MAN SAYS NAVAL ANALYST TOLD OF SPYING
description: A Navy counterintelligence analyst has admitted that he provided Israel with hundreds of pages of classified military documents, including one stack more than 15 inches high of mostly top-secret papers, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today.

title: FOR BEARS' WILSON, LAUGHTER'S A TONIC
description: The moment had arrived when Otis Wilson seemed to have finally lost his mind. In fact, his football helmet was all Wilson had misplaced, but at that moment, his helmet was more important than his mind.

title: No Danger Cited in Fire
description: A chemical dye smoldered for half an hour at the Ciba-Geigy Corporation plant here Tuesday, but the fire posed no hazard to the environment or to nearby residents, company and state officials said today. The fire started at about 6 P.M. in a room where about 3,000 pounds of the chemical, Terasil Orange, a dye for textiles, were drying, the company said. A worker in the area was not injured, Ciba-Geigy said.

title: Money Fund Assets Off
description: Retreating after last week's sharp gain, assets of the nation's money market mutual funds fell $698.1 million, to $209.05 billion, in the four-day week ended Tuesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Leading the decline, the 73 institutional funds fell $707.1 million, to $53.79 billion, while the 87 broker-dealer funds fell $64.7 million, to $94.12 billion. Marking the week's only upturn, assets of the 192 general purpose funds rose $73.7 million, to $61.15 billion.

title: I.R.S. Agent Testifies He Was Offered Bribe
description: A Federal undercover agent testified yesterday that he was offered a bribe in 1979 to arrange for a reduced prison term for a relative of Andrew Russo, a reputed captain in the Colombo crime organization.

title: Weight the Leaded Tax
description: To the Editor:

title: Change at Wimbledon
description: There'll always be an England, perhaps, but it won't necessarily always be the same. That became evident enough yesterday when R. E. H. (Buzzer) Hadingham, the chairman of the Wimbledon Tournament Committee, announced that for the first time in the tournament's 108-year-old history yellow balls will be used for the 1986 event.

title: DOW SOARS 18.92, TO 1,475.69
description: With technology and drug issues providing extraordinarily strong leadership, the stock market rose sharply yesterday to new record ground, as Wall Street kept alive a tradition of climbing the day before Thanksgiving.

title: Spies and Non-Spies
description: It would be unbelievable in fiction:

title: Dear Nasa
description: This mysterious letter turned up on our video display terminal yesterday. It appears that the cockroach who used to leave messages in a newspaper office by dive-bombing the keys of Don Marquis's typewriter is still around, or that he taught his descendants how to use a computer keyboard and that they, like him, can't shift and type at the same time. dear nasa i hear you are still looking for a journalist to fly into space on your shuttle and report on the wonders of the firmament so now you realize senator jake garn s bowel sounds were not the final word on the emptiness of space but ever since you flew mr garn the senator who decides how much money to give you each year your choice of passengers has seemed a little tainted taint is what we roaches feed on and after crouching all day in a crevice behind the stove at night we yearn like nobody else for the coolness of space yes i would make a good passenger on your shuttle nasa i have no human frailties and muck is what i live in i sure wouldn t rake it you don t want the muckraking kind do you nasa not aboard your shuttle you want someone who believes in sending men to mars even though there s nothing that robots couldn t do there cheaper well i believe in that my kind can t colonize mars without humankind there too you want someone who will laud space as the new universal frontier of humankind and also the perfect basis for strategic defense against those other humans i can subscribe to those two things i often harbor incompatible thoughts in different nerve ganglia it doesn t upset me unless i try to walk as well you want a writer who understands congress won t vote big budgets for nasa unless there are humans cavorting in space so we need the shuttle to take them there and the space station to house them and missions to mars to keep them busy rockets and robots may be the most efficient way to explore space but they lack panache and sang froid sang froid nasa is something we roaches have in our veins they say you expect 5000 applications from reporters for the seat on your shuttle pick me nasa i won t take up much room and i ll report the story of why we need humans in space just the way you want it

title: THERMODYNETICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

title: JUDGE RULES WHITE HOUSE ERRED IN REVIEW SYSTEM FOR REGULATIONS
description: A Federal district judge has ruled that the Reagan Administration violated the Freedom of Information Act by refusing to disclose the status of regulations that had been proposed by the Food and Drug Administration but held up by White House budget officials.

title: NUCLEAR SUPPORT SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DOUBLEDAY PUBLISHING NAMES NEW PRESIDENT
description: Doubleday has named Richard Malina president of its publishing division, succeeding Henry Reath, who resigned on Monday. Frank Cermak, executive vice president of the publishing division, also resigned.

title: California's High Court, 6-1, Overturns a Death Sentence
description: The death sentence of a man charged with robbing and murdering a camper has been overturned by the State Supreme Court because one of the jurors gave the others erroneous information on the law.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Bowery Savings Bank has named Edward Grebow executive vice president.

title: GOOSE-FEATHER CHRISTMAS TREES RETURN
description: THE shape may be sketchy and the branches on the skimpy side, but the simplicity and charm of the goose-feather Christmas tree is making it a popular holiday tabletop decoration.

description: b-Net income

title: POOR GATE BOTHERS N.I.T.
description: Skimpy early-round crowds drew most of the attention yesterday at the Big Apple National Invitational Tournament news conference for tomorrow night's semifinals at Madison Square Garden. In the 7 P.M. game, St. John's plays Duke.

title: Sweden to Close Embassy
description: Sweden is to close its embassy in Beirut because recent clashes between Shiite and Druse militiamen have made it impossible for the embassy's six staff members to work normally, the Foreign Ministry said today. ''The embassy will be closed until the situation becomes more stable,' a Foreign Ministry spokesman said.

title: KOCH LIFTS CURBS ON USE OF WATER AS RESERVOIRS RISE
description: New York City yesterday lifted all mandatory water restrictions and declared the drought emergency of 1985 a problem solved.

title: ICO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: PAULEY PETROLEUM reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-The company broke even.

title: We Know What Today Is
description: The evergreens on New York's Avenue of the Americas were strung with colored lights a week or two ago - and pretty ridiculous they looked, too, what with warm breezes, soft rains and a sun that's been as flirtatious in November as it was in May. Department stores had already tacked up the fake greenery. Television ads started featuring full stockings and a flaming hearth, and the saga of Rudolph sounded through many an elevator.

title: Sid Farber, Builder of Homes And L.I. Industrial Buildings
description: Sid Farber, a residential and industrial builder, died of pnuemonia Tuesday at Mather Memorial Hospital in Port Jefferson. L.I. He was 72 years old and had homes in Belle Terre, L.I.; Manhattan; St. Croix, V.I., and Monte Carlo.

title: ALASKA AIRLINE AGREES TO PAY $300,000 FINE
description: The Federal Aviation Administration announced yesterday that Alaska Airlines had agreed to pay a $300,000 fine for alleged violations of F.A.A. safety rules.

title: Fonar Chairman Finds 'Justice for Little Guy'
description: Dr. Robert V. Damadian, founder and chairman of the Fonar Corporation, was understandably jubilant after a Federal District Court jury in Boston ruled last week that a subsidiary of Johnson & Johnson had infringed upon a valid patent developed by Dr. Damadian and held by Fonar.

title: Inquiry Over, Hughes Says
description: The Hughes Aircraft Company said today that a Federal grand jury had dropped its investigation into charges that the company had paid a $1 million bribe to a Saudi Arabian businessman in order to win a $1.8 billion contract with the Royal Saudi Air Force in 1981.

title: ONEIDA LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 26
description: b-Including a tax credit of $750,000 for the quarter and the 9 months and after a nonrecurring net charge of $1,582,000 for the 9 months. c-Including a tax credit of $700,000 for the quarter and the 9 months.

title: MOYNIHAN RISES TO DEFEND ALFRED E. SMITH
description: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan has called on historians and Irish-Americans to examine recent charges that Alfred E. Smith received large sums of money from a political patron while he was Governor of New York in the 1920's.

title: A.M.C. to End Jeep CJ Models
description: The American Motors Corporation announced today that it would stop building its Jeep CJ models this January, ending about 45 years of production of the direct descendant of the famed World War II workhorse. A company spokesman, Lloyd Northard, said he expects there will be some layoffs of the 700 hourly and 40 salaried workers involved in production of the Jeep CJ-5 and CJ-7 models at its Jeep plant in Toledo, Ohio.

title: BOARD OF ETHICS, IN A REVERSAL, CRITICIZES LAMBERTI
description: The New York City Board of Ethics, in a reversal, said yesterday that Ralph J. Lamberti, the Borough President of Staten Island, had engaged in a conflict of interest in going into partnership with a local developer.

title: HOW TAXPAYERS WOULD FARE
description: Middle-income taxpayers in a variety of family and financial circumstances would have tax savings ranging from 2 percent to 28 percent under the House Ways and Means tax revision plan, according to an analysis by a professional tax accountant.

title: TEST FOR COWBOYS TODAY
description: If the Dallas Cowboys hadn't played so flat the last time they met the St. Louis Cardinals, they wouldn't find themselves in the precarious situation they're in now: with four games left, they and the Giants are tied for the lead in the N.F.C. Eastern Division and one of their remaining games is with the Giants. But first, the Cowboys have to dispense with the Cardinals, Thursday in Dallas (4 P.M., Channel 2).

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: A TRANQUIL MUSEUM Many of those who observe the holiday in the traditional, gastronomic manner, will be seeking events today that are in the class of none-too-strenuous things to do before sitting down at the table or after leaving it.

title: Bechtel Task in Austria
description: Bechtel Overseas Inc., an American engineering company, won a $545,000 contract today to find a buyer for Austria's only nuclear power plant. The Zwetendorf plant, built seven years ago but never used, is owned by Austrian electric utilities.

title: Ghanaian in Spy Swap Case Reported to Be Headed Home
description: A Ghanaian national ordered out of the United States for spying on the Central Intelligence Agency was reported to be on his way to his home today as part of a swap for eight countrymen accused of working for the American intelligence agency.

title: SINGAPORE ACTION TROUBLING PRESS
description: A recent apology to a Singapore court by the editor of The Asian Wall Street Journal for an editorial has raised some troubling journalistic questions, according to journalism and human rights organizations.

title: Fisher Brothers Offers Eurobonds
description: The Fisher Brothers Financial Realty Company is issuing $160 million of 10 3/4 percent Eurobonds due 2000, secured by property in New York City, at a price of 99 3/8, through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers International.

title: POLICE PRESSING HUNT FOR KILLERS OF A SHERIFF'S OFFICER IN NEWARK
description: Essex County authorities questioned scores of people today in an effort to track down two men who shot and killed an Essex County sheriff's officer and seriously wounded another during an aborted holdup of a tavern here late Tuesday.

title: RAVEN INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
It's Unanimous
description: Vince Coleman, the St. Louis outfielder who stole 110 bases in helping the Cardinals win the National League pennant, was chosen by a panel of sportswriters yesterday as the National League Rookie of the Year, surprising virtually no one. He was the unanimous choice of the 24 members of the Baseball Writers Association of America who vote for the award, making it the first time since 1972, when Carlton Fisk of the Boston Red Sox was chosen as the top American League rookie, that a selection has been unanimous.

title: PHILHARMONIC: BERNSTEIN CONDUCTS MAHLER'S 7TH
description: IT is always a good idea to try to be on hand whenever Leonard Bernstein appears for one of his periodic reunions with the New York Philharmonic, whose music director he was during one of the orchestra's most exciting decades. And when the music he chooses to conduct is that of Mahler, a composer with whom Mr. Bernstein feels a particular identification, the attraction becomes irresistible.

title: THE BIEDERMEIER STYLE FINDS NEW ADMIRERS
description: BIEDERMEIER furniture - crafted of blond fruitwoods and boasting classical columns, pediments and moldings - is fast becoming one of today's most popular antique furniture styles.

Auel's new novel, ''The Mammoth Hunters,'' the third installment in the author's phenomenally successful ''Earth's Children'' series starring Ayla, the super cave woman of the ice age.

title: The Editorial Notebook;   Corporate Justice, Texas-Style
description: The merger wars are going nuclear. Last week a jury in Houston decided that Texaco had captured Getty Oil after Getty was legally sold to Pennzoil. It decided Pennzoil deserved history's largest civil damage award, $11.7 billion.

The Mayor's Pumpkin Is Missing
description: M ayor Koch will have to wait another year to get his giant Thanksgiving pumpkin from the homeless men who live at the Camp La Guardia shelter in Orange County.

description: The Navy, in a bid to buttress its decision requiring contractors to bear a greater share of plant investment expenses, released a study today that concludes military contractors are earning higher profits on their military work than on their commercial projects.

description: The Raytheon Company, the technology concern that makes everything from Sidewinder missiles to Amana microwave ovens, yesterday named R. Gene Shelley to be president, effective June 1.

description: The Philadelphia Board of Realtors today imposed a 90-day moratorium on business in a predominantly white neighborhood struck by recent racial demonstrations.

The Atalanta/Sosnoff Capital Corporation, headed by Martin T. Sosnoff, bought 5.4 percent of American Can and 4.73 percent of First Executive. Mr. Sosnoff personally bought 1.56 percent of First Executive's stock.

title: EAST BLOC AND SUMMIT TALKS: RESPONSES VARY
description: The Soviet Union's Warsaw Pact allies have reacted to the Soviet-American summit meeting with subtly differing positions, according to authorities on Eastern Europe.

title: MANY IN POLL SEE BLESSINGS CLOSE AT HAND
description: In a year of violence and disaster on the world stage, Americans will give thanks today for blessings close to home. ''I'm thankful for my husband,'' Margaret Mills of Wilmington, Del., said as she prepared for the holiday.

title: NBC Delays Cable Decision
description: A spokesman for the National Broadcasting Company said the network would not decide until Jan. 31 whether to proceed with a proposed all-news cable television network.

title: Countrywide Sets Home Loan Issue
description: Countrywide Mortgage Obligations Inc., a subsidiary of Countrywide Credit Industries, a mortgage banking firm, is offering $126.7 million of collateralized mortgage obligations through underwriters led by Paine Webber Inc.

title: INVENTION DESIGN ENGINEERNG ASOCIATES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Gift to Kennedy Center
description: General Motors has pledged $1 million to the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts to help begin its $42 million national fund-raising campaign. Roger B. Smith, the chairman of G.M., said, ''We hope that our gift encourages other corporations to generously support the center's campaign.''

title: Salomon Mortgage Issue Has a Yield of 10.724%
description: Salomon Brothers Inc. is offering two kinds of mortgage pass-through securities totaling $325 million.

title: Foreign All-Stars
description: Want an all-star team of talented college basketball players imported from abroad? Try this one:

title: RUTGERS GETTING THE GOOD WORD
description: Rutgers had just won its opening game of the season, by 78-70 over Fairleigh Dickinson Monday night. Darren Campbell, still in his red and white uniform, sat on a bench in a spare locker room in the Rutgers Athletic Center, talking about the man who has been his basketball coach for just two and a half months.

title: UEBERROTH OT SEE PLAYERS IN DRUG CASES
description: The baseball commissioner's office sent letters yesterday to 24 players who have been involved or implicated in drug use, summoning them to meetings with Commissioner Peter Ueberroth in January.

title: Don't Spare the Gravy
description: Every penny the Defense Department spends is carefully watched these days for evidence of waste.

title: U.S. ARMS STANCE IS FIRM, AIDES SAYS
description: The United States does not intend to modify its current negotiating proposal significantly before the Geneva arms talks convene again in January, the director of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency said today.

title: Woman in Car Killed by Rock
description: A woman traveling with her family to a Thanksgiving reunion in Pennsylvania was killed Tuesday by a 25-pound chunk of rock apparently thrown from a highway overpass, a spokesman for the Huron Township Police Department said.

title: CRASH LEADS TO SEIZURE OF 13 ON DRUG CHARGES
description: Federal, state and local investigators announced the arrest today of 13 people on narcotics charges after an inquiry that began in January with a highway accident in the northern Westchester County suburb of Somers.

title: Thanksgiving, Then and Now
description: On Thanksgiving, we welcome the early Puritans into the mainstream of American history. During the rest of the year, they fare less well, and many people blame them for much of what is allegedly wrong with contemporary society. But on Thanksgiving, the Puritans seem less objectionable. After all, our own holiday, even the turkey dinner, is said to have originated with that bountiful Plymouth harvest of 1621.

title: RECITAL: SZERYNG, VIOLINIST
description: THE violinist Henryk Szeryng brought Bach, Brahms, Debussy, Ravel, a short novelty piece, and much of his familiar polish of intonation and execution to Carnegie Hall Monday evening for his only recital here of the season.

title: Moroccan King in Paris; Mideast Is Likely Topic
description: King Hassan II of Morocco arrived today for a three-day official visit that is expected to focus partly on the King's role in the Middle East peace process.

title: USACAFES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company reported only 11 months in fiscal 1984 because it went public in October 1983. The pro forma figures for 1984 included revenue of $17,255,000, net income of $2,206,000 and share earnings of 40 cents.

title: SELECTED READINGS FOR TODAY'S FEATS
description: FIFTEEN or so years ago, with the arrival of a Xerox machine in my parents' home in mid-November, our family traditions grew longer.

title: DYCOM INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
CUOMO CHOOSES UPSTATE JUSTICE FOR HIGH COURT
description: Governor Cuomo nominated an upstate Republican to the state's highest court today, his sixth designation to the seven-member court.

title: CONCERT: ADAM ANT
description: TEEN-AGE girls screamed every time Adam Ant came to the front of the Radio City Music Hall stage Tuesday night, and every time he made a leaping, two-legged kick. When he finally removed his shirt, the screams redoubled.

title: Another Record
description: When the Chicago Bears play at Miami next Monday night, Walter Payton, who has rushed for at least 100 yards in each of his last seven games, will have a chance to set a National Football League record. These are the longest such streaks in N.F.L. history: O.J. Simpson, Buffalo (1972-73)7 Earl Campbell, Houston (1979)7 Walter Payton, Chicago (1985)7 Jim Brown, Cleveland (1958)6 Franco Harris, Pittsburgh (1972)6 Earl Campbell, Houston (1980)6 Walter Payton, Chicago (1984)6 Eric Dickerson, L.A. Rams (1984)6 Rob Goode, Washington (1951)5 Jim Brown, Cleveland (1961)5 Jim Nance, Boston (1966)5 O.J. Simpson, Buffalo (1975)5 Walter Payton, Chicago (1977)5

title: ACCORD NEAR ON TRADE ROUND
description: A 90-nation conference appears close to final agreement on another major step toward opening a new round of trade-liberalizing negotiations next year.

title: HIS PITCH LURES 'INSTANT INSIDERS'
description: GERALD GUTERMAN barely pauses for breath before beginning his spiel. ''You can invest and make a cash profit, or you can give your money to Uncle,'' he says. ''You don't have a choice - you do have to write a check.''

title: KELLY OUTLINES HIS IDEAS FOR BEATRICE
description: Donald P. Kelly, chief executive-designate of the Beatrice Companies, said today that when he takes over Beatrice he would likely scrap the company's prominent advertising campaign that promotes the Beatrice name.

title: MONEY FUNDS LOWER
description: Rates paid on certificates of deposit and bank money market accounts showed little or no change for the week ended yesterday. During the same period, money market mutual funds moved lower, negating the increase of a week ago.

title: The Klinghoffers Sue P.L.O. for $1.5 Billion
description: The family of Leon Klinghoffer, the 69-year-old Manhattan man who was slain during last month's hijacking of the Italian cruise ship Achille Lauro, yesterday sued the Palestine Liberation Organization for $1.5 billion for ''wanton and coldblooded murder.''

title: FIRE, NOT BULLETS, REPORTED TO KILL MOST VICTIMS ON HIJACKED PLANE
description: Most of the passengers who perished in the commando storming of a hijacked Egyptian airliner Sunday died from smoke inhalation, not bullet wounds, according to a high-ranking hospital official here.

title: Grumman Seeking Fairchild Republic
description: The Grumman Corporation said yesterday that it had initiated negotiations with Fairchild Industries to acquire Fairchild's financially troubled Republic unit, which employs 3,500 at its plant in Farmingdale, L.I.

title: STANDARD BRANDS PAINT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 27
Coach's Request: Deterrent or Not?
description: Coach Jim Boeheim's asking the referees to call a two-shot technical foul against his own Syracuse basketball team last Saturday night was highly unusual, all right. On the other hand, there is as yet insufficient evidence as to whether it will also prove highly and lastingly effective in correcting the manners of some of the Orange's student followers.

title: OFFICER HELD IN SEXUAL ATTACKS ON PROSTITUTES
description: A New York City police officer was indicted yesterday on charges that he sexually attacked eight prostitutes in Brooklyn and threatened them with a gun or a knife.

title: Atlantic City Line Given Green Light
description: Representative James J. Florio said today that the Federal Office of Management and Budget would permit the spending of $30 million for a railroad line between this resort and Philadelphia.

title: INACOMP COMPUTER CENTERS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 2
Winning Edge
description: Nancy Reagan, in a speech to Pros for Kids, a group of athletes fighting drug addiction among youngsters: ''You're winning one for Mrs. Gipper.''

title: Education Vouchers Would Help Public Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: Union Carbide Says It Plans To Resume Making Aldicarb
description: The Union Carbide Corporation is planning to resume production of aldicarb, a pesticide ingredient, as early as next month to meet demand for the next growing season, according to company officials.

title: MAXWELL LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
3 PRIESTS GIVE $1.3 MILLION FOR HOTEL FOR THE HOMELESS
description: Three Fransciscan priests who have won wide praise for two residences they have set up for the homeless were awarded $1.32 million by the city yesterday to help buy a rundown building and rehabilitate it into a third home.

title: TRADE GAP NARROWED IN OCTOBER
description: The American trade deficit narrowed to $11.45 billion in October, a sharp improvement from September's record figure and a sign, according to some analysts, that the nation's darkest trading days may be ending.

title: Education Vouchers Would Help Public Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: THEATER: 'THE PHILADELPHIA STORY'
description: Yes, comparisons are invidious, but in the case of ''The Philadelphia Story,'' they are inescapable. Anne Twomey is not Katharine Hepburn, but as the boat fanciers in the play would put it, she is ''yare,'' and manages, after some drift early on, to bring the new production at the Hartman Theater into port with colors flying.

title: CHEMFIX TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
MARKETING SYSTEMS OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BROWNING-FERRIS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago results reflect pretax charges to general administrative expenses of $2.9 million for the quarter and $8.1 million for the year related to the settlemenet of litigation.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: HELPING ROSES TO WEATHER THE WINTER
description: IT'S time to start thinking about next year's roses. If the bushes are going to survive winter, they will need a little help. Rosebushes that have been grown well will have the best chance. Healthy vigor is always a plus. Plants that grow in sunny locations where the soil drains well will be strong. If they have been fed in early spring, as the rosebuds are breaking, and once again after June bloom, they should be sturdy now.

title: HOLIDAY TRAFFIC IN CITY SETTING RECORDS
description: There was one good thing to be said about the traffic leaving New York City yesterday for the Thanksgiving weekend: It was better than the traffic is expected to be for those coming back on Sunday.

title: NOT JUST A COFFEE TABLE: NEW CHOICES
description: THIS season's new architecture and design books tackle subjects as large as an entire country and as small as a single decorative object. The formats are as varied as the topics: some are large-format classics for the coffee table, visual journeys through pages of luscious photographs. Others are more scholarly or more practical endeavors: design history books meant to be read and absorbed, design dictionaries and how-to books.

title: HALLEY'S COMET
description: Halley's Comet will rise over the New York City area at 2:03 P.M. today and set at 4:06 A.M. tomorrow.

title: Jobless Rate Up 0.2% in New York
description: New York State's unemployment rate edged up by 0.2 of a percentage point in October from 6.6 percent the month before, the State Labor Department reported today, saying it was the lowest rate for October since 1974.

title: SHUTTLE ORBITING WITHOUT A HITCH
description: The flight of the space shuttle Atlantis, which began with a spectacular night launching Tuesday, continued without a hitch today, and NASA officials said it was one of the smoothest space missions they had ever seen.

title: 2d Study Finds Aspirin Helps in Heart Disease
description: Hundreds of thousands of Americans who have a dangerous heart condition, unstable angina, might live longer if they took daily doses of aspirin, a new study suggests.

title: POP: SONGS BY SYLVIA SYMS
description: AFTER an absence of two years, Sylvia Syms has returned to New York at Park Ten, the restaurant at 10 Park Avenue, a more complete and fulfilled singer than she has ever been in her long and successful career.

title: Nissan Raising Prices
description: The Nissan Motor Corporation said today that it was increasing all of its car and truck prices an average of 4 percent, or about $400 a car, because of the increase in the value of the Japanese currency. Nissan's parent company in Japan has been the most vocal of the auto makers there about the need to adjust prices because of the change in the value of the yen. Recently, it increased the prices of the cars it sells its American subsidiary by 4.5 percent.

title: FLAMES MANHANDLE RANGERS
description: In their blazing red uniforms, the Calgary Flames appear as a squadron of overgrown skaters, inch for inch the biggest team in hockey. They are rough and they check and they actually move well, too.

title: VEGAS COURTS LOW ROLLERS
description: The self-proclaimed ''city that never sleeps'' is awakening again after a few years' doze.

title: An Unrehearsed Entrance
description: The Danish Government gave its Order of the Commander's Cross to the violinist Isaac Stern at a glittering embassy party Tuesday night, and there was a bit of disappointment when one of the invited guests, Mstislav Rostropovich, the cellist-composer who conducts the National Symphony, sent his regrets, saying that a rehearsal would keep him away.

title: U.N.A. CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
DePreist to Replace Tennstedt in Concert
description: James DePreist will conduct the Philadelphia Orchestra in its Carnegie Hall concert next Tuesday, replacing Klaus Tennstedt. Mr. Tennstedt has returned to Germany because of a throat ailment, the orchestra announced.

title: ARTFUL ENTRANCES: DECORATED DOORS
description: PERHAPS it is because they already have frames that doors suggest themselves to artists and craftsmen as a type of canvas. Newly popular, decorated doors done in a variety of materials and methods - cut tin, stencils, wood, glass and metals -make the act of walking from one room into another a slightly special moment in the everyday life of a household.

title: BOSSY'S HAT TRICK GIVES ISLANDERS A TIE
description: The assessment of both locker rooms was unanimous: Mike Bossy was awesome tonight, and was the reason the Islanders managed a 4-4 tie against the Minnesota North Stars.

title: Former Argentine President Defends Falklands Invasion
description: A former Argentine military President, Leopoldo Galtieri, has told a court-martial that ''British aggression'' justified launching the war over the Falkland Islands in 1982 and says history will absolve him.

title: Girl Kills 2 Boys and Herself
description: A 14-year-old girl, who was reportedly distraught over losing her boyfriend, fatally shot herself in the head Tuesday after killing the boy and his friend outside a school gymnasium, the authorities said today. They said the girl, who died today, had taken a .22-caliber semi-automatic rifle from home. A Sheriff's Department official said the three teen-agers were honor students.

title: CORRECTION
description: A capsule summary in some editions of Metropolitan Report on Tuesday about the history of the former Madison Square Garden, at Eighth Avenue and 50th Street, misstated the number of New York Rangers Stanley Cup victories and the name of the basketball association that sponsored a 1946 game between the New York Knickerbockers and the Chicago Stags. The Rangers won Stanley Cups in 1928, 1933 and 1940, and the association was the Basketball Association of America.

title: 2 SERIES ON NEW YORK ON CHANNEL 31
description: CHANNEL 31, WNYC's enterprising television station, has introduced two new series of half-hour programs about the city it serves, and they can be sampled tonight. ''Only One New York,'' which celebrates several cultural doings around town, can be seen at 9 o'clock. It is followed by ''Neighborhood Voices,'' an exploration of one of the city's communities. On the basis of tonight's offerings, the second is by far the more interesting.

title: Mission Will Miss Interest Payment
description: Mission Insurance Group Inc., the financially troubled insurance company said that it would not pay its semiannual interest payment of $950,000 due Dec. 1 on its 9 percent debentures of 2003, of which about $50 million worth are outstanding.

title: BENIHANA NATL reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 13
JUDGE DENIES BAIL IN CHINA SPY CASE
description: Larry Wu-Tai Chin, accused of spying for China for more than 30 years, was denied bail today after a Federal prosecutor argued that he was likely to flee the country and would be welcomed by the Chinese ''with open arms.''

title: A TOUCH OF THE DEEP IN FABRIC DESIGNS
description: ALTHOUGH Hope Van Der Wolk studied fabric design at the Rhode Island School of Design, her inspiration for her new fabrics came from a snorkeling trip in the Virgin Islands.

title: Technology;   Cutting Clutter In Memories
description: PERSONAL computers are becoming able to keep more things on their minds at once. But as with people, having too many things on one's mind sometimes leads to trouble.

title: Peter Bessell, Witness In '79 British Scandal
description: Peter J. Bessell, a former member of the British Parliament who wrote a book on a 1979 scandal involving a Liberal Party leader, died at his home Tuesday after a long illness. He was 64 years old.

title: Coach Loses Job
description: The Mississippi State football coach, Emory Bellard, who boldly forecast his team would capture the Southeastern Conference championship this season but failed to win a conference game, was dismissed yesterday. Athletic Director Charley Scott said Bellard's contract was being terminated as of Jan. 15, 1986, but he was ''immediately relieved of all duties.''

title: OIL-DRI CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Sakharov's Wife Books Flight on Monday
description: Yelena G. Bonner, the Soviet dissident who is the wife of Andrei D. Sakharov, has booked a ticket on a flight from Moscow to Rome next Monday, a spokesman for the Italian airline Alitalia said today.

title: UNION IN FRANCE CONFIRMS IT GETS U.S. FUNDS
description: A French labor union said today that it had received American Government funds to support foreign trade union activists who had come to France to escape persecution in such countries as Poland and Afghanistan. The union said there was ''nothing scandalous'' in its activities.

title: TEXACO STOCK RALLIES AFTER EXTENDING SLUMP
description: Texaco Inc. stock continued to slump in very heavy trading yesterday in the wake of the company's statement Tuesday that it could be forced into bankruptcy by the requirements of appealing the verdict in the Pennzoil case. But the stock rallied in the afternoon, closing less than a point below its opening level. Apparently investors overcame their initial apprehension.

title: COMPUTER STOCKS SURGE ON INCREASE IN ORDERS
description: Computer industry executives said yesterday that the two-day surge in high-technology stock prices was based on significantly stronger orders in October and November. But they said the climb in orders might not be strong enough to assure an end to the slump that has plagued the business for more than a year.

title: THE DANCE: NEW CHOREOGRAPHER
description: WE are in for an era of tours de force, if ''Fresh Tracks'' is any guide to the future of modern dance. The program of dance by new choreographers, which opened on Tuesday at the Bessie Schonberg Theater, 219 West 19th Street, placed heavier emphasis on the theatrical and personal than on craft and quality of movement.

title: EXPERTS SAY U.S. AND ISRAEL HAVE A HISTORY OF COOPERATION ON INTELLIGENCE
description: Relations between intelligence agencies of the United States and Israel are normally marked by the closest cooperation, but over the years there have been occasional reports that Israelis spied on Americans or engaged in clandestine operations in this country.

title: Pair Fined for Breaking Immigration Laws
description: A brother and sister convicted of conspiring to violate immigration laws by importing fellow Indonesians and selling them as servants have been fined, placed on probation and ordered to pay the aliens' way back home by Federal District Judge Richard Gadbois.

title: CHRYSLER RESUMES LOWER CAR RATES
description: The Chrysler Corporation said today that it was offering buyers 8.6 percent financing or direct rebates of up to $1,000 on many of its 1985 and 1986 model automobiles. The program begins today and runs until further notice.

title: Turkeys
description: ''W e're coming into the home stretch,'' Fred Oppenheimer said, looking relieved. ''I've had it with turkeys!''

title: McDonald's Issue
description: The McDonald's Corporation is issuing $100 million of 10 percent Eurobonds due 1993, plus warrants at a price of 101 1/8, through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley International.

title: A.T.&T. Seeks Rate Changes
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company today proposed increasing rates for private business circuits by $290 million a year, effective Jan. 2, and said it would soon lower the price of international phone calls by $150 million a year.

title: INTERMARK GAMING INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Potlatch to Reopen Idaho Operations
description: The Potlatch Corporation, a major forest products company based here, said it would reopen its Idaho wood products operations because wage and benefit concessions from the International Woodworkers of America union would save the company approximately $11 million annually.

title: More Airports Needed For Corporate Planes
description: To the Editor:

title: SmithKline Offer
description: The SmithKline Beckman Corporation said it would offer early retirement incentives to 700 employees and expects the program to produce a charge against first-quarter 1986 earnings of as much as $30 million. It said the offer, effective Jan. 1, would be made to employees at its Philadelphia headquarters whose combined age and years of service with the company total 75 years or more. The incentives include the addition of five years of service and five years of age to pension benefit calculations, and a special one-time payment equivalent to two to nine months of an employee's salary.

title: COWBOYS WIN BEHIND WHITE
description: Danny White rifled four touchdown passes today as the Dallas Cowboys defeated the St. Louis Cardinals, 35-17, to improve their record to 9-4, one-half game better than the Giants in the National Football Conference East. Dallas meets New York on Dec. 15. White hit 14 of 26 passes for 235 yards, throwing touchdown passes of 53 and 16 yards to Tony Hill, 18 yards to Mike Renfro and 19 yards to Doug Cosbie, the tight end.

title: Craig Wolff on Hockey;   NILAN LIKES TOUGH-GUY ROLE
description: Life as hockey's villain has its drawbacks. He is scorned by some opponents, verbally abused by the fans, and his mother is worried sick. But Chris Nilan says he will not change his ways.

title: WARREN AND F.B.I. SPLIT OVER REPORT
description: Government documents made public 22 years after the slaying of President Kennedy suggest that the Warren Commission's report on the assassination put an end to a long-standing political alliance and personal friendship between Chief Justice Earl Warren and J. Edgar Hoover, Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: MOVIES
description: ''Shoah,'' at Cinema Studio 1 and 2, is Claude Lanzmann's huge, exhaustively researched and detailed film about the Holocaust, not as it is re-created through archival footage of the death camps, but as the death camps are remembered today. The ''witnesses to genocide'' include survivors and former Nazi officials who planned and operated the death camps, as well as German and Polish civilians, some of whom reveal feelings that are no better than mixed.

title: Planning Ahead
description: Americans are keenly aware of the blessings of an abundant harvest. Thus, it's appropriate to recall that just a year ago we were discovering the human catastrophe unfolding in sub-Saharan Africa.

title: REBELS RAID SOUTH AFRICAN OIL PLANT
description: Anti-Government guerrillas staged a rocket attack early today on a plant in South Africa that makes oil from coal and the police said the three rebels were killed in a gunbattle as they sought to flee.

title: Staying Upbeat In a Down Season
description: The huge flowered wreath shaped like a ''1'' that Mack Brown received from Tulane's booster club last week was a tribute he says he will remember for a long time. Lest there be any confusion as to its significance, however, let it be noted that the coach was not being honored for leading his team to the top spot in the football polls. On the contrary, the 27-17 victory over Southwestern Louisiana the previous Saturday was the first of the season for the Green Wave, who proceeded to fall to Southern Mississippi and, given an expected trouncing at the hands of Louisiana State tomorrow, will finish at 1-10. But Brown, nearing the end of his first season in New Orleans, is keeping the sunny side up. ''This is, by far, the most satisfying win I've had at Tulane,'' he deadpanned after the Southwestern Louisiana game.

title: PLAN ON CRIME FILE DRAWS QUESTIONS
description: A Justice Department plan to build a computerized national file on white-collar crime suspects has been questioned by three lobbying organizations.

title: Art From Life
description: It is a familiar scene: an old man wearing a cap, an older woman talking to a younger one, a child climbing into the younger woman's lap.

title: Soviet in New Overture On Ties to Albanians
description: The Soviet Union made its warmest overture to Albania in years in an article in the Communist Party newspaper Pravda today, urging improved ties and describing the current cool relations as abnormal.

title: EDUCATIONAL OFFICIAL WAS HOSTAGE IN IRAN
description: William F. Keough Jr., former head of the American School in Pakistan who was one of 52 Americans held hostage for 444 days in the United States Embassy in Teheran, died at his home in Washington Wednesday. He was 55 years old and suffered from amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, a degenerative disease of the nervous system, known as Lou Gehrig's disease.

title: SHEPP ON SAXOPHONE
description: The saxophonist Archie Shepp is appearing through Sunday at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South (242-1785), near Bleecker Street, with a group that includes the singer Jeanne Lee and the vibraphonist Gunter Hampel. Sets begin at 10 and 11:45 P.M. and 1:30 A.M. today and tomorrow; 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M. Sunday; there is a $10 cover and a $6 minumum.

title: SURGE IN STRIFE FROM LEFT AND RIGHT SLOWS COLOMBIA'S PEACE EFFORTS
description: In the last two weeks there has been a surge in fighting and right-wing terrorism in Colombia's long guerrilla war, signaling a further setback to President Belisario Betancur's efforts to bring peace to this country.

title: JOHN P. SHANLEY, 70, EX-EDITOR
description: John P. Shanley, former radio-television editor of The New York Times, died of lung cancer yesterday at the Mercy Hospice in Rockville Centre, L.I. A resident of Bellerose Village, L.I., he was 70 years old.

title: AUCTIONS
description: THE 4-foot-5 1/2-inch-tall copy of the Statue of Liberty that belonged to Frederic Auguste Bartholdi will be auctioned at 2 P.M. tomorrow at Sotheby's, York Avenue at 72d Street. The figure, one of many made to raise money to build the 305-foot-high colossus, is expected to sell for more than $125,000, which would be an auction record for one of these reductions.

title: O'BRIEN IS SACKED SEVEN TIMES AS LIONS UPSET JETS
description: No, it wasn't the dome. It wasn't the short work week, either, or the crowd noise.

title: An N.B.A. Realist
description: When 38 fouls were called against Phoenix in Wednesday night's loss to Portland, the Suns' Walter Davis had an explanation: ''We're 2-15. I don't expect nothing from the refs.''

title: The U.N. Today: Nov. 29, 1985
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: ART: JENNIFER BARLETT, 15 YEAR RETROSPECTIVE
description: FEW contemporary artists are more controversial than Jennifer Bartlett. To her many defenders, her work is immensely ambitious and endlessly rich and inventive, and her serial, cinematic and novelistic approach has pioneered new ground for painting. Her detractors believe that she has flaws as a painter, that her work is weakened rather than strengthened by its eclecticism and that no matter how how large and ambitious it is, her painting is only skin deep.

title: Carolina Constable Is Killed In Attack With Machine Gun
description: Law officers across the Carolinas hunted today for two robbers who killed a constable in an early morning machine-gun attack and sped away with a deputy firing at their car.

title: Gannettt Buys Peekskill Star
description: The Peekskill Evening Star, a newspaper with a daily circulation of 10,500 and a Sunday circulation of 12,500, was purchased Wednesday by Gannett Westchester-Rockland Newspapers, its publisher said. The Star was sold by Ogden Newspapers, a West Virginia-based company that had owned it for 12 years. No sale price was announced.

title: Who'll Protect the John Andersons?
description: It looks awful, like cigar-smoking thugs snatching a taxi away from women in nice suits waiting patiently at the curb. Since 1976 the League of Women Voters, the very image of nonpartisan concern for good government, has sponsored the televised Presidential debates. Now it has been muscled out of the way by the Democratic and Republican Parties, which have agreed that they will sponsor future debates.

title: Pentagon Aide to Be Investigated
description: The Pentagon said Wednesday that it would investigate a senior auditing official who had pressed associates to help cover legal expenses of his former chief, who was dismissed for trying to punish a whistleblower.

title: Shelter Alarm
description: New York had a problem.

title: GERMANY'S CAUTIOUS COURSE
description: The West German economic recovery is proving even stronger than Government projections had foreseen. But efforts by the United States to get Bonn to step on the gas and assert its role as the engine of Europe are running into stiff resistance here.

title: Woman, 86, Saved By Grandchildren
description: Two sisters 5 and 7 years old saved the life of their partly blind, 86-year-old great-grandmother during a house fire, authorities said today.

title: HALLEY'S COMET
description: Halley's Comet will rise over the New York City area at 1:51 P.M. today and set at 3:48 A.M. tomorrow.

title: DETROIT EXPERIMENTING WITH THE PLASTIC LOOK
description: When Detroit decides to design a more expensive version of a popular car, it usually means that the new model will have a few bits of additional chrome and a plusher interior. Pontiac's plan for the new Fiero GT, a high-priced offspring of the successful Fiero two-seat sports car, was dramatically different, however.

title: RULING ON PHONE ACCESS AIDS CASE FOR BUSINESS
description: The Federal Communications Commission division in charge of telephone services has ruled that it is legal for a local telephone company to provide service to business customers in another local phone company's franchise area whenever the customer requests the service.

title: HUNDREDS QUESTIONED IN SLAYING OF WOMAN IN L.I.
description: Hundreds of people have been questioned in the investigation into the August slaying of a woman in her 28-room Hewlett Neck mansion, but no arrests have been made, according to the Nassau County police.

title: POLISH LEADER SEES LONG CONFLICT
description: Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Polish leader, says the Communist Party faces a long struggle against enemies inside the country, the official press agency reported today.

title: ISRAEL SAID TO LINK AMERICAN TO UNIT ON ANTITERRORISM
description: An internal Israeli investigation has found that Jonathan Jay Pollard, an employee of the United States Navy, was working as an intelligence operative for a secretive Israeli counterterrorism bureau, a highly placed Israeli source said today.

title: Prison Guards Foil Escape
description: Six death row inmates, one of whom had a fake pistol made out of cardboard, tried in vain to escape from the Mecklenburg Correctional Center on Wednesday, officials said. The warden, Toni Bair, said security officers recognized that the gun was a fake.

title: ASTRONAUTS LAUNCH A 3D SATELLITE AS THEY PREPARE FOR SPACE WALK
description: The crew of the space shuttle Atlantis, celebrating ''one of the best'' Thanksgivings, launched an uninsured $50 million satellite today to clear the way for an important two-man space walk on Friday.

title: Parents 'on Cloud 9'
description: The release of Richard Ondrik ''was the most marvelous Thanksgiving present we could have had,'' his mother, Louise Ondrik, said today.

title: HAPPY NEW BEGINNING FOR A STORYBOOK LIFE
description: HER life story reads like a movie script: Russian film star searches for her father, a retired American admiral. He is traced to Florida, she obtains a visa after her father pleads with Soviet officials, and they meet for the first time. While in the United States, she falls in love with an airline pilot, marries him a month later and settles in Connecticut. Then the offers come rolling in - from publishers, television executives, cosmetics companies.

title: SNOW, MORE SNOW AND A YEARNING FOR YESTERYEAR
description: Snow and cold are hardly new here, but the past week has been something everybody will remember.

title: LABOR DEPT. AIDES REBUT MEESE VIEW
description: Senior officials at the Labor Department have prepared a memorandum with a point-by-point rebuttal of the views of Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d and other Reagan Administration officials on the Government's affirmative action program.

title: No Columnist, He
description: Senator Gary Hart of Colorado has declined an offer by The Washington Times, a daily newspaper published here, to write a regular column for its opinion section.

title: MARCOS BACKS PACT ON BASES
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos said today that he favored the extension of a treaty with the United States on military bases, and warned of war in Asia if the bases were removed.

title: AIDES HINT PRESIDENT WILL SPEAK TO NATION ABOUT ESPIONAGE CASES
description: White House officials said today that President Reagan would most likely ''speak to the nation'' about the recent series of espionage arrests, possibly in his weekly radio address Saturday.

title: WINTER HOURS AT ZOO
description: Winter hours are now in effect at the Bronx Zoo, Bronx River Parkway and Fordham Road.

title: STUDY CLEARS USE OF SOME SOLVENTS
description: The Environmental Protection Agency, after a two-year study, has concluded that chemicals used by the high-technology and electronics companies south of here do not present a serious cancer risk.

title: ART: AT THE GUGGENHEIM, 40 YEARS OF SCULPTURE
description: EVEN 30 years ago, few people would have argued that our century would be remembered as much for sculpture as for painting. It was the great painters who had made the running, from the Paris Salon d'Automne of 1905 onward, with the great sculptors somewhere in the margin.

title: And Forget the Gin
description: According to Jobson's Wine Marketing Handbook, Washington consumes more vermouth for its population than any other city in the country: 52.2 cases a year for every 100,000 residents in 1984, compared with 42.8 cases for New York, the runner-up. Capital distributors attribute this leadership position to the fact that vermouth is popular in embassy social circles as an aperitif, in addition to its more common use as a marginal ingredient in the martini.

title: VOLUNTEERS SHARE FOOD AND FEELINGS OF HOLIDAY
description: The old woman walked alone through the rain to Trinity School on the Upper West Side. At the door, a boy offered to take her coat.

title: DRUNKEN DRIVING
description: Residents of New York and New Jersey will fall into step with a walk tomorrow sponsored by the organization Mothers Against Drunk Driving. Since August, the group has conducted community walks nationwide to draw attention to the problem of those who drive while intoxicated.

title: 'BEEHIVE A REMINDER THAT THE 60's WERE FUN
description: THE 1960's may have been the decade of Vietnam, assassinations and social revolution, but as the exuberant cabaret revue ''Beehive'' reminds us, the decade also produced its share of transcendentally silly fun. The show, which is enjoying an open-ended run at Sweetwater's, features six of the most promising young female singers in the New York area glossing the songs and voices of an array of singers from Lesley Gore to Janis Joplin.

title: FRAUDULENT AUTO ACCIDENTS VIEWED AS A THRIVING RACKET
description: Derek says he was recruited at a car wash with the promise of a quick $300. Soon he was part of a ring that deliberately crashed automobiles into cars of unsuspecting motorists to collect fraudulent insurance claims.

title: Maker of Fake MSG Jailed
description: Chinese television said today that a court in Fuzhou sentenced a man to life imprisonment on Tuesday for producing fake monosodium glutamate and selling it as the taste-enhancer commonly used in Chinese cooking. The court found Zheng Qing and two accomplices guilty of producing 28 tons of fake MSG, valued at $6,300. The two others were sentenced to three years and two and a half years in prison.

title: WORKERS ARE CONTAMINATED AT NUCLEAR PLANT
description: Six workers who thought they were participating in a radiation-free drill at an Alabama nuclear plant earlier this month were contaminated by a radioactive liquid that had been used to increase the realism of the exercise.

title: Debate Over RICO Suits Highlights Inadequacy of State Courts
description: To the Editor:

title: NICARAGUA'S DISABLED: A GROWING LEGACY OF WAR
description: While gunfire echoes and artillery shells fall on remote mountain battlefields, here in the capital people must confront the grimmest of reminders of the effects of Nicaragua's fratricidal war.

title: Ex-officer at G.E. Joining Bank Group
description: The American Express Bank Ltd., the international banking arm of the American Express Company, announced that George J. Stathakis, formerly president and chief executive of the giant General Electric Trading Company, will become associated with the bank in its merchant banking group.

title: FOES OF MARCOS GAINING LISTENERS
description: Raul S. Manglapus, founder of the Movement for a Free Philippines, recalls that he had to plead for appointments when he wanted to see members of Congress five years ago. But now he says they call him, eagerly seeking information about the crisis in his homeland.

title: Ireland's Senate Backs British-Irish Accord
description: The Irish Senate approved the British-Irish agreement today, clearing the last hurdle for the accord that gives Ireland a consulting role in governing Northern Ireland.

title: ST. JUDE HOSPITAL CONSIDERS MOVE TO ST. LOUIS
description: St. Jude Children's Research Hospital, which operates the world's largest childhood cancer research center, is considering moving to St. Louis, but Memphis officials are fighting to keep it here.

title: HOLIDAY CAROLING
description: An 81-member chorus will sing holiday songs today at 7:15 P.M. at Pier 17 of the South Street Seaport. The caroling, which lasts about 30 minutes, is part of a series of free holiday music events at the seaport; similar performances will be held every evening except Monday, through Dec. 29. On Saturdays and Sundays, the caroling begins at 5:15 P.M.

title: City in Michigan Plans Layoffs to Cover Deficit
description: Officials in Benton Harbor, where more than one-third of the work force is unemployed, plan to lay off city employees, freeze spending and seek state aid to help cover a $2.2 million deficit.

title: Unsettling a Piece of Old France in the New World
description: Once upon a time off the east coast of Canada there lived a French colony called St. Pierre and Miquelon.

title: Topics;   Helping Hands Hard Corps
description: Governor Cuomo of New York likes the idea of offering scholarships to college students who will take public service jobs after graduation. Last year he authorized a Teacher Corps to pump new talent into public schools.

title: Yelena Bonner Says a Hitch Over Her Exit Visa Is Solved
description: Yelena G. Bonner, the wife of Andrei D. Sakharov, told relatives here today by telephone that she had to argue with Soviet authorities to list the United States as a destination on her passport.

title: A VISIT BY LONDON'S OPERATIC 'FIRES'
description: One of the remarkable things about the Fires of London, Peter Maxwell Davies's music-theater ensemble that is taking over Alice Tully Hall for the weekend, is that it plays contemporary music and makes it pay.

title: Advertising;   H.H.C.C. Joins Polaroid Team
description: Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos of Boston has joined the agency roster of the Polaroid Corporation in nearby Cambridge. The assignment is for the industrial, technical and professional products resigned in September by Doyle Dane Bernbach, which bade farewell to the client that grew to world fame with its help.

title: Army Officer Assumes Sierra Leone Presidency
description: Maj. Gen. Joseph Saidu Momoh was sworn in today as President of Sierra Leone, succeeding Siaka Stevens, who retired after ruling this West African coastal nation for 17 years.

title: CHINESE BRING A GOOD IDEA TO A NEW YORK CITY MATCH
description: Written bidding, which provides a record of the proceedings, avoids reviews and prevents overhearing, is an excellent idea that is popular in the Far East and the South Pacific but unknown in this country. It was in use Sunday on Chinese soil, so one might guess Peking or Shanghai.

title: Heart Surgery Due for Chiles
description: Senator Lawton Chiles, Democrat of Florida, is to undergo a coronary bypass operation next week to correct blocked arteries, his Washington office reported Wednesday. The office said the Senator, who is 55 years old, was admitted to Lakeland Regional Medical Center Tuesday for further tests after a visit to the Bethesda Naval Hospital in Maryland. Tests there, the office said, ''concluded that Senator Chiles has arterial occlusion requiring coronary bypass surgery.''

title: Congress, Good and Bad
description: Congress is traditionally and pre-eminently a place where the varied economic, social and sectional interests of a continental democracy assert themselves, clash, test their strengths and reach compromise that's often acceptable, if not entirely satisfactory, to all. And those who lose can come back to fight again another day.

title: Median Income Decline Seen
description: The typical middle-income American family with children lost $3,152 in pre-tax income in the last 11 years because of inflation, according to a Democratic Congressional study made public today.

title: CLUBS CAN PROVIDE BARGAINS FOR SKIERS
description: People who like the outdoors generally like it better when other people are around. This is especially true of skiers, who socialize as well as exercise.

title: Cargo Jet Lands After Fire
description: A Northwest Orient 747 cargo plane was forced to make an emergency landing at O'Hare International Aiport today shortly after takeoff when one of its four engines apparently caught fire and shut down.

title: Buttons
description: Sometimes a journey turns up the unexpected.

title: NEW TWIST FOR AN OLD BUILDING IN JERSEY
description: During many gray years of decline after World War II, this former industrial city across the Hudson River from New York looked back to its better days as a means of muddling through a less-than-glorious present. But in the last few years Jersey City, like other nearby riverfront communities, has been undergoing a revival, and this has given residents and developers a more hopeful outlook.

title: Dollar in Sharp Decline Abroad
description: The dollar was down sharply against all major European currencies in active trading today. Gold prices also fell.

title: Fabrication of Fans
description: The day after the Bears crushed the Dallas Cowboys, 44-0, on Nov. 17, The Chicago Sun-Times published an account of despondent Cowboy fans watching the game at a rural west Texas bar near the town of Eden. Yesterday, the newspaper announced that it had dismissed the reporter who wrote the article after concluding that neither the bar nor the fans existed and that the reporter, Wade Roberts, had made the whole thing up. The dismissal was announced a day after Mike Royko, a former Sun-Times columnist, questioned the authenticity of the article in his column in The Chicago Tribune.

title: No Easy Way Out
description: American leaders came home from Geneva with the impression that Moscow now would like to find a way out of Afghanistan. This was conveyed in public by Soviet spokesmen, who repeatedly spoke of the need for a ''political solution,'' as well as officially in private. They emphasized the role that United Nations mediation should play.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Wednesday about the Republic division of Fairchild Industries incorrectly described the timetable set by the Air Force for the division to correct problems at its Farmingdale, L.I., plant, where the T-46A trainer aircraft is being built. The last of the major improvements are to be made by December 1986.

title: Surprise Holiday Gift For a Brooklyn Thief
description: Whoever stole what appeared to be Christmas gifts from Representative Charles E. Schumer's locked car Wednesday night is in for a big surprise.

title: CAIRO'S ARMY HAS NEW JOB: MILK THE COW
description: Each day Mohammed rises at 5 A.M. to milk his cows. In a long, narrow barn, he attaches metal suction pumps to the udders of a succession of none-too-contented cows and flips a switch. He repeats this exercise twice a day, as do farmers at modern dairy farms throughout Egypt.

title: STEPINAC ROUTED BY WHITE PLAINS
description: The tailback Ronnie Mitchell ran for a touchdown and kicked a field goal to lead White Plains to a 16-0 victory over Archbishop Stepinac at Highlands Field in White Plains yesterday.

title: Guru Invites Disciples To Join Him in India
description: Followers of Bhagwan Shree Rajneesh have received an invitation from the Indian guru to join a commune in Poona, India, but those remaining today at the settlement in central Oregon showed little enthusiam for the offer.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: YOU do a double take upon encountering the life-size mannequins that await you inside the glass doors of Batons. Beyond the sleek front room with its rose-marble bar and austere tables, you pass the bustling open kitchen - ''Careful, hot plates!'' - then enter a wide-open dining room under an arching skylight. Unadorned walls and a rough cement floor inset with black-marble diamonds suggest one of the more pleasant subway stations in Toronto. The name of the two-month-old restaurant is derived from the whimsical black and white light cylinders that sprout like weeds around the room.

title: ARAFAT FOES ADD 2 KILLINGS TO TERRORISM UPSURGE
