description: There has been an upsurge in terrorist activity recently by the underground Palestinian group headed by Abu Nidal, who has been accused by Egypt of masterminding the hijacking of an Egyptian airliner to Malta.

title: COLLEGE'S GROWTH HAS OLD SAVANNAH IN AN UPROAR
description: Savannah has never had a reputation as a center of education. As a city of grace and charm that always knew how to throw a party - yes, even for William Tecumseh Sherman, the Union Army general who marched through Georgia. As an elegant setting for conversation, by all means. As an environment for academic pursuits, hardly.

title: CITY BALLET: 'QUARTET RETURNS
description: ''BRAHMS-SCHOENBERG QUARTET,'' which George Balanchine created in 1966, could never be viewed as one of the choreographer's best ballets. Yet he maintained it in the repertory with regularity - possibly because the music appealed to him and possibly because of the obvious opportunities for classical dancing that it affords the New York City Ballet.

title: COLORADO RAILROAD LOCKED IN BATTLE
description: The Denver & Rio Grande Western Railroad would like to remain the little railroad that could.

title: NEW MOTTO FOR TEXAN: FENCE ME IN
description: When the ancient Chinese wanted to protect themselves from invading hordes, they built the Great Wall.

title: MICHIGAN CHEMICAL HAZARD LEADS TO DISPUTE
description: A chemical believed to cause cancer has been seeping into underground water supplies here, and Gov. James J. Blanchard and the Federal Environmental Protection Agency are disputing how the problem should be handled.

title: Games That Matrimonial Lawyers Play
description: To the Editor:

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Nets vs. Atlanta Hawks, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, 7:35 P.M. This is the teams' first meeting this season. They split six games last season. (Television - SportsChannel, 12:45 A.M., tape. Radio - WPAT 930, 7:30 P.M.) Knicks vs. Celtics, at Boston, 8:05 P.M. The 232d consecutive sellout crowd for a Celtic game at Boston Garden will be on hand to watch Patrick Ewing and the Knicks meet the Celtics for the second time this season. Larry Bird and the Celtics swept all six games from the Knicks last season and won their first game this season, 113-104, in Madison Square Garden last Saturday. (Television - Channel 9 and WTBS, 8 P.M.) Colleges: St. John's vs. Duke, 7 P.M., and Kansas vs. Louisville, 9 P.M., Big Apple N.I.T. semifinal doubleheader at Madison Square Garden. (Television -USA Network, 7 P.M. and 9 P.M. Radio - WCBS 880, 770, 7 P.M. only.) North Carolina vs. Missouri, 7 P.M., and Villanova vs. Nevada-Las Vegas, 9 P.M. Great Alaska Shootout, opening round, at Anchorage. The Tar Heels are coming off big victories over U.C.L.A. and Iona in Chapel Hill. Coach Rollie Massimino and his defending champion Villanova team go up against Jerry Tarkanian's Nevada-Las Vegas team. (Television -ESPN, 7 P.M.) Harness Racing Garden State, 8 P.M. The Breeders' Crown Pace for 3-year-old colts and geldings, final in this year's series of Breeders' Crown races, is the feature, with a purse of about $600,000. Nihilator, a winner in 34 of 37 career races, makes his final start before being retired to stud.

title: Quake in California
description: An earthquake measuring 4.5 on the Richter scale of energy was felt early today in an area 30 miles southeast of Hollister, but no damage was reported. Each unit increase in the scale, which is an index to earthquakes' severity, represents a thirtyfold increase in energy released. A reading of 4 on the scale can indicate moderate damage.

title: STEELER DEFENSE TO TEST ELWAY
description: John Elway and the Denver Broncos are back in Pittsburgh Sunday, and who could forget the odd turn of events of their last trip?

title: A STREET, ALBEIT UNOFFICIAL, CALLED J
description: The city fathers of Washington no doubt had good reasons for not including a J Street in their alphabetical layout of thoroughfares. But residents of a community in the Northeast section of the city, undaunted by the omission, have come up with an unofficial J Street all their own.

title: More in Poll Back Execution
description: American support for the death penalty for a variety of serious crimes has increased sharply over the last seven years, according to the latest Gallup Poll.

title: MUSEUMS
description: The ''Henri de Toulouse-Lautrec'' exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art has been a runaway success, but it is not an exhibition that matches the popular idea of Lautrec as a master of ''colorful night life.'' Rather, it shows him as a professional who could turn his hand to whatever subject was put before him. It also shows him as a printmaker who could make use of a rapidly evolving technology without allowing it to drag him along. He was its master, not its servant, and there is fascination in the sight of him making his way from one state to another - adding here, taking away there, aiming always at great lucidity of statement.

title: 3 Firefighters Hurt In Mount Vernon
description: Three firefighters were injured and 41 families were evacuated when a fire tore through a six-story apartment building this afternoon, fire officials said.

title: ...and Free Tea, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: Chevron Gets Break In Oil Price
description: The Chevron Corporation has entered into a contract with Saudi Arabia that offers price discounts on some of the crude oil that Chevron buys during the fourth quarter, according to a Chevron official.

title: Humidifier Drowns Baby
description: A 3-month-old baby drowned after rolling off a couch and falling into a humidifier Wednesday, the police reported.

title: A Vote to Waste Energy
description: The Government recently extended the deadline by which the nation's automobile manufacturers must comply with Federal fuel efficiency standards, which aimed at an average level of 27.5 miles per gallon by 1986. This rollback in the timetable for better mileage for American cars represents not only a cave-in to Ford and General Motors and an insult to Chrysler -which had already programmed its models to conform to the regulations - but, most important, a serious blow to our efforts to achieve energy independence.

title: CHILLING 'CARRIE' IN VENGEFUL RETURN - AS A MUSICAL
description: CARRIE in the locker room, at the high- school prom, in the graveyard, and now ''Carrie,'' the Broadway musical - audiences should prepare themselves for chills and trills, courtesy of Stephen King and the composing team of Dean Pitchford and Michael Gore. The last two have written a rock score. Lawrence D. Cohen, who wrote the screenplay for the movie ''Carrie,'' has reconceived the tale in theatrical terms. The Broadway producers Barry and Fran Weissler, Frederick M. Zollo and Ivan Bloch are at the starting gate. And Terry Hands, of the Royal Shakespeare Company, is about to sign on as director. If all goes according to plan, ''Carrie'' should begin rehearsals in late spring or early summer, and it should be on Broadway next fall.

title: REFRIGERATOR'S THANKSGIVING
description: Last Thanksgiving, William (The Refrigerator) Perry was unconcerned about his weight, which was zero on some scales. That is, he stepped on the scale and when the needle zoomed past the maximum, 350, it came to rest back on zero.

title: DRINKING AGE RISING, ABLANY ADDS CHECKS AT VERMONT LINE
description: Additional sobriety checkpoints will be set up along the Vermont border when the minimum drinking age in New York is raised from 19 to 21 on Dec. 1, Governor Cuomo said today.

title: Banner in Sky Waves Above Reagan Ranch
description: With a lucky break from the weather, President Reagan and his family got a Thanksgiving greeting from the sky as they gathered for a turkey dinner at their mountaintop ranch north of here.

title: THE STAGE: 'MAIDEL IN HARTFORD
description: Separated for almost 20 years, two sisters are reunited in America after World War II. The younger sister has been in New York with her father since she was 4; she has grown up as an American. The older sister is a survivor of the Holocaust. The three come together and the father, acting as family historian, takes out a small notebook and begins to read the names of relatives in Poland. The older sister interrupts. She, too, has a notebook, and she reads her names, many of them the same. The list is a mournful litany of the murdered and the missing, including her mother and her infant daughter.

title: 3 Protesters Slain By Haitian Forces
description: Policemen and soldiers killed at least three students today and wounded others protesting against ''misery'' in the town of Gonaives, the scene of violent food riots last year, a radio station said.

title: Penelope Karagias, a Broker Of Brooklyn Apartment Sales
description: Penelope Karagias, a Brooklyn real-estate broker who was active in apartment sales in Brooklyn Heights, Park Slope, Cobble Hill and Carroll Gardens, was found dead of carbon-monoxide poisoning on Tuesday morning in a garage opposite one of her offices at 343 Smith Street, the police reported.

title: Sick Girl, 12, Is Flown To Reunion With Mother
description: A partly paralyzed 12-year-old girl arrived today from Hungary for medical treatment and was met by her American mother, whom she had not seen in eight years.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: THERE were any number of ways that Johnny Nicholson could have chosen to give a party celebrating the start of his 37th year as a restaurateur, so he decided to do everything.

title: Late Act Wins Queens County
description: Greentree Stable's Late Act, the odds-on favorite of the crowd of 10,152, raced to a 6 1/4-length victory in the $87,300 Queens County Handicap yesterday at Aqueduct.

title: POP-JAZZ
description: This weekend, a forceful jazz quintet will be at the Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South, at 11th Street (255-4037). The leader is Elvin Jones, whose splashy cymbals and tom-tom patterns were the polyrhythmic foundations for some of John Coltrane's most important music. His current group features Sonny Fortune on alto saxophone. Sets begin at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M. today through Sunday; there is a $10 cover and a one-drink minimum.

title: Girl, 2 1/2, Dials for Help After Baby Sitter Is Hurt
description: A 2 1/2-year-old girl who seemed ''real calm'' dialed a telephone operator for help after her baby sitter fell down a flight of stairs and was knocked unconscious, the police say.

title: Games That Matrimonial Lawyers Play
description: To the Editor:

title: Mexico Raises Prices of Oil
description: Encouraged by a firmer market and growing winter demand, the state petroleum monopoly Petroleos Mexicanos said today that it was raising the price of its light Isthmus crude oil by an average of 76 cents a barrel in December.

title: CORRECTION
description: An obituary yesterday of Herbert Prashker, a lawyer who specialized in labor law, misidentified one of his children. Marti Prashker is his daughter.

title: BROWN COMES BACK AS COACH IN N.I.T.
description: Ever since he left pro basketball for the University of Kansas, Larry Brown says, he has found peace of mind and a fair measure of tranquillity.

title: GALLERIES
description: One of the many ways in which the presence of sculpture can be felt this fall is in the number of exhibitions by established sculptors in the 57th Street area. One of the handsomest shows is ''Isamu Noguchi, Bronze Sculpture 1959-1962,'' at the Arnold Herstand Gallery, 24 West 57th Street, through Dec. 14. It contains nine pieces, almost all cast from balsa wood. Because the original material is so light, the bronze remains light as well. The works have none of the frozen bulk that has tended to identify bronze with the academic tradition.

title: SOVIET IMMIGRANTS' JEWISH INDENTITY IS STUDIED
description: Most Soviet Jewish immigrants in New York City have been in the United States five years or more, are becoming American citizens, live in apartments in Brooklyn or Queens with or near their parents or in-laws, are 30 to 50 years old and have one child.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: If Thanksgiving has come, can Christmas movies be far behind?

title: A Simple Method for Testing New I.R.S. Forms
description: To the Editor:

title: PHILADELPHIA SEEKS TO HOLD RADICAL LIABLE IN FIRE
description: The city is asking that a survivor of the radical group Move and the owner of its fortified house be held legally responsible for the May 13 battle with the police in which 11 people died and 61 houses were destroyed.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Consolidated Natural Gas Company, Pittsburgh, has elected L. J. Timms Jr. president of the Consolidated Gas Transmission Corp., a pipeline subsidiary based in Clarksburg, W.Va., effective Jan. 1. He succeeds George A. Davidson Jr., who has been elected a vice chairman of the parent company.

title: JAZZ-CABARET
description: In the six years that Panama Francis and his Savoy Sultans have been one of the bands that play for dancing at the Rainbow Room, the Art Deco fantasy of 30 Rockefeller Plaza, they have achieved a skillful mixture of the crisp, swinging music that the original Savoy Sultans played at the Savoy Ballroom in Harlem in the 1940's and the soft but swinging pop tunes and waltzes that go with the elegance of the room.

title: A HOLIDAY WARNING ON TOYS
description: A panel of Government and industry toy specialists has urged holiday shoppers to wrap children's gifts in ''love and safety.''

title: Democrats Eye Virginia
description: Encouraged by the Democrats' sweep of statewide offices in Virginia's elections earlier this month, the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee has hired one of the chief organizers of the party's victory there. Tom King, who was campaign manager for Mary Sue Terry, the victorious candidate for Attorney General, has become political director of the committee.

title: Markets Closed
description: All United States stock and commodity markets were closed yesterday in observance of Thanksgiving Day.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 29, 1985
description: International

title: TITO'S HERITAGE BEING DEBATED IN YOGOSLAVIA
description: The personality of Josip Broz Tito, long beyond criticism, has become a subject of a re-examination that may reflect differences within the collective leadership that succeeded him.

title: NEW LEADERS AND A NEW ERA FOR ENVIRONMENTALISTS
description: The environmental movement, an agent of broad change in the nation's economic, social and physical fabric in the last 15 years, is about to plunge into a new era as a new group of top leaders steps into place.

title: CLUES FORTHCOMING ON THE $3.5 MILLION SENATOR
description: Who is the $3.5 million Senator?

title: KAHANE'S RISE TROUBLES JEWS IN U.S.
description: The growing popularity in Israel of Rabbi Meir Kahane, the leader of a movement that favors ejecting all Arabs from that country, has paradoxically strengthened American organizations seeking to improve relations between Jews and Arabs in Israel.

title: SCIENTISTS INSERT GENES OF HEPATITIS VIRUS INTO MICE
description: Researchers using advanced techniques to manipulate the genes of mice say they may have developed the first animal model for studying how hepatitis causes liver cancer in human carriers of the disease.

title: JERSEY'S OLDEST GRANGE FADES WITH RURAL LIFE
description: Suburban life is closing in all around the oldest Grange chapter in New Jersey. Across the road from Pioneer Grange No. 1 - chartered 113 years ago -two modern buildings now stand, filled with IBM and Amway employees.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 29, 1985
description: International The U.S. won global support for a new round of trade-liberalizing negotiations it is seeking to reinforce the world's faltering commitment to free trade and to revitalize the international economy. After three days of often difficult talks, officials from 90 countries agreed unanimously to name a panel to draw up a detailed program for the proposed talks and said their governments would adopt it. [Page A1, Column 4.]

title: Girl, 7, Wounded By a Playmate, 5
description: A 7-year-old girl was critically wounded when a 5-year-old playmate apparently used her father's .22-caliber handgun to shoot the girl in the head, the police said today.

title: Horford Cooperates
description: Tito Horford, the 7-foot-1-inch basketball prospect who enrolled at Louisiana State University after being barred from playing for the University of Houston and then dropped out of L.S.U., has been cooperating with collegiate investigators in an effort to be allowed to play for Houston next season, according to The Houston Post. Horford, who was born in the Dominican Republic and attended high school in Houston, told the paper that he planned to enroll at the University of Houston in January and hoped to play basketball there.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I would like people to think of New York City as the place to be when Halley comes.'' Mayor Koch. [B5:1.]

title: HENNING STRESSES CHARACTER
description: Lorne Henning was already balding when he left the Islander organization after 13 years and accepted the job as head coach of the Minnesota North Stars. So he knows the task that had stymied 12 North Star coaches before him has not caused his hair loss. The job, however, has been a source of some frustration so far this season, especially Wednesday night, when Henning had his first opportunity to coach against his mentor, Al Arbour, as the Islanders made their first visit to the Met Center.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: MERRY GENTLEMEN (AND ONE LADY). By J. Bryan 3d. 324 pages. Illustrated. Atheneum. $17.95. J. BRYAN 3D'S first brush with glory was in 1917, when he rode in the same elevator as Jess Willard, the heavyweight champion. His next approach to it, in a somewhat modified fashion, was in 1934, when he got to know Arthur Samuels, the editor in chief of House Beautiful. By this time, Mr. Bryan himself was managing editor of Town and Country, but Samuels came trailing glamorous associations of a different order - his wife was a well-known actress and he had collaborated on the score of a musical starring W. C.Fields.

title: DANNY MIXON, PIANIST
description: The pianist Danny Mixon is playing solos today through Monday from 9:30 P.M. to 1:30 A.M. at the Burgundy Cafe, 467 Amsterdam Avenue, at 82d Street (787-8300). There is a $7.50 minimum.

title: FARM BILL: SHORT OF GOALS
description: The Senate farm bill, much of which is expected to survive in final legislation, takes a long stride toward the free market that the Reagan Administration has sought for American agriculture.

title: Topics;   Helping Hands Metro Magic
description: The Washington Metro has no human token sellers. Its machines print fare cards that are good for more than one ride.

title: CHINA FREES AMERICAN IN HOTEL FIRE CASE
description: An American businessman was freed today after serving five months of an 18-month prison term for purportedly causing a hotel fire that killed 10 people in Harbin last April.

title: RETAILERS ON A TIGHT SCHEDULE
description: New York City's big retailers are greeting the opening of the 1985 Christmas shopping season today with perhaps their most carefully laid plans in a number of years.

title: 'MINI-SYNOD' IN NEW YORK HAILS CHANGE
description: Without any of the scarlet robes and ceremony that distinguish the Synod of Bishops now being held in Rome, the parishioners of St. Joseph's Church in Greenwich Village held what they called their own ''mini-synod'' to discuss the state of Roman Catholicism.

title: FRENCH HISTORIAN AND AUTHOR
description: Fernand Braudel, widely regarded as one the great historians of the century, died yesterday in Paris. He was 83 years old and lived in Paris.

title: TEXAS A&M IN COTTON BOWL
description: Kevin Murray of Texas A&M threw three touchdown passes tonight to beat Texas, 42-10, and lead the Aggies into the Cotton Bowl for the first time since 1968.

title: BLUES: TURRENTINE AND HARRIS
description: THE blues are hanging dark and heavy at the Blue Note (131 West Third Street) this week, through Sunday, where the saxophonist Stanley Turrentine and the pianist Gene Harris are playing together for the first time in 25 years.

title: Bruins Lose First Game At Home, 3-0
description: Peter Stastny scored the ninth hat trick of his National Hockey League career tonight, as the Quebec Nordiques became the first visiting team to win in Boston this season, beating the Bruins by 3-0.

title: BANGKOK ELECTS ASCETIC EX-GENERAL AS MAYOR
description: He doesn't drink or smoke or eat meat. Seven years ago he took a vow of celibacy. His trademark is a farmer's coarse cotton shirt.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: FRIDAY CRAFTS FOR CHRISTMAS AT WBAI FAIR Thanksgiving over, hordes of Christmas shoppers will hit the streets this weekend, and many of them are likely to make the annual pilgrimage up to Columbia University for the WBAI Holiday Crafts Fair. The fair opens this weekend, skips next weekend and resumes for two more go-rounds on the weekends of Dec. 13-15 and Dec. 20-22. It offers an extravagantly varied selection of items, with 128 exhibitors each weekend and a 90 percent turnover from one weekend to the next. There will be quilts and tapestries, jewelry and ceramics, blown glass and scrimshaw, chandeliers, handmade metal knives, handcrafted baskets, cloth wall-hangings, musical instruments, stained-glass screens and lamps, handmade toys, dolls, puppets and marionettes, games and puzzles, kaleidoscopes and lots more. Admission is $4, with all proceeds going to WBAI-FM, a listener-supported radio station. The fair is open today from 5 to 9 P.M. and on Saturday and Sunday from noon to 7 at Ferris Booth Hall, 115th Street and Broadway. Information: 695-4465.

title: How to Lose a Canal
description: Sometimes politics does not involve launching new ideas as much as getting out from under old ones. More than 40 years ago some Floridians came up with the idea of building a canal across the state, cutting a short route from the submarine-infested Atlantic to the Gulf of Mexico in the interests of the military - and perhaps benefiting some real estate and shipping interests, too.

title: AS HALLEY WAXES, WILL CITY WANE?
description: Mayor Koch has asked his science advisers for ''a reasonable plan'' to dim the city's lights to give New Yorkers a better chance to view Halley's comet.

title: ART: BRITAIN'S EARLY PHOTOGRAPHY
description: SO rapidly did photography catch on that the history of its development in most countries is essentially the same as it is in Britain, which shares the credit for the invention with France.

title: A Musical Trend
description: The orchestra of the future?

title: California Police Search For 2 Escaped Killers
description: The police were searching throughout the state today for two convicted killers who escaped from a temporary holding cell in the county courthouse.

title: DANCE
description: Mention of the Cubiculo to most New York dancegoers is likely to stir memories of an age that now seems lost. Everyone has his favorite image of the place where Marian Sarach cantered down a wall in wooden clogs and Phoebe Neville moved through the dark with a light-filled crystal ball. That highly adaptable and atmospheric little box of a theater was home to many of the small modern dance troupes and idiosyncratic solo performers of the late 1960's. The theater closed in 1978. But the National Shakespeare Company will reopen it with a two-week festival of dance, theater and music. Tonight's performance by the Rod Rodgers Dance Company is by invitation only. But tomorrow, Kei Takei's Moving Earth will perform early sections of the starkly dramatic ''Light,'' Miss Takei's continuing signature work. And on Sunday, Frances Alenikoff presents ''Speaking in Tongues,'' described as a multimedia ''journey through the maze of inner and outer reality.'' Performances at the Cubiculo, 414 West 51st Street, are at 8 P.M. Tickets are $10. Reservations: 265-2139.

title: FLORIDA IN BATTLE OVER WATER LANDS
description: The State of Florida, which in the late 1800's encouraged development by selling land for 25 cents an acre, is embroiled in a legal battle to maintain ownership of land under and along the state's rivers, lakes and streams, land that some landowners say the state has already sold.

title: Advertising;   'Bad News' From Red Lobster
description: RED LOBSTER INNS OF AMERICA, the only General Mills division to achieve its profit objectives in fiscal year 1985, will move its advertising to another agency in February.

title: BLEGVAD TO PERFORM
description: The British songwriter Peter Blegvad will perform tomorrow at Irving Plaza, 17 Irving Place, at 15th Street (477-3728), with a band that includes the drummer Anton Fier, the singer Syd Straw and the guitarist Jody Harris. Music begins at about 11 P.M.; tickets are $10.

title: GATT, BACKING U.S., VOTES TO PREPARE NEW TRADE ROUND
description: The Reagan Administration finally won decisive global support today for the new round of trade-liberalizing negotiations it is seeking to reinforce the world's faltering commitment to free trade and to revitalize the international economy.

title: MALTA NOW WARY ON DISASTER CAUSE
description: The Maltese Government backed away today from its official explanations of the storming of an Egyptian airliner amid growing indications that a large number of passengers died as a result of Egyptian bombs used in the assault.

title: THEATER: 'DENNIS,' BY JAMES RYAN
description: ALLARD K. LOWENSTEIN, the one-time Congressman and longtime liberal activist, was a man obsessed, and so was Dennis Sweeney, the deranged former civil-rights worker who assassinated him in 1980. James Ryan, the author of ''Dennis,'' the new play about these star-crossed men, seems to share his subjects' single-minded passion for pursuing justice, or their own conceptions of it, to the bitter end. In ''Dennis,'' Mr. Ryan has not only absorbed the increasingly voluminous (and controversial) literature about Mr. Lowenstein and Mr. Sweeney - starting with the accounts of Teresa Carpenter, David Harris and Richard Cummings - but he has also conducted his own journalistic research. One admires the playwright's diligence, even though the results thicken rather than lift the fog.

title: 40 Hanukkah Lamps
description: Over 40 Hanukkah lamps, each representing a time period and style, are on view at the Jewish Museum, Fifth Avenue and 92d Street, through Feb. 16.

title: 3 INDIANS CHALLENGE TRIBAL COURT ON RIGHTS ISSUE
description: A dispute over tribal powers and the performance of an Indian tribunal that one lawyer calls a ''kangaroo court'' has reached the reservation of the Red Lake band of Chippewas.

title: BLACK PROFESSIONALS REFASHION THEIR CAREERS
description: A growing number of black executives are abandoning jobs in big corporations to open their own businesses or to accept management positions in black-owned companies where they see greater potential for advancement.

title: O'BRIEN'S PROBLEMS SHOW AGAIN
description: In an otherwise outstanding year, Ken O'Brien has had two seasonlong problems: the fumble and the sack. And today, neither he nor his Jet teammates could overcome those problems in the Detroit Lions' 31-20 upset of the Jets.

title: Advertising;   Timberland Assignment Grows at SSC&B:Lintas
description: SSC&B:Lintas Worldwide, one of the agency networks of the Interpublic Group of Companies, has added to the Timberland Company assignment it got in August. The job then was to advertise the well-known shoe products throughout the United States and Greece with billings of some $6 million.

title: CALCIUM IN DIET MAY CUT RISK OF COLON CANCER, STUDY FINDS
description: A new study provides biological evidence supporting the theory that people may be able to lower the risk of colon cancer by adding calcium to the diet, according to an article published today.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: TUCANO, the French restaurant with a colorful ornithological ambiance at 333 East 60th Street, has closed. Ricardo Amaral, the owner, who also has the discotheque Club A in the same building and is a partner in Alo Alo, an Italian bistro at Third Avenue and 61st Street, says he is planning to revive Tucano in the near future and offer a different cuisine, perhaps Brazilian.

title: EAST VILLAGE BOUTIQUES BECKON UPTOWNERS
description: The East Village has a reputation for the outrageous. And, yes, there are still people there who wear their hair in strange colors and sell clothes made of rubber and cellophane. But gradually many of the designers and shopkeepers who work in the East Village have broadened the scope of their offerings to appeal to shoppers from uptown as well as downtown. This seems to be especially true of designers who have their own boutiques and are interested in selling their clothes wholesale to other stores.

title: Fairfield Communities Is Losing Its President
description: Fairfield Communities Inc., a leading developer of retirement and recreational resort communities in the Sun Belt, announced that George F. Donovan, its president and chief operating officer, has resigned.

title: Milking Consumers and Farmers
description: Item: The Elmhurst Dairy sells milk to the Food Mart grocery in Rockland County, New York, for $1.70 a gallon and to Palummo Brothers, a store about the same size in Staten Island, for $2.36 a gallon. Item: The Dairylea Dairy sells milk to Convenience Foods in Rockland for $1.71 a gallon; it charges Heartland Bagels in Staten Island $2.29.

title: Why Is a D Average Too Tough?
description: Can they possibly be teaching anything so difficult in the Texas public schools that a determined student can't get at least a D? Gov. Mark White and the Texas Legislature say every student ought to attain that much. The state's high school coaches and some parents and students disagree. They want to erase from the books Texas's ''no pass, no play'' law, which says a student must get a passing grade - at least a D - in every course to play football or participate in extracurricular activity. For Texas's sake, and that of other states as well, the law's supporters must hold that line.

title: Dr. Jean Delacour, 95; Leading Ornithologist
description: Dr. Jean Delacour, a celebrated ornithologist and a former operator of the Bronx Zoo who at age 15 had already developed one of the world's finest collections of birds, died on Nov. 5 in Los Angeles. He was 95 years old.

title: POP: MAZE AT THE BEACON
description: POP-SOUL music doesn't get any more benevolent than the songs of Maze, the eight-man band that played two shows Wednesday at the Beacon Theater, at Broadway and 74th Street. All seven of Maze's albums have sold more than half a million copies each.

title: AUTHORITIES ORDER DENTIST TO PULL OUT A SCULPTURE
description: Dr. Gary S. Rappaport, a local dentist, is preparing for an extraction by a building crane.

title: Martens and His Cabinet Are Installed in Belgium
description: Prime Minister Wilfried Martens was sworn in today as head of the country's 33d postwar Government, which closely resembles the previous Government.

title: His Best Catch
description: Bill Cosby, her television husband, gave his approval, and a couple of hours later Phylicia Ayers-Allen gave hers. So today Ahmad Rashad, instead of feeling like a turkey, is, in his words, ''the happiest person in the world.''

title: SUDANESE ORDER 3 REFUGEE AGENCIES TO LEAVE
description: The Government has ordered the expulsion of three refugee resettlement agencies implicated in the airlift of Ethiopian Jews from the Sudan to Israel from 1981 to 1984, officials said today.

title: Economic Scene;   Trying to Deal With Deflation
description: ECONOMIC policy makers, like generals, have a tendency to fight the last war, and their last war was against inflation. But the actual battle now confronting the United States and other industrial countries is against deflation.

title: U.S. IN WARNING TO NEW ZEALAND ON SHIP VISITS
description: The Reagan Administration has told New Zealand that if it enacts legislation barring visits by ships capable of carrying nuclear weapons the United States will almost certainly scrap a mutual defense treaty, according to senior Administration officials.

title: COMPANIES FIND TWIST IN HOLIDAYS
description: Christmas and New Year's are approaching and with them the sweet season of office parties and family feasts. But this year the calendar will be unkind to millions of workers who have come to count on celebrating each holiday with three or four consecutive days off.

title: The Karen People in Burma Are More Than an Ethnic Group
description: To the Editor:

title: DR. JOHN TO PERFORM
description: The keyboardist-singer-guitarist Dr. John will perform tonight and tomorrow at the Lone Star Cafe, 61 Fifth Avenue, at 13th Street (242-1664), with a band that includes Bernard Purdie on drums. Shows begin at 9:30 P.M. and about midnight; tickets are $12.

title: 7-Hour Blackout in London
description: The main business area of London, an area of one and a quarter square miles, was blacked out by a seven-hour power failure that ended at about 11 A.M. today.

title: A GLIMPSE OF RUSSIAN LIFE
description: THANKS to such carefully selected imports as ''Masterpiece Theater'' and all those delicious situation comedies starring Penelope Keith, American viewers know something about British television. But, primarily because of language differences, they know surprisingly little about television in other countries. WNYC/Channel 31 has taken an admirable step toward remedying this situation with a series offered on Sundays at 10 P.M. called ''Window on World Television.'' Observing that New York has a sophisticated and curious audience that regularly attends foreign films with subtitles, the station believes that the same interest will extend to international television dramas and documentaries.

title: TEXAS RULE ON SCHOOL GRADES IS SHRINKING FOOTBALL TEAMS
description: Some Texas communities lost more than a third of their high school football players because of a state rule that prohibits them from playing if they receive failing grades, according to reports prepared in the trial of a suit challenging the law.

title: STAGE
description: This weekend is the last chance to see the only serious play that has opened on Broadway yet this season, a stirring revival of ''The Iceman Cometh,'' as directed by Eugene O'Neill's foremost contemporary interpreter, Jose Quintero. Jason Robards is back in the role in which he made his name three decades ago - the salesman Hickey, a mesmerizing evangelist for death. Among the down-and-out congregants at Harry Hope's end-of-the-line saloon are such fine actors as Donald Moffat, Barnard Hughes and James Greene. At the Lunt-Fontanne, 205 West 46th Street (575-9200), through Sunday only.

title: MARTIN IS THANKFUL FOR GIANTS' CONCERN
description: On other Thursdays, the Giants leave the practice field at 4 or 4:30 P.M. and straggle out of the locker room by 5:30. Today, to get the players home early for Thanksgiving dinner, practice for the game Sunday here against the Cleveland Browns was moved up.

title: Plea by Bell Twins
description: Mike Bell, the Kansas City Chiefs' defensive end, and his twin brother, Mark Bell, a former N.F.L. player, have pleaded not guilty to Federal drug charges filed against them in Wichita, Kan., last month. The Bells, who were among 31 defendants indicted on various drug charges Nov. 20, entered their pleas on Wednesday.

title: A NEW, PURIFIED FORM OF COCAINE CAUSES ALARM AS ABUSE INCREASES
description: A new form of cocaine is for sale on the streets of New York, alarming law-enforcement officials and rehabilitation experts because of its tendency to accelerate abuse of the drug, particularly among adolescents.

title: Tainted Turkeys Exchanged At Foodtown Supermarkets
description: Worried customers went to Foodtown stores that were opened in New York and New Jersey today to exchange turkeys after the supermarket chain recalled some of them suspected of containing a high level of bacteria.

title: REFITING 'EDWIN DROOD' FOR ITS BRODWAY RUN
description: A malady common to the species known as ''Broadway audience'' was a major concern for the cast and crew of ''The Mystery of Edwin Drood'' when they decided to take the musical from its summer home at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park to the Imperial Theater on West 45th Street, where it opens on Monday.

title: Smaller College Playoffs
description: Although there is no structure outside the various polls to determine a national champion in Division I-A college football, there are such championship playoffs in the three other divisions, which perform before small crowds and with only occasional television coverage.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: Opera can be experienced on every level in New York, from the grand to the spunky, and in the latter range, the two best choices this weekend are ''Parade'' at the Metropolitan Opera tonight at 8 and ''The Second Hurricane'' at the Henry Street Settlement tonight and tomorrow night at 7:30 and Sunday afternoon at 3.

title: Achievement in Goals
description: Michael Cortright's three field goals for St. Mary's High School made little difference in the Phoenix school's 44-13 victory over Chaparral High of Scottsdale, Ariz., Wednesday night, but they did a lot for Cortright. The three kicks, from 26, 41 and 37 yards out, in the quarterfinals of the Arizona Class AAA football playoffs, brought his career field-goal total to 34 and gave him a national schoolboy record.

title: Market Place;   Analysts' View Of Bell Issues
description: WALL STREET houses are renewing their praises of the seven regional Bell companies that were divested from the American Telephone and Telegraph Company at the start of 1984. Salomon Brothers expects shares of the Baby Bells to exceed the performance of Standard & Poor's 500-stock index and other telephone issues over the next 6 to 12 months.

title: TOKYO FRETS OVER STRONG YEN
description: With the yen at its highest level in years, the Japanese Government has met one important demand from its increasingly restive trading partners. But the strength of the yen now threatens to frustrate another request from abroad - that Japan stimulate its domestic economy.

title: Jesse Zunser, 87, Dies; Critic at Cue Magazine
description: Jesse Zunser, an editor and critic at the old Cue magazine for 31 years, died of lung cancer Wednesday at his daughter's home in Washington. He was 87 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: PRIVATE GUARDS GET NEW ROLE IN PUBLIC LAW ENFORCEMENT
description: Thousands of private security guards are taking over some of the police functions of the Federal, state and local authorities around the country.

title: BECKER IS UPSET AT AUSTRALIAN OPEN
description: Michiel Schapers, a 26-year-old from Rotterdam, the Netherlands, upset Boris Becker, the 18-year-old Wimbledon champion from West Germany, in the second round of the Australian Open tennis championships today at Kooyong. The scores were 3-6, 6-4, 7-6, 4-6, 6-3.

title: CASE AGAINST COLONEL DROPPED
description: A Federal district judge has dropped charges against an Army officer who was accused in a scheme to sell 1,140 antitank missiles to Iran and arrested in a subterfuge operation conducted by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: MAJOR TRAFFIC DELAYS AVOIDED
description: Traffic was extremely heavy on the major highways, bridges and tunnels around New York City yesterday, but a spokesman for the Department of Traffic said that despite steady rain, the city generally avoided major accidents and tie-ups among motorists traveling to and from holiday festivities.

title: UPPER WEST SIDE
description: Following is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given.

title: !)NEW COMEDIES IN PUNCH LINE FESTIVAL
description: LAST season, Manhattan Punch Line - which bills itself as ''New York's only comedy theater'' - staged a festival of one-act comedies. More than 100 manuscripts were submitted, from which eight plays were chosen to be produced. The event proved successful, and the theater decided to put on another festival this fall.

title: Advertising;   Canadian Agency Wins Filene's of Boston
description: When it comes to handling retail advertising accounts, Saffer, Cravit & Freeman, a Canadian agency, must be something special, the way it continues to attract clients from the south. The latest is Filene's, the Boston department store that has been doing all of its advertising in-house for the last couple of years.

title: 2 NEWARK TEEN-AGERS HELD IN SLAYING OF OFFICER AT BAR
description: Two Newark teen-agers were arrested today and charged in the fatal shooting of an Essex County sheriff's officer and the wounding of another during an apparent robbery attempt on Tuesday, officials said. A third suspect was being sought. The two in custody were Guyron Walker, 19 years old, and a 17-year-old whom the police did not identify because of his age. They were arrested at their homes after a 42-hour search, according to Thomas J. D'Alessio, the Essex County Sheriff.

title: Business International Names New Chairman
description: The Business International Corporation, a privately held research, publishing and consulting company, said that John C. Haley, currently deputy chairman of Kissinger Associates Inc., the political and economic risk consulting firm, has been named chairman and chief executive.

title: PENN STATION, AFTER 75 YEARS OF UPS AND DOWNS, IS REBUILDING AGAIN
description: Pennsylvania Station - opened 75 years ago this week during the golden age of passenger railroads, demolished and rebuilt more modestly half a century later when the railroads were at their nadir - is in the process of being rebuilt again.

title: Aid for Farmer Still Planned
description: A woman who promised to avert a debt-ridden farmer's eviction said Tuesday that she still planned to buy his land despite her husband's arrest on theft and forgery charges. Melvin Dixon was arrested Monday by the Bleckley County sheriff on warrants issued in Fort Pierce, Fla., three days after he and his wife, Linda, came to Cochran to announce her agreement to buy the farm of 66-year-old Oscar Lorick. Lorick's attorney, Alvin McDougald, had said the Florida couple would purchase the 79-acre farm for $75,000 and allow Mr. Lorick to spend the rest of his life on the property for $1 a month.

title: Arrests at Protest On Griffiss Base
description: Eleven demonstrators were arrested at Griffiss Air Force Base today during a protest marking the second anniversary of an attack on a B-52 by activists known as the Plowshares 7, officials said.

title: HARLEM BLUES
description: The Harlem Blues and Jazz Band will play swing tunes and Mama Lu Parks and her Savoy Lindyhoppers will dance today and tomorrow at 9 and 11 P.M. at the Village Gate, Bleecker and Thompson Streets (475-5120). Tickets are $10; there is room for dancing.

title: BETTY BOOP BRIGHTENS A RAINY PARADE
description: Above rows of umbrellas, light poles and ogling crowds, Betty Boop floated on the moon. She was tall, 72 feet, and heavy, 285 pounds, and shapely. And she was adept at stealing attention from Snoopy, Yogi Bear and Woody Woodpecker, balloons that for years have enchanted audiences at the Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade.

title: THE SCREEN: 'FLOWING'
description: MIKIO NARUSE (1905-1969), the Japanese director of ''Late Chrysanthemums'' (1954), which opened at the Film Forum Wednesday, and ''Flowing'' (1956), opening at the Public Theater today, had absolutely no patience with - or interest in - location photography. In her book ''Japanese Film Directors,'' Audie Bock reports that ''Naruse disliked not only crowds but scenery, weather, color and any other background element that distracted from acting.''

title: FOR ITHACA, PLAYOFF IS USUAL MYSTERY
description: Jim Butterfield will tell you he is not one of those football coaches who thinks he knows it all.

title: HEMISPHERE COURT BACKS FREE PRESS
description: In a recent landmark opinion, the Inter-American Court of Human Rights ruled that compulsory licensing of journalists is not compatible with the 1978 American Convention on Human Rights, a hemisphere covenant.

title: The U.S. Must Act
description: The hungry people of Africa are very far away from America, in both miles and circumstances. Many Americans have difficulty imagining the conditions in which most Africans live. Some also question the extent of our responsibility there. Africa seems to them so far away, and they question whether our aid can make any real difference to its seemingly unending plight. This is a sadly shortsighted view, for there are strong moral and practical reasons why Americans cannot ignore Africa.

title: BANK OPENS IN CHINA
description: China's first joint-venture bank with foreign partners has opened in the Xiamen Special Economic Zone, the official press agency reported today. The Xiamen International Bank opened Thursday in the special economic zone in the southern province of Fujian, the agency said. The bank is a venture of the Fujian branch of the Industrial and Commercial Bank of China, the Fujian Investment and Enterprise Corporation, the Xiamen Construction and Development Corporation and the Panin Group Corporation of Hong Kong, the report said.

title: HALF A WORLD AWAY, RUSSIAN FIGHTS U.S. DIVORCE
description: Like other Russians married to Americans but barred for years from joining them in the United States, Yelena V. Kaplan was caught between two cultures.

title: WOZNIAK BUYS APPLE STOCK
description: Apple Computer Inc. said today that Stephen Wozniak, the company's co-founder, had bought $5 million worth of Apple stock and announced plans to buy as much as $15 million more.

title: FEDERAL RESERVE
description: All data in millions of dollars LatestPreviousYear WeekWeekAgo Monetary Aggregates M-1*as of Nov. 18 $616,600 R $613,800 #552,000 Adj. Mon.Base (St.Louis Fed) *(11/27)#233,400 R 230,400 #216,200 Reserve Position, Eight New York BanksDaily averages for two weeks ended Nov. 20 Excess (Deficit) Reserves (Incl. carryover)R 79 #39 (36) Borrowings at Federal Reserve#197 #98 #187 Net Federal Funds PurchasesR 8,649 #8,141 #8,157 Basic Reserve Surplus (Deficit)R (8,767)(8,200)(8,380) Federal Reserve CreditDaily averages, week ended Nov. 27 Gov'ts. and Agencies Held Outright#179,611 #178,449 #164,130 Gov'ts. and Agencies Under Repurchase#0 R 1,349 #83 Float#1,258 R 1,494 #1,156 Other Assets#13,696 R 13,610 #11,225 Other Factors Affecting ReservesDaily averages, week ended Nov. 27 Gold Stock#11,090 #11,090 #11,096 Special Drawing Rights#4,718 #4,718 #4,618 Currency in Circulation#191,750 R 191,558 #179,847 Treasury Deposits#2,587 #3,008 #2,978 Other Items Gov't.

title: Staten Island Rembrandt
description: To mark the 41st birthday of Representative Dan Glickman, a Kansas Democrat, his wife, Rhoda, took the shuttle from Washington to New York to buy a cake with the Congressman's portrait on it.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 33. 1. The lamp is lifted. Explain. 2. ''Shall I die? Shall I fly'' has entered a well-known canon. Explain. 3. According to Reagan Administration officials, the arrests of four people in five days on espionage charges (are/are not) coincidental. 4. The only full square block that now lies empty in mid-Manhattan was in the news. Where is it and what was the reason? 5. ''I just want to get on with my writing,'' said Edmund Morris, a Pulitzer Prize-winning biographer. To what writing was he referring, why was it in the news, and will he or won't he share the royalties with his subject? 6. American citizens are now the targets of about (35/45/55) percent of all international terrorist incidents, according to State Department figures. 7. If the Chicago Bears win Monday night, they will equal a mark set by the 1934 Bears team. What is the achievement? 8. Round-the-clock trading of major American and international stocks moved a step closer to reality. What happened? 9. Prince Charles and President Reagan share exclusive company with Anthony R. Cucci, the Mayor of Jersey City. Explain. 10. This is the centennial year of a weapon that may have killed more people than any other. Identify it. 11. Future Presidential debates may get a new sponsor. Who would run them and who would be replaced? 12.

title: THE WRONG WILLIE JONES SPENDS 3 MONTHS IN JAIL
description: For the first 33 years of his life, Willie Jones says, his name never got him into trouble.

title: TWAINS'S SESQUICENTENNIAL MARKED BY IMBROGLIO IN HANNIBAL
description: Mark Twain, who never had much use for anniversaries, seems to have reached back across th years to teach a lesson to those who have been trying to make something big out of something he would say wasn't worth shucks.

title: USACAFES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company reported only 11 months in fiscal 1984 because it went public in October 1983. The pro forma figures for 1984 included revenue of $17,255,000, net income of $2,206,000 and share earnings of 40 cents.

title: East German Arms Budget
description: East Germany today announced a 7.7 percent increase in military spending for 1986. Western diplomats said the increase could signal East German readiness to shoulder a larger portion of the upkeep of Soviet forces and weaponry stationed in East Germany as the Soviet Union has committed itself to improving its own economy.

title: Lesson for Becker
description: When Boris Becker, the 18-year-old Wimbledon champion, was upset by an obscure Dutch player, Michiel Schapers, in the second round of the Australian Open, the development came as a surprise to many tennis professionals, but not to John McEnroe. ''A lot of people were very quick to assume that Becker was just going to walk in and be No. 1, and I think he's starting to believe it,'' McEnroe said.

title: RANGERS OVERWHELM CAPITALS' DEFENSE
description: Twice they scored when it seemed the opponents' defensemen looked the other way. Twice they scored by cutting a path between the defensemen. And once they scored by knocking a defenseman down from behind.

title: COMPUTER 'WINDOWS' KISPLAY PROGRAM DATA
description: A scientist at AT&T Bell Laboratories in Murray Hill, N.J., was granted a patent this week for a computer terminal that can simultaneously display data from several programs in small ''windows'' on a single computer screen.

title: California Reactor Shuts
description: The Unit 2 reactor at the Diablo Canyon nuclear power plant shut down automatically Thursday when instruments detected a problem in a non-nuclear portion of the system, a utility spokesman said. No radioactive material was released in the incident, said Ron Weinberg, spokesman for the Pacific Gas and Electric Company.

title: GENTEEL SOCIALISM ON THE FARM
description: More welfare for farmers? The House and Senate have already surrendered to agriculture lobbies by voting subsidies that will make rich farmers richer. How can farmers ask the public to go further and bail out the Farm Credit System?

title: INCO PLANS TO CUT WORK FORCE BY 6%
description: Inco Ltd., the world's biggest nickel producer, said it would cut its output of the metal by up to 20 percent and lay off or retire 1,300 employees, about 6 percent of its work force.

title: OPERA: 'THE LIGHTHOUSE' BY FIRES OF LONDON
description: Peter Maxwell Davies, the British composer whose ''Eight Songs for a Mad King'' is his best-known score outside his native land, tries for a similarly phantasmagoric theatrical effect in ''The Lighthouse,'' a chamber opera that had its New York premiere last night at Alice Tully Hall. Unfortunately, this fully staged performance looked rather amateurish, especially in its inept lighting, which did nothing at all to redeem a tiresomely jagged and atonal piece whose chief musical interest lay in the pointillistic orchestral score played by the Fires of London, the 12-musician group led by Mr. Davies.

title: TWENTIETH CENTURY-FOX FILM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net loss

title: REAGAN ADVISER ON SCIENCE SAYS HE IS RESIGNING
description: George A. Keyworth 2d, President Reagan's science adviser, said today that he was resigning and would leave the Administration at the end of the year to set up a private consulting concern.

title: JOE LOUIS BIOGRAPHY STARTED AS COLLEGE PAPER
description: Chris Mead had a vague notion in college that his name might one day appear in magazines and newspapers. He thought -''dreamed would be more appropriate,'' he admits - that his dexterity at scooping up ground balls, pivoting and throwing to first base would get him there.

title: NCNB EXPANSION
description: The NCNB Corporation said the Federal Reserve Board had approved its applications to acquire Pan American Banks Inc. of Miami, Bankers Trust of South Carolina and Southern National Bankshares Inc. of Atlanta.

title: G.M. SETTLES A 1966 BIAS CASE
description: In a settlement reached in a 19-year-old lawsuit over racial discrimination, the General Motors Corporation has agreed to pay $239,000 to 226 current and former black employees at its plant in Lakewood, Ga.

title: NEW YORK AVOIDS DEALING WITH DEATH
description: While other states make progress in dealing with death, New York remains a backwater.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Sammy Winder, the Denver Bronco running back who underwent arthroscopoic knee surgery, has been given medical clearance to start against the Pittsburgh Steelers tomorrow. . . . Tony Jacklin, the British golfer who had considered resigning as captain of the European Ryder Cup team after it won the cup in a surprise victory in September, said he had decided to remain as captain when the team defends the cup against the United States in 1987. ''I cannot resist a challenge,'' he said, noting that the team could become the first to defeat a United States Ryder Cup team on American soil. . . . Jose DeLeon, the Pittsburgh Pirate right-hander who struggled to a 2-19 season this year, has been trying to improve his form by pitching for the Mayaguez Indians in the Puerto Rican Winter League.

title: PARR'S HEAD PLEADS GUILTY
description: The head of a discount broker and bond dealer in New York City pleaded guilty yesterday to three counts of fraud that according to Federal prosecutors led banks nationwide to lose $22 million.

title: 'TRADITION' IN A TRIVIA GAME
description: Question: During what holiday is gelt given to children?

title: 26,000 Ugandans End 3-Year Exile in Rwanda
description: Almost 26,000 Ugandans who fled to Rwanda in October 1982 have returned voluntarily to their country in the last three months and have been accepted by the Ugandan Government as citizens, the Rwandan Government said.

title: Suspicious Blaze Hits Arab Group's Offices
description: A suspicious fire did major damage to the national headquarters of the Arab Anti-Discrimination Committee tonight, less than two months after the committee's West Coast director was killed in a bombing, fire officials said.

title: FOR 75 DARING YOUNG BRAZILIANS, SCHOOL IS A CIRCUS
description: There was no roll of drums and no crowd to hold its breath, but 18-year-old Walter Ariel Zanotti tossed back his hair, tensed his muscles and then, gripping the trapeze, launched himself into the void.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: LONG WINDED Flushing, not to be outdone, is presenting its marathon, the New York City Chamber Music Marathon. From 2 P.M. to 8:45 P.M. tomorrow, chamber music from the Renaissance through the Baroque and Romantic eras into the 20th century will be performed in the Trinity Lutheran Church.

title: JOHNSON MATTHEY
description: The police said they have found evidence that fraud occurred at Johnson Matthey Bankers in 1981.

title: 5 HAITIAN STOWAWAYS DISAPPEAR IN A DISPUTE
description: Five Haitian stowaways, who had been shuttled between the United States and the Bahamas in an immigration dispute, have escaped from a dungeonlike cargo box aboard a freighter and are believed to have fled into Miami.

title: RORER BUYS DRUG UNIT OF REVLON
description: In a deal that will nearly double the size of its business, Rorer Group Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire Revlon's worldwide prescription drug operation for $690 million in cash.

title: AMERICAN STORES CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 2
description: b-Including a gain on the sale of stores in Arizona of $13,980,000, or 47 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months.

title: JUDGING STOCK DISCOUNTER ADS
description: HOW much can investors save by using a discount broker? And how well do the discount brokerage advertisements explain both the dollar and percentage savings?

title: Village Life Revisited
description: THE VISITORS. By Ronald Blythe. 239 pages. Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $16.95. In ''Akenfield,'' his superb oral history of a Suffolk village, the British writer Ronald Blythe drew a minutely detailed portrait of life in the English countryside. By interviewing members of the community from all classes and professions - from an illiterate hermit to the blacksmith to the local justice of the peace - and allowing them to deliver their own monologues to the reader, Mr. Blythe was able strip away our nostalgic fantasies of a pastoral Eden, and replace them with an unsentimental picture of the repressive, fatalistic - and often stultifyingly provincial - way of life that still exists 100 miles from London.

title: JACOBS GROUP LIFTS INTERNORTH STAKE
description: Irwin L. Jacobs, the Minneapolis financier, said he had increased his investment group's stake in HNG-Internorth Inc. to 9.1 percent, from 7.9 percent, of the company's 44 million shares.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: OUTSIDE THE COURT, EDWARDS TRIAL IS OFTEN A FESTIVE AFFAIR
description: There is a pay phone in downtown New Orleans that rings persistently. The other day a reporter idling nearby picked it up twice. The calls were from the State Attorney General, Billy Guste, and from the owner of the New Orleans Saints, Tom Benson.

title: St. Lawrence Seaway Is Blocked Again
description: A freighter slammed into a drawbridge on the St. Lawrence Seaway today, injuring two people and blocking the waterway for the third time in a year.

title: NOW ON DECK, WALTER MITTY
description: OK., so a 46 mile-an-hour fastball isn't going to strike fear into the heart of Buddy Biancalana, much less strike out Don Mattingly. But even Dwight Gooden needs a few warm-up tosses before he begins throwing what we baseball types refer to as ''heat.'' Just a few more pitches to loosen up the right arm and maybe someone in the know - like Bill Robinson, the Mets' batting coach, who is taking part in the first Big Apple Sports Expo - might call the front office and tell the general manager, Frank Cashen, that he has found the experienced pitcher the Mets could use to win the National League East next year. The ole right-hander could always return to his newspaper job after the World Series.

title: NEW HEAD NAMED FOR WOMEN'S UNIT
description: Governor Cuomo today named Judith Avner, a New York City lawyer involved in women's rights and minority and family issues, to head the Division for Women.

title: U.S. AGENCY JOINS PREGNANCY FIGHT
description: The Justice Department has urged the Supreme Court to strike down state laws requiring employers to give more generous disability leave and other benefits to pregnant employees than is required for others.

title: BARGE'S CONDITION IS CITED IN SINKING
description: A 30-year-old barge that sank a year ago off Norwalk killing six people aboard an accompanying tugboat probably went down because of poor maintenance, according to a report by the National Transportation Safety Board.

title: THE SECRETS BOOM
description: So many Federal employees are now selling American secrets to foreigners that the country faces an acute secrets shortage.

title: ACQUISTION PACT BY SUPERIOR CARE
description: Superior Care Inc. of Great Neck, L.I., a provider of home health care services, said that it had signed an agreement to acquire the Hospital Capital Corporation, a British health care and hospital development concern. The deal would involve an exchange of 11 million new Superior common shares for the majority of Hospital Capital's outstanding shares.

title: POLICE DRAW FIRE NEAR CAPE TOWN
description: A police patrol came under fire in a squatter camp outside Cape Town today, and in the ensuing battle officers killed one black man and wounded another, the police said.

title: 562 OFFICERS ARE MADE SERGEANTS
description: In a hurriedly arranged ceremony yesterday, 562 New York City police officers were sworn in as provisional sergeants under an unusual agreement to use racial quotas in promoting some officers.

title: Exiled Seychelles Leader Is Shot Dead in London
description: Gerard Hoareau, exiled opposition leader from the African island nation of the Seychelles, was shot and killed today by an unidentified gunman on the doorstep of his London home, the police said.

title: RISE IN LEGAL DRINKING AGE STARTS AMID HOPE AND SOME SKEPTICISM
description: Starting at 12:01 A.M. tomorrow it will be illegal for anyone under 21 years of age to be sold an alcoholic beverage in New York State.

title: Not Enough Time
description: Rey Dempsey, who was dismissed as the Memphis State football coach after two losing seasons, including a 2-7-2 mark this year, said he had not been given a chance to build a winning team.

title: BUILDINGS PROTECTED IN QUAKES
description: A GREEK inveno received a patent this week on a method of constructing buildings to protect them against damage caused by earthquakes.

title: PETROLITE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
NIHILATOR TRIUMPHS IN FAREWELL RACE
description: Nihilator, the most exciting performer in harness racing in his two years on the track, captured the last series of the Breeders Crown here tonight and then retired to stud.

title: NATIONAL STEEL'S JAPANESE ALLY
description: A dozen or so Japanese steel executives here are taking an intense interest in the workings of the National Steel Corporation, America's sixth-largest steel producer.

title: Signals of N.F.L. Truly Bilingual
description: The quarterback is called ''el mariscal de campo'' (literally, the field marshal).

title: O'BRIEN WEAKNESS EXPOSED BY LIONS
description: Winning coaches always sound smarter than losing coaches.

title: HALLEY'S COMET
description: Halley's Comet will rise over the New York City area at 1:39 P.M. today and set at 3:30 A.M. tomorrow.

title: TURNAROUND AT CAESARS WORLD
description: Henry Gluck is going shopping soon, not just for holiday gifts, but also for perhaps a large hotel company, or maybe even a cruise line.

title: NEWS SUMMARY SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 30, 1985
description: International

title: PANEL'S TAX PLAN IRKS SOME SUPPLY SIDERS
description: Since the House Ways and Means Committee completed drafting its tax revision package last weekend, disciples of supply-side economics have attacked the plan for failing to accomplish what they regard as the chief goal in restructuring the tax system -lowering tax rates across the board.

title: No Headline
description: To Protect Murals Against Earthquakes

title: Syracuse Routs U.S.C., 102-68
description: Wendell Alexis scored 22 points and Rafael Addison 20 as Syracuse trounced Southern California, 102-68, tonight.

title: Trump Plan Would Unbalance Manhattan
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 Dead in Texas Explosion
description: An explosion Thursday that killed three people in a mobile home and injured two others was a result of an explosive device, fire officials said today. ''It was definitely an explosive device involved,'' said Butch Hall, spokesman for the Fort Worth Fire Department.

title: ADDING NUMBERS
description: When little numbers are missing, the United States Postal Service loses big numbers - $10 million and 250,000 hours of labor a year in misdelivering, redelivering and returning mail in Manhattan.

title: SLAYING SUSPECT IN BARSSHOOTING IS HELD IN JERSEY
description: A third suspect in the slaying of an Essex County sheriff's officer surrendered today, authorities said.

title: Gearing Up for '86
description: Next week the Democratic National Committee is embarking on the most ambitious campaign training program it has yet conducted, aimed at making a strong party showing in the Congressional and state elections of 1986.

title: YUGOSLAV WINS SLALOM
description: Bojan Krizaj mastered a perfect second heat down a tricky course to win the closing event of the World Series of skiing, a men's special slalom, in this Italian Alpine resort today.

title: ISRAEL'S STUTTER
description: The United States Government and our correspondent in Israel, Thomas Friedman, have been given a bizarre account of how Israel apparently violated its supposed policy against spying on the United States in the United States.

title: BROKERAGE LIST DELAY BY BANKS
description: Some 15 to 20 banks have requested extensions of the Jan. 1 deadline for registering their brokerage businesses, according to the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: KOCK PROPOSES $1 TRANSIT FARE IN JANUARY '87
description: Mayor Koch yesterday offered a two-year financial plan for the Transit Authority that would increase the subway and bus fare by 10 cents, to a dollar, in January 1987, a year later than other officials have proposed.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''As difficult as this case may be, I don't think there's been any implication that the normal relationship has been in some way fundamentally interrupted.'' - Charles Redman, State Department spokesman, on spy case implicating Israelis. [9:4.]

title: WEBCOR ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
WOMAN, 21, DIES IN A HOUSE FIRE
description: A 21-year-old woman confined to a wheelchair was killed and another woman was critically injured early this morning in a house fire, authorities said.

title: Study Shows Brain Fighting Alzheimer's Disease Damage
description: Under attack by Alzheimer's disease, the brain tries to repair itself but it ultimately loses the battle, scientists reported Thursday.

title: Patients Should Decide
description: To the Editor:

title: Richard Price Is Dead at 55; Helped Found Esalen Center
description: Richard Price, a co-founder of the Esalen Institute, was killed in a fall while hiking Monday in Hot Springs Canyon near the center.

title: MSR EXPLORATION LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
HILLENBRAND PACT WITH BED MAKER
description: Hillenbrand Industries said it had reached a definitive agreement to purchase all the assets of Support Systems International Inc., a maker of wound-therapy beds, for $100 million in cash, plus contingent payments based on financial performance over a five-year period.

title: MANY HESITANT TO SHARE 'STAR WARS'
description: President Reagan's recent pledge to share a space-based antimissile system with the Soviet Union has baffled many defense industry executives and even some Pentagon officials.

title: Quotas Give U.S. Workers a Chance
description: To the Editor:

title: F.D.A. Is Lax in Enforcing Medical Regulations
description: To the Editor:

title: Call It Prime Court
description: To the Editor:

title: THE STATE DEPARTMENT IS CALLOUS TO DIPLOMATS
description: A team of medical investigators recently checked doorknobs and diplomats' clothing in the United States Embassy in Moscow, searching for traces of a chemical dust used as a tracing agent by the Russians. Though the disclosure of the ''Moscow spy dust'' scheme caused a minor uproar a few months ago, one question seems never to have been adequately answered: Why did the State Department, which knew of the dusting practice for nine years, not inform its employees about this potentially dangerous chemical?

title: LEGAL PROCEEDINGS ON MAXXAM BID
description: Justice William H. Rehnquist of the United States Supreme Court denied a stay that would have halted the buyout of the Pacific Lumber Company by Maxxam Group Inc. The stay was sought by Pacific Lumber shareholders who oppose a takeover of the San Francisco-based forest products concern by Maxxam, which is led by the Houston investor Charles E. Hurwitz.

title: TEL ELECTRONICS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: ISLANDERS TOP JETS BY 4-1
description: The Islanders took a 3-0 first-period lead tonight and went on to a 4-1 victory over Winnipeg, handing the Jets their fifth straight defeat.

title: Pressure Putts
description: Fuzzy Zoeller, named to replace Gary Player in the Skins Game, where the entire purse could theoretically be won on the final hole: ''I'm just tickled to death to be here to choke for $450,000.''

title: U.S. PRESSES ISRAEL FOR TALKS WITH 2 NAMED IN SPY CASE
description: The United States today stepped up its public pressure on Israel to permit questioning of two Israeli diplomats, and possibly other officials, in connection with the case of a United States Navy employee, Jonathan Jay Pollard, charged with selling secret documents.

title: Sergei Gerasimov, 79; Soviet Film Director
description: Sergei Gerasimov, a leading film director in the Soviet Union since the 1930's, died of a heart attack Thursday, a spokesman for the Union of Cinema Workers said yesterday. He was 79 years old.

title: PRICES TO FARMERS RISE
description: Prices farmers get for raw products rose 2.4 percent in the latest monthly reporting period, the second consecutive such increase, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Dartmouth Dismissal
description: His teams won or shared three Ivy League titles in his eight years as Dartmouth's football coach, but after three straight losing seasons, including a 2-7-1 mark this year, time ran out for Joe Yukica yesterday. The 54-year-old coach was dismissed by the school's athletic director, Ted Leland.

title: AUCHINCLOSS TO BE HONORED
description: Louis Auchincloss, the novelist and Wall Street lawyer, will receive the first Washington Irving gold medal for literary excellence. The award will be given next Friday at the Plaza Hotel, during the annual dinner of the Saint Nicholas Society. Members of the society, founded by Washington Irving to preserve the historical and literary heritage of the City of New York, are descendants of people who lived in New York State before 1785.

title: ST. JOHN'S LOSES ON DAWKINS SHOT
description: Even in the best of circumstances, it's rare this early in the season that two teams will play with the sustained intensity with which St. John's and Duke performed last night at Madison Square Garden.

title: HOSTAGE-TAKER KILLS HIMSELF
description: An armed man apparantly killed himself after holding a 20-year-old woman hostage for two hours in an Italian restaurant in Staten Island last night and firing at least eight shots through the restaurant window, the police said. The woman, Laura D'Agostino, who the police said worked as a hat checker at the restaurant, Roberto's at 981 Bay Street in the Rosebank section, was held from 7:13 to 9:20 P.M., while a police emergency hostage team waited outside. When she emerged, she told the police that the man had shot himself in the head.

title: SPACE MICROWAVE LABS reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
description: b-After a pretax access writedown of $692,000. c-After a pretax charge of $69,000 from expenses incurred in an abandoned public stock offering.

title: HUGE DEMAND FOR ASHLEY STOCK
description: The demand is 34 times the supply of the initial offering of shares in Britain's Laura Ashley fashion empire, the merchant bankers handling the sale said.

title: THE LESSON OF NOVEMBER'S RAINS
description: Hurricane Gloria soaked the ground around New York City's reservoirs, causing November's unusual rains to flow to the storage basins and ending this year's drought emergency. Mayor Koch announced its end with an enthusiasm that reduced to a comparative whisper his sensible appeal for mandatory metering of water use. To avoid future emergencies, universal metering would be more helpful than autumn rain.

title: PCA INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
description: b-Including a tax credit of $1,060,000 for the quarter and 9 months related to the costs of closing operations in Japan.

title: 5,000 LACK POWER IN HUDSON VALLEY
description: About 5,000 homes, most of them in Ulster County, were without power for a second day as a result of downed power lines from freezing rain on Thanksgiving Day.

title: ARGONAUT ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BIRD LEADS CELTICS OVER THE KNOCKS
description: Larry Bird answered the Celtics' call in the third quarter tonight when Boston, caught up in the Knicks' slowdown style, needed him most.

title: 'COURT' BACKS COAST BAGELS
description: Competition between the New York bagel and the San Francisco version was no stale issue for the California Court of Historical Review, which ruled Wednesday the West Coast bagel is every bit as good as New York's.

title: MORE LOCALITIES ARE DIVESTING OVER SOUTH AFRICA
description: Spurred by fears of increasing violence and economic problems in South Africa and bolstered by President Reagan's announcement of limited sanctions against the country, more and more states and municipalities are divesting themselves of holdings in companies doing business there.

title: No Rest for the Weary
description: An odd warble was afflicting the public address loudspeaker at the Farragut West subway stop, so the waiting passengers could not quite get the word that train arrivals were as uncertain as tax reform.

title: SPECIAL AIR FARES APPEAL TO TRAVELERS
description: But for the airlines' ''turkey fare,'' the Welkers would have sacrificed their Thanksgiving fare and spent the holiday on the road.

title: SATURDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Knicks vs. Philadelphia 76ers, at Madison Square Garden, 7:30 P.M. (Television - MSG, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WPAT, 930; 7:20 P.M.) Nets vs. Cleveland Cavaliers, at Richfield, Ohio. The Nets won three of the five games played against the Cavaliers last season. (Television - SportsChannel, 11:30 P.M., tape. Radio - WNBC, 660; 8 P.M.) College: Georgia Tech vs. Michigan, Tipoff Classic, Springfield, Mass. (Television - Channel 2, 1:30 P.M.); Medgar Evers at Staten Island, 4 P.M.; Concordia at L.I.U., 7:30 P.M.; Yale at Fairfield, 7:30 P.M. Women: City College at Staten Island, 5:30 P.M. Football Vanderbilt at Tennessee, (Television -WTBS, noon); Florida State at Florida, 12:30 P.M.; Houston at Rice, 2 P.M. Auburn vs. Alabama, at Birmingham. (Television - Channel 7, 3:30 P.M.) Notre Dame at Miami. Gerry Faust will be making his last appearance as coach of Notre Dame. (Television - Channel 2, 3:30 P.M.); West Virginia at Syracuse (Television - ESPN, 7:30 P.M., in New England, parts of New York State, Pennsylvania, West Virginia, Maryland, Delaware, New Jersey, Virginia and the District of Columbia. Radio - WNYE-FM, 91.5; 7:20 P.M.); Oklahoma at Oklahoma State, 7:30 P.M. (Television - ESPN, 7:30 P.M.); Louisiana State at Tulane, 8 P.M.; Georgia at Georgia Tech (Television - WTBS, 8 P.M.) Golf The $450,000 Skins Game, at Bear Creek Country Club, Murietta, Calif. The purse has been increased by $90,000 over last year, with the first six holes worth $15,000 each, the next six $25,000 each and the final six $35,000 apiece.

title: McEnroe Fined for Outburst
description: John McEnroe vehemently criticized the condition of the court today during his second-round victory over Danie Visser of South Africa in the $1.5 million Australian Open championships.

title: WINTHROP INSURED MTGE INV II reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
RETURN TO TRADITION: THE CLOTH DIAPER
description: Christopher Agnew, 23 months old, seems to prefer cloth diapers. Not that he has actually voiced an opinion, but his mother, Antiss, says, ''He seems to be more comfortable in them.''

title: Shiites Say They Raided Israeli Force in Lebanon
description: The Shiite Moslem militia Amal said today that it had attacked positions manned by Israeli troops and their South Lebanon Army allies with rocket-propelled grenades and machine guns.

title: TO FIRST LADY OF PHILIPPINES, THE MARCOS ERA IS CAMELOT
description: Sometimes, says Imelda Romualdez Marcos, when the accusations of extravagance, corruption and misrule get her down she thinks of her favorite movie.

title: Phoenix Airport Threat
description: A man who said he had a bomb forced the evacuation of a terminal at Phoenix Sky Harbor International Airport today but was arrested without incident.

title: BOB EVANS FARMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 25
Poland Is Said to Start Wide Purge of Scholars
description: The Polish authorities have begun a nationwide purge of political opponents in universities and colleges by removing more than 20 senior scholars from influential administrative posts, opposition sources said today.

title: SABOTAGE CRIPPLES JAPAN RAIL LINES
description: Saboteurs today knocked out key rail communications and signal systems, forcing the shutdown of 23 commuter lines during the morning rush hour and causing a nightmarish journey to work for millions of riders.

title: SHOPPERS WORLD STORES reports earnings for Year to Aug 30
description: b-Net income including a gain of $409,000 from an accounting change.

title: 55 COURTS-MARTIAL ARE CHALLENGED
description: Soldiers are appealing 55 court-martial cases to the military's highest court, asserting that Army commanders illegally took action to discourage testimony by defense witnesses.

title: SOUTH CONTINUING GAINS IN MIGRATION
description: The South over the last five years has continued to lead the nation in gaining population, jobs and migrants from other regions despite a decline in some of its industries and an economic resurgence in the Northeast, according to new census figures.

title: RHODE ISLAND'S PASSING STAR
description: In the last two seasons, the University of Rhode Island football team has broken or tied 226 records at the national, New England, Yankee Conference or school levels. But Tom Ehrhardt, the quarterback responsible for most of these standards, is unimpressed.

title: UNIVERSITY GRAPHICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
STATES TRY NEW ROUTES TO REVIVING INDUSTRIES
description: When Dwight Carlson needed money in 1982 to expand Perceptron, his high-technology company here, he went to an unlikely source: the state government in Lansing.

title: Dutch Decide to Pare Nuclear Role in NATO
description: The Netherlands brushed aside objections from its allies today and decided to reduce its involvement in training and equipping for wartime nuclear tasks within the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

title: 4 AMERICAN PRELATES SET FORTH POSITIONS ON ISSUES IN CHURCH
description: Four American prelates participating in the extraordinary Synod of Bishops here offered their views today on several controversial issues that have so far not been discussed in the synod itself.

title: BIRD LEADS CELTICS OVER THE KNICKS
